column2: In 1926 the chief concern of arbitration was with the interests of buyers and sellers of merchandise -- and within the range of small claims. But in these ten years the principle, which is as old as ARISTOTLE, has been extended in its application to most of the controversies arising out of the association of human beings in commercial relations.
Housing properties made up the bulk of the New Jersey turnover reported yesterday.

Liens for sums aggregating about $1,000,000 were filed here yesterday by Joseph T. Higgins, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Second District, against Zelik Josefowitz, Lithuanian financier, and four of his relatives.

ALBANY, Feb. 20. -- "The fight against crime" is the announced topic of Governor Lehman's radio appeal for popular support of his law-enforcement program which he will deliver Sunday evening over the Columbia Broadcasting System, with a State-wide hook-up.

Price movements continued mixed on local commodity futures markets yesterday. The volume of trading increased. On the cash markets wheat, oats, antimony, tin and rubber advanced, while corn, rye, cotton, lard, silk, butter, eggs and cocoa declined.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 20. -- Forty-eight hours before the world's richest race is to be run at the Santa Anita track there is a wider divergence of opinion as to the outcome than at any period since the entries closed last December. The $100,000 added purse is no longer conceded to Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Discovery, as was the case some weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- Since the administration's Supreme Court score will be under campaign attack on three grounds -- constitutional disregard, incompetent draftsmanship of the laws and the legal strategy used in defending them -- there is real importance in proof submitted to this correspondent that in both of the important today eases the New Deal has won its own lawyers worked out the strategy themselves.

OTTAWA, Feb. 20 (Canadian Press). -- Deposits of the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada increased $11,879,161 for the week ended yesterday, the weekly statement of the bank showed today. Deposits of chartered banks declined $231,923.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- In a day devoted largely to conferences with callers interested in politics, President Roosevelt today made a tentative engagement to speak before the National Democratic Club in New York in April, if a suitable date can be arranged.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 20. -- Joe Wells of Newell, W.Va., carded a 72 to pace a field of fifty-six in the qualifying round of the third annual Mid-Ocean-Castle Harbour invitation golf tournament today. Eddie Driggs Jr. of Garden City, L.I., was runner-up with a 73.

With the exception of March contracts, which gained 2 points yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange were slightly easier than on Wednesday. A lower range of quotations in Liverpool, where pressure from India was a feature, and reports of an increased acreage in extreme Southern Texas influenced sentiment.
TRENTON, Feb. 20. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman, who reopened the Lindbergh kidnapping case, tonight was "more convinced than ever" that the crime was still unsolved.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 20. -- L'Affaire Tnesba, involving a non-existent veteran to whom the Rhode Island Senate on Tuesday voted a $100 bonus, gave signs today of developing into a first-class political rumpus.

AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 20 (AP). -- Mediators of the Federal Department of Labor sought common ground tonight for an arbitration conference to end the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company strike as labor controversies in three Ohio cities put more than 16,000 out of work.

MADRID, Feb. 20. -- Many political prisoners were released throughout Spain today on orders from the Attorney General for their "provisional liberty" pending the granting of an amnesty for 30,000 prisoners, and tonight the new Leftist government took the first step toward proclaiming that amnesty.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20. -- The contract to furnish the army with 2,592 feather (duck) pillows, on which bids were opened here Monday under invitation 178, has been awarded to the Comfort Pillow and Feather Company at the net price of $1.2375 for delivery to the New York general depot and $1.3025 for delivery to the St. Louis medical depot.

NYACK, N.Y., Feb. 20. -- Howard Van Buren, one of the most prominent residents here and a descendant of President Martin Van Buren, shot and killed himself today in his home at South Nyack. The body was found by servants this morning in a bathroom with a bullet wound in the temple and a revolver clutched in the right hand.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- As a first step in a broad program fostered by the administration to bring about reforms in connection with reorganizations and the activities of protective committees, steps are being taken to expedite action on a bill introduced by Representative Sabath of Illinois.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- Dr. F.E. Townsend and the man who will head the House investigation of his old-age pension movement agreed today on one point -- the Californian will have a major role in the inquiry on his plan to pay $200 a month to the aged.
BUFFALO, Feb. 20 (AP). -- Ships which ply the Great Lakes are being measured this Winter preparatory to being marked with a "load line," indicating the depth to which they may be safely loaded.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Feb. 20. -- Senior Dance, the last exclusive formal event for members of the graduating class at Mount Holyoke College, will be held tomorrow night in Chapin Auditorium. A classical theme of blue and silver has been used by the committee, headed by Miss Muriel Johnson of Scarsdale, N.Y., for the decorations.
Four players reached the quarter-final round in the first day's play in the National Squash Tennis Association veterans' tournament at the Columbia University Club yesterday.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., Feb. 20 (AP). -- The former Anne Gould, great-granddaughter of the late Jay Gould, was married to Herman H. Elsbury, cowboy and "dude wrangler'' of Cody, Wyo., here on Saturday, it was disclosed today. It was a day after her first husband, Frank Meador, member of a Texas ranching family but now a bank clerk, received a divorce in San Antonio, Texas.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 20. -- The British Government won a reprieve recommendation today from the California Supreme Court for Alexander Mackay, 29-year-old Scotsman under sentence to hang Feb. 28.

ROME, Feb. 20. -- The publication in the Giornale d'Italia yesterday of the Maffey report holding that Great Britain had no outstanding interests in Ethiopia is still the chief subject of discussion in Rome political and diplomatic circles.

Something about "Hallowe'en," which was acted at the Vanderbilt last evening, suggests that Henry Myers more than half believes the hocus-pocos he has shaken into a play. He has written a methodical tale about a woman who is possessed of the devil in a New England inn on Hallowe'en.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP). -- Army housing and construction to cost $29,960,733 was proposed today in a bill introduced by Chairman McSwain of the House Military Affairs Committee. The work would be spread over five years.

ALBANY, Feb. 20. -- Senator John J. Dunnigan, Democratic leader of the upper house, today joined the fight to make pari-mutuel betting legal at the New York tracks as he introduced a measure for a constitutional amendment to permit use of the machines.

The administration's victory in the TVA case emphasizes anew a fact that has long been recognized -- namely, that government, limited though it is by constitutional provisions, yet possesses vast powers which, if not wisely used, may prove destructive to the welfare of our citizens and even to government itself.

We dropped in the other evening at an informal session of The-Big- One-That-Got-Away Club, one of charter groups of the Anglers' Hot Stove League. In this case the boys -- mainly trout and bass fans -- were gathered in front of a fireplace, and not around a stove, but the arguments were just as heated as any Winter pow-wow of backwoods fishermen lolling in Uncle Ezra's village store.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20. -- Prices of hogs were on the down grade today with the losses running to 25 to 40 cents a hundred weight as the result of larger receipts. Some under-weights were regarded as 50 cents lower. In the last two days the general market has dropped fully 50 cents, while stock under 170 pounds is off 75 cents to $1.

It is very rarely that the performance of a soloist can match an orchestral interpretation directed by Arturo Toscanini. When a soloist of such capacity arrives, and Mr. Toscanini from his stand on the rostrum discourses great music with him and the audience, it is an occasion to remember.

Explaining its refusal to join Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, in accepting for $1,475,000 a proposed settlement of suits amounting to $22,500,000 against the New York Title and Mortgage Company and others, the State Mortgage Commission said yesterday that it believed it was acting "solely for the protection of mortgage certificate holders."

Net income of the Superior Steel Corporation in 1935 was $46,691 after Federal taxes, interest, depreciation and other charges, it was announced yesterday. This is equal to 41 cents each on 113,576 shares of $100-par capital stock outstanding, excluding 1,424 shares held in the treasury.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20. -- Dr. Frederick A. Cook, who in 1909 announced that he had reached the North Pole, has opened a fight to have his claim confirmed as a scientific achievement. He is making his headquarters at the Bismarck Hotel.

On the same day as it passed on the TVA case, the Supreme Court handed down another decision which attracted hardly a tenth as much attention, but which, in its broader implications, was certainly not less important. Three Mississippi Negroes had been declared guilty of the murder of a white man and sentenced to death on the basis of confessions extorted from them under torture.

Ninety-four students of Columbia College have received King's Crowns awarded by the Advisory Committee on King's Crown Activities, it was announced yesterday. The award is the highest recognition accorded by the college for extra-curricular non-athletic activities.
Stephen T. Kelsey is with Burton, Cluett Dana.

A decision to stand pat on its style protection program was reached here last night at a meeting of the board of the Fashion Originators Guild of America and affiliated manufacturing groups. The board directed strengthening of the enforcement machinery of the guild's program and reported no defections in the ranks of manufacturing members.

Mrs. Sarah Leah Bruckman, who says she is 109 years old but is modern enough to want to trim her years to a mere 100, finally has retired from her role of Good Samaritan in the East Bronx, where she actively ministered to the needy for nearly thirty-five years.

Brokers' loans, as reported by member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City, rose $1,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $944,000,000. The rise was in loans to out-of-town brokers, loans to brokers and dealers in New York City being unchanged at $882,000,000.

After the first act of Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" at the Metropolitan Opera House last night Artur Bodanzky was too fatigued to continue his conductorial activities and relinquished the baton to Karl Riedel for the two final divisions of the music drama.

Stirred by the discovery that the heavy steel cars used on the city's independent subway system are apparently as susceptible to "telescoping" in cases of collision as the flimsy wooden vehicles used on the elevated lines, Mayor La Guardia is planning a thorough study of methods of removing this hazard.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 20 (AP). -- Bullets caused a panic in a Common Pleas court room today as detectives shot Clayton J. Clausen, 30, on trial for robbery, after he shouted that he was going to blow up the building.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 20. -- Today's developments at Asuncion prove that the new de facto government will be a military dictatorship in the hands of an army junta which is dissatisfied with the Chaco peace terms.

LONDON, Feb. 20. -- Despite a further increase in imports of merchandise last year, Great Britain's payments abroad showed a substantial credit balance. Estimates issued by the Board of Trade show an increase of 10,000,000 to 185,000,000 in net receipts from overseas investments and an advance of 5,000,000 to 75,000,000 in income from shipping.

IT was a track talk with appropriate decorations. The discussion began in the doorway of the trophy room at the New York A.C. The topic was the indoor national championships just ahead. Could Venzke repeat over Cunningham? Too bad Joe Mangan wasn't in shape to make it a triangular contest at the "metric mile."

ROME, Feb. 20. -- Today's official war bulletin confirms that Marshal Pietro Badoglio's army is once more on the march southward. The next Italian objective presumably is Alaji Mountain, a natural fortress of tremendous strength rising almost 11,000 feet above the sea level and barring access to Lake Ashangi.

Twenty-two of the thirty-one persons indicted on insurance fraud charges in Brooklyn on Wednesday were arraigned yesterday before County Judge John J. Fitzgerald in Brooklyn. Detectives were still searching for the nine other defendants.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20. -- Donald D. Conn, executive vice president of the Transportation Association of America, said today that he had refused to permit a representative of the Wheeler Senate Railroad Investigating Committee to inspect the files of his organization.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- Despite a reduction of a quarter of a billion dollars in processing taxes collected, the Treasury reported today a net gain of almost $50,000,000 in internal revenue for the first seven months of the fiscal year. Collections in January alone were somewhat under those of January, 1935, because of the elimination of processing taxes, but virtually every other category showed large increases.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and the reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date.

In the Senate Monday Mr. HOLT of West Virginia, a consistent supporter of Mr. ROOSEVELT, charged that the administration of WPA in his State is for politics mainly or only. According to him, the head of WPA in West Virginia uses this selective method, which recalls Mr. FARLEY'S preliminary tests, laid down early in 1933, for ascertaining the merit of applicants for office:

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 20. -- Miss Patty Berg, 18-year-old Minneapolis schoolgirl, continued her victorious march today by defeating Mrs. Leon Solomon of Memphis, Tenn., in the semi-finals of the annual Championship of Palm Beach, at the Palm Beach Country Club.

The Very Rev. Dr. Leopold Kroll, for the last eight years dean of Holy Trinity Cathedral and dean of the theological school at Port au Prince, Haiti, was consecrated Bishop of the Missionary District of Liberia, West Africa, yesterday morning in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
PARIS, Feb. 20 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 20. -- Fifteen German emigres were arrested here today and charged with widespread Communist activities among German political refugees. Their object, it is alleged, was to discredit the German emigres' Socialist leaders and turn the emigres themselves toward bolshevism. It is also charged that they sharply criticized the internal situation in Czechoslovakia and interfered with this country's home affairs.

ATLANTA, Feb. 20 (AP). -- Governor Talmadge's financial "dictatorship" of Georgia met opposition today from two State officials, who refused to approve spending of 1936 revenue without an appropriation bill.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 20. -- More than 800 members of society gathered at the Miami Biltmore Country Club tonight for the third annual Helen Lee Doherty Milk Fund ball. Several hundred dollars was contributed to the fund which was established three years ago by Miss Doherty, daughter of Colonel and Mrs. Henry L. Doherty.
May I explain certain facts to Mervin J. Sacks, whose letter was published in THE NEW YORK TIMES?

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 20. -- Tentative approval of a modified plan of reorganization for the Symington Company of Rochester, and its subsidiary, the Gould Coupler Company of Depew, N.Y., was granted today in Federal court by Judge John Knight.

Leading all the way, Grover Cleveland High School's basketball team gained undisputed possession of first place in the Queens Division P.S.A.L. race by defeating John Adams High, 39 to 25, in the Cleveland gymnasium yesterday.

The share market is still without what may be rightly termed "important" selling -- selling that might suggest that large holders are liquidating extensively. After proceeding cautiously yesterday during the forenoon, the market appeared to take courage when irregularity rather than weakness characterized active issues, and the advance was resumed in the late trading.

Handicap adjustments among indoor polo players rated at five goals or lower and who may compete in the Junior and Sherman Memorial Divisions of the national championships were announced yesterday by the handicap committee of the Indoor Polo Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- Any irregularities in connection with Works Progress Administration projects in New York City will be investigated "to the fullest extent," and "appropriate action directed in each case," Aubrey Williams, deputy administrator of the WPA, said today.

Abject humiliation is the lot of an American living abroad these days. To read the emotional and short-sighted outgivings of Hiram Johnson, the legalistic but completely unrealistic remarks of John Bassett Moore and to watch lesser fry sizzling, is to taste of bitterness indeed.

BERLIN, Feb. 20. -- Travel in Germany is expected to be considerably more expensive this year than last as a result of a new agreement concluded today at the sixth annual "standstill" conference, which determined the further liquidation of 1,380,000,000 marks of short-term credits owed by German banks and other concerns to creditor banks of eight nations and included in the so-called standstill agreement.

Investors in the $20,000,000 of Series C-2 of guaranteed mortgage certificate sold by the New York Title and Mortgage Company have voted overwhelmingly to have the 300 properties and the mortgages securing their investments reorganized by trustees appointed by Supreme Court Justice Frankenthaler.

The chaste stage of the Adelphi became last evening the caldron for a witches' stew. For out of Herbert Asbury's novel of the same name Howard Chenery has fashioned the play called "The Devil of Pei-Ling." Blood is in it, and thunder and more murders committed or promised than were offered by even the Lord High Executioner of an early-season tenant of the theater.
OSAKA, Japan, Friday, Feb. 21 (AP). -- A strong earthquake shook the Osaka-Kobe-Kyoto district today.
TOKYO, Feb. 20. -- A general election was held throughout Japan today when 877 candidates contested 466 seats. The election was the dullest yet recorded, Tokyo voting stations seemed lifeless.

Joe Mangan of the New York A.C. yesterday completed his withdrawal from the national track and field championships at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night. A brief but pointed telegram reached Secretary Daniel J. Ferris from the ex-Cornellian. It read: "Unable to compete Saturday."
The Texas Pacific Railway reported yesterday a substantial gain in net income for January. The statement follows:

INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 20. -- "Nazi weather," as the Germans refer to what the Britons call "King's Weather," meaning just the weather everybody would choose for every public occasion, seems to stop short at the frontiers of the Third Reich.
The New York Teachers Guild, in a statement issued yesterday, takes exception to the recommendations of the Commission on State Aid to Municipal Subdivisions as they affect education.

Last Sunday afternoon it was my privilege to witness the effects of a well-meaning but inefficient and unenforceable law which prohibits a child under the age of 16 from entering a theatre unless accompanied by an adult.

The dream of the late Henry M. Flagler for an overseas railway route will be studied on next Wednesday by holders of the Florida East Coast Railway's $12,000,000 of 4 1/2 per cent first-mortgage bonds with a view to deciding whether that route is to be consigned to the list of lost enterprises or continued as a going concern.
LONDON, Feb. 20 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

Declaring that prison reform is proceeding too slowly in this country, Sanford Bates, director of the United States Bureau of Prisons, yesterday advised study by the nation of a plan to establish special penal colonies on islands and other remote places owned by the United States.

The Downtown Athletic Club staged an "Olympic Headliner Luncheon" yesterday with potential Olympians and two ex-Olympic champions on the dais, while several hundred club members applauded as they were introduced. It was an informal get-together.

The prospect of a strike in 8,000 apartment, loft and office buildings throughout the city, involving 75,000 elevator operators and other service employes, was increased considerably yesterday when the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations issued a statement declaring that under no circumstances would it grant the demand of the Building Service Employes Union for a closed shop.

Since tentative plans for the proposed World's Fair contemplate holding it during the year 1939 only, the New York World's Fair Corporation cannot for the present comply with the request that it seek to have the 1940 Olympic Games held on Long Island, George McAneny, president of the corporation, said yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 20. -- Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh spent nearly three hours in the House of Commons today as guests of Miss Megan Lloyd George and Harold Nicolson, M.P., biographer of the late Dwight Morrow, father of Mrs. Lindbergh.

On a bid of $1,000,000 the Bowery Savings Bank yesterday acquired at auction the Hotel Woodward and an adjoining building in a foreclosure action against the Woodward Company and others. The hotel consists of two buildings, seven and twelve stories high, at the southeast corner of Broadway and Fifty-fifth Street, and the adjoining structure is six stories high, at the southwest corner of Seventh Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- Governor Landon is expected here to set the pace in the Republican Presidential race by winning the six delegates from New Mexico, which will be the first State to select its full complement of convention delegates.

The estate of Irving I. Bloomingdale, late vice president of Bloomingdale Brothers, who died abroad on Oct. 29, 1929, was valued at $7,949,699 on July 31 last, according to the second intermediate accounting filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

Formal charges seeking the removal of William F.X. Geoghan as District Attorney in Kings County will be filed with Governor Lehman as an aftermath of the Drukman murder case, it was announced yesterday by John Haynes Holmes, chairman, and Rabbi Stephen S. Wise and Dr. John L. Elliott, vice chairmen, of the City Affairs Committee.

For the large crop of diplomatic gossip that has sprung up in Europe during the past few days several reasons are hinted at. These are largely hypothetical. It is said that the delay of the League of Nations in the matter of embargoes may be partly due to hopes of an adjustment which will end the war in Ethiopia.

VOLTAIRE told the other man, "I disagree heartily with every word you say, but I will defend to the death your right to say it." But what would VOLTAIRE have said if one of the things which the other fellow was burning to state was that as soon as he, the other fellow, got the chance he would promptly close the mouth of VOLTAIRE and everybody else who disagreed with him, the other fellow?

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- When future Attorneys General walk down the fifth floor corridor of the new Department of Justice Building they will doubtless recognize the aristocratic lineaments of one of the figures in a mural suggesting an ideal workingman's home in an era of social justice.

OSAWATOMIE, Kan., Feb. 20. -- Pledged to Governor Landon for the Republican Presidential nomination, the first Kansas delegates to the Republican National Convention were chosen today in this village from which John Brown went forth to Harper's Ferry.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 20. -- Election of 108 new members and associates was announced today by the Yale chapter of Sigma XI. The 108 include nine from the faculty, twelve from research fellows, two from alumni at large, two promotions from alumni associates, two from the medical school, and forty-five from the graduate school.

LONDON, Feb. 20. -- Although there was no break today in the political clouds which have enveloped the Naval Conference, there was a growing belief in British and American circles that the difficulties could be surmounted and the agreements already reached be initialed by the four participating powers without much more delay.
A large majority of the clergy in the United States oppose the Roosevelt New Deal, according to a special Literary Digest poll, the results of which were announced yesterday.

The celebration tomorrow of Washington's Birthday will be the occasion of a series of luncheons, dinners and dances arranged by historic and patriotic societies. The holiday falling on the first day of the week-end will be responsible, it was indicated yesterday, for an unusually heavy volume of travel to and from the city.

Carmine Peduano, 27 years old, of 150 Lake Street, Brooklyn, who, according to the police, has evaded seven summonses for traffic violations in the last year and a half and during the same period has been involved in three serious accidents, was before Magistrate Cullen in Brooklyn homicide court yesterday on a charge of reckless driving.

PARIS. Feb. 20. -- Some signs of the end of hoarding, it is asserted here, are visible in the weekly statement of the Bank of France, published today. At least, in the in crease of 112,000,000 francs in the gold stocks is being counted a considerable amount of gold ingots which have been returned to the bank by French holders.

A difference of opinion as to the best method of bringing order out of chaos in the taxicab industry arose yesterday between members of the joint legislative committee investigating taxicabs and fares at a hearing in the State office building.

Sam Leslie yesterday was returned to the Giants, the club with which he had his first major league experience. He was purchased from the Dodgers, according to the announcement by Secretary Eddie Brannick, "for a substantial sum," although neither Brannick nor President Horace Stoneham would indicate the amount.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP). -- A Greek offer of actual cash in part payment of war debts -- the first from a defaulting European debtor nation in more than two years -- has been accepted by the United States.

All the old tenement houses owned by the North River Savings Bank will be improved to conform to the requirements of the Multiple-Dwelling Law, Henry G. Raab, realty officer of the bank, reported yesterday to Tenement House Commissioner Landon W. Post.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 20. -- A new competitive record for Lakewood Country Club links and a one-stroke lead over the field in the $2,500 St. Petersburg open golf championship were held today by Paul Runyan, professional from White Plains, N.Y.

MELBOURNE, Friday, Feb. 21. -- Lincoln Ellsworth, whose explorations have taken him to both the Arctic and the Antarctic, said today he might return to the Arctic regions where he sees great possibilities for further exploration.

A substantial reaction in business activity occurred last month from the comparatively high level for December, the Annalist reported yesterday, and as a result its index of business activity had its first setback since May, 1935, the preliminary index declining to 91.2 from 94.8.

The excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $40,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $3,040,000,000, following a decline of $90,000,000 in the previous week, according to the weekly report of the Federal Reserve System, published yesterday.

MOSCOW, Feb. 20. -- This surprising new Soviet effort to root out "left deviations," which less than a week ago was concentrated on the ultra-modernistic grand opera, veered today to proletarian kitchens and "monstrous trick architecture."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The cotton-spinning industry was reported today by the Census Bureau to have operated during January at 111.9 per cent of capacity, on a single-shift basis, compared with 103.8 during December last, and 102.6 during January last year.

A summons and complaint in a suit for alleged breach of contract and damages of $100,000 brought by Florence Walton, former dancing partner of Maurice Mouvet, against Frederick H. Prince, 77-year-old chairman of the board of Armour Co., were filed yesterday in Federal court.
Two postponed matters hurry to catch up with Broadway tonight, as follows:

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas increased 4 per cent for the week ended Feb. 15, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The increase is the same as that reported for the previous week.

MADRID, Friday, Feb. 21. -- Eight persons were known dead and forty-five were reported wounded in riotous demonstrations in various parts of Spain last night, as an out-growth of the victory of Leftists in last Sunday's general elections.

The annual Dixie dinner dance of the New York Southern Society was held last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. It was one of the largest in this series of dances, more than five hundred persons -- members of the society and their guests -- being in attendance.

Listed among the passengers booked on the French liner Ile de France for Plymouth and Havre are several prominent musicians, including Sir H. Hamilton Harty, English composer and conductor of the London Symphony; Robert Casadesus, French pianist, who came here several weeks ago for concert appearances in several American cities; Mrs. Casadesus, Bernardino Molinari, conductor, and his wife, and Jan Smeterlin, Polish pianist.

A warrant for the arrest of William Fox, former motion picture producer, was issued yesterday by Federal Judge William Bondy, for contempt of court growing out of Fox's failure to submit to examination in a suit brought against him by the Capital Company, a California corporation, which operates theatres.

The recent Senatorial inquiry into munitions and the origins of the World War was characterized by Professor James T. Shotwell of Columbia University last night as "conceived in terms of Marxian idealism without the learned Senators knowing they were indulging in it."

Claims of sovereignty over lands discovered by modern explorers, specifically in cases where flags were dropped in Antarctica by Lincoln Ellsworth, are discussed in an article by Charles Henry Hyde, Professor of International Law at Columbia University, in an article that will be published today in The Independent Journal of the School of Journalism at the university.

WARSAW, Feb. 20. -- Prayers for preservation of Hebrew ritual in the slaughter of cattle were made in all synagogues in Poland today. The Rabbis Association of Poland also sent a radiogram to the more important Jewish religious communities of the world with a request to join in the prayers.

Bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday amounted to $5,647,394,000, compared with $5,255,517,000, for the corresponding week a year ago, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This represented a gain of 7.5 per cent in the year. Last week the gain was only 2.2 per cent because of the Lincoln Birthday holiday.

THE new mystery by Dorothy L. Sayers is the Louvre Museum, the Coliseum, the Mickey Mouse of detective stories. In it mystery-writing technique is lifted from the plane of checkers to the plane of chess, and the chess figures come alive. Ideas rather than mechanics move the plot, and characters with blood and brains fill the pages.
Five groups of employers and two union heads signed a two-year agreement at City Hall yesterday which Mayor La Guardia said would settle differences in the garment industry involving 105,000 workers.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:
LOWELL, Mass., Feb. 20 (AP). -- Surgeons said John McCoy, 47, whose right arm was amputated as he hung from a crane fifty feet above the ground, apparently was recovering today.

Regulation of the value of the dollar in terms of purchasing power is needed to regain prosperity and to prevent future depressions, according to Frank E. Gannett, newspaper publisher, who spoke on this phase of monetary reform yesterday at a luncheon of the Technical Association of the Pulp and Paper Industry at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The directors of the Eastern Malleable Iron Company have declared a dividend of 50 cents a share on the new $25-par stock. Previously the company paid quarterly dividends of 5 cents on the old $5-par stock. Under the recapitalization plan ten old shares will be exchanged for one new share.

Conflicting proposals which have been advanced in Washington with respect to a Federal merchant marine policy have made it impossible for the shipping industry to commit itself on the subject of Federal aid, according to operators.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Feb. 20 (AP). -- Another unsupported tale of the finding of Paul Redfern, long-lost aviator, in the jungles of Brazil, brought action by two governments and a denial by one of the purported rescuers today.

BERLIN, Feb. 20. -- Just ten days after foreign newspaper readers learned of the event, the German press received today a brief official bulletin informing the public that ten priests and forty-five Catholic lay leaders of youth organizations had been arrested.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows.

The Federal Housing Administration yesterday published a note from Mayor La Guardia congratulating the sponsors of the National Home Show and Building Exposition to be held in the Port Authority Building from March 23 to April 4. "I am keenly interested in the purposes you hope to attain and will cooperate with you in every reasonable way to make it a success," the Mayor wrote.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20. -- Breaking of the cold wave over the Winter wheat belt and a forecast for snow in the Southwest failed today to affect the wheat market on the Board of Trade. Trade was light and there was a resumption of spreading operations between May and July.
WARSAW, Feb, 20. -- The government has appointed a receiver for liquidation of the properties, in Poland of the Methodist Episcopal Church, South, which are valued at $500,000.
Prices of several commodities were increased last week, and The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices advanced to 127.2 on Tuesday from 126.6 the Tuesday previous.

LAWRENCE, L.I., Feb. 20. -- Coming back strongly in the second half, the John Marshall High School basketball team of Richmond, Va., conquered Lawrence High, 42 to 35, before 1,000 fans tonight in the latter's gymnasium.

By a rising vote the House of Representatives has created a special committee to investigate the finances of the Townsend Plan. One of the Townsendites sees in this action "symptoms of political jitters." Another deplores "the singling out of this great movement" for political persecution.

MUNICH, Germany, Feb. 20. -- The Reich prosecutor demanded a sentence of six years at hard labor, together with subsequent police surveillance and deprivation of civil rights for six years, for Karl Nisselbeck, United States citizen, at the third hearing of his trial for high treason in the People's Court here today.

BERLIN, Feb. 20. -- The Boerse opened weak today but strengthened somewhat at the close. The falling tendency characteristic of the market for the last eight days apparently has not been reversed, however, as the recovery was spotty and unconvincing.

Active support of the Centre Club, an organization of 1,000 Catholic college graduates, was pledged last night to the newly formed Catholic Youth Association in its efforts to reduce juvenile delinquency in the city.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 20 (AP). -- Dr. Francis E. Townsend said tonight that his old-age pension organization neither will sponsor a third party nor join movements in any State that would involve a conflict in the Presidential preferential primary of either major party.

MEXICO, D.F., Feb. 20 (AP). -- The Southern Pacific Railway of Mexico agreed to raise salaries of its lower-paid employes in an agreement, made public tonight, by which a strike on the railway was averted a few hours before it was scheduled to start at noon.
The New York Rangers picked up another point in the National Hockey League race by holding the Chicago Black Hawks to a 1-1 tie at Madison Square Garden last night.

Mayor La Guardia is considering construction of a milk pasteurization plant in the Bronx Terminal Market to serve as a "yardstick" in the reduction of milk prices and to smash the existing "milk trust," William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets, Weights and Measures. asserted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- An amendment limiting the spending power of the Secretary of Agriculture to $500,000,000 a year under the pending AAA substitute bill was tentatively agreed on in the House today. General debate on the measure was concluded to the accompaniment of renewed demands for protection of consumers and dairy farmers under the proposed conservation program.

Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt took the initial steps yesterday in her plan to appeal her suit for the custody of her daughter, Gloria, to the Supreme Court of the United States in a certiorari proceeding on the ground that her constitutional rights have been violated.
FREDERICKSBURG, Va., Feb. 20. -- Prompted by civic pride and just plain curiosity, residents of this historic city showered bushels of iron washers into the Rappahannock River today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- A heavy blow was struck at the underworld today when the Senate passed unanimously a bill making it a crime to ship firearms and ammunition in interstate and foreign commerce except by licensed dealers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- An attempt will be made by the government to bring a test case involving the right of the PWA to make loans and grants for the construction of municipal power plants before the Supreme Court at this session in the hope of obtaining a quick decision.

The Furness-Withy passenger steamer Nova Scotia was safely en route to Bermuda yesterday in the tow of the Furness-Prince liner Eastern Prince, which went to her aid after she had lost her propeller late Wednesday. The Eastern Prince, coming north from South American ports, answered the Nova Scotia's call and got a towline across yesterday at 7:51 A.M.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- An army "court of honor" tonight found Colonel Joseph I. McMullen, legal adviser to the Assistant Secretary of War for fifteen years, guilty of dishonorable conduct and sentenced him to demotion, to partial forfeiture of pay and to official reprimand.

BOSTON, Feb. 20. -- Six New Yorkers and two Philadelphians remained in the running for the national racquets singles championship at the conclusion of the first round of play at the Tennis and Racquet Club today.

The Furness-Withy passenger steamer Nova Scotia was safely en route to Bermuda yesterday in the tow of the Furness-Prince liner Eastern Prince, which went to her aid after she had lost her propeller late Wednesday. The Eastern Prince, coming north from South American ports, answered the Nova Scotia's call and got a towline across yesterday at 7:51 A.M.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- An army "court of honor" tonight found Colonel Joseph I. McMullen, legal adviser to the Assistant Secretary of War for fifteen years, guilty of dishonorable conduct and sentenced him to demotion, to partial forfeiture of pay and to official reprimand.

BOSTON, Feb. 20. -- Six New Yorkers and two Philadelphians remained in the running for the national racquets singles championship at the conclusion of the first round of play at the Tennis and Racquet Club today.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Feb. 20. -- The Beeches, spacious Northampton estate where former President Calvin Coolidge spent the last years of his life, is for sale.

Testimony given by Dr. T.V. Soong, Finance Minister of the Chinese National Government, before Edwin S. Cunningham, American Consul General in Shanghai, was responsible in part for the setting aside of a verdict for $48,594 here in favor of Gordon B. Enders, World War aviator who bought twenty bombers from the United Aircraft Exports, Inc., of Hartford, Conn., for the Chinese Government and sued that company for a balance due on commissions.

Throwing a million to the dogs is a common enough phrase these days, but obtaining revenue of nearly $1,000,000 from the dogs of one State is quite another matter. New York's Commissioner of Agriculture, PETER G. TEN EYCK, made public on Wednesday, however, the fact that the license fees derived from 398,508 of the State's 471,122 dogs had amounted in 1935 to $924,435.40.

Holders of the 7 per cent preferred stock of the Endicott Johnson Corporation, which has been called for redemption on May 21, at $125 a share, will receive today an offer expiring on March 2 of a new 5 per cent preferred stock of the corporation at the offering price to the public of $103.50 a share.

At the annual meeting yesterday of the directors of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, Robert J. Dodds of Pittsburgh was elected a director for three years, Thomas I. Parkinson, president, announced. Andrew E. Tuck was appointed a vice president and Glenn McHugh and Nils Olsen, second vice presidents.

TRENTON, Feb. 20. -- Reeve Schley, chairman of the State Emergency Relief Council, told Governor Hoffman today that $3,415,000 would be needed for March and that unless the money was made available the council would be forced to cease functioning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- The American Federation of Labor today warned all affiliated unions which are directly chartered by it that it would not tolerate any organization that allied itself with the industrial union bloc known as the Committee for Industrial Organization, headed by John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America.

WOBURN, Mass., Feb. 20 (AP). -- Illuminating gas caused the collapse last night of two nurses aiding in the delivery of a baby and severely affected Dr. Thomas F. Halpin, the attending physician, according to Elmer E. Silver, president of Choate Memorial Hospital, who said the gas escaped from a sterilizing apparatus that had been in use for twenty-five years.

The annual report of the Radio Corporation of America for 1935, made public last night, shows a net income of $5,126,873 after all charges, reserves and taxes. This was equal, after annual dividends on the Class A preferred shares, to $4.43 a share on 766,897 shares of Class B stock.

Her Guggenheim Fellowship renewed, Angna Enters, distinguished mime and versatile artist in many fields, spent last Summer traveling and studying in Egypt, the Near East and Spain. She has returned to present her brilliant "Episodes in Dance Form" in a tour that extends from coast to coast, and with several hundred drawings and water-colors, which travel too, and are now being shown at the Ehrich-Newhouse Galleries until March 7.

The energy of the WPA here was concentrated yesterday upon putting into effect its new system of controlling the rental and utilization of automobiles, trucks and equipment used on WPA projects, but the officials were silent on the question of fraud and suspected fraud in connection with this problem.
The Metropolitan Museum. of Art announced yesterday its purchase of "a great painting by Titian entiled 'Venus and the Lute Player.'"

The record set recently by the Pennsylvania Railroad in selling bonds with a 3 3/4 per cent coupon is likely to be equalled by the Virginian Railway in a forthcoming financing operation, according to proposals under consideration yesterday.

Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy refused yesterday to approve the incorporation of the General von Steuben Bund, partly on the ground that the name resembles that of the Steuben Society, organized in 1919, which has never taken steps to protect its name, and because the petitioning society at a von Steuben celebration here on Nov. 27 neutralized the singing of "The Star-Spangled Banner" with the Nazi "Horst Wessel" hymn.

Taking issue with Controller Frank J. Taylor's statement that the 1936 budget was out of balance by $2,650,232.25, Mayor La Guardia declared emphatically yesterday that the budget "was and is balanced.''

The enactment by Congress of several railroad labor regulation bills, now pending before it, would add a billion dollars to the cost of railroad operation and increase the cost of transporting each carload of freight by $20, J.J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads, declared yesterday at the 145th annual meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers.

Another $1,250,000 to defray the expense of removing snow and ice from the city's streets was voted by the Board of Estimate in a special meeting at 6 o'clock last night while the Weather Bureau predicted more snow for today. The additional appropriation brought the total to $6,350,000, the heaviest borrowing for snow-removal in the history of the city.

Supreme Court Justice McGeehan reserved decision yesterday on the application by Attorney General Bennett to continue a temporary injunction restraining the Associated Gas and Electric Company and sixteen affiliated utility corporations from deducting from the wages of their employes any money to be applied on the purchase of bonds, notes or other securities of the Utilities Employes Securities Company of 61 Broadway.

The enactment by Congress of several railroad labor regulation bills, now pending before it, would add a billion dollars to the cost of railroad operation and increase the cost of transporting each carload of freight by $20, J.J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads, declared yesterday at the 145th annual meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers.

The record set recently by the Pennsylvania Railroad in selling bonds with a 3 3/4 per cent coupon is likely to be equalled by the Virginian Railway in a forthcoming financing operation, according to proposals under consideration yesterday.

Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy refused yesterday to approve the incorporation of the General von Steuben Bund, partly on the ground that the name resembles that of the Steuben Society, organized in 1919, which has never taken steps to protect its name, and because the petitioning society at a von Steuben celebration here on Nov. 27 neutralized the singing of "The Star-Spangled Banner" with the Nazi "Horst Wessel" hymn.

The Federal grand jury which for more than a week had been considering the evidence in the hoax kidnapping of himself engineered by Caleb Milne 4th refused to indict him yesterday and the youth was freed. United States Attorney Lamar Hardy thereupon dismissed Milne's $6,500 bail and said the government would make no further effort to prosecute him.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 20. -- Miss Bam, a 10-to-1 shot, made a flock of Florida Derby eligibles look bad in winning the St. Petersburg Purse of seven furlongs today at Hialeah Park. A.G. Tarn, Winnipeg horseman who captured the second leg of the local trainers' race, had the daughter of Blazes in prime condition and the filly scored by a length and a half over the Brann-castle Farm's Ugin.

Taking issue with Controller Frank J. Taylor's statement that the 1936 budget was out of balance by $2,650,232.25, Mayor La Guardia declared emphatically yesterday that the budget "was and is balanced.''
BERLIN, Feb. 20. -- Considerable improvement in world trade took place during the last few months of last year, according to a survey by the Reich Statistical Office.

MOSCOW, Feb. 20. -- A Soviet-Japanese deadlock over the proposal to create a commission to investigate border incidents in the Far East became apparent today as the government's leading organ, Izvestia, launched a strongly worded editorial attack on the Japanese attitude.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- Wholesale prices turned upward in the week ended on Feb. 15, according to the Labor Department's index. The average, based on the 1926 level as 100, rose to 80.6 from 80.4 the preceding week. A year ago the index stood at 79.4.

PRAGUE, Feb, 21. -- Premier Milan Hodza left today for Belgrade, where he will arrive tomorrow morning. Czech political circles believe the main object of his conversations in Yugoslavia will be the status of Austria and the proposed Hapsburg restoration.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

AKRON, O., Feb. 21 (AP). -- Good-year Tire and Rubber Company officials obtained a court order late today to permit coal shipments through a picket blockade at the company's three plants, where a strike has thrown 14,000 workers out of employment.

A few nights ago the Museum of Science and Industry burst into blossom. Few were aware, however, that years of patient labor had been given to its development, and especially in recent years, by CHARLES R. RICHARDS, whose illness prevented his witnessing the realization of the hopes of its founders.

The Kings County Lighting Company, according to testimony given by Andrew J. Gonnoud, its president, before the Public Service Commission yesterday, will contest payment of real estate taxes based on additional assessed valuation of its property made by the city after Oct. 1, 1935.

MUNICH, Feb. 21. -- Karl Nisselbeck, naturalized United States citizen, was sentenced in the Peoples Court of Munich this morning to two years' imprisonment for being "an accessory to attempted high treason." His nine months' imprisonment during the preliminary investigation was deducted from the two-year term.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 21. -- Eddie Driggs of Garden City. L.I., was among the winners today in the third annual Mid-Ocean-Castle Harbour invitation golf tournament. In the first round of match play he defeated Allison Choate of Rye, N.Y., 5 and 3, and in the second he took the measure of Vincent Frith of Bermuda, 7 and 6.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP). -- Contending that there was a $200,000,000 saving at stake, Senator Vandenberg, Michigan Republican, started a drive today against further appropriations for the Florida ship canal, the Passamaquoddy power project, and three other work-relief-financed undertakings, until each is approved by Congress.

One fears that "Mainly For Lovers" is a bit of a rag. It comes to the Forty-eighth Street Theatre from dear old London town with a teapot tale of a married couple which does not get on well together and an unmarried couple which promises to do very much the same thing.
BERLIN, Feb. 21. -- The German Foreign Office revealed tonight that in its note of last May 25, it charged that the proposed Franco-Soviet pact effectually nullified the Locarno pact.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- An adjustment of Brazilian credits to United States nationals was arranged today when Oswaldo Aranha, the Brazilian Ambassador to Washington, and E.P. Thomas, president of the National Foreign Trade Council, signed an agreement by which Brazil undertakes to release to United States commercial creditors up to $30,000,000 of frozen exchange.

Another Venzke-Cunningham duel will give added zest to the forty-eighth annual national indoor track and field championships at Madison Square Garden tonight. As far as the A.A.U. is concerned this 1,500-meter battle will be just one of sixteen title tests.

A twelve-story apartment house is planned for 46-48 East Seventy-eighth Street, Pease Elliman, brokers in a recent sale of the site, reported yesterday. The property, assessed at $127,000, was conveyed last Wednesday by the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, as committee of Laura G. Kirby, to the 46 East Seventy-eighth Street Corporation, Philip Wellins, attorney.

The comprehensive loan exhibition of the works of Paul Gauguin, to be held at the Wildenstein Galleries beginning on March 20, has been arranged with a view to the benefiting of two charities. There will be an admission fee of 50 cents, the proceeds being divided between the Societe des Amis de Paul Gauguin and the Penn Normal, Industrial and Agricultural School of St. Helena Island, S.C.

ROME, Feb. 21. -- Well-informed circles in Rome gave a broad hint this afternoon that Italy would refuse to enter any new international obligations, and particularly would refuse to accept any restriction on her freedom of action where the navy is concerned, as long as sanctions remained in force.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- Authority for an actual issue of $60,344,000 of bonds and a nominal issue of $9,656,000 was asked today of the Interstate Commerce Commission by the Virginian Railway under whereby the road a plan would save $618,200 per year in fixed charges.
Directors of the Twenty-third Street Association voted yesterday by eight to four to support the West Side Association of Commerce in its proposal to re-zone the midtown West Side of Manhattan.

Stanley LeBlanc, an energetic young man from Wedgeport, a little fishing village on the shores of Lobster Bay in Nova Scotia, has been around the city the past few days, calling on various big-game fishermen and extolling the advantages of his home town as a tuna angling resort. Apparently he has had some attentive listeners, judging from the list of bookings he displays.

BOSTON, Feb. 21. -- Roger Knapp, 17, of Melrose, Mass., a high school senior, is the strongest of hundreds of thousands of college and high school boys tested in the United States and Canada, Professor Frederick Rand Rogers of Boston University, said today.

Observance will be made today by patriotic and historic societies in church services and in a series of luncheons, dinners and dances of the 204th anniversary of the birth of George Washington. Flag ceremonies, a parade and the placing of wreaths on the city's several statues of the Father of His Country also will be included in the day's program.

CAMDEN, N.J., Feb. 21. -- Nearly 150 "brain trusters" of puzzledom, who scorn the most difficult crossword problems as mere child's play, arrived in Camden tonight to sharpen their wits during the next three days on anagrams and rebuses at the 105th semi-annual meeting of the National Puzzlers' League.

CAMERON, S.C., Feb. 21 (AP). -- The sport of ancient Kings and knights -- a lancing tournament -- will have a strange setting on the Golden Kernel Plantation tomorrow, when plumed lancers will be ringed with spectators in automobiles instead of royalty in medieval costume.

Faced by a proposal of the oil companies to increase the cost of fuel oil by 10 cents a barrel, steamship operators have protested to the House Committee on Merchant Marine and have obtained its promise of a conference, it was learned yesterday.
Evidence already developed has been sufficient, Special Prosecutor Hiram C. Todd said yesterday, to justify Governor Lehman's order to investigate in all its phases the murder of Samuel Drukman.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Feb. 21 (AP). -- Professor George W. Stewart, head of the University of Iowa Physics Department, predicted today that science would develop a treatment for deafness in which the skin of the back or abdomen will be made to serve as "ears."
I was interested in a letter in which John Stuart Thompson compared laws of "well-managed New Zealand" to our "amateur political methods."

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21. -- Federal Judge George A. Welsh, in handing down a decree today on the preferential status of war veterans in the allotment of WPA jobs, limited its application and assured Federal officials that he had no wish to hamper the work-relief program.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $24,344,772, compared with the revised total of $12,073,675 for this week. The weekly average for the year to date now stands at $22,296,335.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 21. -- Sharing honors on today's program were two large annual charity events, the Green and White Ball at the Colony Club for the benefit of the Children's Welfare Aid, and the Tombola by the Women's Guild of Bethseda-by-the-Sea at the Cloisters, Garth and Gardens of the Church, attended by nearly 1,500 persons.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 21. -- How to "build a social soil" in which the spirit of cooperation can thrive over competition is the problem that youth must figure out for an adult world, 400 delegates to the State Youth Conference were told tonight by Mrs. Grace Overton, Indiana author, in the keynote speech opening a three-day session here.

BERLIN, Feb. 21. -- Trading on the Boerse was somewhat more active today and prices a trifle firmer. The falling tendency that bad continued for about ten days appears to have been brought to a definite standstill. The market's significance as a barometer of business conditions, however, continues slight.

Revision of the fair-trade practice rule governing the distribution of tobacco products was sought yesterday in a resolution adopted by delegates to the annual convention of the National Association of Tobacco Distributors in session at the Hotel New Yorker.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP). -- Appointment of Dr. James H. Kimball, recognized authority on weather conditions over the North Atlantic air routes, as principal meteorologist and official in charge of the New York City Weather Bureau station was announced today by W.R. Gregg, chief of the Weather Bureau.

It was practically inevitable that, with Josephine Baker back in town after her barbaric era abroad, she should sooner or later turn up as the star of a local night spot She, if any one, was the personification of that mad, pre-depression night life which put the gay in Paree for most Americans.

The journey of a modern Dante into the lower depths of the "inferno" of the atomic inner citadel, the nucleus, penetrating spheres hitherto forbidden to the most cunning ingenuity of man's devices, was described yesterday at the joint meeting of the American Physical Society and the Optical Society of America at Columbia University.
After every airplane crash there is an investigation as to the cause. In general the results of these investigations are pathetically small and uncertain.
COSHOCTON, Ohio, Feb. 21. -- One out of every five persons in this city of 10,885 lay ill today of an intestinal malady which State health officials attributed to contaminated water.

BEIRUT, Syria, Feb. 21 (AP). -- The secret resignation of the President of the Syrian Republic, Ahmed Ali Bek El-Abed, on Feb. 15, following the request of a delegation of Nationalist women, was learned today.

Jose Iturbi, the Spanish pianist and conductor, has been appointed conductor of the Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra for next season, it was announced yesterday by A.M. See, executive director of the Rochester Civic Music Association. His acceptance of the post removes another from the field of possible conductors for the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra to succeed Arturo Toscanini, who will not return next season.

On a fifteen-yard victory in the last event on the program, the 400-yard relay, New York University's swimming team defeated City College, 42 to 29, in their annual meet last night in the Beaver pool.

Because of an article severely criticizing the political views of former Governor Alfred E. Smith, Manhattan College's weekly student newspaper, The Quadrangle, was suppressed yesterday by order of Brother Patrick, president of the college.

PARIS, Feb. 21. -- Tempers ran high, most unparliamentary language was used and at least one resounding smack in the face was administered within the precincts of the French Chamber of Deputies today in the course of a debate on last week's assault on Leon Blum and all that has developed from that incident.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21. -- Arrivals of hogs here today were somewhat in excess of the demand and with prospects of a larger run next week unless adverse weather conditions should develop. Prices generally dropped 10 to 15 cents a hundred pounds, with some sales suggesting a loss of 25 cents.

The speed of Alston Jennings in the sprint events enabled Columbia's swimming team to defeat Navy, 45 -- 26, last night in an Intercollegiate Association meet in the Morningside Heights pool. Jennings won the 50 and 100-yard races in decisive fashion and was anchor man on the victorious relay team.

Sermons on brotherhood will be preached tomorrow in the city's churches and this will also be the topic of discourses this morning in synagogues because today and tomorrow are the third annual Brotherhood Days throughout the United States under the auspices of the National Conference of Jews and Christians.
Anne Morrow Lindbergh's "North to the Orient" (Harcourt, Brace) has gone into an eleventh edition, making the number of copies printed thus far 230,000.

The railroads substantially increased their aggregate expenditures on maintenance in 1935, figures issued yesterday by the Interstate Commerce Commission disclose. The compilation shows a gain of 5.5 per cent in gross revenues, of 7.7 per cent in maintenance-of-way expenses, 6.8 per cent in outlays for maintenance of equipment and 7.5 per cent in transportation expenses in 1935.

The Emerald ball, outstanding Catholic social function in Brooklyn, at the Waldorf-Astoria last night, brought out the second largest crowd since its inception ninety-six years ago. About $20,000 was subscribed by the Emerald Association's 4,000 patrons who attended. Proceeds will go as usual to the orphan asylums of the Diocese of Brooklyn.

PARIS, Feb. 21. -- Premier Sarraut and Professor Andre Siegfried were guests of honor at a Washington Birthday dinner held by the American Club of Paris tonight. The club's president, Theodore Rousseau, and its honorary president, Ambassador Jesse Isidor Straus, presided.

A private funeral service at which Mrs. Franklin D. loosevelt was one of the friends present was held yesterday morning for Mrs. Settle Lehman Fatman, a sister of Governor Herbert H. Lehman and widow of Morris Fatman, at the home of Judge Irving Lehman of the Court of Appeals, another brother, at 97 I West Sixty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- The report that the Securities and Exchange Commission is preparing for Congress on the advisability and feasibility of the segregation of the functions of broker and dealer has been delayed for further study of the part that such dual activities by members of the Stock Exchanges have played in promoting speculative dealing in the current market.

The old question as to whether a college team is better than a club team will be answered to some extent in the Metropolitan A.A.U. championship basketball tournament which is now in progress. Among the colleges which are competing are C.C.N.Y., Brooklyn, St. Francis and John Marshall, while some of the clubs which are represented are the Crescents, Union Temple, Heberton Cyclones and Staten Island A.C.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 21. -- George Washington received his first college diploma as a reward for driving the British troops out of Boston. And it was Harvard's first Doctor of Laws degree, the university's archives disclosed today.

Because customs officials cannot see eye to eye with Museum of Modern Art officials about what is art, the museum will have to post bond for nineteen examples of European abstract sculpture borrowed for a special exhibition.

As was anticipated, the London dispatches have some illuminating things to say about the Maffey report on Ethiopia made public in Italy. It was a confidential and secret document which somehow fell into Italian hands. Such things will happen; and in order to score a point, extracts from the archives of a foreign nation are sure to get into print if available.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 21. -- The last of the testimony in the trial of Edward Cannon, charged with first degree murder, was heard this afternoon, and Justice Witschief adjourned court until Monday when the attorneys will begin their summations.

In a report from Garmisch-Partenkirchen in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Feb. 16 is this statement: "Walter Brown, manager and coach of the United States squad, displayed a handful of fan mail from German fans wishing him bad luck, saying, 'We feel sorry for your boys.'"

Three new films are scheduled to open today. They are "Road Gang," featuring Donald Woods and Kay Linaker, at the Strand; "Yellow Dust," with Richard Dix and Leila Hyams, at the Rialto, and "You May Be Next," with Ann Sothern and Lloyd-Nolan, at the Globe.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- The possibility of a Progressive-conservative combination to force an upward revision of income tax schedules in the lower brackets by reducing exemptions and increasing the normal rate became of increasing concern to Congressional leaders today as President Roosevelt disclosed that he had not yet come to any final conclusions on new tax proposals to be submitted to Congress.
" Those guys thought they had me," remarked our Mr. Bloom of the House of Representatives, "but I got in high gear. Nobody's caught me yet on facts and statistics."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- The Committee for Industrial Organization, a bloc of eight unions fostering industrial unionism in the mass-production industries, met here today and refused to obey the request to dissolve, served on the committee by President William Green of the American Federation of Labor, upon order of the federation's executive council.

You are in for it now, by golly, from both Virginians and North Carolinians. Your editorial references to "A Virginia Nomination" -- that of Judge Isaac M. Meekins by The Elizabeth City Independent -- are disturbing alike to geography and politics.

A gray-haired woman reached angrily into the pocket of her shabby coat in Harlem Court yesterday, drew out a $100 and two $50 bills and tossed them on the table before Magistrate Bernard Mogilesky. In this way she expected to repay money she and her sister had accepted from the Emergency Relief Bureau while they had accounts totaling $2,270 in a bank.

The recent New Deal proposal to divide the country into twelve districts for administrative purposes was assailed last night by representative Hamilton Fish Jr. at a dinner of the Traffic Club of New York, held at the Hotel Commodore.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 21. -- Fred Stettler's original statement to the police, which Captain Wallis announced as a confession of the murder of Carl S. Barbour and his wife, was a story of how the couple were slain with a hammer and their bodies placed on a bed. The bed was set afire by a time-clock device.

I take exception to Mr. John Sloan's letter condemning dog racing which was published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Feb. 15. Every time that dog racing is mentioned in any of the States a great wail comes from the horse-racing interests, which claim that their sport is the sport of kings, that the horses are thoroughbreds running for the sport only and that everything connected with their operations is on a superior plane.

Three murderers, caught almost in the act and spattered with the blood of their victim, were not guilty enough to be indicted by a grand jury. By what mysterious processes, what ineptitude or corruption, did they go scot-free? So they might have remained had it not been for the courageous activity of Mr. McGOLDRICK.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- With eleventh-hour changes which would give the Secretary of Agriculture even broader powers to adjust farm output than he had under invalidated sections of the old Agricultural Adjustment Act, the House today passed the administration's $500,000,000 Soil Conservation Bill by a vote of 267 to 97.

Mrs. Rose Sadera, 28 years old, killed herself, her 7-year-old daughter, Anna, and her 5-month-old son, Karl, with gas yesterday afternoon in the kitchen of her home on the second floor of a two-family house at 61-15 168th Street, Flushing Heights, Queens.

Judge Robert A. Inch, in the Federal court, in Brooklyn, yesterday reserved decision on a motion to dismiss the petition in reorganization under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act filed by the Bush Terminal Company on Nov. 16, 1934, and also the equity receivership of the company which was begun on April 1, 1933.

Captain Jack, wire fox terrier owned by John Nickens of Manhattan, was named the best dog of 712 to show as the fifth annual pet dog show at Bloomingdale's came to a close yesterday. The selection was the choice of the two judges, Steve Severn and Everett Turbush.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- President Roosevelt today gave his unequivocal support to efforts to push through at this session of Congress legislation giving civil service status to postmasters of the first, second and third classes.

In furtherance of his policy to rid the city of known criminals, Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday that beginning Monday squads of picked detectives would be stationed in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens to keep in touch with the activities of the underworld and to "harass gorillas, racketeers and gunmen."

BERLIN, Feb. 21. -- The Hindenburg, Dr. Hugo Eckener's new airliner, which is now approaching completion at Friedrichshafen, is scheduled to leave for the United States May 6, according to an announcement issued by the Zeppelin Works today.
NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 21. -- City Commissioner Reginald Parnell was indicted today on a charge of malfeasance in office while he was Director of Revenue and Finance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- The State Department took under consideration today a protest by the Board of Missions of the Methodist Episcopal Church, South, against the suspension by the Polish Government of the activities of its Society for Education and Culture in Warsaw.

Thirty-nine families were ordered out of a six-story apartment house at 16 Marble Hill Avenue, in the Spuyten Duyvil district, at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon when an underground combustion threatened the foundations of the building. Six families had moved out before the Tripod Holding Corporation of 1,819 Broadway, owner of the structure, induced the Tenement House Department to allow the tenants to remain.

PARIS, Feb. 21. -- Finance Minister Marcel Regnier, appearing before the Chamber Finance Committee today, declined to give full details with regard to transfers in connection with the new British loan or explain precisely how the exchange guarantee had been arranged.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- Decreases of approximately 650,000 in employment and $17,900,000 in payroll totals between December and January, representing a net loss of 129,000 workers in factories and 520,000 in non-manufacturing industries, were reported today by Secretary of Labor Perkins.

BOSTON, Feb. 21. -- The elimination of Stanley G. Mortimer of New York, four-time holder of the title, by E.M. Edwards of Philadelphia and the spectacular advance of Clarence C. Pell Sr., veteran New Yorker, seeking his thirteenth crown, featured the quarter-final round of the forty-sixth national racquets championship at the Tennis and Racquet Club today.
FREDERICKSBURG, Va., Feb. 21. -- Tense excitement pervaded this gayly bedecked historic little city tonight, on the eve of what promises to be a momentous test of an American legend.

Like many other citizens who are readers of history, I am in more or less of a daze. Just when I thought I had Lincoln, Jefferson and Jackson safely anchored and properly labeled in their respective niches in history as I know it, along came a Democratic hurricane with a Republican tornado at its heels, and between the two of them those three immortals were carried off to Heaven knows where.

LONDON, Feb. 21. -- Betting pools on the results of league soccer football matches on Saturdays which are known to have yielded 16,000 for a one-penny stake and to have attracted between 20,000,000 and 30,000,000 in the course of a year are to be suppressed if possible by the action of the football league management committee.

The fifth performance this season of Puccini's "Madama Butterfly" was marked last night by the first appearances of Edith Mason and Charles Hackett in the chief roles and delighted a capacity audience at the Metropolitan Opera House.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 21. -- Harvard's undefeated varsity boxing team shut out Princeton, 8 -- 0, in the first boxing match between these ancient rivals in the Harvard indoor athletic building this evening.

New York University's women's basketball team routed the University of Baltimore combination, 33 to 16, yesterday on the court of the School of Education gymnasium at Washington Square. It was the third straight triumph for the Violet since its opening-game defeat at the hands of Brooklyn College.

As reported to the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers, the preliminary estimate on world gold production in 1935 makes possible some remarkable comparisons. Last year's world production was placed at "something more than 30,000,000 ounces."

" Let Freedom Ring," which started out on Broadway and then reversed the usual procedure by moving to Fourteenth Street, will close after this evening's performance at the Civic Repertory Theatre. At the moment, that is the only official closing, but several other productions are hanging by just a thread or so, and some of them may fall over the week-end.

MADRID, Saturday, Feb. 22. -- All of Spain's 30,000 prisoners convicted of or awaiting trial for "political and social" offenses who have not already broken jail or been released provisionally by order of the new government's Attorney General will be freed today.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 21. -- Contrasting the Roosevelt recovery policies with those of the Hoover administration, Postmaster General Farley declared tonight that the former President's program in the depression had been designed to help only "those at the top," ignoring the masses of population and most of the business world.

WASHINGTON, Feb, 21. -- Thirty-two "regulars," favorable to the re-election of Senator McAdoo as Democratic National Committeeman are on the list of California delegates to the national convention, approved by President Roosevelt.

Proponents of the plan for the joint development of the power and navigation resources of the St. Lawrence River by the United States and Canada have renewed their efforts to obtain the necessary treaty authority as a result of the decision of the Supreme Court in the Tennessee Valley Authority case.

MANGUM, Okla., Feb. 21 (AP). -- Trapped by one hundred possemen, a Negro who assertedly admitted that he had beaten a five-year-old white girl to death and critically injured her mother, was shot and killed today when he tried to escape.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 21 (AP). -- A high official of the Methodist Episcopal Church, South, may be sent to Poland to direct legal action against Polish suppression of a Methodist organization.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 21. -- The Society of the New York Hospital, which operates the Bloomingdale Hospital here and the New York Hospital in New York, announced today the temporary discontinuance of the Convalescent Hospital for Children which has been operated on the Bloomingdale Hospital property for the last twenty-eight years.

The authority of Henry G. Alsberg as national director of the Federal Writers' Project has been curtailed and in future Victor F. Ridder, local WPA administrator, will have direct authority over that and other white-collar projects, it was admitted yesterday by William L. Nunn.

The eight-to-one decision of the Supreme Court in the TVA case has evoked a chorus of praise from almost all quarters, and the specific character of the decision as elucidated by Chief Justice Hughes has been dwelt upon with clarity and emphasis in editorial comment, of which the leading editorials in THE TIMES of yesterday and today are notable examples.

Selling of March cotton by houses doing government business featured trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. Though it was estimated that one firm distributed over 15,000 bales of March, the demand for cotton proved so active that prices fluctuated within an unusually narrow range to end 3 to 7 points lower than on Thursday.

President ROOSEVELT said yesterday that a new tax bill will be submitted to Congress soon after his return from a week-end at Hyde Park. The general impression in Washington is that it will be designed to raise about $500,000,000, primarily through the reimposition of processing taxes; but how closely these will resemble the old processing taxes of AAA, either in scope or form, remains to be revealed.

The Federal Theatre Project, which has been in difficulties before, got into more trouble yesterday. This time it was caused by figures. The Stuyvesant High School earlier in the week said that it would like to see a play; the WPA was willing and recommended Show 4A as a nice little number.

ROCKVILLE CENTER, L.I., Feb. 21. -- John Marshall High's quintet, Southern Atlantic high and prep school champion, continued its successful invasion of Long Island by routing South Side High, 47 -- 34, tonight before 1,000 persons in the losers' gymnasium.

Ned Irish has quite successfully promoted "big-time" basketball at the Garden. As a good showman, he attempts to fill in the wait between halves of college contests by introducing some entertaining feature. This year it is games between youngsters from settlements and clubs.

In observance of Washington's Birthday all banks and security and commodity markets throughout the country will be closed today. Canadian and foreign markets will be open as usual, with the exception of the London Stock Exchange, which will observe its usual Saturday holiday.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 21 (AP). -- One fireman was killed and several were injured tonight by one of many explosions which occurred when flames swept the hold of a nitrate-laden ship at her dock here.

BOSTON, Feb. 21 (AP). -- Dismissal of a woman who held a railroad snow shoveler's job for three days until wind blew off her cap and revealed her long hair stirred a protest tonight from advocates of equal rights for women.

LONDON, Feb. 21. -- John Howeson, unchallenged dictator of the world's tin industry for many years, was sentenced today to twelve months in prison for his part in the great pepper and shellac gamble which collapsed and shook the commodity markets of London just a year ago.
