TORONTO, Feb. 21. -- "We have to face the eternal paradox, that laws are made in this final form by Parliaments and Congresses -- that is, by people notoriously incompetent for their tasks," Lord Tweedsmuir, Governor General of Canada, said today in an address to the Law Society of Upper Canada.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 21. -- Avenging a defeat she sustained at the hands of her younger rival three weeks ago, Mrs. Maureen Orcutt Crews of Miami routed Miss Patty Berg, 18-year-old Minneapolis high school girl, in the eighteen-hole final for the championship of Palm Beach at the Palm Beach Country Club today. Mrs. Crews triumphed by 4 and 3.

Retail trade in the metropolitan area during the week continued to suffer from the adverse weather conditions, although volume picked up on Thursday and yesterday. Retail executives here estimate that sales for the week will probably show a decrease of about 5 per cent under the same period a year ago, a figure including the loss in trade due to Washington's Birthday falling on a Saturday, as against a Friday last year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- On the House side of the Capitol another indication of possible trouble over taxes developed today. At a closed session of the Ways and Means Committee Representative Lamneck, Democrat of Ohio, cited a law which forbids any government department or establishment from making tax recommendations to Congress. How strongly such a point might be pressed remained unknown.

An unusual burst of activity on the eve of a holiday developed in the commodity futures markets yesterday. Sugar futures advanced into new high ground but the market as a whole was irregular. On the cash markets, gains occurred in raw sugar, rye and rubber, while corn, cotton, butter, eggs, tin, hides, wool tops and silk declined.

Pedestrian traffic on the west side of Fifth Avenue between Forty-second and Forty-third Streets was seriously inconvenienced during the evening rush hour yesterday by a demonstration of about 800 Communists and their sympathizers picketing outside of 500 Fifth Avenue.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 21. -- With the sun shining and the clods of mud whipping darkly from his flashing heels, the champion, Discovery, ran a sensational half-mile at the Santa Anita track this morning in what was his final trial for the world's richest race, the $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap, to be run tomorrow before 50,000 persons.

Mayor LA GUARDIA said the other night at the Ethical Culture dinner that he can no longer bring himself to make commencement addresses. Before the great crash it was easy to tell the students that if they worked hard and ran straight the world was theirs.
Value of Dollar in Exchange. The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 21 (AP). -- Pierre S. du Pont, chairman of the board of the du Pont Company, in an answer filed with the Federal Board of Tax Appeals in Washington today, denied the claims of the Internal Revenue Commissioner for an additional tax of $617,316 on his 1929 income.

Opening its case against eight officers of the defunct Pelham National Bank charged with misapplication of funds, the government told a jury before Federal Judge William Bondy yesterday that John T. Brook, former president of the bank, used its resources to back up stock operations totaling $4,000,000 for the enrichment of his family.

ALBANY, Feb. 21. -- Speaker Irving M. Ives of the Assembly asserted tonight that the action of Governor Lehman on the demand for the ouster of District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn would be a test of the Governor's sincerity in his campaign for his anti-crime program.

Official confirmation of the report that John (Buddy) Hassett would be the Dodgers' first baseman this year came yesterday from Business Manager John Gorman in a lengthy statement extolling the talents of the Bronx boy and revealing Manager Casey Stengel's satisfaction with the deal.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 21. -- Blocked in its effort to buy the local properties of the Tennessee Electric Power Company, the Chattanooga Electric Power Board moved today to hasten the use of TVA current here by construction of its own distribution system.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 21. -- The favorites came through for the most part in the first round of match play in the sixth annual Winter golf championship of the New York Athletic Club on the St. Augustine links today. The winning list included William J. Waite, who led the qualifying field, and Robert H. Goffe Jr., chairman of the club's golf committee.

Executors of the estate of Anna B. Bliss, widow of William Henry Bliss, New York attorney, who died at Santa Barbara, Calif., on Feb. 22, 1935, have petitioned Surrogate James A. Delehanty for a construction of her will. They say that if they are compelled to pay the taxes out of the residuary estate, as the will directs, they will require $7,500,000, which would virtually liquidate the estate.

In discussing Mike Tiernan the other night I looked up a clipping which included a statement by George Moreland that Tiernan was responsible for the origin of "Giants" as the appellation of the New York National League Club. The clipping explains the incident as follows:
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 21 (AP). -- Jimmy Hines, Garden City, L. I., broke par over a rain-soaked course today to lead the $2,500 St. Petersburg open at the halfway mark.

Fordham's swimming team closed its season yesterday afternoon by scoring a 48 -- 23 victory over Cornell in the Maroon pool. It was the Rams' fifth triumph in six starts and climaxed the best aquatic campaign on Rose Hill in recent years.

Mrs. Peter L. Harvie of Troy, N.Y., was nominated yesterday for the presidency of the Association of Junior Leagues of America, Inc., at the board meeting of the association in its executive offices at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The division in the Republican party in New York State showed signs of widening yesterday and criticism of the selection of delegates and alternates-at-large by the State committee under domination of the party organization increased.

As Sir Walter Raleigh said to Lord Coke: "You tell me news, sir!" The news in your editorial "A Virginian Nomination" is not that I am distressed by the enthusiasm of my friend but that I find myself a Virginian.
ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Feb. 21. -- Great Croat nationalist demonstrations marked the anniversary of the clash between gendarmes and Croat peasants near Zagreb, which resulted in several Croat deaths.

LONDON, Feb. 21. -- Following his father's example, King Edward will broadcast a message to his subjects throughout the British Empire at 4 P.M. March 1. His speech will be carried by all British transmitters.

PARIS, Feb. 21. -- Surprise is being expressed on the Bourse that the 40,000,000 credit extended at the beginning of this week to the French Treasury by a group of British banks has not exercised more influence on rentes. In the past, much smaller credit operations have had beneficial results, but this time several rente issues have continued to decline and are now at the lowest rate registered since the conversions of 1932.

MEXICO, D.F., Feb. 21. -- Samuel C. Faneuf, 60-year-old assistant manager of the Amparo Mining Company in the State of Jalisco, who ten days ago was kidnapped and taken off to the mountains with another American mining engineer from the company, Paul W. Avery, made an unexpected appearance this morning in the village of Etzatlan, near the Amparo mining property.

VIENNA, Feb. 21. -- The newspaper Telegraf published today a dispatch from its New York correspondent reporting that Alfred Edouard Frauenfeld, former Nazi chief in Vienna, would arrive in New York March 1 to be publicity director for a German concern.

A recent article included the statement that there are no more left-handed catchers in baseball. The fact is that there is one of this rare species right in our midst. He is Lou Haneles, a star on the City College team. He was the only southpaw catcher in college baseball last season.

La Salle Academy clinched the Manhattan-Richmond C.H.S.A.A. championship last night by defeating its closest rival, St. Peter's High of Staten Island, 33 -- 22, on the Curtis High floor. The winners are unbeaten in tournament play with nine successive triumphs while St. Peter's is next with seven victories and two reverses.

PARIS, Feb. 21 (AP). -- Miss Sonja Henie, world's premier woman figure skater, appeared well on her way to her tenth successive world championship today when she led sixteen rivals from nine nations through the compulsory figures. The competition will be concluded tomorrow with the free skating.

LONDON, Feb. 21. -- The stock markets here were active and cheerful today. British funds remained firm. In the foreign market Brazilian issues were in renewed demand because of the debt arrangements. Heavy buying of Canadian securities followed better American advices overnight.

The charge that Lawrence T. Dermody, lay superintendent of the Harlem Hospital, discriminated against the work of Negro artists engaged in a Federal art project of designing six murals for the institution was made yesterday afternoon by Charles H. Alston, supervisor of the hospital project and chairman of the Harlem Artists Guild.
New bond financing this week amounted to $52,997,000, compared with $25,787,000 last week and $18,708,000 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- Leaders of the Townsend plan for old age pensions met the challenge of a pending Congressional investigation into their methods of raising funds and their expenditures with an announcement today that they would contest Congressional seats in upward of 300 districts in all States.

Jamaica High went into a first-place tie with New Utrecht in the Metropolitan Interscholastic Hockey League by defeating the Bensonhurst skaters, 3 to 1, at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. Poly Prep and Brooklyn Prep battled to a 1-1 deadlock in the other league contest.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP). -- Jacob Baker, Assistant WPA Administrator in charge of writing the $2,600,000 national guide book, asserted today that his work relief writers would not seek to "debunk" cherished American legends in the manner of recent popular histories.

HELSINGFORS, Feb. 21. -- Four thousand Finnish Ingrians whom the Russian secret police in April, 1935, deported from their homesteads to the Kasakstan Soviet Republic in Central Asia and 3,000 in the Ural region are being exterminated, says the newspaper Uusi Suomi here.

SAN QUENTIN PRISON, Calif., Feb. 21 (AP). -- James B. Holohan suddenly quit the wardenship of San Quentin prison today in the middle of an investigation into a counterfeiting plot carried out behind its walls.
IF Chuck Hornbostel, the hustling Hoosier, would like to know how to go about beating a botanist on a board track, a few suggestions may be in order.
The Barnard Junior Promenade took place last night at the Savoy-Plaza. There were ninety couples present in the ballroom, where supper was served, and in the Gold Room, where there was dancing.
ROME, Saturday, Feb. 22 (AP). -- Emperor Haile Selassie, it was said in informed circles early today, has advanced proposals to the League of Nations for termination of the Italo-Ethiopian War.

In addition to plans for a showroom and store building at Madison Avenue and Seventy-ninth Street, owners, through their architects, yesterday submitted plans for altering a number of existing buildings in Manhattan. Plans also were filed for a dwelling in the Bronx and various homes in Queens.

Attorneys for Zelik Josefowitz, Lithuanian financier, who is passing the Winter months in St. Moritz, Switzerland, appeared for him yesterday in Federal court in an effort to reclaim 10,000 $20 gold pieces seized last Tuesday by Secret Service agents in the Josefowitz vault in the Chemical Safe Deposit Company, 32 Liberty Street.

A Mardi Gras entertainment and dance was held last night at the Plaza for the benefit of the Rosary Foundation, an organization made up of Dominican priests and prominent members of the Roman Catholic laity. The proceeds will be donated to the fund for the publication of a magazine by the foundation, which has headquarters at 141 East Sixty-fifth Street.

Movements of stock prices yesterday were indecisive. For the most part, the market fluctuated irregularly within a narrow trading range. The closing was firm with a scattering of issues claiming fair-sized gains. With a two-day holiday in prospect, it was natural that activity diminished, since the day was virtually devoid of news that might be expected to have much influence, marketwise.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 21. -- General Jose Felix Estigarribia returned to Asuncion, Paraguay, under arrest this morning and is a prisoner at the aviation school at Campo Grande, outside the capital. According to reports from Asuncion the former commander-in-chief of the Paraguayan Army had made a tour of Chaco garrisons, trying to organize a counter-revolution, but all the officers swore allegiance to Colonel Rafael Franco, Provisional President.

Regulation of the taxicab industry by the Transit Commission was approved unanimously yesterday by representatives of civic organizations testifying before the joint legislative committee investigating conditions in the industry.
WARSAW, Feb. 21 (AP). -- A proposal for a mass emigration of Jews from Poland was placed before the government today.

The present approach to slum clearance embodied in the Federal administration's housing plans is wrong, it was said yesterday by Thomas Adams, who served for seven years as general director of plans and surveys of the Regional Plan of New York and Its Environs.

The New York City League of Women Voters asked Assemblyman A.L. Moffat, chairman of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee, yesterday to oppose the bill now before the State Legislature calling for a moratorium on the Multiple Dwelling Law requirements for fire-retarded halls and stairways and separate sanitary facilities for each tenement family.

Cleto Locatelli, Italian welter-weight, and Izzy Jannazzo, East Sider, renewed their ring feud last night in Madison Square Garden before a record low in attendance for the arena's boxing history, and the former triumphed again in ten rounds.

Substantial progress has been made in stopping a "million-dollar-a-year racket" in the city hospitals by means of checking closely on applicants for free treatment and forcing those able to pay to do so, Hospital Commissioner S.S. Goldwater announced yesterday.

A few years ago Lennox Robinson told what happened to Inish when a strolling Ibsen troupe played there. Suicides broke out all over the place and normal human beings became at once actors. The latest play by Edwin L. and Albert Barker has something of the same general idea.

Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, announced yesterday that he had approved a plan to sell to the Aetna Casualty and Surety Company the stock of the Home Title Guaranty Company and the title business of the New York Title Insurance Company and of the Lawyers Title Corporation.

The Underwood-Elliott-Fisher Company in its report for 1935, which was made public yesterday, shows net profit of $3,095,870 after depreciation, Federal income taxes, reserves and other charges, equivalent after preferred dividends to $4.36 a share on the outstanding common stock.

For the second time in a week the attention of realty interests was focused on the upper East Side yesterday when a contract involving the sale of one of the finest town houses in the city was announced.

Retail distribution continued at a slower pace this week as the result of adverse weather conditions, while orders to wholesalers in nearly all branches were curtailed, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. With some cities failing to equal last year's showing, the agency says, the estimated gain in retail sales from the 1935 comparative volume was held down to 1 to 5 per cent.
BOSTON, Feb. 21. -- With the largest entry in the history of the organization, the Eastern Dog Club today began its twenty-fourth annual all-breed exhibition in the Mechanics Building.

Mgr. John A. Ryan of the Catholic University, in an address to the delegates of the Federation of College Catholic Clubs in which he defended the New Deal, assailed its critics and urged the continuance of the Roosevelt administration in office, said: "Congress should have the constitutional power to regulate industry, commerce, agriculture, labor and finance."

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 21. -- For an hour today John Charles Thomas, concert and opera singer, held an unofficial world speed record for light runabouts, but a determined young woman from Port Washington, L.I., Mrs. Maud Rutherfurd, regained her laurels with a time-eclipsing dash over listless Lake Worth.

ENDA JESUS, Ethiopia, Feb. 20 (Delayed). -- The Italian Army moved twelve miles today in a swift push southward, which the routed and demoralized Ethiopians failed to oppose with a single shot. The Italian positions now stretch at the foot of the line of mountains over which towers Mount Alaji, which Italy once held and lost when Major Toselli was defeated and killed in 1896.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 21. -- The tiniest heavenly object known to astronomers, a body one-third of a mile in diameter, or 1-25,000th that of the earth, has just been photographed by the Harvard College Observatory, Dr. Harlow Shapley, director, announced here tonight.

TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 22. -- The possibility that a third party, opposed to militarist domination of the government, might hold the balance of power in the new House of Representatives arose today in returns from the general election.

Notification to the Fashion Originators Guild of America by Lord Taylor that the store "will regard any concerted action by the guild or its members in interfering with the purchase by the store of merchandise in normal channels as an illegal conspiracy," for which damages will be claimed, featured the developments yesterday in the controversy between retailers and the guild regarding the extension of the guild's style-protection program to dresses under $10.75, wholesale.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- President Roosevelt retired early tonight in preparation for departure by train soon after dawn tomorrow to visit Philadelphia and reach Boston by the dinner hour.

FREDERICKSBURG, Va., Feb. 21. -- Four hundred cherry trees, brought from Japan and five States of the nation, are to bear blossoms and fruit for the one which Parson Weems said youthful George Washington cut down with his hatchet.
LONDON, Feb. 21. -- The Marquess of Londonderry, former Air Minister, has returned after three weeks in Germany convinced that her new air force is not directed against Great Britain.

The annual report for 1935 of the New York Steam Corporation issued yesterday showed a net income of $779,362 after all deductions. This is equivalent, after preferred dividends, to 41 cents each on 360,000 no-par common shares, compared with $1,086,108, or $1.26 a share, for 1934.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

Charles H. Tuttle, former United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, formally took office yesterday as president of the Greater New York Federation of Churches. Mr. Tuttle was elected at the annual meeting of the board of directors in the Parkside Hotel on Thursday.

MOSCOW, Feb. 21. -- Failure on a large scale of collective farms to provide individual households with cattle as required by the new agricultural constitution promulgated a year ago was charged today by Jakoff Arkadievich Yakovleff, Commissar for Agriculture.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- A topographic sketch made by George Washington, at the age of 15, of his own school grounds, and a drawing of the building in which he was painstakingly acquiring the knowledge which was to make of him the most famous surveyor in American history, illustrate two pages of his copybook, now nearly 200 years old, which is one of the rare manuscripts and treasured possessions of the Library of Congress.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 21. -- Excitement above the ordinary reigned at Hialeah Park today. The big crowd was subjected to suspense and thrills, due to finishes so close that the photographic eye had to be called into constant play and to a futile claim of foul which delayed the result of the third race.

INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 21. -- Today's International Ski Federation downhill races for men and women were run off under snow conditions variously described by the spectators and competitors alike as "suicidal" or "murderous."

For the first time in two seasons Grete Stueckgold appeared in a song recital last night at Town Hall. The comely soprano, with her irresistible graciousness and charm of personality, at once found favor with the large gathering which seemed bent on conveying to her their delight at hearing her again on the concert stage.
TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 21. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman conferred tonight with attorneys for both sides in the Hauptmann case.

FROM a distant university in South Africa twoscore mining students recently brought their "war cry" to the top of the Empire State Building. On a tour of this country, they had ascended to see Manhattan from its highest point.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22. -- Merchandising came back fairly satisfactorily with the rise in temperatures toward the end of the week. Wholesale dry goods houses reported sales totals as high as 5 per cent above the like week of 1935, despite the fact that snow-clogged roads still hampered Mid-West trade.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- Assistant Secretary of the Navy Henry Latrobe Roosevelt died at the Naval Hospital at 5:15 o'clock today of a heart attack following intestinal influenza. He was 56 years old.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- Following is the text of Senator Borah's Washington Birthday address over the radio tonight:

Despite statutory assurance that no taxpayer will be subjected to unnecessary examinations or investigations of his affairs in connection with the verification of income tax returns, much litigation has resulted from the Treasury's endeavors to conduct two or more such inquiries in respect to a single taxable period.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Feb. 22. -- An Estonian plebiscite arranged to determine whether the nation prefers a constitutional regime to the present dictatorship will be held tomorrow, Monday and Tuesday.

My admiration goes to Arthur Krock for his clear and impartial dispatches from Washington, and most recently for his candid opinion that no anti-war legislation could possibly be effective unless it were premised on the sort of consultation and rapid cooperation that would bring an aggressor to his senses before he knew what struck him.

RADIO actors are usually quick to confess that they are no better than their parts. The comedian admits his success depends upon his jokes. The key to the orchestral broadcast is the conductor -- called "the forgotten man" of radio, because he directs sound but never confides even a whisper to the "mike."

For the first time in the history of the American Woman's Association, a legislative topic affecting women in general and those in the business and professional world in particular, will be brought before a general meeting of the association Tuesday evening at the clubhouse.

TRUJILLO CITY, Dominican Republic, Feb. 22. -- The Dominican Republic paid tribute to George Washington today when President Rafael Trujillo officially opened the republic's finest boulevard and named it George Washington Avenue.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 22. -- Evils which have grown up in college sports were sharply condemned by President Angell of Yale University today in his annual Alumni Day address to about 2,000 graduates. He cited the tearing down of goal posts at football games, booing of players and officials, and similar practices which have grown into football and hockey games and to some extent into basketball games.

WASHINGTON, Pa., Feb. 22. -- The Philadelphia Inquirer and its chief officers were found not guilty tonight of a criminal libel charge brought by Charles J. Margiotti, Attorney General of Pennsylvania.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 22. -- Student opposition to any change in the current system of obtaining scholarship funds from current income was emphasized this week at Vassar College.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- Winter sports lovers are visiting the playgrounds of Pennsylvania in large numbers to enjoy one of the longest stretches of real Winter weather known here in many years. More than twenty inches of snow remains in the Poconos, with every indication that the Winter sports will continue here for several more weeks at least.

Hunter College students, whose studies were interrupted by the fire which closed the Park Avenue building, will resume on an emergency part-time program tomorrow, according to an announcement yesterday by Mrs. Mary Belden James Lehn, registrar.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 21. -- Following disclosure of conditions in the Pennsylvania Industrial School at Huntingdon that were branded by Governor George H. Earle as showing "fire hazards of the worst sort" and "barbaric disciplinary methods," fifty-four State-controlled institutions are now under investigation by State Police.

THE story of "Secret Marriage" hews to the median line of Kathleen Norris's reliable romantic formula. In the first place, it has the kind of subject she likes best to deal with -- a subject which seems topical though it need not necessarily be so.

The entrance of the United States into the World War was due to an effort to "retrieve and protect" a flood of money loaned to Europe by American financiers, the Rev. Joseph A. McCaffrey, chaplain of the 165th Infantry (Fighting Sixty-ninth), said yesterday.

AMONG the letters recently received from correspondents discussing various aspects of motoring and its problems is one from E.M. Marshall of Redding Ridge, Conn., suggesting a means for detecting repeaters in traffic court. He writes:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- Two New Deal projects -- one actual, the other shadowy -- suffered jointly a decided setback this week when the Supreme Court for the second time in eight cases defended by the administration sustained the government pleading. This is a paradox, but it is true.

Until women have removed a few more of the discriminations practiced against them, they will have to work and vote together, in the opinion of Miss Lena Madesin Phillips, president of the International Federation of Business and Professional Women.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 22. -- President Roosevelt came back to Harvard tonight to attend the 100th anniversary of his college club, the Fly, and to dine in an atmosphere of disapproval for his administration and his policies as strong as that of a Liberty League banquet.

MADRID, Feb. 22. -- Thousands of Socialists and Communists carrying red banners and singing "The International" paraded through the main avenues of Madrid tonight in celebration of the sweeping amnesty for "political and social" offenders, which became effective today.

With the signing of Albert (Max) Butcher, tall right-handed hurler, whose contract was returned yesterday, the potentially formidable pitching staff assembled by Manager Casey Stengel is in line with two exceptions.

Led by Johnny Grimes and Henry McMullen, who scored four goals apiece, the La Salle Military Academy sextet routed Brooklyn Tech, 10-3, in a Metropolitan Interscholastic Hockey League game at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 22. -- In one of the roughest finishes seen in a big stake in many years, A.A. Baroni's Top Row won the world's richest race, the $135,700 Santa Anita Handicap, before 50,000 persons today. The handicap champion Discovery under his top impost of 130 pounds trailed as Top Row, Time Supply and Rosemont finished as named.
OBERLIN, Ohio, Feb. 22 (AP). -- Half a century ago a young chemist broke the seal on the secret of turning aluminum from a laboratory curiosity into a useful metal.

DALLAS, Feb. 22. -- Warmer weather for the last few days has resulted in a decided upturn in the volume of retail sales throughout the Eleventh Federal Reserve District. Other business activity also reflects improvement with the better weather. Building operations have been resumed.

A STORM of conflicting opinion is usually raised by any mention of William Saroyan, whose meteoric advent on the literary scene dates from the publication last year of "The Daring Young Man on the Flying Trapeze."

PROBABLY few countries have villages with queerer names than many in England. While motoring through Cornwall recently a party of Americans noticed a signpost pointing the way to a village called "Come to Good" -- one mile off the main road between Truro and Helston.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 22. -Columbia University remained undefeated in five starts in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League but it was forced to play its hardest game of the season to down a fighting Harvard quintet, 29 to 27, in the Harvard indoor athletic building tonight.

HERE is a new way of writing about churches and religion. For this book is as vivid and dramatic as a motion picture, as secular as the morning paper, as objective as an experiment in chemistry, and yet it lacks nothing in the reverence for spiritual things with which it is written.

If rents go up this year, higher taxes cannot be made the excuse. The city's basic real estate tax rate for 1936, Controller Taylor announced last week, will be 2.65 per cent, a six-point reduction from last year.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 22 (AP). -- A golfer comparatively unknown in open competition, Leonard Dodson of Pembine, Wis., blocked the veteran Harry Cooper's drive for the $2,500 St. Petersburg open championship today by tying the Chicago professional in the final round.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- Industrial activity in the United States in February has been slightly lower than in January, after allowing for the usual seasonal increase, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly business survey. Most of the weekly indicators, however, show only minor variations and afford no evidence of any significant recession from the relatively high level of activity reached earlier in the week.

Gene Venzke did it again. Thundering down the final homestretch with a surging lift of tremendous drive and power, the picture runner from Penn once more turned back Glenn Cunningham last night. But this time he gave his performance an added fillip and a touch of greatness. He broke the world's record.

CHICAGO. -- William Hale Thompson, Chicago's colorful Republican Mayor during the era of prohibition, crime and mounting municipal debts, has suddenly popped into the limelight just people were asking, "What's become of Big Bill?"

MOST tourists who come to Florida spend much of their time fishing, and they are at it again this season with as much enthusiasm as ever. The more patient sooner or later bring in catches that make just as good conversation as a hole-in-one or an operation.

PARIS, Feb. 22. -- Ambassador Jesse I. Straus today entertained at luncheon at the United States Embassy the diplomatic representatives of all the American republics in observance of the anniversary of Washington's birth. Referring to President Roosevelt's proposal for a Pan-American anti-war conference, Mr. Straus said: "All of us here can rejoice together at our increasing friendship, mutual confidence and interest in each other's peace, prosperity and economic progress.

In July, 1935, ABRAHAM ABRAHAMSON, Assistant Professor of Economics at Bowdoin on leave, was appointed Works Progress Administrator for Maine. There was much grumbling among some Democratic politicians. This has continued and increased. No such trivial charge as inefficiency has been brought against him.

FROM the welter of American civilization, remarked Harold Nicolson lately, six products have emerged which he would like to see more slavishly imitated in this country. They are orange juice for breakfast, thermostat heating, air conditioning, universal refrigerators, cheap bathrooms and the American type of wandering or perambulating foreign correspondent.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 22. -- In the opening round of the National Squash Racquets Championship play today, Donald Strachan of Philadelphia, defending title-holder, won his first match in straight games from Coe Kerr of Yale and then went on to defeat Charles Brainard of Hartford, who had drawn a bye in the opening round.

IN "Summer in williamsburg," David Fuchs's first novel, there was a character known as Old Miller, an odd old Jew who spent his time mumbling prayers in the Greenwood Cemetery, collecting from 50 cents to $5 a prayer from hurried mourners.

THE Yale Literary Magazine has reached the astounding and implausible age of a century and the undergraduate editor are making magnificent bones about it. For the centennial issue they have collected a garland of new work by such old contributors as Thomas Beer, Archibald MacLeish, Sinclair Lewis, Waldo Frank, Walter Millis, Lucius Beebe, Philip Barry, Henry Seidal Canby, Stephen Vincent Benet, William Lyon Phelps, George Soule, Leonard Bacon, John Farrar and Thornton Wilder.

Typhoid fever takes its greatest toll in villages and small towns of less than 10,000 inhabitants, rather than in strictly rural areas or large cities, according to a study by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, made public yesterday.

A STIMULATING group show, devoted mainly to the work of French artists or artists affiliated with the French school, is being held, until March 14, at the Marie Harriman Gallery. It contains, in addition to paintings by Cezanne, Von Gogh, Renoir, Picasso, Matisse and Derain, two canvases by the American artist Walt Kuhn.

An organization of war veterans who are members of the WPA Federal theatre project in New York was launched yesterday "to combat the element of communism in the theatre project and other WPA units." A nucleus meeting of the organization, which will be known as the Federal Theatre Veterans League, was held at the Union Church, 229 West Forty-eighth Street.
District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Kings County struck back yesterday at critics who have accused him of laxity in the investigation of the murder of Samuel Drukman.

GENEVA, Feb. 22 (AP). -- A session of the League of Nations Sanctions Committee of Eighteen, to discuss application of an oil embargo against Italy, was specially convoked by the League today to be held March 2.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 22. -- The Naval Academy varsity triumphed in the main engagement of a fencing double-header today, defeating New York University in a closely contested match, 14 to 13, after the plebes had lost to the Violet freshmen, 15 1/2 to 11 1/2.

ROME -- Sanctions have made Italy the land of substitutes. Italian scientists and inventors are dedicating their efforts to the discovery of means whereby the importations that have hitherto been considered indispensable may be replaced by materials and articles produced in Italy.

While the Old Guard of the Socialist party may support President Roosevelt for re-election, the real Socialist party will not, The Socialist Call in a statement signed by its editorial board declared in its latest issue, published yesterday. The statement criticized an editorial in The New Leader which condemned Norman Thomas for his recent attack on the President, and it asserted that The New Leader editorial revealed the position of the Socialist Old Guard.

How the United States Treasury dominated the world silver market in 1935, and how it suddenly relinquished that domination in the final month of the year, are described from the viewpoint of one of the "four just men" who daily fix the price of silver in London in the annual circular of Pixley Abell, leading bullion brokers in London, which has just been received here.

In spite of the fervor with which women in recent years have allied themselves with consumer movements, prime ribs of beef for which they pay top prices occasionally turn out to be only medium and the reassuring little purple stamp "Strictly Fresh" on this morning's half dozen eggs proves a fraud and a delusion.

MOTORISTS bowling along one or another of the country's new highways past orchards and farm acres in the Southwest and West are apt to forget what the pleasant panorama looked like before irrigation converted it into something of a garden spot.
ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 22. -- Yale lost to Cornell, 71 -- 42, in their twelfth annual indoor track meet in the drill hall tonight.

Arturo Toscanini accepted yesterday morning an invitation to conduct the opening concert of the newly organized Palestine Symphony Orchestra on next Oct. 24 at Tel-Aviv, it was announced by Bronislaw Huberman, Polish violinist and founder of the orchestra.

MR. VERRILL thinks too much attention has been paid to treasure hunts that were failures while those that have been successful have been neglected. And so in this book he has selected a score and more of authentic accounts of the fairly recent finding of buried treasure, either by accident or by organized search.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 21. -- Much discussion has been aroused by the Virginia Legislature's inquiry into nepotism in the State government. Considerable criticism has been directed at the State Supreme Court of Appeals, five of whose seven justices were found to have members of their immediate families working for them in secretarial capacities.

In his introduction Mr. Ilin describes the first book of world geography that he knew as a boy. This little geography, he says, told "in a most objective and detached way about uninhabited stretches of tundra in the north and uninhabited stretches of desert in the south."

PARIS, Feb. 22. -- Following yesterday's strong support of the government by the Left parties in the Chamber of Deputies, the Bourse came today under the influence of those who are opposed to the Left policy. There seems indeed to be a deliberate campaign against the government going on through intermediary public funds.

LONDON, Feb. 1. W.H. AUDEN, a poet of the modernist school, a very young man whose work is as a red rag to the conservative mind, has produced at the Westminster Theatre, in collaboration with Christopher Isherwood, a piece called "The Dog Beneath the Skin," which is intended as a satire on capitalistic society in general and on Nazism in particular.

LAST week, if all went well, London saw the premiere of the Pavlova memorial film, entitled "The Immortal Swan," booked for the Regal Cinema as the first stop on its campaign to raise funds for a monument to the great dancer in Regent's Park.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 22. -- Matthew Monahan Jr. of Lake Placid made the fastest time ever recorded on the Mount Van Hoevenberg bob run in two-man racing today to win the North American title.

GENEVA, Feb. 21. -- The League of Nations, now that it has moved into its impressive new palace, has gained an air of solidity and permanence which it had badly lacked. Every bank building attests to the high value that men attach to outward appearances; but every bank failure proves that these are not enough.

BOSTON, Feb. 22. -- The weather continues the principal factor in New England business. Extreme cold, snow and icy roads have combined to keep retail trade below expected levels and, to some extent, also have resulted in curtailment of manufacturing operations, the result of difficulties in distributing merchandise.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 22. -- Showing strength in the foils and saber, the Princeton fencing team downed the St. John's University of Brooklyn swordsmen, 20 -- 7, today in the university gymnasium. The Tiger captain, Kirk Alexander, intercollegiate epee champion, was defeated in his speciality by O'Connor and Niedzielski of St. John's, although he managed to defeat Kraemer.

MADRID, Feb. 21. -- Perhaps the best conclusion to be drawn from the recent election is that Spain -absorbed completely in internal politics because there is no external threat to her national security -- is still divided into two great rival camps.

AFTER twenty-one long years, during which many New Yorkers forgot the call of the North Woods, the sportsmen's show is coming back to revive the vision. Next Saturday guides Indians, lumberjacks, husky teams and live furred and finned and feathered denizens of the woods and shores of all Northeastern America arrive in town.

UPON the shoulders of A. Edward Barit falls the mantle of the late Roy D. Chapin as head of the Hudson Motor Car Company. He has been in the background of the executive personnel of the Hudson company for a long time.

ALTHOUGH particular pains have been taken to keep even a spark of genius from slipping into the paragraphs appended hereto, there is still the possibility that somewhere in the lines to come there may lie the plot for something called "Sam, the Old Scenario Man (or the Reading Gaols of Hollywood)."

If the Republican party is to defeat Roosevelt next November it must "re-establish the alliance of Eastern manufacturing, commercial and financial interests with Western farmers on which it was founded and by virtue of which it has remained the majority party, in normal times, ever since the Civil War."

Perhaps more thrilled and excited than when he made his first training trip to Marlin, Texas, with the Giants twenty-six years ago, Secretary Eddie Brannick yesterday marshaled the small official going-away party into the Florida Special at Penn Station and headed for Pensacola and (he hoped) a lot of sunshine.

PARIS. SMART Parisian women, who are undoubtedly the canniest sartorial "pickers and choosers" in the world, are always much interested in the smaller couture houses. Though these may bring no great style message to the world at large, they offer well-made models with a personal touch.
TOKYO, Feb. 22 (AP). -- Almost complete election returns were announced tonight.

AT this time of year, when the Atlantic seems very cold and gray and when, after one has traveled it, one is confronted by a Europe still under the mantle of Winter and a Mediterranean filled with the alarums of war, South America materializes out of potential holiday lands with winsome attraction.

DESPITE the bitter cold of a New England Winter and the icy gales that lash the coast with sleet and hail, 200 small fishing boats are plying their trade around Casco Bay, Me. They are open, motor-driven craft, 20 to 25 feet in length.

THE character of Gaius Octavius, destined to become the famous Emperor, Augustus Caesar, is not generally represented as an especially attractive one. Cold, calculating, merciless, Arthur Weigall describes him as "far more ruthless" than either Lepidus or Mark Antony, his colleagues of the pitiless Triumvirate

BLEEDING HEART YARD is hidden away in a busy section of London, and the association of Hatton Garden is all with diamond merchants now. But when Sir Christopher Hatton, Queen Elizabeth's Chancellor, filched this land from the Bishops of Ely as the site of his own homestead Hatton Garden was both beautiful and rural.

Mrs. Rachel Fayette was 105 years old yesterday. She celebrated her birthday with customary festivity in the Graham Home for Old Ladies, 320 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn. Sound in mind and body, the veteran of twenty-three such parties smiled or frowned, chatted or kept "mum" just as she pleased.
F.J. Podesta of the Columbia University Club, seeded No. 1 in the tourney, advanced to the quarter-final bracket of the National Class C squash tennis championship at the City A.C. yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 22. -- With Governor Lehman due to go on the air tomorrow night in a radio appeal to the people for support of his anti-crime program, Assemblyman Abbot Low Moffat announced today that he would introduce a compromise pistol possession bill.

DURING the Century of Progress Fair there was held in Chicago and New York the First International Congress of the World Fellowship of Faiths. Its eighty-three meetings, which continued through the greater part of a month, heard 242 addresses made by 199 messengers and spokesmen from a bewildering number and variety of races, countries and religious faiths.

Brilliant performances in the one-mile runs were among the standout achievements as Evander Childs High of the Bronx and St. John's Prep of Danvers, Mass., captured team titles in the national interscholastic indoor track and field championships conducted by the A.A.U. in Madison Square Garden yesterday.

PROFESSOR FURNAS was one of perhaps quite a number of people who came away from A Century of Progress exposition with "a feeling of disappointment." Not only was science cast into the shade by a competing ballyhoo, which, on the whole, suggested a century or two of retrogression, but science itself seemed imperfect.

MARGARET LANE has chosen as the locale of her first novel a part of London which is not only fascinatingly romantic in itself but which has an intriguing literary association. The identity of the "Yard" where so much of the action of the story takes place is established by the dedication to Pearl Binder, who did the lithographs for Thomas Burke's "The Real East End."

THE Book-of-the-Month Club has concluded arrangements with La Societe Nouvelle Sequana in Paris to make available immediately to readers of French in this country an outstanding book published each month in France. The distribution will be done by a new society called the French Book-of-the-Month Club, with offices at 386 Fourth Avenue, New York City.
MONTREAL. Feb. 22. -- McGill's hockey team went down to its first defeat of the season in college combat today, losing to Harvard's sextet by 7 to 4 in the Forum.
GLENDALE, Calif., Feb. 22. -- Dr. Francis E. Townsend offered his
DAYTON. TESTS on a number of airplane engines, some of which surpass in power anything now in service, are being conducted at Wright Field, it was disclosed last week.

Opening the field trial season for retrievers, the second annual Maryland retriever trial will be given under the sponsorship of the American Chesapeake Club on Saturday, March 28. Entries will close on March 21.
This being election year, the administration has been driving for a short session of Congress and a peaceful one. In the interests of brevity much was accomplished last week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- In giving the army a record peacetime appropriation of more than $375,000,000, Congress has borne in mind the admonition concerning all work and no play, and earmarked the sum of $34,940 for the "welfare" of the army.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 22. -- Sablin, consistent 4-year-old son of Display in the black and yellow silks of Edward F. Seagram, raced to his fourth and most notable victory in as many starts this Winter when he easily captured the third running of the Joseph McLennan Memorial Handicap, feature today at Hialeah Park.

Upon learning that her supposed fiance had married another woman, Elizabeth Volochin, 21 years old, administered a lethal dose of sleeping powder to Stephen Shubunka, 30, of 715 West 170th Street, early yesterday, according to the police. The girl then attempted to take her own life by the same method, which at first led the police to believe the case was a suicide compact.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- In a vigorous plea for the United States to refrain from entanglements with foreign powers in affairs not specifically concerning this country, Senator Borah tonight contrasted what he termed the unneutral attitude of Great Britain in the Italo-Ethiopian war with the British position when Japan was invading Manchuria.

LIBERALISM as a conscious and aggressive movement arose in Great Britain as two different streams flowed into one. One of these streams was the humanitarian and philanthropic zeal that became so active late in the eighteenth century and that in various forms is still a mighty current.

CLAIM RENEWED: When Commodore Robert E. Peary returned from his dash farthest north in 1909, he was amazed to find the world paying homage to Dr. Frederick A. Cook, who claimed discovery of the North Pole the year before. Peary's supporters would not accept Dr. Cook's story.

IN order to form some idea of the cultural gap that separates Chaucer's day from our own, and of the social and scientific changes of the intervening centuries, one need merely glance through the pages of Mr. Plimpton's book, which is intended to show what sort of education a man like Chaucer may be supposed to have received.
Besides being an Olympic year, women in sports will be more internationally minded than usual with several important tests receiving their attention.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., Feb. 22. -- Snow trains brought hundreds of skiers from New York today for the Winter sports carnival.

While it was practically impossible to obtain any figures in the Worth Street district on the state of gray cloth stocks last week, selling agents and brokers admitted that they were unusually high on some constructions and menaced the price structure.

With the fading of any hope at the second London Naval Conference for another international agreement restricting sea armaments, the future construction policy of the United States Navy will present a new problem -- or, rather, an old problem in an aggravated form. When the current treaties expire on Dec. 31,

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 22. -- Thirty-four undergraduates elected to Phi Beta Kappa at Brown University will be formally recognized at special chapel services on Thursday. The new members will be initiated at the annual banquet on March 4.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 22. The junior class at Vassar College gave its annual prom tonight in Students' Building. Faculty members received the students and their guests at a reception after dinner.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 22. -Yale tonight evened its basketball series with Princeton, winning by 47 -- 44, after the Tigers staged a superb second-half rally. Captain Tommy Wilson of Yale was outstanding on offense and defense in the contest, an Eastern Intercollegiate League affair.

The Columbia freshman basketball team defeated Scarborough School, 23 -- 14, yesterday in the Morningside Heights gymnasium. Anderson and McCormack were the Lions' high scorers with 8 and 6 points, respectively. The Blue led by 13 to 6 at half-time.

FREDERICKSBURG, Va., Feb. 22. -- Walter Johnson, the "Big Train" of baseball and hero of countless thousands of American youngsters, today threw a silver dollar across the partly frozen Rappahannock River as part of an observance of the 204th birthday anniversary of George Washington.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 22. -- James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, deplored signs of a return of speculative activity today in an address before 200 members of the Princeton National Alumni Association.

SOIL has become, all of a sudden, the talk of the nation. It makes the first page as often as the Supreme Court. It shares time on the air with the budget and the dentifrices, and it is flatteringly mentioned at all the banquets, even the gold-plated ones. Soil has caught the public's imagination at last.

Four members of the crew of thirty-two men on the oil tanker Albert Hill were missing yesterday following an explosion shortly before noon in the forward tank which ripped out the deck and started a fire that the crew fought for two hours.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 22. -- Manhattan College defeated Seton Hall for the second time this season tonight, 45 -- 27. The Jaspers went ahead late in the opening session to lead, 21 -- 16, at the half.

THIRTY years in any man's business is a long time. The experience of thirty years in any business should give to the man who has had it the right to speak with authority about it, but thirty years in the business of the theatre seems to leave a man just about where he began.

THE new Second symphony by Roy Harris will be given its first presentation by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, under Richard Burgin's direction, this Friday and Saturday in Boston, Mass. The program will also include the Fifth piano concerto by Beethoven, with Leonard Shure as soloist.

RED BANK, N.J., Feb. 22. -- North American ice boat championship honors, held in this part of New Jersey for many years, received a severe jolt today when a small boat, built along modern streamlining ideas, outsailed most of the speedsters on runners built up here from years of experience.
BERLIN, Feb. 22. -- This week's diplomatic travel in Central Europe provides food for thought.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- The power to raise margin requirements provides an effective instrument for controlling excessive credit demands by stock market speculators, the Federal Reserve Board said today in its monthly bulletin, intimating broadly that there was no need to fear a runaway speculative market so long as this instrument was available.

ATHENS, Feb. 22. -- Reports that Cyprus will be ceded to Greece by Great Britain, provided King George retains the Greek throne, gained further credence here today as a result of news from the island that no attempt will be made to fortify it.

The McMahon Memorial Temporary Shelter for Children, 128 East 112th Street. will be the beneficiary of a card party to be given tomorrow afternoon at the Cosmopolitan Club by a group of women headed by Mrs. Peter McDonnell and Mrs. James 1. McDonnell.

PARIS. AMONG the many brilliant men who are now writing for the French theatre there are three whose talent is not only essentially dramatic rather than literary, but also possesses the powerful individual quality which belongs to the creation of original work.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22. -- Colonel Brueckman was honorary president of the Maennerchor and had been its active president from 1882 to 1885. He was the last surviving member of the Chelsea Beach Company, an organization that developed the Chelsea section of Atlantic City, many years ago.

OTTAWA, Feb. 21. -- The Canadian-American trade treaty had been expected to furnish the main issue for Parliament this week, but instead the chief subject for discussion proved to be the important matter of budget balancing. If freer trade is one of the two legs of which the new Liberal administration expects to stand in the next five years, the other is governmental economy.

Prospects of an immediate upswing in sales of major household electrical appliances as a direct result of the Supreme Court's ruling on the TVA cheered one branch of the electrical manufacturing industry try last week, while producers of power generating and distributing equipment were plunged into gloom over the effect they fear the decision will have upon their markets.

COLOR has returned to haunt the film producers. Scarcely recovered from the grim chain-clanking of "Becky Sharp," the first full-length picture in the new Technicolor, they now are confronted with a more significant specter in "The Trail of the Lonesome Pine," which opened last week at the Paramount.

Editor and Publisher, trade journal of the daily newspaper field, publishes in its current issue the following descriptive article on the new system for the rapid transmission of news photographs about to be put into operation throughout the country by THE NEW YORK TIMES through Wide World Photos:

A COLLEGE degree or a high school diploma is no guarantee of an individual's real educational status or mental equipment. This in effect is the charge made by Dr. William S. Learned in the annual report of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Learning published last week.
About $20,000 has been added to the Y.W.C.A.-Y.M.C.A. Joint Campaign Fund since the final report luncheon on Feb. 7, when the total reported was $403,209, it was announced yesterday.

WASHIIVGTON, Feb. 21. -- The recent severely cold weather, following, in the main, many mild Winters, has caused people throughout the country to ask: "Does this portend a return to the reputed cold Winters of 'granddad's day' years ago?"

A pirate theme reminiscent of the days when the "Jolly Roger" flew at the masthead of rakish vessels plying southern waters has been devised for the ball, Quat' Z' Arts Night in Nassau, which will climax the series of entertainments now being arranged for he Beaux-Arts Society cruise to Nassau, B.W.I.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 22. -- Comparatively moderate temperatures in the last two days revealed the stored-up buying power ready to deluge stores in the Eighth Federal Reserve District. On these periods department stores, which have suffered severely by the continuous blizzards, were crowded with buyers.

A mail vote last week by the directors of Region No. 2 of the American Power Boat Association, comprising New York State, resulted in the unanimous election of Wilbur F. Crook as chairman and manager of this area, according to an announcement yesterday by George W. Sutton Jr., the A.P.B.A. president.

Last week was TVA week for the stock market. The financial community was disappointed that the Supreme Court's decision last Monday went against the utilities, but it found some solace in the fact that the ruling was limited in scope. Speculative interest in utility stocks waned and for a day or two pressure of speculative selling persisted.

New York City's recurrent efforts to keep pace with its growing water needs have been thrown into relief by two recent developments. The first was the completion of a new water tunnel from the Hillview Reservoir in Yonkers down through the eastern portion of the city, which will provide better distribution of existing supplies.

SEATTLE, Feb. 22 (AP). -- Two men were reported killed, a third was missing and others were believed trapped today as snowslides roared down a two-mile stretch of the Snoqualmie Pass Road in the high Cascades.

LONDON, Feb. 22. -- John Howeson, until last year the "world's tin king," spent his first day today behind the bars of grim Wormwood Scrubs Prison where Lord Kylsant, owner of the Royal Mail Shipping fleet, served a twelve months sentence for fraud in 1931.

Many indications that "the expansion of governmental services is not determined solely by the economic necessity of these services" were found in a survey of the State and local expenditures of the forty-eight States, the results of which are announced in the current issue of Social Research, quarterly publication of the New School for Social Research.
OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 21. -- There is a United States Senatorship to be settled in Iowa next November, and there is a good stiff piece of work cut out for the man who lands it.

Despite a propitious start earlier in the season, when estimates indicated sales gains of 10 to 20 per cent, Spring merchandise buying has slowed down to a point where many lines are running behind a year ago and the increases in others have been shaved sharply, manufacturers reported here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- An immediate campaign to organize about 500,000 workers in the steel industry was proposed today by the Committee for Industrial Organization, which pledged for the drive a contribution of $500,000 from its eight unions to the American Federation of Labor.
BELGRADE, Feb. 22. -- Premier Nulan Hodza of Czechoslovakia arrived in Belgrade today and had an audience with the regent, Prince Paul.

Activity in the wholesale markets here increased last week, but it did not reach the level anticipated for this period of the season, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by the McGreevey, Werring Howell Company. However, the orders placed revealed a decided trend toward better Spring merchandise, the buying office commented.
WITH his bags all packed for the trip to the Giants training sector at Pensacola, Secretary Edward Aloysius McGonigle Brannick waxed prophetic on the coming baseball season.

Ordinarily, February is too early in a Presidential year to talk of the probable effect of the political campaign on business. That discussion rarely begins until candidates have been named at the conventions and the campaign issues defined. Even in such a year as 1896, when the political battle subsequently brought trade almost to a halt, financial markets advanced considerably during January and February; the great success of the Government's popular loan providing the stimulus.

LENT brings noticeable changes to the food markets and restaurants of New York and modifies the diets of millions of people. More fruits, vegetables and cereals are consumed during the Lenten season, and fish comes into its own as a food of prime importance.

The Alumni Society of Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, will observe "Good-will Sunday," which is sponsored by the National Conference of Jews and Christians, by attending the 11 A.M. service today in the Riverside Baptist Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, of which the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick is the pastor.

Among the many suggestions and panaceas which are offered as solutions of the present economic situation the matte, of a surplus population seems to have received relatively little attention. When politicians are emphasizing the economic difficulties which will confront our 'children's children might it not be advisable to consider the matter from another angle than that which chiefly concerns the payment of taxes?

A wailing baby cradled on a dusty pile of wool in a sorting plant in Southern Peru was an unforgetable picture to Miss Frieda Miller, United States Government representative at the labor conference at Santiago, Chile, in January, under auspices of the International Labor Organization at Geneva.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Feb. 22. -- Women students at Swarthmore College assumed the aggressive in campus social life tonight at a "co-ed dance" and they were determined that the college social situation should remain reversed for the next seven days, designated as "leap year week."

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Feb. 22. -- The Imp, Rear Commodore Elisha W. Price's Class A ice yacht, triumph over Frank Johnson's Princeton by the narrow margin of 53 seconds in the feature ten-mile race of the Long Branch Ice Boat anal Yacht Club's holiday program on the South Shrewsbury River today.

I have read with great interest Allardyce Nicoll's excellent essay on poetry in the theatre (printed in last Sunday's TIMES) and should like to add a few lines. In view of the fact that a number of American poets have been working in terms of the theatre for many years past, I'm sorry Professor Nicoll confined his comment to Maxwell Anderson's "Winterset" and T.S. Eliot's "Murder in the Cathedral."

This volume may very well help to solve the problem of packing up enough books for a Summer vacation to satisfy eager young read ers. Between these covers are forty-nine stories. Most of the authors included have proved their popularity with children over a long period of years.

AIKEN, S.C. -- The annual series of Spring tournaments at the Palmetto Golf Club starts tomorrow. First comes the handicap match play for the Dolan Cup. The annual Southern Cross event is scheduled for the week of March 16.

FRANKFURT-AM-MAIN, Germany, Feb. 22. -- The Prince of the Carnival of the Rhineland town of Heddenheim is accused of having taken in vain Chancellor Adolf Hitler's appearance and eight organizers of the carnival have been jailed.

AN unusually cold and bitter Winter has kept Scouts all over the country busy at their self-appointed task of keeping feathered creatures supplied with food. Literally tons of grain have been placed at regular posts in districts frequented by wild life, and the birds come in immense numbers to take advantage of Scout hospitality.

ROME, Feb. 22. -- Usually reliable sources said today that Italy's African armies would drive ahead steadily in the hope of taking Mount Alaji before March 1 and consolidating every position held by Italy prior to her defeat by the Ethiopians in 1896.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 22. -- Frank Ianni's 5-year-old bay gelding Biff scored his first 1936 victory today when he romped home ahead of the field in the featured Rex Handicap at the Fair Grounds. The victor passed the judge's stand at the finish four lengths in front of Pharatime.

ALTHOUGH abroad the novelette of from fifteen to thirty thousand words has gained immense popularity, it has never succeeded in obtaining a foothold in this country. An American book publisher will discourage any author, no matter how distinguished, from presenting him with such a manuscript.

MOSCOW, Feb. 22. -- The Order of Lenin, one of the highest honors of the Soviet Government, was awarded to V.I. Mezhlauk today on the fifteenth anniversary of the founding of the State Planning Commission, of which he is chairman.

A new working hypothesis on the cause of cancer, based on experimental evidence, was presented last week at a symposium on the cause of cancer at the New York Academy of Medicine by Dr. James B. Murphy of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research.

Believing that the possibility of being granted open hearings by the Senate Judiciary Committee on the Robinson anti-monopoly bill is remote, food, drug and other interests who are opposing the measure in its present form, pushed preparations last week for a bitter fight when the legislation comes up on the floor of the Senate for action.

MR. LEHMER in "Fightery Dick" calls his collection "A Book of Free Ballads," by which he means that all his pieces are narrative pieces, and that when he does not wish to follow traditional ballad forms and meters he considers himself at liberty to exercise complete freedom in both these particulars.

ON the riverward side of Tenth Avenue in West Thirtieth Street -- past the smoky forge of Owen Lavelle, horseshoer, and a sleazy row of warehouse where packing-box commerce is done -- stands a dull, unlovely building from which (you'd never suspect it) emerge the first physical embodiments of what eventually become some of Broadway's most handsome productions.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- A record influx of visitors are being entertained here over the Washington's Birthday weekend. Some of the hotels reported capacity reservations as early as Tuesday.

In handing down yesterday the second and third major rulings adverse to public utility interests within a week, the Federal Court at Charlotte, N.C., was considered here to have followed the reasoning of Chief Justice Hughes's opinion in the Supreme Court decision on the powers of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

MONTREAL. -- The skiing event in the Laurentians today is the first annual Taschereau downhill race on the Taschereau Trail at Mont Tremblant. It is sponsored by the St. Jovite Ski Club and the event is open to men and women of Class 2 and 3, to veterans, and to juniors of 13 to 17 years.

ALTHOUGH she has lampooned metropolitan manners in her plays, Dawn Powell is best known as a novelist of small-town life. This label, obviously, is too limited. Unlike Phil Stong -- who is ill-advised whenever he deserts Iowa -- Miss Powell is as wickedly at home in the city as ever she was in the hinterland.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 21. -- Herbert Hoover's plan to send an uninstructed harmony delegation from California to the Cleveland convention has hit a snag in Frank F. Merriam's Presidential boom and the refusal thus far of the septuagenarian Governor to agree not to enter a Merriam ticket in the Presidential primary to be held in May.

Following several months of heavier traffic, the railroads have greatly increased their equipment purchases since the first of the year, with the result that orders for steam locomotives placed to date in 1936 are nearly double the total for all of 1935.

" It was not until the week of Feb. 10 that actual starvation conditions began to show in the pathological examinations of birds," states the Conservation Department. "During that week the game protectors were authorized to purchase feed and to distribute it where birds were known to be congregating and where the normal Winter food was covered with ice and snow."

IN most sections of the country during the week trade continued to suffer from weather conditions. When temperatures moderated there was a rush of buying reported, so that retailers are confident of largely increased sales as soon as there is a real turn in the weather.

The annual military ball of the Veterans of Foreign Wars will be held on Friday at the Manhattan Ballrooms, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street. Centering around the traditional massing of the colors at midnight, a military pageant has been arranged under the direction of Thomas P. Layer, Junior Vice Commander of the New York State Department, V.F.W.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 22. -- Martin L. Harvey, the young Negro president of the Christian Youth Council of North America, told the 500 delegates to the New York State Youth Conference in session here today that youth must decide the course of a "new world."

BALDWIN, L.I., Feb. 22. -- Two field goals made from unfavorable positions on the court by Johnny De Angelis with less than three minutes of play remaining enabled the Baldwin High School basketball team to come from behind and top John Marshall High of Richmond, Va., 20 to 19, tonight.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Feb. 22. -- Forty students at Bryn Mawr College are engaged in a study with Dr. I.A. Richards, a fellow of Magdalen College, Cambridge, which educators believe may help to effect significant changes in methods of teaching English in colleges.

LONDON'S most interesting event of the week -- at least to this side of the water -- takes place on Wednesday at the St. James, when "Pride and Prejudice" opens with Celia Johnson and Hugh Williams in the company. Another of Miss Jerome's plays, "Jane Eyre," will open a try-out in Birmingham tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- Jubilance on the one hand and a muted claim of victory on the other were elicited from government lawyers today following the decisions at Charlotte, N.C., on municipal power allotments and the Utility Holding Company Act.

MR. BENNET was so odd a mixture of quick parts, sarcastic humor, reserve and caprice that the experience of three and twenty years had been insufficient to make his wife understand his character," wrote Jane Austen in "Pride and Prejudice."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- In reaching a decision on the new taxes to be asked of Congress, the administration looks for expert guidance to the Treasury Department's Division of Research and Statistics. Charged with the duty of preparing estimates of tax receipts, this Treasury unit is also called upon to estimate the probable return from all new tax proposals.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- Renewed advocacy of large public power projects has resulted from the TVA decision of the Supreme Court on a scale so sweeping as to make TVA a "mere working model in comparison," the Chamber of Commerce of the United States declared today.

City College's varsity basketball team brought its home season to a successful close at its gymnasium last night, spurting in the second half to leave a hard-fighting Villanova College five far behind.

Walter Spence, veteran New York A.C. star and former Rutgers luminary, created a new world's record in both the 100-meter and 100-yard events in a feature swim of the aquatic program staged by the New York Athletic Club last night.

DURING the recent Senate hearings one of the speakers, the editor of a Washington newspaper, surprised his audience by lashing out strongly against investigations of munition making and international banking as being inefficient in getting at the root of the matter and harmful in that they led public thought and effort on a false trail.

THE three Es -- education, engineering and enforcement -- constitute the secret of Milwaukee's plan of traffic safety, worked out over a score of years and developed to the point where it is being used as a model for the rest of the nation, according to Dr. Basil L. Corbett, secretary of the Milwaukee Safety Commission.
SKIPPING the rest of the season and also the Summer, which can be done easily on a Sunday morning in February, you may consider this event of next Fall:

J. E. Seegar of the Newburgh Gun Club, a Class A gunner, was the winner of the George L. Lyon Memorial Trophy over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. He took the shoot by breaking 193 out of a possible 200 targets.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- With conference committee negotiations apparently the only obstacle confronting enactment of the furthest-reaching farm relief program ever sponsored by a major political party, the new farm income goal added to the AAA substitute in the House stands out as a much-disputed provision.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Feb. 22. -- After barricading himself and his 2-year-old daughter Pauline in his house at Gales Ferry last night, John E. Goodluck, 32-year-old submarine base sailor, who had previously threatened to kill his wife and others with an automatic shotgun, was finally forced by tear gas to surrender after a five-hour siege.

Your editorial "Our Record Winter" omitted to mention that this Winter, "conceded to be unprecedented as far as Weather Bureau records go," was predicted in the columns of THE TIMES more than four months ago under the caption "Goosebone Seers See Hard Winter."

About seventy-five employes of firms holding membership in the New York Stock Exchange have passed the new examination and qualified as customers' men since the Exchange instituted this requirement on Feb. 1. Examinations are held every Monday morning at the Exchange by Dr. Birl E. Schultz, director of the Stock Exchange Institute, and by officers of member firms throughout the country whenever necessary.

VIENNA, Feb. 7, 1936. AN unusual and singularly interesting bicentenary was celebrated on Feb. 2 at Klosterneuberg, a grubby little western suburb of Vienna, whose principal attraction is its superb monastery and cathedral, where Bruckner played the organ.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- Incredible as it may seem in view of the recent Supreme Court decision invalidating the AAA, the next fortnight will witness the beginning of the most ambitious plan of agricultural adjustment ever attempted on the American Continent.

The Governors Island trio turned in a brilliant performance last night, defeating the league-leading New York A.C. team, 14 to 5 1/2, in a Metropolitan League polo game at the Squadron A Armory. The outcome was never in doubt following a five-goal attack by the soldiers in the second period.

SEA ISLAND, Ga. -- The first of a series of exhibition tennis matches at the Cloister Tennis Club, in which Martin J. Simmons, Sea Island professional, and Jess Baker, professional at the Jekyl Island Club, will meet is scheduled for next Friday.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 21. -- The most plausible explanation of the murder of Walter Liggett last December 9 is that the liquor and gambling underworld of Minneapolis wished to silence the crusade for reform which he had been waging in his Mid-West American Weekly.

LANCASTER, Pa., Feb. 22. -- "Hell Week" of Franklin and Marshall College came to a close today, as the fraternities completed their "informal" initiation of freshmen. Formal initiations will take place during the next two weeks.

MADRID, Feb. 22. -- Bolshevism has been trying a new weapon in Spain. That weapon is "the united front" and its success has surprised even its inventors. The united front has put Spain at the mercy of 3,000,000 Socialists, anarchists, syndicalists and Communists, some of whose leaders and organizations are reported to be paid and subsidized from Moscow.

REMINISCENT of the late Rider Haggard's steep romances, but entirely distinctive in the weird, grisly tale it tells, this story is one of the ablest adventure novels to appear in recent months. Its fantastic plot seems to be unduly elaborated and long drawn out by masses of geographical descriptive matter, which, oddly enough, never has the effect of slowing down the action and wearying the reader.

IN a recent correspondence I endeavored to present the sisterly helper type of woman as personified in the sister of Nietzsche. Today I want to speak of Frau Ricarda Huch, who may well be called the greatest creative spirit among the women of Germany.

DR. CANBY'S book reminds one of Byron's "mildest manner'd man that ever scuttled ship or cut a throat." He looks back at his own college years in the Nineties -- "the Gothic Age" -- at Yale with a good deal of pleasure.

Secret Service men of England, Germany and France are the chief actors in this sensational drama of international intrigue. The scene of most of the episodes is Geneva, to which city Colonel Granby of the British Secret Service has come incognito, or so he believes. In reality his identity is known from the first to the secret agent of the German Reich, whose official designation is L. 52.

A break-down of the balance sheet of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey by The Lamp, the official publication of the company, shows that at the close of 1934 there was invested an average of $15,016 for each employe of the company. The publication also discloses that the 129,307 employes of the company in 1934 received an aggregate compensation of $166,000,000, or an average of $1,283 each.

IN 1853 Count Arthur de Gobineau published a two-volume "Essai sur l'Inegalite des Races Humaines," and dedicated it to George V of Hanover. He was not an authority on anything, but something of a poet and philosopher.

NASSAU, Bahamas. -- The annual water carnival and championship races sponsored by the Nassau Aquatic Club will be held on Tuesday in the British Colonial swimming pool. The final event in the series of water polo matches for the Halcyon Shield will be one of the features.

FREDERICKSBURG, Va., Feb. 22. -- George Washington was credited today with sponsorship of the principle of Federalism that later found expression in Woodrow Wilson's conception of the League of Nations.

BY now the youthful, prematurely gray Russian director, Anatole Litvak, has probably found himself an easy chair in Hollywood and is perhaps engaged in absorbing some of the intrigue of "Sahara," the Moroccan spy film featuring Charles Boyer and Madeleine Carroll, which he will direct for Walter Wanger.

AS Congress has inquired into the safety of commercial airlines, following the accidents last year, two events have occurred which show that the final factor in safe flying is the skill, courage and judgment of the pilot. Despite the reliability of engines, the strength of planes, the efficient ground organization and the weather service -- all factors in transport flying -- the human element is still the most important in a crisis.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22. -- No serious complaints from manufacturers, merchants or other large receivers have been made of the railroads functioning during the unusual weather conditions. Incoming and outgoing freight, especially all kinds of fuel for manufacturing and domestic purposes, seem to have met the demand, and this helped to keep industry, merchandising, hotels and household affairs upon an even keel.

New York University's basketball team recovered from its slump in impressive fashion last night and overwhelmed Fordham, 46 -- 27, at the University Heights gymnasium in the Bronx before a capacity crowd. The Violets took the lead at the start and were never headed.
