The United States Supreme Court's decision on Monday upholding the right of the government to acquire transmission lines in order to find an adequate market for power generated at Wilson Dam, Muscle Shoals, viewed as a surplus product derived from a constitutional government undertaking, has left the problem of public power vs. private power exactly where it stood before the decision, in the opinion of utility leaders.

TORONTO, Feb. 22 (AP). -- In one of the wildest and most exciting games of the National Hockey League season here, the Toronto Maple Leafs defeated the Montreal Maroons, 1 -- 0, tonight and went into a tie with their rivals for the international group lead.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 22 (AP). -Police held Serdo Ech, Croat laborer, for questioning today in connection with the disappearance of a woman long sought as a conspirator in the assassination of King Alexander of Yugoslavia.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 22. -- President Stanley King of Amherst College received the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws from Williams today at a convocation of alumni here for the sixth annual midwinter reunion. At the same time Williams honored one of its alumni, Principal Lewis Perry of Philips Exeter Academy, by presenting to him the James Rogerson Cup for "service and loyalty" to the institution.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22. -- Pennsylvania easily defeated Cornell at the Palestra tonight, 38 to 21, to break a fifth-place tie with the Ithacans in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League. Roger Hanger and Bob Dougherty starred in the Red and Blue victory, the former getting 13 points and the later 12.

Although Americans have much to learn from the French in the art of cooking, there are certain features of hotel administration that this country can teach the world, A. E. Godon, director of the Hotel Crillon in Paris and president of the French Association of Hotel and Restaurant Directors, declared yesterday.

When Samuel Drukman was an inconspicuous garage clerk in Brooklyn, playing the races and stealing from his employer, he could not have dreamed that his untimely taking off would result in such a cause celebre as now threatens to tear apart the enforcement of law in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON social life has sprung into action this Winter far more elaborately than at any time during the last three years. There is an anti-depression grandeur in the hiring of whole orchestras and entire night-club floor shows from New York; in the decorating of vast golden-oak interiors with silvered smilax and fir trees; in inexhaustible cases of dry champagne.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- The TVA decision, although limited in scope, has given advocates of the New Deal renewed confidence, despite prior adverse judicial decisions, that the program of the present administration may still be realized within the framework of the Constitution as that document is being currently interpreted by the Supreme Court of the United States.

Albert Rosen, 42-year-old ex-convict, was shot and killed early yesterday when he refused to put up his hands when ordered to do so by Patrolman Edward Moody, who discovered him robbing the Sylvianna Dress Shop at 2,343 Broadway.

A statistical study, just completed by the National Industrial Conference Board, of the effect of machinery on employment and purchasing power deals another blow to the ghost of technocracy and confirms the conclusions which the bulk of economists have long maintained.

ALBANY, Feb. 22. -- Most mandatory legislation affecting budget expenditures of cities, counties, towns and villages throughout the State, whether enacted at the Capitol during the years preceding adoption of the Home Rule amendment to the Constitution, or since, would be wiped from the statute books with consequent large savings possible to the municipalities under a bill introduced this week by Senator Joseph Clark Baldwin 3d of New York City.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- The reputed income of $90,000 a year drawn by Walter J. Cummings, treasurer of the Democratic National Committee, from positions reported to have been obtained through the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, is being investigated by Senator Couzens, he announced today. He has asked the RFC and Interstate Commerce Commission for data on the salaries.

RHART PHILLIPS, author of "Cuban Sideshow," is the wife of the Havana correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, J.D. Phillips, and in her book, based on a diary she kept of the revolutions that began with the downfall of President Gerardo Machado and furiously raged until the ancient Spanish city became a veritable madhouse, she proves herself a very capable newspaper woman.

THE problem of what may go on the screen without precipitating a minor crisis continues to befuddle the industry. While the controversy surrounding "It Can't Happen Here" is the most engaging of the week, there are others of lesser international but greater domestic importance.

ACCORDING to Louis La Beaume, vice president of the American Institute of Architects, whose views are quoted in the Feb. 15 issue of The Art Digest, the modernists have begun a retreat, the traditionalists a forward movement.

FIVE operas will be presented at the Mozart Festival to be held from May 29 to July 5 in the Glyndebourne Festival Opera House, Lewes, Sussex, England. Four cycles have been arranged for subscription performances, comprising five Thursdays, four Wednesdays, three Tuesdays and five Sundays.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- Winter vacationists here have a busy sports program this coming week, with two big league baseball teams in training, the annual Festival of States sports tourney under way, and preparations being made for the annual yacht race to Havana.

HERE is a new version of "Art in America." The text that constitutes Part I (revised and rewritten) was first published in 1934. It covers the early period, from 1600 to 1865. Part II, issued as a separate book by Reynal Hitchcock in 1935, carries the story on from Civil War times to the present.

HAVANA -- The gayest period of the Winter season begins today with the opening of the traditional carnival. After three successive days of celebration parades will be staged each Sunday afternoon for four weeks. Decorated floats and private cars filled with costumed merrymakers will circle the Prado and Malecon Drive.

MR. STREET says that where be comes from is so far south that the boys think Virginians are damnyankees. His home town is near rugged little Sullivan Hollow. Miss. The Sullivan Hollow folks caught a revenue officer once, Mr. Street says, and he was a good, strong fellow, so they hitched him to a plow.

The similarity of pronunciation of the words "pneumonia" and "ammonia'' sent four police radio cars and two ambulances racing to a six-story apartment house at 54 West Seventy-fourth Street yesterday afternoon in expectation of finding "four persons dead from ammonia" at that address.

THE growth and development of modern tendencies in politics and economics, as well as in social, religious and intellectual standards, can be traced in the two centuries with which Professor Cheyney has dealt. His work provides a detailed panorama of a period usually slighted in general histories and deplorably neglected in most school and college textbooks.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22. -- M. Harvey Taylor, chairman of the Republican State Committee, withdrew today as a candidate for the Republican nomination for Auditor General. It was learned at the same time that Auditor General Frank E. Baldwin would not press his candidacy for State Treasurer.

Henry L. Doherty of the Cities Service Company holds the distinction of being a director of more corporations than any other individual in the United States, while John D. Rockefeller Jr. and J.P. Morgan serve on few boards, most of which are of a philanthropic nature, according to the 1936 edition of Poor's Register of Directors.

SUNSETS, storms, flowers and haunted lanes and gardens -- these are the magic of the Island. And they play upon the lives of the gifted, impoverished du Frocq family until rare visions shine before their eyes. "Island Magic" is a glowing book.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22. -- Following is the text of President Rosevelt's address at Temple University today:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 22. -- Resolutions pledging Christian Endeavor units in Westchester County to oppose all legislation that might lead the United States into war were adopted this afternoon at the forty-third annual convention of the county's Christian Endeavor Union.

THIS is a thoroughly successful biography for young people and one that adults also will find a moving and absorbing book. Miss Hawthorne shows us Emerson in his boyhood home, where the four brothers, "born to be educated," had a Spartan but not unhappy childhood.

ZION CITY, Ill., Feb. 21. -- Wilbur Glenn Voliva celebrated last Friday the thirtieth anniversary of his accession to the leadership of the ascetic sect founded by John Alexander Dowie as the Christian Catholic (Apostolic) Church -- and he celebrated it by redoubling his drive to recapture economic and political control of this city of worshipers which he lost as a result of the depression.
CHARLOTTE, N. C., Feb. 22. -- Opinions in two cases affecting the conflict between New Deal policies and public utilities were handed down today by the Fourth United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

Its title suggesting a remedy for midwinter woes, a "Spring Fever Dinner Dance" will be held on Friday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin for the benefit of the Children's Orthopedic and Surgical Ward of the New York Post-Graduate Hospital.

THE Brooklyn Museum is pursuing its admirable policy of presenting special unfamiliar aspects of art to its public and making them familiar through an individual technique of installation and copious notes of information accompanying them.

NEXT Thursday night an experiment in education reaches a new stage of its progress. Under a plan approved by John S. Roberts, Associate Superintendent in charge of high schools, two senior students from each of the city's forty-three high schools will attend the weekly "Town Meeting of the Air" at Town Hall.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP). -- Word from the White House to "keep Thursday night open" quickened expectation of Congressional leaders today that President Roosevelt will soon make known his tax recommendations.

A PLEASANT, fairy-tale type of story, with all difficulties resolved by a proper assorting of Jacks and Jills, Alice Ross Colver's "Strangers at Sea" furnishes agreeable entertainment for a few idle hours. The scene is a steamer on a West Indies cruise, the characters those passengers who sat at the chief engineer's table.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 22. -- Dr. and Mrs. Leland Eggleston Cofer gave a luncheon in honor of the Hon. Andrew Farrant of London, their house guest, today at Capricho.

PINEHURST N.C. -- The series of golf tournaments began the past week with the thirty-second Tin Whistle anniversary tournament and will continue almost without a break until the second week of April on the remodeled No. 2 course at the Pinehurst Country Club.

American and English period furniture and decorations, early American silver and Sheffield plate, paintings and porcelains will be sold at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Friday and Saturday afternoons.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 22. -Kazuo Takahashi, new manager here for the Nippon Yusen Kaisha Company, arrived Thursday from New York. He succeeds S. Nakase, transferred to Kobe.

BERLIN, Feb. 21. -- Having already celebrated famous victories in the "battle of labor" and the agrarian "production battle," Germans are just now celebrating victory in the "export battle" occasioned by the publication of details of last year's foreign trade.

Warnings that British policy would drive Italy into alliance with Germany were uttered frequently while the Ethiopian and Mediterranean crisis was developing last year. Premier Pierre Laval was particularly disturbed over the possibility, since it would again face France with danger on two frontiers. The British, however, seemed not to take the prospect seriously; they did not believe Hitler and Mussolini could find a common ground on which to construct an entente.

PARIS, Feb. 21. -- Into the discussion of the advantages and disadvantages of the Franco-Soviet pact of mutual assistance there has entered so much political passion that many people are wondering whether even if finally ratified the pact will not become a dead letter from the outset.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP). -- Senate investigations have cost $796,369 since the New Deal was inaugurated. Months of work by skilled interrogators who make interviews and pore over papers precede the unrolling of testimony in open hearings.

A VIVID reminder of the debt that both collector and decorator owe to the East is afforded in the newly opened galleries of Chinese and Indian decorative art at the Brooklyn Museum. Since the seventeenth century Oriental art has played an important part in interior decoration: the period marks also the beginning of collecting porcelain, bronzes and lacquer work.

WOMEN who have been leading lives devoid of exercise during the Winter are turning now to supervised exercise courses -- for even the more indolent will want to be in shape for a round of golf or some tennis when Spring comes around again.

The banning of "The Children's Hour" in Boston was caused by the Mayor and a few others who could undoubtedly find something objectionable in "Alice in Wonderland," and not by public sentiment. Theatre patrons will probably be deprived of seeing this play, although there is a $4,000 advance sale of tickets.

THE strongest, most arresting impression one gets from this book is that of the personality behind it. Not often does one encounter such gusto, such robust response to life's multifarious appeals such unquenchable joy in seeing, doing, thinking as are manifest all through Dr. Schleich's memoirs.

The City Club has proposed a four-point program for reorganization and elimination of county offices under the Home Rule Amendment. It proposes abolition of the offices of Sheriffs, Registers, Commissioners of Records and Public Administrators, and the transfer of their functions and records to other existing city and county offices.

IN this book of thirty stories the entertainment is both rich and varied. "Cosmopolitans" exhibits all the expertness which readers of W. Somerset Maugham have come to expect. The characterization, necessarily sketchy, is done with sharpness and economy.

A.W.O.L.: To the mind of Senator Frederick C. Broomhead, the Rhode Island Legislature has been entirely too generous this session in granting special cash awards to war veterans. Last week, to stop the practice, he introduced a bill to pay $100 to Evael O.W. Tnesba, identified as a member of the Twelfth Machine Gun Company.

OUR nerves, we fear, are jaded by the impact of so many celebrities. We have lost perspective. Can it be we have got like the plaintive Turk who sang, "Life has lost its zest for us, on the banks of the Bosporus?" Allah forbid! But celebrities don't mean anything to us any more.

FROM this book one learns how they do it in England when they heed the back-to-the- country call. There have been many books telling in detail the experiences, achievements and reactions of Americans who put the city and city life behind them and set forth to build a new home and a new life in the country.

SEEFELD, Tyrol, Feb. 22. -- Today's slalom races, completing the combined downhill-slalom tests of the International Ski Federal championships, were held under entirely different conditions from the bruising and bone-breaking scenes of the downhill competition at Innsbruck yesterday.

If State legislation such as that recommended by Governor Lehman to prevent encroachments on Nassau and Suffolk County well water should become effective retroactively, New York City would face the immediate danger of a water shortage, according to Maurice P. Davidson, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.

A group of young women are aiding in the sale of boxes and seats for the recital by Myra Hess, pianist, on the afternoon of March 1 at the Town Hall for the benefit of Hartley House Music School. They are the Misses Jane Witherspoon, Elizabeth Culver, Katharine Schuyler Cammann, Clarinda Boardman, Dorothea Culver, Josephine Terry, Cornelia de Villiers Schwab and Eleanora Swenson, under the chairmanship of Miss Rosalie Williams.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- Speaker Byrns today appointed a special committee of eight members, four Democrats and four Republicans, to investigate the methods and financing of the Townsend old-age pension plan and all other pension plans for the aged.

TODAY aluminum celebrates its fiftieth birthday. Not that chemists had not heard of it before 1886, but that young Charles Martin Hall of Oberlin, Ohio (he was 22), and equally young Paul Heroult of Paris in that same year, thousands of miles apart, independently hit on the modern way of producing aluminum commercially.

BERLIN, Feb. 22. -- Trading on the Boerse was quiet but resistant today. Small gains appeared all along the line, although transactions generally were small, often almost insignificant. Mannesmann was the sole exception, with a turnover estimated at 300,000 marks and the price up 5-18 point.

Milton Baron of the City A.C., the defending titleholder, and L.H. Sonneborn of the Yale Club were the winners in the two matches played yesterday in the national veterans' squash tennis championship on the courts of the Columbia University Club.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 22. -- Rutgers gained its third consecutive victory in the Intercollegiate Swimming Association before a large Alumni Day crowd today by defeating Penn, 40 -- 31. The Scarlet natators took first place in every individual event except the 50-yard free style, in which Gisburne and Wark of the visitors nosed out Stanley Rose in a blanket finish.
SAN ANTONIO, Texas Feb. 22 (AP). -- The meeting at Alam Downs ended today with Money Getter winning the George Washington Handicap over the mile and a sixteenth route for a $1,200 purse.

Congress, showing no apparent concern about the national deficit, has now voted one bonus to the veterans and another to the farmers. It is significant that these are the only two important measures which have made headway at the present session. The veterans claim to have x million votes.

The vexing question of officer promotion in the navy which has disturbed the service ever since there was a navy has again come to a head, and Congress and the service itself are trying to find a solution.

IN his first novel Richard Sale attempts to make us listen to a spiritual message by linking it with the most blood-and-thunder circumstance. It is a curious but not unusual union. Most popular evangelists understand the combination.

JIM DILANEY, known to his friends as "Slim," was "just a run-of-the-brush cowhand" in the old days of the open range in Texas, and when the chance offered to get into San Antonio, after trailing longhorns for months in the brush country, he was hungry for entertainment.

The Benjamin Franklin High School, organized less than two years ago to meet the particular problems of adolescents in an East Harlem immigrant neighborhood marked by delinquency, is widening its activities to include parents instruction in a program coordinating all social and educational agencies in the community.

WATER-COLORS that are simon pure; water-colors not necessarily less desirable because of their admixture of gouache; gouaches that, if you want to be a stickler for precision, are no doubt simon pure, and a sparse sprinkling of pastels -- these constitute the current show at the Whitney Museum; Part 2 of the second biennial, which may be visited until March 18.

THE strategy and political manoeuvrings at peace conferences and other awesome gatherings are as nothing compared with the saga of diplomacy reported by Geoffrey Barkas. Mr. Barkas, in case you haven't heard, is the gentleman who took a large technical staff into the heart of darkest Rhodesia, South Africa, to photograph natural exteriors for the new Gaumont-British film production, "Rhodes, the Empire Builder," starring Walter Huston.

SELDOM has Eugene Higgins invested his paintings with deeper emotional qualities or clarified these dark symphonies with surer rhythms than in the present exhibition of recent small canvases and monotypes at Kleemann's (till March 1).

Purchase by Sears, Roebuck Co. of a seat upon the Commodity Exchange here was seen yesterday by authorities as a merchandising precedent of great future importance. Officials of other large retail organizations were reported as watching the action with keen interest, but as far as could be learned at the week-end no other major distributors have as yet taken a similar step.

SINCE he became famous by the original manner in which he "covered the waterfront," Max Miller has had a kind of roving assignment from his public. He may go anywhere he likens and cover what he likes and be sure of a number of faithful readers.

TORONTO, Feb. 21. -- Ontario's gold mines produced bullion to the value of $6,210,577 in January, compared with $6,894,686 in December and $5,551,388 in January, 1935. The average recovery was $10.29 a ton last month, against $11.61 a ton in December.

Mischa Elman appeared as soloist with the National Orchestral Association in the third of the programs of violin concertos which he is giving with that organization on five Saturday afternoons in Carnegie Hall. The concertos yesterday were Bruch's in G minor, Dvorak's in A minor and Lalo's "Symphonie Espagnole."

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 22. -- Under the system started at Dartmouth College in 1928 to stimulate the initiative and encourage the self-reliance of exceptional students by freeing them from routine, ninety-five men, including six New Yorkers, are now doing special honors work in ten major fields of study.

THIS is that same John Gibbons who won the hearts of Americans who had the good luck and good judgment to read his books about his travels on foot through various countries, especially his last one, that told of his journey round about the United States on foot, by bus, by hitch-hike and occasionally by train, a wholly delightful book of keen observation, humorous good nature and naive truth-telling.

PARIS, Feb. 22. -- Miss Sonja Henie of Norway won her tenth and, according to her announcement, her last world's figure skating championship today with an almost faultless performance in the free skating part of the competition.

Members of the New York chapter, Knights of Columbus, were urged, in the name of their deceased fellow Knights, to lead Catholic action against atheism and communism at their annual solemn pontifical memorial mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning.

ONLY a years ago few the growing of dahlias from seed was deemed too bothersome, and for amateurs perhaps impractical. Nevertheless, perhaps because it was a gamble, they began to try it. Now it is known that growing dahlias from seed is one of the more fascinating pursuits that the gardener, amateur or professional, is privileged to undertake.

-TORONTO, Feb. 22 (Canadian Press). -- The first step in encouragement of the reading habit is "to get information about what is available right down to everybody," Lord Tweedsmuir said today in an address to the Association of Canadian Bookmen.

BERLIN, Feb. 22. -- After a trial which kept the German public agitated for weeks the court at Schwerin passed sentence today on Adolf Seefeld, 65 years old, charged with innumerable sex crimes and with the murder of more than thirty boys.

PARIS. -- Formation of the recent Sarraut Cabinet, which was the 100th of the Third Republic, was the occasion for reviews of French Parliamentary history which emphasized the short-lived character of French governments.

TROY, N.Y., Feb. 22 (AP). -- Dr. Earl E. Cummins, Professor of Economics at Union College, warned labor leaders today of what he termed the "dangers" of "Government control of labor organizations without the existence of a strong labor party to protect labor interests in the government sphere."

A NEW edition, in one volume, has appeared of "The Letters of John Keats" (Oxford University Press, $5), which contains a clear record of his friendships and gives pathetic sidelights on his feverish race with death to attain fame -- a race he won by the narrowest margin.

Retail trade in the metropolitan area once more labored under the handicap of adverse weather conditions and sales volume of leading department stores here was estimated to show a decline of about 5 per cent as compared with the same period last year.

While the plan of the Fashion Originators Guild to extend its style protection efforts to dresses below the $10.75 price range has been under heavy attack from retailers, the program has tended to be successful as far as dresses wholesaling at $16.75 and above are concerned, according to a consensus of both retailers and manufacturers here last week.

Bruna Castagna, Italian mezzo-soprano, who was recently engaged as a member of the personnel of the Metropolitan Opera Association, will make her first appearance at the Metropolitan on Monday evening, March 2, as Amneris in Verdi's "Aida," it was learned yesterday from authorities at the Broadway house.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Feb. 22 (AP) -- Economic damage amounting to $28,039,577 was caused by last July's floods in Central and Southern New York, an area of rich farm lands, quiet residential communities and highly industrialized centers, Michael H. Cahill of Corning, president of the Central and Southern New York Flood Control Council, reported today.

SOFIA, Feb. 22. -- After a trial lasting two months, a military court passed sentence this morning on Colonel Damian Veltcheff, leader of the unsuccessful putsch of October, 1935, and his co-defendants.

FOR quite obvious reasons, Columbia's last two releases have been generously interlarded with Beecham re-pressings from London. With this nobody can quibble, for when Sir Thomas gets down to recording he does it in earnest, and one may be sure that at least one and generally two things will happen.

LONDON, Feb. 22. -- As a protest against the suppression of academic freedom in Nazi Germany, Oxford University will not send representatives to the 550th anniversary celebrations of Heidelberg University next Summer.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Feb. 22. -- A policeman did traffic duty today in the middle of the Niagara River above the dry American Falls because hundreds of sightseers insisted on walking from the American shore to Goat Island.

Wads suspiciously like "chawin' tobacky" bulged the jaws of a quartet of 11-year-olds yesterday in a Washington's Birthday celebration that included rubber horseshoe pitching, real wood-chopping, imitations by a National Guardsman and strawberry shortcake.

HOLLYWOOD. ON the eve of transferring to other hands the property he developed from a 200-seat nickelodeon to a world-wide film manufacturing and distributing concern valued at several million dollars, Carl Laemmle tomorrow will celebate the thirtieth anniversary of his entrance into the newest and liveliest of the arts.

LONDON, Feb. 22. -- Has Marshal Pietro Badoglio inflicted a decisive defeat on the Ethiopian forces? is a question being widely discussed here. The delay in the answer from Addis Ababa had tended to strengthen the impression made by the Italian reports.

VIENNA. -- The nature of "German economic help" is attracting unfavorable comment in parts of the Hungarian press. Every one wonders how bankrupt Germany still manages to import foodstuffs from abroad. This is how she does it in Hungary:

Applications for the principalships of Junior High Schools 139, Manhattan, and 125, Queens, should be filed not later than tomorrow in the office of the associate superintendent in charge of personnel, on forms obtained in that office at 500 Park Avenue.

PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 21. -- From the Atlantic Seaboard, almost 3,000 miles away, Senator Borah continues to provide the Far Northwest's paramount political topic. One question was uppermost this week: What effect will his rejection of the Townsend old-age pension plan have on his chances for re-election to the Senate in Idaho?

THE gerbera has long been looked upon as a sort of exotic sophiscate among flowers -- something beyond the reach of the home gardener. With its long stems and huge daisy-like blooms in a wide range of colors -- including orangy salmon and deep pinks and reds -- lasting exceptionally well in bouquets or arrangements, it has rapidly increased in popularity since its introduction as a florists' flower.

WHILE heavy shipments by air always strike one as a bit incongruous, the fact remains that many shipments of machinery and relatively heavy, bulky cargos appear on the air-borne manifests these days. A case in point was cited last week by L.O. Head, president of the Railway Express Agency, which now handles the shipment of goods on nearly all of the nation's airlines.
RYE, N.Y., Feb. 22. -- There was a large gathering of members and their guests today at a buffet luncheon and entertainment held at the Apawamis Club here in celebration of Washington's Birthday.
AUGUSTA, Ga. -- Two dances, three golf tournaments and a series of polo games will be the features of Augusta's social and sport program this week.

THE departure of Toscanini from the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra after this season probably puts an end to a brilliant period of guest-conducting which has distinguished the past of this organization. It is possible, indeed, that the period of virtuoso conductors considered as indispensable features of orchestral seasons is drawing to its end in America.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- As the hunting season with the private pack of James and Jackson Boyd approaches its height many prominent Easterners have arrived to take part in the weekly fox and drag hunts, which promise even the best of riders plenty of thrills.

IT was early of a cold, rainy morning in Manchester, England The time: November, 1933. Walter Greenwood, the old clock puncher, who had set the hour of appointment, was to meet me in the lobby of the Manchester Repertory Theatre.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 22. -- Five hundred Rutgers University alumni returned to the campus today for the annual midwinter alumni day activities.
BERLIN, Feb. 22. -- Establishment of official matrimonial bureaus for Nazi Germany was proposed today in the official journal of the Public Health Department.

American funds are being used to the extent of $200,000,000 annually to finance a foreign flag merchant marine while construction of American tonnage has lagged far behind that of competitors for world markets, according to Nelson Macy, president of the Navy League of the United States.

GRAND opera in America is going streamlined. Opera singers, for the first time in memory, tend generally toward slimness, and thus fit realistically the youthful roles they portray. So lissome they often are nowadays at the Metropolitan Opera House they endow the romantic elements of the stage tale with credibility and glamour.

ROME, Feb. 22. -- Italians were disappointed, on reading today's war bulletin, to find no reference to Mount Alaji. Every one had confidently expected that Marshal Pietro Badoglio would announce that his troops had occupied or at least reached that vital point in the Ethiopian defenses.

An encouraging subscription has been reported for the performance of Katharine Cornell's revival of "Saint Joan" the night of March 5 at the Martin Beck Theatre, which has been taken over by members of the New York Branch of the Southern Women's Educational Alliance.

Plans for a full evening of entertainment are now being made by several committees arranging the gala jubilee to be held by the Junior League on April 17 in its clubhouse at 221 East Seventy-first Street. The clubhouse will be opened to the public for the fete, which is to benefit the Junior League Welfare Fund in its support of the Housekeeper Service, the Clothing Center and the Occupational Therapy Department at City Hospital.

THE readability laboratory recently established at Teachers College, Columbia University, is concerned with the problem of readable books on serious subjects for the average American citizen. Books of useful information on personal or public problems, or on popular science, are constantly being offered to the public by publishers and authors.

An increase in the tempo of industrial activity will occur in the "rather immediate future," members of the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents predicted yesterday in their February report on business conditions in the United States and Canada.

PUPILS in the biology course at the Stevens High School, Lancaster, Pa., no longer receive instruction from books and preserved specimens alone. They learn from motion-picture camera studies, from living specimens and from models.

Excerpts from the report of Dr. Henry S. Pritchett, president emeritus of the Carnegie Foundation, appearing in THE TIMES of Feb. 17, with respect to the so-called National Security Law, merit the serious consideration of those in political control of the various State governments.
The Long Island University quintet defeated the George Washington University five of Washington, D.C., 43 -- 31, before 2,000 at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium last night.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Feb. 22. -- Dr. C.W. Scranton of East Orange and Frank G. Traeger of Montclair successfully defended their 410-gauge title during the first day's competition in the second annual Eastern two-man team skeet championships at the Loantaka Skeet Club today.

SHUTTLING back and forth across the International Boundary, a new air mail service, carrying the Royal Mails of Canada and United States mails, was inaugurated a few weeks ago by Canadian Airways. The new route links Vancouver and Seattle on the Pacific Coast.

THE TIMES'S narratives of death and destruction arising from severe inter conditions indicate that the incidence of inconvenience and suffering falls with greater severity on people well south of the northern boundary of the country.

MR. EWEN has taken the whole personality of the modern art of orchestral conducting as his field. The modern art does not go back very far, but disabilities of age -- Mr. Ewen being hardly 29 years old -- compel him to rely on the reports of older witnesses for his judgments of all but the latest, strictly contemporary, conductors.
AS far as most of us are concerned, the measured progress of the gnarled old gentleman with the scythe on his shoulder is perhaps a bit on the speedy side.
A CONCRETE result of the recent American Artists Congress, held here in New York, has been the formation of the League of American Artists, proposed and accepted at the closing session.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22. -- Judge Joseph Buffington, senior member of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals in this district, celebrated the closing of his forty-fourth year on the Federal bench yesterday by bringing out a book dealing with the spiritual side of George Washington.

Two men of the Medici family, it is said, once flew upon an enemy in such a blind fury of assassinating rage that in the act they stabbed themselves. Something like that seems to be happening to violent assailants of President ROOSEVELT. It is on their bodies, not his, that one looks for the resulting wounds.

SAULT STE. MARIE, Ont., Feb. 22 (Canadian Press). -- A story stretching back forty years attaches to the names of the Michigan towns of Rudyard, twenty-four miles southwest of here, and Kipling, a few miles away in the Upper Peninsula.

One commendable feature of this old-fashioned Winter that we are living through is its truly national character. It is apparently as long and as wide as the United States. Two years ago, when sub-zero temperatures had their own way with New York and the adjoining territory, the Weather Bureau said that it was only a local phenomenon.

ASHTON, Idaho, Feb. 22 (AP). -- Lloyd Van Sickle, driving for the Porcupine CCC Camp, sprang an upset by taking the twentieth running of the American Dog Derby here today. His time for the twenty-five-mile course was 2 hours 14 minutes 4 seconds.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla. -- The second annual South Florida Tennis Championship Tournament begins today and, continuing through March 1, will find a climax for this season in the Blue Ribbon invitation tournament scheduled at the Surf Club.

Late this afternoon Pat Mulvey, track builder, and a staff of 300 carpenters will complete construction of a saucer-shaped pine track in Madison Square Garden. Tonight at 9 o'clock fifteen teams will start a whirr-on-wheels after Floyd Gibbons, globe-girdling reporter, fires the pistol shot which will transform the Garden into the nation's cycling mecca.

DECATUR, Ala., Feb. 22 (AP). -- Two of the Scottsboro case defendants have been indicted for assault with intent to murder, it was reported today, but all Judge W.W. Callahan of the Morgan Circuit Court would say was that "it's against the law" to give out information concerning a grand jury action.

AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 22 (AP). -- A court of six judges drew up rules late tonight for conduct of the strike at the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company in connection with an injunction restraining strikers from interfering with operations at the plant.

Nothing definite concerning the plans for the Cunard White Star liner Majestic can be ascertained beyond the statement from the head offices of the joint companies in Liverpool that she will be a stand-by ship at Southampton for a time -- at least until the Queen Mary has entered the New York service next June.
PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Events appealing largely to the esthetic sense comprise this week's program, which, although more varied than it has been in several weeks, contains no major sports tournaments.

ROME, Feb. 21. -- It was with relief even more than with exultation that the Italian people learned of the great Enderta victory that Marshal Pietro Badoglio won last week. They were relieved that the seemingly unending period of waiting was over at last and the northern army was on the march again.
HONOLULU, Feb. 22 (AP). -- Molokai Island's leper colony is ready for its murder hearing -- as rare on that isolated island as they are common in continental United States.

A ONE-WEEK short course in flower gardening, beginning tomorrow, is announced by the New Jersey State College of Agriculture, to be given at the college farm, New Brunswick. The course is intended for persons interested in flower gardening, including those who specialize in individual flowers, such as dahlias, asters and gladioluses.

FROM time immemorial the bridges across the Seine have been important in the history of Paris. Thirty of them, within the city limits, unite the right bank with the left, yet so greatly has traffic increased in the French capital that even this number is proving inadequate and the municipality is hard put to it to find a way of relieving the congestion.

The Constitution is "not the private property of private property," and "we have got to have cooperation, whether it be voluntary or involuntary," Charles H. Tuttle, former United States Attorney, declared last night at the sixtieth anniversary dinner of the Sons of the Revolution in the State of New York.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 22. -- Champion Gamecock Duke of Wales, American-bred greyhound, owned and shown in the ring by George S. West of Chestnut Hill, Mass., tonight won the title of best in show as the twenty-fourth annual exhibition of the Eastern Dog Club closed.

There was an impromptu and gay party, with square dancing, last Monday night in the Community Building at Norris, Tenn., the "model town" in which live most of the 1,000 workers who are building the Norris Dam. The master of ceremonies was F.C. Schlemmer, construction superintendent, who called the turns for the dancers (see above).

The decision of the Supreme Court of the United States invalidating the Louisiana Press Tax Law will undoubtedly receive wide approval from New Dealers and anti-New Dalers alike. However, it is doubtful if the public realizes the implications of the case.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 22. -- Holding that California's Unfair Practices Act, which prohibits resale of commodities at prices less than those paid by the retailer, constitutes a monopoly threat to all business, Judge L. Clarence Kincaid in Superior Court ruled the act unconstitutional today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- Stocks of distilled spirits remaining in bonded warehouses at the end of January amounted to 230,425,312 tax gallons, the Treasury stated today.

THE new French short-wave station Radio-Coloniale will be built in the central part of France -- although the definite site has not been selected, according to a report received at the French Embassy in Washington. The installation will comprise two powerful transmitters, one rated at 100 kilowatts and the other 50 kilowatts.

A WORLD inclined to skepticism is watching a twentieth-century crusade. There are no statistics to indicate the number of people affected. The crusade, like all movements in religion, arouses mingled emotions. One fact is undeniable: in a number of countries and among thoughtful communities in the United States the name of the crusade, "Oxford Groups," has become or is fast becoming a household word.
The public interest created by the Townsend plan and pending Federal old-age security legislation has resulted in an increase in the number of applications for old-age pensions in New York City.
CINCINNATI, Feb. 22 (AP). -- Arbiters seeking a settlement of an Indiana-Ohio "dog war" appealed to "Fido" and "Rex" tonight to stay on their own side of the State line.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 22. -- Setting a record believed to be unequaled by any other alumni group in America, 7,883 Harvard graduates contributed in 1935 to the Harvard Fund, which is a permanent organization for receiving contributions for the unrestricted use of the university.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 22. -- United as never before in a militant program to obtain Federal aid for schools in every State, 10,000 school administrators from all parts of the country are gathering here for the largest convention of the Department of Superintendence of the National Educational Association since the expansive days of 1929.

LONDON, Feb. 21. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin's Cabinet is now enjoying the strategic advantage that any government is bound to have when it is preparing for war or actually conducting a war and is therefore immune to attack on domestic issues.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Feb. 22. -- American youth will supply the "winning punch" in the re-election of President Roosevelt, Postmaster General Farley told Missouri's young Democrats today at their State convention here this morning.

There is not a great deal of excitement in this story, but that is probably because the author, formerly in charge of C.I.D., New Scotland Yard, has made his hero adhere closely to the regular procedure, and because the detecting of crime, as carried on by an efficient organization, is a matter of patient investigation of all possible phases of the case rather than one of hair-raising adventure.

THERE is a great deal of talk going around these days about sequences and continuity, camera angles and close-ups, multiple exposures, fadeouts and dissolves. Bridge players annoy their partners with irrelevant remarks about panorama shots and haze filters and business men disrupt conferences to argue the relative merits of F. 2.7 lens and F. 1.9 in cinematography.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Feb. 22. -- Potential rescuers from the air, sea and land joined today to save three schoolboys apparently marooned on an ice floe in Hempstead Harbor. But while aid was converging from all sides the boys leaped to safety, and sheepishly explained to waiting policemen that they meant no harm and were sorry they caused such a disturbance.

When David Lawrence defends the honesty of the Supreme Court your reviewer may be right in saying there has been no attack on their honesty. But when Mr. Lawrence replies in THE TIMES of Feb. 15 to Mr. Chamberlain's criticism he goes to the opposite extreme from arguing a sure thing.

HAVING introduced "Lady Precious Stream" to London and New York, S.I. Hsiung has translated another Chinese play, "The Western Chamber," which has just been published in England by Methuen. It is, according to Chinese authority, an accepted masterpiece of the classical Chinese drama.

Granting the artistic perfection of Jo Mielziner's setting for "Ethan Frome" and the stickling of Guthrie McClintic for veracity of detail therein, I wonder why these two gentlemen have permitted a gross architectural fault in the Frome dwelling.

A new policy toward property owners who place high valuations on their property in condemnation proceedings was announced yesterday by Corporation Counsel Paul Windels in his report to Mayor La Guardia on the activities of his department in 1935.

Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx renewed his fight yesterday for legalization of a municipal lottery, urging Governor Lehman and leaders of the Legislature to pass a bill authorizing such a program.

THIS book makes no claim to originality. It is merely a record -- but a valuable one -- of ten epic struggles in American labor history, from the railroad strikes of 1877 to the general strike in San Francisco in 1934.

IN spite of the many requests received by the Royal Academy, no extension of time for the exhibition of Chinese art at Burlington House is possible. The whole of the time available from the closing day, March 7, to March 27, the first receiving day of the Royal Academy Summer Exhibition, will be required, owing to the necessity for packing the exhibits sent to the Chinese exhibition with special care.

AT the second concert devoted to compositions derived from the Composer's Forum Laboratory, to be given Wednesday evening at 8:30 o'clock at the Federal Music Building, 110 West Forty-eighth Street, Henry Cowell, Charles Haubiel, Marion Bauer, Frederick Jacobi and Harold Morris will be represented by original works.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- A quickening national interest in problems associated with broadening and strengthening the Federal civil service system is reflected in various sectors of the Washington theatre. House and Senate committees are reconsidering several salient measures dormant on their calendars for months, and President Roosevelt recently has conferred with departmental advisers on ways and means to end patronage abuses in the emergency agencies.

Exactly fifty years ago today 22-year-old CHARLES M. HALL, who had graduated from Oberlin but eight months before, rushed into the laboratory of his erstwhile Professor of Chemistry, Dr. FRANK F. JEWETT, and, exhibiting some shining globules, remarked: "I have it."

THE years from Victoria's Golden Jubilee to King George's Jubilee form the background for a serious, carefully written novel by Jane Oliver. She records the young romance and long years of marriage of Hester and Timothy Derwent.

A READER favorably impressed by some of Mrs. Burr's previous novels may deem her departure here into the domain of semi-historical fiction ill-advised and scarcely successful. The setting for most of the story is the Southwest in the early months of the Mexican War, with Santa Fe predominating' and Kearny's bloodless capture of the city providing the main historic event.

QUEBEC, Feb. 22 (Canadian Press). -- Ovide Carriere of Quebec won the Quebec international dogsled derby here today when he mushed his panting huskies across the finish line with a total elapsed time of 6 hours, 40 minutes, 42 seconds for the three thirty-mile heats.

GEORGE RUSSELL is not in "The Australian Encyclopedia," which contains a fairly complete biographical dictionary. His career was not spectacular and he did not engage in what is called "public service." But it was worthies like Russell who directed the laying of the foundations of the Australian Commonwealth and established the most powerful conservative class in the nation, the land-owning, sheep-raising "squattocracy."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- Although details of time, place and scope are still lacking, President Roosevelt's proposed extraordinary inter-American conference to discuss means of preserving the peace which now reigns in the Western Hemisphere must be regarded as a major development in world politics.

THIS title seems more optimistic than the story itself. When one out of three youthful marriages survives little more than a year with its charter members, the prospects for marriage look black. Statistically speaking, 33 1-3 per cent is pretty low grade.

FRESH and crisp as the tissue paper that envelops them in their delivery boxes are the new frocks that lie inside. While city streets and countryside have a heavy load of snow, it seems almost incongruous to talk of Spring frocks, but, somehow, one look at the cheerful things brings a calming assurance that zero weather and ice cannot last forever.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 22. -- The Queen of Bermuda, with 540 passengers aboard, delayed its sailing for New York until tomorrow morning as accidents prevented repeated attempts by the tender Castle Harbour to get a line to the S.S. Nova Scotia.
ABBEVILLE, Ga., Feb. 22 (AP) -- President Roosevelt's first primary contest for renomination takes place on Wednesday in a South Georgia county. His opponent will be Governor Talmadge.

PLANS for a "super-resort city," containing attractions for every type of visitor and zoned so that pleasure seekers of varied tastes need not tread on one another's toes, are being laid here. The program, which originated in the mind of Mayor Charles D. White, has been discussed in recent weeks by leaders of civic, political and business organizations and heads of the railroad lines that enter the resort city.

Some twelve years ago the government appeared to conclude that even in polar regions a discovery coupled with a taking of possession would fail to support a valid claim of sovereignty unless followed by actual settlement.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 22. -Army won its first 1936 sport engagement with Navy today. It was the annual basketball game, played before 3,500 spectators, who filled the Cadets' new gymnasium. The score was 35 -- 19.

Merrill Fink's accurate shot-making and good all-around play featured Blind Brook's triumph over Boulder Brook in their Metropolitan Indoor Polo League match at the Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn last night. The score was 10 to 4 1/2.

Lenten sewing classes, which are institutions in New York, soon will begin work in behalf of their various beneficiaries. The Cathedral Class, that works for the Fresh Air Association of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, will have its first session of this season on March 3 at the home of Mrs. Stephen C. Clark, 46 East Seventieth Street.

A "substantial part" of the dress business which was diverted by retailers to other centers when the threat of a dress strike overhung the New York market is flowing back to this city, Morris Kolchin, executive director of the Affiliated Dress Manufacturers, Inc., declared yesterday.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 22. -Army won its first 1936 sport engagement with Navy today. It was the annual basketball game, played before 3,500 spectators, who filled the Cadets' new gymnasium. The score was 35 -- 19.

Merrill Fink's accurate shot-making and good all-around play featured Blind Brook's triumph over Boulder Brook in their Metropolitan Indoor Polo League match at the Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn last night. The score was 10 to 4 1/2.

Lenten sewing classes, which are institutions in New York, soon will begin work in behalf of their various beneficiaries. The Cathedral Class, that works for the Fresh Air Association of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, will have its first session of this season on March 3 at the home of Mrs. Stephen C. Clark, 46 East Seventieth Street.

Tribute to the enduring characteristics of the philosophy of George Washington for their service both as guideposts and bulwarks in a period of political unrest was the keynote of the celebrations held throughout the city yesterday to commemorate the 204th anniversary of the birth of the Father of His Country.
BERLIN, Feb. 22 (AP). -- Ernst F.S. Hanfstaengl, chief of the foreign press section of the Nazi party, drew an implied parallel between George Washington and Adolf Hitler today.

WOMAN'S invasion of the field of architecture and its allied arts -- sculpture, mural painting, interior decoration and landscape architecture -- has won formal recognition in the current exhibition of the Architectural League of New York.

LAKE PLACID. -- The North American four-man bob-sled championships this morning at the Olympic Mount Van Hoevenberg bob run bring to a climax the gala week-end activities at this snow-covered resort. Of the hundreds who are here for the holiday period many are spectators at the races, but others are enjoying their first ride down the mile-and-one-half slide.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 22. -Princeton's hockey team conquered a fighting Yale aggregation in a quadrangular league game at the Hobey Baker Memorial Rink tonight, 5 to 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 . -- Now that the neutrality question has been disposed of for the session and the stop-gap farm bill has passed -the critical phases in both the House and Senate -- and the Supreme Court apparently has done its worst to the New Deal, Congressional leaders have recovered their earlier confidence that the Seventy-fourth Congress may be adjourned at some date near May 1.

ROME, Jan. 30, 1936. THIRTY curtain calls -- an average of six per scene -- stamped the official seal of success on Franco Alfano's new opera, "Cyrano de Bergerac," after the play of Edmond Rostand, on its much-heralded premiere at the Royal Opera House last week. Equal favor is attending subsequent performances.

Miss Gena Tenney, who was graduated from Barnard College in 1933 and studied during the following two years at the Royal College of Music in London, will be the director of the Barnard Glee Club when it meets with the University of Virginia Glee Club in a joint concert Feb. 27 at 8:30 o'clock in Barnard Hall.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Feb. 22. -- Westchester's first municipal automobile safety council, organized here two weeks ago, enrolled about 500 new members during the first series of four sectional monthly meetings held in various parts of the city during the past week, I. Leonard Heuslein, temporary general chairman, announced today.

MONTREAL, Feb. 22. -- The Montreal Canadiens cut two points from the Americans' margin in the race for a play-off berth in the International Group of the National Hockey League tonight when they took a 1-0 decision from the New Yorkers in a hard-fought game.

YOUTHFUL radio listeners, from 11 to 16 years of age, prefer adult entertainment to programs designed specially for children, according to the results of a questionnaire circulated by the Children's Aid Society among 700 of its boy and girl club members in seven tenement neighborhoods in the New York area.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 22. -- Openly dissatisfied with the slate of delegates selected by President Roosevelt to represent California at the Democratic National Convention, State Senator Culbert Olson, chairman of the California central committee, today bolted the President's slate and said he would organize a new group of Democrats.
TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 22. -- Postmaster General Farley tonight challenged any political party to meet the Democrats in the 1936 campaign on the record of President Roosevelt.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Feb. 22. -- The annual meeting of the Smith College Alumnae Council will be held here Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday, with delegates attending from the sixty-five Smith Clubs in this country, Honolulu, Japan and China and from the fifty-seven classes which have been graduated.

FOR sheer entertainment "Banjo on My Knee" ranks ace-high. It is a grand yarn about the shanty-boat colony at Island 21 in the Mississippi, near Pecan Point, Tenn. Harry Hamilton knows his river people well, and gives a complete and convincing picture of them.

Debutantes headed by Miss Barbara Crim are aiding Mrs. A. Taylor Jones and members of her committee in the sale of boxes and seats for the performance of "Parsifal" in the afternoon of March 20, in which Kirsten Flagstad and Lauritz Melchior will have the leading roles.

The Pomona stories were told over the wireless in England in the B.B.C. Children's Hour. They crammed with everyday events -- visits from friends, playing Indians, tea and tennis parties, varied by the greater excitement of accidents, fires and burglaries.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Feb. 22 (AP) -- George Washington the Mason was honored by that fraternity on his birthday anniversary today by delegates from all over the country.

Rising temperatures resulted in a moderate upturn in business activity toward the end of last week in many sections of the country which have been suffering for weeks from cold and stormy weather. Unfavorable weather conditions, however, continued to retard trade and industrial activity in the Midwest and Northwest, and reports from all sections of the territory indicate severe business recession during recent weeks.

RUDYARD KIPLING has been dead only a few weeks and already he has become something of a legend. That is, perhaps, because he had virtually ceased to write a generation ago, and his spiritual influence, potent as it had been in the Nineties, had waned almost entirely by 1914.

An "extraordinary year" for business in general and advertising was predicted here yesterday by Roy S. Durstine, newly elected president of Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., "if Washington will step aside and let the wheels of progress turn."

A NUMBER of rare books and pamphlets of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries, long marked as missing in the catalogue of Christ Church Library. Oxford, were discovered recently by an assistant librarian. Of forty-two vanished works of this period thirty-four were traced to the auctioneer's catalogue of the library of the Rev. H.F. Lyte, author of the hymn "Abide With Me."

OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The Democratic New Deal became the chief issue tonight in the 1936 Senatorial race with Governor Marland, a stanch backer of the Roosevelt program, an avowed candidate against Senator Gore.

The 483,000 horsepower of electrical energy which the government expects to produce by harnessing the rivers of the Tennessee Valley fades into comparative insignificance when it is compared with the total sum of power which it is proposed to develop throughout the nation under governmental projects completed, under way, or at least in their preliminary stages.
TORONTO, Feb. 22 (AP). -- Ontario's legislators and Toronto's art critics considered today whether a painting in the Queen's Park Hall of Fame is a portrait of Laura Secord or of Sir George Ross.

At the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon "Die Meistersinger" was repeated with a cast of singers whose respective interpretations of the roles of this music-drama are known. That fact in no way detracted from the public interest in the occasion.

EASTON, Pa., Feb. 22. -- Eight Lafayette College students from New York City and vicinity, and a large number from New Jersey, are included on the dean's list at Lafayette. This list is composed of the highest scholastically ranking students in the college.

WINTER PARK, Fla., Feb. 22. -- The tenth annual issue of the Rollins Animated Magazine will be "published" before an outdoor audience of "subscribers" tomorrow as a feature of Founders' Week at Rollins College.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 22 (AP). -- A plucky young woman, Mrs. Maud Rutherfurd, found today in Lake Worth's blustery seas that "Washington" must spell "luck" for her.

EDWARD JOHNSON has agreed. He will sing once this season with Lucrezia Bori in "Pelleas et Melisande." It will be something of a farewell for Mr. Johnson as a singer. His position as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association will not be affected, although he will have to take off several days from his managerial duties for rehearsals and rest.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Feb. 22 (AP). -- Young Republicans of the State are 100 per cent behind their President, Walter J. Mahoney, in his quarrel with Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, according to Paul Lockwood of New York, chairman of the board of the Young Republicans, who spoke here today.

WESTCHESTER COUNTY, often regarded as a model community, appears to be suffering from a severe case of too much government. Blessed and cursed by being the only part of the mainland bordering the nation's largest city, it has derived from its proximity to the metropolis population, wealth and prominence, while from this simple fact of geographical position it has drawn most of its troubles.

A MEMORIAL exhibition of prints by the late Ernest Haskell was held at the Macbeth Galleries in 1926. At these same galleries will now be found (until March 2) a small group of Haskell's very accomplished etchings, representing several more or less distinct phases in his development.

NOW, when seed lists are being made up, it is well to keep in mind the fact that many of the perennials, if started early, will flower quite generously the first season. The same is true of the biennials. Therefore gardeners who make a practice of growing seedling plants of annuals often add some of the hardy kinds, as the treatment they require is much the same.

MR. ALDINGTON states in his preface to this book that it is made up of the "clouds of ideas or pseudo-ideas which dim the mental landscape of our epoch." The sketches are material "unsatisfactory for the artist in fiction," his whimsies, his ideas concerning people and situations.
The following table shows some important dividend meetings scheduled for this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange and the last distributions ordered by the directors:

MOSCOW, Feb. 21. -- As seen from Moscow the Far Eastern situation presents no immediate danger of a Soviet-Japanese war aside from the always-present possibility that the army, joyously irresponsible a Kwantung appears to be, may at any time become involved in some incident too serious to be passed over.

Twenty-six first assistants and other faculty members from the high schools of Brooklyn attended a dinner conference at THE NEW YORK TIMES Building last Thursday evening to discuss the preparation of teaching-plans and articles for the Constitution Contest, which THE TIMES is conducting for high school teachers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 22. -- Belief that the government must continue the Works Progress Administration was emphasized by delegates of the United States Conference of Mayors today at their South-Southwest regional meeting.

PARIS, Feb. 22. -- During the past week more than thirty prominent Spanish families have fled to France, according to dispatches from Biarritz. In all, about 125 persons have taken refuge on the Basque coast, it is said.

WINNIPEG, Man., Feb. 22. -- Winnipeg wheat futures registered small advances today in a listless session. Prices were 1/4 to 3/8 cent higher, with the market reflecting a steady trend at Liverpool. At the close the May future was quoted at 83 3/4 cents, bid; July, 84 5/8 cents, and October 83 1/2 cents.

Politics in Spain is a great national occupation. Up and down the land, on the streets, in salons, in clubs and cafes, Spaniards like to talk and act politics. Last week, when a Left coalition won the bitterly contested election for the Cortes, or Parliament, Spain ran true to form.

LONDON, Feb. 14, 1936. THE death of King George caused an upheaval in the world of music as in every other branch of national life. Many concerts were postponed or canceled, including some which should have introduced important novelties.

Representative Wright Patman of Texas asked support for legislation to protect the small business man and to curb monopolies at the annual convention yesterday of the National Association of Tobacco Distributors at the Hotel New Yorker.

NEW Russian operas, "And Quiet Flows the Don," by I.D. Dzerzhinski, and "Komarinski Muzhik," by V.V. Zhelobinski, have had their premieres in their native land. Both composers are youths in their twenties.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- Secret Service agents unearthed in New York City this week a $338,000 cache of hoarded gold. It was the largest seizure made since President Roosevelt signed his executive order of Aug. 28, 1933, calling in all monetary gold under authority of the Emergency Banking Act.

The Federal income taxpayer who desires to make deductions for traveling expenses, the Bureau of Internal Revenue says, is required to "attach to his return a statement showing the nature of business in which engaged, number of days away from home during the taxable year on account of business, total amount of expense incidental to meals and lodging, and total amount of 'other expenses' incident to travel and claimed as a deduction.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 22 (AP). -- Frank E. Gannett, publisher of the Gannett newspapers, in a statement issued today lauded Senator William E. Borah as "the only man who can wage a successful campaign against a master politician and arouse the nation to action by vigorous, convincing appeal."

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22. -- The value of education as a means of developing a "cooperative relationship between citizens" and of a "sense of fair play among men" was extolled by President Roosevelt today in a speech here before 4,000 persons who gathered in the auditorium of Temple University to see him receive the extraordinary honorary degree of Doctor of Jurisprudence.

JUMPING at conclusions is one of the commonest mistakes in the world, and for that reason this book is ineptly named. A jumper might reasonably infer from the title that the contents concentrated on equatorial lands, whereas they occupy only a small part of its pages.

RADIO. amateurs, numbering! moe than 45,000 in the United States, are mourning the loss of a friend and faithful ally in the passing of i Hiram Percy Maxim of Hartford, i Conn. As an ardent wireless amai teur Mr. Maxim is remembered by !veteran experimenters of pre-war days by the musical tone of his quench spark gap which spelled out the call letters of his pioneer station.

ALBANY, Feb. 22. -- Republican leaders in the Assembly made known today their plans for the two-day demonstration they intend to stage on Capitol Hill next week against the policies of Governor Lehman and of the New Deal.

CAMDEN, S.C., Feb. 22. -- Fugitive, chestnut gelding owned by Mrs. G.H. Bostwick of Westbury, L.I., won the Washington Birthday Plate today in the principal event of the annual Washington Birthday races.

THE first aircraft show of 1936 has just closed its doors in Southern California, and in the nine days of its existence something like 90,000 persons bought tickets and passed through the turnstiles. Billed as the National Pacific Aircraft and Boat Show, the emphasis -- with Cliff Henderson as inpresario -- was on the air part, and it was the air division that drew the crowds.

Sidney Howard, Pulitzer Prize winner and president of the Dramatists Guild, returned from Hollywood yesterday and took a firm stand beside Sinclair Lewis in charging that Will H. Hays had been responsible for the decision to abandon the production of a film version of Mr. Lewis's novel "It Can't Happen Here."

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- The two outstanding social events of the coming week will be the annual benefit ball for the Lady Cubitt Compassionate Fund and a farewell garden party at Government House, at which the Governor, General Sir Thomas Astley-Cubitt, and Lady Cubitt will entertain government officials, officers of the America and West Indies Squadron of the Royal Navy and the Bermuda Garrison and members of the American Winter colony.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- A total of 173 brokers and dealers applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission for registration between Jan. 20 and Feb. 15, the commission announced today.

Young matrons and debutantes of this and recent seasons will take part in the three one-act plays to be presented by members of the junior branch of the New York Women's League for Animals the night of March 4 and the afternoon of March 7 at the MacDowell Club for the benefit of the Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital for Animals.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 22 (AP). -- The Polish Government order suppressing an organization of the Methodist Episcopal Church, South, in Poland has been lifted temporarily, Methodist headquarters here was informed today by its representative in Warsaw.

BAD OEYNHAUSEN, Germany, Feb. 22. -- The national synod of the semi-independent confessional church, representing a majority of the Protestant clergy, after a heated debate lasting all day definitely repudiated all attempts to compromise with the Nazi regime in the church as represented by Hanns Kerrl, Reich Minister for Church Affairs.

Whether or not the world is to experience a naval race "all depends on Japan and Germany," Rear Admiral Yates Stirling Jr., retiring commandant of the Third Naval District, said yesterday in an interview at his office in the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

A CRITICAL analysis of the recent Carnegie International Exhibition and the awards made by Gilbert Ryder, is the leading contribution to the London Studio for February. "It is difficult to say that the 1935 show was of any greater significance than the previous year's offering," in Mr. Ryder's considered opinion.

STORM JAMESON has turned aside for the moment from her long and arduously planned work, "The Mirror in Darkness" -- a series of novels designed to give us a view of contemporary English life in nearly all the phases a story teller may grasp -- to give us a view of life in England as it may become a few years hence.

At a period when far-reaching national and international questions are determined by interpretations of the Constitution of the United States it is somewhat startling to read in the THE NEW YORK TIMES of Feb. 13 that the new "Laboratory in Readability" of Teachers College, Columbia University, has "rewritten" the Declaration of Independence, to make it "easy to read," and will "rewrite" other such documents, and publish them for public use.

A NEW line of trucks and buses following the streamline design has been introduced by Reo. The new models, ranging in capacity from one-half ton to six tons, have a base list price of $445. Brakes are hydraulic and engines of various types may be chosen, some with five-speed transmission.

THE Eastern championships, largest of the year's major tournaments, begin on March 2 at the Commodore Hotel. Conducted by the Knickerbocker Whist Club through a committee of which George Reith is permanent chairman, this tournament has been renewed annually since it was first held in 1927.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 22. -- Four children, ranging in age from 40 days to 8 years, were burned to death tonight, despite efforts of their father, who received possibly fatal injuries in attempting to rescue them.

Sidney Howard, Pulitzer Prize winner and president of the Dramatists Guild, returned from Hollywood yesterday and took a firm stand beside Sinclair Lewis in charging that Will H. Hays had been responsible for the decision to abandon the production of a film version of Mr. Lewis's novel "It Can't Happen Here."

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- The two outstanding social events of the coming week will be the annual benefit ball for the Lady Cubitt Compassionate Fund and a farewell garden party at Government House, at which the Governor, General Sir Thomas Astley-Cubitt, and Lady Cubitt will entertain government officials, officers of the America and West Indies Squadron of the Royal Navy and the Bermuda Garrison and members of the American Winter colony.
TOKYO, Sunday, Feb. 23. -- The general election in Japan has confirmed the Cabinet of Premier Keisuke Okada in power and has registered a strong popular vote against fascism.

New evidence that it is possible to detect the motion of the earth in space by purely terrestrial experiments which, if corroborated by further experiments, would knock out one of the two main pillars upon which rests Einstein's special theory of relativity was presented yesterday at Columbia University before the joint meeting of the American Physical Society and the Optical Society of America.

Methods of intensifying efforts to achieve the program outlined in July at the international convention of the Catholic Daughters of America were discussed yesterday by members of the order's Supreme Board, which met for an all-day session at the headquarters of the organization, 10 West Seventy-first Street.

Dean Franklin De R. Furman of the Stevens Institute of Technology at Hoboken announced yesterday that thirteen freshmen, nineteen sophomores, eighteen juniors and eighteen seniors had won places on the dean's list at the institute.

HAMLIN, W. Va., Feb. 22 (AP) -- A family of eight lay critically ill from poisoning today in a hill country home, their illness brought on by what Prosecutor W.S. Damron said was a 14-year-old daughter's retaliation for a chastisement.

AS a young man Mr. Guernsey went in 1880 from his home in Cooperstown, N.Y., into what was then the far Western wilds, where he cast his lot with the ambitious Wyoming cattle country and has lived there ever since.

IN scores of yacht clubs and homes this month stay-at-home chart travelers are joyously busy at their peculiar pastime. They are plotting their paper cruises and are as absorbed in it as though working out a chess problem.
TOKYO, Sunday, Feb. 23. -- The general election in Japan has confirmed the Cabinet of Premier Keisuke Okada in power and has registered a strong popular vote against fascism.

New evidence that it is possible to detect the motion of the earth in space by purely terrestrial experiments which, if corroborated by further experiments, would knock out one of the two main pillars upon which rests Einstein's special theory of relativity was presented yesterday at Columbia University before the joint meeting of the American Physical Society and the Optical Society of America.

Methods of intensifying efforts to achieve the program outlined in July at the international convention of the Catholic Daughters of America were discussed yesterday by members of the order's Supreme Board, which met for an all-day session at the headquarters of the organization, 10 West Seventy-first Street.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23. -- Prices on lard futures here had a fairly wide range last week and closed 35 cents a hundred pounds lower for the week on both May and July while liquidation by tired speculators, holders and hedging sales by packers furnished ample opportunities for the shorts to get in, but there were several days the shorts had to bid prices up to cover and they were accommodated by packers' selling.

LONDON, Feb. 21. -- Comment here on the French Government's new credit in London is, on the whole, favorable. The operation had a stabilizing influence on the franc, causing a partial repatriation of French funds and making it certain that there will not be an immediate devaluation of the franc.

A 34-year-old truck driver, Gerard Markesse, who had once been arrested for robbery, was shot dead about 3:15 P. M. yesterday in a dark tenement hallway at 67 James Street, about three blocks from the Oak Street police station.

SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 23 (AP). -- Karl Weiss, a genealogy director in the Latter Day Saints Church, said today that George Washington, Abraham Lincoln and Franklin D. Roosevelt all were direct descendants of Lady Elizabeth or Isabel de Vermandois of Norman nobility, who lived during the twelfth century.
BERLIN, Feb. 23. -- The Olympic games, both Summer and Winter, are seen on this side of the water as developing into a massed European attack on American athletic supremacy.

The last three years have been characterized by much thought and utterance upon the subject of wealth, its distribution and ownership. Some very interesting facts and statistics on the matter are contained in a recently published pamphlet which uses the following estimates in crediting the women of this country with ownership of three-fourths of the nation's wealth:

"Charity and the power of seeing are related, for without charity we are blind," the Right Rev. Leopold Kroll, who was consecrated Bishop of Liberia, Africa, last Thursday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, declared yesterday morning in his sermon at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (The Little Church Around the Corner), Twenty-ninth Street, east of Fifth Avenue.

Representatives of the United Mine Workers, headed by John L. Lewis, and anthracite operators will begin negotiations here this morning for a new wage and work agreement. The agreement signed between them five years ago expires March 31.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- A campaign to organize the steel industry will be undertaken this Spring by the American Federation of Labor, but whether it will be of limited proportions or of the broad scope suggested by the Committee for Industrial Organization was a matter of considerable speculation today.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 21. -- The stock market in the Netherlands has shown general improvement in recent weeks, the index number of stock prices for January being 36 against 33.1 in December. The firmness is not due to any monetary factors, but rather to the increasing confidence in world recovery emanating from the United States.

Officials of the Townsend plan carried their campaign into Long Island yesterday afternoon with a meeting attended by 500 persons in the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Earl C. Clements, co-founder with Dr. Francis B. Townsend, was the main speaker.

The working girl in an office cannot clothe herself respectably for less than $77.75 a year, according to one of seven budgets made up by six prominent home economists, whose findings were made public last night by the New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor.

LONDON, Feb. 21. -- Boom-like conditions followed by a wave of profit-taking and consequent reaction have prevailed in the stock markets here this week. The settlements just concluded were the heaviest in many months.

ATHENS, Feb. 23. -- A large Cavern, penetrating sixty-five feet under the bluff-like eastern face of the Acropolis, is being excavated by Lincoln MacVeagh, the American Minister to Greece. A man can walk the full length without stooping, but few travelers observe the entrance, although it is visible from the near-by theatre of Dionysus.

The calling of all outstanding 7 per cent bonds issued in 1926 for stabilizing the currency of Belgium, featured announcement last week of bonds called for payment before maturity. Other notices were few and, excepting for one large block of industrial bonds, mostly for small amounts of municipal loans.

DETROIT, Feb. 23 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, renewing his criticism of Representative John J.
