O'Connor of New York, which led the House Rules Committee chairman last Sunday to offer to kick him "all the way from the Capitol to the White House," challenged Mr. O'Connor today to meet the issue of the Frazier-Lemke bill in open debate in the House.

Why is it deemed necessary when one has already paid a good price for an ocean voyage or a cruise to go through all the red tape and additional expense involved in obtaining a deck chair? The small sum required is inconsequential, but the principle should be considered.

BERLIN, Feb. 23. -- Foreign tourist travel within Germany and cruising by Germans beyond the confines of the Reich are improving over conditions of a year ago. German steamship companies report their January bookings for /North Atlantic travel were double those for the preceding January.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 23. -- A denunciation of William Randolph Hearst, Frank Belgrano, Alfred E. Smith, Father Coughlin, the Daughters of the American Revolution and the American Liberty League as forces "combined in an effort" to destroy both "American ideals" and "freedom in schools" was cheered at a meeting of 1,000 school administrators here today.

Establishment of a State Department of Justice, to be headed by an Attorney General appointed and removable by the Governor instead of an elected official, was endorsed yesterday in a report made public by the committee on State legislation of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, of which Mason H. Bigelow is chairman.

LONDON, Feb. 21. -- The Board of Trade's estimates of Great Britain's overseas balance reveal that payments in 1935 resulted in a net surplus of 37,000,000, compared with a debit balance of 2,000,000 in 1934 and an even balance in 1933. There was a visible adverse balance of 263,000,000, against 294,000,000 in 1934, but invisible exports are calculated at 300,000,000, against 292,000,000 a year before.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 23. -- The cotton market here ruled rather quiet all last week. Trading had been restricted by a desire to await the final outcome of the legislation pending in Washington, and the market was affected also by the continued liquidation of the March position, the first notice day for which will be tomorrow.

Two thousand models of the French liner Normandie have been built in all parts of the world by men and women in a variety of fields of work, as prospective contenders in a contest which has just been concluded by the Model Builders League.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- The Committee of Utility Executives expressed the opinion tonight that the decision of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals at Charlotte, S.C., yesterday in the American States Public Service Company case constituted a "sweeping and significant victory for the industry, despite the limitation by the appeals court to the specific case before it."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP). -- Conjecture whether Senator Borah of Idaho was "burning all bridges behind him" in his drive for the Republican Presidential nomination arose today out of an announcement that a political ally was seeking his Senatorial seat.

While output was higher in the United States, Great Britain, Australia and in most of the South and Central American countries, world industrial production remained about the same in December as in November, according to the monthly report issued yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1936 as well as last price, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

America's latest dance steps, including "The Fleet," a new "swing" rhythm that is expected to attain the popularity of the "Carioca," the "Piccolino" and other hits, were demonstrated to 400 dancing teachers yesterday at the Hotel Astor at the annual ballroom dancing exhibition of the National Dance League.

BERLIN, Feb. 21. -- The conclusion of a new standstill agreement has had little perceptible effect upon sentiment here. Official comments on the transfer situation and the outlook continue to be unfavorable.
Reports from London say that two books published by Harper are heading the English best-seller list. John Gunther's "Inside Europe" and George Seldes's "Sawdust Caesar."

PARIS, Feb. 23. -- The competition among nations of the world for space at the Paris Exhibition in 1937 has become so keen that directors are having difficulty in reserving ground apportioned to the United States while awaiting a definite decision from Washington as to American participation.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 23. -- One hundred and eighty-eight passengers of the Furness-Withy steamer Nova Scotia were still held aboard their disabled ship tonight, continuing storm conditions having prevented the transfer of passengers to tenders.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 23. -- The regular fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for Feb. 15 shows the following changes in paper pesos:

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $5,315,050,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 23. -- Chris H. Ripp of Jamaica, L. I., earned permanent possession of the E. R. Bradley Trophy for 1151-limited hydroplanes as the Washington's Birthday regatta ended today.

Favored by London, where it ran for almost a year, "Love on the Dole" makes its American bow tonight at the Shubert. This is the play adapted by Donald Gow and Walter Greenwood from the latter's novel, which means that it is a pretty grim study of unemployment in an industrial town in Lancashire.

I The Barat Settlement will be the[ i beneficiary of a dinner dance to be[ held tonight in the Starlight !oof[ Far'den of the Vraldorf-Astoria un-[ der (he auspices of the Women's Auxiliary of the settlement. The funds reltliz.d will further the. educational and recreational program of l.he Barat Settlement at Houston and Chrystie Streets among adults and children in a crowded district of the city.

Five thousand spectators turned away from the Fifty-ninth Street Lake in Central Park in disappointment yesterday as the Park Department's Winter carnival had to be called off after three finals had been contested.

A modern version of Shakespeare's "Macbeth," which will portray the role of Lady Macbeth from a "psychoanalytical point of view," will be presented by the Drama Department of New College, Columbia University, March 4, 5 and 6 in the Earl Hall Theatre on the Morningside Heights campus.

A BEN KANDEL'S "City for Conquest" (Covici, Friede, $2.50) might be a grand book except that its nerves are shot. Every twenty minutes or so it goes off into a fit of something approaching hysteria, deserting the ordered ways of straight tale-telling to embarrassingly seek the slippery heights of prose-poetry, in which the author attempts lyrically to express his wonderment at New York.

LONDON, Feb. 23 (AP). -- Visits to army flying fields, mysterious letters, a cipher code and activities of a young woman furnished the background for the approaching spy trial at Old Bailey of Dr. Hermann Gortz, middle-aged German lawyer-writer.

Senator BORAH chose Washington's Birthday to make a vigorous and unyielding isolationist speech. It will probably be popular with many of those whose support he is asking in his quest of the Presidency. But he cannot be accused of "extemporizing lifelong convictions" or changing his views in order to win votes.

PARIS, Feb. 23. -- Through the whole debate on the Franco-Soviet pact of mutual assistance which will be concluded Tuesday in the French Chamber of Deputies there has been running like a constant refrain the statement "Russia has not paid her debts."

CHICAGO, Feb. 23. -- Grain traders of the world are not in agreement on immediate prospects. The volume of speculation is light and there are no indications of an early increase. The crop scare season is virtually at hand -- it generally starts early in March.

TRENTON, Feb. 23. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman today was reported considering a new reprieve for Bruno Richard Hauptmann -- one which would not be announced until within five minutes of electrocution time during the week of March 30.

Martha Graham, probably the most adventurous of our dancers, attempted a new feat in the line of decor in her recital at the Guild Theatre last night, when she introduced "mobiles" designed by Alexander Calder as preludes to three movements of her new cycle entitled "Horizons."

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 24 (AP). -- Assemblyman Horace M. Stone, Onondaga Republican, accused by Governor Herbert H. Lehman tonight of being among those active in the battle "to strangle and defeat" the anti-crime program, asserted in reply that the Governor distorted the facts in saying that he opposed the entire program.

Long Island University's fine exhibition against Rice on Wednesday and Manhattan's unexpected victory over New York University on the same night were the highlights during the week in Eastern intercollegiate basketball.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 23. -- A general strike in this city against the French regime in Syria, which has continued for thirty-six days, shows little prospect of ending soon.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 23. -- Aubrey (Buck) Wells and his Keene Mountaineers won the North American four-man bobsled championship on the Mount Van Hoevenberg bob run this morning and tossed all existing North American and course records into the discard.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- Government lawyers conferred over the week-end on their strategy in two more New Deal battles now approaching in the Supreme Court, the first the slum-clearance case, which will be argued a week from tomorrow, the second the Guffey Coal Control Act, which is to be debated nine days later.

While the demand for Spring apparel and accessories in the wholesale markets here was more active last week than in the preceding week, sales were well under normal for this period of the year, reflecting the lag in retail buying in many sections.

DETROIT, Feb. 23 (AP). -- Three quick first-period goals and Doug Young's fast solo dash in the third gave the Detroit Red Wings a 4-3 victory over the New York Americans tonight in a National Hockey League battle. A crowd of 8,500 saw the game.

Twenty pastors of Protestant churches in Brooklyn and Queens exchanged pulpits yesterday morning. The Brooklyn pastors preached on "Church Unity." Those in Queens used the general theme "Preparation for Lent."

While most of New York slept early yesterday morning a fireball of startling brilliancy streaked across the black sky for a brief four or five seconds until its career ended in a burst of dazzling pyrotechnics.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23. -- The largest purchases of oats futures here last week, especially of the May position, were by processors who obtained them from elevator interests. These latter are understood to be the largest holders of the cash grain.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- Senate inflationists disclosed today that they have decided to refrain from offering any mandatory "cheaper money" amendments to the tax bill being formulated by the administration.

Declaring that it is the attitude of the hosiery industry that it shall neither lose nor profit in the refunding of processing taxes, the tax committee of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers issued recommendations yesterday for the procedure to follow in connection with refunds.

The Supreme Court's decision in the TVA case leaves it an open question whether the broader phases of the government's power program are within its constitutional sphere, the Guaranty Trust Company says in the current issue of its publication, the Guaranty Survey.

Sharp criticism of the attitude of the Colombian Government in denying payments to the United States and British holders of its external loans while, at the same time servicing its obligations to French and Belgian creditors during 1935, was expressed by the Colombian Bondholders Committees in an announcement today.

On Aug. 28, 1933, a moratorium went into effect in New York State until July 1, 1934, on foreclosures on all real estate mortgages where interest, taxes and other charges had been paid. The moratorium, in other words, applied solely to default in the payment of principal or installments of principal.

TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 23 (AP). -- Director of Athletics J.F. McKale at the University of Arizona said tonight that Henry (Hank) Leiber, holdout outfielder of the Giants, has been appointed head baseball coach at the institution and will report for duty tomorrow morning.
Despite the holiday week-end, real estate brokers and managing agents of business properties reported an unusually large volume of business-space leases in the city and outlying sections.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 23. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated at 53 per cent of capacity, unchanged from the preceding week. Production in earlier weeks of the year fluctuated between 50 and 51 per cent, while for four weeks before the holidays the rate was 57 per cent, the highest in point of tonnage since June, 1930, except for two trifling exceptions.

ALBANY, Feb. 23. -- Powerful groups of lawyer legislators have banded together to strangle an extensive program of anti-crime measures, Governor Herbert H. Lehman told the people tonight in a Statewide radio broadcast.

PARIS, Feb. 21. -- The French loan of 40,000,000 from London will not, as was first planned, be in the form of an issue of treasury bonds but will be a nine-month credit to the French Government, to be drawn on at will with option to repay before maturity.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23. -- Corn prices here averaged lower last week, with the range on futures 1 1/8 cents a bushel, closing at about the lows, but around 5 cents above the season's low. Trading was limited to hedging sales against moderate purchases of cash corn to arrive from the interior, which was taken by industries.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 23. -- Top Row, winner of $104,600 yesterday in the world richest race, the $135,700 Santa Anita Handicap, was cut down in the running and was being carefully nursed today to prevent infection. A.A. Baroni, who claimed the horse for $3,500 two years ago and trained him to win more than $200,000 said:
Jimmy Hines of Garden City, L.I., is setting the scoring pace for barnstorming players, according to statistics released yesterday by the Professional Golfers Association to The Associated Press.

Terming the Constitution of the United States "the greatest document ever written by the hand of man, the foundation of our national life and the protector of our liberties," Bishop William T. Manning, in a sermon yesterday morning urged loyalty to it and to every activity of human life.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23. -- Wheat futures here closed at around the inside of the week, May at 98 3/4 cents a bushel, up 5/8 cent from the previous week, millers buying the May offerings. July wheat closed 3/8 cent lower, at 88 7/8 cents, while September closed the same as the previous week at 88 1/4 cents. May wheat closed 9 7/8 cents over the season's low.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 21. -- Opinion here on the future of the gold bloc nations remains divided, some circles pointing to the diminishing margin between British-American and gold bloc wholesale prices while others believe a readjustment of gold currencies unavoidable.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP). -- High State Department officials asserted today that the two years of discussions with Panama were nearing a conclusion and that the prospect was good for a settlement of all questions. They voiced the hope that an early agreement would result.

After a single performance last month at the Metropolitan Opera House the Jooss European ballet returned yesterday afternoon to open a series of five performances in the much more suitable Alvin Theatre. Here there are no vast auditorium spaces to swallow up the intimate character of Mr. Jooss's choreography and the many excellences of his company.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 23. -- Leaders of the American Joint Distribution Committee, meeting here to plan for the 1936 national campaign for $3,500,000 to aid Jews overseas, today issued a statement to clarify misconceptions that arose from reports originating in the recent visit to this country of the British delegation headed by Sir Herbert Samuel.

The annual International Skating Carnival, to be held on March 22 and 25 at Madison Square Garden, is being supported by a large committee of patrons and patronesses. The net proceeds will benefit jointly the convalescent relief division of the Bellevue Hospital Social Service Bureau, and the Carroll Club and its vacation camp.
GREENWOOD LAKE, N.Y., Feb. 23. -- The second attempt to shoot mail-carrying rocket gliders across the New York-New Jersey State line was partly successful here today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23. -- Increased marketing of hogs at Chicago and other points, as the result of better transportation facilities and a greater movement by farmers to market their stock, made a weak and declining market. Intermittent sharp rallies were followed by breaks.

BERLIN, Feb. 21. -- Conflicting rumors concerning the dividend policies of commercial banks, the steel trust and potash concerns dominated the week's business sentiment. As general expectations became less optimistic, leading stocks were irregular and showed a declining tendency.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- Merits and demerits of the Civilian Conservation Corps as a factor in the economic life of the country have split the ranks of professional foresters into two opposing camps, it was disclosed today in a newly published issue of The Forestry News Digest.

Declaring the beauty of the State Forest Preserve had been marred by two recent highway projects, the Association for the Protection of the Adirondacks made public yesterday a resolution urging that public hearings be held before plans are adopted for future highway relocation projects.

WARSAW, Feb. 23. -- Although General Hermann Goering, German Air Minister, did not shoot a lynx in the forest of Bilowicza, his second visit to Poland was crowned with diplomatic success. He will be able to report to Chancellor Adolf Hitler that Polish-German relations, strained during the last few weeks, now are as good as they were when the non-aggression declaration was signed two years ago.

Panhandling and begging have increased and arrests have decreased materially in the past two months in the opinion of Magistrate Jonah J. Goldstein. Magistrate Goldstein believes that abolition of the magistrates' courts mendicancy squads, an Emergency Relief Bureau project started more than a year ago and recently discontinued, is responsible for the rise in begging on the streets.

World industrial production remained at about the same level in December as in November, but the gold value of world trade advanced in November for the fourth consecutive month, the National Industrial Conference Board announced yesterday.

A further narrowing in trading in cotton futures occurred here last week and, although there was a decline of 25 points in the spot price, futures ended unchanged to 6 points lower than the closing prices of the preceding week.

Denial that the so-called Old Guard of the Socialist party was supporting President Roosevelt for re-election as against the candidate of the Socialist party was made yesterday by Old Guard leaders in replying to a published statement by the Left wing, headed by Norman Thomas.

SHEFFIELD, England, Feb. 23. -- A scientist here has invented a new type of stainless steel which is claimed to be considerably cheaper than the present method and will revolutionize hundreds of industries.

A spectacle that entertained New Yorkers annually in the years before the United States entered the World War will be revived on an enlarged scale when the National Sportsmen's Show moves into Grand Central Palace next Saturday for an eight-day run.

ROME, Feb. 23 (AP). -- Fascists waited impatiently tonight for news of the capture of Alaji in a renewed drive by the northern army in Ethiopia. Officials insisted the push could not halt short of this objective, the furthest point reached by the Italian expedition of 1895-96 which was virtually wiped out.

Several younger members of society are assisting in the plans for the entertainment to be known as "A Night in Bermuda" which will take place tonight in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center for the benefit of the Victoria Home for Aged British Men and Women.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- With a special House committee of four Democrats and four Republicans preparing to investigate the methods and financing of the Townsend Old-Age Pension Plan, the American Liberty League today characterized the Townsend program as a "token of a state of mind created by the New Deal's dazzling promises of the more abundant life."

Amendments to New York State laws which would prohibit the future investment of trust funds in parts of bonds and mortgages are among the recommendations to be submitted to the Legislature today by the joint legislative committee to investigate bondholders and other committees, trustees and fiduciaries.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- The National Labor Relations Board held, in a decision announced today, that the United Aircraft Manufacturing Corporation of East Hartford, Conn., was guilty of unfair labor practices and ordered it to offer re-employment and pay back wages to Axel G. Benson, president, and seventeen other officers of Industrial Aircraft Lodge, 119, Machine, Tool and Foundry Workers Union, who were employed by it until labor troubles of last September.

BOSTON, Feb. 23. -- In one of the most grueling matches in the forty-six-year history of the national racquets championships Edward M. Edwards of Philadelphia became the 1936 champion when he vanquished Clarence C. Pell of New York, a twelve-time titleholder, in the final match at the Tennis and Racquet Club today.

As a consequence of investigations conducted in 1935 by the Department of Investigation and Accounts, twenty-two public employes, some of them in substantial executive positions, resigned under fire or were discharged, according to the annual report of Commissioner Paul Blanshard to Mayor La Guardia. The report was made public yesterday.

PENSACOLA, Fla., Feb. 23. -- This throbbing little metropolis that looks down from the north upon the vast expanse of the Gulf of Mexico went into its final stages of flutterings today as it greeted the vanguard of Giants who tomorrow will launch their 1936 training campaign.

BOSTON, Feb. 23 (AP). -- The New York Rangers strengthened their play-off chances by coming from behind for a 4-3 triumph over the Boston Bruins tonight before 13,000 at the Boston Garden. A three-goal burst in less than two minutes of first-period play upset the Bruins' morale and plunged them into their fourth straight setback.
BOSTON, Feb. 23. -- Three bandits invaded the Keith Boston Theatre, in the heart of the theatrical district, tonight, cowed four persons and escaped with $12,800 in weekend receipts.

An alliance between supporters of Senator William E. Borah and Young Republicans to try to elect "liberal" delegates to the Republican National Convention was proposed yesterday by William Ziegler Jr., chairman of the Progressive Republican State Committee, in a letter to Walter J. Mahoney of Buffalo, president of the Association of New York State Young Republican Clubs.

HONOLULU, Feb. 23. -- Ending a trip from California that had been slowed by intermittent headwinds, Captain Edwin C. Musick brought the China Clipper clown on Pearl Harbor at 11:35 A.M. today, twenty-three and a half hours after he had taken off.

Joseph Schuster has been named as the new first 'cellist of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, succeeding Alfred Wallenstein, who will retire at the end of this season to devote himself to radio work, according to an announcement yesterday. Mr. Schuster will assume his post with the beginning of next season.

LONDON, Feb. 23. -- Circumstances are conspiring to popularize Britain as a Winter holiday resort at the expense of other centers of Europe, apart from well-advertised Winter sports grounds, which are reported here to have had a prosperous year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- Of the estimated total of $220,000,000 of mortgage loans made in 1935 by all classes of private financial institutions for the building of new urban one-to-four family homes, 55 per cent was made by member institutions of the Federal Home Loan Bank system, according to an analysis made public today by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

BERLIN, Feb. 23. -- Leaders of Jewish organizations in countries throughout the world will assemble in London in the next two weeks to form a central organization for dealing with varied aspects of the new problem that confronts them -- the necessity for a Jewish exodus from Germany.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Feb. 23. -- Citizens of all faiths were invited by President Roosevelt tonight to join forces and "make capital out of religious understanding" in the world-wide issue between "belief and unbelief."

Reverence for holy persons and sacred things and respect for authority were urged by the Rev. Dr. William H. Kephart m his sermon yesterday morning at the North New York Congregational Church, 143d Street near Willis Avenue, Bronx.

Travel and steamship men here predict that the passenger figures of this season's Winter cruises will be the largest of the last ten years. The popularity of cruises with Americans has been particularly heartening in the face of little improvement in Winter travel on the Atlantic.
PUEBLO, Col., Feb. 23. -- Vast clouds of dust churned over parts of Colorado, Texas, Nebraska, Oklahoma and Kansas today on the heels of a departing cold wave.

The revival of Beethoven's only opera, "Fidelio," after an absence of six years; the debut of Bruna Castagna, Italian contralto, and the return to the company of Grace Moore will be among the leading events of the twelfth week of the Metropolitan Opera season next week.

An offering to the public of 32,000 shares of 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock of $100 par value of the Holland Furnace Company will be made today by a group headed by F.S. Moseley Co. and including H.M. Byllesby Co., Harris, Hall Co., Inc., and the Metropolitan St. Louis Company. The shares are being priced at $102 each.
MADRID, Spain, Feb. 23. -- Demonstrations continued in Spain today in celebration of amnesty to 30,000 prisoners convicted or awaiting trial for "political and social offenses."

LIMA, Feb. 23. -- Foreign commerce of Peru in 1935 amounted to 483,683,138 soles, an increase of 13,586,199 soles over the total in 1934. Customs duties amounted to 37,778,697 soles, an increase of 3,340,053.

I read with great interest the letter of Robert Nathan in THE TIMES of Feb. 13. I am glad Mr. Nathan gave me this chance to clarify his erroneous impressions of the bills I introduced in the Senate last week.
Exactly at 9 o'clock last night in Madison Square Garden Floyd Gibbons, globe-trotting news commentator, fired a pistol shot which launched New York's sixtieth international six-day bicycle race.

Echoing recommendations expressed in a pastoral letter by Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, the Rev. Henry F. Hammer, assistant rector, preaching at high mass at the cathedral yesterday, urged generosity and universality of contribution in the annual envelope collection to be taken up next Sunday and by which it is hoped to realize $25,000 toward the running expenses of the church.

PARIS, Feb. 23. -- Faced with the fact that during this Winter tourist traffic and receipts in France have shrunk to the lowest figure of many years, Premier Albert Sarraut has taken a sound step toward removing one of these many troublesome irritations of official origin which tend so much to discourage tourists from coming here.

Winning seven of his eight matches in the nine-man final round-robin round, John R. Huffman of the New York A.C. successfully defended his metropolitan saber championship in the annual competition contested yesterday at the Fencers Club.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 23 (AP)-Emergency crews battled flood and snow in Pacific States today as the storm death toll for two days mounted past ten.
ALBANY, Feb. 23. -- The text of Governor Lehman's radio address tonight on "The Fight Against Crime" was as follows:

The ability to approach God and obtain forgiveness without the aid of a mediator is one of the fundamental principles of Protestantism, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

ALBANY, Feb. 23. -- After twenty-two months of investigation of public utility practices, the Mack utility investigating committee gave to the Legislature today, in a 111-page final report, the benefit of its work. The conclusions may be summarized as follows:
BALTIMORE, Monday, Feb. 24. -- Former Governor Albert C. Ritchie, a nationally known figure in the Democratic party, died suddenly at his apartment here early today. He was 59 years old.

The need for a permanent city planning board and a master plan "to guide the orderly physical development of the city as a whole" is stressed in the report of the committee on city development of the Fine Arts Federation of New York, which will be issued today.

The executive committee of the Citizens Union will meet this afternoon and, as part of its program, discuss the activities of the authorities in the investigation of the murder of Samuel Drukman in a Brooklyn garage last March. Meyer and Harry Luckman and Fred J. Hull, convicted of murder in the second degree, have been sentenced to twenty years to life each.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 (AP). -- The maximum team strength in the senior division of the national indoor polo championship has been increased to twenty-one goals, to permit Winston Guest's New York Optimists to compete, Herbert J. Lorber, tournament chairman, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- The necessity for keeping Congress going and at the same time preventing it from attempting any important action until President Roosevelt submits his tax and work relief program was the unusual problem facing the administration leaders tonight as they looked forward to an uncertain if non-productive week.

NO great heavyweight prospects but plenty of light reading. That is Jack Dempsey's summary of his "white hope" hunt to date. Over the protests of Manager Joe Gould, who has been waxing indignant over any "white hope" hunt while Jersey James Braddock, hale and hearty, is wearing the heavyweight crown, Dempsey is continuing his campaign relentlessly.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Feb. 23. -- A Connecticut team, Doug Hadden and Charles Wisner of Westport, won the second annual Eastern all-bore two-man team skeet championship at the Loantaka Skeet Club today with a score of 191, two under the winning total a year ago.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 23 (AP). -- Leigh Wade, American pilot and aircraft demonstrator, denied in an interview today assertions before the American Senate Munitions Committee regarding his alleged connection with a shipment of arms and sale of a ship to Brazilian revolutionaries.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 23. -- A protest to President Roosevelt and Senators Copeland and Wagner against "misleading displays" of the War Department was unanimously voted today at the closing session of the New York State Youth Conference.

The necessity of realizing the presence of the Lord in the turning points of one's life, as a part of one's resources, for counsel and companionship was stressed by the Right Rev. Warren L. Rogers, Bishop of Ohio, in his sermon yesterday morning at St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue at Fifty-third Street.

Mr. Danenberg's comment on Harold Riegelman's address on water supply and metering misses the point. Mr. Riegelman showed that by metering, the heavy impact of debt service on the Delaware project could be deferred until a more propitious time, that it may be possible to indefinitely postpone the second stage of the project, and that in any event the city cannot waste water without paying for it.
BELGRADE, Feb. 23. -- The official communique issued tonight following the interview between the Czech Premier Milan Hodza and the Yugoslav Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch stated:

A strong man, struggling with grief, is always a moving sight. It is particularly so when he is shaken not by a personal misfortune but by distressing public events. This was the spectacle presented by Postmaster General FARLEY in his Kansas address on Saturday evening.

In view of the capital and operating costs of the George Washington Bridge, abolishment of pedestrian tolls would be without reason, the Port of New York Authority has declared in a reply to Representative Edward A. Kenney of the Ninth New Jersey District, who has urged the Authority to discontinue the 5-cent toll.

The Rutgers swimming team assured itself of at least a tie for the championship of the Intercollegiate Swimming Association by its triumph over Penn on Saturday. Previous to the meet, both had been unbeaten in two encounters and the Scarlet's triumph gave it undisputed possession of first place.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., Feb. 23 (AP). -- A general break-up of the entire seventy-mile-long ice gorge in the Ohio River started tonight, alleviating fears of serious damage to more than 2,500 homes in the lowlands.

The fifth round of the women's championship at the Marshall Chess Club was contested yesterday in two sections. Mrs. Mary Bain of Astoria and Miss Helen White of Manhattan triumphed in Section B and remained in a tie for the lead with scores of 5 -- 0 each.

Albert Abrams, 13 years old, of 458 Snediker Avenue, in the East New York district of Brooklyn, was drowned yesterday afternoon in the icy waters of Fresh Creek, an arm of Jamaica Bay, and a 12-year-old friend narrowly escaped drowning when the ice broke beneath the weight of the two boys.

Twelve experts on nutrition, delegated by the Health Committee of the League of Nations in October to investigate the eating habits of the world, announced yesterday that, in almost every country, the diet of the average man and woman was deficient in essential factors.
MOSCOW, Feb. 23. -- Soviet newspapers declared today that the Far Eastern situation was creating the danger of "another world war."

The Interborough Rapid Transit system, as a whole, showed an increase in traffic in January for the fifth consecutive month, according to the report of Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver, while the Manhattan division showed a gain for the seventh consecutive month.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Feb. 23. -- Benjamin F. Finke's Marconi-rigged Class A ice yacht Bobby won two point races and Rear Commodore E.W. Price's Imp captured one as the Long Branch Ice Boat and Yacht Club staged the biggest regatta in its history today.

It is just a matter of simple arithmetic, 3:04 plus 1:02 equals 4:06. In the wake of Gene Venzke's spectacular victory over Glenn Cunningham in world's record time at the Garden on Saturday came the query yesterday as to what the winning mark might have been had their stirring struggle been at a mile instead of 1,500 meters.

For the closing week of February, events on the New York art calendar, if not as numerous as on a few occasions this season, nevertheless make up in variety anything they may lack in quantity. For subject-matter there is a range from the famous birds of Audubon to paintings by Soutine and the art of the omnipresent "comic strip." And both the Federal and Municipal Galleries will have new group shows.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Feb. 23. -- The new Paraguayan Government has canceled the credentials of all delegates and attaches at the Chaco Peace Conference, according to today's dispatches from Asuncion.

Marjorie Edwards, 13-year-old violinist, made her New York debut at the Town Hall last night, adding her mite to what seemed to be starting out as "prodigy week." A slim girl, tall for her age, Miss Edwards is a native of California. Her teacher has been Kathleen Parlow, and she has appeared in solo recital and with orchestra in the West and in the Berkshires.

PARIS, Feb. 23. -- Jean Marie Clamamus, a Communist Deputy, was elected Senator today in one of the queerest senatorial elections ever held in the Paris district. In the upper house he will take the seat of former Premier Pierre Laval, who, having been elected both for the Seine Department and for his native Puy-de-Dome last October, chose to represent the Puyde-de-Dome district, thus causing a new election for one seat in the Seine Department.

Drastic changes in the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Law and its administration, now being debated by the Legislature, were opposed yesterday by Colonel Ralph C. Tobin, president of the Retail Wine and Liquor Guild, Inc.

It was a clear Saturday afternoon, sparkling with possibility. Joie Moscato, 6 years old, and his sister Rose, four years older, strolled westward across the latticed shadow of the Third Avenue elevated at Eighty-sixth Street.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Feb. 23. -- Colonel E. Francis Riggs, retired United States Army officer and head of the insular police since 1933, was shot and killed today by two young Nationalists whose names were given as Elias Beauchamp and Hiran Rosado.

BOSTON, Feb. 23. -- Joseph McGrath, chairman of the Democratic State Committee, said tonight that Governor Landon of Kansas was a "counterfeit Coolidge" and was being kept out of New England until after the Republican National Convention.

Oxford University, through its governing council, has declined to participate in the 550th anniversary celebration at Heidelberg University. Three weeks ago Dr. HENSLEY HENSON, Bishop of Durham, had a full column letter on the subject in The London Times.

LONDON, Feb. 23. -- Revelations of a new type of "marriage racket," yielding huge profits to an international white slave ring, have led Scotland Yard to launch the biggest clean-up drive here in recent years.

RED BANK, N.J., Feb. 23. -- Scooting over the snow-covered ice of the Navesink River today, the new Wisconsin-built front-steering boat Jack Frost again demonstrated her speed against the fast craft here, many of which are nine times her size.

President ANGELL of Yale University has made discerning answer to the question to which many good citizens have not been able to find one that has been quite satisfying to themselves: "Why should teachers object to taking an oath of loyalty?" First of all, it is because the requirement of such an oath carries "the outrageous initial "implication that teachers are not "loyal" as individuals or as a group.

Coal gas fumes from the Furnace in the basement of a five-story apartment house at 1,537 White Plains Road, near Guerlain Street, the Bronx, overcame three occupants of the building and temporarily dazed four others shortly before 11 o'clock yesterday morning.

C. B. Lee in your issue of Feb. 8 refers to the injustice of the government's paying the remaining benefits under the old AAA contracts, as the payments in many cases relate to the 1936 crop and farmers have suffered no financial injury.

The Supreme Court in the NRA decision having warned Congress against delegating "unfettered discretion" to administrative officials, and in the AAA decision having declared that Congress cannot regulate agricultural production, the two houses of Congress have now passed what is called the Soil Conservation Bill.

Demolition of the Second Avenue elevated line and the construction of a tunnel by-pass in Second Avenue to relieve traffic congestion near the Queensboro Bridge will be the objectives of an intensive campaign culminating in a mass meeting early next month, the First Avenue Association announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 (AP). -- Chicago's Black Hawks stirred up their biggest offensive effort of the National Hockey League season tonight to trounce the Toronto Maple Leafs, 5 to 1, before 12,000 spectators in the Chicago Stadium.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 23. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 83.8, which compares with 83.4 the week before, 83.5 two weeks before, 84 three weeks before and 83.9 four weeks before.

With sugar futures buoyant at the close of the period, and other commodities sharply lower as a result of widespread liquidation in advance of March deliveries, commodity futures markets were active throughout most of the past week. On the cash markets wheat, oats, raw sugar, eggs and antimony advanced, while cotton, corn, rye, Santos coffee, cocoa, lard, copper, tin, silk, wool tops, rubber and hides lost ground.

Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey warned last night that a "crisis" faces the State Saturday when all funds for the care of needy will have been expended. He spoke over Station WOR in an appeal to the State Legislature to act quickly so funds may be made available, and declared that $5,400,000 must be raised to provide relief until the end of March.

MONTREAL, Feb. 23. -- Announcement was made here tonight of a new offer that had been submitted for reorganization of Price Brothers Co., Ltd., newsprint concern, seeking its removal from bankruptcy and making provision for adequate working capital.

The National Association of Tobacco Distributors voted yesterday at the close of its annual convention to urge the passage of an amendment to the Social Security Act which would compel employers of four or more workers to pay an unemployment insurance tax on their total payrolls.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 23. -- Two Dartmouth alumni gave of their blood today in an effort to save the life of Latta McCray of Dayton, Ohio, star guard of the Green football team, who was seriously injured yesterday while skiing.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Feb. 23. -- The text of President Roosevelt's radio address in the celebration of Brotherhood Day was as follows:

After six weeks of balloting on the offer of their employers to renew their 1935 wage contract for another year, seamen employed by ship lines operating from ports of the Atlantic seaboard have overwhelmingly decided to demand a new contract at a higher wage level.

CAMDEN, N.J., Feb. 23. -- Six new arrangements of letters may make a bid for recognition as full citizens in the English language as a result of the 105th semi-annual convention of the National Puzzlers League, Inc., which closed here tonight.

CORNING, N.Y., Feb. 23. -- Shipment of the 200-inch telescope disk will wait for better weather, it was learned today from Dr. J.C. Hostetter, director of development and research of the Corning Glass Works.

Nine important indices show gains since Jan. 1 ranging from 3.23 to 116.32 per cent, according to a compilation by Ladenburg, Thalmann Co. The largest gain was in non-residential building. The compilation follows:

1Winnesot, lural (Iredit; Salomon Bros. Yfutzler will offer today a new issue of $845,000 State of ]E[innesota 1.70 per cent rural-credit certificates of indebtedness, dated Feb. 29 and due in 1941, priced to yield 1.60 per cent. The certificates are general obligations of the State, exempt from all present Federal income and Minnesota State taxes.

Breaking 98 out of 100 targets, L.F. Sanman annexed the high scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. He also won the scratch trophy in the shoot at 155 targets, returning a card of 146.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 23. -- Donald Strachan of Philadelphia, defending titleholder, today lost his semi-final match in straight games to Germaine G. Glidden of Harvard in the national squash racquets championship.

Net income of the Sun Oil Company for 1935 was $7,100,238, or $3.45 a share on the 1,886,594 shares of common stock outstanding on Dec. 15, last, before the distribution of a 7 per cent stock dividend, J. Howard Pew, president, stated in his annual report, made public yesterday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 23 (AP). -- Leonard Dodson of Pembine, Wis., defeated Harry Cooper, veteran Chicagoan, by one stroke today in a play-off match to win the $2,500 St. Petersburg open golf tournament. They tied at 283 at the end of the 72-hole play Saturday.

WATERTOWN, Conn., Feb. 23. -- Paul Fessenden Cruikshank will succeed Horace Dutton Taft as headmaster of the Taft School here at the end of the present academic year, it was announced today by the board of trustees.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 23. -- Twenty-four members of the senior class and eight members of the junior class of Princeton University have been nominated to membership in Phi Beta Kappa, honorary scholastic organization, it was announced here today by Professor Whitney J. Oates, secretary of the Princeton Chapter.

The altercation between the Legislature and the Executive as to the source and nature of the opposition to certain of the so-called "crime bills" has diverted attention from the drastic features of other bills, the enactment of which would impose unnecessary hardships on law-abiding citizens, without in any way decreasing crime.

BERLIN, Feb. 21. -- Money was easy during most of this week, and Gold Discount Bank promissory notes were bought. Later, offers of cash abated, but the day loan rate remained low today at 2 1/2 to 2 3/4 per cent. Virtually all Reichsbank credits given in the last week of January were repaid by Feb. 15.

Two men were burned fatally and a third is in a serious condition despite the efforts yesterday of rescuers who crawled through flames to save them in a fire in a rooming house at 339 Johnston Avenue, Jersey City.

MOSCOW, Feb. 23. -- The Soviet Government's proposal to Japan for a commission to investigate and prevent border incidents between the Mongolian People's Republic and Manchukuo, as revealed in a Toss news agency statement last night, is the first formal, official admission here of Soviet concern over the external relations of the Mongolian State.

PENSACOLA, Fla., Feb. 24. -- Flanked by an admiring group of some 160 pupils of the Bill Terry School for Higher Baseball, the staff of pitchers and catchers upon whom Memphis Bill will pin his 1936 pennant hopes swung briskly into action today as the Giants officially launched their training campaign in the new quarters at Legion Field.

The Mack utility investigating committee was authorized by joint resolution of the State Legislature in April, 1934, after the Federal Trade Commission had uncovered the letters linking Senator WARREN THAYER to a utility company payroll. In the report it has now submitted, it finds, with a few exceptions, "no impropriety" existing between any member of the State Legislature or public officer and any person interested in public utility companies.

The upheaval in the writers' project, which began with the recent dismissal for "insubordination and inefficiency" of Samuel Duff McCoy as assistant director, continued yesterday with the transfer to other WPA jobs of fourteen employes, described as leaders in the factional warfare which has impeded progress of the project.

GRAND JUNCTION, Tenn., Feb. 24 (AP). -- Dr. Blue Willing, white and lemon pointer owned by L.D. Johnson of Evansville, Ind., set a high mark over a muddy eight-mile course today for twenty-four other dogs entered in the national championship bird trials.

ALBANY, Feb. 24. -- In tonight's session of the Senate the bill reducing present jury exemptions, one of the crime series, went through with practically no debate. Up-State Republicans who had held it up were satisfied when volunteer firemen who have served five years were continued exempt.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 (AP). -- The first meeting of champions in the ninth annual Golden Gloves tournament tonight ended in a technical knockout triumph for Johnny Brown of Chicago over Patsy Urso, Detroit veteran of amateur boxing.

The annual dinner dance in behalf of the Barat Settlement was held last night in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the women's auxiliary of the settlement. Proceeds will aid the work of the settlement, which carries on an extensive educational and recreational program for adults and children in a crowded district of the city.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- Capital artists and judicial circles wondered today whether a figure in a mural sketch drawn for a Federal building (a figure giving a helping hand to a group of underprivileged) was that of Justice Harlan F. Stone of the Supreme Court.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Feb. 24. -- After a two-day visit to Hyde Park House, his mother's home here, President Roosevelt left for Washington at midnight to begin active preparation of a new tax bill, in conference with administration leaders on Capitol Hill.

A banking group headed by Edward B. Smith Co. and R.H. Moulton Co., Inc., yesterday won bonds of Los Angeles County, Calif., taking all of the bonds as 3 1/4s. The group paid 100.63 for $4,279,000 of city school district bonds, maturing from 1938 to 1961; 100.62 for $3,758,000 of city high school bonds, due from 1938 to 1961, and 100.59 for $356,000 of junior college district bonds, due from 1937 to 1961.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 24. -- Columbia's basketball team topped Dartmouth, 35 -- 34, tonight in a sensational game, marked by an orgy of foul calling unsurpassed in Hanover in many years. The teams battled from start to finish at a foul-a-minute pace.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- An assertion that 40,000,000 persons, or about a third of the population of the country, would apparently be government tenants if the administration's housing program were carried to a logical conclusion was made in a brief filed with the Supreme Court today.

Isidore Goldberg, millinery importer, who did business as I. Goldberg, Inc., grossing as much as $3,000,000 a year, admitted yesterday on the witness stand that he had paid bribes to examiners at the United States appraisers' stores to have them undervalue the merchandise he was receiving.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- The Senate passed a bill exempting from State and Federal taxation preferred stock, capital notes and debentures of banks in possession of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation; adopted the Byrd resolution for an investigation of methods of reorganizing the Federal Government with a view to economy; confirmed the appointment of Ralph L. Emmors as District Attorney for Northern New York and recessed at 4:19 P.M. until noon tomorrow.

ROME, Feb. 24. -- Following a meeting between Premier Benito Mussolini and the German Ambassador, Ulrich von Hassel, who has just returned from Berlin after a series of conferences with Chancellor Adolf Hitler, Rome today was full of rumors of a five-power agreement, supposedly in discussion among Italy, Germany, Poland, Austria and Hungary, to counter-balance the Franco-Soviet pact.

A deal for property adjoining the American Radiator Company's tall building in West Fortieth Street is reported to be pending between the radiator firm and the Bowery Savings Bank, owner of the parcels involved.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 24. -- Tired but cheerful after an unexpected four and one-half day extension of their West Indian holiday cruise, the Furness-Withy liner Nova Scotia's 103 passengers were landed by tender at Hamilton at 2 o'clock this afternoon and were accommodated at a Hamilton hotel.

The general belief that Gene Venzke and Glenn Cunningham would be rematched for another mile race before the end of the season was turned to certainty yesterday when Director Frank A. Brennan announced that they would meet in the Columbian Mile that will feature the annual Knights of Columbus track carnival at the Garden on March 14.

WINTER PARK, Fla., Feb. 24. -- Citing statements made by Herbert Hoover, Alfred E. Smith and Senator Joseph T. Robinson as examples to be condemned, Owen D. Young, industrialist and chairman of the advisory council of the National Broadcasting Company, pleaded today for greater temperance of language in radio addresses.

William M. Calder, former United States Senator, heads the list of delegates and alternates designated by the Brooklyn Republican organization for the National Convention, according to an announcement yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 24. -- The stock markets here were quiet today and generally easier. There was less demand for British funds, but they held firm. Brazilian and Continental European securities declined in the foreign market. Home rails weakened further and the foreign issues were dull. Internationals were dull and lower.

The American Institute of Architects has initiated a movement to "achieve a higher national housing level and to improve building and mortgage standards" through cooperative efforts of architects, builders, government agencies and financial institutions.

A Brooklyn grocery store proprietor was shot and killed about 6:30 o'clock last night by one of two bandits who attempted to rob the shop owned by him and his two brothers at 203 Avenue U, Brooklyn. Both robbers escaped, apparently on foot.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 24. -- Asserting that work relief was the American way of meeting the unemployment problem, the South and Southwest regional groups of the United States Conference of Mayors went on record in closing their session here today as favoring continuation of the Works Progress Administration by the Federal Government.

Sir Auckland Geddes, former British Ambassador to the United States; Rear Admiral A.F. Forbes-Sempill of the British Navy, Sir James and Lady Calder and the Duchess of Lecera, lady in waiting to the ex-Queen of Spain, are among the notables arriving today from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 24 (AP). -- The streets of old New Orleans echoed the merriment of thousands tonight as the lid was thrown off for the approaching climax of the city's historic Mardi Gras.
In requesting license holders to provide detailed reports of their take of fish and game, the New York Conservation Department is not interested primarily in obtaining statistics.
Van Alstyne, Noel Co., Inc., have prepared a study of earnings for the last four years of the Port of New York Authority, covering all operations and including income from the general reserve fund.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

LONDON, Feb. 24. -- The Court of Criminal Appeal today refused to allow bail to John Howeson, one-time dictator of the world's tin industry, and Louis Hardy, director of many of his companies, who are now in Wormwood Scrubbs prison, starting a year's sentence for issuing a fraudulent prospectus.

An eight-story loft building at 8 East Forty-first Street and two five-story apartment houses at the northwest corner of Columbus Avenue and Eighty-fourth Street were among the four Manhattan parcels bought in by plaintiffs at Manhattan foreclosure auctions yesterday.

A drastic reorganization for the Chicago North Western Railway was predicted in the report for 1935, issued yesterday by Fred W. Sargent, president. The company entered bankruptcy last June, and since then the management has had intermittent conferences with insurance companies on reorganization terms.

Experiments at Bellevue Hospital showing that the noise resulting from the explosion of an inflated paper bag raised the pressure on the brain to four times normal were described last night at the New York Academy of Medicine by Dr. Foster Kennedy, professor of neurology at Cornell University Medical College and attending physician in charge of the neurology department at Bellevue.

MADRID, Feb. 24. -- Under pressure from Socialists, who are not represented in the government, but whose votes made possible the Left coalition's victory in the Spanish general election, the Azana Cabinet today decreed the reinstatement of all employes who were dismissed for participation in the Marxist revolutionary general strike in October, 1934.

The front of Carpenters' Hall, a four-story brick building at 217 Court Street, near Wyckoff Street, Brooklyn, collapsed at 2:20 P.M. yesterday, slightly injuring one of five workmen who were renovating a store front on the first floor. Five other persons in the building, which is used as a headquarters for several unions, escaped unhurt down a rear fire-escape.

MONTREAL, Feb. 24. -- Heavy firing along several fronts resulted in spectacular gains by almost a dozen players and affected some of the leading positions in both groups, weekly statistics of the National Hockey League showed tonight.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 24. -- The Nassau County Board of Supervisors approved today a resolution empowering County Attorney James L. Dowsey to start proceedings for the acquisition of land for the widening of Franklin Avenue from the Garden City line to Mill Road, Hempstead.

Government bond dealers found little pertinent information concerning the government's forthcoming financing, other than the date of the formal announcement, which is next Monday, In Secretary Morgenthau's statement, issued late yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- The American General Corporation of Jersey City has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $22,000,000 of 4 per cent debentures due on April 1, 1956, with ten-year purchase warrants for common stock attached and 440,000 shares of 10 cent par value common stock.

RED BANK, N.J., Feb. 24. -- Attacked by a big airedale while leading with Ruppert and Gillig's ice yacht Eskimo in today's race, Oscar Brand, skipper, was forced to bring the craft up into the wind in the first lap and withdraw from competition before he was able to fight off the vicious animal.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- In stressing Governor Landon's especial availability for the Presidential nomination of his party, his record as a budget-balancer has been particularly emphasized and, if the Republican standard is entrusted to him, that -- in contrast with the Federal deficit under President Roosevelt -- will be one of his chief reliances for votes.

About 25,000 employes of the General Motors Corporation In the United States and Canada have received more than $11,000,000 in cash and stock of that company in the annual disbursement under the General Motors Corporation's Employes Savings and Investment Plan, it was announced yesterday by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of General Motors.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 24. -- Mr. and Mrs. Lisle E. Pritchard of New York, who are guests of Mrs. Pritchard's mother, Mrs. Mercer P. Moseley, at her Winter residence in Miami Beach, will be the honor guests at a party to be given by Richard Ford at his residence on Friday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24. -- While the arrivals of hogs here today were somewhat below trade expectations, the demand was not aggressive and prices were steady to as much as 20 cents a hundredweight lower compared with those on Friday. Hogs weighing over 275 pounds were the hardest to sell.

Mail orders received in the market here yesterday were reported somewhat more numerous than at the beginning of last week, reflecting in part an accumulation over the holiday week-end. However, some retailers are noting an improved consumer response to initial Spring offerings and, with the first signs of moderating weather, will launch their new offerings aggressively.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- Refusing to take immediate action on the proposal of the Committee for Industrial Organization, which offered to finance to the extent of $500,000 an organization campaign in the steel industry, President William Green decided today to lay the matter before the Executive Council of the A.F. of L.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 24. -- In the best Western manner, with only the substitution of a truck for horses, armed thieves held up the conductor of a train here tonight and, after breaking into four freight cars, escaped with a quantity of valuable merchandise.

Lower quotations in Liverpool, a sharp break in silk, selling of new crop months by houses with Japanese connections and March liquidation preparatory to notices today caused a decline of 8 to 13 points in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday.

BERLIN, Feb. 24. -- Having legalized dueling in the army and among student groups, National Socialist spokesmen now demand extension of the dueling right and presumably of the concomitant right to bear arms to all German men.

Members of a special committee of national turf authorities will meet in Louisville, Ky., during Kentucky Derby week to formulate plans for an organization to inaugurate an international race meeting, it was announced yesterday by John F. Shevlin, secretary of the New York State Racing Commission.

In the brochure about Bernard College called "A Review of the Years" circulated at the dinner in honor of Dean Gildersleeve I regret that the number of the first class is given as fourteen. I don't know how this error crept into the records, unless that -- having but little clerical help -- the students in botany became confused with the regular students.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 24 (AP). -- The whereabouts of Hank Leiber, hard-hitting young outfielder of the Giants, was as big a mystery tonight as whether he will sign a contract for the 1936 season.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- Secretary Morgenthau said today that a financing program to refund about $450,000,000 of Treasury bills maturing on March 16 and $558,819,200 of Treasury notes due on April 15, and to raise whatever new money it was felt was needed would be announced on Monday.

DUBLIN, Feb. 24 (Canadian Press). -- The British people must recognize the right of the Irish not only to determine their form of government but also their relations with the United Kingdom, President Eamon de Valera said today. He stressed that such an attitude was essential as a step toward lasting Anglo-Irish friendship.
Dr. George J. Ryan, president of the Board of Education, prepared yesterday to take to the public his fight for a $300,000,000 State bond issue for new school construction throughout the State.
LONDON, Feb. 24 (AP). -- A 7 1/2-pound son was born to the former Barbara Hutton today and began life with the assets of a European title and the prospect of inheriting a Woolworth fortune.
A one-man show of water-colors (Maine landscapes) by William Zorach opens today at the Downtown Gallery, 113 West Thirteenth Street. It is his first show in this medium since 1932.

The "under-maintenance policy," on which the Long Island Railroad based an appeal for additional revenues, was the subject a sharp of attack by Leon G. Godley, Transit Commissioner, and George R. Lunn, Public Service Commissioner, yesterday at the fourteenth hearing on the railroad's application for an increase in commutation rates.

Possibilities of an adjustment of the issues involved in the controversy between the Fashion Originators Guild of America and leading retail stores were seen here yesterday as it became known that a conference between officials of the guild and E.J. Frost, vice president of William Filene's Sons Company, Boston, is scheduled to be held this morning at the offices of the guild.

American men have become more style-conscious and now are more particular than they were to select clothing that reflects their individuality and enhances their personality, it was declared yesterday at the opening of the seventeenth annual Men's Style Show of the New York Custom Cutters Club at the Hotel Commodore.

The sixtieth international six-day bicycle race spun past the twenty-four-hour mark last night in Madison Square Garden with a crowd of about 10,000 cycling fans yelling their encouragement to the teams in the grind.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 24. -- In two court actions the Strutwear Knitting Company, closed because of labor difficulties since August, moved today against State and city officials, holding them responsible for loss of business.

Herbert M. Weiss, bookkeeper employed by John T. Brook when the latter was president of the Pelham National Bank, testified yesterday in Federal Court, that at Brook's request in 1929 he had signed notes that had put him $20,500 in debt to the bank.

ALBANY, Feb. 24. -- Reiterating a recommendation that the Legislature create a State commission to cooperate in making a success of the world's fair of 1939 in New York City. Governor Lehman expressed willingness tonight to confer later with city, State and fair officials to devise ways and means of insuring success for the fair.

With a profusion of novelty items which ranged from $200 glass vanity tables to 50-cent brass and copper ash trays, 250 manufacturers of giftwares yesterday offered Spring and Summer lines at the semi-annual New York gift show being held this week at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Nineteen applications for amateur riders' certificates were granted by the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association at a meeting of the executive committee of the board of stewards, it was announced yesterday by Frank J. Bryan, secretary.
A short time ago an editorial "A Warning on Water' was published in THE TIMES, and the public was informed that "the present outlook can fairly be called critical."

NO one could take exception to the statement in your editorial on "The 'Travel' Mark" that "it is now generally agreed" that currency management "has reached its highest point of thoroughness in Germany."

" Little Paddy" McGuire, the miniature handyman at City College, climbed the iron stairs to the roof of the main tower of the administration building to put the flag at half-staff in tribute to Henry L. Roosevelt. He came back with a large sea gull under one arm.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Feb. 24. -- Snow Flake, F. Bliss Price's speedy Class A ice yacht, jumped into the lead in the point standing for the Long Branch Ice Boat and Yacht Club's Board of Trade Cup as she outsailed five other club yachts to win two contests ver a ten-mile course on the South Shrewsbury River today.

LONDON, Feb. 24. -- Italy threw a new obstacle into the path of the naval conference today by announcing that no naval agreement could bind her until League of Nations sanctions had been withdrawn and until the British fleet had been recalled from the Mediterranean.

MOSCOW, Feb. 24. -- While Soviet anxiety over the Far East was noticeably relaxed today by the apparent victory of the moderate Minseito party in the Japanese elections, Marshal Vassily Bluecher has issued a general order to the special Far Eastern Red Army to be on the alert as never before against the danger of attack.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 24. -- Motion pictures showed today that Top Row, winner of $104,600 in the Santa Anita Handicap on Saturday, interfered with Time Supply, Rosemont, Azucar and Whopper, his contenders in the furious stretch drive for the world's richest turf prize, which totaled $135,700.

Negotiations for a new agreement to take the place of the one expiring March 31 were begun here yesterday by leaders of the United Mine Workers, headed by John L. Lewis, and a committee of Pennsylvania anthracite operators. The joint conference of miners and operators met at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- After unexpectedly sharp opposition, the Senate passed today the administration bill to exempt from Federal and State taxation all preferred stock, capital notes and debentures of banks held by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, and also all income therefrom.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 24. -- Condemned as "an unfortunate hybrid,'' the Relief Administration's "emergency education" came in for hard words today from both speakers and resolutions drafted by the resolutions committee, at the annual convention of the department of superintendence of the National Education Association.

JAFFA, Palestine, Feb. 24. -- Arab labor pickets attacked construction work on government school buildings here today and stoned Jewish laborers and policemen, dangerously wounding one British constable and seriously damaging a building.

TRENTON, Feb. 24. -- An attack upon Governor Harold C. Hoffman for his activities in the Hauptmann case developed tonight on the floor of the Legislature when Republican members accused the Governor of devoting himself to a "will o' the wisp" and neglecting the relief problem.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Feb. 19 shows increases for the week of $18,000,000 in total loans and investments, $31, 000,000 in Reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $51,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and $44,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks, and a decrease of $23,000,000 in government deposits.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 24. -- A jury was selected this morning in the Court of Quarter Sessions here to try four former deputy sheriffs on a charge of manslaughter in the fatal shooting last September of Mrs. John Crempa, Scotch Plains farmer's wife.

There was little or nothing in the news over the holiday week-end calculated to give followers of the share market a clue to what may logically be expected, marketwise, in the immediate future, and trading yesterday was hesitant. Share prices held within narrow limits throughout the day, edging lower in the slowest trading for a full day since Jan. 22.

LONDON, Feb. 24. -- The United States is "infinitely stronger" today than at any time during her participation in the World War, Sir Austen Chamberlain declared in a discussion of world affairs tonight at the annual dinner of the Birmingham Chamber of Commerce.

OTTAWA, Feb. 24. -- Western cattle raisers of British Columbia, lumber mill operators of Ontario, whisky distillers and, to a lesser extent, fishermen of the Maritime Provinces have reaped a considerable advantage from the new trade treaty between Canada and the United States.
ROME, Feb. 24 (AP). -- Marshal Pietro Badoglio, Italian commander-in-chief in East Africa, reported today: "Nothing special except intense road building activity occurred on the Eritrean front.

The Irving Air Chute Company has declared a quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock. This places the stock on an annual dividend basis of $1 a share, compared with a former rate of 60 cents.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 24. -- The two "toughest boys in Newark," one 7 and the other 8 years old, were held as juvenile delinquents tonight after they admitted ringing a dozen false fire alarms in the last month and proudly told how they "ganged up" on other children to steal their pennies, candy and toys.

OBERLIN, Ohio, Feb. 24 (AP). -- Scientists and educators honored the memory of Charles M. Hall today at the opening of a celebration marking the semi-centennial of his discovery of producing aluminum through the electrolytic process.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP). -- Representative Treadway of Massachusetts charged today that an Agriculture Department report on "cotton production in the United States" had been "doctored" to withhold facts from the public.

ATLANTA, Feb. 24 (AP). -- Governor Eugene Talmadge ousted two State officials today on charges of misconduct in office for their refusal to honor warrants under the financial "dictatorship" he set up Jan. 1.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 (AP). -- An eleven-point program for reform in public utilities was introduced in the Senate tonight on recommendation of the committee to investigate utilities, whose report was published yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- Evelyn Laye and an able supporting cast captured Washington theatre-goers tonight in the American premiere of "Sweet Aloes," the British comedy by Jay Mallory.

BERLIN, Feb. 24. -- Trading on the Boerse was quiet and mixed today, with no definite tendency developing. Heavy industrials fell slightly, Mannesmann losing 1/2 point and Hoesch 1/8. Potashes were totally stagnant and chemicals quiet, I.G. Farben losing 1/4 point.
SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 24. -- Removal of General Hagood threw army circles here into a turmoil of indignation today.

In an address last night before the American Association of Social Workers at 315 Lexington Avenue, William Hodson, Commissioner of Public Welfare and member of the Emergency Relief Bureau, urged that the 13,000 employes engaged in the administration of relief in this city under the direction of the ERB be placed on a civil service basis.

TEL AVIV, Palestine, Feb. 24 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency). -- Miss Henrietta Szold, a New York social worker and Zionist leader, replied today to Palestine Jewry's greetings on her seventy-fifth birthday, stating that without their assistance she could have achieved nothing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- The Senate directed today that a study be made of the machinery of the Federal Government with a view to recommendations to the next Congress for reorganization and simplification in the interest of economy.
Ten batterymen seeking places on the 1936 varsity baseball team at Fordham University reported to Coach Jack Coffey yesterday afternoon in the college gymnasium for the first workout of the season.

There were many supper parties in connection with "A Night in Bermuda" given last night in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center for the benefit of the Victoria Home for Aged British Men and Women, Ossining, N.Y. It was the final event in a series held in conjunction with the Bermuda show at the British Empire Exhibition, under the auspices of the British Chamber of Commerce.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 24 (AP). -- American women who served overseas during the World War were praised today by Mrs. Herbert Hoover for having worked "as efficiently, as effectively, as untiringly as though you were doing it under the most ideal homeland conditions of any 'business or professional' woman."

BELGRADE, Feb. 24. -- Before leaving the Yugoslav capital today Premier Milan Hodza of Czechoslovakia conferred with Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch, who gave Yugoslavia's consent to participate in negotiations regarding a Danubian pact, accepting Mr. Hodza's plan in principle.
Further activity on Cooper Street, in the Inwood section of Manhattan, was indicated by building plans filed yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 24. -- A pall of fog over London today, turning daylight into complete darkness, was graphic proof of a report the Department of Scientific and Industrial Research has just issued asserting that pollution of the atmosphere of England by sulphur and smoke is steadily growing worse.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- Charges made by Representative Brewster of Maine of wasteful expenditures for housing and the furnishings of houses and dormitories for engineering and administrative personnel at the Passamaquoddy project were denied today by Major Gen. Edward M. Markham, Chief of Army Engineers, in a letter to Mr. Brewster.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 24. -- Former President Eusebio Ayala of Paraguay, who has been a prisoner of the new regime since last Monday, has been moved to Asuncion police headquarters, where he will remain a prisoner until the government has decided what to do with him, according to today's dispatches from Asuncion.

ALBANY, Feb. 24. -- The Senate passed four more bills in Governor Lehman's tax program tonight and thus, with the exception of one taxi bill, shifted to the Republican Assembly the entire Lehman budget and tax schedule.

DETROIT, Feb. 24. -- In a statement in which he accused President Roosevelt and Postmaster General Farley of breaking political agreements made in 1932, former Governor William A. Comstock today announced his resignation from the Democratic party, of which he has been one of the wheel horses for nearly thirty years.
LEEDS, England, Feb. 24. -- Experts dealt a shattering blow here today to the claims of Italians for their "wool" made from milk.

ADDIS ABABA, Feb. 24. -- Your correspondent at the northern headquarters of the Ethiopian army reports outstanding successes for two flying columns dispatched by Ras Imru from his camp a few miles west of Aksum on the Selaclaca road last week.

OURAY, Col., Feb. 24 (AP). -- A three-mile-wide snow avalanche killed a woman and two men today and imprisoned twoscore miners in the famous old Camp Bird gold mine for several hours. They were later released.
In his speech at Rollins College yesterday, Mr. OWEN D. YOUNG made, with characteristic urbanity, moderation and literary charm, a suggestion that must appeal strongly to thoughtful men and women.

PORTSMOUTH, England, Feb. 24. -- The late King left instructions that his famous racing cutter Britannia be broken up if none of his sons would take her over. As matters stand at present this fate seems certain to befall her, for neither Edward VIII nor any of his brothers is inclined to continue Britannia in commission as a racing craft.

BERLIN, Feb. 24. -- The white tie and swallow-tail full-dress suit have been rehabilitated in the Third Reich as something the well-dressed "racial comrade" may wear in the evening. And this rehabilitation is backed by no less an authority than Dr. Joseph Goebbels, the Propaganda Minister.
LONDON, Feb. 24. -- Foregoing is the text of the address of Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden before the House of Commons today:

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 24. -- Faust, Florida Derby hope of the Wheatley Stable, scored his first victory of the season in the featured Fort Pierce Purse that attracted nine 3-year-olds at Hialeah Park today. Although seldom out of the money, the son of Diavolo had disappointed many times, this being the second triumph of his career.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- Major Gen. Johnson Hagood, commander of the Eighth Corps Area and the Third Field Army and critic of the WPA, was relieved of his command today and ordered to his home at Charleston, S.C., "to await orders."
LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 24 (AP). -- For the first time in twenty years Nebraska's primary election ballot this year will not carry the name of former Governor Charles W. Bryan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- The special House committee which will investigate the Townsend plan and other proposals for old-age pensions will meet on Wednesday to map out their program. Due to absence from the city of some of its members a committee meeting scheduled for today was postponed to Wednesday.

Social announcements have an etiquette not more delicate and intricate than those of Presidential candidates. A technique has to be followed by them as carefully as by Mr. and Mrs. Rospogliosi Smith announcing the engagement of their daughter Persephone Jane to Mr. Winkelried Jones.

Andre Perugia, who makes shoes for the new Empress of Manchukuo, for the remaining queens of Europe and for the noble ladies of Burke's Peerage and the Almanach de Gotha, said here yesterday that American women were ruining their arches in pursuit of a false idea of what constitutes an aristocratic foot.

Firemen, policemen and Department of Sanitation employes at work on Columbus Avenue cooperated yesterday to rescue thirty persons from a fire in a five-story tenement at 100 West Ninety-second Street.
WINTER PARK, Fla., Feb. 24. -- The text of Owen D. Young's address at Rollins College was as follows:
RYE, N.Y., Feb. 24. -- New Rochelle High and Greenwich (Conn.) High scored overwhelming victories in Westchester Interscholastic Ice Hockey League games at Playland Casino tonight.

Brooklyn College, the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club and Union Temple gained the quarter-final bracket, while the Brooklyn Jewish Center reached the second round by scoring triumphs in Metropolitan A.A.U. basketball tournament games in Brooklyn last night.
