WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- The House agreed quickly today to a conference with the Senate on the new $500,000,000 Soil Conservation Bill.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- Representative Cooper, Republican, of Ohio declared today the order relieving General Hagood of duty was akin to "Hitler policies,"

LONDON, Feb. 24. -- Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, may leave that office soon to become the coordinator of the three defense departments under the government scheme that is to be announced next month for British rearmament.

" No experiment to establish the ether can prove that I am right," EINSTEIN is reported to have said when his theory of relativity was first announced, "but a single experiment may prove that I am wrong." Thus encouraged, at least a dozen experimenters have for years been trying to measure the velocity of light in the direction in which the earth is traveling in its orbit and again in a direction at right angles.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 24. -- More than 2,000 men and women on relief stormed the State House here tonight while their leader, granted the privilege of addressing the Legislature, warned the members of "trouble" unless they act to provide relief funds after March 1.

The problem of combating the lung disease silicosis, which affects workers in so-called dust industries, will be discussed by the Board of Health on March 10, Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health and president of the board, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24, -- The administrative officials of the regional offices of the Securities and Exchange Commission will confer here, from March 9 to 13, on cooperation in administration of the provisions of the Securities Act of 1933, the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 24. -- Following his upset victory yesterday over the defending titleholder, Donald Strachan of Philadelphia, Germaine G. Glidden of Englewood, N.J., a Harvard undergraduate and protege of Lawrence Cowles, coach of such other champions as Rawlins, Dixon and the Pool brothers, won the national squash racquets crown at the Hartford Golf Club today by halting Andrew C. Ingraham of Cleveland.

After a long and honorable career in England "Love on the Dole" has finally come to the Shubert, where it was acted last evening. It is welcome; in fact, it is virtually prescribed as theatregoing. For Ronald Gow and Walter Greenwood have turned Mr. Greenwood's novel of the same title into one of the most honest social dramas of our time.

LONDON, Feb. 24. -- Anthony Eden today made his first speech to the House of Commons since he had become British Foreign Secretary. His address had been anxiously awaited because of the strained situation throughout Europe since the Hoare-Laval peace program broke down.

Ralph Valladares's goal from the side in the last eighteen seconds of an overtime period provided the Textile High quintet with a thrilling 26-to-25 victory over Stuyvesant in a Manhattan Division P.S.A.L. meeting on the James Monroe court yesterday.

BOSTON, Feb. 24. -- Governor Curley spent $115,000 out of his own pocket in the campaign in Massachusetts to elect President Roosevelt, he told the President while riding in an automobile with him Saturday.

Plans were announced yesterday by the James Butler Grocery Company to sell out its 483 chain stores to present managers and organize a voluntary chain of about 2,000 owner-managed stores within a seventy-five-mile radius of Long Island City.

Speakers at a symposium arranged by the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities agreed last night that public relief is a right, not a privilege, although they stipulated the needy must be deserving and discharge their obligations to society. The meeting, which was open to the public, was held in the bureau's auditorium, 285 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, made it known today after a conference with James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, that the Exchange would not make an appearance at the hearings beginning tomorrow before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee on the bill submitted by the commission to continue and expand unlisted trading on national security exchanges.

Rather than have the pet green parrot that had been given to her by friends in Mexico subjected to fourteen days' quarantine at the Hoffman Island, Mrs. Cora Lazansky, wife of Edward Lazansky, presiding justice of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, threw the bird through a porthole from the steamship Yucatan of the Ward Line while the vessel was anchored off Quarantine yesterday.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 24. -- Miss Charlotte Darling, star of the Germantown Cricket Club, paced the field into the semifinal round as competition in the ninth annual women's invitation squash racquets tournament started on the courts of the Ardsley Country Club today.

The kidnapping charge made last week by Joachim F. Paffrath, former financial secretary of the Deutscher Konsum Verband, an adjunct of the Friends of the New Germany, against six fellow-members, showed signs of breaking down in Felony Court yesterday when Paffrath admitted he had not been forcibly taken from the liner Deutschland on the night of Feb. 16, as he previously had charged.

A burglar looted the penthouse of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph I. Straus atop of 115 East Eighty-sixth Street on Saturday. Jewelry valued at $9,000 was taken from Mrs. Straus's bedroom. A maid and the cook were in other parts of the twelve-room apartment at the time.

STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 24. -- In letters to leaders of both houses of Congress today, Lester P. Barlow, Stamford inventor, asked the appointment of a commission to examine in secret his new military proposal, which, he said, would enable the President to convince the nations of the world of the futility of hoping for protection by increasing armaments.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 24. -- The army, police and public will pay tribute tomorrow to Colonel E. Francis Riggs, insular police chief, who was slain yesterday. He will be buried in the post cemetery of the Sixty-fifth Infantry.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- A total of 1,912 firms employing more than 977,000 maintained NRA wage and hour provisions after the Schechter decision and 1,448 firms employing more than 405,000 did not, according to a survey of companies having government contracts.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 24. -- Two hundred members of the Old Guard Society of Palm Beach golfers and their guests gathered tonight in the grand loggia of the Breakers for their annual banquet, at which Ellsworth C. Warner, president, awarded trophies won at this Winter's tournaments.

Convinced that the Assembly was trying to choke the anti-crime measures prepared by experts, including the three great State agencies for the improvement of law and justice created by the Legislature, Governor LEHMAN laid his case before the people. His broadcast address Sunday was a dispassionate review of the history of the bills and their treatment in the Assembly.
The Central Park Casino has pulled down its flag and conceded defeat in its long battle with Park Commissioner Moses over the latter's right to void its ten-year lease and evict it.

Creation of a bureau of industrial relations to function in the maritime field has been recommended to shipping operators by J. Caldwell Jenkins, vice president of the Black Diamond Steamship Corporation, it was announced yesterday.

The estate of Mrs. Dorothea Harding, widow of J. Horace Harding, who was trustee of the Frick art collection and chairman of the American Railway Express Company, was appraised yesterday at $2,720,389 gross and $2,400,542 net. Mrs. Harding died Feb. 23, 1935, a resident of Rumson, N.J.

Organized selling will be applied to the building material and construction field through the establishment of Housing Guilds throughout the country, under the sponsorship of Johns-Manville dealers. Yesterday the company inaugurated a two-weeks' training course for eighty-eight Eastern seaboard dealers at the Hotel Commodore, at which the company's "packaged" home and modernization campaign was outlined.

BERLIN, Feb. 24. -- Hanns Kerrl, Reich Minister for Church Affairs, was still hesitating today as to what action to take in the face of the deliberate rejection of his claim to authority in the Protestant Church by the confessional clergy's National Synod.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 24. -- Count Damien de Martel, French High Commissioner for Syria, informed the new Syrian Government today that France was ready to negotiate a treaty with Syria and to propose her as a member of the League of Nations.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

One of the least creditable aspects of the Roosevelt Administration has been its record in the matter of the civil service. The number of employes in the executive branch of the Government (wholly aside from those in the army and navy, the Civilian Conservation Corps and on the rolls of the various relief agencies) has increased by more than 235,000 since Mr. ROOSEVELT took office.

Criticizing Mayor La Guardia yesterday for increased realty assessments in the Bronx, Ferdinand Steinfeld, president of the Van Nest and Morris Park Taxpayers Association, said the voters who elected him should now have the right to ask for his impeachment.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 24. -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors rescinded today its approval last week of a resolution containing a joker clause which barred action on a new county charter until next year.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 24. -- Closing fast in the stretch, Smooth, a consistent money horse from V.H. McMullen's stable, whipped six rivals in the mile and a furlong race which topped the card at the Fair Grounds today.

Lent, which begins tomorrow with Ash Wednesday, will be widely observed in this city, not only in the Roman Catholic, Protestant Episcopal and Lutheran parishes, but in many of the other denominations as well.
Wildcat O'Connor, Carbondale, Pa., welterweight, earned a decision over Frankie Blair of Camden, N.J., in the feature bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.
The Harvard and Cornell Club squash racquets teams will meet Thursday at the Yale Club to decide the metropolitan Class C championship for the season.

In an aggressive statement reviewing his repeated efforts to obtain indictments in the murder of Samuel Drukman, Police Commissioner Valentine accused District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Kings County yesterday of having "flatly refused" to heed his demands for resubmission of the case after the April grand jury had failed to indict.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 24. -- Professor Paul H. Fall, Mayor of Hiram, Ohio, and chairman of the Chemistry Department at Hiram College, has been appointed Associate Professor of Chemistry at Williams College. He will take up his new duties here next semester.

Pursuing its program of clarifying the situation surrounding trading in stocks of listed companies which are in receivership, bankruptcy or reorganization, the New York Stock Exchange revealed yesterday two additional steps to aid investors.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- Jouett Shouse, president of the American Liberty League, today sent a telegram to Professor George S. Counts asking whether he had said that the American Liberty League regarded those who "believe in the real liberties" as "Reds, Bolsheviks and Communists."

Steps aimed at the "introduction of a new and more intensive type of trade association activity in the coat and suit industry" were approved last night at the annual meeting of the Industrial Council of Coat, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., at the Hotel New Yorker.

Most commodity futures were lower on the commodity futures markets yesterday, with silk particularly weak in active trading. Sugar was firmer. On the cash markets only wheat, raw sugar and standard tin gained, while cotton, corn, rye, oats, butter, eggs, beef, wool tops, rubber, silk and cocoa declined.

The opening this evening -- and it is the last one of the week -- is "The Postman Always Rings Twice." James M. Cain, who wrote the novel, dramatized it himself (with a little assistance by Russel Crouse). The company includes Richard Barthelmess -- emerging from the movies for his first starring role in the theatre -- Mary Philips, Joseph Greenwald, Walter Vonnegut, Charles Halton, Dudley Clements and Mary Holsman.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- The 1937 Agriculture Supply Bill, carrying $161,863,147, was introduced in the House by the Appropriations Committee today and was immediately taken up for consideration, in the hope of passage by the end of the week.

Mrs. Cartwright Hooker gave a luncheon yesterday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for Miss Lucy Waller of Durham, N.C., who is visiting her sister, Mrs. William D. Carmichael Jr. at her home, 950 Park Avenue. The other guests were Mrs. Carmichael, Mrs. Louis Faugeres Bishop Jr., Mrs. Graham Thompson, Mrs. William Blount, Mrs. Westley M. Hunt, Mrs. Edward Friendly, Mrs. William Chapman, Mrs. Edward Yaggy and Miss Rosalie Bailey.

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 24. -- James S. Hoey, Internal Revenue Collector for the Second District of New York, through an agent, filed seven liens in the Federal District Court here today against the Associated Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries and three against the Associated Securities Corporation for an aggregate of $54,073,224.15 in income taxes, including $613,333.10 in interest charges.

Samuel Fassler, Commissioner of Buildings, accompanied by a group of engineering experts, made another inspection of the Criminal Courts Building yesterday on the recent complaint of the nine General Sessions judges that the structure is unsafe for occupancy.

It was children's evening at Carnegie Hall last night. The National Orchestral Association, which is a training ensemble for youthful instrumentalists, looked and acted like mature veterans compared to the quartet of soloists in their 'teens who were on public view.

When the steamship Haiti of the Colombian Line arrived yesterday morning from the West Indies and Central America, Captain Lawrence W. Long, the master, reported that the ship had passed through a strip several miles long where dead mullet were on the surface "as thick as seaweed."

MADRID, Feb. 24. -- Thirty thousand ardent Spanish politicians are having the time of their lives today. Last week they were all in prison, many serving life sentences. Now they are being feted as martyrs of the Spanish Republic.

ALBANY, Feb. 24. -- Opponents of Governor Lehman's law-enforcement program again trained their guns upon him in the Assembly this evening. The Governor was denounced by several speakers, including the three Assemblymen whom he named in his radio address of last night as leaders of the opposition, as a "character assassin" and a Czar "wielding the longest whip in the world, one reaching from the second floor to the third of the Capitol Building."

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 24. -- Four hundred and forty-six members of the sophomore class of Princeton University were elected to membership in the eighteen upperclass eating clubs today at the end of the two-week "bicker period."

ABOUT four years ago Gene Venzke ran a mile in 4:10 on the Madison Square Garden track and immediately became the high hope and the great expectation for our side in the Olympic Games, or at least the 1,500-meter event on the Olympic program that was being prepared at Los Angeles.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 25. -- Laughing Sun, the big 4-year-old son of Sun Edwin from the New York stable of Mrs. W. Plunket Stewart, showed his flying heels to a small but meritorious field of milers in the featured Wildwood Purse at Hialeah Park today.
The Downtown Athletic Club and Squash Club teams reached the final round of the play-off for the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class B team championship last night.

PARIS, Feb. 25. -- Presenting the Franco-Soviet treaty of mutual assistance as "the encirclement of spirit of aggression," but carefully insisting that that did not necessarily mean encirclement of Germany, Foreign Minister Pierre-Etienne Flandin made a plea for the pact today in the Chamber of Deputies.

DESSYE, Ethiopia, Feb. 25. -- Ethiopian general headquarters here confirms the capture and destruction on Feb. 13 of Rama, an Italian fortified position on the main road from Adowa to Asmara, the Eritrean capital.

ROME, Feb. 25. -- A five-power agreement among Italy, Germany, Poland, Austria and Hungary is thought to have been brought considerably nearer by Anthony Eden's House of Commons speech yesterday. The British Foreign Secretary's remarks gave Italy clearly to understand that Great Britain had not lost faith in sanctions and would press for the application of further coercive measures.

HONGKONG, Wednesday, Feb. 26. -- There is considerable interest at present in South China's reactions to Japanese policies. It is significant that several Japanese of high rank, officials and non-officials, have been visiting South China during the past few months, and the reaction of the leaders at Canton has been openly unfavorable.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 25 -- A bill designed to prevent loss of tax revenue to New Jersey by forbidding New Jersey corporations from merging with out-of-State corporations was before the New Jersey Assembly today after passage by the Senate.

Betty, Sally and Buddy, heralded as the "only live moose family in captivity," arrived in New York yesterday. They formed a vanguard for car after car of "atmosphere," much of it alive, to bring a tang of the northern wild to the National Sportsmen's Show which opens at the Grand Central Palace on Saturday.

Moving swiftly through Harlem yesterday to cut off the raw materials that go into the making of cheap "corn whisky" by hundreds of small still owners, government agents arrested two women and eleven men on charges of failing to report sales of ingredients to the Alcohol Tax Unit of the Internal Revenue Department.

The Spring production promised by Robinson Smith and Frederick W. Ayer turns out to be "Left Turn," by Jean Burton and William DuBois. A satirical play about politics, with a Western city for its setting, it was rumored at one time to have as its leading character a gentleman not unlike Upton Sinclair.

A Columbia scientist, who tried Pavlov's experiments with conditioned reflexes on college boys instead of dogs, reported yesterday, after years of research, that human beings react like animals when they are fatigued or under strong emotional stress.
BERLIN, Feb. 25 (AP). -- The Reichsbank statement as of Feb. 22 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

District Attorney William C. Dodge announced late yesterday afternoon the appointment of John T. Cahill, a former Assistant State Attorney General, as a special Assistant District Attorney on his staff to prosecute the remaining felony and misdemeanor indictments against about twenty officers and directors of four defunct title mortgage companies.
In reference to THE TIMES article "Business Girls Get $78 Dress Budget" -- if the thing were not so absolutely absurd to any intelligent business man or woman, I should "see red."

Mrs. Ethel du Pont Barksdale, daughter of Victor du Pont, one of the early partners in the du Pont business, left an estate appraised yesterday at $4,522,682 gross and $4,451,907 net, of which $3,596,423 was in securities.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Feb. 26. -- With the arrival here today from Japan of the new Ambassador, Hachiro Arita, and the return of Lieut. Gen. Rensuke Isogai, Japan's military attache, by the same steamer, it is expected that there will be immediate resumption of Japanese pressure on China, for Japanese officials candidly admit that "Arita means business."

Bizet's opera "Carmen," with Rosa Ponselle singing the title role, was presented last night by the Metropolitan Opera Association before a large audience that enthusiastically welcomed Miss Ponselle in her first Brooklyn appearance with the Metropolitan this season.

Six members of a New York Nazi organization, who had been arrested on charges of kidnapping one of their resigned members last Saturday as he was about to sail for Germany, were dismissed yesterday by Magistrate George B. De Luca in Felony Court after Assistant District Attorney Raymond Leo had suddenly abandoned prosecution of the case.

Before the Long Island Railroad made its application for an increase in commutation rates it studied a rate reduction and even experimented with several forms of low fares, Andrew Howard Shaw, the Long Island's general passenger agent, told Transit Commissioner Leon G. Godley and Public Service Commissioner George R. Lunn yesterday at the fifteenth of a series of hearings on the Long Island's application of increases in the commutation rates.

Climaxing an afternoon and evening of sensational riding, the field in the sixtieth international six-day bicycle race in progress at Madison Square Garden was reduced to eleven teams last night. Following the close of the 10:30 P.M. sprints three teams retired from the track.

Professor BRIGGS of Teachers College, speaking in St. Louis at Monday's meeting of the National Education Association, called attention to the obligation upon the teachers as a profession to help develop a comprehensive program of education which will make education contribute "more directly, assuredly and completely" to the preservation of democratic society and the promotion of its interests.

Alice Ehlers, Viennese harpsichordist, made her debut here in a recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. She played old music by Bach, Byrd, Pachelbel, Kuhnau, Handel, Couperin, Rameau and Domenico Scarlatti. The re-creation of the characteristic flavor and color of these works requires an artist of imagination and background besides performance on the instrument intended by the composers.

LINDENHURST, L.I., Feb. 25. -- Vincent Kiernan, 16 years old, was accidentally shot and killed here last night by another 16-year-old youth, the local police reported today in announcing that investigation of Kiernan's death had solved thirteen burglaries in Lindenhurst and one in Babylon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- The National Labor Relations Board was caught today between the opposing fires of industrial and craft unionists as its members perused the record in the case of two cigarette and tobacco corporations whose machinist employes, a minority, asked that their organization be designated the proper unit for collective bargaining.

TRENTON, Feb. 25. -- Attorney General David T. Wilentz, who prosecuted Bruno Richard Hauptmann, returned from a Florida vacation today with the declaration that no State witnesses would be recalled for "persecution or to satisfy the whim of any individual."

Because of waning interest by philanthropists in the National Navy Club of New York. Inc., at 93-5 Park Avenue, due to the rare presence of the United States fleet in local waters in recent years. the directors of the club got permission from Supreme Court Justice Levy yesterday to transfer all its property to the Young Men's Christian Association.
The Schenley Distillers Corporation declared yesterday an initial quarterly dividend of $1.37 1/2 per share on the 5 1/2 per cent preferred stock, payable April 1 to stock of record March 16, 1936.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25. -- The market for hogs turned heavy today after opening steady to 10 cents a hundred weight below yesterday's closing, and late sales showed losses of 15 to 25 cents. The early top of $10.40 was the same as yesterday, but late in the day the practical top was $10.25.
The warmest day since Jan. 15 swept into New York yesterday on southwesterly and southerly winds originating in the Gulf of Mexico.

BERLIN, Feb. 25. -- Germany has already passed the foreign political danger zone created by her rearmament and is now able to defy any attempts at foreign interference in her affairs or policies, according to a pamphlet issued by Major Jost, chief of the War Ministry's press department.

The effects of the recent cold wave were strikingly reflected in last week's mortality statistics for New York City, made public yesterday by the Department of Health. Total deaths jumped to 1,980, the highest since the second week of January, 1933, when 2,004 deaths were recorded.

The strong St. John's Prep quintet clinched the Brooklyn Division C.H.S.A.A. championship by routing Holy Trinity, 28 -- 12, last night on the losers' floor after rolling up a 15-4 lead in the first half. The victory was the twelfth in thirteen tournament starts for St. John's.

BERLIN, Feb. 25. -- Mgr. Bannasch, former head of the central information office of the Catholic episcopate in Germany, is reported to have been released from prison tonight in view of the decision to abandon the charges of high treason pending against him.

Mrs. Edward Prime gave a luncheon yesterday at the Beekman for Mrs. William Massena Benjamin. Other guests were Mrs. Lewis L. Delafield, Princess Irbain-Khan Kaplanoff, Mrs. Hamilton Fish Benjamin, Mrs. Olney B. Mairs, Mrs. Winthrop Gardiner, Mrs. E. Guidet Auchincloss, Mrs. Frederick Wells, Mrs. Norman S. Dike, Mrs. A. Perry Osborn, Mrs. James Gore King and Mrs. Alfred Edey.

PARIS, Feb. 25. -- Foreign Minister Pierre-Etienne Flandin today received the Italian Ambassador, Vittorio Cerruti, who presented a note reserving for the future Italy's action with regard to the British fleet's activities in the Mediterranean.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- Gifts of securities made by officers, directors and principal stockholders of corporations in December and previous months, as made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, to which they were reported, aggregated almost $15,000,000.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 25. -- Organized American school administrators took unprecedented action today by registering militant disapproval in two "infringements" of their academic rights, one in Massachusetts and the other in the District of Columbia.

The army properly maintains strict discipline and necessarily denies to its officers complete freedom of speech, particularly in such matters as criticism of their superiors or of civilian departments of the Government. There are on record a number of comparatively recent cases in which soldiers of high rank have been disciplined for the expression of such criticism.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,779,200 barrels, compared with 2,774,250 in the preceding week, a rise of 4,950 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decrease of 12,700 barrels in California and a gain of 8,350 in Louisiana were the important changes.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 25 (AP). -- The University of Miami maintains a classroom on the floor of the Gulf Stream for its students in zoology.

LONDON, Feb. 25. -- The British Cabinet, which is holding daily meetings in an eleventh-hour rush to complete its rearmament program for presentation to Parliament, is now tackling the industrial phase of the undertaking.

F.J. Podesta of the Columbia Club and Thomas D. Flynn of the Bayside Tennis Club, the two top-seeded players in the annual metropolitan Class C squash tennis championship, played up to their ratings yesterday by advancing into the quarter-finals with comparative ease.
LONDON, Feb. 25. -- Various new reports from the Continent concerning what Italy will do or will not do have been received by the British Government with complete calm, tinged by a bit of ridicule.

Cash dividend payments by the companies of the Standard Oil group in the first quarter of this year are estimated at $19,901,570 in a compilation by Carl H. Pforzheimer Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange. In the first quarter of 1935 cash distributions by these companies amounted to $18,122,737, excluding a stock dividend of 1,399,345 shares of the Mission Corporation by the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- The power of the Securities and Exchange Commission to demand public revelation of details regarding over-the-counter securities would be written into law under a bill presented by James M. Landis, chairman of the SEC, to the Senate Banking and Currency Committee at a hearing today.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

BERLIN, Feb. 25. -- The Boerse was stagnant today, with a tendency toward weakness. The explanation was that social considerations overbalanced financial conditions. It is carnival time in the Rhineland and there is even less than the customary almost total lack of interest in securities which is characteristic of the shattered and paralyzed Berlin market.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- The Associated Gas and Electric Company asked the Board of Tax Appeals today for relief from an income tax assessment of $39,911,263, levied against it last December in New York, asserting that the Commissioner of Internal Revenue erred in computing the income of the company and its 150 subsidiaries.

ALBANY, Feb. 25. -- Governor Lehman signed today two Mandelbaum bills to restore the Bureau of Combustibles to the Fire Department and to give the Fire Commissioner in New York City broad powers over fire prevention.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- House and Senate conferees today reached an agreement in only three hours on the Soil Conservation Bill, farm relief measure, clearing the way for speedy enactment.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 25. -- Thousands of sorrowing Baltimoreans paid their last respects today to former Governor Albert C. Ritchie at Christ Protestant Episcopal Church, where the body lay in state.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- Requests by members of Congress for information as to the status of WPA projects approved and under construction in their districts are being refused, Works Progress officials said today.

LONDON, Feb. 25. -- The British Government has been warned to expect an important move from Brussels. The Belgian Government at the present moment is discussing ways and means to remedy a dangerous situation that may be created when the demilitarized zone along the Rhine finally disappears.

Governor HOFFMAN'S latest statement in the BRUNO HAUPTMANN case ends on an emphatic note. If his alleged discoveries about the Whited testimony are not significant, "then I "do not know just what is important "in the case." But that is precisely the question which millions of his countrymen have been asking.

Leaders in civic, social and philanthropic circles of Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx are members of the committee for the thirty-second annual meeting and dinner of the Big Brother Movement to be given on Friday at the Yale Club.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- On recommendation of Senator Glass the Senate passed today by a voice vote the administration bill to increase the capital stock of the Commodity Credit Corporation from $3,000,000 to $100,000,000. It sent the measure to the House for consideration.

Theodore Gold of New York University won the national junior epee championship at the Fencers Club last night by defeating Paul Bremer of Hamilton College in a fence-off for first place after they tied in the final round robin.
MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 25 (AP). -- Grand jury indictments of two police captains today brought fresh demands from Better Government Committee leaders that the department be divorced from politics.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- Owing to a decline from the high level of activity in December in the automobile and allied industries, the increase in industrial production in January was less than is customary for that season of the year, said the Federal Reserve Board's monthly business review today.

George H. (Pete) Bostwick, one of the best-known amateur riders in America, will sail for England today on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania to make another attempt to capture the Grand National Steeplechase at Aintree on March 27, probably the most difficult race run in any country.

Federal investigation of the recent dismissal of Major Wilfred E. Boughton, head of New York's WPA Industrial Re-employment Bureau, was requested in a resolution adopted yesterday by the Board of Aldermen.

Business in the garment center featured the commercial rentals reported by brokers yesterday. Among other contracts for space were included one for a. school and one for an art gallery. The list was as follows:

LONDON, Feb. 25. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange were quiet again today owing to political uncertainties, but the tendency was steadier. Some armament stocks hardened, notably Vickers, as a result of the reports of English steel corporations.

Korekiyo Takahashi's death may prove the most damaging to Japan of all the tragic events of the military coup. His financial genius kept Japan's finances sound, her bonds easily salable, her markets buoyant and her industrialists confident through the agitated years following the Manchurian incident in 1931.

TORONTO, Feb. 25. -- The Toronto Maple Leafs played a 2-2 tie with the New York Rangers before a crowd of 10,000 tonight and took over undisputed leadership of the National Hockey League International Division, as the Montreal Maroons lost to the Chicago Black Hawks.
MUNICH, Feb. 25. -- Because he is disliked by local Nazi functionaries, Hans Knappertsbusch, noted conductor of the Bavarian State Opera, has been retired from his post at the age of 48.

The extreme Japanese militarists have failed in the main objective of their coup, that of gaining control of the government. That is the significance of the Emperor's calling upon Admiral Mineo Osumi to form a new Cabinet, for the Admiral, Navy Minister in the expiring Cabinet, is known not only as a more convinced liberal than Premier Okada but also as a leader of greater forcefulness.

TRENTON, Feb. 25. -- Beset by critics of his State fiscal policies and his activity in the Hauptmann case, Governor Hoffman today faced what may become a revolt against his ambition to be one of New Jersey's delegates at large to the Republican National Convention.
BOSTON, Feb. 25. -- The Boston Bruins beat the New York Americans, 3 -- 2, in an exciting National Hockey League contest tonight before 8,500 at the Garden.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- The nine justices of the Supreme Court were asked today to decide the fate of 12-year-old Gloria Laura Morgan Vanderbilt, who, her mother, Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt, told the court in a brief, is now "shuttled back and forth each week like a tennis ball" between her parent and her aunt, Mrs. Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney.

Warning that twice as many new lepers are developing each year as are now in all the leper colonies in the world, Perry Burgess, president of the Leonard Wood Memorial, appealed last night for the mobilization of scientists and humanitarians for a world-wide drive to eradicate leprosy.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25. -- Clyde B. Aitchison, Interstate Commerce Commissioner, suggested today that opposing counsel in Chicago's petition for inclusion in the Eastern time belt thresh out what he interposed as a possible constitutional issue.

A good many board-room stockholders who read the speech delivered at Princeton University on last Saturday by James M. Landis feel that the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission may be "holding out" on them. In his address he deplored the tendency of officers and directors "totoy with the stocks of their corporations" which, he said, was revealed by the commission's monthly shareholding reports.

OTTAWA, Feb. 25 (Canadian Press). -- Of the 11,000 shareholders of the Bank of Canada, scattered throughout the Dominion, fewer than half were present today at the bank's first annual meeting. The bank was opened on March 11, 1935.

Both the Building Service Employes Union and the Realty Advisory Board, representing some 8,000 buildings operating under agreement with the union, prepared yesterday for what is expected to be the showdown on the union's demands for a closed shop, wage increases and reduction in hours for some 75,000 elevator operators and other service workers.

Reactionary sentiment prevailed yesterday in the share market, mildly so during the early trading but obviously so from about 1:45 to 2:30 P.M.; in the final half-hour prices steadied. At the closing, leading issues were down from fractions to 4 points on the day.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- Emergency relief investigators in New York have been unconsciously playing fast and loose with the Mayor's English in reporting on the human misery they have encountered, as shown by a number of "boners" found in their reports.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 25. -- As rapidly as fast trains can travel and as quickly as conductors, brakemen and engineers can exchange news at distant terminals and deserted watering places, the story of the Jersey Central Railroad train which "lost" its conductor and brakeman was being spread today.

Assuming that it is a foretaste of Spring we have been enjoying, New York may venture to look back with the Weather Bureau upon 328 degrees of temperature deficiency since Dec. 1. One can easily think of larger deficits in other fields of interest, but a daily average of almost 4 1/2 degrees below normal over a period of nearly three months is decidedly cold, when it is a Winter normal to start with.

A banking group headed by the First Boston Corporation won yesterday the award of a new issue of $2,750,000 of city of Easton, Pa., water works bonds at a price of 101.363 as 2 3/4s. The bonds are dated March 15, 1936, and mature serially from 1937 to 1966.

The number of buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday was less than in the previous week. However, the total was above the corresponding period a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES. During the past week the number of arrivals was 875, as against 913 registered a week ago and 838 listed in the same period last year.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 25. -- Mrs. H. Stuart Green of the home club, who captured the honors in 1933, eliminated Miss Priscilla Bowes of the Cynwyd Club and Miss Charlotte Darling, New Jersey champion, today to reach the final round in the ninth annual invitation squash racquets tournament at the Ardsley Country Club.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 25. -- President Angell of Yale said tonight of Dean Doherty's appointment:

American hybridizers are wresting world leadership from plant breeders abroad in the introduction of new plants, Leonard Barron told the Junior League yesterday in the first of a series of four weekly lectures on "New Gardens for 1936."

Industries contemplating organized promotions must give prime consideration to the desires and wishes of consumers, who have become a great deal more exacting during the depression years, Paul T. Cherington of Cherington, Roper Wood, told members of the Trade Association Executives of New York at their monthly luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Following the first severe snowstorm we encountered, the snow was never cleared from West Seventy-third, Seventy-fourth, Seventy-fifth and Seventy-sixth Streets and was allowed to accumulate following subsequent snowstorms, with the result that the streets are in such condition as to make them dangerous and difficult for pedestrians and vehicles.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 25 (AP). -- A charter for the Nemours Foundation, created by the will of Alfred I. du Pont, was approved today in Circuit Court by Judge Dewitt T. Gray.

ALBANY, Feb. 25. -- The three Assemblymen named by Governor Lehman as leaders of "powerful groups of lawyer legislators" who sought to block his crime program, set forth their position in the controversy today.

Avery Brundage, president of the American Olympic Committee, returned from Garmisch-Partenkirchen, Germany, on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania yesterday, lavish in his praise of the Fourth Olympic Winter Games and highly interested by the news that the Princeton invitation track meet was to be run free of charge.
The Park Department turned down flatly yesterday a final plea for permission to continue operating the Central Park Casino as a restaurant.

Reported revelations yesterday by Edward A. Hausman, bogus lawyer, in an extensive fake accident claim racket were accompanied by an announcement by District Attorney Dodge that he had created an Accident Fraud Bureau in his office. Hausman, who is under indictment in several alleged insurance claim frauds, was brought to the prosecutor's office from his cell in the new penitentiary, where he is serving a term for posing as a lawyer.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., Feb. 25. -- Failing by only one stroke to tie the women's course record set by Miss Virginia Van Wie in 1930, Miss Patty Berg, 18-year-old Minneapolis golf sensation, won the qualifying medal in the South Atlantic championship today at the Ormond Beach Golf Club.

PINEHURST, N.C., Feb. 25. -- George T. Dunlap Jr. showed some of the golf which three years ago made him national amateur champion as he and R.P. Davidson figured among the first-round winners today in the thirty-second annual Spring handicap match play tourney for pairs.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 25. -- Edward A. Cannon, 27, was found guilty of murder in the second degree here this afternoon by a jury requiring nearly twenty-four hours to agree upon a verdict. He was accused of causing the death of Hilda Price, 19, on New Year's morning.

LONDON, Wednesday, Feb. 26. -- In informed Japanese circles here this morning it was said that as soon as the liberal trend of opinion in Japan had revealed itself in the general elections last Sunday action by the younger army officers of the military Fascist group had been expected.

Directors of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation at a special meeting yesterday discussed the refunding of $92,000,000 secured 6 per cent sinking-fund bonds, as well as the unification plans which are now being studied by the Transit Commission.

The Continental Motors Corporation advised the New York Stock Exchange yesterday that it had contracted to sell for cash by April 15 its entire stock interest in the Continental-Divco Company, a wholly owned subsidiary.

Admiral Keisuke Okada, retired, was chosen as a "dark horse" Premier of Japan in July, 1934, after a life devoted to the navy. He was not a party politician and served as a mild-mannered buffer between the quarrels and ambitions of opposing factions.

Maryland rather than Pennsylvania should receive the distinction of having the second printing press in the American Colonies, says Lawrence C. Wroth in the new number of The Colophon, a book collectors' quarterly, which has just been issued.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- Walter E. Edge, former Governor of New Jersey and former Ambassador to France, said today that New Jersey's delegates to the Republican National Convention would be instructed for Governor Landon.

PENSACOLA, Fla., Feb. 25. -- The matchless pitching of Carl Hubbell, which for two years topped the National League in effectiveness and which even last season promised to remain a thing of beauty and a joy forever, is something which henceforth will be seen only when occasion demands it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- The case of Major Gen. Johnson Hagood threatened today to become an outstanding issue in the political campaign when Senate Republicans, speaking through Senator Hastings, threw at the Democratic leaders a charge that suspension of the army officer from duty, following his criticism of the WPA before a Congressional committee, was an example of fear and "terrorism" which the administration was attempting to spread among the critics of the New Deal.

The most recent attempt at a political assassination in Japan, where such acts are regarded as an extreme but accepted form of protest, had for its victim Dr. Tatsukichi Minobe, professor at the Imperial University in Tokyo. He had published a book putting forward a new theory of the status of the Japanese Emperor and had created a political sensation by suggesting that the Emperor was merely the "highest organ of the State."

GRAND JUNCTION, Tenn., Feb. 25. -- Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare's big black and white pointer, Tips Manitoba Jake, fought through mud and Summery heat today to give a surprise performance in the second day's running of the national field trials.

An advanced program for greater control of social diseases in New York State is in preparation and soon will be launched, Dr. Thomas A. Parran Jr., State Commissioner of Health, revealed yesterday. He was here to attend a meeting of the advisory council of the department of welfare and health of the State Federation of Women's Clubs.

ALBANY, Feb. 25. -- A move to supplant Melvin C. Eaton as chairman of the Republican State Committee at the Spring meeting was sidetracked temporarily here today at a four-hour conference of nine county leaders.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 25. -- Five men, one of them a young New York advertising man and college graduate and another who was located in Hot Springs, Ark., through his pet Pomeranian dog, were indicted here today on charges of robbery in the first degree.

Eleven championships will be defended at the annual metropolitan A.A.U. indoor track and field title games which the Jefferson Club will conduct on Saturday at the 245th Field Artillery Armory (the old Thirteenth Regiment Armory) in Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 25. -- A gloomy picture of industries "folding up" or moving away and of the unemployment and relief problems becoming graver was painted this afternoon at the first joint hearing before the Assembly committees on Public Relief and Welfare and Ways and Means on the Brownell bill providing for a commission to investigate unemployment conditions in the State and recommend remedial measures to the Legislature.

ALBANY, Feb. 25. -- Extension for at least another year of the law prohibiting guaranteeing of mortgages or issuance of certificates of participation in guaranteed mortgages, was urged today in a third report of the legislative committee on guaranteed mortgages.

MOSCOW, Feb. 25. -- Another tragedy of the north was indicated today in a report by the All-Union Arctic Institute of the disappearance of Sigismund Lun, a scientist, and a hunter named Shirokhik. They set out last November over the ice floes at the edge of the entrance to the White Sea to study the migration of seals and other sea animals.

ALBANY, Feb. 25. -- The work of local police departments and minor courts has been "disappointing," for the most part, in the enforcement of the liquor laws, the State Liquor Authority declared today in its annual report to Governor Lehman and the Legislature. It advocated a strengthening of the present State control law, and not "ill-considered tampering" with it.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 25. -- The music room of Playa Riente was the setting tonight for a musicale for 200 guests given by Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Dillman in honor of their guests, Mrs. John S. Newberry and Mrs. Benjamin S. Warren.

PHILIP VAN CISE started as the Little Eva of District Attorneys. He wanted desperately to do good but was poorly equipped for battle. He slipped into office in Denver, Col., in 1920, through a rift in the Republican machine. Although he was the Republican candidate, the boys at party headquarters had drawn funny pictures of him and pasted them on the walls during the campaign.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 25. -- Tommy Goodwin and Dr. H.L. Nietert, both of New York, failed to survive the first round in the annual two-ball invitation foursome tournament at the Palm Beach Golf Club today. They lost to J.W. Madden of Omaha and John Cushman of Greenville, S.C., 5 and 4.

America must build for herself "new defenses, through the spread of recently acquired scientific knowledge, against its orators, its mountebanks, its mimics and its emotional giraffes," Dr. Oscar Riddle, internationally known biologist, told the American Institute last night, at a dinner at the Hotel Pierre observing its 108th anniversary.

New York State participants in the Landon-for-President movement are planning a pilgrimage to Topeka to pledge their support to the Governor of Kansas in his Presidential campaign, it became known yesterday.

Secrecy surrounded the meeting yesterday between representatives of the Fashion Originators Guild of America and retailers who have participated in the controversy over extension of the guild's program to dresses wholesaling below $10.75. Spokesmen for both sides refused to give out any official information regarding the conference, which was expected to pave the way for an adjustment of the differences between the two groups.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 25. -- A dozen witnesses testified for the State today in the trial of four Union County deputy sheriffs for the fatal shooting last September of Mrs. Sophie Crempa, Scotch Plains farmer's wife.

Captain D.P. Laubach of the Mitchel Field aviators team was among the winners yesterday in the opening round of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association Group 2 singles championship. Captain Laubach turned back Percy Kynaston of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club, 10 -- 15, 6 -- 15, 15 -- 10, 15 -- 5, 15 -- 10, on the Crescent courts.

DEMING, N.M., Feb. 25 (AP). -- Roger W. Toll, superintendent of Yellowstone Park, and two others were instantly killed seven miles east of here today when the automobile in which they were riding was in a head-on collision with another driven by Thomas Henry Ohmar of New Milford, Conn.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 (AP). -- New work for men and money was advanced tonight by Charles F. Kettering, vice president and research director of the General Motors Corporation, as one of the most important goals of scientific research.
The City Athletic Club team clinched the title in the Eastern Squash Racquets Association Group I competition last night by registering its eighth victory of the season.

Fire of undetermined origin ruined a two-story brick factory occupied by the Safety Tire and Rubber Company at 29-16 Fortieth Avenue, Long Island City, yesterday. Thomas F. Gallagher, a partner in the concern, estimated the damage at $100,000.

Giving high praise to the governments involved for successfully concluding the reciprocal trade agreement between this country and Brazil, V.F. Boucas, Brazilian manager for the International Business Machines Corporation and a financial and trade adviser to the Brazilian Government, urged exporters yesterday to adopt a new and more active selling program in the Brazilian markets.

This matter of the Judge Meekens candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination is of wider territorial interest than perhaps you know as yet. Though what my Southern friends impartially call a Yankee without regard to whether he comes from Vermont or Oregon, I feel personally concerned and somewhat wrought up about your crediting Virginia with an Elizabeth City jurist.

HADDONFIELD, N.J., Feb. 25. -- Fear that poison left to kill dogs in an exclusive residential area here might inadvertently get into the hands of children was expressed tonight as the police started a search for the poisoner.

An exchange of shots at short range between a hold-up man and two detectives in a retail liquor store at 4,820 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, resulted last night in the fatal wounding of Leonard Epstein, 24 years old, of 935 Fifty-third Street, Brooklyn, son of Edward Epstein, the proprietor.

The joint conference of anthracite operators and miners meeting here in efforts to negotiate a new agreement to replace the one that will expire March 31 devoted yesterday afternoon to a detailed discussion of the decline of the industry in the last ten years.

The Commonwealth and Southern, Corporation reports a consolidated net income of $9,533,475 after all deductions in the year ended on Jan. 31, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to one cent a share on 33,673,325 no par common shares, comparing with a revised net income of $7,610,427, or $5.07 a share, on 1,499,454 preferred shares in the preceding year.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- Registration of $7,178,500 of first and consolidated mortgage bonds was asked of the Securities and Exchange Commission today by the Central Illinois Light Company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- Copyright legislation passed by the Senate and now pending in the House was dictated by the broadcasting, motion-picture and hotel interests and has for its main purpose the hamstringing of the composers of the nation, the head of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers asserted before the House Patents Committee today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- President Roosevelt led the nation in paying tribute to Henry Latrobe Roosevelt today as the late Assistant Secretary of the Navy and distant cousin of the Chief Executive was buried in Arlington at the close of an impressive military funeral.

MADRID, Feb. 25. -- Republican Spain, with a Left government again in power, today defined her foreign policy. Foreign Minister Augusto Barcia recalled that the republican constitution outlawed war as an instrument of national policy and committed this country to unequivocal adherence to the League of Nations.

An attempt to show how $2,500 a year could be established as a minimum income for each family through what he calls "industrial adjustment" is made by Mordecai Ezekiel, economic adviser to the Secretary of Agriculture, in a book to be published by Harcourt Brace tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- President Roosevelt returned from Hyde Park and attended the funeral of Henry L. Roosevelt, Assistant Secretary of the Navy.

The Musical Art Quartet, assisted by Harold Bauer in the performance of Ernest Bloch's Quintet for piano and strings, played last night in Town Hall. The order of the program was unusual, in that the most modern composition, and also the one most calculated to make a brilliant effect, came first on the program, followed by Mozart's Quartet in G major (Kochel 387) and Brahms's quartet in G minor.

Showing the first profit, with the exception of 1933, since 1927, the American Woolen Company, Inc., in its pamphlet report for 1935, issued yesterday, announced a net profit of $2,740,599 after all charges, including depreciation, in contrast with a net loss of $5,458,495 for the preceding year.

James M. Cain has turned his shilling-shocker into a play, preserving the fanciful and impatient title it wore on the bookstands, "The Postman Always Rings Twice." It turned up callously at the Lyceum last evening with Richard Barthelmess as the snide killer and Mary Philips as the passionate killeress.

Major Gen. Frank Parker, who commanded the "Fightin' First" Division in the closing weeks of the World War, returned to his old command yesterday to round out his forty-six years of service in the army.

Messages congratulating the Palestine Foundation Fund on its fifteenth anniversary were made public here yesterday from David Lloyd George, former Prime Minister of Great Britain; Simon Marks, English philanthropist, and Leopold Amery, former British Secretary of State for the Colonies.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 25. -- The Associated Gas and Electric Company of New York, its subsidiaries, and the American Securities Corporation of Delaware were named joint defendants today in an action brought by the Federal Attorney of the Northern New York District to enforce a $54,000,000 tax lien on all property of both companies.

ALBANY, Feb. 25. -- A Republican drive to make the life of the New York State unemployment insurance system dependent upon United States Supreme Court approval of the Federal Social Security Act was turned back on strictly party lines in the Democratic-controlled Senate today.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Feb. 26. -- Reports were received here today of a most daring military coup in Tokyo. Apparently, however, there was an almost instant seizure of all means of communication and Shanghai is getting only snatches of information.

PARIS, Feb. 25. -- Considerable surprise and controversy has developed here as a result of the government's sudden decision to forbid exportation of the newly completed film version of Victor Marguerite's "La Garconne."

Nonpartisan administration by the States of Federal health security funds was urged yesterday by Dr. Thomas Parran Jr., State Commissioner of Health, in a luncheon address to 1,500 physicians, nurses and public health experts.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- Despite a previous understanding among Commerce Department officials that F.L. Adams and Commander H. McCoy Jones, officials of the Bureau of Navigation and Steamboat Inspection, would be reinstated, Secretary Roper said tonight that he had dismissed them.

ATLANTA, Feb. 25 (AP). -- Administration agencies provided funds today for operation of Georgia's fiscal affairs as Governor Eugene Talmadge charged a "plan hatched in Washington" created the impasse which resulted in his ouster of two financial officers.
ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 25 (AP). -- Housewives were advised today to take up brooms, mops and dustpans as major beauty aids.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 25 (AP). -- The Fighter, the Milky Way Farm's candidate for the Kentucky Derby, raced six furlongs on a drying track at Santa Anita Park in the fast time of 1:11 today to win the Palos Verdes Handicap.

Viennese newspapers declared last month that Mr. Knappertsbusch had been deprived of his passport and was thus prevented from leaving Germany. The German press did not mention his predicament. The report did not surprise the conductor's friends in Vienna, since it was known there that his intransigeant anti-Nazi attitude had brought him into conflict with the ruling powers of the Third Reich.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- Secretary Ickes asserted today that if utility companies failed to carry the Duke Power Company case, involving the right of PWA to make loans for municipal utilities, to the Supreme Court at once, they "throw themselves open to a charge of deliberate delay in order to defeat the recovery program."

Returns to date indicate that the railroads earned in January their largest gross revenues for the month in five years. The estimate is based on returns by the first thirteen railroads to report. Aggregate gross revenues of $299,000,000 by all railroads in January is indicated.

Evidence of a marked improvement in the shipping industry was provided yesterday in reports from four sources involving ships operated by the International Mercantile Marine Company. Increased passenger and freight business, new high marks for established services and the opening of at least one new market were indicated.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25. -- Apprehension is increasing regarding the outcome of the new Winter wheat crop because of continued reports of dust storms and dry conditions from the Southwest and probabilities of a new cold wave over the belt, which is now largely without snow protection.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- The administration suffered a rebuff in the House today when on a record vote it rejected the measure approved by the Senate to exempt from Federal and State taxation all preferred stock, capital notes and debentures of banks held by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Prices generally were lower on the local commodity futures markets yesterday, with most staples active. On the cash markets, corn, cocoa and tin advanced, white declines appeared in cotton, rye, butter, eggs, wooltops, silk and rubber.

Stewart P. Scott, former Yale star and assistant Eli football coach, has been added to the New York University football staff, it was announced yesterday by Head Coach Dr. Marvin A. (Mal) Stevens. It also was revealed at the same time that the assistants of last year had all been retained.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 25. -- Professor Robert E. Doherty of Yale University was elected president of the Carnegie Institute of Technology today at a tumultuous meeting of the trustees which saw Mayor William N. McNair and members of the City Council almost trading punches.

The Temporary Galleries of the Municipal Art Committee opens today a new group of exhibitions at 62 West Fifty-third Street. From now on it is proposed that the exhibitions remain on view for three weeks instead of two as was the practice with the first shows.
LONDON, Feb. 25. -- Diplomacy discovered today a new road that might lead the naval conference out of the worst of its political difficulties.

MONTREAL, Feb. 25 (AP). -- The Chicago Black Hawks ousted the Montreal Maroons from the lead in the international division of the National Hockey League with a two-goal outburst in the third period that brought them a 2 -- 0 victory tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- The Republicans, forming their mass attack against the administration, will use every encouragement they can devise to turn Major Gen. Johnson Hagood into an open campaign critic of the present government. This was made clear today when Senator Hastings, chairman of one of the Republican campaign committees, took up the general's case on the floor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- Charging that the War Department was making "an ass of itself" in disciplining General Hagood, Representative Blanton said tonight that he had photostatic evidence that Hagood had been told he could testify "freely, fully and frankly."

Failures in both the retail and wholesale divisions showed no change in the week ended Feb. 20, as compared with the previous five business days, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Defaults in the retail group, the report states, continued below the average so far this year, the decline amounting to 11.7 per cent against 14.5 per cent in the previous week.

Jack O'Brien, the Prospect Park Zoo's 13-day-old black bear cub, which is being reared on a regimen that rivals that of the Dionne babies for strictness, will be placed on public exhibition for two hours daily in a glass incubator beginning Saturday, Captain Ronald Cheyne-Stout, director of Park Department zoos, announced yesterday.
When your dogs have treed a bob-cat and you see the critter perched on a limb in plain view, it's a simple thing to take aim and bring the quarry down.

BOSTON, Feb. 25. -- Harvard defeated the University City Club of Cambridge, 8 to 1, in a hockey encounter at the Arena tonight. The Crimson, never forced to extend itself, coasted to victory on a pair of goals in the first period and three more in each of the other sessions.
Legislation dealing with fractional payments of principal toward eventual liquidation of a mortgage should provide for mandatory reductions of interest.
Business and apartment deals featured the Bronx realty trading reported yesterday.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- The most intense interest was manifested here tonight over reports of a military coup in Japan, but official sources were without any definite information. Neither the State Department, the Navy Department nor the Japanese Embassy had received any reports through their official channels on the situation.

Governor LANDON is in the hands of his friends, but in spite of all temptation to secure the nomination he remains indifferent. Topeka hotels have prospered from the swarm of correspondents sent to study him. The latest, Mr. MULLINS of The Boston Herald, dwells with wonder on the revival of the ancient myth that the office must hunt the man.

Three of the leading motion picture producing groups, Warner Brothers, Paramount and RKO, with total assets of $767,237,638 and 1,811 theatres under their control, were accused yesterday of conspiring to monopolize interstate commerce in motion pictures in a Sherman Anti-Trust Law injunction suit filed in Federal court by Attorney General Homer S. Cummings.

IF any fervid fan is worrying about the holdout situation as it affects his favorite team, there is comfort in history. Few holdouts hold on. The only case that comes to mind of a holdout with a really good grip was the case of Johnny Kling, great catcher of bygone days. Johnny held out for a full season, which is par for the course.

A suit brought by the receiver of S.W. Straus Co., Inc., of New York to recover about $200,000 of collateral from the Manufacturers' Trust Company was dismissed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Humphrey in Brooklyn.

Negotiations between railway managements and labor unions on the protection of employes in unifications centered yesterday on a demand by labor for an agreement to protect employes displaced by economy moves by individual railroads in addition to unifications by two or more railroads.

Frank McLoughlin of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club, seeded first in the tourney, was among the victors yesterday in the Eastern Squash Racquets Association Group II championship tourney at his home club courts.
CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (AP). -- Former Mayor William Hale Thompson came out of retirement tonight and back into politics, in which for sixteen years he was rated one of the country's sensation-makers:

PINEHURST, N.C., Feb. 26. -- Flashy golf by A.C. Giles of New York, who a few years ago played considerable competitive golf in Connecticut, featured today's second round in the pairs handicap Spring golf tournament.

The share market recovered its poise somewhat yesterday, if not actually in terms of prices, from the unsettlement of the last few days -- unsettlement which is now more confidently ascribed to correction of the "technical" position. Selling pressure was manifest at times, but it was notable that as the market dipped, the volume of trading diminished.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Members of the Franklin Township, N.J., committee conferred with Resettlement Administration officials today and made a detailed study of plans for the proposed $6,000,000 "planned community" near Bound Brook, N.J.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- A $10,000,000 experiment in combating drought in the South and Midwest, moving and rehabilitating stricken families and giving increased livelihood to at least 6,000 Pueblo and some Navajo Indians has been started by the Resettlement Administration in cooperation with the Soil Conservation Service, CCC and the Bureau of Indian Affairs.

The selection of a successor to Dr. THOMAS S. BAKER, who retired last year as the president of the Carnegie Institute of Technology in Pittsburgh, must have been a peculiarly difficult task. Whatever its name may imply, the institute was conceived on broad lines.

Foreign Minister FLANDIN, in his speech to the Chamber of Deputies on Tuesday, was thought to be replying indirectly to something said on the previous day by the British Foreign Secretary, Mr. EDEN. The latter, in describing to the House of Commons the settled British policy, declared that it would have nothing to do with "encirclement."

Your correspondent Mr. Norris is quite right in enlightening Mr. Bloom of the fact that there were dollars in existence in Washington's time. They were, as is generally known, the Spanish-milled dollars.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- The following order enabling WPA contractors to requisition union labor direct from recognized labor organizations rather than go first to the United States Employment Service was issued today by Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, to end delays:

CHICAGO, Feb. 26. -- The statement that former President Hoover is suffering from a "confirmed state of jitters" was made by Secretary Ickes today before the Union League Club in an address devoted largely to a defense of New Deal legislation and to criticism of its opponents.

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 27. -- The demonstration that young officers and men belonging to the Tokyo garrison carried out early yesterday was similar to that of May, 1932, in which Premier Ki Inukai was assassinated, but it was on a larger and bloodier scale.

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, Democratic leader in New Jersey, announced yesterday the selection of State Senator William H. Smathers of Atlantic City for the nomination in May as the Democratic candidate for United States Senator.
LONDON, Feb. 26. -- Thomas W. Ward, Ltd., of Sheffield has purchased the liner Homeric to break it up for scrap. The price paid for the vessel is believed to have been 74,000.

Jacob (Gurrah Jake) Shapiro, listed a few months ago by Police Commissioner Valentine as one of the ten ranking public enemies in town, was freed of a vagrancy charge by Magistrate Anthony F. Burke yesterday in West Side Court.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Feb. 27. -- Inner circles of the Chinese Government are dismayed over the immediate implications of the coup in Tokyo, but they are heartened when taking a long view of the situation.

Specialty shop trade thus far this year has held up very well in comparison with last year, despite the adverse weather conditions experienced. The head of one of the leading Fifth Avenue shops, for example, reported yesterday that he had been greatly impressed by the "vitality of consumer demand."

The Long Island Railroad, through its valuation engineer, D.O. Lyle, tried yesterday to have entered into the record a 365-page valuation report that weighed more than ten pounds as part of its defense of the application for an increase in commutation rates.

Radiating quiet optimism about the present state and the probable future of the Dionne quintuplets, Dr. Allan Roy Dafoe, their physician, arrived in New York yesterday from Callander, Ont., for a week of rest and relaxation. He said his five famous charges, who have their own hospital and nurses in the little Ontario community, are not being shown to the public during the Winter.
A tense situation still prevailed in Tokyo twenty-four hours after an attempted military coup. The following were outstanding features of the situation:

Chairman EATON of the Republican State Committee is busy preparing for his vacation in California. He must be considered as constructively present at the pow-wow of nine county leaders, down-State and up-State, at Albany Tuesday. He gave his blessing to the meeting after he heard of it: "These "men have my support for everything "they do."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Purchase of speculative securities for portfolio accounts in national or other member banks was prohibited today in regulations issued by J.F.T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency.

There are critics of the Administration who will say that in vetoing a fifty-million-dollar bill for seed loans yesterday the President strained at a gnat after swallowing a whole caravan of camels. What is a mere fifty million compared with the billions spent by the Government during the last three years?

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Following is the text of the memorandum from General Craig to Secretary Dern recommending punitive action against General Hagood, preceded by an explanatory statement by the War Department made in connection with the publication of the memorandum:

Lee Pattison, director of the Federal Music Project of New York City and New York State, replied yesterday to the list of grievances outlined by the Grand Opera Artists Association of America of 125 West Forty-fifth Street.

The New York Water-Color Club announces that its forty-seventh annual exhibition will be held in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, opening with a private view and reception on Wednesday evening, April 15, and to the public next day.
PENSACOLA, Fla., Feb. 26. -- "Sink or swim, I am sticking to my sinker ball and have no intention of trying anything else."

Thirteen years ago Senator Pepper of Pennsylvania declared in an address that the sanctions of the League of Nations would not work. He said: "An organization to force nations to behave is bound to fail." Asserting that there should be "a frank acknowledgment that the coercive features conceived at Versailles have no rightful place in the covenant," he called for a rewriting of that instrument.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 26 (AP). -- An ironical view of parts of ex-Governor Al Smith's recent Liberty League speech in Washington was expressed here today by Edward A. Filene, Boston merchant and advocate of consumer cooperative department stores.

The Rev. Dr. Edward Rochie Hardy Jr., who was known as Columbia's child prodigy back in 1920 when he entered that university at the age of 12, brought suit yesterday in Federal Court to compel Postmaster Albert Goldman to accept in the mails envelopes bearing an attack against William Randolph Hearst.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 26. -- A fighting Yale hockey team, handicapped by an epidemic of influenza that had four of its regulars in a weakened condition and forced the coach to remain behind in New Haven, downed Princeton, 4 -- 3, in a thrilling and fast encounter in the Hobey Baker rink tonight.

With only two and one-half trading sessions remaining in February, it appears possible that this month will be the first since last March to show a net decline in the stock averages on the New York Stock Exchange. At the close yesterday THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks stood at 117.76, or .67 point under the closing price on Jan. 31.
ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 26 (AP). -- The up-State Works Progress Administration today announced approval of fifty-four projects involving allocations of $331,261.57.

TENAFLY, N.J., Feb. 26. -- Mrs. Mary Peacock, 35 years old, of 95 Columbus Drive, was accosted in Jefferson Avenue here this morning by John L. Kamena, a family acquaintance, who fired four pistol shots into her chest, abdomen, right temple and hand, then killed himself with the weapon.

Though the issue was unfortunately made a partisan one, the Senate at Albany very properly rejected the proposed amendment declaring New York State's Unemployment Insurance Law inoperative in the event that the United States Supreme Court should declare the Federal Social Security Act unconstitutional.

Scores of letters embodying complaints, suggestions, applications, "tips" -- the gamut of correspondence flooding Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine's desk every day -- reached headquarters yesterday. But only one, from a young man in Queens, struck the commissioner as unique.

Recommendations designed to protect the public and the various branches of the food and grocery industry from "unfair and unlawful discrimination and deception" in connection with certain trade practices will be submitted to the leading groups in the industry this week for consideration, it was announced here yesterday.

BOSTON, Feb. 26. -- Charles H. McGlue of Boston, former Democratic State Chairman, agreed today to return to Clement Molway and Louis Berrett the $2,000 he received from them last year after he had helped them to get a State award of $5,000 for mental anguish they suffered in undergoing trial for a murder they did not commit.

Regarding the scare of a water famine, your readers have followed with interest the many enlightening communications that have been addressed to you on this subject. Most of them take for granted that we are in a dangerous way, and either we must meter all users of water or add additional reservoirs to supplement the alleged present inadequate facilities.
The governors of the New York Curb Exchange have approved the listing applications for the following:

CHICAGO, Feb. 28. -- Competition with cheaper cuts of beef and the return of warmer weather brought about a further reduction of 1/2 to 1 cent in fresh pork loins, with the top price in the local market 17 1/2 cents a pound wholesale, the lowest level since Feb. 1, 1935.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- At Senator Metcalf's request his resolution proposing a Senate investigation of the removal of Major Gen. Hagood was referred to the Military Affairs Committee. Chairman Sheppard said that it would be considered Friday.

Mrs. Russell Law gave a luncheon yesterday at the Beekman for Mrs. Gilbert Lucas. The other guests included Mrs. Walter H. Close, Mrs. James Lincoln Ashley, Mrs. J. Harwood Priddy, Mrs. Ernst Schmitz, Mrs. Herbert D. Williams, Mrs. Edgar D. Wolfe, Mrs. George A. Skinner, Mrs. John Shipman, Mrs. Ernest Baxter Osborne and Mrs. H. Sheppard Plimpton.

BURLINGTON, N.J., Feb. 26. -- William Wahtley Jr., 12-year-old son of a Burlington carpenter, was drowned at 5 o'clock this afternoon in the Delaware River here when he tried to save his puppy, which had broken through the thin ice. The dog, Jiggs, a 10-month-old male German shepherd, managed to get ashore by itself, but the boy sank in twelve feet of water and disappeared.

With customary secrecy, The Players are now considering what revival they will offer in late May or early June. They have not yet decided, but two candidates are in the lead -- "The Old Homestead," Denman Thompson's long-enduring triumph, and James A. Herne's "Shore Acres."

The St. Francis College basketball team scored its sixth straight triumph and its thirteenth victory in twenty games this season in defeating St. Peter's College of Jersey City, 43 to 27, last night in the St. Francis gymnasium in Brooklyn.
Milton Perkel tallied 16 points as the Brooklyn College quintet crushed the Brooklyn Central Y.M.C.A., 46 -- 24, at the Union Temple court last night.

The field in the sixtieth international six-day bicycle race in Madison Square Garden was reduced to ten teams last night as the riders went past the half way mark on the journey that is to end Saturday night at 11 o'clock.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26. -- Members of the Chicago Board of Trade voted down today by 334, to 298 a proposal to make the hours of trading from 9:45 A.M. to 1:30 P.M., except on Saturdays, when the session would have been from 9:45 A.M. to noon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- In his Lincoln Day speech in New York, Senator Vandenberg, who may be nominated for President by the Republicans in 1936 instead of 1940 (he would vastly prefer the latter date), called on "Jeffersonian Democrats" to join the campaign against the New Deal.

Having received substantial income payments while all the taxes ion the real estate security of their certificates were being paid in full, none of the investors in the $2,000,000 of Series F guaranteed mortgage certificates sold by the New York Title and Mortgage Company appeared yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler to object to the account presented by the trustees for the court's, approval.

Knopf will publish on April 20 Rom Landau's "God Is My Adventure," a volume concerned with such contemporary religious and spiritual leaders as Count Keyserling, Frank Buchman, George Jeffries, P.D. Ouspensky and Shri Meher Baba.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 26. -- John Crempa told from the witness stand today the story of his one-man war against a public utility company which lasted for eight years. The tragic climax was reached last September when his wife, Sophie, was shot and killed while a posse of Union County deputy sheriffs was attempting to arrest him on a contempt warrant.

AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 26. -- As Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor, conferred with a Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company union committee today three deputy sheriffs clashed with pickets in the first encounter of that nature since the strike of rubber workers began nine days ago.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 26. -- By a vote of 3,096,835 shares to 3,610, stockholders of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation meeting here today ratified an agreement entered into by the directors, merging the company with four of its subsidiaries under the name of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation of Delaware.
