CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 26. -- Penetrating Yale's zone defense with amazing success in the second half, Harvard's varsity basketball team recorded a surprising 36 to-32 victory over the Blue quintet at the Harvard indoor athletic building tonight before a crowd of more than 1,200.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Taking unprecedented action, the War Department struck back tonight against charges that "political discipline'' was used on Major Gen. Johnson Hagood in relieving him of command for criticism of the Works Progress Administration.

MADISON, N.J., Feb. 26. -- A herd of twelve deer was driven by hunger from the woods into the back yards of residences in Central and Ridgedale Avenues here this morning. Early risers saw the deer, which ranged from 70-pound fawns to 200-pound bucks, munching bread-crusts that had been scattered about for birds and trying to get at garbage.

John T. Cahill, former Assistant State Attorney General, was sworn in yesterday by General Sessions Judge Wallace as a Special Assistant District Attorney to continue prosecutions in the remaining indictments against twenty-four former officers of three defunct title mortgage companies.

Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, for fifty years a leader in the movement for the emancipation of women, charged yesterday that women "who wasted their time playing bridge" were guilty of a crime against society. In an address before the women's division of the American Jewish Congress at the Commodore, Mrs. Catt urged women to turn their attention to the fight to maintain individual liberties against the onslaught of dictatorship.

Disciplining of Major Gen. Hagood was criticized as "without reason or excuse" yesterday by Major Gen. John J. Byrne, retired New York National Guard Coast Artillery commander and president of the Military and Naval Club of New York.

Although yesterday's Tokyo dispatches said that Korekiyo Takahashi, Japanese Finance Minister, had been wounded rather than killed, Riichi Takahashi, his youngest son, was informed in a cablegram received here yesterday at 9 A.M., that his father was dead.

Gregory Mangin of New York, defending champion, was given the first seeded berth in the field of sixty-four who will play in the national indoor men's tennis championships, according to the draw announced yesterday by the United States Lawn Tennis Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Questions concerning the government's financing in March were discussed today by Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau and members of the executive committee of the open market committee of the Federal Reserve System.

TOKYO, Feb. 26. -- Yesterday's proceedings in the trial of Lieut. Col. Saburo Aizawa for the murder last August of Lieut. Gen. Tetsuzan Nagata, director of the Military Affairs Bureau of the War Office, closed in an atmosphere of prophetic tension after the ideals of young army officers regarding social and political reconstruction in Japan had been expressed in the boldest terms.

Viscount Makoto Saito, Lord Keeper of the Privy Seal, by his liberalism while Premier of Japan from May, 1932, to July, 1934, incurred the bitter hatred of jingoists and reactionaries. He assumed the leadership of the government after the assassination of Premier Ki Inukai and formed a coalition Cabinet in which were represented men of the two major parties as well as nonpartisans.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 26 (AP). -- The American Legion, completing a year's review of communism in the United States, recommended today a three-point legislative program as a means of combating the spread of the doctrine in this country.

The unusual activity in trading in stocks of thirteen public utility companies on Feb. 17, the day on which the United States Supreme Court announced its decision on the Tennessee Valley Authority, has been made the subject of an investigation by the New York Stock Exchange.
Bankers have been invited to submit bids on March 18 for a new issue of $959,000 of primary road refunding bonds of Harden County, Iowa. The bonds will mature serially from 1937 to 1945.

TORONTO, Feb. 26 (Canadian Press) -- By a decision today of the Ontario Court of Appeal, the application of the National Trust Company, Ltd., as trustee for bonds of the Great Lakes Paper Company, Ltd., for approval of a sale of the assets of the paper company to Lynn Aldrich and John Gefaell was referred back to the court for reconsideration.

While new crop months recovered $1 a bale on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, houses doing government business released a quantity of March contracts which closed the spot month unchanged from Tuesday, compared with a gain of 21 points in December.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 26. -- Miss Nancy Pearman of Bermuda conquered Miss K. Cerf of Montclair, N.J., 8 and 6, today in the first round of the annual women's Bermuda championship, played under perfect conditions over the Riddells Bay course today.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 26. -- Swirlingl chunks of ice and muddy water, loosened by 50-degree temperatures, swept Western Pennsylvania's streams to flood stages tonight andI threatened serious damage to lower Ohio River communities.
CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (AP). -- From several quarters of the American Legion here today came condemnation of the removal of General Hagood.

A strong second half attack paved the way to a 37-17 victory for the New College girls' basketball team over Hunter College yesterday in Thompson Gymnasium of Teachers College at Columbia. After being deadlocked at 12 -- 12 at the half, New College put on several good formations that overcame Hunter's sound defense.

The Title Guarantee and Trust Company must return to the Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company collateral of about $2,500,000 which was deposited with it shortly before the State Superintendent of Insurance took over the mortgage company for rehabilitation.

Loft rentals to manufacturing firms in the midtown area continued in volume yesterday. An increasing demand for store locations in the financial district of lower Manhattan, by merchants expecting to profit from general business improvement, was reported by Cushman Wakefield.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP). -- Replying to a "gold clause" suit of the Dixie Terminal Company of Cincinnati, the government told the Court of Claims today that it had jurisdiction "to entertain only suits to which the United States has consented."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Tunes played in Milwaukee taverns troubled the House Committee on Patents today and a threat to impeach an unnamed Federal judge in Wisconsin was voiced as the hearing on the Copyright Bill passed by the Senate and pending in the House was continued.

A banking syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., will offer a new issue of $55,000,000 of New York Edison Company, Inc., first lien and refunding mortgage 3 1/4 per cent bonds, Series D, due on Oct. 1, 1965, at par and accrued interest.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Opportunity for extensive practical experiments in radio television was given by the Federal Communications Commission today when it authorized the A.T. T. and the New York Bell Telephone Company to construct a coaxial cable between New York City and Philadelphia. Under the permit actual construction must start before July 1.

Despite declining automobile production, irregularity of prices and unsatisfactory weather conditions, production of steel has been increased this week to 55 per cent of capacity, a gain of 1 1/2 points over last week, according to The Iron Age.

The long struggle for supremacy between the civil power and the military in Japan has plainly come to a head. Assassination as a political instrument is no novelty in the history of the country. It may be traced back to a national tradition that far antedates the present parliamentary system.

Henry Parish, vice president of the Bank of New York and Trust Company, was examined yesterday before Surrogate James A. Delehanty as to his knowledge of the business affairs of the late Miss Mary G. Thompson, 91-year-old philanthropist, and the manner in which her will was drawn.

The sealed verdict in the trial of the $150,000 slander suit brought by Mrs. Viola Raphael against Mrs. Lucy Cotton Thomas Magraw was opened before Supreme Court Justice Valente yesterday and was found to be a verdict of 6 cents.
ALBANY, Feb. 26. -- Governor Lehman today signed three more bills in his sixty-point program of anti-crime legislation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Senator Borah demanded today that the uninstructed delegates plan fostered by Eastern "conservative" leaders be abandoned and that candidates for the Republican nomination for President submit themselves to the primaries. He offered to enter the New Jersey primaries "if all parties in New Jersey will agree to abide by the result."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- As Secretary Roper of the Department of Commerce today defended his dismissal of two ranking officers of the Bureau of Navigation and Steamboat Inspection, it developed that the unauthorized release of a report on sea safety which was involved in their punishment apparently had stimulated the department to take action looking toward more adequate rules for the protection of passenger vessels at sea.
Police Commissioner Valentine was made a member of the Circus Saints and Sinners Club yesterday afternoon, but not until after he had been "mussed up."

Disclosure that two rings of "fixers" and forgers operating in Brooklyn and Manhattan have placed some 1,000 persons in WPA jobs by means of forged referral cards they sold to unemployed at $5 to $30 apiece was made yesterday by Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26. -- Aggressive buying of July wheat, headed by houses with Eastern connections which were active yesterday also, swept all before it today on the Board of Trade and carried the new crop deliveries 1 1/2 to 1 5/8 cents a bushel above yesterday's finish and to the highest level since early in January.

Charles H.C. Pearsall was elected president of the Colombian Steamship Company. Inc., and its subsidiaries, the Colombian Mail Steamship Company and the Ocean Transport Company, at a meeting of the directors yesterday afternoon. Henry F. Markwalter was re-elected vice president and Victor E. Fegley was chosen treasurer.
ALBANY, Feb. 26. -- A concurrent resolution proposing an amendment to the State Constitution to limit real estate taxes was offered today by Senator Crawford, Democrat, of Kings.

MOSCOW, Feb. 26. -- The establishment on the initiative of Joseph Stalin of a graduate school of propaganda connected with the Communist University of Moscow was announced today by Andrew Andreyeff, secretary of the Central Committee of the Communist party.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 26. -- Directors of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company took preliminary steps today for refunding of its $84,962,000 of first-mortgage 5 per cent bonds with debentures convertible into common stock.
COLUMBUS, Feb. 26 (AP). -- Borah-for-President forces today selected Frank E. Gannett, newspaper publisher, as their second choice for the Republican nomination for President.

Lent was ushered in yesterday with special Ash Wednesday sermons in Protestant Episcopal, Roman Catholic, Lutheran and other parishes, the services marking the beginning of the penitential season which ends on Easter Sunday.

The shadows of a possible war between playwrights and theatrical producers loomed over Broadway last night when the managers, after a hastily called meeting at the Hotel Astor, signified their unanimous rejection of the proposed terms of a new basic agreement between the two groups which would go into effect on March 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Printing of the 38,000,000 "baby bonds" to pay the soldiers' bonus was started today by the Bureau of Engraving and Printing, in the presence of officials and veterans' leaders.

Reconstruction of Stuyvesant Square, on Second Avenue between East Fifteenth and East Seventeenth Streets, has been begun by the Park Department. WPA workers have fenced off the south half of the park on both sides of Second Avenue and have moved in a quantity of concrete forms and other equipment. They have begun to excavate for new walks and other improvements.
WALLACE, Idaho, Feb. 26 (AP). -- Three men were believed swept to their death in a passenger coach of a Northern Pacific train late today by a snowslide in the Coeur d'Alene Mountains east of here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- A definite indication of the administration's tax program for this session is expected to come from a conference between President Roosevelt and Congressional leaders scheduled for tomorrow night.

A special meeting of stockholders of the National Lead Company has been called for April 16 to vote on a plan to split the common shares ten for one, reducing the par value from $100 to $10, and to exchange ten new shares for each old one. A two-thirds vote of each class of stock will be necessary to ratify the plan.

The Salle d'Armes Vines first team, national champion, added to its laurels by capturing the women's interclub fencing competition, hold last night at the Fencers Club with the sanction of the A.F.I.A., Each member of the winning squad received a medal.

The effect of the Japanese political assassinations upon financial markets and upon Japanese financial and commercial relations with the rest of the world were relatively mild. The principal repercussions were a fall of less than 1 per cent in the value of the yen in foreign exchange and declines of 2 or 3 points in Japanese bonds.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- A proposed issue of $40,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds, of which $31,500,000 would be used to construct and equip a new plant, was registered today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- President Roosevelt today vetoed a bill which would have appropriated $50,000,000 to continue the custom of providing funds for seed loans to farmers.

William H. Johns, recently appointed chairman of the executive committee of Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., was awarded a gold medal for his "distinguished services to advertising" at a dinner last night at the Hotel Waldorf Astoria, sponsored by Advertising and Selling, a publication, which is resuming the practice of annual advertising awards established by the late Edward W. Bok and administered by Harvard University from 1924 through 1930.

Yielding only one field goal and four fouls, the powerful Poly Prep basketball team crushed Marquand School under a 55 -- 6 score on the Dyker Heights court in one of the leading schoolboy games on the metropolitan program yesterday Paul Gravenhorst tossed in ten field goals and a penalty shot for twenty-one points in leading the winners; who led at the half, 31 -- 5.

PARIS, Feb. 26. -- A heavy drop in prices in nearly all departments took place on the Bourse today following the news from Japan and its reaction in London. Coming on top of the weakness in the market in the last eight days, the new slump promises to make the end-of-the-month settlement difficult for those who two weeks ago put credence in the signs of recovery they then saw.
Japanese official circles here minimized the potential effects of the army revolt upon the empire's governmental structure and foreign policy.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Depletion of American wild life due to exploitation and neglect is impairing a national resource the economic value of which is well above $1,000,000,000 annually, according to a report made public today by the National Resources Committee.

Minor advances were general on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. Silk futures were easier and hides slightly lower. On the cash markets, rye, flour, lead and zinc advanced, and coffee, rubber and standard tin declined.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 26. -- Six German airmen have been sentenced to one week's imprisonment in Czechoslovak cells for illegal crossing of the frontier.

Federal Judge William Bondy denied a motion for a mistrial after a heated exchange during which an attorney accused Charles T. Murphy, Assistant United States Attorney, of prejudicing the jury at yesterday's session of the trial of John T. Brook, president, and seven other officials of the defunct Pelham National Bank on charges of filing false reports with the Controller of the Currency.

Net income of the New York Telephone Company for 1935 was reported yesterday as $30,031,378, which was equal, after preferred dividends, to $6.74 a share on the common stock. It compared with $31,591,828, or $7.11 a share, earned in 1934.

The need for more space, new equipment and additional beds to meet the growing demands caused by new developments in the medical world was stressed last night in the annual report of Joseph J. Baker, president of the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn, an affiliate of the Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities.

In a statement issued here last night making an oblique criticism of Attorney General David T. Wilentz, prosecutor of Bruno Richard Hauptmann for the kidnapping of the Lindbergh baby, Governor Harold G. Hoffman of Hew Jersey offered his own evidence tending to discredit Millard Whited, who placed Hauptmann near the Lindbergh estate just before the kidnapping in 1932.

New York and Boston yachts and crews have been organized to challenge the Bermuda yachtsmen in the international races at Bermuda starting April 1. This year there will be sixteen days of competition, the Long Island Sound Interclubs first meeting the Bermuda one-design craft, then the six-meter sloops on both sides contesting the Prince of Wales Cup.

The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad has estimated that its minimum revenues in 1936 will be $76,200,000, against $71,113,280 in 1935, an increase of 7.2 per cent in statements filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission. Net operating income was estimated at a minimum of $9,185,000, against $8,179,548, an increase of 12.3 per cent.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 26. -- The names of sixteen sophomores of Princeton University, who were elected members of Princeton's upper class eating clubs on "secondary" bids, were announced this afternoon by Howard Menand Jr., president of the interclub committee.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 26. -- The Princeton swimming team won its sixth straight meet today, overcoming Columbia by 55 -- 16 in the Brokaw pool. In an exhibition 150-yard medley relay, a Princeton team composed of Howie Willey, Dick Hough and Hank Van Oss, set a new world's record of 1:21.8 for 25-yard pools.

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 27 (Reuters). -- Tokyo, lying under a pall of snow, is outwardly calm today, but the mutiny has not yet been completely suppressed. The rebels are still in possession of various government departments and police headquarters.

ALBANY, Feb. 26. -- High taxes, labor legislation and failure to balance the State budget by economies have placed industry in this State at a disadvantage in costs in competing with manufacturers in other States, spokesmen for industries, large and small, testified today before the Public Relief and Welfare and Ways and Means Committees of the Assembly.
The Fire Department will resume control at 9 o'clock this morning of the Bureau of Combustibles as the result of the signing by Governor Lehman of a bill restoring the bureau to the department.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Another apparently "unauthorized" report on sea mishaps was forwarded to the press tonight after Secretary Roper had defended the dismissal of two officials for alleged "insubordination" in connection with a previous incident.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., Feb. 26. -- Finishing with an eagle 2 on the thirteenth hole, Miss Patty Berg, 18-year-old Minneapolis star, won her first-round match from Miss Alice Rutherford of Aiken, S.C., in the women's South Atlantic championship at the Ormond Beach Golf Club today.

Eddie O'Brien of Syracuse, the No. 1 American hope for the Olympic 400-meter title, yesterday filed entry for the Casey 600 that will feature the Knights of Columbus track carnival at Madison Square Garden on March 14. A victory then would give the national 400 and 600 meter champion an unbeaten season on the boards.

The second "Modern Dance Recital" in the series of eight which is being presented by the New School for Social Research took place last night before an appreciative audience. Three soloists and two groups collaborated on the program.

The investigation of the charges of bribery and official bungling in the early handling of the Samuel Drukman murder case in Brooklyn a year ago was continued yesterday by the extraordinary grand jury summoned by Governor Lehman.
An elderly merchant plunged to his death in crowded Thirty-fourth Street at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, despite the efforts of a 22-year-old stenographer and a window cleaner to save him.

GEORGE V's funeral expenses amounted to $125,000, according to a budget estimate laid before Parliament. It is more than a little grim to be confronted with an itemized bill of costs the obsequies of a King-Emperor; grim, but chastening to human vanity, and so in the end salutary.
Mike Belloise, Bronx featherweight, pounded out a decision over Norment Quarles, Jack Dempsey's protege from Hendersonville, N.C., in the feature bout of ten rounds at the Star Casino last night.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 26 (AP). -- Crystal Prince, negotiating the mile and a sixteenth in 1:44 4-5 today, scored his second victory in six starts during the Santa Anita Park season. With Danny Brammer up, the 7-year-old gelding finished three-quarters of a length ahead of Impeach.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP). -- Senate action on the $1,000,000,000 Rural Electrification Bill was put back a week today as part of a drive by administration leaders to cut it small enough to meet the quoted wishes of President Roosevelt.

S.E. Berry, New York sportsman, expresses the hope that this State will emulate Pennsylvania in the establishment of special trout streams on which the take of fish will be controlled by rigid restrictions.
LONDON, Feb. 26. -- The only public comment by the British Government concerning the Tokyo assassinations was made today by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden to Parliament.

CATSKILL, N.Y., Feb. 26. -- Dr. George Coles Stebbins, evangelist, singer, composer of Gospel music and director of chorus and congregational singing, celebrated his ninetieth birthday quietly today at the home of his sister, Mrs. R.D. Miller, with whom he lives.

ANADARKO, Okla., Feb. 26 (AP). -- Emma Willis, 18-year-old girl, was acquitted today of murder charges in the shotgun slaying of her sharecropper father, Iddis H. Willis, slain in his home Dec. 21. The jury held the girl "not guilty by reason of insanity."

Japan has sowed the wind of leniency with crimes of "loyalty." She is reaping the whirlwind of murderous revolt against the Emperor himself. She cannot, with Job, protest her innocence for the afflictions that have come upon her.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- An early start on the House investigation of the Townsend old-age pension scheme and its financial structure was predicted today when the investigating committee held its first meeting, appointed a counsel land decided to ask the House for an appropriation of $50,000.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (AP). -- Representatives of the grain and livestock markets joined ether opponents of a local change from Central to Eastern standard time today with the assertion that they would suffer "confusion and losses" if the Interstate Commerce Commission granted a petition for the proposal.
LONDON, Feb. 26. -- Italy made it clear today that she would find some pretext for delaying completion of the new naval agreement whether the other powers are ready to initial it or not.

The Lafayette College Glee Club and Choir made its second appearance in concert at the Town Hall last night. The chorus of fifty male voices, which is under the direction of John Warren Erb, is one of the increasing groups of undergraduate ensembles which are turning their attention to unhackneyed and rewarding music.

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 27. -- Tokyo was quiet under martial law this morning after fighting yesterday between loyal forces and 3,000 rebellious young officers and men who assassinated Premier Keisuke Okada, Viscount Makoto Saito, his predecessor and Keeper of the Lord Privy Seal, and General Jotaro Watanabe, Inspector General of Military Education, and mortally wounded Finance Minister Korektyo Takahashi.

Housing, loft and garage properties in Manhattan and the Bronx were put up for bidding by auctioneers at foreclosure sales yesterday. Four parcels were auctioned in each of the two boroughs, all being struck down to the plaintiffs who instituted the foreclosure proceedings.

There is no longer any ten-goal player in indoor polo. Winston F.C. Guest, the brightest star the indoor game has produced, was lowered, it was announced yesterday, from that figure, where he had been alone since 1930, to 9 goals at a meeting of the handicap committee which adjusted high goal ratings for the coming national championships.

George H. (Pete) Bostwick, well-known gentleman rider, sailed yesterday aboard the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania for England, where he will ride his steeplechaser, Castle Irwell, in the Grand National at Aintree on March 27.

Pressing the government's income-tax evasion cases against the late Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, racketeer, and three of his henchmen, Harry M. Hickey, acting collector of internal revenue for the Albany district, filed tax liens by mail in Federal court here yesterday for a total of $292,039.07.

Following a City Hall conference yesterday on the condition of the Criminal Courts Building, Mayor La Guardia indicated he would make an independent study of reported danger spots in the building before reaching any decision.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 26. -- Staging a brilliant rally to win the final two games, Miss Margaret Bostwick, New York State champion, defeated Mrs. H. Stuart Green of Tarrytown in the final of the ninth annual invitation squash racquets tournament at the Ardsley Country Club today.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.
The professional in American racquets had his long-awaited day of glory yesterday with the inauguration of the national open championship at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

Equipment for an expansion of its nation-wide system for transmitting pictures by wire was demonstrated yesterday by The Associated Press when a news photo was sent from a portable transmitting machine over the regular wirephoto network.
PARIS, Feb. 26. -- The effects of the Tokyo assassinations may have on European politics and notably on the Franco-Soviet treaty will be discussed by the council of French Ministers tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Concern over the uprising of army troops in Tokyo continued unabated here today, notwithstanding reassuring official reports from Japan.

SO he's off to Aintree again. Good luck go with Pete Bostwick this time. Last year the grinning Fates whisked him out of the saddle and sent him pinwheeling along the turf when it seemed that he had a great chance to go on and win.

A whirlwind drive in an overtime period gave Columbia a spectacular 36-to-30 victory over Princeton at the Morningside Heights gymnasium last night, kept the Lions unbeaten in seven Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League starts and moved them to within a step of the championship.

The regular Class A race of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League came to a close last night, with the Columbia Club and New York Athletic Club teams ending their campaigns in a tie for the title. Since the season opened late last year each of the leaders has been defeated only once in fourteen matches.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 26. -- Wacoche, 5-year-old gelding in the silks of W.C. Stroube's Corsicana Stable, and Jockey Johnny Longden combined to score a hard-earned victory in the featured Grade B Handicap of seven furlongs at Hialeah Park today.

Among the passengers sailing today on the Ausonia of the Cunard White Star Line for Plymouth and London are three Japanese naval officers, Commanders Yoshimitsa Iwanori, Sakae Terayoma and Yuriji Yakabe. Others sailing include Mrs. H.A. Crayden, Mr. and Mrs. J.W. Denoon, Hui-Nun-Kao, J. Cubbon, Mr. and Mrs. W.F.D. Jarvis, Mrs. A.E. Miller and Mrs. T.H. Morgan.

A police bullet, rather than a slug from the pistol carried by a holdup man, fatally wounded Leonard Epstein, 24 years old, during an attempted hold-up Tuesday night of his father's liquor store at 4,820 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday by Commissioner Valentine.

Representatives of eight civic and mercantile groups joined yesterday in a petition asking Mayor La Guardia to support pending State legislation which would restore city control over $109,500,000 of the city budget.

Representatives of eight civic and mercantile groups joined yesterday in a petition asking Mayor La Guardia to support pending State legislation which would restore city control over $109,500,000 of the city budget.

GRAND JUNCTION, Tenn., Feb. 26 (AP). -- High winds and a drizzling rain, together with mediocre heats, spoiled the third day of the national field trials here for the largest gallery to follow the blue-blooded hunters since the opening.

ROME, Feb. 26. -- Premier Benito Mussolini's dream of a five-power agreement embracing Italy, Germany, Poland, Austria and Hungary has been scotched, if not definitely killed, by the refusal of Chancellor Adolf Hitler to join the proposed combination.

The Five-Star Anti-Freeze container used by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., and designed by Jim Nash, has been awarded the Irwin D. Wolf trophy in the annual competition for distinctive merit in packaging, sponsored by the American Management Association.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 26. -- Only one public school class in St. Louis went to school today, but that class showed 5,000 school administrators from all parts of the country how freedom of speech really works in the class room.

LONDON, Feb. 26. -- A sharp fall in prices of Japanese bonds on the London Stock Exchange today followed the assassinations in Tokyo, although selling was not heavy. Far Eastern news, with the dull advices from Wall Street over night, had a restraining influence on the markets, which were generally dull.

ALBANY, Feb. 26. -- Representatives of truck and bus operating companies appeared in force today at a Senate committee hearing to protest against the Berg bill, designed to prevent a bus or truck driver from being required to stay at the wheel more than ten consecutive hours.

BERLIN, Feb. 26. -- German adherence to the four-power naval agreement about to be initialed in London is now virtually assured and if formal notification to that effect has not already been communicated to the British Foreign Office such action is impending.

Final plans have been completed for the "Spring Fever Dinner Dance" to be held tomorrow in the Caprice Room of the Weylin for the benefit of the Children's Orthopedic and Surgical Ward of the New York Post Graduate Hospital.

STOCKHOLM, Feb. 26. -- Speculation was aroused here today by the news that Mrs. Alexandra Kollontay, Russian Ambassador to Sweden, had commissioned Sweden's leading brain surgeon, Dr. Herbert Olivecrone, to rush to Moscow by plane to an unnamed patient.

The joint conference of anthracite operators and miners which began sessions here on Monday in efforts to negotiate an agreement to replace the one expiring March 31 began consideration yesterday of the problem of bootleg mining.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- President Roosevelt vetoed the $50,000,000 seed loan bill and arranged for a conference with Congressional leaders on taxation tomorrow night.

MADRID, Feb. 26. -- A Cabinet decree re-establishing the rebellious Catalan Generalidad, or regional government, but not allowing the regional Parliament in Barcelona to resume its sessions yet, was approved by a standing parliamentary committee tonight and later signed by President Niceto Alcala Zamora.

HELSINGFORS, Feb. 26. -- The plebiscite in Estonia arranged to determine whether the nation prefers to return to constitutional rule or to retain the present dictatorial regime resulted in a great victory in favor of the Constitution. Out of an electorate of 770,000, 472,416 voted for the Constitution and 148,878 for the dictatorial regime.

I think one thing should be pointed out in reply to the observations about present Soviet trends in today's Topics of The Times Friends of the Soviet Union are not in the least "crestfallen' over that reaction which is now apparent in Moscow.

The Board of Education, at a meeting last night, rejected a request of the Board of Estimate that free bus transportation be provided for physically handicapped pupils of parochial and other non-public schools at which no tuition is charged.

HERSHEY, Pa., Feb. 26. -- The New York Rovers and Hershey each gained a point in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League race tonight, playing seventy minutes to a 1-1 tie in the Hershey Ice Palace before a crowd of 3,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Revision of the proposed legislation to extend trading in unlisted securities beyond June 1 was indicated as members of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee asserted today that the bill should not be rushed, and representatives of over-the-counter dealers appeared before the committee to oppose expansion of the authority of the Securities and Exchange Commission, at least without careful study.

Artur Schnabel brought his series of Beethoven sonata recitals to a close at Carnegie Hall last night before another huge audience which hung with bated breath upon every phrase the pianist evoked from the keyboard. There were five sonatas on this final program.

HERSHEY, Pa., Feb. 26. -- The New York Rovers and Hershey each gained a point in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League race tonight, playing seventy minutes to a 1-1 tie in the Hershey Ice Palace before a crowd of 3,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Revision of the proposed legislation to extend trading in unlisted securities beyond June 1 was indicated as members of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee asserted today that the bill should not be rushed, and representatives of over-the-counter dealers appeared before the committee to oppose expansion of the authority of the Securities and Exchange Commission, at least without careful study.

Artur Schnabel brought his series of Beethoven sonata recitals to a close at Carnegie Hall last night before another huge audience which hung with bated breath upon every phrase the pianist evoked from the keyboard. There were five sonatas on this final program.

The Board of Education, at a meeting last night, rejected a request of the Board of Estimate that free bus transportation be provided for physically handicapped pupils of parochial and other non-public schools at which no tuition is charged.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Feb. 27. -- The Japanese Embassy here declares it has been authoritatively informed that by means of persuasion by their regimental and divisional commanders the revolting troops in Tokyo were persuaded this morning to return to their barracks and that their withdrawal from the government buildings they occupied has already begun.

MOSCOW, Feb. 26. -- Officials of the Soviet Union, which next to China is most closely affected by any important event in Japan, are studying every scrap of information filtering in from Tokyo, not concealing their concern over this morning's attempted military coup d'etat.

The question whether Melvin C. Eaton will be re-elected as Republican State chairman will probably depend on whether the group of county chairmen who conferred in Albany on Tuesday can agree among themselves on a successor to Mr. Eaton, it was said in informed quarters here yesterday.

SPOKANE, Wash., Feb. 27 (AP). -- Senator Borah said in a letter published here tonight that he was fighting "a group of men under whose leadership the (Republican) party has been brought to its present exigent condition."

LONDON, Feb. 27. -- The naval conference sank deeper and deeper into political difficulties today and by nightfall the only powers in substantial accord were Great Britain and the United States on one hand and Britain and Germany on the other.

Literal compliance with the Multiple Dwellings Law is not only a physical impossibility but would involve serious harm to the interests of landlords and dispossess 1,500,000 tenants, Andrew Mills Jr., president of the Dry Dock Savings Institution, declared last night at the annual dinner of the Savings Banks Real Estate Managers at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The Choral and Dramatic Clubs of the Lenox School presented yesterday afternoon and evening in the school auditorium, 52 East Seventy-eighth Street, the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta, "Trial by Jury," for the benefit of the Lenox Fresh Air Fund. The fund last year gave vacations during the Summer months to more than eighty needy children.

For $165,000, it was announced yesterday, Samuel Goldwyn has acquired the film rights to Sidney Kingsley's "Dead End," which in its legitimate form enters tonight on its fifth month at the Belasco Theatre. Jesse L. Lasky had also been a bidder.
Auctioneers offered a long list of properties in Manhattan at foreclosure sales yesterday.

A one-story trucking and storage building will replace the three structures at 412-16 East Twenty-third Street, between Avenue A and First Avenue, according to plans submitted yesterday. The plot, 66 by 98.9 feet, has been owned by the Union Dime Savings Bank since March, 1933.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 27 (AP). -- Norman Bright, high school teacher from Sunnyvale, Calif., defeated Glenn Cunningham of Kansas, world's record holder, in the one mile feature race of San Francisco's indoor track meet tonight.

With the operations of the producers' pool hampered by congestion at warehouses and with a sharp recovery in the stock market, prices on the Cotton Exchange moved within narrow limits yesterday to end 2 points higher to 5 points lower than on Wednesday.

ROME, Friday, Feb. 28 (AP). -- Rumors that Emperor Haile Selassie was sick or wounded circulated here today following receipt of Italian dispatches from Jibuti, French Somaliland, that the Ethiopian ruler's Swedish physician had suddenly been summoned to Dessye, near where the Emperor was understood to have his headquarters.
More than 1,870 Hunter College students will use new quarters provided for them yesterday through a lease of space at 2 Park Avenue at an annual rental of $160,000.

Why not take some hints about snow removal from other cities? I once saw snow falling in London and almost as soon as the first flakes reached the streets men were at work with hose flushing it off as fast as it fell. As soon as a storm begins, the attack in this way should be made at least on the principal streets.

Some half-ashamed apologists for the assassinations in Japan say that similar crimes occur in other countries. They do. The old Czardom in Russia was called a tyranny tempered by assassination. King HUMBERT was shot in Rome. In Serbia the royal family was made away with in a series of ghastly murders.

A new move to finish the construction of Grant's Tomb, which has stood uncompleted on Riverside at 123d for thirty-nine years, was undertaken yesterday at the annual meeting of the trustees of the Grant Monument Association.
Your report of the address of Mr. Landis of the SEC at Princeton includes three desiderata quoted direct from Mr. Landis as follows:

The sixtieth international six-day bicycle race in Madison Square Garden swung into its fifth day with more intensive riding and hardly less public interest. It was estimated that another gathering of 10,000 fans, late in arriving but steadfast in its interest, witnessed last night's riding.

Possibly the greatest tribute to the work of Charles Boyer in "Le Bonheur" (Happiness), which reached the little Cinema de Paris yesterday from France, is the fact that he actually makes some members of the audience believe that a man can rationalize himself into leaving such a fascinating woman as Gaby Morley.

VIENNA, Feb. 27. -- Great satisfaction is expressed in Austrian official circles over the forthcoming visit of Premier Milan Hodza of Czechoslovakia. It has been decided that on his arrival, now expected March 9, a new Austro-Czech commercial agreement will be initialed.

MOSCOW, Feb. 27. -- A widely circulated rumor was proved baseless today with the arrival here by airplane of Dr. Herbert Olivecrona, noted Swedish brain specialist. What he really came for was to act as consultant on an injury to I.A. Akuloff, secretary of the All-Union Central Executive Committee.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed the reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date.
WALLACE, Idaho, Feb. 27. -- Avalanches killed one youth and buried four other persons today, bringing to sixteen the death toll of snowslides this season in the Western mountain country.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 27 (AP). -- Campillo, 5-year-old black gelding of the Greenfield Stable, won the California-bred championship today at Santa Anita Park. With Bobby Jones up, Campillo ran the mile in 1:39 1-5, finishing a length ahead of Lady Florise.

GRANT JUNCTION, Tenn., Feb. 27 (AP). -- Another "queen" made an impressive bid for the championship of the bird dog world in the national field trials as Sulu, performing brilliantly, outclassed Homewood Flirtations in today's heats of the annual classic.

Pointing to increases in the city's operating expenses and to a prospect of a "mountainous burden of debt," William Church Osborn, chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission, called last night for united action by taxpayers to reduce the budget by $100,000,000 and to halt further debt increases except for projects "obviously self-supporting."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP). -- An assertion by a theatre owner that "block booking" contracts had driven "millions of patrons" away from motion picture shows, set witnesses into a sharp exchange today at a Senate subcommittee hearing on a bill to outlaw "compulsory" bulk leases of film productions.

Waiting for a train in Baltimore Mr. ROBERT FROST was caught by a reporter of its Sun. Conforming to the custom of the place, he talked politics. He even produced a political poem. His first venture in a field new to him, so far as we know, is called "To a Thinker."

Although the weather conditions in the Metropolitan area have been far from encouraging, the enthusiasm of the increasing army of skiers has not abated. This was indicated yesterday when the railroads revealed that another comprehensive schedule of "snow trains" has been arranged for this week-end to transport the skiers to the rolling slopes and snowy trails that abound in the Poconos, Berkshires, Catskills, Adirondacks and the White and Green Mountains.

TRENTON, Feb. 27. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman launched today an attack upon another of the witnesses who identified Bruno Richard Hauptmann. This time it was Joseph Anthony Perrone, the Bronx taxicab driver who took one of the ransom notes to the home of Dr. John F. Condon on March 12, 1932, and in Flemington identified the prisoner as the man who had given it to him.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27. -- The Rev. Dr. J. Oliver Buswell, president of Wheaton College, was found guilty today by the judicial committee of the Presbytery of Chicago of insubordination and conspiracy to undermine the Presbyterian Church.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler signed yesterday an order that may mean hundreds of thousands of dollars to investors in guaranteed mortgage certificates and an equal loss to the creditors and stockholders of the title companies that sold them.
LONDON, Feb. 27. -- To end the controversy which has vexed Britain for more than a century the government announced legislation to abolish tithes paid by landowners to churches.

The pressure of funds awaiting a housing boom and the enlarged channels prepared to supply the funds even of commercial banks, were the subjects of discussion yesterday at the third annual convention of the Mortgage Conference of New York in the Commodore Hotel.

Asa Ethridge's plea of haematophobia did not save him from a jail sentence in Homicide Court yesterday when he was arraigned as a hit-and-run driver. Magistrate Perlman sentenced him to fifteen days in the workhouse.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Wholesale prices advanced slightly during the week ended on Feb. 22, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The index, based on the 1926 average as 100, rose to 80.8 from 80.6 the week before.

The first thirty-seven railroads of the United States to report showed net operating income of $24,850,000 last month, against $17,690,000 in January, 1935, an increase of 40.5 per cent, and against $19,328,000 in January, 1934, an increase of 28.6 per cent, Gross revenues for January were $158,348,348, against $140,175,000 in January, 1935, a rise of 13 per cent, and against $135,509,000 in January, 1934, an upturn of 16.9 per cent.

A three-point program for dry goods wholesalers for guidance in adjustment of their processing tax claims against sellers was sent out yesterday by Flint Garrison, director general of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute.

Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., operator of mail, passenger and express air service, reported yesterday for 1935 a net income of $19,404, which was equal to 3 cents a share on 623,135 shares of $5 par value capital shares. This contrasted with a net loss of $407,702 in 1934.

BERLIN, Feb. 27. -- In retaliation for the expulsion from Sweden of three German citizens alleged to have carried on political and propaganda activities there, the German Government has summarily withdrawn the residential permits of three Swedes engaged in legitimate commercial activities in Germany.

Small and unimportant changes were shown in the report of the Federal Reserve System for the week ended on Wednesday, published yesterday. Excess reserves of member banks of the system rose $20,000,000 to $3,060,000,000, although actual reserves were up only $7,000,000 to $5,839,000,000.

Immediate reorganization of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee to raise funds to cover the deficits of twelve of the city's major family welfare agencies was announced yesterday after a meeting of prominent civic, business and philanthropic leaders in the offices of J. P. Morgan Co.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Two more ship subsidy bills were introduced in the Senate today, reviving somewhat the prospects of legislation at this session of Congress, but those closely in touch with the situation indicated that only direct and positive action by President Roosevelt would bring any actual results.

TRENTON, Feb. 27. -- James Kearns, 26 years old, shot to death his 23-year-old bride of a month and critically wounded her two sisters on the street here today. Kearns fled to Lawrence township, where he was captured.

TRENTON, Feb. 27. -- Reports were current at the State House today that Governor Hoffman and the Essex County Republican delegation in the Legislature may effect an agreement for passage of bills that would continue Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf, State Police Superintendent, and Arthur W. Magee, Acting Motor Vehicle Commissioner, in office.
TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 28. -- Efforts to induce the military insurgents, in whose revolt four great leaders have been slain, to submit peacefully had not met with success early this morning.

A slight decline this year in newspaper department store advertising percentages in relation to sales, but an increase in dollar expenditures for publicity was foreseen yesterday by F. W. Spaeth, manager of the sales promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

A demand for the employment of qualified women on equal terms with men was made yesterday by business and professional women in three countries, in connection with the annual International Night arranged by the International Federation of Business and Professional Women.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Enactment of legislation to provide for the registration of lobbyists and revelation of their sources of income was recommended today by the House Rules Committee in a report on the investigation conducted last Summer into the utilities lobby.

ATLANTA, Feb. 27 (AP). -- Fortified with almost $2,000,000 to operate his financial dictatorship, Governor Eugene Talmadge today ignored talk of impeachment and lashed out at the New Deal, which he blamed for the present state of Georgia's monetary affairs.

The American General Corporation, an investment company formed last year by consolidation of eight units in the United Founders group, reported yesterday that its net assets on Dec. 31 were valued at $50,710,385, equivalent to $2,504.52 for each $1,000 principal amount of debentures.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 27. -- The recently discovered "Delporte Object" one-third of a mile in diameter and the smallest heavenly body known excepting meteors, has been found to be an asteroid or small planet, Dr. Harlow Shapley, director of the Harvard Observatory, said today.

The removal by Kenneth F. Simpson, New York County chairman, of five Republican election inspectors in the Fourteenth Assembly District South became known yesterday as the result of charges that the removal was a retaliatory move on the part of Mr. Simpson.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- "President Roosevelt will be re-elected with more electoral votes than in 1932," Postmaster General Farley declared today in reviewing the political situation and economic trends. He based this conclusion on the prediction that Pennsylvania would be carried next November.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- There is an obstacle to the otherwise smooth strategy which the managers of Governor Landon prefer to adopt. The strategy is to keep the Governor out of all primaries except those in his own and neighboring States, where he is sure to win, and let his delegate majority come from the big uninstructed Eastern delegations.
BERLIN, Feb. 27. -- The Boerse fell slightly or, in the rather indirect phraseology of the Berlin financial press, it was "mixed."

After listening to twenty-nine speeches by representatives of teachers, civic, parent, industrial and other public groups, a mass meeting held last night in the assembly hall of the Board of Education, 500 Park Avenue, unanimously adopted a resolution to marshal public support for the proposed $300,000,000 bond issue for new schools. Copies of the resolution will be sent to the Governor and legislative leaders.

Morris Haberman, 35 years old, who described himself as a salesman, of 131 East Fifty-fifth Street, was arrested early this morning in the midtown district on charges of robbery growing out of the hold-up last year of two jewelry firms from which a total of $108,000 worth of gems was stolen.

PARIS, Feb. 27. -- By 353 votes to 164 the Chamber of Deputies decided this afternoon to ratify the five-year pact of mutual assistance between the French Republic and the Soviet Union, which has been in suspense since it was initialed last May by Pierre Laval, then Foreign Minister.

In Topics of The Times you stated that Professor James Harvey Robinson resigned from Columbia University in 1919 on the issue of academic freedom, and that "with Professor Robinson seceded his distinguished associate, Charles A. Beard."

Export of merchandise last month, as shown by the Commerce Department's report, was the largest for any January since 1931. This was in spite of $757,000 decrease from last year in shipments to Italy. The $22,200,000 increase in January's total exports over 1935 was attributable mainly to increased sales abroad of industrial machinery, motor cars, cotton and oil.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Following is the text of the new "Soil Conservation and Domestic Allotment Act," finally approved today by Congress, the first six sections constituting the old Soil Conservation Act of 1935; Sections 7 to 17, inclusive, completing the act, and Sections 2 to 5, inclusive, appended at the end, being in the nature of amendments to other existing law:

The plight of the Christian men and women who fled from Germany because of Nazi persecution and terrorism was described yesterday afternoon and evening at a conference and dinner under the auspices of the American Christian Committee for German Refugees at the Hotel Astor.
SHANGHAI, Friday, Feb. 28. -- Despite the official attempt to minimize the gravity of the Tokyo situation, many admitted facts reveal that the dangerous tension is continuing.

LONDON, Feb. 27. -- The British boycott of the 550th anniversary celebrations of Heidelberg University this Summer has become so widespread that it is doubtful whether a single university or learned society in this country will accept the invitation to send delegates.

OTTAWA, Feb. 27 (Canadian1 Press). -- Deposits by the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada decreased $6,277,080 in the week ended yesterday and deposits by chartered banks increased $6,264,055. The statement follows:
TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 28 (Reuters). -- The rebellious troops have now been given until noon to surrender.

The share market yesterday regained most of the ground lost in the three preceding days as leading stocks were bid up 1 to 4 1/2 points in the widest advance since Dec. 3. Trading, however, appeared to be mostly professional in character, and the volume of business was not increased much; the share total on the Stock Exchange was 2,310,000, against 2,019,000 the day before.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 (AP). -- The Binghamton area was the only place in up-State New York tonight where there was a threat of floods. Breaking ice Jams and falling temperatures saved a number of other communities during the day from the danger of high water.
Amateur boxing's most famous tournament, the Golden Gloves competition, swung into the homestretch at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

The Merchants Association of New York announced yesterday that it would hold a public meeting at 2 P.M. next Monday in its assembly room in the Woolworth Building to give business generally an opportunity to express its views on the pending legislative resolution to amend the State Constitution to limit real estate taxes.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27. -- The City Council passed today a bill to end the lease of the municipal gas works to the Philadelphia Gas Works Company, a subsidiary of the United Gas Improvement Company. The measure, endorsed by Mayor Wilson, notifies the Gas Works Company that the lease will not be renewed upon its expiration on Dec. 31, 1937.

Miss Lucile Thieriot, who is sailing today with her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Thieriot, on the Georgic for a West Indies cruise, gave a farewell luncheon yesterday at the Lombardy. Her guests were Mrs. Edward Rotan, Mrs. John Hamilton t{aker, Mrs. John E. Gerli, Mrs. Rodney Farson, the Misses Frances Brewster, Anne Richardson and Gigiotta ]Jertelli.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- President Roosevelt held a conference at the White House tonight to discuss taxes with Congressional leaders and discussed the relationship of business problems to social security at luncheon with members of the Business Advisory Council.

LONDON, Feb. 27. -- The following is the full text of the statement presented today by the Italian Ambassador, Dino Grandi, to Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden to explain why Italy will not sign a naval agreement at present:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The Treasury will borrow $1,250,000,000 in cash on March 16, of which about $800,000,000 will be in "new money" to help pay the bonus and other obligations. Secretary Morgenthau revealed today that, of the total cash borrowing, more than $450,000,000 will be used to pay nine issues of bills maturing on that date.

Frederick A. Muschenheim, president of the Hotel Astor Corporation, broke all precedents yesterday -- much to the delight of his press agent -- by consenting to an interview in his modest office. The occasion was his sixty-fifth birthday, which was celebrated last night with a family dinner in the Muschenheim home, an old-fashioned brownstone and brick house at 218 West Forty-fifth Street.

The performance of the uncut "Goetterdaemmerung" yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House was almost a repetition so far as members of the cast, headed by Melchior and Flagstad, were concerned. But the performance addressed itself to an audience other than those of the regular subscription series, and that audience, in a theatre filled to capacity, was quick and emphatic in showing its approval of a very fine interpretation.

LONDON, Feb. 27. -- The British Government has definitely abandoned its old formula that "there shall be no war for ten years," upon which it has based its defenses and foreign policies from year to year ever since the last war.

A fight to the finish between the Realty Advisory Board, representing large real estate interests, and Local 32B of the Building Service Employes Union, appeared probable yesterday when Walter Gordon Merritt, counsel for the building owners, declared war upon the union.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 27. -- Dnieper, Florida Derby candidate of Mrs. P.A.B. Widener, earned new prestige by the decisive manner in which he defeated seven others of his age in the Gadsden Purse at Hialeah Park today.

MONTREAL, Feb. 27 (AP). -- The Boston Bruins reduced the Rangers' margin to a single point in their battle for third place in the National Hockey League's American division by defeating the Maroons, 2 to 1, tonight, while the Rangers were taking a 4-2 setback at Detroit.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
The American open racquets championship resolved itself into a test of professional supremacy yesterday as the last of the amateurs were eliminated from the tournament at the Racquet and Tennis Club.
LONDON, Feb. 27. -- Edward VIII as King promises to be an even greater salesman for the products of the British Empire than he was as Prince of Wales.

The following film programs, which will be shown over the week-end, have been endorsed by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of faculty members and parents of children in public and private schools:

With an eye on the Olympic Games of 1940 rather than those of this year, Count Henri de Baillet-Latour of Belgium, president of the International Olympic Committee, arrived in New York yesterday on board the Italian liner Conte di Savoia.
THERE was encountered yesterday a citizen of Flatbush who was soaked with rain and steaming with indignation.
When the last big sportsmen's show was held in New York City, in 1915, there was not a single exhibit at Grand Central Palace that dealt with salt water fishing.

Moderating weather has sent prices for hogs, cattle, butter and eggs sharply lower, and The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices dropped 2.3 points to 124.9 on Tuesday from 127.2 on the Tuesday previous.

Every year, come November, December, January, when indignant citizens or citizens' groups complain about the size of certain items in the New York City budget, successive Mayors shrug their shoulders helplessly. What can they do? These items are mandatory by State legislation.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 (AP). -- Candidates for berths on America's Olympic team will be busy almost up to the day the S.S. Manhattan steams out of New York bound for Germany with the nation's champions on July 15.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Feb. 27. -- A witness at the trial of four Union County deputies for the killing of Mrs. Sophie Crempa, Scotch Plains farmer's wife, last Fall, swore on the stand today that the sheriff's men had devoted several days before the shooting to target practice.

The letter of your correspondent who quoted headlines showing the vagaries of the dollar almost gave me the jitters. I had no idea that our dollar had been acting so strangely, and certainly no notion that those who write our financial headlines could be suffering from astigmatism. So I fell to wondering what a dollar does for me and its possible vagaries in performing that duty.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 27. -- Charging that many Kansas schools are closed and teachers' salaries "notoriously low," a group of educators queried Governor Alfred Landon today as to his stand on education if elected President of the United States.

Most commodity futures gained in the local markets yesterday in less active trading. Wool top and coffee futures were lower. The recovery in silk futures was a feature. On the cash markets, corn and silk eased, while wheat, rye, cocoa, butter, eggs, lead, tin, rubber and cotton advanced.

Fifty-nine men and women received their diplomas last night as graduates of the Bellevue Schools of Nursing in the school auditorium, 440 East Twenty-sixth Street. Nearly every State in the Union, Hawaii and the Philippine Islands were represented in the classes in Bellevue and Mills Schools, affiliates of Bellevue Hospital.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., Feb. 27. -- Miss Patty Berg, 18-year-old Minneapolis star, who was runner-up to Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare for the national title last year, and 21-year-old Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky., playing in defense of her title, advanced to the semi-finals of the South Atlantic championship at the Ormond Beach Golf Club today.

An appeal to the sixty-two private hospitals which receive city subsidies to use their ward facilities to capacity to relieve overcrowding in the city's thirteen general hospitals was made yesterday by Dr. S.S. Goldwater, Hospital Commissioner.
LONDON, Feb. 27 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

As a reward for her sensational achievements in golf during 1935, when she went to the final round of the women's championship, little Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis has been included on this year's Curtis Cup team, which will represent America in the international matches with Great Britain in May.
The American Council of the Institute of Pacific Relations yesterday attributed the present uprising in Tokyo to "fundamental economic maladjustments" in Japan, according to The Associated Press.

KANSAS CITY, Feb. 27. -- Announcement that Governor Landon would not enter the Ohio primaries represents the major decision to date in the movement for the Republican Presidential nomination in behalf of the Kansan.

HONEFOSS, Norway, Feb. 27. -- During recent months and weeks I have received extremely important news, from authentic sources, relative to the terrible regime against political prisoners whose fidelity toward the Soviet Union is beyond doubt and whose only "crime" is that of criticizing the ruling bureaucracy.

PARIS, Feb. 27. -- Addressing the American Club in Paris today, Dr. Alberto Pirelli, honorary president of the International Chamber of Commerce and Italian delegate to both the Dawes Plan and Young Plan conferences, delivered a strong attack on the work of the League of Nations with the Italo-Ethiopian conflict.

DUBLIN, Feb. 27. -- Economic considerations forced the Irish Free State to make the recent coal-cattle trade pact with Great Britain, President Eamon de Valera admitted in the Dail Eireann tonight. He spoke on a bill introduced to give Parliamentary sanction to the agreement.

The powerful Thomas Jefferson High School quintet gained its sixth Brooklyn P.S.A.L. victory in as many starts by crushing Eastern District High, 31 -- 17, at the Jefferson gymnasium in Brooklyn in one of the feature schoolboy games played yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Feb. 27. -- Answering the challenge by A.A. Baroni to match his Santa Anita champion Top Row against any and all comers for a side bet of $50,000, Bud Stotler, trainer of A.G. Vanderbilt's Discovery, speaking for Vanderbilt, accepted the issue today and declared that his stable would run Discovery against Top Row "any time and any place."

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, presiding at a meeting at Town Hall last night, heard Mrs. Eugene Meyer, wife of the publisher of The Washington Post, bitterly assail the New Deal program as "bewildering experimentation," while many in the audience of more than 1,500 persons booed and cheered the speaker.

OUT of the brutal reality of operating rooms and vivisection laboratories, out of weeks at base hospitals during the war and years of experimentation before and since that time, George Washington Crile, a great surgeon and something of a romantic philosopher, has evolved a hypothesis which stretches like a lacy dream bridge beyond the frontier of positive knowledge toward the discovery of the fundamental nature of the living processes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- With scarcely a dissenting voice and with little argument, the Senate and House completed action on the administration's $500,000,000 Soil Conservation Bill today. President Roosevelt's signature is said to be assured before the end of the week.

The most impressive feature of yesterday's advance in stock prices was the quality of the leadership. Before the market declined last week, many low-priced stocks of dubious merit were being purchased eagerly, and it was said they were being taken by those who were poorly informed.

EL PASO, Texas, Feb. 27 (AP). -- Power from picketed plants of the El Paso Electric Company lighted this city and twenty-six surrounding communities in New Mexico and Texas again tonight after a sudden stoppage by a strike early in the day.
LA GRANGE, Ky., Feb. 27 (AP). -- David W. Griffith, movie producer, has at last decided to free himself legally from the wife with whom he has not lived for twenty-five years.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 27. -- Paraguayan revolutionary leaders today published a proclamation in the name of the army, characterizing the Buenos Aires peace pact as laughable, as a "consummation of the continual criminal treason" against Paraguay by the deposed regime dating from 1913.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Broadway song writers and their spokesmen again today assailed the broadcasting companies, the large hotels, the motion-picture producers and the taverns and cabarets of the country as "pirates" of copyright music, as the House Committee on Patents continued its hearing upon pending copyright legislation.

The securities of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation of Delaware, following the merger of the New Jersey corporation and its subsidiaries, were admitted to the list by the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. They comprised the 7 per cent cumulative preferred $100-par value stock, the 5 per cent cumulative preferred $20-par value stock and the no-par common stock.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 27 (AP). -- Torrents of ice-gorged water from mountain streams poured into cities and towns of Western Pennsylvania today, raising the death toll to four and causing property damage far into the thousands while a new cold wave bore down on the region.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 27. -- Nearly 150 were entertained today at the tea Mr. and Mrs. Charles Lewis Harding gave in the patio and grounds of Chiora for their guests, the Hon. Mrs. Mount Joy Fane and Miss Mary Sherrard of London, his niece.

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 28 (by transpacific telephone to San Francisco). -- Japan, facing prospective military or Fascist government, waited tensely this morning as the army insurgents in Tokyo failed to carry out an offer to return to their barracks by 8 A.M.

January sales of the reporting wholesale firms averaged about 12 1/2 per cent higher than a year ago, the Federal Reserve agent here indicated yesterday, a somewhat larger increase than in the two preceding months. This favorable comparison was due in considerable part to a gain in sales of the men's clothing concerns, which showed the largest advance over a year previous since March, 1934.

Asserting that "a situation more damaging and extensive than had originally been imagined is now before us," the City Affairs Committee announced yesterday that it would postpone the presentation of charges against District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Kings County pending the outcome of the new developments in the Drukman murder case.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27. -- Arrivals of hogs here were sharply lower today because of severe snowstorms in parts of Iowa, Minnesota and Wisconsin and the recent drastic reduction in prices. A somewhat more general demand resulted in sales today showing 10 to 40 cents a hundredweight above Wednesday's, with weights under 170 pounds showing the most appreciation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- President Roosevelt informed Congressional leaders tonight that he would send a message to Congress, probably early next week, demanding increased taxes to bring the ordinary budget back into balance during the fiscal year 1936-37, including provisions for amortizing the additional cost of prepayment of the veterans' bonus voted by Congress over his veto.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 27 (AP). -- Frank E. Gannett, newspaper publisher whose name is on the Ohio primary ballot as "second choice" to Senator Borah, asserted today that the Senator provided the only hope of accomplishing what Mr. Gannett said must be the Republican campaign cry -- "beat Roosevelt."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull sent an official message of regret to Foreign Minister Koki Hirota of Japan today on the assassination of officials in Tokyo.

Early tomorrow afternoon the members of the New York group of the Yankees' first squad will leave for the club's training camp at St. Petersburg, Fla. They are scheduled to depart from the Pennsylvania station at 12:38 o'clock on the Seaboard Air Line's "Orange Blossom Special."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The France-Soviet pact that the Chamber of Deputies ratified today differs materially from the offensive and defensive alliance between France and Russia that existed at the outbreak of the World War. The present arrangement is a treaty of mutual assistance, operative only in the event the territory of one of the signatories is the object of an unprovoked aggression by a European power.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 27. -- Argentina today sent two cruisers to Rio de Janeiro carrying the Minister of Marine, Rear Admiral Eleazar Videla, and a large good-will mission to Brazil. Admiral Videla will represent President Agustin Justo at the graduating exercises of the Brazilian Naval Academy, when commissions will be given to cadets who accompanied President Getulio Vargas of Brazil on his visit to Buenos Aires last year.

AURORA, Ill., Feb. 27. -- The eligible bachelors of Aurora, a long list of whom is posted in the City Hall, are expected to scurry to cover Saturday as women officially take over the town in observance of the extra day which makes 1986 a leap year.

ROME, Feb. 27. -- Premier Benito Mussolini this evening received the French Ambassador, Count Charles de Chambrun, who called to inform him that, according to current reports, the French Government would do everything in its power at Geneva next week to avert a further stiffening of sanctions.

LONDON, Feb. 27. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange were irregular and prices were unsettled today because of the Japanese crisis, although the tendency was steadier. Yesterday's small rally in Japanese bonds was not held, renewed weakness developing on reports from the Far East.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- A new housing program for persons of small incomes was put forward today by the American Federation of Labor. It asked for an expenditure in two years of $500,000,000 by the Federal Government.
FRANKFURT-AM-MIAN, Germany, Feb. 27 -- German coal research workers claim a new success, saying they have solved the problem of producing fat and ultimately soap from coal.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- As a result of disclosures before the Senate Munitions Committee that obsolete and discarded service machine guns have fallen into the hands of South American insurrectionists, Attorney General Cummings announced today that he had begun an investigation into that situation and also to determine whether some of these weapons had been acquired by American gangsters.

BERLIN, Feb. 27. -- An impressive symbol of Germany's reviving industrial prosperity was provided today when the Vereinigte Stahlwerke, Germany's steel trust and biggest single concern, declared a dividend of 3 1/2 per cent, the first dividend since 1930.

Despite the announced opposition of Broadway theatrical managers, members of the Dramatists Guild of America, meeting yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Shelton, unanimously ratified the terms of a new basic agreement covering the production of plays which would curtail the participation of the managers in both the disposition and financial proceeds from the sale of film rights to produced plays.
The case of Major Gen. Hagood raises a constitutional issue which far transcends any point involved in the treatment of a particular army officer. The question is simply this:

The Maritime Association appealed yesterday to members of Congress representing seaboard districts to oppose the bill sponsored by Representative Pettengill which would abolish the fourth section of the Interstate Commerce Act.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- No member of the Roosevelt family will be named as successor to Henry L. Roosevelt, Assistant Secretary of the Navy and a distant cousin of the President, who died unexpectedly Saturday. Five of the family have held the position in little more than a generation.

The Norfolk Western Railway is to spend $5,000,000 in the construction of 1,000 coal cars and five Mallet locomotives, the purchase of 20,000 tons of rails and the enlargement of switching yards, according to advices from Roanoke, Va.

An amended bill to restore the salaries of the city's public school teachers, which were cut in 1932, replacing the original Feld-Crews bill, was approved last night by the executive committee of the Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations at a special meeting at 130 West Forty-second Street.

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 28. -- Premier Keisuke Okada met his death in the snow in the garden of his residence Wednesday morning. He was called out by the army insurgents and tried to flee across it. He was shot down and his assassins drew a single mat over his body.

Like TOLSTOY, PAVLOV lived the life of an individualist. Czars might come and go, bourgeois might be mowed down like grass in the public squares, the heavens themselves might cave, but he kept on experimenting with his dogs, rats and monkeys. When an assistant explained that the revolution had stopped all street vehicles and made him ]ate, PAVLOV grumbled: "That is no excuse."

With the splendid record of twelve victories in fourteen bouts to his credit, S. Thompson Stewart Jr. of the Salle d'Armes Vince captured the national junior saber crown last night on the New York University strips in the East Building at Washington Square.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 27. -- The Tokyo assassinations must be considered as additional proof that Japan is "still in the throes of an economic upheaval resulting from the industrial revolution that began in Japan some seventy years ago," said Dr. Robert K. Reischauer of the Princeton Department of Politics in an interview here today.

District Attorney Geoghan of Brooklyn yesterday exonerated Detectives Frank Bowman and Otto Tietgen of the Fourth Avenue precinct in Brooklyn in connection with the fatal shooting on Tuesday night of Leonard Epstein, 24 years old, who was felled during an attempted hold-up of a liquor store owned by his father at 4,820 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn.

ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- In the wake of testimony at public hearings, the Republicans in the Assembly pushed ahead today with their program for challenging Governor Lehman and the Democrats on the score of an inquiry into the basic causes of unemployment relief.

A woman teacher, accused of striking a 10-year-old Negro boy who, she said, had called obscene names after her, was paroled for trial in Special Sessions on a charge of simple assault yesterday by Magistrate Earl A. Smith in Washington Heights Court.

LONDON, Feb. 27 (AP). -- Normal conditions have been "practically restored" in Tokyo after a military rebellion, a communique received by the Japanese Embassy here from the Tokyo Foreign Office announced today.

An expression from Pope Pius XI invoking "prosperity and happiness" to non-Catholics who assisted in the National Eucharistic Congress in Cleveland last Fall, is contained in a letter to Cardinal Hayes from Cardinal Pacelli, Papal Secretary of State.

More than 100 American artists have donated examples of their work in painting, sculpture, lithography, etching and drawing as a nucleus for the foundation of a museum in Biro-Bidjan, the autonomous Jewish region in the Far East in the U.S.S.R., according to the announcement yesterday by the Art Commission for the Biro-Bidjan, 799 Broadway.

The junior class of Columbia College will hold its annual prom tonight in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Guests of honor will include Dean and Mrs. Herbert E. Hawkes, Associate Dean and Mrs. Nicholas McD. McKnight, Dr. and Mrs. Robert L. Carey and Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Hubbard. They will occupy a box.
WINCHESTER, Mass., Feb. 27. -- A 200-year-old grandfather clock here stopped at the same moment its 73-year-old owner died in Ancaster, Ont., several hundred miles away, his sons said today.

NEWTON, N.J., Feb. 27. -- Dr. John V. Ward, 38 years old, of Ridgefield, N.J., prominent pediatrician and war veteran, was found dead last night in his automobile parked in the Vernon-Warwick Road here. A garden hose had been inserted in the exhaust pipe to lead carbon monoxide gas into the car.

Motor buses on Broadway, between South Ferry and Times Square, are carrying at least 50 per cent more passengers than did the trolley cars which they replaced, according to estimates made yesterday on the basis of figures being compiled by the Transit Commission and the operating company.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 27. -- Interpreting the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Law as permitting the transportation into this State of liquor purchased in other States for personal use, Judge Gerald Nolan of Westchester County dismissed today an indictment against Joseph Ryan, 40 years old, of 756 Main Street, New Rochelle.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Problems arising in the relationship between conduct of normal business and administration of the Social Security Act were discussed today by President Roosevelt and the members of the Business Advisory Council, who were his guests at a White House luncheon. No conclusions were reached, it was stated.

Bank clearings for the five days ended on Wednesday registered a gain, with the total for twenty-two leading cities at $5,018,780,000, compared with $4,609,952,000 for the same period of 1935, an increase of 8.9 per cent, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Business men were urged last night by Judge Jeremiah T. Mahoney, former president of the Amateur Athletic Union, to follow the rules of sport and not take unfair advantage of their competitors. Speaking at a dinner at the Hotel Astor, which marked the close of the eighteenth annual convention of the National Knitted Outerwear Association, Judge Mahoney declared that in business, as well as sports, "we all like to applaud an honest winner."
