Financial markets continued generally unperturbed yesterday by the events in Japan. The yen, which had declined 27 points on Wednesday, recovered 6 points to 28.96 cents. Japanese bonds felt the pressure of further selling and some of them fell 2 or more points on top of similar losses the previous day.

Greater participation by business men in governmental affairs and particularly a more active part in legislative committee hearings was urged yesterday by Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York and of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, at a luncheon of the Advertising Club.

CLEARWATER, Fla., Feb. 27. -- Manager Casey Stengel of the Dodgers, affable but not too informative, confident, but not overconfident, paced up and down in his hotel suite this afternoon discussing his practically new ball club.

The War Department has shown excellent judgment in breaking its usual rule of silence in such matters and in making public a memorandum on the disciplinary action taken in the case of Major Gen. HAGOOD. The incident has aroused so much controversy, both inside and outside Congress, that it is desirable to have a statement of all relevant facts.

An "amicable" understanding has been reached between the Fashion Originators Guild of America and Lord Taylor, terminating the "red carding" of that store by the guild, according to announcement made last night by Maurice Rentner.

Protesting against what he termed the "law's delays," Heywood Broun, president of the American Newspaper Guild, addressed a letter yesterday to Federal Judge William Bondy, urging him to come to a "speedy ruling" on the application of The Associated Press for an order restraining the National Labor Relations Board from conducting a hearing on the Morris Watson case.

The Commonwealth of Massachusetts has issued a call for bids for a new issue of $900,000 of notes, award of which will be made on Monday. The notes will be dated March 6, and become payable on July 8.
Large apartments in buildings on Fifth and Park Avenues and adjoining streets were leased to new tenants yesterday.

A six-story apartment house to be built at 54-70 Cooper Street will cost $250,000, according to plans filed yesterday by Miller Goldhammer, architects, for the T. G, R, Construction Corporation, Morris A. Goodman, president, of 1,450 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- In line with its study of investment trusts and investment companies, the Securities and Exchange Commission has sent a questionnaire to about 100 depositors for some 225 trust-share issues of unincorporated and incorporated fixed and semi-fixed investment trusts.

Nine men arrested late Wednesday in the Hotel Alvin, 223 West Fifty-second Street, pleaded not guilty yesterday morning in Jamaica (Queens) Court to charges that they took part in a $20,000 hold-up at 11 P.M. Feb. 5 in the office of Charles W. Froessel at 161-19 Jamaica Avenue.

BERLIN, Feb. 27. -- If ratification of the France-Soviet mutual assistance pact provokes surprise in German official and political quarters it is only because of the impressive majority with which the Chamber of Deputies rewarded Foreign Minister Pierre-Etienne Flandin's eleventh-hour appeal.

Virginia has sprung to the defense of one of her very first families in taking up the cause of Captain JOHN SMITH. Writers on the Virginia section of the WPA guidebook of the United States have brought forward one incident which reflects no credit, at least by modern standards, on the co-founder of Jamestown and the good friend of POCAHONTAS.
AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 27. -- A plan to end the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company strike has been submitted to the union and the management by Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor.

PENSACOLA, Fla., Feb. 27. -- Toiling away at an as yet undetermined wage, nominally set at the munificent salary of one dollar a year, may not seem to be much of an incentive for any man, least of all one who rates as an experienced and accepted master at his calling.

Prediction that the coming coronation ceremonies in London will have an influence on fashions was made at the February luncheon meeting of the Fashion Group, Inc., of 30 Rockefeller Plaza, in the main ballroom of the Hotel Biltmore yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Frederick L. Adams, chief investigator and special agent of the Bureau of Navigation and Steamboat Inspection, who with Commander H. McCoy Jones was dismissed by Secretary Roper for "violent and explosive insubordination," rejected as "obnoxious" a conditional offer today from the Commerce Secretary that he voluntarily resign.
Leases of space in business structures in the city continued again yesterday when brokers and renting agents of buldings here reported a wide variety of rentals.
PARIS, Feb. 27 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP). -- Major Gen. Johnson Hagood formally relinquished command of the Eighth Corps Area and the Third Army at San Antonio today as Congressional friends here failed in an effort to have his "punishment" set aside or modified.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Justice Jesse C. Atkins in the District Supreme Court today set for hearing on March 30 five of more than twenty suits in which utility companies seek injunctions to prevent the allocation of PWA funds to municipalities for the construction of power plants.

Retail package deliveries in metropolitan and suburban areas showed an increase of 3 per cent for the week ended Feb. 22, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The figure is slightly under that for the preceding week when a gain of 4 per cent in number of packages handled was reported.

Many reservations have been made for the performance of "Heidi" to be given tomorrow morning at the Barbizon-Plaza Theatre by the Clare Tree Major Players for the benefit of the Children's Welfare Federation. Dr. Victor Nef, the Swiss Consul General, and his young daughter, Miss Irene Nef, will be guests of honor at the performance, the fifth in a series of six plays being presented for the same beneficiary.

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 28 (By Radiophone to Shanghai). -- A condition of the greatest tension continues in Tokyo after Wednesday's assassinations of political leaders, the revolting troops refusing to capitulate. They are still occupying the unfinished Diet building at 11:30 this morning and are surrounded by an immense force of the regular army, but defy demands to surrender.

With mills starting the formal showings of men's wear Fall fabrics, the wool goods markets turned more active this week, according to the New York Wool Top Exchange Service. A large number of buyers were in the market, placing substantial commitments for delivery over the next four months and providing mills with specifications on their contracts.

Coincident with the issuance of its preliminary income account for 1935, showing earnings of $1.29 a share on the common capital stock, the Anaconda Copper Mining Company yesterday announced that its directors had declared a dividend of 25 cents a share, the first since 1931.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP). -- The Interstate Commerce Commission appointed today Thomas L. Hanson of New Jersey and M.C. Cleveland of New York to a joint board to aid in administration of the 1935 Motor Carrier Act in those States.
DETROIT, Feb. 27. -- Detroit's pace-setting Red Wings snapped New York's string of nine National Hockey League games without defeat tonight, trimming the Rangers, 4 -- 2, before 9,000 fans.

A very agreeable "Concertino" in F minor by Giovanni Pergolesi, edited by that true musician and exceptional investigator of old music, Sam Franko, opened the Philharmonic-Symphony concert, conducted by Hans Lange, last night in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Franko has reinforced Pergolesi's writing, apparently exercising discretion and perspicacity in the business, with some middle parts, some "imitations" and a little counterpoint.

ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- A preliminary tabulation of reports governing about 14,000 retail trade firms in New York State shows that from mid-December to mid-January employment dropped nearly 19 per cent, and payrolls declined about 14 per cent. According to a statement

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Ohio organization Republicans pitted a "favorite son" Presidential candidate today against Senator William E. Borah of Idaho for control of the State's fifty-two delegates to the National Convention, reiterating a decision made months ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Feb. 26, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,482,000,000, a decrease of $22,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $29,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1935.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission published today a summary showing that in January registration statements covering $275,696,001 became fully effective, thus releasing the securities for sale. This compares with $212,084,096 effective in December and $11,044,405 in January, 1935.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27. -- A resumption of speculative buying of wheat futures on the Board of Trade today, attributed partly to local short-covering, lifted prices for all deliveries to a new high level for the curent movement, the May selling at the best figure since late in January.

ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- Speaker Irving M. Ives of the Assembly announced tonight that he would reply over the radio on March 7 to Governor Lehman's recent attack on the air upon Assembly foes of his crime program.

A reduction of about 50 per cent in the administrative personnel of the main office of the WPA, with a consequent saving of more than $300,000 a month in salaries and wages, was announced yesterday by Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator.

The action of the Securities and Exchange Commission in requesting the New York Stock Exchange to resume the collection of reports of trading by members for their own account has again raised the question whether these figures will be made public by the commission.

James Monroe High School's quintet hurdled another obstacle in its path toward an unbeaten league season when it routed Morris High, 34 -- 12, in a Bronx division P.S. A.L. contest at the Monroe gymnasium yesterday. The triumph was Monroe's sixth straight in the tournament and strengthened the Crimson and Gold tossers' hold on first place.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Charges that Representative Blanton of Texas questioned General Johnson Hagood at length and in detail about the Works Progress Administration at the secret committee meeting which resulted in the punishment of the general by the War Department, but that Mr. Blanton later deleted his own questions from the record, leaving the remarks of the general intact, were sent to Secretary Dern tonight by Senator Byrnes.
Alexander Grosset, former head of the publishing house of Grosset Dunlap, who died Oct. 27, 1934, at Greenwich, Conn., left an estate appraised yesterday at $1,579,713 gross and $1,524,192 net.

Miss Marion Lloyd, Salle d'Armes Vince star and member of the last two American Olympic teams, captured the round-robin final in the first of a series of Olympic fencing try-outs for women held last night at the Fencers Club under the auspices of the A.F.L.A. The former national titleholder swept through her five bouts in the preliminary round and captured all seven tests in the final.

A trustee's report on the results of operations of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation, now in reorganization, filed in the Federal court yesterday indicated a net profit in 1935 of $665,297 by the corporation and its subsidiaries.

New York University's swimming team defeated Carnegie Tech, 45 to 23, yesterday in the Park Central Hotel pool. It was the fifth triumph in eight starts for Coach Frank Wall's squad and the closing meet of one of the best seasons enjoyed by the Violet in several years.

A Stradivarius violin, insured for $30,000, was stolen last night from the star's dressing room at Carnegie Hall while its owner, Bronislaw Huberman, the Polish violinist, was giving a recital on the stage one flight below.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, ordered immediate cessation today of work on four vocational schools being built in Mississippi, upon finding truth in charges that in reality they were factories. It was charged that the municipalities which constructed them already had made contracts with textile firms for the use of the buildings, and in one case for its sale at less than one-third its cost.
Kenneth Chantler of Montreal and Norbert Setzler of the Racquet and Tennis Club will meet today at 2:30 o'clock for the American open racquets championship.

An axiom of Broadway and the entertainment world is that Washington's Birthday marks the end of the Winter season, the climax of heavy spending, the beginning of comparatively lean pickings. Indications during the past week and promises for the immediate future would appear to prove the point.

Dr. Mary L. Jobe Akeley, African explorer, returned on the Hamburg-American liner Hansa yesterday from her ethnological study of Southeastern Africa, but she reserved making public her findings until a later date. She said she preferred first to talk over her experiences and data with colleagues at the American Museum of Natural History.

A report holding the Fashion Originators Guild of America to be "an unlawful combination which violates the Sherman and Clayton anti-trust laws" was sent yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association to member stores throughout the country.
The admission of eight new partners to member firms was announced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange as follows:

CHICAGO, Feb. 28. -- A warning of the danger of an unsound inflation of credit has been given by the Federal Advisory Council in a recommendation to the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System that a substantial increase be made in the reserve requirements of member banks.

Mrs. Hilda M. Peterson, 42 years old; Charles H. George, 62, a lawyer, and John J. Langan, 41, were acquitted by a General Sessions jury yesterday after a three-week trial on an indictment charging that they aided her fugitive husband, William F. Peterson, to defraud Mrs. Marie Y. deCarie of 300 Park Avenue of $23,000 in his fake stock-trading scheme.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

The huge audience which packed Carnegie Hall last night to hear Bronislaw Huberman, the Polish violinist, in his first recital of the season, witnessed the unusual sight, at such an event, of a soloist acting from time to time as conductor of an accompanying chamber orchestra.

Assertions that the Bank of the Manhattan Company and the former directors of the New York Title and Mortgage Company and its subsidiary, the National Mortgage Corporation, could pay much more than the $1,475,000 which Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, was willing to accept in settlement of two suits for $22,500,000 damages were made yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Frankenthaler in argument against approval of the settlement.

Miss Helen Locus, New York University's high-scoring right forward, again led the Violet girls' basketball team to victory yesterday. Tallying 27 points, she enabled the Violet to triumph over St. Joseph's College, 39 to 16, on the court of the School of Education at Washington Square.

L.J. Hershfield and H. Herbert, both formerly of the Brooks Uniform Company, have been appointed to take charge of the sales department at the Joseph F. Webber Uniform Corporation, at 273 Fifth Avenue.

Several bills on Governor Lehman's anti-crime program were approved in a report of the legislative advisory committee of the New York County Republican Committee, submitted yesterday by Harold Riegelman, its chairman, to County Chairman Kenneth S. Simpson.

Details of the plan of reorganization for the Colon Oil Corporation were not approved yesterday by Federal Judge Goddard when submitted by counsel for the company, but he said he believed the plan to be fair and equitable and set March 13 for further hearings on it.

Bus lines operating in competition with railroads will probably meet the reduction in fares for the railroads ordered by the Interstate Commerce Commission, executives of bus systems said here yesterday.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 28. -- The State closed its case today in the trial of four deputy sheriffs charged with manslaughter in connection with the killing last Fall of Mrs. Sophie Crempa, Scotch Plains farmer's wife.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Pursuing his purpose to restore the government's fiscal outlook to the brightness with which it shone before the Supreme Court invalidated the agricultural processing taxes and Congress forced prepayment of the veterans' bonus over his veto, President Roosevelt today projected a tax bill designed to raise at least $786,000,000 annually in additional revenue for the next three years, then $620,000,000 a year for the following six.

Business pushed forward with more freedom in all directions this week as the result of more favorable weather conditions, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The volume of retail buying rose to the highest level in three weeks, the agency says, and in some sections the gain was 15 to 20 per cent over the preceding week.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 28. -- Charges that an effort had been made to get members of the New Jersey State Police to admit that evidence was "framed" in the preparation of the case against Bruno Richard Hauptmann were made to Governor Harold G. Hoffman today.

LONDON, Feb. 28. -- "A few days ago," says this week's issue of The Engineer, "a few visitors were shown samples of the work carried out on the metal bonding process invented and developed by F.F. Gordon, director of Speak Jackson, Ltd., Sheffield.

The first of a series of two orchestral concerts under the leadership of Paul Stassevitch took place in Town Hall last night. Mr. Stassevitch led a group of some fifty-five players of strings and woodwinds through a program well adapted to the intimate atmosphere of Town Hall.

DALLAS, Feb. 28 (AP). -- The Dizzy Dean holdout began to look alarmingly genuine tonight. The St. Louis Cardinal hurler not only talked of quitting the diamond "for at least a year" but started dickering for a hand in other interests.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week amounts to only $14,121,795, representing fifty-five municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $25,519,772 for this week. The weekly average for the year to date is $22,654,495.

FRANK SIMONDS, before his death last month, had pretty well succeeded in establishing in the mind of the reading public the categories of the "satisfied" and the "hungry," or the "have" and the "have-not" nations. Germany, Italy and Japan he placed in the "have-not" classification. These countries, he said, need sources of raw materials and outlets for growing population pressure.

Construction of the West Side Improvement under the revised plan prepared by Park Commissioner Moses is adding twenty acres of land, valued conservatively at $8,000,000, to Riverside Park, it became known yesterday. This is incidental to the main purpose of the improvement: the covering of the New York Central tracks and the extension of the West Side highway to 129th Street.

In a little more than a month another trout season will roll around. That realization in itself is enough to start trouters digging through closets and examining rods and lines, but the mild, spring-like weather of the past few days has provided additional incentive to check up on last year's equipment.

The fast skating Jamaica High School sextet gained sole possession of first place in the Metropolitan Interscholastic Hockey League by routing Poly Prep, 4 -- 1, in the feature game of a double-header last night at the Brooklyn Ice Palace. The Queens six previously had shared the lead with New Utrecht, which was idle last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Presenting a solid front in opposition to the Pettingill-Neely bill to outlaw the trade practices known as "block booking" and "blind selling," film producers told the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce today that it is no fault of theirs that Mae West and "Little Caesar" are more popular with American audiences than are "Abraham Lincoln," "Alexander Hamilton" and "Alice in Wonderland."

Net assets of the Equity Corporation were valued at $24,053,370 at the close of 1935, equivalent to $7,647 for each $1,000 debenture, to $81.17 a share of $3 convertible preferred stock and to $1.58 a share of common stock, it was reported yesterday.

The breaking of a thirty-inch water main in the Woodside section of Queens at 4:30 A.M. yesterday put a mile of city subway out of service for nearly twelve hours, disrupted rush-hour travel into Manhattan, flooded near-by streets, filled hundreds of cellars with water and left thousands of householders without water, gas and electricity for several hours.

I desire to express my appreciation of your editorial this morning in which you commend the Senate at Albany for rejecting the proposal to make our Unemployment Insurance Law inoperative in the event that the Federal Social Security Act is declared unconstitutional.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 28 (AP). -- The Iowa State Republican Committee gave free rein to its twenty-two delegates today in choosing a Presidential candidate at the National Convention, and adopted a ten-point farm program.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange improved yesterday, led by the March delivery, which moved up to 11.19 cents a pound without encountering, selling orders from the pool. Continued dry weather and deficiency of moisture in the Western Cotton Belt influenced trading in new-crop months and left the list 1 to 6 points higher on the day.

Two closings are definite for this evening, and one or two more may be achieved secretly in the dead of night "Winterset" leaves the Martin Beck, where it has lingered through 178 performances, and "Hallowe'en" departs the Vanderbilt after an even dozen.

Herbert Benjamin, secretary-treasurer of the National Unemployment Council, a Left Wing Communist organization, will be called before a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn early next week, it was announced yesterday by Commissioner of Accounts Paul Blanshard, to substantiate his charges that $1,000,000 weekly is being wasted on 40,000 persons fraudulently placed on WPA rolls.

Robert Lehman and Cecil P. Stewart have been appointed by committees acting for approximately 60 per cent of the outstanding bonds of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation to deal with the question of effecting an economically sound merger in the communications industry, Mr. Stewart, chairman of the independent committee, said yesterday in a letter to bondholders.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 28. -- The Chilean Government this afternoon suppressed a revolutionary movement led by a group of retired army officers, according to censored dispatches from Santiago tonight. The insurgents attempted to capture General Novoa, commander-in-chief of the army, in an effort to seize the reins of government, according to the report.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28. -- Max Hauser, a new York jewelry salesman, was robbed of $33,000 to $34,000 in unset diamonds today by three bandits, who kidnapped him just before noon from a taxicab in front of a hotel on North Michigan Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- A general downward revision of basic railroad passenger fares to 2 cents a mile in coaches and 3 cents in Pullman cars, whether one way or round trip, was ordered today by the Interstate Commerce Commission in its most important decision since 1920.

LONDON, Saturday, Feb. 29. -- Lord Horder, physician-in-ordinary to King Edward, paid an unexpectedly early visit today to Countess Haugwitz-Reventlow, the former Barbara Hutton, hovering between life and death after the birth of her first child and an operation.

TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 29 (Reuters). -- The army mutineers, who had promised to return to their barracks by 8 o'clock yesterday morning, were still occupying various government buildings twenty-four hours later.

Towboat operators changed their traditional opposition to the extension of harbor lines within the port district yesterday when they endorsed the proposal of Borough President Ingersoll to extend the bulkhead line along the Sheepshead Bay line by twenty-five feet.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28. -- Urgent short covering in wheat on the Board of Trade apparently ran its course today, and while the market showed stubborn resistance to selling pressure in the face of weakness in Liverpool, bulges were not maintained and the close was 1/8 to 5/8 cent a bushel lower than yesterday, May leading the decline.

PARIS, Feb. 28. -- French opinion in response to Chancellor Adolf Hitler's offer of friendship, conveyed in an interview with Bertrand de Jouvenel published in the Paris Midi today, appears to be inclined to answer, "At what price?"

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 28. -- It was learned in Chaco peace conference circles today that diplomatic recognition of the new government in Paraguay probably would not be extended generally unless it formally agrees to abide by the peace protocols already signed.
Six of Canada's leading women skaters will be featured in a specialty number in the International Skating Carnival on March 22 at Madison Square Garden, it was announced yesterday.

The order of the Interstate Commerce Commission calling for a reduction in the basic passenger fare was considered by railroad men here a victory for the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, which, alone among the important passenger-carrying lines in the East, has advocated the tariff embodied in the commission's decision.

Tears of happiness will come to the eyes of some hundreds of New Yorkers when the curtain rises at the Golden Theatre and WILLIAM GILLETTE once more treads the New York stage. Those who have seen him on his recent tour of a few weeks out of town report that audiences everywhere find it difficult to believe his 80 years, for he seems actually younger than when he was Sherlock Holmes six years ago.

The decision of the Interstate Commerce Commission ordering a reduction in railroad passenger rates from the present standard level of 3.6 cents a mile in the East to 2 cents a mile for coaches and 3 cents for Pullmans is one of the most interesting and important decisions of its history.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- The Kingdom of Norway has filed an amendment to its registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 for the issuance of $17,000,000 of twenty-year 4 1/2 per cent sinking fund external loan coupon bonds due on March 1, 1956, fixing March 2 as the offering date.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- An outline of his plans for tax legislation to raise $786,000,000 annually for three years and $620,000,000 annually thereafter was given by President Roosevelt at his press conference. The President also issued an executive order earmarking $30,000,000 for seed loans to farmers.

LONDON, Feb. 28. -- Operations in the London Stock Exchange today were quiet, but prices were firm, sentiment being helped by Wall Street's sharp recovery yesterday. British funds were weakened further by prospects of more corporation loans soon.
LONDON, Feb. 28 (AP). -- The United States women's squash racquets team lost the second match of its tour today, falling before the Kensington Country Club team, 4 -- 1.

The news, cabled yesterday, of the death of Antonio Scotti in Naples recalls another occasion, still fresh in the memory of thousands of the music lovers of this city, which happened three years ago, or a few days more than three years ago -- to be exact, on Jan. 20, 1933.

Owen D. Young, national chairman of the campaign of the Thomas Alva Edison Foundation, announced yesterday that the funds raised in its current drive would finance grants for intensive technical training to one or more youths from every State in the Union.

ATLANTA, Feb. 28 (AP). -- Holding that it is the duty of the State courts to determine Georgia's legal officials, the Postoffice Department today reopened the mails to Governor Eugene Talmadge's de facto officers, named under his financial "dictatorship."

Six leaders of a boss barbers organization, which at one time had 6,000 members in this city, were found guilty in General Sessions yesterday on a conspiracy charge in connection with a campaign of sabotage in 1934 and 1935 in which 300 plate-glass windows were smashed to intimidate non-members to raise prices.

GRAND JUNCTION, Tenn., Feb. 28. -- Four contenders for the national bird dog championship slipped out of the running today, as they failed to display the hunting form that had stamped them as threats.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Applications by several additional corporations to have information concerning salaries and other data held confidential have been denied by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the information has been made public.

BERLIN, Feb. 28. -- An international unofficial conference to consider ways to satisfy the colonial and raw material demands of dissatisfied powers has beer called by the Royal Institute for International Affairs to meet in London in the Summer of 1937.
Being one of those women who receive the relief allowance given by the A.I.C.P. and having lived comfortably for two years on $8 a week, I am constrained to write in defense of the A.I.C.P.

The appointments of George L. Harrison as president and Allan Sproul as first vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York for terms of five years each commencing tomorrow were announced yesterday.
Suburban realty trading increased yesterday, housing deals being reported in various parts of the area surrounding the city.

The consolidated income account of the Johns-Manville Corporation and subsidiaries, exclusive of the Johns-Manville Credit Corporation, was made public yesterday and showed for 1935 a net profit of $2,164,858 after deducting provisions for depreciation, depletion, obsolescence and Federal taxes. The profit was equivalent, after allowing for 7 per cent dividends on $7,500,000 of preferred stock, to $2.19 a share on 750,000 common shares.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

PARIS, Feb. 28 (AP). -- Karl Schafer of Austria again showed his superiority over the world's ranking men figure skaters today when he paced sixteen rivals from nine nations through the compulsory figures in defense of his world championship.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
Grand Central Palace echoed to the pounding of hammers up to a late hour last night as more than 200 workmen rushed to complete preparations for the opening of the National Sportsmen's Show today.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, Feb. 28. -- Heidelberg University's official Student League issued today a protest against the decision of Birmingham University in England not to send delegates to the exercises in June celebrating the 550th anniversary of the founding of Heidelberg.
Chuji Machida, who has been appointed Japanese Finance Minister in place of the slain Korekiyo Takahashi, is expected to carry one of the heaviest burdens of the new Cabinet.

The founder and late editor of The Iconoclast once declared that "there is something in the soil that gives flavor to literature and it is death to transplant it." One wonders if Owen D. Young has not succumbed more or less to be able to discern anything alarming in the speeches he dispassionately discusses in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

LONDON, Feb. 28. -- France today showed new and surprising willingness to initial a naval treaty almost exactly along the lines of the draft agreement already acceptable to Great Britain, the United States and Germany.

As there seems to be some question as to how the New York baseball Giants were named Giants, it might be wise to look at the record, as Al Smith would say, in order to clear up once and for all any doubts that any modern fan may hold about the matter.

When her evening dress was ignited by a dropped cigarette or the tip of a match, Mrs. A.G. Buchsbaum, 22 years old, of the Hotel Westover, 253 West Seventy-second Street, became a human torch last night in the lobby of the Music Box Theatre at 239 West Forty-fifth Street.

BEILIN, Feb. 28. -- A pessimistic reaction resulted on the Boerse today from the acceptance of the Soviet compact by the French Chamber of Deputies. Nervousness, with realization selling, was apparent, although the down trend was checked by the usual influences that limit the Boerse's usefulness as an economic barometer.

With what was called defeatism the world became familiar during the Great War. People despaired in winning it. The forces and instruments of destruction were so great on both sides that no nation could hope to issue a victor. Peace must be made as early as possible, even if it should appear to be disgraceful.

AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 28. -- The arbitration proposal of Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor, was accepted today by an executive committee of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company strikers and of the United Rubber Workers of America.
Directors of Montgomery Ward Co. declared yesterday a dividend of 20 cents on the common stock. This is the first payment since a quarterly dividend of 75 cents was disbursed on Aug. 15, 1930.
Store buildings, apartment houses, dwellings and sites were among the New Jersey items reported transferred yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- An investigation of charges that Pennsylvania relief workers have been threatened with "blacklisting" unless they contribute to Democratic campaign funds was ordered today by Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, on evidence submitted by Senator Vandenberg.

Charles Willis Thompson's desire to know whether it is sumac or juniper that colors the waters of the placid Pasquotank River which flows by Elizabeth City, a beautiful North Carolina town, has come to my attention through his letter published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.
Six-day cycling tradition was discarded last night as the sixtieth international grind at Madison Square Garden spun past its fifth day and toward its goal tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Any doubts that may have been entertained here as to the trend of events in Japan were dispelled today with the receipt of apparently reliable advices from Tokyo pointing to the formation of a government dominated by the army with the acquiescence of the country.

TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 29. -- Chuji Machida, who was Minister of Commerce and Industry in the Cabinet of Premier Keisuke Okada, assassinated by the army revolters Wednesday, has been appointed Minister of Finance.
Continuance of apartment rental activity was reported yesterday, the listings including tenants in various suburban houses, as follows:

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Feb. 29. -- Major Gen. Rensuke Isogai, Japanese Military Attache here, confirmed yesterday the belief that pressure by Japan on China would continue regardless of the outcome of the Tokyo situation.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 28. -- Control of the American Trust Company, a $272,000,000 organization, was returned to local interests today with the purchase of two thirds of the common stock of the bank from the American Company, a subsidiary of the Atlas Corporation.

The James Butler Grocery Company, operator of 483 stores, which filed a petition to reorganize under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Laws on March 19, 1935, yesterday filed in the Federal court in Brooklyn a plan of reorganization. Judge Mortimer W. Byers fixed April 3 for a hearing on it.

ALBANY, Feb. 28. -- Senator Walter W. Stokes of Otsego County today introduced a concurrent resolution carrying an appropriation of $5,000 for the purpose of suitably celebrating the centennial of baseball, the national sport," in 1939.

Extensive damage to street paving has been done in Brooklyn and Queens by the month-old covering of ice and snow from which the pavements are emerging. In Manhattan, however, borough engineers reported that a preliminary inspection showed only normal Winter damage.

To avoid "traffic congestion, confusion and public condemnation," Park Commissioner Robert Moses asked the Board of Estimate yesterday to authorize lowering of the grade of a part of Grand Central Parkway Extension in the Flushing Meadows so that the parkway may be ready for the opening of the Triborough Bridge this Summer.

One of the present national titleholders of indoor polo starts the defense of that title tonight as the indoor season begins to enter its championship stages. One of the two games to be played at Squadron A Armory, Ninety-fourth Street and Madisan Avenue, is the opening match of the Manhattan circuit elimination, and Governors Island, which defeated the Detroit Polo Club for the national title last year, faces Squadron A in this match.

The New York Title and Mortgage Company, in rehabilitation, yesterday bought in at a foreclosure auction the sixteen-story apartment house at 104-10 West Eighty-sixth Street. The action was against the 82 Realty Corporation for $726,537, due, with taxes, , totaling about $1,048.

Wilhelm Furtwaengler, internationally known opera and symphony orchestra conductor, has been appointed general musical director of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society, for the 1936-37 season, it was announced officially yesterday.

The yen was steady and unchanged while Japanese bonds recovered somewhat yesterday as financial markets continued to accept calmly the developments arising out of the political assassinations in Japan. Bankers here reported that their business cables from Japan were coming through in the normal manner, but that no word was being received regarding political developments.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- After vetoing a bill appropriating $50,000,000 for crop-production loans to farmers, President Roosevelt today ordered set aside $30,000,000 for this purpose, of which he allocated $7,000,000 for immediate use.

EL PASO, Feb. 28 (AP). -- Organized labor declared economic war against the strike-crippled El Paso Electric Company tonight while armed company guards patrolled power lines and a grand jury began an investigation of alleged sabotage.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 28. -- A record high price for the Hialeah Park season was established today when High Mabel, a 2-year-old filly owned by C.H. (Pat) Knebelkamp of Louisville, Ky., drove to a hard-earned victory in the three furlongs of the second race and paid $268.10 for a $2 mutuel ticket.

Milder weather aided trade here during the week, and volume of leading department stores here was estimated as showing about a 5 per cent increase over the same period last year. Initial offerings of Spring apparel received greater attention from the public and a sharp pick-up in this branch of the business, which has been lagging, is now anticipated.

When Leap Year Day, the quadriennial visitor to the calendar which causes 366-day years, ends tonight, the records of the local marriage license bureau will show an increased number of certificates issued for weddings for the first two months of this year over the same period in 1935.

Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins dismissed yesterday the taxpayer's suit brought by a Socialist group in Brooklyn seeking to enjoin the city and its transit advisors, Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr., from proceeding with their pending plan to unify all rapid transit lines.

BOSTON, Feb. 28. -- After a day of rioting, during which twenty-one men and women were arrested and nearly twoscore were injured, Governor Curley tonight called upon representatives of 4,000 striking garment workers and the affected manufacturers to confer with him tomorrow regarding a settlement.

PENSACOLA, Fla., Feb. 28. -- Although it has been generally accepted that Burgess Whitehead, the infielder the Giants obtained from the Cardinals in a trade that sent Roy Parmelee and three other players to St. Louis, will be the new second baseman at the Polo Grounds this year, a young man breezed in on Colonel Bill Terry today who may prove that transaction to have been more or less unnecessary.

TOKYO, Feb. 28 (Reuters) -- Consternation reigned this morning when Tokyo woke to find there was a new crisis in the rebellion. The military guards who had been withdrawn overnight were again in every street, and a cordon was drawn around the area occupied by the rebels, access to which was forbidden.

The Italian Government announced yesterday that its troops have occupied Alaji -- furthest point reached by the Italian army that invaded Ethiopia forty years ago. It was here that the tide of invasion began to ebb when an Italian force that had been flung too far south to receive adequate support was overwhelmed on Dec. 7, 1895.

LONDON, Feb. 28. -- With the Japanese insurgent troops still defying the government three days after their wholesale political murders, British opinion concerning the significance of the revolt is beginning to undergo revision.

PARIS, Feb. 28. -- Following yesterday's ratification by the Chamber of Deputies of the Franco-Soviet pact of mutual assistance questions of the Russian debt to France and the granting of new commercial credits were raised today at a meeting of the Chamber Finance Commission attended by Foreign Minister Pierre-Etienne Flandin and Commerce Minister Georges Bonnet.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- An order to reduce the number of workers on WPA jobs as rapidly as work is made available on PWA and other types of Federal relief jobs has been issued by Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, to State WPA Administrators.

Mrs. Maryon Cooper Hewitt, who recently was accused of causing the sterilization of her daughter, Ann Cooper Hewitt, is in the Medical Center, Jersey City, suffering from an overdose of a narcotic, it was disclosed last night.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 28 (AP). -- Edward Cannon, 27, was sentenced to serve a term of twenty years to life in prison today for the New Year's Eve party slaying of Hilda Price, 20-year-old waitress.

The Indoor Polo Association of America has been receiving so many inquiries from polo followers as to the method in which we are deciding the national championships that I believe an explanation of it will be of value to many readers. In our opinion it is one of the most complete methods any sport has for discovering true champions.
The English best-seller, "The Life and Times of King George the Fifth," edited by Sir Philip Gibbs, will be published in this country by Lippincott early in March.

With twelve champions defending their titles, the Metropolitan A.A.U. indoor track and field title games will be staged by the Jefferson Club tonight at the 245th Field Artillery Armory in Brooklyn. Two events -- weight throw and broad jump -- will serve as a preliminary this afternoon at Ohio Field.

ALBANY, Feb. 28. -- With Governor Lehman's budget and revenue bills passed and the bulk of his crime measures also approved in the upper house, it was learned today that the Democratic leaders of the Senate are considering putting through a concurrent resolution for final adjournment on March 17, when the Legislature resumes work Monday evening.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Vital parts of the rail-rate decision of the Interstate Commerce Commission are as follows:
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 28. -- Stressing extensive use of native plant material and vivid color, the eighth annual flower show of the Garden Club of Palm Beach and the Gardeners Association opened this afternoon at the Royal Poinciana conservatories.
MEXICO, D.F., Feb. 28. -- President Lazaro Cardenas today replied to the invitation from President Roosevelt to participate in a Pan-American peace conference.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Feb. 28. -- The fortieth anniversary of the death of Ante Starcevitch, founder of the Croat Nationalist party which carried on the early struggle against Hungary in the last century, was made the occasion today by the Extreme Nationalists for violent demonstrations against Belgrade.

The list of twenty-five centers in which the National Preaching Mission will be conducted this Fall under the auspices of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America was announced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Samuel McCrea Cavert, general secretary of the council.

Price movements in the market for commodity futures were irregular yesterday. The volume of trading was somewhat lower than on the preceding day. On the cash markets, raw sugar, cotton, eggs, cocoa, silk and rubber advanced, while wheat, corn, rye, oats, butter, tin and wooltops declined.
The second half of the semi-final round of amateur boxing's biggest show -- the annual Golden Gloves tournament -- was staged at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

The offering of $55,000,000 of New York Edison 3 1/4 per cent bonds on Thursday swelled this week's total of new-bond financing to $87,770,072, the largest volume since the week ended on Jan. 24, in which $93,803,000 was marketed. Last week's offering's amounted to $52,997,000 and those in the week a year ago to $13,154,000.

Following the precedent established in the outdoor tennis championships last Summer, the national indoor men's and women's tourneys will be staged together for the first time under one roof, with the men's singles opening on the Seventh Regiment Armory's courts today.

Successful daily reception of radio facsimile weather maps by the Ile de France, throughout her recent Atlantic crossing from New York to Havre, was announced yesterday by Charles J. Pannill, president of the Radiomarine Corporation of America.

The response to the Citizens Family Welfare Committee appeal of last year gave gratifying evidence that the flame of personal charity had not been blown out by public relief grants and by the taxes that made them possible. The hoped-for minimum, $2,000,000, was exceeded by more than half that amount.
W.B. Calloway, general passenger traffic manager of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, said here yesterday:

America's only Olympic champions at Garmisch-Partenkirchen, Ivan Brown and Alan Washbond, driver and brake of the victorious boblet team, arrived home yesterday on the United States liner President Harding, bearing their laurels modestly and completely delighted with the feat that they accomplished.

The Associated Gas and Electric Company mailed yesterday to security holders of the system a letter advising them of assessments, including claimed interest and penalties, totaling $50,962,163, filed this week in Utica, N.Y., against the company and subsidiaries for taxes.

The Fire Department will start a drive today to remove fire hazards from the 3,000 odd theatres and places of public assembly in the city, utilizing powers granted to it by the recently enacted Mandelbaum Act, which among other things restored the Bureau of Combustibles to the department.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Validity of the suit which Robert A. Taft, son of the former President and Chief Justice, brought in the Court of Claims last March on behalf of the Dixie Terminal Company to collect $1.07 in interest as of Oct. 15, 1934, on a $50 Fourth Liberty bond, which had been called in October, 1933, for redemption on April 15, 1934, is sharply questioned in a brief filed by the government.
QUEBEC, Feb. 28. -- All penalties against St. Lawrence paper mills of this province were rescinded today by Premier Taschereau. In a brief statement he said:

ALBANY, Feb. 28. -- The State Department of Health, arriving at its figures by a new "proportional" method, estimated today that the State's population was 13,226,417 on July 1, and predicted that it would be 13,345,909 by next July 1.

Stuyvesant Square has been taken in hand by Park Commissioner MOSES with the aid of WPA workers. Since the square is just 100 years old, it will obviously stand a bit of reconstruction, provided the work is completed before another hundred years have elapsed, as one may occasionally be tempted to fear from the pace of reconstruction in other small city parks.

Because tomorrow is the first Sunday in Lent, most of the sermons will touch upon the duty of observing in some form the pentential season. In the denominational churches, as is the custom on the first Sunday of the month, there will be holy communion.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Feb. 29. -- The first break in the ranks of the revolting troops who assassinated four government leaders in Tokyo Wednesday and had since been holding several government buildings occurred at 11 o'clock this morning, Tokyo time, when 200 armed with heavy machine-guns surrendered and submitted to being disarmed.

The camera finish of horse races is a splendid thing for the thoroughbred sport. The fact that the New York State Racing Commission, through its chairman, Herbert Bayard Swope, has requested New York racing associations to install a camera at the finish means that the Empire State will keep up the pace already set as a leader in sponsoring innovations and improvements.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 28 (AP). -- Alfred G. Vanderbilt's Discovery was withdrawn today from the $10,000 added San Juan Capistrano Handicap because the 1935 handicap champion was reported out of shape by Trainer Bud Stotler.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., Feb. 28. -- Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis today celebrated her selection as a member of the American Curtis Cup team by defeating Miss Jane Cothran of Greenville, S.C., in the semi-finals of the women's South Atlantic championship at the Ormond Beach Golf Club, 9 and 7.

MOSCOW, Feb. 28. -- The Franco Soviet mutual assistance pact ratified yesterday by the French Chamber of Deputies and now awaiting action by the Senate, instantly calls to mind the Franco-Russian military alliance of the pre-World War epoch.

The hearing on the Wheeler-Rayburn bill for extension of the powers of the Federal Trade Commission to be held by the Senate Commerce Committee on Tuesday morning will attract a number of publishers and representatives of the advertising field, who are expected to voice objections to certain provisions.

Holding their opponents to a single field goal in the first half, Long Island University's unbeaten basketball team scored an easy 46-21 victory over Gallaudet College of Washington at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy court last night to end their regular schedule unbeaten.

A STRANGE jinx seems to be pursuing the Olympic program as it is now conducted. Perhaps what the Olympic Games need is a permanent home in a peaceful country. Say Switzerland. It has been a long time since the little Alpine republic was in a war or raised the wrath of other nations by its treatment of squads of strangers or sections of its own citizenry.

Proposals to strengthen the State realty brokers' license laws are being studied by real estate boards in the metropolitan district as the basis for recommendations to be made to Albany legislators by the Real Estate Association of the State of New York.

At the national A.A.U. championships last Saturday night the judges announced the high jump bar as being set for 6 feet 9 inches. Two men, Johnson and Burke, cleared it in what had been announced as a try for a world record. Then the officials found the bar to be 1-16 of an inch lower.

The Rev. Robert McCaul, who until this week has been conducting an evangelistic center in the church section of the Manhattan Towers Hotel, Seventy-seventh Street and Broadway, explained yesterday that his group had forced the trustees of the property to take dispossess action against them early this week only as a protest to being supplanted by the Mormon Church.

Mrs. R. Clifford Black gave a dinner last night in the King Cole Room of the St. Regis to celebrate the birthday of her younger daughter, Miss Judith Black. The other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Gast, the Misses Sybil King, Cherry Shaw, Ethel Worthington and Adlumia Sterrett; Farish A. Jenkins, Robert E. Chapman, Robert C. Black 3d, Joel A.H. Webb, Robert S. Gast Jr., Robert W. Rogers and Francis H. Collins 2d.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- The policy of the "good neighbor" is "a reality, vital, active and effective" and no longer merely a hope or an objective," Secretary Hull said tonight in a radio address prepared by him and read by Under-Secretary William Phillips over the National Broadcasting System.

UNIVERSITY, Va., Feb. 28 (AP). -- Virginia's boxers began the defense of their Southern Conference boxing title in elimination bouts this afternoon and tonight by moving six men into the semi-finals and one to the finals. Ray Schmidt, light-heavyweight, was the only Cavalier defeated.

The Japanese Consulate General here announced yesterday that all foreign embassies, consulates and citizens in Tokyo were being carefully guarded during the present disturbances, and that none has suffered violence or damage.

The profit and loss surplus of the Pennsylvania Railroad declined in 1935 from $190,248,738 to $184,532,669, according to a summary of the company's report for 1935 issued yesterday by Martin W. Clement, president.

ITALIAN NORTHERN ARMY, Headquarters in Ethiopia, Feb. 28. -- Italian forces occupied Mount Alaji today without meeting any resistance from Ras Mulugheta's routed army. The historic ridge was taken this morning after a surprise thrust that was not expected for several weeks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- The special investigation of air mail contracts, begun two years ago by the Department of Justice after Postmaster General Farley's sensational annulment order, exonerates the aviation companies of both civil and criminal liability and makes no recommendation for procedure against them.

NAPLES, Italy, Feb. 28. -- Antonio Scotti, beloved baritone who sang for thirty-three successive seasons at the Metropolitan Opera in New York, died here in poverty on Wednesday and was buried today. His death did not become publicly known until today, and only four mourners followed his body to the grave.

CLEARWATER, Fla., Feb. 28. -- It rained last night, but the fine weather that so recently embraced this West Coast resort came right back this afternoon to smile upon the opening conditioning exercises of the 1936 Dodgers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- The increased activity on the Stock Exchanges in January carried the dollar value of sales on all registered securities Exchanges in that month to the highest figure since the Securities and Exchange Commission began the compilation of figures on this basis in October, 1934, the commission reported today.

A badly needed salvage operation has been launched under the auspices of the American Christian Committee for German Refugees. Two hundred Protestant and Catholic clergymen attended the dinner on Thursday night at which it was decided to raise a fund of $400,000 for the resettlement of 2,500 Christian refugees.

The "Spring Fever Dinner-Dance," plans for which were made during the spells of near-zero weather and snow of recent weeks, was held last night in the Caprice Room of the Weylin as a means to aid the children's orthopedic and surgical ward of the New York Post-Graduate Hospital.

The first of what may be a series of suits filed throughout the United States to recover some of the hundreds of millions of dollars paid to the government by processors prior to last Aug. 1, when courts impounded the levies pending a test of the constitutionality of the AAA, was begun here yesterday by three tobacco manufacturers.

I must confess that I had paid no attention to the A.I.C.P.'s rather ridiculous statement except to read the headline over the story and shrug my shoulders at such nonsense. But a perusal of Miss Kingdon's letter has aroused the sleeping lion in me.

Leading members of the Metropolitan Opera Company who knew Mr. Scotti well during his brilliant reign at the Broadway house paid strong tributes to him. In the absence of Paul D. Cravath, president of the Metropolitan Opera Association, who sailed for Europe last Wednesday, Cornelius N. Bliss of the board of directors issued the following statement:

The New York County Lawyers Association asked Attorney General Bennett yesterday to take action against four corporations which it alleges have been engaged illegally in the wholesale practice of law.

The third program of motion pictures of the Museum of Modern Art Film Library, to be shown to the public on March 3 and 4, at 8:30 P.M. at the museum, 11 West Fifty-third Street, will be devoted to the David Wark Griffith masterpiece of two decades back, "Intolerance.''

CHICAGO, Feb. 28. -- The market for hogs was irregular today. Weights under 250 pounds were quoted at 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight higher and heavier kinds were slow and steady to 10 cents higher, buyers taking the heavy kinds at barely steady prices.

A man still has the legal right to sue for alienation of the affections of his wife despite legislation passed by the State Legislature last Winter banning such actions, Justice Leander B. Faber declared yesterday in a decision handed down in Queens Supreme Court.

DUBLIN, Feb. 28. -- The new trade agreement negotiated with Great Britain has been received throughout the country without any great jubilation. Not even the most ardent Fianna Fail supporters can regard it in the nature of a popular triumph.

THE unusual in decoration is quite appropriate in a recreation room, because here one escapes from the ordinary workaday world, seeking relaxation and amusement. Gay colors and quaint murals play their part in the newest game rooms, hobby rooms and snuggeries.

Before the largest gallery to see a racquets match in this country since Charles Williams and Jock Sourer played in 1922, Norbert Setzler was crowned yesterday as the first holder of the American open title.

One of the winners in the Julia Ellsworth Ford contest for juve nile writers, this book tells of the coming of age of a Kahuilla Indian boy of the California desert a century and a quarter ago, and of his relentless quest for the mountain lion which had maimed his grandfather, the old chief.

WHEN an artist whose title to greatness is as clear as Martha Graham's goes experimenting afield as she did last week with her new suite, "Horizons," the event cannot be allowed to go by default merely because it is unsuccessful.

Three plays will be presented by the Junior Branch Players of the New York Women's League for Animals on Wednesday night and Saturday afternoon at the MacDowell Club, 166 East Seventy-third Street. The entire proceeds will be donated toward defraying the expenses of the free work of the Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital, maintained by the league.

WITH Norway attaining greater international popularity as a skiing ground, the range of the Winter sports season in Europe has been notably extended. This Winter happens to be one of the best that Norway has had in the last four or five years and "seven feet of snow" has figured in the daily skiing reports with almost monotonous regularity for the past two months.

More than 2,000 members of the American League Against War and Fascism tied up pedestrian and automobile traffic at Fortieth Street and Sixth Avenue yesterday afternoon when they decided to hold a mass meeting at the southwestern corner of Bryant Park. The police stopped the meeting after a half hour because its leaders failed to produce a large enough American flag.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 29. -- Heart Break, speedy 6-year-old daughter of Morvich racing in the silks of R.A. Coward, came through with another victory today when she defeated six speedy sprinters in the Blue Bonnets Handicap at the Fair Grounds.

Eight thousand thoroughbred dogs were registered in the stud book of the American Kennel Club during the month of January, according to the latest compilation announced yesterday by the governing body. This exceeds the total for all dogs entered during the first ten years that registry was maintained.

To stimulate interest in the Stony Wold Sanatorium, the alumnae of that organization -- young business women who have been patients -- will give a tea on Saturday afternoon in the Florentine Room of Schrafft's, 200 West 57th Street. Among the specially invited guests are Mrs. James E. Newcomb, who founded the sanatorium in 1901; Edmund G. Vaughan, the president, and Mrs. Vaughan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP). -- An aroused Wisconsin constituent, who believes members of Congress ought to cut out "the extras they are getting from the government in addition to their salaries," heard today from Senator Duffy, Democrat of Wisconsin, that he (the Senator) had run $4,750 behind in 1934.

PRAGUE, Feb. 5, 1936. FROM April 4 to 9 Prague will be the scene of an International Congress for Musical Education under the sponsorship of the "SHV" (Spolecnost pro Hude-bni Vychovu, or Society for Musical Education).

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP). -- On the basis of new evidence, involving a mysterious affidavit, the United States will begin before the German-American Mixed Claims Commission May 12 an attempt to reopen the Black Tom and Kingsland World War "sabotage" cases, involving claims totaling $40,000,000.

PARIS, Feb. 27. - Hand-painted leather buttons, decorated with illustrated verses from Baudelaire's famous "Invitation au Voyage," trim a novel hand-knit travel costume, by Kostia de Var. "Il Etait un Petit Navire" enlivens the buttons of red and gray hand-knitted linen beach overalls.

CLEARWATER, Fla., Feb. 29. -- Casey Stengel led the early contingent of the Dodgers' training squad through three hours of brisk work today. He split the task into two sessions, with time out for luncheon, and promised the athletes a shorter and easier job for Sunday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 29. -- Chicago will be on permanent Eastern standard time tomorrow for the first time in fifty-three years. The new time, one hour earlier than Central time, which was imposed on Chicago by the railroads in 1883, is designed to give Chicago and its suburbs 365 more daylight hours it year.

The Panama Pacific Line yesterday announced that Acapulco, on the Pacific Coast of Mexico, would be a regular port of call for its liners on voyages from California to New York, effective with the sailing of the liner Virginia from San Francisco on March 14.

CHICAGO, Feb. 29. -- Wheat futures closed today 1/8 cent lower to 1/5 cent higher on the Board of Trade, while Kansas City and Minneapolis ended to 1/3 to 3/8 cent down. Little attention was paid to a recession of 3/8 to 3/4 cent in Winnipeg.

The long conflict between civilians and soldiers for control of the Japanese Government burst forth last week in political assassination and rebellion, precipitating a crisis of vast and dangerous potentialities not only for Japan but also for all the world.
An American, George B. Coleman Jr., young oil man and amateur driver of Miami, Okla., now holds officially the world's record for outboard boats.

Serious, sane violin playing, which made no bid for favor by emphasizing mere display, was heard from Toscha Seidel at his recital given before a large and responsive audience yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. He opened his program with the first American presentation of the sonata in A major by David Monrad Johansen, which was followed by the Bach "Chaconne," the Conus concerto, and a group of shorter items by Godowsky, De Falla and Rachmaninoff.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 29. --Delegates from thirty-one colleges will participate in the session of the Model League of Nations to be held for three days, beginning Thursday, at Vassar College.

Mrs. Estelle M. Sternberger, president of World Peaceways, will receive a gold medal for distinguished peace work and Franz Werfel, novelist and playwright, will receive a similar award for distinction in literature from the Jewish Forum at its eighteenth anniversary dinner next Sunday night in the Hotel Astor.

Bismarck, until Nazis began to write history in terms of Hitler, was honored by Germans as their outstanding statesman. He unified the Reich and made it great; after that he had one great fear. He was haunted by the possibility of an anti-German coalition, such as a Franco-Russian alliance, around the Reich's borders.
HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 29. -- Dartmouth College has taken another step forward in the practical field by stimulating activity in a "Dartmouth-in-Politics" movement.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- The government payrolls are soaring. The stratospheric total exceeds $11,000,000 a day, on the basis of a twenty-six-day month. This money is being distributed directly or indirectly among more than 4,400,000 employes in the Federal departments, on government construction projects, on the works program and in emergency conservation activities.

WILLIAM ZORACH'S one-man show of water-colors at the Downtown Gallery (until March 14) should add considerably to the reputation the artist has earned in this field. Zorach has not established a formula; his use of the water-color medium subserves the mood in which a given theme is approached; at the same time, his is a very definite style.

TRAFFIC safety will play an important part in the discussions at the seventh annual Greater New York Safety Conference which will open for three days beginning Tuesday in the Hotel Astor. Investigating the cause of accidents, modern methods of handling traffic summonses and developing safety consciousness are among the topics to be discussed by experts in each field.

A gala luncheon, featured by a fashion pageant entitled "Accents on Spring," will be held in the Caprice Room of the Weylin on Tuesday in behalf of the occupational therapy department of the Hospital for Ruptured and Crippled.

THE generous sprays of velvety red roses here and there in the Ambassador apartment of Herr Ernst Lubitsch were not, the roguish host explained (anticipating an almost certain facetious inquiry on the subject), a bon voyage offering from Mae West.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 29. -- Yale's social year will reach a climax here next week-end when a thousand couples will participate in the sixty-fourth annual junior promenade.

NEW YORK, today, is a city covering an area of 300-odd square miles, with more than 7,000,000 people, piled up in layers until the tallest building reaches 1,200 feet. It could not exist without a network of intricate and ingenious machinery which reduces to minutes the time required for its inhabitants to communicate with one another and to exchange information with almost any part of the civilized world.

RICHMOND, Feb. 29. -- While trade volume in the Fifth District generally showed a seasonal decline from the Fall and Winter levels, there was an increase in January and the first half of February over the corresponding period of last year, the Richmond Bank states in its monthly review.

RYE, N.Y., Feb. 29. -- The Apawamis Club here was the scene tonight of a leap year dance. Among those who gave dinners before the dance were Mr. and Mrs. L.D. Kingsland, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur M. Milburn, Mr. and Mrs. William J. Demorest, Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Hollaman, Mr. and Mrs. Wesley M. Oler and Mr. and Mrs. James Talcott.

Many dinners will be given before Rimsky-Korsakoff's "The Invisible City of Kitezh" on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House by the Art of Musical Russia Company and the Philadelphia Orchestra, as a benefit for the Musicians Emergency Fund.

PROGRESSIVE education recorded one of its most widespread victories at the convention of the Department of Superintendence of the National Education Association at the St. Louis last week, John A. Spargo, superintendent of schools in Nutley, N.J., reported it.

NOTHING so insinuatingly challenges the old, pedagogic postulate that there is no royal road to knowledge -- at least, a knowledge of history -- as the series edited by the brilliant and resourceful Associate Professor of History at Harvard University, William Leonard Langer, who is preparing "Liberalism, Naturalism and Socialism, 1832-1852," for it.

As a general rule an amended tax return, made voluntarily and upon the same basis of reporting as the original, may be filed by a taxpayer at any time within the period of limitation fixed by statute. An exception to this general rule is found in the Capital Stock Tax Law, literally construed.

Although sugar and copper futures were higher, small declines were the rule yesterday on the commodity futures markets here in light trading. On the cash markets wheat, corn and rye advanced, while cotton, lard, butter, eggs, Straits Settlements tin and rubber declined.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- With the coming of Spring, Pinehurst has so many sports tournaments that this week it welcomes a period devoid of major golf events. The thirty-second annual Spring golf tournament having just been concluded, preparations are under way for the sixteenth annual seniors' tournament (March 10, 11, 12, 13), and the second annual meet of the Sand Hills Steeplechase and Racing Association, to be held on March 14.

EVEN though it may still seem that Spring is somewhat "far behind," the time for early seed-starting is here. Some gardeners, indeed, have already made their first planting. Even where one does not have the advantage of a hotbed, seeds sown now, by the time they are ready for transplanting five or six weeks hence, may be transferred to the open if given a sheltered position then.
LONDON, Feb. 28. -- Next week's list of theatrical events are as follows:

The Southern Pacific Railway Company's passenger revenues increased 10.9 per cent in 1935. The improvement was attributed principally to the business pick-up of the year, but credit was given also to the stimulus provided by air-conditioned cars and continuance of the low fares established in 1933, according to Hale Holden, chairman, in his report for 1935.

A need to vitalize Public School curricula that now are "purged by patriots and punctuated by public utilities" was pointed out yesterday by Austin H. MacCormick, Commissioner of Correction, at a youth conference preceding the annual joint luncheon of the High School Principals Association and the High School Teachers Association in the Hotel Commodore.

The National Sportsmen's Show, a glorified indoor exposition of what is customarily described as the great outdoors, was revived in this city yesterday after a lapse of twenty-one years. If the opening-day attendance was any criterion, the show was, in the parlance of the theatre, a smash hit.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, Feb. 29. -- William Coyle Jr., New York State champion and topped seeded entry of the Montclair A. C., was one of four competitors to gain the semi-final round as play in the annual squash racquets invitation tournament of the Ardsley Country Club started today.

THIS first novel is a large family piece loosely packed with the more trembling incidents in the life of the clan of Bodleys. who inhabit the land between Crownport and Handsome Cove, Massachusetts, from 1858 to the present.

Two hundred and fifty-one students at Manhattan College have been cited for scholastic excellence during the recently ended semester. Eighty-eight have received first honors, while 163 received second honors on the dean's list.
Checking an unexpected threat in the opening round, Gregory S. Mangin successfully started the defense of his national indoor tennis crown at the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday.

THE post-war world that long ago agreed to the proposition that "generals die in bed" will enjoy Mr. Forester's sardonic and unsparing portrait of a self-made Englishman of war. And not entirely because it is a Briton who is being skinned, though actuaries report that the anti-British feeling you might this long after the American Revolution call Big-Bill-Thompsonitis continues to flourish.

Details of an agreement under which 1,000 non-Russian Jewish families will be settled in the Jewish autonomous territory of Birobidjan, Soviet Russia, have been made public by William W. Cohen, chairman of the American Committee for the Settlement of Jews in Birobidjan.
NEWSPAPERS reflect life from day to day, without correction for historical perspective. However much they miss, in what they record they are faithful mirrors of their times.

On Wednesday of this week the Roosevelt Administration will complete its third year in office. It came into power at the most critical stage of a great financial crisis, with banks closed in many States, business activity at a very low level and a large part of the public in a panic.

BARCELONA, Feb. 20, 1936. NEARLY 300 scores were sifted by the jury which met recently here to prepare the programs for the fourteenth annual festival of the International Society for Contemporary Music, to be held in Barcelona from April 18 to 26.

PENSACOLA, Fla., Feb. 29. -- Bill Terry'e pitchers and catchers, who today completed their week's training in advance of the remainder of the Giant squad, have a day of relaxation scheduled for them tomorrow. They will embark upon a fishing and chowder party on the Gulf, and quite a day is in prospect.

ROME, Feb. 29. -- Only twenty-four hours after the occupation of Mount Alaji, today's war bulletin clearly foreshadowed the early elimination of the threat to Marshal Pietro Badoglio's right flank represented by the presence in Tembien Province of Ras Kassa and Ras Seyoum and their 40,000 men.

VIENNA, Feb. 28. -- Premier Hodza's plan to unite the two systems of the Danubian area -- the Little Entente and the signatories of the Rome protocol -- was badly upset by Yugoslavia's refusal to cooperate economically with Austria except on a reciprocal basis or to enter an economic combine which did not include Germany, Yugoslavia's most important market since her big Italian customer has been barred by sanctions.

TOPSHAM, Vt., Feb. 29. -- On the cover page of the annual report of Topsham, to be distributed among the population of about 200 before Town Meeting convenes on Tuesday, is the picture of Red Echo Jessica, captioned "A Daughter of Topsham," the "only Guernsey cow in the country to be four times national class leader."

IT is Parents' Day at Craiglea Preparatory School in England and a cricket match is in progress between pupils and parents when Mrs. Bernard-Moss arrives on the scene. She has come all the way from St. Paul, Minn., to see her two stepsons, who have been sent to England to school because threats have been made to kidnap them.

CONTRIBUTIONS of allied sciences are playing an increasing part in the rapid progress in aviation, which has put the United States, in many particulars, ahead of the world. Some of the magic of electricity, for example, is in daily use in the big plant of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation at Paterson, N.J. An

THE most important operatic event seen in this city for several decades was the world premiere of Gian Francesco Malipiero's three-act music drama, "Giulio Cesare" (after Shakespeare), at the Teatro Carlo Felice last night.

The Business Women's Round Table Luncheon Club, an aggressive organization, held its quadrennial Leap Year Day meeting yesterday at the Iroquois Hotel and listened to speakers predict great things for the womanhood of this country.

Only a few unsubscribed seats remain for the first of the two recitals this afternoon at Town Hall for the benefit of Hartley House Music School. Myra Hess is the artist for this afternoon and John Charles Thomas will be the soloist at the second recital on March 15.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- The address of Hirosi Saito, Japanese Ambassador, delivered over an NBC radio network tonight, was as follows:

ALBANY, Feb. 28. -- On the eve of momentous moves in the Legislature having political implications nation-wide in scope, the Republican party in the past week has made some "important adjustments," although for weeks and perhaps months to come there may not appear even a ripple on the surface to indicate that political depths have been stirred.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 29. -- Pennsylvania Democrats opposed to the New Deal may file petitions within the next week entering the name of Colonel Henry Breckinridge, New York lawyer, in this State's Presidential preferential primary.

AFTER forty years the money question has returned to play an important part in the American political and financial scene. The question "Are we headed for inflation?" obtrudes itself insistently wherever men make plans, economic, social or political. Inflation talk, running in waves, rattles the dollar in the foreign exchange market, titillates the stock market, harries the banker and business executive.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 29. -- Princeton scored a wrestling victory over Yale today, 17 1/2 to 10 1/2, Ross, Reed, Quinn and Captain Treide of the Tigers all emerging victorious in their bouts.
QUEBEC. -- Ski outings to Lake Beauport, tobogganing on the Dufferin Terrace slide and open-air skating form the chief Winter sports for members of the United States colony in Quebec this week.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y. -- Last week-end, during the Washington's Birthday holiday period, Lake Placid was host to the largest crowd of Winter sports visitors since the Olympic Winter Games here in 1932. Special trains brought residents from various points in the United States, filling every hotel, cottage and boarding house in this community.

BUFFALO, Feb. 29. -- With nearly 800 entries on the benches, the Kennel Club of Buffalo today opened its twelfth annual dog show in the Broadway Auditorium. Many of the stars which had flashed at Westminster and at Boston were in the competitions, and there was much guessing as to the ultimate award tomorrow night, when G.V. Glebe of Bryn Athyn, Pa., will name the best in show.

By breaking 97 out of a possible 100 targets, A.L. Burns won the high scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. In the shoot at 155 targets, a yearly fixture, Burns also was high, scoring a leg on both the scratch and the handicap cup with a card of 145.

Recently I asked for my money back at a local movie house which has afforded me many an evening of good entertainment for several years. The first feature was enjoyable. Then came a short in bad, blurred colors wherein a son and old mother began a sitting-room dialogue recommending a much-advertised medicine for indigestion I at once went to the box-office and got my money back.

The American Joint Distribution Committee cannot be weary in its well-doing. More than ever are its services needed in meeting the tragic inhumanities which are inflicted upon a helpless people by a godless government. The fresh appeal made by this committee is largely on behalf of youth for whom there is no assured abiding place in Germany, their homeland.

IF the Muse of Hollywood has anything to say about it (which she probably won't have) there are two Omars whose names will go ringing down in history -- one of them spelling the last name "Kiam."
