The first Omar wrote the Rubaiyat, but the second Omar designs costumes for Samuel Goldwyn's pictures, and if you think that is a less important achievement you just don't know the Muse, who spells her own name "Oblivia."

The collection of Egyptian antiquities of Garrett Chatfield Pier, archaeologist and author, will be sold at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., by his order on Friday and Saturday afternoons. Included also will be ancient Greek and Etruscan pottery and Syro-Roman glass and a group of Oriental rugs consigned by other owners.

The distinctive Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. track and field championship, with its individual events subordinated to the all-important battle for the team title, will be presented in Madison Square Garden on Saturday.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 29. -- "Two Million Daze," a musical farce in two acts, was presented here today at afternoon and evening performances by the Dialectic Society of the United States Corps of Cadets, as the annual "Hundredth Night Show."

THAT Hugh Ross will be the conductor in charge of the program of the twelfth annual Westchester Musical Festival, now less than three months away, was announced recently by Laurence D. Redway, newly elected president of the Festival Association, in a statement regarding the plans for the event.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- A gain of 14 per cent in total retail sales in 1935 over 1934 brought the total to $32,600,000,000, which was equal to two-thirds of the volume of 1929, the first year for which an actual count ever was made of the nation's business, the Department of Commerce announced today.

PARIS, Feb. 29. -- Rentes slumped again heavily today on the Bourse to new low levels. The 3 per cents lost 70 centimes, dropping to 68.60 francs. For this new decline various reasons are given, as, for instance, fears that revision of former Premier Laval's decree laws, which has been proposed, will upset the budget balance which was somewhat precariously established on paper at the end of the last session.

The two articles on the future of the Philharmonic-Symphony (which apply to all such organizations) bring to mind the fact that if these organizations are to continue at all, there must be an increase in income and a decrease in expenditures.

MILAN, Feb. 10, 1936. THE latest dispatches from Turin confirm the total destruction by fire yesterday morning of the Teatro Regio, or Royal Opera House, of that city, as the result of a short circuit, it is believed.

The city's cash receipts, exclusive of borrowings, reached a record high of $882,949,808 last year, Controller Frank J. Taylor reported yesterday, as against $761,454,395 in 1934 and a mere $627,397,283 in 1932.

SEATTLE, Feb. 29. -- Political observers along the Pacific Coast were watching with interest today as Seattle's organized young voters went into the final stretch of their strongest bid for control of the city government.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 29. -- A fast, hard-riding Yale polo team had little trouble in downing Princeton, 18 to 3, in the university Riding Hall today.

IN all the great gallery of English literary portraits there is no truer, richer picture of a woman than Sheila Kaye-Smith's "Joanna Godden" (E.P. Dutton Co., $1). In brilliant analysis Miss Smith has arraigned against each other the two types of females -- the warm, loyal, primitive, maternal, and the cold, selfish, sophisticated, parasitic.

In April, 1934, after letters were published connecting State Senator Warren Thayer with the payroll of utility interests, the Legislature started the Dunnigan-Mack committee on its investigation of public utility practices. Last week the committee made its final report.
The Jekyll Island Club, off the southern coast of Georgia, will inaugurate its new season with an invitation handicap four-ball golf tournament to be held March 6-15.

HOW many have ever read Beddoes, asked Lytton Strachey in 1907, or, indeed, have ever heard of him? For that matter, he has not lacked admiration. No poet in the "Short History of English Literature," written some years earlier by Professor Saintsbury, is better praised in the remark that: "It may be questioned whether, though we have since had far greater poets than he, we have ever had greater poetry than his."

A NEW Venus has entered the Metropolitan and regal honors attend the event. Instead of being put through the usual Ellis Island formalities, which include leisurely publication in the bulletin and temporary installation in the Room of Recent Accessions, the large canvas by Titian called "Venus and the Lute Player," purchased for an unnamed sum from Lord Duveen of Millbank, was placed on public display without a moment's wait.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of Feb. 9 is an article, "The Shuttle That Wove Lincoln's Fate," which digs up long-discredited fictions to prove that President Lincoln's assassination was plotted at Richmond by the Confederate Government, and that Jacob Thompson and Clement C. Clay conspired with John Wilkes Booth to murder the war Executive.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 29. -- Williams College, host for many years to the Institute of Politics and more recently to the Institute of Human Relations, will be the scene of the ninth annual session of the New England Model League of Nations, convening here March 12-14 to discuss the Italo-Ethiopian situation.
BANGOR, Me. -- Voluntary contributions of money have not only provided jobs for the heads of needy families in Bangor but have provided the city with a new industry as well.

EVERY week a few fortunate thousands board the cruise ships leaving New York for near or distant ports, and tens of thousands go to see them sail. Seeing a liner off is a highly popular way of "going places" in New York, and while a friend on the passenger list greatly adds to the occasion, this does not really matter to the enthusiast.

The 1936 college freshman is throwing overboard the traditions of the naive and bespectacled student, who haunts the libraries and museums, a recent Journalism Club survey at Hunter College reveals. The answers of 964 of the 1,200 incoming freshmen indicate that the modern version of the college entrant ranks high in versatility as well as in scholarship, and supports herself in part as she prepares for a vocation.

FROM a remote coral isle in the Indian Ocean has recently come a stirring tale of shipwreck, the marooning of eighty-two persons with scant supplies, and their subsequent rescue. The scene of the story is Eagle Island, the property of the Societe Huiliere de Diego et de Peros and a source of copra.

THE paintings of the late John Kane, house painter and winner of prizes in Carnegie International exhibitions, will be featured in three invitation exhibitions to be held abroad. Recently his work has been on view at the Detroit Institute.

DUBLIN, Feb. 28. -- The Lenten pastoral letters issued this week by the Catholic hierarchy to their flocks reflect conditions that are in the main peaceful and free from any serious crime. Irish Bishops are no longer troubled to any degree with the existence of political violence or illegal armed associations.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 29. -- Better shopping weather resulted in a conspicuous expansion of retail sales at Kansas City this week, with dollar volume probably 8 per cent larger than last week, but this was not sufficient to offset the retarding effect of snow and ice and subzero temperatures earlier in the month, and the February total was estimated at about 1 per cent under a year ago.

Credentials in commerce to the successful candidates in the commercial examinations held by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York will be awarded Thursday in the chamber at 65 Liberty Street. The examinations are held under the terms of an endowment by the late A. Barton Hepburn, who was president of the chamber from 1910 to 1912.

Action of the Judiciary Committee of the Assembly in killing ratification of the Child Labor Amendment is designated as "against all our democratic principles" in a statement issued yesterday by the New York League of Women Voters. The disappointment of the league members at the committee action is apparent in the sharp criticism voiced in the release.

IN the lusty days of the 1830's, when the Erie Canal was the romantic symbol of a nation's growing power, one of the most beloved figures on the waterway was Decy Quinn. Some said there was devilment in her, old Zebulon Pike muttered that a saint walked with her, and every one wondered whether she were really the daughter of Michael Quinn, "canawller," for there was a mystery about her birth.

NOW the NRA belongs to the ages, and out of the public records and the memoirs of participants its history is being slowly put together. Its ultimate significance no less than its immediate accomplishments will be determined only when present passions have cooled.

WITH arrangements concluded between the United States and Great Britain and the United States and Germany for experimental transatlantic air service, which will, in all probability, see its inception this Summer, and with discussions now in progress in regard to a French service, there is a beehive of activity in foreign commercial aircraft factories.

WHEN the first European settlers landed on our coast something came down to the shore to meet them. It marched proudly; until then it had been invincible; it had conquered all who came to it, compelling men to be like it, to become part of it, melting into it and adopting its way.

GENEVA, Feb. 29. -- The outlook for an oil sanction is clouded on the eve of the Committee of Eighteen's meeting to decide what to do about the experts' report. The most optimistic view one hears is that it is even money whether this measure will be taken.

Miami Beach led all Winter resorts last month in stock market trading activity, contributing about 10 per cent of the volume of business transacted on the New York Stock Exchange, according to a canvass of representative brokerage firms.
AURORA, Ill., Feb. 29. -- Bachelors went into hiding here today as unmarried girls took over the executive jobs of the city for Leap Year Day.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- The value of building permits issued in January was 2.7 per cent above the December level and 122.5 per cent greater than for January, 1935, Secretary Perkins stated today, on the basis of reports from 790 cities.

When Japanese militarists attempt, by a coup as in the last few weeks or by adroit propaganda as in the course of the last five years, to establish their own supremacy in the land, they are motivated by something more than romantic ideology.

EVER since "The Hotel" Elizabeth Bowen has been giving repeated proof that she is an exceptionally subtle and fastidious writer. Up till now, however, her books have been too elliptical, too rarefied; in her anxiety to avoid the obvious she has barely escaped preciousness.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Feb. 29. -- Rhythmic interpretations of many moods and themes, ranging from compositions based on primitive rituals to those attuned to syncopated jazz, will be presented by the students of the modern dance at Mount Holyoke College during their annual recital on Thursday in Chapin Auditorium.

HAMILTON, Bermuda. -- Preliminary matches in the annual Belmont Manor ladies' championship golf tournament will be played tomorrow over the hillside course of the Belmont Manor Golf Club, and play will be continued each day until Saturday, when the finals will be followed by the presentation of the championship trophy and other prizes.

Led by Captain Bill Holiday, who won two events, the Carnegie Tech swimming team defeated Manhattan, 35 to 33, in a dual meet at the De Witt Clinton High School pool yesterday. The first places were evenly divided, each team capturing four.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- Because of a lack of competitive bids, the government turned to the navy today as a possible builder of a giant new liner to replace the Leviathan.

TRAVELING the new highway to Mexico, D.F., is still an adventure, though many tourists are inclined to exaggerate the hardships that lie behind the travel bureau's warning that the road is "not quite finished."

World events, social and political, are influencing fashions this Spring far more than ever before, according to Tobe, fashion authority and consultant to more than 100 leading stores, who returned last week from Paris and London.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- The Export-Import Bank is prepared to discount notes due to American exporters from the Bank of Brazil, given in payment for exports from the United States, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the advisory committee for the bank said today.

Mrs. Jarvis Cromwell has just been appointed benefit chairman for the performances of the Hollywood Symphonic Ballet on the nights of March 23 and 24 at the Metropolitan Opera House, which have been taken over by the women's committee of the Boys Club of New York.

BOSTON, Feb. 29. -- The advent of more propitious weather has resulted in improved department store sales in the First Federal Reserve District. Nearly all wholesale lines are reported as more active also. Local merchants are preparing for an active Easter selling season.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Feb. 29. -- Smith College celebrated Leap Year today with supper dances in the various college houses. Eight hundred men were guests over the week-end.

AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 29 (AP). -- The Central Labor Union designated tonight a committee empowered to call a general strike in Akron if force should be used to break the blockade at the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company.

LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 29. -- Governor Alfred M. Landon of Kansas called upon Republicans tonight to make clear to the needy "that the changes we pledge will bring order out of chaos by purging" Federal relief "of partisanship, of waste and of incompetence."
LONDON, Feb. 29. -- France and Germany today authorized their Ambassadors here to go ahead with the completion of the new naval agreement along the lines already drawn up in London.

TO look from the title page of this book to the pictured face opposite is to have curiosity so piqued about the story behind one and the personality behind the other that only reading the book can answer the questions they send thronging into one's mind.

The radio transmitter is one of the great central power plants of public opinion, and public opinion is the master of our politics. Yet, somehow, in the field of politics, we are demanding no greater responsibility than in the days of the fanning mill.

PARIS. PRINTS will make an exciting chapter of the style story of the coming season. French textile creators have revolutionized printed fabrics both in technique and conception. They have turned from abstract to personal subjects.

MOSCOW, Feb. 29. -- News of the suppression of the Japanese revolt and the reappearance unharmed of Premier Keisuke Okada was received with intense interest here, where every shift in the Japanese internal situation is watched for its possible effect on the Soviet's Far East.

A note on THE TIMES music page last Sunday stating the fact that "Don Giovanni" is not to be given at the Metropolitan this season has aroused me from a passive state of hopefulness to one of active resentment and disappointment with the opera management.

ATLANTA, Feb. 29 (AP). -- In vain today Governor Eugene Talmadge presented a personal demand to Atlanta banks for $2,000,000 of impounded State funds to add to the $10,000,000 cash which he said he had gathered in the State Treasury under his financial "dictatorship."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP). -- A survey of the government's emergency activities went to President Roosevelt today from the National Emergency Council.

WASHINGTON, -- By executive order President Roosevelt has given the navy jurisdiction over another mid-Pacific island -- Kure, or Ocean Island. Within the far-flung Hawaiian archipelago, Kure is about ten statute miles west and slightly to the north of Midway Island.

FOR those who like to read slowly, pausing often to relish a fine bit of characterization, or to chuckle over humor, or to watch the flash of bush and tree into green and yellow in the Spring sunshine, or to savor sly satire on man and his interests -- war, religion, politics -- this will prove a most satisfying book.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 29. -- Rallying in the second half, Penn won a hard-fought Eastern Intercollegiate League game from the Harvard quintet at the Palestra tonight, 35 to 26, before 4,000 fans. By the victory the Red and Blue moved into second place.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 29. -- More than 200 attended the "carnival" costume ball at the Surf Club, Miami Beach, tonight, the first costume event of social importance at Miami Beach in three years.

MAGNIFICATION mania, symptomized by the urge to make mountains out of molehills, is contagious. And many citizens of New York and Chicago were exposed to it recently, at 10 cents per exposure, by the introduction of a slot-machine microscope.

FOR Thomas Burke the night holds an irresistible attraction. Witness his titles: "Limehouse Nights," "More Limehouse Nights," and now "Night-Pieces." The weird and sinister which lurk behind tremulous shadows; the evil skulking in darkness; persons of crooked mind and more crooked ways -- these offer a wealth of material to his pen, a pen scarcely leas able than that of Stevenson or Poe.

THE SCHOOL OF FEMININITY" begins its story with Mary Wollstonecraft and ends it with Virginia Woolf. Between these writers -- between the impassioned outcry of the "Vindication of the Rights of Women" and the beautiful, deadly suavity of attack in "A Room of One's Own" -- Miss Lawrence has gathered into a somewhat thick volume most of the outstanding women novelists of England and America.

THE Manhattan booklover is ever on the hunt for bargains. At all seasons he may be found roving through his favorite haunts, alert for a rare edition or an autographed copy of some old work. He ranges from East Fifty-ninth Street and its big bookshops to lower Fourth Avenue and its smaller, cozier places.

AIRLINE operators whose lines penetrate the tropics have been studying with interest the effect of climate on wings and other parts of planes. In some cases the development of fungous growth inside the wing has followed lack of proper ventilation.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 29. -- Officers and directors of the National League of Masonic Clubs, meeting at the Hotel Madison here today, reported that 100 young men had been specially trained for the United States Diplomatic Service through the organization's efforts.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 29. -- Enrollment in the new music courses at Princeton University, revival of the university Glee Club and the orchestra and the largest demand for symphony records in years are among indications of a growing student interest in music here which the Princeton alumni weekly has hailed as "almost sensational."

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 29. -- Plans for a nation-wide emergency peace campaign, to start on April 21 and continue two years, were announced here today By Ray Newton, secretary of the peace section of the American Friends Service Committee.

To assist the Music Lovers' Foundation, Inc., in bestowing old-age pensions on artists of distinguished musical achievement who are insufficiently provided for, and to aid dependent members of their families, a gala concert will be given under the direction of Albert Morris Bagby, president of the foundation, on the afternoon of March 17 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- This year, as February merges into March, there is no perceptible change in local activities as in previous seasons. Calendars are filled for weeks to come with sports, cultural and social affairs, showing no hint of a slowing of the midseason's swift pace.

IF you have been reading the news from Hollywood recently, you must be aware of the major and minor explosions that have been popping all over the place. It was bad enough when the great Miss Dietrich, Mr. Cagney, Miss West and even Mr. Raft began acting up.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 29. -- The New Haven Railroad System will take no immediate action on the Interstate Commerce Commission's order cutting passenger fares, but the trustees believed that the road faces a "material reduction" in income if the change goes into effect.
THE late February atmosphere seemed ideal for broadcasts from Japan to roll into the New York area during the early part of the week before the coup by the military silenced the Tokyo transmitters.

AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 28. -- Two "sit-down" strikes in this area, one at the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company works in Akron and the other at the Columbia Chemical Company plant in Barberton, have attracted considerable attention because such tactics are seldom used by disaffected workers in the United States.

"Chamber Music of the Nations," a second series of five chamber music concerts by the Philharmonic-Symphony Chamber Orchestra, sponsored by Bennington College, will be given at Town Hall on five Monday evenings, Nov. 9, Dec. 7, Jan. 4, Feb. 1 and March 1, 1936-37.

Q.E.D.: In Federal Court in Trenton last week it became necessary for the purpose of the record to establish whether Milford G. Farley was a pharmacist. Judge Forman asked Mr. Farley if he knew how to make a tomato and bacon sandwich. "No, your honor," the witness replied.

UNDER the chairmanship of Edward P. Warner, former Assistant Secretary of the Navy and vice chairman of the Federal Aviation Commission, topics of widely diversified interest in aviation will come before the conference of the Greater New York Safety Council next Wednesday afternoon.

ROGER W. BABSON, known throughout the world as an expert on finance and financial statistics, emerges in the pages of his autobiography as a man who belongs in the class of American leadership that holds such figures as Edison, Ford and Coolidge.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 29. -- A touch of seasonable weather gave ample evidence of pent-up buying created during the month of blizzards. Re tail stores have been filled to capacity with shoppers and department stores report 10 per cent gains over last year.

VALPARAISO, Chile, Feb. 29. -- The thwarted attempt to take possession yesterday of army headquarters in Santiago by a group of retired officers, inspired and supported by members of Congress and others loyal to the exiled ex-President Carlos Ibanez del Campo, has revealed a wide network of revolutionary interests seeking to overthrow the administration by creating a panic in military circles.

Borden's Farm Products Company has found no sentiment in favor of a strike among its employes, it was announced yesterday by H.A. Cronk, president of the company. Mr. Cronk's statement discounted the action of shop stewards of Local 584, International Brotherhood of Teamsters and Chauffeurs, in voting authorization to union leaders Friday night to call a strike of milk wagon drivers whenever union officials saw fit.

Customs were reversed and certain traditions of leap year upheld last night at the Leap Year Assembly held in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. The fourth assembly of a series inaugurated in 1924, the party was one of the gayest of the Winter in this city and it drew a large attendance, many of the guests coming from Washington, Philadelphia, Boston and even Southern resorts.

SPRING usually brings shifts in radio's acts, and apparently the approaching season of greenery and robins will run true to form this year. There are sponsors who sign off, and others merely lighten up their shows to make them more appropriate for the outdoor season and daylight saving time.

LAST week Professor William B. Cartmel of the University of Montreal rose at a joint meeting of the American Physical Society and the Optical Society of America to assert that there is an ether and that as a consequence relativity must be rejected.

DARK hints of internal strife, spasmodic outbursts of stars and the open shifting of producers from lot to lot have thrown the town into a state of unrest that has not been paralleled in recent screen history. The upheaval has assumed greatest proportions at Paramount, but all other studios, with the exception of Metro, have felt its effects.

BERMUDA, Feb. 29. -- Nine hundred guests, including naval and military officers in full-dress uniform, members of the Bermuda Parliament and the Bermuda Government service, and many prominent Americans attended the farewell reception given today by Sir Thomas Astley, Governor General, and Lady Cubitt at Government House.

BERLIN, Feb. 29. -- Trading on the Boerse was friendly today, although activity was strictly limited. Heay industrials were slightly firmer, Mannesmann gaining ' point and Rheinstahl ,i. Machines were somewhat stronger. Orenstein Koppel gaining 1 point, as did Schubert Salzer.

THERE is a new system of permanent waving designed for women who like to move about while the heat is being applied to the hair, instead of sitting in one stiff position, and who haven't more than half an afternoon to give to it.
KANSAS CITY, Kan., Feb. 29 (AP). -- At 65 years of age Mrs. L.M. Straight, housewife, developed an intense desire to look at the moon.
THE beginning and ending of the world -- Broadway!

THERE'S a picture for you!" said my dinner companion. Looking across the room I saw a sight which I have good reason never to forget. Perhaps it was Dame Fortune herself who whispered in my ear at that moment.

The Governors Island polo team won the first game in defense of its national junior indoor polo title last night, defeating Squadron A, 14 to 5 1/2, before the largest crowd of the season at the latter's armory.

The National Socialist revolution passed the foreign political risk zone in less than three years. Germany is free in her armament policy and can determine the speed, extent and aim of her policies in all fields according to her own judgment.

FROM the standpoint of year-round enjoyment, the Winter aspect of a rock garden is fully as important as its floral display during Spring and Summer. Since the general layout is intended to represent -- at least to some extent -- a miniature Alpine panorama, its rugged contours offer a background for plantings designed to bring out the austere beauty of the Winter landscape in characteristic detail of cold-enduring verdure.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Feb. 29. -- Woman may still be credited with a talent for ingenuity although she has put aside the hairpin which was once her stock of all trades. Members of the Theatre Workshop Course at Wellesley College who make pearls out of peppermint drops, and "wrought-iron" gates out of insulated wire retain for their sex a reputation for resourcefulness.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 28. -- New Jersey's year-old failure to find a satisfactory method of financing unemployment relief narrowly escaped precipitating a crisis this week as available relief funds all but vanished. Governor Harold G. Hoffman, suspending his efforts to solve the problem, left it in the hands of a committee of the Legislature.
THE following letter has bean received from Edmund L. Goodman of New York, who has recently returned from a motor trip abroad:

LONDON, Feb. 28. -- Despite its own sufficiently grave preoccupations, Europe has watched the Tokyo uprising with keen interest and some apprehension, for Japan, though a long way off, is a vital factor in world politics and world economy, and what she does in Asia directly affects the prospects for peace and prosperity in Europe.

NEARLY every gardener who tries to raise seedlings indoors faces the discouraging loss of quantities of plants through "damping-off." This disease is inherent in almost any kind of soil and many methods have been used to control it -- with varying degrees of success.

The Coca-Cola Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday a net income of $15,804,256 for 1935 after depreciation. Federal taxes and other charges, according to preliminary figures. In 1934 the company earned $14,328,668 after similar deductions.

THE Eastern Championships, beginning tomorrow afternoon at the Hotel Commodore and lasting through the week, will cast a temporary shadow over bridge club activity in New York, though not so much as in previous years.

Lord PONSONBY, after long service in the House of Commons "raised" to the peerage, where he became leader of the Opposition, seems to be an ironist. His plan, more than once expressed, for "reforming" the House of Lords is to abolish it. The other day that House voted to abolish trial of peers by peers.

Apropos Mr. Downes in this morning's TIMES on the future of the Philharmonic -- has any one ever inquired why people buy, or do not buy, tickets to this or that concert? It is taken for granted that they pay to hear Mr. Toscanini.

BEAUTY has come back to the sea again in the new great liners after a period in which size and power were the only factors that counted. The first tendencies toward its return were seen in the big German express steamers that ruled the Atlantic after the war.

MOST Americans are aware of the glamour of Texas statistics. They have heard that the Lone Star State is almost as large as Germany and Great Britain combined, that it will hold 200,000,000 people when it is as thickly populated as Belgium, that it specializes in the biggest grapefruit, the fastest-moving blizzards, the longest-horned cows and so on.

It is the consensus of women who have jobs, directed at those who are looking for them, that neither optimism nor opportunity is lacking in the business world. A series of pamphlets to be released this month by the National Federation of Business and Professional Women stress the fact that ability, initiative and proper training will balance the admitted disadvantages in some fields.

New York City's quota in the 1936 national $3,500,000 fund drive of the Joint Distribution Committee has been set at $1,500,000, it was announced yesterday by Paul Baerwald, chairman of the organization. The money raised by the campaign will be expended chiefly for the aid of Jews in Germany but also will be applied toward the committee's work in Eastern and Central Europe.

At a discussion conference held under the auspices of the Child Research Clinic of the Woods Schools of Langhorne, Pa., Dr. John Levy of the Columbia University Psychiatry Department made some statements which are disturbing.

PARIS. THE Paris fashion collections shown for the coming Summer display a reach of imagination seldom equaled in the history of the couture; at any rate, not since those pre-war days when the very name of Poiret, Paquin or Worth conjured up a sartorial Arabian Nights entertainment.

MODERATING temperatures through the country brought the upturn in trade during the week that was expected. Only the Pacific Coast reported slow business, and the rise in the Middle West and Northwest was impressive.

With retail distribution showing the sharpest recovery, business activity gained greater momentum in most sections of the country last week, following the temporary, slump caused by severe weather conditions earlier last month. Reports from all districts gave evidence of a wide expansion in trade and industry during the current month, merchants being especially confident over pre-Easter prospects.

The first of the three Norwich victims of murder is an English spinster employed at a boys' boarding school who, having won a tidy little fortune in a French lottery, is promptly decoyed to London by a swindler, one Throgmorton, and slain, his female accomplice, an actress, then assuming the dead woman's identity, speeding to Paris and safely collecting the rich prize called for by the lucky lottery ticket.
THERE may soon come a day when each and every American microphone will have engraved upon it, as a reminder to all speakers at the gateway of the ether, these eloquent words of Owen D. Young:

It was a very genuine pleasure to read Mr. Downes's article "Future of Philharmonic" in yesterday's TIMES, especially the line: "Why shouldn't a Philharmonic-Symphony subscriber, well in advance of a season, know what he is going to hear?"

A BEAUTIFUL title can be a snare and a delusion. Hester Billiter was lovely in her ways no less than in her person. But she was not dead. We leave her near to it at the beginning of the book while we retrace her previous history, but her ultimate recovery is no secret.

TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 29 (AP). -- Frank L. Pinet, secretary of Kansas Teachers Association, wrote today to George A. Davis, secretary of the American Federation of Teachers, to give him "the facts" of the Kansas school situation.

There is every indication of a brilliant audience at the matinee performance of "La Boheme" on Wednesday at the Metropolitan Opera House, with Grace Moore and Nino Martini in the leading roles, which benefits the Free Milk Fund for Babies.

TAKE Mr. Behrman on his own terms. In a world pulsating with anger and contention he goes on writing in a friendly spirit about the people he understands. He has no program. He does not know how to set the world to rights.

IF Professor Shapley should happen to visit Mr. Gordon's production of "Ethan Frome" at the National, he would be surprised to find that the stars in Jo Mielziner's sky correspond exactly with the configurations of astral bodies in the heavenly firmament.

WASHINGTON. -- President Roosevelt recently prescribed by executive order, and the heraldry experts of the United States Navy have now designed, an official flag for the Vice President. Hitherto when a Vice President on a mission for the President went aboard a warship the commander hoisted a flag of his own selection.

The events in Tokyo last week brought to a head the clash between soldier and civilian statesmen which has characterized Japanese politics ever since the military machine started to rumble across Manchuria in 1931. For five years the diplomatic admonitions of the civilian chiefs of the Japanese Government have failed to hold back the militarists; last week's revolt was in large part an attempt to put the civilians completely out of the picture.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- Marcel Maas of the faculty of the Brussels Conservatory played a group of four piano pieces today for guests of the Belgian Ambassador and Countess Van der Straten-Ponthoz at the Belgian Embassy. The pianist, who is a brother of Robert Maas, 'cellist of the Pro Arte Quartet, was heard here last year in a number of private recitals.
Mayor La Guardia spoke on "Two Years of Fusion -- With a Look Ahead" to about 300 members of the City Affairs Committee at a luncheon at the Hotel Astor yesterday, with reporters excluded.

A group of exceedingly glum statesmen emerged from the White House Thursday night. For three and a half hours they had been talking to the President about that most distressing election-year topic -- taxes. Also, they had been listening to the President on the same subject, and had found no comfort in his words.

Henry M. Brookfield Jr. gave a dinner last night in the King Cole Room of the St. Regis for Miss Alyce Pressprich of Rye, and Samuel Brookfield, and for Miss Hildegarde Schultz and William Norton, whose engagements were announced recently.
Announcement is made by Mrs. Louis Kaiser that the second Lincroft charity horse show will be given on the Kaiser estate, Lincroft Farm, Lincroft, N.J., on Saturday and Sunday, July 25 and 26.

ALTHOUGH the exact figures are not yet available, the Boy Scouts who qualified for the top rank of Eagle in 1935 promise to outnumber the record of 14,517 set in 1934. From this achievement the Scout may go even further. To the twenty-one merit badges prescribed for Eagles he may add two or three times that number, ranging from architecture to zoology.

PARIS, Feb. 28. -When last Thursday the Chamber of Deputies ratified by an imposing majority the pact of mutual assistance between France and Soviet Russia, its partisans here claimed enthusiastically that the Chamber had thereby put the coping stone to the edifice of collective security that France had been so long building.

Enrollment for the 1936 Summer's Citizens' Military Training Camps of the Second Corps area begins today in New York, New Jersey and Delaware. More than 4,400 young men from these States are expected to attend the camps.

AUGUSTA, Ga. -- With the arrival today of Robert Tyre Jones of Atlanta, with a party of friends, and three tournaments scheduled for the week on local courses, the interest of the Winter colony concentrates on the ancient game.

Leading all the way, Blind Brook's well-mounted combination continued as the Metropolitan Indoor Polo League pace-setter by vanquishing Fort Hamilton, 11 to 8, at the Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- A new appeal to American business not to capitalize on foreign wars by increasing exports to belligerents for the sake of additional profits was made by President Roosevelt today coincident with the signing of the second of a series of temporary neutrality laws.

At an unofficial and ex-parte hearing before a "citizens' jury" into the circumstances surrounding the disorder in the vicinity of Madison Square last Feb. 15, when the unemployed and WPA workers met there, it was charged that the police "provoked" the disturbance; that the police resorted to "brutality,'' and that Boy Scouts might have handled the situation better.

ON the historic waterfront of St. Louis, gateway to the West and the old frontier, the National Park Service will soon begin preliminary work on a memorial to Thomas Jefferson, third President of the United States, whose purchase of the Louisiana Territory brought under the flag a vast Western empire.

The extra day's business due to leap year combined with the moderating weather to bring retail trade in February to a more satisfactory close than had been anticipated, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

Surveys of travel conditions at sea from the standpoint of comfort have been completed by engineers of the United States, Great Britain and Italy in connection with the construction of the new Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary and the operation of the Italian liner Conte di Savoia.

QUATRE-VINGT-TREIZE," epic opera, with libretto by Henri Cain and music by Charles Silver, was produced recently in Paris for the first time at the Opera-Comique under the baton of Albert Wolff. It is another of the growing number of modern works for the lyric stage dealing with the days of the French Revolution.

When events rock Japan the repercussions are felt by an ever-increasing population and an ever-expanding empire. From an isolated nation in the middle of the last century Japan has swiftly emerged, fighting wars of arms and of trade until today -- industrially, commercially and militarily powerful -- she dominates in a large section of the world.

HE'S BACK: Chicago's most sensational Mayor came out of retirement last week and promised to work for "honest elections." For three four-year terms William Hale Thompson ran the Windy City. In 1915 Big Bill got into office by appealing to German and Negro voters; in 1919 he campaigned for a free Ireland.

A debutante committee under the chairmanship of Miss Nancy Blagden has been formed to assist at the performance of the children's opera, "The Enchanted Hour," to be given on the night of March 10 at the Junior League by and for the benefit of the children's chorus and orchestra of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association.

IN "The Poor Little Rich Girl," Eleanor Gates so effectively dramatized the plight of those who have nothing while apparently having everything, that the title of her parable was adopted into the language. She returns to the same theme in the present story.

LONDON, Feb. 29. -- British political interest will be divided during the coming week between the oil sanction discussions in Geneva on shortening the present war and the heavy parliamentary agenda in London on preparing for the next war.
BOSTON, Feb. 29 (AP). -- A suggestion that Democrats draft Henry Ford for President was made today by Dean Gleason L. Archer of Suffolk Law School to the Democratic State Committee.

The sixty-second Kentucky Derby, to be run May 2 at Churchill Downs, has attracted 102 entries, according to an announcement yesterday from Matt Winn who popularized the test inaugurated in 1875 until it became the best known horse race in the country.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 29. -- Coach Joe Nil's Army swimmers completed their first undefeated season today with a victory over the University of Pittsburgh mermen by a score of 46 to 25.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- Army discipline or politics?

MADRID, Feb. 28. -Two weeks after the holding of a general election, one-half of Spain is still lined up politically in opposition to the other half. Despite the majority which the Left coalition will have, the Catholic Popular Actionists will still be the largest party in the Cortes when it is convened on March 16.

THIS quaint little book has the rich interest that inheres in the story of a universal human experience yet differs from anything known to its readers. For it is the story of a childhood, but of a childhood utterly different from anything familiar to Occidental memory.

For the second time this season the St. Francis College quintet beat Brooklyn College in an overtime period, triumphing by 27 -- 25 before a capacity crowd of 1,200 at the Union Temple Court in Brooklyn last night.

Sportsmen's Show sidelights: That slender, bespectacled man with thinning hair and keen eyes who hovers around the handsome New Brunswick exhibit is George Allen, one of the best-known fishing guides in the Canadian Province.

SLY innuendo and outright abuse have long been heaped on the pens supplied by the British Postoffice. At last the government has found a de luxe model with which it hopes to win the respect and admiration of the public; 10,000 of them, graceful in shape and vivid red in color, have been issued to postoffices throughout the country.

A NEW type of biography is under consideration by Burton J. Hendrick, author of "The Life and Letters of Walter H. Page," "The Training of an American" and "The Lees of Virginia." What Mr. Hendrick has in mind is nothing less than a biography of the Federal Constitution, that document which the "nine old men" down in Washington have the job of interpreting.

In the controversy between the New Deal on the one hand and the Constitution as interpreted by the Supreme Court on the other, many argue under the delusion that the New Deal is a modern technique while the Constitution represents old-fashioned and outworn ideas.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 29. -- After trailing by 28 -- 17 at the half, the Brown five rallied to top Yale, 51 to 46, tonight. Kennedy of the home quintet took scoring honors with 25 markers, while Kelley starred for the Elis with 15.

SKIERS who want to save their precious week-end hours for downhill running are today seeking districts where there are ski tows. They can get four times as much downhill skiing in a day, they figure, on a slope where there is a ski tow to haul them up the mountain as at a place where they must climb up under their own steam.

TORONTO, Feb. 29 (AP). -- Harvey Jackson made a comeback tonight after going since December without a goal and led the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 4-2 triumph over the Chicago Black Hawks. The victory kept the Leafs a point ahead of the Montreal Maroons in the race for the International Group lead in the National Hockey League.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- Armed with an obscure provision of the Agricultural Adjustment Act, unscathed by the recent Supreme Court decision, the agricultural arm of the government reached out today to recapture the once profitable Philippine market for American flour.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP). -- The National Association of Manufacturers contended today that fifteen bills in Congress were upsetting the President's promised "breathing spell" and constituted a threat to further business recovery.

GOUCHER COLLEGE is well launched into the second year of its new program of realistic education for women. The first year was experimental and successful; undergraduates and faculty responded to the new plan with enthusiasm; alumnae and the educational world followed its progress with keen interest.

AIKEN, S.C. -- Starting off what should be the first "big week" of the Spring sport season here, the Aiken Polo Pony and Hunter Show is scheduled for this morning and afternoon at the Cochran Polo Field. It is being staged for the benefit of the Aiken unit of the S.C.P.A. and the Schofield Normal and Industrial School here for Negro students.

THE International Flower Show committee of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, of which Mrs. Walter Parsons is executive chairman, will make use of the Dutch or Flemish motif in its displays and arrangements.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 29. -- Seventy-five members of the Milbrook Country Club and guests attended a leap year dinner dance at the clubhouse tonight at which women were hosts. The dining hall was decorated with cupids and hearts.
WASHINGTON. -- Each Senator and Representative may have ten or twelve copies of the map of the United States prepared by the Land Office for distribution after July 1.

PARIS, Feb. 29 (AP). -- Karl Schafer of Austria gave an almost faultless exhibition of ice acrobatics tonight in the free skating as he made a successful defense of his world figure skating championship.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 28. -- Continued warlike declarations of the new military government of Paraguay are believed in many quarters to endanger the prospects of the Chaco peace. It is pointed out that they are being used by Bolivian army officers as justification for their demand for a larger political influence in the government at La Paz.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28. -- Chicago will become an Eastern standard time city on Sunday. So it has been ordained by the City Council, and all the clocks will follow that ruling -- all except the railroad clocks.

The issue of excess reserves, which divided the banking community last Fall, was raised again last week after lying dormant more than two months. The question was brought forward again by the publication on Friday by the Federal Advisory Council of a renewed recommendation for prompt action to reduce the volume of excess reserves in the hands of member banks of the Reserve System as a precaution against credit inflation.

Eleven-year-old Eleanor Baumann of Woodcliff, N.J., made the stage appearance yesterday morning that she won by good yodeling on Feb. 18. At that time she defeated eleven boys to capture first place in the Children's Welfare Federation's yodeling contest.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- The card for the second annual hunt race meeting of the Sandhill Steeplechase and Racing Association to be held on the new course, midway between Southern Pines and Pinehurst, on Saturday, March 14, was announced this week.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 29. -- Columbia, with a well-balanced team, easily won the triangular track and field meet with Princeton and Pennsylvania on the Franklin Field boards today before a crowd of 5,000. No admission was charged.

CHICAGO, Feb. 29. -- Merchandising activities expanded sharply as the Middle West thawed out. Mail-order houses experienced a rush that tested their ability to handle the business. Sales of the large department stores here were from 10 to 15 per cent ahead of the like week of last year, while the extra day of business, due to leap year, will probably give sales for the full month a satisfactory increase over February, 1935.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- Industrial production in the week ended on Feb. 22 was held to a steady pace, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly business review, although output was somewhat curtailed by the Washington's Birthday recess.

Like many other great artists, especially operatic artists, ANTONIO SCOTTI made a large part of his reputation in New York, at the Metropolitan Opera House. He was active here a full man's lifetime, and has died at an opera singer's green old age, leaving memories of great art deeply impressed upon New York operagoers.

Three hundred chapters of Hadassah throughout the country will merge the celebration of Purim, commemorating the liberation of the Jews of Persia 2,700 years ago, with founders' day programs next Sunday. The date marks the twenty-fourth anniversary of the organization, which was established by Miss Henriette Szold in 1912.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 29 (AP) -- A local association, which in 1746 already had been dubbed "ancient," claims the honor of being the oldest social club with a continuous history in the United States.

ABOUT half way through this narrative of a career Mr. Cram remarks that "in architecture, as in all else, you cannot lift yourself by your bootstraps." At another point he describes the process by which he approached the problem of designing buildings for the Rice Institute at Houston, Texas.

PERCY MARKS'S first novel, "The Plastic Age." created some little stir as a realistic document of the extracurricular activities of campus youth back in the F. Scott Fitzgerald days of "This Side of Paradise." His new book has gone "Sorrell and Son," not to say "Stover at Yale" brought up-to-date.

THE function of a literary critic on the staff of a newspaper is ordinarily supposed to be limited to the expression of judgments on the quality of books sent for review. That is no light or easy task, and one might imagine that most men would not wish to add to the burden and responsibility of it.
LEIPZIG, Feb. 29 (AP). -- Germany's trade barometer, the annual Leipzig Spring fair, opens tomorrow with an unprecedented response on the part of exhibitors and buyers.

MOSCOW, Feb. 29. -- Protest against the fulsome flattery of "Stakhanoffites" -- workers who were decorated for setting a new pace in industrial production -- was voiced by Comsomol officials today on the ground it is giving the Stakhanoffites swelled heads and interfering with their work.
TOKYO, Feb. 29. -- When the Japanese Army insurgents surrendered today they were disarmed and taken to their barracks as prisoners in army trucks guarded by armed soldiers wearing steel helmets.

IF after reading the Austrian criticisms of his "Silent Woman" Richard Strauss does not pack his kit and take the next train to Vienna, it can only be because the Nazis won't let him. Not since he conferred upon mankind the indestructible "Rosenkavalier" has he encountered such a puff.

The Public Service Commission will argue before the Court of Appeals in Albany, beginning on Thursday, with the National Association of Railroad and Public Utility Commissioners appearing as amicus curiae, its appeal from the denial by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of its right to enforce a revised system of accounts on leading public utility companies.
WELLESLEY, Mass., Feb. 29. -- One hundred and seventy members of the graduating class of Wellesley College and their escorts attended the senior prom here tonight in the ballroom of Alumnae Hall.

In the discussion evoked by the opinion of the majority of the Supreme Court in the TVA case, the dissenting opinion of Justice McReynolds has been largely overlooked. Both should be read in the light of the AAA decision.

THE invention of an electron tube that permits human eyes to see in the dark and to penetrate the invisible, announced recently by the American Association for the Advancement of Science, will be looked upon with more than ordinary interest by at least one group of hobbyists.

We have scrupulously refrained from any military defense of our two land borders; have undertaken two costly wars solely to sustain our devotion to liberal government; and have arbitrated critical territorial and political differences.

About 85,000 persons in this city were being cared for by private family welfare organizations on Jan. 1, Laurence M. Marks, chairman of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee, said yesterday in announcing plans for a campaign for funds. Headquarters for the drive will be opened tomorrow at 14 Wall Street and active solicitation by 3,000 volunteer workers will start as soon as possible.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 29. -- A special intensive course in textile research designed to meet the requirements of executives, research directors, and others particularly interested in this field of manufacture will be given at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology beginning on March 20, it was announced today.

Several German-American relief organizations in the metropolitan area will benefit from a Spring Festival, plans for which are now being made under the auspices of the German-American Charities, Inc. The event will be held on the night of April 17 in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria and is a preliminary function toward the re-establishment of the annual German-American Charity Ball held here in years past.

BOSTON, Feb. 29. -- Completely outclassing its opponents at every stage of the game, a smooth-working Harvard hockey team routed a disorganized Princeton sextet, 8 -- 0, tonight at the Boston Arena before 4,000 fans and climbed into a first-place tie with Dartmouth in the quadrangular league.

Bond prices were confined to narrow limits in routine trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The turnover was the smallest to date this year for a two-hour session, the volume amounting to $7,843,400, compared with $8,837,100 on Saturday, Feb. 15.

DALLAS, Feb. 29. -- Business throughout the Eleventh Federal Reserve District has shown marked recovery with the return of warm weather. Retailers report a rush of buying that has gone far toward wiping out the temporary slump caused by the severe weather conditions.

More than 350 photographs taken by amateurs all over the country, as well as examples of professional photography, will be placed on exhibition tomorrow in the gallery at the offices of Carl Zeiss, Inc., at 485 Fifth Avenue.

LONDON, Feb. 7. THE censorship of plays in England is exercised by the Lord Chamberlain, advised by certain readers whom he appoints. His powers are absolute; his decisions are not to be disputed, even in Parliament.
BURLINGTON, Vt., Feb. 29. -- Vermonters will go to the polls next Tuesday, their annual March meeting day, to settle a question which has been bothering them for more than two years.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 28. -- Upton Sinclair's sudden emergency from retirement to become nominee candidate for President at the May 5 Democratic primary in California may have national repercussions if the EPIC ticket of delegates should be successful at the polls.

Mrs. Maryon Cooper Hewitt will oppose any attempt to extradite her to California to face prosecution on the charge of her daughter, Ann Cooper Hewitt, that her mother caused her to be sterilized, it was said yesterday by William V. Breslin, Mrs. Hewitt's attorney.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., Feb. 29. -- Failure to sink a four-foot putt on the third extra hole proved extremely costly to Miss Patty Berg, 18-year-old Minneapolis star, in her final match against Miss Lucille Robinson of Des Moines, Iowa, for the women's South Atlantic championship at the Ormand Beach Golf Club today.

WHEN President Roosevelt stood in the white glare of the klieg lights at the Capitol on Jan. 3 and thundered defiance of foes at home and admonition to disturbers of the peace abroad he was at the very summit of a career of showmanship that might well make many a professional green with envy.
TOKYO, Sunday, March 1. -- The alleged leader of Tokyo's abortive four-day revolt, Captain Teruzo Ando, shot himself in the head yesterday and died.

BOSTON, Feb. 28. -- David I. Walsh, senior Senator from Massachusetts, at last has issued a statement on the political situation and his personal position which is as remarkable for what he did not say as for what he said.

DETROIT, Feb. 28. -- No sooner had it been announced from Washington that harmony had been achieved in the Democratic party in Michigan than former Governor William A. Comstock withdrew from the organization and emphasized that harmony seemed impossible.

BEELIN, Feb. 28. -Ratification of the Franco-Soviet pact of mutual assistance by the French Chamber of Deputies has brought back into the foreground of international politics the matter of the demilitarized Rhineland and the Locarno treaty upon which its demilitarization depends.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- The administration's Pan-American peace conference plan appeared today to have come to a standstill because of the continued failure of the Paraguayan Government to accept President Roosevelt's suggestion that such a conference be held.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- A new question concerning the Congressional resolution which barred payments in gold was put before the Supreme Court today in a brief which stated that bonds totaling $980,000,000 were affected by the issue.

Frank Nordell of the New York A.C., the in-and-outer of other seasons but a gem of rare consistency in this, the Olympic year, added another brilliant chapter to his checkered career last night. In the Metropolitan A.A.U. track and field championships, which the Jefferson Club staged at the 245th Field Artillery Armory in Brooklyn, the rangy Winged Footer turned in not one outstanding performance but two of them in the space of a half hour.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 29. -- Seasonal expansion is encouraging business men to put forth new efforts, as is evidenced by progressive financing by large corporations in this district. Steel, iron, chemical and textile plants, which are a large factor in industry in this district, are being put in order for greater production.

FRIEDRICHSHAFEN, Germany, Feb. 29. -- Next week the first Zeppelin really built to be a transocean liner will make her maiden voyage over Lake Constance. The ship, which will be christened in due time as the Von Hindenburg, has a gas capacity of 200,000 cubic meters in comparison with the 115,000 cubic meters of the Graf Zeppelin.

CARSON CITY, Nev., Feb. 28. -- Boulder Dam and its powerhouses, with their capacity of 1,835,000 horsepower, will be delivered to the United States Government on Sunday by Six Companies, Inc. Thus will be terminated five years of labor on what is heralded as the greatest engineering feat since the Panama Canal was built.

THE belief is widely spread that the population of Idaho consists of Senator Borah and other persons whose only purpose in life is to keep their admired fellow-citizen in Washington. But this book is a good corrective of that fallacious notion.

The Board of Education sanctioned yesterday a petition of high school social science teachers that they be allowed one more month in which to submit their teaching-plans (syllabi) and articles in the Constitution Contest which THE NEW YORK TIMES is conducting in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 29. -- Taking the last two bouts, Harvard's varsity boxing team remained in the undefeated ranks today as they punched out a 5-to-3 decision over the Army team before a record-breaking crowd of 1,800 at the Harvard indoor athletic building.

OLD MAN WEATHER, who has played such uncomfortable tricks on groundlings during the past two months over nearly all the vast territory from the Atlantic seaboard to the Continental Divide, has had little effect, airline operators reported last week, on wing-borne travel.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 29. -- Limiting the Indians to a single field goal in the first half, Princeton's five downed Dartmouth, 34 to 24, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League contest tonight.

WITH the departure of the cutter Pontchartrain from Boston today on a reconnaissance cruise, the Coast Guard is ready to start the North Atlantic ice patrol which it conducts annually by international agreement.

A NUMBER of routes are open to American tourists who are planning to visit South Africa this year -- and many are preparing to attend the Johannesburg Jubilee, designed to mark fifty years of progress and development. The jubilee opens on Sept. 15 and extends through January, 1937.

Gustav Kilian and Heinz Vopel rode home the winners of the sixtieth international six-day bicycle race, which came to a close at Madison Square Garden last night. The sturdy German pedalers swung into sole possession of first place at 10 o'clock, and for the remaining hour successfully fought off all bids made by their rivals to register their second successive triumph in New York and their sixth in the United States.

Six borough directors of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, elected at the February convention of the organization, will begin their terms Tuesday morning at the monthly meeting of the officers in the Hotel Astor. A seventh, Mrs. Charles Clement of Queens, who served part of a prior term, was re-elected for another two years.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 28. -- The Supreme Court's decision upholding the government's sale of Wilson Dam power has been received in the Tennessee Valley by TVA supporters -- an overwhelming majority of the population -- as a turning on of the green "Go" light.

ALBANY, Feb. 29. -- The question whether a resolution adopted by the Legislature on April 11, 1935, was valid in declaring the emergency at an end and thus requiring New York City to restore the salaries of policemen and firemen to the level of 1932, or whether this must be accomplished through enactments of a legislative bill, is to be put before the Court of Appeals Monday in two actions.

RED BANK, N.J., Feb. 29. -- Rube White, the village carpenter who won the North American ice-boat championship on Feb. 6, concluded today he could not conquer nature. He started out with his old-fashioned homemade and gaffed mainsail craft Elizabeth R., in the renewal of the runner sailing competition today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- The President gave to his Congressional leaders at the White House tax conference Thursday night a lesson in administrative responsibility and political sense which they should not have required. That they were surprised and anxious is an unintended reflection upon the sincerity and wisdom of their party leader, the head of the nation.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 29 (AP). -- Four men were held by Miami Beach police today in connection with the theft of $20,000 in cash and jewels from the Colony Hotel here yesterday morning.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 29. -- More than 600 young women are on the Rutgers University campus as guests for the annual Junior Prom Week-end festivities. The program opened last night with the prom.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 29. -- Paul van Zeeland, 42-year-old Premier of Belgium, will retire April 1, exactly one year after he asked for and obtained plenary powers for twelve months to restore the shattered economy of his country.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Feb. 29. -- A combination of leap year features, St. Patrick's Day decorations and dances of the "gay Nineties" marked the dinner-dance tonight at the Rockaway Hunting Club, which was attended by about 150 members of the south shore and their house guests.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- Three bills which James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, laid before the Senate Finance Committee during the past week embody the administration's plan for bringing the vast over-the-counter trade in securities under Federal supervision and for regularizing unlisted trading on exchanges.

CANBERRA, Feb. 29. -- Australian Laborites, desperately eager to win the Federal elections in 1937, have buried their differences and become a united party for the first time since 1931, when the Lang and Scullin factions parted.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 29. -- The St. Nicholas A.C. defeated a weakened Yale varsity six tonight, 7 to 2. Scoring four times in the opening session, the New Yorkers had easy going thereafter, leading comfortably all the way.
Trade price-fixing brought a further improvement in quotations for near months on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, the market ending with a gain of 4 to a loss of 3 points.

The first open meeting of the Federal Theatre Veterans League, composed of workers on the Federal Theatre Projects who wish "to combat the element of communism in the Theatre Project and other WPA units," was held yesterday afternoon in the Union Church, 229 West Forty-eighth Street, with some 200 veterans present. Major William L. Ball presided.

MEDFORD, Mass., Feb. 29. -- A novel method of teaching undergraduate economics courses at Tufts College has proven eminently successful in its several weeks of trial, according to Dr. William Trufant Foster, new instructor in economics.

The distinction of being the first New York City child born on Feb. 29 and having a birthday only once in four years appeared to have been won by the as yet unnamed son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Gross of 690 Woodward Avenue, Brooklyn, who was born in the Jewish Hospital at five minutes past midnight yesterday morning.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 29. -- Women's activities will be predominant on the University of Pennsylvania campus next week. The third annual exhibition of art by women students will open on Monday, and two days later the Women's Student Government Association will entertain representatives of similar organizations from near-by colleges and universities to discuss mutual problems.

TOKYO, Sunday, March 1. -- As the last of the Japanese Army insurgents surrendered yesterday, one of history's most miraculous escapes from assassination came to light. Premier Keisuke Okada reappeared in the flesh.

BERLIN, Feb. 29. -- The Reich government apparently is in no haste to indicate the nature of its reaction to the ratification of the Franco-Soviet pact by the Chamber of Deputies, and this attitude is also reflected in official and press comment, which is in striking contrast with the more acrimonious earlier verdicts on the pact's political implications.

THE slang of the American soda jerker has been recorded at last. Dr. Harold W. Bentley of Columbia University and a group of students working for the National Youth Administration have spent the last five months in a study of what they describe as the "linguistic concoctions of the soda jerker."

AS in previous exhibitions at the Temporary Galleries of the Municipal Art Committee, 62 West Fifty-third Street, the groups formed by the artists themselves are allotted one floor each in the current show. MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 29. -- Mantagna, 4-year-old gelded son of Sweep, in the white and red silks of William H. Furst, raced to a smashing victory in the first running of the Widener Challenge Cup Handicap of a mile and a quarter today before close to 20,000 fans, the biggest crowd thus far of the Hialeah Park meeting.

BERLIN, Feb. 29. -- The complete professional rehabilitation of Wilhelm Furtwaengler, eminent operatic and orchestral conductor, who resigned his various posts more than two years ago, was forecast today in an official announcement that he would shortly resume his activities as "guest conductor of the Berlin State Operas."

Hoffman were learned today after the Executive had sent a sharp letter to Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf, State Police head, demanding action in the renewed investigation of the kidnapping and murder of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr.

MOSCOW, Feb. 28. -- Although the standard of living in Russia is still markedly lower than among employed workers in advanced Western countries its level this Winter is decidedly above last Winter's. Mr. Carter adds a new volume to his series of adventure stories dealing with notable incidents of the American Revolution with this tale of a lad who played his own small part when Danbury was burnt by Governor Tryon's troops.

PARTICULARLY in consideration of Miss Johnson's extreme youth, "This Bed Thy Centre" was a rather striking first novel. Chaotic as it often seemed, and somewhat confused in purpose, it had qualities of vitality and humor which set it apart.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 29 -- Undergraduate yachtsmen at Brown University are looking forward today to expansion of Brown's yachting program as a result of a special campaign for funds which will be launched by the Executive Committee of the Associated Alumni.

BERLIN, Feb. 29. -- Harms Kerrl, Minister for Church Affairs, today rewarded Hanover's Bishop August Marahrens for deserting the more stubborn of the independent Protestant clergy and coming over to the government's side in the religious controversy in Germany.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 28. -- During his four terms as Governor, Albert C. Ritchie so dominated the Democratic party in Maryland that it is impossible to contemplate his sudden death this week without expecting political eventualities of an immediate nature.

The New York Infirmary for Women and Children will benefit from the premiere here of the Ruth Page Ballet tonight and tomorrow at the Adelphi Theatre. Mrs. Marshall Field, Mrs. Harold E. Talbott, Mrs. Norman de R. Whitehouse and Mrs. Frank A. Vanderlip, as members of the arrangements committee under the chairmanship of Mrs. Henry Martyn Alexander, have been active in the sale of subscriptions and are interested in the financial success of the undertaking.

The arrest of two WPA workers, one of them a member of the Democratic Club of the Eighteenth Assembly District South, on charges of conspiracy against the government in the sale of WPA jobs was disclosed yesterday by Thomas F. Cullen, agent in charge of the Division of Investigation of the WPA.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- Extensive improvements in fishing and boating facilities are being made here in preparation for Atlantic City's Summer visitors.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 29. -- A forward step in student self-government, whereby two members of the men's Student Council at Cornell were added to the Faculty Committee on Student Conduct, was announced today by the university. Heretofore disciplinary problems were exclusively the prerogative of the faculty.

SAN JUAN, P.R. -- Behind the assassination of Colonel E. Francis Riggs, American head of the insular police force of Puerto Rico, by two young Nationalists lies the problem of this island's future political status.

Battle lines for a renewal of the old war between the modernist and traditional schools of architecture began to appear yesterday, with Flushing Meadows, site of the 1939 World's Fair, as the objective of both groups.

THIS book by a retired marine officer urges the adoption in this country of the military system of Switzerland, which demands six weeks of military training in camp of every young man when he reaches 20 years and afterward asks of him only two or three eleven-day periods of camp service.

An American fact-finding commission is quartered in a hotel on the outskirts of Havana. Its personnel includes experts in various lines whose mission is to investigate conditions in Cuba and prepare an exhaustive report. Many of the Cubans are hostile toward the commission, looking upon its activities as just plain American snoopery.

Victor F. Ridder, local WPA Administrator, denied yesterday the request for prevailing wages on WPA projects submitted to him on behalf of its members of the Federation of Architects, Engineers, Chemists and Technicians. Mr. Ridder contends that the WPA "was never meant to be a substitute for normal employment."

FRANZ MEHRING'S "Karl Marx" is all admirable example of that thoroughness which, throughout the nineteenth century, was universally regarded as the distinctive characteristics of German scholarship. The high claim made for it by the publishers of the American translation, that it is "the definitive biography of Karl Marx," does not seem to go beyond its merits.

Motor buses will replace street cars on two more routes in Manhattan on Friday. Hugh J. Sheeran, president of the New York Railways Corporation, announced yesterday that operation of buses would begin that day on the company's lines on lower Seventh Avenue and Eighth Street.

The need for passage of the Schwartzwald-Crewes Occupational Disease Bill now pending before the Legislature, providing for workmen's compensation and the compulsory use of a device protecting workers against dust hazards, was stressed yesterday by George Meany, president of the New York State Federation of Labor.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 29. (AP). -- Six hunderd miles from the nearest ocean and probably destined never to get wet except in the rain, a trim craft, fashioned after a Coast Guard cutter and fully equipped, was ceremoniously christened at Fort Oglethorpe tonight.

A broad-shouldered WPA worker performed some difficult acrobatics yesterday and saved a crippled 2-year-old child and his 23-year-old uncle from drowning in the murky green water under the West Ninety-seventh Street pier.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 26. NOT FOR CHILDREN," Elmer Rice's latest and much discussed play, made its American bow last night under the auspices of the Pasadena Community Playhouse, its first production in fact since the London Stage Society put it on briefly a few months ago.

The Interstate Sanitary Commission, created by a pact signed by New York, New Jersey and Connecticut in 1931, at last is ready to embark on its task of preventing the pollution of harbors, rivers and bathing beaches in and about the metropolitan area.

WINGING into town last week, with a whole host of engaging tales about Dr. Allan Dafoe and his quintuplet wards, and a cold that had him "all fussed up," came Director Henry King of Twentieth Century-Fox, just ahead of his latest film, "The Country Doctor."

CHICAGO, Feb. 29 (AP). -- The Western Conference faculty committee today gave the University of Wisconsin a choice between restoring athletic control to its faculty or suffering suspension from the Big Ten.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- In 1933 our new economic program was defensive in temper because the country was on the run. Today it is everywhere apparent that confidence has been bestirred and recovery inspired. The task confronting us has therefore become quite different from what it was in 1933.

Milder weather stimulated retail trade in the metropolitan area last week. Sales of leading department stores were estimated as showing a rise of about 5 per cent over the corresponding period last year, and merchants became increasingly confident over pro-Easter prospects.

Mrs. Mary Anderson Sanborn's recent statement that "ninety-nine out of one hundred public speakers pronounce government 'government,' or at least it sounds so over the radio," is timely. When a speaker uses all the n's in the word it is noticeable -- and refreshing. This careless pronunciation is rather frightful.

A fear that the rebellion in Japan last week presages an intensive trade drive by that nation in every market of the globe spread apprehension among foreign traders and domestic manufacturers here yesterday. These interests believe that the military faction which gained ascendancy through the Tokyo uprising will intensify Japanese competition in order to create exchange with which to further ambitions on the Asiatic mainland.
Columbia's basketball team advanced to within a game of the Eastern Intercollegiate League title last night with an easy 59-26 victory over Cornell at the Morningside Heights court.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 29 (AP) -- Charges that John Stewart Bryan Jr., a vice president of the Richmond Academy of Arts, violated Virginia law in the displaying of "indecent" paintings here were dismissed in police court today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- Senator Borah intends, if nominated for the Presidency, to have as his running mate on the Republican ticket Frank E. Gannett, the New York publisher, who has entered the Ohio primaries with the Idaho Senator as candidate for second choice for the Presidential nomination.

BY "footprints" Mrs. Miller means relics, influences, of the past, of any kind, material or spiritual, and in her travels in Palestine she has been alert to find and understand them and sensitive in her perception of their existence and their nature.

THE notion of a "Greenwich Village Follies" for late Spring is as yet only a whisper. But, clearly, it is one to heed. The last carnival to bear that memory-evoking title came from the Shubert studio in 1928. Now it is A.L. Jones and Morris Green, still teamed as The Bohemians, Inc., who are pondering another edition.

A search for the "longest happily married couple" in New York is being conducted by Uncle Robert so that suitable honors may be conferred at the ninth annual celebration of Parents Day on the Mall in Central Park on Sunday afternoon, May 10.

DODGE CITY, Kan., Feb. 28. -- Return of dust storms to the hard wheat area in Kansas, Oklahoma and Southeast Colorado has convinced the wheat farmers that tillage in a manner to prevent soil-blowing is their only salvation. There is some discouragement over the recurrence of these storms, but so far there is more distress to individuals in trying to breathe than damage to the wheat.
In THE TIMES there appeared recently a commendable letter by William Zerffi on the vital subject of population curbs.

WARRENTON, Va. -- F. D. Gaskins will act as manager for the eleventh annual Stuyvesant School Horse Show to be held May 1 on the school grounds. Mr. Gaskins, manager of the Warrenton Horse Show for many years, has also conducted shows in Washington, Richmond and Culpeper.

The board of directors of the Catholic Young Women's Club will give its thirteenth annual luncheon bridge and fashion show on Tuesday at the Plaza to raise money for the continuation of its work. The organization provides young business girls with recreational facilities at a nominal fee, in return for which the girls do social service work at the branches and at orphanages.

Though it is only a third of a mile in diameter and therefore no more massive than an average mountain, much could be made of the "Delporte Object," discovered earlier in the month, for the reason that it came within 1,500,000 miles of the earth -- nearer than any of the 1,200 planetoids thus far charted.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- President Roosevelt began today the actual drafting of the message he will send to Congress early next week, possibly on Tuesday, in which he will demand the passage of a tax bill requiring $786,000,000 before the session adjourns.

BOSTON, Feb. 29 (AP). -- Garment manufacturers and representatives of 4,000 striking workers agreed today, at Governor Curley's request, to begin negotiations at once to end a strike that began Thursday.

Lighthearted fun and an enthusiastic display of the charms of quaint old England are Dornford Yates's strongest bids for entertaining the reader of light fiction. In his latest novel he takes his group of amiable young English people back to White Ladies in England, where many of his admirers like them best.

OF John C. Fremont there were always a number of opinions; of his brilliant and charming wife there has never been but one. In his lifetime men distrusted his purposes, his judgment, some of them even his integrity.

The Keith-Albee-Orpheum Corporation has declared a dividend of $1.75 a share on the 7 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock. The dividend, payable out of capital surplus, is for the quarter ended on Dec. 31, 1931, and is the first payment since Oct. 1, 1931, when a similar amount was disbursed.
