Aside from the heaviness of railway shares as followers of the market were unconvinced that the reduction in railway fares ordered by the I.C.C. would materially aid the carriers by increasing business, the stock market was dull yesterday and generally without incident.

New requirements for school medical inspectors whose temporary appointments were contested recently in the Supreme Court have been formulated by the Board of Education in preparation for an examination for permanent licenses.

OPERATIONS are under way to salvage a "huge treasure" believed to be hidden in the hold of the Polluce, a Spanish sailing ship that sank 130 years ago in the Portolongone Bay, Island of Elba. This difficult task has been undertaken by the Artiglio, the Italian salvage vessel which attracted world-wide attention last year when it brought up the gold stored in the hold of the sunken liner Egypt.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 29 (AP). -- Colonel Henry Breckinridge of New York prepared today to challenge the Democratic New Deal to a popularity contest in the Buckeye State.

City officials will break ground Tuesday morning for the new $1,500,000 Bronx Industrial High School at 161st Street and Tinton Avenues, it was announced yesterday by Arthur S. Tuttle, Acting State Director of the Federal Administration of Public Works.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 29. -- Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Hasler gave a dinner dance for eighty tonight in the patio of their home here.

When Olga Cristo-Loveanu appeared here for the first time a few seasons back, she devoted her talents exclusively to the singing of Rumanian folk-songs. Last night in the Town Hall she returned with a more ambitious program, including lyrics by Beethoven, Enesco and others, as well as operatic arias, such as "Divinites du Styx," from Gluck's "Alceste," and "Pleurez, mes yeux" from Massenet's "Le Cid."

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 29 (AP). -- Five contractors and four representatives of the plasterers' and lathers' unions were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on a charge of conspiracy to defraud the government.

DOROTHEA BRANDE, well known as author and lecturer, tells here how there came to her, in a sudden flash of illumination from the pages of a book she was reading, understanding of why she had not succeeded as well as she knew she ought and realization of what she must do to make her life more significant, her efforts more efficacious.

THIS definitive edition of Tolstoy's collected works is by far the finest achievement in scholarship that has come out of the Soviet Union. The idea was conceived in 1918 by Countess A.L. Tolstoy, Leo Tolstoy's daughter; V.G. Chertkov, the leader of the "Tolstoyists," and other students and former friends of the great writer.
LONDON, Feb. 29. -- A report that Russia was shipping more "knocked-down" submarines from Europe to her naval base on the Pacific Ocean circulated among members of the naval conference tonight.

An exhibition badminton tournament will be held on Thursday night at the Beekman Tower Hotel, 3 Mitchell Place, under the auspices of the missions committee of the woman's auxiliary to the National Council Diocese of New York. Net proceeds from the tourney will be used to advance the work being conducted in western missionary districts.

BELLEAIR HEIGHTS, Fla., Feb. 29. -- Putting together two brilliant sub-par rounds, Harry Cooper, Chicago professional, spreadeagled a strong field today to gain a commanding lead at the half-way mark of the Florida West Coast open golf championship.

Florence Easton was fervently welcomed back to the Metropolitan fold by the huge audience which attended last night's performance of Wagner's "Die Walkuere" at the Broadway house. The former favorite, who was last heard on the same stage in "Madama Butterfly," April 10, 1929, made her reappearance as Bruennhilde, at this second presentation in the popular-priced Saturday night "Ring" cycle.

ROME, Feb. 28. -The first serious attempt by Premier Mussolini to resume his political honeymoon with Chancellor Hitler, which had been cut short by the assassination of Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss of Austria in July, 1934, has just been made.

ONLY four of Rimsky-Korsakoff's operas are known in this city. They are "Coq d'Or," "Snegurotchka" and "Sadko," which have been in the Metropolitan repertory, and "The Czar's Bride," given in the New Amsterdam Theatre in May of 1922 by a traveling Russian company.

Four hundred volunteer workers from various departments of the Y.W.C.A. of New York will convene Friday at the Central Branch for an all-day discussion of leadership in that field. Mrs. Howard Gillespie Myers, chairman of the volunteer personnel committee, will be in the chair.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- Representative Blanton of Texas accepted full responsibility today for the testimony Major Gen. Johnson Hagood made before the House Appropriations Subcommittee on Military Affairs in December, which caused him to be removed from his command last week.

CHICAGO, March 1. -- Grain traders are confused by the change in time schedules at leading points effective tomorrow. Chicago is working on a schedule an hour later than formerly, while Minneapolis and Winnipeg continue on their old schedule.

If HORACE were alive, wouldn't he regret that he ever wrote that non omnis moriar? Wouldn't all the drumming and trumpeting, two thousand years of it in one, bore him? Rome was more than noisy enough in his day, and he was a member of the Anti-Noise Society. On the other hand, wouldn't he have enjoyed the characteristic Repplierian piece that AGNES REPPLIER has written about him in The Atlantic Monthly?

LONDON, March 1. -- King Edward VIII made history today by going to a broadcasting studio and talking to the citizens of his worldwide empire not as "my subjects" or "my people" but simply as "fellow-men."

AIKEN, S.C., March 1. -- Bit of Gold, a chestnut gelding owned by Mrs. George McMurtry of New York, was the winner of the championship for the best hunter in the Aiken polo pony and hunter show at the Post Polo Ranch today. Ridden in the events by Eddie Drink-water, Bit of Gold captured the prize presented to the champion hunter by Mrs. Dunbar W. Bostwick.
BERLIN, March 1 (AP). -- A new anti-Semitic wave was ushered in today in Germany following weeks of quiet because of the Winter Olympics.

The Ruth Page Ballets, whose home is with the Chicago Grand Opera Company, made their first New York appearance last night at the Adelphi Theatre under the patronage of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children. The program consisted of four ballets, three of which were new to this city, the fourth being "Iberian Monotone," Miss Page's setting of Ravel's "Bolero," and in many ways the most effective thing she has done.

Recent physiological and biological advances have brought still nearer the development of a rhythm method of birth control that is 100 per cent reliable, Dr. Frederick W. Rice, widely known gynecologist, told more than 400 members of the National Catholic Alumni Federation yesterday at a symposium at the Centre Club, 120 Central Park South.

Ray Lev, the gifted young pianist who has been heard in New York in recital, was the soloist yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, playing the Beethoven C minor concerto. She had earlier disclosed a beautiful tone and an exceptional interpretative talent.

With the first week of March the number of exhibitions on the art calendar swings sharply upward again, approximately twoscore new attractions being listed. Large museum comprehensives and one-man shows by young artists, academism and modernism, painting, sculpture, black-and-whites and work in other media may be found on the roster of new shows.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses will submit to Mayor La Guardia today a proposal for radical budgetary changes to enable the Park Department to charge small fees for the use of many recreational facilities that now are free, to make its income-producing activities self-supporting and to maintain them out of a special fund.

BUFFALO, March 1. -- Bunjie, the all-white English bulldog owned and shown by Reg P. Sparkes of Toronto, won the special for the best in show at the close of the twelfth annual exhibition of the Buffalo Kennel Club tonight. The judge was G.V. Glebe of Bryn Athyn, Pa.

In some directions, trade activity decreased last week. It would be strange if it had not done so; for, although preparation for Springtime business often speeds up wholesale industry toward the end of February, the unexpectedly sustained activity during December and January must to a certain extent have anticipated such a movement.

LEIPZIG, March 1. -- Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Propaganda Minister, opened the annual Leipzig Spring Fair today with the customary plea for foreigners to buy more in Germany and the customary assertion that the world crisis is largely to be attributed to other nations' treatment of Germany since 1919.

Acting twenty-four hours in advance of the announced schedule, the Building Service Employes Union called a strike yesterday in apartment houses and apartment hotels on the upper West Side of Manhattan and in the Bronx as the first move in what the union announced would be a general walkout throughout the city to go into effect today.

IT was in the New York Athletic Club and Joe Pearman had the floor. Joe is a long, slab-sided, black-haired chap with a serious view of life. But happiness is always breaking in. No matter how serious his thoughts or his words, he can't keep the twinkle out of his eye. He was talking about walking -- walking for speed. He is an old walking champion, a former national titleholder and Olympic competitor.

LONDON, Feb. 28. -- Although subdued by the unwelcome but inevitable discussion concerning the disturbing international situation in connection with the Parliamentary debate on defense and by the revolt in Japan, the security markets here ended the week on a more confident note.

One of the mistakes in religious life is the effort toward standardization and mass production of spiritual perfection among Christians, the Rev. G. Stanley Russell of the Deer Park United Church, Toronto, Canada, declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

Though he considered the industry "reasonably honest," Commissioner of Licenses Paul Moss announced yesterday new regulations, effective immediately, further to curb racketeering in the secondhand automobile business and to protect purchasers more fully.

While hundreds of city folk deserted the metropolitan area over the week-end to engage in skiing over the slopes of the Catskills and Berkshire Hills, thousands of out-of-towners took advantage of Sabbath excursion railroad fares and descended on New York yesterday to view the picturesque National Sportsmen's Show at the Grand Central Palace.

The severe weather over a great part of the country in February caused a general recession in business activity, but the decline is to be considered purely temporary, according to the monthly bulletin of the National City Bank, published today.
May I reply to the interesting article by John Dewey concerning American liberalism, printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of Feb. 23?

Offering will be made to the public today of a new issue of $17,000,000 of Kingdom of Norway 4 1/2 per cent sinking fund external bonds due on March 1, 1956, at par and accrued interest by a banking group headed by Lazard Freres Co., Inc. Others in the group are Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.;

DETROIT, March 1 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin criticized practices of chain store merchandisers today, and announced that his National Union for Social Justice would support the Robinson-Patman bill introduced in Congress, which he said would protect "the independent merchant, the public whom he serves, and the manufacturer from whom he buys from exploitation by unfair competitors."

The annual report of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for 1935, to be made public today, shows consolidated net income of $132,794,782 for the Bell System, equivalent to $7.11 a share on 18,662,275 shares of A.T. and T. stock, compared with $111,167,554, or $5.96 a share, in 1934, and with $100,341,875, or $5.38 a share, in 1933, the low point for many years.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 1. -- Appointment of the 1936 Princeton memorial fund committee here today by William A. Carlile Jr. of Columbus, Ohio, president of the senior class, marks the twentieth anniversary of the graduating class insurance plan of pledging a gift to the university to be paid at the twentieth reunion of the class.

Instead of Verdi's "Requiem." the Eighth and Ninth symphonies of Beethoven will be performed under Arturo Toscanini on Thursday night, Friday afternoon and Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. This change in the PhilharmonicSymphony program was necessitated by the continued indisposition of Dusolina Giannini.
CHICAGO, March 1. -- An old team-mate, Glen Brydson, did all the damage tonight as the New York Rangers lost by 2 to 1 to the Chicago Black Hawks in the Stadium.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, March 1. -- The Nazi Government will probably now undertake a counter-campaign against the refusals of the English universities of Oxford, Cambridge and Birmingham to accept an invitation to send representatives to the ceremony celebrating the 550th anniversary of the founding of Heidelberg University.

Myra Hess, the English pianist, gave her second recital of the season at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon for the benefit of the Hartley House Music School. It was her final local appearance this year, and a capacity audience responded enthusiastically to her interpretations.

The long movement of gold into the United States was halted temporarily in February when shipments of the metal to Europe were made for the first time since September, 1934. Exports were $20,600,800 to Feb. 8. when the outward flow ended.
Mr. and Mrs. Lionel C. Perera Jr. gave a reception with dancing yesterday afternoon at the home of Mr. Perera's parents at 49 East Eightieth Street.

About one-half of the area in the metropolitan district now served by WNYC, the city's radio station, would be affected by the proposed change of its broadcasting frequency from 810 kilocycles to 1,130 kilocycles, Frederick J.H. Kracke, Commissioner of Plant and Structures, said yesterday.

BOSTON, March 1. -- Dwight W. Morrow Jr., brother-in-law of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, reported to Massachusetts State police authorities two weeks ago tomorrow the theft of papers containing intimate information concerning the Lindbergh baby kidnapping.

The following table gives the amount of dealings in the stock from which the averages are computed, as well as the total dealings in the rails and industrials, and the combined trading in both classes of issues and the number of the latter appearing in the daily and weekly transactions:

The playgrounds of the city cannot, as Commissioner MOSES states, under any conceivable theory be made self-supporting or even revenue producing. When relief funds give out they must be provided for in the annual budget. But this statement does not apply to certain new "recreational facilities" other than playgrounds, the cost of whose annual operation will amount to upward of $1,700,000 (in addition to the cost of water, electricity, power, ).

GENEVA, March 1. -- A belief that the Committee of Eighteen will do something to tighten sanctions against Italy grew here on the eve of its meeting tomorrow to consider the experts' report on the proposed oil sanction and the general sanctions situation.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 1. -Starting tomorrow and until May 15 applications for tickets to the third annual Princeton invitation track meet in Palmer Stadium on Saturday, June 13, will be received and filled. Regulations governing the applications were announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics.

MOSCOW, March 1. -- The Soviet Union abolished today the old mythical gold ruble and stabilized the paper ruble for external trade as well as for internal trade at five to the dollar. The rate went into effect internally on Feb. 1. The new valuation will apply on foreign transactions beginning April 1.
ATLANTA, March 1 (AP). -- The financial "dictatorship" of Governor Eugene Talmadge was attacked in court proceedings accepted late today by Superior Judge B.P. Gaillard at Gainesville.

RYE, N.Y., March 1. -- On the toss of a coin, 25-year-old Joe Dille, Bronx hospital employe, won the senior men's indoor tri-State speed skating championship tonight on Playland rink after he and Joe Bree of Tuckahoe, N.Y., had finished even at the conclusion of six hours of grueling racing.

The sale by Mrs. Robert E. Burke to the Port of New York Authority of her home in Weehawken was the outstanding realty transaction in New Jersey over the week-end. The dwelling is located on the easterly side of Kingswood Road at the top of the Palisades.

LONDON, Feb. 28. -- In the weekly fluctuations now occurring in the Bank of England's circulation are reflected only the normal currency requirements of other banks. This week's increase of almost 3,000,000 is attributed to the customary end-of-the-month expansion, stimulated a little, perhaps, by tax payments, although over a wider period circulation may be expected to show further expansion if current cheerful views of trade prospects are confirmed.

Mr. Gillette has repented of his retirement and very sensibly, too, and has come back in a pleasantly acted revival of "Three Wise Fools," which lighted the Golden Theatre last evening. Many of his old friends were sitting, wreathed in smiles, all through the theatre.
ROME, March 1. -- Complete elimination of the armies of Ras Kassa and Ras Seyoum in Northern Ethiopia is reported in dispatches from the front today.

Congress already knows the substance of the tax message which the President is expected to send early this week and is already well embarked on a warm controversy over it. Democratic opinion seems to be divided between a desire to support the Administration and terror of new taxation in an election year.

Setting the pace throughout the race, Miss Dolores Smith, 17-year-old Brooklyn girl, recorded a surprise victory in the senior Metropolitan A.A.U. 100-yard free style championship event to feature the meet conducted yesterday in the 75-foot pool at the clubhouse of the Women's Swimming Association of New York.

BELLEAIR, Fla., March 1. -Harry Cooper of Chicago won the Florida west coast open golf tournament today, taking revenge on Leonard Dodson of Pembine, Wis., who defeated him last week in the play-off of the St. Petersburg open. Dodson finished second, one stroke back.
Sixteen persons were arrested on the West Side yesterday in disorders resulting from the building service strike.

Two luminaries of the American stage -- William Gillette and George M. Cohan -- held a colloquy on the stage of the Golden Theatre immediately following last evening's performance of "Three Wise Fools." The first night audience remained in their seats to witness Mr. Cohan, as well as other first line players, pay tribute to an actor 80 years young, who was making another "farewell" appearance.

Stolen or bootleg coal moved in interstate and intrastate channels in 1935 reached a total of 3,607,600 tons, according to a study just completed and made public yesterday by the Anthracite Institute. The traffic in stolen anthracite last year increased 18 per cent over that of 1934, when the illicit tonnage was estimated at 3,056,000.

The Railway Express Agency reported for 1935 its largest gross revenues and net income since 1931. Net income is described as "payments to carriers" in the report, because it is distributed in dividends to the railroads of the country.

Transactions involving contracts of sale on apartment houses in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn were announced over the week-end. Banks figured prominently as sellers in some of the deals. Several of the houses will be remodeled. The week-end activity also included deals for buildings used for trucking and garage purposes.
Play-off hopes loomed more brightly for the New York Americans as they handed the Boston Bruins a 5-2 defeat at Madison Square Garden last night before a crowd of 10,000.

PARIS, March 1. -- Confronting the Italian dictatorship at a time of victory in Ethiopia and the German dictatorship offering peace in a newspaper interview and getting ready for a new violation of the peace treaty in the Rhineland, the French and British Foreign Ministers,

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month was slightly less active than in January, but it was the largest for a February since 1931. Sales in February as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES totaled 60,871,262 shares, compared with 67,211,035 in January and 14,404,225 in February, 1935.

Dividends declared for shareholders last month were the largest for a February since 1932. The increases included most groups of industries, and particularly the copper, mall-order, motor, oil and steel classifications. Resumptions of payments, extra dividends, increased rates and payments against arrearages carried the total well above that of a year ago.

With many leading teams in the metropolitan district idle during the past week, chief interest in basketball circles was centered around Columbia's progress in the Eastern Intercollegiate League and Long Island University's undefeated quintet.

Philip Frank, violinist, gave a recital last night in the Town Hall. Since his appearance there last season Mr. Frank had the honor to be chosen as one of the soloists to represent American music at the jubilee celebration of the late King George V in London, and afterward made a European tour.

H.E.B. suggests licenses for cats. What is to prevent any one who has a cat without a license stealing the license from another cat? I know the collar of our cat was taken off -- probably by some boy -- and returned to us by a woman living several miles away.

BERLIN, March 1 (AP). -- Appointment of Wilhelm Furtwaengler as conductor for the New York Philharmonic Symphony Society, in addition to the Prussian State Opera, was viewed in German musical circles today as a victory for the principle of unfettered art.

New announcements last week of bonds called for redemption before maturity were the most numerous in several weeks. Public utility and industrial calls predominated, with the largest for months following March. Additions to the list for February were few and raised the months' total to $129,082,000, compared with $128,380,000 in the preceding month and $165,658,000 for February, 1935.

Since these nights belong to the theatre's great names, mark this one down for George M. Cohan. He arrives this evening -- 8:30 o'clock -- at the Alvin in "Dear Old Darling," a matter of his own devising. Something like his fiftieth signed play, they say.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 1. -- A costume ball was held at the Carolina last evening, attracting practically the whole of the cottage colony and many of the guests of the resort's hotels. Most of those at the party passed in review during the grand march before the judges, Henry Beale Spelman, Mrs. William W. Windle and Mr. and Mrs. James H. Walker.

Passage of the Robinson-Patman bill now pending in Congress was urged in one of eleven resolutions adopted by 400 delegates to the fifteenth annual convention of the United Independent Retail Grocers and Food Dealers Association, which was held yesterday in the Hotel Commodore.
Two religious plays, "Veronica's Veil," and the Passion Play under auspices of the Holy Family Church, opened their annual official seasons in Union City, N.J., yestedray.

At Lincoln on Saturday evening the chairman presented Governor LANDON not only to his immediate Nebraska audience but, as he said, "to the people of the United States." It was a phrase happily chosen. The Governor proceeded at once to make a speech addressed to the whole country.
CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., March 1 (AP). -- Six children were burned to death today and their mother was fatally burned when fire destroyed a farmhouse on the Middlesex Road eight miles south of here.

NEW ORLEANS, March 1. -- Trading in the cotton market here last week felt the distracting influence of the carnival festivities, closing with the Mardi Gras holiday on Tuesday. Most of the business consisted of the evening-up of commitments.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1936, as well as last price, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:
The Christian church is facing the gravest situation in its history, Bishop William T. Manning declared in a Lenten sermon yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
Roving around the sportsmen's show at Grand Central Palace, you come across some unexpected novelties.

Foreign exchanges were only mildly upset by the outbreak of the military in Japan last week. A semblance of nervousness naturally accompanied news of the disturbance but this was attributable more to the unexpectedness of the crisis than to any belief that the exploitation would run beyond the city of Tokyo.

In THE TIMES of Feb. 24 Ralph C. Tobin, president of the Retail Wine and Liquor Guild, while admitting that certain changes should be made in the State liquor laws, states that this should be done only after consultation between the Liquor Authority and the trade.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., March 1. -Chief of Police Ross Federico of Quogue, near here, received a telephone call at headquarters early this morning from Frank G. Raynor, 46 years old, of East Quogue.

Outside of sugar, cocoa and secondary metal futures, which advanced, declines were the rule in the local commodity futures markets last week, although silk futures recovered about one-half of their early losses. In the cash markets, wheat, corn, flour, raw sugar,

CHICAGO, March 1. -- Expectations that Argentina would have a large crop of corn this year led to selling here last week, largely by pit traders. Price movements held to a narrow range. Reports later in the week from Iowa that roads in the best sections were impassable and that there was no movement from the country led to buying for investment and to cover short sales.

MADRID, March 1. -- Huge demonstrations in favor of proletarian rule and Catalan separatism took place today in Barcelona. Simultaneously more than 100,000 impatient Socialists and Communists paraded through the center of Madrid.

With glasses tinkling cheerfully and a suite full of guests who paid little or no attention to the ceremony as such, the New York Film Critics -- capitalized in type, if not in the financial records -- presented yesterday afternoon their awards for the best picture, the best performances and the best direction of the screen year of 1935.

CHICAGO, March 1. -- Prices of hogs moved widely last week, and the market on Friday closed irregular, with an unsettled feeling on the movement from the country and the demand for fresh pork loins. Loins here closed at 16 to 19 cents a pound, compared with 17 1/2 to 21 cents a week before and 15 1/2 to 18 cents a month ago.

FISHKILL, N.Y., March 1. -- Thrilling performances by the diminutive Olav Aasen of the Norsemen Ski Club gave him all the major honors today in the Middle Atlantic States ski jumping tournament on the Norway Ski Club's hill.
OLD WASHINGTON-ON-THE-BRAZOS, Texas, March 1 (AP). -- This village of 250 will open a $15,000,000 birthday party tomorrow for the largest State in the Union.
WASHINGTON, March 1. -- The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress last week are given in the following tabulation:

The Norbeck bill, one of the many bills pending in Congress which propose to limit the powers of the United States Supreme Court, is disapproved by the New York County Lawyers' Committee, in a report of its committee on Federal legislation made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation called today for bids on $14,700,000 of equipment-trust certificates of the Illinois Central Railroad Company maturing from 1936 to 1944 and fifty-seven issues of securities of municipalities, counties and school districts of twenty-eight States and the Territories of Alaska and Hawaii.

DETROIT, March, 1 (AP). -- A near-riot of players climaxed a National Hockey League game tonight in which the Red Wings conquered the Montreal Candiens by 3 to 1. Two major penalties and the first match penalty of the season were given by officials in the last two minutes of play.
Following is the text of the agreement demanded by the Building Service Employes Union from building owners in the strike which went into effect yesterday:

HOLMENKOLLEN, Norway, March 1. -- Olaf Hoffsbakken of Norway won first prize and the King's Cup in the combined cross-country run and ski-jump event of a two-day international ski meet today as American stars were left far behind.

BERLIN, Feb. 28. -- The Boerse declined this week on news of the Japanese outbreak and ratification of the Russian treaty by the French Chamber of Deputies. In general, the international situation induced anxiety which obliterated the effect of the resumption of dividends by the steel trust and other satisfactory corporation reports.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- The Treasury announced today the details of its March financing program, a combined offering of $650,000,000 of 2 3/4 per cent 12-15 year bonds and $600,000,000 of 1 1/2 per cent five-year Treasury notes for cash, with the secretary reserving the right to increase the bond or note issues to the extent that $558,819,000 of 2 7/8 per cent notes, maturing on April 15, are turned in for exchange.

Dan O'Mahoney, young Irish grappler who made his way to the world's heavyweight championship in less than six months, will risk his crown tonight when he opposes Dick Shikat, a former titleholder, at Madison Square Garden. They will wrestle to a finish, with one fall deciding the match.

Prices of cotton futures continued their irregular movement last week with a downward trend, as they did last month. Fluctuations were moderate and the market was comparatively quiet. Closing prices on Saturday on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net declines of 1 to 16 points in the week.

For the first time this season in a weekly fixture the gunners of the New York Athletic Club were divided into classes at the Travers Island traps of the organization yesterday. There were two divisions, the prizes going to the handicap leaders.
Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, proposed last night that the "peaceful elements" on WPA projects should disown the "communistic leadership" of WPA groups and form groups of their own.

Wholesale markets here were more active last week as milder weather stimulated the buying of Spring merchandise, particularly in the women's wear division. Many out-of-town buyers, who had delayed their trips here until weather conditions improved, arrived in the market, placing a heavy volume of new orders and reordering on various items.

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, preaching yesterday morning in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, likened the fast tempo and feverish activity of modern living to Oriental water torture, which through the ceaseless monotony of falling drops drove the victim mad.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Mach 1. -- Joe McCarthy led a squad of his Yankee ball players here this afternoon, prepared to launch tomorrow the twelfth training season for Colonel Jacob Ruppert's athletes at Huggins Field.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- Scientists of the Carnegie Institution have succeeded in measuring one of the atomic forces that hold the universe together, they announced today. They have measured what is scientifically known as the "proton-proton interaction," or the forces between the nuclei of two hydrogen atoms when they are separated by less than two-ten-thousand billionths of an inch.
The following statement on the service strike was issued by the Realty Advisory Board last night:

Call and time money rates in February were stationary for the fourth consecutive month. Quotations for call loans were three-quarters of 1 per cent on the New York Stock Exchange and 1 1/4 per cent on the New York Curb Exchange, compared with 1 and 1 1/2 per cent, respectively, a year ago.
The Roosevelt administration was charged by Nicholas Murray Butler yesterday with indifference to its responsibilities with regard to peace.

Borough President James J. Lyons's Municipal Assembly bill to limit supervisory unemployment relief positions to residents of New York City is condemned as "unsound'' and "provincial" in a report of the Legislative Advisory Committee of the New York County Republican Committee, made public yesterday by County Chairman Kenneth S. Simpson.

CHARLESTON, S.C., March 1 (AP). -- The first comprehensive presentation of non-objective art in the United States and the first public exhibition of the Solomon R. Guggenheim collection began here tonight with a pre-view at the Gibbes Art Gallery.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- An authoritative source disclosed today that justices of the Supreme Court are willing to delay their Summer vacation, if necessary, to expedite final decisions in New Deal cases brought to them promptly.
WASHINGTON, March, 1. -- The texts of the Treasury's new offering of 2 3/4 per cent bonds and 1 1/2 per cent notes, made public today, were as follows:
WASHINGTON, March 1. -- Three international air records and three national marks made by American aviators in February have been certified by the National Aeronautic Association.

Securities offered to the public here in February differed markedly from the marketings in the preceding month. The total of the bond issues was smaller, while stock flotations were larger. Compared with a year ago, however, both classes of investment increased and provided the largest volume of emissions for any February since 1930.

J.P. Morgan Co. and the National City Bank, fiscal agents for the Government of the Argentine Nation, have announced that they will have available $306,700 for the purchase of the government's external 6 per cent bonds, issue of Oct. 1, 1925, and $175,291 for the purchase of the external 6 per cent bonds, public works issue of Oct. 1, 1926, at flat prices below par until April 1.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- The position of the twelve Federal Land Banks was strengthened further in the fourth quarter of 1935, the Farm Credit Administration announced today. It cited as an outstanding accomplishment the return of the banks to the investment markets, after five years, for new money for farm-mortgage loans.

Basing their estimates on bookings and applications for passenger space received to date, operators of steamship services to foreign lands predict that travel next Summer will produce a new high mark for the post-depression period.

LONDON, Feb. 28. -- Despite Wall Street's reactions which, like recent British experience in security movements, is the outcome of a somewhat excessive speculative exuberance, the opinion here is that all available facts point to an upward rather than a downward movement of both business and security prices.

With most of the action packed into the final five minutes, the Atlantic City Sea Gulls downed the New York Rovers at Madison Square Garden yesterday, 3 to 1. The defeat ended the Red Shirts' chances of finishing in a tie for second place in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League with the Pittsburgh Yellow Jackets.
It has frequently been stated that farm income was at lowest ebb in 1932 and did not begin to rise until the Roosevelt administration came into drastic being a year later.

Two thousand persons, attending the fifty-first annual meeting of the Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society yesterday at the Hotel Astor, urged Congress to "humanize" sections of the immigration law affecting resident aliens by enacting the Kerr-Coolidge bill.

A bit on the negative side, perhaps, the news from Fourteenth Street this morning is that Michael Blankfort's new play, "The Crime," is no "Waiting for Lefty." It is probably only fair to add at once that Mr. Blankfort didn't intend to write a "Waiting for Lefty."

BERLIN, Feb. 28. -- Industry has been quiet here. Minister of Economics Hjalmar Schacht's alleged plan to relax the prohibition against industrial expansion has yielded only the withdrawal of the ban on new foundations in the printing industries.

Leg muscles stiffened, tempers shortened and building officials had their hands full yesterday as a result of the first elevatorless and in many cases heatless Sunday in the history of a large section of the upper West Side.
A study entitled "Jean Jaures and French Socialist Patriotism," by Harold R. Weinstein, will be published shortly by the Columbia University Press.

The total volume of personal loans made in this community has reached substantial proportions and is still growing, according to the annual report of the Provident Loan Society of New York, made public for today by Jeremiah Milbank, president.

Service to 15,193 families and homeless persons was given by the Charity Organization Society of the City of New York, 105 East Twenty-second Street, between Oct. 1, 1934, and Sept. 30, 1935, according to the fifty-third annual report made public yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, March 1. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 54 per cent of capacity, up 1 point from the rate of the two preceding weeks. While the increased rate is expected to be held, no marked increase in any individual class of demand was observed.

BUENOS AIRES, March 1. -- The Radical party asserted tonight it had swept the country today in the first election in which it had participated since the 1930 revolution, which overthrew its leader, Hipolito Irigoyen. It is believed to have won control of the Buenos Aires City Council from the Socialist party.

ASMARA, Eritrea, March 1. -- Ras Kassa's army in the Tembien region of Ethiopia, northwest of Makale, has been destroyed. He himself is fleeing for his life with a few followers. Now between the Italian forces and Addis Ababa all Northern Ethiopia lies open and almost defenseless.

Navy's water polo team dethroned Columbia as champion of the Intercollegiate Swimming Association as a result of its victory over Penn on Saturday. The triumph was the third straight for the unbeaten Middies, and, as their postponed game with C.C.N.Y. has been cancelled, they cannot be overtaken. Rutgers is at present in second place, with Columbia, which won the title in 1934 and 1935, third.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- President Roosevelt today signed the new Farm Bill, enacted by Congress last week, under which the administration plans to maintain the benefits to farmers begun under the Agricultural Adjustment Act, which the Supreme Court declared unconstitutional.

ALBANY, March 1. -- A $15,000,000 reduction in Governor Lehman's $308,000,000 executive budget has been made by the Ways and Means Committee of the Republican-dominated Assembly, it was reported tonight at the Capitol on reliable authority.

In the world's attempts to "make man forget he has a soul" and transform him into "a sort of fat penguin waddling stupidly among the nuts and bolts of factory machinery," we are witnessing today "the greatest crucifixion since Calvary, the martyrdom of man" by the social order, Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen charged yesterday at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

TOKYO, Monday, March 2. -- The appointment of a strong Cabinet is viewed today as the most urgent problem facing Emperor Hirohito now that the military revolt has been suppressed. Martial law probably will be continued in Tokyo until the problem has been solved.

Postponement of all capital expenditures, of any increase in State aid to schools and of the proposed eight-hour day to State employes is urged upon Governor Lehman as part of the State's budgetary policy by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

The relativity theory advanced by Professor Einstein is held in such uncomprehending awe by the vast majority of people that it is not generally known there exists a far from unanimous acceptance of it in the scientific world.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- A resolution calling for the immediate recall of the United States delegation to the London Naval Conference will be introduced in the House tomorrow by Representative George H. Tinkham of Massachusetts, he announced today.
WASHINGTON, March 1. -- The text of the statement by President Roosevelt on the signing today of the Soil Conservation and Domestic Allotment Act follows:

Man must continue to have new and "better" illusions as incentives to progress, illusions which are formulated from "intelligent observation, careful interpretation, and a scheme of living based upon unities rather than differences," declared Dr. Ira S. Wile, psychiatrist, in an address delivered yesterday morning at the Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street.

LONDON, March 1 (AP). -- Countess Barbara Hutton Haugwitz-Reventlow, five-and-ten-cent store heiress, who is seriously ill following the birth of a son, was reported today to be definitely on the road to improvement. A member of the household said the doctors were not expected to return tonight and that no further bulletin would be issued before tomorrow.

Religious worship decked out in the panoply and accompanied by the fanfare of the circus or the stage accounts for the loss of "God consciousness in our American life," the Rev. Dr. William H. Rogers, pastor of the First Baptist Church, Broadway and Seventy-ninth Street, said yesterday in his sermon.
The text of King Edward's first broadcast to the Empire since he ascended the throne, received in the United States through the N.B.C. and Columbia chains, follows:

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $5,315,013,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 1. -- Richard Hoe Lawrence, former banker, art collector and a grandson of Richard Hoe, inventor of the Hoe rotary press, was found dead from drowning at about 7 o'clock this evening on the beach about seven miles from a cottage in which he had been staying this Winter.
LAKELAND, Fla., March 1. -- Fifteen-year-old Jimmy Risk of Cocoa, Fla., led a fleet of sailing craft in Lakeland's Winter regatta today to set a new world record with his Moth type Little Doris.

PENSACOLA, March 1. -- This gay Foridian sector, which has been having a lot of baseball in its midst for the past month, first with the Bill Terry school and for the past week with the Giant pitchers and catchers, began taking definite shape today as a major training base with the arrival of the infielders and outfielders who will struggle this year to bring another National League pennant to the Polo Grounds.

PARIS, Feb. 28. -- Although the return flow of gold to the Bank of France has somewhat increased the resources of the money market, rates have not varied. Call money is at 3 1/4 per cent and longer accommodation is not obtainable at less than 3 1/2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- Senator Borah announced today that he would carry his fight for the Republican Presidential nomination into New York State, following a conference with W. Kingsland Macy, former chairman of the Republican State Committee, and William Ziegler Jr., chairman of the Progressive Republican State Committee.

FACE bathed in perspiration, glittering helmet not quite straight on his head, General Count Hellmuth von Moltke, Prussian Chief of Staff, rushed into the German Foreign Office about 5:30 on the afternoon of Aug. 1, 1914, with a paper in his hand. That paper was the order for a general mobilization. A half hour earlier Count Pourtales, German Ambassador, had delivered a declaration of war to the officials in St. Petersburg.

MOSCOW, March 1. -- The word "competition" was outlawed by the Communist party today in so far as it concerns Soviet industry and other group enterprises. In its place the word meaning "friendly contest" must be used henceforth.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- Reports published simultaneously today by Secretary Ickes, Public Works Administrator, and Harry L. Hopkins, head of the Works Progress Administration, pictured the manner in which each felt the programs carried out by the agencies they direct are serving to bring the country out of the economic depression.

MADISON, Wis., March 1 (AP). -- The Western Conference faculty committee ultimatum threatening the University of Wisconsin with suspension unless control of athletics is restored to the faculty inspired a variety of comment from members of the Board of Regents today.

Two cents a mile on the railroads has a meaning outside railroad economics and finance. It is a return to the basic ideas and ideals of an earlier generation; one might almost say a return to normalcy. In a well-regulated world a train ride cost 2 cents a mile, a bushel of wheat sold for a dollar, a car or subway ride, a cigar and a glass of beer cost 5 cents each.

LONDON, Feb. 29, -- The Economist's fortnightly index of British commodity prices, based on the average for 1927 as 100, stood at 70.9 on Feb. 26, against 71.2 a fortnight before, 71.3 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

Harvard's fast hockey team was ready today for its final Quadrangular League game against Yale at New Haven next Saturday night. Victor over Princeton by a crushing score of 8 to 0 before 4,000 persons in the Boston Arena Saturday night, the Crimson can clinch at least a tie for the championship by defeating the Blue in its final game.

The penultimate week of the Metropolitan Opera season will begin next Monday evening with a performance of Verdi's "Rigoletto," in which John Charles Thomas will give his first impersonation of the title role here. The cast will include Josephine Antoine, Bruna Castagna, Frederick Jagel, Virgilio Lazzari, Angelo Bada and Alfredo Gandolfi, with Ettore Panizza conducting.

The Schenley Distillers Corporation and subsidiary companies have issued their annual report for 1935, showing a consolidated net profit of $8,035,268 after all charges, equivalent to $7.65 a share on the 1,050,000 common shares. In 1934 the profit was $6,970,961, or $6.63 a share on the same amount of stock.
ALBANY, March 1. -- Following is a tabulation showing how New York City members in the Legislature voted on important roll-calls last week:

BOGOTA, Colombia, March 1. -Criticism of two War Ministers who served under former President Enrique Olaya Herrera is contained in a report to the House of Deputies by a commission that investigated Colombian contracts with foreign armaments manufacturers, especially those with the Skoda interests of Czechoslovakia during the tension with Peru over Leticia.

KANSAS CITY, March 1 (AP). -The Kansas City Star said today that control of the Kansas City Southern Railroad by L.F. Loree, veteran chairman, might be challenged at the annual meeting here on May 12 and that the move might result in abolishing the present New York headquarters in favor of a policy of centering all operations here.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- Unemployment increased more in January, 1936, than it has in any January in five years, according to the estimates of the American Federation of Labor, made public today. The estimate found that the ranks of the jobless were swelled by 1,229,000 men in January, to reach a total of 12,626,000.

RED BANK, N.J., March 1. -- Harry McMahon's gaff-rigged Class A ice boat Breeze won a ten-mile race on the Navesink River this morning that was more of an obstacle event than a contest of speed. Breeze finished 48 seconds ahead of George E. Ruppert and George J. Gillig's jib-headed Pirate II, champion for years until Rube White drove his Elizabeth R. into top place last month.

NEW HAVEN, March 1. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 83.3, which compares with 83.8 the week before, 83.4 two weeks before, 83.5 three weeks before, and 84 four weeks before.

BERLIN, Feb. 28. -- In the view of banks here, the alarm in the United States over the enormous increase in stock-market activity may be justified by the desire to prevent speculation, but the activity itself is an infallible precursor of improvement in trade.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- A hard drive in Congress to cut huge hunks out of Federal expenditures, particularly those supporting emergency functions, was considered certain tonight to follow as a reaction to the demand for $786,000,000 in new and "substitute" taxes which President Roosevelt has announced he will send to the Capitol early this week, perhaps on Tuesday.

HUDSON, N.Y., March 1. -- A new method of training to meet the "deadlocks" and obstacles of life is described in the first issue of The Sociometric Review, which tells of a new social science used at the New York State Training School for Girls.

If the United States were playing an active and responsible part in efforts to put an end to war, it would not be helping Italy fight a war by selling her oil, copper, trucks, tractors, scrap iron, scrap steel and other essential war materials and supplies, without which the conquest of Ethiopia would be impossible.

Viscount Forbes, motor boat racer and the son of Countess Granard, sister of Ogden L. Mills; Count Roland von Faber-Castell and Baron Louis Empain are among the prominent persons arriving this afternoon from Europe on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 1. -- Joe Stripp, who received $9,000 for playing in 109 games last year, was offered a contract for $7,000 this year and is holding out, not only for a restoration but an increase over the previous season's figure, can buy his release from the Brooklyn club for $10,000 if he wants it.

The gospel of Christianity has wrought tremendous changes in the world and continues to affect the thought of the world, but its chief foe at the moment is its own defeatist attitude, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin said in his sermon yesterday at the James Memorial Chapel of Union Theological Seminary, Broadway, between 120th and 122d Streets.

TRENTON, March 1. -- A burglary of the rooms of Dwight Morrow Jr., brother of Mrs. Anne Morrow Lindbergh, at Cambridge, Mass., has been reported to Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf, head of the New Jersey State police, it was learned today.

TRENTON, N.J., March 1. -With an estimated $32,500,000 needed to finance emergency relief until Dec. 31, the State Relief Council tonight had only sufficient funds in sight to last until the middle of this month.

The bill introduced in the State Legislature by Senator Williamson providing for the assessment of real estate according to the income derived from it, instead of the present method of assessment at the full value, should be entitled: "An act to discourage building construction, and to encourage speculations in land values to hold valuable city lands out of use."

BOSTON, March 1 (AP). -- Postmaster General Farley, as chairman of the Democratic National Committee, will fire the opening gun in New England tomorrow in his nation-wide fight to send only Roosevelt-pledged candidates to the national convention.

ST. THOMAS, V.I., March 1. -- The island's small police force turned out en masse last night following the receipt of a radiogram from Captain Fothergill of the British ship Seven Seas Sound, who left St. Thomas three hours before, bound for Port Limon, Costa Rica, that he was turning back because of a threatened mutiny.
ROME, March 1. -- Returning to Rome after a long trip in Mediterranean lands, I find the Italian leaders are much more decided and in a better state of morale than they were a few weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- The Federal Power Commission announced today that it had, on or before Feb. 26, granted authorizations, subject to further investigation, to 638 applicants under Section 305(b) of the Federal Power Act to hold interlocking directorate or other official positions in electric public utilities and other companies.

Just as Thomas Paine's "Confederation of Nations" was the inspiration for Woodrow Wilson's League of Nations, so many of the old-age pension proposals of today are undoubtedly taken from Paine's essay on "Agrarian Justice."

The first of the monthly index numbers compiled by Dun's Review and given out yesterday showed a very slight fractional increase in the average during February, which was the third successive month to score a fractional advance. Compared with a year ago, the March 1 index number showed an advance of 1 5/8 per cent.

The Roosevelt administration "is well on its way toward wrecking the country," Jouett Shouse, president of the American Liberty League, charged last night. He spoke at the annual Founders Day dinner of Phi Delta Theta, college fraternity of which he is a member. The dinner was held at the Ambassador Hotel.

TOKYO, Tuesday, March 3. -- Though the Japanese public has never been less able than now to guess who will head the next administration, the crisis today seemed to be moving along normal lines toward a constitutional solution.

Mr. Cohan is up to his old tricks again in "Dear Old Darling," which he and some of his friends acted at the Alvin last evening. They happen to be clever and affable tricks to which most of us have been accustomed for some time; and despite Mr. Cohan's weakness for overemphasis, they result in an oddly amusing, freakish evening of show-shop suspense.

GENEVA, March 2. -- Premier Benito Mussolini faces now the strong probability of having to choose tomorrow or within about forty-eight hours between a combined oil and tanker embargo and peace terms acceptable to the League of Nations and to Ethiopia.

A renewal of the demand of seamen employed on intercoastal ships for a parity of wages on the Atlantic and Pacific Coasts yesterday resulted in the tie-up of the Panama Pacific liner California at her pier at San Pedro, Calif.

The American Tobacco Company reports in its annual statement for 1935 a consolidated net income of $23,652,642 after deducting expenses, interest, taxes, depreciation and other charges. After preferred dividend requirements, the income is equal to $4.44 each on 4,619,390 shares of combined common and common B stock outstanding.

PANAMA, March 2 (AP). -- Following the receipt of the news of the signing of Panama's treaty with the United States in Washington today, President Harmodio Arias issued a manifesto calling upon the citizens for "fair and impartial judgment."

CHICAGO, March 2. -- The shipping demand for hogs averaging 230 pounds and down was strongly in evidence here today, with prices steady to as much as 10 cents a hundredweight lower, compared with Friday's level. Heavier kinds sold slowly at 10 to as much as 25 cents lower and packing sows were off 15 to 25 cents.
The Board of Health of the Department of Health adopted the following resolution yesterday:

ALBANY, March 2. -- Republicans and Democrats came into a head-on collision tonight on investigation of unemployment relief with the conflict cast against the background of the 1936 Presidential and gubernatorial campaigns.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Prison-made goods produced in one State may not be sold in other States which have laws against this practice, the Supreme Court unanimously decided today in upholding the Hawes-Cooper act.

LONDON, March 2. -- The Stock Exchange here opened the new account today in a cheerful mood. British Government securities were quiet, with more new loans in prospect, but there was brisk buying of British railways.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Constitutionality of the 1933 Securities Act to regulate the sale of stocks was challenged in the Supreme Court today in a brief filed by James Edward Jones, New York dealer in oil securities.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 2. -- Complimenting Mr. and Mrs. Paul A. Schoellkopf of Lewiston Heights, N.Y., who arrived today, and in farewell to Mr. and Mrs. Peter A. Porter, who will return on Wednesday to Buffalo, Mr. and Mrs. William Russell Huntley gave a tea this afternoon at Jungle Nest.

All of the orchestra seats and boxes have been sold for the performance tonight at the Winter Garden of the Ziegfeld Follies, which will be the tenth annual theatre party given for the benefit of the Palestine Lighthouse Institute for the Blind in Jerusalem. A supper party will be given in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria after the performance by Mrs. Fanny Eitingon, chairman of the benefit committee.

Members of the University of Texas Ex-Students Association of New York gave their annual dinner dance last night in the Rainbow Grill, Rockefeller Center, to celebrate the opening of the Texas Centennial celebration. A program of entertainment featuring prominent Texas professionals now in this city was presented.

MANCHESTER, N.H., March 2 (AP). -- Postmaster General James A. Farley asserted tonight that the American people repealed the economy plank in the 1932 Democratic platform after President Roosevelt had carried out his word to enact it in law.

Arguments on the proposal to amend the State Constitution to limit real estate taxes were presented yesterday at a public meeting held under the auspices of the Merchants Association in the Woolworth Building.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., March 2. -- A bed used by George Washington during the Revolutionary War was destroyed here today with a number of other antiques in a fire in the home of Dr. George Schuyler Colfax. Dr. Colfax is a great-grandson of General William Schuyler Colfax, who served with Washington.

Italy needs peace and knows it. There is no doubt of that. The rather haughty terms in which Rome announces that the Italian Government is ready to consider peace proposals from any source cannot deceive anybody -- certainly not the Italian people. They have been hard hit by the war, in men, money and reputation.

No one could object to the chief ostensible purpose of the new Farm Law -- the control and prevention of soil erosion. Yet if this were the sole or central object of the new measure, that measure would hardly need to exist at all, for this object was already provided for in the old Soil Conservation Act of 1935.

BALTIMORE, March 2. -- Colonel Henry Breckinridge, Assistant Secretary of War in the Woodrow Wilson administration, will be a candidate in the Maryland Presidential primaries, officers of the Anti-New Deal Association for Defense of the Constitution declared officially here today.
TOKYO, March 2. -- The Cabinet announced today that Sub-Lieutenant Mata Yamamoto had been dismissed from the army in connection with last week's rebellion and assassinations.

Following last month's pattern of trading, steel stocks led yesterday's upturn on the Stock Exchange. A further increase in steel operations; and rumors of a firmer situation in steel prices supplied the background for the rise of these shares. United States Steel common, in the last few minutes of trading, reached the highest level for 1934, 1935 and 1936, at 65 3/4.

The Ardsley Country Club team, representing Westchester, captured the women's metropolitan squash racquets team championship yesterday, defeating the Cosmopolitan Club squad, New York representatives, 3 to 2, in a match on the losers' court.

LONDON, March 2. -- The British Government learned officially today to its unbounded relief that Germany was willing to limit the size and gun caliber of her new warships and to exchange building plans with the British Admiralty on the basis of whatever treaty might emerge from the London conference.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The Republic of Colombia has filed an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the permanent registration on the New York Stock Exchange of $21,205,000 of 6 per cent external sinking-fund gold bonds, due on Jan. 1, 1961, and $30,018,500 of 6 per cent external sinking-fund gold bonds, due on Oct. 1, 1961.

The situation of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation was never more promising, Eugene G. Grace, president, says, in a letter to the company's employes, published in the current edition of The Bethlehem Review.

" Saint Joan," scheduled for revival tonight by Katharine Cornell, will instead open next Monday evening at the Beck. Having already taken ill with the grip and laryngitis, which obliged her to cancel three performances in Pittsburgh last week, Miss Cornell is now reported to be suffering also from sinus.

In the Grand Central area, with many large office buildings and hotels, the strike of elevator operators and other building service employes was scarcely noticed yesterday. Except in a few buildings on side streets and one or two on Fifth and Lexington Avenues, the workers were not called out by the union.
Danno O'Mahoney relinquished the world's heavyweight wrestling championship last night, actually conceding the title to Richard Shikat, powerful German, in their meeting at Madison Square Garden.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 2. -- A two-week exhibition of modern art in the Yale Gallery of Fine Arts opened today, sponsored by the New Haven Committee of the Museum of Modern Art of New York. Mrs. Henry Hotchkiss Townshend is chairman of the local committee, and a committee consisting of Mrs. Ernest L. Mortimer, Professor Theodore Size, Mrs. W.H. Dunham Jr., Mrs. Frederick W. Hilles and Mrs. Sherman Kent arranged the event.
LONDON, March 2 (AP). -- Countess Barbara Hutton Haugwitz-Reventlow, gravely ill after the birth of her first child a week ago, was pronounced "out of danger" tonight by her physicians.

Spokesmen for bus systems have announced that their lines operating in competition with railroads will probably meet the reduction in railroad fares ordered by the Interstate Commerce Commission. By this they doubtless mean that they will continue to keep their rates substantially under those charged by the railroads.

LONDON, March 2. -- A Labor Opposition's motion of censure against the Baldwin Ministry on the ground that it had failed to restore the depressed industrial areas was, as had been expected, used today by the government to strengthen its own argument for rearmament.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 2. -- After his stormy oration of yesterday concerning the status of Joe Stripp, holdout third baseman, Manager Casey Stengel was a gay and smiling director of Dodger conditioning exercises today, putting his mixed squad of regulars, Allentown boys and rookies through morning and afternoon sessions.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The report for January sent to Congress today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation showed that for the first time in any month since it went to the aid of banks to help them weather the depression, no new loans were authorized for any of the active banks of the country.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Describing as "bunk" the idea that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation forced banks to sell their preferred stock and capital notes to it when the campaign was on to strengthen the capital structure of the banks of the country, Jesse H. Jones, chairman, said today that the RFC welcomed moves by the banks to retire the stock but was not exerting any pressure.

Irwin L. Moore, vice president of the International Hydro-Electric System, was elected yesterday president of the company to succeed Archibald R. Graustein, who resigned as president and director after having held those positions since the company was organized in 1929.
Leases by the city in Manhattan and Brooklyn for Emergency Relief Bureau quarters and rentals by retail store chains featured the business leasing reported yesterday.
Eight men said to have been associated with the Specialty Bakery Owners of America, Inc., were arrested in Brooklyn yesterday on charges of operating a bakery racket in that borough.

The most elaborate, complex and, in a sense at least, the most be- wildering exhibition arranged thus far in its career by the Museum of Modern Art was opened privately with a reception last evening. Beginning today this exhibition, which addresses itself to Cubism and many other forms of abstract art, may be visited by the public through Sunday, April 19.

Mayor La Guardia, Police Commissioner Valentine and Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, were attacked yesterday by five witnesses appearing before a "citizens' jury" inquiring into the circumstances in which the meeting of unemployed and WPA workers in Madison Square on Feb. 15 ended in disorder with several of its leaders and others being taken into "protective custody" by the police.

ROME, March 2 (AP). -- An official Italian source declared tonight that complete victory on the East African battlefronts "is in our hands, and we will not be satisfied until all Italian aims are achieved."

Most futures were lower on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. Trading was dull. On the cash markets, wheat, rye and rubber advanced, while cotton, wooltops, lard, tin, corn, oats, butter and cocoa declined.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP). -- Friends of both men disclosed today that President Roosevelt had reappointed Anning S. Prall as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission for a term extending to March 11, 1937.

In an effort to prevent Columbia College dormitories being turned into "miniature zoos," Herbert B. Howe, director of men's residence halls, has ordered dormitory students to get rid of their animal pets. This ruling, based on an old statute of the university, affects the home life of three young alligators, seven white mice, three small turtles and several cats and dogs.

SYRACUSE, March 2 (AP). -- The test of the State Unemployment Insurance Law will be carried to the Court of Appeals in a fight on the Supreme Court decision of Saturday upholding constitutionality save in one provision, the attorney for two plaintiff firms announced today.

At the first meeting this morning of the Cathedral Sewing Class at the home of Mrs. Stephen C. Clark, 46 East Seventieth Street, the members will be entertained while they work by Miss Marjorie Burden in recitations and piano numbers by Miss Madden. The second session of the class, of which Mrs. Frank Hunter Potter is president, will be at the home of Mrs. Charles D. Dickey, 37 East Fifty-first Street, on March 10.
CHICAGO, March 2. -- Chicago had its first business and school day under Eastern standard time today in the midst of a lively controversy as to the wisdom of quitting the Central time zone.

Scoring its eighth straight victory, the St. Francis College five avenged a previous setback when it defeated the St. John's University quintet, 30 to 22, before a capacity crowd in the Degray Gymnasium, Brooklyn, last night. It was the final game of the season for the Franciscans and gave them a record of seven defeats and fifteen victories, thirteen of which they scored in the last sixteen games.

Karl Schroeder of Sweden, the young stalwart who appears to have succeeded to the mantle of Jean Borotra as the ruler of Europe's indoor courts, advanced another step in his quest of the national indoor tennis championship yesterday as the favored array swept the boards at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

Little-used stairs in Wall Street towers continued to get little use yesterday as the building service strike began. The financial district developed an acute attack of "jitters" in anticipation of the strike call, but nerves suffered more than leg muscles when the call actually came at 1:15 P.M.

LONDON, March 2. -- Three members of the invading American Wolfe-Noel Cup team, Miss Anne Page and Miss Cecilia Bowes of Philadelphia and Mrs. Ary J. Lamme of Rye, N.Y., survived the first round of the women's British squash racquets championship which opened at the Queens Club this morning.

The twelfth week of the Metropolitan Opera season began last night with "Aida." The news interest of the evening was the debut of Bruna Castagna, Italian contralto, who developed a following in her appearances in the Hippodrome's late popular-priced operas. She proved to be a satisfactory Amneris.
Building plans filed yesterday included a $280,000 apartment house for the Bronx, a $49,500 group of dwellings for Brooklyn and three groups of homes for Queens. The details were as follows:

REVELSTOKE, B.C., March 2 (AP). -- A disconnected tender broke loose and ran wild down a grade near here early today, smashed into a stalled work train with terrific momentum and killed fifteen railway employes.
The April selection of the Book of the Month Club is Peter Freuchen's long-postponed autobiography, "Arctic Adventure," which will be published by Farrar Rinehart on March 30.

So genuine has been the reception given by New Yorkers to the National Sportsmen's Show at the Grand Central Palace that its sponsors, the Campbell-Fairbanks Expositions, Inc., announced last night that they have definitely decided to stage another exhibition in 1937.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 2. -- The largest squad of Yankee ball players to start training in the regime of Joe McCarthy as manager got a flying start on the 1936 Spring campaign today at Huggins Field before one of the largest crowds ever to witness an opening day's exercises.

The struggle for control of the Standard Investing Corporation between the present management and a group led by Wallace Groves, president of the Phoenix Securities Corporation, was brought to a vote yesterday at the annual meeting of shareholders of Standard Investing, an investment trust.
The committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange authorized yesterday the listing of the following securities:

CLEVELAND, March 2 (AP). -- A net profit of $4,455,735 for 1935 was reported today by the Republic Steel Corporation in contrast with a net loss of $3,459,428 in the preceding year. This profit was after deduction for all charges, including depreciation and depletion.
Mayor La Guardia mobilized all city departments yesterday behind his effort to protect life and health in the building strike.

The New York Curb Exchange has admitted to unlisted trading Sherwin-Williams Company 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock, Series AAA, par value $100. The shares are issuable in exchange for the 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock, Series AA, on a share-for-share basis.

Women interested in the Robins' Nest, a home for convalescent crippled children in Tarrytown, have arranged "An Evening of Music and Exploration" to be given Monday at the New York Junior League Clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street, for the benefit of the home.

Marked by the first mild Saturday which has been experienced locally for months, retail trade at the week-end was excellent, retail executives here reported yesterday. Several leading establishments, using the figures for the first Saturday in March last year for comparison, had sales increases of 25 per cent or more.
Brooklyn College beat the Seth Low quintet, 35 -- 20, as the teams closed their intercollegiate campaigns at the Union Temple court last night.

The strike of elevator operators and other service employes in apartment, office and loft buildings was extended yesterday from the West Side to other parts of Manhattan, causing an increase of hardship and inconvenience to thousands of tenants and creating a situation that compelled Mayor La Guardia to proclaim an emergency.

OTTAWA, Ont., March 2. -- The expulsion of Italy's chief representative in Canada, Consul General Luigi Petrucci, was demanded in Parliament today on the ground that he had made undiplomatic speeches and had attempted to coerce Italo-Canadians to serve Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy.

IT begins to look as though M'sieu Lestairre Patrick and his Rangers will have to un-strap their skates and take to boats shortly, the ice is getting that thin under them. Furthermore, a couple of heavy falls wouldn't do the Americans much good, either. And this in a Winter when the ice was so thick at Niagara that tourists were walking across the top of the Falls!

TRENTON, March 2. -- Attorney General David T. Wilentz washed his hands today of any connection with a further reprieve for Bruno Richard Hauptmann by indicating that he would not oppose such action by Governor Harold G. Hoffman and would not consent to it.

MIAMI, Fla., March 2. -- "Old Southern Plantation Night" will be observed at the Miami Biltmore Hotel on Wednesday. Among those with reservations are Mr. and Mrs. Charles K. Spofford, Mr. and Mrs. Henry March, Mr. and Mrs. Jacques C. Nordeman and Miss Elsie Hunter of New York; Mr. and Mrs. W. E. Robinson of Forest Hills, Mrs. J.A. Gove of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Miss Estelle Stewart of Atlantic City, N.J.
WASHINGTON, March 2. -- President Roosevelt devoted most of his day to consideration of the tax message he is expected to send to Congress tomorrow.

Followers of the share market continue to be too greatly concerned with the question of what Congress will do to raise the new revenues that the President will outline in his forthcoming tax message to take very decided action market-wise.

Columbia's basketball team clinched the championship of the Eastern Intercollegiate League last night, but for most of the second half it seemed as if the winning of the title would have to be deferred.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 2. -- Escorted by the Argentine cruiser Almirante Brown, Rear Admiral Eleazar Videla, Argentine Navy Minister, arrived here at 10 o'clock this morning aboard the Argentine cruiser Veinticinco de Mayo. The Brazilian cruisers Bahia and Rio Grande do Sul and a naval air squadron picked up the Argentine warships at Ilha Grande and escorted them into port.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- A plea that the Senate demand the restoration of Major Gen. Johnson Hagood to his active command was made by Senator Smith today. He interrupted the debate on the Interior Department Appropriation Bill to take the floor in defense of his fellow South Carolinian.

MOSCOW, March 2. -- Soviet statistics published today reveal wage increases and more abundant food purchases for Russia's 24,700,000 industrial and office workers. They show the average wage last year was 2,271 rubles. This is 22.6 per cent higher than the 1934 average of 1,853 rubles.
Congress and the Supreme Court have displaced President Roosevelt as the center of national interest, according to the American Year Book of 1935, which came off the press yesterday.
The Manufacturers Trust Company is trustee for $1,750,000 4 1/2 per cent convertible debentures, Series A, of Adolf Gobel, Inc.

The State of Minnesota yesterday awarded a new issue of $4,468,000 of public-relief certificates of indebtedness to a banking group composed of the Northwestern National Bank, Minneapolis; the First National Bank, St. Paul, and the First National Bank, Minneapolis, at a price of par for 2 1/4s.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Investigation of the lobbying activities of public utility holding companies and their subsidiaries by a Senate committee, which was resumed today, was under way little more than an hour before the authority of the committee to subpoena the telegrams of corporations, firms or individuals was challenged in the District Supreme Court by the Chicago law firm of Winston, Strawn Shaw.

After arresting the two promoters of the Knights of Columbus Sweepstakes contest last night, police raided the offices of the American Contest Company, 15 East Fortieth Street, and arrested ten others after making an examination of the company books.

In the midtown area west of Fifth Avenue, between Forty-second and Twenty-third Streets, the building strike, called by the union for noon, went into effect in about fifty buildings without incident. This district includes the lofts of the fur and garment industries, several large hotels, and is dotted with tall office buildings, including the Empire State Building.

Rowland B. Haines and Philip T. Moore, both representing the Columbia University Club and seeded second and third respectively, were among those who advanced to the second round yesterday in the national amateur squash tennis championship at the Yale Club.

At least 5,000 strike-breakers had been recruited last night to replace striking building service employes. The majority, a survey indicated, were being supplied through hastily formed employment agencies and through the long-established Bergoff Industrial Service, Inc., of 551 Fifth Avenue.

Several large properties were bought in by plaintiffs at Manhattan foreclosure auctions yesterday. The parcels included two eleven-story apartment houses on the easterly Madison Avenue block-front between Eighty-second and Eighty-third Streets, a twelve-story apartment structure at the southeast corner of West End Avenue and Seventy-eighth Street and a fourteen-story loft building at 246 West Thirty-eighth Street. Details of the sales were as follows:

In a city like New York it is impossible to submit to the interruption of one of the essential services on which the life of the community depends. This means the delivery of milk and food, the provision of heat and electric power, the maintenance of lines of communication, whether vertical or horizontal.

An advance in prices of all-wool styles by one mill and the naming of quotations on the 1936 lines by two other important manufacturers were features of the blanket market yesterday. The American Woolen Company increased quotations, while the Pepperell Manufacturing Company and the Carolina Cotton and Woolen Mills released new prices on their ranges.

Delegations representing the National Retail Dry Goods Association and the Retail Dry Goods Association of New York will oppose the Vandenberg amendment to the Duffy Copyright Bill at the hearing in Washington next Tuesday, it was announced here yesterday.

I read with interest in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Feb. 23 an article entitled "Roster of Federal Dams." It has occurred to me in view of the publicity, these dams are receiving -- most of which is unfavorable and prejudicial -- that the public would have a better understanding of the purposes for which they are being built if each project were discussed on its individual merits.
Putting the spotlight on two versatile woodsmen who are entertaining the crowds at the National Sportmen's Show:

Public offering will be made today by Kuhn, Loeb Co.; the Lee Higginson Corporation and Brown Harriman Co., Inc., and associates of a new issue of $44,000,000 of Chicago Union Station Company first-mortgage 3 3/4 per cent bonds, Series E, due on July 1, 1963. The bonds will be priced at 104 1/4 and accrued interest, to yield more than 3.50 per cent.

Prince and Johnny sat in the Central Avenue police station in Jersey City last night and the problem of getting Johnny's coat off remained unsolved. Prince, whose ancestry is apparently collie and police dog, objected.

A plea that retailers and the Fashion Originators Guild agree on the essentials of the guild's program and permit "liberty of action in non-essentials by either side" was made in a letter sent yesterday by John Burke, president of B. Altman Co., to Maurice Rentner, chairman of the guild, and made public last night.
