AKRON, March 2 (AP). -- Mrs. Lucy Booth, a minor stockholder in the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, filed suit today in Common Pleas Court to compel Paul W. Litchfield, Goodyear president, to negotiate with striking rubber workers.

Great investor enthusiasm greeted the Treasury's announcement of the details of its March financing yesterday, according to specialists in government securities, and a heavy oversubscription of the largest offering for cash by the government since 1919 was apparent at an early hour.

The aims of the Baldwin Home Rule Bill, recently introduced in the Legislature and designed to repeal most of the State's mandatory legislation affecting budget expenditures of all communities, were outlined yesterday by State Senator Joseph Clark Baldwin 3d, author of the bill, at a luncheon of the Citizens Budget Commission in the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP). -- Over the opposition of some Senators who accused him of "Prussianized" conduct toward soldiers in the World War, Colonel Duncan Kennedy Major Jr. of New York City was confirmed by the Senate today as a brigadier general.

PHILADELPHIA, March 2. -- A commission of nine appointed by the last Presbyterian General Assembly to investigate conditions in the presbytery of Philadelphia announced today that it had found "no evidence of any theological heresy that could in justice be called unpresbyterian or that could justify suspicion, criticism of a brother or refusal to work with hires."

TRENTON, March 2. -- A deal reported to have been made between Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, the Democratic leader of the State, and Governor Harold G. Hoffman blocked action tonight on a bill by which the Governor's opponents in his own party had hoped to tie his hands, at least for a while, on action that might supplant Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf as head of the State police.
This reader appreciated those reflections in THE TIMES of Feb. 27 on "The Ways of Weather."
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 2. -- Hitting its stride in the second half, Manhattan's basketball team scored convincingly over the Yale quintet, 36 to 24, in the Payne Whitney Amphitheatre tonight.

Subscription books for the $17,000,000 Kingdom of Norway twenty-year 4 1/2 per cent bonds due on March 1, 1956, have been closed, Lazard Freres Co., Inc., syndicate managers, announced yesterday. The bonds, which had been offered at par, were quoted late yesterday at 99 7/8 bid and 100 1/4 asked.

Aniceta Shea, winner of one of the Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation Awards, received her prize yesterday afternoon in the form of a debut recital at the Town Hall. She proved to be a dramatic soprano whom nature had generously endowed.
ALBANY, March 2. -- The text of Governor Lehman's message to the Legislature recommending a social security program was as follows: To the Legislature:

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 2 (AP). -- Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, asserted tonight that speculators seeking easy and quick profits in the stock market were the source of most of the troubles of the Exchanges.

ATHENS, March 2. -- King George, in a general's uniform, today opened the first crown session of Parliament since 1923 with an appeal to the parties, still divided around the personality of Eleutherios Venizelos, whom he did not mention by name, to bury the feud that has tragically marked Greece's post-war history.

ROME, March 2. -- The decision of the Committee of Eighteen at Geneva to delay any further action on sanctions until another effort has been made to conciliate the Italo-Ethiopian issues has not been badly received in Italy.

Broadway's theatrical managers met yesterday morning at the offices of the League of New York Theatres in the Paramount Building, discussed the crisis brought on by the new demands of the Dramatists Guild and agreed to maintain a united front.
Mayor La Guardia issued the following statement on the strike yesterday:

LONDON, March 2. -- As a result of negotiations of Pan American Airways for an air route to Copenhagen via Iceland and Greenland, the Greenland Board today granted permission for the company to continue test flights in Greenland in 1937.

Mrs. Nettie Lazarowitz, widow of Isadore, lower East Side landlord, who was slain by two thieves on Jan. 3, had a premonition in a dream Sunday night that if her daughter would go to Delancey and Ludlow Streets she would capture the man they had been seeking by his Rogue's Gallery photograph for the last two weeks.

GRAND JUNCTION, Tenn., March 2. -- Sulu, a smart little pointer from the kennels of A.G.A. Sage of New York City, was judged champion of the nation's bird dogs today for her outstanding performance in the national field trials.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Giving no explanation, the Supreme Court refused today to consider the argument of the Lambs Club of New York that it was not really a "social, sporting or athletic" club under the meaning of the revenue laws.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Feb. 26 shows decreases for the week of $94,000,000 in total loans and investments, $22,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and $14,000,000 in government deposits, and an increase of $11,000,000 in time deposits.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Plans of the Great Northern Railway to finance its July 1 maturity of $100,766,000 of Series A 7 per cent general mortgage bonds by the issuance of new securities to be purchased or lent upon by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, were approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP). -- Senate approval of a $143,986,000 Interior Department appropriation was won today by administration leaders, despite attacks from both sides of the chamber against a $57,000,000 grant to carry on reclamation projects started by PWA.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The administration is completing its third year with a definite turn toward reducing the Federal deficit. This deficit represents, to its critics, the cost of the New Deal; to its friends, the price of recovery.

Sidney H. Rhodes, Mayor of Deal, N.J., and for eighteen years vice president of Weber Heilbroner, clothiers, was found shot dead late last night in a room at the Peter Stuyvesant Hotel, 2 West Eighty-sixth Street. He was 56 years old.

SHANGHAI, March 2. -- Although Major Gen. Rensuke Isogai, Japanese military attache of the Peiping Embassy, opened an analysis of Japan's position toward China today by declaring, "fortunately there is to be no change from the policies outlined in our previous conversations," when he continued he displayed an almost conciliatory attitude.

A seeded team of well-known tournament players was eliminated yesterday in the first session of the annual play for the Curt H. Reisinger Cup of the Eastern contract bridge championships at the Hotel Commodore.
Sales of apartment houses on the East Side and of several properties in Harlem were reported by brokers yesterday.
Following is the strike proclamation issued by Mayor La Guardia yesterday:

The last of the five concerts of chamber music, old and new, which have been given this season by Hans Lange and the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under the auspices of the Scholarship Fund of Bennington College, took place yesterday evening in Town Hall.
Richard Shikat was born in Tilsit, East Prussia, on Jan. 11, 1898.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP). -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the West Virginia chain store tax applied to filling stations leased by refining companies.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., March 2 (AP). -- New Mexico Republicans, holding the first Republican convention of the campaign, today unanimously endorsed Governor Alfred M. Landon of Kansas for the party's Presidential nomination.

BERLIN, March 2. -- Wilhelm Furtwaengler, whose reappointment to the staff of the Berlin State Opera as "guest conductor" was officially announced last week, probably will conduct only a few operas before the current season closes.

MIAMI, Fla., March 2. -- Silvio Coucci, ace rider for Mrs. Payne Whitney's Greentree Stable, celebrated his arrival from Santa Anita by stealing the spotlight at Hialeah Park today. The Bronx youth won the fifth race astride Tempestuous and made it two in a row aboard his employer's Torita in the featured Regret Purse.

In a report which describes the East River as "probably more contaminated than any similar body of water in the world," the committee on sanitation of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York recommends the construction of disposal works to remedy the situation. The report will be submitted to the monthly meeting of the chamber Thursday.

Political leaders through public statements are directing too much attention to the stock market, Thomas I Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, told a meeting of the New York representatives of the company held in the Hotel New Yorker yesterday.

ELIZABETH BOWEN'S "The House in Paris" (Knopf, $2.50) is the sort of novel other writers wish they were able to write. Those who have struggled with words will appreciate the magic precision with which Miss Bowen uses them. They will recognize the wealth of impressions which went into some of her descriptive phrases and delight at the diamond-like compactness of the finished prose.

PHILADELPHIA, March 2. -- Temple University closed its regular basketball season tonight by defeating Villanova at the Arena, 41 to 27, in the second part of the final college double-header. The West Chester Teachers defeated P.M.C. in the other game, 41 to 34.
ALBANY, March 2. -- A bill making it a misdemeanor to sell gasoline to intoxicated automobile drivers was passed in the Senate tonight by a vote of 46 to 4.

Snow that began to fall over the New York area about 8 o'clock last night was expected to turn to rain today, according to the Weather Bureau's forecast last night. The temperature probably will rise steadily during the day, weather officials said.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., March 2. -- Mr. and Mrs. Thomas O'Toole, parents of four young children, were sentenced today to three years in jail because they accepted relief checks when they had more than $11,000 in the bank.

After absorbing March contracts released by pool brokers at 11.22 cents a pound the market on the Cotton Exchange lost some of the early gain yesterday and closed 4 points higher to 5 points lower than on Saturday. Selling orders at 11.20 cents were apparently withdrawn and the limits raised 2 points, but trade demand was still around previous closing levels, so that March lost 2 points on the day.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- About 500,000 of the 3,817,781 persons now employed under the administration's $4,880,000,000 work relief program are not relief clients, but persons hired under exemption orders because of the need for skilled workers, according to estimates of some technical advisers of Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, it is said.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, March 2. -- The Nazi government struck back at the Universities of Oxford, Cambridge and Birmingham today when the rector of Heidelberg University formally withdrew its invitations to all British universities or academies to send delegates to the ceremonies marking the 550th anniversary of the university's foundation.

How New York retail trade grew from Indian barter to imposing department stores and how the city's communications developed from couriers on horseback to radio has been dramatized in two permanent exhibits at the Museum of the City of New York to be opened to the public tomorrow following a private showing this afternoon.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows: Quotations are in cents:

Brewers of the State believe they are setting something of a precedent in denouncing as unfair to brewers a bill imposing a tax of 6 cents a gallon on all beer brought here from outside the State. The measure, now before the Legislature, is classed as unfair because brewers operating in this State pay only 3 1-3 cents a gallon tax.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:
WARREN, Ohio, March 2 (AP). -- Flames in the Hotel Warren forced Mr. and Mrs. Owen Canole of Akron to leap to their deaths from a window ledge today and burned another man to death in his room.

EDMONTON, March 2 (Canadian Press). -- Citizens of Alberta learned today of increased taxation when Charles Cockroft, Provincial Treasurer, delivered his budget speech before the first social credit Legislature in the world.

PHILADELPHIA, March 2. -- The Pennsylvania Railroad announced today completion at its Altoona works of a streamlined steam engine of "a strikingly new type" which, it stated, presented "the most highly perfected and advanced locomotive design yet produced by aerodynamic science for the reduction of wind resistance."

A true philanthropist died Sunday. His name never appeared in the lists of those who contributed substantial sums to charity, but ask any one who knew Nick Palumbo and the answer is "he was good to everybody."

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The House voted, 181 to 146 today to impeach Judge Halsted L. Ritter of the Southern District of Florida. The vote came after nearly five hours of arguments, with the House membership in the role of grand jury and members of the Judiciary Committee both defending and prosecuting the Florida jurist.
ALBANY, March 2. -- Governor Lehman sent to the Legislature tonight a special message recommending a comprehensive social security program having eight basic points.

Twenty-two men, said to be members of a rum ring, which made profits of $7.000,000 since repeal by selling bootleg liquor smuggled here from Canada and elsewhere, were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury.

On the theory that only three starters are needed in any race to make a world's record official, there will he only three in the field for the Columbian Mile that will feature the annual Knights of Columbus indoor games at the Garden a week from Saturday.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- In clearing its docket of two-thirds of all cases awaiting decision, the Supreme Court today finally disposed of two New Deal matters and made ready for arguments on two more such subjects within the next ten days.

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 2. -- The training season proper of the Giants began with a flourish today as the regular infielders and outfielders joined forces with the batterymen on Legion Field, which for more than a month has seen so much activity on its surface that Groundkeeper Henry Fabian has virtually given up in despair of ever getting a luxuriant turf on it.

One hundred and eighty building employes of London Terrace, 135 of them elevator operators, doormen and porters, walked out at noon yesterday and left the fourteen buildings in the development temporarily without service.

EDWARD VIII, in speaking over the air waves to his peoples, used the American term "radio" in place of the British "wireless." But apparently he succeeded in making himself understood by the inhabitants of the British Commonwealth of Nations.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP). -- Jesse Jones, chairman, said today that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation had no power to regulate salaries paid by borrowing banks although it "scrutinizes salaries pretty closely" when payments on loans are tardy.
WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Following is the text of the announcement by the State Department of the signing of the agreements with Panama:

LONDON, March 2. -- The London stage, which has always neglected Ibsen, is receiving an intellectual stimulus from Cambridge. The Arts Theatre group opened a six weeks' repertory season of four Ibsen plays with "A Doll's House" at the Criterion tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Mrs. Charles Evans Hughes and scores of other prominent women saw the Supreme Court in a new role at the annual stunt party dinner given tonight by the Women's National Press Club.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Encouraged in his fiscal plans by a rush of investors to subscribe to the government's offering of $1,809,000,000 in cash and refunding securities placed on the market this morning, President Roosevelt doubled efforts in preparation of the revenue message which he hoped to lay before Congress tomorrow with a request for $786,000,000 in new and "substitute" taxes.

The town residences of Governor Herbert H. Lehman, former Governor Alfred E. Smith and hosts of other persons prominent in all spheres of the city's activities felt in some degree yesterday the strike of the building service employes.

Although the Building Service Employes Union has called out its members in many buildings under the jurisdiction of the State Mortgage Commission, the strike has not affected apartment houses, hotels and office buildings under two other State Agencies -- the Banking and Insurance Departments.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 2. -- Harvard University will send a delegate to the 550th anniversary of the founding of the University of Heidelberg, it was made known here tonight with an announcement of acceptance of the invitation extended by the German university.

The student council of the City College School of Business and Civic Administration went on record yesterday as opposed to the section in the Associate Alumni majority report declaring President Frederick B. Robinson unfit to head the city institution.

HAVANA, Feb. 18. -- The benefits derived by both the United States and Cuba from the reciprocal trade agreement were emphasized today by Jefferson Caffery, the United States Ambassador, in a statement to the press.

Generally higher prices ruled for listed bond market yesterday, with sales in moderate volume. The market for United States Government loans attracted considerable attention in view of the official announcement yesterday morning of the details of the Treasury's March financing.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 2. -- The defense charged today in the trial of four Union County deputy sheriffs for the killing of Mrs. Sophie Crempa, Scotch Plains farmer's wife, that Mrs. Crempa and her husband, John, opened fire on the deputies before they fired a shot.

LONDON, March 2. -- Once again the Italians claim to have won a big victory. Once again the only rational attitude toward that claim is one of suspended judgment. A conflict where there are no impartial observers and where one side's account must inevitably arrive late because of poor communications does not encourage hasty assumptions.

The annual capacity of the steel industry for producing pig iron and steel ingots declined last year, it was announced yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute. The capacity on Dec. 31 last was 69,789,554 gross tons annually, compared with 70,046,366 on Dee. 31. 1934, a decline of 256,812 tons.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- President Roosevelt's policy of the good neighbor in the Western Hemisphere received practical application again today when a treaty, conventions and agreements were concluded with Panama providing for vital changes in the relations of the two countries.

One of the major undertakings of the Federal Art Project of the WPA, the formation of a gigantic index of American design, has been illustrated in an exhibition of antique costumes worn in this country in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, arranged by the Federal Art Project at R.H. Macy Co., for two weeks. The display was opened yesterday afternoon.

A dress rehearsal of Beethoven's opera "Fidelio," which is to have its first performance in the current revival next Saturday afternoon, was held at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday morning. The event was arranged exclusively for members of the Metropolitan Opera Guild, who packed the opera house.

Twenty-seven arrests in strike disorders in which about ten men, including a policeman, were injured, were made yesterday by swift-cruising patrolmen in radio cars and on motor cycles. Fifteen arrests were made on Sunday.

The La Guardia administration has been particularly efficient in its staff work: purchase, budget-making, personnel, law. The annual report of the Corporation Counsel reveals what immense services a well-conducted Law Department can render to the city. The contrast with Tammany shiftlessness here is especially striking.
Mayor La Guardia's effort to settle the building service strike yesterday resulted in an agreement to resume negotiations at City Hall at 10 o'clock this morning.

PITTSBURGH, March 2. -- When the National Labor Board refused to accept the position taken by Jones Laughlin that it is not engaged in interstate commerce, the company withdrew today from the hearing in which it is charged with violating the Wagner Labor Act.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 2. -- Another witness was called in a surprise move by Thomas J. Mooney at the resumption today of his hearing on an application for a writ of habeas corpus.

Tony Canzoneri, world's lightweight champion, scored an impressive knockout victory over Steve Halaiko, veteran Buffalo campaigner, in the second round of a scheduled ten-round feature contest at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

A list of 178 foreign governmental and corporate securities, comprising approximately 50 per cent of the foreign securities now traded on the New York Stock Exchange, for which applications for permanent registration have been approved for listing and registration, in accordance with the provisions of the Securities Exchange Act, was made public yesterday.

Mrs. Nicholas F. Brady gave a luncheon yesterday at her home, 910 Fifth Avenue, for members of the committees arranging the annual international skating carnival which will be held March 22 and 25 at Madison Square Garden for the benefit of the convalescent relief division of the Bellevue Hospital Social Service Bureau, the Carroll Club and the Carroll Vacation Camp.

CHICAGO, March 2 -- Prices of wheat on the Board of Trade held today within a range of 1/2 cent a bushel. Outside trade was small and there was comparatively little of the spreading between the May and July that has been frequent recently. Scattered selling of the May by commission houses because of easiness in other markets was offset largely by buying by mills and cash interests.
MOSCOW, March 2. -- "Keep your powder dry," was the advice of Marshal Mikhail Tukhachevsky, Assistant Defense Commissar, today in an address to Stakhanoffists of aviation.

In his address over the radio on Washington's Birthday Senator Borah stressed once again his uncompromising demand for complete isolation as the keynote of American foreign policy. The corollary is that he would peremptorily dismiss any thought of our ever having anything to do with the League of Nations.

MONTREAL, March 2. -- The New York Americans, driving confidently toward their first play-off berth in nine years, threaten to take all individual scoring honors of the National Hockey League season, the weekly statistics showed tonight.

The first of the managers' tryouts went on last evening in the drama's sister borough of the Bronx. There, in the Willis Theatre, which the WPA rescued from a fate worse than the movies, namely, darkness, Mr. Lee Shubert, the option holder, saw tried out "A Womany of Destiny."

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP). -- Opposing all efforts to restrict the constitutional power of the Supreme Court, Senator Vandenberg asserted tonight that if any of these succeed it will be a "sad day for popular government and for the perpetuation of American liberties."

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- A bill embodying the basic principles of the Walsh bill by including in government contracts wage and hour standards and forbidding the employment of children or convict labor was introduced in the House today by Representative Arthur D. Healey, Democrat, of Massachusetts.

Leading New York corporation lawyers discovered to their consternation over the week-end that the Senate Lobby Investigating Committee in Washington had in its possession confidential telegrams exchanged with their clients during the period covered by the investigation.

ALBANY, Tuesday, March 3. -- The Republican Assemblymen at a conference which came to a close shortly before 1 o'clock this morning approved a proposal by the fiscal leaders of the lower house to cut $15,562,369 out of Governor Lehman's executive budget.

Staving off a strong fourth-quarter bid by the losers, the Grover Cleveland High School quintet maintained its unbeaten pace in the Queens Division of the P.S.A.L. by topping Richmond Hill, 28 -- 26, at Cleveland yesterday. The victory was the tenth in a row, seven of which have been scored in the tournament, for the home team.

TRENTON, N.J., March 2. -- The Young bill, which would "freeze" highway funds and make them available for emergency relief purposes, was defeated for the fourth consecutive time here tonight by the State Assembly. The final vote was 32 to 28.
GAINESVILLE, Fla., March 2. -- Headway in a dramatic fight against leukemia, dread blood disease invariably fatal to man and beast, is announced by Dr. M.W. Enamel of the University of Florida.
Several apartment houses and a vacant plot changed hands in Bronx sales reported by brokers yesterday.

The securities markets yesterday greeted with caution publication of the administration's tax proposals, but late in the day prospects of higher dividends and smaller undistributed corporate surpluses won enough traders over to a bullish attitude, which resulted in gains of 1 to 3 points for the day, while a few issues were 4 to 8 points higher.

It is a human trait to be thrilled by contact with old, familiar scenes. This may explain the appeal of the recreational exhibits at the National Sportsmen's Show. By portraying the beauties in nature that we know and love, they evoke memories of days spent in the enjoyment of simple pleasures. Our minds are freed temporarily of the burdensome thoughts of the workaday world; forgotten are the rigors of a frozen Winter.

Properties on the upper West Side and in Harlem figured in several of the Manhattan realty transactions reported yesterday. An apartment site was purchased in West 215th Street, and two East Side tenements were acquired by investors.
The following are designees for delegates and alternates to the Democratic National Convention from Congressional districts wholly or partly in New York City:

CHICAGO, March 3. -- Michael L. Igoe, United States District Attorney, will start presenting evidence to a Federal grand jury tomorrow against Arthur W. Cutten, grain speculator, on charges of evading income-tax payments totaling $100,000 for 1929, 1930 and 1933.
WASHINGTON, March 3. -- President Roosevelt's message to Congress asking tax legislation was as follows:

Supreme Court Justice Edgar J. Lauer dismissed yesterday the suit for $14,896,032 brought against Floyd B. Odium and other directors of the Securities Allied Corporation, formerly the Chatham Phenix Allied Corporation, for alleged waste and conversion.

The last of the college basketball double-headers will be staged in Madison Square Garden tonight with an all-local cast. Manhattan will meet Fordham in one battle while N.Y.U. will engage City College in another traditional encounter.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., March 3. -- Tony Penna, young Pensacola (Fla.) professional, turned in a six-under-par 64 to lead the field at the end of the first eighteen holes of the $2,500 Hollywood open golf tournament today. Penna carded 33, 31 -- 64 for the par 36, 34 -- 70 course.

Judge Robert A. Inch in the United States District Court in Brooklyn signed yesterday an order reversing a finding of Edward C. MacDonald, special master, authorizing the Chemical Bank and Trust Company to file a blanket claim for holders of bonds of the Prudence Bonds Corporation, fifteenth series, now undergoing reorganization.

One youth was killed and his two companions were seriously injured shortly before 9 o'clock last night in a skidding accident that hurled a car from the middle of Eleventh Avenue over the curb and against a building at Forty-sixth Street. There were few persons on the sidewalk and none was in the path of the car.

LONDON, March 3. -- Renewed activity in armament and aircraft shares sprang up today on the London Stock Exchange following publication of the government's white paper. British funds were quiet, although local loans and old consols attracted buyers in the afternoon. Japanese bonds continued to recover on more encouraging news from Tokyo.

J. Howard Carter, Acting Federal Attorney, announced yesterday that the Federal Government would take immediate steps to prosecute any action by strikers or strike-breakers that interfered with the delivery of mail in apartment and business houses.

ALBANY, March 3. -- Elimination of grade crossings under the jurisdiction of the Public Service Commission was characterized as "clumsy, unbusinesslike, costly and inefficient," by Colonel Frederick S. Greene, State Superintendent of Public Works, in his annual report to the Legislature today.

BERLIN, March 3. -- Miss Christel Cranz, Black Forest girl ski star who won for Germany the first gold medal available in the recent Winter Olympics, has been rewarded with appointment to the position of instructor in the School of Physical Education at Freiburg University.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 3. -- Two undergraduate one-act plays and an adaptation by an undergraduate of the Book of Job will compose the program of a private bill to be presented here tomorrow and Thursday nights by the Theatre Intime, student dramatic society, in the Murray Theatre.
ROME, March 3. -- The text of Premier Benito Mussolini's address to his Cabinet today follows:

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- The compromise ship subsidy bill embodying views of the Postoffice and Commerce Departments was laid before the Senate Commerce Committee today, and Chairman Copeland declared that he thought the measure, if it received adequate administration support could be the basis for legislation to pass the Senate at this session.

The necessity for community action as well as private and individual effort to prevent casualties, particularly "this terrible toll of highway accidents," was impressed upon nearly 5,000 persons attending the seventh annual Greater New York Safety Conference yesterday in the Hotel Astor.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 3. -- General Ivan Luckoff, the War Minister, today notified the officers of the Sofia garrison that the government had decided upon the immediate dissolution of the Officers' League, an organization that for the last fourteen years has played a prominent part in Bulgarian politics and that was greatly interested in the coup by which Kimon Gueorguieff became Premier.

The pamphlet report of Standard Brands, Inc., for 1935 shows a consolidated net income of $12,744,963 after all charges, as previously published in the preliminary statement. After deducting preferred dividends of $494,142, there was available $12,250,820, equal to 97 cents a share on the common stock outstanding

A fast-passing St. Michael's High quintet of Union City, N.J., made a successful start in its bid for permanent possession of the coveted Bishop Thomas E. Molloy Trophy by conquering De La Salle Institute, 25 to 17, last night at the Columbus Council, K.C., hall in Brooklyn.

Twenty-one charitable institutions receive bequests totaling $110,000 in the will of Charles Klingenstein, retired silk merchant and trustee of Mount Sinai Hospital, who died on Feb. 10, it was learned yesterday when his will was offered for probate in Surrogate's Court.

The social security program that Governor LEHMAN has presented to the Legislature merely carries out the recommendations that he made in his annual message on Jan. 1. One section of the Federal Social Security Act provided for Federal grants to those States enacting legislation, conforming to certain standards, for aid to the dependent old, to dependent and crippled children, to the needy blind, and for maternal welfare.

ASMARA, Eritrea, March 3. -- Emperor Haile Selassie's last army in Northern Ethiopia, that of Ras Emerou in the Takkaze River region of Tembien, has been crushed like those of Rases Mulugheta, Seyoum and Kassa, the Italians announced this evening.

TRENTON, March 3. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman received today Colonel H Norman Schwarzkopf's letter supporting his charge that State police under him had been approached by an agent of the Governor with "promises and threats" as Anthony M. Hauck Jr., Prosecutor of Hunterdon County, prepared to go to court in an effort to prevent another reprieve for Bruno Richard Hauptmann.

Mrs. Henry Clay Ellsworth gave a luncheon yesterday in the King Cole Room of the St. Regis for Miss Shirley Wallace Henderson, whose marriage to Samuel Benjamin Jones 3d will take place Friday at Broadacre, the home of Mr. and Mrs. J. Lester Parsons in Llewellyn Park, West Orange, N.J.

Iona Prep's quintet closed its regular Bronx-Westchester C.H.S.A.A. campaign in a tie with Fordham Prep for the title by beating Manhattan Prep, 27 -- 21, on the winner's floor in New Rochelle yesterday. Iona and Fordham Prep, which scored seven victories in eight starts each, are to meet in a playoff, the date for which has not been set.

The first New York performance of Rimsky-Korsakoff's opera, "The Legend of the Invisible City of Kitezh and the Maiden Fevronia" was given last night before a large and very interested audience in the Metropolitan Opera House by the Philadelphia Orchestra, the Art of Musical Russia, Inc., and soloists listed herewith, under the baton of Alexander Smallens.

Retention of the Mayor as an elected official and the substitution of a unicameral city council for the Boards of Estimate and Aldermen are among the recommendations of the charter revision committee of the City Fusion Party, of which Michael Potter is chairman. The report was made public yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., March. 3. -- Don Meade, who started the day tied with Johnny Longden for riding honors at Hialeah Park, scored a triple today to assume an undisputed lead with thirty victories during the meeting. Longden rode one winner to run his string to twenty-eight.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 3. -- Only a matter of $500 is keeping Van Lingle Mungo, Brooklyn's ace pitcher and one of the stars of the National League, from reporting to Manager Casey Stengel. Vice President Joe Gilleaudeau now has come that close to meeting Mungo's salary demands.

John E. Gratke, a hearty fellow who is to Broadway what Dexter Fellows is to the circus, revealed yesterday some of the details of the "vast panorama of progress" that will mark the celebration of the Broadway Association's twenty-fifth birthday in May.

THE thing to do now is to snatch away the whistles from those basketball referees so that the college schedule can be completed in a hurry. The Olympic basketball program is up in the air and can't be brought down to earth or a hard floor until the college quintets wind up their own wars.

CHICAGO, March 3. -- Buying of May wheat against sales of July, which gossip in the trade indicated was partly in changing over hedges from the old into the new crop future, caused a rapid widening today of the difference between the positions on the Board of Trade, with May ending at a premium of 10 5/8 cents, compared with 9 1/4 cents yesterday.
Value of Dollar in Exchange. The dollar on the local foreigm exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

SHANGHAI, March 3. -- Japan's apparent willingness, as announced yesterday by Major Gen. Rensuke Isogai, military attache of the Japanese Embassy, to permit the Central government to dispatch armies into Shansi Province in order to combat the inroads of Communists has two strings attached to it, both humiliating to China and one almost certain to precipitate a new civil war.

The State of Minnesota will be in the market on April 3, with a new issue of $2,650,000 of highway and general obligation bonds. The bonds will be dated March 1, 1936. Bidders are requested to name an interest rate not exceeding 3 per cent.

GENEVA, March 3. -- The League of Nations Committee of Thirteen -- the group of mediators -- appealed to Italy and Ethiopia today to open "in the framework of the League and in the spirit of the covenant" armistice and peace negotiations and, to general surprise, decided to give them a week instead of the expected forty-eight hours to answer.

With the present design of wings, airplanes will be limited to a speed of about 575 miles an hour, Dr. George W. Lewis, director of research of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics, showed last night at a special meeting of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences that was held in the New York Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- The "Green Belt" city, a $6,000,000 housing establishment planned by the Resettlement Administration at Bound Brook, N.J., will be turned over to local ownership as soon as completed, Rexford Guy Tugwell, Resettlement Administrator, informed a committee from Franklin Township, N.J., today.

By all odds the most important news yesterday, marketwise, was the President's revolutionary tax suggestions in the message to Congrass. An outline was available on the financial news tickers soon after midday.

THE guinea pig panic has lessened. Bootblacks have taken down the signs on which they warned possible customers that sometimes poison might be detected in the shoe-blacking used by their competitors. Shavers now shave with little thought of cost, already half-forgetful of what they were told concerning the unnecessarily short life of safety-razor blades.

The annual Eastern contract bridge championships took another surprise turn yesterday when the favored team of P. Hal Dims, Waldemar yon Zedtwitz, Walter Malowan and Sherman Stearns checked up on scores half way through the semi-final round of the play for the Reisinger Cup to find itself 2,490 points behind the team of A. Mitchell Barnes, Sydney Rusinow, B.J. Becket and Samuel Fry Jr.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- A picture of darkened night clubs, silent microphones and a world bereft of popular music if the Duffy Copyright Bill passes was presented before the House Patents Committee today by Rudy Vallee.
DETROIT, March 3. -- The session of the American College of Physicians heard today of human hearts that had been revived after death and made to beat for as long as four hours.

ALBANY, March 3. -- By a 4-to-3 decision the Court of Appeals today declared unconstitutional the Minimum Wage Law for women. Chief Judge Crane wrote the prevailing opinion, in which Judges O'Brien, Hubbs and Finch concurred, while Judge Lehman's dissenting opinion was approved by Judges Crouch and Loughran.

All of the 300 building, service employes at London Terrace, largest apartment house in the world, continued on strike yesterday, but the management was able to provide service which kept the fourteen buildings warm and one elevator running in each.

With much of the city's vertical traffic completely or partly paralyzed by the strike yesterday, individual Ingenuity and enterprise blossomed forth to cope with the circumstances created by the walkout.

The New York City Tunnel Authority received from Washington yesterday the contract forms covering the PWA $58,365,000 loan and grant to build the Thirty-eighth Street vehicular tunnel connecting Manhattan and Queens.

SHANGHAI, March 3. -- As a Chinese Communist army swept into Shansi Province tonight grave fears were aroused for more than a score of American missionaries believed to be in the path of the invasion.

The first African flower show ever held in this city opened yesterday in the Horticultural Hall, Rockefeller Center, with an exhibition of 7,000 flowers and plants, many of them unusual and strange looking.

BERLIN, March 3. -- Trading on the Boerse was stagnant again today, with some signs of weakness that failed to develop into a tendency. Activity is always limited in the Berlin market and it has been even more than usually notable for its absence in the last few years.

The David Belasco estate yesterday took back at a foreclosure auction sale the Belasco Theatre, which the estate had sold in August, 1934, to Mrs. Elmer Rice, wife of the playwright who recently resigned as regional director of the Federal WPA theatre project.

For many years Eastern Republicans were accustomed to go to national conventions riding like young Lochinvars in a reverse direction. They usually had a candidate of their own. They almost always expected to write the party platform. Largely holding the power of the party purse, they were much sought out, consulted and deferred to.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 3. -- Under a new system of elections started this year twenty-two seniors and four juniors of Rutgers University were chosen last night for membership in the New Jersey Chapter of Phi Beta Kappa.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- President Roosevelt said today that he will advise Congress, probably between March 10 and 18 concerning the appropriation needed for unemployment relief in the fiscal year beginning July 1.

Mayor La Guardia is expected to veto the compulsory city residence bill for relief employes when it comes before him on a statutory public hearing in his office at the City Hall at 9 o'clock this morning.

ALBANY, March 3. -- Governor Lehman sent to the Senate the nomination of Henry E. Bruckman, Assistant Chief Inspector in the New York City Police Department, to succeed Edward P. Mulrooney as head of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Division.

For the third consecutive week the number of visiting buyers registered in the market was below the preceding week. However, the total for the week ended yesterday was above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

There have been controversies between the United States and Panama as to their rights under the Treaty of 1903 Almost from the time it was made public. Panama contended that when it granted to the United States certain sovereign fights it had kept real sovereignty.

LONDON, March 3. -- The long-expected announcement of the British Government's new policy and program for rearmament was given to Parliament today in a White Paper. The policy section seems on first impression to be more militant than the facts of the actual construction program revealed.

United States Government bonds continued in good demand yesterday both on the New York Stock Exchange and in the outside market. Eight of the outstanding Federal long-term loans were carried to new high levels for the year, while three, namely, the Treasury 3 1/4s of 1944-46, the Treasury 3 1/4s of 1941, and the new Home Owners Loan 2 1/4s of 1942-44, established new high marks since their issuance.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- A comparison of "emergency" expenditures by the Treasury for the first eight months of the present fiscal year and the corresponding period of the previous fiscal year is given in the following table:

LONDON, March 3. -- In the strenuous second day's play of the British squash racquets championship today at the Queen's Club, which saw two rounds run off, Miss Anne Page and Miss Cecilia Bowes of the American group advanced to the quarter-final bracket.

A fashion show entitled "Accents on Spring Fashion Revue" was held during the luncheon hour yesterday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin. A generous percentage of the receipts was donated to the occupational therapy department of the Hospital for the Ruptured and Crippled.

ALBANY, March 3. -- Amendment of the State Liquor Control Law to prevent Summer hotels from selling beer in communities remaining dry under local option was demanded today by representatives of the Anti-Saloon League, the Woman's Christian Temperance Union and the Federated Council of Churches at a hearing before the Assembly Excise Committee.
GENEVA, March 3. -- The China committee of the Council of the League of Nations met privately yesterday to consider continuation of the League's reconstruction assistance to Nanking.

DETROIT, March 3. -- In connection with the meeting of the American College of Physicians a new insulin which promises to make the lives of sufferers from diabetes more nearly normal was announced today by the Department of Internal Medicine of Harper Hospital.

Princess Otto von Bismarck, Count Albrecht von Bismarck, Sigvard Bernadotte, grandson of King Gustav of Sweden, and Salvador de Madariaga, Spanish Ambassador at Large, are among the passengers sailing tonight for Europe on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen.

When President Nicholas Murray Butler, as head of the Carnegie Peace Foundation, takes the Roosevelt administration to task for failing to take full advantage of the opportunities afforded by Italy's violation of the Kellogg pact, many might be constrained to ask, "Is Saul also among the prophets?"

Stressing of high colors and the featuring of the price point of $42.75 to supplant the $39.75 price line were approved yesterday as basic items in the Fall merchandising program of the Medium Price Coat Associates at a meeting of the steering committee of that body at the Garment Center Capitol Club.

BOSTON, March 3 (AP). -- Speedy Bob Gracie outskated the Boston Bruins defense men twice tonight to pull his Montreal Maroons teammates into a National Hockey League 3-3 overtime tie before a crowd of 10,000 at the Boston Garden.
WASHINGTON, March 3. -- Approval of new rules to promote safety at sea, recommended by officials of the Bureau of Navigation and Steamboat Inspection, was announced today by Secretary Roper.

CHICAGO, March 3. -- Receipts of hogs here today were smaller than expected. This factor, combined with a fairly active shipping demand and a forecast for unfavorable weather, resulted in a stronger market. Sales were steady to 10 cents a hundredweight higher, compared with Monday's levels.

SAN PEDRO, Calif., March 3. -- Tied up since early Monday by a strike of 374 unlicensed members of her crew, the Panama-Pacific inter-coastal liner California was still held in port today while company officials and union representatives wrangled over a wage settlement.

Business failures declined in the retail, wholesale and manufacturing divisions, but increased in the construction group in the five business days ended Feb. 27, compared with the previous week, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- Reports received from officers, directors and principal stock, holders of corporations concerning transactions in equity securities in January, published today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, showed stock gifts of only about $200,000, in contrast with the large gifts in previous months which by the end of December, just before the higher gift tax rates went into effect, had risen to an aggregate of about $100,000,000 since June.

The "finks" formed a union of their own yesterday. Its life was transitory and its accomplishments negligible, but nevertheless it staged what was probably the first "strike" of strike-breakers in history.

A plea that the laundry industry continue to observe the State Minimum Fair Wage Act, which was held unconstitutional yesterday by the Court of Appeals, was made in a joint statement issued last night by Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, and Miss Frieda S. Miller, Director of the Division of Women in Industry and Minimum Wage of the State Department of Labor.

The first general primary fight within the ranks of the Socialists of New York State since 1919 came into existence officially yesterday when the two wings into which the party is split each filed complete slates in New York City of candidates for delegates and alternates to the Socialist National Convention, and members of the State committee.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 3. -- Several new faces appeared at Huggins Field for the second training session of the Yankees today, bringing the squad nearer completion.

Another large and enthusiastic crowd thronged Grand Central Palace yesterday to view the attractive exhibits of the Sportsmen's Show and watch experts of the great outdoors perform interesting feats of their craft. During the twelve hours in which the exhibition was open to the public Manager Albert C. Rau estimated that close to 20,000 had attended.
ROME, March 3. -- Premier Benito Mussolini opened the Cabinet meeting this morning with a detailed review of the international situation in the light of recent Italian victories in East Africa.

Advertising linage and results for the first two months of this year confirm to some extent the switches in media predicted at the close of 1935, authorities pointed out here yesterday. Newspapers are showing the largest gains, magazines are about holding to 1935 increases, while radio revenue in general is about equal to or slightly under last year.

MONTREAL, March 3. -- The desperate efforts of the Montreal Canadiens to overtake the New York Americans for the third place play-off berth in the National Hockey League's International Section brought results tonight when the flying Frenchmen sped to a 3-1 victory over Red Dutton's men and cut New York's margin in the group to one point.

A trend toward smaller gardens was reported yesterday by H. Stuart Ortloff, landscape architect, in a lecture at the New York Junior League, the second in a series being held there on Tuesday mornings for the benefit of the North Mianus Garden Club project, in Greenwich, Conn.

Candidates for delegates and alternates to the Republican National Convention favoring the nomination of Senator William E. Borah for President in ten Congressional districts were disclosed last night, when the time for filing designating petitions for the primary election on April 2 expired at midnight.

ALBANY, March 3. -- The controversy between Governor Lehman and the Republicans over an inquiry into unemployment relief was sharpened today as the Democratic-controlled Senate passed the Dunnigan bill, embodying the Governor's ideas on the manner of conducting. such an investigation.

Governor HOFFMAN'S message to the joint session of the New Jersey Legislature set forth in plain and forceful terms the needs of public relief in that State. More money must be had than is now in sight. The Governor estimated the minimum requirements for the next twelve months at $30,000,000.

After devoting the greater part of the season, as is its wont, to the work of younger painters -- work often in a frankly "experimental" stage -- the Montross Gallery, 785 Fifth Avenue, has brought forth from stock a group of oils and water-colors by twenty American artists who are Montross "regulars."

Declaring that he had promised President Roosevelt that the new building which will house the Bronx Industrial High School for Girls would be completed within a year, Mayor La Guardia yesterday asked the cooperation of the building contractors and workmen who will erect the building to avoid slowing up the work with labor troubles.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- The Treasury ended the eighth month of the 1936 fiscal year with a deficit of $2,410,404,680, its receipts having been $2,348,281,700 and expenditures $4,758,686,381 through Feb. 29. For the same period of the last fiscal year the deficit was $2,249,923,235; receipts $2,262,012,132 and expenditures $4,511,935,367.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP). -- The Wheeler bill to expand the Federal Trade Commission's investigative powers drew fire today from two business groups on the ground that it would permit on administrative agency to conduct "fishing expeditions" against all persons doing business in the nation.

Phillip Wubnig, 55 years old, of 1,038 Dumont Avenue, Brooklyn, retired from the police force three and one-half years ago and opened a curio and book shop. But yesterday he exemplified the saying, "Once a cop, always a cop."
TRENTON, March 3. -- The New Jersey Legislature, ignoring the ardent plea of Governor Hoffman, adjourned for the week late today without providing funds for relief.
WASHINGTON, March 3. -- Taxes suggested by President Roosevelt today in his message to Congress were as follows:

BARROW, Alaska, March 3. -- Identity of a derelict ship locked in the Arctic ice far off Point Barrow puzzled both natives and whites today, but some believed she might be one of seven stanch whalers which sailed into the northern seas fifty years ago and never returned.

TOKYO, Wednesday, March 4. -- Yesterday was occupied in Japanese fashion with allocation of responsibility for the recent army rebellion. It was settled by the resignation en bloc of seven members of the Supreme War Council, who have asked to be released from active service and have agreed that none of their number shall accept any post.

ALBANY, March 3. -- After listening to an attack on Governor Lehman by Assemblyman Harold P. Herman over a vetoed Nassau County crime bill and sharp criticism of the Chief Executive by Assemblyman Horace M. Stone leader of the opposition to Governor Lehman's law enforcement program, the Assembly passed eight of the anti-crime bills today with dissenting votes on only two of the measures.

Yesterday was the hundredth anniversary of the departure from Rushville (Yates County), New York, of MARCUS WHITMAN and his wife for missionary work among the Indians in the far Northwest -- the Walla Walla Valley in what is now the State of Washington. Mrs. WHITMAN and her companion Mrs. HENRY SPALDING were the first white women to cross the American Continent to the far Northwest.

Leases for expansion in the midtown area featured the business rentals reported yesterday. Among the lessees was the Consumer Distribution Corporation, recently organized by Edward A. Filene to administer cooperative department stores throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- Exchange subscriptions on the Treasury's $1,809,000,000 issue of bonds and notes will be closed on Thursday night, Secretary Morgenthau announced today. Cash subscriptions closed last night after a heavy oversubscription.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- There are many millions of stockholders in this country, but there are many more millions who own no stocks. Of the stockholders, only a small minority manage the great corporations in which they have an interest and decide the question whether to plow excess earnings into the business, or pile them up into surpluses beyond prudent reserve requirements.

Ellis Island is going to have an attractive dining room for immigrants, according to Rudolph Reimer, Commissioner of Immigration, who yesterday visited the studio of Edward Laning, WPA artist, to give his final approval to one of a series of mural paintings being executed for the island.

The Works Progress Administration now has nearly 1,400 relief workers engaged on an $11,000,000 waterfront modernization program in New York City which has been approved by President Roosevelt and the WPA authorities in Washington, it was announced yesterday by Victor F. Ridder, local WPA administrator.

In a recent letter to THE TIMES, "Protection for Investors," it was held that investors do not want safety at the expense of profits. Actually, the true investor desires safety of capital, but at the same time he wants a living yield on his money. But what the investor wants and what he gets are two different things.

PHILADELPHIA, March 3. -- Appointment of George W. Norris as president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia has been rejected by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System in Washington, it was announced today.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, March 3. -- "Conciliation" is a word that always makes Ethiopians suspicious when used in connection with their war with Italy, as they believe it must necessarily involve heavy material concessions on their part induced by force, while the aggressor is usually asked only to sacrifice part of his unrealized hopes.

Tonight's visitor from England is "Sweet Aloes," stopping at the Booth under the management of Lee Ephraim. This is the play by "Jay Mallory," in reality Joyce Carey, which ran for something more than a year in London.

ALBANY, March 3. -- Langdon W. Post, Tenement House Commissioner and spokesmen for social welfare groups, led an attack today on the Stephens bill which would grant a moratorium for another year on requirements about to become effective in the Multiple Dwellings Law.
The Republican candidate for President will probably "come out of the West," Charles D. Hilles, Republican national committeeman, told members of the Ivy Republican Club last night.

Abandoning what little pretense they had made on Monday of hiring only qualified workers, most of the more than a dozen hastily formed employment agencies supplying strike-breakers were sending men out yesterday on jobs as quickly as they could be registered.

BERLIN, March 3. -- The German Army and police have been put on a fish diet two days weekly to relieve the food shortage which has already led to drastic rationing and cattle and pig slaughter but is still draining the Reichsbank's slender reserve for necessary fats and foods.

TOKYO, Wednesday, March 4. -- Emperor Hirohito commanded Prince Fumimaro Konoye, distinguished young leader in Japanese liberal and naval circles, to create a new Cabinet today to replace that of Premier Keisuke Okada, shattered by a short-lived military uprising.

Closer cooperation between private institutions and the Department of Public Welfare is needed to provide more complete care of the homeless and neglected children of the city, William Hodson, Commissioner of Public Welfare, declared yesterday.

An army of more than 4,000 city employes has been enlisted by the Health Department to serve as elevator operators and to provide heat for buildings in cases of emergency in the service strike, Health Commissioner John L. Rice announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 3. -- Ten securities registration statements involving nearly $45,000,000 in proposed issues have been filed recently, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

Leslie Howard's production of "Hamlet" has definitely been postponed from April until next October. This was learned last night from W. Herbert Adams, Mr. Howard's lawyer, following a midnight telephone conference between Mr. Adams and John Houseman in New York and Mr. Howard in Hollywood.

ALBANY, March 3. -- The Assembly Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment, controlled by a Republican majority, adopted this afternoon an amendment to a tax bill, sponsored by Senator Buckley and passed by the Senate, which would cut in half the present two-cent-a- gallon emergency tax on gasoline used for motor vehicle fuel.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- Mixed feelings were aroused in the Senate and House by President Roosevelt's tax message, Democrats holding that it was the only way to meet unexpected requirements and Republicans charging that to tax the reserves of corporations would hinder continued operation.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 3. -- Thomas Hewes of Hartford, who resigned two years ago as Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, today was made general counsel of the Rossia Insurance Company of America and a member of its board of directors.

The City Athletic Club became the official champion of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association Group 1 team competition which was concluded yesterday. Clinching the title last week the City A.C. team, playing on its home court, triumphed over Block Hall, 3 to 2, for its ninth victory in ten engagements to wind up the season.

A new contract is now being drawn up between the Fashion Originators Guild and the Uptown Retail Guild of this city and will be ready in about a week, it was announced yesterday by Maurice Rentner, chairman of the guild. Both groups are now in accord, he said.

KIEV, U.S.S.R., March 9. -- All but two members of the executive committee of the Central Trade Union Council of Ukrainia have been dismissed, one has been arrested and some lesser officials will be put on trial for alleged large-scale graft and favoritism in the administration of union funds collected from workers.

While declaring it impossible to form a considered opinion on the new tax proposals by President Roosevelt until the plan is presented in more detailed form, leading industrialists and bankers here yesterday saw in the suggestions the possibility of far-reaching economic and financial consequences, extending beyond the mere problem of taxation.

It is not very often that a tie ending in hockey proves anything but tiresome. The case was not true last night at Madison Square Garden, however, as the Rangers battled the Toronto Maple Leafs for seventy minutes with only a scoreless deadlock to show for their efforts.

LONDON, March 3. -- The last serious obstacle to conclusion of a three-power naval treaty among the United States, Britain and France was removed today when the French and American delegations reached a complete agreement on the battleship problem.

The doors of Proctor's Theatre at Fifty-eighth Street and Third Avenue will open at 9 A.M. Saturday to admit any youngster within the boundaries of the East Fifty-first Street district who wants to see an elaborate entertainment arranged especially by Captain Hugo Wunsche in cooperation with the Police Safety Bureau.

Hundreds of delivery men and messenger boys were grumbling last night over aching backs and calloused feet, but deliveries of milk, groceries and other essentials to apartment houses affected by the strike were reported to have been carried out completely yesterday.

A change in the play-off system in the National Hockey League was made yesterday when the board of governors convened at the Hotel Commodore. The change involves the manner in which survivors of second and third place rounds will compete for the right to meet the first-place winner.

Shipyards in the United States on March 1 were building 137 ships of 166,280 gross tons, an increase of nearly 400 per cent over the total a year ago, according to a report issued yesterday by the American Bureau of Shipping.

Although the Securities and Exchange Commission has been making for some time a study of the trading in stocks of American corporations on the London Stock Exchange, there are many brokers who feel that undue importance is being attached to such transactions.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla,, March 3. -Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis won the medal today in the qualifying round of the women's Florida East Coast golf championship. The 18-year-old star posted a pair of 37s, her 74 being only two strokes over men's par and giving her a two-stroke lead over rs. Maureen Orcutt Crews of Miami, the defending titleholder.

The Department of Health reported yesterday 1,489 cases of measles for last week, an increase of 510 cases over the preceding week and of 806 over the same week last year. Seven deaths from this disease were reported, compared with one each for the other two periods.

The Oratorio Society of New York presented the entire Mass in B minor by Bach for the tenth consecutive season at Carnegie Hall last night. Albert Stoessel and his chorus of 300 had the assistance of Winifred Cecil, soprano; Rise Stevens, mezzo-soprano; Dan Gridley, tenor, and Robert Crawford, baritone.
The strike of elevator operators and other building service employes gained in strength yesterday as Mayor La Guardia continued without result his efforts to bring about a settlement.

Samuel Goldwyn, film producer, put himself on record yesterday as favoring the terms of the new minimum basic agreement of the Dramatists Guild of America, which would make it possible for a playwright to contract directly with a film producer for both the stage and screen production of his work on a straight royalty basis.

The newly crowned Class B champion, Vincent Furno of the Columbia University Club, accounted for the elimination of one of the game's veteran stars, Thomas R. Coward, in the second round yesterday of the national squash tennis championship at the Yale Club.
LONDON, March 3. -- Following is the text of the White Paper on British rearmament submitted to the House of Commons today:

Most staples advanced sharply in yesterday's trading on the commodity futures markets. Cottonseed oil and wooltop futures declined. Wide swings in coffee futures were a feature of the trading. On the cash markets, wheat, corn, oats, tin, silk and rubber advanced, while cotton, butter, eggs, cocoa and refined sugar were lower.
More than 5,000 building service strikers went on a rampage on Park Avenue late last night after their first general strike meeting at the Star Casino, 105 East 107th Street.

Liquidation up to Dec. 31 last of more than $61,000,000 of wholly owned mortgages issued by the title and mortgage guaranty companies taken over by the State Insurance Department was reported yesterday by Louis H. Pink, Superintendent of Insurance.
Brooklyn College vanquished the Lenox Hill A.A., 27 -- 18, in the quarter-final round of the Metropolitan A.A.U. basketball tournament at Union Temple last night.

Abraham R. Landes and his wife, Martha, the owners of a millinery shop at 215 West Seventy-fifth Street, were found dead about 10:45 o'clock last night as the result of a suicide pact executed in the kitchen of their three-room apartment at 310 West End Avenue.

The George Washington assembly room at the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, was filled yesterday afternoon while a Spring fashion show, presented by Mrs. Pleasants Pennington under the auspices of the club, took place.

Operations in connection with the resumption of sale of cotton from the producers' pool had a tendency to ease prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. Because of extensive government holdings in the spot month, however, March gave way slowly and ended unchanged, compared with a 7-point loss on July, which fluctuated over a range of 15 points.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- Testimony that the aggregate amount of public utility bonds now outstanding about represents the aggregate value of all public utility properties in the country was given before the Senate Lobby Committee today by Victor A. Dorsey of Chicago, appraiser of utility properties.

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 3. -- Despite Bill Terry's dramatic announcement last Fall that he was through as a player and the recent acquisition of Sam Leslie from the Dodgers, the Giant pilot is still hoping to continue as an active performer.

A new record for the number of signatures on petitions designating candidates for public office was achieved last night when the Bronx Democratic organization, headed by Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn, filed with the Board of Elections petitions for the primary election on April 2, said to carry a total of 198,783 signatures.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,774,700 barrels, compared with 2,779,200 in the previous week, a decline of 4,500, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Decreases of 24,300 and 7,100 barrels, respectively, in Oklahoma and California were offset by small gains in other areas.
ALBANY, March 3. -- Following are the texts of the opinions of the Court of Appeals on the minimum wage law:

Stockholders of the Second National Investors Corporation, Third National Investors Corporation and Fourth National Investors Corporation yesterday re-elected the present management, headed by Fred Y. Presley, president, and approved a new management contract with the National Investors Corporation, under which each of the three investment trusts will pay National Investors an annual management fee of not more than one-half of 1 per cent of the average market value of their gross assets.

The ranks of the established order held firm throughout the day in both the men's and women's divisions of the national indoor tennis championships yesterday as play came down to the quarter-finals at the Seventh Regiment Armory.
AKRON, Ohio, March 3 (AP). -- Paul W. Litchfield, president of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, told a press conference today:

ROME, March 3 (AP). -- All big banks in Italy became public credit institutions today in the most sweeping banking decree ever passed in the kingdom. The drastic step was taken by the Council of Ministers.

Equipped with a shotgun and a helmet to prove that he means to "meet force with force and violence with violence" during the building service strike, Frederic Coudert Bellinger, a partner in the law firm of Coudert Brothers, and a tenant in the apartment house at 925 Park Avenue, began yesterday to organize the Tenants Defense League.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- In one of the most sweeping revenue proposals submitted by him since he took office three years ago tomorrow, President Roosevelt today recommended to Congress a wholesale revision of corporation taxes, designed to exact $620,000,000 annually in additional revenue from corporations and their stockholders, primarily to pay for the farm program and extra cost of the veterans' bonus.

With private detectives and city policemen standing guard, the building strike continued in orderly fashion yesterday in office and fashionable apartment buildings on upper Fifth and Park Avenues, the upper West Side of Manhattan and the midtown district.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 3. -- The first of the seven Union County deputies who took part in the raid on the Crempa home at Scotch Plains last Fall, which resulted in the killing of Mrs. Sophie Crempa, took the stand for the defense today in the trial for manslaughter of four of his colleagues.
A $150,000 six-story apartment house project for Brooklyn was among the plans filed in the city yesterday, as follows:

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 3. -- A decision announced here today by the special judicial commission of the Presbyterian Synod of New Jersey upholds a verdict of the Presbytery of West Jersey, which found the Rev. Carl McIntire of Collingswood guilty last year of charges of disobedience and conduct unbecoming a minister.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 3. -- The Yale Dramatic Association tonight presented in the University Theatre "Wings Over Europe" as its midwinter production, of which several performances are traditionally given as a feature of the annual junior promenade festivities.

In a reply to my recent letter in these columns, "J.Y." accuses me of inconsistency in my statement that Sweden's prosperity was due to her managed currency. He says that "Sweden has had prosperity before and so have most of the other countries of the civilized world on a fixed gold standard."
Following were the developments yesterday in the strike of elevator operators and other building service employes:
Mrs. John Bierwirth, defending titleholder, gained the semi-final round in the women's, metropolitan squash racquets championship yesterday on the courts of the Junior League.

A net profit of $801,527 was reported yesterday for 1935 by the American Metal Company, Ltd. This was equal to $12.02 each on 66,670 preferred shares. It contrasted with a deficit of $232,485 in 1934. The figures for 1935 do not include net losses of $205,646 on sales or write-offs of investments, charged to contingent reserves, nor operating results of subsidiaries more than 50 per cent or less than 80 per cent owned.
BERLIN, March 8 (AP). -- The Reichsbank statement as of Feb. 29 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

TORONTO, March 3. -- New contracts between the Ontario Hydro-Electric Power Commission and the Gatineau Maclaren Power Companies of Quebec were released tonight in the Ontario Legislature by Attorney General Arthur Roebuck.

WASHINGTON, March 3, -- Rental and benefit payments to farmers cooperating in seven adjustment programs of the AAA in the calendar year 1935 totaled $580,821,074, according to a report issued today by the controller of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

Two large and virtually identical numbers on different pages in yesterday's TIMES demand to be brought together. On Page 22 we find approximately 24,000,000 persons now dependent on various forms of relief in the United States.

Against his attorney's will, but apparently to him own satisfaction, Meyer Luckman appeared yesterday before the special grand jury in Brooklyn that has been investigating the murder of Samuel Drukman and its attendant circumstances, including rumors of bribery.

The task of selecting five college basketball teams to compete in the Olympic finals at Madison Square Garden early in April will get under way this week-end with several of the country's outstanding quintets, including unbeaten Long Island University, among the absentees.

ALBANY, March 3. -- Hundreds of students from almost thirty normal schools, colleges and universities swarmed into the Senate chamber here today to register violent protest at a public hearing against the Nunan Students' Oath Bill. There were sharp exchanges.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 3. -- In celebration of the birthday of his daughter, Miss Mary Munn, a buffet dinner was given by Charles A. Munn tonight at Amado. Small tables were placed in the patio. Later movies were shown and an orchestra played for dancing.

Joseph C. Monier, an active figure in the Cotton Exchange for the last thirty-six years and co-plaintiff in a pending suit for $1,500,000 against the Guaranty Trust Company, committed suicide yesterday in his office at 60 Beaver Street, according to the police.

The appointment of Henry E. Bruckman, assistant chief inspector in charge of the detective division of the Police Department, as chairman of the State Liquor Authority was announced in Albany yesterday by Governor Lehman. Mr. Bruckman retired Monday from the Police Department, although his retirement was not announced until yesterday.

A flying squad of sixteen members of the Building Service Employes Union descended upon the New York Stock Exchange Building just as trading began at 10:02 o'clock yesterday morning and marched into the lobby through the 11 Wall Street entrance.

Two sonatas for 'cello and piano, the familiar one in E minor, by Brahms, and that of Arnold Bax-formed the chief items on the program offered by Beatrice Harrison, 'cellist, and Henri Deering, pianist, at their joint recital last night in the Town Hall.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The Senate lobby investigating committee omitted its public hearings today while Senator Black, the chairman, and his colleagues prepared to meet the challenge of its powers to subpoena correspondence scheduled to begin in the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia next Wednesday.

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 4. -- With Manager Bill Terry home in Memphis having his injured leg examined and a drizzling rain falling on the encampment he left behind him, the Giants' training activities bogged badly today and finally came to a complete standstill for the first time since New York's baseball colony established itself here.

The Maine coast and Haytian subjects divide rather sharply the current exhibition of canvases by Stephen Etnier at the Milch Galleries (until March 21). Paintings in the first group afford the artist's brush its fullest scope in presenting the delightful blue northern skies of midsummer, the cool bracing air, the suggestion of the sea near at hand even when not actually glimpsed.

The prospect of criminal action against members of the crew of the Panama Pacific liner California for tying up the ship at its pier in San Pedro, Calif., with a demand for higher wages was considered yesterday here and in San Pedro.
The eighth annual play for the Reisinger Cup for contract bridge teams of four narrowed down to two teams yesterday in the semi-final round of seventy-two hands in the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau announced today that he had authorized the New York Federal Reserve Bank, as fiscal agent of the Treasury, to purchase through the Bank of Canada silver newly mined within the Dominion of Canada.

The service strike reached five small buildings in the financial district yesterday, but workers in the taller structures continued to rebuff the efforts of flying squads to call them from their posts.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 4. -- Six days ago the official opening of the Dodgers' training activities began and today Manager Casey Stengel declared a half holiday for the batterymen, which was his way of expressing his satisfaction over the progress made in the preliminary exercises.

ROME, March 4. -- There has been a distinct swing in the last twenty-four hours in favor of accepting the League of Nations' invitation to negotiate with Ethiopia. Most Italians oppose a cessation of hostilities, for they have been brought to a high pitch of excitement and patriotic fervor by recent victories, but in official circles sentiment is undergoing a change.

A discovery of major importance in art was revealed here yesterday when M. Knoedler Co., Inc., announced that it had found in Austria and brought to this country a painting by the great early Italian master, Piero della Francesca (c. 1418-1492).
PRINCETON, N.J., March 4. -- Pennsylvania's five defended its four-year-old record against Princeton tonight, downing the Tigers, 20 to 12, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game.

Sanitation Department employes will clear apartment houses of garbage accumulation in cases where it constitutes a health menace and where it can be shown that it can be cleared away by no other means, Health Commissioner John L. Rice announced last night.

A confession said to have been made yesterday in the District Attorney's office by an 18-year-old youth that he was the slayer of a clerk in a chain grocery hold-up at 1,420 Third Avenue on Nov. 27, led to the exoneration of another youth detained in the Tombs as a suspect in the crime.

The tendency to drop Monday night performances in favor of an added matinee is now a full-fledged trend. "Fresh Fields" will next week become the fifth attraction to do so (extra matinee on Thursday), and "Ethan Frome" will join the procession the week of March 16.

The share market did not follow up yesterday its brisk advance of the day before. Followers of the market had had an opportunity to give some sober thought to the wide ramifications of the new plan for taxing corporations as suggested by the President, so that yesterday witnessed a moderate but unenthusiastic upward movement of share prices until about the final half hour of trading.

CHICAGO, March 4. -- Hogs were in good demand here today with the general market steady to 15 cents a hundredweight higher than on Tuesday. Some heavyweight hogs and packing sows were up as much as 25 cents, after having shown relative weakness of late.
TOKYO, March 4. -- Prince Kimmochi Saionji, the Elder Statesman, tonight had not yet solved the problem of finding statesmen strong enough to form a new administration.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP). -- The House of Representatives today became embroiled in a protracted debate about Communists and communism, in the course of which a broadcasting company on one hand was accused of "treason" and, on the other, the right of free speech was defended.
