As there is a prospect of having a World's Fair in New York in 1939, it is not too early to give thought to the furbishing of the city where good housekeeping attention is obviously required, and also to resuscitating ordinances that had been made in past years for the general betterment of life in the city.

Ten yachts are coming to this country from Europe for the race to Bermuda in June, which loomed yesterday, as the tentative entries were checked up, as one likely to draw a record number of between forty and fifty starters. Eighteen American craft are listed at this early date as likely participants.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Protection to railroad workers who might be affected by future mergers or consolidation of lines would be provided in a bill introduced today by Senator Wheeler of Montana and Representative Crosser of Ohio.

New York University regained its old winning touch and its old mastery of the courts last night as the Violet wrenched a bitterly fought game away from City College in the waning minutes of their traditional basketball tussle in Madison Square Garden.

Retail trade here picked up yesterday, following somewhat poorer trade on Monday and Tuesday, retail executives reported. The strike of elevator men and building service employes, particularly those in apartment houses, was said to have played some part in the showings on the first two days of the week, chiefly in the creation of a consumer psychology tending to postpone shopping.

Several commodity futures declined on the local Exchanges yesterday, whereas rubber, copper and cocoa advanced. The volume of trading was somewhat heavier. On the cash markets, cotton, lard, oats, corn and wool tops declined, while wheat, tin and rubber advanced.

More than 35,000 persons visited the National Sportsmen's Show at the Grand Central Palace yesterday, eclipsing the previous high mark registered last Sunday, the second day of the show, according to Sheldon H. Fairbanks, promoter. During the five days of the exhibition, according to Mr. Fairbanks, the attendance has totaled more than 116,000.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., March 4 (AP). -- Backed by the State, W.O. Fife of Albemarle, Commonwealth's attorney, planned today to institute civil actions in the courts of the City of New York to recover valuable historical documents which he alleges were stolen from the court house here and sold to collectors.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt were honor guests at a dinner given tonight at the Mayflower Hotel by the members of the Cabinet in celebration of the third anniversary of his inauguration.

ST. CLOUD, Minn., March 4 (AP). -- Spasmodic pounding on cells at the State Reformatory today signaled a continuance into a second foodless day of a hunger strike by most of the 1,156 inmates in protest against prison fare and regulations.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Ten cruisers and six destroyers in units commanded by rear admirals will visit West Coast ports of South America after the annual fleet manoeuvres off the West Coast of Central America and in the Panama area in May, the Navy Department announced today.

ROCHESTER, March 4. -- Before 1,200 representatives of the church city officials, ministers from every Protestant faith in the city, and laity, the Rev. Dr. Bartelle H. Reinheimer of New York, executive secretary of the National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church, was consecrated as the first Bishop Coadjutor of Rochester today.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP). -- Bipartisan tribute was paid tonight to Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College, New York, in honor of her twenty-fifth anniversary as dean of that college.

MOSCOW, March 4. -- The desire of the government to hasten the building of good highways throughout the Soviet Union whose roads, where any at all exist, are among the worst in the world, resulted today in a decree ordering peasants to contribute six days' labor annually on the highways in their neighborhoods.

LONDON, March 4. -- Dr. Chaim Weizmann, Zionist leader, is arriving here Sunday from Palestine for a series of consultations on the increasingly serious position of Jewish communities in many countries.

PHILADELPHIA, March 4. -- The directors of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia took the first step today toward choosing a successor to George W. Norris, the retiring governor, whose election as president of the bank was rejected in Washington yesterday by the governors of the Federal Reserve System.

FRIEDRICHSHAFEN, March 4. -- Dr. Hugo Eckener's new trans-atlantic dirigible LZ129, soon to become the Hindenburg, made a successful three-hour trial flight over Lake Constance this afternoon. The weather was calm, so no difficulties were encountered.

CHICAGO, March 4. -- Presentation of evidence before the Federal grand jury against Arthur W. Cutten, wealthy grain speculator, on charges of evading income tax payments for 1929, 1930 and 1933 was begun today by government prosecutors.

CANBERRA, Australia, Thursday, March 5. -- Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons today told a powerful deputation representing thirty-nine Australia-wide organizations that sought reduced taxation that no relief was possible while the world outlook continued uncertain.

DETROIT, March 4. -- The John Phillips Memorial medal for 1936 was presented tonight before the American College of Physicians to Dr. Eugene Markley Landis of Philadelphia. In bestowing the honor the president of the college, Dr. James Alexander Miller of New York, said:

There is said to be in this country a permanent rolling population of 25,000 persons who live in trailers the year round, following the sun hither and yon. It isn't hard to believe, once you get a close-up of these modern homes on wheels.

Members of the Junior Branch Players of the New York Women's League for Animals presented three one-act plays last night at the MacDowell Club for the benefit of the Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital for Animals.

Heats for four events were drawn up yesterday by the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. for its annual indoor track and field championships at Madison Square Garden on Saturday. These seedings will be subject to approval tomorrow by Referee Rupert B. Thomas of Princeton.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 4. -- The holdout situation involving Charley (Red) Ruffing, ace right-hand pitcher of the Yankees, reached a critical stage today.
WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The Federal Reserve Board's announcement of its new policy follows:

ALBANY, March 4. -- Governor Lehman reappointed Robert Moses, New York City Park Commissioner, today as president of the Long Island State Park Commission. The nomination was immediately confirmed by the Senate.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 4. -- Elections to the Vassar College chapter of Phi Beta Kappa and fellowship awards for next year were announced at a college assembly today.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Challenging the good faith of the government, Pierre S. du Pont, industrialist, filed a reply to the "second amended answer" of the government before the United States Board of Tax Appeals today.

Evelyn Laye, having graduated from "Bitter Sweet," is now to be seen in "Sweet Aloes," which settled into the Booth last evening. Although the titles have an odd similarity, the resemblance stops there, for "Sweet Aloes" is an emotional drama that is songless.

NEWARK, N.J., March 4. -- Nine men, two women and a 10-year-old boy were held by the Newark and Union (N.J.) police tonight for investigation in connection with the robbery of 3,759 gallons of confiscated alcohol from a Federal warehouse at 39 Hamilton Street, this city, some time Sunday.

NEWARK, N.J., March 4. -- In a letter attacking an agreement between the University of Newark and New York University under which the Newark institution will give courses in the first two college years in cooperation with the New York school, Richard D. Currier, founder of the New Jersey Law School, and his wife resigned today from the board of trustees of the University of Newark.

An amplifying and power tube for use in radio and television described as capable of tremendous current amplification in a fraction of a second was demonstrated last night by Philo T. Farnsworth, youthful television inventor, at a meeting of the Institute of Radio Engineers at the Engineers Club.
NORRIS, Tenn., March 4. -- To the screaming of a siren set off by President Roosevelt, potential kilowatts began piling up today behind Norris Dam, fourth largest in the world.

ALBANY, March 4. -- Bitter partisan strife which is certain to continue until the final gavel falls over the 1936 legislative session was foreshadowed in developments today in the Republican-controlled Assembly, where Governor Lehman's budget bills and one of his most important revenue measures were reported to the floor with amendments opposed by the Governor. The other revenue bills were reported in the form he submitted them.

MOSCOW, March 4. -- The Soviet Union is prepared to go to war with Japan if necessary to prevent destruction of the independence of its virtual political ally, the Mongolian People's Republic -- Outer Mongolia.

New York City's campaign to lessen drunken driving started yesterday with the first session of the special court set up to hear cases of motorists arrested for driving while intoxicated. Four persons were fined $100 each with the alternative of ten days in jail and their licenses were revoked, two were found not guilty and two had their cases adjourned before Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio at a special session in Homicide Court, 300 Mulberry Street.

THE story is that the I.C. 4-A, under pressure from within, is about to turn away from metric measurements in competition and go back to the mile and fractions thereof again. If this happens, the A.A.U. probably will follow suit and a long leap backward will have been made by the athletic leaders of this country.

MIAMI, Fla., March 4. -- Socially prominent women who have been named as sponsors of the various races scheduled for Charity Day, next Monday, at Hialeah Park, will each present the winner of the race she sponsors with a floral tribute at the conclusion of the event. Proceeds of the day go to aid charities in the Greater Miami area.

HACKENSACK, N.J., March 4. -- Joseph A. Preston and John Moles, former officers of the closed Cliffside Park Title Guarantee Trust Company of Cliffside Park, N.J., were put on probation for three years and fined $1,000 each today by Judge Walter Van Riper in Bergen County Special Sessions Court.

A recent news item states that the National Navy Club, at Park Avenue and Fortieth Street, has closed its doors because there is not a sufficient number of sailors in and about New York to warrant the expense of keeping the club open.

After listening to Opposition to the Lyons compulsory city residence bill for relief employes yesterday morning, Mayor La Guardia closed a public hearing on the bill without indicating whether he would approve or disapprove it.

Brooklyn teams dropped both ends of the Catholic school non-league basketball double-header in Madison Square Garden yesterday as St. Michael's High of Union City, N.J., vanquished St. John's Prep, 21 to 14, after Xavier High of Manhattan had routed St. Augustine's High, 38 to 12.

PHILADELPHIA, March 4. -- Mrs. Cornelia Bryce Pinchot, wife of former Governor Pinchot, conferred with political leaders here today on plans for entering the contest for the Republican nomination for Congress in the fifth district, which lies in Northeast Philadelphia.

TOKYO, Thursday, March 5 (AP). -- A declaration attributed to Joseph Stalin that the Soviet Union would strongly resist any Japanese attack on Outer Mongolia was characterized today by a Foreign Office spokesman as "a bluff made now because Japan is absorbed in internal troubles."

TRENTON, March 4. -- For the first time Isidor Fisch, the man, since dead, from whom Bruno Richard Hauptmann says he got the Lindbergh ransom money, was placed near the scene of the kidnap murder by a witness whose signed statement today was in the hands of Governor Harold G. Hoffman.

LOS ANGELES, March 4 (AP). -- A man who said he was Dr. Leonard K. Hirshberg, 59 years old, was held tonight on a fugitive warrant. Officials here said they were notified that he was wanted on a charge of defrauding Mary P. Nason of Binghamton, N.Y., of $10,000 in securities.

The Power Memorial Academy and New York Cathedral Prep quintets became the first teams to gain the quarter-final bracket in the seventh annual metropolitan Catholic high schools championship last night in the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, gymnasium. Each advanced at the expense of a Brooklyn opponent.

New York WPA workers will be reduced by 10,000 during March and by 40,000 by the end of June, Victor Ridder, local WPA director, announced yesterday in Washington, after an hour's conference with Works Administrator Harry L. Hopkins. At present there are about 240,000 on the WPA rolls here.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., March 4 (AP). -- Dust storms, whipped up by high east winds in the Oklahoma Panhandle, skipped across the northwest tip of Texas today and laid a heavy pall over the Pecos Valley and the eastern plains of New Mexico.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- After Senator Dickinson, who is a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, had set off today's Senate debate by reading in soft tones a prepared address, Senator Robinson jumped to his feet and declared:

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The President started operation of the Norris Dam in the Tennessee Valley by pressing a key at the White House; sent to the Senate the nomination of Lamar Hardy to be District Attorney for the Southern District of New York, and, with Mrs. Roosevelt, was guest tonight at the annual dinner given in their honor by members of the Cabinet.

With play in the singles at a standstill for the day, Gregory Mangin of Newark and John Van Ryn of East Orange and Philadelphia led the field into the semifinals of the national indoor tennis doubles championship yesterday at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

Work will be begun immediately on the construction of a twelve-story and penthouse nurses' home and school for St. Luke's Hospital north of the hospital building between West 114th and West 115th Streets at an estimated cost of $1,200,000.

BOSTON, March 4. -- Captain Fred Moseley led Harvard to victory in the third and deciding game in the twenty-eighth annual hockey series with Princeton before a small crowd of 3,000 fans at the Boston Garden tonight. The score was 3 to 2.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The controversy raised last November when President Roosevelt appointed Lamar Hardy as attorney ad interim for the Southern District of New York was revived today, when the recess appointment was sent to the Senate in the form of a nomination for confirmation.

Meyer and Harry Luckman and Fred J. Hull, who were convicted of murder in the second degree for slaying Samuel Drukman, were taken yesterday morning from the Raymond Street jail in Brooklyn to Sing Sing prison to begin serving terms of from twenty years to life.

Miss Marion Lloyd of the Salle d'Armes Vince, former national champion, won first honors in the fencing competition for the Mildred Fish medals at the Fencers Club last night. With the event closed to senior fencers, six outstanding contestants competed.

Awards of $1,618,114 for Sheepshead Bay properties acquired by the city in connection with the widening of Emmons and Neptune Avenues in Brooklyn were made yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP). -- Forecasting a drastic shake-up, the Federal Reserve Board announced tonight that on April 30 it would terminate the services of the chairmen of six regional banks in line with procedure intended to avoid "dual executive responsibility" at the twelve Federal Reserve banks and to place the chairmanships upon a "purely honorary basis."

PRINCETON, N.J., March 4. -- A small audience of subscribers witnessed a private showing of two one-act plays written by undergraduates presented by the Princeton Theatre Intime tonight in the Murray Theatre. An adaptation of the Book of Job was also given.
PARIS, March 4. -- Urgent action looking toward ratification of the Franco-Soviet pact in the French Senate was decided upon today by the Foreign Affairs Committee of the upper house.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The first major reaction to President Roosevelt's day-old proposal to levy a tax averaging 33 1/3 per cent on undivided profits of corporations was a proposition discussed by a Ways and Means subcommittee today to offer a special tax inducement to corporations to build up reserves to cushion themselves against the shocks of future depressions.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The National Labor Relations Board today ordered the Fashion Piece Dye Works, Inc., of Easton, Pa., to cease and desist from employing detectives to watch employes seeking to exercise the rights guaranteed under the Wagner Labor Relations Act.

CANTON, Ohio, March 4. -- Pohala's Blossom's Speedwell, pointer owned by Mrs. S.R. Spencer of Suffield, Conn., and shown for the first time in any ring by Mrs. P. Hoopes, won the special for the best pointer today at the opening of the second annual dog show of the McKinley Club.

GENEVA, March 4. -- There were important but general and inconclusive Anglo-French conversations here on the European situation, it is stated authoritatively, before Foreign Minister Pierre-Etienne Flandin of France left for home today and Anthony Eden, the British Foreign Secretary, and Joseph Paul-Boncour, French delegate to the League of Nations, went to Paris, whence the former plans to fly to London tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Orders to cut WPA rolls have been given by Harry L. Hopkins, Administrator, to all State WPA directors in order to reduce the number on work-relief jobs to about 3,000,000 by July 1, it was revealed today. Some officials believe that many of those dropped will be hired by private industry in its seasonal pick-up, but some probably will become dependent on local relief.
FRIEDRICHSHAFEN, March 4. -- Builders' statistics on the new LZ129 are as follows:

AT ITALIAN FIELD HEADQUARTERS, Adi Quala, Northern Ethiopia, March 4. -- With every army Emperor Haile Selassie had in Northern Ethiopia annihilated beyond any possibility of reorganization, the Italian forces prepared today for a more or less indefinite period of consolidation.

BERLIN, March 4. -- The Boerse was firm today, although, as usual, activity was strictly limited. Heavy industrial and electrical shares resumed the leadership of the underlying armament boom in all industrial securities.

BALTIMORE, March 4 (AP). -- A charge that by fostering an "economy of scarcity" the New Deal had destroyed millions of jobs was made tonight by Colonel Henry Breckinridge in an address before the Association for the Defense of the Constitution.

LONDON, March 4. -- The speeding-up of Britain's naval construction all along the line was foreshadowed today by Viscount Monsell, First Lord of the Admiralty, when he submitted estimates for the new fiscal year totaling u9,880,000 more than those of a year ago.

CHICAGO, March 4. -- May wheat showed relative strength again today on the Chicago Board of Trade compared with the new crop futures, although the spreading between the near-by month and the July was far less than yesterday. Aggregate trade was not large.
AUSTIN, Texas, March 4 (AP). -- The first official State Mother-in-Law Day in the country will be celebrated by Texas tomorrow.

TRENTON, March 4. -- The Republican State Chairman, Henry W. Jeffers, charged Governor Hoffman today with a "direct violation of the law" by appointing to county boards of election persons other than those recommended by him.

Senator LA FOLLETTE, creator and chief of the Progressive party, has consented to the New Deal rather grudgingly and frostily. It is far too niggardly for him. In Providence Sunday he poured ice water on the "temporary and ill-planned projects" that seem so grandiosely expensive to Tories and niggards.
WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Engineering contracts totaling $449,168.03 were awarded by the War Department today to the following companies:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 4. -- Ten Harvard faculty members have received grants for research from the Harvard University Committee on Research in the Social Sciences, as a result of a recent gift of more than $200,000 from the Rockefeller Foundation for use during five years.
Bankers have been invited to submit bids on next Wednesday for a new issue of $1,026,000 of primary road refunding bonds of Dallas County, Iowa. The bonds will mature from 1937 to 1944.

PARIS, March 4. -- Attention on the Bourse today was concentrated on rentes, which gave another astonishing display of their susceptability to being influenced. In the morning they fell nearly a full point to a price that by general accord is not in the least justified at a time when the French treasury has sufficient credit abroad to be able to borrow in London at half the rate it must pay in Paris.
ELIZABETH, N.J., March 4. -- The four Union County deputies on trial here for the killing last September of Mrs. Sophie Crempa, Scotch Plains farmer's wife, took the stand in their own defense today.

LONDON, March 4. -- Joseph Stalin's fiery benevolence toward the Outer Mongolian Republic, as expressed in his interview with Roy W. Howard, lent special significance to the showing at the Soviet Embassy tonight of a film record of big Red Army manoeuvers at Kiev last September.
WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The New Deal was extolled and condemned today on the occasion of its third birthday.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 4. -- George Bernard Shaw proclaimed himself today the most popular man in the United States, and then declared he was not a success by his own standards.
CINCINNATI, March 4 (AP). -- A church of the First Presbyterian congregation organized northwest of the Ohio River was being wrecked today.

Christian and Jewish leaders joined yesterday with officials of the women's division of the United Palestine Appeal in the campaign for $1,500,000 to be raised in this area for the benefit of Jewish settlements in Palestine.

The Republican National Committee has purchased, for distribution over the country, 200,000 copies of James P. Warburg's anti-New Deal book, "Hell Bent for Election," it was learned yesterday. More than a week ago Doubleday, Doran Co., the publishers, announced receipt of orders exceeding 200,000 copies, but at the time the purchaser was not named.

NANGKING, China, March 4. -- Presaging possible precipitation of a crisis of the first magnitude in China's domestic and international affairs, a Japanese Embassy spokesman affirmed today that "Japan is going to hold China to General Chiang Kai-shek's acceptance of Foreign Minister Hirota's three points."

Production of pig iron in February, according to The Iron Age, was the largest for the month since 1930, exceeding the output of February, 1935, by 13 5/8 per cent. Allowance in all comparisons should, however, be made for the extra leap year day in February.

LONDON, March 4. -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's personal report on the fast few days' happenings at Geneva is awaited by the British Cabinet with considerable tension. It is known in advance that he brings what to all practical purposes amounts to a French ultimatum to the British Government.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP). -- A mass meeting of 1,500 independent merchants, gathered from many sections of the country, applauded plans today to urge all members of Congress to back laws intended to stop alleged price discrimination in favor of chain stores.

Grace Moore made her first appearance in several seasons at the Metropolitan yesterday afternoon. She sang the role of Mimi in "La Boheme," in a special performance with Helen Gleason, Nino Martini, Carlo Morelli, Virgilio Lazzari, George Cehanovsky, Max Altglass and Louis D'Angelo. Mr. Papi con ducted.

The market value of stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange advanced $1,037,090,850 during February, according to figures issued yesterday by the Exchange. On March 1 there were listed 1,192 stock issues aggregating 1,322,819,505 shares having a total market value of $51,201,637,902.

MIAMI, Fla., March 4. -- The customary graded handicaps, offered each Wednesday at Hialeah Park, served as the chief attractions at the Miami Jockey Club's plant today. The featured Grade A event saw Edward F. Seagram's Biography taking the purse in little more than a gallop under Silvio Coucci.
WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Two States asked the Supreme Court today to sustain the Guffey Coal Act as the only means of regulating the soft coal industry, inside as well as outside, State borders.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The largest corporate issue ever filed for registration under the Securities Act of 1933 -- a $90,000,000 issue of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company of San Francisco -- was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The will of Mrs. Settie Lehman Fatman, widow of Morris Fatman and sister of Governor Herbert H. Lehman, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday, leaves most of her estate, believed to be worth about $3,500,000, to her two daughters. ]rs. Fatman died in her apartment at the Savoy-Plaza on Feb. 19.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., March 4. -- Clarence Doser of Rochester, N.Y., led sixty-one professional golfers into the final thirty-six holes of the $2,500 Hollywood open tournament today after an almost unprecedented exhibition of par-shattering golf.

The purchase of a plot at Fourth Avenue and Eleventh Street that once was part of the original farm of Peter Stuyvesant, peg-legged Dutch Governor of old New York, was sanctioned yesterday by Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe so that the government may build a branch postoffice there.

The Columbia University chapter of the Teachers Union announced yesterday through its executive committee that it "strongly" opposed participation by Columbia in the anniversary ceremonies of Heidelberg University in June.

The majority decision of the Court of Appeals invalidating the State's Minimum Wage Act is unfortunate for more than one reason. It means the destruction of a carefully drawn law, admirably administered, under which, for example, wages paid to more than 22,000 women and minor employes in the laundry industry in New York State have been raised from the previous appalling average of $10.41 a week to at least $13.42.

ALBANY, March 4. -- Assemblywoman Jane Todd and Charles J. Tobin, the latter representing the State Catholic Welfare Committee, came into conflict today at a public hearing on Miss Todd's two bills to liberalize the Divorce Law and halt hasty marriages.
The May choice of the Literary Guild is Trygve Gulbranssen's "Beyond Sing the Woods," which Putnam will publish next month.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP). -- With administration support, Senator Norris today beat back attempts to place new restrictions on his $420,000,000 Rural Electrification Bill and hoped to put it through the Senate tomorrow.

The Salvation Army will mail announcements today of its 1936 Citizens Appeal to 7,500 residents of the city, according to Chalmers Wood, chairman of the city-wide campaign. Intensive solicitation will begin next month to obtain a goal of $500,000.

In the discussion whether or not married women should hold jobs, there is a surprising lack of perspective. Unmarried girls blame their unemployment on the fact that married women take jobs; married girls indignantly reply that they have a perfect right to be useful and "express themselves."

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP). -- Class I railroads today arrayed legal and executive experts before the Interstate Commerce Commission in an effort to continue indefinitely emergency freight charges estimated to yield $104,500,000 annually.

LOS ANGELES, March 4. -- The reported theft of naval secrets and their sale to a foreign power were the subject of a Federal grand jury investigation begun here today. Two American youths were in custody and a search was being made for Orientals suspected of complicity in the alleged plot.

The National Peace Conference made public yesterday a protest to President Roosevelt and the Congress against the government's increasing military and naval expenditures for armament which it called "unprecedented in peace-time history," and an appeal for "the complete coordination and cooperation of army and navy and the aviation forces."

The contest between opposing factions for a controlling position in the management of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, which culminated at the annual meeting last September with the removal of Colonel J.S. Hammond as chairman, was brought to a close yesterday when Hemphill, Noyes Co. reported that they had acquired the stock holdings of Colonel Hammond.

The aggregate investment in the New York World's Fair, for landscaping, construction and exhibits, by the time the gates open on the Flushing Meadows in 1939, was estimated at $45,000,000 yesterday by George McAneny, president of the fair company.

Yesterday saw the positively last appearance of a famous date in our national history and political life. It was the last March 4 to which anybody will pay attention, with the exception of historians writing about the past.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 4. -- Four members of the 1936 American Curtis Cup team -- the Misses Patty Berg and Marion Miley and Mrs. Maureen Orcutt Crews and Mrs. Opal S. Hill -- were victors in their first-round matches of the Florida East Coast golf championship today.

MEMPHIS, March 4. -- Tentative plans to reduce the intensively cultivated acreage devoted to cash crops throughout the United States by about 30,000,000 acres, in return for Federal benefit payments of $440,000,000, were sent farm leaders here today by Agricultural Adjustment officials in Washington on the eve of a series of regional conferences at which the new soil conservation program will be worked out in detail.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP). -- Copyright laws which would recognize that no property is more peculiarly a man's own "than the labor of his mind" were urged today before the House Patents Committee.
WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Promulgation of new regulations pertaining to the administration of Federal taxes on gifts was announced today by Guy T. Helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue.

The first fatality to result from the building-service strike occurred early last night when a special guard assigned to a twelve-story apartment house at 151 Central Park West was crushed to death in a freight elevator. The police reported that death was accidental.

Only last June Dr. ALEXIS CARREL informed us that, thanks to a mechanical heart and lung devised by Colonel LINDBERGH, he had for days kept alive in glass such extirpated animal organs as hearts, kidneys, livers and spleens. So we are prepared for the statement of Dr. WILLIAM B. KOUNTZ that he and Professor ANREP have achieved a somewhat similar success with human hearts.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., March 4. -- Charlie Lee, Negro chauffeur for President Theodore Roosevelt and Mrs. Roosevelt, whose family he had served for thirty-two years, died yesterday of a stroke in the cottage he occupied at Sagamore Hill.

After another conference lasting from 1 P.M. yesterday to 4 A.M. this morning, negotiations between building owners and leaders of the strike of elevator operators and other building service employes ended in a deadlock as the strike entered upon its fifth day.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Timing himself with a stop-watch held in his left hand, President Roosevelt pushed a gold telegraph key at 2 P.M. today to begin operation of the great Norris Dam in the Tennessee Valley.

Distribution of spot cotton from the producers' pool eased near months on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, but trade buying created resistance on limited recessions and a late recovery left the list a point higher to 4 points lower than on Tuesday. Beneficial rainfall in Eastern Texas failed to extend into dry western sections of either that State or Oklahoma, where Winter moisture has been deficient.

Senator ASHURST, chairman of the Judiciary Committee, stated yesterday that in view of the protests received by him against the nomination of Mr. LAMAR HARDY as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, hearings will be held before action on the nomination is recommended to the Senate.
WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Senator Borah in his statement today on President Roosevelt's corporation tax proposal said in part:

PHILADELPHIA, March 4. -- "The eternal mystery of the world is its comprehensibility," Albert Einstein states in an 11,000-word article on "Physics and Reality" in the current number of The Journal of the Franklin Institute, published today.

The present code of traffic regulation, "designed for the horse and buggy days" of the city, will be replaced at an early date by a revised system, permitting an increased speed limit and progressive traffic lights, it was disclosed yesterday at the seventh annual Greater New York Safety Conference in the Hotel Astor.

Ed Wynn, stage and radio comedian, appeared before Supreme Court Justice Shientag and a jury yesterday in a serious mood. He was defending suits for $115,000 brought by his uncle, Samuel Greenberg, and the latter's wife, Ruth, for services they said they had rendered in caring for the comedian's wife. Hilda Keenan Wynn.

The important feature of the Wolf Award is its stimulation to sound thinking about merchandising possibilities of packages, Martin Ullman, designer, declared yesterday at the Wolf Award luncheon at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Irwin D. Wolf, vice president of Kaufman Department Stores, Inc., and donor of the awards, presided.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The North Pennsylvania Railroad Company was authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to extend the maturity of $1,500,000 of first mortgage bonds from May 1, 1936, to Jan. 1, 1953, to bear interest during the extended period of 3 1/2 per cent.
MOSCOW, March 4. -- The government issued a decree today drafting men and women inhabitants of villages and farms throughout Soviet Russia for work on a vast roadbuilding program.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP). -- The National Association of Manufacturers today attacked the Wheeler-Rayburn bill to expand the Federal Trade Commission's investigative powers as "one of the most enormous and unprecedented extensions of power which has ever been embodied in proposed legislation."

DONALSONVILLE, Ga., March 4. -- President Roosevelt today won his first test of strength against Governor Talmadge in a special Presidential preference primary in Seminole County. The primary was called by the county's Democratic executive committee.

LONDON, March 4. -- Armament shares weakened today in trading on the London Stock Exchange as a result of second thoughts on the government's defense program. Renewed demand sprang up for British Government securities, but otherwise the market was irregular.
Value of Dollar in Exchange. The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows.

The injunction proceedings against the Fashion Originators Guild of America by William Filene's Sons Company, Boston, and a meeting yesterday afternoon between John Burke, president of B. Altman Co., and Maurice Rentner, chairman of the guild, which yielded "no progress," dispelled hopes of an early termination of the controversy between the guild and retailers on extension of the guild's style-protection program to dresses wholesaling below $10.75.

LONDON, March 4. -- Armament shares weakened today in trading on the London Stock Exchange as a result of second thoughts on the government's defense program. Renewed demand sprang up for British Government securities, but otherwise the market was irregular.
Value of Dollar in Exchange. The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows.

The injunction proceedings against the Fashion Originators Guild of America by William Filene's Sons Company, Boston, and a meeting yesterday afternoon between John Burke, president of B. Altman Co., and Maurice Rentner, chairman of the guild, which yielded "no progress," dispelled hopes of an early termination of the controversy between the guild and retailers on extension of the guild's style-protection program to dresses wholesaling below $10.75.

LONDON, March 4. -- In a dramatic struggle which held a large Queen's Club gallery spellbound for more than an hour, Miss Anne Page of Philadelphia joined the rest of the American team on the sidelines in the British squash racquets championship today.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Chief enforcement officers of forty-three States have organized to make 1936 the "toughest year in history" for the "lunatic fringe" of automobile drivers responsible for most traffic accidents and deaths, it was announced here today.

GENEVA, March 4. -- The League of Nations Committee of Eighteen met today and set its two experts' committees to work again, the one to draw up a concrete plan for applying an oil and tanker embargo against Italy in case of need and the other to consider the tightening of the existing sanctions in several minor ways.
ALBANY, March 4. -- A bill to permit bars in theatres in New York City was introduced today by Assemblyman Herbert Brownell Jr., New York Republican.

No par common stock of the National Department Stores Corporation was admitted yesterday to the list by the New York Stock Exchange, and common and first preferred shares of National Department Stores, Inc., were suspended from dealings.

Adverse weather conditions throughout the country, combined with the usual seasonal decline after the turn of the year, forced wholesale sales and collections in January and February to the lowest levels in several months, according to the February survey of the National Association of Credit Men.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- In some of the criticisms of the President for transmitting to Congress the revenue-raising suggestions of the Treasury there is once more to be observed that partisanship, that lack of consistency and logical process, which are peculiar to the human race.

LONDON, March 4 (AP). -- A middle-aged German lawyer-writer, accused of espionage upon Great Britain's air force, heard documents read in Old Bailey Court today tending to implicate him in spying on American air forces during the World War.

The plans of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, to expand the university's educational plant in the metropolitan area, received a setback with the announcement yesterday that Seth Low Junior College, Brooklyn unit of Columbia, would be discontinued after June, 1938.

The McBurney School basketball team routed the Riverdale Country Day School quintet, 43 -- 24, at the latter's gym yesterday. Jack Padden contributed fifteen points for the victors, who led at half-time, 18 -- 13.

THE TIMES published yesterday the text of the White Paper stating the British case for rearmament The British Government does not accept the theory that large armaments necessarily mean safety; it says, in fact "that a general raising of levels all around is no guarantee of peace."

BERLIN, March 4. -- Mgr. Cesare Orsenigo, Papal Nuncio to Germany, again protested to the Foreign Ministry against the treatment German Catholics are receiving. Previous protests are understood to have received only perfunctory or evasive replies.

SAN PEDRO, Calif., March 4. -- United States District Attorney Peirson Hall said today he had asked the Attorney General's office in Washington whether he should seek indictments charging the striking crew of the liner California with mutiny and obstructing the United States mails.

LONDON, March 4. -- The British program of rearmament as outlined in yesterday's White Paper will be approved next week in the House of Commons by a vote showing the full strength of the Conservative party behind the government. But some who will vote for it as a party measure will criticize it in debate on a motion for its rejection that is to be presented by the Labor Opposition.

The report of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company for 1935, issued yesterday, shows a net profit of $5,452,240 after all charges for interest, discount and minority equities in the earnings of its subsidiaries. This compares with a net profit of $4,553,964 in 1934.

The WPA's Experimental Theatre got under way last evening up at Daly's Theatre, on West Sixty-third Street. The first item on a dossier that is to include plays that may not be sound commercially but nevertheless deserve a showing was "Chalk Dust," by Harold A. Clarke and Maxwell Nurnberg.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 4. -- In the patio of their villa, Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Hasler entertained today with a tea dance for a hundred guests.

The desire of consumers in some districts to take advantage of the present shaded prices for steel products has prompted the placing of heavy orders for March rolling. This, according to the weekly summary of The Iron Age, is partly responsible for a further rise in steel ingot production to 56 per cent of capacity, an increase of 1 point over last week.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Fighting for a place in the Stanley Cup play-offs, the New York Americans will engage the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League contest at Madison Square Garden tonight. It will be the fifth meeting of the campaign between the teams.

Witnesses appearing before the "citizens' jury," set up to inquire into the causes of disorder at a meeting of unemployed and WPA workers in Madison Square last month, objected yesterday to several phases of the administration of relief which they contended led to the recent disturbance.

With many delivery boys learning to save energy by summoning customers downstairs by telephone to receive their orders, fewer delays in handling deliveries of food, milk and other essentials were reported yesterday by companies serving the strike areas.

Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, warned the laundry industry yesterday not to reduce wages of women pending an appeal to the United States Supreme Court from the 4-to-3 decision of the Court of Appeals holding the Minimum Fair Wage Law unconstitutional.

Sabotage and assaults decreased yesterday as striking building workers tried, instead, to demonstrate their strength by parading in columns of two through affected areas. The police halted the processions everywhere without injuring marchers.

There is no startling novelty in the idea of taxing a corporation surplus. It has been proposed many times. The elder Senator LA FOLLETTE turned longing eyes in that direction. Representative O'CONNOR says that he introduced bills to that end ten years ago. Most of the projected measures have broken down on the question of the proper size for a surplus.

WICHITA, Kan., March 4 (AP). -- Kansas Republicans threw their full weight today behind Governor Landon for the party's Presidential nomination, pledging to him the State's eighteen delegates to the Cleveland convention.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Ears grow longer, the nose a little longer and distinctly broader, and the mouth widens with the years, changing materially the appearance of the individual, according to Dr. Ales Hrdlicka, curator of physical anthropology of the Smithsonian Institution, who has taken measurements of thousands of men and women including white "old Americans," Pueblo and other Indians, Eskimos and Negroes.

ALBANY, March 4. -- Backed by Mayor La Guardia, a bill was introduced in the Assembly tonight that would enable New York City to create a municipal Power Authority to establish its own public utility services without pledging the credit of the municipality.

ROME, March 4. -- The Italo-Austro-Hungarian feast being held in Rome this month reached the hors d'oeuvre stage today with the arrival of Prince Ernst yon Starhemberg, Austrian Vice Chancellor. As his visit is unofficial, he was received without any particular ceremony, only Fulvio Suvich, Under Secretary for Foreign Affairs, and Baron Pompeo Aloisi, delegate to the League of Nations, and the Austrian Legation staff being at the station to greet him.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 4 (AP). -- Litigation between Joseph F. Cannon and his former son-in-law, F. Brandon Smith of Charlotte, who recently sued him for alleged alienation of Mrs. Smith's affections, was settled out of court today.

The largest railroad refunding operation to which the public has been invited to subscribe in the last five years will be announced today in the offering of a new issue of $60,344,000 of first lien and refunding mortgage 3 3/4 per cent bonds of the Virginian Railway Company and due on March 1, 1966.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- First action against Major Gen. Johnson Hagood for his criticism of WPA "stage money" was taken, it was revealed today, on Feb. 11, by Aubrey Williams, Acting WPA Administrator, who wrote to Secretary Dern that such statements could not be ignored, and suggested that General Hagood make a public apology.
The Louisville Nashville Railroad has reported a net income of $487,140 for January, against $218,588 in January, 1935.

ALBANY, March 5. -- Governor Lehman made clear tonight that he was maintaining a hands-off policy on the strike of building service employes in New York City. Under State law, the Governor said, he could intervene only upon the request of Mayor La Guardia.

Announcement by the Governors of the Federal Reserve System that they would terminate the services of six Federal Reserve Bank chairmen, including J. Herbert Case, chairman and Federal Reserve agent of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, was received here yesterday with surprise and regret by bankers.

The building service strike spread northward yesterday from 155th Street to the Harlem River, including all of Washington Heights, and then continued on to take in Harlem. In other parts of the city the situation was unchanged.

The American Red Cross has sent word to all its chapters that it is faced in our own country with responsibilities and needs which exceed its available resources. It therefore has made a special appeal for contributions to be dispatched to the international committee for the assistance of the Ethiopian Red Cross in the emergency in which it finds itself.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation has agreed, subject to the approval of the Interstate Commerce Commission and the courts, to lend $3,000,000 to the trustees of the Western Pacific Railroad Company for rehabilitation purposes, and to take $1,000,000 of equipment trust certificates of the Erie Railroad, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the RFC, stated today.

Increases in commodity prices in the last week were somewhat greater than losses, and The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices recovered slightly, rising to 125.0 on Tuesday from 124.7 (revised) the preceding Tuesday.
Brooklyn College and the Crescent-Athletic Hamilton Club scored in the semi-final round of the Metropolitan A.A.U. basketball championship at the St. George Hotel last night.

LONDON, March 5. -- Naval experts of the United States, Britain, France and Italy agreed today to forbid the building of any capital ships smaller than 17,500 tons during the lifetime of the new naval treaties.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., March 5. -- A tall, soft-spoken pro from Deal, N.J., 24-year-old Vic Ghezzi, coasted home today the winner in the $2,500 Hollywood open golf tournament.

Reflecting the activities of dealers in government securities in connection with the new Treasury financing, the total of brokers' loans, as reported by member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City, rose $101,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a new high level of $1,031,000,000.

The largest single group of Jewish refugees to reach this country from Germany, 200 men, women and children, arrived yesterday on the United States liner Washington as quota immigrants. They were admitted as permanent residents on the basis, in most cases, of avowals giver by relatives here that none would become public charges.

Harry F. Wolf of the New York A.C., defending champion, moved into the semi-final round of the national amateur squash tennis championship at the Yale Club yesterday by registering a straight-game triumph over W.K. Rice of the Harvard Club.

Following is the text of a statement by Secretary Wallace concerning plans for putting into effect provisions of the new Soil Conservation and Domestic Allotment Act, as read simultaneously yesterday at regional farm conferences in Chicago and Memphis:

The American Locomotive Company reported yesterday in its annual statement for 1935 a loss of $1,421,289 after depreciation, Federal capital stock taxes and other charges, after $50,182 income represented by appreciation in the market value of securities previously written down.

Herb Welch of Haines Landing, a village on the shores of Mooselookmeguntio Lake in the Rangeleys of Maine, has been dazzling the tyro rod wielders at Grand Central Palace with his exhibitions of fly casting in the big tank. The 57-year-old, gray-haired Welch is one of the most interesting personalities at the Sportsmen's Show.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- More than 700,000 WPA workers will be dropped from their jobs before July 1, Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, declared late today just before the fourth, and probably most important, conference on relief needs for the fiscal year 1937.

There will be a stout legal battle over the right of a Senate committee to take possession of and use for its own purposes certain promiscuous Western Union telegrams. The intent was plain enough. Senator BLACK and his subcommittee suspected that officials of utility companies had sent compromising dispatches when the Holding Company Bill was pending.
LONDON, March 5 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

Prices moved narrowly and interest was nominal yesterday in the commodity futures markets here. In the cash markets cocoa, sugar, eggs, tin, cotton and rubber advanced, while wheat, rye, oats, butter, silk and lard moved down. Other items were unchanged.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- The next step in the government's silver policy, Secretary Morgenthau indicated today, may be the negotiation of buying agreements with South American countries by which the United States Treasury would purchase practically all of the newly mined product of the countries with which agreements were made.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Reports and recommendations made by five of the seven committees appointed by George L. Berry, Industrial Coordinator, have been sent to members of the Industrial Council who will meet here next Thursday to discuss the findings.

Primo Carnera, the huge Italian battler who once held the world's heavyweight championship, will test the fighting qualifications of Isidore Gastanaga of Spain tonight when the pair collide in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden.

The following film programs, which will be shown over the weekend, have been endorsed by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of faculty members and parents of children in public and private schools:

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- It is not yet clear whether the Republicans in the coming campaign will attempt to make major capital of the vindictive spirit the administration has often shown toward its critics and of the frequent charges that Federal functions have been used for reprisal.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Submission by the Treasury today of a distasteful alternative to President Roosevelt's proposal to levy a high tax on undivided corporation profits as a substitute for existing corporate taxes, and thereby produce $620,000,000 in permanent additional annual revenue, was believed to have given a decided impetus to the President's suggestions.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 5. -- Mr. and Mrs. Grover Whalen will leave tomorrow for New York after passing a month with Mr. and Mrs. William Theodore Hoops at Casa Eleda. They gave a dinner tonight at the Everglades Club in honor of their hosts.

A move to unify the theatre managers and producers against the new minimum basic agreement of the Dramatists Guild of America was revealed yesterday with the dispatch of a letter to all producers requesting that they pledge themselves against reading or buying manuscripts submitted by members of the guild.

Good Counsel High of Newark, winner of the honors last year, and St. Michael's High of Union City, N.J., led the way into the quarterfinals, as the second round of the seventh annual Metropolitan Catholic High School basketball tournament was completed at the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, clubhouse in Brooklyn, last night.
U. S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:
ADDIS ABABA, March 5. -- A British ambulance unit at Alamata, near Quoram, was bombed yesterday morning by an Italian plane. The damage was serious, three patients being killed.

Supreme Court Justice McGeehan denied yesterday the application by Attorney General Bennett for a temporary injunction restraining the Associated Gas and Electric Company and seventeen affiliates from selling Associated System bonds to their employes.

The suit brought by the Harlem Market Company, Ltd., to restrain Mayor La Guardia and other city officials from allegedly coercing Harlem produce merchants into moving into the municipally owned Bronx Terminal Market was dismissed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Collins.

CANTON, Ohio, March 5. -- The award for the best dog in the show as the second annual exhibition of the McKinley Kennel Club closed tonight was won by the Newfoundland, Champion Waseeka's Sailor Boy, owned by Miss Elizabeth B. Loring of Ashland, Mass., and shown by Tom Gately, professional handler of Hempstead, L.I.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 5. -- Brooklyn's quartet of holdouts today was reduced to a trio when Jimmy Bucher ceased demanding another contract and returned his signed papers to Secretary John Gorman.
PARIS, March 5 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:

ATLANTIC CITY, March 5. -- Fifty million mosquitos will be indelibly "dyed" red, green, yellow, blue and brown in the Chicago area next Summer so entomologists may study their flight range and plan the elimination and control of the pest accordingly.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., March 5. -- The Rev. Dr. Archey D. Ball was "asked" today not to return as minister of the First Methodist Episcopal Church of Englewood when his term expires next month because his "liberal" preaching and advocacy of social reform was resented by the conservative leaders of his congregation.

Described by H.B. La Quatte, president of the club, as a man who had done a "business job in a political office," Governor Frank D. Fitzgerald of Michigan told members of the Advertising Club of New York at a luncheon meeting yesterday at the clubhouse, 23 Park Avenue, how he had balanced his State's budget in one year.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 5. -- Both the State and the defense rested today in the trial of four Union County deputy sheriffs for the killing last Fall of Mrs. Sophie Crempa, Scotch Plains farmer's wife. The woman was shot on the porch of her home during a raid by the Sheriff's men, who were attempting to serve a Chancery Court contempt warrant on her husband, John Crempa.

Beethoven's Eighth and Ninth symphonies made up the program of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under Arturo Toscanini at Carnegie Hall last night. Verdi's Requiem had been planned, but the illness of Dusolina Giannini caused the change.

Declaring that hundreds of defaults of unguaranteed first mortgage bonds could have been avoided if underwriting in the past had been hedged with effective safeguards, the joint legislative committee to investigate bondholders' and other committees, trustees and fiduciaries urged yesterday in its third report to the Legislature the creation of mortgage banks as a preliminary safeguarding measure.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas rose 10 per cent for the week ended Feb. 29, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The increase, one of the largest for any weekly period thus far this year, compares with a gain of 3 per cent for the preceding week.

BANGOR, Me., March 5. -- Fred D. Jordan, publisher of The Bangor News, started a campaign two months ago to obtain employment for idle men and women who are not on relief and do not desire to accept relief and are thus excluded from government work.

MIAMI, Fla., March 5. -- Songmaker, a gray gelding that changed ownership twice at this meeting, scored a surprise victory in the first division of the St. Johns Purse, a one-mile test for 3-year-olds that was split into two sections today at Hialeah Park.
BALTIMORE, March 5. -- The text of the speech of Secretary Hull here tonight before the Young Democratic Clubs of Maryland was as follows: ...
ALBANY, March 5. -- Governor Lehman's budget and tax bills were advanced today to third reading in the Assembly with indications that they would come up for final action Monday.

BERLIN, March 5. -- The Movement, the official organ of the National Socialist Student League, appeared today with a furious attack on Heidelberg romanticism. The article is apparently the Nazi student chieftains' contribution to the dispute over the university's projected celebration of its 550th anniversary.

There is a great deal of unclarified thought current on the subject of colonies. We frequently meet with the contention, ably maintained notably by Sir Norman Angell, that, whether as an outlet for excess population or as an access to raw material, the possession of colonies is not of much determining consequence.

Efficient banking at New York has reason for deep regret at the Reserve Board's failure to reappoint Mr. J.H. CASE to the post of chairman and Federal Reserve Agent at the New York Reserve Bank. Mr. CASE has occupied official positions in the bank since 1917, when, as deputy governor, he took general charge of the multitudinous details in the Liberty Loan campaigns.

LONDON, March 5. -- King Edward spent three hours today aboard the Queen Mary in a seven-mile tour of the giant liner and then plunged into some of the worst Glasgow slums, where he found conditions that he branded "appalling," and where he assured an awed little boy of his identity.

OTTAWA, March 5 (Canadian Press). -- Deposits by the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada decreased $4,483,018 in the week ended yesterday and deposits by chartered banks increased by $356,676, the bank's weekly statement said today. The statement follows:

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Federal courts were "warned" today by Senator Black against enjoining the delivery of documentary evidence to a Senate committee. The Lobby Committee chairman on the Senate floor declared that should any court grant such an injunction, Congress should immediately enact legislation depriving the courts of such power.
Strikers' activities in the building service workers' walkout reached a low point yesterday. There were only forty-six calls for radio patrols up to nightfall, including calls from practical jokers.

Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey, speaking at a luncheon of the Broadway Cheese Club at the Hotel Astor yesterday, said that the fate of Bruno Richard Hauptmann was unimportant in comparison to finding the solution of the Lindbergh kidnapping and murder case.
ALBANY, March 5. -- Republicans in the Assembly demanded broad amendment of the Unemployment Insurance Law today while admitting the futility of their demand in the face of Democratic opposition.

Federal funds which are being spent for the Tenessee Valley Authority are not flood control, soil reclamation or navigation, but actually to place the United States Government in the power business, Wendell L. Willkie, president of the Commonwealth Southern Corporation, declared last night in a defense of the public utility companies' broadcast over the NBC system.

ATHENS, March 5. -- King George tonight broke up a dangerous meeting at the War Ministry of leaders of the anti-Venizelist military league by summoning their leader, Minister of War Papagos, to the palace and demanding his resignation and that of Under-Secretary of War Plakis.

A rebuke for extreme militarism, reassurance for foreign powers and comfort for financial circles in Japan to be found in Emperor Hirohito's naming of Koki Hirota as Premier of Japan and again in Mr. Hirota's own selections for posts in the Cabinet.

BERLIN, March 5. -- The National Socialist Reichstag will convene in extraordinary session in Berlin on Friday, March 13, and Chancellor Adolf Hitler will make his long-awaited declaration on German foreign policy. The date of convocation, it was learned, was decisively influenced by the ratification of the Franco-Soviet pact by the French Chamber of Deputies and its impending acceptance also by the French Senate.
Following were the developments yesterday in the strike of elevator operators and other building service employes:

TOKYO, Friday, March 6. -- Accepting yesterday an imperial command to form a Cabinet, Koki Hirota, Foreign Minister in the last two Cabinets, quickly announced most of his appointments. Those thus far made are:

LONDON, March 5. -- Sir John Simon, Minister for Home Affairs, admitted today in the House of Commons there was Jewish persecution going on in the East End of London, which he attributed to the Fascist movement. He further declared that this was potentially very dangerous and said that extra police precautions were being taken to put an end to these outrages, which were becoming numerous.

GENEVA, March 5. -- The League of Nations gave out a telegram tonight from Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia accepting its appeal that peace negotiations be opened but sharply conditioning acceptance on respect for the League covenant.

The new board of governors of the Federal Reserve System has not yet got around to considering such problems as the $3,000,000,000 of excess reserves that has worried commercial bankers, but it has shown a good deal of energy in "shaking up" the personnel of the system.

Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, Chancellor of New York University, declared yesterday that the university probably would not be represented at the University of Heidelberg's 550th anniversary celebration in June. He outlined his attitude in the following statement:

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Approximately 92 per cent of the amount due, or $39,973,270, in dividends on $702,007,353 of preferred stock which the Reconstruction Finance Corporation bought in banks and trust companies, and 90 per cent, or $18,004,885, of the amount due as interest on capital notes and debentures of such institutions which it holds have been paid regularly, Jesse H. Jones, chairman, said today.

LONDON, March 5. -- There was a special meeting of the Cabinet tonight to hear the report of Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, who returned from Geneva this afternoon and will return there Monday for the meeting of the League of Nations Conciliation Committee of Thirteen.

Recovering all the previous day's loss as selling pressure lifted, prices on the Cotton Exchange ended yesterday unchanged to 7 points higher than on Wednesday. An upturn in Liverpool, in contrast with Wednesday's decline here, widened the differences between the two markets, and a feature of the day's trading was the purchase of July against sales abroad.

The market value of bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange appreciated $276,708,944 in February. The Exchange announced yesterday that on March 1 there were 1,462 bond issues with a par value of $43,015,263,454 having a total market value of $40,624,571,422, compared with $40,347,862,478 on Feb. 1.

Unless the long deadlock in the New Jersey Legislature over methods of financing relief is ended by March 15, the whole burden of supporting the 300,000 persons on relief rolls will be shifted upon the municipalities, it was announced yesterday by Albert H. Hedden, New Jersey relief director, at Trenton.
SHANGHAI, Friday, March 6. -- Koki Hirota's appointment as Premier of Japan has caused genuine surprise in Chinese official circles at Shanghai and Nanking.

As the play in the Eastern championships at contract bridge neared its climax yesterday at the Hotel Commodore the defending champion quartet of Sydney Rusinow, A. Mitchell Barnes, B.J. Becker and Sam Fry Jr. led the other surviving team of four by 1,520 points at the half-way mark of the final session in the play for the Curt H. Reisinger Trophy.

Responding to the appeal from abroad of Dr. Chaim Weizmann, president of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, for funds to aid Jewish refugees in various parts of Europe, leaders of the United Palestine Appeal opened a campaign here yesterday to raise $1,500,000 for that cause.

Threats to call out unions of workers in various trades in sympathy with the building service employes, and caustic criticism of District Attorney William C. Dodge, characterized a meeting of the Central Trades and Labor Council of Greater New York and Vicinity at Beethoven Hall, 210 East Fifth Street, last night.

The biggest expansion in advertising in more than a decade will follow enactment of President Roosevelt's proposed taxes on corporation surpluses, advertising executives here agreed yesterday. Harking back to the early 1920s, when heavy excess profits taxes were imposed, they said that companies spent large sums for advertising in order to bring down the amount on which such taxes could be levied.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended March 4, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,478,000,000, a decrease of $4,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $19,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1935.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP). -- The Supreme Court was asked today to decide whether man and wife are one or two taxpayers when they file a joint return.

The demand for stocks yesterday was selective in character, which is perhaps another way of saying that many sections of the list failed to advance. During most of the day the trend was uncertain, and at the close of trading prices were irregularly higher.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- The Federal Trade Commission today entered an order against the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company of Akron and its subsidiaries to "cease and desist" from discriminating in price in favor of Sears, Roebuck Co., thereby allegedly driving many independent dealers out of business and tending to create a monopoly.

MEXICO, D.F., March 5. -- It is not the province of the Mexican Government to provoke anti-religious campaigns, President Lazaro Cardenas told a meeting of school teachers last night at Guadalajara. Teachers from every section of the State of Jelisco attended the meeting.

Four properties in Manhattan and a similar number in the Bronx were taken over by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales yesterday. Dwellings and tenement houses formed the bulk of the auctioned realty.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Mayor La Guardia's proposal for establishing a landing field five minutes from the Battery by taking over vacant space on Governors Island was presented to the House Military Affairs Committee today and met strong opposition from the army.

Because of the feeling against German goods noted on the part of retailers in England, the Houndsditch Warehouse Company, Ltd., one of the largest wholesalers in department store lines in England, is now buying in the United States the goods which it formerly purchased in Germany, it was stated yesterday by P. Halperin, head of the company, which has annual sales in excess of $10,000,000.
ALBANY, March 5. -- The text of Governor Lehman's special message to the Legislature today is as follows:

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- President Roosevelt formally became a candidate for re-election tonight. A White House announcement stated that he had signed primary petitions which will place his name on the ballots in Maryland, Massachusetts and Ohio.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- A sudden decision by the government to transfer to States and municipalities the responsibility for acquiring land for slum clearance and low-cost housing projects became apparent today when the Department of Justice, without previous warning, obtained a Supreme Court dismissal of two condemnation cases arising in Louisville and Detroit.

The Insurance Company of North America reported yesterday that the value of its assets on Dec. 31 was $96,762,181, compared with $83,321,023 a year before, while surplus to policyholders rose to $54,324,419 from $41,668,673 in the year. Stocks and bonds at the year-end were held at $82,628,271 and on that date had a market value of $85,869,807.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- George M. Cohan played a one-day stand before a House committee today, testifying among other things that he was "a handy man to have around" when it came to writing patriotic songs and adding an explanation of how he happened to write the war-time hit "Over There."

A more-than-seasonal rise of $73,000,000 in the total of money in circulation in the country was reported for the week ended on Wednesday, in the Federal Reserve statements issued yesterday. This increase of circulation over the first of the month was chiefly responsible for a decline of $26,000,000 in member-bank reserves and a reduction of $20,000,000 in excess reserves to $3,040,000,000.

LONDON, March 5. -- At the completion of the semi-final round of the British squash racquets championship today at the Queen's Club the chances of the American team for victory in the international match on Monday looked decidedly bad.

While the National Sportsmen's Show continued to attract capacity crowds to Grand Central Palace yesterday, Sheldon H. Fairbanks, the promoter, was busy interviewing prospective exhibitors from all parts of the country and planning a more elaborate 1937 show.

Trading in United States Government obligations yesterday again was the feature in bond dealings on the New York Stock Exchange. Persistent demand for the long-term Treasury issues carried them to new high levels on a turnover of more than $2,000,000.

DETROIT, March 5. -- The severe type of silicosis is gradually disappearing from industry, Dr. A.J. Lanza, assistant medical director of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, told the American College of Physicians here today. A milder type is common among workers, he added.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- The Eastern Gas and Fuel Associates of Boston filed today a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $75,000,000 of first-mortgage and collateral trust bonds, Series A, 4 per cent, due on March 1, 1956, the proceeds from which will be devoted chiefly to refunding purposes.

The American Radio Telegraphists Association announced yesterday that it had undertaken nation-wide fight on Senate bill 3954 introduced by Senator Copeland, which is intended to promote safety of life at sea through revised regulations for the use of radio.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- A sharp decrease in the index of wholesale prices in the week ended on Feb. 29 was noted today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The bureau's index, based on 100 as the 1926 average, decreased to 79.9 from 80.8. A year ago the figure was 79.6.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed the reserve note circulation and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date.

Details of the plan under which 40,000 WPA workers in New York City will be dropped not later than June 15 were made public yesterday by Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, who said 12,000 were scheduled for dismissal in the next three weeks.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Denying applications that the material be held confidential, the Securities a d Exchange Commission made public today salaries paid and other data submitted to it by seven corporations in registration reports.
PARIS, March 5 (AP). -- Confident their request for exemption from the usual delays of French marriage laws would be granted, Douglas Fairbanks Sr. and Lady Ashley tonight planned a quick wedding.

District Attorney William C. Dodge announced yesterday that he had warned James J Bambrick and George Scalise, leaders of the building service strikers, that if they said or did anything in the future to encourage violence or destruction of property by members of their union or sympathizers, prosecution would follow.

BERLIN, March 5. -- The boerse today resumed its tendency toward weakness combined with listlessness. As the market has reversed itself every second day recently, its vagaries are regarded by the business community as of little consequence, however, and the underlying armament boom in all industrials is still regarded as the dominant financial factor.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- President Roosevelt signed primary petitions for entering the contests in Massachusetts, Maryland and Ohio and conferred on relief budget needs with Harry L. Hopkins and other persons.

James J. Bambrick, president of the Building Service Employes Union, in a radio address last night over Station WEVD, said the union was appealing to individual owners and the general public in an attempt to overcome the "arrogant defiance" of the Realty Advisory Board and to bring about an early settlement of the strike.

As far as the New York Americans are concerned, Larry Aurie could have postponed his return to action to some time other than last night. For the scrappy little forward for the Detroit Red Wings, appearing in his first game since an injury relegated him to the sidelines on Feb. 18, played a large part in leading his team to a 4-to-1 triumph over Red Button's harassed skaters at Madison Square Garden.

LONDON, March 5. -- Both the Labor and the Liberal sections of the Opposition in Parliament have composed their resolutions disapproving the government's rearmament plan, which is to be debated on Monday. Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin will open the proceedings with a motion that the House of Commons endorse the defense proposals that the Cabinet set forth in its White Paper on Tuesday.

This week's boom in first-nights wanders to a close this evening at the Mansfield with "The Fields Beyond," or life in the home of a Midwestern college president. With a bow to the Drama Critics Circle, the curtain will rise at 8 P.M. and find Reed Brown Jr., Merle Maddern and Helen Claire in the leading roles.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 5. -- Members of Harvard's Pi Eta Club were still wondering tonight who would be the chorus girls in the club's annual musical show.

Twice coming through by the slim margin of a single match, the Fencers Club retained its national senior foils team championship by turning back the Salle d'Armes Wince, 5 -- 4, at the Fencers Club last night in the final.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 5. -- When the president of the Killers' Club walked out of the Michigan City "pen" to visit his home in the Loop district and, incidentally, to kill the political boss who sent him up eight years before, he created a situation that ran for three acts at the Shubert Theatre tonight along novel stage lines in Robert Ardrey's comedy, "Star Spangled," at a well attended premiere.

The French liner Normandie has been altered in several respects during her Winter lay-up with a view to improving her qualities of navigation and the comfort of her passengers, it was announced yesterday.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 5. -- An aggravated case of hold-out with a mystery proved the live topic today in the Yankee camp as rain just about ruined the daily training workout.

A purchase offer of $1,376,282 made to the State Superintendent of Insurance by the Aetna Casualty and Surety Company for three title companies now in the superintendent's hands, was submitted yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Brower in Brooklyn for approval.

With their 121 apartment houses more than 92 per cent rented and no unpaid taxes, the 4,500 investors in the F-1 $28,000,000 issue of guaranteed mortgage certificates sold by the New York Title and Mortgage Company received assurances yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler of increased income for this year, when the court took under advisement the accounting by the trustees, Aaron Rabinowitz, James L. Clare and Lawrence N. Martin.

Bank clearings in the twenty-two principal cities in this country for the week ended on Wednesday amounted to $6,062,379,000, compared with $5,947,995,000 for the same period of last year, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The gain of 1.3 per cent compares with one of 8.9 per cent in the preceding week, which was of five days.

Savings banks officials of the American Bankers Association opened their annual Eastern conference yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria with a program of addresses and discussions directed toward the problem of savings bank investments of today and tomorrow.

Newtown High School's basketball team moved out in front in the Queens Division P.S.A.L. race by handing Grover Cleveland High its initial setback to the tune of 24 to 22 yesterday in the Newtown gymnasium. Prior to their meeting, Cleveland was setting the pace with seven victories in as many league contests.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 5. -- A Yale junior promenade planned along the social traditions that date as far back as the gay Nineties was tonight informally launched with the arrival of many of the "prom girls" and their chaperons. The formal round of events will not begin until tomorrow, when the promenade itself will be held.

MEMPHIS, March 5. -- Agricultural leaders representing more than two-thirds of the commercially cultivated farm lands of the country were gathered today in regional conferences here and at Chicago to learn for the first time officially what was expected of them under the new soil-conservation program to qualify for Federal benefits estimated by AAA spokesmen at $470,000,000 a year.

Professor EINSTEIN'S example might be taken to heart by public speakers. He received a gold medal from the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia last May but, to everybody's astonishment, made no speech on that occasion.

Miss Sue Slough of Cincinnati, a student in Teachers College, has been chosen to play the leading feminine role in "Off Your Marx," 1936 Columbia varsity show. Women students will take part in the annual production for the first time since the shows began in 1893.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Many of the subscriptions for the Treasury's latest issue of bonds and notes were not bona fide or had been padded, Secretary Morgenthau announced today. Only the subscriptions regarded as legitimate, however, will be considered, the Secretary stated.
Investment buying of apartment properties featured realty activity in the Bronx yesterday.

ROME, March 5. -- Prospects of Italian acceptance of the League of Nations peace appeal appeared less bright today. Yesterday it could be said that the chances were more in favor of acceptance than of refusal.
