Today, although it is not yet possible to say the reverse, nevertheless the sentiment in favor of refusing has gained ground.

BOSTON, March 5. -- Seven New England radio stations refused tonight to broadcast a speech by Earl Browder, general secretary of the Communist party in America. Instead, they broadcast the music of a Boston dance program.

A Communist proposal that men and women throughout the country join in forming a Farmer-Labor party to break the "rule of Wall Street" was presented last night by Earl Browder, secretary of the Communist party of the United States, in a speech from 10:45 to 11 o'clock over WABC and a network of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

NANKING, China, March 5. -- China not only has not agreed to accept the three points Koki Hirota, Japan's never Premier, enunciated recently for stabilizing Chino-Japanese relations, but she cannot decide her attitude until Japan has officially greatly amplified and clarified their implications and explained what detailed application of them would mean.
LONDON, March 5. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange were firm in quiet trading today. Investment buying of British Government securities continued despite increased competition from new loans.

The letter from T.J. Kehoe describing the merits of the Fort Peck Dam brings to light many commonly accepted fallacies in regard to the causes and control of floods in the Mississippi Valley. Competent engineers have devoted years to studies of the Mississippi River and its tributaries and they are not all in complete accord as to the best solution of the various problems.

CHICAGO, March 5. -- May wheat, which has been leading the upturn of prices for that grain on the Board of Trade, turned reactionary today, while the new crop months developed relative strength. Buying of July against sales of the May by operators who were taking profits on recent spreading operations narrowed the difference to around 10 cents a bushel at the close, against 11 cents on Wednesday.

A five-point program of health insurance for the American people was advanced last night by Dr. Michael M. Davis, director of the Julius Rosenwald Medical Service Fund of Chicago, speaking at the America's Town Meeting program at Town Hall, which was broadcast over an N.B.C. hook-up.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 5 (AP). -- The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences awarded gold statuettes tonight to Victor McLaglen and Bette Davis for the best screen performances of 1935, and selected "Mutiny on the Bounty" as the best picture.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- The Senate passed the Norris Rural Electrification Bill today without a record vote, after its author had offered amendments limiting its scope to which he announced the administration was agreeable. The measure was sent to the House.

It is increasingly clear that the chief obstacle to a settlement of the building service strike is the demand for a closed shop. The union has offered to submit this question to arbitration, along with all other matters in dispute. The refusal of the realty companies to make the closed shop a subject of arbitration is warranted.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP). -- Asserting a "small scandal now was better than a big stench later," Senator Vandenberg tonight proposed a nation-wide investigation of reports that politicians were collecting campaign funds from relief workers.

With a scarcity of snow in the metropolitan area, devotees of the sport of skiing are expected to flock to the Adirondacks, Berkshires, Poconos and the White and Green Mountains, where snowy slopes and excellent skiing terrain beckon them.
Realty organizations and landlords generally reported yesterday that rent collections were normal and that they were having no difficulty with tenants because of the building service strike.

LONDON, March 5 (AP). -- A German accused of espionage in England, Dr. Hermann Gortz, took the stand in Old Bailey today and described what he called his "great success" in questioning American, French and British fliers on the western front during the World War.

BOSTON, March 5 (AP). -- The presidents of Harvard University and of Smith and Tufts Colleges urged the Legislature today to repeal a Teachers' Oath Act which compelled their faculty members to swear fealty to Federal and State Constitutions.
RKO Radio's film of Phil Stong's "The Farmer in the Dell," featuring Fred Stone and Jean Parker, opens today at the Palace.

A conference on "Does Art Education Prepare for Living?" will be held today and tomorrow at the Arts Guild, 309 East Thirty-fourth Street. The meetings have grown out of a preliminary conference held in November and attended by representatives of students and faculty in eleven Eastern colleges.

ALBANY, March 5. -- Reinstatement of William R. Hayward as principal of Theodore Roosevelt High School in New York City was ordered today by Dr. Frank P. Graves, State Commissioner of Education. Dr. Graves directed that a new trial be given to Mr. Hayward, who was suspended from duty on Feb. 18, 1935, on charges that he had misapplied pupils' deposits on school books.

Style is steadily becoming a more important factor in the marketing of American-loomed wool pile carpets and rugs, according to opinions expressed at the annual dinner of the Floor Covering Advertising Club at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night.

Assemblywoman Jane Todd deserves a world of credit for her courageous divorce reform fight. Is it not high time that our outmoded divorce laws should be amended to be more in keeping with modern experience and thinking?
Two business buildings occupying important sites in the midtown section passed to new control in deals announced yesterday.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- By a margin of one vote, the Senate decided today against changing the existing dual system of assessing tolls on ships going through the Panama Canal. The situation arose when, on a roll-call vote, a substitute amendment by Senator Bailey calling for an investigation instead of immediate change in the system prevailed by 35 to 34.
WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Secretary Perkins, clad in an evening gown, settled by telephone last night the strike on an inter-coastal liner at San Pedro.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 5. -- Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis, 18-year-old medalist, and Mrs. Maureen Orcutt Crews of Miami, defending titleholder, continued their victorious march in the quarterfinals of the Florida East Coast golf championship for the new Mrs. William R. Kenan Jr. Trophy on St. Augustine links today.

The city Health Department emergency service for strike-stricken apartment houses has been extended to the new strike areas in Harlem and Washington Heights, Health Commissioner John L. Rice announced late yesterday afternoon.

In the week ended March 1 there were 310 automobile accidents in New York City, which resulted in ten deaths. This compared with 484 accidents and seventeen deaths in the corresponding week of 1935. The record for this year's week seems comparatively encouraging.

CHICAGO, March 5. -- The demand for hogs here today was less active and the market steady to 15 cents a hundredweight lower, although some sales were regarded as 25 cents lower compared with the best on Wednesday. The easiness occurred in the face of an advance of 1/2 to 1 cent a pound in fresh pork loins, which were quoted at 16 1/2 to 20 cents, wholesale.

LOS ANGELES, March 5. -- The 15-year-old Teapot Dome scandal, which linked the names of Edward L. Doheny and Albert B. Fall, was raked up anew today when the government filed a claim for $5,188,721.77 against the Doheny estate. In twelve tersely phrased pages the document reviewed the history of the scandal.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 5. -- Despondent because he had given the information leading to the arrest of Luis Carlos Prestes, alleged leader of the radical revolt last November, Victor Allen Barron, 27 years old, an American, committed suicide here today by throwing himself from the second floor of police headquarters.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 5. -- More than 200 student delegates from twenty-nine colleges in the Middle Atlantic States assembled at Vassar College today to test their understanding of international relations by conducting a model League of Nations tomorrow and Saturday in the manner of Geneva.
" Die Meistersinger" was the opera for the last but one of the special Wagner matinees yesterday in the Metropolitan Opera House

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 5. -- Federal authorities today moved to stop the lawless Nationalist movement, headed by Pedro Albizu Campos, allegedly designed to overthrow the United States insular government. The Nationalist leader and six of his closest associates were arrested and later freed, each on a $10,000 bond.

The city of Brockton, Mass., yesterday obtained a rate of 0.239 per cent on a new issue of $500,000 of notes, awarded to Leavitt Co. The notes are dated March 6, and become payable on Nov. 24 and Dec. 4.

Net income of the Burroughs Adding Machine Company and subsidiaries for 1935 was reported yesterday as $5,113,528 after allowances had been made for depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges. This was equivalent to $1.02 each on 5,000,000 no-par shares of capital stock.

An atmosphere of tranquillity surrounding the national indoor tennis championships was abruptly dispelled yesterday as the procession of the elect was challenged, with heavy repercussions, at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

The Pacific Eastern Corporation and its subsidiaries, the American Company and the Pacific American Company, Ltd., reported yesterday net assets of $36,311,082 on Dec. 31, equivalent to $6.49 a share on the capital stock outstanding on that date, compared with $25,296,723, or $4.44 a share on Dec. 31, 1934. The company is an investment trust controlled by the Atlas Corporation.

FRIEDRICHSHAFEN. Germany, March 5. -- The new Zeppelin LZ-129 was in radio connection today with two wireless stations on the North American coast during her second trial run, which lasted seven hours and forty-five minutes. She established the clearest connection with the Canadian station at Chatham and exchanged greetings.
Modern streamlined automobiles were condemned yesterday at the Greater New York Safety Conference as possessing many hazards which are building up the accident rate "in an alarming manners."

Miss Katherine Gould, chairman, and Miss Virginia Brown gave a tea yesterday afternoon in the Rainbow Room Lounge, Rockefeller Center, for members of the committee arranging the dinner dance to be given March 24 in the Rainbow Room for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the Bennett Junior College, Millbrook, N.Y.

The situation in Tokyo is beginning to clarify. For nearly a week we saw unroll a spectacle combining tragedy, drama, melodrama, mystery. It was like being present at a play compact of motives alien to our world and acted in a foreign language of which only a few words here and there could be seized.

THERE was once a discussion on track matters in the Penn A. C. -- it was during the running of the Penn Relays -- and Joe Labrum of Penn asked how long Tom Keane had been coaching the track squad at Syracuse.

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 5. -- With the clearing of skies and the receipt of advance information that the treatment of Bill Terry's damaged left knee in Memphis had turned out an unqualified success, there came today a noticeable acceleration in the pace of the Giants' training activities.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 5 (AP). -- Mae West and the Paramount studio jointly accused each other of voiding her movie contract today. Out of a welter of conflicting statements, only one fact seemed clear -- that she would make her next picture for another company.

With the collapse of Mayor La Guardia's efforts to settle the strike in apartment and office buildings, the walkout resolved itself yesterday into a contest of endurance between the Building Service Employes Union and realty interests.

MOSCOW, March 5. -- An unusually friendly interchange took place today between Ambassador Tamekichi Ota of Japan and Maxim Litvinoff, the Foreign Commissar, when the former visited the Foreign Office to convey the Tokyo government's assurance that recent events in Japan would not affect Soviet-Japanese relations.

ALBANY, March 5. -- Governor Lehman sent a special message to the Legislature today recommending the passage of a measure particularly directed against the "higher ups" of organized crime in addition to those included in his law enforcement program, which has been before the Senate and the Assembly since early in January.

CHICAGO, March 5. -- A decision that responsibility for the New Deal administration with its "mistakes" and "extravagances" must be put on the shoulders of President Roosevelt was made today by Republican leaders of fifteen Central West States, meeting in conference here.

Two convicted racketeers, taken from the penitentiary to stand trial as loan sharks, suddenly pleaded guilty to extortion and coercion in General Sessions Court yesterday after eleven witnesses had testified they had been forced to pay the men exorbitant sums on small loans under threats of death.

BALTIMORE, March 5. -- A plea for currency stabilization in terms calculated to encourage favorable foreign reaction to that end, coupled with an assertion of the necessity of permanent monetary arrangements and a balanced budget, was made by Secretary Hull in an address before the convention of the Young Democratic Clubs of Maryland here tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 5 (AP). -- Mae West and the Paramount studio jointly accused each other of voiding her movie contract today. Out of a welter of conflicting statements, only one fact seemed clear -- that she would make her next picture for another company.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, March 6. -- Imperial headquarters today issued a comprehensive denial of Italian reports of Ethiopian defeat and chaos on the northern front, pointing out that such reports were published coincidently with the meetings of the Geneva Committees of Eighteen and Thirteen.

The executive committee of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society issued a statement following a meeting yesterday, declaring that there was "no foundation whatever" for the "impression" that the appointment of William Furtwaengler as general musical director of the society "has a national or racial significance."

The need for unity among consumers in supporting the demands of organized labor, for higher wages and shorter hours in the hosiery industry was stressed by speakers at a luncheon meeting yesterday at the Women's City Club, 22 Park Avenue. The meeting was held under the auspices of the Women's Trade Union League and the American Federation of Hosiery Workers.
Following are the buildings covered by the agreement signed yesterday between the Building Service Employes Union and the Prudence Company:

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 6. -- Hope that something soon might develop toward bringing about a settlement in the case of Hank Leiber vs. the New York Giants was expressed here today when Manager Bill Terry, returning to camp after his two-day sojourn in Memphis, disclosed that he had sent a wire to Phoenix, Ariz., urging his errant outfielder to report at once.

No funds for the 1939 World's Fair will be forthcoming from the present Legislature, according to opinion in informed quarters yesterday. If the fair is to become an actuality, its basic improvements will have to be financed entirely by the city, it was believed.

The directors of the Federal Reserve Banks of New York and Boston have elected George L. Harrison, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, a member of the Federal Open Market Committee for the year beginning on March 1, it was announced yesterday at the Reserve Bank.

Several tumultuous ovations and numerous curtain calls testified to the emphatically favorable impression made by Bruna Castagna in her first assumption of the role of Azucena in Verdi's "Il Trovatore," at the Metropolitan Opera House last night.
PARIS, Saturday, March 7. -- Foreign Minister Pierre-Etienne Flandin, who will return to Geneva Monday, gave a resume of France's difficult foreign situation before the Cabinet yesterday.
WESTON, W. Va., March 6 (AP). -- Teresa Hawkins slept restfully tonight after an operation intended to stop a laughing attack which has continued for nine days.

MONROE, Conn., March 6. -- Lazarus Heyman, associate judge of the Danbury City Court, will be arraigned Monday in Trumbull Town Court for speeding, Prosecutor Alfred D. Gion said today. It is his twelfth arrest for motor vehicle violation since 1925 and his sixth for speeding, according to police records.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 6. -- The veteran of the Yankees' training camp is the hardest worker in the squad. His name is Lou Gehrig, the lone link between the old and the new in Yankee Spring camps, starting his twelfth year in Colonel Jacob Ruppert's livery.

Old-timers of the boots and saddle era of a generation ago paused a bit wistfully yesterday at the doors of the Riding Club in West Sixty-sixth Street to watch an occasional horseman emerge for a canter in Central Park.

A police system functioning without the aid of fingerprints, radios and other modern innovations could not be expected to cope successfully with modern crime. There is a precise analogy between this hypothetical situation and a situation actually existing in State law.

The seventh annual metropolitan Catholic high schol basketball tournament reached the semi-final round last night, with St. Augustine's registering one of the biggest surprises thus far in the competition when it upset the strong St. Michael's five of Union City, N.J., 33 -- 22.

The proprietor of a liquor store at 175-25 Jamaica Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, shot and fatally wounded one of two hold-up men who, according to the police, invaded his store at 11:30 last night. Before his death at the Mary Immaculate Hospital, Jamaica, about an hour later, the wounded man identified himself as Walter Horn, 24 years old, of 134-04 Thirty-fifth Avenue, Flushing, Queens.

The Works Progress Administration here posted regulations yesterday under which the 40,000 WPA workers who are to be dropped by June 15 will be permitted to seek private employment. Meanwhile the relief workers' organization protested against the impending cut. The WPA announcement follows:

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- A 150- word bill, which imposes heavy fines upon any person or corporation attempting to influence the votes of its employes through "fear or intimidation," was hailed by administration leaders today as an eventual addition to the political armament of the New Deal.

The exhibition of paintings, prints, drawings and sculpture contributed by more than a hundred American artists for the establishment of an art collection for Biro-Bidjan, the Jewish Autonomous Territory in Russia, opened with a private view last evening in a large improvised gallery at 57 Fifth Avenue.
One of the missing historical Virginia court records which that State alleges was stolen and which it has taken steps to recover by legal means was found to be in New York yesterday.

The Broadway theatre loses three guests after this evening is over, the longest resident being "At Home Abroad," which departs from the Majestic and goes on tour. It gave 198 performances hereabouts, twenty-nine more than "Jubilee," leaving the Imperial, and 190 more than the Golden's "Three Wise Fools."
SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., March 6. -- Elections to Theta Chapter of Phi Beta Kappa at Mount Holyoke College were announced today by President Mary E. Woolley, who is herself a Senator in the society.

Exchange of checks at the principal clearing houses of the country in February amounted to $24,011,219,986. This was a decline of 12.8 per cent from the preceding month, but was 15.4 per cent above the total in February, 1935.

Prices of commodity futures were generally better in quiet trading yesterday. Sugar was a feature, advancing to new seasonal high prices on heavy purchases by refiners. In the cash market, cotton, silk, rubber and eggs were higher, while wheat, corn, oats, rye, flour, cocoa, butter, lard and tin were lower.
ROWE, March 6. -- The possibility that peace may grow out of the League of Nations appeal to Italy and Ethiopia appeared even less bright today than yesterday.

THE report from the Van Cortlandt region is that the Manhattan track team will follow the green line to victory in the I.C. 4-A indoor championships this evening. The Jaspers are the defending champions and have a good chance to repeat. But Cornell, Harvard and one or two other teams are not giving up until the points are counted.

Joseph T. O'Neil, the Staten Island insurance salesman who filed a designating petition to oppose former Governor Alfred E. Smith in the Spring primaries for delegate to the Democratic National Convention, was still in the fight last midnight when the deadline for declarations came at the office of the Board of Elections.
Auctioneers put up at foreclosure sales yesterday six tenement houses in Manhattan and two in the Bronx.

Harry F. Wolf, national amateur squash tennis champion for the last six years, and the man who preceded him as titleholder, Rowland B. Haines of the Columbia University Club, will meet once more for the crown in a match this afternoon at the Yale Club.

It has been customary to observe April 6 as Army Day, because it is the anniversary of our entering the World War. Would it not be well to change the date to avoid such an annual reminder of conflict with nations with which we are now at peace? Our people as a rule are not enthusiastic about celebrating wars, and especially the beginnings of wars.

Baron Amaury de La Grange, French Senator, and Baroness de La Grange; Sir Charles Mendl, attache of the British Embassy in Paris, and Lady Mendl are among those sailing today for Havre via Plymouth on the French liner Champlain. Others leaving are Kurt Jooss, Mr. and Mrs. C.F. Crandall, Charles Houssaye, Donald Lowrie, Dr. and Mrs. Homer Gage, Count and Countess Aymar de Dampierre, Mr. and Mrs. Howard Black, Dr. J.E. Gendreau and Maurice Duperrey.

Following seven highly eventful and successful days at the Grand Central Palace, the National Sportsmen's Show will climax its run today and is expected to establish a new record at the gate for this type of entertainment, according to its promoter, Sheldon H. Fairbanks.

Eight more ponies and the International Polo Challenge Cup constituted one more part of America's polo shipments to England yesterday when the American Banker of the American Merchant Line cleared New York for London. The mounts were the string which Stewart Iglehart plans to ride in the matches against England in June and the cup is the famous trophy first played for in 1886 to be defended by the Americans in London this Spring.

In the strange Alice-in-Wonderland world of modern mathematics, where parallel lines meet somewhere on the border of plus or minus infinity and the square root of minus one is very much of a reality, Albert Einstein has just slain a mathematical jabberwock, which had recently come out of its lair to give battle to relativity.

CHICAGO, March 6. -- Republican chiefs of the Midwest adopted plans today for a "Republican Volunteers'' organization, a general Republican club for the 1936 campaign "to send the party doctrines into every nook and corner of the land."

Primo Carnera, the huge Italian who once held the heavyweight championship of the world, stopped the Spanish battler, Isidoro Gasta naga, in the fifth round of a scheduled ten-rounder at Madison Square Garden last night.

Retail distribution reached the highest levels since last December in many sections of the country this week, gains being as much as 25 to 30 per cent over the previous week, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
TRENTON, N.J., March 6. -- Every trooper and officer in the New Jersey State police has been asked whether he has been approached by agents of Governor Harold G. Hoffman, it was learned today.
It was with a great deal of interest that I read the letters of Mr. Denenberg and Mr. Edwards on the question of our water supply, and I wish to state emphatically that I agree with the former.

The law passed last year by the State Legislature prohibiting employers from obtaining temporary injunctions against workers in labor disputes without a full court hearing of the case was turned against a union yesterday in a decision of Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins construing the law.

LONDON, March 6 (AP). -- Dr. Hermann Gortz quailed under the shadow of Nazi "higher-ups" at his trial for violating the British Official Secrets Act today and declared he dared not answer questions concerning them because he might be "tried for high treason in Germany."

What is termed the most comprehensive fine prints show ever arranged by the National Academy of Design will be held in conjunction with the 111th annual exhibition of the academy which will open to the public on March 18 at the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, and will continue until April 10.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 6. -- Two titled British women, Viscountess Hastings and Lady Marian Cameron, declared in an interview at their hotel today that they had been held there incomunicado since yesterday. Richard Gavin Freeman, a young man who they said had accompanied them from Britain to Brazil, was held at police headquarters.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 6. -- After deliberating nearly three hours a jury of twelve men returned a verdict of not guilty late this afternoon in the trial for man-slaughter of four Union County deputy sheriffs.

The share market was fairly buoyant most of yesterday and more than 100 issues established new high marks for the year and longer on the Stock Exchange as the steady demand more than offset profit-taking. Leadership was rotated, with the steels, motors, oils and various other groups in brisk demand at times.

Replying to the broadcast of Thursday evening in which Earl Browder, secretary of the Communist party in the United States, urged the formation of a national Farmer-Labor party, Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. last night denounced the activities of American Communists, rebuked spokesmen of the New Deal for what he classed as socialistic tendencies and voiced his support of Senator Borah for the Republican Presidential nomination.

Twelve hundred realty owners voted 100 per cent approval and support yesterday of the attitude of the Realty Advisory Board's committee in its recent meeting with the Mayor in refusing to arbitrate the question of the closed shop with striking building service employes.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art will place on exhibition this morning a newly acquired fifteenth century Italian painting, "The Birth of the Virgin," attributed to Fra Carnevale.

Rehabilitation of the exterior marble of City Hall will be undertaken shortly by the Municipal Art Commission in cooperation with engineers in the office of Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan, Mr. Levy announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- By a vote of twelve to two the Senate Military Affairs Committee decided today to report unfavorably to the Senate the Metcalf resolution demanding investigation of the removal of Major Gen. Johnson Hagood from command of the Eighth Corps Area. The committee held that an inquiry was not necessary.

DUBLIN, March 6. -- When the Dail Eireann came to the debate on the Financial Bill last evening the Deputies were surprised to learn that Deputy Frank MacDermott, who severed his connection with the Cosgraveites some months ago, had been conducting talks with members of the British Cabinet with a view to ending the Anglo-Irish dispute.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- A charge that President Roosevelt personally ordered abandonment of the slum clearance cases in the Supreme Court yesterday because the administration feared defeat of the constitutionality of the low-cost housing program was made today by Henry P. Fletcher, chairman of the Republican National Committee.

After using the metric system for three years, the I.C.A.A.A.A., at its annual convention at the Columbia University Club last night, voted overwhelmingly to go back to the yardage plan starting with the next indoor meet in 1937. The vote was 27 to 3, with one college, Haverford, not voting.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 6. -- Revealing the Administration's absolute reliance on the general welfare clause to protect the constitutionality of the new Soil Conservation Act, Secretary Wallace today startled an audience of more than 500 cotton farmer representatives with what they regarded as a virtual challenge to the Supreme Court to find it invalid.

BERLIN, March 6. -- The session of the Reichstag originally fixed for next Friday was tonight almost precipitately advanced to tomorrow, when that body will meet at noon to receive a pronouncement by the government on the foreign political situation.

The Consolidated Oil Corporation reported yesterday for 1935 a consolidated net income of $11,306,904, after expenses, interest, taxes, reserves for depreciation and depletion and other charges. This was equal, after preferred dividend payments, to 73 cents a share on the 14,218,835 common shares outstanding.

The 1935 American Hebrew Medal for outstanding service in promoting better understanding between Christians and Jews has been awarded to Roger Williams Straus by a committee of distinguished Americans, it is announced in the current issue of The American Hebrew.

Marketing of two large railroad issues lifted the total of new bond financing this week to $131,488,000, the largest volume since the week ended on Jan. 17, in which offerings were $148,366,000. Last week's total was $87,770,072. A year ago the offerings in the week amounted to $69,864,000.

The sixth day of the strike of elevator operators and other building service employes found both the Building Service Employes Union and the realty interests pitted against it settling down yesterday for a prolonged contest, with no effort from any quarter to bring the struggle to an end by collective negotiations.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- After one glance at the distasteful alternatives suggested yesterday by the Treasury, Democratic framers of tax legislation in Congress today began an earnest effort to refine President Roosevelt's proposal for a high levy on future undistributed corporate incomes, preparatory to a drive for its enactment.

I have noticed that a famous bit of silverware is to start across the ocean from this country to England. It is the International Polo Challenge Cup. This news is important because it marks the introduction of a new sporting angle in the polo relations between England and the United States.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission called today a hearing for 10 A.M. on March 20 on the application of the Balaban Katz Corporation to withdraw from listing and registration on the Chicago Stock Exchange 26,126 shares of 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock.

TOKYO, (Saturday) March 7. -- Yesterday was filled with unexpected events, the interpretation of which is not yet clear. The resignation, of Generals Senjuro Hayashi, Sadao Araki, Jinzaburo Mazaki and Nobuyuuki Abe from the Supreme War Council have been accepted and they have been placed in the first reserve -- that is to say, retired.

The report of the United States Rubber Company and subsidiaries for 1935, issued yesterday, shows a net profit of $2,231,377 after expenses, interest, provision for depreciation, taxes, contingencies and other deductions. This is equivalent to $3.43 each on 651,091 shares of non-cumulative, 8 per cent $100-par preferred stock.

The terms upon which the Prudence Company signed its agreement with the Building Service Employes Union at City Hall yesterday include an increase of $8 a month in wages, reinstatement of the 3,500 strikers and no discrimination for strike activities.
LONDON, March 6 (AP). -- Great Britain ordered the Ambassador to Rome today to protest strongly against the alleged bombing of a British Red Cross unit in Ethiopia by Italian planes.

Two musicales will be given in the near future in aid of the Jacob A. Riis Settlement House. The first will be held next Thursday afternoon at the home of Mrs. Lionello Perera, 49 East Eightieth Street, with a trio composed of Yella Pessl, piano; Lillian Fuchs, viola, and Lillian Rehberg, 'cello.

CHICAGO, March 6. -- Markets for hogs were erratic today. A good demand prevailed early at steady prices, but as soon as the buying became less aggressive prices eased 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight. The top price was $10.55, or 10 cents lower than on Thursday, while the day's average was off 10 cents at $10.

Criticism of the proposal of Louis A. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, to sell for $1,376,282 the New York Title Insurance Corporation and the Lawyers Title Corporation, subsidiaries of the mortgage companies of the same names, besides the Home Title Guaranty Company, to the Aetna Casualty and Insurance Company, was voiced yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler.

Wilmer Hines of Columbia, S.C., and Henry Culley of Santa Barbara, Calif., third ranking team of the country and aspirants for the United States Davis Cup doubles assignment, negotiated a particularly difficult hurdle in the national indoor championship at the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday when they defeated Dr. Lawrence Kurzrok of Brooklyn and Jack Pitman, young Yale graduate.

Sparse Gray Hackle is indignant at being called a reformed worm fisherman by your Wood, Field and Stream editor. He says that fishing editors use him for a whipping boy, even though, were it not for the copy which pours from his smoking typewriter, they might have to do many an honest (ha!) day's work.

Consolidated net income of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and subsidiaries in 1935 was $23,773,509, which was equal to $2.53 a share on the common stock after provision for preferred dividends had been made. In 1934 earnings for the common stock were $2.82 a share. The decline amounted to $1,579,442.
A rise in Egyptian cotton strengthened the Liverpool market and prices on the Cotton Exchange here improved 10 points yesterday to close 3 to 6 points higher than on Thursday.

Mae Scheible, described by Federal investigators as "vice queen" of New York and Pittsburgh, and Joseph P. Ryan, her alleged companion and business associate, were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury for conspiracy and violation of the Mann Act.

The force that Japan's army extremists unleashed in Tokyo last week turned back yesterday, with augmented volume, directly against the army itself. Directed by the Emperor, it wiped out at one stroke virtually the entire directing power of Japan's aggressive continental policy of the last five years, leaving in the active field only Major Gen. Kenji Doihara and his chief aide, Major Gen. Seishiro Itagaki.

NEW ORLEANS, March 8 (AP). -- Ridge Mor, 5-year-old son of Morvich, owned by F. Ianni, scored an upset today in winning the featured sixth race at the Fair Grounds track. Trailing the field for the greater part of the six furlongs, Ridge Mor passed Mrs. H.W. Stewart's Cruising and Mrs. E.B. Shipp's Irene's Bob coming into the stretch and won by a length in the good time of 1:12 4-5.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Just three days after the House Appropriations Committee refused President Roosevelt's request for a $12,000,000 appropriation to continue work on the trans-Florida ship canal, the Chief Executive gave an additional $200,000 in work relief funds to army engineers to continue construction.

The annual report of the International Business Machines Corporation puts net income for 1935, including foreign subsidiaries and branches at $7,090,530, after all deductions and Federal taxes. The earnings are equivalent to $9.88 each on 717,412 no-par shares outstanding, compared with $6,597,362, or $9.19 a share, based on an equal number of shares, and with $9.38 each based on 703,345 shares outstanding at the close of 1934.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., March 6. -- The Mad Hatter's Ball, first exclusive formal dance ever given by the sophomore class at Mount Holyoke College, will be held tomorrow night in Chapin Auditorium. Characters from "Alice in Wonderland" will provide the theme for the decorations.

Random notes of a Sportsmen's Show observer: The impressive exhibit of the New York Conservation Department reminds visitors that "this State has everything" for the sportsman as well as for the vacationist and tourist. It also tells the story of the State's work of more than fifty years of forest protection and care of the State forest preserve.

The Consolidated Gas Company of New York yesterday filed with the Public Service Commission of New York an application for approval of the issuance of $70,000,000 aggregate principal amount of debenture bonds, according to an announcement by the company.

AMSTERDAM, March 6. -- Julius Streicher's anti-Semitic Stuermer was burned during a mass meeting here last night organized by the Liberal State party as a protest against the distribution of this paper in the Netherlands by an Amsterdam news store circulating propaganda for the Netherlands National Socialist movement.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Several experimental airplanes flights that are expected to be made across the North Atlantic to the United States this Summer by the Compagnie Air France is a result of arrangements made today at a meeting of French representatives with the Interdepartmental Committee on Civil International Aviation of the United States.

Agencies for delivery of food and for messenger service reported yesterday they were prepared to handle any problems arising from extension of the building strike area. No special preparations were necessary, they said, but enough extra men were available for any emergency.

DETROIT, March 6 (AP). -- Many cases of sudden death in small children may be caused by hyper-sensitivity to ordinary foods, Dr. George L. Woldbott of Detroit declared today, instead of the thymus gland derangement to which they often are attributed.

Manhattan College will make a bold bid for its third straight indoor track and field championship of the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. at Madison Square Garden today in face of precedent to the contrary. Mindful of the fact that no team has ever triumphed thrice in a row, the Jaspers look upon their designation as favorites with anything but elation.

TRENTON, March 6. -- With representatives of twenty-one States east of the Mississippi present, the interstate conference on transients and settlement laws opened today in the Assembly Chamber at the State House here. Concluding sessions will be held tomorrow.
Violence and mass picketing in the building tie-up in Manhattan and the Bronx resulted in the attest yesterday of forty-eight men and twelve women.

ATHENS, March 6. -- A shift by the Communists from an independent position to one favoring the Venizelists gave Themistocles Sophoulis the Presidency of the Chamber of Deputies tonight over Charilandos Vozikis. The vote of 158 to 136 came after a session which caused federal soldiers to clear the public galleries.
LONDON, March 6. -- The heaviest expenditure on aviation since the World War is called for in the air estimates for the coming budget year submitted to the House of Commons today.

Enterprising executives of major league baseball clubs might find that they could increase attendance figures and the fan's enjoyment by hiring a few musicians to play before the game and between innings. At least it would be an interesting experiment to try -- an experiment that has been highly successful at college football and professional hockey contests.

Assistant starters are among the most criticized of race-track officials and I, who have grown up in the starting atmosphere, feel that the public should be acquainted with their problems and their contribution to racing.

As a defense of the Administration, Secretary HULL'S speech at Baltimore was perhaps the best yet made. This is because it was not extravagant. It was moderately reasoned. It did not claim everything, nor deny that mistakes had been made in the rush of emergency treatment.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 6. -- Two titled British women and a man, reported to have come here as a commission to investigate whether the revolt of last November was a Communist uprising are being detained by the police, the two women at their hotel, and will be deported immediately, the newspaper El Globo declared today.

Another fine residence in the Lenox Hill section was sold yesterday when the Cortlandt Field Bishop estate disposed of the five-story English basement dwelling at 15 East Sixty-seventh Street. The deal was arranged by Pease Elliman, Inc., who negotiated the sale of the Grayson M.-P. Murphy town house at 11 East Seventieth Street just two weeks ago.

A plan for reorganization of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Company has been proposed by the independent protective committee for holders of the Colorado Industrial Company first-mortgage 5 per cent gold bonds guaranteed by Colorado Fuel and Iron.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

LONDON, March 6. -- Prices strengthened on the London Stock Exchange today after a quiet opening. British Government stocks led the upward procession, while industrials were generally active and firm.
BOSTON, March 6 (AP). -- Senator David I. Walsh will run as a candidate for Democratic convention delegate pledged to President Roosevelt.
Housing deals made up the bulk of the New Jersey realty operations reported yesterday.

LONDON, March 6. -- The chief hope of the British Government concerning its European entanglements today is that it will be saved from further awkward and perhaps dangerous situations by a favorable answer from Rome to Geneva's latest proposal of a conciliation agreement between Italy and Ethiopia.

The City College administrative committee of the Board of Higher Education has denied permission to the student council to hold a referendum "on the subject of whether or not the president of the college should be removed or as to his fitness for the office."

Alexander Smith Sons Carpet Company of Yonkers, one of the largest rug and carpet companies in this country, asked the United States district court yesterday to declare the National Labor Relations Act unconstitutional in an injunction suit to restrain the Regional Labor Board from entertaining complaints against the company.

Whether you find the new, intimate, exotic (and all those things) night club of Josephine Baker too thrilling will probably depend on whether you absorb the legend of the erstwhile toast of Paris. To pretend that Miss Baker, circulating among the guests at her East Fifty-fourth Street Chez and bidding them all to be merry, is as glamorous as the legend implies requires a lot of concessions from the pretender.

STANFORD UNIVERSITY, March 6. -- Former President Herbert Hoover has written a semi-satirical, semi-philosophic essay, entitled "I Am a Fisherman," for the "Chaparral," Stanford University's, humorous magazine.

Sufficient 5 1/2 per cent debentures of Remington Rand, Inc., have been deposited to insure the effectiveness of the plan of exchange for the new 4 1/4 per cent debentures, James H. Rand Jr., president, said yesterday. He estimated that at least 75 per cent of the debentures would be deposited for exchange by Tuesday.

Warnings that in the search for new fields for the investment of deposits of savings banks there must be no repetition of the banking errors of the pre-depression days were sounded yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria at the concluding sessions of the twelfth annual Eastern savings conference of the savings division of the American Bankers Association.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Proposals of increased pensions for the widows and orphans of veterans whose deaths were not the direct result of their military service were "thinly disguised general service pension bills," Donald A. Hobart, National Commander of the American Veterans Association, told the House Committee on World War Veterans Legislation today.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Subscription figures and allotment bases for the Treasury's cash offering of 2 3/4 per cent bonds and 1 1/2 per cent notes, to be dated March 16, were announced today by Secretary Morgenthau.

The annual award of the Park Association of New York City for "outstanding service to the parks of the city" was presented yesterday to John D. Rockefeller Jr. at a luncheon of the board of directors of the association at the Luncheon Club in Rockefeller Center.

A mass meeting to protest Columbia University's acceptance of an invitation to attend the anniversary celebration at Heidelberg University in June will be held on the campus in front of Hamilton Hall Monday at noon.
WASHINGTON, March 6. -- The Senate Lobby Investigating Committee held two stormy public hearings today as it continued its inquiry into lobbying activities of public utilities companies.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 6. -- A working model of the League of Nations was opened at Vassar College today by 200 delegates from twenty-nine colleges in the Middle Atlantic States, for the declared purpose of finding out "what keeps it from being effectual."

Tomorrow being the second Sunday in Lent, many of the sermons in the city's churches will deal with the penitential season. In not a few churches there will be reception of new members and baptismal ceremonies. Several visiting Protestant Episcopal bishops will deliver sermons tomorrow and preach at daily Lenten services through next week.

BERLIN, March 6. -- Trading on the Boerse today ended soft and listless. Notable in the trading situation has been the market's refusal to respond, as expected, to the favorable production and sales reports of various large concerns. This possibly has been due to the Boerse's essentially artificial character caused by rigid supervision and ill-concealed control and possibly to the business community's skepticism.

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., son of the President, went down the bay yesterday afternoon on the United States Coast Guard cutter Manhattan from Floyd Bennett Field and boarded the Cunard White Star liner Carinthia to greet friends arriving from Nassau.

SHANGHAI, March 6. -- "We have evidence that Japan is busy fomenting a separatist movement in Fukien Province similar to that in East Hopei in order to create new embarrassment to Nanking and divert attention from developments in the northern provinces," it was specifically charged by a Chinese Government spokesman in Shanghai today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 6. -- The Yale junior promenade, danced tonight in Woolsey Hall by nearly a thousand couples, opened the series of festivities of the annual social week-end. The auditorium, devoted historically to Yale's commencements and formal mass meetings, was transformed into a ballroom, its dance floor bordered by boxes containing university officials.

Criticism of the President's proposal to tax corporations solely on their undistributed profits at a rate in the neighborhood of 33 1-3 per cent has rightly emphasized the great importance of these corporation surpluses as a "cushion" for maintaining dividends and employment during lean years.

It is impossible to understand and hard to forgive the misapprehension of the friends of Governor LANDON in Nebraska. They offered Mr. BORAH a compromise degrading to his high solitary virtue. If he would keep out of Nebraska, the Governor would keep out.

Charles S. Haight, admiralty counsel, urged shipping men and exporters yesterday to enter the fight on the side of the State Department for the extension of its program of reciprocal trade agreements, which, he said, is being opposed by strongly organized minorities.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 6. -- Mr. and Mrs. Cummins Catherwood of Ardmore, Pa., were honored by Mr. and Mrs. A. Atwater Kent at a tea today at Ocean View cottage. Nearly 150 persons were present.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP). -- A Presidential defense of Federal policies in school aid was accompanied today by a promise that "if and when" the government enters into a purely educational program it will be directed by educational agencies.

BERLIN, March 6. -- The German labor service army, for which every young German male is drafted for six months, now totals 182,370 men, including 20,000 of the permanent training personnel, according to a survey just issued by the Reich Statistical Office.

With Frank McGuire, who made 13 points, and Rip Kaplinsky leading the attack, the St. John's University five terminated its season last night by conquering the Providence College quintet, 43 to 34, before a capacity crowd at the De Gray gymnasium in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- The plan under which business men of Bangor, Me., cooperate in supplying jobs for the unemployed, started as a protest against Federal relief, was praised today by administration, Congressional and national business leaders here.

LONDON, March 6. -- A private members bill in the House of Commons to enable bars to keep open until midnight instead of closing at 11, o'clock was withdrawn today as a measure which could not possibly be enacted. There was not even the formality of a vote, but the debate gave the House one of its periodical humorous sessions and was chiefly a duel between Lady Astor and A.P. Herbert, playwright.
LONDON, March 6. -- The Marquess of Lansdowne, son of the Foreign Secretary during the first half of the Edward VII reign, died at his home here today of pneumonia at the age of 64.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Telegrams from the files of the Western Union, Postal Telegraph and other communications companies were obtained by the Senate Lobby Investigating Committee by "a subterfuge" to which the executive branch of the government, of which President Roosevelt is the head, was a party, it was charged tonight by Jouett Shouse, president of the American Liberty League, in a broadcast over a National Broadcasting Company network.

Production of steel ingots in the United States last month averaged 118,712 gross tons daily, 5 per cent above the 112,942 in January and almost 2 per cent more than the 115,740 in February, 1935, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 6. -- Prices of wheat on the Board of Trade dropped today to a new low mark on the current downturn as the result of free selling of futures, which trade comment attributed to professional traders, both local and in New York, who are now in Florida.

BUENOS AIRES, March 6. -- The government's offer of 30,000,000 pesos of short-term Treasury notes was oversubscribed by 20 per cent. Subscribers offered to take them at annual interest rates varying from 2 1/8 to 3 per cent.

Thirteen girls from Hunter College, in sympathy with the striking building service employes, picketed in front of 820 Park Avenue, where Governor Lehman has an apartment, a little after 5:30 P.M. yesterday. A half hour later seven other girls, wearing tin hats and carrying signs and double-barreled, toy pop-guns paraded in front of 925 Park Avenue, the home of F.C. Bellinger, lawyer and former soldier who had operated an elevator earlier in the strike.

CHICAGO, March 6. -- Word from Washington that processing taxes may be collected on livestock, grain and other farm products to help pay the cost of the New Deal's $500,000,000 Soil Conservation and Domestic Allotment Act impeded efforts today to create facilities for the administration of the new program in the central West.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP). -- A traffic policeman to give stop and go signals on the country's airways was installed today by the Department of Commerce.

The contract bridge team of Fred D. Kaplan, Charles Vogelhofer, Morie Elis and Irving Epstein won yesterday the Reisinger Trophy at the Eastern contract bridge championships in the Hotel Commodore after five days of strenuous play. They defeated Sam Fry Jr., B. Jay Becker, Sydney Rusinow and A. Mitchell Barnes, the defending champions, by 2,660 points at the end of the seventy-two hands in the final round.

ROME, March 6. -- Today's war bulletin announces that Italian troops have occupied the town of Corbeta, thirteen miles southeast of Mount Alaji. On the right wing other troops are reported on the march toward Fenaroa and Samre, respectively nineteen miles southwest and twelve miles southeast of Gaela, which in turn is about twenty-five miles southwest of Makale.

ADDIS ABABA, March 6. -- Major Gerald Burgoyne, a Briton, who was chief of the transport detachment serving three ambulances of the Ethiopian Red Cross, was killed during an aerial bombardment when Ras Kassa's forces were withdrawing east of Alaji, it was announced here today.

BUENOS AIRES, March 6. -- President Rafael Franco of Paraguay has telegraphed to the Presidents of Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Peru, Uruguay and the United States that Paraguay can not be held responsible if the failure of the neutral mediators to recognize the new de facto government of Paraguay allows the time limit for exchanging prisoners to expire on Sunday without their release.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 6. -- Starting with the current No. 1 man of his mound staff, George Earnshaw, and going right down the line with Clark, Frankhouse, Zachary, Leonard and Brandt, Manager Casey Stengel this afternoon took advantage of the returning sunshine to send his squad through the longest batting practice to date.

The pace-setting Jamaica High School hockey team defeated Brooklyn Tech, 2 to 1, last night in a Metropolitan Interscholastic Hockey League match at the Brooklyn Ice Palace. Manual Training upset Brooklyn Prep, 3 to 2, in the other game on the program.

LONDON, March 6. -- Responsibility was placed squarely up to Japan and Italy today to decide whether the maximum gun caliber of battleships shall be reduced from sixteen to fourteen inches in the new naval treaty.

Flashing a powerful offensive in the second half after holding only an 11-5 advantage at the intermission, the powerful James Monroe High quintet crushed Theodore Roosevelt, 45 to 12, on the Monroe court to continue unbeaten in the Bronx Division of the P.S.A.L. yesterday.

An aggressive campaign to improve business in the 125th Street section, which will be given greater importance by the opening of the Triborough Bridge in July, will be undertaken by the Uptown Chamber of Commerce, Colonel Leo Philipp, president, announced yesterday.

In the annual pamphlet report of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, issued yesterday, Eugene G. Grace, president, said that cash expenditures for additions and improvements to properties last year amounted to $24,104,024. The estimated cost of completing constructional undertakings authorized and in progress on Dec. 31, 1935, was $4,150,000, he said.

WARSAW, March 6. -- Prohibition of Hebrew ritual slaughtering would be unconstitutional, Mgr. Von Gollowicz, State Under-Secretary in the Ministry of Education and former Professor of Canon Law at Vilna University, declared yesterday at a meeting of the Sejm committee appointed to deal with the bill for the abolition of ritual killing of cattle.

New York's Latin Quarter is to have another fine new structure in the form of an addition to St. Luke's Hospital. Our own Latin Quarter is miles away from where most people would say it is. It is not Greenwich Village and inhabited chiefly by proletarian writers and artists.

We have been reading about the accident racket for the past few weeks. The District Attorney has organized an Accident Fraud Bureau, and a thorough investigation of faked claims and dishonest lawyers is promised. We are told that ambulance chasing is worse today than it was in 1928, when the Appellate Division ordered its investigation.

The Harvard hockey team will have an excellent chance of clinching its annual series with Yale when the rivals clash for the second time this season at the New Haven Arena tonight. The contest will be the seventy-fifth between the schools on the ice.

TRENTON, March 6. -- Faced with one of the most serious problems ever before the State Legislature, State officials and leaders of the Senate and Assembly will meet tomorrow in an effort to find a way to break the long deadlock on relief financing.

About 2,500 employes in seventeen large midtown hotels joined the building service strike yesterday, according to Chris Houlihan, president of Local 32-C, the hotel workers' division of the union. Since the strike started Sunday sixty-two hotels have been affected, Mr. Houlihan asserted, and more than 7,000 of their employes were on strike.

Winning seven of the eight events, Columbia's swimming team defeated City College, 49 -- 22, last night in the Morningside Heights pool in a league meet. Al Huse was the only Lavender swimmer to triumph, coming in first in the 150-yard backstroke race, a few feet in front of his team-mate, Sam O'Regan.

BERLIN, March 6. -- It was confirmed here today that the first mutually satisfactory agreement for the exodus of foreign Jews from Germany had been concluded between the Reich and the Netherlands. It was believed that this may serve as a model for similar agreements with other countries, but only with those which buy more from Germany than they sell her, thereby creating a necessary balance of foreign exchange for the transfer of Jewish capital.

The author of "The Fields Beyond" and the audience which was studying it at the Mansfield last evening can agree on one point. Watertown College, somewhere in the Middle West, is intolerable. It is provincial, smug, stupid, mean, overbearing, petty, malicious, and one of the president's daughters is impertinent.

ALBANY, March 6. -- In a sharp message to the Legislature today, Governor Lehman demanded that the Republicans restore to the budget an item of $11,160,010 for debt service which was stricken out in the lower house.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- President William Green of the American Federation of Labor has appealed to national and international unions affiliated with the federation for contributions to a $750,000 campaign fund to organize workers in the iron and steel industry this Spring.

The Carlton-Cooke Plating Corporation, an electroplating firm founded in 1860, has leased an additional floor in 67 Frankfort Street, in which the company has been for fifty years. The six-story building is on the block front between Jacob and Cliff Streets, facing Brooklyn Bridge.

The William H. Nichols Medal, highest honor of the New York Section of the American Chemical Society, was presented last night at a dinner at the Hotel Pennsylvania to Professor William Mansfield Clark of the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine.

MADRID, March 6. -- When the parliamentary sessions resume Premier Manuel Azana will have to choose between continued dictation from the Socialists who elected him or an open break with the Marxist leader, Francisco Largo Caballero, whose aim is to establish a Soviet form of government as quickly as possible.

CHICAGO, March 6. -- A 21-year-old Detroit Negro, from whom Joe Louis took many beatings in a gymnasium, emerged with knockout honors in the ninth annual Golden Gloves amateur boxing tournament in the Chicago Stadium tonight.

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, Democratic National Committeeman for New Jersey and leader of the State's Democratic party, announced yesterday the organization designations for delegates at large and alternates to the forthcoming Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- The General American Transportation Corporation of Chicago has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 169,600 shares of $5 par value common stock, the net proceeds from which would be used to obtain control of the assets of the Pressed Steel Car Corporation, to purchase equipment and for other corporate purposes.

George Nichols was named chairman of the Atlantic class of racing yachts at the organization's annual meeting last night in the Union League Club. He succeeds Robert N. Bavier. F.L. Meinertz was elected secretary and treasurer. Joseph F. Watkins was chosen chairman of the rules committee.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., March 6. -- More than 500 persons attended funeral services this afternoon in Zion Methodist Episcopal Church here for Charles H. Lee, Negro chauffeur to the late President Theodore Roosevelt, who died suddenly on Wednesday at his cottage at Sagamore Hill here.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- President Roosevelt told newspaper men today that officials of the administration, considering a series of stamps to honor American army and navy heroes, have been unable to agree on what heroes should be honored.

LONDON, March 6. -- "The abnormal expenditures are due to special measures in connection with the Italo-Ethiopian dispute," said a memorandum from Viscount Swinton, Air Secretary, accompanying the Air Force budget. The statement disclosed for the first time the extent of British aircraft activities in the African crisis.

Mrs. Edwin M. Bulkley will give a reception on Monday at her home, 320 Park Avenue, for women who are arranging the luncheon in celebration of the thirty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the United Neighborhood Houses of New York, to be held at the Biltmore on March 14.
ADDIS ABABA, March 6 (Reuters). -- An Italian airplane flew over this capital today at a height of 7,000 feet, circling over the city an hour. It reappeared later at an even greater height.

With snow remaining a white patchwork in the leafless woods it is hard to conjure up the thin, exasperating song of the mosquito which can do so much to make the warm months miserable. But men and women who make war upon the winged pest have learned preparedness.

Native tribes of Mozambique and Swaziland in Southeast Africa still cling to their age-old traditions and costumes and strongly resent any efforts by the white man to introduce his type of civilization into the region, Dr. Mary Jobe Akeley, African explorer, declared in an interview yesterday.

Volunteer leaders of the Young Women's Christian Association and members of its executive staff outlined the accomplishments in the various departments conducted by that organization last year at a conference of these leaders, held at the headquarters of the executive board, 600 Lexington Avenue, yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., March 6. -- A young colt, comparatively untried as a juvenile last year, tonight stands on the threshold of what many think will be equine greatness, as the main one among eleven named for tomorrow's $20,000 added Florida Derby.

The Most Rev. Amleto Giovanni Cicognani of Washington, D.C., Apostolic Delegate in the United States, will preside tomorrow at three services in St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church, Lexington Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street. The occasion will be the celebration of the 350th anniversary of the Bull "Salvator" in which Pope Sixtus V conferred unique honors on St. Thomas Aquinas, "The Angel of the Schools."

When I read an article in THE NEW YORK TIMES this morning stating that strikers are eligible for home relief called up the Sales Tax Department and asked them to tell me definitely the object of the tax. I was informed that the tax was definitely collected for the relief of the unemployed.

Buses replaced street cars yesterday on the lower Seventh Avenue and on the Eighth Street crosstown lines of the New York Railways Corporation. Several trolley cars will be operated daily on the two routes, however, to protect franchise rights pending the outcome of litigation over the rights of preferred stockholders of the company.

FRIEDRICHSHAFEN, March 6. -- Dr. Hugo Eckener and his corps of eight Zeppelin commanders had an amusing experience today in seeking official approval from the Commission of Civil Servants of the Air Ministry for their new LZ 129. The functionaries were expected to make the trip yesterday, but as they did not arrive on time Dr. Eckener went off without them.

The railroads began 1936 by earning in January their largest net operating income for the month since 1930, according to a statement issued by the Association of American Railroads yesterday. The total was up 63.1 per cent from January, 1935, this gain being realized from an increase of 13.2 per cent in gross.

LONDON, March 6. -- The American women's squash racquets team lost to the King's Club men of Richmond, 4 to 1, tonight. Arranged by the English women's association as a "friendly battle," it provided the best possible practice for our players for next Monday's Wolfe-Noel Cup encounter.

ALBANY, March 6. -- Governor Lehman signed today seven more bills in his program of anti-crime legislation as Speaker Irving M. Ives of the Assembly prepared to go on the air tomorrow night and support the Republican position on the crime program.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week amounts to $31,754,000, with two States and 119 municipal issues being represented. This compares with the revised total of $15,971,795 for this week. The weekly average for the year to date is $21,986,225.

The Treasury's announcement of the oversubscription of its $1,250,000,000 financing offer stimulated further heavy buying yesterday of United States Government loans. Trading in those issues again held the spotlight as twenty of the twenty-one long-term Federal bonds rose to new high levels for the year, while seventeen were carried to the highest prices since they were issued.

Chairman FARLEY'S tour of New England does not seem to be well understood. He is not this time seeking votes but delegates. He is thinking not of next November but of June, when the Democratic National Convention meets. Anybody can see that Mr. FARLEY as he passes from city to city is giving instruction, but it is not so clear why he is also asking instructions -- that is to say, instructed delegates.

The "barbarity" of our present deportation laws will be eliminated and 20,000 criminal aliens now in this country will be deported if the Coolidge-Kerr bill, now pending in Congress, is passed, according to Daniel W. MacCormack, United States Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, who spoke last night at the annual dinner of the National Council on Naturalization and Citizenship at the Hotel Astor.

Intent on getting much of the business lost because of unfavorable weather last month, stores in New England carried furniture promotions into the present month. Response to the special sales was spotty, with some establishments reporting sharp gains over previous weeks and others only nominal improvement.

Directors of the General Electric Company declared yesterday a dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock, comparing with 20 cents in each of the two preceding quarters and with 15 cents quarterly previously from April 25, 1934.

Because of an unpaid judgment for $1,511 for rent against Dorothy Russell, a diamond and emerald ring once owned by her mother, Lillian Russell, was the subject of a suit by the Tishman Realty and Construction Company on trial yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Lauer.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- The world, shaken by the suffering of jobless millions and the thunder of armies on the move, has only one alternative to the impending tragedy of general war -- a restoration of natural trade among nations.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP). -- A Republican demand for a Senate investigation of the administration's work relief activities was drafted today in one corner of the Capitol while from another came a Democratic demand that any new relief appropriation be limited to $1,000,000,000.

BELGRADE, March 6. -- Parliament, already stained -- figuratively only, for the affair happened in a different building -- with the blood of Stepan Raditch, Croat leader, and two other Croat Deputies murdered in 1928, was today the scene of a determined attempt to assassinate Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch during the Premier's expose of the foreign political situation.

With Mayor La Guardia in a jocular mood, the Board of Estimate voted yesterday to spend $75,000 on temporary repairs to the Criminal Courts Building, where structural weaknesses were discovered in a recent survey.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 6, -- Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis, the medalist, faltered on the greens today and was defeated by Mrs. Opal S. Hill, Kansas City, Mo., in the semi-finals of the Florida East Coast golf championship on the St. Augustine links.

MADRID, March 7. -- The Azana government today was concerned with two serious problems -- first the delay in President Niceto Alcala Zamora's threatened resignation and, secondly, the postponement of the apparently inevitable devaluation of the peseta.

Victory in two of the most important games of the indoor polo season went to the New York Athletic Club and Evergreen Farms last night. The former defeated Blind Brook in a fast, interesting game at the Squadron A Armory, 9 1/2 to 6, and Evergreen Farms upset Governors Island in the second match, 6 1/2 to 3.

A compromise basic passenger fare somewhat higher than the one specified in the order issued by the Interstate Commerce Commission on Feb. 28 is to be discussed by the presidents of the leading passenger-carrying lines in the East within a week or two.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 7. -- Representative Ernesto Ramos Antonini, the Liberal party legislative leader, in a lengthy statement criticized United States authorities for action against Pedro Albizu Campos and Nationalist leaders on charges of sedition and conspiracy to overthrow the government.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., March 7. -- The Romance Languages clubs at Wesleyan University, La Societe Francaise and La Tertulia, have demonstrated how unutilized space in a basement, formerly serving as a coal bin, can be transformed into an ultra-modern, gay and attractive clubroom.

THE scene favored most frequently, though second of course to Tarzanian Africa, in the Burroughs extravaganzas has been the planet Mars, where, once again producing Prince John, the mighty war lord himself, this present feat of boundless imagination is unrolled.

A total of forty-two summonses were served yesterday afternoon on the employes of nineteen theatres in four boroughs in a drive to end the practice of permitting children to attend theatres without adults accompanying them.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP). -- An inquiry into the effect of the WPA on civil service standards and private wage rates was asked of Harry L. Hopkins, the WPA Administrator, today by representatives of unemployed engineers and professional men in New York City.

MILLIONS of visitors have been thrilled by the tumult of waters that makes Niagara Falls a mecca for Summer tourists. It took the severe and prolonged Arctic weather of January and February, however, to transform the famous cataracts into a major Winter attraction.

LZ129: After four years in the building, the dirigible LZ129 made its first flight over Lake Constance last Wednesday. Its chief designer, Dr. Hugo Eckener, went aloft with it to see how his latest contribution to lighter-than-air aviation behaved.

THE theme in Paul de Kruif's new book is dollars vs. human lives, money bag values over against the values of human welfare and life. It is a theme that is getting more and more consideration these days and Mr. de Kruif, of course, presents it with his well-known emotional and sensational skill.
MONTREAL. -- Trips to the Laurentians are popular with Montrealers at this season, for good skiing conditions usually are found in the Northern hills during March, and one may acquire a sun tan.

JOSE ITURBI will conduct the Philadelphia Orchestra at its seventh New York concert Tuesday evening, March 17, in Carnegie Hall. The program will contain three novelties. One of these will be an intermezzo from the opera "Don Juan de Manara," by Eugene Goossens, which will receive its world premiere on this occasion.

AMHERST, Mass., March 7. -- Increasing air-mindedness among the New England colleges is evidenced by the meeting of the Association of New England College Flying Clubs held recently at Amherst College, and the plans for the second intercollegiate flying meet to be held at La Fleur Airport in Northampton on May 9.

LONDON, March 7 (Canadian Press). -- Half a million soccer fans who stayed away from the weekend fixtures are the newest argument against the English League's ban on advance listing of the games. Only 416,000 attended today's forty-four matches which would normally have drawn about 1,000,000.
Purim, the Jewish festival commemorating the deliverance of the Jews of ancient Persia from the persecution of the king's minister, began last night and will be celebrated today throughout the world.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 7. -- A bill before Congress to grant to President Arturo Alessandri special powers has aroused intense political discussion because of his failure to reach an agreement with the Radical party for participation in his Cabinet.

THE abatement of zero weather through the Northern tier of States has made the haul-away automobile shippers happy. The roads out of Detroit have been dotted the last few days with caravans on their way to dealers.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Although it is March, villas in this area remain filled with house parties and hotels are daily turning away visitors arriving in numbers indicative of early February. To entertain the large contingent planning to stay until May, a diversified program is being arranged.

PHILADELPHIA, March 7. -- A group of 200 subscribers tonight attended the first of a series of orchid room supper dances planned by Miss Frances Clark of Berwyn and Wesley R.M. O'Neill of this city, who are co-chairmen of the affairs.

LEWISTON, Me., March 7. -- Political leaders smiled when Donat J. Levesque, neighborhood grocer, announced his candidacy for Mayor of Lewiston, but the quiet and unassuming merchant is now Mayor-elect by the largest majority ever given a candidate here.

PHOTOGRAPHIC memories may retain a hint or two dropped here last Fall of another addition to the distinguished line of collaborations by Arthur Schwartz and Howard Dietz. Before Mr. Schwartz left for Hollywood last Thursday the hint had blossomed into the completed synopsis of a musical play, by name "Between the Devil," for production in this city next season.

A NEW biography of William Randolph Hearst is announced for publication late in April by Equinox Cooperative Press. The title is "Imperial Hearst: A Social Biography," and the author is Ferdinand Lundberg. Henry Hart, who sends us this information describes the book as "a detailed and factual account of William Randolph Hearst's career in journalism, politics and finance, from the beginning to the present day."

A total of 12,725 dogs have become A.K.C. champions of record in this country, according to figures given out yesterday by the American Kennel Club. These comprise all the dogs that have won the championship title during the fifty years of the official stud book, during which period the total number of dogs registered was 1,065,000.

THE skill of men and women as automobile drivers has been the subject of thousands of tests by Dr. Harry R. De Silva, of the Harvard University Bureau for Street Traffic Research, with the general finding that there are no perfect drivers, that skill varies with age, and that women drivers on the whole are not so expert as men.

The second recital for the benefit of Hartley House Music School will take place at the Town Hall on March 15. John Charles Thomas of the Metropolitan Opera Association will be the artist. The school provides instruction in all branches of musical art to talented children of poor parents.

Stimulated by a growing demand for all types of Spring merchandise, business throughout the country registered substantial improvement last week as much of the hesitancy caused by weeks of adverse weather was swept aside. With retailers featuring fresh stocks of apparel and other seasonable lines, shoppers thronged stores in leading centers, sales figures mounting to the highest levels since Christmas in many sections.
Theatrical openings under the aegis of the WPA mark the progress of the government theatre in New York. Five major productions are now on the boards and eighteen others are in rehearsal.

DR. DOLITTLE is perhaps the best known personality in children's books of twentieth century, and to find his characteristic sayings enshrined in a birthday book is only one more indication of the reality and permanent popularity of our kind-hearted old friend who "liked animals so much better than the 'best people.'"

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 7. -- Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch, who yesterday escaped an assassin's bullets in the Chamber of Deputies, today presented the Cabinet's resignation to Prince Paul, the chief Regent, who accepted it and immediately instructed Mr. Stoyadinovitch to form a new Cabinet.

MOTORISTS of the United States have paid more than $5,318,615,856 in State and Federal gasoline taxes since taxation of motor fuel to finance highways was inaugurated by Oregon on February 25, 1919, it is reported by Baird H. Markham, director of the American Petroleum Industries Committee.

The President supplied Congress and the nation with another surprise last week. It was a tax message which turned out to be not at all in conformity with its lugubrious advance notices. Congress had expected:

Winter tried to take possession of the city again yesterday, just two weeks before the official arrival of Spring. But a bright sun in a clear sky turned Winter back with a jump of 7 degrees in temperature within little more than an hour in the afternoon.

The immense throng which gathered at the Metropolitan last night to hear Wagner's "Siegfried" was yet another proof, if one were needed, that it has always been a fallacy to imagine that the music dramas of this composer require pruning and excisions to make them palatable to the public at large.

MARGARETE DESSOFF, director of the Dessoff Choirs, is retiring from all of her musical activities upon advice of her physicians. She expects to spend most of her time abroad. Since her arrival in this country from Germany in 1923 Miss Dessoff has influenced standards of choral concerts and particularly of a cappella singing throughout the land.

IN this witty book recording a journey to London undertaken eighty years ago a perspicacious Frenchman scintillatingly portrays not only the Victorians, their manners and customs, but also Victoria and the Prince Consort themselves.

MARY GRAHAM BONNER has chosen for the setting of "Rainbow at Night" a remote cove on the coast of Nova Scotia -- a spot so bleak and inhospitable and rock-strewn that it looked at first sight incapable of supporting life of any kind.
