A series of lecture-recitals by Lehman Engel, composer-conductor, will open tomorrow night at 8:30 o'clock at the 135th Street Y.M.C.A. as an extra-curricular activity under the auspices of the music education and music appreciation unit of the Federal Music Project.

The number of New York City wage-earners who are unemployed but not on relief exceeds the number on public relief, it was announced yesterday by Laurence M. Marks, chairman of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee, who based his statement on estimates made for the committee.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- While American officials today hastily assumed the attitude of aloof observers of Germany's reoccupation of the Rhineland, Dr. Hans Luther, German Ambassador and co-signer of the Locarno pact when he was Chancellor, immediately set about interpreting the German action as "a great, constructive program toward peace."

MACON, Ga., March 7 (AP). -- Carefully avoiding commitments for Presidential candidates, the Republican State committee called its Georgia convention today for May 9 in Atlanta amid talk of organizing a solid bloc of Southern voting strength at the national convention in Cleveland.

Staffordshire and luster ware, paintings, silver, ivories, bronzes and other art objects, antique Oriental rugs and furniture, the property of the estate of the late George D. Cochran, will be sold at auction at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Thursday, Friday and Saturday afternoons.
WASHINGTON, March 7. -- Labor unrest, spreading along a wide front in the last week, evoked immediate action from Federal and State agencies designed to deal with industrial disputes.

NEW YORK sits for a new portrait under the feverish, ardent hand of Aben Kandel. Like Chicago under Sandburg's lyric scrutiny, Manhattan Island, 1907-1927, appears to Mr. Kandel as the romantic "City of the Big Shoulders."

AS the Presidential election approaches Americans of opposing views are turning to Britain for vindication. In spite of the hazards of drawing parallels from foreign countries, whose history and problems are necessarily different from those of the United States, Britain's experience in the recent years of adversity is examined in the hope that it may supply hints as to America's future and indicate the policies she should follow.
ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., March 7 (Canadian Press). -- The "wooden walls" of Newfoundland sailed off to the ice floes today for their annual slaughter of the main seal pack off Labrador.

Jeanette Baton has already shown in her "A Daughter of the Seine, the Life of Madame Roland," in "The Flame, St. Catherine of Siena" and in "Young Lafayette" that she can make history and biography vivid and thrilling to young readers.

TECHNICALLY "Marriage by Conquest" fails into the classification of historical romance, belonging at least in part to that subdivision of the species devoted to cloak-and-sword melodrama. More than this it is difficult to say. Certainly the romance is more important than the historical element.

THOUGH the year is not far advanced and in the customary succession of monthly lists to come one may reasonably expect to find a deal that is above the average, something very much out of the ordinary will be required to take the palm for 1936 over Mme. Lotte Lehmann's Lieder Recital just released by Victor in Album M-292.

Four of the buildings of the Trailside Museums at Bear Mountain have been kept open to the public all Winter for the first time, the Commissioners of the Palisades Interstate Park announced yesterday. The Trailside Museums are conducted in cooperation with the American Museum of Natural History.

When New Yorkers file their State personal income tax returns next month all except those in the lowest brackets will find themselves obliged to pay considerably heavier taxes than last year. The increases range from about 10 to 80 per cent, with the heaviest increase falling upon those married men with two children in the $15,000 bracket for taxable net income before deduction of personal exemptions and credit for dependents.

The next luncheon of the Safe Drivers Committee will be held on Friday at the Lombardy. Further plans of the committee in campaigning for safe driving will be discussed, and awards will be made to members who continuously have held clean records in their driving.

Twenty years ago the Religious Education Committee of the Race Street Yearly Meeting in Philadelphia set out to assemble a book of stories to illustrate the ethical principles and religious truths that the Society of Friends consider of primary importance.

The first part of this story deals with the trial of Margaret Sampson for the murder of Bessie McIntosh, described by Mr. Wilberforce, who is a member of the jury. Much of it makes strange reading, for the trial procedure in Scotland, where the story is laid, appears to differ in several respects from that of American courts.

SCARCELY had Producer Samuel Goldwyn waved auf wiedersehen to Gotham last Wednesday from the deck of the Cherbourg-bound Berengaria when Director William Wyler was discovered sipping sherry in a Broadway bazaar.

With the victims of the Japanese Army's violence in Tokyo buried, with 1,400 rebels under arrest in their barracks and with the civilian forces struggling with the army to form a new Cabinet to rehabilitate constitutional government, it is possible at last to assess with some degree of assurance the net results of the military's "blood purge."

An original musical comedy, satirizing professionalism in college football, will be the Spring offering of the City College Dramatic Society. The story grew out of a false report last November that Bill Rockwell, back-field star on the City College football team, was Ted Londos, a Chicago professional playing under an assumed name.

DETROIT, March 7. -- The statement that President Roosevelt, seeking early and drastic tax reduction, wants to turn relief burdens back to local governments as soon as possible, but fears they are not yet ready to take up the load, was made by Secretary Daniel C. Roper before the Detroit Economic Club today.

PARIS, March 7. -- With Chancellor Hitler's announcement of Germany's reoccupation of the demilitarized zone on the Rhine the Treaty of Versailles, with the exception of its territorial clauses, is admitted to have fallen to the ground.

CHICAGO, March 7. -- Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, today urged farmers at the North Central States Agricultural Conference to regard the new Soil Conservation and Domestic Allotment Act "not as an emergency but a permanent" measure.

As the Metropolitan enters its final fortnight of the main season, this week's bills are marked with a profusion of "last times." It looks as if the final count of the season's repertoire will add up to thirty, with "Cavalleria Rusticana" as a late though not unexpected visitor to take the place of "Norms."

IS there any limit to speed? At a special meeting of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences held in New York last week Dr. George W. Lewis said that there is. And he ought to know because he is the director of research of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics which maintains at Langley Field, Va., big and little wind tunnels in which airplanes and parts of airplanes are tested.

The fourth of the series of five violin concerto programs being given by Mischa Elman and the National Orchestral Association, with Leon Barzin conducting, brought a packed house to Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. Mr. Elman accomplished some of the most brilliant and inspiring playing heard from him during the cycle to date.

CHICAGO, March 7. -- Invention of a radio light-phone for use in military manoeuvres was announced today by a soldier-scientist as the first of a series of scientific weapons which he believes will enable the "electric eye" to win the next war.

Here is something for those who like crime puzzles that are both intricate and amusing. The setting, in the heart of London, is a museum founded and conducted by a wealthy and eccentric Orientalist, and the story begins when an old man in long white whiskers jumps down from the wall of the museum and accuses a policeman of murder.

WHEN the Interstate Commerce Commission announced a slash in the basic railroad rate last week, effective June 2, it dropped a prize plum into the lap of a travel-minded nation. Bus lines are already contemplating proportional reductions.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 7. -Buddy Hassett, the $40,000 first baseman the Dodgers acquired from the Yankees, and who has yet to prove his calibre as a major leaguer, put himself on display in a Brooklyn uniform for the first time today and found himself pretty much in the limelight.

As a gesture of good-will and a basis for future cooperation on their mutual interests, the A.W.A. has extended invitations to presidents of 300 suburban clubs in the metropolitan area for tea at the clubhouse at 353 West Fifty-seventh Street at 5 o'clock tomorrow afternoon.

HOLLYWOOD. THE GREEN PASTURES" company is breaking up and it is an exodus unlike any other that the town has witnessed. Instead of waiting for fame to beckon from another studio, now that the drama is in the cutting rooms, the players are returning to their Pullman cars, their kitchens and their chauffeur uniforms.

Sanitation Commissioner Thomas W. Hammond was called upon yesterday by Aldermanic President Timothy J. Sullivan to take immediate action to clear the city streets of accumulated garbage and refuse, a condition which Mr. Sullivan contends constitutes a definite health menace.

Ten speakers, the majority of whom are prominent in some phase of crime correction, will address a forum on "Youth and Crime Today," to be held on Wednesday and Thursday under auspices of the New York Herald Tribune. Sessions will be held both morning and afternoon of both days in the auditorium of that newspaper.

Charging Victor H. Ridder with "incompetence and gross negligence" in his capacity as Works Progress Administrator for New York City, Representative Vito Marcantonio declared yesterday morning that, though "personally absolutely honest, Mr. Ridder's tactics are provoking an unnecessary amount of trouble in the relief situation."

It was almost a year ago -- Saturday, March 16, 1935, to be exact -- that Adolf Hitler threw a bombshell into European politics by denouncing the military clauses of the Treaty of Versailles and proclaiming the rearmament of the Reich. That -- and Mussolini's adventure in Ethiopia -- has been at the bottom of Europe's recurring war scares.

Mrs. William H. Moore will give a reception tomorrow afternoon at her home, 4 East Fifty-fourth Street, for the artists who will sing the leading roles in the performance of "Parsifal" the afternoon of March 20 at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the New York Kindergarten Association.

A tropical setting suggestive of the island of Madeira off the coast of Africa has been devised for the Madeira Ball which will be held at the Plaza on March 20 in behalf of the Madison House Society. Net proceeds of the event will contribute to the support of the settlement house maintained by the society in the interests of under-privileged families of the lower East Side.

The postponed performance of "Saint Joan" for the benefit of the Southern Women's Educational Alliance will be held on Thursday night at the Martin Beck Theatre. The performance, originally arranged for last Thursday, was postponed owing to the illness of Katherine Cornell, who has the leading role.

FOR a number of years Spud Johnson has been publishing single poems in little pamphlets. This is his first book and it places him in the front rank of the poets who have taken the Southwest and its peoples as their subject-matter.
The text of Mayor La Guardia's telegram to the Realty Advisory Board and the Building Service Employes Union, renewing his appeal for arbitration of the strike issues, follows:

TESTS completed at the Daniel Guggenheim School of Aeronautics of New York University and also by the Bureau of Air Commerce, it was disclosed last week, indicate the development of a stabilized aircraft fuel which de-ices the carburetor when ice has formed therein and prevents further accumulations.

Congress eventually will revise Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act of June, 1934, to eliminate defects becoming apparent in the corporate reorganization statute, but more court decisions and interpretation of the section are needed before it can be revamped.

Edward S. Wood, a husky speedster from Huntington School in Boston, carried off two titles last night in the national interscholastic individual swimming championship meet in the Columbia University pool, Wood, whose home is Balboa, Canal Zone, won the 50 and 100 yard free-style honors in impressive fashion.

With the mounting toll of street and highway automobile accidents, safety education in the schools and colleges of the country is becoming an important part of the curriculum and courses are being extended to cover not only pedestrian conduct but intelligent driving.
PARIS, March 7. -- France has laid Germany's latest treaty violation before the Council of the League of Nations. That is the procedure called for in the situation.

The colder weather continues to result in an increasing number of complaints of buildings without heat or emergency elevator service, Health Commissioner John L. Rice announced yesterday. In the eighthour period from 4 o'clock Friday afternoon until midnight, he stated, a total of 276 complaints of all sorts were received as against 198 in the same period Thursday and 111 on Wednesday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 7. -Harvard routed Yale, 11 -- 0, tonight as the ancient rivals closed their hockey seasons. Registering clusters of goals in each of the three periods and checking the Yale attack throughout, the Crimson easily gained its second victory of the season over the Elis.

Joseph Campbell of the Union League Club, second rated performer, led the field in the Metropolitan squash rackets association Class C singles championship into the second round by defeating T.N. Lawler of the Princeton Club, 15 -- 12, 11 -- 15, 15 -- 10, 15 -- 10, as play got under way yesterday at the Downtown Athletic Club.

The Barrere Little Symphony, now in its twenty-second year of activity, presented a program of more than ordinary interest yesterday afternoon before a large gathering of enthusiastic listeners at the, Town Hall. Alice de Cevee, pianist, was the soloist. As is his custom, Georges Barrere, founder and conductor of the organization, prefaced each number with informative comment, spiced with sallies of wit and humor.

THIS authoritative, explanatory be found very Useful by both students and laymen. In both illustrations and text it covers simply enough to meet the needs of the ordinary reader all the structural systems of the body.

WHOLESOME, agreeable in tone, but not too sweet, this quiet novel has for heroine a deserving girl matched unfairly against the worldly troubles which have overtaken her family through the financial dereliction of her father.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 7. -- Dissatisfied with the administration's first offer of $100,000,000 a year for converting 11,000,000 acres of cotton normally raised throughout the South into soil-conserving crops, adamant producers of the staple today demanded $27,000,000 more as the price of their cooperation.
TORONTO, March 7. -- Announcement by the United States Treasury that it will purchase all silver mined in Canada this year was the highlight of mining developments here this week.

REBECCA WEST has always been one of the least provincial of English writers, with a friendly smile for the ways of other people and a critical smile for the ways of her own countrymen. One can even imagine her going without her tea and not looking like either a martyr or a nervous wreck.

THE assembling of the musical scores of some 500 early classical musical works at the New York Public Library, under the supervision of Carleton Sprague Smith, chief of the music division, promises to place the collection in the rank of such famous ones as those of the Nationalbibliothek in Vienna, or the Bodleian Library at Oxford.
COLORADO SPRINGS, March 7. -The text of Herbert Hoover's speech to the Young Republican League of Colorado was as follows:

ALBANY, March 7. -- The supreme political challenge of the session was hurled at Republicans in the Legislature by Governor Lehman on Monday night, when he transmitted to the lawmakers a special message recommending the enactment of an eight-point social security program.

Manhattanville's strong basketball team experienced little difficulty in overwhelming the sextet from Mount St. Joseph's College of Philadelphia, 35 to 6, at the Benziger Gymnasium on the victors' campus yesterday. It was the forty-fifth consecutive triumph in four seasons for the Scarlet and the fifth victory of the current campaign.

MOSCOW, March 7. -- Another evidence of softening toward worthy Soviet citizens even though they are not members of the Communist party or even spring from families deemed "class enemies" is shown in a protest by a high authority of the Communist party against the dismissal from their jobs of three efficient brothers who had been expelled from the party.

ANDOVER, Mass., March 7. -- Andover Academy's basketball team checked a last-period Exeter rally to score a 36-to-30 victory today in the final game of the campaign. It was Exeter's first defeat, Andover having dropped three and Exeter tied one during highly successful seasons.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 7. -Dartmouth and Princeton closed their Quadrangular Hockey League seasons today with the Tigers emerging victorious, 4 to 3, in a hard-fought game. A crowd of 1,200 watched the game.

THE Federal government's fifteen-dollar-a-month cheek to 109,000 needy college students pays the whole college expenses of some; to others it is only a slight boost toward solvency, so the United States Office of Education reported last week.

IT is important to wear the right kind of stockings with the Spring suits, for stockings are more conspicuous with a trim tailleur than with the fluffier, feminine sort of costume. In addition to color, there is texture to consider.

Mayor La Guardia's difficulties with snow, noise and racketeers, and Alfred E. Smith's declination of a White House invitation provided last night a field of abundant opportunity for lampooning and satire by the past and present political writers who constitute the Inner Circle.
HAMILTON, Bermuda. -- The most important event listed for this week is the third annual Bermuda Command I-Iorse Show, to be held Thursday on the grounds of the Bermuda Agricultural Station.
AKRON, Ohio, March 7 (AP). -Strikers used force today to prevent the police from clearing streets near the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company of picket shelters.

THE public and the city fathers were advised the other day that the recreational facilities of New York's parks -- notoriously neglected over a considerable number of years -- had been quadrupled during the past twenty-four months.
LONDON. -- Just as he greatly influenced the trend of fashions as Prince of Wales, King Edward is already responsible for further changes since his accession to the throne of Great Britain.

ITALIAN FIELD HEADQUARTERS, Ethiopia. -- Interesting sidelights on how the Ethiopians fight have been given to the writer by an officer, a personal friend, who fought in the great Tembien battle of January.

For nearly six years I have mentally written countless letters to you, the directors of the Philharmonic, the Columbia Broadcasting Company or some vague "Dear Sirs" in appreciation of the Sunday afternoon broadcasts of the Philharmonic.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- Dominated by the drop in automobile production, industrial operations in February did not show the customary seasonal expansion, the Department of Commerce reported today. Steel ingot production, however, expanded steadily in February, with the rate for the month estimated at 53.5 per cent of capacity, or about half-way between the December and January rates.

Brooklyn, famed as the City of Churches, may soon be famous also as providing grave diggers for legislation that encroaches on the Constitution. Last year the NRA met its demise when it collided with a Brooklyn chicken dealer. Last week, the New York Court of Appeals declared unconstitutional the State minimum-wage law for women after the manager of the Spotlight Laundry, Inc., in Brooklyn, had focused attention on the law.

Manhattan College performed the unprecedented in Madison Square Garden last night. For the third year in a row the Jaspers swept on to the team championship of the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A., and thus made a little history on their own account.

Performances of "Ozma of Oz," the second and last children's play to be produced this season by the New York Junior League Players, will be given this week and next in the great hall of the league clubhouse at 221 East Seventy-first Street.

LONDON, March 7. -- The complete lack of instant British political activity in reaction to Chancellor Adolf Hitler's latest stroke makes as significant news as would the sudden calling of the emergency week-end Cabinet meeting which in London customarily marks a crisis.

LONDON, March 7. -- Miss Margot Lumb, slim blonde squash racquets wizard, won her second successive British title today before a packed gallery at the Queen's Club. Following her 9 -- 5, 9 -- 5, 9 -- 4 defeat of the Hon. Anne Lytton-Milbanke she received the large, silver championship trophy from Miss Nancy Cave, chairman of the Women's Squash Racquets Association and former titleholder.

SEA ISLAND, Ga. -- With the full moon inspiring evening out-of-door parties at Sea Island, an oyster roast will be held tomorrow evening at the picnic pavilions on the beach. Cloister guests and many Sea Island residents will attend. The Washboard Orchestra, composed of island Negro musicians, will furnish music.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 7. -- The annual promenade week-end of the junior class of New Jersey College for Women closed this evening with the presentation of "Back to the Kitchen," a musical comedy written and produced by members of the class. A satire on the Russian revolution, the show was presented at the Little Theatre on Douglass Campus at the college under the direction of Miss Jeanne Lockwood of Pompton Lakes.

WESTPORT, N.Y., March 7. -- An ill man and his 9-year-old daughter, who was overcome by smoke, were rescued when fire swept through four buildings in the business section of Westport early today, with a loss of $75,000.

YOU an approach the gargantuan abstract show at the Museum of Modern Art (March 3-April 19) in one of many ways -- or, if you prefer and be qualified, in all of the possible ways simultaneously. Of course, if you have a closed mind, nothing will come of the visit and you might better stay at home, snug and slippered, with your comforting airtight convictions.

LONDON, March 7. -- The outstanding feature in the foreign exchange market here today was weakness in the franc on the German news; at one time the franc was down to 75 1-64 to the pound, but it rallied on control operations, closing at 74 29-32.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., March 7. -- The Boulder Brook Club here was the scene tonight of a "country dance" preceded by a beefsteak dinner.
SAN PEDRO, Calif., March 7. -- Nicholas Murray Butler and George Bernard Shaw let go with both barrels of caustic sarcasm today at each other through the medium of interviews.

FIGHTING dual hills on one hand and attempting to take advantage of the double-feature situation on the other, the studios are formulating plans for the coming year which will probably increase the number of films from the 460 made this season to about 600 for the 1936-37 period.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 7. -The annual junior promenade, Winter highlight of the Princeton University social calendar, will be held in the university gymnasium on March 20, it was announced today By Earle N. Cutler Jr., '37, of Morristown, N.J., chairman of the junior prom committee.

THE first New York appearances of the Ruth Page Ballets last week served to throw light on the subject of creating a really serviceable American ballet theatre. Fundamentally, Miss Page's approach seems to be completely sound and practical.

The outstanding fact of 1936 is the increased wealth and income of the American people, Donald R. Richberg, former head of the NRA, asserted yesterday in an address before members of the Columbia University Club at a luncheon meeting.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP). -Presidential allocation of another $200,000 to the Florida ship canal, after the House had refused a $12,000,000 appropriation, stirred clashing comment today from Senator Fletcher of Florida and Senator Vandenberg of Michigan.

ROME, March 7. -- At almost the minute when Chancellor Adolf Hitler, in Berlin, was announcing the reoccupation of the Rhineland, Premier Benito Mussolini, in Rome, was informing the Italian Cabinet Council that he had decided to accept "in principle" the invitation of the League of Nations to negotiate peace with Ethiopia.

GENEVA, March 7. -- Dissimulation plays such a role in all diplomacy it usually is hard to know, especially from the outside, when its really big moments occur. How easy it is to be deceived by its thunder machines and stage lighting is evident from all the premature war scares which in recent years have harrowed public nerves even outside the United States, where alarmism over Europe seems to be so generally chronic.

PLANS for an international exposition to be held in Paris in 1937 have been in existence for some years, but it is only now that visual evidences of the tremendous amount of work that the exposition entails are beginning to appear.

Contracts to acquire the stores they operate have been signed by 25 per cent of the managers associated with the James Butler Grocery Company, which plans to organize a voluntary chain of 2,000 or more owner-managed stores, it was announced yesterday by Arthur C. Jones, general manager of the Butler Company.
BERLIN, March 7. -- The text of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's speech before the German Reichstag today follows:

With a program far more ambitious than the promotional campaign which brought sales increases of 30 to 50 per cent last year, manufacturers of electrical household appliances will seek to better 1935 results this year through a drive to be operated in cooperation with the Edison Electrical Institute.

AS the Second Spanish Republic swings back to the hands that first gave it shape five years ago, the name of one man is again identified with it. The man is Manuel Azana, whom all Spain, whatever its political feelings, recognizes as the most ardent champion of a liberal, democratic, bourgeois regime.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- With President Roosevelt as the silent guest of honor, all speeches being barred by custom, the White House Correspondents Association tonight held its fifteenth annual dinner.

MORE snow? Yes; but the first robins have appeared! And here and there impatient gardeners, armed with pruning shears or pole-saws, are venturing out into the open. No matter how severe the weather, pruning can be done now.

YOUR article "German Literature As Reflected by Emigres," printed in the second Sunday edition of the N.Z.Z. of Jan. 26, has received much attention and has been much discussed and quoted, not to say exploited, in news papers of various tendencies.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 7. -- Yale and Harvard tied today in their varsity boxing meeting, 4 -- 4, while the Eli freshmen scored a decisive 7-1 victory over the Crimson yearlings. The meet was the first at Yale decided by judges, with Referee Cluney as the final arbiter.

The first step in the launching of the proposed league of cooperative department stores, sponsored by E.A. Filene, Boston merchant, was taken here yesterday with the announcement by the Consumer Distribution Corporation of a plan of organization which will serve as a guide for the establishment of local community units of the league.

Described as one of the meanest thieves ever arrested here, Charles L. Drew, 34 years old, alias James A. Braddock of Haverhill, Mass., was held without bail yesterday by United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter on six mail theft charges, including a theft and fraud practiced on a sick maid of Mrs. Irving Berlin, wife of the song writer.

OMAHA, Neb., March 6. -- On the basis of rather sketchy information from the Chicago regional meeting as to the method of rewarding farmers for undertaking a soil conservation program, local administrators will have to do some fast work.

IT is bonspiel time in Scotland, that means it also is bonspiel time throughout the world wherever curling is played. In the United States, Canada, Alaska, Switzerland and, of course, Scotland the old game is having a banner year.

AUGUSTA, Ga. -- During the Lenten lull in social activities the interest of Augustans and Winter visitors centers on golf, polo and tennis. Many are looking forward to the annual South Atlantic State tennis tournament, which will be held here March 26 to 29, inclusive.

In speaking at the opening exercises of the High School of Art and Music, Mayor La Guardia enumerated two objections usually raised against the idea of such a high school. One, according to the Mayor, was that people do not care for good music; the second is that people just could not understand why there was need for such a school.

AMONG a collection of film "primitives" placed on exhibition in New York a few nights ago was a two-reel thriller, chronologically comparable to an Aldine folio in typography or a Cimabue in painting, entitled "The Fugitive, or, The Taking of Luke MacVane."

IT is not altogether flattering to the current screen to report that by far the most interesting and provocative picture of the week was D.W. Griffith's "Intolerance," produced twenty years ago and revived, for showing in the nation's universities and libraries, by the Museum of Modern Art Film Library.

AN automatic buzzer which signals to pedestrians behind when the cab is about to back is one of the features of the new taxicabs placed in service in this city by the Parmelee System. A wide, thick sponge rubber cushion lining has been provided below the passenger compartment window separating the driver and passenger to protect riders from injury when precipitated forward by a sudden stop.

THIS is a long short story about a famous world flier and a fair lady, dealing with romantic love and defeat. There seems to be little reason for it despite the obvious care with which it has been written in language which is impeccable but by no means distinguished.

Aside from the nervousness caused yesterday by the heightening of the Franco-German tension, the stock market last week was definitely under the influence of the President's tax message to Congress that advanced a suggestion for a 33 1/3 per cent levy on undistributed corporation income.

Delay in the announcement of prices for steel products in the second quarter of the year, together with the revival several months ago of the practice of granting secret concessions to buyers, has focused the attention of the financial and industrial communities on the steel-price problem.

Practically every State east of the Mississippi last week sent heads of public welfare departments and relief organization executives to meet with representatives of the Federal Government to try to agree upon the future responsibility for relief of the half million men, women and children who make up our army of transients, hopelessly wandering from one part of the country to another and constituting an increasing social menace.

A FRIENDLY English story that covers a great deal of ground at what seems a pleasantly leisurely pace, "The Three Friends" is a wholly delightful book. It probably should be saved for a downhearted evening, for it mixes pathos and rollicking humor in a comfortable blend.

CHICAGO, March 7. -- Strong buying of wheat futures here and in Winnipeg by shorts and commission houses, based on the reports from Europe, and continued dry weather in the American Southwest, sent prices soaring today on the Chicago Board of Trade after scattered liquidation was completed.
ATLANTIC CITY. -- With indications pointing toward the largest Spring holiday crowds in six years, preparations are under way here for the traditional Palm Sunday and Easter-fashion parades.

BERLIN, March 7. -- The Olympic committee here is considering a plan to erect at various central locations in Berlin large television tents in order to give those of the 300,000 or 400,000 guests expected for the Olympic games who will be unable to attend any major event at least an idea of what is going on in the various stadia.

WHEN the first transatlantic flights were making aviation history back in 1927 there used to appear on Roosevelt Field, Long Island, a quiet, almost shy little man, with a gentle smile and ready wit, to whom aviators would go with anxious eyes asking for advice on the weather.

Sharp gains in sugar futures and improvements in hide, cottonseed oil, wool tops and copper prices imparted an undertone of strength to the commodity futures markets yesterday. Rubber, coffee and cocoa futures, however, declined slightly. On the cash markets, eggs alone eased, while gains were marked up for all the grains, and cotton, raw sugar, lard and butter.

NEWARK, N.J., March 7. -- The Essex Troop poloists of Newark retained their New Jersey low-goal polo championship tonight by defeating the 112th Field Artillery trio of East Orange, 9 -- 3 1/2, in a hard-fought final before 2,000 at the Essex Troop Armory.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT leads as the most "news-worthy" person in the headlines as dramatized in the five years that "The March of Time" has been on the air. In the 250 scripts the President's acts had a conspicuous place in seventy-two episodes.

PHILADELPHIA. -- Notice from Harrisburg that a half-million Pennsylvania residents and organizations are expected to pay a new State personal property tax has served to emphasize that the present Democratic administration is about to engage in a determined drive to bring large amounts of hidden wealth to light.

I am wondering in what line of work Emanuel Celler is engaged. Has he, and many others whose sentiments are akin to his own, ever been forced to seek employment in his line of work day after day, week after week, month after month without success, disheartened, discouraged no end?

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 7. -- Showing to advantage in the lighter classes, Yale's varsity wrestling team conquered the Harvard grapplers by 17 -- 13 at the Harvard Athletic Building today. Yale also won the freshman meet, 18 to 16.

YOUR INCOME TAX" was written primarily for the use of taxpayers who prepare their own returns for the year 1935. In several respects the book is a novel presentation of the subject, with practicality predominant. While its brevity of expression has tended to abridge the discussion of the finer points of the law, the authors assert no claims for either completeness or perfection.

Showing the way throughout the match, the hard-riding Squadron C team of Captain Milton Kornblum and the Pflug brothers, Carl and John, conquered Fort Hamilton, 16 to 12, last night in the Brooklyn circuit junior division indoor polo final at Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn.

WELLINGTON, N.Z. -- A drive against all that is "foreign" is being urged chiefly by overseas interests upon New Zealand and to a less extent upon Australia, lesser in effect, at any rate, because Australia better knows its own mind and has all along adopted a more independent attitude.

THE basement, is rapidly becoming one of the most important rooms of the home and even its former drawbacks are now being made to contribute to usefulness and decorative effect. Necessary supporting pillars, for example, are encircled by-seats, and the low ceiling is made to give an effect of coziness.

FULL AND BY" is not a tale of clipper days, of rakish masts and towering canvas, of exotic cargoes and far romantic ports. The two-masted coastal schooner Jason bore about as much resemblance to the clippers that had preceded her era, even to the brig from which she had been cut down, as a peddler's spavined nag bear to a thoroughbred.

AN unusual program of works for ancient instruments will be presented Tuesday afternoon, March 17, at the Town Hall by Yella Pesse, harpsichordist; Suzanne Bloch, lutenist, and Carl Dolmetsch, player of the recorder.
Disturbing European news attracted more business to the Cotton Exchange yesterday than for some time and prices made net advances of 2 to 16 points.

THE Staatsoper's latest mistake is called "Anna Karenina." It was committed just twenty-four hours after the Greta Garbo film had enraptured Vienna and thus afforded opportunity for some deadly parallels. Jeno von Hubay's Tolstoy opera is over twelve years old and has been performed in a number of places without taking root anywhere.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 7. -Mr. and Mrs. Emil J. Stehli of New York, who arrived today at the Everglades Club, were guests tonight at a dinner given by Mr. and Mrs. J. Terry West at Villa Tramonto.

HOUSTON, Texas, March 7. -- Croon, 5-year-old mare owned by W.C. Stroube, won the Ben Milan Handicap at Epsom Downs today. A crowd of more than 10,000 persons, the largest of the meeting, saw the consistent daughter of Stimulus lead Mrs. A.M. Creech's heavily supported Sound Advice across the finish line in the five and one-half furlong race in the sparkling time of 1:05 4-5.

A mild corrective movement developed in the bond market yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. European political news and certain nervous selling in stocks dampened trading interest in underlying securities. As a result, trading in bonds, generally, became routine with only minor price changes during the two-hour session. Total transactions amounted to $7,374,600, compared with $7,843,000 on Saturday a week ago.
Led by the franc, European currencies plunged downward yesterday on news of Germany's denunciation of the treaty of Locarno and her invasion of the demilitarized Rhineland zone.

PARIS. FOR a month or more the Paris theatres have been doing exceptionally good business. It is perhaps worth noting that the two plays which are among the most successful, both deal with the same subject -- the conflict and the contrast between the older and the younger generation -- and are both written from the older generation's point of view.

CHICAGO, March 7. -- Republican women leaders of the Midwest, meeting in a regional conference today, urged unanimously the ignoring of all candidates, "favorite sons" and platforms until after the party's national convention in June.

THE heroes of Fallada's two previous books. Pinneberg of "Little Man, What Now?" and Kufalt of "The World Outside," were pathetic, weak, insufficient creatures, though decent enough, who were crushed by economic circumstance and victimized by their fellow-men.

HONORABLE Reader Pon Wing, a versatile gentleman who is press agent, local distributor and Eastern representative as well of the Grandview Motion Picture Producers of San Francisco, folded his smartly cut New World jacket on the seat beside him and leaned forward in his shirtsleeves to watch the screen at the New Chatham Theatre, overlooking the famed Five Points on the Bowery fringe of Chinatown.

LONDON, March 7. -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden used strong words to condemn the German Government's action when Ambassador Leopold von Hoesch of Germany presented to him this morning Chancellor Adolf Hitler's memorandum concerning the Rhineland.

WATERVILLE, Me., March 7. -- Valuable "finds" in the field of Americana and American literature have been uncovered in the Colby College library in recent weeks during the reclassifying of some 100,000 books and pamphlets by Dr. J. Periam Danton, librarian, and G. Donald Smith, his assistant.

The General Cable Corporation has sent telegrams to stock brokers asking that they cooperate with it by furnishing the names of all persons to whom they have delivered its preferred stock in the last two years so that proxies for this class of stock may be obtained for the annual meeting on March 18, when a vote will be taken on a proposed capital change.

IN the early morning air the New York listener often finds surprises, and during the past week one was VWY, Poona, India, broadcasting one side of a conversation directed to London. Apparently the man in India was a radio telephone engineer, for he discussed technicalities and interspersed a few pleasantries on the 8,980-kilocycle channel.

OF seven works commissioned for performance by the League of Composers this season two have received first hearings; five are scheduled for March and April, and several will enjoy repeat performances before June. The purpose of the plan is to promote presentations of new American works through mediums not specifically dedicated to modern music.
PARIS, March 5. -- Again bracelets are important. Herz is making a stunning one of big squares of black onyx; in each square an enormous yellow diamond is set.

The program of safety which was discussed and exhibited at the Safety Conference last week in this city, attended by thousands, is one which looks toward giving all the chance for higher adventure. Sir Bedivere lamenting the passing of King Arthur spoke of the old days when "every morning brought a noble chance" and "every chance brought out a noble knight."

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 7. -For the fifth time in twelve years Mrs. Maureen Orcutt Crews, formerly of Englewood, N.J., gained the Florida East Coast golf championship today, winning the eighteen-hole final from Mrs. Opal S. Hill of Kansas City, Mo., erstwhile Western titleholder, 4 and 3.

BERLIN, March 6. -- The University of Heidelberg, the oldest university in Germany, which was created in 1386 by the doughty Elector Rupprocht I of the Palatinate, has taken advantage of the Olympic year in Germany to announce the celebration in June of the 550th anniversary of its foundation.

IF we depended upon the comedies that come from England we would feel like strangers. Our frivolities are likely to be mutually antipathetic. "Fresh Fields," "Eden End" and "Mainly for Lovers" accentuate our different tastes in manners and suggest that, for the most part, Englishmen and Americans should not try to occupy the drawing-room together.

Freed only eighteen years ago from Czarist rule, the small Baltic Republic of Estonia has whirled through a variety of political experiences. Now, after about sixteen months of stern dictatorial rule, with its accompaniment of mass arrests of opponents of its method of government, the electorate, by 3 to 1, has voted to return to democracy and to resurrect its Constitution and Parliament.

The Seamen's Church Institute of New York, which for several years has tried to determine the origin of a ship's figurehead of Sir Galahad, announced yesterday that again it had been disappointed. The figurehead, which is larger than life-size and shows a knight in armor about to draw his sword, stands above the entrance to the institute building at 25 South Street.
TRENTON, N.J., March 7. -- Reciprocal agreements to care for wanderers was recommended today by the Interstate Conference on Transients and Settlement Laws.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 7. -The thirty-fifth annual exhibition of the New Haven Paint and Clay Club, Inc., opened here today with a reception at the West Gallery of the Free Public Library.
BRYN MAWR, Pa., March 7. -- Nearly fifty students at Bryn Mawr College have responded with enthusiasm to a movement designed to promote out-of-class discussion of philosophical problems.

Encouraged by the provision for temporary housing quarters for Hunter College students at 2 Park Avenue, the student organizations and alumnae association are urging the erection of a new building on the site of the fire-scarred Park Avenue building at Sixty-eighth Street.

AHITHERTO unsuspected peril to which writers of fiction are exposed has been revealed by a libel action brought against Beatrice Kean Seymour. She had laid the scene of one of her novels in such a way that it was possible that the plaintiff's house might be thought to be denoted.

COLORADO SPRINGS, March 7. -- Crushing taxes, repudiation of debts or inflation are certain sequels to the New Deal, Herbert Hoover declared tonight before the Young Republican League of Colorado in a speech which was broadcast nationally.

NANKING, March 7. -- Japan will view with concern and will not consent to any arrangement for possible loans or credits from the United States and Britain for railway construction in China, a Japanese Embassy spokesman said today.

ALBANY, March 7. -- Governor Lehman is making a "political football" of his crime program and picking a fight with the Legislature merely to develop an issue on which to run for re-election, Speaker Irving M. Ives of the Assembly asserted tonight in a State-wide radio broadcast.

In addition to being featured by better planning, retail advertising copy this year will be more factual, it was stated yesterday by Frank Spaeth, manager of the sales promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

OTTAWA, March 6. -- Major C.H. Douglas, founder and principal preacher of social credit, has broken with Premier William Aberhart its chief practitioner. After weeks and months of ostensible urging on Mr. Aberhart's part and of obvious coyness on the part of Major Douglas, evangelist and disciple have at last come to the parting of ways.

MANY things which are extremely difficult in fact are sometimes made to appear extremely easy in fiction. Among them, interfering in other people's lives, for those other people's good. As almost every intelligent person knows, there are few things more dangerous than attempting to improve your friends' characters, correct their error, or straighten out the tangles wherein they have enmeshed themselves.

MOUNT RAINIER of the eternal snows, which recently claimed the life of young Delmar Fadden of Seattle when he attempted a perilous ascent in Winter, is the nucleus for one of America's most beautiful national parks.

Except for several suicides by soldiers who felt humiliated by their role in it, the insurrection of Wednesday, Feb. 26, was not followed last week by further violence. But on the political battleground the conflict between the extreme militarists and the moderate statesmen of Japan continued.

VIENNA, March 7. -- Interesting details regarding the work of Nazi terror groups were revealed at the trial of two Nazis who were sentenced to five years' imprisonment each for organizing terrorist activities.

PHILADELPHIA, March 7. -- Presiding over booths and restaurant accommodations at the annual Ritttenhouse Flower Market on May 21 will be many active sponsors long identified with the traditions of this colorful Spring affair.

IN using the term "liberal" to describe the period from the beginning of the French Revolution to the present time, with which the concluding volume of his history deals, the warden of New College, Oxford, has in mind the system of political, civil and religious freedom which he finds "now firmly established" in Great Britain and the dominions and among the French, Dutch, Scandinavian and American peoples.

THE admirers of George Santayana -- and they have long constituted a coterie as passionate as it was small -- are not the least among those astonished at the fact that a book of his should within a fortnight have become a best-seller. It was surprise enough to most of them that he should, at the age of 72, have published a first novel.

A MORAL can be pointed by merely citing some of the events of Antonio Scotti's career -- this although music commentators are not traditionally expected to moralize -- only to retail events and impressions. Here, however, the moral is implicit in the tale.

ROMANCE in a dozy little town on the Carolina coast is the theme of Helen Topping Miller's new novel. Pretty, silvery-blond Linda Rhett lives there, looking after her father's parsonage, managing missionary societies, playing the church organ and mothering her older brother who, at 28, is still a sort of problem child.
The Travelers Aid Society will benefit from a luncheon and fashion parade entitled "Breath of Spring," which will be held on Tuesday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- The crash of an American Airlines plane near Goodwin, Ark., Jan. 14, in which seventeen persons were killed, was officially declared a mystery today by the Department of Commerce in a report prepared after intensive investigation.

Perhaps the most interesting part of the industrial recovery has been the rise of steel production. Traditionally, that industry has for many years been taken in the United States as a measure of general trade conditions. Some aspects of this season's production have been unusual.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., March 7. -- Since last year, when control of Williams College athletics was shifted from the alumni office to the health and executive departments, the graduates' sphere of influence has been transferred to the college's fraternity system.

THERE is still time, though not much, for residents in the United States and Canada to register their incunabula in the forthcoming revised edition of the "Census." The work is to be called "Second Census of Fifteenth Century Books Owned in America." Miss Margaret Bingham Stiliwell, who is editing this important compilation for the Bibliographical Society of America, warns that the closing date is March 16.
ALBANY, March 7. -- Governor Lehman has signed the bills extending for another year the moratorium on mortgage foreclosures and the measure striking at abuses in deficiency judgments.

The retirement of Captain Schuyler F. Cumings from command of the United States liner Washington and the appointment of Captain Giles C. Stedman as his successor was announced yesterday by A.J. McCarthy, general manager of the International Mercantile Marine Company, owner of the line.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman declined the invitation of President Roosevelt to pass Friday night in the White House in order to be on time as host to more than 2,500 Brooklyn orphans yesterday morning. For two hours he sat with the children at their theatre party and laughed and applauded with them.
Harry F. Wolf of the New York Athletic Club won the national amateur squash tennis title for the seventh consecutive year yesterday, a feat unparalleled in the history of the game.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 7. -- Reorganization of the student union committee and negotiations to lease the University Inn Barn, a private structure, are evidence of the renewed interest in a student union building and the growing trend toward organized social activities at Syracuse University.

In commemoration of the 250th anniversary of the granting of the charter to the City of New York, 1686-1936, the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, has placed on exhibition original manuscripts, documents, letters, pamphlets and books dealing with that event.

With the approach of the Easter season preparations are being made for the annual Butterfly Ball, which will be held on Easter Tuesday, April 14, at the Ritz-Carlton. For years one of the principal parties of the Spring in this city, the event is arranged by the Junior Auxiliary of the House of Rest at Sprain Ridge, near Yonkers.

Colonel John O'Neill, assistant general superintendent of the International Mercantile Marine piers along the Chelsea waterfront, retired last week after being in the employ of the company here and in Boston more tan twenty-five years.

" Picture Scripts," edited by a group of teachers in the elementary department of a progressive school, are planned to supply interesting reading matter and authentic information for 7 and 8 year olds who are beginning to read and to use books for themselves.

Retail trade in the metropolitan area continued quite active last week. The strike of elevator operators and service men in apartment house areas had somewhat of an adverse psychological effect upon shoppers from those sections, but package deliveries were nearly normal and sales figures for department stores here were estimated as showing about a 5 per cent increase over the corresponding week last year.

More or less coerced by his wife, Everard Blatchington goes with her to attend a show of sorts given by the pupils of Santley Free School, an institution conducted by as choice a pair of faddists as one could hope to meet anywhere. While the entertainment is going on, Blatchington makes the acquaintance of some of the teachers and pupils.

T.H. Lawrence was the high-over-all gunner at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. He triumphed by breaking 97 out of 100 targets. He also won the Class A handicap honors, returning a card of 97 -- 3 -- 100. A.S. Cornhill defeated J. Mercadante in a shoot-off to take the Class B prize.
The death of Antonio Scotti marks the passing of another of those great artists who helped make the early years of the century a golden age for operatic voices.

To the average American, the word professor conjures up a vision of a bewhiskered dodo, maundering over the Latin participles and forgetting his umbrella, his address and the number of his children. The image comes partly from the vanished past both of academic life and of the musical comedy stage.

PARIS, March 7. -- Paris received the news today of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's denunciation of the Locarno pact and the reoccupation of the demilitarized Rhineland zone with perfect calm. Great crowds were on the streets when newspapers began coming out with early editions shortly after noon, and everywhere they were snapped up by the public and read with excitement.

SYDNEY, Australia. -- An Australian diplomatic corps, giving this country full control of its external relations, will soon come into being if Sir George Pearce, Minister of External Affairs, has his way. Sir George is now reviving the first intelligence service possessed by the Commonwealth, an organization laid down by ex-Prime Minister Stanley Bruce in pre-depression years and one of the victims of the last Labor government's economy.

A default put Gregory Mangin in the final round of the national indoor tennis championship yesterday and the stunning victory of Leonard Hartman of New York over Frank Bowden in the other semi-final removed the player who had twice defeated the defending champion on covered courts this Winter.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla. -- Concluding the major golf events for this season on the East Coast is the second annual national amateur-professional best-ball matchplay championship scheduled to be played from Wednesday through Saturday of this week at the St. Augustine links.

ST. LOUIS, March 7. -- The sharp increase in retail trade following the severe weather has held up fairly well in the Eighth Federal Reserve District and wholesale houses report a good run of orders. The general business situation from all accounts is preparing for an active Spring, but the impetus ex- pected has not materialized in a marked degree at present.

ALASKA is facing (if advance bookings are any gauge) its biggest Summer tourist season and is opening travel bureaus in towns that have never seen a party of holiday sightseers. Beginning in June, large and small cruise ships sailing from Seattle and Vancouver will land passengers at coast towns to continue by rail and bus to inland points.

BERLIN, March 7. -- The German Foreign Office's semi-official voice, the Diplomatische Korrespondenz, abandons diplomatic language and gives Joseph Stalin the lie in reply to his recent statement that the Soviets are not supporting efforts for world revolution.

HONOLULU. -- Official denial of statements attributed to V.S. McClatchy, executive secretary of the California Joint Immigration Committee, to the effect that a textbook on Japan, written by Miss Ruth Pratt, has been furnished during the present school year to additional schools in the territory of Hawaii, has been made.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- Decisions of the United States Board on Geographical Names during a twelve-month period fill a pamphlet of twenty-six pages and fix definitely the spelling of many domestic and foreign place names.

A short circuit underneath a three-car northbound Second Avenue elevated train soon after 7 o'clock last night plunged 100 passengers into darkness and left them, amid considerable confusion, stalled between Twenty-ninth and Thirtieth Streets, four blocks from the nearest station.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 7. -- A book luncheon will be given at the Hotel Davenport, Stamford, by the Connecticut Pioneer Branch of the League of American Pen Women on March 27. Will Irwin and his wife, Inez Hayes Irwin, will be honor guests.

The first week of March brought a decided spurt of activity in the wholesale markets, according to the report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring and Howell Company. This increased activity was particularly evident in dresses, with the new collections being received enthusiastically.

Women attending the luncheon and fashion show entitled "Styles of a Century" on April 7 in the ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria are requested to bring packages of useful articles for resale at the Generosity Thrift Shop, the beneficiary of the party.

SOME thirty years ago Lord Palmer created a fund to enable young composers to hear their own work performed by a first-rate orchestra. Incidentally, the fund might bring the composer in touch with the public, but the main purpose was rather to give him the opportunity, as the result of experience, to amend his ways if amendment were necessary.

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., March 7. -- John Allan and Jack Graham, both members of the home club, gained the semi-final round in the Class A division as play in the annual Westchester squash racquet championships were resumed at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club at Scarborough today.

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 7. -- The Giants' 1936 pennant preparations, which have been conducted along general lines, appearing to a casual observer perhaps even a bit haphazard, began to take definite shape today when Manager Bill Terry announced the first intramural game tomorrow.

New York's first National Sportsmen's Show in twenty-one years concluded its eight-day run last night at the Grand Central Palace after attracting what is believed by its promoter, Sheldon H. Fairbanks, to be the greatest turnout of spectators of any show of its type in the world.

IN Los Angeles for many months they have been holding Townsend Plan meetings every noon in the old Mason Opera House on South Broadway. "Old Mason" and the buildings around it were the center of everything affluent and elegant in Southern California about the turn of the century, when Los Angeles had a population of 102,000.
TOKYO, Sunday, March 8. -- An explanation of the attitude of the Japanese army in the present Cabinet crisis was given authoritatively today.

PARIS. THREE ideal types, all feminine in the extreme, are fighting for supremacy in the new Summer mode. The first belongs to the Edwardian period, when girls were fairly smothered in lingerie. The second is associated with the Directoire and the first Empire, when the chic of great ladies was judged by the scant weight of their wardrobe.

Mr. Barbee's letter scarcely calls for extended comment. The circumstances of the Baltimore episode in Lincoln's career are too well attested to be altered by an afterthought from Lamon. The existence of a pilot was certainly reported to Lincoln from several responsible sources and those about him did not doubt it.

Two committees, an English and American, including prominent musicians, yesterday announced a drive for funds for the purpose of establishing a memorial to Gustav Holst, who was one of the outstanding composers of the contemporary English school. Mr. Holst died in London in 1934 at the age of 59.

IN his preface to this posthumous collection of his wife's short stories, Mr. Mencken says that Sara Haardt was obsessed by the conflict between the old, dying South of tradition and the new South struggling to be born.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 7 (AP). -- Miami Beach police reported the arrest tonight of three armed bandit suspects and recovery of alleged loot valued at about $50,000 and including jewelry, clothing and pawn tickets.
