"At this distance it seems only a small round tower." Euphranor, who has visited the castle, assures him that it is a large square building with battlements and turrets.

As all the leading colleges in the Metropolitan district, with the exception of Columbia, have completed their regular seasons, interest during the week in basketball circles will be centered on the basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday.

The University of Pittsburgh swimming team overwhelmed Manhattan, 48 -- 20, in a dual meet at the De Witt Clinton High School pool yesterday. The victors captured first places in seven of the eight events. It was the last dual meet of the season for the Jaspers, whose record for the campaign is three victories and five defeats.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 7. -- Taking first place in six of the eight events, Yale's well-balanced swimming team defeated Rutgers before 2,000 persons tonight, 48 to 23.

TAMPA, Fla. -- Tourist clubs here will give a number of special entertainments this week for visiting groups from near-by cities. Clubs in Lakeland, Clearwater and St. Petersburg will participate in the picnic and afternoon card party which the Tampa Indoor Games Club will give on Tuesday.

The New York City Tunnel Authority formally accepted at City Hall yesterday the $58,365,000 loan and grant which the Public Works Administration has agreed to furnish to build the East River vehicular tunnel.

If every bed in every hospital in the country had an occupant, statistics indicate, less than 7 per cent of the nation's patients could be accommodated. On Tuesday at the Hotel Roosevelt the function of the public health nurse toward the other 93 per cent will be the theme of the second annual luncheon of the National Organization for Public Health Nursing.
SYRACUSE, March 7. -- Discovery of a time bomb, addressed to Chancellor Charles W. Flint of Syracuse University, was announced at noon today by Syracuse postal inspectors.

THERE have heretofore appeared World War books by three outstanding official of the War De partment. In priority of publication these books are first, "My Experiences in the World War," by General Pershing; second, "Newton D. Baker -America at War," by Frederick Palmer; third, "
WASHINGTON, March 7. -- Friends and foes of the Guffey Coal Conservation Act filed briefs with the Supreme Court today.
SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- The largest crowd of the season is expected next Saturday afternoon to witness the second annual steeplechase meet to be held on the new course on Midland Road.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 7. -- Capturing the 400-yard relay race, the final event on the program, Harvard's undefeated swimming team subdued Princeton, 40 to 31, tonight.

The quintets of St. Augustine's High of Brooklyn and Don Bosco Institute of Ramsey, N.J., gained the right to meet in the final of the seventh annual metropolitan Catholic high school tournament by registering semi-final round victories at the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus clubhouse, in Brooklyn yesterday.

IGOR SCHWEZOFF, son of an officer in the Czars army, grew from childhood to youth in the period of the war and the Russian revolution. His attitude toward the Bolshevist overturn, which occurred when he was 13 years old, is one of childlike acceptance which probably presents the nearest possible human approach to impartiality.

CONSIDER the difference between theory and fact, as discovered by rile in "The Postman Always Rings Twice," this play of mine that opened twelve days ago at the Lyceum. In theory, as explained by me to Bob Sinclair, the director, and such other persons as had time to listen to me, this opus was a sound job down to the middle of Act II.
The Rhineland was evacuated June 30, 1930, by the last of the Allied forces that had entered shortly after the close of the World War and remained for twelve years.

MONTREAL, March 7 (AP). -- The Montreal Maroons tonight scored a 5-3 victory over the Detroit Red Wings to win their season series with that team in the National Hockey League. Each team previously had won two home games with the other, played in Detroit, ending in a tie.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 7. -- A strenuous conflict has been going on behind the scenes in Westchester during the past ten days to determine whether the partial reformists or the complete reformists shall submit their county charter proposals to the voters of the county this year.

PASSION: The question of haggis from Scotland or from France came up in the Canadian Parliament last week. Because of foot-and-mouth disease regulations, the Scottish product is barred; but he who wants haggis may get it from France. This does not satisfy at least one man, whose complaint was read in the House by William Fraser, Liberal.

Up and down the Atlantic seaboard, wherever yachtsmen congregate at clubs and shipyards, there will be hundreds henceforth who will lose their qualms of fear about a Spring or Fall cruise down South to Florida, now that the last remaining outside passage between the Delaware River and Miami has been eliminated.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 7. -- Membership in the honor school has been awarded to thirty-three freshmen in the College of Arts and Sciences of Rutgers University in recognition of their scholastic standing.

BOSTON, March 7 (AP). -- A long row over the presentation by the theatrical division of the Massachusetts Works Progress Administration of the play "Valley Forge" brought the transfer of one official tonight and the demotion of another.

JUST opened at the Brooklyn Museum is a new show: the forty-sixth annual exhibition of Pictorial Photography by the Department of Photography of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences. Forty-six years that photographers have been trying to make an art of their work with the camera!

LAKE PLACID, N.Y. -- Late Winter visitors at this Adirondack resort are enjoying some of the finest skiing of the entire season. As many as twelve groups set out from the Lake Placid Club within the past few days to ski to various points in this vicinity and through the high mountain trails and passes.

EASTON, Pa., March 7. -- Lafayette College will celebrate on March 20 the seventieth anniversary of the founding of its engineering courses. The program will include addresses by several of the leading engineers in America, an engineering and industrial exhibit, dinners and conferences.
Only thirteen persons were arrested as a result of the building service strike yesterday and the police described the day as the quietest since the strike got under way.

THERE seems to be an unwritten law that no guests are to watch Arturo Toscanini, noted Italian maestro, rehearse an orchestra. His word is law. But radio, invisible and mysterious as it is, provides a spyglass through the windowed studio booth -- the "crow's nest," in which the sponsor finds most comfortable chairs and a superb view of the performance.

The American Express Company yesterday reported a net income for 1935 of $1,225,994, including $633,163 profit on sales of United States Government, State, municipal and other marketable securities, and after deducting expenses, taxes, reserves and other charges.

BOISE, Idaho, March 6. -- Until a few weeks ago Idaho citizens were asking, "Will Governor C. Ben Ross run against Senator Borah?" Now that it is definitely believed that Cowboy Ben will ride to the Senatorial wars, the question is phrased: "Will Senator Borah run against Governor Ross?"

MOSCOW, March 7. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler's speech was received here as the last desperate bluff -- indeed as almost an effort at blackmail -- by the Fuehrer to forestall Parliamentary ratification of the Franco-Soviet pact, but his effort contains ludicrous and naive contradictions which temper the menace.

LONDON, March 7. -- The Chinese art exhibition in the Royal Academy closed today. It is estimated it has been seen by 400,000 persons. The Italian exhibition a few years ago drew 500,000, but the Chinese was the most successful of all other national art shows held in London.

DALHART, TEXAS. SHADES of the Eighties on the plains of Texas, when six-guns ruled the West and savage loboes took their toll from cattle herds, were recalled recently when the Commissioner's Court of Dallam County placed a bounty of one cent each on 10,000 roaming jack rabbits.
LOS ANGELES, March 7. -- Bernard Shaw was heckled by an interviewer today as, arriving on their world tour, the British author and Mrs. Shaw sought out a quiet spot in a hotel dining room.

THE vagaries of love are greater than the vagaries of any other human occupation," says Philip Wylie. And this is the reason that romances of all varieties, light and heavy, continue to sell well and offer endless entertainment.

ADVICES from London state that Pierpont Morgan has lent his celebrated painting, "Miss Linley and Her Brother," for the Gainsborough exhibition, which is declared to be the most representative collection ever assembled and contains pictures not previously seen by the public.

Philip Halperin, managing director and chairman of the board of the Houndsditch Warehouse Company, Ltd., London, England, announced here yesterday that he has concluded arrangements with the E.W. Bruno Corporation, in association with Kirby, Block Co., for representation in this country.

A DEGREE in "public administration" will be offered hereafter at the University of Texas to meet the need of local governmental units for trained public officials, according to Dr. J.A. Fitzgerald, dean of the Business School.

With its job rolls virtually full, the National Youth Administration turned yesterday to a critical evaluation of the experiment which has provided employment and educational subsidies for 22,500 young people in this city.

ALBANY, March 7 (AP). -- President Roosevelt and Postmaster General Farley, facing an administration dilemma as to who should be included in a contemplated series of stamps to honor American heroes, had two offers of assistance tonight. They came from Dr. Dixon Ryan Fox, president of the State Historical Association, and Edward N. Scheiberling, State Commander of the American Legion.

Baron Amaury de la Grange, French Senator, sailed for home at noon yesterday on the French liner Champlain. A member of the Senate Committee on Aviation, he came to this country to confer with officials of the government and airways on a projected transatlantic air service between the two countries.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 7. -- "The team just doesn't figure to be as poor as it was last year. It doesn't seem possible for a club to have two such bad years in succession."

PHILADELPHIA, March 7. -- Mrs. Cornelia Bryce Pinchot, wife of former Governor Pinchot, told a group of her supporters here this afternoon that on Monday she would file nomination petitions as a Republican candidate for Congress in the Fifth Pennsylvania District, embracing much of Philadelphia's textile area.
PARIS, March 7. -- The marriage of Douglas Fairbanks and Lady Ashley today was held in the gold-leafed marriage salon of the Eighth Ward City Hall, under a ceiling of floating pink-fleshed cupids.

An outline of possible contributions women can make to government after a careful study of the subject will be submitted on Tuesday by Pearl Bernstein, secretary of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment, at the budget campaign closing tea of the New York City League of Women Voters.

THE world has plenty of bluebirds, blueberries, bluefish, blue grass, blueprints, blue laws, blue songs and just plain blues, out it has long suffered from a limited choice of blue coloring matter for painting, printing and dyeing.

In their daily shuttle up and down, the city's elevators travel 100,000 miles, which is four times around the earth at the Equator. On this tremendous journey they bear, besides freight, 15,000,000 passengers, almost twice as many as all those carried by the subways, trolleys, elevated and buses.

While Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. prepared last week to take the Minimum Wage Law for women to the United States Supreme Court, a move to take the case to the laundry owners concerned was launched by the League of Women Voters.
BERLIN, March 7. -- Germany re-established the "watch on the Rhine" today.
TOLEDO, March 7. -- The fourteenth annual dog show of the Toledo Kennel Club opened this morning with an entry of 558 dogs, the largest in the history of the club.

IT is not surprising, in view of the widespread interest that is bound to be stirred by the exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, to find several galleries concurrently offering one-man shows by satellites who have been going in heavily for this sort of thing.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- As the primaries approach for the selection of delegates to the Republican National Convention, with the first in New Hampshire next Tuesday, the strategy of leading contenders for the nomination for President is becoming more clearly defined.
WASHINGTON, March 7. -- A desire to await the March 15 yield from income taxes before deciding upon the size of the Revenue Bill was expressed today by some members of Congress.

WARRENTON, Va. -- The Warrenton Hunt has announced meets during March on Mondays, Wednesdays and Saturdays, weather permitting. But though the weather is now very tempting, the ground, softened after deep freezing, is not yet fitted for cross-country riding.

SINCE the first pulse-beat of time the street cleaner has been -- with one notable exception -- neglected in legend and in history. The Job of Hercules on the untidy Augean stables achieved classical record, but that was due to the strong man's flair for publicity.

PARIS, March 7. -- The elections of members of the French Chamber of Deputies will be held April 26 with a run-off balloting May 3. The Chamber defeated Thursday a bill for a proportional count on a single balloting.

A PRESIDENTIAL-ELECTION year brings out unexpected crops of biographies, but there is no reason to believe that this volume has the purpose of aiding the candidacy of its subject. It may be a useful document, however, for the nominee to whom this journalistic political wanderer gives his support in 1936.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP). -- Work of the Senate Lobby Committee, sharply assailed by the American Liberty League and other groups, was defended today by Chairman Black with the comment that "there have been countless false statements made about us."

IT has been said of my novel "An American Tragedy" that in it the idea of economic stratification, the wealthy members of society superimposed upon the poor, and the tragic results of the same to the less fortunate were more implied than argued, and with this I agree, since it was what I intended.

Hope for settlement of the strike of elevator operators and other building service employes was revived last night after another appeal to both sides by Mayor La Guardia to submit the dispute to arbitration.

BERLIN, March 7. -- Germany today cast off the last shackles fastened upon her by the Treaty of Versailles when Adolf Hitler, a commander-in-chief of the Reich defense forces, sent his new battalions into the Rhineland demilitarized zone.

Foreign traders and domestic manufacturers emerged last week from a study of this country's 1985 trade with entirely different conclusions in the lively controversy over the effectiveness of the nation's reciprocal trade policy. As a result the coming weeks will witness a renewal of the battle in which one side seeks to have the program extended while the other aims at forcing its abandonmnt on the ground of complete failure.

Weekly meetings are being held by members of the Junior League who are working on various committees in arranging the gala jubilee to be held at the league clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street, on April 17. The occasion will be the first time the building has been opened to the public since its official inauguration as the new headquarters of the league several years ago.

A large attendance of members of society is assured for the annual International Ice Skating Carnival which will be presented at Madison Square Garden on two nights -- March 22 and 25 -- for the benefit of the convalescent relief division of the Bellevue Hospital Social Service Bureau, and the Carroll Club of New York and its vacation camp.

Entries in the Constitution Contest for the best teaching plans and articles prepared by high school teachers, which THE NEW YORK TIMES is conducting in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, reached a total yesterday of 301 public and preparatory institutions.

Dr. Herbert J. Spinden, president of the American Anthropological Association, will leave for Nicaragua on Tuesday in an effort to determine the origin of the ancient Chorotegan tribes and collect articles made by the Mosquito and Suma Indians who inhabit the little-known forest land southwest of Matagalpa.

Through the austere oak portals of the United States District Court yesterday morning measured voices with varying pitches, punctuated by the sharp raps of a gavel, penetrated with what seemed the unreasonable repetition of an odd formula.
LONDON, Sunday, March 8. -- Typical of British press comment on the re-entry of German troops into the demilitarized Rhineland zone is that of Viscount Rothermere's Sunday Dispatch, which says:

FORGING ahead after the slackening caused by adverse weather conditions, retail trade in some sections last week was the best since the Christmas season. Other centers reported fair gains and particularly bright prospects. Pent-up demand is being released.

Sweeping changes are to be made by the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange in devising a new contract to replace the present A coffee contract. Members of the Exchange will be called to a meeting on March 30 to vote on a new contract in which trading would replace the A contract entirely beginning with May, 1937.

The extent to which New York City's normal life hangs upon the comparatively slender elevator cable was vividly demonstrated last week. The city's vertical transportation system carries more passengers daily than all its other transit facilities combined.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 7. -Federal Judge Harlan W. Rippey denied today the petition of three corporations for a temporary injunction to restrain the Labor Relations Board from acting upon complaints of unions that the concerns were guilty of unfair labor practices in violation of the Wagner Labor Relations Act.

THIS tale goes far toward justifying the saying of its titular character that "anything can happen in Arizona." Henry Harrison Conroy, fat, heavy and 55, had spent all his life on the vaudeville stage, but retired there-from to become a rancher when an uncle died and left him the J Bar C Ranch in Wild Horse Valley.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- In certain particulars the controversy between the Lobby Inquiry Committee of the Senate and the attorneys and industrialists whose complete telegraphic files it has either copied or attempted, over certain periods, to seize, contains elements of more importance to citizens than the discussion over judicial supremacy as expressed in the invalidation of acts of Congress by the Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- The Board of Tax Appeals in a ruling made public today upheld Roosevelt Sons Investment Fund in the proceedings begun by the Bureau of Internal Revenue on March 9, 1934, to collect an additional assessment of $104,000.86 in connection with income tax for 1929.

The share market evinced considerable nervousness yesterday over the latest threat to the peace of Europe, and the steady advance of prices begun earlier in the week was arrested. At the closing of the half-day trading period stocks were irregular, with many of the leaders off fractionally, a few down a point or two.

Selection of the United States team to take part in the Olympic yacht races off Kiel, Germany, next August was confirmed yesterday by Philip J. Roosevelt, president of the North American Yacht Racing Union.
REPORTS and statistics on the business of broadcasting reveal that 1935 was a year of progress and prosperity for the "ethereal" industry here and abroad.

Much has been written and more has been said about the decline of the dramatic stock company. The talkies and the radio have been named as the cause for the dearth of the resident units. Other than the Summer companies and the few sponsored "festivals," the country sees very little of good companies.

PARIS, March 7. -- French officials declared tonight that France was ready to use her army, supported by her allies, to compel Germany to evacuate the Rhineland, but that she first would exhaust the peaceful methods possible under the League of Nations.

AFTER eighteen years of rule the Soviet Government has at last removed the emblems of the Czar from the four towers of Moscow's Kremlin, the ancient fortress which encloses many historic palaces and cathedrals built by the Romanoffs and their predecessors.

MANCHESTER, N.H., March 7. -- In an election unique in New England's industrial history, 3,669 employes of the Amoskeag Manufacturing Company, once the largest cotton textile combine in the world and now involved in reorganization proceedings in Federal court, today voted to accept a 15 per cent wage cut and permit "permanent peaceful operations."

WHEN Professor Hull of Swarthmore speaks of a Dutch Quaker migration to Pennsylvania he adds a new phase to Colonial history. The migration in question is that earuest movement of settlers from the Rhine Valley to Germantown, close by Philadelphia, in 1683.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- Four officers of S.S. Kresge Company received remuneration in 1934 of more than $100,000 each, according to data filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the corporation which was made public today after the commission had denied a request that it be considered confidential.

TORONTO, March 7 (AP). -- The Toronto Maple Leafs retained their one-point lead over the Montreal Maroons in the International Group of the National Hockey League tonight when they buried the Canadiens under an 8-1 score. The Maroons defeated Detroit.

That Germany has created a grave situation in Europe is readily apparent. Military occupation of the Rhineland is a clear violation both of the Versailles Treaty and of the Locarno Pact. It is a brusque repudiation of HITLER'S many declarations that he had no intention of jeopardizing the safeguards of peace erected on Germany's western frontier.

LONDON, Feb. 14. TWO pieces call for attention this week. The first, upon which comment may reasonably be brief because, though a good play, it is not one that provokes controversy, is "St. Helena," by Mr. Sherriff, the author of "Journey's End," and Jeanne de Casalis.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 7. -- More than 200 students, representing twenty-nine colleges in the Middle Atlantic States, closed their two-day experiment at Vassar College today in the conduct of a model "League of Nations." It was undertaken to discover if they could formulate a more effectual system of cooperation than the League itself has so far devised.

LONDON, March 6. -- Tired British Cabinet Ministers, hopeless of assuring peace by any international methods known to themselves, this week formally recommitted their government and country to preparation for war. It means that Britain is going to make the armament race already started on the Continent a much more serious affair by entering it herself, determined to run faster and further than any other competitor.

Beethoven's "Fidelio," revived yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House, with Kirsten Flagstad in the title part, attracted an immense throng, and moreover was a pronounced success with the audience. This is unusual. "Fidelio," a great work which is part convention and part masterpiece, does not always come off so well with the audience.

Hereafter, when you meet an old friend after a lapse of years and notice an indefinable difference, you need no longer be content with saying, "Somehow, you've changed." With sufficient data and a tape measure, you can measure the change pretty accurately.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 7. -- The vastly improved Harvard varsity basketball team scored its most impressive victory since joining the Eastern Intercollegiate league three years ago by defeating Cornell, 41 -- 24, in the Harvard indoor athletic building tonight.
The sale of liquor originally produced considerable Federal revenue. Prohibition halted little of the sale, but all the revenue. Repeal renewed that income.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- Carrying out a circus theme, the annual Beaux Arts Ball will be held next Thursday night in the Coliseum, providing another major social affair for Winter guests. Costumes will follow the tradition of the tan-bark, and acts from Ringling Brothers Circus will complete the "big top" atmosphere.

The phenomenal success of the National Sportsmen's Show provided additional proof, if such evidence were needed, of the outdoor-mindedness of the New York public. Viewing the capacity crowds and enthusiastic response in retrospect, one pauses to wonder why the promoters waited so long to bring the exposition to so fruitful a field.

I am glad your critic finds "Love on the Dole" an "honest and moving drama . . . beautifully acted." Amid the roar of "smash hits," the merely "honest and moving" is so likely to escape notice in the theatre. The less honest and more bizarre and sensational is a luckier bidder for that quick and facile success which has come to be almost the only alternative of failure along Broadway.

You pointed out in your recent editorial "Against Sterilization" that Dr. Abraham Myerson and his committee of the American Neurological Association disapprove compulsory sterilization, which is true, but you failed to state that both this committee and the British commission approve voluntary sterilization.
ROME, March 6. -- The League of Nations' peace appeal was so sudden that it left the majority of Italians gasping for breath.

A benefit concert and dance will be given under the auspices of Wellesley and Princeton interests in the metropolitan area on the night of March 27 in the ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The Princeton University Glee Club and the Wellesley College Choir will participate in the concert, net proceeds of which will benefit jointly the Music Library at Wellesley and the Music Fund of Princeton University.

Seven goals by Henry McMullen featured La Salle Military Academy's 9-1 triumph over New Utrecht High in their Metropolitan Interscholastic Hockey League game at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. The Oakdale sextet is now tied with 3rooklyn Prep for second place.

MANILA. -- Events since the inauguration last November of the Philippine Commonwealth Government are rapidly focusing public attention upon problems to be faced, and these are assuming greater and greater importance. Settling down to the sober business of living under a new government is not without its apprehensions.

TWELVE experts on nutrition, appointed by the League of Nations to study the nutritional needs of humans from birth to adult age, submitted a report recently in which it was asserted that dietary deficiencies are common in America and Europe.

CHICAGO, March 6. -- Chicago's well-advertised Health Commissioner, Dr. Herman N. Bundesen, is pressing his fight to wrest the Democratic primary nomination for Governor from Henry Homer, the holder of office. Dr. Bundesen has inscribed upon his banner the famous but somewhat tarnished slogan of American politics -- "To the Victors Belong the Spoils."
The annual luncheon of the Association of Assistants to Principals will be held Saturday at the Hotel Pierre. Miss J. MacDonald of 110 New York Avenue, Brooklyn, is in charge of reservations.

A strong performance with the saber enabled Columbia's fencing team to tie Navy at 13 1/2 to 13 1/2 yesterday in the Morningside Heights gymnasium. The Lions were trailing by 11 1/2 to 6 1/2 when the broad sword competition started and the Blue won seven of the nine bouts to earn the deadlock.

Whenever a great public question is thrown into politics, it is in danger of being wrongly stated. Partisans on both sides will exaggerate and perhaps misrepresent the real points at issue. As the debate grows hotter and the party attacks more violent, the public seems to fall more and more into the hands of extremists on either side.

Pupils who studied under Rubin Goldmark at the Juilliard Graduate School of Music will serve as ushers at funeral services for the composer at 10 A.M. today in the concert hall of the school, at 130 Claremont Avenue. Mr. Goldmark, who was president of the Bohemians, and for thirteen years head of the theory department of the school, died on Friday at the age of 63.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- If history repeats itself, the forthcoming Federal tax legislation, as ultimately adopted, will be basically different from that originally proposed. Nevertheless, if the projected principle of high rates of taxes upon undistributed earnings is enacted the consequences may be disastrous in their effects upon corporate forms of business enterprise.

NEW ORLEANS, March 7. -- Biff, a 5-year-old gelding from Fred Ianni's Stable, gave seven other sprinters an exhibition of his speed today in winning the six furlongs of the Pass Christian Handicap at the Fair Grounds.

PARIS, March 7. -- On the Bourse, news of the German decision to denounce the last restrictions of the Treaty of Versailles and to ask for a new Locarno agreement caused an immediate fall in rentes. Speculators soon found, however, that there was no public alarm and after having dropped a whole franc and more, rentes recovered, closing only slightly lower than yesterday's rates.

Werner Egk's "The Magic Fiddle" ("Die Zaubergeige") was given its first performance in Berlin recently. It tells the story of Kaspar, a peasant, who meets an elfin prince who bestows upon him a magic fiddle which will bring him fame and wealth, if, like Wagner's Alberich, he forswears mortal love.

When they had finished gathering together out of old newspaper clippings and committee reports the history of the Women's City Club, Mrs. Edward Dreier, Mrs. Genevieve Earle and Mrs. Lillian Dunlop, who have been guiding its activities these twenty years, leaned back in their chairs and indulged in reminiscence.

Detective Charles S. Corbett, whose charge of bribery in the Samuel Drukman murder case was one of the basic reasons for a special term of the Supreme Court, a special grand jury and a special prosecutor in Brooklyn, has been examined by a psychiatrist, it was revealed yesterday.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 7 (AP). -- Joe Mangan of the New York A.C. caught the judges' eyes when he ran what appeared to be a dead heat with the world-record holder, Glenn Cunningham of Kansas, tonight. They ran in a special mile race that featured the New England A.A.U. track and field champions at the auditorium.

A RULER without territory, but one who is held by his millions of followers in Asia, Europe and Africa to be literally worth his weight in gold, is the Aga Khan, religious head of the Ismaili sect of Moslems, who recently began his fifty-first year on the gadi (throne) of the Imam, at the age of 61.

MOSCOW, March 6. -- Reports in the Soviet press from time to time of sabotaging of the Stakhanoff movement and even of the murder of workers for increasing the pace show that the movement is meeting with the resistance that Joseph Stalin foresaw in the beginning.

ONLY eight teams of four entered the competition for the Curt Reisinger Cup in the Eastern tournament last week -- the smallest field this event ever attracted. The explanation is an encouraging one. The team-of-four tournament was held during the afternoons, and many of the bridge enthusiasts who customarily play in every tournament were unable to spare the time from their business.

Under the caption "Sanctions and the League" W.H. Pinkham by inference condemns the principle of sanctions as ethically unsound and physically impractical. In common with the traditional argument of isolationists, he points to their failure to produce results in Manchuria and Ethiopia, ignoring the fact that in neither case could they have been successfully applied by reason of our synthetic neutrality.

ATLANTA, March 7 (AP). -- Governor Talmadge today alleged that Clark Howell Sr., editor of The Atlanta Constitution, had threatened him with impeachment unless he granted demands of legislators for an extra session.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 7. -- Young women, untrained in any sort of domestic activity, are combining academic careers with housekeeping and doing it successfully at Vassar College.

The Hasty Pudding Club of Harvard University will present its annual amateur production in this city on April 3 at the Mecca Temple. Entitled "The Lid's Off," the book, music and acting for the production will be done by members of the club, which is one of the oldest of its kind in the country.

Marshaling the same arguments they presented back in 1920, when taxes on undivided corporation profits were first suggested, business executives last week moved to present strong opposition to President Roosevelt's proposal for a levy of approximately 33 1-3 per cent on corporation surpluses.

MEMPHIS, March 6. -- The American farmers went home from two great regional farm conferences, held at the capitals of the grain and cotton areas this week, appreciating for the first time the sweeping character of the Supreme Court decision that ended government control of their operations and the processing tax method of financing that scheme.

AMONG the students of social science on both sides of the Atlantic no names enjoy a greater respect than do those of Sidney and Beatrice Webb, a respect in their case not unmixed with affection. Their monumental work on the Soviet Union is the most ambitious attempt that has yet appeared in any language to interpret the stupendous changes that have taken place during the last eighteen years in the former Empire of the Czars.

THE days when women suffered in silence having been definitely relegated to the past, modern authors are prone to brandish the intricacies of holy wedlock for our edification. The marriage in question differs from the majority, in that it is devoid of in-law complications or economic pressure.

TO a lover of the sea, of strange lands and remote places, and of physical risks, it would appear that the author of this book has led an ideal existence. On the other hand, it is easy to imagine that the experiences of Mr. Robinson could be very upsetting to a land-lubber.

The sixth national training conference of the Boy Scouts of America will be held at French Lick, Ind., from Wednesday through March 18. A two-day meeting of the organization's national and regional staffs will be held on Monday and Tuesday in French Lick.

BERLIN, March 7. -- Germany today resumed her "watch on the Rhine" when, with an astonishing bravado that dared challenge Europe to war or to peace and left the world breathless for the moment, the new German Army crossed the military frontier, which hitherto has separated it from France, and occupied the demilitarized Rhineland zone created by the Versailles treaty and reaffirmed at Locarno.

Wesley M. Dawson, district tax supervisor for the State personal income tax, announced yesterday that executive, administrative and clerical employes of the WPA are not subject to the tax. Although there has been no formal ruling; he explained, the attitude of the tax authorities at Albany is that these employes are performing Federal functions and therefore are not taxable by the State.

SPRING has really arrived at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, where, promptly on schedule, on March 1, the first snowdrops put in an appearance with their green and white buds. The Vernal Witchhazel is already unfolding its coppery colored flowers and its Japanese cousin is ready to follow suit.

MIAMI, Fla., March 7. -- In the most amazing performance brought off by a 3-year-old at a Winter track, Joseph E. Widener's Brevity today equaled Discovery's mile and a furlong world record when he won the $26,050 Florida Derby before 20,000 persons at Hialeah Park.
Nearly 300 members of the junior class of the New York University School of Commerce attended the annual promenade last night in the Teakwood Room of Essex House.

Miss Nancy T. Putnam, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert William Putnam of Rye, N.Y., gave a dinner last night in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria for Miss Hildegarde Schultz and William S. Norton, whose marriage will take place on April 4.

BURLINGTON, Vt., March 6. -- When Vermonters on March 3 polled a majority of 12,000 votes against the Green Mountain Parkway in a heated contest which brought out some 74,000 voters, they made a final decision on a question which has split the State wide open for almost all of three years.

SCARLET fury blazes once more over whether some paint on canvas is an immortal work of art or a felonious outrage. The Republic, this indicates, may be getting back to normal times. For when the whole country is engrossed in economic upheaval the cubists, dadaists and futurists are likely to be widely regarded as normal, even stodgy, fellows.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 6. -- Despite the efforts of Governor Talmadge and his spokesmen to make light of it, Seminole County's vote on Wednesday dealt a heavy blow to the Georgia Executive's campaign against President Roosevelt and the New Deal.

DALLAS, March 7. -- Spring weather has brought a marked revival in trade throughout the Eleventh Federal Reserve District and as a result, the spirit of optimism that was so evident immediately following the holiday season has returned.

The team of Jules G. Wetzlar and T. Cunningham won the Goldman Cup play, the leading pairs event of the bridge season, last night at the Eastern Contract Bridge championships at the Hotel Commodore, after a full week's session of play.

CLARENCE DAY was a most admirable character in the literary world and his life was saved from tragedy only by the fine courage of his gallant spirit. He enlisted in the navy at the time of the Spanish-American War and in the course of his service contracted a bad case of arthritis that grew worse and worse until he became helplessly bedridden.

THE phrase "hands across the border" has taken on a new meaning for students of the Woodstock, N.B., High School and of Ricker Classical Institute at Houlton, Me. History and social science classes of the two schools recently held the first of a series of joint meetings to discuss current problems of mutual interest to the United States and Canada.

ROUSSEAU began his "Confessions": "I have begun on a work which is without precedent, whose accomplishment will have no imitator. I propose to set before my fellow-mortals a man in all the truth of nature; and this man shall be myself."

VIENNA, March 7. -- Official Vienna declared tonight that no one conversant with the trend of German policy could be surprised by today's events. It was pointed out that this policy has been going on since the Chancellorships of Gustav Stresemann and Dr. Heinrich Bruening, and Adolf Hitler merely changed the methods of application, the sudden surprising moves having been initiated by himself.

THE claim of discovering fresh talent for stage and screen been so much exploited by various producers, agents and whatnot that the public can't be blamed for a certain amount of confusion, especially when they read biographies which don't jibe.

Five persons were killed and one other was seriously injured soon after 3 A.M. yesterday when an automobile left the Interborough Parkway at an underpass near Cypress Hills Street, Glendale, Queens, and crashed into a pillar supporting an overpass.

FOR the first time in almost eight years Boy Scout executives will gather next Wednesday for a conference at French Lick, Ind. These men are the professionally trained and paid leaders of the movement. There are less than a thousand of them, against more than 220,000 other leaders who give their time freely.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- Contending that the Southern Railway apparently was planning to recover compensation because part of its Vasper-La Follette branch would be under water as a result of the construction of the Norris Dam, the Tennessee Valley Authority today filed a petition with the Interstate Commerce Commission asking that the Southern be required to apply for and receive a certificate of public convenience and necessity authorizing abandonment of the branch line.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- The power of courts to nullify acts of Congress was attacked today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, who declared that this practice establishes "government by the judiciary."

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP). -Officials of Federal lending agencies estimated today that they would be able to cut more than $1,000,000,000 from the amounts that Congress had given them permission to spend.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 7. -- The arrival this week of forty-one tons of steel at the Palmer physical laboratory of Princeton University heralded the installation of a cyclotron, expected to bombard atoms with particles traveling at higher speeds than have heretofore been obtained.

Pretzels, whose picture has appeared on countless bottles of bock beer, won first prize yesterday afternoon in a "goat beauty contest" at the Mall in Central Park. A small crowd of "repeaters" (those who follow goat contests) attended the event, which was conducted under the auspices of the Brewers Board of Trade.

LONDON. -- Labor camps for the workless, tried out already in many lands, are gradually being adopted by Great Britain. The government, faced with a bloc unemployment which, except for a few months last Autumn and this Winter, has not fallen below 2,000,000 since 1919, has come to believe that the dole alone is not adequate.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- While the House Ways and Means Subcommittee studying the proposed new tax schedule suspended sessions until Monday and individual members went over the various suggestions today, the Chamber of Commerce of the United States summoned its Federal taxes and expenditures committee to meet here next Thursday to consider the proposals.

INTEREST in model-building circles is centering upon the forthcoming decision in the world-wide contest, sponsored by the French Line in conjunction with the Model Builders Guild, which resulted in the submission of 2,000 models of the liner Normandie.

I read THE TIMES comment on King Edward's speech with interest. May I point out that the phrase "Oxford accent" is itself an Americanism? I never recall hearing the phrase till I came to this country. A little reflection should show that there is no sense in it.

An appeal to those who would conserve the beauty of natural scenery to protest against the proposed Grand Lake-Big Thompson trans-mountain water diversion project through Rocky Mountain National Park was made yesterday afternoon by Horace M. Albright, former director of the Division of National Parks.
PARIS, March 6 -- The logic of the course which France has followed ever since the World War has reached its inevitable conclusion.

SEVERAL facts disturbing to the experienced driver, who believes he can take care of almost any emergency on the road and relies on his supposed ability to do so, have been unearthed in a survey by the safety education division of Michigan's State Highway Department.
Jerry Horan, president of the Building Service Employes International Union, who arrived from Chicago Friday, denied yesterday that he was a close friend of Al Capone.

President of the City College. THE heart of a college or university is the library. It gives life to every department. The extent of its resources establishes the range of independent work of professors and students; the effectiveness of its operation sets the pace of scholarly endeavor.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 7. -- Yale Sheffield Scientific School Fraternities and clubs tonight held as and dinner dances, and the Guests of Junior Promenade Week attended in large numbers the Yale-Harvard five athletic events and the production of "Wings Over Europe" by the Yale Dramatic Association as the final numbers of the annual society week-end of the University.
ALBANY, March 7. -- The text of the radio address by Speaker Ives tonight was as follows:

WEST POINT, N.Y., March 7. -- Army and Penn State battled to a 4-4 tie at boxing in one of the features of an attractive sports program at the Academy today. The bouts were closely fought, notably in the 155-pound and unlimited classes, where intercollegiate champions were competing for State.

PARIS, March 7. -- After many vicissitudes, which included a collision between his automobile and a taxicab as he was on his way to the wedding this morning, Douglas Fairbanks, 53-year-old film actor, was married by Mayor Gaston Drucker of the Eighth Ward of Paris to Sylvia Hawkes, formerly the wife of Lord Ashley of Britain.

MR. POWELL'S world-wide rovings, as described in his long list of twoscore and more of books, show that he had left unvisited not many of the places on the face of the earth to which it was possible for travelers to go. But not yet had he paid extended attention to the countries and the colonies of the Caribbean.

WARSAW, March 7. -- Chancellor Hitler's speech did not surprise Warsaw. The Locarno repudiation had been expected here following the ratification of the Soviet pact by the French Chamber of Deputies and, indeed, General Hermann Goering, German Air Minister, during his recent hunting visit here told Colonel Josef Beck, Polish Foreign Minister, of the German Government's intentions.

Announcement has been made here of plans for a Bermuda Blue Ball to be held at the Hamilton Hotel in Bermuda on April 1 as a benefit jointly for the Seamen's Church Institute of New York and the Seamen's Institute of Bermuda. Prominent members of Bermuda society and the Winter colony there are active in preparations for the event.

PHILADELPHIA, March 7. -- Driving hard in the closing minutes, Columbia erased Penn's five-point lead to defeat the Red and Blue, 27 to 25, at the Palestra tonight for its tenth victory in as many starts in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League.

HANOVER, N.H., March 7. -- Dartmouth closed its Eastern Intercollegiate League season by defeating the strong Princeton quintet tonight, 48 to 40. With the Nassau five fighting to overcome a three-point lead in the closing fifteen seconds.

I am writing this letter in what is probably the vain hope that you will use your column to plead, beg, urge, insist that actors and actresses on the Broadway stages make themselves understood. It is not a matter of hearing. One can hear well enough.

ETON, they say, is being modernized Eton of the celebrated playing fields -- Eton of the "distant spires" and "antique towers that crown the watery glade" -- Eton of the little top hats, is being modernized. As the largest, the most expensive and easily the most famous of the English "public schools" (which are not public but private).
BALTIMORE, March 7. -- Former United States Senator Bruce, a Democrat, announced today that he would vote for the Republican candidate in November's Presidential election.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 7. -- Blair Academy dominated the sixteenth annual Rutgers University interscholastic swimming championships in the Rutgers pool today, capturing the team title for the second consecutive year and setting two new national records in the 300-yard medley and 200-yard free-style relays.

OPENING of German's Berlin to Leipzig, 186-mile television-phone line during the past week was heralded in dispatches as the first public "see-speech" circuit across which telephonists may view each other as they converse.

TOLD skillfully as an adventure memoir in the Stevensonian manner, this story has its beginnings in England of the Eighteen Twenties, but its principal events happen at sea and in a strange utopian colony -- Port of Heaven -- flourishing piously on the coast of Peru.

THERE is a great deal of charm in the contents of this small, modest-looking, paper-bound volume. Its twenty-four short sketches deal for the most part with famous characters of pre-revolutionary Russia. Some of them apparently record Mr. Peterson's own experiences.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 7. -- A record number of 300 Harvard College freshmen, or about one-third of the entire class, are taking courses this year which are not ordinarily open to first-year students, it was revealed here tonight by Dr. Richard M. Gummere, chairman of the Harvard committee on admissions.

LONDON. APPARENTLY the poetic film will not come into its own as quickly as was anticipated a few months back. For British producers who then were full of plans for filming Shakespeare now are holding their hands, presumably, until they have seen what sort of reception is accorded Norma Shearer's "Romeo and Juliet" and Elisabeth Bergner's "As You Like It."

TRENTON, N.J., March 7. -- The breach that has been developing between Governor Harold G. Hoffman and Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf over the Bruno Richard Hauptmann case was widened today when the State Police Superintendent did not make his weekly report on the renewed investigation ordered by the Governor.

FOURTEEN canvases by Camille Pissarro have been placed on view (until March 28) at the Durand-Ruel Galleries. This admirable show raises no new issues, naturally enough, concerning French Impressionism; but it does provide an excellent scenario of the artist's development from 1873 to 1896, and is of particular value in that the pointillist phase of 1886 has been prominently featured.

BERLIN, March 7. -- Losing not a moment's time, Chancellor Adolf Hitler and his party already have launched the election campaign which is to renew the mandate given the Nazis three years ago to rule dictatorially. The present allNazi Reichstag was elected Nov. 12, 1933, but Hitler had asked for totalitarian powers through the Reichstag and received them in the election of March 5 the same year.

Once more the question of taxation dominates the scene in Washington. President Roosevelt's message of last week, recommending a new revenue bill to raise three-quarters of a billion dollars, has confronted Congress with the most painful of all issues to be faced in an election year, posed new questions for the Democratic party, and brought from the Republicans a jubilant assertion that this is only the first installment on the cost of the New Deal.

Disclosing a new angle in the effort of the New York Stock Exchange to enlighten the uninitiated among investors and purchasers of shares, Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, in almost every speech in his present "good will" tour of the South and Southwest, has stressed the need for caution when buying stock.

A SIGNIFICANT feature of the air news of the week was the order placed by United Air Lines, amounting to about $1,000,000, for ten of the new twenty-four-passenger Douglas DC-3 transports. This step marks a breakdown in the practice of purchasing equipment on the part of the airlines from allied manufacturing groups, which has been the general practice where operators were connected through holding companies with plane-building units.

EARLY last November when his impassioned tabulators reported to him that some 400,000 souls had paid tribute to "The Children's Hour" since its opening year previously, Herman Shumlin, producer of the play, laid down his Proust, wrinkled his brow, and started to ponder.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- The number of needy high school students being aided by the program of the National Youth Administration totals 166,347, Aubrey Williams, NYA director, stated today. These students are receiving a maximum of $6 monthly for part-time work supervised by school authorities.

GENEVA, March 7. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler's offer to return to the League of Nations and his other proposals were overshadowed here today by his occupation of the Rhineland after having denounced the Treaty of Locarno in the unilateral manner the League condemned a year ago.

THIS book is exactly what its title represents it to be -- no less and no more. It is not a biography of the man who built Trinity Church in Boston, the Allegheny County jail in Pittsburgh and the Marshall Field store in Chicago. It is not chatty. It is not personal.

THE annual convention held by the Society of American Magicians in Chicago recently drew a record attendance among amateur magicians who dabble in the "black art" as a hobby. Of the 900 members active in the organization many enthusiasts are engaged in professional work requiring mental proficiency.

Another in the series of Dolphin Dances for debutantes of next season will take place on April 3 in the grand ballroom of the Pierre. This will be the third Easter dance in the series, and many former subscribers, including debutantes of this season and last, are expected to attend.

NASSAU, Bahamas. -- The yachting season is in full swing in Nassau. The final heats in the Royal Nassau Sailing Club series for the New York Yacht Club Cup are scheduled for next Wednesday and Friday; the ladies' race for the Dr. James C. Ayer Cup will be sailed on Saturday and the series for the Anthony Drexel Cup and a schooner race will be sailed later in the month.

LIGHT, atmosphere and cool color are preoccupations of Stephen Etnier, whose annual exhibition at the Milch Galleries will be current through March 21. For the canvases in the present show, Etnier has divided his attention between the Maine coast and Haiti.

TRADITIONS of cultural difficulty about certain plants often do not have any real foundation in fact. Usually they are based on a lack of understanding of the needs of the species or variety involved. As a result many interesting flowers are never grown in the open because it is the accepted belief that they will thrive only in a greenhouse, under conditions of semi-tropical heat and moisture.

NATION-WIDE mobilization of its 752 affiliated motor clubs for a greatly expanded program of activities designed to reduce highway fatalities and injuries was announced by the American Automobile Association last week.

BOSTON, March 6. -- Postmaster General Farley had ample reasons for coming to New England this week in his political capacity as Chairman of the Democratic National Committee. New Hampshire on Tuesday, first of all the States, will hold its Presidential primaries.

PHILADELPHIA, March 8. -- Senator Borah's announced determination to enter the Pennsylvania Presidential preferential primary came as a surprise to many politicians in view of the fact that several weeks ago, upon the advice of former Governor Pinchot, he had virtually agreed to stay out because of the expense involved.

Sanitary District of Chicago. A new issue of $41,469,000 Sanitary District of Chicago 4 per cent refunding bonds, series B, due on Jan. 1, 1955, and callable variously on Jan. 1, 1937 to 1954, will be put on the market today at prices to yield 1 to 3.77 per cent to the optional call dates.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., March 8. -- "Never take the easy way out," Dr. Archey D. Ball of the First Methodist Episcopal Church told his congregation in his sermon this morning. Because of his liberal views and emphasis on social reforms, Dr. Ball was "asked" this week to end his pastorate here next month.

BERLIN, March 6. -- By declining to less than 74,000,000 marks in the last week in February, the Reichsbank's reserve established a new low record. The lowest in earlier years was 77,000,000 marks. Since July, 1935, there has been a decrease of 26 per cent.

ROME, March 8. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler's denunciation of the Locarno treaty is regarded as the greatest piece of luck that has come Italy's way since the beginning of the Ethiopian controversy. The general belief is that it means the end of sanctions and that it will help Premier Benito Mussolini enormously in getting what he wants in Ethiopia.

ADDIS ABABA, March 8. -- The death of Ras Mulugheta, War Minister and leader of one of Ethiopia's three northern armies, was admitted today at Quoram. It was stated he has succumbed to pneumonia, resulting from exposure.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1936, as well as last price, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

The pamphlet report of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and subsidiaries for 1935 shows current assets of $33,739,291 at the close of the year, including $19,159,123 cash, and current and accrued liabilities of $14,249,786.

Miss Dorothy Locke, former national champion, exhibiting an encouraging return to form, captured the second of the Olympic series of fencing tryouts yesterday on the strips of the Fencers Club. It was a superb performance that the Salle d'Armes Vince star gave in winning eleven of her twelve engagements in convincing style.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- The administration's farm program, enacted into law as the Soil Conservation and Domestic Allotment Act, which President Roosevelt signed a week ago, has for its prime object the continuance of cash benefits to farmers during the forthcoming national campaign, the American Liberty League maintained in a pamphlet issued today.

In reference to THE TIMES dispatch from San Juan, P.R., reporting the arrest of several members of the Nationalist party, and the comments from Washington that Secretary Ickes considers the Nationalists' leader, who was arrested, very dangerous, I concur with his views that law and order should prevail.

Selection of the official poster design from among the numerous suggestions submitted to the Cotton-Textile Institute has formally launched preparations for the 1936 observance of National Cotton Week, June 1 to 6. Picturing an average American family and an average home against a cotton boll background, the red, white and blue poster emphasizes the claim that today "everybody uses cotton" everywhere.

Two works not yet presented this season will return to the repertoire in the closing week at the Metropolitan Opera House next week. They will be Debussy's "Pelleas et Melisande," which will open the week next Monday evening, and Wagner's "Parsifal," which will be presented in a special matinee on Friday afternoon.
Two new issues of bonds of telephone companies amounting to $4,050,000 will be placed on the market today.

Negotiations for settlement of the strike of elevator operators and other building service employes, which were terminated in a deadlock early Wednesday morning, will be resumed today, Mayor La Guardia announced last night.

Spring distribution of legal-sized trout in New York State waters is well under way, the Conservation Department reports. Planting activities were inaugurated last week with the liberation of 10,000 catch-able brook trout in the streams of Hamilton and Warren Counties.
PEN portraits inspired by a reading of "The Anatomy of Personality" (Harper, $3), in which Drs. Howard W. Haggard and Clements C. Fry of Yale University give me some dandy new words to play with:

A meeting of Chinese laundrymen, ordinarily held with exemplary Oriental calm and the shrewdness of men engaged in the most popular Chinese industry in this country, broke up in a brawl with swinging chairs in a meeting room at 196 Canal Street last night, with three men arrested and four others in hospitals.

Out of a "worthy and well-meaning social enthusiasm" there is arising a conception that the chief function of the church is to "destroy capitalism and bring in that vague entity called the 'New Social Order,'" the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, the pastor, said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

ROME, March 8. -- Germany's action of yesterday was expected and Chancellor Adolf Hitler has never concealed that military reoccupation of the Rhineland zone would be a natural consequence of Germany's rearmament.

LONDON, March 8. -- Miss Eleonora Sears of Boston, non-playing captain of the American international squash racquets team, today announced the line-up of the players as they will meet the British women tomorrow in the annual Wolfe-Noel Cup match on the Landsdowne House courts.

The American Smelting and Refining Company reported yesterday for 1935 a consolidated net income of $13,768,153 after all charges, including taxes and bond interests. This was equal, after dividend requirements on both classes of preferred stocks, to $5.01 each on the 1,829,940 shares of common stock outstanding. It compares with $7,583,202, or $1.63 a common share, in 1934.

BERLIN, March 8. -- The German Army, through General Werner von Blomberg, the War Minister, thanked Chancellor Adolf Hitler today for restoring military sovereignty to the Rhineland and pledged unswerving devotion to him and the Nazi cause.

Religion will be the last great battleground in the world and the opposing forces will be "a society that is God-conscious" and "a society that calls itself God," Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen, Professor of Fundamental Theology at the Catholic University of America, Washington, D.C., predicted yesterday in the second of a series of Lenten sermons at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
The action of the Court of Appeals in declaring the Minimum Wage Law unconstitutional has not abolished the problem which must be met.

Arthur Fear, baritone of the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, London, gave a recital yesterday afternoon at the Town Hall before an audience which made up in enthusiasm for what it lacked in size. The English vocalist and actor, who first appeared here two years ago, proved at his best in ballads by his countrymen.

PARIS, March 6. -- The Chamber of Deputies will adjourn in a few days, probably after voting some increased expenditures. It is believed, therefore, that the question of devaluation of the franc will not come up again before the new Chamber meets after the elections on May 26.
WASHINGTON, March 8. -- The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress last week are given in the following tabulation:

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $5,315,013,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

The Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman of Central Congregational Church, Brooklyn, warned against the danger that we might lose our political freedom as a result of "widespread paganism" in a sermon yesterday morning commemorating the twenty-fifth anniversary of the pastorate of the Rev. Dr. John Howland Lathrop at the Unitarian Church of the Saviour, Pierrepont Street and Monroe Place, Brooklyn.

Hemphill, Noyes Co. have opened an office in the Fletcher Trust Building, Indianapolis, under the direction of Roger G. Wolcott. E.E. Bollinger, H.T. Hession and Yale Rice are with him. Richard Roelofs Jr. also is with the company.

Your editorial regret that the police safety program proposes increased traffic speed in New York follows an outworn theory that speed per se causes accidents, whereas speed actually reduces accidents by relieving traffic lanes of the hesitating tactics, passing attempts and nervous confusion always found in dense population centers. Speed, via momentum, is a fatality factor but not a causation.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- President Roosevelt's fiscal advisers have taken such a definite stand against alterations in the proposed undistributed corporate profit tax that the President may have to act to prevent a serious contest within his own political family.

Before setting out to reform the world a person should reform himself, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of Riverside Church, at 122d Street and Riverside Drive, said in his sermon yesterday.

A Christian program of race relations to combat prejudice and to work for social justice for the Negro is the only solution to the interracial problem in the United States, the Rev. John La Farge, prominent Jesuit educator and writer, said yesterday.

When President ROOSEVELT sent his tax message to Congress last week he set in motion machinery for the enactment of the fifth major revenue bill to be enacted in the space of five consecutive years. In 1932 the Hoover Administration, which had lowered taxes temporarily immediately following the 1929 stock-market panic, sought to raise them in order to balance a budget which had already been thrown out of equilibrium.

A resolution inviting Democrats dissatisfied with the New Deal to support the Republican nominee for President and virtually promising them recognition by cabinet and other appointments if the nominee is elected will be introduced and probably adopted at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland in June, it was learned yesterday.

BERLIN, March 8. -- While German troops with all the accoutrements of war were still marching westward into the formerly demilitarized Rhineland zone, the German nation observed with mingled pride and anxiety today the third Heroes' Memorial Day, created by Chancellor Adolf Hitler in honor of the dead of the last war and the National Socialist movement.

Generally firmer prices were the result of last week's moderate trading in local commodity futures markets, but coffee ended weak and wool tops and cottonseed oil were low points. In the cash markets, wheat, cotton, raw sugar, tin, silk and rubber were up for the week, while losses appeared in dairy products, flour, oats, lard, wooltops and cocoa.

A triple tie for first place among Mrs. Mary Bain of Astoria, Mrs. Raphael E. McCready of Hackensack and Mrs. Adele Rivero of Manhattan existed in the women's championship tournament at the Marshall Chess Club after the seventh round had been contested yesterday.

ADOLF HITLER steps into the Rhineland with two broken peace treaties in his hands and graciously offers Europe to sign some new ones. This is the extraordinary spectacle presented by his words and acts of last Saturday. The world may be excused for asking what a German signature would be worth when it is offered by a Chancellor who has just repudiated one.

While strikers of the Building Service Employes Union picketed the Hotel Lexington yesterday afternoon, nearly seventy professional artists', photographers', fashion and clothing models met in the hotel, at Lexington Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, and discussed preliminary plans for the formation of a Models Equity Association.

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 8. -The 1936 model of the Giants, which next Friday will commence operations against the Indians, staged a preview today when Colonel Bill Terry divided his forces and turned them loose on each other for the season's first intramural game.

The increase in consumer buying in most sections of the country was reflected in all branches of the wholesale apparel market here last week. Substantial orders were placed for coats, suits and dresses by buyers in the market and reordering of Spring merchandise was also active.

LONDON, Monday, March 9. -London newspapers almost without exception beseech the British and French Governments today to examine Chancellor Adolf Hitler's offer as an opportunity to bring peace to a distracted Europe.

NEW ORLEANS, March 8. -- The cotton market here was dull last week so far as trading in future contracts was concerned. Traders are unwilling to enter upon new commitments until it is known definitely how the Washington administration will carry out the provisions of the new Farm Control Act and what will result from the President's plan for new taxes.

In Mr. HOOVER'S address to the Colorado Young Republicans on Saturday evening, perhaps the most significant sentence, politically speaking, was the one in which he said that he neither needs nor seeks further "honors" at the hands of his fellow-countrymen. This seems to be a tacit announcement that he will not strive for another Presidential nomination.
METZ, France, March 8 (AP). -Alsace and Lorraine echoed to the tramp of marching feet and rumbling trucks today as France moved reinforcements up to her Rhineland fortifications.

Both in trade and on financial markets, last week, the forward movement continued. Loadings of railway freight, as reported for the closing week of February, increased 11 3/8 per cent over 1935. They had been exceeded during any weekly period of the past five years only by one week in the Autumn of 1933 and by seven last Autumn.
BERLIN, March 8. -- Six German professors, all winners of the Nobel Prize for physics, are now engaged in a public controversy on the issue, "German Physics vs. Jewish Physics."

Miss Vera McCrea, president of the New York League of Business and Professional Women, made public yesterday the names of twenty-three women who have been voted "women of achievement for 1936" by the organization. They will be honored at a dinner on Wednesday evening, March 18, at the Hotel Pennsylvania at which Grover Whalen will be the toastmaster.

The racial pride and endurance of the Jewish people were recalled yesterday in the city's synagogues with sermons and symbolical plays in celebration of Purim, the festival commemorating the deliverance of the Jews from Haman, the Persian Minister, as related in the Book of Esther.

LONDON, March 6. -- All reports point to the continuance of the British trade recovery. In certain industries in February there was a slight falling off in the volume of new orders, out on the whole active conditions were maintained, while there was difficulty experienced in some directions in obtaining an adequate supply of skilled labor.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 8. -When young John (Buddy) Hassett's purchase by the Dodgers was officially made public Secretary John Gorman's announcement stated without qualification that "Hassett will play first base for Brooklyn this year."

Net income of the Corn Products Refining Company last year amounted to $8,347,907 after expenses, taxes, depreciation, provision for contingencies and estimated loss on investment in mortgage and other charges. After providing for regular dividends of 7 per cent on the preferred stock, the income was equal to $2.62 a share on 2,530,000 shares of common stock. In 1934 the company earned $9,702,696, or $3.10 a common share.

PARIS, March 8. -- Bertrand de Jouvenel, whose interview with Chancellor Adolf Hitler, published here Feb. 28, has been the subject of much comment because of its "offer" of friendship to France just before the German decision to reoccupy the Rhineland, today corrects in a note in the Paris Midi many false suppositions regarding that interview.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine will swear in 200 rookie policemen -- the first to be appointed since 1933 -- at police headquarters this morning. Mayor La Guardia is expected to attend the ceremonies at 10 o'clock. The commissioner also will promote twenty-six policemen, naming a new inspector, a deputy inspector, two captains, seven lieutenants and fifteen sergeants.

BUENOS AIRES, March 8. -- Paraguay took formal steps today to put the Chaco peace pacts into effect in a manner that is expected to result in the diplomatic recognition of her de facto government this week.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP). -President Roosevelt, Vice President Garner and members of the Cabinet were advised today to look for guidance to Him who declared:
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP). -- The Postoffice Department, intensifying its drive against books it calls "obscene," is looking to Congress for legislation to assist its campaign.

Breaking 97 out of 100 targets, E. Milliken won the High-Over-All Cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. In the contest for the Class A trophy, Milliken bowed to A.L. Cornwell, who took an extra string, 25 -- 24.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- Secretary Ickes reported today that $1,985,485,000 had been expended on 16,233 completed PWA projects costing $1,000,000,000, and 4,419 projects under construction which will finally cost $2,200,000,000.

MOSCOW, March 8. -- The measured Soviet interpretation of Adolf Hitler's statement, based on study of the full text, is that it clearly shows Hitler's aggressive designs in the east -- meaning in the last analysis Soviet Russia -- after which let the west beware.

The conservative wing of the United States Supreme Court was accused of thrusting its "pet economic or social theory" into the Constitution in a radio address delivered yesterday afternoon by Martin T. Manton, senior judge of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
For distinguished services in the fields of peace, literature and philanthropy three gold medals were awarded last night by the Jewish Forum at its eighteenth anniversary dinner in the Hotel Astor.

MADISON, Wis., March 8 (AP). -Moving deliberately to straighten out the athletic muddle at the University of Wisconsin, President Glenn Frank said today he intended to withhold appointments of new faculty members on the athletic board until harmony was restored.

LONDON, March 6. -- Although the French credit arranged in London was concluded only three weeks ago, its influence as a strengthening factor for the franc already appears virtually to have ended. Fresh uneasiness concerning the franc has been aroused by reports of the impending resignation of Jean Tannery as governor of the Bank of France and by discussion of the possibility of devaluation before the French elections.
LONDON, March 8. -- France can punish Germany in several ways without resorting to arms.

DETROIT, March 8 (AP). -- The Boston Bruins, battling for a play-off position in the National Hockey League, scored three goals in the opening period tonight and then went on to down the Detroit Red Wings, 5 -- 2, before a crowd of 9,000.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 8. -- The Princeton University honor roll for the first term of the academic year, made public here today by Wilbur F. Kerr, registrar of the university, lists 564 students.

The broad investment demand for recent new high-grade bond issues together with the opportunities presented for scaling down fixed interest charges through refunding operations, have worked together to speed up negotiations between bankers and corporation officials for new loans in an endeavor to take advantage of current investment conditions.

After five days of light trading and minor fluctuations last week, Saturday's market on the foreign exchanges was upset upon news of the German occupation of the Rhineland towns. All currencies sustained sharp declines on the possibility that Germany's action might presage open conflict.
CHICAGO, March 8. -- Prices of wheat, corn, oats and rye on the Board of Trade here last week for future delivery were as follows:

PITTSBURGH, March 8. -- Nation-wide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 56 per cent of capacity, up 1 point from the rate of the preceding week, which had been revised upward 1 point, compared with an average of 57 per cent in four weeks before the holidays.
The first editorial in your issue of March 6 summarizes concisely the essential matters involved in the present strike.

The Children's Aid Society, which cares for homeless boys between the ages of 16 and 21 at its Newsboys' Home, 244 William Street, reported yesterday that the number of transient boys cared for at the home had decreased by one-half since the Federal Government discontinued its transiency program last November.

Edwin Strawbridge and Lisa Parnova, both of whom have given frequent solo dance recitals here in past seasons, joined forces last night for the first time in New York at the Guild Theatre after a season together on tour. A large audience assembled to see them and gave indubitable evidence of enjoying itself hugely.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 8. -- Milt Marion of St. Albans, L.I., won the beach road race for stock cars today. Tommy Elmore of Jacksonville, Ala., was second and Ben Shaw of Westville, N.J., third. All three drove Fords.

The Maid of Orleans, in the person of Katharine Cornell, makes her postponed appearance this evening at the Martin Beck. Accompanying her in this revival of Mr. Shaw's "Saint Joan" are, among others, Arthur Byron, Brian Aherne, Maurice Evans, Charles Waldron, Eduardo Ciannelli and George Coulouris, all under the direction of Guthrie McClintic; and the settings and costumes are of Jo Mielziner's designing.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- Congressional chieftains intimated today that ship subsidy legislation and the $420,000,000 rural electrification bill might be scrapped, along with other controversial measures, if necessary to protect the May 1 adjournment goal.

MANCHESTER, N.H., March 8. -Revolt against the Roosevelt delegate slate dictated by Postmaster General Farley is increasing as New Hampshire prepares to vote Tuesday in the country's first primary to select delegates to the national conventions.

Activity in the calling of bonds for payment before maturity was smaller last week. The announcements were principally for bonds of industrial and public-utility corporations, for redemption in future months. Additions to this month's list were few, and consisted of small amounts of foreign and municipal bonds.

Communism is a menace to both religion and government in this country because it has gained a foothold in the public schools and colleges, Arthur J.W. Hilly, former corporation counsel, declared yesterday at a communion breakfast in the Hotel Commodore of the Regis Alumni Association of Regis High School, 55 East Eighty-fourth Street.

THE photo from Sarasota showed Jimmy Foxx in a Red Sox uniform standing with one hand on the batting cage. Joe Cronin was in the picture, too. He was shown leaning heavily on James Emory Foxx. Joe probably will hold that pose through much of the coming season.

When we think of the silk and satin and powdered hair of the founders of the Republic, and of the mighty WEBSTER, CLAY and CALHOUN, most of us agree sadly that the days of the giants are gone, and that Congress has been steadily declining in manners, morals and intelligence.

Cotton futures continued to fluctuate narrowly last week. Net changes in prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were from a 3 to 20 point advance. The greater strength was shown in the more distant deliveries.

MIAMI, Fla., March 8. -- With general agreement among horsemen that Joseph E. Widener's Florida Derby winner, Brevity, is the best 3-year-old ever to race at a Winter track, discussion today turned to whether or not his showing during the rest of the year will radically change American training methods which have prevailed for generations.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- No woman, or man, for that matter, ever filled a job quite like the one recently completed by Malvina Hoffman, the slim, silver-haired New York sculptress whose work is shown in many European and American museums.

Eight artists have declined invitations to show their work next Autumn at the international art exhibition at the Carnegie Institute in Pittsburgh, according to Miss Katherine Schmidt, chairman of the rental committee of the American Society of Painters, Sculptors and Gravers.
