The Williamson bill requiring a delay of three days between the issuance of a marriage license and the marriage ceremony itself, is disapproved by the bar association, in a report made public by its committee on State legislation.

Pointing to recent attacks on our civil liberties and warning of the ominous increase of power and control "of the military over matters of a civil character," the Right Rev. G. Ashton Oldham, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Albany, emphasized in his sermon yesterday the growing dangers to freedom in the United States.

DETROIT, March 8 (AP). -- Speaking for the Ford Motor Company, William J. Cameron declared tonight in criticizing the administration proposal to tax corporation surpluses that "our accumulations carry us through" periods of business depression. He spoke during i the Ford radio program.

BALTIMORE, March 8 (AP). -- Lieutenant Robert K. Giovannoli of Lexington, Ky., hero of the spectacular bombing plane crash during army tests at Dayton, Ohio, last October, was instantly killed today in a crack-up of his army plane at Logan Field here.

NEW HAVEN, March 7. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 82.8, which compares with 83.3 the week before, 83.8 two weeks before, 83.4 three weeks before and 83.5 four weeks before.

The Apostolic Delegate in the United States, the Most Rev. Amleto Giovanni Cicognani, presided yesterday morning at the celebration of the Feast of St. Thomas Aquinas at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church, Lexington Avenue at Sixty-sixth Street.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 8. -Hungry and worried about the "other 20,000,000 persons" on relief food allowances, but willing to "stick it out," the five members of the family of the Rev. William H. Alderson of Hempstead have been living on $8.20 for food since the beginning of Lent.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- In a telegram to Secretary of State Hull, the Committee for the Nation today took exception to Mr. Hull's statement with respect to the present stability of the dollar and to his plea for international stabilization of currencies, as made by the Secretary at the convention of the Young Democratic Clubs of Maryland in Baltimore on Thursday.

PARIS, March 6. -- The return of the Bank of France for Feb. 28 shows that month-end expansion requirements were somewhat difficult to meet. Bills discounted increased 546,000,000 francs, loans against securities and government bonds were up by 322,000,000 francs, while private deposits decreased by 654,000,000 francs.

PARIS, March 8. -- The average Frenchman's bitterness over Chancellor Hitler's action of yesterday and the fear of war were reflected in the French press today, which was unanimous in asserting the government must take a strong stand for punishment by the League of Nations. Newspapers, however, advised "coolness."

Wesley M. Dawson, district tax supervisor of the State personal income tax, said yesterday that taxpayers are filing their returns earlier than ever this year. Although the returns are not due until April 15, he went on, taxpayers "are flocking to our offices in the State Office Building at 80 Center Street in greater numbers than ever before."

More than a score of new exhibitions face the ardent gallery-goer as Winter wanes and signs of Spring appear. Works by Oriental and Occidental, academician and abstractionist, sculptor and painter and etcher are included among the new openings.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- President Roosevelt appealed today to railroad labor and management to settle their impending conflicts of interests by agreement among themselves instead of bringing the problems to Congress for solution by legislation.

CHICAGO, March 8 (AP). -- Chicago's Black Hawks defeated their most persistent annoyers this season, the Canadiens of Montreal, 2 to 0, tonight to cut two points off the Detroit Red Wings' hold on first place in the American group of the National Hockey League.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP). -The New Deal faces two major tests this week in the Supreme Court, with the constitutionality of the Guffey Coal and the 1933 securities laws at issue.

ASMARA, Eritrea, March 8. -- The order to cease firing was sent out all over the northern war front this morning when it was learned that Premier Benito Mussolini had accepted the proposal of the League of Nations to discuss peace terms.

The Rev. Dr. Joseph Richard Sizoo, pastor for the last twelve years of the New York Avenue Presbyterian Church in Washington, has accepted a call to the pastorate of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, now known as the "Church in Rockefeller Center."

Last week was full of troubles for Prime Minister ABERHART of Alberta. Major DOUGLAS, "father of Social Credit," gave notice of his intention to end his contract as Reconstruction Adviser to the Provincial Government. He had been expected to come toward the close of March.

Hans R.L. Cohrssen's letter asks a question that should be answered: "But is looking backward the proper way of solving our present-day problems?" By "looking backward" he means holding to a monetary unit of fixed value in terms of world money -- gold -- instead of having managed currency of no fixed value, which in his opinion is forward-looking, modern, up to date.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- The following is the text of the letter from President Roosevelt to J.J. Pelley of Washington, president of the Association of American Railroads, and J.A. Phillips of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, vice chairman of the Association of Railway Labor Executives:

The suit of Robert David Lion Gardiner to have the will of his 93-year-old great-aunt, Miss Mary G. Thompson, declared invalid on the ground that she was unduly influenced when she bequeathed most of her $15,500,000 estate to six public institutions, will begin this morning before Surrogate James A. Delehanty and a jury.

The old guard of the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. stood by on Saturday and watched Manhattan College sweep on to its third straight indoor track and field championship. And they have not seen the last of the Jaspers either. If one of them was to have halted the Green's surging rush, then this was the year because the task will loom even more formidable a season hence.
BERLIN, March 8 (AP). -- The official German News Agency announced tonight that efforts had been started to normalize the long-strained relations between Germany and Lithuania.
A playlet entitled "Use Your Cellar, or Have You a Little Bowling Alley in Your Home?" in thirty-six scenes, will open this evening on the roof of the French Building in Rockefeller Center.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- Senator Borah announced today that he would enter the Presidential primary in Pennsylvania on April 28, thereby adding to the indications that his aggressive campaign to win support as the Presidential nominee at the National Republican Convention at Cleveland on June 9 will be waged in most of the primary States.

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., March 8. -- Donald Nightingale of the home club carried off the Class A Westchester squash racquets championship when he defeated Jack Graham, a club-mate, in the final at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club today. The score was 15 -- 7, 15 -- 6, 9 -- 15, 15 -- 7.

Columbia swept on to its first Eastern League title since 1931 and Manhattan clinched its right to represent the metropolitan area in the district Olympic eliminations as the intercollegiate basketball season ended its semi-final week.

A model of a cosmosarium, a new kind of "glass house" in which men and women may look at their earth from the objective view of a philosopher with his head in the clouds, was placed on exhibition yesterday at the Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History.

Headed by United States champion Frank J. Marshall and Reuben Fine, American internationalist, the team of the Marshall Chess Club defeated the Rice-Progressive Chess Club, 5 -- 2, in the fourth round of the annual interclub series of the Metropolitan Chess League yesterday.
Sunny skies and moderate temperatures, together with the hope that Winter has nearly ended in fact as well as according to the calendar, started New Yorkers yesterday on their annual Spring exodus.

GENEVA, March 8. -- The Council of the League of Nations was summoned to meet Friday at 11 A. M. after France telegraphed today declaring Germany had "expressly violated Article 43 of the Treaty of Versailles and Article I of the Treaty of Locarno" and asking the Council to act under Article IV of the Locarno agreement.

ADDIS ABABA, March 8. -- Premier Benito Mussolini's reply to the appeal of the League of Nations conciliation committee of thirteen has been received here with suspicion and surprise. Although it is realized that the acceptance is perhaps due to the pressure of sanctions and the threat of their intensification, it is pointed out that other considerations may have influenced Il Duce.

Mrs. Duer McLanahan and Mrs. Ellery S. Husted head a group of women active in the sale of boxes and seats for the performance of the Monte Carlo Ballet Russe the night of April 13 at the Metropolitan Opera House, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Society for the Relief of Half Orphan and Destitute Children.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8. -- This was a day of rest in the Yankee training camp for everybody save Manager Joe McCarthy and his board of strategy.

The fight launched by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York against confirmation of the adminterim appointment of Lamar Hardy as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York will go before a subcommittee of the Senate Judiciary Committee at a hearing in Washington this afternoon.

BERLIN, March 6. -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht's recent currency measures have been confined to the restriction of trade by barter, on the ground that goods for which Germany easily could get foreign currency were being exchanged for imports of an unwanted character, and to permitting, under certain conditions, the use of the so-called foreigners' "special-account marks" for payment of German exports to any country.
PARIS, March 8. -- Excerpts from the radio talk by Premier Albert Sarraut to the nation tonight on the Rhineland crisis follow:

The New York Rovers played their last home game of the season in Eastern Amateur Hockey League competition yesterday and lost. Before a crowd of about 13,000 spectators the strong Pittsburgh Yellow Jackets downed the Red Shirts, 4 to 2, in Madison Square Garden.
PARIS, March 8. -- The text of France's appeal to the League of Nations against Germany's violation of the Locarno treaty follows:

The New York Chamber Music Society, Carolyn Beebe, president and founder, closed its season of "Sunday salons" at the Plaza last night. The concert marked the end of the society's twenty-first year. A program combining music of various schools was arranged for this occasion.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- The administration plans to hold a Pan-American peace conference in South America this Summer whether Paraguay attends or not, it was learned today, as the tense situation in Europe caused by Chancellor Adolf Hitler's denunciation of the Locarno pact strengthened President Roosevelt's determination to make North and South America a Gibraltar of peace in a nervous and war-threatened world.

BERLIN, March 6. -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht's recent currency measures have been confined to the restriction of trade by barter, on the ground that goods for which Germany easily could get foreign currency were being exchanged for imports of an unwanted character, and to permitting, under certain conditions, the use of the so-called foreigners' "special-account marks" for payment of German exports to any country.
PARIS, March 8. -- Excerpts from the radio talk by Premier Albert Sarraut to the nation tonight on the Rhineland crisis follow:

The New York Rovers played their last home game of the season in Eastern Amateur Hockey League competition yesterday and lost. Before a crowd of about 13,000 spectators the strong Pittsburgh Yellow Jackets downed the Red Shirts, 4 to 2, in Madison Square Garden.
PARIS, March 8. -- The text of France's appeal to the League of Nations against Germany's violation of the Locarno treaty follows:

A new attitude for Roman Catholics toward communism, nazism and fascism was urged yesterday afternoon by Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the Catholic University, Washington, D.C., in one of a series of lectures being given at St. John's University, Lewis and Willoughby Avenues, Brooklyn.

HARRISBURG, March 8 (AP). -- A glacier-like ice pack, shoved along! at high speed by the force of the Susquehanna's newly-freed waters, crashed down on the Summer colony between Rockville and Dauphin early today, demolishing ten cottages and damaging more than forty.

PARIS, trch 8. -- The death of Jean Patou was almost unnoticed today by a public gravely concerned with the Franco-German crisis, lriq obituary notice was confined to eighteen words in a single newspaper. The cause of death was given as a heart attack.

A Harvard hockey team which finished its schedule with a spectacular rush stands in full possession of the Quadrangular League championship today without the necessity of a play-off with Dartmouth. The Crimson achieved this position by crushing Yale under a league-record score of 11 to 0 at New Haven Saturday night after Princeton had eliminated Dartmouth at Princeton in the afternoon, 4 to 3.

Twenty thousand persons are expected to file into Madison Square Garden tonight to witness the finals of the tenth annual Golden Gloves amateur boxing tournament. Eightenn contests, showing boxers in all the standard classes from the fly-weight to the heavyweight, will be presented by The Daily News A.A., with the sanction of the Metropolitan Association of the A.A.U.

BOSTON, March 8. -- Lieutenant Governor Joseph L. Hurley of Fall River formally announced his candidacy tonight for the Democratic nomination for the Governorship. His entry is believed to have been hastened by recent reports that Attorney General Paul A. Dever also would seek the nomination.

Napoleon said that God was on the side of the largest battalions, and a similar condition seems to prevail in the world of stockholders and corporations. Fortune is with the side that controls the most stock, and stockholders must sit in futile exasperation while their officials vote themselves preposterous salaries.
Leaders in the city's musical life attended funeral services for Rubin Goldmark, distinguished American composer, yesterday morning in the concert hall of the Juilliard Graduate School of Music.
CHICAGO, March 8. -- Local statisticians made estimates last week of this year's wheat crops.

CHICAGO, March 8. -- Sentiment in the wheat pit on the Board of Trade here was bearish most of last week, particularly on Friday, when the lowest prices were touched as the result of unloading attributed to large operators who are passing the Winter at Miami, and are connected by private wire with commission houses here.

WARSAW, March 8. -- A strong modern armed force is the only guarantee of peace and security in present-day Europe, the independent Warsaw press declares today in commenting upon Adolf Hitler's speech to the Reichstag.

TOLEDO, March 8. -- The best in show award at the fourteenth annual exhibition of the Toledo Kennel Club was won tonight by the English setter Ch. Robin Hood of Marional, owned by the Marional Farms of Dayton. Charles Davis handled the winner.

Presenting a defense so sturdy that their goalie was called on to make only seventeen saves, the New York Americans held the New York Rangers scoreless at Madison Square Garden last night. At the same time, Red Dutton's men made a first-period goal by Joe Jerwa stand up, with the result that they registered a 1-to-0 triumph in the National Hockey League.

ALBANY, March 8. -- A sharp attack was made today by three members of Governor Lehman's Cabinet upon the Republican program to slash more than $15,000,000 from the budget as submitted by the Governor.

The Postoffice Department wants a list of army and navy heroes to depict on stamps, but members of the administration cannot agree. President ROOSEVELT and Postmaster General FARLEY are among those who have their own ideas on who is a hero and who is not.

Dean Carl W. Ackerman of the Columbia School of Journalism, who recently returned from a three months' tour around the world, asserted in a report to the Columbia trustees that newspapers and press associations throughout Europe and the Orient had, with "a few conspicuous exceptions," improved their news services, raised professional standards and become "more vital sources of public information."

The Italian Line will abolish the so-called "special class" of accommodations on the liners Rex and Conte di Savoia this Spring, it was announced yesterday. The passenger quarters, public rooms and deck space now assigned to this class will be converted to tourist class effective with the sailings of the Conte di Savoia on April 25 and of the Rex on May 9.

BERLIN, March 8. -- As observed today, the public reaction to Chancellor Hitler's dramatic obliteration of the demilitarized zone in the Rhineland and his denunciation of the Locarno pact suggests an element of restraint, and press discussions also appear to assume that the Fuehrer's Reichstag speech and seven-point peace program are self-evident developments that speak for themselves.

TOKYO, Monday, March 9. -- The Japanese Navy today came to the assistance of Koki Hirota, whose efforts to form a new Japanese Cabinet have been blocked for three days by the refusal of high army authorities to approve his plans. The naval chiefs expressed their satisfaction with Mr. Hirota's attitude and assisted him in trying to overcome the army's objections.

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the gala concert in behalf of the Music Lovers Foundation arranged by Albert Morris Bagby for the afternoon of March 17 in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The artists will be Miss Lucrezia Bori, Giovanni Martinelli, Miss Editha Fleischer, Richard Bonelli and Emanuel List, all of the Metropolitan Opera; Alexander Siloti, pianist; Miss Grete Stueckgold, soprano; and Efrem Zimbalist, violinist.

CHICAGO, March 8. -- Handlers of livestock are having difficulty in rearranging their operations as a result of the adoption of Eastern standard time in Chicago whereby there is an hour's difference between Chicago and Western markets.

Under the auspices of the Loyola School, a luncheon and card party will be held tomorrow at the St. Regis for the benefit of the Jesuit Seminaries, which train young men for the priesthood and for work in the mission field. Mrs. Thomas E. Murray Jr. heads the benefit committee.

TRENTON, March 8. -- Talk of a further reprieve for Bruno Richard Hauptmann was revived in official circles here today following a decision in Supreme Court at Paterson yesterday declaring that Governor Harold G. Hoffman is responsible to the people and not to the courts.

PARIS, March 8. -- Proclaiming that the German proposals contained in yesterday's memorandum were "inacceptable" and that there would be no negotiations "under menace" of German troops in the Rhineland, the French Government today formally laid the case of Germany's treaty infraction before the League of Nations Council, summoned a meeting here on Tuesday of the signatories of the Locarno agreements and prepared its measures of frontier defense.

A movement to obtain 50,000 signatures on a petition which will be submitted to President Roosevelt and Attorney General Cummings in behalf of Captain William F. Warms and Eben S. Abbott, acting master and chief engineer of the Ward liner Morro Castle when she was burned at sea, Sept. 8, 1934, has been started by a group of maritime organizations.

MIAMI, Fla., March 8. -- Treking over the course in intermittent showers, Gene Sarazen, former United States and British open champion, and his partner, Jimmy Hines of Garden City, L.I., the sensation of professional golf on the West Coast this Winter, registered a notable triumph in the first round of the annual international four-ball tournament at the Miami Country Club today.

ALBANY, March 8. -- New stock corporations formed in this State in February numbered 1,536, or sixteen more than in that month last year, Edward J. Flynn, Secretary of State, reported today. The charters last month brought the total this year to 3,438.

A three-cornered tie looms as a possibility in the Intercollegiate Swimming Association as a result of Columbia's victory over C.C.N.Y. on Friday. Rutgers is unbeaten in three starts but must face the Lions tomorrow and defeat will drop the Scarlet into a deadlock with Columbia and Penn.

VIENNA, March 8. -- The Vienna press, obviously on higher instructions, was silent concerning the news from Germany with the single exception of the Tageblatt. This paper devotes its editorial to the expression of the hope that the "worst fears will not be realized."

HAVEN, Conn., March 8. -- More than 21 per cent of the students in the undergraduate schools at Yale are on the Dean's List, which was made public today. The list is made up of students who have attained a general average of 80 per cent or more in their studies.

Actual deliveries of rayon yarn to American mills exceeded those for January, as well as the 1935 monthly average, according to the index of the Rayon Organon, published by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc. The unadjusted index, based on actual shipments, stood at 516 for February, against 477 for January and 441 for February, 1935.

HOUSTON, Texas, March (AP). -- Billy Jones, 7-year-old gelding owned by T.C. Worden, made every post a winning one in the feature race at Epsom Downs today. The Worden star chalked up his fourth victory in a row, the first three being recorded at Santa Anita.

The Pennroad Corporation reported yesterday for 1935 a net income of $1,713,277 after expenses and taxes. This was equivalent to 19 cents a share on the capital stock and was an increase of $592,361 over the net income for 1934, which was $1,120,916, or 12 cents a share.

Paid admission symphony concerts will be inaugurated in New York by the concert division of the Federal music project, beginning on March 22. Lee Pattison, city and State director of the project, said yesterday, in making the announcement, that the attempt was to be made "to determine whether citizens are interested in supporting a program of popular-priced symphony concerts after government aid to music has been discontinued."

Miss Cornell and Mr. Shaw beat us all into reverent submission last evening. Not that we were offering much resistance, for the play was "Saint Joan," which has been increasing in popular stature ever since it was first acted a dozen years ago; and Miss Cornell's preeminence in the role was virtually assured.

Plans for uniting farmer, labor, liberal and radical left wing groups into a third party to enter a full ticket in the coming Presidential campaign were discussed last night at a dinner of the Commonwealth Federation of New York at a dinner at the Town Hall Club.

MIAMI, Fla., March 9. -- With A.W. Abbott's Nightcap winner of the featured Hibiscus Purse, the Hialeah Park meeting came to an end today with a benefit program which realized approximately $30,000 for charity, according to an estimate by Joseph E. Widener, president of the Miami Jockey Club.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler would never have dared to move troops into the demilitarized Rhineland had not Great Britain and France alienated the good-will of this country by refusing to pay their war debts, Senator J. Hamilton Lewis of Illinois said in the Senate today in a discussion of the debt situation.

LONDON, Tuesday, March 10. -- Dr. Jacob Gould Schurman, United States Ambassador to Germany at the time the Locarno treaty was signed, today urged the statesmen of Britain and France to take Chancellor Adolf Hitler's "plan of European settlement" at its face value.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 9. -- The Rev. William H. Alderson, his wife and their three young children continued today on their $8.20 weekly relief diet, which they began Feb. 25 as a Lenten, social service experiment. Each member of the family will begin tomorrow weighing daily.

President ROOSEVELT has sent a particularly interesting letter to the railway managers and the railway labor leaders. The two groups have been trying for some time to find a formula under which large economies in the merging of railway facilities can be achieved without undue loss of employment.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The Senate passed unanimously today a resolution introduced by Senator Borah directing the Federal Communications Commission to supply to the Senate a detailed report of the activities of all its agents "in any inspection or alleged seizures of telegrams and records of telephone communications, or other private communications to or from any point in the United States."

The New Jersey State Highway Extension Sinking Fund Commission will offer for sale on March 24 various municipal bonds of the State of New Jersey aggregating $4,737,000. These bonds represent holdings of the Sinking Fund Commission.

Net income of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company for 1935 amounted to $11,398,739 after the deduction of depreciation, depletion, losses and expenses in connection with property removals and Federal and State income taxes, according to the fifty-second annual report sent to stockholders today.

WINTER PARK, Fla., March 9 (AP). -- Dr. Hamilton Holt, president of Rollins College, announced today that President Roosevelt will receive an honorary degree of Doctor of Literature here March 21 at special convocation exercises.

MOSCOW, March 9. -- Spoilage of serious proportions in last year's bumper cotton crop because it was picked before ripe has resulted in the dispatch from Moscow to Uzbekistan of an investigating committee of forty members headed by the Vice Commissar for Light Industry, Mr. Yeremin.

BELLEAIR, Fla., March 9. -- For the second successive year, medalist honors in the annual women's Belleair golf championship were captured today by Mrs. Maureen Orcutt Crews of Miami. Apparently unhampered by a driving rain, the former New Jersey golfer clipped a stroke from par with a brilliant 79 to lead a field of thirty-two.
Amateur boxing's outstanding tournament of the year in this city -- the Golden Gloves -- came to an end at Madison Square Garden last night.

An offering to the public will be made today by Shields Co. and F. Eberstadt Co., Inc., of 62,500 shares of 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock, carrying commonstock purchase warrants, and 50,000 shares of common stock of the Detroit Gasket Manufacturing Company.

Addressing 188 new lawyers admitted to the bar yesterday, Presiding Justice Francis J. Martin of the Appellate Division launched a broad attack upon public disorder and declared that officials who cannot enforce the criminal laws should be removed from office.

PHILADELPHIA, March 9. -- Four candidates, including Mrs. Cornelia Bryce Pinchot, wife of the former Governor, filed at Harrisburg today as candidates for the Republican nomination in the Fifth Congressional District. The district is in Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- New York City police officials and a representative of the French Republic joined today in asking the Supreme Court to construe the Franco-American extradition treaty of 1909 so that the three Neidecker brothers may be returned to France to face charges arising from the closing of the Travelers Bank of Paris.

The prediction that a major building revival, making necessary the construction of at least 250,000 homes during 1936, is on the way, was made yesterday by Stewart McDonald, Federal Housing Administrator, at the opening of the Cellar Reborn exhibit on the roof of La Maison Francaise in Rockefeller Center.

ALBANY, March 9 (AP). -- Allocation of $889,564.01 for twenty-nine new work relief projects and completion of fourteen others was made today by Lester W. Herzog of the New York State Works Progress Administration.
Two large apartment structures in the Bronx and two small houses on the West Side of Manhattan were reported sold yesterday.

QUEBEC, Que., March 9. -- Primitive snow shoes fashioned out of birch branches by the use of razor blades, gunny sacks and two coils of fuse saved the lives of John Rainville, Rouyn prospector, and A. Lamothe of the Quebec Colonization Department, when they were lost three days in the woods of Northern Quebec last week.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Officials of rail labor unions were greatly upset today by President Roosevelt's letter frowning upon legislation to care for laborers displaced by projected mergers and expressed the hope that they could prove to him that the consolidations proposed by Coordinator of Railroads Joseph Eastman would displace considerable labor and at the same time not be so economical as contended.

CONCORD, N.H., March 9. -- Free of internal conflict for the first time in many years, New Hampshire Republicans are avoiding friction in tomorrow's Presidential primaries with the idea of maintaining party solidarity for the campaign.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP). -- A new clash over rival ship subsidy legislation coincided today with elimination from the Postoffice Supply Bill of a $26,500,000 appropriation for continuing present ocean mail grants.

With Broadway's managers and playwrights still at odds over the new minimum basic agreement, the Dramatists Guild will hold another general meeting shortly, it was learned yesterday. Although no date has been set, it may take place next week.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP). -- After months of loose-jointed activity, advocates of Governor Landon of Kansas for the Republican Presidential nomination are about to be brought together under the generalship of John D.M. Hamilton.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 9. -- Jardin Bijou was the setting for a large tea given by Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Logan this afternoon.

Two sisters and their husbands were arrested and held yesterday on the complaint of Federal Housing Administration officials, who said that their prisoners had committed the "largest individual fraud" yet perpetrated in connection with home-modernization loans.

Five young men, dressed as though for a Saturday night spree, drove north in a taxicab yesterday and waited outside a restaurant at 242d Street and Broadway, where the I.R.T. subway ends. They made no move toward paying the $4.15 bill they had run up, and the driver watched them carefully.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- A special form designated 8-A for the registration on national Securities Exchanges of additional securities of corporations was issued today by the Securities and Exchange Commission in an effort to simplify procedure and obtain more pertinent information.

Manhattan foreclosure auction sales yesterday included a fifteen-story apartment house at 332-44 East Fifty-seventh Street. Two dwellings in West 121st Street were sold after numerous bids were made at a partition sale. The results were as follows:
MADRID, March 9. -- With the death toll caused by political strife mounting almost hourly there seemed to be a danger tonight that class hatred might develop into civil war in Spain.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Chairman Black of the Senate Lobby Committee tonight accused the American Liberty League of fighting against the Public Utility Holding Company Control Bill and then endeavoring to keep the details of that campaign buried in secrecy.

BENTON, Ill., March 9 (AP). -- Fifteen Southern Illinois Works Progress Administration supervisors asserted today that WPA employes were being solicited for funds to aid Herman N. Bundesen, who seeks the Democratic gubernatorial nomination.
In the comment on the voiding of the Minimum Wage Law by the Court of Appeals, one fundamental fact seems to have been lost sight of.

CHICAGO, March 9. -- While receipts of hogs here today were somewhat above trade expectations there was a fairly aggressive demand with prices steady to as much as 15 cents a hundredweight higher compared with Friday's levels. Light weights showed the most strength on active buying by shippers.

ROME, March 9. -- The second day after Chancellor Adolf Hitler's sensational denunciation of the Locarno treaty finds Premier Benito Mussolini still sitting contentedly on the fence and giving no sign of leaning either toward France or toward Germany.

BERLIN, March 9. -- Talk of imposing sanctions on Germany aroused in the Foreign Office today incredulous astonishment, and heated protestations that Germany will stick to her guns regardless of consequences.

That was a highly interesting and significant document, prepared and presented by the National Peace Conference and printed by THE NEW YORK TIMES March 5. Doubtless any statement on so vital a subject as the preservation of peace by our country and which bears the signatures of so many Americans of prominence and loyalty would merit and receive respectful consideration.

Murray W. Stand, majority leader of the Board of Aldermen, was chosen yesterday as chairman of the Aldermanic-Board of Estimate Joint Committee which will consider reform of county government in New York City.

Various housing properties in Brooklyn, Queens and other parts of Long Island, in addition to a Westchester home, were reported sold yesterday by the Title and Mortgage Rehabilitation and Liquidation Bureau of the State Insurance Department.

More than 200 Columbia University students and several instructors attended a mass meeting on the university campus yesterday and, with only one dissenting voice, adopted a resolution urging the university to withdraw its acceptance of an invitation to attend Heidelberg University's 550th anniversary celebration in June.
WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Preliminary to Supreme Court arguments tomorrow on the Securities Act of 1933 and Wednesday on the Guffey Coal Conservation Act, both sides presented briefs today.
WARSAW, March 9. -- More than 1,000 students of the technical college of Warsaw University occupied the college's main building early this morning and will stay there three days and three nights.
Sales of General Motors cars to dealers and to consumers declined last month from January's total, but were higher compared with February, 1935, according to an announcement yesterday.

Irked by the amateur entertainment offered at the Brooklyn Fox Theatre, Nevins Street and Flatbush Avenue, a group of unruly youngsters in the balcony expressed their disapproval with a shower of assorted vegetables and a salvo of catcalls shortly after 9:30 o'clock last night.

LITTLE ROCK, March 9. -- From Memphis to Natchez and from here east, sentiment of Delta cotton farmers is rapidly crystalizing in favor of the administration's stopgap conservation program, which would mean an expenditure of about $125,000,000 a year for cotton alone.

LONDON, March 9. -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, in stating the British Government's attitude toward the new Locarno situation in Parliament this afternoon, was fully as severe in his denunciation of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's unilateral repudiation of the Locarno treaty as Premier Albert Sarraut had been last night in his broadcast to the French people.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 9. -- The first steps in connecting a forty-two-inch branch to a sixty-inch water main while the latter remains under full pressure of fifty pounds a square inch were completed by engineers today.

As in previous seasons, members of the Junior League of New York and the New York City Visiting Committee will be in charge of a booth to be maintained for the benefit of occupational therapy patients at the International Flower Show, which will open March 16 at the Grand Central Palace.

An entertainment entitled "An Evening of Music and Exploration" was held last night at the clubhouse of the Junior League, 221 East Seventy-first Street, for the benefit of the Robins Nest, a home for convalescent crippled children in Tarrytown. Several dinners were given before the benefit.

The student council of City College withdrew yesterday the scheduled referendum on the fitness of Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of the college, and substituted another proposal. This action followed a warning from Charles H. Tuttle, chairman of the Board of Higher Education committee investigating Dr. Robinson.

WARSAW, March 9 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency). -- Two Jews were killed and four seriously injured today in rioting in the town of Prsytyk, District of Radom. Scores were beaten or wounded and 700 Jewish families were thrown into panic.

BASLE, Switzerland, March 9. -- The political problems Germany has raised dominated the informal talks of the governors of the big European central banks at their monthly meeting here in the past two days as members of the board of the Bank for International Settlements.

Mrs. Robert J. Kelly gave a luncheon yesterday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin for Mrs. J. Howell Carroll, Mrs. John Hubbard, Mrs. Harry Sedgwick, Mrs. Herbert S. Darlington, Mrs. Walter E. Lambert, Mrs. Robert Appleton and Mrs. Edwin C. Walker.

Mayor La Guardia's efforts to settle the building service strike by arbitration were halted again yesterday when the Realty Advisory Board, representing large realty owners, told the Mayor that it could not enter into arbitration except on certain conditions.

ALBANY, March 9. -- A statutory speed limit of fifty miles an hour for automobiles and other measures designed for highway safety were urged by Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, in his annual report to the Legislature tonight.

Seven offers for the stock of the National Surety Corporation, being sold by Louis H. Pink, Superintendent of Insurance, were opened yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente. The highest bidder was the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation, which offered $10,031,000 for the block of 100,000 shares. Justice Valente will hear recommendations today by Superintendent Pink with respect to the bidding.

LONDON, March 9. -- The British women's squash racquets team crushed the American players by 5 -- 0 today, regaining possession of the Wolfe-Noel Trophy, which they lost last year at Boston after holding it in 1933 and 1934.

BERLIN, March 9. -- The German Government was formally notified by the League of Nations Secretariat today that France and Belgium had appealed to the League Council against Germany's military occupation of the Rhineland and that the Council would presently discuss the appeal.

It is Arthur Hopkins who brings along this evening's contribution to Times Square. Call it "Star Spangled," Robert Ardrey's comic saga of a Chicago Polish-American family. George Tobias, Millard Mitchell, Garson Kanin, Edward Craven, Natasha Boleslavsky and Marjorie Lytell are some of those taking part, and the Hopkins curtain will rise grandly at 8:46.

THE one important thing to be said about Rebecca West's new book, "The Thinking Reed" (Viking, $2.50), is that it is in some ways the most intelligent, and certainly is the most witty, piece of writing to appear this season. That, although called a novel, it is less a novel than a brilliant discussion of men, women and money does not matter so much.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 9. -- Aggravation of his holdout problem robbed Manager Joe McCarthy today of what pleasure he got out of the Yankees' workout under difficult conditions.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The Association of the Bar of the City of New York presented before a subcommittee of the Senate Judiciary Committee today its opposition to confirmation of the appointment of Lamer Hardy as attorney for the Southern District of New York.

ALBANY, March 9. -- Senator William E. Borah's contest for delegates to the Republican National Convention gained official status in this State today when the New York Borah-for-President Committee filed its certificate with the office of the Secretary of State.
ALBANY, March 9. -- The Democratic Senate made short work tonight of the Republican plan, already passed in the Assembly, for conducting a broad inquiry into unemployment and relief.

Exports and imports from and into the United States by classified groups of merchandise during January, as given out by the Department of Commerce, compare as follows with those of a month ago and the corresponding period in 1935.

Magistrate Savarese in Jamaica Court discharged yesterday seven men who were arrested on Feb. 26 when detectives raided the Hotel Alvin, 223 West Fifty-third Street, following a robbery on Feb. 5 at the office of Charles W. Froessel, lawyer, at 161-19 Jamaica Avenue, Jamaica.

Mayor LA GUARDIA'S formula for a settlement of the building service strike should be accepted by the realty owners without further loss of time. They were entirely right in refusing to surrender to the demand for a closed shop and a monopoly of labor in an industry in which uninterrupted service is essential to the life of the community.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting banks in 101 leading cities on March 4 shows an increase for the week of $200,000,000 in total loans and investments, a decrease of $65,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, a decrease of $124,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and an increase of $211,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks.

The strike of building service employes was extended to Columbia University yesterday with the walkout, at noon, of more than thirty elevator men and porters. By late afternoon, not one elevator in the thirteen buildings of Teachers College, which extends from 120th Street to 122d Street and from Broadway to Amsterdam Avenue, was running.

The Board of Education informed Dr. Frank P. Graves, State Commissioner of Education, in a brief mailed to him last night, that it believed his order of reinstatement for William R. Hayward as principal of Theodore Roosevelt High School opened the way for an "attack upon the validity of all dismissals" by the school board.

MONTREAL, March 9. -- While the sniping pair of New York Americans, Schriner and Chapman, were closely checked by opposing defense men for three games, sharpshooters of the Detroit Red Wings, Chicago Black Hawks, Toronto Maple Leafs and Montreal Maroons advanced through last week to threaten a race for National Hockey League scoring honors.

Declaring that the information specified on routine court papers provided an adequate statement of cause for the dismissal of a charge of homicide against a defendant appearing before him yesterday, Magistrate Charles Solomon, sitting in Homicide Court, Brooklyn, told William McCarthy, Assistant District Attorney, that he could not see why he should state his reasons in a written statement as required by one of the recently enacted Lehman anti-crime measures.

The advance notices said that the Oilers of McPherson, Kan., were the tallest and best basketball team in the world. They arrived in New York yesterday for their game with Long Island University and assorted collegians at Madison Square Garden tomorrow and promptly proved the point as to their size.

Convinced that the New York State milk control law is so firmly entrenched as a political measure that opposition to its renewal after April 1 is practically futile, advertising interests here are as yet making little effort to obtain any change in its provisions.

IN the wake of various labor disputes and picket parades, consider the striking situation in what might be called Disorganized Baseball. There is no unity at all among the laborers on the big league diamonds and precious little unity among the capitalists or club owners. Not enough to go around, anyway.

CHICAGO, March 9. -- Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Railroads, looking forward to a "live and growing" railroad industry, today blamed both management and labor for failure to start economies to rehabilitate languishing broads.

Permission was given yesterday afternoon to the Church of the Puritans in West 130th Street east of Fifth Avenue to sell its edifice to a Negro congregation of "a sister communion" and to disband as a congregation. This action was taken by the Presbytery of New York at a meeting in Rutgers Church, Seventy-third Street west of Broadway.

NEW LONDON, Conn., March 9. -- Mrs. Anna Blake of Mystic was sentenced to thirty days in the county jail today after she had pleaded guilty to aiding in the abduction of her daughter, Jennie, 18, who refused to marry the man her mother had picked for her.
TOKYO, March 9. -- Premier Koki Hirota's Cabinet, completed tonight and installed in the presence of the Emperor, is predominantly a Cabinet of officials.
ASMARA, Eritrea, March 9. -- Italian troops resumed offensive operations on all Ethiopian fronts today after a one-day suspension.

After remaining in a state of comparative calm during most of the day in the face of the European tension, the share market met heavy selling in the final hour yesterday and prices went from fractions to about 4 points below Saturday's closing level, with some of the higher-priced issues losing even more.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Senator Vandenberg today asked an appropriations subcommittee not to include in the War Department Appropriation Bill any money for the Passamaquoddy tidal power project or the proposed Florida ship canal.

IRONWOOD, Mich., March 9 (AP). -- Anticipating the best year of production since 1930, iron mining ranges of Upper Michigan and Northern Wisconsin are speeding up operations. Most of the mines are on a five-day basis, which is now accepted as full time.

Ambrose V. McCall, Assistant State Attorney General, in charge of the Bureau of Securities, obtained yesterday from Supreme Court Justice Witschief in White Plains an injunction permanently restraining eight former officers and directors of the Westchester Trust Company of Yonkers from dealing in securities of that company, individually or as members of any certificate holders or other reorganization group.

A large number of objections to the validity of designating petitions for the primary election on April 2 were filed yesterday with the Board of Elections. Some of these contained only general charges and are not expected to be followed by court action.

NEWARK, N.J., March 9. -- Building service men walked out today in eight or more office buildings here, including a few of the principal ones. Elevator service was crippled, forcing hundreds of persons to walk up many flights of stairs. Several minor clashes between "flying squads" of union men and building employes and guards occurred.

NEW ORLEANS, May 9. -- Mayor T. Semmes Walmsley, one of the chief foes of the late Senator Huey P. Long, decided today to adjust his differences with the Long political machine by resigning as Mayor, provided the State administration would restore local self-government to New Orleans.

Thomas Jefferson's five ran its victory string in the league to nine in a row and assured itself of at least a tie for the Section I, Brooklyn P.S.A.L., title by vanquishing Franklin K. Lane High, 35 to 25, on the Orange and Blue tossers' court yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 9. -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors may act within a week on a partial reorganization of county government if the Commission on Government makes a favorable report to the board's special committee on reorganization of county government Wednesday night, Bert McCulloch, chairman of the Supervisors committee, reported to the board today.
Another of the new longitudinal bus routes in Manhattan will start operation on Thursday on Sixth Avenue and Sixth Avenue Extension, the New York City Omnibus Corporation announced yesterday.

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 8. -- Despite certain apprehensive feelings, by now practically dispelled, as to whether Hal Schumacher and Freddy Fitzsimmons have fully recovered from the arm ailments of last year, and with the burning question of Hank Leiber's future status still unanswered, interest in the Giant training camp has suddenly switched to three other young men.

"German Travelers Hail Sailing Italian Troops." The affecting scene was in Naples, where a shipload of German tourists fraternized with a shipload of Fascist troops bound for Ethiopia. The greetings were of the most ardent kind.

PARIS, March 9. -- Rentes fell 1 franc 50 centimes to I franc 80 centimes today on the market, which suddenly, unexpectedly add without justification, in the opinion of many, was nearly in a panic as the result of the Rhineland situation.

Harold W. Pierce of Boston has been named chairman of the championship committee of the United States Golf Association for 1936, it was announced yesterday. This and other appointments were made by John G. Jackson, president of the association.
LONDON, March 9. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin's address to the House of Commons today was in part as follows:

The largest net income since 1929 was reported yesterday for 1935 by the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company in its annual statement. The net income, in the amount of $11,983,380, was equal to $4.49 a share on 79,974 preferred and 2,666,315 common shares, combined, which share equally in all dividend distributions above $3.50 a share on both stocks.

"No Friendly Voice," which will be published this week by the University of Chicago Press, is the first book to be written by Robert M. Hutchins, president of the university. It consists of a series of addresses delivered to educational, academic and business groups throughout the country.

MIAMI, Fla., March 9 (AP). -- A freakish forty-three-mile wind and rainstorm that struck Miami tonight injured about thirty persons, flattened a carnival show, damaged many small buildings and blew down electric lines in the northwest and southwest sections.
FORT MYERS, Fla., March 9 (AP). -- The Reds offered Babe Ruth a chance to return to baseball, but Mrs. Ruth put her foot down and the former home-run king decided today to remain in retirement.

Mrs. John Van Ryn's first quest for the national indoor tennis championship was crowned with victory last night when she defeated Miss Norma Taubele of New York in the final round of the tournament at the Seventh Regiment Armory, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3.

METZ, France, March 9 (AP). -- France poured men and materials into her Rhineland fortifications tonight amid a flurry of excitement over a report that a German plane had flown over the French fortress at Thionville.

TRENTON, N.J., March 9. -- Although a joint legislative committee on emergency relief decided today to recommend taxes on amusements, tobacco, cosmetics and soft drinks as a major part of its program for making about $20,000,000 available this year, the House tonight adopted a resolution petitioning the Federal Government to contribute the full amount.
Your Moscow correspondent, Harold Denny, painted an interesting though a regrettably incomplete picture in his dispatch in which he compared the Russian standard of living with our own.
WASHINGTON, March 9. -- President Roosevelt received a delegation of American Federation of Labor leaders, who presented a housing program calling for an annual Federal expenditure of $500,000,000.

GENEVA, March 9. -- Germany has been asked if she wishes to participate in the League Council meeting called for Friday to rule on charges by France and Belgium that Chancellor Hitler has violated agreements on the Rhineland.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 9. -- In a Cabinet shake-up today Governor Earle transferred Dr. J. Evans Scheehle of Llanerch, formerly his personal physician, from the post of Secretary of Welfare to that of Secretary of Forests and Waters.

TOKYO, March 9. -- Koki Hirota, the son of a stonemason who rose to an outstanding role on the world stage, completed today formation of his Cabinet and it was ceremonially installed in the presence of Emperor Hirohito tonight in the Phoenix Hall of the Imperial Palace.

BERLIN, March 9. -- The press throughout the Reich carried today clear warning to all Jews that if they attempt to exercise citizenship rights and vote in the coming Reichstag elections, they will be arrested and prosecuted whether or not their names are still registered on official voting lists.

A 352-pound blue marlin, largest of that species to be caught in Bimini waters this season, fell to the rod of an Atlantic City sportsman, Daniel Stebbins, last week. The fish measured 10 feet 11 inches in length, 50 3/4 inches in girth and had a tail spread of forty-seven inches.

Opinions given by farmers and farmers' representatives from twelve Eastern States meeting in New York yesterday indicated that payments for land taken out of crop cultivation for soil conservation under the new Soil Conservation and Domestic Allotment Act would not be considered adequate by farmers in the East, where land is intensively cultivated.

ADDIS ABABA, March 9. -- A telephone message received this morning from Erga Alem, the principal town of Sidamo Province, stating the town had been bombed, caused alarm here. Shops were shut, and the population fled to the hills or took refuge in foreign legations.

Ten Protestant religious organizations are named as beneficiaries in the will of Miss Mary Bussing, daughter of John S. and Ann Van Nest Bussing, descendants of Dutch Colonial residents of New York, who died at her home on last Nov. 15, it was revealed yesterday when the will was offered for probate in Surrogate's Court.

Jonas Lie, president of the National Academy of Design, does not endorse the attitude of the American Society of Painters, Sculptors and Gravers in boycotting the international art exhibition of the Carnergie Institute in Pittsburgh.

ROME, March 9. -- The urgency of Premier Benito Mussolini's need to settle his Ethiopian controversy in order to be free to act in Europe may have been responsible for reports that he had ordered a suspension of military operations in East Africa.

SYRACUSE, March 9. -- The making and mailing of a hoax bomb addressed to Charles W. Flint, chancellor of Syracuse University, and found in the postoffice Saturday, brought twenty-five students of the university into police court today on charges of disorderly conduct.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Senator Fletcher introduced in the Senate today a bill to permit until the end of this year Federal insurance of loans for modernization of private homes and business buildings. The existing authorization expires April 1.

Two unusually interesting stage works, one of them new and the other sung in New York for the first time in English, were performed last night in the theatre of the Juilliard School of Music by the opera department of that institution.

LONDON, March 9. -- The European crisis had a depressing effect today on the stock markets here. Prices in most groups were generally lower, but the decline was more a precautionary markdown by jobbers than a sign of nervousness. There was no panic of selling, although British Government issues weakened sharply on steady offerings throughout the day.

Assurance from Gene Venzke that he will be fit and ready to renew his rivalry with Glenn Cunningham and Joe Mangan in the Columbian mile at the Knights of Columbus games at Madison Square Garden Saturday night was received yesterday by Frank Brennan, director of the meet.
My heart is with the flag-bearing patriots who picketed the Columbia broadcasting studios the other night. But my head is on the side of William Paley and his great network.

ALBANY, Tuesday, March 10. -- At 3 o'clock this morning the Republican-controlled Assembly was debating Governor Lehman's principal budget bill, after having defeated by a straight party vote of 79 to 68 an amendment to restore the $11,160,000 debt service item which had been eliminated by the Ways and Means Committee.
LONDON, March 9. -- A Berlin correspondent of The Times of London tonight telephoned his paper the following story:

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Appeals for a total of $2,659,077,265 in loans and grants for carrying out 6,801 permanent construction projects have been received from States and communities, but no funds are available for honoring these requests, Secretary Ickes told the Senate today in response to a request for information.

Europe was in deep confusion yesterday over the German remilitarization of the Rhineland and the attempt of other powers to meet the situation. Following is a summary of news from the various capitals:

Most commodity futures were weak yesterday in fairly active trading, mainly in sympathy with the uneasiness in stocks and the foreign exchanges. Hides and lead futures were slightly higher. On the cash markets lard, pork, wool-tops and silk advanced, while wheat, corn, rye, oats, butter, eggs, rubber and tin declined.

Many supper parties will be given in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Thursday night after the performance of "Saint Joan," with Katharine Cornell in the leading role, at the Martin Beck Theatre, which has been taken over on that night to raise funds for the Southern Women's Educational Alliance.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Continued improvement in business activity was indicated today by the Treasury's figures on money in circulation, showing $5,846,231,715 in the hands of the public on Feb. 29, an increase of $109,161,000 in a month and of $379,529,000 in a year.

NEW ORLEANS, March 9. -- Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, heading a group of Exchange governors and members on a Southwestern tour, said in an address here today that the Exchange is purely a market place and a mirror of industrial conditions.

Germany has again shown herself proficient in the gentle art of making enemies. Chancellor HITLER'S triumphant stroke has instantly solidified European opinion against him. It is no crafty "encirclement" devised by scheming imperialists which now confronts the German Government, but rather a spontaneous union of nations determined to uphold the sanctity of treaties so long as they are in vigor.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- As part of a drive to finance the campaign against President Roosevelt, Chairman Henry P. Fletcher of the Republican National Committee announced tonight that $1 "participation certificates" would be sold in an effort to get "a million dollars from a million Americans."
LONDON, March 9. -- The complete text of the speech delivered by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden to the House of Commons today follows:

BOSTON, March 9. -- Federal Judge Elisha H. Brewster today took under advisement a bill of complaint brought by the William Filene's Sons Company against the Fashion Originators Guild of America, Inc., of New York.
LOS ANGELES, March 9. -- Death Valley Scotty, mystery man of the desert, came into Los Angeles today "to look for some mules."

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- A prediction that civilian populations far behind the battle lines will be bombarded with a rain of fire-spreading bombs in the "next war" is made by Lieut. Col. A.M. Prentiss of the Chemical Warfare Service.

Stanley Galowin, youthful star of the home club, made his debut in the Eastern Squash Racquets Association Group 1 championship tournament yesterday and defeated A. G. Townsend, Jackson Heights representative, 15 -- 12, 18 -- 15, 15 -- 7, at the City A.C.
LONDON, March 9. -- A new naval treaty was completed tonight except for the escape clauses and replacement provisions, which are still being discussed informally among the delegations.

The prospect of the organization of a conference of all freight lines in the intercoastal trade has been upset by the efforts of the Shepard Line to effect new rates which are below those of competing lines, according to shipping men.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

ATHENS, Ohio, March 9 (AP). -- An Ohio University psychologist reported today after research that writers reached their peak in literary production at 41, chemists were best between 30 and 35, inventors at 35 and astronomers between 40 and 45.

The calmness with which the management of the Stock Exchange received over the week-end news of the latest menace to peace in Europe seemed yesterday to indicate that events of the last eighteen months have approximately exhausted the capacity of market officials for alarm.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 9. -- Senator Borah and Colonel Henry Breckinridge entered the Pennsylvania Presidential preferential primaries today. Both acted on the last day for filing petitions. The election will be on April 28.
In committing another violation of the Treaty of Versailles and in denouncing the Locarno agreement of 1925, Nazi Germany has once more defied the outside world.

We have become habituated to astronomical figures in association not only with celestial distances and galactic numbers but also with terrestrial expenditures and debts. It is a happy relief to see them applied to a service which is concerned with the health of "countless homes."

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- "Idiot's Delight," a new play by Robert E. Sherwood, opened to a full house at the National Theatre tonight, which greeted with enthusiasm the pacifist theme, with its sub-theme of denunciation of dictators and international munitions manufacturers, and enthusiastically cheered the co-stars, Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne.
An exhibition of photographs by Thomas Bouchard was opened yesterday at the Delphic Studios, 724 Fifth Avenue, where it will continue until March 23.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 9. -- Some of the Dodgers who already have seen more of the minor leagues than is to their liking today had reason to feel trepidation as to whether the coming season will find them playing the big time or back in the lower loops.

BOSTON, March 9 (AP). -- A reorganization plan designed to "rehabilitate rather than liquidate" the Amoskeag Manufacturing Company, which owns large textile mills in Manchester, N.H., was filed in Federal court today by John L. Hall, attorney for the company.

PARIS, March 9. -- Representatives of France, Great Britain, Belgium and Italy will begin a discussion tomorrow morning at the Quai d'Orsay on an issue that may be defined in this way: Is an attempt to be made to impose on Germany respect for the Locarno treaty, or is a new Locarno to be made with Adolf Hitler's proposals as a basis?

One of two representatives of the Cambridge Union who debated with undergraduates of some twenty-six American colleges and universities records in The Nineteenth Century his impressions of a six-week journey in parts of our student world. Naturally he is struck by the wide extension of "college education" and the habit of working one's way through college without infringement of "social status."

A threefold Japanese invasion of the New York art exhibition field began yesterday. A large exhibition of modern industrial art was supplemented by a one-man show of oils and drawings by Eitaro Ishagaki and a show of old brocades and textile panels.

COLOGNE, Germany, March 9 (AP). -- Foreign residents said tonight that Chancellor Adolf Hitler's Rhine army, despite appearances to the contrary, had marched in well prepared to defend itself if necessary.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 9. -- Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Lamont of New York, Mr. and Mrs. Wynant Vanderpool of Morristown, N. J.; J. Pennington Gardiner of Boston and Mrs. Hildegarde Heffinger of New York were the luncheon guests today of Dr. and Mrs. W. T. Porter of Boston at the Mid-Ocean Club.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals in a decision handed down yesterday reversed Federal Judge Grover M. Moscowitz of Brooklyn in the latter's recent ruling that trustees appointed in reorganization proceedings for the Prudence Company, Inc., could distribute proceeds from securities that have a book value of $15,733,000.

Benjamin De Loache, American baritone, gave his first New York recital under the auspices of the Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon, and made an immediately favorable impression. It is not often that a debut recitalist reveals as much intelligence, taste and awareness of interpretive requirements as did Mr. De Loache.

Borough President James J. Lyons accused the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration yesterday of issuing an order to stampede Mayor La Guardia into vetoing the compulsory City Residence Bill affecting relief workers, which is now before the Mayor.
LONDON, March 9 (AP). -- Found guilty of espionage, Dr. Hermann Gortz, middle-aged German lawyer, was sentenced today to four years' imprisonment.

Dismissal notices to the 12,000 WPA workers to be dropped here by April 1 will be in the mails within a few days, Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, said yesterday. Two weeks' notice will be given. The plans call for the reduction of the WPA forces by 42,000 by June 15.

A squad of thirty-five aspirants, most of whom were freshmen, reported for Spring football practice yesterday at Columbia. Coach Lou Little, in civilian clothes, directed the workout in the Morningside gymnasium, and announced that the Lions will move to Baker Field as soon as the ground is dry.

Wildcat O'Connor, Carbondale (Pa.) welterweight, and Frankie Cinque, Washington Heights, fought eight rounds to a draw in the feature bout before 2,000 at St. Nicholas Palace last night. Cinque weighed 145, a pound more than O'Connor.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 9 (AP). -- Governor Paul V. McNutt of Indiana sent a hall wabbling down the No. 16 alley in the Coliseum for a 310-pin strike tonight and the thirty-sixth annual American Bowling Congress was off for a month's run.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Some developments in the administration's position with reference to the St. Lawrence deeper waterway were expected as a result of a conference on that subject today between Frank P. Walsh, chairman of the Power Authority of New York, and President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Robert A. Taft, son of the former President, began his battle today before the Court of Claims to recover $1.07 gold in interest on a $50 Fourth Liberty Loan bond which had been called in October, 1933, for redemption on April 15, 1934.

BERLIN, March 9. -- The Boerse was weaker today in response to the strained international situation and talk of sanctions. Activity as usual was strictly limited and entirely under official control. No accurate reports are obtainable regarding the real situation in private trading, in which securities now mostly are handled.
LONDON, March 9. -- British unemployment dropped by 134,701 to 2,025,021 in February, according to returns released tonight. This made up for almost half the January increase.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The Shell Union Oil Corporation, in its amendment filed today to its registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 setting tomorrow as the date for the offering of $60,000,000 of fifteen-year 3 1/2 per cent debentures, told of an oral offer which the company has with Lehman Brothers to sell its holdings of 148,326 shares of the Flintkote Company, producer of asphalt shingles, for $6,674,670.

All classes of bonds suffered yesterday, the sharpest reaction of the month, but trading volume was somewhat below the recent daily average. The advance of the past week or so had carried prices to a level where even a moderate amount of selling pressure was sufficient to precipitate a substantial setback.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange turned easier yesterday after an early improvement and not only lost all the morning gain but closed unchanged to 6 points lower than on Saturday. Nervousness over European political developments brought a sharp rise in Liverpool, and houses carrying government contracts here were able to distribute about 10,000 bales of March at a slightly higher price level.

The thirteenth and penultimate week of the Metropolitan Opera season began last night with a performance of "Rigoletto" in which John Charles Thomas made his first appearance here in the title role. His impersonation won the approval of the audience.

Anxiety over the warlike course of events in Europe shook the financial markets yesterday. Foreign currencies fluctuated violently, first falling and then recovering; stocks, after moving uneasily most of the day, fell under a sharp burst of selling in the last hour that knocked representative issues down from a fraction to more than 4 points, and bonds met the most severe reaction in a month.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The Treasury Department and the Bureau of Internal Revenue plan to change at once income tax regulations requiring foreign correspondents making brief visits to this country and writing solely for their home newspapers to fill out income returns and, in most cases, pay taxes.
CHICAGO, March 9. -- The "Triumph of St. Patrick," an oratorio by Pietro Yon, organist of St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York, was given its Chicago premiere tonight in Orchestra Hall.

NEWARK, N.J., March 9. -- An upset marked the opening of the national amateur Class A 18.2 balk-line billiard tournament at the Newark Athletic Club today as Seymour Kling, 36-year-old New Yorker, conquered the veteran Edgar T. Appleby, four-time holder of the championship, 300 -- 159.

Warning them that political influence would avail them nothing, Mayor La Guardia told 199 rookies who were sworn in as probationary patrolmen in the gymnasium at police headquarters yesterday morning that they should look upon their new jobs as a lifetime profession.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Reaffirmation by Treasury officials of their opposition to any major change in President Roosevelt's tax plan, together with rumors that the administration might take the matter to the country to "educate" the people on the efficacy and justice of the proposed undistributed corporate profits tax sent House leaders today in search of a compromise on the question of "depression-cushioning" reserves.

" Case of Clyde Griffiths," which is the newest derivative from Theodore Dreiser's "An American Tragedy," has been postponed until Friday evening. Lighting and scenery trouble, say the producers. That defection leaves tonight in the hands of the WPA, which is offering "Conjur-Man Dies," by the late Dr. Rudolph Fisher, up at the Lafayette in the Bronx.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 10. -- Leaving the bulk of her property to the Folger-Shakespeare Memorial at Washington, D.C., to insure its continuance the will of Emily C.J. Folger, who died at her home, 11 St. Andrews Lane, Glen Cove, on Feb. 21, was filed here for probate today with Surrogate Leone D. Howell.

There was a large attendance at the luncheon bridge given yesterday afternoon in the roof garden of the St. Regis for the benefit of the Jesuit seminaries. The party is held each year under the auspices of the Loyola School, of which the Rev. Francis E. Garner is headmaster.
BERLIN, March 10 (AP). -- The Reichsbank statement as of March 7 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

CHICAGO, March 10. -- Operating results of Marshall Field Co. in the first two months of this year improved by about $240,000 over those of the corresponding period of 1935, James O. McKinsey, chairman of the board, told stockholders today at the annual meeting.

ALBANY, March 10. -- The Senate passed one and the Assembly defeated two anti-crime hills today which were related to or part of the Lehman series of measures for better enforcement of the criminal law.

HACKENSACK, N.J., March 10. -- Two Jewish students, one of them cast as Shylock, withdrew from a classroom production of Shakespeare's "The Merchant of Venice" at Hackensack High School today as Rabbi Irving Silman of Hackensack Hebrew Institute continued a campaign to have the play stricken from the sophomore English course at the school because the character of Shylock "is the foulest slander ever penned by the hand of genius."

NEWARK, N.S., March 10. -- With a delicate masse as his most potent weapon, Edmond Soussa of Cairo, Egypt, recorded his second straight victory in defense of the national amateur 18.2 balkline billiard championship tonight at the Newark Athletic Club, routing Edgar T. Appleby of New York, 300 to 122.

Augmented income for two distinct classes this year is just beginning to attract the attention of some business organizations, which are shaping their merchandising and advertising plans to capitalize on the increased spending power, according to comment here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP). -- Admiral Hugh Rodman, U.S.N. retired, who commanded a squadron of the allied fleet under Admiral Beatty, described the British officer as "one of the finest, most efficient and inspiring leaders bare ever known."

GENEVA, March 10. -- The meeting of the Council of the League of Nations on the Locarno-Rhineland situation will be held in London Saturday instead of in Geneva Friday, it was announced here late tonight. It was added that the meeting of the Committee of Thirteen originally set for tomorrow to consider the very conditioned Italian and Ethiopian acceptances on its peace appeal had been deferred until next week.

The nervous tension that had existed in the stock market since Saturday morning over the troubled European situation was somewhat relaxed yesterday as foreign dispatches indicated that a calmer view was being taken of Germany's occupation of the erstwhile demilitarized Rhineland zone.

The railroads reduced their aggregate net loss in 1935 to the lowest level in three years, according to reports by 149 Class I railroads to the Interstate Commerce Commission. Their net income in December was the best for the three-year period.

ALBANY, March 10. -- More than 2,000 dairy farmers thronged the capital city today and heard Peter G. Ten Eyck, Agriculture Commissioner, demand a broad legislative inquiry into the entire milk industry before making any changes in the present milk-control system.

A noted French wartime general and an American banker arrived from Europe yesterday on the French liner Ile de France, both expressing optimism at the outcome of the recent political disturbances in Western Europe refusing to consider the threatening political clouds along the Rhine as too serious for diplomatic solution.

In a highly exciting final round contest the St. Augustine's High School quintet of Brooklyn defeated Don Bosco Institute. 28 to 22, as the seventh annual Metropolitan Catholic High Schools championship tournament ended at the Columbus Council, K of C., clubhouse in Brooklyn last night.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- President Roosevelt will be told next week by the Railway Labor Executives Association that the twenty-one standard railway unions will agree to withhold legislation to protect employes displaced by mergers and consolidations if the carriers will consent to a "stand-by" arrangement for one year.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission revealed today facts concerning several corporations, having concluded after hearings that to keep the data confidential, as requested, was not in the public interest.

WARSAW, March 10. -- Poland as an ally of France and at the same time a friend of Germany has found herself in a delicate situation as a result of Germany's repudiation of Locarno and her occupation of the demilitarized Rhineland. From different quarters has come pressure for some new declaration of the Polish attitude toward this new situation.

A jury in Bronx County Court yesterday convicted three men of the kidnapping last August of Battisto Salvo, former policy banker, who will be sentenced today for obstructing justice by refusing to tell the authorities of the crime. Eight days after Salvo was released, on Aug. 22, two of the men said to have abducted him were slain.
ASMARA, Eritrea, March 10. -- After Sunday's cessation, hostilities in the African campaign continued on all fronts in full force today.

The Kolisch Quartet, consisting of the Messrs. Kolisch, Lehner, Khuner and Heifetz, presented the third and final concert of its subscription series at the Town Hall last night. The program began with Beethoven's B flat major quartet, Op. 130, including the Grand Fugue, which is designated as Op. 133.

LONDON, March 10. -- Admiral Earl Beatty, British naval hero and one of the outstanding personalities of the World War, died tonight after a long illness. He was automatically retired on Jan. 17 after reaching the age limit of 65.

The State of Louisiana yesterday awarded a new issue of $2,500,000 of 4 1/2 per cent highway bonds to a banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a price of 108.645. The bonds are dated March 1, 1936, and mature from March 1, 1939 to 1960.

The New York County grand jury dismissed yesterday charges against Frederick A. Thiergard, 31 years old, of 1,060 East Eighteenth Street, Brooklyn, and Miss Irene Kennedy, a clerk in the Education Department. They were accused of having attempted last October to tamper with the papers to be used in one of the department's examinations for teachers in health education.
Hubert R. Brown, 66 years old, of 1,192 Park Avenue, fell or jumped ten floors to his death yesterday from a fire escape in the rear of the building at 70 Fifth Avenue, in which he had offices.

A letter from President Roosevelt was read last night at a dinner at the Hotel Commodore celebrating the thirtieth anniversary of the Kent School, Kent, Conn., and the sixty-second birthday of its founder and headmaster, the Rev. Frederick H. Sill.

The powerful Samuel J. Tilden High quintet, which previously had clinched the group title, continued its unbeaten stride in Section 2 of the Brooklyn P.S.A.L. tourney by routing Erasmus Hall, 36 -- 24, yesterday on the winner's court in one of the outstanding games involving Metropolitan school teams.

CRISTOBAL, C.Z., March 10. -- The final effort of Treasure Recovery, Ltd., to discover the Cocos Island treasure prior to the expiration in April of the concession for hunting was admitted to be a failure with the revelation today of the disappearance at Jamaica of the mysterious Belgian, Peter Bergmans.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- The Senate, which asked the Federal Communications Commission yesterday for all the facts in regard to its inspection and seizure of telegrams in connection with the lobby investigation, will be informed by the commission that its aid to the committee headed by Senator Black was merely incidental and supplementary.

CHICAGO, March 10. -- An attempt to evade $414,525 income taxes for 1929 was charged to Arthur W. Cutten, grain speculator, in an indictment returned by the grand jury today before Federal Judge Charles E. Woodward in District Court. Mr. Cutten is seriously ill in his hotel apartment.

CHICAGO, March 10. -- That the Reconstruction Finance Corporation expects to lose $10,000,000 on its $90,000,000 loan to the Central Republic Bank and Trust Company, made in 1932, even if successful in collecting the $14,000,000 sought from more than 4,500 stockholders of the bank in this State, was the statement made in court today.

The Midtown Gallery, 605 Madison Avenue, just above Fifty-seventh Street, opened yesterday its fourth anniversary group exhibition, to remain until the end of March. The Midtown began its career in 1932 at 559 Fifth Avenue and moved to the present address last October.
