Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, recommended yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Valente that the offer of $10,031,000 by the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation for the entire stock, comprising 100,000 shares of the National Surety Corporation be accepted because it was the highest of seven bids made by banking and investment houses.
The premier woman figure skater of the world, Miss Sonja Henie, arrived in New York yesterday aboard the French liner Ile de France.

The annual report of the Long Island Lighting Company for 1935, issued yesterday, showed a consolidated net income of $2,411,489. This was equal, after preferred dividends, to 27 cents a share earned on 3,000,000 common shares. It compared with $2,252,855, or 22 cents a common share, for 1934.

BERLIN, March 10. -- The total German military force in the formerly demilitarized Rhineland zone was raised to 50,000 men overnight when the Rhineland battalions of the green-clad "State police" that had been there all the time were formally incorporated into the army today.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- Within five days every WPA project in the country will have posted before it red, white and blue signs of identification, Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, announced today.

ALBANY, March 10. -- The Howard bill to provide for State regulation of fee-charging employment agencies drew the principal attention today at a public hearing on numerous labor bills pending in the Legislature, with sharp differences of opinion voiced by friends and foes of the measure.

MADRID, March 10. -- Socialists and Communists, whose "celebration" of the Left election victory has accounted for forty-eight deaths and the burning of twenty-seven churches and convents in the provinces in three weeks, tonight turned their attention to this city.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- Chester C. Davis, Agricultural Adjustment Administrator, was assigned by President Roosevelt today to go abroad and study at first hand the conditions that have a bearing on domestic agricultural problems.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 10. -- One of Casey Stengel's immediate worries was eradicated today when Van Lingle Mungo, ace of the Dodger hurling corps, signed his contract after a brief conference with Vice President Joe Gilleaudeau.

NEWARK, N.J., March 10. -- John A. Moffitt, conciliator of the United States Department of Labor, tried today to bring about a settlement in the building service strike here. He conferred with leaders of the Building Service Employes Union and spoke by telephone to Federal Judge William Clark, who has offered his services as an arbitrator.

TRENTON, March 10. -- As the joint legislative committee on emergency relief continued work today on a plan to impose luxury taxes to raise funds for the unemployed, protests on the proposal and demands for a public hearing before action is taken by the Legislature were received by Governor Hoffman.

BERLIN, March 10. -- Dr. Joseph Goebbels, the Minister of Propaganda, informed the world in opening the Reichstag election campaign tonight that it would have to accept Chancellor Adolf Hitler's proposals for the reorganization of European and international relations whether it would or not.
LONDON, March 10. -- Germany will commit no overt act in the Rhineland, Chancellor Adolf Hitler told G. Ward Price, correspondent of The London Daily Mail, in an interview in Munich today.

LONDON, March 10. -- The present situation is not to be understood unless one essential fact is always borne in mind -- that the real tussle now is not between France and Germany but between Great Britain and France.

ATHENS, March 10. -- A secret agreement with Yugoslavia, Rumania and Turkey signing away Greece's Parliamentary reservations against participating in wars outside the Balkans, which was concluded in Geneva twenty months ago by former Foreign Minister Demetrios Maximos, was revealed by Eleutherios Venizelos today.

Kenneth S. Simpson, New York County Republican Chairman, disclosed yesterday that an attempt had been made, before the expiration of the time for filing designating petitions and declinations, to harmonize the party differences in the Eleventh Congressional District by withdrawing Frederic R. Coudert Jr. as a candidate for delegate the Republican National Convention. Mr. Coudert is not a resident of the district.

MIAMI, Fla., March 10. -- The Sage Stables' Bright Haven, favorite with an opening day crowd of 8,000 persons, captured the Pan American Handicap before Governor Sholtz and his host, Big Bill Dwyer, as the last race meeting of the Florida season got under way today at Tropical Park.

CHICAGO, March 10. -- The foreign political situation was displaced today as the dominating price-making influence in the wheat market on the Board of Trade by reports of dust storms in parts of the Southwest, and while these reports were not accompanied by buying orders, local shorts were somewhat nervous because of the forecast suggesting generally fair weather in that section.
Alex Yokel, producer of "Three Men on a Horse," returned from England yesterday on the French liner Ile de France, having successfully ushered his race-track farce into the London theatrical world.

The Park Department announced with considerable pride yesterday the birth of a Rhesus monkey at the Central Park Zoo. The pride was pardonable, since officials could not recall a similar occurrence in Central Park history.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- Lawyers, public officials and legislators see one of the most interesting political developments in the country's history in the briefs filed in the Supreme Court by the representatives of sovereign States praying for the validation of the Guffey act.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,758,650 barrels, compared with 2,774,700 in the preceding week, a drop of 16,050, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Declines of 26,300 and 20,250 barrels, respectively, in Oklahoma and east of California and a rise of 21,900 in Texas were the important changes.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP). -- Mayor Ellenstein of Newark discussed with Federal officials today three projects designed to save Newark about $2,000,000 and enable it to acquire the old army base property at Fort Newark for $1,000,000.

Supreme Court Justice Albert Conway of Brooklyn, who pointed out that he is the only Albert Conway listed in the Brooklyn telephone directory, took legal steps in his own court yesterday to prevent one Albert Cikanowich from using the name Albert Conway and Cikanowich's son from calling himself Albert Conway Jr.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- Unanimous approval of the Rogers bill, authorizing acquisition of 4,000 new combat planes "at any time within the next five years," was given by the House Military Affairs Committee today, and the bill probably will be brought to the floor soon for action.

BELLEAIR, Fla., March 10. -- Miss Bernice Wall of Oshkosh, Wis., 1935 winner of the tournament, was the only favored player to be eliminated in the first round of the women's Belleair golf championship today. She lost by 1 up to Mrs. Marion Turpie Lake of Plandome, L.I., on the final green.

If humorous implications were enough, "Star Spangled," which opened at the Golden last evening, would be the comedy of the season. Robert Ardrey has very little skill for expressing his ideas in play form, but his sense of the ridiculous is unhackneyed and keen.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- The Securities Act of 1933, passed by Congress at President Roosevelt's suggestion to force "truth in securities," was denounced before the Supreme Court today as an effort to regulate the conduct of American citizens, and defended by the government as a protection to the American public.

A children's opera entitled "The Enchanted Hour" was presented by the children's chorus and orchestra of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association last night in the clubhouse of the New York Junior League, 221 East Seventy-first Street. The proceeds will aid the children's groups which gave the program.

The oxalis plant awakens punctually at 8:30 o'clock in the morning in February and goes to bed equally on the dot at 5:30 in the afternoon, these hours varying with the month. The stringbean plant turns its leaves edgewise to the sun to avoid sunburn.

The plan to exchange the 5 1/2 per cent debentures of Remington Rand, Inc., for equal face amounts of 4 1/4 per cent debentures with common stock purchase warrants attached was ratified yesterday by holders of more than 75 per cent of the present issue.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- The Federal housing program was declared by President Roosevelt today to be in a mess because of the inability of the groups concerned (builders, real estate experts and financiers) to agree.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes declared today in a formal statement that "a group of fanatics representing an infinitesimal minority in Puerto Rico has apparently embarked on a course of violence," and warned bluntly that "the government of the United States will not tolerate terrorism or murder."

ALBANY, March 10. -- The eleven-point program for legislative changes in the regulation of public utilities proposed by the Mack Utility Inquiry Committee drew scant attention today when bills in the program were brought up for a public hearing.

A modified Pacific Coast wage scale for unlicensed seagoing personnel was awarded to the employes of fourteen lines operating from Atlantic Coast ports at a meeting of committees of shipowners and the International Seamen's Union yesterday afternoon in the offices of the American Steamship Owners Association, 11 Broadway.

Moderate recoveries were recorded by most commodity futures here yesterday, but cocoa and some of the metals were easier. On the cash markets, wheat and cotton advanced and rubber rose to a new high price for the year. Rye, cocoa, butter, Straits tin, silk and wool-tops declined.

Buying by Bombay and other foreign interests, mainly in the new crop, together with less nervousness over the outlook in Europe completed with a sharp recovery in the stock market, brought an improvement of 3 to 9 points in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday.

The elimination of A.E. Watt of Jackson Heights, second seeded player, by Captain D.P. Laubach of Mitchel Field, an unranked entry, featured the competition as the semi-final bracket in the Eastern Squash Racquets Association Group 1 championship tournament was filled on the courts of the City A.C. yesterday.

Support for the Livingston bill to create a State distributive trades commission to deal with retail trade evils, particularly the use of "loss leaders," was voiced yesterday by representatives of more than 100 retail organizations at a meeting held yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker under the auspices of the Inter-Industry Committee, formed by groups of retailers and wholesalers.

In accordance with custom, Miss Rosalie Knapp of the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club on Long Island, will be chairman of the women's committee of the United States Golf Association during 1936, it was announced yesterday.

The hearing into the managerial affairs of Isidoro Gastanaga, started by the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday, was postponed until March 27. Solly King, who holds a contract for the fighter's services, did not appear at the meeting, and his claim that Louis Soresi has been acting as pilot for Gastanaga as well as Primo Carnera, whom the Spaniard fought last Friday, could not be substantiated.
ROME, March 10. -- Italy's attitude toward Adolf Hitler's denunciation of Locarno continues to be a closely guarded secret, Premier Benito Mussolini evidently not yet being ready to show his hand.

PARIS, March 10. -- A report by the Senate Foreign Affairs Commission approving the Franco-Soviet treaty was distributed today in the Senate, which, despite the tenseness of the international situation, will go forward with debate on its ratification tomorrow.
A.W. Paine of the Harvard Club let down the committee that seeded him No. 1 in the metropolitan Class C squash racquets championship yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., March 10. -- Sending a magnificent second shot with bulletlike speed to the edge of the green on the concluding hole, Gene Sarazen, former United States and British open and P.G.A. champion, got a birdie 4 to win with Jimmy Hines of Garden City, L.I., in the second round of the annual international four-ball golf tournament at the Miami Country Club today.
Foreclosure sales kept auctioneers busy yesterday, when bids were taken on a dozen properties in Manhattan and two in the Bronx.
Nine years after the Davis Cup was lost to France on its courts, the Germantown Cricket Club of Philadelphia will stage the most important cup tie arranged in this country in all that long interval.

Prosecution Ratio Low. Following its well established precedent, the New York regional office of the Securities and Exchange Commission declined yesterday to comment upon published reports that it was investigating transactions in common stocks of the Atlas Tack Corporation and the Budd Wheel Company, both of which are listed on the Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- When former Judge Burns told the court today that the SEC's refusal to permit withdrawal of registration was based on its own rules and not set forth in the act itself, he was questioned by Justices Butler and McReynolds on where the commission derived power to make such rules, and replied that it received that authority from Congress.

A proposal submitted to the Legislature to legalize tolls on freight moving through the State Barge Canal was attacked yesterday by a group of canal shippers and defended by the railroads of New York State.

A more accurate idea of how top-ranking A.A.U. teams will fare against crack college teams in the Olympic tryouts will be furnished in Madison Square Garden tonight when the Oilers of McPherson, Kan., favorites for the American Olympic basketball berth, face an All-Metropolitan college quintet that will place its reliance on the unbeaten Long Island University players.
SACRAMENTO, March 10 (AP). -- Governor Frank F. Merriam suddenly announced today that he would support Governor Alfred M. Landon of Kansas for the Republican Presidential nomination.

Delegates of the various clubs in the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound were notified yesterday by Edward A. Hodge, secretary, that the general meeting at which the championship racing schedule for next season will be adopted will be held at the Harvard Club at 8 P.M. on March 20.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 10. -- The thirty-first annual dog show of the Capital City Kennel Club opened today in the Columbus Auditorium with an entry of 330 dogs. Colonel Robert Guggenheim of Babylon, L.I, and Jesse M. Balsley of Avalon, N.Y., are the Judges.
Operators figured prominently as buyers of apartment properties in Manhattan in transactions announced yesterday.

Controller Frank J. Taylor made public yesterday a plan to refinance $35,000,000 in revenue notes, issued on Oct. 30, 1933, and maturing on next Nov. 1, on a basis that would save upward of $1,800,000 in interest over a five-year period.

The family of James P. Gilleeny was evicted from its former home at 45-18 Thirty-ninth Avenue, Sunnyside, Queens, yesterday morning after a lively but peaceable demonstration by a crowd of sympathetic neighbors.

In the Caprice Room of the Weylin yesterday a gala fashion show entitled "Breath of Spring" featured the luncheon hour. The function had been arranged for the benefit of the Travelers Aid Society. Miss Florence Weicker acted as master of ceremonies and announced the program.

WESTPORT, Conn., March 10. -- Hundreds of telegrams and other messages poured in today on Miss Lillian D. Wald, founder of the Henry Street Settlement in New York, who observed her sixty-ninth birthday at "House-on-the-Pond," her home.

Two weeks ago President ROOSEVELT gave his endorsement to a bill to provide civil service status for postmasterships of the first, second and third class. There has been no action on it, despite the fact that a relatively idle Congress has had ample opportunity to consider the President's proposal.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- Charges were made today by Secretary Ickes that the Duke Power Company and the Central Vermont Public Service Corporation were seeking to thwart PWA's municipal power program, which involves the expenditure of $78,000,000.

Gregory Mangin's dominion over the indoor tennis courts in this country was reaffirmed once again last night when the defending titleholder won the national championship for the fourth time in the last five years.
MIAMI, Fla., March 10. -- The tenth anniversary Southern dinner of the Committee of One Hundred took place at the Surf Club, Miami Beach, tonight.
A plea for greater public support of the work carried on by the National Organization for Public Health Nursing was made yesterday at the annual luncheon of the organization at the Hotel Roosevelt.

ALBANY, March 10. -- The Assembly passed today the Byrne bill, making amendments in the Unemployment Insurance Law. Since it had already been approved by the Senate, it now goes to the Governor, who is expected to sign it.

THE TIMES published a statement by William D. Rawlins, executive secretary of the Realty Advisory Board, to the effect that the lack of service in apartment buildings does not permit tenants to withhold payment of rent.

A start toward formulating an adequate basic program for the conservation of all natural resources will be made under the new Soil Conservation and Domestic Allotment Act, Secretary of Agriculture Henry A. Wallace intimated yesterday.

Senator BLACK, long famous for his impartiality as an inquisitor and an investigator, is naturally vexed by the criticism, or rather the ferocious persecution, to which his committee is being subjected. It is insulting to quote the Constitution in regard to the pious and necessary processes which he follows in the search for transgressors and the seizure of their papers.

OTTAWA, Ont., March 10. -- Canadian nervousness regarding Europe found expression in Parliament today in a denial by Prime Minister Mackenzie King that the Dominion had committed herself in any way in support of an empire defense policy.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 10. -- Returns tonight from Rhode Island's special election indicated defeat of the Democratic proposal for a State constitutional convention.

A well-balanced team of speedsters from Rutgers University gave the Scarlet the championship of the Intercollegiate Swimming Association last night by defeating Columbia, 48 to 23, in the Morningside Heights pool.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- Lamar Hardy appeared before the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee today to establish his qualification for the post of Federal Attorney for the Southern District of New York, an interim appointment by President Roosevelt.

Dr. Henry C. Sherman, Professor of Chemistry at Columbia University, has been chosen to receive the bronze plaque awarded annually by the Alumni Association of the Graduate Schools of Columbia University for "outstanding contributions to the human race."

BERLIN, March 10. -- The Boerse today recovered slightly from yesterday's slump and the opening tendency favored limited buying on the basis of yesterday's closing levels with early gains ranging from 1 to 3 points for favorite issues.

Lady Olive Astley Cubitt, wife of the Governor of Bermuda and Major Gen. Sir Richard and Lady Howard-Vyse are among the passengers leaving tonight for Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania. Others sailing on the ship include Mr. and Mrs. H. Bradley Martin, Clive Pearson, Lionel Montague, Lady Eaton of Toronto, Sir Ian Walker.

TOKYO, March 10. -- Many high officers holding executive positions in the War Office, on the General Staff and among the divisions and regiments involved in the recent revolt have tendered their resignations.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

ALBANY, March 10. -- The Democratic State Senate and the Republican Assembly were in a deadlock tonight over Governor Lehman's fiscal program, including three of his four executive budget bills and one of his six revenue measures. This bill provides for continuance for another year of the temporary emergency tax of 2 cents a gallon on gasoline.

The pamphlet report of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation and subsidiaries for 1935, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income of $4,386,816, equal to 50.2 cents each on 8,738,811 common shares, compared with $4,051,590, or 46.4 cents a share, earned in 1934.

Elfrieda Bos Mestechkin, violinist, was soloist with the New York Woman's Symphony Orchestra, Antonia Brico conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall. Miss Mestechkin gave a fiery performance of the Tchaikovsky concerto, one which stirred the audience to exceptional enthusiasm.

BOSTON, March 10. -- Party opposition to an instructed Roosevelt delegation from Massachusetts to the Democratic National Convention has lessened with the recent agreement of Senators Walsh and Coolidge, critics of the national administration, to go on the slate approved by Chairman Farley and Governor Curley.

BOSTON, March 10. -- Bishop William Lawrence, Massachusetts Episcopal prelate, called for the repeal of the State Teachers Oath Law before a capacity crowd of 1,300 persons in a State House auditorium today.

Small House Associates, described by its founders asia "limited architectural service," will open an office at 101 Park Avenue this morning for builders and plot owners planning houses to cost between $3,500 and $8,000.
A variety of buildings, including a flat, a factory, a garage and a taxpayer, passed to new control in the Bronx yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 10. -- The market for hogs here was unsettled today, ranging from as much as 15 cents a hundredweight higher than yesterday on butcher stock in the early trading and showing moderate losses on lighter kinds later. The top was $10.60, or 10 cents less than yesterday, while the day's average was unchanged at $10.10.

LONDON, March 10. -- Viscount Cecil of Chelwood, organizer of last year's gigantic "peace ballot" and acknowledged spokesman of millions of pro-League of Nations voters in Britain, warned tonight that it would be worse than useless for the League to censure Germany and do nothing further about it.

Mayor La Guardia selected Harry Uviller yesterday as the new impartial chairman in the dress industry under the agreement recently signed which averted a strike of 105,000 workers in the industry in the metropolitan area.

BOSTON, March 10 (AP). -- Paul Runge's accurate slashing in a mob milling about the Detroit net gave the Boston Bruins a 1-0 overtime victory over the American group leaders tonight before 15,000 at the Boston Garden.
State Senator John McNaboe's bill requiring that all Police Departments in the State be raised to full quota strength was endorsed by the Board of Aldermen yesterday by a vote of 65 to 2.

Warning that the world is confronted with a crisis "frightfully similar" to that which led to the World War, Mayor La Guardia appealed to American women last night to take the leadership in a militant drive to keep this nation out of war.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- Support for President Roosevelt's proposal for a tax on undistributed profits of corporations was believed today to have been materially strengthened by the strong stand of the Treasury against major alterations of the plan, among them the provision suggested in Congress to allow "depression-cushioning" reserves.

With bristling hair and angry, watchful eyes, Nellie, a small terrier, crouched against the body of her master, Carl Lindstrom, who had committed suicide early yesterday in the kitchen of his apartment at 2 West 104th Street. Agents from the A.S.P.C.A. were forced to carry the whimpering dog from the room.

The two greatest novels in all literature are "War and Peace" and "Henry Esmond." Both books were completed by their authors at the age of 41, and that is the perfect age for the novelists. So it was recently determined at Ohio University.

Besides "Pelleas et Melisande" and "Parsifal," operas which hitherto have not been performed this season and have already been announced, the Metropolitan yesterday announced the remainder of the operas for the last week.
The Western Electric Company, Inc., reports for 1935 a consolidated net income of $2,620,279, equal to 44 cents a share on 6,000,000 capital shares, comparing with a loss of $7,751,548 in 1934.

Hiram C. Todd, special prosecutor in the Samuel Drukman murder case, charged yesterday in open court that on May 1, 1935, while the case was under consideration of the April grand jury, an Assistant District Attorney of Kings County received $2,000 from Leo P. Byk, who had a criminal record.

ONE thing about coming out of a mining camp into the inheritance of a big, brand new fortune is that you are free of the bugaboo of "good taste," are unconscious of new caste loyalties, and, coming fresh to the problem of what to do with large sums of money, find this no problem at all. You don't pick and choose for what is fitting to buy -- you just buy everything.

The movement of bond prices yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange continued toward lower levels. The trading pace, however, showed a further slackening and sales amounted to only $11,232,600, compared with $13,743,600 on Monday.

Brokers and managing agents of buildings in the midtown section of Manhattan announced a list of new tenacies yesterday which included contracts for entire floors. Several of the larger units were taken by manufacturers.

COLOGNE, Germany, March 10 (AP). -- Heavy combat equipment has been drawn into the Rhineland by Germany, it was learned today. Cologne, it was disclosed, has one of the biggest garrisons, with more troops than were officially admitted, and also is an important center for heavy artillery.

MONTREAL, March 10. -- The Montreal Maroons and the New York Rangers fought through seventy minutes of hard-hitting hockey to a scoreless tie tonight in a National Hockey League game that reached its fastest pace in the overtime as both teams tried hard for a victory.

Charges of kidnapping were made yesterday against four men arrested in Harlem on the complaint of a building superintendent who alleged he had been forced into a taxi and taken to 312 West 125th Street, the Harlem unit of the Building Service Employes Union.

MANCHESTER, N.H., March 10. -- President Roosevelt and Colonel Frank Knox appeared assured of the support of New Hampshire's delegations to the Democratic and Republican National Conventions as a result of today's State-wide Presidential primary.
WASHINGTON, March 10. -- A defense of the activities of the WPA and a plan for an additional immediate appropriation of $700,000,000 for the PWA were made in the Senate today.

The Department of Health reported 723 cases of scarlet fever last week, an increase of 123 over the preceding week and of 93 over the same week last year. There were three deaths from this disease, compared to five the week before and two in 1936.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 10. -- Genuine Florida heat cracked down on the Giants' training camp today, and the boys, who have been a trifle discouraged at the weight chart which Trainer Willie Schaeffer keeps with exacting care in the clubhouse, experienced no difficulty peeling off the necessary poundage under a broiling sun.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 10. -- The Democratic party of Westchester County went on record today in favor of the plan for reorganization of county and local government recently announced by the Westchester County Commission on Government.

CLEVELAND, March 10. -- Women of the Democratic county organization have threatened to boycott a lecture here tomorrow night by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt unless Burr Gongwer, county chairman, is put on the slate of delegates to the national convention.

One of the most significant dispatches in yesterday's TIMES described the domestic troubles which the German people and Government are feeling acutely. The implication was that HITLER'S stirring appeal to national pride, along with his challenge in this regard of foreign opinion, was partly intended to divert attention from disturbing internal conditions.

Harold Denny, in his March 6 dispatch to THE TIMES, relative to the troubles of "Stakhanoffism" in the Soviet, calls for some comment. This new movement, for Russia, has been practiced in this country for many years, having been brought forcibly to the front by Taylor in his book "Industrial Management" about twenty-five years ago.

With the extension of the building service strike to the Grand Central and Times Square areas yesterday, marking the tenth day of the walkout, Walter Gordon Merritt, counsel to the Realty Advisory Board, made overtures last night looking toward the resumption of peace negotiations.

ALBANY, March 10. -- Reform in county governmental structure under the new constitutional amendment on county reorganization was debated for four hours today at a public hearing on measures to put the amendment into effect.

Miss Dorothea Darlington gave a reception with music yesterday afternoon at the Ambassador as a birthday celebration for both her father, Dr. Thomas Darlington, and her young nephew, Thomas Darlington. The hostess was assisted in receiving by Mrs. Gustavus C. Darlington, Mrs. Charles Darlington and Miss Annabelle Darlington.
WASHINGTON, March 10. -- An indefinite blanket exemption from registration for utility holding companies doing an intrastate business was granted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, explained at the annual convention of the National Association of Independent Ice Cream Manufacturers, held yesterday at the Hotel Park Central, the need of rigid inspection of the vast quantities of milk and other products used in the manufacture of ice cream here.

PARIS, March 10. -- Faced with an absolute refusal by France to negotiate with Germany so long as German troops were in the Rhineland and with a demand by Belgium, as well as France, that the Reich's denunciation of the Locarno treaty should be answered by more than a few chiding words, the British delegation decided this evening to transfer the conversations to London.

TRENTON, March 10. -- The Rev. Wallace John Gardner, vicar of the Chapel of the Intercession, Trinity Parish, New York City, was elected today Bishop Coadjutor of the Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey. If he accepts the position, the Rev. Mr. Gardner will become Bishop of the diocese automatically in the event of the resignation or death of the incumbent, the Right Rev. Paul Matthews of Princeton.
PARIS, March 10. -- Following is the text of Premier Albert Sarraut's declaration in the Chamber of Deputies today on Germany's remilitarization of the Rhineland:

Specific objections against the petition designating Joseph T. O'Neil, Staten Island insurance salesman, as a candidate for delegate to the Democratic National Convention against former Governor Alfred E. Smith were filed yesterday with the Board of Elections.
LONDON, March 10. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange were steadier today, with British Government securities regaining part of yesterday's losses.

Showing a sharp reduction in loans payable because of sales of securities from the portfolio, the Amerex Holding Corporation, formerly the Chase Corporation, reported yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders a net income of $452,319 for 1935, compared with $387,880 for 1934.

Some years ago the Artef Players Collective produced H. Leivick's "Hirsh Lekert," the story of a young shoemaker who attempted to assassinate a Czarist official for suppressing a May Day demonstration and flogging its participants, and paid the penalty when he failed.
WASHINGTON, March 10. -- President Roosevelt discussed the housing situation at his press conference and said he would submit a message on relief before he departs for a fishing cruise March 19.

Mrs. Edith Weed Bishop, 30 years old, wife of Henry A. Bishop Jr., a broker, and daughter of Samuel Weed, banker of Norwalk, Conn., was in the women's prison yesterday. She is accused in two grand larceny indictments of having stolen antiques.

France will not make war upon Germany. Such is the declaration of the head of her Government, who adds that the French will take their complaints against Germany to the Council of the League of Nations. This is in full accord with the plan and purpose of the British Government as announced by Foreign Secretary EDEN and Prime Minister BALDWIN.

Twice last night the New York Americans found themselves trailing the Toronto Maple Leafs in their National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden. But each time Red Dutton's stick-wielders drew themselves up to even terms and then, for good measure, went into the lead themselves.

STRASBOURG, France, March l0 (AP). -- Three Nazi war planes were reported to have flown today over French Rhineland fortifications, which were reinforced over the week-end by 50,000 troops. Military headquarters at Metz was informed that a German observation craft had hovered over Montmedy early today and that two similar planes had flown over Kanfen and Veckring in the afternoon.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- Issues in the case of J. Edward Jones, petitioner, v. the Securities and Exchange Commission, have now been clearly defined. Today's arguments in the Supreme Court forecast the possible or probable test of the constitutionality of the Securities Act of 1933.

A new method of quoting steel prices, establishing quantity discounts and eliminating secret concessions, was introduced yesterday by the Republic Steel Corporation in opening its books for business in steel sheets for the second quarter of the year.

Mrs. James J. Storrow gave a dinner last night in the King Cole Room of the St. Regis for Lady Astley Cubitt, wife of the Governor of Bermuda, who sailed later on the Aquitania. The other guests were Colonel and Mrs. Romer Lee of Galhampton, Somerset, England; Miss Llewellyn S. Parsons and Miss Eveline Robertson.

THE tall tales of tall men were told by a short visitor. The orator was Gene Johnson, coach of the Oilers, a towering team that hails from McPherson, Kan., and uses the four-alarm fire system when going to work on the basketball floor.

TRENTON, March 10. -- A new date for the execution of Bruno Richard Hauptmann has been decided on, Colonel Mark O. Kimberling, principal keeper of the State prison here, announced today. He declined to give the date, but it is believed to be Friday, April 3.

PHILADELPHIA, March 10. -- The Philadelphia Clearing House Association made public today a minute passed at a special meeting on Thursday, praising the work of George W. Norris, who was rejected for the presidency of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia last week by the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System.
In THE TIMES this morning I noticed an article regarding a minister's family who was hungry after living for twelve days according to the $8.20 budget allowed people on relief.

LONDON, March 10. -- The British Government is now doing to Germany what Elihu Root said on Feb. 15, 1916, that the Wilson administration was then doing to Germany, by first sending severe notes to Berlin and then mild ones -- "first shaking the fist and then the finger."

An ex-convict strike-breaker working at 888 Park Avenue used a house pass-key early yesterday morning, according to the police, to enter a fourteenth-floor apartment and loot it of $55,000 jewelry and a $1,500 mink coat.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP). -- The Senate transformed itself with great solemnity today from a legislative body to a court of justice in preparation for the impeachment trial of Federal Judge Halsted L. Ritter of Florida.

Robert P. Lee of Riverhead, L.I., forwards an interesting account of a day's fishing in the Gulf Stream off Miami. Mr. Lee made the trip to Florida with a group of members of the East End Surf Fishing Club, including S.L. Cavanaro, Joseph W. Kratoville, Joseph Leverone, George Tate and Stanley Duvall.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 10. -- Lou Gehrig cast aside all caution today at Huggins Field and scooped up bunts, whipped the ball around in his first throwing exercises and raced all around the infield after each turn at bat, but almost went on the hospital list along with Catcher Arndt Jorgens as the Yankees staged a thorough drill.

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 11. -- Colonel Bill Terry's varsity swung heavily into action today, cracked down on Mark Anthony Koenig's jayvees by a score of 6 to 1 and forthwith put the Giant commander in a most amiable frame of mind.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11. -- Judge Joseph Buffington of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals suggested today that the case involving what, if any, preference should be given war veterans as applicants for Federal work relief jobs ought to go to the Supreme Court as soon as possible.

With the unveiling of a bronze plaque in honor of General Evangeline Booth, the Salvation Army marked the fifty-sixth year of its existence in the United States at noon yesterday in its national and territorial headquarters, 120 West Fourteenth Street.
A New York sportsman who owns a fishing camp on the Neversink River in the Catskills drove up to the stream the other day to get a first-hand view of conditions.

For the fourth successive day prices on the Cotton Exchange displayed a broadening tendency. The market absorbed more than 20,000 bales of March cotton from the producers' pool and closed with a net gain of 1 to 9 points. Houses with foreign connections continued active buyers, particularly in the new crop.

Governors Island and Squadron A last night won the Manhattan circuit indoor polo championships in the final matches of the eliminations, held at Squadron A Armory. Governors Island, by turning back the New York Athletic Club, 12 to 7, captured the junior honors and Squadron A took the Sherman Memorial from the Gypsy Polo Club, 11 to 3 1/2.

Participation of outside labor leaders in the building service strike was condemned yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the New York Board of Trade in the Hotel Pennsylvania. A resolution adopted by the board opposed the closed shop and called for the preservation of law and order in the controversy.

The Indefatigable had gone "in a burst of flame and smoke." The Queen Mary had "towered up to heaven in a pillar of fire." It was the opening phase of the Battle of Jutland, and in forty-one minutes Admiral BEATTY, commanding the British battle cruisers, had lost two of his six ships.
PROVIDENCE, March 11. -- Harvard defeated Brown, 37 to 29, in a basketball game marked by the fine defensive play of both teams tonight.

A ceremony unique in American dog show annals took place yesterday at the headquarters of the American Kennel Club, in which the statuesque Russian wolfhound Champion Vigow of Romanoff was officially named as the best American-bred dog in the United States for the show season of 1935.

DORCHESTER, N.B., March 11 (AP). -- Arthur Bannister, a 20-year-old lumberjack, was convicted today of murder in the weird "baby doll murder-kidnap" case, a conviction carrying a mandatory sentence of death.

The annual report of the North American Company and subsidiaries, issued yesterday, showed a consolidated net income of $13,431,472 after all prior deductions. This was equal, after preferred dividends, to $1.35 a share on 8,575,335 common shares and compared with $10,792,414, or $1.04 a share, earned in 1934.

JUAREZ, Mexico, March 11 (AP). -- Another exodus of a religious group from the State of Chihuahua was foreseen here tonight as agrarians retained control of fertile Juarez Valley, including the wealthy Mormon settlement of Colonia Juarez.

Higher prices in a comparatively quiet market characterized trading in stocks yesterday. Pending clarification of the political moves now being made in Europe, followers of the market were disposed to pay more attention to trade reports, which were, in the main, favorable, and to the progress of the administration's tax plans.

Harold Bauer, pianist, and the Manhattan String Quartet were heard at the Town Hall last night in a joint concert, which was the final event of the sixth Town Hall endowment series. The quartet, consisting of Rachmael Weinstock, Harris Danziger, Julius Shaler and Oliver Edel, all natives of New York, made its debut here in 1931, appeared later with the Beethoven Association, and again in an independent concert last season.

BUENOS AIRES, March 11. -- The provisional government of Paraguay, headed by Colonel Rafael Franco, has decreed a totalitarian State, declaring the revolutionary party and the State inseparable, suspending all political activity for one year and putting all industries under the Minister of the Interior.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- Charges that the Guffey Coal Conservation Act paves the way for the government to control the economic life of the nation and of the sovereign States were heard by the Supreme Court today as arguments attacking the law's constitutionality began.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11. -- Governor Hoffman of New Jersey, visiting the Philadelphia motor boat and sportsmen's show in connection with its observance of New Jersey Day, was suggested today for a place on the Republican Presidential ticket by Mayor Frederick Von Nieda of Camden.

ROME, March 11. -- Although Italy has not yet broken the silence she has obstinately maintained about the attitude she will assume at the League of Nations Council meeting at London, Saturday, toward Chancellor Adolf Hitler's denunciation of the Locarno pact, it can be said she will throw the whole weight of her influence against the application of sanctions against Germany.

Mayor La Guardia showed his sympathy for the building service strikers yesterday when he visited the New York Herald Tribune building to address a conference of women's club delegates on juvenile delinquency and its cure.

The city of Boston yesterday obtained a rate of 0.68 per cent plus a premium of $24 for a new issue of $3,000,000 of short-term notes, and awarded the issue to a group composed of Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.; Hemphill, Noyes Co. and G.M.P. Murphy Co.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- Investigation of the Works Progress Administration in West Virginia has revealed none of the irregularities charged against it by Senator Rush D. Holt, according to a report made public tonight by Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator.

VIENNA, March 11. -- Premier Milan Hodza of Czechoslovakia left last night for Prague after a protocol for a future commercial treaty between Austria and Czechoslavakia had been drawn up and signed by himself and Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg. Political and economic conferences with Austrian Ministers filled his entire day here.

Lack of adequate vocational and recreational opportunities for adolescents, political interference with law enforcement, parental laxity and sentimentalism regarding punishment were cited yesterday before 300 representatives of women's clubs as causes for the current rise in juvenile delinquency and crime.

The complete movie script of Robert Benchley's "How to Sleep," to which the Academy of motion Picture Arts and Sciences awarded its prize for the best comedy short of 1935, is reprinted in "Bedside Manna," edited by Frank Scully, recently published by Simon Schuster.
WASHINGTON, March 11. -- An apparent clash between New Deal art and that of the Hoover administration resulted today in the removal of three sculptured panels from Justice Department walls.

Members of the Ladles' Auxiliary of the Fresh Air Convalescent Home of St. Vincent de Paul have arranged a card party for Saturday afternoon in the ballroom of the Plaza in behalf of that organization. Proceeds will be devoted to the maintenance of the home in Spring Valley, N.Y., which cared for 567 women during the last year as well as provided vacation periods for about 1,500 children from New York.
NOW is the time for the hockey fans to look at the schedule and dabble in a few problems in simple arithmetic, all of them beginning with "If." For example:

The longer and harder the postal officials squabble as to which military and naval heroes should be put on the proposed new issue of postage stamps the better. It will defer the appearance of any new issue.

SAN PEDRO, Calif., March 11 (AP). -- A discovery which may help link the civilization of the ancient Incas of the Andes with a contemporary Indo-Iranian culture, via a transpacific bridge of islands, was announced here tonight.
Six arrests arising from the strike were announced by the police yesterday, bringing the total number to date to 216.
ALBANY, March 11. -- Four bills designed to strengthen the State Mortgage Commission Law were passed today in the Senate by unanimous vote. They were sponsored by Senator Joseph, Democrat, of Bronx.

A telegram has been sent to President Roosevelt protesting that the $11,000,000 program for modernization of the city's docks being carried out by the WPA should come under the jurisdiction of the PWA, the General Contractors Association of New York announced yesterday.
Value of Dollar in Exchange The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotat-Ions for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

The third performance in the series of "Modern Dance Recitals" sponsored by the New School for Social Research, took place last night, with four dancers participating. Eleanor King, formerly of the Humphrey-Weidman concert group, presented six numbers: "Gagliarda and Siciliana" (Respighi), "Mother of Tears" (Reutter), "Summons to Sabbath" (Diamond). "Song of Earth" (Goossens), "Peace -- An Allegory" (Scarlatti), and "Festivals" (Debussy).

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- Tentative plans have been made by President Roosevelt for a radio address from Winter Park, Fla., on March 21, when he visits that city to receive a degree from Rollins College.

The organization meeting of the Women's Auxiliary to the Medical Society of the State of New York, composed of wives of physician members of the various constituent county societies in the State society, was held yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. More than fifty delegates attended.

TOKYO, March 11 (By Wireless). -- Japan does not know the exact nature or extent of an agreement existing between Soviet Russia and Outer Mongolia. That in itself is sufficient to restrain the hands of Tokyo from precipitating actual war between Outer Mongolia and the Japanese-allied Empire of Manchukuo.

BERLIN, March 11. -- The question of whether Germany will be represented at the London discussion among the Locarno treaty powers and whether she will send a representative to the League of Nations Council meeting on Saturday remained unclarified today, and no hint was forthcoming from official quarters to indicate that these matters were even under active consideration.

CHICAGO, March 11 (AP). -- Harrison E. Spangler, director of the western division of the Republican National Committee, asserted today in an open telegram to President Roosevelt that enactment of the proposed $1,600,000,000 Tax Bill would "further retard recovery."

The fourth and final performance of "Die Meistersinger" was presented at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. The excellence of the familiar cast was not lost on the large audience, nor the workmanlike job turned in by Karl Riedel, who conducted.

HONOLULU, March 11. -- Reporting that the way is now open for experimental airplane flights from Hawaii to New Zealand, W.T. Miller of the Aeronautical Bureau of the United States Department of Commerce returned aboard the Coast Guard cutter Itasca yesterday from two months' exploration as far south as Pago Pago.

More cotton spindles were scrapped last year than in any other year in the industry's history with the result that the current total of about 29,000,000 spindles is practically equivalent to the figure for 1910, according to the fifth annual survey of the Association of Cotton-Textile Merchants of New York, released yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 11. -- Peace between factions in the Democratic party in Connecticut is expected to be proclaimed when Postmaster General Farley comes to this State on March 28 for a harmony dinner.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- "Jackass" and "fool" were epithets exchanged on the House floor today. They stirred the leaders to action against "the increasing disorder of the House," and inspired Speaker Byrns to lecture members on parliamentary manners.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP). -- Upholding Republican protests that the projects had not been specifically authorized by Congress, a Senate Appropriations subcommittee today rejected a $29,000,000 proposal for continuing work on the Florida ship canal, the Passamaquoddy tide-harnessing project in Maine and three others.

NEWARK, N.J., March 11. -- The price-fixing provisions of the New Jersey law enacted in June, 1935, to regulate the cleaning and dyeing industry were held to be in violation of the "due process" clause of the Federal Constitution in an opinion handed down today by a Statutory Federal Court of three judges here.

In your editorial "Steel and Recovery" the statement is made that "the recent classification of our own export trade in 1935 showed shipments of iron and steel exports to have reached the highest tonnage of any year since wartime."

ALBANY, March 11. -- A voluntary reduction by savings banks in their interest rates on mortgages from 6 to 4 1/2 per cent will be urged in the report to the Legislature this week of the Joint Legislative Committee on Banks and Investment Trusts, Senator Thomas F. Burchill, the chairman, said today.

The governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange approved yesterday the listing of securities of six companies, including 387,726 shares of no-par common stock of the Byron Jackson Company hitherto traded on the San Francisco and Los Angeles Stock Exchanges.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 11. -- Sixty-four senior golfers from many sections, with ages running from a minimum of 55 to a maximum of 82 years, participated today in the qualifying round of the sixteenth annual North and South championship.

BRUSSELS, March 11. -- Premier Paul van Zeeland, appearing before Parliament today, made a full statement of the Belgian case that carried so much weight in the conference of the Locarno treaty powers at Paris.

Net earnings of the General Foods Corporation and subsidiaries for 1935 amounted to $11,730,768 after all charges, including provision for taxes, according to the preliminary statement, to be made public today. This is equivalent to $2.23 on each of 5,251,440 shares of common stock outstanding at the year's end.

A storm lashed New York yesterday, causing minor property damage and crippling commercial airplane traffic. Fresh east and southeast winds, accompanied by a steady rain, blew all day, sometimes reaching a velocity of 35 miles an hour.

BERLIN, March 11. -- Reports from Protestant clergy in the Rhineland which have become available here throw a peculiar light upon the possible explanation of the charges of cooperating with Communists for which fifty Rhineland Catholic Youth leaders -- priests and laymen -- were imprisoned some weeks ago.

Thirty-one men were taken into custody for questioning and investigation last night in a surprise raid on the American Confidential Bureau, Inc., 605 Fifth Avenue, an agency that has supplied guards and strike-breakers during the building service strike.
BOSTON, March 11 (AP). -- Senator L.J. Dickinson, Republican of Iowa, declared tonight that the New Deal, in itself, has been recovery's greatest enemy.

Three hundred agricultural leaders, representing farmers in twelve Eastern States, put forward without a dissenting vote yesterday their views on Federal farm policy under the new Soil Conservation and Domestic Allotment Act.

Fashion and life itself are the two dominant forces in advertising today, Estelle Hamburger, vice president of Jay-Thorpe, said last night at the advertising session of the training course of the Fashion Group at its headquarters in the RCA Building.

LONDON, March 11. -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden put up a brave fight at today's Cabinet meeting to get his colleagues to agree to full-hearted support of the demand of France and Belgium to the League of Nations Council that economic sanctions be imposed upon a treaty-breaking Germany.

CHICAGO, March 11. -- The wheat market continues to fluctuate erratically within the same narrow range in which it has held for some time, and a good part of today's operations represented shifting of positions by professional operators.

C.R. Parker Jr. of the Princeton Club, who defeated A.W. Paine, top-ranked Harvard Club star on Tuesday, continued his winning march in the metropolitan Class C squash racquets championship yesterday by downing C.J. Baker Jr. of the Cornell Club.

LONDON, March 11. -- An appeal to British Jewry to raise 1,000,000 for the expatriation of Jews from Germany will be formally opened at a meeting here Sunday. The appeal follows the recent mission of Viscount Bearsted, Sir Herbert Samuel and Simon Marks to the United States, where $10,000,000 is to be collected by American Jews for the same purpose.

BUENOS AIRES, March 11. -- The Radical party won an overwhelming victory in the Buenos Aires city elections March 1. The Socialist party has long controlled the municipal government of the federal capital regardless of the political color of the national government.

MIAMI, Fla., March 11. -- Rallying on the closing holes, Gene Sarazen, former United States and British open and P.G.A. champion, and Jimmy Hines of Garden City, L.I., won their semi-final round match in the international four-ball golf tournament at the Miami Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- The President received a report from Sumner Welles, Assistant Secretary of State, that all South American nations except Paraguay have accepted his invitation to a Pan American Peace Conference. The President attended tonight a dinner given in his honor by members of the "Little Cabinet."

TORONTO, March 11. -- Net earnings of Noranda Mines, Ltd., for 1935, amounted to $5,901,613, according to the annual statement published today. This equaled $2.63 a share, compared with $2.19 for 1934.

Aroused by the menace of moronic automobile drivers, Magistrate Charles Solomon of Brooklyn asked Mayor La Guardia yesterday to launch an immediate check-up to clear the streets of incompetent drivers.
The committee on foreign business of the New York Stock Exchange has elected Howland S. Davis to fill a vacancy caused by the resignation of Elton Parks.
HOUSTON, Texas, March 11 (AP). -- Chanceview, J.J. Flanagan's 4-year-old gelding, cantered home an easy length victor in the Arlington Handicap, feature at Epsom Downs today.

BOSTON, March 11 (AP). -- Former Governor Joseph B. Ely, a Democratic foe of the New Deal administration, credits the success of Roosevelt-pledged delegates in New Hampshire to "all the power of the greatest patronage organization this country has ever seen."

LONDON, March 11 (AP). -- A Russian source said tonight that Maxim Litvinoff, Russian Foreign Commissar, was on his way to Paris to assure the French Government of unlimited support in collective opposition to Germany's military occupation of the Rhineland.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 11. -- "Talk of the Town," a one-act farce concerning the Princeton University upper-class club system, will be produced in the Murray Theatre here Wednesday through Saturday nights of next week by the Theatre Intime, undergraduate dramatic society.

Some Granite State boys were sick of Administration policies. Old reliable Dr. FARLEY went up there and summoned the best medical aid. The internes were called forth from the offices to resist the spread of the disease. The WPA and the other agencies of relief and uplift joined in the good work.

CHIPLEY, Ga., March 11 (AP). -- President Roosevelt; in a second test against Governor Eugene Talmadge, piled up an overwhelming lead today in incomplete returns from a Presidential preference primary in rural Harris County.

An American engineer who spent two years in the employ of the Soviet Government objected, in a letter on this page yesterday, to the characterization of the average Russian worker as lazy and inefficient. He found most of the inefficiency in Soviet industry due to bad leadership.

HEIDELBERG, March 11. -- Heidelberg University announced the acceptance of invitations to attend its 550th foundation ceremonies next June by four more American colleges -- College of the City of New York, University of Virginia, University of Kentucky and Davison College.

The will of James Harvey Robinson, historian and philosopher, filed in Surrogates' Court yesterday, directs that his estate be held in trust and the income paid in varying amounts to relatives, educators who collaborated with him, and friends. Dr. Robinson died on Feb. 16, leaving an estate valued formally at "more than $20,000."

Governor Alfred M. Landon of Kansas, regarded as the leading candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, is not expected to make any speeches in the East before the Republican National Convention in Cleveland in June.

A plea to real estate interests to stop what he described as "blocking the road" to State laws for improving "old-law" tenements and Federal legislation establishing a low-cost housing program was made yesterday by Nathan Straus in a radio talk.

A gain of 1 point in steel operations has carried the rate of furnace operations to 57 per cent of capacity, the highest level since early last December, according to the weekly summary by Iron Age, issued yesterday. The gain was due in part to the placing of heavier orders for March delivery, in anticipation of steadier prices in the second quarter of the year, according to the magazine.

Probably the giddy patrons of the Lafayette Theatre in Harlem are better satisfied with murder hocus-pocus than with sociology. Having appealed to their better natures with Frank Wilson's "Walk Together, Chillun," the WPA foundation has moved on to the goose-flesh and shudder of "Conjur' Man Dies," by the late Rudolph Fisher, a Negro author known best for his novel entitled "Walls of Jericho."

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- Adoption of the Duffy bill as originally drafted for the purpose of bringing up to date the Copyright Law of 1909 and clearing the way for American affiliation with the International Copyright Union through adherence to the Berne convention, was urged today before the House Committee on Patents by Dr. Wallace McClure of the State Department.

CHICAGO, March 11 (AP). -- A cooperative research laboratory for the railway industry was proposed today by Ralph Budd, president of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy, as one avenue to solution of what he called the "railroad problem." He spoke at the annual meeting of the American Railway Engineering Association.
ALBANY, March 11. -- Legalized lotteries, in which a share would go to the State or local governments for unemployment relief, were urged and opposed today at a hearing at the Capitol.
One of the sufferers from the devalued dollar is the New York Public Library, according to the annual report of the institution for 1935, presented yesterday afternoon to the board of trustees.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 11. -- The special for the best in show at the thirty-first annual exhibition of the Capital City Kennel Club in the Columbus Auditorium was won tonight by the bloodhound Ch. Brigadier of Reynalton, owned by the Giralda Farms, Madison, N.J., and shown by McClure Halley.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- President Roosevelt broke another precedent by being the honor guest tonight at a dinner given for him by twenty-two members of the "Little Cabinet," including Miss Josephine Roche, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, who was the one woman in an otherwise "stag" party.

Hiram C. Todd, special prosecutor who is investigating charges of bribery in the Drukman murder case, has directed the service of more than 1,000 subpoenas for the banking and brokerage accounts of thirty-nine persons, many of whom are prominent in Brooklyn politics, it became known yesterday.

BELLEAIR, Fla., March 11. -- Miss Kathryn Hemphill of Columbia, S.C., caused the only upset of the day by eliminating one of the favorites, Mrs. Maureen Orcutt Crews of Miami, in the second round of the women's Belleair golf championship today, 2 up.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- From a legal standpoint the outstanding feature of today's argument on the so-called Guffey Coal Bill was that the case has been so linked with the opinion of the court in Schechter Poultry Corporation vs. United States, 295 U.S. 495, that the government must either distinguish the two cases or rely upon economic rather than legal grounds for any chance of a favorable outcome.

Considerable political significance is naturally seen in the statement by Governor MERRIAM of California that he favors the nomination of Governor LANDON. This means, it is thought, that the Kansas Executive will have the California delegation at the Republican convention in Cleveland.

The anti-semitism in some countries of Europe is due to the efforts of the ruling groups to conceal from the masses their failure to cope with critical economic conditions, Alexander A. Troyanovsky, Soviet Ambassador to the United States, said last night.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- All Latin-American countries except Paraguay have formally accepted President Roosevelt's suggestion for the early convening of a special Pan American peace conference, Sumner Welles; Asisstant Secretary of State, notified Mr. Roosevelt today.
DETROIT, March 11. -- President Roosevelt's message to the Detroit Seaway Conference, as read by Senator Pittman, was as follows:

The Hamilton Easter Field Art Foundation has selected for its 1936 Print Club work by three Americans -- Yasuo Kuniyoshi, Emil Ganso and Ernest Fiene. These prints were made especially for the foundation. Kuniyoshi's lithograph is of a girl at a cafe table.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 11 (AP). -- A National Association of Manufacturers official said tonight that the association was withholding judgment on the Roosevelt administration's new tax plan until there was opportunity to study details.

At this season of the year, with Federal income tax payments due in less than a week, much grumbling is heard in Wall Street about the tax on capital gains. It is pointed out that in the depression years many individuals realized heavy losses on investments and were unable to deduct them from profits because the latter were negligible or non-existent.
Columbia's basketball team went on to its eleventh consecutive Eastern Intercollegiate League victory last night when Yale bowed by 49 to 36 at the Morningside Heights gymnasium.

The Shippers Conference of Greater New York voted yesterday to support the contention of the Port Authority that freight moving through the union inland terminal at 111 Eighth Avenue should be included in the favored class in the operation of the store-door pick-up and delivery service which the trunk line railroads plan to inaugurate.

MADRID, March 11. -- Premier Manuel Azana tonight summoned Francisco Largo Caballero, the militant Socialist leader, to his office, and after a lengthy conference it was decided that special Marxist brigades should be organized immediately here and all over the country to put an end to the killings and burning of churches which have occurred in the guise of "celebration" of the Left Front's election victory.

TRENTON, Thursday, March 12. -- The New Jersey Assembly defeated early this morning the omnibus, luxury tax bill, which had been designed to make available $8,000,000 to finance relief expenditures for the rest of this year. The vote was 19 to 37, which was twelve votes short of what was needed for passage.

The dates for the 1936 racing season in New York State, as submitted by the Jockey Club, were ratified without change at a meeting of the State Racing Commission yesterday. The commission also adopted a number of resolutions, including one for the installation of an "electric eye" at all tracks in the metropolitan circuit.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- Exemption of insurance companies, banks, trust companies and possibly certain other fiduciary institutions from the heavy levy on undistributed corporate profits proposed in President Roosevelt's new tax plan was virtually agreed upon today by the Ways and Means subcommittee on taxation.
DETROIT, March 11 (AP). -- Grace Moore said today that she is "walking out" on her motion-picture contract until "Hollywood learns to treat me more like a human being and less like a machine."

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 11. -- Casey Stengel sent his Dodgers through their first intramural contest today and a youthful graduate of Bill Terry's Pensacola baseball school almost stole the show. The game, a seven-inning affair, was won by the Phelps Fusileers, 4 to 3, over the younger and speedier team designated the Berres in honor of Brooklyn's second-string catcher.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 11. -- An inheritance of $12,283, which had been on deposit for eight years in a bank here to the credit of a man who was during that time a charity patient in a Brooklyn hospital unaware of his legacy, was turned over to his destitute widow today.
INNSBRUCK, Austria, March 11. -- Although Innsbruck is hut eight hours' journey from Vienna the visitor to the capital of the province of Tyrol finds the two cities poles apart politically.
Plaintiffs bought in five properties in Manhattan at foreclosure sales yesterday. One sale scheduled for yesterday was adjourned to Friday.

LONDON, March 11. -- Signature of the new Anglo-German naval treaty is almost certain to be postponed until after the diplomats have had a chance to settle the crisis caused by Germany's military reoccupation of the Rhineland.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 11. -- Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Pulitzer gave a dinner at their residence tonight at which guests paired for the invitation golf tournament to be played tomorrow, through Sunday, at the Seminole Golf Club, with Mr. Pulitzer, Charles A. Munn and John Barry Ryan Jr. as hosts.

WARSAW, March 11. -- The Poles are pleased that the League of Nations Council meeting will be held in London instead of Geneva, where the French are more at home. The Poles prefer the British atmosphere because, although they have assured the French that they will faithfully carry out their alliance obligations, they find the British viewpoint closer to their own.

The Cathedral Prep basketball team defeated St. Francis Prep 19 to 15, yesterday on the latter court to tie St. John's Prep for the championship of the Brooklyn Division of the C.H.S.A.A. Cathedral and St. John's each won twelve games and lost two in the tourney.

New York agents of the Interns Revenue Department prepared yesterday to remove from New York to New Jersey Henry C. Steneck, former president of the Steneck Trust Company of Hoboken, N.J., and his brother, George W. Steneck of 350 Central Park West, former vice president of the company.
All clerks in the magistrates' courts, including the thirty-two now serving by appointment, were put under civil service yesterday by a resolution of the Municipal Civil Service Commission.

Pressure against the main body of bonds listed on the Stock Exchange was lifted yesterday, but it was the dullest five-hour session this year. Sales dwindled to $10,898,200, compared with $11,232,600 on Tuesday. Moderate gains prevailed throughout the list of domestic corporate loans, particularly the second-grade issues.
ALBANY, March 11 (AP). -- Rivers were reported rising in the southern tier area of New York State tonight following a day of almost steady rain.

A decided and somewhat sudden shift in the trend of coat demand to high shades has resulted in marked improvement in dressy coat activity for this season and lays the groundwork for strong color promotion in this merchandise for Fall, it was stated last night by Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc.

MANCHESTER, N.H., March 11 (AP). -- Speculation over the political fate of former Senator George H. Moses held New Hampshire's interest tonight in the wake of the nation's first Presidential primary, which voted him second place on the Republican slate of delegates at large.

No one can take issue with your conclusion that "nothing that is said or done can alter the fact that the great reserves built up by American business and industry were a source of strength and confidence in this country when it faced a time of great trouble."

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- Senator Barbour of New Jersey demanded a complete investigation of the activities of the Resettlement Administration in a resolution introduced in the Senate today. It is understood that the Senator was moved to this action by difficulties which have arisen in connection with projects at Hightstown and Bound Brook in his State.

The Board of Education, reversing a decision it made two weeks ago, approved at its meeting last night a request of the Board of Estimate that free bus transportation be provided for physically handicapped pupils of non-public schools at which no tuition is charged.
LONDON, March 11. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange were generally firm today. British Government stocks, however, became irregular and a rally in the morning was followed by profit-taking.

NEWARK, N.J., March 11. -- As the competition passed the half-way mark, Percy Collins of the Illinois A.C., Chicago, joined Edmond Soussa, defending titleholder from Cairo, Egypt, in a tie for first place in the national amateur 18.2 balk-line billiard championship tonight at the Newark Athletic Club.

A General Sessions jury returned yesterday a verdict of first-degree arson against Bernard Thornton, 57 years old, a former actor, for starting a fire with a Christmas tree at 1:30 A.M. on Jan. 14 in the ground floor hallway of the tenement at 153 West Sixteenth Street.
DETROIT, March 11. -- "Early undertaking" of the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence seaway project was predicted by President Roosevelt tonight in a message read to the seaway conference here.

Up until yesterday one Sutherland and one Kiernan were seeking the Democratic leadership of the Sixteenth Assembly District, embracing Coney Island, but now there are two Sutherlands and two Kiernans in the race, and thereby hangs a tale of a plot and a counterplot executed at the eleventh hour.

Giving another of her fine performances, Miss Dorothy Locke, home-club star, successfully defended her women's metropolitan fencing championship by vanquishing Mrs. Joanna de Tuscan of the Salle de Tuscan of Detroit, 5 -- 3, in an interesting fence-off last night on the Salle d'Armes Vince strips.

Faced with suits involving more than $70,000,000 as a result of defaults in payments on guaranteed mortgage certificates, the Bank of the Manhattan Company challenged yesterday the right of trustees of certificated issues to sue it in behalf of individual investors and asked Supreme Court Justice Julius Miller to dismiss an action for $6,000,000 brought by the trustees of Series Q certificates sold by the New York Title and Mortgage Company.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11. -- C. Francis Gummey Jr. and R.M. Ehret of Philadelphia gained the first victory as the national court tennis doubles championship was opened at the Racquet Club today, defeating Daniel A. Newhall and L. Scott Landreth, also of this city, 6 -- 5, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2.

PARIS, March 11. -- Officially, Paris stands pat today on its position that there can be no negotiation with Germany over her repudiation of the Locarno treaty until she has given proof in deeds, not in words, of her respect for international law.

Again a serious situation has arisen, which threatens the continuation of the fight to eradicate that appalling menace, the Dutch elm disease. The Agricultural Department Appropriation Bill now before the Senate carries, as it came from the House, only $261,000 for this purpose.

Price movements of commodity futures were mixed on local exchanges yesterday. Sugar, coffee, hides and silk were strong and several other staples moderately lower. On the cash markets cotton, butter, hides, antimony, corn, rye and refined sugar advanced, while cocoa, eggs, tins, rubber and raw sugar eased.
A building project and an apartment house deal featured the Bronx transactions reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- After the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia today enjoined the Senate Lobby Committee from making a fishing expedition among the private telegrams of a Chicago law firm -- resting its action on at least two sections of the Constitution and clearly made precedents in high court decisions -- Chairman Black of the committee said he still favors a statute which would prevent courts from issuing such injunctions.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- The Senate struck from the Postoffice Appropriation Bill today the sum of $26,500,000 which the House had approved to pay shipping companies under the ocean mail contracts provided for by the Jones-White act of 1920.

The complete original manuscript of Joseph Conrad's story "Under Western Eyes" was bought by Gabriel Wells for $2,400 last night at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc. The sale comprised the library of the late Marsden J. Perry of Providence, R.I., and property of other owners.

Banished from the city by the police on Dec. 11, Harry Strauss, 28 years old, who gave his address as 558 Sackman Street, Brooklyn, was held yesterday in $500 bail for hearing tomorrow by Magistrate Mason in Pennsylvania Avenue court, Brooklyn, on a charge of vagrancy.

New York University scored twenty-nine points to take the team trophy offered in the athletes' development track and field meet at the 102d Engineers Armory last night, which attracted more than 300 competitors. The event, conducted by the Metropolitan A.A.U., in conjunction with the home armory, was by far the most successful of the series for novice and handicap competitors held this year.

In a letter sent to stockholders of the Otis Steel Company, E.J. Kulas, president, has asked for approval of preliminary steps for refunding $12,684,649 of debt, maturing on or before March 1, 1941, at a lower rate of interest than the present average of about 5.65 per cent.

PARIS, March 11. -- Foreign Minister Pierre-Etienne Flandin has gone to London for vital conversations beginning tomorrow, French officials said tonight, "almost" convinced he should wage a "preventive" war against Germany now, rather than "submit to carnage two years from now, when the treaty breakers will be strong."

Robert Jackson, former secretary of the Democratic National Committee and committeeman from New Hampshire, who resigned last Winter after President Roosevelt had criticized the activities of officials of the Democratic organization as attorneys in Washington, is directed in an order of Supreme Court Justice Levy filed yesterday to show cause today before Supreme Court Justice Church why he should not be adjudged in contempt of court and imprisoned.

George M. Cohan's "Dear Old Darling," with himself in the leading role, will close up shop on Saturday night at the Alvin. It opened there only on March 2, after an out-of-town try-out period of nine weeks, and so has the rather dubious honor of being among the briefest items in the Cohan dossier.

BERLIN, March 11. -- The Boerse was firmer today, although activity, as usual, was limited. The business community continues to disregard the official quotations and privately to carry on transactions in securities.

GENEVA, March 11. -- France's demand for evacuation of the Rhineland before parleys with Germany was strongly supported today at a meeting of the permanent League of Nations delegates of the Little Entente and the Balkan Entente.
WASHINGTON, March 11. -- The Supreme Court chamber was packed today. In all, 1,174 persons entered the marble-columned room to hear part of the arguments; it holds only 320 at one time.

MIAMI, Fla., March 11. -- Before running of the Flamingo Polo Club Purse event, an innovation race for gentlemen riders, at Tropical Park this afternoon members of the club were guests of William Vincent Dwyer of New York, managing director of the Gables Racing Association, at a buffet luncheon.
Apartment house and dwelling deals featured the Manhattan realty turnover reported yesterday.

Settlement of the strike of elevator operators appeared to be near this morning as a conference of representatives of the Realty Advisory Board and strike leaders brought about by Mayor La Guardia adjourned at 5 o'clock to meet again at 3 o'clock today.

Settlement of the strike of elevator operators appeared to be near this morning as a conference of representatives of the Realty Advisory Board and strike leaders brought about by Mayor La Guardia adjourned at 5 o'clock to meet again at 3 o'clock today.

Stimulated by milder weather during the last week of the month, chain-store sales in February made a much better showing than was anticipated. The first twenty-five chains to report did an aggregate business of $152,602,741, a gain of 7 per cent over February, 1935, according to the monthly compilation issued yesterday by Childs, Jeffries Thorndike, Inc., and Hammons Co., Inc.

Anthony Bongiorno, 41 years old, of 379 Menahan Street, Brooklyn, accused by Commissioner of Accounts Paul Blanshard as the leader of a ring in Brooklyn selling WPA jobs by means of stolen cards, was arrested yesterday afternoon on charges of conspiracy.

Ultimately the Social Security Act will benefit about 30,000,000 persons in the United States, Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, told 300 women members of the Civitas Club at Grace Episcopal Church on Brooklyn Heights yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, March 11. -- A blistering denunciation of Germany's stroke in the Rhineland was delivered in a speech at Cambridge tonight by Sir Austen Chamberlain, former Foreign Secretary and the last survivor of the three European statesmen who negotiated the Treaty of Locarno.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, told a delegation of representatives from New York unemployed groups today that he would not dismiss Victor Ridder, WPA Administrator in New York City, "because he has done a good job for us."

CHICAGO, March 11. -- Deputy marshals went to the bedside of Arthur W. Cutten, grain trader, in a hotel here, today and served a warrant based on a Federal indictment charging income tax evasion. Mr. Cutten has been seriously ill of heart disease since Christmas.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 11. -- The Yankees started competition at Huggins Field today with gratifying results. In the first scrub game of the season the Regulars downed the Yannigans, demonstrating that the pitchers are ahead of the hitters in the preparatory work. The count was 5 to 1 and should have been a shutout.
