MOSCOW, March 11 (AP). -- An appeal for a united front at conversations of European powers on the Locarno Treaty was launched tonight in the official press.

Denunciation of the German Government for its armed coup in occupying the demilitarized Rhine sector and the hope that "cooperative processes" would find some way of averting war were expressed last night by United States Senator James P. Pope, a member of the Senate Foreign Relations and Senate munitions committees.

HACKENSACK, N.J., March 11. -- Partial victory in his campaign to have Shakespeare's "Merchant of Venice" removed from the high school curriculum was claimed today by Rabbi Irving Silman when Edward T. Marlatt, principal of the school, ordered class-room dramatization of the play stopped.

PARIS, March 11. -- The Army Commission of the Chamber of Deputies viewed the international situation so seriously today that it decided to send a six-man delegation to inspect frontier fortifications.
Men who deserted from the navy shortly after the armistice are among those who are eligible for and are now applying for the bonus, it was learned yesterday.

The famed Oilers of McPherson, Kan., came on with a surging rush in the homestretch to nip the Metropolitan College All-Stars right at the tape last night, defeating the collegians, 45 to 43, in the most brilliantly played and spectacular basketball game that Madison Square Garden ever has seen.

Gregory Mason of New Canaan, Conn., an ethnologist who revealed the discovery of an ancient lost city in the jungles of Colombia, returned yesterday on the steamship Calamares of the United Fruit Company.

MIAMI, Fla., March 11. -- The featured spot on today's Tropical Park program was given over to the Flamingo Polo Club purse, a one-mile claiming event, with amateur riders performing. This unusual event attracted many Miami and Palm Beach social leaders and the crowd was bolstered considerably by the presence of women.
TOKYO, March 11. -- Two important resignations today were those of Baron Kitokuro Ikki as president of the Privy Council and of Juichi Tsushima as Vice Minister of Finance.

Lotteries under the guise of "sweepstakes" and "treasure hunts" are potentially a more sinister and far-reaching racket than any this country has suffered from to date, William Hodson, Commissioner of Public Welfare, declared yesterday at a meeting of the League for Political Education at Town Hall.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- Allocations of the Treasury's borrowing for March 16, resulting in $905,653,550 in "new money," will raise the public debt on that date to approximately $31,400,000,000 and the Treasury's cash balance to $2,673,000,000, according to figures released today by Secretary Morgenthau.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 11. -- Bobby Nevitt, Tiger guard, went on a personal scoring spree tonight, dropping in eight baskets and two foul tries for an 18-point total to lead the Princeton basketball team to a 37-27 victory over Cornell in an Eastern Intercollegiate League contest.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 11. -- Showing the way to six other fleet ocean-racing yachts, the Water Witch, winner of the recent Miami-Nassau sailing race, scudded over a twenty-five-mile course off Miami Beach today to take the Sir Thomas Lipton Challenge Cup on both elapsed and corrected times.

The Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association of San Francisco declared yesterday two quarterly dividends of 75 cents a share each, the first payable on March 31 to stock of record of March 20 and the second on June 30 to stock of record of June 20.

The New York elevator strike and other incidents that conspired to make his visit an unhappy one, hastened the departure yesterday of one of the city's noted guests. General Jorge Martinez, one of the ranking generals of the army of Colombia, got tired of it all after twenty-four feverish hours in the city, and sailed away at noon with Mrs. Martinez. six children and three mfiitary aides.

The report of the American Sugar Refining Company for 1935, issued yesterday, showed a consolidated net income of $3,570,930 after taxes, depreciation, interest and other charges. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 93 cents each on the 450,000 shares of common stock.

A squad of thirty candidates for the Fordham University varsity baseball team reported to Coach Jack Coffey at Fordham Field yesterday for the first outdoor practice of the 1936 season. After two hours of work, rain interrupted the practice.

MADRID, March 11. -- Catholic priests and nuns, threatened with violence as political disturbances continued in Central and Southern Spain, were fleeing for the frontier and other points of safety tonight.

CHICAGO, March 11. -- Formation of a new concern, headed by James Norris, president of the Norris Grain Company, to take over the elevators of the Rosenbaum Grain Corporation, has been proposed to holders of the bonds outstanding against the properties.
ALBANY, March 11. -- Rival groups were in conflict today at a public hearing on a series of bills designed to change the liquor control system.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP). -- Authoritative sources disclosed tonight that the engagement of Lewis Douglas, former Budget Director, and Controller General J.R. McCarl will be proposed to aid a Senate committee's investigation of government agencies.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- The Senate Lobby Committee was rebuked today by Chief Justice Alfred A. Wheat in the District of Columbia Supreme Court when he enjoined the seizure of telegraphic correspondence of the law firm of Winston, Strawn Shaw of Chicago.

If the fact needed emphasis, it was shown unforgettably last night in Carnegie Hall that no musician hates a dead note more than Arturo Toscanini. No one is more aware that music lives only when it is sounded, or more solicitous to make the tone that comes from each instrument the living voice of the composer.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- Harry A. Visel of 21 Jones Street, New York City, a wounded World War veteran, has sent his current compensation check to the Democratic National Committee "to help defeat the enemy of 1936," the committee disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP). -- The Navy Department announced today that the President had approved recommendations of the Line Selection Board for promotion of 221 lieutenants to lieutenant commanders, and 430 junior grade lieutenants to lieutenants.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- A contract was awarded by the War Department today to the Wright Aeronautical Corporation of Paterson, N.J., for 512 airplane engines and spare parts, at a cost of $3,850,000. Four hundred and thirty-two of the engines will be of the most powerful type ever built.
ALBANY, March 11. -- Democratic leaders in the Senate have accepted one of the Governor's budget bills with Republican amendments providing for substantial reductions of its items.
LONDON, March 11. -- King Edward let his people know today that although he is a bachelor at 42 he is still thinking of getting married some day.

CHICAGO, March 11. -- Heavy hogs were in demand here today and prices advanced 10 to 20 cents a hundred weight. Other weights and packing sows ranged from steady to 10 cents higher than on Tuesday. The relative strength in lard the last few days has had some effect on the price of heavy weight hogs.
LONDON, March 11. -- The international political atmosphere on the eve of the Locarno conference in London tomorrow is charged with the gravest fears and doubts.

Feeling ran high during the World War among the science professors. French and German physicists were not easily reconciled. More recently we saw Soviet Russia trying to distinguish between capitalistic and communistic science and fanatically attempting to drag the dialectic materialism of MARX into the laboratory.

The Hamburg-American liner Hamburg, arriving today from Europe, will bring Luis Calderon, Spanish Ambassador to Washington, accompanied by his family. Others on board are Dr. Georg Krause-Wichmann, Mrs. August Janssen, Mr. and Mrs. Oliver M. Hayden, Frank Frisch St., Dr. and Mrs. Friedrich Hiller, Arthur Tuckerman, Mathew G. Hill, Mr. and Mrs. G.L. Vickers, James H. Andrews and Theodore Clay Lindsey.

BERLIN, March 12. -- The German Government warned today that it would withdraw its proposals for the pacification of Europe sooner than renounce its sovereign rights in regarrisoning the Rhineland, declaring the nation preferred "honorable isolation" to inequality.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP). -- Cottonseed crushed in the seven-month period from Aug. 1 to Feb. 29 was reported today by the Census Bureau at 3,282,706 tons, compared with 2,923,812 in the same period a year ago. Cottonseed on hand at mills on Feb. 29 amounted to 371,860 tons, against 580,238 a year ago.

BELLEAIR, Fla., March 12. -- Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare, women's national champion, today played the finest golf of the Belleair championship to defeat Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky., 6 and 5, to reach the final, where she will meet Miss Kathryn Hemphill of Columbia, S.C., who eliminated Mrs. Marion Turpie Lake of Long Island, 4 and 3.

While Mayor La Guardia, upon his return from Washington last night, was taking steps to reconvene today the peace conferences in the building service strike, the Realty Advisory Board suddenly announced that it had broken off all negotiations with the union.

TRENTON, N.J., March 12.-- Governor Harold G. Hoffman has been convinced that Bruno Richard Hauptmann "either has told all he knows or cannot tell," and, as a result, he said today, there would be no further reprieve unless "developments made it necessary."

MIAMI, Fla., March 12. -- Johnny Revolta of Milwaukee, P.G.A. champion, and Henry Picard of Hershey, Pa., metropolitan open titleholder, successfully defended their laurels in the international four-ball golf tournament at the Miami County Club today.

Following an advance of $101,000,000 last week, brokers' loans, as reported by member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City, rose $58,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $1,089,000,000 the largest amount this year, according to the condition statement of the member banks published yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation delayed consideration of bids today on $14,700,000 of 4 per cent equipment trust certificates of the Illinois Central Railroad pending the completion of legal details in regard to collateral at the request of investment bankers interested in them, but it was said that they would be offered again within a short time.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- The House, which yesterday received a lecture from Speaker Byrns on parliamentary good manners, as a result of epithets hurled by its younger members, witnessed the spectacle today of two of the oldest and most dignified stalwarts in the chamber shaking their fists under each other's noses in a roaring debate.

CHICAGO, March 12. -- Competition between shippers and city butchers for the small supply of hogs offered today lifted prices 15 to 25 cents a hundredweight. The top price was 15 cents higher at $10.75 than yesterday, while the day's average was up a like amount to $10.30. Most sales were at $10 to $10.65.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- A sharp exchange between Senator Duffy of Wisconsin and Representative Daly of Pennsylvania in which Mr. Duffy protested that he was being "badgered" and Representative Deen of Georgia threatened to withdraw unless "dignity" was restored, enlivened the morning session of the House Patents Committee, which has under consideration proposed revision of the Copyright Law.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- The War Department Fund Bill, raised to a peacetime record of $603,230,604 was reported today by the Senate Appropriation Committee, minus the $12,000,000 asked for the Florida ship canal, but including about $50,000,000 more for rivers and harbors than the measure as passed by the House provided for in its total of $545,226,318.

A financial group headed by Stone Webster, Inc., will acquire a controlling interest in the $48,000,000 Oklahoma Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries, if a refunding plan proposed by Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc., is approved by holders of securities of the company.

WASHINGTON, March 12.--The Brain Trust--past and present, for it is unlikely to grow in the future-- will undoubtedly come in for much attack during the campaign by opponents of the President's re-election. Most of the assaults will be unfair. Yet there is one solid basis for criticism which was well expressed by a visitor to this country, Dr. B.F. Stephens, a municipal government expert from New Zealand.

Thanks to a goal by Ott Heller in the overtime period last night, the Rangers are still in the running for a play-off berth in the American group of the National Hockey League. The tireless blue-jerseyed defense man blasted a drive past Normie Smith in the Detroit Red Wings' net when all signs pointed to a tie ending, and his shot enabled New York to turn back the Automobile City skaters, 4 to 3.

Helen Klovrza, sales secretary to the eastern manager of the direct mail division of Reuben H. Donnelly Corporation, was awarded the President's Gold Medal of the Advertising Club of New York, at the graduation exercises held last night. The award was made on a thesis submitted at the finish of the advertising and selling course of thirty lectures conducted annually by the club.

Sidney Luckman, a swarthy thick-set young man who had been sought by investigators of the Drukman murder case since Jan. 1, was held in $50,000 bail as a material witness in the case by Supreme Court Justice Erskine C. Rogers in Brooklyn yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 12 (AP). -- James V. Martin of Hempstead, L.I., filed a bill of complaint totaling $15,000,000 today in the United States District Court. He alleges violation of three of his patents by the United Aircraft Corporation and two of its Connecticut subsidiaries.

A test suit to determine the liability of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company for losses in millions of dollars of mortgage-certificate transactions of the closed Bond and Mortgage Company of Brooklyn was filed yesterday in the Supreme Court by Mr. and Mrs. Louis J. Harris of 75 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn.

LONDON, March 12. -- The confusion and divergence of views which have characterized the British Government and Parliament since Chancellor Adolf Hitler's coup in the Rhineland are no greater than in the country generally. The British have been perplexed by the unexpected events for which they had no ready-made policy, although their attitude has been the most vital of all.

Former President Herbert Hoover assailed the taxation of life insurance as illogical and declared the government had a responsibility to conduct itself so as not to injure the values of the savings of policy holders, in an address last night at the golden jubilee dinner of the Life Underwriters Association of New York City at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

After advancing for three consecutive months, retail prices during February remained unchanged as compared with the preceding month, according to the Fairchild Retail Price Index. The composite index stands at 88.3, an increase of 1.9 per cent over the corresponding month a year ago.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 12. -- Mrs. Adah H. Aime of 3,804 Greystone Avenue, Riverdale, New York City, director of the National Youth Administration in the district comprising Westchester, Putnam, and Rockland Counties, announced her resignation this afternoon.

The Continental Bank and Trust Company is trustee, registrar and paying agent of $1,800,000 of 16 Court Street first mortgage refunding income and sinking fund leasehold bonds. It also is registrar for Trenton Valley Distillers Corporation 1,250,000 shares of $1 par common stock and for Crown Drug Company's 32,000 shares of $25 par preferred stock and 507,000 shares of 25 cent par common stock.

It was remarked during the last half of 1935 that BENITO MUSSOLINI had done ADOLF HITLER a great service. The Italian Dictator had displaced the German as the Bad Boy of Europe. Now HITLER returns the favor. MUSSOLINI takes second place in the news, though it is a very important place, and one in which he is evidently doing a lot of hard thinking about the right policy for him to pursue.

LONDON, March 12. -- Britain does not intend to start military consultations with the general staff of any foreign power, Alfred Duff Cooper, Secretary of State for War, assured the House of Commons today.

BERLIN, March 12.--Chancellor Adolf Hitler, in a speech at Karlsruhe, tonight backed up his seven-point peace program and justified his denunciation of the Locarno pact and his troop invasion of the demilitarized Rhineland zone.

The Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year 1935 a net income of $1,935,137 after depreciation, interest, amortization, Federal income taxes and other charges. This is equal to $1.47 a share on 1,344,394 shares of no-par capital stock, excluding 16,206 shares held in the treasury.

ALBANY, March 12. -- A permanent tax on gasoline at the rate of three cents a gallon, and application of the entire proceeds from this levy and the license fees of motor vehicles, estimated at $88,000,000, for highway purposes, are recommended by the legislative Highway Committee, of which Senator George R. Fearon, Republican floor leader, is chairman, in a report which will be filed with the Legislature tomorrow.

The Roman Catholic Church is pictured as the "ultimate bulwark" against State absolutism in the report for 1935 of the Rev. Dr. Edward Roberts Moore as director of the social action division of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York made public yesterday.

Representatives of 250 women's organizations attending the New York Herald Tribune's round-table conference on crime and youth voted yesterday to "do something about it," after hearing more than a dozen speakers declare that juvenile delinquents who provide the recruits for the underworld's army of criminals are the products of adolescent neglect.

It has become increasingly obvious that in the eyes of most of its sponsors the proposed tax on corporation surpluses is not primarily a revenue measure but a new economic "reform." If increased revenue were the first objective, it could be obtained in far simpler and far less dangerous ways.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 12. -- A capacity house greeted the performance tonight of the Monte Carlo Ballet Russe at the Florida Theatre for the benefit of the Good Samaritan Hospital. Mrs. Maurice Fatio and Hugh Dillman, members of the hospital board, arranged the event and were assisted by the theatre management and a committee of fifteen women.

John Henry Lewis will engage in the first defense of his world's light-heavyweight championship when he meets Jock McAvoy of Lancashire, England, in a fifteen-round bout at Madison Square Garden tonight.

The life of a doctor is shorter than that of other professional men, and it is the duty of the doctor's wife to increase his life span, Health Commissioner John L. Rice yesterday told 750 women at the first annual luncheon meeting of the woman's auxiliary of the Kings County Medical Society, held at the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn.

NEWARK, N.J., March 12. -- Edmond Soussa of Cairo, Egypt, and Percy Collins of the Illinois A.C., Chicago, kept pace with each other in the race for the national amateur Class A 18.2 balkline billiard championship tonight, each winning his encounter at the Newark Athletic Club.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- Seeking to simplify further the registration of securities on national securities exchanges, the Securities and Exchange Commission adopted today a new form for companies that are successors to companies having securities already registered.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- The number of broker and dealer firms in the over-the-counter market throughout the United States, registration of which with the Securities and Exchange Commission was effective as of Jan. 31, was 5,426, according to a summary made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

ALBANY, March 12 (AP). -- A mimic President Roosevelt engaged in a duel with "Bull Constitution," in the presence of figures representing Alfred E. Smith and Liberty Leaguers, was a feature of the annual stunt show of the Legislative Correspondents Association tonight.
U.S. Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- Development of new problems in the practical application of President Roosevelt's high levy on undistributed corporate profits and a desire of tax bill framers to await the results of March 15 income tax returns before proceeding much further combined today to indicate a considerable delay before the plan is reduced to legislative form.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 12. -- Eastern teams filled many of the qualifying positions after the 36-hole medal round in the second annual national amateur-professional best-ball championship on the St. Augustine links today.

BALTIMORE, March 12 (AP). -- The long litigation over the Z. Smith Reynolds tobacco fortune was ended today as far as the rights of the heirs are concerned, and two new names were added to the roster of the world's "rich children."

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- Senator Holt charged in the Senate today that Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, had "whitewashed" his charges of maladministration of the WPA in West Virginia in the report made public yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12. -- Starting the defense of their national court tennis doubles championship, Ogden Phipps and William Rand of New York easily advanced to the semi-finals of the twenty-seventh annual national tournament at the Racquet Club today.

Eighteen strike-breakers with a total of 108 arrests on their police records were freed in Yorkville court yesterday, but the American Confidential Bureau, Inc., 605 Fifth Avenue, which hired them as apartment-house "guards," had its license suspended as a result of the arrests.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., March 12. -- The girls of Highland Manor School and Junior College here approve of the school authorities listening in on their personal telephone calls if their parents have requested it or when the school authorities consider it necessary for the students' welfare.

The following film programs, which will be shown over the weekend, have been endorsed by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of faculty members and parents of children in public and private schools:

KOENIGSBERG, March 12. -- General Hermann Goering, the Siegfried of the Third Reich, tonight summoned East Prussians in an election campaign address to die with Chancellor Adolf Hitler if need be in defense of the decision to reoccupy the Rhineland.

A setback in prices in the cotton market in Liverpool and weakness in stocks here resulted in an easier tone on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, but mill demand for near months closed the list 5 points higher to 5 lower than on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- Robert P. Skinner, Ambassador to Turkey, has reported to the State Department that excavations made at the site of ancient Troy reveal that the legend of Helen and the ten years' war has little foundation in fact.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- First returns to the Federal Government for the unemployment tax imposed on employers by the Social Security Act must be filed on or before Jan. 31, 1937. This will represent payrolls of the calendar year 1936, Guy T. Helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, said today.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- The Grand National Treasure Hunt, recently praised by Mayor La Guardia with the hope that legal lotteries could be established in New York State, was cited today to show cause why it should not be forbidden the mails.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- A warning that the issue of Federal power was in the balance and that the government might have to use armed force if the Constitution was not sufficiently strong to meet every situation, was given in the Supreme Court today by John Dickinson, Assistant Attorney General, as he pleaded for the validity of the Guffey Coal Conservation Act.

A large exhibition of contemporary Italian painting opened with an invitation preview last evening in galleries on the sixth floor of International Building, Rockefeller Center. It is held under the joint auspices of the College Art Association and the Italy-America Society.

HERE'S a go. John Henry Lewis, the lively young Negro from Arizona and points west, had no qualm and raised no quibble over risking his light heavyweight championship in the Garden this evening, although it will be Friday the 13th all the way to the witching stroke of midnight.
ALBANY, March 12 (AP). -- Flood waters swept over New York State today, hindering traffic and forcing hundreds to evacuate their homes.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., March 12. -- "S" pins, highest award of the Smith College Athletic Association, were given to three undergraduates today, and three students received certificates which will lead to the award of the pins in their senior year.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- A request that the Congress appropriate $2,340,000,000 to continue the WPA program after July 1 was submitted to President Roosevelt by Mayor La Guardia on behalf of the National Conference of Mayors.

CHICAGO, March 12. -- Opposition of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the allowance of $1,600,000 in fees and expenses to lawyers, committees and others in connection with the reorganization of the Middle West Utilities Company resulted today in a flare-up before Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson when Orville Taylor, counsel for the common stockholders' committee, challenged the right of the government and its "alphabetical department," the RFC, to come here and conduct an "inquisition."

Net profit of the Wheeling Steel Corporation and subsidiaries for 1935 was $3,497,626 after depreciation, depletion, Federal income taxes and other deductions and including $100,000 profit from sale of investments, according to the annual report, issued yesterday.
KARLSRUHE, Germany, March 12. -- A partial text of Adolf Hitler's Rhineland speech tonight, including all portions dealing with foreign policy, follows:

Unrelenting, though by no means spectacular, selling during the entire afternoon sent stock prices sharply lower yesterday. Many of the leading issues were down 1 to 6 points on the day, eclipsing Monday's break and establishing the widest declines in THE NEW YORK TIMES averages of twenty-five industrial stocks and of fifty railway and industrial issues since July 26, 1934.
HOVE, England, March 12 (AP). -- Miss Anne Page and Miss Cecilia Bowes, both of Philadelphia, today advanced to the quarter-final round in the South England squash racquets championship.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- The House Military Affairs Committee refused today to table bills to provide a municipal landing field for airplanes on Governors Island and appointed a subcommittee to draw up one bill combining three proposals by Representative Peyser and New York City officials.
" J.Y.'s" rejoinder to my request for an impartial investigation of the effect of monetary policy upon economic conditions contains a number of misstatements which need rectification:

Increasing pressure was exerted in almost all classes of listed bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The general decline, which was the sharpest of the week, took place on a heavier turnover, with sales amounting to $13,003,000, compared with $10,898,200 on Wednesday.

Theodore Dreiser's "An American Tragedy" comes back to town this evening in a new form -- or, at least, a new dramatization. For Erwin Piscator and Lina Goldschmidt have adapted the novel into a play called "Case of Clyde Griffiths," and the Group Theatre and Milton Shubert are putting it on at the Ethel Barrymore.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP). -- Spokesmen for dealers in securities traded outside the organized Exchanges asked the Senate Banking Committee today to draft specific minimum standards to govern the types of issues permitted in unlisted trading on Exchanges in the future.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- Mayor La Guardia, on behalf of the National Conference of Mayors, today requested President Roosevelt to ask appropriation of at least $2,340,000,000 to continue the WPA program after July 1. He also submitted to the President a detailed report from Mayors of 100 principal cities praising the WPA work program as superior to the dole and asserting the WPA projects undertaken have been useful and needed.

Plans of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation for refunding bank loans and part of its funded debt have progressed rapidly in recent weeks, and discussions are going forward on the basis of $35,000,000 of convertible debentures with a coupon rate of possibly 3 1/2 per cent to be offered to stockholders.

DETROIT, March 12. -- The Great Lakes-St. Lawrence Waterway Conference, which closed a two-day meeting here today, adopted a resolution commending President Roosevelt for his work for the project and tabled a motion demanding immediate ratification of the treaty with Canada.

Replying yesterday to criticism of his department for having issued a driving license to a low-grade moron, Charles A. Harnett, Motor Vehicle Commissioner, said the license in question had been suspended four times last year.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- In the final legal arguments over the Guffey Coal Bill today, John F. Dickinson, Assistant Attorney General, stressed the government's contention that the Guffey bill should be sustained even in the face of the NRA decision.

Foreign central banks increased their deposits with the Federal Reserve Banks here $15,116,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the Federal Reserve statements published yesterday. This increase, which lifted foreign central bank deposits to $64,391,000, indicated, apparently that, in the face of the week's European political uncertainties, the foreign banks of issue took the precaution of replenishing the funds they had here against the contingency of having to support their exchanges.

Gene Venzke definitely will run against Glenn Cunningham and Joe Mangan in the Columbian mile at the Knights of Columbus meet at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night. The University of Pennsylvania senior gave this assurance yesterday in a telephone conversation with Frank Brennan, director of the games.

Broadcasting House, according to The (London) Observer, is satisfied that the voice of King EDWARD VIII is "technically as good for the purpose in hand" as his father's was. He prepares his own speeches, as his father did, and follows the modern style in cutting out all rhetorical ornament.

TRENTON, March 12. -- Another effort will be made by the Legislature tomorrow night to adopt a program whereby $3,000,000 may be made available monthly for emergency relief. Unless provision is made before Sunday, the State will shift to the municipalities the entire burden of caring for the needy.

AIKEN, S.C., March 12. -- Mrs. Grace Eustis's The Mole outran the field in the renewal of the annual Aiken point-to-point race over two and a half miles in the Hitchcock Woods today. Ridden by Howard C. Fair, the 7-year-old chestnut gelding, a 8-to-2 favorite, finished three lengths ahead of Captain Demetri Ivanenko's Vauxtoi, with the owner up.

CHICAGO, March 12. -- Shorts in the wheat market were stampeded into covering commitments today by the European political situation, which caused a break in stocks; by a heavy United Kingdom and European demand for Canadian cash grain and by dry weather and dust storm in the Southwest.

Floods from the heavy rains and thaws swept the Northeastern and Middle Atlantic States yesterday and resulted in accidents in which eight persons were killed, three of them in the metropolitan area and five in New England. Many others were injured as high waters made thousands homeless.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- Wholesale prices in the week ended on March 7 continued downward, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average as 100, was 79.7, compared with 79.9 the preceding week and 79.6 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP). -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized a committee for holders of refunding mortgage bonds of the Chicago, Indianapolis Louisville Railway to intervene in the road's reorganization proceedings.

Few measures have as little justice or excuse as the City Residence Bill introduced by Borough President LYONS, which has been approved by the Board of Estimate and the Board of Aldermen and now awaits action by the Mayor. It provides that no person not a resident of New York City shall be eligible for employment in the Emergency Relief Bureau or in other relief agencies.
An extra dividend of 25 cents a share in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 75 cents has been declared by the Independent Pneumatic Tool Company.

Lieutenant Cameron McRae Winslow Jr., U.S.N., and Mrs. Winslow gave a reception yesterday afternoon in their new home at 405 East Fifty-fourth Street. The party was in the nature of a housewarming and the guest of honor was Miss Ethel Royster of Norfolk, Va., who is visiting in this city.
A taxpayer, factory building and dwellings passed to new control in Brooklyn sales and leases reported yesterday.

The directors of the Twenty-third Street Association will meet next Wednesday In Cavanagh's Restaurant, 260 W. 23d St. The moratorium on provisions of the Multiple Dwelling Law will be among the subJects discussed.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the proposed transfer of the membership of John C. Giles to Egbert Moxham, a partner in Shields Co., for $174,000, and that of Ronald M. Craigmyle to Roy M. Mulford who, if elected, will become a partner in Craigmyle, Marache Co.

The petition nominating Joseph T. O'Neill, Staten Island insurance salesman, for delegate to the Democratic National Convention from the Eleventh Congressional District, in opposition to former Governor Alfred E. Smith, the regular candidate, was thrown out yesterday by the Board of Elections for lack of sufficient valid signatures.

A jury before Supreme Court Justice Shientag, after deliberating five hours, awarded $1,000 yesterday to Mrs. Ruth Greenberg in her suit against Ed Wynn for $100,000 for taking care of the comedian's wife in 1929 and 1930. On the claim of her husband, Samuel Greenberg, Wynn's uncle, for $15,000 allegedly spent on Mrs. Wynn, the jury gave nothing.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 12. -- The blustery winds and heavy rainstorms which have made this training siege the most unseasonable in the memory of the oldest Yankee camp attache are menacing the perfect conditioning of Joe McCarthy's athletes.

Theatrical managers, angered by the terms of the new minimum basic agreement of the Dramatists Guild, threatened yesterday to bind themselves legally not to produce plays of any authors who are members of the Guild. This threat was contained in a resolution unanimously adopted by members of the League of New York Theatres at a meeting called to discuss means of seeking redress from the terms of the new agreement.

Commodity futures were somewhat unsettled yesterday. Sugar and cottonseed oil futures were strong. Cash markets were strong, only coffee and butter declining. Cotton, all grains, tins, silk and cocoa advanced.

The great chords which usher in the Beethoven "Egmont" overture also ushered in the first of the fourth pair of New York concerts of the season by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Dr. Serge Koussevitzky conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall.
Plans for a new building were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase of a site in the Fifty-seventh Street retail shopping zone.

A triple bill consisting of "Cavalleria Rusticana," "Pagliacci" and the ballet, "Errante" brought a huge audience to the Metropolitan Opera House last night. Due to the indisposition of Lucrezia Bori, who had contracted a cold, Hilda Burke appeared as Nedda in the Leoncavallo opera.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- Duty reductions on nine tariff items and assurances against increase on fifteen others are given by Nicaragua in the reciprocal trade agreement with the United States, signed in Managua last night, according to a summary issued by the State Department today.

WILLARD HUNTINGTON WRIGHT puts down twenty rules for detective story writing and declares for "fundamentalism" in that art, in one of the several introductions to his new S.S. Van Dine omnibus, "Philo Vance Murder Cases" (Scribner, $2.50). The omnibus contains "The Dragon Murder Case,"

WARSAW, March 12. -- The story of a veritable pogrom in Prztyk, Central Poland, was told to the Senate today by the Rev. Moses Schorr, Warsaw's chief rabbi, who is also a Senator. Three persons were killed and twenty-one wounded when a frenzied peasant mob attacked the Jews in the township, raided their houses and demolished their shops.

Stewards for the coming meetings at Jamaica, Aqueduct, Empire City and Saratoga and the names of trainers and jockeys to whom licenses have been issued were announced at a session of the Jockey Club held yesterday at the club headquarters, 250 Park Avenue.
LONDON, March 12 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

The withdrawal of more than 71,500 WPA workers from city parks Monday morning was threat-ened last night by Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, un-less Park Commissioner Robert Moses permits the display of the official WPA insignia on WPA projects.

The constitutionality of New York real estate assessments was questioned in an address on methods of combating confiscatory taxation which Thomas E. Huser, attorney and chairman of a committee of the Real Estate Board of New York, made yesterday at a luncheon of the Owners' Division of the board in the Hotel Commodore.
PARIS, March 12 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:

LONDON, March 12. -- The laws of literary libel are becoming so oppressive for authors and publishers in this country that thirty-four outstanding British writers banded together tonight to demand "drastic reform."

A few minutes after he had entered a guilty plea in Special Sessions yesterday to making fraudulent State income tax returns for 1933 and 1934, Dr. Jacques P. Alper, 37 years old, admitted confederate of Nicholas (Nick) Montana in the vice leadership of this city, began making a confession on his past activities to Charles Pilatsky, Assistant District Attorney.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., March 12. -- Confronted by the problem of giving attention to the Rhineland crisis despite original plans to concentrate on the Ethiopian situation, the New England Model League of Nations met tonight in Chapin Hall on the Williams College campus in the opening of its ninth annual session.

Although bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday were below those of the previous week, the total was 7 per cent above the amount in the same period for 1935, according to reports to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. For the twenty-two leading cities in the United States aggregate clearings were $6,015,502,000, compared with $5,624,416,000 for the week ended on March 13, 1935.

LONDON, March 12. -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden returned to the attack in the meeting of the British Cabinet this morning. He took up the line of yesterday's argument that Britain's good name in the world depends on maintaining a policy of backing collective security through the League of Nations as followed at Geneva in the last year.

Although wool goods markets were quiet this week, prices remained unchanged, according to the weekly report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service. The lull was welcomed, the report says, by a number of men's wear mills which are just emerging from four to five weeks of active buying and are about to swing from Spring into Fall production.

A vellum copy of the Kelmscott Press edition of the works of Geoffrey Chaucer, one of the outstanding typographical achievements of the nineteenth century, was sold to the firm of Charles Sessler for $7,100 yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., during the auction of the library of the late Marsden J. Perry of Providence, R.I., and items from other consignors.

MONTREAL, March 12 (AP). -- A bewildering third period attack swept Toronto into the International Division lead in the National Hockey League tonight with a 6-to-3 victory over the Montreal Canadiens. The triumph put the Maple Leafs a point ahead of the Maroons, with whom they had been tied, and virtually wiped out the Canadiens' chances of getting into the play-offs.

MADRID, March 12. -- Yesterday's hero became today's criminal in Spain when General Lopez Ochola was arrested and held for trial at Guadalajara Barracks on charges of "cruelly" suppressing the Socialists during the Asturian miners' rebellion of October, 1934.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 12. -- William H. Borden, a junior from Rumson, N.J., has been chosen president of the Princeton University Triangle Club for next year and twenty-eight undergraduates have been elected to membership, it was announced today by Walter H. Smith of Pelham, N.Y., retiring president of the club.

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 12.-- The Giants' 1936 training activities, which thus far have moved along very satisfactorily, all things considered, will enter upon their second phase tomorrow with the arrival of the Cleveland Indians for the opening of the exhibition schedule.
WASHINGTON, March 12. -- Senator Robinson called tonight upon former President Hoover to "apologize publicly to the Roosevelt administration."

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- William Randolph Hearst, charging infringement of the freedom of the press, asked the District of Columbia Supreme Court today for an injunction to prevent the Western Union Telegraph Company from surrendering to the Senate Lobby Committee one telegram signed by him and subpoenaed by that committee.

KARLSRUHE, Germany, March 12. -- Adolf Hitler, wildly cheered by an election meeting of 40,000 persons, proclaimed tonight that "nothing will move us to renounce" Nazi sovereignty in the Rhineland. But he assured France, Czechoslovakia and Poland that armed German forces would not move against them.

Business is booming for the tackle stores these days. The lines of customers at the showcases grow increasingly larger as the opening of the trout season approaches. Experienced anglers are placing well-worn equipment and beginners are inquiring as to their needs in the way of rods, reels and lines.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date, while total bills discounted were at the lowest.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- The Kingdom of Yugoslavia applied today for permanent registration of $14,875,000 of forty-year 8 per cent external gold bonds due in 1962 and $28,929,000 of 7 per cent secured external gold bonds, Series B, due in 1962, on the New York Stock Exchange, bringing the total of foreign governments which have made such applications to twenty-five.

LONDON, March 12. -- The London Stock Exchange awoke suddenly today to the seriousness of the European crisis and prices in almost every department went tumbling. British Government stocks fell sharply on a moderate amount of selling, while European bonds were uniformly weak.

PRAGUE, March 12 (AP). -- America won its first two matches today in the Swaythling Cup international table tennis competition. In the first match the United States team defeated Yugoslavia, 5 to 1, and in the second it triumphed over England by a 5-2 score.
ST. PAUL, March 12 (AP). -- A snowstorm, especially severe in Northern Minnesota, swept Northwest States today, after parts of the same area were threatened with floods.

STRASBOURG, France, March 12 (AP). -- France's frontier army, "ready for any eventuality," waited on the fringe of Hitler's rearmed Rhineland today while diplomats talked in London. Although carloads of soldiers returning from their leaves continued to arrive at frontier stations, army officials said that the movement was ended "for the moment."

War between Old Deal mural art and New Deal mural art continues to rage in the corridors of the Department of Justice in Washington. The Herbert Hoover school of symbolic decoration has lost three more panels to the Franklin D. Roosevelt school of realists.

A settlement was reached yesterday and objections were withdrawn in the will contest over the $15,000,000 estate of Miss Mary Gardiner Thompson, 91-year-old philanthropist. Rosalie Gardiner Jones, counsel of record for Robert David Lion Gardiner, a grandnephew, who objected to the probate, told Surrogate James A. Delehanty that her client and his sister, Alexandra Diodati Gardiner Creel, had accepted $100,000 each and their great aunt's town house in settlement of their claim.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended March 11, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,474,000,000, a decrease of $4,000,000, compared with the preceding week and an increase of $11,000,000, compared with the corresponding week in 1935.
BOSTON, March 12. -- Torrential rain over New England cost at least five lives today, sent two landslides tumbling down mountainsides and flooded innumerable highways, homes and factories.

Bobbs-Merrill will publish March 18 a novel about modern Japan entitled "To the Mountain." The author is Bradford Smith, Professor of English at St. Paul's University, Tokyo, and lecturer at the Imperial University.

BUENOS AIRES, March 12. -- The Chaco peace conference circles here deny that diplomatic recognition has been extended to the de facto government of Paraguay, as officially announced at Asuncion today.

MIAMI, Fla., March 12. -- Sir Quest, 3-year-old gelded son of Sun Edwin in the New York stable of Mrs. W. Plunket Stewart, was successful in the Vernal Handicap of six furlongs that headlined today's card at Tropical Park.

In accounting for the rise of numerous low-priced stocks in the last month, speculators in Wall Street have unconsciously availed themselves of one of the standard explanations given in 1929 for the high prices of securities prevailing at that time.

LONG BEACH, L.I., March 12. -- One-third of the street lights in this city were not lighted by the Queensborough Gas and Electric Company at 6 o'clock tonight, the usual hour, in a move by the company to bring the city's expenditures for light and power in accord with its appropriation. There are 1,300 street lights in the city and 485 of them were dark.

A plea of guilty of fraudulent practices in the "stuffed flat" racket was entered in Special Sessions yesterday by Mrs. Sarah Radin, 49 years old, who used her apartment at 20 Macaw Place, Washington Heights, as a decoy for the sale of spurious furniture "bargains," pretending she was breaking up her home.

In accounting for the rise of numerous low-priced stocks in the last month, speculators in Wall Street have unconsciously availed themselves of one of the standard explanations given in 1929 for the high prices of securities prevailing at that time.

LONG BEACH, L.I., March 12. -- One-third of the street lights in this city were not lighted by the Queensborough Gas and Electric Company at 6 o'clock tonight, the usual hour, in a move by the company to bring the city's expenditures for light and power in accord with its appropriation. There are 1,300 street lights in the city and 485 of them were dark.

A plea of guilty of fraudulent practices in the "stuffed flat" racket was entered in Special Sessions yesterday by Mrs. Sarah Radin, 49 years old, who used her apartment at 20 Macaw Place, Washington Heights, as a decoy for the sale of spurious furniture "bargains," pretending she was breaking up her home.

Invoking treaty rights granted her people in 1794, Mrs. P.L. Garrow, full-blooded Canadian Indian from the St. Regis reservation, established yesterday the right of Indians to pass back and forth over the Canadian border without payment of duty on household effects or small quantities of Indian-made merchandise.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., March 12. -- A passenger train on the Berkshire division of the New York, New' Haven Hartford Railroad was derailed a mile and a half south of Great Barrington this afternoon at a washout caused by flood waters of the Green River.

Dense fog over New York and vicinity yesterday morning tied up all river and harbor traffic, delayed thousands of ferryboat commuters in getting to their offices and kept hundreds of passengers on ocean liners from getting home on time.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 12. -- The Board of Supervisors accepted this afternoon the refusal of the Westchester Government Commission to approve an immediate modified reform of county government. The action was a victory for the commission in its fight for adoption of a plan for the complete reorganization of county and local government in Westchester.

The article by Arthur Krock entitled "States' Briefs on Guffey Act Set Up Court Landmark," in which he says that representatives of six States have appeared as amici curiae praying for the validation of the Guffey act, presents indeed a very novel and interesting situation.

Martha Graham, one of this country's leading dancers, revealed last night that she had declined an invitation from Germany to represent the United States at the International Dance Festival to be held in Berlin next Summer with the Olympic Games.

BERLIN, March 12. -- A special attempt at composing the ruffled international situation was seen in an offer in the statement by the government today not to increase German troops now in the Rhineland.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- Judge Halsted L. Ritter of Florida appeared today before the Senate, sitting as a court of impeachment to formally answer charges of improper sharing of fees with his former law partner preferred by the House.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 12. -- Accompanied by all the fanfare of a major league opening day at home, but with a crowd numbering only 800, the Dodgers today opened their grapefruit league season by downing the visiting Phillies, 11 to 7.

ALBANY, March 12 (AP). -- Lester W. Herzog, administrator of the up-State Works Progress Administration, announced today the allocation of $521,415.96 for operation of forty-five work relief projects.

The State of California yesterday awarded a new issue of $5,000,000 of veteran welfare bonds to a banking group composed of the Bankamerica Company, the Anglo California National Bank, the American Trust Company and Mitchum, Tully Co., at a price of 102.217.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- The administration's official reply to recent attacks by Herbert Hoover was made tonight in a nation-wide broadcast by Senator Joseph T. Robinson, who asserted that Mr. Hoover and his fellow-Republicans had no economic plan or even theory to offer and that the former President is "apparently trying to secure for himself the Presidential nomination."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 12. -- Springfield defeated Providence, 33 to 24, tonight to gain the right to represent New England at the coming Olympic basketball trials in New York. The contest was played before a large crowd in the Harvard gymnasium.

BUENOS AIRES, March 12.-- Argentina's once famous heavy-weight boxer, Luis Angel Firpo, was acquitted today of complicity in a fraudulent real estate transaction for which he was indicted several years ago. In his prime Firpo, known as the "Wild Bull of the Pampas," knocked Jack Dempsey out of the ring in a match for the heavyweight title of the world.

A wage agreement, signed by representatives of the International Seamen's Union and fourteen Atlantic seaboard lines on Tuesday providing for wages and working conditions based on Pacific Coast standards, was repudiated yesterday by members of the union.

Grover Cleveland High took undisputed possession of the Queens Division leadership, while the Alexander Hamilton team moved into a challenging position for Section I honors in the Brooklyn group by winning their P.S.A.L. basketball contests yesterday.

As a further step in the movement to curb unfair trade practices in distribution, the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., will sponsor a bill, which has been drafted for early introduction in Congress, to amend Section 2 of the Clayton Act, it was stated yesterday by Paul S. Willis, president of the organization.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 12. -- Yale University has accepted the invitation to be represented at the 580th anniversary of the founding of the University of Heidelberg, according to an announcement made today. A delegate will pay the respects of Yale to the great tradition of Heidelberg and to the friendly associations which have existed between the two institutions.

PARIS, March 12. -- To the jumble of European treaties and pacts the French Senate contributed one more today by ratifying in a single session the Franco-Soviet treaty of mutual assistance. It was the passage of this treaty by the Chamber of Deputies that had given the German Government its pretext for its demolition of the Treaty of Locarno, its disregard of the Treaty of Versailles and its occupation of the Rhineland.

A theological essay to be given world-wide circulation among Episcopal communicants appeared here yesterday from the hand of Bishop William T. Manning, propounding the doctrine that the disunion of Protestantism and Catholicism is a "sin" and that "all churches have sinned."

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- Real estate foreclosures in January numbered 12,340, a decline of 29.3 per cent, and in urban communities of 32 per cent, from the number reported in January, 1935, according to a compilation made public today by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

LONDON, March 12. -- The Council of the League of Nations will meet under the same roof where King Edward lives when it assembles in St. James's Palace Saturday morning to consider what to do about Germany's denunciation of the treaty of Locarno.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- After weeks of bickering, experts have agreed upon the essential form of a subsidized low-cost housing and slum clearance project which will cost the government only a small first outlay. President Roosevelt will be asked at a conference tomorrow to choose between alternate methods of financing it.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 12. -- Supreme Court Justice Graham Witschief denied today a motion for a change of venue from Rockland County of a suit by a stockholder of the Metropolitan Jockey Club, operators of the Jamaica (L.L) Racetrack, to compel the club to pay dividends to its stockholders.

Press dispatches reporting the death of James Cameron a few days ago commented on his connection with the War Transactions Section of the Department of Justice during its post-bellum investigations. A circumstance of that service deserves to be recalled at this time when the methods and ethics of Federal investigatorial procedure are in the public mind.
The redesigning of City Hall Park has been shelved temporarily by the Park Department, and its plan for remodeling Madison Square Park has been abandoned, it became known yesterday.
TORONTO, Ont., March 12. -- The Province of Ontario will soon enter the long-term money market, Prime Minister Mitchell Hepburn said today in his budget address to the Legislature.

LONDON, March 12. -- A unanimous declaration that Germany's military reoccupation of the Rhineland was "a clear violation" of the Versailles and Locarno treaties was made this afternoon by the delegates of Great Britain, France, Belgium and Italy in their first London session.

ROME, March 13.--The European situation is only just now beginning to be viewed with alarm in Italy. It has taken a decided turn for the worse in the past twenty-four hours. It is thought here that the possibilities of a peaceful solution are rapidly decreasing.

After listening to District Attorney Samuel J. Foley's description of the three men convicted of kidnapping Battisto Salvo, former policy banker, as "some of the most dangerous and desperate who have ever come into the Bronx," Judge Lester W. Patterson yesterday sentenced the three to fifty years to life in Sing Sing prison.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- An application to the Interstate Commerce Commission today by the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railway to buy from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation $3,619,000 of its Series A and $1,033,000 of its Series B equipment trust certificates, which the RFC had acquired from the Public Works Administration, attracted attention in investment circles as it was the first request of the kind since market conditions have been favorable for flotation of such securities.
WASHINGTON, March 13. -- The House today voted $50,000 to the special committee appointed to investigate the financial methods of the Townsend Plan.

MOSCOW, March 13. -- Ratification of the Fanco-Soviet pact by the French Senate, while expected, was received with satisfaction here. It is accepted as the strongest stone in the structure of collective security which rim Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, following the initiative of the late Louis Barthou of France, has been trying unceasingly to create.

The annual exhibition of oil paintings at the Salmagundi Club opened last evening with a private view and will be open to the public tomorrow and thereafter until April 3. There is no hint in the show, which is large and varied as to subject matter if almost entirely academic in the approach of the artists, of the ravages of that abstractionism which has been so in evidence in the galleries recently.
Two men were indicted yesterday on charges of attempting to influence members of the April (1935) grand jury in Brooklyn which failed to find indictments in the murder of Samuel Drukman.

PARIS, March 13 (AP). -- A German financial official, a usually reliable source said tonight, is in Paris seeking to persuade France to drop her demand for sanctions against Germany because of the remilitarization of the Rhineland.

CHICAGO, March 13. -- Receipts of hogs continued light today but a fairly good shipping demand resulted in a quick clearance of the offerings at prices steady to 10 cents a hundredweight higher. The weights above 230 pounds showed the most strength.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 13. -- The problem of whether to fine a young speeder whose violation of the law was apparently occasioned by his interest in a lecture on safe driving faced Acting Recorder Aaron London here today.

ALBANY, March 13. -- Senator John J. Dunnigan sent an invitation today to Assemblyman Abbot Low Moffat, Republican chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, to attend the public hearing the Senate will hold on Governor Lehman's budget from which the Republicans cut almost $15,000,000.
An American Group, Inc., is holding its only exhibition of the season at the Ehrich-Newhouse Galleries, 578 Madison Avenue. The show opens to the public today and will continue until April 4.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Although once rebuffed by the Senate in an attempt to obtain ratification of a treaty providing for development of the St. Lawrence Waterway, President Roosevelt made it clear today that he intended to continue his efforts to frame an acceptable treaty if he was re-elected to the Presidency.

The Appellate Division ruled unanimously yesterday that License Commissioner Paul Moss has the right to revoke the licenses granted to pin-game establishments here, upholding a recent decision of Supreme Court Justice Samuel Rosenman in refusing an injunction to restrain Mr. Moss.

Recently enacted anti-crime legislation was referred to by County Judge John J. Fitzgerald in Brooklyn yesterday as "nitwit legislation evolved by theorists who lacked sufficient common sense to consult with experts in the matter."

General Motors Corporation, with a total of 20,666,031 lines, was first among general advertisers in newspapers of ninety-five cities last year, superseding Liggett Myers, the 1934 leader, according to Media Records. The latter company was second with a total of 18,368,496 lines, all concentrated on Chesterfield cigarettes.

The Securities and Exchange Commission, through its regional office at 120 Broadway, has adopted the questionnaire method of investigating stock market transactions in preference to sending its agents directly to brokerage houses, it was learned yesterday.
PRAGUE, March 13 (AP). -- The American team suffered its first setback in the international table tennis competition for the Swaythling Cup today, losing to Austria by 5 to 1.

WARSAW, March 13 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency). -- New disorders broke out today in Skrzyn and Turka in Central Poland as Jewish labor proclaimed a nation-wide strike for next Tuesday in protest against anti-Semitic excesses.
In your editorial today you express the view that the realty owners should accept the Mayor's formula for settlement of the strike. The implication is that the employers' attitude is wrong.

James Monroe High School's fast-traveling quintet clinched the Bronx Division, P.S.A.L. championship with a convincing 41-to-22 decision over the De Witt Clinton team at the Monroe gymnasium yesterday. The victory was the ninth in as many games for Monroe in the tournament. Clinton wound up its drive in second place.
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 13. --Startling upsets featured the first-round matches in the second annual national amateur-professional best-ball championship on the St. Augustine links today.

BOSTON, March 13. -- In Massachusetts and elsewhere in New England today word went out from State health authorities to boil water in those communities whose ordinarily safe supplies had been polluted by flood water spilling into reservoirs and filter beds.

Twelve young men, said by the police to be strike-breakers, were arrested by three detectives at about 7:45 o'clock last night as they sat in an automobile and a taxicab in Seventy-third Street between Second and Third Avenues.
Flood conditions continued serious in parts of New Jersey yesterday, with many families homeless, roads and bridges out of commission and cities and towns threatened by rising waters.
OTTAWA, March 13. -- Over protests from Conservative members, the House of Commons today passed tariff changes in the Canadian-American Trade Treaty which put magazines back on the free list.

Although the press in the United States suffers less from censorship, than that of any other nation, it faces the prospect of losing some of this freedom if "certain bills now pending in Congress" are passed, Professor Clyde R. Miller, head of the Bureau of Educational Service in Teachers College, Columbia University, said yesterday.

The annual report of the International Harvester Company for 1935, made public yesterday, shows a net profit of $19,618,238 after expenses, depreciation, depletion, taxes and other charges. The profit is equivalent, after dividend requirements on the preferred stock, to $6.19 a share on 2,245,773 no-par common shares.

BERLIN, 2:36 A.M., March 14. -Recalling Reich Propaganda Minister Goebbels's reference to the German press as his "piano," it is significant that the editors in Berlin so far in their handling of the foreign difficulties have been concentrating on the theme of keeping the League of Nations "pure."

In line with what many of its members are terming their "liberalizing" policy, the New York Yacht Club is to have a ladies' day in the clubhouse at 37 West Forty-fourth Street on March 22, from 4 to 7 P.M. It is the first time that women have been invited within the club since its present quarters were established on a Winter's day in 1901.

Charging that "a definite effort to bottle up the Child Labor Amendment in the Senate Judiciary Committee" at Albany was being made by political groups, Courtenay Dinwiddie, secretary of the National Child Labor Committee, asked the support of civic and welfare groups yesterday for a move for a public hearing.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 13. -Devoid of major upsets and productive of the anticipated close three-cornered struggle among Lehigh, Penn State and Princeton for the principal laurels, the Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association's thirty-second annual championship meet progressed through the semifinals today in the Princeton University Gymnasium.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 13. -Massachusetts players won two of the three first division matches contested in the first round of the sixteenth annual seniors' North and South golf championship today. S.M. Paterson, Boston, and Harold C. Buckminster, Winchester, both triumphed by 2 and 1.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals only $17,693,150, representing seventy-nine municipalities. The revised total for this week is $37,126,000. The weekly average for the year to date is $23,362,568.

Mr. and Mrs. Lewis W. Francis of 81 Remsen Street; Brooklyn, gave a tea at their home yesterday for the entire faculty of Packer Collegiate Institute, for the first time since Mr. Francis assumed the office of president of the board of trustees of Packer.
No change was apparent in any section of the market, and on light demand for funds all quotations remained steady.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 13. -- Cornell today put its football fortunes in the hands of 42-year-old Carl G. Snavely, head coach at the University of North Carolina. He will start Spring practice here April 7 under a three-year contract, having resigned his post at Chapel Hill, N.C., today, James Lynah, director of the Department of Physical Education and Athletics, announced.

BERLIN, Saturday, March 14. -The Deutsche Diplomatische Korrespondenz, mouthpiece of the German Foreign Office, disclosed today that Germany would build fortifications at strategic points in the Rhineland, demilitarized until its reoccupation by German troops last Saturday.

Mr. Moses seems to be thoroughly justified in his objections to plastering red, white and blue stickers marked "USA -- WORK PROGRAM -- WPA" over all of the relief construction work throughout the entire city park system. As there are "literally thousands" of such jobs going on in the city parks, most of them conducted wholly or in part by relief labor, there would have to be thousands of such stickers.

The nation-wide celebration of the 200th anniversary of the birth of Barbara Heck, the pioneer of American Methodism, will be brought to a close with a meeting and reception Wednesday at 3:30 P.M. in John Street Church, 44 John Street, the "Cradle of American Methodism."

Mrs. James Roosevelt was in the luncheon party of Mrs. Alma Clayburgh yesterday in the Tapestry Room of the Ritz Tower before the Philharmonic Symphony concert at Carnegie Hall. The other guests were Mrs. Edward M. House, Mrs. M. Taylor Pyne Jr., Mrs. John Hubbard, Mrs. Hokan Bjornstrom Steffanson, Mrs. Arthur W. Little, Mrs. Alexander Smallens, Mrs. John H. Finley and Mrs. Clifford Caver.

In an effort to break the new deadlock between the Realty Advisory Board, spokesman for large realty interests, and the Building Service Employes Union, which is directing the strike of elevator operators and other building service employes, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday the appointment of a "board of survey" to investigate the situation and facilitate arbitration of the dispute.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses announced yesterday that relief work in the city's parks had stopped pending the outcome of the battle of posters. He declared that Victor F. Ridder, local WPA Administrator, had shut off supplies and materials, forcing a stoppage of work, because Mr. Moses refused to permit the WPA to display its red, white, and blue posters on WPA projects.

PARIS, March 13. -- The fact that Foreign Minister Pierre-Etienne Flandin has decided to return to Paris to consult with the Cabinet brought home to France tonight the severe difficulties being encountered by her policy in London.

PARIS, March 13. -- Little business was done on the Bourse today, and prices sagged slightly, although they recovered toward closing time. Rentes were heavy. With few exceptions, such as Canadian Pacific, shares at the end were lower than yesterday's. Francs weakened to 74.90 1/2 to the pound and 15.07 1/2 to the dollar.

BERLIN, March 13. -- In an election campaign speech at Nuremberg, Julius Streicher, editor of the anti-Semitic newspaper Stuermer, declared the Rhineland occupation could not have been carried out by a parliamentary regime.

Take the premiere of the new show on Wednesday night in the Rainbow Room, the debut of Elsa Maxwell the following evening at the New Montmartre and the arrival of Norma Terris last night at the Versailles and you have just about taken the cream off the top of the past week's nocturnal events -- or the coming week's, either, so far as present indications are concerned.

Labor unrest has spread to the younger artists, who are now refusing to lend their paintings to museums and special exhibitions unless they receive a rental for the period during which the paintings are hung. Most of us would like to see the artists make a better living, but it may be questioned whether this is the wisest way for them to go about it.

A luncheon was held yesterday at the Lombardy by the Safe Drivers Committee, a group of young women of society who have pledged themselves to abide by all rules and regulations of safe driving. During the luncheon new members were enrolled on the committee after signing the organization's safety pledge and a brief speech was given by Arthur O. Dietz, president of the Commercial Investment Trust, Inc.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- The Republic of China today joined those nations that have applied for permanent registration of securities on the New York Stock Exchange by making an application for the listing of the 6,000,000 issue of the old Imperial Chinese Government 5 per cent Hukuang Railway sinking fund gold loan of 1911, due serially from 1922 to 1951.
MIAMI, Fla., March 13. -- Serge Mdivani and his bride were luncheon guests of Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Wrightsman at the Surf Club, Miami Beach, today.
LONDON, March 13. -- The heads of the delegations of the Locarno powers met in absolute secrecy today. The discussion took the following course:

CHICAGO, March 13. -- New York and other Eastern cities won recognition in the annual national traffic contest, sponsored by the National Safety Council, the grand prize in which was awarded today to Evanston, Ill.

John Patrick Kenney, 22-year-old "fire buff," was arrested yesterday on a charge of attempted arson after Chief Fire Marshal Thomas P. Brophy said he had confessed to starting a fire on Feb. 11 at Public School 57 at 176 East 115th Street.
A West Side housing sale to an operator was among the Manhattan realty items reported yesterday.

Conrad Thibault, who has won wide acclaim as a radio singer, gave his first New York recital at the Town Hall last night. The young baritone from Massachusetts won a scholarship in 1927 at the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia and while a student there appeared in leading roles with the Philadelphia Grand Opera Company.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Member banks of the Federal Reserve System balanced assets and liabilities at $44,122,035,000, showed deposits of $38,454,183,000 and loans and investments of $29,984,874,000 on Dec. 31, 1935, the Federal Reserve Board made known today in announcing the result of its most recent "bank call."

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- President Roosevelt has made available $18,411,633 in work relief funds through the WPA to combat Spring floods in forty-four States. The Red Cross rushed trained workers into Eastern flood areas.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- The executive committee of the Association of American Railroads decided today to inform President Roosevelt that the association was willing to continue conferring with the twenty-one standard railway unions for a voluntary agreement on the status of employes affected by mergers or consolidations. The President in a recent letter to leaders of labor and management requested them to try and settle their differences without recourse to Congress.

NEWARK, N.J., March 13. -- A small wooden toothpick brought a dozen policemen, several radio cars, an emergency squad and a crowd of several hundred persons here today to Broad and Market Streets, Newark's busiest intersection.

Price movements continued mixed yesterday on the local commodity futures markets, with sugar, coffee and cocoa slightly firmer, while other staples were hesitant or weak. On the cash markets, wheat, corn, rye, butter, lard and refined sugar advanced, while declines appeared in oats, eggs, antimony, tins, silk, rubber, wool tops and cotton.

Knowing your substantial interest in public matters and realizing that practically every Eastern owner of a motor yacht is a reader of THE NEW YORK TIMES, may I, through your columns, invite attention to a number of proposed bills introduced in the United States House of Representatives by Congressmen Sweeney and Bland of Ohio?

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 13. -Mrs. Harold Baring of London, who has taken the tower apartment at the Everglades Club, was honored by Mrs. William Randolph Hearst with a luncheon today at the Seminole Club. She and Mrs. Julian Allen will return tomorrow to New York and will be in Palm Beach for Easter.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- On orders from President Roosevelt, all of the work relief agencies have been instructed by Daniel W. Bell, Acting Budget Director, to make no further commitments for work relief projects that cannot be completed before July 1, the beginning of the new fiscal year.

Luis Calderon, Spanish envoy to the United States, said on his return from Spain yesterday that the new government was, in his opinion, a stable one and likely to remain in power some time. The envoy arrived on the Hamburg-American liner Hamburg, accompanied by his wife and two young daughters.

ALBANY, March 13 (AP). -- Allocation of $663,560.88 for the operation of thirty new work relief projects and continuation of three others was announced today by Lester W. Herzog, up-State Works Progress Administrator.

Germany's troop occupation of the demilitarized Rhineland zone may imperil the foundation of international relations for generations to come, declared Paul van Zeeland, Premier of Belgium, in a broadcast from London yesterday afternoon over a nation-wide network of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

The supposedly baneful effect of Friday the Thirteenth was keenly felt yesterday at the Marriage License Bureau in the Municipal Building. Fewer licenses were issued than in any day since the bureau was established in 1908. Only thirty-six were issued as against a daily average of eighty-five.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., March 13. -- The Council of the New England Model League of Nations tonight upheld the sanctity of treaties, passing resolutions to censure Germany for violation of the Locarno pact and urging the Assembly to "evolve practical means for the application and spirit of Article 19," which deals with treaty revision.

On the eve of the six-year deadline limiting prosecution the government yesterday obtained the indictment of four men, including Frank Hendrick, who was a candidate for the Republican nomination to the United States Senate in 1922, and Isidor Goldberg, head of the Pilot Radio Tube Corporation, for violations of the Income Tax Laws.

Substantial price recessions again ruled in the listed bond market yesterday, with almost all major groups registering losses. The selling movement gained momentum as the total of sales expanded to $14,473,900, compared with $13,003,000 on Thursday.

HURST PARK, England, March 13 (AP). -- Louis Stoddard of New York, riding his own Blue Banner II, a 5-to-1 shot, won the R.E. Sassoon Memorial Steeplechase today by a head from Lord Abergavenny's Mellburne, quoted at 7 to 2.

WASHINGTON, March 13.--In its first definite action on President Roosevelt's proposed tax on undistributed corporate profits, the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Taxation today approved a tentative schedule of rates, which, according to its members, would encourage "cushion" reserves against future depressions and at the same time raise $620,000,000 in additional annual revenue from corporations and their stockholders.

Clyde Griffiths, hero of "An American Tragedy," murdered Roberta Alden as a result of the law of economics. That is the burden of the skeletonized version of Dreiser's novel which Erwin Piscator and the late Line Goldschmidt wrote and which the Group Theatre has admirably staged as "Case of Clyde Griffiths."
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 13. -- Much to his satisfaction, Manager Joe McCarthy of the Yankees today found that Johnny Broaca is in shape. In the second and last of the training camp's scrub games Broaca hurled four innings of well-nigh perfect ball as a member of the Yannigans.

DENVER, March 13 (AP). -- Federal District Judge J. Foster Symes approved today a conditional reorganization plan for the Colorado Fuel and Iron Company. He required that articles of incorporation of the new company must be voted on by the stockholders if a proposal for a $15,000,000 bond issue is decided on. He cut fixed charges of the concern from $1,600,000 to $225,000 a year.
BUFFALO, N.Y., March 13 (AP). -- WPA authorities acted quickly today to investigate charges that hundreds of pay vouchers in Buffalo had been forged.

A petition to reorganize under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law was filed in Federal Court yesterday by One Park Avenue, Inc., operators of a building at that address, which is between Thirty-second and Thirty-third Streets. Attached to the petition was a plan for reorganization which was reported to have been found acceptable by 71 per cent of bondholders.

Bill Call, versatile swimmer from St. Francis Prep, was the star of the qualifying competition for the annual championship meet of the Association of Private Schools in the Columbia University pool yesterday. Call led the entrants in the 220-yard free-style trials and then went into action again to place second among the six successful aspirants for the fancy dive title.
A new book of verse by Edgar Lee Masters, "Poems of People," is to be brought out by Appleton-Century this Summer.

Offering of the largest industrial bond issue under the Securities Act of 1933, consisting of $60,000,000 of Shell Union Oil Corporation 3 1/2 per cent debentures, lifted the total of new bond financing this week to $119,227,000. This compares with $131,488,000 placed let week, and with only $9,040,000 offered a year ago.

CHICAGO, March 13. -- Organized for the purpose of "debunking" superstitions, the Anti-Superstition Society tonight held its fifth annual Friday the 13th meeting in an atmosphere which would have made believers in signs of bad luck hunt for storm cellars.

The share market reflected again yesterday the nervousness felt over the European situation. Steady pressure, particularly in the afternoon, sent the main body of stocks down from fractions to about 3 points on the day, and a few 4 to more than 6 points lower.
