A bank robber with one of the longest police records in the United States, whose operations extended from the State of Washington to Vermont, was routed out of hiding yesterday by Department of Justice agents in a tear-gas raid on a four-story brick apartment house at 1,492 Bushwick Avenue, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Interpreting the new Motor Carrier Act to imply that common carrier trucks operating entirely within the boundaries of a single State must file their tariffs if they accept business moving in interstate commerce, the Interstate Commerce Commission today issued a notice to that effect to all motor carriers subject to the act's provisions.

The State of Vermont yesterday awarded a new issue of $1,500,000 of bonds to a banking group composed of the National City Bank, Stone, Webster Blodget, Inc.; L.F. Rothschild Co. and Paine, Webber Co. at a price of 101.02 for 1 3/4s.

LONDON, March 13. -- A plan by which Great Britain would give a definite guarantee of military aid to assure security for France and Belgium to compensate those two countries for moderation in handling Adolf Hitler's violation of the agreement demilitarizing the Rhineland was the most tangible thing emerging from today's discussions of the Locarno treaty powers here.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

I happen to belong to the huge army of gullible sport lovers who, in recent months, have been victimized at important boxing matches held in this city. We have spent considerable sums in the purchase of so-called "ringside" seats only to find that the seats labeled as such were a city block, and more, distant from the ring.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 13. -- A production of "Nine Till Six," a three-act modern drama by Aimee and Philip Stuart, was presented as the second hall play by Vassar College freshmen tonight. It will have a second performance tomorrow night.

The mile triumvirate of the year -- Gene Venzke, Glenn Cunningham and Joe Mangan -- will match strides for the second and last time this season tonight when they sprint away from the starting mark together in the Columbian mile that will feature the Knights of Columbus indoor carnival at Madison Square Garden.

MIAMI, Fla., March 13. -- Overnight expectations are that the stake feature of the first Saturday of the Tropical Park meeting will go to a Canadian-owned horse, namely Sablin, the Display gelding which carries the colors of E.F. Seagram.

PHILADELPHIA, March 13. -- As a result of the rise of a powerful Democratic organization in Philadelphia, Allegheny County and elsewhere, together with an increase of from 8 to 10 per cent in Democratic registration, the leaders of the Democratic party are encouraged to believe that President Roosevelt may carry the State in November.

BERLIN, March 13. -- The Boerse for all practical purposes today was completely stagnant and weak at the opening and entirely listless at the closing. The market reflected the business community's custom of withdrawing entirely from the official Boerse whenever a crisis appears and doing all its business in securities privately.

MADISON, Wis., March 13 (AP). -- Intent on extending their occupation of the Capitol at least another night, 100 WPA strikers arranged to while away evening hours with a mock session of the Legislature.

Opposition to the bill proposed by Alderman Charles E. Keegan requiring the registration of aliens in this city was expressed at a public hearing in City Hall yesterday before the Aldermanic committee on local laws.

THE HAGUE, March 13. -- The Amsterdam Stockholders Association scored a distinct success in its gold-clause suit against the Royal Dutch Shell regarding this company's 4 per cent dollar loan of 1930 when the Netherlands High Council, or Supreme Court, passed judgment today upholding the gold clause.

The market, one broker remarked yesterday, is selling "and Europe" rather than "ex Europe" as it did earlier in the week. This observer felt that the market had scarcely more than begun to discount the influence of any war shock, should hostilities occur.

In all this debate about Heidelberg University and its 550th anniversary no one so far has thought of mentioning the Heidelberg Man. Yet it may well be that he enters into the controversy. He lived 50,000 years ago or more, but something of him apparently survives in his native land.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Application to present-day conditions of the social philosophy of the prophets of Israel was urged tonight by Rabbi Nathan Rosen of Brooklyn in a "keynote" address at the biennial convention of the United Synagogue of America and the Women's League of the United Synagogue.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP). -Reports submitted to the House for the first two months of this year revealed today that sizable contributions are pouring into the Republican National Committee, but that contributions are few and far between around Democratic headquarters and the American Liberty League.

NOW for the stretch run, which is what the Columbian Mile will be at Madison Square Garden this evening. Venzke, Mangan and Cunningham should be as close as that at the finish, though not necessarily in that order.
MANCHESTER, Eng., March 13 (AP). -- Dr. Buck Ruxton was sentenced tonight to pay with his life for the murder of his wife and a nursemaid.

PARIS, March 13. -- Passed with a large majority by the Senate yesterday under the force of a general desire to appear strong and united in the face of Germany, the Franco-Soviet pact in reality will not assume full significance until completed by other Franco-Russian accords.

Jule Gordon, as head of a committee of perfume and hair tonic importers and manufacturers, told District Attorney William C. Dodge yesterday that thousands of barber shops in this city were defrauding their customers by using bootleg preparations.

A meteorological disturbance which had the appearance of a meteorite falling somewhere in central New Jersey was reported by Jersey householders and also by pedestrians on lower Manhattan early today.

LONDON, March 13. -- All sections of the London Stock Exchange continued to slide today as a result of international anxieties. Favorable company reports had no effect upon sentiment, which remained overshadowed by the prospect of a protracted crisis and the possibility of economic sanctions against Germany. British Government stocks slumped badly in the morning, although a slight rally in the afternoon offset some of the losses.

PHILADELPHIA, March 13. -John S. Sinclair, 39 years old and a deputy governor of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, was elected president of the bank for a five-year term at a special meeting of directors today. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System in Washington confirmed the election.

Many pastors tomorrow will preach sermons based on the discourses of Jesus delivered at the Lake of Galilee, the scene of so many of His public teachings. Tomorrow will be the third Sunday in Lent. Several of the leading Protestant Episcopal churches in Manhattan will have their annual confirmation services, with a Bishop preaching the sermon.

The light heavyweight championship of the world is still in the United States. John Henry Lewis, Negro holder of the crown, successfully repulsed the titular bid of Jock McAvoy, courageous challenger from Lancashire, England, with little difficulty in a fifteen-round clash at Madison Square Garden last night.

Dock Commissioner John McKenzie said yesterday that the new free trade zone the city would establish at Stapleton, S.I., with the consent of the Federal Government, was virtually certain to prove successful.

LONDON, March 13. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin sprang a complete surprise on the nation tonight by appointing the Attorney General, Sir Thomas Inskip, to the new Cabinet post of Minister for the Coordination of Defense.

ROME, March 13.--Premier Benito Mussolini has definitely thrown down the gauntlet to Great Britain in East Africa by moving troops toward Lake Tana, the principal sphere of British interest in Ethiopia. News from Asmara, Eritrea, in fact, confirms that two Italian forces have invaded Amhara Province, whose capital, Gondar, is only twenty-three miles from the north shore of Lake Tana.

BOSTON, March 13.--Ten dead, upward of 200,000 persons thrown out of work by the enforced closing of water-powered mills and manufacturing plants and property damage which probably will exceed $50,000,000 was the flood toll counted in New England tonight.

A decline of one-half of 1 per cent in the cost of living of wage-earners of the United States in February was reported yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board, which pointed out that it was the first decline in total living costs since last July.

ALBANY, March 13. -- Supreme Court Justice Francis Bergan today denied an application of the City of New York for an order against the Public Service Commission and the Jamaica Water Supply Company on rates for hydrant rental.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Among the passengers sailing for Europe today on the French liner Ile de France are Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney, John Hay Whitney, Marie Therese de Laboulaye, daughter of the French Ambassador to the United States; Lord and Lady Charles Cavendish, Lady Alexandra Metcalfe and Countess Dorothy di Frasso.

Thomas F. Devaney, vice-president, has addressed a letter to stockholders of Ulen Co. announcing approval of a plan for the reclassification of capital by the board of directors which is to be submitted to the stockholders at their annual meeting on April 2.

When Congressmen yield to choler and "hurl" epithets at one another, their wild words may be "expunged" from the Congressional Record, but is the unanimous consent supposed to justify this amnesty to ill temper desirable? The Record is tampered with in many ways and stuffed with all sorts of dreary, irrelevant and unheard matter; but wouldn't it be some restraint on the discourtesies of debate if they were to be printed?
ALBANY, March 13 (AP). -- A mile-long ice jam broke late today at Coeymans, south of here, wrecking dozens of boathouses and piers along the Hudson liver.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 13. -- Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley this afternoon threw out several bids received last week for the Title and Mortgage Company of Westchester County, offered for sale by Louis Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, as a step in the liquidation of the Westchester Title and Trust Company and the Lawyers Westchester Mortgage and Title Company.

The Yale Club has joined fourteen other institutions in various parts of the country in paying a rental fee for exhibiting works of members of the American Society of Painters, Sculptors and Gravers, it was learned yesterday.

ASMARA, Eritrea, March 13. -The steady march of Italian forces on all fronts continued today. Gradually but steadily the northern and central sections of Ethiopia are being caught in huge pincers, reaching down from the western plains in the direction of Gondar and along the eastern part of the plateau toward Lake Ashangi and doubtless later Dessye.

The appointment of a technical committee of experts to study all phases of the martitime labor problem was urged upon Senator Copeland as chairman of the Senate Committee on Commerce yesterday by the National Conference on Safety at Sea.

The WPA appears to be the greatest single contributor to the theatrical news of this morning. In the first place, its Living Newspaper -- which had certain difficulties with the State Department over "Ethiopia" -- will finally get under way with "Triple-A Plowed Under."

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Following a conference with President Roosevelt on the legislative situation, Speaker Byrns asserted emphatically today that no legislation other than the prospective tax bill would be permitted to delay adjournment beyond May 1. He added:

With only ten more trading days in the March position, convering of short obligations held the spot month within narrow limits on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, but an unsettled stock market eased quotations 3 to 11 points.

CHICAGO, March 13.--Buying of wheat futures which was attributed to Wall Street houses with connections in Florida and which coincided with the late wetness in stocks, lifted the May wheat contract on the Board of Trade today 1 1/2 cents a bushel from the early low point and into new ground on the current upturn.
BUENOS AIRES, March 13. -- The objective of the new totalitarian State in Paraguay is "a democracy of workers and peasants," according to Provisional President Rafael Franco.

THANKS to a pretty political paradox, the current issue of Debrett's Peerage includes an inconspicuous entry headed "Passfield, Baron." It is inconspicuous because it is relatively short and unornamented with a device showing foxes' heads erased, a lion passant, two doves proper, , , The Passfield arms, crest and supporters, so runs a meek and ingenuous statement in tiny type, were "not exemplified at time of going to press."

A vast crowd cheered Herr HITLER to the echo on Thursday when he declared that he had now established Germany's jurisdiction over the entire Reich, and had won for her a place of perfect "equality" among the nations. But suppose that this equality turns out to be isolation?

PHILADELPHIA, March 13. -For the second straight year, Ogden Phipps and William Rand of New York will be called upon to defend their national court tennis doubles championship against William L. Van Alen of Philadelphia and his brother, James H., of New York.

Members of the United Parents Association and other educational groups stressed the need for additional schools yesterday when the Board of Estimate considered the city's capital outlay budget of $89,991,150 for 1936.

The rent payers and consumers of New York do not have to live and work here indefinitely. If rents are pushed up because of unjustly higher building wages and costs, there will be more rent delinquencies and less money available for the payment of wages. This means less work and more laborsaving devices. Already taxes and building upkeep leave next to nothing for the owners.

GENEVA, March 13. -- Various reports have been current in the last few days that the example of Germany in reoccupying the demilitarized Rhineland zone might be followed by other countries with similar obligations, notably Turkey in respect to the Dardanelles.

The fast-skating La Salle Military Academy hockey team retained its hold on second place in the Metropolitan Interscholastic League by routing Poly Prep, 6 -- 1, in the feature contest of a double-header last night at the Brooklyn Ice Palace. In the other clash New Utrecht turned back Brooklyn Prep. 3 -- 1.

The ceaseless struggle for existence that goes on among the creatures of the wild, a struggle that is intensified when Winter snows and cold cut off the normal sources of food, is pictured in a bulletin just received from the Wisconsin Conservation Department.
I would like to suggest certain changes in the allotment of dates for racing in this district in the hope that it may reach the eyes of the State Racing Commission.

A new question has arisen to complicate the Olympic situation. On Feb. 28 there appeared in several papers a story from Chicago which announced the designation of various A.A.U. national, Y.M.C.A. national and N.C.A.A. tournaments as Olympic semi-final tryouts.

The New York Stock Exchange has been advised by two foreign corporate issuers that they will not apply for permanent registration of their securities under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. The companies and their issues are Unterelbe Power and Light Company 6 per cent, Series A bonds, due in 1953, and Toho Electric Power Company, Ltd., 7 per cent, Series A bonds, due in 1955.

LONG BEACH, L.I., March 13. -Following a complaint by Mayor Charles Gold against the action of the Queens Borough Gas and Electric Company in cutting off a third of the street lighting service here the City Council met in executive session tonight to discuss further action.

BERLIN, March 13. -- Disquieting reports from the London conferences of the League of Nations and Locarno treaty powers, successive government pronouncements obviously designed to avert international action against Germany and the simultaneous election speeches with their talk of "Germany's shining armor" and their tenor of do or die are beginning to arouse the German people.

A correspondent has forwarded to me your issue of Feb. 2, in which Miss Gabriele Reuter reports the death of Nietzsche's sister and describes her funeral, which was honored by the presence of Adolf Hitler and other distinguished guests.

Prolonged rainfall affected retail trade in the metropolitan area during several days of the week, but despite this leading department stores here had sales gains over the corresponding period last year. The increases ranged up to 10 per cent or more, but the average was said to be somewhat under that of the preceding week.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Indications that a housing program designed to continue and expand governmental encouragement of private building in the low-cost field would be recommended to Congress appeared definite today following another White House conference.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- The Senate Committee on Immigration has written into the Coolidge-Kerr Immigration Bill a provision which would make it mandatory for the Commissioner of Immigration to deport any alien convicted of a crime involving moral turpitude.
ALBANY, March 13 (AP). -- Miss Rose Freistater took off thirty pounds in an effort to get a permanent teaching job, but it was no use.

CLEVELAND, March 13. -- While final plans for reorganizing the Van Sweringen Company, holding corporation for $44,000,000 in real estate, will not be filed until May 5, it has developed that the company will recommend elimination of more than $12,000,000 in common stock.

Mrs. Florence G. Hugo, widow of Francis M. Hugo, former Secretary of State, left an estate appraised yesterday at $141,623 gross and $133,441 net, principally in securities worth $125,463. The residue is put in trust for her son, Francis, the income to be paid to him depending upon his use of alcoholic beverages.

ALBANY, March 13. -- The appointment of Edward J. Pierce, senior bank examiner of the State Banking Department, as Deputy Superintendent of Banks was announced today by the department. The salary is $7,000 a year. Mr. Pierce lives at 1 Plaza Street, Brooklyn.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 13. -- Before a cheering crowd of 5,000 spectators at Recreation Hall tonight, Izzy Richter of Penn State accounted for the defeat of the only defending champion, as the first day's tests in the Eastern intercollegiate boxing championships came to an end.
LONDON, March 13. -- Millions of trade unionists in all the democratic countries of Europe will be represented next Thursday at a conference in London to discuss the international crisis.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 13 (AP). -- President Roosevelt was assured tonight of Ohio's fifty-two votes for renomination at the Philadelphia convention but the New Deal faced a popularity test in the Ohio primary, May 12.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- The Consumers Power Company has filed an amendment to its registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 for the issuance of $55,830,000 of first mortgage bonds due in 1970, fixing the interest rate at 3 1/2 per cent.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 13. -- After batting continually for 667 minutes since the opening of play on Wednesday, the touring Yorkshire cricket team today declared with 556 runs for nine wickets in its match with the Jamaica team. The English county champions' total was the highest innings against Jamaica, surpassing the Marylebone tally of 510 obtained at the cost of six wickets in 1926.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- The Consumers Power Company has filed an amendment to its registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 for the issuance of $55,830,000 of first mortgage bonds due in 1970, fixing the interest rate at 3 1/2 per cent.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

PHILADELPHIA, March 13. -- Flood waters swirling through Eastern Pennsylvania today left four persons dead, more than 500 families homeless and thousands of homes and business structures partly inundated.

I wish to congratulate John Kieran on his excellent article, "The Backward Leap in Athletics," in THE TIMES of March 5 in which he pointed out the inadvisability of replacing metric measurements with the mile and fractions thereof in track competition.

Under questioning by counsel for creditors and stockholders of title companies, Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, admitted yesterday that his proposal to sell three title insurance companies now under his control originated in conversations between one of his employes and the Aetna Casualty and Surety Company's officials who have bid $1,376,282.

John Henry Lewis weighed 172 1/4, four pounds more than Jock McAvoy, for their light-heavyweight championship fight at Madison Square Garden last night. The referee was Arthur Donovan and the judges Marty Munro and Charley Lynch.

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 13. -The Giants and Indians started their seventeen-game exhibition series today, but, despite elaborate preparatory measures, only the Clevelanders somehow managed to get off their goal line.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- William Randolph Hearst filed a complaint in the District of Columbia Supreme Court today in which he charged Senator Black and other members of the Senate Lobby Investigating Committee and all members of the Federal Communications Commission with having entered into a conspiracy to deprive him of his constitutional rights.
TRENTON, March 13. -- By unanimous vote of the quorum present, the State Association of Republican County Chairmen formally endorsed Governor Landon of Kansas tonight for the Presidential nomination.
Apartment house investment purchases featured the Bronx realty turnover reported yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., March 13. -Spurred into action by the earlier achievement of Percy Collins of the Illinois A.C., Chicago, who had run 132 points, Edmond Soussa of Cairo, Egypt, surpassed that feat by amassing a string of 134 tonight to regain the tie with Collins for first place in the national amateur Class A 18.2 balkline billiard championship.

PARIS, March 13. -- The presence in Paris this week of a high official of the Deutsche Bank who was said to be acting as an unofficial observer for the Reich has added credence to the reports that the moves by the Reich are as much economic as political.

Starting with the premise that all American workers are entitled to a decent standard of living, involving a living wage and reasonable hours, let us turn to an analysis of the conditions in the realty industry. Why cannot the industry, for the most part, meet its tax and interest obligations? The answer, of course, goes back to 1929.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 13. -- Last year the Dodgers won the Citrus Circuit pennant and finished fifth in the National League. Recalling that, Manager Stengel didn't know whether to be happy or worried tonight after his Dodgers had scored a second straight victory today, this time defeating the Reds, 3 to 2.

BOSTON, March 13 (AP). -- The Traveler says that Charles M. Hawks, Massachusetts director of the Townsend Plan, announced today that the National Surety Company of New York had ordered all surety bonds of Townsend workers canceled, the order effective thirty-five days from today.

Eight Manhattan properties and one in the Bronx were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. Among the Manhattan offerings were the fifteen-story Van Dorn apartment house at 148-50 West Fifty-eighth Street, a two-story taxpayer at the southeast corner of Third Avenue and Forty-first Street and two six-story multi-family structures on the upper West Side.

New life insurance written in February was 7.6 per cent less than in the corresponding month in 1935, according to a report of the Association of Life Insurance Presidents. The report, which reflects the figures of forty-two companies having 83 per cent of the total life insurance outstanding in all United States legal reserve companies, shows that new paid-for life insurance amounted to $665,140,000 in February, compared with $719,598,000 in February last year.

TOKYO, March 13. -- Japan's queerest religion, called Omotokyo, was dissolved today by the Home Office, its property was confiscated, its temples ordered destroyed and its leader, Wanisaburo Deguchi, was held with seven associates for criminal trial on charges that include lese-majeste.

LONDON, Saturday, March 14. -The Times publishes today an editorial which approves additional British military assurance to France if that is necessary to attain a peaceful settlement of the dispute with Germany.

Joseph F. Higgins, assistant to James J. Hoey, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Second New York District, reminded New Yorkers yesterday that midnight on Monday would be the deadline for the filing of Federal income tax returns.

BELLEAIR, Fla., March 13. -- Miss Kathryn Hemphill, the 24-year-old Carolinas' champion of Columbia, S.C., overrode the "Friday the 13th" superstition today when she played luckily as well as sub-par golf to win the women's Belleair championship by defeating Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare of Philadelphia, ranking woman player of the United States, by 3 and 2.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., March 14. -- Student members of the Bryn Mawr League, which sponsors many social service activities, directed maids and porters at Bryn Mawr College in a performance tonight of Booth Tarkington's "Clarence."

PRINCETON, N.J., March 14. -- More than 2,200 photographs of biblical manuscripts in Greek Orthodox monasteries on Mount Athos, in Macedonia, many of which have never before been photographed and several never before seen by scholars, have been obtained by an expedition sponsored by Princeton University during the past Winter, it was announced today.

WHEN, at some future time, you are hopefully asked whether you have ever come across "The Abandoned Wood," you will know that you have encountered one of the predictably few but predictably enthusiastic admirers of this book.

EVERYWHERE in Europe rearmament is being hurried on. If some countries announce their schemes of rearmament as regretful necessity while others announce them in tones of martial pride, common to all of the rearming nations is an air of confidence that the measures taken are technically sound.

For the past ten years my family has had eight subscriptions (per year) to the Philharmonic concerts. With the appointment of a Nazi conductor, we will, of course, cancel those subscriptions for the future. It is public knowledge that, although Mr. Furtwaengler had trouble with the Nazi regime in 1933 through supporting Hindemith, he has since capitulated and has even been accorded honors by the Nazi government.

MUNICH, Germany, March 14. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler told the world tonight that he had made Germany what she was today and that he assumed sole responsibility for her actions in regard to foreign nations.

READING Will Levington Comfort's "Apache" (E.P. Dutton Co., $1) one wonders whether there ever existed, or will exist, an inter-racial or international conscience, for, in his slightly fictionized biography of the famous Mangus Colorado, who preceded Gerenimo as chief of the Apaches, he shows in all its horror the white man's ruthless and dishonest treatment of the Indians.

PHILADELPHIA, March 13. -- It is quite obvious that the chief result of the entrance this week of Senator William E. Borah and Colonel Henry Breckinridge in the Pennsylvania Presidential preferential primary will be psychological in nature.
FARGO, N.D., March 13. -- Free of hampering entanglements with the Federal courts, William Langer, removed as Governor of North Dakota in 1934 by the State Supreme Court, is on the comeback trail.

Rossini's overture to "L'Italiana in Algeri" and the Brahms Fourth symphony formed the first half of the program offered by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under Arturo Toscanini, at last night's popular concert in Carnegie Hall. The rest of the list was identical with the one performed Thursday evening and Friday afternoon.

TRENTON, March 14. -- C. Lloyd Fisher, chief counsel for Bruno Richard Hauptmann, announced after a visit to his client in the death house at the State prison this afternoon that he would move for a new trial next week. Failing that, he added, his last resort would be to seek another hearing before the Court of Pardons, which recently refused to grant a pardon or commutation of sentence.
AUGUSTA, Ga. -- Three lectures by noted men, a tour of Augusta's gardens, three golf tournaments and a musical program by a Negro chorus will be among the activities here this week.

The American sugar refining industry will be reduced to but a shadow of its former proportions if the Washington government persists in its sugar policy, according to Earl D. Babst, chairman of the board of the American Sugar Refining Company.

WARSAW, March 13. -- An ardent plea for an increase in Poland's armaments was made last Tuesday by the War Minister, General Tadeus Kasprzycki, whose speech in the Senate was an indirect reply to Chancellor Hitler's declarations.

To foster interest in the patriotic work of the Crusaders, the newly organized New York Women's Committee of that organization is sponsoring a special luncheon and fashion revue entitled "Easter Parade," which will be held on March 24 in the Caprice Room of the Weylin.

BUENOS AIRES, March 14. -- The government and the people united this afternoon in extending a triumphant welcome to Argentina's first Cardinal. Santiago Luis, Cardinal Copello, Primate of Argentina, Archbishop of Buenos Aires, received from the government all the official pomp and military honors usually reserved for visiting heads of States.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., March 13. -- Ill luck pursues Herbert Hoover as Governor Merriam plumps for Landon and thereby strengthens the one candidacy that already threatens Mr. Hoover's carefully laid plan for an uninstructed delegation from his home State to the Cleveland convention.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 14. -- Two Rutgers University debating teams will go West at the end of this month for the most extensive tour ever attempted by the university, Professor Richard C. Reager, coach of debate, announced today.

THE exhibits of the Garden Club of America and the Federated Clubs of New Jersey and New York at the Flower Show this week will be of special interest to women gardeners. Horticulture as well as flower arrangements are featured by each of these organizations.
BERLIN, March 14. -- The Boerse was virtually inactive and well under control today. After a weak opening prices showed strength on an insignificant turnover of securities.

Convinced they have come into a period of increased consumer buying which will bring volume business to every branch of the home-furnishing industry for five to seven years to come, producers of rugs, furniture, electrical appliances and small housewares will concentrate this year in building up consumer acceptance of medium and better price merchandise, spokesmen for the various industries said yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, March 14. -- The sale of the interests of Carl Laemmle in Universal Pictures is regarded by the industry as another step toward the merging of British and American film operations looking toward the world market. With this deal, C.M. Woolf of British and Dominion Films becomes a nominal factor in local production.

AIKEN, S.C. -- The week ahead in Aiken will be featured by the forty-first annual Southern Cross Tournament at the Palmetto Golf Club. The qualifying round will be played Monday, the leaders to be paired for match play beginning Tuesday.

EACH year America's many rose fanciers look forward with curiosity to new rose introductions from all parts of the world. And a still larger host of plain general gardeners wait eagerly to learn how these debutante roses perform and which of them, under average garden conditions, will prove most satisfactory.

The juvenile set in the vicinity of Mott Street, a Chinatown artery on the lower East Side, where tenements teem with children, has gone literary. No longer do the poorly shod boys in the neighborhood have to confine their reading to textbooks, theatre posters and barber shop periodicals; no longer do they have to tag after sight-seeing barkers to get descriptive background on the Oriental sector.

OF all the calumnies wherewith the face of bolshevism was blackened in the first five years after the revolution none caused the Bolsheviki more distress and fury than the legend of the nationalization of women. Because if there was one thing upon which they prided themselves it was that their revolution had liberated Russian womanhood -- or at least made possible its liberation from intolerable servitude and drudgery.

Alexander Harsanyi, youthful violinist, who has held a fellowship at the Juilliard School of Music and is a graduate of Columbia University, made his first appearance in a recital last night at the Town Hall before a large and approving audience.

MOSCOW, March 13. -- No feature of Adolf Hitler's recent denunciation of the Locarno Treaty together with his sending of troops into the Rhineland has drawn less attention here than his diatribe against bolshevism and his declaration that Nazi Germany is a bulwark against the Communist menace.
QUEBEC. -- St. Patrick's Day celebrations and mid-Lent festivals will help make the coming week pass quickly for Winter sports enthusiasts in Quebec.

PARIS, March 12. -- Some Summer styles are literally "ringing a bell." Molyneux has created an evening frock for Marie Bell to wear in a new play at the Comedie Francaise. In its gayety it suggests a jester's costume.

The concert by John Charles Thomas this afternoon at the Town Hall will be for the benefit of the Hartley House Music School, which provides instruction in all branches of musical art to children of poor parents.

ALBANY, March 13. -- The end of the week finds that wholly mythical personage to whom Alfred E. Smith, while Governor, on more than one occasion whimsically referred as "Old Man Politics" firmly enthroned on Capitol Hill.

HANS LANGE will conduct the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra this week, at which time he will include on his program Carl Ruggles's "Men and Mountains," which will be given its first performance Thursday evening.

The La Salle Military Academy hockey team won the championship of the Metropolitan Interscholastic League by defeating the Jamaica High School sextet at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night, 2 -- 0. In another league fixture the Brooklyn Tech skaters defeated Manual Training High School, also by a 2-0 score.

Mrs. Henry Hope Reed will represent the Hospital Occupation Committee of the New York City Visiting Committee at Booth 303 at the International Flower Show, which will open tomorrow at the Grand Central Palace. The booth, which is jointly shared with members of the Junior League of New York, is maintained for the benefit of occupational therapy patients.

NEW careers have often sprung from interests that began as hobbies. Many champion sportsmen believed their vocations lay in other fields of endeavor; they skated and sprinted and played golf for pastime.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., March 14. -- Student athletes and faculty Thespians did their bit for the swimming-pool fund at Mount Holyoke College today through the presentation of two entertainments which brought many alumnae back for the week-end.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP). -- Cotton consumed during February was reported by the Census Bureau today to have totaled 516,649 bales of lint and 53,565 of linters, compared with 591,309 and 55,974 in January this year, and 480,339 and 62,513 in February last year.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., March 14 (AP). -- The alleys of the American Bowling Congress were taken over tonight by the first group of 1,479 out-of-State teams entered in this year's classic. The out-of-State representation is the largest in history, the previous high being 1,165 at Cleveland in 1930.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 13. -- Alabama is engaged this week in the more or less pleasant business of counting its alcoholic liquors before they are served.

The fiftieth, anniversary of the establishment of the alternating current system in America will be celebrated Friday with simultaneous meetings by the American Institute of Electrical Engineers in forty-eight principal cities in the United States, it was announced yesterday by A.W. Berresford, chairman of the committee on celebration.

WELLESLEY, Mass., March 14. -- The Agora Society at Wellesley College tonight converted the living room of its home into an ancient Japanese stage and gave an audience in tabloid form the experiences of a day in the theatre in feudal Japan.

LOOKING back from the vantage point of the latest recommendations for feeding babies, published by international experts of the League of Nations, one can see a long path traveled since the turn of the century. The old way was dependent to a large extent on family tradition and "common sense"; the new way is guided by the constantly expanding research of the medical profession in alliance with the dietitian and the chemist.

WASHINGTON, March 14.--Coordination of WPA publicity and information services, now completed, brings into being a news and information disseminating organization of 250 to 300 persons, which exceeds in size any single New Deal organization of its type except, perhaps, that of the defunct NRA.
IT is not difficult to discriminate between the value of beauty, which is not a luxury but a necessity, and the value of ugliness, which is the cause of much of our mental indigestion today.

LONDON, March 14 (AP). -- The following are the Board of Trade figures for the month of February: Total imports, 62,310,000; exports of British products, 35,110,000; re-exports, 5,650,000; total exports, 40,76,000; excess of imports, 21,550,000.

HERE is a first novel that is bright with contemporaneity. Most of the people in it are clamoring and stammering to know the why of life. Most of them are ill-adjusted to it. Some of them are reaching up desperately, trying to feel the experience of living and some are trying to numb themselves against the dark world.

SPRING becomes official next Saturday, but as every nature loving rambler in and around New York knows, Spring -- even in this northerly latitude -- does not wait upon the almanac. She made her debut this year in bleak mid-February, when the first stilled flock of red-wing blackbirds swirled into a frozen cat-tail marsh beside a metropolitan parkway.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 14. -- Torrential rain today washed out the scheduled first Spring exhibition game of the Yankees with the Boston Bees and marooned Manager Joe McCarthy's athletes in the lobby of the Hotel Suwannee.

MOVING northward with the Spring is becoming more and more the custom of American tourists to the Southern Winter resorts. Two or three decades ago the family that broke its blizzard hardships with two weeks or a month in Florida, in Southern California or on the Gulf Coast usually hastened straight home after the holiday was over.

EVERLASTING flowers are grown more frequently in order to have bright-colored flowers for Winter than for their contribution to Summer borders, yet they give a fine stand of color in the period of their growth. The simple culture they demand is little to pay for the pleasure they give in both Summer and Winter, and their diversity of color and form makes parting with garden flowers less difficult when frost comes.

WORKS by seven composers, four of them American, two French and one Czech, will be presented by the League of Composers at its concert Monday, March 23, at the French Institute. These composers include Marion Bauer, Otto Luening, Isadore Freed, Evelyn Berckman, Albert Roussel, Jean Francaix and Bohuslav Martinu.

Thirty-two well-known architects have contributed photographs, floor plans and outline specifications of houses they have designed to an exhibition of residential architecture which James McCutcheon Co. will present at their store, Fifth Avenue and Forty-ninth Street, for two weeks beginning tomorrow.
STATION 2UW, Sydney, Australia, boasts that it is on the air twenty-four hours a day, every day of the year. The wave is 267 meters, 1,125 kilocycles.

Roosevelt; the other is Edward VIII, according to Dr. A. Lloyd James, Professor of Phonetics at the University of London and member of the British Broadcasting Corporation's Advisory Council on Spoken English.

THAT strain of poetry and mysticism which is part of the German heritage runs as an undercurrent through this unusual novel. "The Baroness," it appears, had a sale in Germany of nearly 100,000 copies. This strikes one as curious, for Ernst Wiechert's strange, lyrical story hardly seems adapted to the present mood of the fatherland.

WASHINGTON, March 14.--A charge by Senator Borah that "the Standard Oil Company" has sought to influence selection of Oklahoma delegates to the Republican National Convention emphasized tonight the depth of the conflict over the Republican Presidential nomination.

The Fordham University Glee Club will present its annual concert at the Town Hall Wednesday evening under the baton of Dr. Frederio Joslyn, director of music at the College, it was announced by the Rev. Theodore T. Farley, S.J., faculty moderator.

One of the largest refunding operations in the bond-readjustment program of the Fletcher Joint Stock Land Bank of Indianapolis was announced yesterday by William B. Schiltges, president of the institution.

LONDON, March 14. -- Germany's claim that the Locarno treaty was destroyed by the Franco-Soviet pact should be submitted to the Hague Court and the decision abided by, Winston Churchill declared tonight in Birmingham.

THIS is one of the finest pieces of ornithological work it has ever been my good fortune to read. My chief, if not my only criticism, is with the inadequacy of the title, or perhaps should say with the English language which has provided us with no comprehensive synonym for ecology or monograph.

Declaring he was amazed at the public apathy in the face of changes in the State Liquor Law proposed by "selfish minorities within the liquor industry," Colonel Ralph C. Tobin, president of the Retail Wine and Liquor Guild, yesterday warned the public that it must come to the defense of the present laws if it hopes to prevent "serious encroachments upon the sound and moral purposes of the laws of this State."

WEIMAR, Germany, March 14. -- Dr. Sasse, the Protestant Bishop of Thuringia, has ordered the pastors in his diocese to read from the pulpit at the close of every Sunday and weekday service until the Reichstag election day, March 29, an Episcopal declaration urging the congregations to vote for Chancellor Adolf Hitler's candidates as a religious duty.

EUGENE JOLAS, editor of Transition, the advance-guard magazine which has been appearing rather irregularly during the past few years, announces that, beginning with the issue of April 15, the magazine will resume its regular appearance as a quarterly with offices in the RCA Building, Rockefeller Center, New York City.
WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Business activity improved in the early part of March, the Department of Commerce reported today in its weekly survey.

PITTSBURGH, March 14. -- Fifteen nationality groups have raised a total of $128,800 toward nationality seminar rooms for the first floor of the University of Pittsburgh's forty-two-story Cathedral of Learning.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14. -- The inventive genius of engineering students at the University of Pennsylvania has been put to the test in recent weeks as they prepared exhibits for the institution's annual Engineering and Fine Arts Day celebration.

ROCHESTER, March 14. -- Donald R. Richberg, former NRA Administrator, called President Roosevelt "the protector and defender of the Constitution of the United States" in an address before the City Club of Rochester today. He assailed critics of the administration who accused Mr. Roosevelt of being a "pink," radical or Socialist.

Shipping operators fear that the bill sponsored by Senator Copeland to regulate government subsidy of the merchant marine will discourage investment of private capital in American lines and retard the construction of new tonnage, according to the American Steamship Owners Association.

THE Ann Arbor May Festival at the University of Michigan, May 13-16, promises to be the most brilliant of these events, which have been held for more than thirty years at this seat of learning. In addition to the Philadelphia Orchestra, under Leopold Stokowski, the artists engaged to appear include opera stars, oratorio singers and important instrumentalists.
Benedict Fitzpatrick's letter on radio English is amazing.

LONDON, March 14.--The various schemes that are being considered in London by both the Locarno conference and the League of Nations Council to offset Adolf Hitler's re-establishment of German sovereignty in the Rhineland have one thing in common.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- As the country warms up for a Presidential campaign both major parties prepare to woo the new young voters. Since 1932, between 7,000,000 and 8,000,000 men and women -- a number excluding Roosevelt's plurality over Hoover -- have attained the voting age of 21.

The other day the executive committee of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York defended the appointment of Wilhelm Furtwaengler as general musical director of the society on the ground of Mr. Furtwaengler's merits as a musician.

LONDON, March 14.--A proposal is under consideration here tonight to call a meeting here of the Committee of Thirteen of the League of Nations Council, which now has in charge all matters concerning peace in Ethiopia.

Three men walking west on Thirty-fourth Street near Ninth Avenue were shot and one fatally wounded about 12:30 o'clock this morning in a rain of bullets fired from a passing automobile as numerous pedestrians ran for doorways.

CLEVELAND, March 14. -- The "Cleveland Classic," the two-day all-breed show of the Western Reserve Kennel Club, opened this morning at the Cleveland Public Auditorium. Celebrating its twentieth anniversary, the fixture attracted the largest entry in Cleveland history, the total being 1,371.

On Jan. 18, 1874, in the Hall of Mirrors at Versailles, a victorious German Army, which had defeated France, proclaimed King William I of Prussia German Kaiser. Bismarck's unification of the Reich was crowned in that ceremony in the French holy of holies; France swallowed the bitter pill, but never forgot.

LONDON, March 14. -- An embattled France offered tonight to soften her stand on the question of Germany's remilitarization of the Rhineland as fourteen nations sat in judgment on the violator of two treaties intended to insure Europe against war.

CLINTON, N.Y., March 14. -- Seventy students of New York State chapters of the American Student Union gathered at Hamilton College today to discuss problems confronting extension of the union's principles on campuses of the State.

MIAMI, Fla., March 14. -- Running fully to expectations before a capacity crowd of 12,000 persons, Sablin today carried the Canadian colors of E.F. Seagram to a neck victory in the Orange Blossom Handicap at Tropical Park. The performance marked the fifth victory in six Florida starts for this gelded son of Display, which was given up a season ago as a racer of only mediocre ability.

The undistributed earnings of large corporations, on which President Roosevelt has proposed to place heavy taxes, proved in the depression years to be not merely the reserves of the corporations themselves but, to an important extent, the "rainy day" reserves of thousands of investors throughout the country.

With Jim Reilly, powerfully built son of the Scarlet's coach, leading the way, the Rutgers natators captured the sixteenth annual Eastern Collegiate Swimming Association championship in the De Witt Clinton High School pool last night.

Arrangements have been completed, subject to approval by the State and national banking authorities, for the Marine Midland Trust Company to take over the business of the National Bank of Yorkville, 207 East Eighty-sixth Street. Marine Midland will assume the liabilities of the Yorkville institution and sufficient assets to cover these liabilities.

PARKING meters in the streets of Oklahoma City and Dallas are proving popular with the public and successful as municipal investments, it is reported in the March issue of Public Safety, National Safety Council publication. When the meters were first installed in Oklahoma City last July they aroused some opposition and a temporary injunction was obtained restraining the city from using them.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 14. -- Plans for the first house to be designed by and constructed under the supervision of students of the School of Architecture of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have been chosen in a competition in which Thomas Akin Jr., '38, of New Bedford, won first place.

LONDON, March 13. -- Next week's openings are these: "Toussaint l'Ouverture," with Paul Robeson, is being shown Sunday by the Stage Society; and the Cosmopolitan Theatre will give Hasenclever's "Marriages Are Made in Heaven." On Monday, at the Embassy, is "Emperor of Make-Believe," by Malcolm Morley and Madge Pemberton, which is about Hans Christian Andersen and Jenny Lind and has Baliol Holloway and Sophie Stewart in those two roles.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 14. -- Forty-seven incorporated villages in Nassau County will hold their annual elections Tuesday. Lively campaigns are in progress in Hempstead, Rockville Center, Cedarhurst Malverne, Lynbrook, New Hyde Park, Island Park, Massapequa Park, Valley Stream and Sea Cliff.

Broadcasting of court trials would be prohibited in New Jersey by a bill pending in the Legislature. The Radio-Photograph Bill, which is designed to protect the dignity of court proceedings, would bar all such equipment from court rooms, except as a part of the evidence in any case.

AMHERST, March 14. -- Unsuspected talent is unearthed each year at Massachusetts State College when Dr. Frank A. Waugh, head of the Department of Landscape Architecture, presents his annual exhibition of paintings, drawings, and sketches, the work of faculty members and wives, students and alumni.

Agricultural credit in Mexico has disappeared; credit for industry and commerce is restricted; the rights of private property are invaded; an atmosphere of "distrust, uncertainty and unrest" exists, and the "frequent attacks of labor against capital will end by creating a social and economic situation similar to communism," asserts a petition presented to President Lazaro Cardenas by various Mexican business associations.

CLEAR TITLE: In Rochester, N.Y., last week Supreme Court Justice Willis C. Gillette handed down a ruling the effect of which is to recognize that the Republican party has a vested interest in the elephant. The People's party (a Democratic offshoot) had used the elephant as its emblem.

NOT so many seasons ago, opera-lovers reading a certain morning newspaper were greeted by the following headline: "The Sunken Bell Hailed at Opera; Mme. Rethberg Again Heroine of Respighi's Work." Thumbing down the list of characters they might have observed, printed minutely above the story, the following obscure notation: "Third Elf, Gladys Swarthout."

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- The serious flood situation that has developed in the last few days in the Northeastern United States and in restricted localities of the Middle West can best be appraised by the statement that it is confined almost entirely to relatively small tributaries or other minor streams.

ALTHOUGH books about Washington can be counted by the hundred, Mr. Ambler, who is Professor of History in West Virginia University, is well warranted in adding to the list his study of our first President's attitude toward and connection with the West of his day.

Wilhelm Furtwaengler, internationally known German conductor of opera and symphony orchestras, has withdrawn from the post of general musical director of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society, to which he was named on Feb. 28, it was announced last night.

Restoration of the old Gracie Mansion in Carl Schurz Park has been virtually completed by the Park Department, an inspection yesterday disclosed. Period furniture is now being assembled, and it is expected that the former country estate of Archibald Gracie, merchant prince of the late eighteenth and early nineteenth century, can be reopened to the public on May 1.

THE small garden without proper design and with uninteresting plants grown out of bounds is all too common. It is not easy to plan and plant a garden. Many things must be taken into consideration; among them, condition of soil, location and appropriate hardy plant material.

As a former subscriber of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society and as a thoughtful liberal, I wish to take issue with the protest made by Dr. Stephen Wise, Mr. I.A. Hirschmann and several others regarding the appointment of Dr. Wilhelm Furtwaengler to the directorship of the orchestra.

OLD-TIMER: Leaving no trail of $50 and $100 bills, as he used to thirty years ago, Death Valley Scotty, otherwise Walter Scott, visited Los Angeles last week. "I need a few more mules to prowl around in the rocks," he said. "

It would seem to a lay observer that a great deal of excessive commotion is happening (or has been manufactured) concerning the appointment of Dr. Wilhelm Furtwaengler to direct the Philharmonic next season. What, after all, has non-martial music to do with politics?

It is strange that so obvious a thing as the relation of the Supreme Court to the Constitution should be so greatly misunderstood by many intelligent men. This relation is not that of the Supreme Court alone but of any court.

ROME, March 14. -- The Italians can find no particular reason for self-congratulation in the turn events are taking in London. The whole tendency seems to be more toward coming to terms with Chancellor Adolf Hitler than toward adopting measures against Germany for her violation of treaties.

BERLIN, March 13. -- While Germany is facing a showdown on her foreign policy of acting first and negotiating afterward, she likewise faces a domestic showdown between the National Socialist radicals and moderates.

ARTISTS, to appear in next season s Town Hall endowment series: Jascha Heifetz, violinist; the Don Cossacks, conducted by Sergei Jaroff; Elisabeth Rethberg, soprano, and Ezio Pinza, bass-baritone; Marian Anderson, Negro contralto; Igor Stravinsky, composer-pianist, and Samuel Dushkin, violinist; Yeichi Nimura and his partner-pupil, Lisan Kay, dancers; Myra Hess, pianist, and as the final soloist, Kirsten Flagstad, soprano.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, March 14 (AP). -- As a result of the neutrals' recognition of the government of Colonel Rafael Franco the mass exchange of prisoners held by Bolivia and Paraguay will get under way as soon as the neutrals can rush the arrangements.

PARIS, March 14. -- The most important fact of the London negotiations today from the French viewpoint appears to have been the adjournment of the Locarno powers' session and the transfer of their activity to the League of Nations.
TORONTO, March 14 (AP). -- The Montreal Maroons regained the lead in the international group of the National Hockey League tonight as they defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 1 -- 0.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., March 14. -- Coast Guardsmen, apparently as much at home in the flooded areas of the Wyoming Valley as on the Atlantic shore line, swung today into the task of taking tenants from hundreds of homes which had been inundated by the Susquehanna River in one of the worst floods here in decades.

CARMEL, N.Y., March 14. -- Contests in Brewster and Nelsonville, two of the three villages in Putnam County, will mark the elections next Tuesday. In Cold Spring two of the present trustees. Robert H. Mooney and James F. Ferris, are running for re-election on the People's party ticket and have no opposition.

BABYLON, L.I., March 14. -- Voters in twelve Suffolk County villages will go to the polls Tuesday to elect seven Mayors and twenty-six trustees. Issues are few except in instances where control of the administration is at stake, as is the case in Amityville and Patchogue, and in Sag Harbor, where a definite plea is made to the electorate for Conservative party support on the ground that the Advancement party no longer stands for progress.

RAPID CITY, S.D. WINTER brought deep snows to the Black Hills of South Dakota and their surrounding prairies, and these will linger until late May or June. Although the white flakes have brought sharp, uncomfortable cold, they are welcome by and large, for they may affect favorably the health, fortune and economy of the folk who live in this hilly region.

LONDON, March 14. -- Cambridge University gained its thirty-fifth track and field victory over Oxford today in their sixty-second annual meet at the White City Stadium. The Light Blue won eight of the eleven events, leaving only the 100-yard dash, three-mile run and low hurdles to Oxford.

While searching for meteorites developed into a favorite Saturday afternoon diversion in many parts of New Jersey yesterday, scientists agreed that the cosmic body which flared across the sky shortly before 3 A.M. had almost certainly consumed itself before striking the earth.
ALBANY, March 14. -- Governor Lehman today signed four more bills of his anti-crime program, making a total of eighteen, all that have thus far been passed by the Legislature.
LONDON, March 14. -- The text of the speech of Foreign Minister Pierre-Etienne Flandin of France to the League of Nations Council today on the Rhineland crisis follows:

THE Easter holidays will see throngs of travelers off on short cruises and railroad trips -- voyages to the picturesque ports of southern islands and the sunny resort cities of the Midsouth. Advance bookings indicate that the exodus will be extremely heavy.

In her capacity as president of the Girl Scouts, Mrs. Herbert Hoover will attend the semi-annual meeting of the board of directors on Tuesday and Wednesday at the national headquarters, 570 Lexington Avenue. Tomorrow she will broadcast over a national network, participating in the "Let's Talk It Over" feature from Station WJZ at 4:30 P.M.

A GROUP show of canvases by a dozen painters divides the Macbeth Galleries this week with a solo exhibition of small and attractive water-colors by Stevan Dohanos. There is a generally bright vernal aspect to the oils in the group.

Stockholders of the Union Bag and Paper Company will vote at their annual meeting on April 14 on a proposal to increase authorized common stock from 200,000 to 300,000 shares, the additional stock to be offered to holders, probably on the basis of one new share for each two held.

LONDON, March 13. -- During the last hectic week as on frequent previous crucial occasions observers throughout the world have wondered what British foreign policy was. The British have wondered too and have sought enlightenment from their government, but the Cabinet, more often than not, has been as perplexed as anybody else.

PLANT improvement goes on continually. It takes, for example, some of the low-growing plants which we have long been accustomed to see sprawling over the forepart of the border and produces varieties that have erect stems.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14. -- Dominating the play in three of the four sets, Ogden Phipps and William Rand of New York won their third straight national amateur court tennis doubles championship by disposing of William L. Van Alen of Philadelphia and James H. Van Alen of New York at the Racquet Club today.
The "Living Newspaper" unit of the Federal Theatre Project staged its first public production here last night while thirty patrolmen guarded the Biltmore Theatre, in West Forty-seventh Street.

Buddy, a goat used as a lawn mower by the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey to level grass around the huge tanks at one of its Jersey plants, won first prize yesterday afternoon in a goat beauty contest to select "Mr. Bock Beer" of 1936.

QUITE the loveliest of recent additions to the lily family, is Lilium phillipinense formosanum. Indeed, this lily has numerous characteristics that recommend it for planting in border or hardy garden. To the writer, its late season of bloom seems one of the most important characteristics.
WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Members of the Coast Guard and navy men were honored by the government today for deeds of heroism.

AMHERST, Mass., March 14. -- Following the example of Columbia and Harvard, the Public Speaking Department of Amherst College has bought an electrograph recording device, enabling students to listen to their own first stammering attempts at public speaking.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 14. -- Because of a recent statement by Dr. Jose Carlos Macedo Soares that Brazil does not contemplate changing her foreign trade policy, American business men and many Brazilians are awaiting with much interest the outcome of the negotiations undertaken by Sebastiao Sampaio, who on behalf of the government is visiting seventeen European countries to negotiate for new commercial agreements.

MEXICO, March 14 (AP). -- President Lazaro Cardenas told the business men of Mexico tonight that despite their protests his government would continue to aid the working classes "in their efforts to rise from misery."

INDUSTRIAL design -- which provides a new profession for the twentieth-century artist -- is a widening field. Today the men and women engaged in it may be called upon to produce anything from a set of dinner ware to a streamlined locomotive.

As a monument to General Sam Houston and his army of Texans, a huge stone shaft costing $1,000,000 will be erected on the San Jacinto battlefield, near Houston, Lieutenant Governor Walter F. Woodul of Texas said yesterday in an interview at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
PARIS. -- On July 29 Paris will celebrate the centenary of the Arch of Triumph. The arch will be illuminated and there will be a special ceremony at the tomb of the Unknown Soldier.

The Missionary Sisters of the Sacred Heart announced yesterday that contracts had been let for the construction of a 100-bed hospital on the block front on Edgecombe Avenue between 163d Street and 164th Street, overlooking High- bridge Park.

In a letter to you, dated Sept. 17, 1935, which you printed under the caption "Problems of Taxation," I pointed out that as the functions of government increase, entailing increasing expenditures, the government consults the people less and less as to the forms which taxation will take.

THE one-time historian of the Democratic party has passed into opposition. He does not like the New Deal nor the men in it, and he has said so. Yet his position is not clearly defined, for Mr. Kent has no particular affection for the Republicans.

PERHAPS Masefield's "Reynard the Fox" is responsible for the fact that this reviewer felt little moved by R.P. Harriss's story of deep-South fox hunting. The color and excitement and drama of the chase is simply not present, and the notebook entries about animal life, flavorsome though they sometimes are, do not seem sufficient in themselves to take us through 240 pages.
MEDFORD, Mass., March 14. -- Paint, Pen. and Pretzels, the dramatic society of Tufts College, will present on March 26 and 27 its major midwinter play, Sidney Howard's "Paths of Glory."

NOW is the time to consider new plants for the rock garden; to decide where these are to be placed and how their growth, foliage and color will harmonize with their neighbors, and--most important of all--to select plants which, by prolonging the season of bloom, will carry the color through the year.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Railroad executives were more confident today that the emergency freight surcharge rates would be extended after June 30, either indefinitely or for a stated period, when the Interstate Commerce Commission announced dates for seven regional hearings before members of the commission or an examiner.

IN air trade with South America the United States now leads the world, according to L.O. Head, president of Railway Express Agency. He predicted last week that, because of the rapid growth in air-express service between the two continents, air trade will eventually create a marked favorable change in the general trade position of this country.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., March 14. -- Brown today climaxed two days of superb swimming to win the New England Intercollegiate Association meet for the fourth consecutive year, amassing 37 points.

BANGOR, Me., March 14. -- America has its metropolitan melting pots, but probably unique in this country is the almost utopian confluence of four peoples dwelling peacefully side by side on the lands of their ancestors up in the northern corner of Maine.

ST. LOUIS, March 14. -- Continuance of seasonable weather has stimulated business in the Eighth Federal Reserve District, and, while the revival is not exceptionally sharp, it is accepted as reassuring, and the slowness is ascribed to the usual Lenten lethargy.

NOW that the Winter sun waxes warmer and one can afford to linger out of doors, a pleasant excursion for nature lovers who ride on late season snow trains to the Berkshires is a ski or snowshoe trip through the Pleasant Valley Bird and Wild Flower Sanctuary at Lenox, reached easily by a trail from the Bosquet ski run, or by two trails from the town.

ONLY recently has Ethel Hueston abandoned the writing of pure romance in order to devote herself to American historical fiction, and particularly to the history of the frontier. In her novel which preceded this one, "Star of the West," she told the story of the Lewis and Clark Expedition and of the Indian woman who acted as its guide and interpreter.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Efforts of the Black committee to show up what its chairman calls "deceitful and fraudulent" lobbying practices gave rise this week to an interesting and in some respects novel conflict between the legislative and judicial branches of the government -- a situation out of which might develop a precedent that would affect future investigations by special committees of the Senate or the House of Representatives.

A fashion revue in conjunction with a card party and tea will take place on March 28 in the Neptune Room of the Pierre for the benefit of the Chapel Fund of St. Joseph's-in-the-Pines, Brentwood, N. The benefit has been arranged by members of the Alumnae of St. Joseph's Academy, of which Miss Cornelia Leary is president.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP). -- Plans for sharp increases in officer and enlisted strength in the navy were disclosed today as ready for submission to Congress next week in a record-breaking peace-time $549,591,299 appropriation bill.

TRENTON, N.J., Sunday, March 15. -- The New Jersey Legislature, still deadlocked over the financing of emergency relief, remained in session early today with the apparent certainty that relief legislation of some kind would be adopted before morning.

GUIDING the efforts of adult students to bridge the gaps in their formal education is a new work of public libraries. It has grown rapidly since the depression dashed the hopes of thousands of Americans to build a foundation in colleges for cultured lives.

SHANGHAI, March 14. -- A Japanese military spokesman declares the Japanese Embassy has received no confirmation of Chinese reports of victories by Shansi troops over invading Communists. The spokesman believes the situation is not becoming any more serious at the moment, but that the Reds are consolidating their positions and will soon launch a new advance, forcing Yen Hsi-shan eventually to ask for assistance to expel the invaders.

John D. Rockefeller Jr. has presented to Colonial Williamsburg, Inc., the capital of Colonial Virginia, a collection of 10,434 manuscripts, comprising some 28,052 pages of headquarters papers of the British Army in America during the American Revolution, according to an announcement made yesterday.

IRISHMEN and lovers of Ireland throughout the world display the shamrock next Tuesday. No national emblem could be more appropriate for a country famous for its greenness. Other national emblems may be beautiful, but none possesses the charm of the little plant which Ireland claims as her own.

BOSTON, March 14 (AP). -- The Boston Sunday Advertiser says that Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., Harvard student and son of the President, characterized Boston society girls as "good sports, grand dancers and swell friends."

By a margin of a half point, the Evergreen Farms poloists triumphed over the New York Athletic Club, 10 1/2 to 10, to win the Metropolitan League championship last night at the Squadron A Armory. The game featured a triple header.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- "A lone Democrat can't beat four billion dollars," said ex-Governor Ely of Massachusetts in explanation of the abandonment of his effort to oppose instructions for the President's renomination to the delegates from Massachusetts. He was referring to the work-relief fund.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 14 -- Notre Dame won its seventh Central Intercollegiate indoor track and field championship today by amassing 31 3/4 points in the annual meet. Marquette finished second with 20 1/2 and Pittsburgh third with 18 1/2.

THE "earn your way through college" illusion is being dispelled. Not only have conditions of unemployment rendered it virtually impossible for a boy to meet his entire college expenses through his own efforts, but the great increase in the total number of students requiring financial aid has brought into focus with inescapable clarity the weaknesses of such a project.

In an opinion requested on Friday by Mayor La Guardia, Corporation Counsel Paul Windels held yesterday that Park Commissioner Robert Moses must permit the display of WPA identification posters on WPA park projects. The Mayor said the opinion was not only "sound and logical, but sensible."

PHILADELPHIA, March 14.--The Fashion Congress for the benefit of the Reed Street Neighborhood House, South Philadelphia, and its Summer camp at Crum Creek Farm, West Chester, will be held in the ballroom of the Bellevue-Stratford on April 29 and 30.

VIENNA, March 13.--The visit to Vienna of Premier Milan Hodza of Czechoslovakia this week illustrates the limits of Austrian foreign policy and the difficulty of realizing in practice Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg's proud declaration a year ago that henceforward Austria would play a subjective, not an objective, role in international negotiations.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., March 14. -- The New England Model League of Nations closed its ninth annual session here today with a resolution to re-examine the entire post-war treaty structure.

RESEARCH on plants makes an important contribution to horticulture. Newly introduced diseases and insect pests confront the gardener every year and must be fought There must be constant breeding for improved varieties of familiar plants.

IT is an old observation that we suit the action to the word. Between hands and mouth there is a natural sympathy. Children learning to write twist their tongues the while they move their fingers. Women who cut cloth sometimes move their jaws in unison with their scissors.

Consolidation, a word bandied about among railroad men for decades, is causing fresh conflict. This time a move to merge railroad facilities has brought about a dispute between rail executives and rail unions in which President Roosevelt has felt it necessary to intervene.

THIS is a special, de luxe, autographed printing of a new short story by Sean O'Faolain. Why "The Born Genius" should be so singled out is not quite clear, for though it is a good tale, touched with O'Faolain's peculiar magic, it seems on the whole inferior to most of the stories in "Midsummer Night Madness."

SAN FRANCISCO, March 14. -- The Virginia of the Panama-Pacific Line, Captain George V. Richardson, left San Francisco today for New York via Los Angeles Harbor, Acapulco, Panama and Havana, with 500 passengers, the heaviest eastbound list of the year to date.
Postmaster General James A. Farley is scheduled for re-election as chairman of the Democratic State Committee, a meeting of which will be held at the Ten Eyck Hotel at Albany on April 16.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- The legal battle over the custody of Gloria Laura Morgan Vanderbilt continued today when Mrs. Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney, aunt of the heiress of 12 years, asked the Supreme Court to deny a recent petition by Mrs. Gloria Moran Vanderbilt, the mother, seeking a review of New York court decisions so that she might regain possession of her daughter.

HAMILTON, Bermuda. -- One of the busiest periods of the 1936 Winter season will begin today. Several events of importance are listed for the present week. Outstanding will be the annual Bermuda tennis championships, opening tomorrow at the Tennis Stadium, with play continuing daily until the end of the week.

BY strict interpretation, an annual is a plant which normally completes its entire life cycle within one growing season and then dies. Thus China asters, Shirley poppies and Virginian stocks are all true annuals. Gardeners, however, frequently apply the name "annual" to plants which do not properly come within this group, but which for the sake of practical convenience are, in the garden, raised afresh each year from seed.

When the International Flower Show opens tomorrow at the Grand Central Palace, visitors will find one section given over to a feature that has enlisted the cooperation of women of society for many years. This will be the tea garden, where young matrons and debutantes will serve as waitresses.

LONDON, March 14. -- The new council for the relief of German Jews, the plan of which was revealed in the United States by a Jewish mission from Britain last January, will make its debut at a public meeting here tomorrow.

THE visitor making his annual Spring pilgrimage to the International Flower Show at Grand Central Palace this week will again be welcomed by a spectacle of gardens so perfect that it is hard to believe Winter still reigns outside.

Common mistakes by which many i! new house's are given a lower loan valuation than the builder thinks is : Justified, and because of which they may even be rejected by conservative lenders of mortgage money, are outlined by the Society of :Residential Appraisers in a statement from Its headquarters in Chicago.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- With outdoor sports flourishing and tourist registrations at the chamber of commerce nearing new high records, indications point to an extended season for St. Petersburg and neighboring Winter resorts.

Members of the Contemporary Art Chapter of the American Colony Charities Association have arranged an unusual event in behalf of the association, an exhibition of amateur photography which will open April 1 in the Art Galleries of the Squibb Building, 745 Fifth Avenue, and will continue there throughout April 4.

IN this posthumously published book Gamaliel Bradford returns to what he always called the land of his first love -- Elizabethan literature, the term being used, as so generally it is, to cover not only the reign of the last Tudor sovereign but also the reigns of the first Stuart kings.

Former students of Rosemary Hall now living in New York, Long Island, New Jersey, Westchester, Connecticut and Pennsylvania are interested actively in the arrangements for a luncheon and fashion show to be held March 24 at Sherry's for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the Rosemary Hall Alumnae.

IN a world where national rivalries take on a steadily sharper tone the Boy Scouts are striving to eliminate the bitterness of competition from their programs. The pitting of troop against troop, or council against council, is discouraged and, indeed, is gradually disappearing.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., March 14. -- Captain Stewart S. Cook, pioneer pound net fisherman of the North Jersey coast, and his wife, Mrs. Annie Riddle Cook, celebrated their seventieth wedding anniversary at their home, 9 Atlantic Avenue, today.

EDMONTON, Alta., March 14 (Canadian Press). -- The master retail trade code, providing for fixing of both maximum and minimum prices, has been approved by the Alberta Government and will become effective April 1.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Major ethical problems of modern civilization will be reviewed tomorrow by Dr. Stanley High of New York before the delegates to the biennial convention here of the United Synagogue of America.

NYACK, N.Y., March 14. -- Fewer contests will mark village elections here next Tuesday than in many years. Six of the eleven incorporated villages have only one ticket in the field and in none of the other five is Republicanism or the New Deal an issue.

THE army marched as Hitler spoke. That was the headline when Chancellor Adolf Hitler informed the Reichstag and served notice to the world that German troops were marching into the demilitarized Rhine zone.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, speaking at the closing luncheon of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association in the Hotel Commodore yesterday, advised the delegates to enlarge the scope of their newspapers to include "useful and interesting" material from the State and national committees of political parties.

STRASBOURG, France, March 13. -- Behind the drama of the week two tense populations have confronted one another across the river that today, more than ever, is the great divide of the European Continent.

ALBANY, March 14 (AP). -- Forecasts of warm weather and rains brought renewed threats of swollen streams and rivers to New York State today, but the danger of serious floods appeared definitely passed.
CONGRESSMAN BLUMPUS is having heat trouble. But it has nothing to do with the climate in the District of Columbia. It is entirely a matter of the Blinders Bill and the voters back home.

IN the last two years hybrid Korean chrysanthemums have been placed on the market. The first one bore the name of Mercury, and was offered in 1933, to be followed last season by five others: Daphne, Ceres, Apollo, Diana and Mars.

The administration's proposed tax upon undivided corporate profits is attacked in a report of a study into this form of taxation made by the National Industrial Conference Board, which finds that in the fiscal year 1935 more than 80 per cent of all Federal tax revenues were collected from business in the first instance.
