While somewhat affected by the heavy rainstorms, retail trade in the metropolitan area made a fairly good showing last week. Gains of up to 10 per cent or more over a year ago were shown by leading department stores, although the average increase for the period was reported smaller than in the preceding week.

Tracy H. Lewis and Tom H. Lawrence staged a keen struggle for the high-over-all cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. The Class A gunners broke 99 out of 100 targets each, tied at 24 in the first shoot-off, then broke 25 straight apiece. The third extra string went to Lewis, 24 to 22.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 14. -- Yale's basketball team won a thrilling Intercollegiate League game from Harvard tonight, scoring by 39 -- 35 after two over-time periods.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 14. -- Miss Caroline Olga Lowe, daughter of the late Bauman Lowe and Mrs. Lowe, has chosen April 18 as the date of her marriage to Charles Dyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank C. Dyer of East Orange. The ceremony will take place in St. John's Episcopal Church with the Rev. Dr. Lyttleton E. Hubbard, the rector, officiating.

Once again Germany's legions have established "Die Wacht am Rhein," and in the war-weary provinces of Alsace-Lorraine French poilus, manning the steel and concrete casements of powerful forts, guard the road to Paris.

MOVIE clubs for children, in which selected motion pictures they have seen may be discussed from the juvenile point of view, are on the curriculum offered by the department of children's activities of the Y.M.H.A. at Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second Street.

DETROIT, March 14 (AP). -- Investigation of the disappearance of $349,000 of a city pension fund disclosed just before Harry M. Tyler, assistant budget director, killed himself last Thursday night, developed a new mystery today when it was learned that balance statements had been called for by a man whose name does not appear on the city rolls.

THIS little tale is so much milkweed fluff. It will probably touch the reader's fancy only for a moment and then drift away forgotten. If you can first of all get past the knobby British humor on the opening pages, you will find yourself in a tangled garden presided over by a merry, smelly old jobbing gardener and a dreamy, lanky young girl.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 14. -- Taking four firsts and the relay and showing team strength throughout, Yale's swimming team rang up its 150th straight dual victory tonight by downing Princeton, 46 -- 25, in the Brokaw Pool.

Though all again is quiet and order in Tokyo, though Japan has disappeared from the front pages of the press, to which she was hurled by mutiny and murder, it is not to be supposed that the old order is restored intact, and that all is once more where it was before the fateful 26th of February.

DATES and places have been announced for the next two important tournaments. The Grand National, principal annual event of the United States Bridge Association, will be held March 30 to April 4 at the Park Central Hotel.

RETAIL trade pushed ahead during the week in most sections of the country under favorable weather conditions. Floods in some areas interfered with business, but impressive gains over last year were reported quite generally.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- The social program of the high season at Hot Springs will be ushered in on March 31 with the theatrical production of the Hasty Pudding Club of Harvard. On the following Saturday the Princeton Glee Club will give its annual Spring concert.

A NATION-WIDE poll is being conducted by the Women's National Radio Committee to determine the best program in the following classifications: Serious music, light music, the non-musical, educational and children's programs.

A well-balanced team of swimmers from St. Francis Prep. Brooklyn, won the championship of the Association of Private Schools yesterday in the Columbia University pool, coming into possession, temporarily at least, of the trophy it shared last year with Poly Prep.

Hunter College students are contemplating a full program of Spring activities with the election of class, club and student council officials almost complete. The organization of the entering freshmen at the Thirty-second Street annex is proceeding rapidly.
BOSTON, March 13. -- The future of the city of Manchester, the industrial capital of New Hampshire, will be decided during the next few weeks by the bondholders of the great Amoskeag plant.

Shortly after 8 o'clock yesterday morning a bus load of youthful athletes left Brooklyn police headquarters, Sixth Avenue and Bergen Street, and headed for Washington for a series of games. They represented the three champion basketball teams of the Police Department's city-wide Athletic League Winter competition.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- One of the attempted improvements of the New Soil Conservation and Domestic Allotment Act over the outlawed portions of the Agricultural Adjustment Act is the new standard for agricultural progress intended to give the farm population the same rate of improvement in living standards as that of the rest of the population.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP). -- A search for the books that children read in the early years of the country has been undertaken by V. Valta Parma, curator of the rare book division of the Congressional Library.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP). -- Twelve States and the District of Columbia are receiving funds from the Social Security Board to pay for the care of 75,167 children that have no means of support.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 14. -- Columbia, champion of the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League, ended the season with a 33-to-27 victory over a hard-fighting Cornell team tonight. The Lions swept twelve circuit games, marking the fourth time they have achieved the championship without a setback.

MIAMI, Fla. -- Arrangements for the visit of President Roosevelt aboard the Presidential yacht Potom c are commanding the attention of Miami. Even if the Chief Executive decides only to touch here on his annual fishing outing in South Florida waters, Miami people will derive satisfaction from the fact that he has chosen this city as a Winter vacation center.
LONDON, March 14. -- The speech of welcome of Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, to the Council of the League of Nations here today follows:

More than 500 members of the Alumni Association of the New York University Law School, including many judges of State and Federal courts, attended the fiftieth annual dinner of the association last night at the Hotel Roosevelt. The event marked the hundredth anniversary of the founding of the institution.

This spy story offers a well-sustained mystery: who is the actual traitor who has sold British army secrets to the military agents of the not-at-all mythical country of "Ronstadt"? Young Bobby Wingate, lieutenant in a tank corps, is charged with the crime; not until the final moments of his trial by court-martial is the identity of the real villain disclosed.

BY way of celebrating its fourth anniversary, the Midtown Gallery has put together a group show of modest dimensions, which ran through the week concurrently with the one-man show of canvases by Isaac Soyer. The Soyer show will end tomorrow, but the group is on till April.

New Jersey chapters of the Daughters of the American Revolution will convene on Thursday morning in the Assembly Chamber of the State House in Trenton for their two-day conference, with Miss Mabel Clay, State Regent, officiating. Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey will welcome the delegates.

John Hay Whitney sailed for England yesterday on the Ile de France of the French Line to witness the running of the Grand National Steeplechase at Aintree March 27. and felt none too optimistic about his chances of capturing the classic.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP). -- Many believe that the knotty problem of writing a $792,000,000 tax bill for President Roosevelt has virtually scuttled hopes for a May 1 adjournment of Congress.

Fighting desperately to retain a slim lead in the closing minutes of play, the basketball team of the College of Mount St. Vincent defeated the strong St. Joseph's College combination of Brooklyn, 17 to 16, in the victors' spacious gymnasium overlooking the Hudson yesterday.
OCEAN CITY, N.J., March 14. -- The body of Mrs. Elizabeth Rue, 77-year-old wife of M. Taylor Rue, a retired mural painter, was found washed ashore on the beach here today.

Stock prices rebounded sharply yesterday from the severe declines of the two days immediately preceding, many leading issues recovering 1 to 3 points, and a few from 4 to as much as 9 points during the half-day trading period. Whether the recovery may be explained mostly on technical grounds is debatable, but the reports from London and the Continent indicating a lessening of the European tension very evidently did play some part.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

William W. Kleinman, an Assistant District Attorney in Brooklyn, obtained yesterday a leave of absence from his duties pending disposition of charges made against his father, James J. Kleinman, who is accused of communicating with a member of the April (1935) grand jury in an effort to influence his vote in the Samuel Drukman murder case.

TRAINED in a social code unlike that of any Western land, reared under circumstances varying from ours, the people of Japan possess a psychology wholly strange to Occidentals. A nation that kills its Cabinet in order, as the murderers aver, "to secure the peace," that blandly assures the West that militarism is dead at the very moment when militarism is flourishing, and that attempts in 1936 to restore a medieval feudalism, is difficult to understand.

Carl Laemmle, founder of the Universal Pictures Corporation, announced his retirement from the motion picture production concern yesterday and the sale of operating control that he had held for thirty years.

If the opening measures of Anton Bruckner's E major symphony, played by Dr. Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, had only served to emphasize the rich and luminous tone-quality of the strings, the performance would have been worth the journey.

PRAGUE, March 14 (AP). -- The United States men's and women's teams both beat Germany in the international table tennis competition today. The women also subdued Austria, 3 -- 0, but later lost to England, 3 -- 1. The American men defeated the Germans 5 -- 3, while the women won 3 -- 2. Jimmy McClure of Indianapolis led the American men, winning all three of his matches.

TAPPAN, N.Y., March 14. -- Members of the Reformed Church in the metropolitan district will assemble here Monday evening at a special service to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the building of the Tappan Reformed Church edifice.
WEST POINT, N.Y., March 14. -- Four Army athlete teams were victors today in a sport program which included a polo game, two fencing encounters and a dual gymnastic meet.

HANOVER, N.H., March 14. -- Nott Terrace High of Schnectady, N.Y., won Dartmouth's first interscholastic track meet today as world and national indoor records fell or were equaled in nearly all the running events.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14. -- The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals here upheld today the conviction on a minor theft charge of Leonard W. McIntosh, chief clerk in the Department of Public Works of the Virgin Islands.

CHICAGO, March 14. -- A rush of selling of wheat futures, based on more peaceful talk abroad, carried prices on the Board of Trade down sharply today, the July delivery at the inside showing 1 3/4 cents under yesterday's finish. A house with Eastern connections that had bought heavily yesterday led today's selling, and many operators here went out of their lines on the way down.

HAD some wise one ventured to prophesy even so little as a year ago that, within twelve months, there would be operating in this country a national theatre, fed by a government subsidy running into millions of dollars and employing several thousand actors, stagehands and varied theatre workers, the reception of that prescient vision would probably have been just short of crude.

Miss Christine Duncan has enlisted the aid of several members of the younger set who will assist in the sale of boxes and seats for the special performance of "Parsifal" the night of April 8 at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the New York City Visiting Committee and the Hospital Music Committee.

MILWAUKEE, March 13. -- The big problem in Wisconsin at the moment is how much fire is hidden by all the smoke at the State University in Madison. Wisconsin, in other words, is wondering about the fate of Glenn Frank, president of the university.

AKRON, Ohio, March 14 (AP). -- Union rubber workers, voting by acclamation here today, accepted two points and rejected others in a plan proposed by the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company to end a strike which has kept 14,000 persons out of work for almost four weeks.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- A proposal to strengthen the general terms of the Van Nuys bill, the administration's measure to prevent employers from influencing their employes in the coming election, with far more specific and drastic terms is regarded as probable by members of the House Judiciary Committee.
SAFETY drives are being promoted all over the country. Drivers are asked to pledge caution in driving. Many accidents are preventable by such simple devices, but, I am afraid, not all.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Charging that the presentation of the pageant, "Triple-A Plowed Under," staged by WPA relief employes at the Biltmore Theatre in New York tonight was nothing but "pure and unadulterated politics," Representative Bacon of Westbury, L.I. said in a statement issued here tonight that the administration was carrying its "open warfare against the Supreme Court" to the stage of the WPA theatre in New York.

THE spirit of Red Gap's immortal Ruggles hovers over the first part of this book. There the gaudy new Western millionaires are spreading triumphant clouds of gold dust eastward -- and watering them down with buckets of generosity and champagne.

A DRESS and accessory designer has arranged to lend a helping hand to women who become confused trying to figure out what accessories they should wear with which Spring gowns or suits and how one set can do multiple duty with several outfits.

THE tide seems momentarily to be running strongly toward autobiography, probably because a considerable number of middle-aged men (autobiography appears to be largely, though, of course, not exclusively, a male pastime) have simultaneously realized that their youths, not yet remote in time, are historic.

A decision handed down last week by Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin upholds the constitutionality of Section 1083a of the New York Civil Practice Act, which places a limitation upon mortgage deficiency judgments during the emergency period fixed by the State Legislature.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- A clash of opinion between two members of the Roosevelt Cabinet today came to light with a disclosure that a third, the Attorney General, had been called upon to prosecute striking sailors on the Steamship California for alleged mutiny.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C., March 14. -- Indigo, speedy gray gelding owned by John M. Schiff of New York, won the Sandhills Cup event, a three-mile race over timber, today, in one of the most exciting finishes ever seen in this locality.

HIT-AND-RUN drivers last year killed 2,150 persons in this country, the American Automobile Association estimates. In addition, more than 4,000 men, women and children suffered injury at the hands of motorists who did not stop to help them.

SINCE its authorization in January, the dance unit of the Federal Theatre Project has undergone a general reorganization and is now functioning as an independent Dance Theatre Project under the wing of the parent body of which Hallie Flanagan is head.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., March 14. -- Retirement of five faculty members at Mount Holyoke College, including three departmental chairmen, will take effect at the close of the academic year. All the retiring faculty receive an emeritus rank.

Mr. SANTAYANA'S appearance, so late in life, as the author of a best seller is a curious, if too obvious, irony. Does anybody remember, has anybody read, the novel with a Bret Harteish title written by his philosophic colleague, JOSIAH ROYCE, nearly fifty years ago? In Sunday school one thought highly of King JOSIAH because all the singing men and singing women spake of him in their lamentations.

TURF is kept healthy, as a rule, when a high state of soil fertility is maintained. Nearly all soils in this region require the regular use of fertilizer to insure the desired supply of plant nutrients. Although certain types of grasses are more tolerant of low soil fertility than others, all species make the most satisfactory growth when the essential elements for growth are present in liberal amounts.
Glenn Cunningham won the Columbian Mile last night. The time was 4:46.8.

SACRAMENTO, Calif. -- Panhandlers are again making their appearance in increasing numbers in Pacific Coast cities, while the "jungles'' near every large town and railroad division point are crowded with homeless men. This is in sharp contrast to the conditions of a few months ago, when panhandling was virtually unknown.

Changes in the program of work of the National League of Women Voters, which will come to vote at the twelfth convention of the organization in Cincinnati in April, will be discussed tomorrow at a meeting of the State board of management of the New York League.

MUNICH, Germany, March 14. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler was greeted here tonight by 300,000 Bavarians assembled in the Theresien Meadows to shout approval of every phrase in his two-hour speech. It was the greatest spectacle of its kind that Munich has ever witnessed and it has been surpassed only by the May Day festivals in Berlin.

The markets of the world could do no more last week than grope their way through the fog of the European situation. The action of our own stock market was typical. Prices declined on Monday, Thursday and Friday and rallied on the other three days.

ONE of the daintiest "fillers" for a rhododendron or kalmia planting is Shortia galacifolia or Little Colt's Foot. This attractive little plant has clusters of large, shiny leaves from which rise flower stalks, each bearing a solitary pink or white flower with crinkly-edged petals.

IN a way, this is one of the most gruesome books of the year. It decidedly is not for gentle natures. There are in it many unsparingly detailed and realistic descriptions of the cannibalism that occurred when the members of the famous Donner party westward-bound ninety years ago were starving in the mountains.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 14. -- Penn State's boxers retained the Eastern Intercollegiate Association title before an enthusiastic crowd of 6,000 persons who jammed Recreation Hall tonight.

IN 1843 Sally Ann Blair's father was, like Davy Crockett of an earlier day, pushing on into the wilderness whenever neighbors got too close. When, in Kentucky, a family moved in not five miles away, he packed up his family and was off to Oregon, to the dismay of his wife, but to the infinite delight of Sally Ann and her brother, David.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 14. -- Today's scheduled meeting with the Tigers being washed out by a steady downpour, Manager Stengel and his Dodgers spent a good part of the day taking the round trip ride of 125 miles to Lakeland and the Brooklyn pilot occupied himself on his return by worrying about the condition of his shortstop, Lonnie Frey.

A unique fashion revue entitled "The Perfume Entry Fashion Show" will take place during the luncheon hour on April 2 at the Ritz Tower for the benefit of the Junior Emergency Relief Society. Costumes, interpretative of the names and odors of the latest products of well-known perfumers, will be worn by the manikins, who will display also bottles of the perfumes.

HAMILTON, N.Y., March 14. -- Selection of 250 student delegates to the model Republican convention to be held at Colgate University on Monday was completed today. Drives to nominate candidates continued, with backers of Al Smith showing surprising strength.

Accelerated discussion among feminine groups on the problem of equal rights for men and women has followed in the wake of the action of the Court of Appeals, voiding the minimum wage law for women in New York State. Opposing views on such protective legislation for women make the decision a point of contention.

THERE is a cheerful heartiness about Mr. Corey's title, a little tang of triumph, that warms the cockles of the heart and suggests that perhaps we have turned the corner in this sinister matter of criminal domination and are getting ourselves out from under the power of gangsterdom.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 14. -- Seven hundred couples are expected here at next week-end for Princeton's forty-eighth annual junior promenade, which will be held in the university gymnasium Friday evening. There will be an additional dance the next night.

BERLIN, March 14. -- Before a madly cheering audience of 300,000 Chancellor Adolf Hitler declared in an election speech in Munich tonight that Germany acknowledged as judges of her actions only herself and God and therefore would never permit herself to be dragged before any international tribunal for anything that she has done.

In his investigation into the crime prosecution machinery of Brooklyn, launched by the Drukman murder case, Special Prosecutor Hiram C. Todd directed the service of subpoenas last week for the banking and brokerage accounts of thirty-nine persons, including:

VIENNA, March 14. -- From European capitals well-known Socialists and liberal leaders are flocking to Vienna to be present at the trial for their lives, beginning Monday, of Karl Ernst Sailer and Mrs. Marie Emhart, alleged leaders, and twenty-eight other men and women Socialists who face prison terms for their part in reorganization of the revolutionary Socialist movement.

From coast to coast, business women go social this week. Bouquets, white gloves and gold heels will be in order at numerous annual festivities celebrating their satisfaction with their jobs and their enthusiasm for individual performances in a field in which they still rank as fairly recent recruits.

ALONG with the ever-widening interest in gardening there is a corresponding improvement in gardening tools. They are of better quality; they have grown lighter in weight and many, for convenience, have either long or short handles.

Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, delivered a message to the blind people of the country yesterday morning through the medium of the phonograph. At the American Foundation for the Blind, 15 West Sixteenth Street, he recorded a statement which will be distributed throughout the country with thousands of talking book machines created by the WPA for the blind.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- William Randolph Hearst took steps in the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia today to hasten a decision on his suit to prevent the Western Union Telegraph Company from turning over to the Senate lobby inquiry committee a telegram he sent to James T. Williams Jr., a local editorial writer.

THOUSANDS of New York and Connecticut parents and children are preparing to do their "window-shopping" for Summer camps next Saturday and Sunday at a unique camp exhibition at the Westchester County Center at White Plains.

Five hundred persons were driven from their homes in the factory district near the Passaic River in Paterson Friday night and early yesterday as the flood waters continued to rise. During the day, however, the waters began to recede rapidly there as elsewhere in North Jersey, and no further danger was expected.

MILAN, Feb. 28, 1936. IT is a curious coincidence that brought together at La Scala, within a few days' distance of each other, the premieres of Wolf-Ferrari's opera on the Goldoni comedy and of G.C. Sonzogno's ballet, "L'Amore delle Tre Melarance" (The Love of the Three Oranges), from Carlo Gozzi's theatrical fable expressly conceived to satirize "If Campiello" and other of Goldoni's plebeian subjects.

AT a great flower show, such as will be seen here in New York this week, the most obvious thing is the one frequently to go unnoticed. That overlooked thing is that behind all the eye-captivating beauty and wonder of the gardens and the flowers there has been immense planning.

New York will see the largest St. Patrick's Day parade on Tuesday afternoon in the seventy-five-year history of these celebrations in honor of the patron saint of Ireland, if the plans of those in charge hold good.

HATS off to Virginia! Not the State, but a town of 13,000 inhabitants in the far northeastern corner of Minnesota, where things musical happen with a vengeance. For seventeen years concerts have been going on in Virginia, real symphony concerts, with guest artists, elaborate program notes and all the other features of events of the kind in the largest music centers of the land.

SOUND in scholarship and admirable in the organization of its vast contents, this reference volume increasingly stirs the reader as he turns its pages with thought of the endless patience, care and hard work that went into its making.

PROFESSOR MULLER of the University of Texas, at present lecturing in Soviet Russia, is one of the outstanding geneticists of our day. It was he who first turned X-rays on the eggs of fruit flies with results that still daze biologists.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 14. -- The Princess Julia Cantacuzene was honor guest at the dinner given by Dr. and Mrs. Leland Eggleston Cofer tonight at Capricho.

IN his search of great men, Emil Ludwig has found a hero: Thomas Garrigue Masaryk, until recently President of the Czechoslovakia Republic. He is Ludwig's ideal as constructive man, philosopher and statesman, an anticipation of the sage of Plato's Republic, his candidate to head a United States of Europe.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14. -- Neil J. Sullivan and Roy Coffin of the Germantown C.C., shorn of their Pennsylvania State championship in an early round upset recently, showed they have no intention of surrounding their national championship so easily by gaining the semi-finals of the United States squash racquet doubles tournament at the Country Club today.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 14. -- Yale outfenced Princeton in all three departments of competition today, winning 20 bouts to 7, after capturing the foils, 8 -- 1, and the epee and saber at 6 -- 3 each.
BOSTON, March 14. -- Maine became the center of the flood peril in New England tonight as rains and warmer weather were forecast for the entire region.
WASHINGTON, March 14. -- The initial issue of the first official daily newspaper of the United States Government rolled from the giant presses of the Government Printing Office today.

The threat of legislation in various States, particularly New York, to restrict the authority of political subdivisions to levy taxes on real property in meeting debt service, continues to be of grave concern to the municipal bond fraternity. Although the market for municipal bonds has not yet reflected the agitation for limitation of municipal taxes, municipal bond men fear the consequences of such legislation and are pressing a campaign of opposition to these proposals.

PARIS, March 14. -- Charles Maurras, co-editor of the Royalist newspaper Action Francaise, who was arrested after a street assault by Royalist crowds on the Socialist leader Leon Blum, was brought to trial today for incitement to assassination.

JUDGING by the number of reservations that have been pouring in for the Lucrezia Borg farewell at the Metropolitan, listed for March 29, it is felt at the Opera House that an auditorium two or three times the size of the Thirty-ninth Street theatre could be filled with eager customers. Somebody, in fact, mentioned Madison Square Garden.

THE garden's past is a magnificent grab-bag from which one can choose and resurrect now a flower long forgotten, now a garden form. Many a plant novelty, highly publicized today, knew its hours of popularity long ago and has since spent its sweetness on the air of an obscure cottage garden until a discerning horticulturist brought it into favor again.

A distinguished audience is expected at the performances of the Hollywood Ballet on the nights of March 23 and 24 at the Metropolitan Opera House, which have been taken over as a benefit for the Boys' Club of New York. Many boxes and seats already have been sold and several of the subscribers will give dinners in advance.
ATLANTIC CITY -- Spring has come early to Atlantic City, bringing with it a host of visitors that seems to indicate a record Palm Sunday and Easter holiday influx.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 14. -- Gene Sarazen, former United States and British open titleholder, paired with Mally Reynolds of Jacksonville, advanced to the semi-finals by registering victories in the second and third round matches of the second annual national pro-amateur best-ball match play golf championship on St. Augustine Links today.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 14. -- Midshipman John M. Alford of Calva, Ill., is the final appointee as "five-striper," or midshipman commander of the regiment, at the Naval Academy, and will fill that position for the remainder of the academic year and during June Week.

Topics close to a homemaker's heart are slated for analysis and comment on Thursday at the Pennsylvania Hotel, where the second annual conference on social security in the homes of this country will be held under auspices of the American Home Department of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs.

I am, unfortunately, an absentee landlord. I own a farm here, or did until the administration took it over. I have just returned from the East only to find that the great AAA has proved to be pretty much of a boomerang.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- The last barrier to unanimous action between the United States and Latin-American republics in holding a conference suggested by President Roosevelt to solidify peace efforts in the Western Hemisphere was cleared away this evening by the extension of formal recognition by the United States and five other powers to the new government of Paraguay.

It is a pity that certain corporation assets have been christened by bookkeepers rather than by active producers of wealth. While bookkeepers call those assets "undivided profits," more realistic men would call them "dividend and wage reserves."
MADRID, March 14. -- The government of Premier Manuel Azana was worried tonight by reports from virtually the whole countryside that Rightists and Leftists were in violent, sporadic outbursts.

The Atlantic Transport liner Minnekahda lay in the Morse drydock in Brooklyn yesterday, being prepared for her final transatlantic crossing. She has been bought by Arnott, Young Co., Ltd., shipbreakers, of Glasgow, and is being reconditioned to take a cargo of scrap iron to the United Kingdom.

American and European paintings of the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, including works of the Barbizon School and French and British portraits, will be offered as auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Thursday evening.

THE arrival of Spring brings energetic but sometimes rash gardening. The Annual urges to dig up, to replant, and to increase the amount of detail in the landscape scheme must be curbed if the gardener would avoid spoiling broad, simple effects which, after all, are usually pleasing.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Neither Lent nor the fact that April is but a fortnight away is having any appreciable effect on the season here, which continues its midwinter tempo. Exhibitions, the annual sun dance and other events are being arranged.

B. IFOR EVANS, who has succeeded the late Allan N. Monkhouse as writer of the valuable column entitled "A Bookman's Notes" in The Manchester Guardian every Friday, is rather unhappy about a prospective danger to the book from the radio and the film, especially the latter.

Underprivileged children of pre-school age who are provided with instruction, supervised rest and play, medical care and proper food in the eight kindergartens and nursery schools maintained by the New York Kindergarten Association will be aided by a special performance of "Parsifal" Friday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP). -- For the second consecutive month China was shown in State Department statistics today to have been the largest purchaser of arms, ammunition and implements of war from the United States during February.

IN any form of art expression, one cannot merely dictate a plan to follow and then guarantee originality. To define originality, an idea must come from the individual, and be executed in a way that is not imitative. This inspiration may come from some outside, remote source but must be carried out in the medium in which technical skill has been acquired.

HERE is something new. Or, if not actually unprecedented (and one of the characters in this book declares that all crime is a repetition of earlier crime), it is at least novel and unusual Indeed, "The Catalyst Club" can lay claim to originality on two counts for the instrument with which the crime is committed is, I think, unique in murder fiction; but that point of novelty is not the most interesting one.

FIGURES surprising to the uninitiated, showing the still-dominant position of miscellaneous flying in mileage and passengers carried, as wall as the far higher accident toll in this type of flying compared with scheduled air-transport operations, were brought out at the recent New York Safety Conference by John H. Geisse, air craft development engineer of the Bureau of Air Commerce.

PARIS. MANY of the significant new fashions launched by the Paris couturiers emphasize the hips mere than any other point of the silhouette. There is considerable speculation in style circles as to how this will be received in America, where, it is believed, the boyish figure with its wide shoulders and slim hips still persists as a popular ideal, cloaked though it may be by utterly frilly and feminine frocks.

Attempts made in previous years to delay and minimize clearances of Spring apparel and to emphasize regular lines in post-Easter selling will achieve greater progress this year in the programs of many stores throughout the country, merchandising authorities here said yesterday.

Regardless of what actuating motives may be asserted in its behalf, a revenue measure which is framed solely with a view to raising revenue, without proper concern for the welfare of those upon whom the tax is imposed, carries a strong implication of deliberate disregard for sound taxation policies.

Without entering into the controversy on sterilization in any direct sense, let me state briefly the fundamental facts uncovered by the committee of the American Neurological Association and its conclusions and recommendations.
Under a steady demand from foreign and domestic consumers, prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered yesterday to close with a gain of 8 to a loss of 2 points on the day.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 14. -- Brown won the New England intercollegiate varsity wrestling title today, scoring 27 points in the finals.

BOSTON, March 14. -- Reports from practically all leading cities in the First Federal Reserve District indicate that retail trade has improved substantially during the last fortnight. The restoration of normal transportation facilities has resulted in a freer movement of nearly all kinds of merchandise.

IN "Monsignor," Doran Hurley has written the story of an inner conflict, the struggle in the divided nature of an able and powerful prelate between the urge for personal power and a no less fundamental desire for spiritual grace.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended March 11, aggregated $8,576,000,000, or 9 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 19 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year.

BASIL CAMERON has been engaged for the fifth season as conductor of the Seattle Symphony Orchestra. The recently completed season of the organization was the most extensive in its history, totaling sixty-five concerts, including road tour appearances in Idaho, Washington, Montana and Utah.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- Visitors at the Greenbrier increase daily, coming from points South for the Spring season, which marks the 158th anniversary of this resort.
CHICAGO, March 14 (AP). -- To the accident prevention director of the nation's "safest" city was given $15,000 today to apply his best safety ideas on a country-wide scale.

As long as a school prevents a considerable number of its children from ever knowing success by branding them as inferior, it will start these children on the road to delinquency, unless an unusually favorable home environment can counteract the influence of the school, according to Burton Fowler, director of the Tower Hill School, Wilmington, Del.

THE ballots being distributed by the Metropolitan Opera Guild to help the opera management in its decisions concerning future repertoire give all, who desire, opportunity to check five preferences for possible revivals, among other choices.

Graduates of the United States Military Academy at West Point, gathering last night at points throughout the world to celebrate the 134th anniversary of the academy, participated in an hour-long radio program broadcast by the National Broadcasting Company over a hook-up declared to be the largest in radio history.

MOSCOW, March 14. -- In Soviet opinion it is vain to hope that Germany will withdraw her troops from the Rhineland, and the rest of Europe may as well reconcile itself to the fact that a dangerous war-threatening step has been taken, against which it must prepare itself.

WHEN Columbia University ousted all animal pets from student dormitories the other day there were immediate repercussions at the headquarters of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. Numerous calls came from people eager to welcome the dispossessed alligators, white mice, turtles, cats and dogs into their homes. There is scarcely an animal, society spokesmen say, that cannot find a home with one or another of New York City's pet enthusiasts.

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 14. -- Chasing the Indians, which was known as an amusing piece of business in these parts some fourscore and a few more years ago, was revived by the Giants today without, however, providing anything particularly amusing for Colonel Bill Terry.

Peak sales figures for the year were recorded in wholesale and retail trade over a wide area of the country last week as Spring buying by distributors and consumers gained momentum as the result of more seasonable weather conditions. The outlook in most districts was for a heavy volume of pre-Easter buying of all types of wearing apparel and other merchandise.

THREE major opera premieres in less than a month have kept Italian music reviewers (and several foreign critics) quite on the jump of late. After Alfano's "Cyrano" at the Royal Opera at Rome and Malipiero's "Cesare" at the Carlo Felice of Genoa, there now comes Wolf-Ferrari's "Il Campiello," a three-act lyric comedy, after the play of Carlo Goldoni, successfully launched at La Scala last week.

IT has long been a baffling question to gardeners why delphiniums would not grow for them as successfully as other perennials. That a gardener here and there achieved wonderful results with them has only deepened the mystery. Only recently have investigations, carried on at widely separated points, where soil and climatic conditions differed, tended to throw some light on the problem.

This story, which tells of a little boy's first experiences on horse- back, is addressed to children of 6 and 7 who are just learning to ride, and is designed to give them confidence and an understanding of the primary requisites of horsemanship.

CHICAGO, March 14. -- A spectacular quarter-mile in world-record time by Ray Ellinwood, long-striding Chicago sophomore, and Michigan's third consecutive team championship, shared the honors tonight in the twenty-sixth annual Western Conference track and field meet in the University of Chicago field-house.

I see that there is some agitation going on to permit bars at the theatres. I am not a member of the W.C.T.U. -- as a matter of fact I was a vice president of the earliest Anti-Prohibition League -- but I think to make drinking between the acts easier will be the death of the theatre.

Bizet's "Carmen" was heard for the seventh and last time this season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. Rosa Ponselle, who assumed the title role in all except one of the "Carmen" performances, finished her operatic duties of the season with this presentation.

THE automobile industry is heading into what is expected to be the most active Spring selling season since 1929. There are many facts to support such an optimistic opinion. Despite sub-zero weather in many parts of the country during most of February, retail passenger car sales were close to those in the same month a year ago.

The railroad industry has always taken the lead in the establishment of good working conditions and labor relations, but it cannot safely get too far in advance of the procession. Nor ought the employes to overlook the fact that if unnecessary railroad costs are not avoided much desirable work that creates employment may not be undertaken.

Several charitable enterprises carried on by the Ladies of Charity of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York will be furthered by a card party and tea to be held next Thursday afternoon at the Plaza. A large subscription has been reported.

ST. PATRICK, drumming the snakes out of Ireland, worked so hard t it that he tore a hole in the drumhead. But for a kindly angel who repaired the break while the good saint kept on thumping, the miracle might have failed.

JOSEPHINE HUTCHINSON, an earnest young actress with red hair, who stepped from Civic Repertory and "Alice in Wonderland" into a screen career in 1934, managed during last week, her first return to our town since she went to Hollywood, to pay off some of her debt to the New York stage.

LONDON, March 14 (Canadian Press). -- Scoring its first league victory since Dec. 26, Chelsea provided the feature of today's football program that saw a great increase in crowds at all matches. As a result of the lifting of the ban on football listings by the English league, the forty-four games played drew a total of 614,000 spectators.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 14. -- Walter O. Briggs's offer of a bonus to his Detroit Tigers for a third straight American League pennant was formally withdrawn today, but training camp observers saw the flicker of a wink behind the announcement.

The fifteen-day strike of elevator operators and other building service employes ended shortly before 2:30 o'clock this morning when representatives of the Realty Advisory Board and the Building Service Employes Union, acting in conference with Mayor La Guardia's new Board of Survey, entered into a three-year agreement providing for arbitration of controversial issues.
THE large mural, "Joan of Arc at the Court of Chinon," by Boutet de Monvel, is being installed in the Children's Room, on the main floor of the Art Institute of Chicago.

Although this is a continuation of the saga of the three intrepid adventurers who first made their appearance in "Wild Cat Ridge," the story is a separate entity in itself. Boys from 10 to 14 will not need to have read the preceding volumes to thoroughly enjoy this full-bodied tale of action, but they win probably want to turn back to "Eagle Cliff" and "The Timber Trail" as well.

YORK, Pa., March 14. -- Deliberate attempts to violate the Federal Constitution were charged to the Roosevelt administration tonight by Henry P. Fletcher, chairman of the Republican National Committee.

NOT all the Mae West stories originate in smoking cars. An appropriate one for the moment was brought in recently by a producer who had some little to do with Miss West's current picture, "Klondike Annie," at the Paramount.

THE NEW YORK TIMES, on the occasion of Dr. Ivan Pavlov's demise, presented several informative and philosophic accounts of his life and work. Your headlines take on the finality of an epitaph: "Discoverer of the Conditioned Reflex, He Viewed Mind and Matter as One Phenomenon."

Two agencies of the government engaged in a strenuous tug-of-war last week. The cause was the President's tax program, by which he seeks to revise the system of taxing corporations in a way that will produce $1,600,000,000 a year, an increase of about $620,000,000 over the present yield.

ROME, March 13. -- If any one had told Premier Benito Mussolini last November when he was still fighting tooth and nail to ward off sanctions that only four months later he would be asked to apply against Germany the very measures he was trying to avert from himself, he probably would have answered it was impossible.

New responsibilities of liberal arts colleges in preparing their undergraduates for the problems, careers and complexities of present-day life were drawn sharply into focus yesterday by Constance Warren, president of Sarah Lawrence College, in an address at a luncheon at the Biltmore under the auspices of the New York League of Business and Professional Women.

ATLANTA, March 14. -- Governor Talmadge's "dictatorship" of State finances in the absence of an appropriation act met a major setback today when a three-judge Superior Court tribunal ruled that no funds could be paid out of the Treasury by George B. Hamilton, the ousted Treasurer, or J.B. Daniel, the de facto Treasurer, except by law.

THE remarkable recent advancement of horticulture in this country is due in no small part to the work of organized plant societies. Today the gardener who aspires to become an authority on dahlias joins the American Dahlia Society; or if his bent is toward orchids he allies himself with the American Orchid Society.

THE use of electricity for horticultural propagation purposes is still in its infancy. On completion of Federal electric projects like the TVA and Boulder Dam, with privately owned electric projects operated in the Puget Sound, the Niagara Falls and other districts, together with the distribution of electric power generated in the coal regions, the cost of electricity for heating and plant-propagation purposes will presumably be lowered.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., March 14. -- Smith College elections to Phi Beta Kappa and Sigma Xi, and also the awards of prizes and fellowships were announced today at the student assembly.

WITH the unveiling of the Per Krohg painting, "Leif Eriksson Discovers America," at the Capitol in Washington on Monday, March 23, will come another stirring reminder of the generous use of saga material as motifs of modern Scandinavian art.

" Women will never be able to use their vote effectively until they are economically free," declared Mrs. Harriot Stanton Blatch, interviewed recently at the Women's University Club, 106 East Fifty-second Street, on one of her infrequent trips to New York from her home in Greenwich, Conn.

I read with interest a letter from T.J. Kehoe in THE TIMES of March 3 under the headline "The Fort Peck Dam"; also another letter on this same subject appearing in THE TIMES on March 7 by Gordon R. Williams under the caption "Mississippi River Floods."
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Federal Register, a government publication with a world-wide circulation of its first issue, today went to press.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Plans for a nation-wide series of dinners on April 13, Thomas Jefferson's birthday, for the benefit of the Democratic National Committee's campaign fund, were announced today.

THESE five little heiresses were not quintuplets. Only two were sisters. They had been hand-picked from a list of the socially select and enormously wealthy, sub-debs attending an exclusive girls' school in the East and given the expensive privilege of a European tour chaperoned by Miss Brenda Angell.

The National Academy of Design has awarded fifteen cash prizes totaling $4,250 and two gold medals in its 111th annual exhibition, which will be opened to the public on Wednesday at the galleries of the American Fine Arts Society, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Since 1929-30 many of us have had a hard time holding on to such amenities as a set of Philharmonic subscriptions when free radio and less costly phonograph records were available as "Ersatz," but we have stood by the ship

MANCHESTER, N.H., March 13. -- President Roosevelt emerged as a complete victor in the New Hampshire Presidential primaries, the country's first election to select delegates to the national convention. He was not only upheld by his party but had the added satisfaction of seeing the Democratic enrollment increase appreciably over 1932 in this adamant Republican State, one of the six to uphold the administration of President Hoover in the election four years ago.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Preservation of business initiative but with governmental checks "to preserve and protect social justice, equity and fair dealing" was recommended to President Roosevelt today in a report prepared by a special committee on industrial policy for the Council for Industrial Progress.

Grace Moore has returned to the Metropolitan fold a definitely more proficient vocalist than when last heard there, a few seasons back. At yesterday afternoon's sixth and final performance of Puccini's "La Boheme" at the Broadway house, the popular young singer merited the welcome she received, a welcome not frenzied, but one that evidenced the delight of patrons of the opera at this improvement of the artist in the domain of song.

ADDIS ABABA, March 14.--Fears are expressed in the highest quarters here that the powers represented at the London meeting of the League of Nations Council may in the absence of an Ethiopian delegation seek to find a speedy end to the Italo-Ethiopian dispute, imposing armistice and peace terms of a so-called "common sense" kind upon the belligerents, in view of the situation arising out of Germany's violation of the Locarno pact.

COMPETITION on the radio has always been a potent force in the development and progress of American broadcasting. Always, right alongside every wave length, is some other actor doing his utmost to "steal" the show. The showmen play an ethereal game of checkers and must be ever on the alert to watch the moves of each performer or troupe.
GENEVA, March 13. -- What is the League's role in the present emergency? Where do events leave the League?

ONCE more Germany and France confront each other across the Rhineland. When the advance guard of the German Army crossed the bridges that span the Rhine it took with it the seeds of a new conflict. For eighteen years no German Army commands had disturbed the sleep of the Lorelei; today the military frontiers of the two nations meet again.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 14. -- The Harvard swimming team easily defeated the Columbia group tonight, taking every first place and allowing but two second places to the visitors to score by 60 to 11.

Pressure was lifted from bonds on the New York Stock Exchange in yesterday's two-hour trading period and, reflecting the rally in stocks, prices generally recovered a substantial part of the decline of the two preceding sessions. Almost all classes of bonds were responsive to the renewed demand, with the widest recoveries among the second-grade and more speculative issues.

Directors of the Oklahoma Natural Gas Company have approved the plan of refinancing proposed by Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc., and tomorrow the officers will mail to stockholders letters and proxy blanks for a special meeting on April 15 for voting on the plan and authorizing new securities.

HIGHWAY safety is discovered to be vitally necessary to well-being in the United States, and deplorably scarce. The motor vehicle in its forty years has advanced our pursuit of happiness a long way, blessing our work and our play beyond the dreams of its inventors.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 14. -- The annual elections in twenty- one Westchester villages will be held Tuesday. Three other Westchester villages have elections fixed by special charters on other dates. Ossining votes in December, Peek- skill April 14, and Port Chester April 28.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Forty-seven Indian tribes, representing a total population of 54,721, are now busily engaged in drafting constitutions under the Indian Reorganization Act of 1934. The act, intended to broaden home rule for Indians, gives the tribes the right to organize and adopt constitutions and by-laws, subject to ratification by majority vote of their adult members, and to final approval by the Secretary of the Interior at Washington.

In his first inaugural address WASHINGTON dwelt upon the expediency of encouraging inventive genius. Congress responded with laws of unprecedented liberality. Of these the act of 1836 had an almost magical effect. That farseeing measure could hardly have been passed more propitiously.

In November, 1912, Great Britain and France signed an agreement by which London promised to support Paris if the peace of Europe were threatened. In July, 1914, France, fearing invasion, asked Britain if she was prepared to live up to her obligations. For a few days London wavered.

While large retailers here favor the principles underlying the Livingston Bill to curb fraudulent retailing practices and eliminate the loss leader, the creation of a New York State commission to do these things finds little favor in their eyes, comment here yesterday indicated.

IF plans do not go awry, color should provide a material contribution to the screen during the 1936-37 season. The optimistic figures of the color people show fourteen pictures definitely slated for Technicolor, with nine others as possibilities.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP). -- N.J. Clarke, vice president of the Republic Steel Corporation, Cleveland, told the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee today "chaos" would result from enactment of the Wheeler bill to abolish the basing point system of fixing prices.

I OUGHT to have begun where I have ended." says Mr. Santayana with a sigh for the brevity of life as he looks over these thirty years of miscellaneous writing. "That pure philosophy to which I was wedded by nature from the beginning * * * has never had time to break through and show all its native force, pathos and simplicity."

MUNICH, Germany, March 14. -- Cannon boomed salutes and radio announcers described every step of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's journey to the speakers' stand after he had arrived in the Theresien Meadows for his speech tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 14. -- Better weather conditions during the past week put an entirely different tone on the retail trade of the Pacific Coast, which had been under the spell of almost a month of severe storms that cut down patronage, especially in women's apparel lines, to a marked degree.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 14. -- The desire of a self-made man to help young men obtain an engineering education at Cornell University will be realized in greater degree than ever, beginning next September, when thirty McMullen regional scholarships will be awarded, doubling the number last year.

IN many a collection of house plants one or more of the maricas will be found. Sometimes the owner is entirely unaware of its genus. Occasionally it is miscalled by the name of its cousin, the moraea. In recent books Twelve Apostles and Toad Lily were the common designations given for this interesting house plant, which deserves to be known by its true name.

NEWARK, N.J., March 14. -- With a soft and delicate touch that captured the admiration of the near-capacity gallery, Edmond Soussa of Cairo, Egypt, successfully defended the national amateur Class A 18.2 balkline billiard championship today at the Newark Athletic Club, repulsing the bid of Percy Collins of Chicago, 300 to 156, in the final.

MADRID, March 14.--While the charred embers of two churches and one Monarchist newspaper plant still smoldered today, Premier Manuel Azana prohibited all further Marxist demonstrations. His order covers manifestations for the confiscation and redistribution of land, and the re-employment of discharged revolutionists and reprisals for alleged Fascist attempts to assassinate Socialist officials.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Seldom does the country have opportunity to witness such a quick, spontaneous and non-partisan reaction as that which followed the submission of President Roosevelt's proposal to tax all undivided corporate profits.

A special tribute to the memory of Antonio Scotti, who died last month in Naples, will be a feature of the gala concert for the benefit of the Music Lovers Foundation, Inc., which will be held on Tuesday afternoon in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

His order covers manifestations for the confiscation and redistribution of land, and the re-employment of discharged revolutionists and reprisals for alleged Fascist attempts to assassinate Socialist officials.

A special tribute to the memory of Antonio Scotti, who died last month in Naples, will be a feature of the gala concert for the benefit of the Music Lovers Foundation, Inc., which will be held on Tuesday afternoon in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
CUSSETA, Ga., March 14 (AP).--A 35-year-old Negro accused of attacking two white women was lynched near this place early today by a mob which took him from Chattahoochee County officers.
ROCHESTER, March 14. -- University of Rochester students who pursue hobbies opened an exhibit of their work in Rush Rhees Library today, the first of its kind sponsored here.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 14. -- Freshmen who enter the New Jersey College for Women next September may compete for various resident and general scholarships for the 1936-37 college year, the scholarship committee announced today.

After completing preparations for her twentieth wedding anniversary and the confirmation of a son, Mrs. Augusta Lewis, 45 years old, wife of Dr. A.S. Lewis of 1,381 Union Street, Brooklyn, was killed early yesterday and her sister, Mrs. Julia Enderlein, 47, of Roxborough, Pa., was injured critically when Both were struck by automobiles at Eastern Parkway and New York Avenue, Brooklyn.

A GREAT awakening comes to the rose garden in the Spring season, and this awakening brings with it two insistent, delightful activities: the making of new rose beds and the setting out of new plants, and the care of plants of the previous year that have come through the Winter.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 14. -- The annual traditional medieval frolic arranged by Form V. the class which studies medieval European history at Rosemary Hall School, Greenwich, was held at the school tonight. Students and members of the faculty who attended came in costumes representing outstanding medieval personages.

With an hour to spare before taking the train back to Albany, Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne leaned back in an armchair at the Harvard Club, smiled pleasantly and told the inquiring reporter to fire ahead.

Committees are now being organized for the annual Butterfly Ball dinner dance which will be held on April 14 at the Ritz-Carlton. The event, as in past years, will be given under the auspices of the Junior Auxiliary of the House of Rest at Sprain Ridge, near Yonkers, to assist the maintenance of that institution in its treatment and care of men, women and children afflicted with pulmonary tuberculosis.

In its latest move to compel holding companies to register under the Public Utility Act of 1935, the government moved yesterday in Federal court here to dismiss a counter suit instituted by the Electric Bond and Share Company and twen-one other public utility companies which assailed the act as unconstitutional.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 14. -- Freshmen who enter the New Jersey College for Women next September may compete for various resident and general scholarships for the 1936-37 college year, the scholarship committee announced today.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 14 (AP). -- Lieutenant Edgar R. Camp swung safely to earth today on his parachute, leaving his crippled plane to crash in a field two miles west of the Colebrook National Guard Reservation.

A GREAT awakening comes to the rose garden in the Spring season, and this awakening brings with it two insistent, delightful activities: the making of new rose beds and the setting out of new plants, and the care of plants of the previous year that have come through the Winter.
ISTANBUL, March 14. -- The Turkish press published today, forty-eight hours late, the communique issued at Geneva after the meeting of representatives of the Little and Balkan Ententes.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 14. -- The annual traditional medieval frolic arranged by Form V. the class which studies medieval European history at Rosemary Hall School, Greenwich, was held at the school tonight. Students and members of the faculty who attended came in costumes representing outstanding medieval personages.

COLLEGE professors and grade school teachers in Massachusetts are banding together to protect themselves from "pressure groups seeking to regulate their activities." The Massachusetts Society for Freedom in Teaching, founded by a committee headed by Professor Samuel Eliot Morison of Harvard University, aims to "foster professional consciousness among teachers"; inform public opinion as to the benefits of "free investigation and honest instruction"; and "guard the professional interests of teachers in legislation."

BUENOS AIRES, March 13. -- A totalitarian State made its first appearance in the Western Hemisphere on Tuesday when the little inland republic of Paraguay, with a population of less than 1,000,000, announced to the world that it had adopted that form of government.

The fast-riding trio representing Fort Hamilton last night defeated Boulder Brook, 13 1/2 to 5, in a semifinal round polo game for the Sherman Memorial Trophy at the Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn. Fort Hamilton will meet with the winner of the Squadron A-Essex Troop encounter scheduled next Thursday in the final on March 21.

THE COLOPHON, as moat colectors are aware, is a quarterly that has been in existence for a little over five years. After rounding out twenty appearances in quarto and earning universal applause for the performance, it retired backstage for a budgetary consultation and emerged an octavo, with less make-up, but with its face shining.

Another week of good retail business increased wholesale activity, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. Apparel business in particular showed a marked improvement and reorders were received in large numbers in all price ranges.
DORCHESTER, N.B., March 14 (AP). -- Crown and defense attorneys, fighting over what evidence should be admitted, blocked action in the "doll-baby" kidnap-murder case today.

If income-tax day comes can Spring be far behind? This year it is less than four days behind. Mr. ROOSEVELT'S internal revenue boys have announced that they will be sitting at the receipt of the customs up to midnight tomorrow, Monday, March 16.

MOST garden books of this Spring's generous crop are practical and trustworthy. Sometimes there appears a volume that has an additional quality. Such a book is that by Dorothy Biddle and Dorothea Blom, entitled "Garden Gossip."

Spain, which had swung under the dominance of the Right after the blood-drenched Socialist insurrection of October, 1934, held an election a month ago in which she swung back to the Left. The line-up was clear-cut: a Fascist-Monarchist-Catholic combination on the Right, led by Jose Maria Gil Robles, and a Socialist-Republican combination on the Left, led by the veteran Republican, Manuel Azana.

ONE of the most howlingly funny incidents in that eternal-formula play, "Boy Meets Girl," now on Broadway, is when the cowboy star turns up with a case of measles he has contracted from the film baby Happy, "America's Sweetest Sweetheart."

ATHENS, Texas, March 14 (AP). -- George Patton, 54-year-old recluse, was rushed to the Anderson County jail at Palestine for safekeeping tonight after he unearthed for officers bones identified as those of a family of four he is accused of slaying.

VIENNA, Feb. 15, 1936. ALTHOUGH the departure from Berlin several years ago of the distinguished German critic and musicologist Dr. Alfred Einstein has delayed work on the projected new edition of Koechel's catalogue of Mozart works, the loss of time will probably prove a blessing in disguise, for it has enabled Dr. Einstein to assemble a considerable mass of new and important material.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 14. -- The site of Nueva Cadiz, historic first Spanish capital in the New World, supposed to be on the small island of Cubagua off the north coast of Venezuela, may never be rediscovered by Talcott Powell, New York magazine writer, who set out on a literary adventure Feb. 27 accompanied by Alfred Wagstaff 3d of New York and Lieutenant Frank J. Caufield of Newark.

Organized in 1917 to help exporters meet wartime difficulties in foreign trade, the Export Managers' Club of New York, Inc., will discuss problems somewhat similar to those of nineteen years ago on Tuesday when more than 500 export managers gather for the organization's nineteenth annual get-together, at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

A court battle over another of the Roosevelt administration's major activities will get under way here Wednesday when the Reciprocal Trade Agreement Act comes under fire before the United States Customs Court.

GARDEN rewards do not come only in bushels of vegetables harvested, nor even in dollars that do not have to be spent at the green grocer's -- though these benefits are real enough to the distraught housewife trying to make ends meet.

When SHAKESPEARE described that wonderful piece of work, a human being, as one that looks before and after, he could scarcely have been referring to man, the political animal. Perhaps he was not well acquainted with the speeches of his day. But as we see it at present in its full development, to attribute to it foresight, or the gift of prophecy, seems almost laughable.

THIS is the story of the voyage of the Anna Swan, which, having reached San Juan after a five-month voyage from New York, sets sail for Africa with a new skipper on board, old Grout having taken sick on the way down.

HOLLYWOOD. THE Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences held its annual dinner last week and 1,247 of the 1,250 paying customers ate. The awards for distinguished service to the throne of cinema art were eagerly accepted by all but two of those honored.

MADRID, March 13. -- Premier Manuel Azana is Acting Foreign Minister in the absence of Augusto Barcia, who went to London to attend the special meeting of the Council of the League of Nations, but Spain's foreign policy is of no great consequence while its new Left Republican government struggles with its paramount internal problem and tries to cope with revolutionary Socialists and Communists whose votes were responsible for the Left election victory.

NO, those lines of spiritual anxiety do not come from a church calendar. They come from George Bernard Shaw's "Saint Joan," which Katharine Cornell has just revived at the Martin Beck Theatre. They come, in fact, from the least Shavian play of the lot and by common consent the best and the one that most nearly approaches greatness.

OTTAWA, March 13. -- Nowhere in the British Empire did this week's news from Europe fall on more unwilling ears than those of the leaders charged with the direction of Canada's political affairs. It threatened to demand imperative decisions not only of foreign, but of imperial policy.

EXPERIMENTS with the 17.4-centimeter micro-wave radiophone circuit across the English Channel between Limpne, England, and St. Iglevert, France, reveal that tides and weather exert "unexpected effects" on the tiny waves.

Displaying superiority with all three weapons, Columbia's fencing team defeated Cornell, 22 to 5, yesterday in the Morningside Heights gymnasium. Cornell made its best showing in the foils division, where it won three of the nine bouts, with Merwin scoring over Menaker and Kellerman.

INEVITABLY Vaslav Nijinsky has become both a legend and an object of controversy. Legend and controversy, indeed, hovered about his name before the last sad curtain was rung down upon his brief and astounding career. He was the greatest dancer of his time and men call him -- perhaps truly -- the greatest dancer that ever lived.

THE first volume ever to be published in English of Lope de Vega's plays, translated by John Garrett Underhill, appears here 300 years after the famous Spanish playwright's death. It is an event which calls for the beating of drums and the blowing of trumpets, for its historical importance, for the skill and vigor of the translations and for the very modern temper of the genius thus tardily revealed.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 14. -- More than 200 Cornell University women students were told by leaders in several fields that exact knowledge of facts and their relationships to each other, plus the new opportunities for women in the attention paid them as consumers, are important factors in life today.

TORONTO, March 14. -- Since 1932 the mining industry of Canada has recovered more rapidly than any other industry in the Dominion, and its output last year is estimated to have been 20 to 25 per cent of the total primary production of the country, according to official statistics.

The report of the Arnold Constable Corporation and its subsidiary companies for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31, issued yesterday, showed a net profit of $221,641 after depreciation, Federal taxes and other deductions. The profit is equivalent to 66 cents each on 37,109 shares of $5-par capital stock outstanding.

NOVELTY dahlias, like new fashions, are often expensive. Every year scores of new varieties, most of them good ones, are offered to the gardening public. To the gardener who has never experienced the joy of growing a fairly complete collection of dahlias, there are available, however, many outstanding varieties which are no longer considered "novelties," but are judged on the basis of outstanding merit and growing quality.

OMAHA, March 13. -- Where Only recently had stood fields of sickly corn which yielded, for want of water, no more than half a crop and often nothing except fodder, there appeared within the past ten days big lakes, the handiwork of a thaw which melted the accumulation of heavy snows faster than ice- choked streams could carry it away.

GOSHEN, N.Y., March 14. -- Voters in the thirteen incorporated villages of Orange County will go to the polls Tuesday to elect Mayors, trustees and in some cases police justices. A quiet election is indicated.

THOUSANDS of letters have come to the Radio Garden Club since the experiment of "radio gardening" was initiated four years ago by the extension service of the New Jersey College of Agriculture at Rutgers University, New Brunswick.

Under an educational project of the WPA in cooperation with the Board of Education thousands of public school children are now acquiring a "cosmic appreciation" in astronomy courses before and after joining an ever-increasing student trek to the Hayden Planetarium.

Joan D.M. Hamilton, who resigned recently as counsel for the Republican National Committee to become manager of the campaign of Governor Alfred M. Landon of Kansas, for the Republican nomination for President, conferred yesterday with former Attorney General Albert Ottinger, chairman of the New York State Landon-for-President Committee.

THE city or suburban indoor gardener would seem to have enough plant enemies to contend with without being plagued by a relatively recent arrival, the White Fly (Trialeurodes Vaporiorum Westw.). But it is here, and apparently here to stay.

After describing many abuses discovered by the Sabath Congressional committee investigating bondholders' reorganization proceedings, Meyer Kraushaar, chief counsel of the committee in this city, asserted yesterday that the courts had been guilty of "politics" in referee and trustee appointments and that about a dozen law firms here monopolized reorganization litigation.

ALTHOUGH it will be news to many, Puerto Rico has its Philharmonic Orchestra, which to date has given six concerts in San Juan since the organization was founded four year ago. Agusto Rodriguez has been the conductor from the start.

PARIS, March 13. -- Deep down below all the official firmness of the French Government's demands, seconded by the whole press, that Germany be made to withdraw from the Rhineland before there are any negotiations for new treaties there is much less stable opinion than is perhaps claimed regarding the course that should be followed now.

FOUR-FIFTHS of this book may be described as common ground. In his own manner, most of these pages could have been written by Mr. H.G. Wells. It is the other fifth that makes all the difference. Mr. Wells -- however disillusioned he may be -- belongs to the twentieth century and none other.
ACADEMISM lifts its head with a jovial Spring grimace as, in the wake of last week's opening at the Museum of Modern Art, the town goes abstract on a scale that must be called rampant.
Postal authorities and detectives arrested eight men yesterday in raids on two offices and charged them with complicity in the sale of lottery tickets through the mails.
Answering criticism directed at the WPA by Park Commissioner Robert Moses, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday that he would permit nothing to interfere with relief for the city's unemployed.

RICHMOND, Va., March 14. -- Hugh Leach, formerly treasurer of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, has been appointed president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond for the term to end on Feb. 28, 1941, said an announcement authorized today by Frederic A. Delano, deputy chairman of the board and an uncle of President Roosevelt.

FOR the first time in the history of aeronautics the North Atlantic is to be spanned this Spring and Summer by an air service. Passengers, mail and express are to be carried on schedules which in frequency of departure will rival those of the best ocean liners.

Two hundred members of the Junior Inspectors Club of Greater New York, an organization of about 150,000 boys and girls enlisted by the Department of Sanitation, met in the University Settlement House 184 Eldridge Street, yesterday afternoon and established the first local unit of the club.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 14. -- Triumphing in the meet's concluding event, the third-place bout in the 175-pound division, Jack Harkness of Harvard today snapped Lehigh's five-year reign as the Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association champion and sent the coveted team laurels down to Penn State, which last held them more than a decade ago.

SIGNS in city parks and suburban dooryards nowadays point to a stunning overthrow of the Old Boreas regime in the United States in the very near future. Hints of deep discontent with the present control of affairs drift into town by grapevine telegraph from Long Island, Westchester, Connecticut and New Jersey. There is growing unrest everywhere.

PARIS, March 14. -- Some improvement in prices took place today in the trading on the Bourse. Rentes and French and foreign securities were all stronger than yesterday. This course of values was remarkable because of the weakness in Wall Street yesterday and the number of rumors that kept circulating in the market. The franc was steady.

A campaign waged for years by the railroads to abrogate the "long-and-short-haul" clause of the Interstate Commerce Law is about to reach a climax in Congress through introduction of the bill of Representative Pettengill of Indiana. The bill, which would repeal the clause, has received a preferred position on the House calendar.

The American public is growing increasingly conscious of its interest in and responsibility toward the maintenance of freedom of the air in radio broadcasting, it is stated in the annual report, made public yesterday, of William S. Paley as president of the Columbia Broadcasting Company.

A LITTLE over a hundred years ago a series of young Americans who were destined to acquire considerable distinction in their native country set sail for Europe. What they saw and learned there, especially in Germany, and what they did with their experiences and impressions after their return to America are the theme and content of this book.

The bill, which would repeal the clause, has received a preferred position on the House calendar.

ALBANY, March 15. -- Louis K. Comstock, president of the Merchants Association of New York, called upon the Cities Committee of the Senate tonight for favorable action on the Baldwin bill, which would repeal laws making mandatory the expenditure of sums by New York City for various purposes.

An unusually serious program of German lieder was interpreted by Emanuel List, the Metropolitan bass, at his recital in the Town Hall last night. Solemnity was the keynote of the schedule, of which at least half a dozen offerings might be characterized as sermons in song.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- The radio is consistently "scooping" diplomacy in making important announcements to the world, according to a statement today by the Short Wave Institute of America, Inc. Official broadcasing stations in Europe strongly compete with each other to reach the air first with their accounts of diplomatic developments, where formerly official communiques of the foreign offices used to be the first to reach the public.

PHILADELPHIA, March 15. -- For the fourth straight year, Neil Sullivan and Roy Coffin of Germantown won national squash racquets doubles championship today by defeating another Philadelphia team, Don Strachan and Brendan D. Walsh of the Country Club.

The Merchants Association announced yesterday its belief that action by Congress on all price-discrimination bills, basing-point bills, and bills to increase the power of the Federal Trade Commission should be deferred pending a comprehensive re-examination of the present anti-trust laws and the Federal Trade Commission Act.

LONDON, March 15.--Germany returned a heavily conditioned acceptance tonight to the invitation of the League of Nations Council to be represented at its meeting to discuss the Reich's sending of troops into the demilitarized Rhineland.
HARRISBURG, Pa., March 15. -Republican leaders feared today that the party's primary campaign in Pennsylvania would be marked by bitter fights over the State Treasurer and Auditor General posts.

John Doty, president of the Foundation Company of New York, Lady Hanbury and James Donahue are among the passengers due to arrive today on the North German Lloyd liner Europa. Others coming from the Channel ports and Bremen include Mrs. Avery Brundage, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Wood Johnson, Emil Winter, Dr. Juozas Leimanas, Dr. W.
