Gerlach, Michael Farmer, Wilhelm Kempff, Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Hornblower and Miss Marlene Stadtlaender.

AKRON, March 15 (AP). -- A new peace proposal was advanced tonight in an effort to settle the strike at the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company's plant as the city waited for its reopening after four weeks' idleness.

Efforts will be made by representatives of the La Guardia administration to speed the progress of transit unification negotiations, which will be renewed today at the second general conference called by the Transit Commission. The first conference was held about a month ago.

Barring the upward revision in the foreign currencies on Saturday which coincided with the possibility of a compromise of the political situation abroad following Germany's garrisoning of the Rhineland, the trend earlier in the week was decidedly downward. New minimum levels for the current movement were established, and in the case of the French franc that bill declined to the lowest since Jan. 23.

Despite the fact that the team was back at full strength for the first time in three weeks, victory again eluded the New York Rovers as the Red Shirts dropped a 5-2 decision to the fast-skating Atlantic City Sea Gulls in a Hershey Cup series fracas at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., March 15. -The Right Rev. William T. Man ning, Bishop of the Diocese of New York, visited St. Peter's Church parish here today and before an assemblage of more than 500 acted as celebrant in the service of institution of the Rev. Frank Clifford Leeming as rector of the parish.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Difficulties in the way of trying to sell to private investors bonds representing the war debts due this country were outlined by Secretary Morgenthau in a letter written to Senator Vandenberg and made public today.

MADRID, March 15. -- The Spanish Army gave what was tantamount to an ultimatum today to Premier Manuel Azana that unless the Left government adopts measures to end widespread violence it would take the maintenance of order into its own hands.

DETROIT, March 15 (AP). -- Father Charles E. Coughlin, defining the principles of his National Union for Social Justice as related to labor, urged the American laborer today to unite and organize, in trade or vertical unions, to seek a living annual wage, "a just share in the profits" and "a voice in determining the maximum hours" of work.

Mrs. Herbert MacGrey Hanscom will give a reception this afternoon at the Versailles for a group of young matrons and debutantes of recent seasons who are aiding in the plans for a luncheon entertainment and fashion show entitled "The Rise and Fall and Rise of Polly," to be held on March 28 at the restaurant for the benefit of Chi Kappa chapter of Stony Wold.

Communism is "the logical end of a 400-year-old experiment concerning liberty" in a world that has been gradually forgetting God, Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen, Professor of Fundamental Theology at the Catholic University of America, Washington, D.C., asserted yesterday in his third Lenten sermon at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
Nathan Straus states: "There are half a million families in old-law tenements in New York City which were condemned in 1900."
WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Tax collections far ahead of last year and well above budget estimates are expected by the Treasury from the first quarterly installments on 1935 incomes.

About 6 o'clock last night Big Dick Butler, former Assemblyman, who ruled the west side docks with iron hand for twenty years, thought it might be a good idea to find out which of his sons was dead -- young Dick or Joe, whom he always called "Big Fella."

Columbia, the new Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League champion, added victories over Yale and Cornell to its string during the week and completed its circuit schedule unbeaten as the regular college season came to a close.

The will to survive in the American Division of the National Hockey League impelled the New York Rangers to herculean efforts to defeat their city rivals, the Americans, in the teams' sixth and last meeting of the regular loop season at Madison Square Garden last night.

MINEOLA, N.Y., March 15. -- George Barkowicz, 17 years old, of 393 Hinsdale Avenue, Brooklyn, alleged to have been one of four occupants of a car with whom a policeman exchanged shots late last night, was captured today in the Bethpage State Park at Farmingdale.

An appeal to the public to support the demands for higher wages and improved working conditions made by 12,000 women employes of hotels, many of whom have answered the strike call of the Building Service Employes Union, was issued yesterday by the Women's Trade Union League.

A pistol duel at 2 o'clock yesterday morning outside a bar and grill at Blake and Atkins Avenues in Brooklyn ended in instant death for James Blasi, 31 years old, unemployed chauffeur of 705 Logan Street. His opponent, Patrolman Dionisio Pasquarella, 31 years old, six years on the force and attached to the Miller Avenue station in Brooklyn, died an hour later in Trinity Hospital.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $5,314,933,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

Reversing the usual practice of having delegates visit a convention, the United Drug Company has arranged to "bring the convention to the delegates," it was announced yesterday by Louis K. Liggett, president of the company. The company has leased a streamlined train which will start from Boston, where the company's headquarters are situated, on March 29, with Mr. Liggett aboard, to tour the country.

PARIS, March 14. -- The Bourse was fully aware of Chancellor Hitler's action in the Rhineland only last Monday, as contradictory news had been received on the Saturday before. The consequent decline was relatively moderate and not at any time like a panic.

Mrs. Raphael E. McCready of Hackensack and Mrs. Adele Rivero of Manhattan in Section A and Mrs. Mary Bain of Astoria in Section B again won in the eighth round yesterday to maintain their lead in the women's championships at the Marshall Chess Club with totals of 8--0.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Diplomatic correspondence published by the State Department today discloses that the United States after the armistice maintained that the Rhineland belonged to Germany and that this country resisted steadily French efforts which, it was convinced, were designed to place that area and the Ruhr under the permanent control of France.

Jackson Harmon Kearns, who was awaiting a hearing on a charge of using the mails to defraud in promoting a sweepstakes contest for the Knights of Columbus, ended his life by gas last night in his apartment at 155 East Fifty-second Street.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 15. -Five Tiger home runs, three of them in a row in one inning, were too great a handicap for the Dodgers, grapefruit league titleholders, today, and although they battled the world champions for eleven innings finally subsided on the short end of a 6-5 count before a crowd of 1,200.

MOSCOW, March 15. -- A higher standard of living among individual members of collective farms, as reflected in increased wages and increased consumption of food and manufactured goods, is shown in official figures published today by the newspaper Pravda.

CHICAGO, March 15. -- The world's grain markets are under the unsettling influence of the menacing political situation in Europe and uncertainty as to the outcome of this year's harvest. A large part of the speculation in futures is professional, and the disposition of most of these traders is to take advantage of the changes in prices on all the sharp and sudden declines and good upturns.

The second appearance this season of John Charles Thomas, baritone, in a recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon, brought out a large audience. The singer was greeted by barrages of applause provoked by his program. The recital was for the benefit of the Hartley House Music School.

MADISON, Wis., March 15 (AP). -WPA strikers holding siege to Wisconsin's Capitol cleaned the rugs and scrubbed the marble floors today, then threatened to call all WPA workers in the State to join them unless their demands were met.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 15. -- After nine weeks in the ice-bound state, sailing dinghies came back into their own today at the Larchmont Yacht Club with twenty-five boats in the competition.

BERLIN, March 15. -- The most unusual feature of the Reichstag election campaign in Germany from the American standpoint is the modest role the candidates have. Nobody has announced who the candidates are.

A house costing $5,000 to build in the New York area would cost $5,150 in Pittsburgh, $4,015 in Birmingham, ' Ale.; $4,915 in New Haven and $3,740 in Montreal, according to the 1936 edition of the Dow Service Cubic Foot Cost Standard Calculator.

Offering of a new issue of $7,178,500 of Central Illinois Light Company first and consolidated mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds due on April 1, 1966, will be made to the public today by a banking group headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc.

A reduction of tolls for the Holland Tunnel has been asked by the Chamber of Commerce of Hokoben, N.J., it was disclosed yesterday. Following a meeting of the board of directors of the chamber last Friday, John T. Soltmann, secretary, wrote the New York Port Authority urging authorization of a "substantial" reduction of tolls.

MIAMI, Fla., March 15. -- The Tropical Park grand stand, jammed to capacity yesterday by the largest crowd in the history of the course, will be extended and enlarged for the racing a year hence as the result of plans discussed over the week-end among Bill Dwyer and his colleagues.
ALBANY, March 15. -- Following is a tabulation showing how New York City members in the Legislature voted on important roll-calls last week:

Mrs. Thomas J. Watson will give a reception tomorrow afternoon at her home, 778 Park Avenue, for Mrs. Herbert Hoover, president of the Girl Scouts, and members of the board of directors of the organization who are in New York for the semi-annual meeting of the governing group to be held tomorrow and Wednesday at the national headquarters, 570 Lexington Avenue.

PITTSBURGH, March 15. -- Nation-wide production of steel ingots 1st week was estimated here at 57 per cent of capacity. For four successive weeks operations have risen bout one point a week. Last week's rate equaled that in the four weeks before the holidays, which with two small exceptions was the highest rate since June, 1930.

The New York chapter of the Dante Alighieri Society inaugurated the new auditorium of the Palazzo d'Italia in Rockefeller Center yesterday afternoon with a musicale and reception in honor of Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association.

The Rev. John Paul Jones, president of the Ministers Union of America, in a sermon in Brooklyn yesterday morning, warned against "the common and fatal tendency to identify the Kingdom of God with the social scheme beneficial in the main to the class in power."

FORT LEE, N.J., March 15. -- Fearing a demonstration by their ousted pastor and those of his flock favorable to him, members of the board of trustees of the Union Church of Palisade stood on the steps of their padlocked church and a policeman patrolled the street this morning during the regular time of worship.
Two Manhattan business property deals and housing transactions in that borough, the Bronx and Brooklyn were reported over the weekend.

Rutgers' triumph over Columbia on Tuesday in the Intercollegiate Swimming Association gave the Scarlet the swimming title and kept the new champion from dropping into a triple tie with Columbia and Penn. It was the first time in twelve years that Yale, which withdrew from the competition this season, did not win.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 15. (AP). -- Harlan Ingwalson, twenty-seven-year-old accountant from Rockford, Ill., pasted the pins for 264, 236 and 202, to take the lead in the singles event of the American bowling congress tonight with 702. The total also carried him into the lead of the all events, his nine-game aggregate being 1,880.

It was natural enough that last week's New York financial markets should have declined -- both because Europe's stock markets set the example in their own response to the movement of German troops into the Rhineland and because, after so prolonged rise, stocks were more vulnerable to a selling movement.

CHICAGO, March 15.--Supplies of pork in cold storage throughout the country have increased for the last four months. Stocks on March 1 were 451,800,000 pounds, an increase of 16,250,000 in February. A year ago stocks were 666,598,000 pounds. The five-year average for March 1 was 735,136,000 pounds.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., March 15. -- Every police officer in Nassau and Suffolk Counties joined Huntington police and State troopers today in a search for the hit-and-run driver who killed two schoolgirls on the Jericho Turnpike near Commack last evening and then sped off toward the city, leaving his victim sprawled by the roadside.

The total cost of the WPA, CWA and other work relief projects has been cheaper than one major riot would have been, Edmond B. Butler, secretary of the Emergency Relief Bureau, said yesterday at a symposium on "The Catholic Church and Labor,"

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 15. -- WPA workers have "muscled in" on Jerry Bailey, and the veteran lumberman of Doodletown, N.Y., admitted today that his profitable Spring coin "collecting" business has been ruined by the competition.

The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, which recently announced that it would return to the downtown area next May 1, has leased 27,000 square feet additional in the Westinghouse Building, 150 Broadway. This will supplement 108,000 square feet in the structure held by the firm under an existing lease.

German Memorial Day was observed yesterday morning at the Zion Lutheran Church, 339 East Eighty-fourth Street, where the Rev. Dr. William Popcke and guest speakers prayed that the peace of the world might not be endangered by European events.

What bids fair to be the heaviest week of the entire local art season comes with the turning of Winter into Spring. Including openings over the week-end, a round half hundred shows appear on the calendar, with a number of events of outstanding interest.

" LEIF the Lucky," son of ERIC, has at last reached the capital of the country whose shores he is believed to have seen, as "Vinland the Good," a thousand years ago. Just where this coast of inviting name was situate is not certainly known, but there is good reason for locating it somewhere in New England's range of latitude.

PARIS, March 15. -- The realization has come to Paris from yesterday's London meeting of the Locarno signatories and the League of Nations Council that a united front and united action against Germany are not going to be obtained.
GUYMON, Okla., March 15 (AP). -- A dust storm described in some places as "the worst since last April" struck today in parts of Oklahoma, Kansas, Colorado and New Mexico.

In an atmosphere bristling with tension, uncertainty and blue-coated guardians of the law, obviously prepared for anything, the Living Newspaper of the Federal WPA Theatre finally got its first edition "on the street," as it were, Saturday night with the showing of its synoptic dramatization of the American farm problem, 1920-1935, "Triple-A Plowed Under."

While cotton traders watched chiefly last week the government selling and progress of the new farm program, futures continued to hold to narrow price movements, with the net changes on the New York Cotton Exchange up 1 to 10 points.

BERLIN, March 15. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler's "last word" to the Council of the League of Nations was sent today. It stresses that Germany will not go to the meeting of the Council in London to discuss its reoccupation of the Rhineland unless France and Belgium and the other Locarno treaty powers promise to enter negotiations regarding Hitler's proposed non-aggression pacts.

MOSCOW, March 15. -- Slight, but very slight, progress toward settling the incidents on the Mongol-Manchukuo frontier was indicated tonight in the publication of an exchange of notes between the Mongolian People's Republic, which has close relations with the Soviet Union, and Manchukuo, which has close relations with Japan.

NEWARK, N.J., March 15. -- More than 125,000 spectators witnessed today the St. Patrick's parade, the first to be held here since 1892. John Haller, acting chief of police, estimated the number of marchers at 30,000.
PORTLAND, Me., March 15 (AP). -Six million tons of ice packed into twenty miles of the Penobscot River menaced Bangor tonight with flood, property damage and possible loss of life.

Conditions in the Virgin Islands are "definitely improving" and our future "is very, very hopeful," Governor Lawrence W. Cramer said in an address to 800 members and friends of the Federation of American Virgin Island Societies at St. Mark's Hall, 57 West 138th Street.

LONDON, March 14. -- The Economist's fortnightly index of British commodity prices, based on the average for 1927 as 100, stood at 70.8 on March 11, against 70.9 a fortnight before, 71.2 a month before and 60.4 on Sept 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

BERLIN, March 14. -- Whereas Chancellor Hitler's coup in the Rhineland was at first taken calmly by Germans and on Saturday of last week even induced an advance on the Boerse, the subsequent aggravation of the international situation has caused a feeling of confusion and discomfiture.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- The United States, with the greatest producing mechanism in the world, has failed to put it to work "chiefly because we were not permitted by the judiciary to work out our attempt to discover how this could be done," the American Federation of Labor asserted today in its current monthly survey of business.
WASHINGTON, March 15.--Some of the sparkle and fire which the public has missed in Congress since the present session began gave promise tonight of returning soon.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., March 15. -- One hundred and fifty-one Union College students who took part in sixteen varsity and freshman sports at Union College in 1935 and 1936 will receive certificates tomorrow night at the ninth annual Block U dinner in the alumni gymnasium.

CLEVELAND, March 15 (AP). -Colonel Leonard P. Ayres, economist and statistician, discussing President Roosevelt's proposed taxation of corporation earnings in a Cleveland Trust Company business bulletin, said today that "it seems clear that we should be threatened by disaster if we should enter another depression without any important accumulations of corporate surpluses."

A member of the April, 1935, grand jury of Kings County is related distantly to Meyer and Harry Luckman, it was reported yesterday. The Luckmans and Fred J. Hull are serving twenty years to life for second-degree murder in the death of Samuel Drukman, a case in which the April grand jury failed to find indictments.

BERLIN, March 14. -- In connection with the occupation of the Rhineland, the inevitable story was circulated that Minister of Economics Hjalmar Schacht's position as an alleged dissenter had been shaken. The banks, however, do not believe that Chancellor Hitler is able to dispense with him and that no German Minister would dare to resign to protest the Chancellor's policies.

NEW HAVEN, March 14. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 82.4, which compares with 82.8 the week before, 83.3 two weeks before, 83.8 three weeks before and 83.4 four weeks before.

Under the auspices of the directors of the Lots for Little Thrift Shop there will be a showing of sound motion pictures of mission work in India Wednesday afternoon at the Convent of the Sacred Heart, 1 East Ninety-first Street, for the benefit of the shop.

BERLIN, March 15. -- The note of Foreign Minister Constantin von Neurath of Germany to Joseph A. Avenol, Secretary General of the League of Nations, replying to the League Council's invitation to be represented at the Council's consideration of Franco-Belgian contentions that the Reich violated the Treaty of Locarno, follows:

The number of entries for twenty-four of the stake events to be run at Saratoga during the meeting in August was announced yesterday by the Saratoga Asosciation. While the total of 2,093 showed an increase over last year of only sixteen eligibles, there were twenty-one more nominators, some of them naming horses for the first time.

The Rev. Dr. Wallace John Gardner, vicar of the Chapel of the Intercession of the Trinity Parish, 115th Street and Broadway, announced to his congregation yesterday morning his acceptance of the post of Bishop Coadjutor of the Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey.

Back to Broadway on Saturday evening, in a two-day engagement which concluded last night, came the nucleus of that embattled company which earlier in the season worked to establish "Let Freedom Ring" in the unfriendly realm of commerce.

Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue and Forty-sixth Street, was the scene of busy preparation all day yesterday as the entrants in the twenty-third annual International Flower Show which opens at 2 P.M. today, put the finishing touches on their exhibits.

ADDIS ABABA, March 15. -- The mist is now beginning to clear on this side of the northern front. It is clear that the Italian claims that they have defeated the armies of Ras Kassa, Ras Seyoum and Ras Emerou are grossly exaggerated.

Miss Marion Lloyd, former women's champion, and John R. Huffman, national three-weapon titleholder, conquered Miss Dorothy Locke and Emil Goldstein, 3 to 1, to win the first mixed team foils tourney to be staged here on the strips of the Salle Santelli yesterday.

Irving Babbitt's last work, a translation from the Pali of "The Dhammapada," will be published by Oxford on April 16. Included in the volume is Professor Babbitt's essay entitled "Buddha and the Occident."

A two-week quest for a white Arabian horse with which it had been planned to revive an old custom in this year's St. Patrick's day parade struck its final snag yesterday when Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. announced that he would not ride one even if it were found.

ROME, March 15.--Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy, Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg of Austria and Premier Julius Goemboes of Hungary, who have linked their States in a semi-alliance and now are anxious over one another's conduct in a changing Europe, will meet here this week to try to re-establish their common point of view.
NEW ORLEANS, March 15. -- Trading in the cotton contract market lacked animation last week, although there were occasional spurts following war alarms in Europe.

Boardwalks along the coast from Atlantic City to Jones Beach became veritable Peacock Alleys yesterday for pre-Spring promenaders who took advantage of temperatures that rose during the afternoon to 61 degrees, one point below the record mark for the date.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- The functions of the Federal Trade Commission, if that body is continued, should be limited to those of investigation and prosecution and its judicial functions transferred to an independent commission, the Council for Industrial Progress said today in a report made public by Coordinator George L. Berry, following its submission to President Roosevelt.

Three members of Columbia's undefeated championship array gained places on the all-Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League team picked for The Associated Press by the seven league coaches yesterday.

The battle between the Park Department and the WPA over the red, white and blue posters designed for identification of WPA projects in the city's parks ended peacefully and without casualty yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- About $2,000,000,000 has been spent on nearly 16,500 Public Works Administration projects and another $2,000,000,000 will be spent on permanent public improvements on which men are now at work, statisticians reported today to Administrator Ickes.

Financing of $6,000,000, whereby the Sharon Steel Corporation will be able to redeem an issue of firstmortgage 5 1/2 per cent bonds of its predecessor company, the Sharon Steel Hoop Company, will be undertaken today by a banking group headed by Speyer Co. and Hemphill, Noyes Co.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, March 15. -- Thousands of workers from other Brazilian States now tilling and picking in Sao Paulo's thriving cotton fields faced a possibility today of losing their jobs.

The wholesale dry goods industry centering on lower Broadway and the lower east side was partly crippled yesterday by a strike called by the Wholesale Dry Goods Employes Union, Local 19,932. The strike, the third to be called on a Sunday in recent months, was ordered by the union in a dispute over minimum wages and maximum hours of employment.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 15 (AP). -- The United States men's table tennis team finished third in its group in the international competition today after defeating Belgium, 5 to 1, in its final match. The Americans trailed Austria, which will play Rumania for the title, and Czechoslovakia.

Net income of the Eastern Gas and Fuel Associates and subsidiaries amounted to $2,873,974 in 1935 after all prior deductions, a decrease of $1,261,036 from 1934, the annual report shows. Funded debt was reduced $1,139,895 and bank loans were reduced $522,000.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 15. -- Serge Mdivani, one of the three Mdivani brothers who attained world-wide notice through their marriages to American heiresses and movie stars, was killed this afternoon in a fall from his polo pony during a match in the Southeastern polo championship at the Gulf Stream Field near Delray Beach, about ten miles south of here.
The Federal Government is the source of all or part of the income of 11,120,925 persons, the National Industrial Conference Board estimated in a bulletin issued yesterday.

Rugby made its seasonal bow yesterday with one of the hardest fought contests ever seen in this vicinity, the Long Island University and French Rugby Club squads battling to a 3-all deadlock at Van Cortlandt Park.

Canon Bernard Iddings Bell of St. John's Cathedral, Providence, R.I., preaching yesterday in the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration, Twenty-ninth Street east of Fifth Avenue, declared that extreme Anglo-Catholics who urged all non-Roman Catholics and all Protestants to "throw themselves on the mercy of the Pope" were advocating a remedy "too absurdly simple for the cure of a complex and partly emotional disunity."

The New Dance League last night presented its second annual recital devoted to "Men in the Dance" at the Majestic Theatre, and attracted its usual large and enthusiastic audience. The program was probably a record for miscellaneousness.

Yesterday's gravure section of THE TIMES had a pageful of highly successful murals from the children's ward in the new psychiatric pavilion at Bellevue Hospital. It is reasonable to assume that the doctors had something to say about the kind of pictures that go into a children's room, especially nervous children.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 15. -- Two of the pre-tournament favorites -- the teams of Gene Sarazen of Brookfield Center, Conn., and Mally Reynolds of Jacksonville and Henry Picard of Hershey, Pa., and Jack Cummins of New York -- won stirring thirty-six-hole semifinal matches in the second annual national amateur-professional best-ball match play golf championship today.

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 15. -The Giants' 1936 Spring training activities came to a positive standstill today when, for the third successive afternoon, the Indians not only polished off our gallant athletes but this time achieved their end with a decisive shut-out.

Breaking 97 out of 100 targets, P. Garino, a Class A gunner, won the high-over-all cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. In the handicap competition the Class A winner was E.B. Horwath, the Class B honors going to W.W. Peabody, who defeated J. Pulido in a shoot-off.

The release of a heavy volume of orders for all types of women's ready-to-wear featured trade activity in the wholesale markets here last week, with indications that delivery delays will be frequent, as many manufacturers were unprepared to meet the large demand.

LONDON, March 15. -- The British appeal for 1,000,000 to assist the expatriation of German Jews was launched today at a public meeting in the Dorchester Hotel attended by leaders of the Jewish community of this country.

PARIS, March 14. -- The money market here is much tighter. In fact, the Bank of France is the only leader among the banks desiring to keep funds liquid because of the public's tendency to hoard notes and gold coins.

A judgment for $50,046, filed in Supreme Court in favor of Hagop Kevorkian, collector of Mohammedan art objects, against Asfar Sarkis, dealers in Islamic art objects at Damascus, Syria, has disclosed an unusual litigation over the importation of the interiors of two historic houses in Damascus.
The prize predicament in big game hunting is supposed to be having hold of a tiger by the tail. Hanging on does not lead to anything and letting go might be worse.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 15. -- A spirited training session lasting close to three hours in a temperature of 82 degrees supplanted the scheduled second exhibition game between the Yankees and the Boston Bees today. The torrential downpour of yesterday rendered Waterfront Park so muddy that playing the game was impossible.

Arturo Toscanini will conduct a special post-season farewell concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society, at his own suggestion. The concert will be for the benefit of the men in the orchestra, for the personnel of Carnegie Hall, with whom he has been associated for eleven years; for the unemployed musicians and for funds of the society.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 15 (AP). -- Some records of a new radio meter, invented at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to trace the preference of radio audiences, were made public here today.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Addresses today by Louis J. Moss of Brooklyn and Dr. Max Arzt of Scranton at the biennial convention of the United Synagogue of America contrasted social justice in America with prejudice and persecution abroad, and urged American Jewry to rally to the support of true democracy here.

It turns out to be Gilbert Miller who will present "Boy Meets Girl" next June in London. George Abbott, its producer and director here, will go over to stage it, or rather, the staging probably will begin in this country, for the troupe will be cast in New York, save for an English player or two.

Acceptance of the settlement recommended by the Mayor's Board of Survey ends the building service strike in the right way. It was out of question to grant the demand for a closed shop and a monopoly of labor in an industry in which uninterrupted service is essential to the life of the community.

Mr. and Mrs. Oliver David Donaldson received yesterday at Gray-Dawn, their home in Sutton Manor, New Rochelle, in honor of Mrs. Donaldson's brother, Major Clifton E. Hickok, Assistant Public Works Administrator of California.
When a great people is facing a great decision, any citizen may properly consider how that decision can best be made. That is the purpose of this letter.

MADRID, March 15. -- For the first time in the history of Spain the "Internationale" was sung by Socialists and Communists who stood with upraised fists this evening in the Cortes, which was convetted into a lepublican Parliament in 1931.

Elevator operators and other building service employes in approximately 2,500 buildings will return to their jobs this morning as a result of the settlement of their strike reached early yesterday through the mediation of Mayor La Guardia's board of survey headed by Pelham St. George Bissell, President Justice of the Municipal Court.
Lieutenant Daniel Doyle of the Arsenal station in Central Park made a contribution yesterday to the technique of crime detection. Like all great contributions, it sprang from necessity.

The opera concert at the Metropolitan Opera House last night included two "scenes intimes." One of these was the quartet from the second act of "Martha," sung by Josephine Antoine. Helen Oelheim, Joseph Bentonelli and Virgilio Lazzari.

OKLAHOMA CITY, March 15 (AP). -- Vigorous declarations that "no one controls me," were answers today of James Veasey, Tulsa oil official, and W.G. Skelly, Republican National Committeeman, to Senator Borah. The Idaho Senator had charged that the "Standard Oil Company" sought to influence the selection of Oklahoma delegates to the Republican National Convention.

IT was Farmer Bill Brown of the revered boxing commission who started it. He was riding away from the Garden in his chariot, heading for his Garrison acres and Guernsey cattle. He was recalling old days and how he had refereed the first fight that Frank Moran, the heavyweight of the open tonneau era, had in this vicinity.

The expert fly fisherman knows that correct manipulation of the lure in the water, to stimulate as closely as possible the movement of the natural insect, often is of greater importance in the catching of trout than the selection of the fly itself.

TRENTON, N.J., March 15. -- After three unsuccessful attempts had been made in the Assembly at a daybreak session this morning to pass a Luxury Tax Bill to obtain funds for emergency relief, a bill previously passed by the Senate to use $3,000,000 of highway money was approved and signed immediately by Governor Hoffman.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., March 15 (AP). -- Officials of three churches outlined the relationship of Scouting and religious and spiritual progress of man today at the sixth annual National Training Conference of the Boy Scouts of America.
WASHINGTON, March 15. -- The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress last week are given in the following tabulation:

TRENTON, N.J., March 15. -- After three unsuccessful attempts had been made in the Assembly at a daybreak session this morning to pass a Luxury Tax Bill to obtain funds for emergency relief, a bill previously passed by the Senate to use $3,000,000 of highway money was approved and signed immediately by Governor Hoffman.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., March 15 (AP). -- Officials of three churches outlined the relationship of Scouting and religious and spiritual progress of man today at the sixth annual National Training Conference of the Boy Scouts of America.
DUBLIN, March 15. -- The past year was one of peace and ordered progress in the Irish Free State.

Somewhat firmer prices resulted from fairly active backing and filling in local commodity futures markets last week, with sugar, rubber, hides and coffee higher on balance, while wool tops, silk, cocoa and cottonseed oil showed slight losses. In the cash markets wheat, lard, pork, cotton, hides, rubber, lead and refined sugar advanced, while corn, rye, dairy products, wool tops, tin, silk, coffee and cocoa declined.

The immediate enactment of a shipping bill, the administrative details of which can be worked out by the government and the ship lines, was urged yesterday by James W. Ryan, admiralty attorney, of 99 John Street.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- The belief that hydroelectric generation is an important factor in bringing about lower rates for electric energy is not entirely confirmed by its findings, the Federal Power Commission said today in an additional report on the electric rate survey which it has undertaken at the direction of Congress.

CHICAGO, March 15. -- Speculative and cash interest in oats still is limited and the volume of business continues light and the price fluctuations are narrow. Prices last week closed 3/8 to 3/4 cent net lower, with the three futures at the close in a 1/4-cent range.

Letters appealing to more than 150,000 Republican voters in the First Congressional District to repudiate the party's Old Guard leadership by voting for Borah delegates and alternates to the Republican National Convention were mailed yesterday.

If the present move by Germany is an act to wring greater consideration for her rights to equality and treatment on a common level with the rest of the world, then her move isn't so bad, but if she actually intends to use force, then her move is very bad.

Letters appealing to more than 150,000 Republican voters in the First Congressional District to repudiate the party's Old Guard leadership by voting for Borah delegates and alternates to the Republican National Convention were mailed yesterday.

If the present move by Germany is an act to wring greater consideration for her rights to equality and treatment on a common level with the rest of the world, then her move isn't so bad, but if she actually intends to use force, then her move is very bad.
ALBANY, March 15. -- The Democratic leadership in the Legislature revealed tonight plans for an attack on the Republican cuts in Governor Lehman's budget.

There are only fifteen pictures of city scenes among the 278 paintings in the 111th annual exhibition of the National Academy of Design, at 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, which will be opened to the public on Wednesday. Guy Wiggins is the only one of the artists submitting paintings of the city who is a member of the academy.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., March 15 (AP). -- His leg broken in a skiing accident, A.P. Kellogg, 30 years old, of Schenectady, lay nearly fifteen hours in the woods north of here while men and dogs battled deep snow to rescue him.

Consolidated net earnings of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., for 1935, after taxes and a deduction of $2,900,000 for premiums paid and unamortized discount on retired bonds, are estimated at $22,500,000 by John A. Brown, president, in a letter to stockholders.

There appeared in the press recently the report of an address by Victor Ridder in which he is quoted as denouncing Communist agitators in the WPA and saying that "by meeting their demands" he would be "guilty of discrimination" since they represented such a small proportion of the workers.

CLEVELAND , March 15. -- The special for the best in the show at the twentieth annual exhibition of the Western Reserve Kennel Club, which closed tonight, was won by a Sealyham terrier, Ch. St. Margaret Magnificent of Clairedale, owned by Clairedale Kennels of Riverhead, L. I., and handled by Leonard Brumby.

MEXICO, D.F., March 15. -- In his broadcast last night President Lazaro Cardenas took direct issue with almost every argument in the memorial addressed to him by banking, industrial and commercial interests as a protest against the government's economic program, which they say is so advanced that they have fears for the nation's economic stability.

You have done a wonderful service to those seeking an understanding of the European situation by publishing in full Chancellor Hitler's speech to the Reichstag and his memorandum to the powers declaring Germany's conviction that the Locarno treaty has been scrapped by France's alliance with Soviet Russia.

LONDON, March 15. -- Paul Robeson appeared tonight in the role of the Haitian liberator in the Stage Society's Sunday night performance of "Toussaint L'Ouverture," a first play by a young West Indian Negro, C.L.R. James.

America is restrained by both policy and reason from taking part in the critical issue which has been raised by Germany's resumption of the right to extend military authority over her Rhineland; but America is deeply interested in a permanent solution of this issue.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 15. -- The Puerto Rico Railway, Light and Power Company, which has an investment of $7,000,000 here and supplies electricity to approximately half the island, is seeking an injunction to stop the carrying out of the rural electrification project of the Federally financed reconstruction plan.
WASHINGTON, March 15. -- A navy submarine has been detailed to carry a group of scientists on a 6,500-mile undersea quest for the cause of earthquakes and volcanic disturbances in the Caribbean.

In a report of its activities, the Grayson M.P. Murphy protective committee for Kreuger Toll Company 5 per cent secured debentures announces it has elaborated jointly with the Colby committee a plan to create an agency to bid for the collateral securing the debentures, in foreclosure proceedings, which will be submitted to debenture holders in the near future.

Following is the text of the settlement agreement between the Realty Advisory Board and the Building Service Employes Union under which the strike was terminated and the men ordered to return to work forthwith:

ST. ANTON AM ARLBERG, Austria, March 15 (AP). -- Austrian skiers took the honors in both the men's and women's events of the two-day Kandahar skiing tournament which ended today as American entries failed to place among the leaders.

LONDON, March 13. -- The markets here are wholly dominated by the European uncertainties following on Germany's reoccupation of the Rhineland. At first the fall in security values was more an expression of uncertainty than of pessimism, but as the week advanced and events unfolded the real gravity of the situation received a clear recognition.
The danger of war in Europe provided the topic for many sermons in the city's churches yesterday.

The United States Steel Corporation has written down the value of its plants and property to an extent which has reduced its fixed property investment account by $287,620,923, according to the thirty-fourth annual report made public for today by Myron C. Taylor, chairman.

It was BURKE, if we remember aright, who said that the world is governed by go-betweens. That saying doubtless alluded to men, not nations. It had reference, probably, to some of the great historic compromises wrought in England by men behind the scenes, who were mediators between extremists of either party.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., March 16. -- "Larger Than Life" is the title of Crosby Gaige's new play, which opened in Court Square Theatre here tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission appeared determined today to require establishment of a sinking fund by the Louisville Nashville Railroad in connection with its proposed sale of $9,292,000 of first and refunding 4 per cent mortgage bonds, Series D.

BOSTON, March 16. -- The Amoskeag Company, by a vote of its trustees, will be able to cooperate in the reorganization of its operating affiliate, the Amoskeag Manufacturing Company, so as to leave the latter with adequate working capital, provided other bondholders adopt a similar attitude.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP). -- The Supreme Court adjourned today until March 30 without announcing a ruling on the governments anti-trust suit against the Sugar Institute. Only two opinions were delivered.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 16. -- Mr. and Mrs. C. Warren Bowring Jr. of New York were the guests of Miss Margaret Bowring of Barbados, B. W. I., at a party given at the Hamilton Hotel today.

RICHMOND, Va., March 16. -- Governor Peery, State Treasurer A.B. Cathright, Attorney General A.P. Staples and Charles R. Burnett, a banker here, are in New York City today conferring with bankers there relative to refinancing the State's $11,750,000 of Century bonds.

The statement of the Chase National Bank as of March 4, 1936, in response to a call by the Controller of the Currency and made public yesterday, showed a decline in all items except investments in United States Government securities.

TOKYO, March 16. -- Koki Hirota's appointment as Premier from the Foreign Ministry and Tsuneo Matsudaira's elevation to Imperial Household Minister from the London Embassy involve extensive changes in Japan's diplomatic service.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- When the President this week submits his new relief budget it will be scrutinized more carefully than any similar document in the past. Democratic politicians will look first for the totals, hoping they will be low enough for campaign defense purposes, yet not too low to make trouble for them among the municipalities and relief beneficiaries in their districts.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Secretary Ickes told the biennial convention of the United Synagogue of America tonight that the Roosevelt administration had made and was making "sincere efforts to mitigate and correct the destructive and ruinous forces that had secured control of the government."

Redemptions by public utility companies were a feature last week of announcements of bonds called for payment before maturity. Both as to actual calls and other proposed retirement, this industry was the leader.

THE baseball magnates have been overlooking or studiously ignoring a little matter brought up by Dizzy Dean in the thick of his salary argument with those hard-hearted capitalists, Singing Sam Breadon and Vestryman Branch Rickey.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 16. Concluding four days of brilliant golf, Gene Sarazen, former United States and British open title holder, and Mally Reynolds of Jacksonville were carried to 39 holes today to win the final of the second annual national professional-amateur best-ball match play championship from Henry Picard, metropolitan open king, and Jack Cummins of New York on St. Augustine Links.

CHICAGO, March 16. -- Hogs were in good demand from local interests and shippers here today and prices were steady to 10 cents a hundredweight higher. The top price was lifted 10 cents to $10.85 while the day's average of $10.35 was 5 cents above the level on Friday.

Former Magistrate Henry M.R. Goodman, counsel to the American Confidential Bureau, Inc., 605 Fifth Avenue, said yesterday at a hearing before Abraham S. Wechsler, deputy chief of the State Division of Licenses, that real estate owners owed his client about $30,000 in salaries of strike-breakers.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Presidents of the Federal Reserve Banks met with the Federal Reserve Board today for the first time since the reorganization of the system. Discussions, according to spokesmen for Marriner S. Eccles, governor of the board, were devoted to internal matters of the Reserve System and did not involve questions of policy.

A man and a woman, arrested Saturday night in Miami, were indicted here yesterday on charges of compulsory prostitution by the extraordinary grand jury inquiring into rackets and vice in New York County. Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor, immediately prepared extradition papers.

MADRID, March 16. -- The President signed today a decree providing for the revision of all proceedings by which Jesuit property was to be returned to the Society of Jesus. All orders authorizing the return were suspended for re-examination.

Phil Baker, Norwalk, Conn., boxer, was awarded a draw with Baby Arizmendi, recognized in New York as the world's featherweight champion, in their ten-round meeting at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

LONDON, March 16. -- Britain ought never to worry over the size of the United States Navy, the House of Commons was told today by Winston Churchill, who directed the destinies of the British fleet during the critical years of the World War.
The New York Stock Exchange yesterday approved the listing of certificates of deposit for $7,500,000 of 7 1/2 per cent bonds, due Sept. 1, 1937, of the Eastern Cuba Sugar Corporation.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- States which have legalized the sale of liquor since national prohibition repeal received a net income of $161,445,808.95 in the last year from license fees and excise taxes, according to figures of J.M. Doran, executive director of the Distilled Spirits Institute.
Yesterday's prize-winners in classes of the Garden Club of America were:

"The Fields Beyond," which had murmured of reopening tonight at the Mansfield after a week's vacation, will definitely not do so. It will rest, if that is the word, on its record of three performances on March 6 and 7. . . . On the other hand, A.H. Woods now says that "Night of January 16" will continue indefinitely in this town.

Embers of the bitter controversy between the administration forces of the Actors Equity Association and the members of the dissolved Actors Forum group flared briefly yesterday afternoon as 709 Equity members met at the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- A one-day "strike," or "feminine day of rest," would play havoc with the normal pursuits of men and would demonstrate that women have a place in industry, Miss Charl Ormond Williams, president of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Club, said today in a radio address.

Plans of six-story apartment houses for University and Nelson Avenues, to cost respectively $175,000 and $60,000, were filed in the Bronx yesterday. A $225,000 brewery improvement project was submitted in Manhattan, nineteen new dwellings were listed for a Brooklyn section and Queens projects included a $105,000 dwelling group for Bellerose.

LONDON, March 16. -- The League of Nations Council after a five-hour fight tonight notified Chancellor Adolf Hitler of Germany of its assent to the first of the two conditions with which he qualified his acceptance of the Council's invitation to be represented in London for consideration of his military re-occupation of the Rhineland in violation of the Locarno treaty.

The unbeaten Thomas Jefferson High School basketball team captured the Division 1 laurels in the Brooklyn section of the P.S.A.L. race when it defeated Alexander Hamilton, its closest rival, 25 to 22, in the Jefferson gymnasium yesterday.

Dr. Charles W. Depping, surgeon, has leased from plans two apartments in the Rockefeller apartment house to be built at 17-23 West Fifty-fourth Street. William A. White Sons were the brokers. Dr. Depping, formerly in a demolished building on the site, now has an office in 13 West Fifty-fourth Street.

A more detailed study of costs, research to classify the many new types of waste materials developed each year, and an improvement in business ethics were urged upon members of the National Association of Waste Material Dealers at the opening yesterday of their three-day annual convention at the Hotel Astor.

An improvement in the status of the Port of New York Authority's transportation facilities and an upward trend in the market for its securities were reported yesterday in the fifteenth annual report of the Authority commissioners, submitted to the Governors and Legislatures of New York and New Jersey.

The board of trustees of the New York Medical College and Flower Hospital has authorized the immediate construction of a new medical college behind the present Flower Fifth Avenue Hospital between 105th and 106th Streets, Dr. Claude A. Burrett, dean and director of the college, announced last night at a dinner of the college's alumni association at the Hotel St. Moritz.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Instructions were sent by the State Department today to Findley Howard, United States Minister at Asuncion, to deliver to Colonel Rafael Franco, Provisional President of Paraguay, a formal letter from President Roosevelt suggesting the desirability of an inter-American peace conference at Buenos Aires.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 16 (AP). -- Booster teams returned to competition in the American Bowling Congress tournament tonight when sixty-four quintets from Indianapolis and thirty-two from Columbus, Ind., entertained the spectators.
ALBANY, March 16. -- Speaker Ives warned Assembly committee chairmen at the close of tonight's session to report as many bills as possible this week "because adjournment may come almost any day."

OTTAWA, March 16 (Canadian Press). -- Exports to the United States increased $6,500,000 in February, the second month of the Canadian-American Trade Treaty, Finance Minister Dunning told the House of Commons today.

MONTREAL, March 16 (Canadian Press). -- Sweeney Schriner's lead in the race for point-making honors was threatened tonight as the National Hockey League entered its last week of campaigning. Paul Thompson of Chicago climbed to within 3 points of the New York American star's 42 in the past week when he earned two assists to bring his total to 39.

PHILADELPHIA, March 16. -- Formation of a protective committee for holders of the Autocar Company's cumulative 8 per cent preferred stock was announced here today. This action was taken after the annual stockholders' meeting on Friday, at which time a merger and reorganization plan was submitted.

Officers and workers of the Volunteers of America gathered yesterday morning at their headquarters, 34 West Twenty-eighth Street, to pay tribute to General and Mrs. Ballington Boo, who have commanded the organization since they founded it forty years ago.

The Metropolitan Water District of California has issued a call for bids for a new issue of $11,808,000 of bonds, award of which will be made on April 10. The bonds will be dated May 1, 1936, and mature on May 1, 1951 to 1986. Bankers have been asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 5 per cent.
Better times for both the taxpayer and the tax collector were indicated last night as the deadline for the Federal income levy found payments running substantially above those of last year.

BOSTON, March 16 (AP). -- Rainfall raised new fears in flood-scourged Maine tonight just as the State was emerging from a five-day onslaught of ice and water that cost one life and caused property damage of millions of dollars.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Seeking safeguards for the revenue possibilities of President Roosevelt's proposed tax on undistributed profits of corporations, the Ways and Means subcommittee on taxation virtually decided today to require domestic companies to collect and return to the Treasury the equivalent of individual income and surtax levies on dividends distributed to foreign stockholders.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., reported yesterday for 1935 a net profit of $26,086,527 after all charges, including provision of $4,602,324 for taxes and $6,278,493 for depreciation, depletion and other purposes. After disbursement of $1,933,898 for preferred dividends, there remained $24,152.628, equal to $1.65 each on 14,584,025 shares of common stock.

TRENTON, March 16. -- The officials who prosecuted Bruno Richard Hauptmann and Governor Harold G. Hoffman, who does not believe Hauptmann's conviction satisfactorily solved the Lindbergh case, were at odds today over the examination of Dr. John F. Condon, ransom negotiator, who will return to New York tomorrow from a Panama vacation.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 16. -- The Cardinals without the Dean brothers were not noticeably weakened today, so far as Casey Stengel could observe. In fact he would much have preferred the absence of Spud Davis, the catcher's lusty bat swinging against the Dodgers having much to do with the 9-3 victory the Frischmen registered over the visitors from Clearwater.

The 1935 Gold Medal of Fellowship, for distinguished service, will be awarded to Owen D. Young at the annual dinner of the Society of Arts and Sciences at the Waldorf-Astoria on April 22. Announcement of Mr. Young's selection as recipient of the award was made yesterday by the society.

Stocking of Connecticut streams in preparation for the opening of the trout fishing season on April 15 will begin this week, the State Board of Fisheries and Game announced yesterday. With country roads in southern sections becoming passable for the board's specially equipped tank trucks, the first plantings will be made in New London, Middlesex, New Haven and Fairchild Counties.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- When the Panama-Pacific steamship California docks in New York on Wednesday officers of the International Seamen's Union will confer with the crew, accused by Secretary Roper of "mutiny" in delaying the ship's departure from San Pedro with demands of wage and hour adjustments.

TORONTO, March 16 (Canadian Press). -- Ontario's mineral production in 1935, valued at $159,044,887, reached a new high record, the Provincial Department of Mines announced tonight in a preliminary report. Production in 1934 was valued at $145,854,173.

At the hearing on the Long Island Railroad's application for an increase in commutation rates, before representatives of the Public Service and Transit Commissions yesterday morning, Parker McCollester, the railroad's special counsel, began a defense of the voluminous exhibit indicating the railroad's properties, exclusive of land, were worth $138,401,095 on Dec. 31, 1934.

MEXICO, D.F., March 16. -- Forty-five foreign insurance companies handling all lines except life insurance went out of business today following an announcement by the Finance Ministry that they had not complied with the new insurance law.

AKRON, March 16. -- An undercurrent of tenseness prevailed here tonight as strikers and members of a "law and order league" awaited an expected move by the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company to reopen plants closed four weeks ago.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 16. -- Eighteen Princeton teams, competing in eight sports, will engage in 133 contests during the Spring season, according to the schedule announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics.

Stockholders of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York voted yesterday by 7,836,658 shares to 758 to change the name of the company to Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and re-elected their trustees by 7,751,161 votes, with no opposing ballots.

ALBANY, March 16. -- The State Unemployment Insurance Law was held unconstitutional in an opinion by Supreme Court Justice Pierce H. Russell today. He ruled that the law violated the due process clause of the Constitution.

The Music Lovers Foundation will be the beneficiary of a concert this afternoon in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The artists will be Giovanni Martinelli, Miss Editha Fleischer, Richard Bonelli and Emanuel List, all of the Metropolitan Opera; Alexander Siloti, pianist; Miss Grete Stueckgold, soprano, and Efrem Zimbalist, violinist.
WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Eleven questions framed by the government to find out how much its citizens know were presented tonight on a radio program sponsored by the Federal Office of Education.

The statement of Sterling National Bank and Trust Company as of March 4 shows deposits of $20,396,893, compared with $20,223,463 on Dec. 31, 1935. Total resources of the bank rose from $23,254,148 at the end of the year to $23,565,636. Cash on hand and due from banks showed a decrease to $4,523,765 on March 4, against $5,896,661 on Dec. 31.

MOSCOW, March 16. -- Serious breakdowns in the Stakhanoff speeding-up movement in Soviet industry, including its abandonment in many lines, caused Communist party and government leaders to demand today that it be revived and strengthened.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Possibility of an early break in the negotiations between the Railway Labor Executives Association and the management committee headed by H.A. Enochs was indicated today following the adjournment until tomorrow of the joint conference.

MANCHESTER, N.H., March 16 (AP). -- The Rockingham Park race track at Salem, which introduced parti-mutuel betting to New England in 1933, became the property of the New Hampshire Jockey Club today. Ralph W. Davis of Manchester, club clerk, announced.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Seeking to have the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 declared constitutional, Burco, Inc., carried to the Supreme Court today the first request for that body to pass on the act.

ROME, March 16. -- The decided stand taken by France in London is believed here again to have brought the general European situation to a delicate stage. The increasing intransigeance on both sides of the Rhine is thought to have reduced the possibilities of a settlement by negotiation of the Franco-German controversy almost to the vanishing point.

OTTAWA, March 16. -- The announcement today by Premier Aberhart of his plan for compulsory conversion of Alberta's $160,000,000 public debt is regarded in Ottawa official circles as cutting the painter which has hitherto linked the Dominion and Alberta credit.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP). -- Reports filed with the House indicated today that working for political organizations has become one of the capital's most lucrative professions.

DENVER, March 16 (AP). -- A rousing finishing drive by Brooklyn College fell short tonight and the Easterners were eliminated by Denver University, 45 -- 40, in an A.A.U. basketball tourney second-round game.

CHICAGO, March 16. -- Prices of wheat declined from the start on the Board of Trade today as a result of the more favorable political news from abroad and continued weakness in Liverpool. At no time was there an active interest in the market, and sales in the aggregate were regarded as the smallest in some time.

Members of the Service Club of St. Thomas Church have arranged a card party and tea in aid of the Church Mission of Help, to take place the afternoon of April 14 in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria. Plans for the party will be completed this afternoon, when members of the benefit committee headed by Mrs. M. Wheeler Stewart meet at St. Thomas Parish House, 1 West Fifty-third Street.

Handicapped by the ice cakes in the river, the Columbia varsity and freshman crews went through an extended drill on the Harlem yesterday. While speed was out of the question due to the necessary roundabout courses, the oarsmen did get some real rowing on several half-mile stretches of open water.

A home should cost between two and two and a half times the yearly income of the person for whom it is built. Mrs. Bert Hendrickson, chairman of the American home department of the New York Federation of Women's Clubs, told a group of women at the exhibition of residential architecture now being shown at McCutcheon's, Fifth Avenue and Forty-ninth Street, yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, March 16. -- Primo Carnera, former world's heavyweight champion, was battered into defeat by Leroy Haynes, formerly of Los Angeles, in the third round of a scheduled ten-rounder at the Arena tonight.

PARIS, March 16 (By Wireless). -- For the benefit of those readers who are daily bombarded with innumerable and confusing messages concerning the details of the London negotiations, I should like to explain clearly a situation that seems to me perfectly simple.

The "baroque-moderne" furnishings and fixtures of the Central Park Casino, its kitchen equipment, its glassware, the cash register reading "$33.40 waiter service" and even the exhaust fan on the roof were sold at auction yesterday, realizing for the trustee in liquidation of the Dieppe Corporation, Frederick H. Cunningham, the "very fair sum" of $7,255.

Picturesque garden spots as far apart in time and space as Marie Antoinette's ill-fated playground at Le Petit Trianon and a modern natural woodland scene in Westchester attracted more than 27,000 visitors yesterday to the opening of New York's annual flower show.

An exhibition of sculpture by Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney will open today at the Knoedler Galleries, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street, to continue until March 28. This is Mrs. Whitney's first one-man show in twelve years, the last previous display having been held in January, 1923, at Wildenstein's.

Now that Herr Furtwaengler's withdrawal as musical director of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society has successfully settled an issue that threatened to imperil its future, it becomes the responsibility of all music lovers, subscribers and citizens who know the value of this institution to support it with even more loyalty than ever before.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- The general principles of a Federal housing program, to include aid for the construction of low-cost housing and for clum clearance, as well as machinery for the acceleration of private building, have been agreed on, Stewart McDonald, Federal Housing Administrator, revealed today after a White House conference.

The recent decision of the New York Court of Appeals by a divided court -- 4 to 3 -- holding the Minimum Fair Wage Law of 1933 unconstitutional in so far as it affects women is so important in its consequences that it should be reviewed by the Supreme Court as soon as practicable.

TIENTSIN, China, March 16. -- If the Chinese Communists who recently invaded and occupied important areas of Western Shansi Province attempt to enlarge the territory under their control, Japan must necessarily take steps to prevent such expansion, Major Gen. Hayao Tada, commander of the Japanese garrisons in North China, said today.

With a crowd of 5,000 looking on, the New York Rovers were defeated for the second time in as many days on their home ice as they bowed to the Baltimore Orioles, 2 -- 0, in the main attraction on the hockey program at Madison Square Garden last night.

VIENNA, March 16. -- Calm but determined defiance of the present Fascist regime in Austria and vigorous demands for the restoration of rights to Socialists characterized the opening session today of the mass trial of thirty persons accused of high treason in the establishment of an underground Socialist movement in the nation.

Although the average of fifty representative stocks was almost a point lower yesterday than on Saturday, the market had its bright spots. The number of issues that advanced, 308, were almost as large as the number of those that declined, 361.

Maxwell Brandon, counsel to common stockholders of the National Surety Company, announced unexpectedly in the Supreme Court yesterday a proposal to reorganize the successor organization, the National Surety Corporation, for the benefit of the stockholders and creditors.

In a letter printed on this page yesterday, former Governor PINCHOT offered an analysis of the Presidential election of 1932, and a forecast of the one of the present year. In his opinion it was the flocking of Progressive Republicans to ROOSEVELT four years ago that elected him.

Because its income is insufficient to meet current expenses, the Authors Club filed suit in Supreme Court yesterday for permission to use part of a fund of more than $250,000 established with the aid of Andrew Carnegie for the relief of literary men and women and their families.

Current developments in Spring merchandising have greatly improved the prospects for Summer lines, according to resident buying office executives here. All indications, they said yesterday, point to an active Easter season which will swing naturally into brisk promotions of Summer goods without any serious letdown.

With the shade of the shamrock the color of the day and with the incidental misfortunes which the weather man may see fit to visit upon the city to the contrary notwithstanding, St. Patrick's Day will be the cause of city-wide celebration today.

Mrs. Herbert Hoover, president of the Girl Scouts, arrived here yesterday morning to attend the semi-annual meeting of the board of directors of the organization. She took part during the afternoon in a national broadcast in which she praised the Scouts' "atmosphere of friendliness" and emphasized the aim of acquainting the younger generation of girls with the achievements of earlier generations.

Gilbert Miller and J.J. Shubert, theatrical producers, are among the passengers due today from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria. Also on the ship are Sir Arthur Salter, Archibald Forbes Jr., Captain J.M. Cobbold, Miss Helen Jerome, Mr. and Mrs. R.S. Clark, Mary Carlisle, actress; Mrs. David H. McAlpin, Mr. and Mrs. G.R. Nicholson, Mrs. E.J. Waring and Louis Lipsky, national co-chairman of the United Palestine Appeal.

HAMILTON, N.Y., March 16. -- Colgate University students, in a model national Republican convention tonight "nominated" Governor Landon of Kansas for President on the third ballot, with Senator Vandenburgh runner-up in the voting.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Senator Borah denied today that he had charged that the Standard Oil Company was behind the candidacy of Governor Landon. In a telegram to the publisher of The Wichita Beacon, who today challenged him to prove that the oil interests were supporting the Kansas Governor, the Senator suggested that the publisher owes Governor Landon an apology "for your blundering defense."

Steel operations this week will average 60 per cent of capacity, or 4.2 points more than last week's rate of 55.8 per cent, according to computations by the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday. This is the highest rate for the industry since the Summer of 1930.
WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Applications for approval of plans for financing were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by two corporations. The amount involved exceeded $40,000,000.

It was refreshing to read in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of March 8 an article by Charles G. Poore which, to my mind, is the best and most comprehensive diagnosis of these recent evidences of psychoses among so-called artists.

CHICAGO, March 16. -- Deposits decreased slightly, loans and discounts expanded a little and cash resources were cut somewhat sharply in banks here during the first two months of 1936. The figures were disclosed today in response to State and national bank calls.

WARSAW, March 16. -- Despite repeated promises of better treatment of the Polish minority in Germany, Poles in the Reich will not be able to participate in the coming Reichstag election as a separate group with their own candidates, it was learned here today.

BERLIN, March 16. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler's acceptance of the League of Nations Council decision in the Locarno treaty dispute was foreshadowed here tonight by a government official who said Germany "probably" would send representatives to London.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- A call for the condition of national and State member banks of the Federal Reserve System as of March 4 was issued today by J.F.T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, and Marriner S. Eccles, Governor of the Federal Reserve Board.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- President Roosevelt made it clear today that he would hold relief costs for the next fiscal year to a minimum, when he refused to agree with Congressional representations that the Civilian Conservation Corps should receive sufficient work relief funds to maintain that body at its present strength of 380,000, instead of reducing it to 300,000 next year.

MANCHESTER, England, March 16 (AP). -- A jobless Briton was jailed today after the police said he admitted attempting to extort 200 by an offer to disclose a kidnapping plot against the 3-weeks-old son of Countess Barbara Haugwitz-Reventlow.

Remembering JOHN KNOX, the school in every parish, the successive generations of lads starting from the countryside to the university, each with a bag of meal on his back, the long and beautiful tradition of education in Scotland, we felt pretty sour last year when Mr. GEORGE BLAKE, patted on the back by Mr. ERIC LINKLATER, told us that "sometimes indeed Scotland seems the "happy hunting ground of the imper-"fectly educated."
WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Secretary Perkins appealed today to both sides in the strike at the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company's plants at Akron to resume negotiations for an amicable adjustment.
Paul Moss, License Commissioner, ordered the closing of thirty pin-game establishments yesterday and notified forty others to remove illegal features before tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Stewart McDonald, Federal Housing Administrator, disclosed before a banking subcommittee of the Senate today plans for a 30 per cent reduction in the payroll of the hous ing administration, effective April 1, and tapering off of loan insurance for home modernization and improvements.

Local Democratic leaders were much interested yesterday in the report that Governor Herbert H. Lehman on his recent visit to President Roosevelt at the White House had agreed tentatively to run for re-election. The report caused no surprise, as it has been assumed for some time that the Governor would comply with a request from the President to run again.

A check for $1,253,773.40, covering a gift tax, was among the day's receipts yesterday at the office of the Collector of Internal Revenue, 271 Washington Street, Brooklyn. Officials in charge of tabulations of income taxes declined to reveal the identity of a woman who had sent in the money with a return on a gift of about $3,000,000 or that of the recipient of the gift.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Financial rehabilitation of small enterprises which are "responsible for slightly more than half of existing unemployment" could be made possible by long-term RFC credits, according to a report to President Roosevelt today by the Council for Industrial Progress.

ALBANY, March 16. -- A double attack on the financial policies of the Lehman administration was the answer of the Republicans tonight to Governor Lehman's criticism of the Republican Assembly for "postponing" an appropriation of $11,160,000 for debt service until next year to enable them to balance the budget with $15,000,000 in gasoline taxes cut out of the revenues.

With the WPA Theatre Project already in one Red scare, it was faced last evening with the beginning of another. For the report ran around Broadway that "Class of '29," to be done next month at the Manhattan Theatre, would wave at least one Red flag, poke fun at the WPA itself, and was in general a sop to Moscow.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 16. -- Fragments of the meteor believed responsible for the brilliant light display seen over New York and New Jersey Saturday morning were reported found in at least four sections of New Jersey today.

Tests in arithmetic given to 20,925 children of 5A Grade have led city school officials to conclude that the "additive" method of teaching subtraction, officially approved here since 1915, is inferior to the traditional "take away" method.

Mrs. Edward Prime gave a dinner last night at the Beekman for Lieutenant and Mrs. Joseph Haskell. Other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Lewis L. Delafield, Mr. and Mrs. Washington Dodge 2d, Mr. and Mrs. John Haskell, William Hoffman Benjamin, Oliver Wells and Charles A. Richards.
WASHINGTON, March 16. -- An effort to force a grant for the Florida ship canal held up the War Department Appropriation Bill all day in the Senate, with opponents of the proposal keeping the floor.

The money market yesterday had one of its periodic heavy turnovers due to cash payments on the new issues of Treasury bonds and notes, payments by the Treasury on maturing obligations, and Federal income and gift tax payments. The turnover for this city was estimated at $1,000,000,000, and the total for the entire country at about $2,500,000,000.

On Jan. 6 Senator Frederick Van Nuys of Indiana introduced a resolution for a Senate investigation of the lynchings which occurred in 1935 following the Senate filibuster against the Costigan-Wagner bill, with particular reference to the action or lack of action on the part of the various States to prevent these lynchings or to punish the lynchers.
Two physicians and two nurses, taking turns, breathed for more than one hour and a half into the throat of an unconscious man early yesterday morning in North Hudson (N.J.) Hospital to save his life.
Additional investment purchases of housing in Manhattan and the Bronx were reported yesterday.
LONDON, March 16 (AP). -- The Divorce Court granted Edmund Owen Fearnley Whittingstall a decree nisi today against the former Eileen Bennett, international tennis player. The suit was not defended.
SAN JUAN, P.R., March 16. -- Governor Blanton Winship will not be a witness at the murder trial of Dionisio Pearson.

Advising sales executives to study closely the promotional and sales technique used by both major political parties in the coming Presidential campaign, Percy C. Magnus, president of the New York Board of Trade, told the Sales Executives Club of New York Inc., at their weekly luncheon meeting in the Hotel Roosevelt that in the next eight months "we are going to witness one of the most extensive sales campaigns this country has ever experienced."

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- A story of how six members of Congress and an alleged lobbyist for railway and utility interests shared a semi-suburban house in Washington last Summer and how as many as forty of "the boys" were wont to forgather in the cool of the evening and discuss the issues of the day was told today before the Senate Lobby Committee.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- A "true cross section" of forty-four industries surveyed at the suggestion of President Roosevelt on changes in labor and trade practice standards was found to have adhered substantially to former NRA Code standards as to labor provisions and fair-trade practices.

Louis Philips, renter of the four-story brick house at 1,492 Bushwick Avenue, Brooklyn, where Federal agents last week arrested Edward Wilhelm Bentz, bank robber, who was smoked out of hiding by teargas bombs, confessed yesterday, according to the police, that he had taken part in ten burglaries of homes in Nassau County.

NEWARK, N.J., March 16. -- Glenn Cunningham and Joe Mangan tried to re-enact their slow waltz manoeuver of the Columbian Mile tonight in the 1,500 meter run that featured the annual Newark A.C. indoor games before a capacity crowd of 5,000 at the Newark Armory.

There is no better resolve with which to of begin St. Patrick's Day or any other day than The Rune of St. Patrick, which runs, as put into rhythmic and rhyming English -- substituting for Tara the place in which one finds one's self in daily struggles with personal "powers of darkness" whatever form they may take in their expression:

TRENTON, N.J., March 16. -- While the Assembly tonight took one step in its quest for $19,000,000 more to finance emergency relief during the balance of this year, the Senate transacted routine business and then adjourned for the week on a day-to-day basis that will enable it to convene at any time its presence may be needed.

Net income of the Northwestern Bell Telephone Company for 1935 amounted to $5,283,398, compared with $4,825,697 in the preceding year, and surplus after dividends, at the same rate for both years, was $1,171,346, against $713,645. Gross revenue, less uncollectibles, was $30,141,782, compared with $28,732,001.

An immediate war will no doubt be averted in Europe, despite the crisis occasioned by Germany's military occupation of the Rhineland, but the underlying threat of German action will remain to trouble world peace, Viscount Cecil of Chelwood, president of the League of Nations Union, said yesterday in an international broadcast from London.

MIAMI, Fla., March 16. -- Showers that began falling yesterday left the Tropical Park racing strip sloppy today, but there was a fairly hard bottom beneath the surface. The going just suited Vote Boy, a 4-year-old gelding by Torchilla and Voterina which carried the silks of T.F. Swords to a driving triumph in the featured Pahokee Handicap.

Two new links of the city's independent subway system will be opened at midnight on Wednesday, April 8, the Board of Transportation announced yesterday. Power will be turned on in the third rails this week for test operations.
