BERLIN, March 16. -- The Reich Government tonight was inclined to appraise today's action by the Leagu of Nations Council at London as something in the nature of an advance skirmish, and competent Foreign Office spokesmen assumed that the Council had not yet definitely disposed of the decisive point advanced in the German reply.

The dense fog that came down at noon yesterday and blanketed the entrance to the harbor from Fire Island to Quarantine interfered with navigation of ships entering and leaving the port and forced Captain Scharf to anchor the North German Lloyd liner Europa a mile outside the entrance to the Ambrose Channel at 4 P.M., where she remained for the night with 779 passengers on board.

Catherine Reiner, Hungarian soprano, who had not appeared in recital here since 1932, returned in a program at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. She devoted her efforts chiefly to songs in German by Brahms, Schumann, Schubert, Wolf, Alban Berg and Strauss.

Coincident with the announcement of the addition of twelve well-known publicists and educators to its advisory staff, the recently formed Institute of Public Relations issued a "pronouncement of policy" yesterday. Two of these policies were a belief in paid advertising to do a merchandising or promotion job and a belief in guarding the integrity of news and broadcast matter.

Yvon Robert, promising young Canadian grappler, last night threw the veteran Ernie Dusek of Omaha in 57:07 in the finish bout of a wrestling show at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory. The victor weighed 218, ten pounds less than his opponent.

BERLIN, March 16 (AP). -- Dr. Ernst Hanfstaengl, Harvard graduate, who is Chancellor Adolf Hitler's foreign press chief, again entered the lists today against Dr. James Bryant Conant, president of Harvard.

James E. Finegan, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, announced last night that his department had given its first non-competitive examination for a major city position to Max Jacob Wolff, candidate for legal assistant to the City Court.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Arrangements have been made for elimination from the banking system of at least 100 uneconomic banks which are insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, it was disclosed today when Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the corporation, asked Congress to extend until July 1, 1938, the period in which the corporation may act through consolidations and mergers to strengthen the banking situation and protect itself against undue losses.
BERLIN, March 16 (AP). -- The Reich turned to the State Department of the United States today for backing in its remilitarization of the Rhineland.

MADRID, March 16. -- Two country estates owned by President Niceto Alcala Zamora were raided today by Communist farm laborers, who confiscated the crops and divided his land, according to unconfirmed reports.

HAVANA, March 16. -- President-elect Miguel Mariano Gomez left tonight aboard the steamship Quirigua of the United Fruit Line for Panama and the United States to rest after his arduous campaign and post-election labors. He will return about May 1 for his inauguration May 20.
The Park Department will inaugurate a new system of currying the parks today, using a specially designed vacuum cleaner instead of the old laborious hand method.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Delay in starting the new soil conservation program was threatened tonight because of a Senate-House conference tie-up over a supply bill carrying the $440,000,000 appropriation for farm relief.

LONDON, March 16. -- The text of a resolution concerning Germany's violation of the Locarno treaty laid before the League of Nations Council tonight by France and Belgium and the text of the telegram sent by Joseph A. Avenol, League Secretary General, to the German Foreign Minister follow:
Your editorial, "Rentals for Paintings" is well meaning but misses the main point.

As a result of the stronger market for spot cotton on Saturday, the pool selling limit for March contract was raised 5 points on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. Prices held within a narrow range and ended 5 points higher to 1 point lower.

While elevator operators and other service employes returned to work yesterday morning in the great majority of the 2,500 buildings affected by the strike of the Building Service Employes Union, which ended in a compromise settlement early Sunday morning, approximately 1,500 strikers in 372 buildings, according to police estimates, found themselves locked out by owners.

J.P. Morgan Co. have canceled all reductions in salaries of employes which were put into effect in the depression, it was learned yesterday, and in addition have made a general increase, raising the salary levels above those paid in 1929.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 16. -- President Will Harridge and Secretary Henry P. Edwards of the American League today saw a Yankee Yannigan uprising that laid low the Ruppert Regulars on Huggins Field.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Spurred by an official report that "a substantial increase in the acreage of crops is to be expected this year," Farm Administration officials are hard at work to whip the son conservation program into shape by the end of the week to prevent a return to normal plantings.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

LONDON, March 16. -- The stock markets here appeared today to have recovered from their recent spell of nervousness over the European crisis. Buying was hesitant at the opening, but in the afternoon there was sudden improvement in the atmosphere.

Isidor Achron, pianist, appeared in recital at the Town Hall last night. His program included Bach-Liszt's Prelude and Fugue in A minor, two preludes and fugues from Bach's "Well-Tempered Clavichord," Beethoven's Sonata, Op. 2, No. 1; a nocturne, two mazurkas and a ballade by Chopin, and a concluding group by Shostakovich, Debussy, Ravel and Liszt.

With the battle of posters settled amicably yesterday morning at a City Hall conference called by Mayor La Guardia, Victor F. Ridder, local WPA Administrator, moved to speed plans for a reduction of 40,000 in WPA rolls by June 30, as ordered by Washington.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 16. -- Amado was the setting tonight for a dinner given by Charles A. Munn, followed by moving pictures.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on March 11 shows increases for the week of $120,000,000 in total loans and investments, $75,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and $21,000,000 in time deposits, and decreases of $91,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and $41,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks.

Once again the gardeners hold the key to the city. Their annual show -- the International Flower Show at Grand Central Palace -- which opened its doors yesterday afternoon to the largest number of visitors ever to throng the aisles on a first day, is a spectacle which rather staggers the imagination.

A fast-moving and active day in the investigation of bribery charges following the murder of Samuel Drukman ended yesterday with the indictment by the Brooklyn extraordinary grand jury of Henry G. Singer, former Assistant United States Attorney.

Appointment of a fashion promotion committee was authorized last night as a part of a comprehensive program of coordinated activity adopted by the Medium Price Coat Associates at a meeting held at the Hotel New Yorker. Thirty-three firms, members of the Industrial Council of Coat, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., and the Merchants Ladies Garment Association, are participating in the stabilization efforts.

In the belief that toys and playthings help to keep youngsters from resorting to petty stealing to satisfy their spirit of fun, The Toyery, Inc., an organization founded to establish "lending libraries" of toys for the poor children of the city, began a drive yesterday for $20,000 with which to continue its work.

IF a four-hour autobiographical monologue by an introvert can ever be any good, then G.B. Stern's "Monogram" (Macmillan, $2.50) is good. This is a time when print has failed to mute the living voice of the author. Every page brings Miss Stern herself into the room, talking, talking, talking. She talks some wit and some nonsense and, now and then, some wisdom.
A biography of Mordecai M. Noah, a figure in New York literary life a hundred years ago, will be published soon by the Jewish Publication Society of America. The author is Isaac M. Goldberg.

OKLAHOMA CITY, March 16 (AP). -- Oklahoma's twenty-one votes at the Republican National Convention will be cast as a unit for Governor Landon of Kansas for President. The Republican State convention invoked the unit rule here tonight as the climax of a session dominated by supporters of the Kansas Executive.

ALBANY, March 16. -- Avowing the urgent need of $30,000,000 to $48,000,000 additional to insure adequate unemployment relief in the coming fiscal year, Assemblyman James J. Wadsworth demanded tonight that Governor Lehman confer with legislative leaders on a program to meet the needs of the situation.

The security and commodity markets failed to make much progress yesterday. Stocks moved narrowly throughout and closed steady, with leading issues showing minor irregularities for the most part. On the Stock Exchange trading was the smallest for a full day since Jan. 21, when light dealings were influenced by the closing of the British markets out of respect to the late George V.

LONDON, March 16. -- The appointment of a Cabinet Minister for broadcasting was recommended tonight by Viscount Ullswater's committee of inquiry in a report urging that the government renew the charter of the British Broadcasting Corporation for another ten years.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 16. -- The Yorkshire County team concluded its cricket tour of Jamaica today with a draw against the Colonials as their five-day test was concluded. This was the second draw of the three-game set, the tourists having taken the opener, which caused Jamaica to lose a series for the first time in ten years.

Most commodity futures were lower yesterday in moderate trading on the local markets. Silk, tins and sugar were firmer. On the cash markets cotton, butter, eggs, wooltops and tins were firmer, and all the grains, lard, pork, Santos coffee and rubber declined.

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 16. -- Thrashed three days hand-running by the Indians, the Giants this afternoon strove desperately to inspire a winning touch at somebody's expense and finally succeeded in catching up with a victim.

FRANKFURT-AM-MAIN, Germany, March 16. -- Although what was to be the first big military parade here in twenty-two years was suddenly called off on Saturday, preparations for today's celebration of the first anniversary of the restoration of Germany's military sovereignty were in no way impaired by this temporary disappointment.

The statement of the National City Bank of New York as of March 4 shows deposits of $1,650,147,302, against $1,652,366,244 on Dec. 31, 1935. Total resources were $1,878,129,542, against $1,880,680,000. Cash on hand and due from banks and bankers amounted to $484,647,497, against $527,491,424.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 16. -- Salvatore Amoroso, a barber, of 239 Main Street, paid a minimum fine of $5 in City Court this morning for working on the Sabbath. The customer, in whose interest Amoroso defied the local blue laws, got only half a shave.

STOCKHOLM, March 16. -- A demented lawyer fired a volley of shots in a Swedish court room today, killing two persons and then committing suicide. The hearing of a divorce suit against a workman, Georg Andersson, was proceeding in a civil court at Nykoeping in Southern Sweden when a former disbarred lawyer, A.R. Willen, entered the court room, went up to the judge's bench, whipped out of his pockets two revolvers and started firing.

Trading in bonds yesterday was the dullest since Sept. 23, last year, with an atmosphere of "watchful waiting" as prices drifted within unusually narrow limits. Transactions on the New York Stock Exchange amounted to only $7,480,700, as compared with $14,473,900 on last Friday.
Chester A. Alberts has formed the firm of C.A. Alberts Co. at 70 Wall Street to deal in over-the-counter securities.

FRANKFURT-AM-MAIN, Germany, March 16. -- Adolf Hitler told a Nazi election meeting tonight that "no might in the world" could overcome the national desire for German sovereignty as his listeners roared approval to a suggestion to "bury the hatchet with France."

PRINCETON, N.J., March 16. -- In an attempt to laugh out of existence what they term "fallacies in the American scheme of government," such as the Bonus Bill, Townsendism and other evidences of the "weaknesses of Democracy," a national organization, to be known as the Veterans of Future Wars, has been formed here by Princeton University students.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 16. -- Bryan M. Grant Jr. of Atlanta, the defending champion, gained an easy victory today in the first round of the seventeenth annual Bermuda title tennis tournament, defeating Reggie Cooper, young Bermuda star, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4.

The Maritime Association announced yesterday that it had filed a protest with the House Committee on Military Affairs against the proposal to extend the bulkhead lines of Governors Island into deep water and establish a municipal airplane landing field on the island.

LONDON, March 17. -- A renewed appeal for an air treaty among European powers was voiced in the House of Commons today by Sir Philip Sassoon, Under-Secretary for Air, in introducing the largest military aviation estimates since the World War.

BERLIN, March 17. -- The Boerse today was again decidedly inactive but firm. Heavy industrials showed advances, Harpener gaining 1 1/2 points, Hoesch 1 1/8, and Mannesmann 1. Potash stocks were, as usual, stagnant. The machine list was mixed and unstable, but Muag rose one-half point.
ALBANY, March 17. -- Following is the prevailing opinion of the Court of Appeals upholding the constitutionality of the Housing, Authority Act, as written by Judge Leonard C. Crouch: ...

Today is the ninety-ninth anniversary of the birth of GROVER CLEVELAND, the twenty-second and twenty-fourth President of the United States -- the only President to be called back to the Presidency after an intermission of four years. There is no formal celebration of the anniversary, but there are plans afoot looking toward a national observance of his centenary next year.

COLOGNE, Germany, March 17. -- General Hermann Goering, the Air Minister, came to Cologne today on a campaign trip worked up to celebrate the restoration of this old Rhenish capital to the position it had occupied since the times of the Roman Emperor Claudius as the bridgehead of the Rhineland defense system.

The American Federation of Labor alleges that there was a 14 per cent increase of production in 1935 with only a 3 per cent increase in workers' buying power. "The end of the NRA," it laments, "was followed by signifi"cant gains in profits, losses to work"ers."

Put to flight after two bottles of champagne had been hurled at him, a would-be robber in a wine and liquor store at 1,108 Park Avenue, between Eighty-ninth and Ninetieth Streets, disappeared last night in a fashionable fifteen-story apartment house at the southeast corner of Ninety-first Street and Madison Avenue.

Price movements of commodity futures on the local exchanges continued mixed yesterday, with declines prevailing. A few staples advanced, with trading moderate throughout. On the cash markets cotton and corn were higher, while wheat, rye, oats, cocoa, eggs, lard, rubber and standard tin declined.

Dr. John F. Condon, who returned home yesterday from a Panama vacation trip, told fellow-passengers on the Grace liner Santa Inez that he had no intention of going to New Jersey to submit to the questioning of Governor Harold G. Hoffman, but would be glad to receive the Governor in his home in the Bronx.

Representatives of sixty-one States sat in a room overlooking a mountain lake in Switzerland in 1932. The occasion was the First World Disarmament Conference. There was a man there by the name of Arthur Henderson. He believed in that queer dream known as disarmament.

The Associated Press lost yesterday the first round in its court battle to enjoin the National Labor Relations Board from interfering with its business by investigating charges of unfair labor practice filed against it by the American Newspaper Guild under terms of the Wagner-Connery act.
DUBLIN, March 17. -- All over Ireland the national festival was observed today, with traditional religious fervor in the morning and with holiday activities in the afternoon.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,808,350 barrels, compared with 2,758,650 in the preceding week, a rise of 49,700, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A gain of 41,550 barrels in Oklahoma was the most important change.

The presidents of the country's four largest passenger-carrying railways will meet here tomorrow in an effort to reconcile conflicting views as to how to bring down passenger tariffs in the East. A reduction in the basic passenger fare is described as a certain result of the meeting, but its exact amount will depend on the outcome of the negotiations.
BERLIN, March 17 (AP). -- The Reichsbank statement as of March 14 shows the following changes from a week before, in reichsmark:

Philip W. Barber, regional director of the Federal Theatre Project, denied yesterday that there was communistic propaganda in "Triple-A Plowed Under," current offering of the "Living Newspaper," or in "Class of '29," scheduled for production by the popular-price unit at the Manhattan Theatre.

Because of continued "lockouts" of former building service strikers and difficulties in adjusting the question of their reinstatement by owners, Mayor La Guardia intervened again last night after James J. Bambrick, president of the Building Service Employes Union, had charged that the lockouts were in flagrant violation of the agreement under which the strike was settled.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., March 17. -- Clark Williams of Greenwich, Conn., New York banker, will entertain a Williams College faculty group for ten days during the Spring vacation at his plantation, the Cedars and the Pines, at Camden, S.C. Mr. Williams was graduated from the college in 1892.

Louis Bouche, whose one-man show has just opened at Kraushaar's, 680 Fifth Avenue, offers salient contrast to scores of exhibitors in the Academy annual, which did its traditional "varnishing" yesterday.

SHANGHAI, March 17. -- Fundamental Chino-Japanese issues cannot be settled until after internal Chinese differences are adjusted, in the opinion of Major Gen. Iwane Matsui, who is returning to Japan after conferences with the leaders of the southern provinces and of Nanking.

PHILADELPHIA, March 17. -- "A prelude to Spring" fashion show will be presented by Mrs. Francis V. Gowen's toy committee for the international garden party of the Philadelphia League of Women Voters in the planet room of the Bellevue Stratford on Friday.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 17. -- Favorites again came through with flying colors today as the Bermuda tennis championships continued on the courts of the Green Stadium before a large holiday crowd. The play was handicapped somewhat by high winds.
HORNELL, N.Y., March 17. -- Candles were pressed into service here tonight when falling limbs snapped power lines throughout the city during a sleetstorm.

Construction contracts of all types last month totaled $142,050,200 in the thirty-seven States east of the Rocky Mountains, the F.W. Dodge Corporation reported yesterday. The total was about 90 per cent larger than that recorded for February, 1935.

The Faddis bill, controlling exports of tinplate scrap, is only the beginning of restrictive legislation in the commodity field, Charles P. Hull, head of the company that bears his name, warned members of the Secondary Metal Institute, a division of the National Association of Waste Material Dealers, in annual convention at the Hotel Astor yesterday.

Houses doing government business released March contracts in the opening and closing trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and, whereas later months lost 7 points, the spot position had a gain of 2 points.

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 17. -- Hank Leiber and a high gale hit this town at once, and if the arrival of the former yielded nothing definite, the wind blast certainly did. It lashed the Giants into something of a wild fury as they ripped into the unsuspecting Atlanta Crackers today and flattened Eddie Moore's team by a score of 27 to 7.

Miss Maribel Y. Vinson, women's national figure skating champion, returned from Europe yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria and paid compliments to her opponents in the Winter Olympics at Garmisch-Partenkirchen.
ROME, March 17. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler's acceptance of the invitation to send a German delegation to the League of Nations discussions in London has been well received in Rome.

Heads up, in a gusty wind that tore at banners, plug hats, kilts and ribbons, 40,000 Irish men and women put on a brave show yesterday in a three-hour St. Patrick's Day parade from Forty-fourth Street to 110th Street in Fifth Avenue while 500,000 cheered.

What has France got in return for the evacuation of the Rhineland; for the collapse of her money which followed the war and the effort at restoration; for the release of America's frozen credits in Germany; for the cancellation of all but the smallest fraction of her claims to reparations; for the voluntary reduction of her armed forces?
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., March 17 (AP) -- New names and totals appeared tonight among the five high shooters in the all events following a check of scores in the American Bowling Congress office
It is the sad duty of this department to report that the ingenious fellows whose business it is to think up new fishing gadgets are lying down on the job.

The repaying of Eighth Avenue on the section between Abingdon Square and West Twenty-third Street, where the abandoned trolley tracks have been removed and a concrete base laid by WPA workers, will be started this morning by regular city forces under the jurisdiction of Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan.

Battisto Salvo, former policy banker, who has been in jail since last October, when he was arrested as a material witness in his own kidnapping, received an indeterminate sentence yesterday from Judge James M. Barrett in Bronx County Court for obstructing justice by refusing to help round up the kidnappers.

LOS ANGELES, March 17. -- Discovery of a new "super-nova" star of enormous proportions in the constellation Virgo was revealed today by Dr. Edwin P. Hubble, astronomer at the Mount Wilson Observatory.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 17. -- A sorry St. Patrick's Day this was for the Yankees, indeed. High winds and the Cardinals overtook Joe McCarthy's athletes simultaneously and sent them crashing down to defeat in their first exhibition game of the year at Waterfront Park.
Apartment house deals by operators featured the Bronx realty transactions reported yesterday.

Service on the four-track main line of the Pennsylvania Railroad to the west was halted by floods, and trains were routed over the tracks of other companies. Service from Washington to New York was also rerouted.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- Every day the House subcommittee delves into the tax proposals new problems appear, for some of which there do not seem to be any satisfactory solutions. How to levy on the dividends paid to foreign investors is one of them.

Lewis Brooks of Philadelphia took the lead in his national amateur pocket billiard challenge match with Edward Rogers of Glen Cove, L.I., the titleholder, last night, when he defeated Rogers, 129 to 95, in the opening session of their three-block contest at the Strand Academy.

Stern Brothers and subsidiaries reported yesterday a net income of $37,935 for the year ended on Jan. 31, after expenses, depreciation, Federal taxes, interest, provision for claims and contingencies and other charges. This was equivalent to $2.47 a share on 15,366 shares of $4 class A stock.

New spirit entered the bond market yesterday as prices advanced over a broad front in more active trading. Virtually all classes of bonds on the New York Stock Exchange participated in the upswing, which lifted the combined price average for domestic corporate issues 0.37 point and foreign dollar loans 0.34 point on the day.

WASHINGTON, March 17.--After a final conference with Democratic Congressional leaders tonight, President Roosevelt completed work on a message to be sent to the Capitol tomorrow on the financing of work relief through the next fiscal year beginning July 1.

Instead of balmy zephyrs when Spring arrives officially Friday at 1:58 P.M., there may be snow on the ground. Yesterday's gusty winds will continue today, accompanied by colder weather and rain, possibly changing to snow.
A downtown move by a drug concern, and expansion leases necessitated by increasing trade were among the business-space items reported yesterday.

The round robin program which will decide the city P.S.A.L. high school basketball champion was approved yesterday at the monthly meeting of the high school games committee at the Hotel Astor. The competition will get under way on Saturday and will be concluded two weeks later with the team winning the most games being declared the title winner.

Stanley Hummel, young American pianist, who several seasons ago achieved distinction as a sonata player with his brother Earle, violinist, made his first appearance of the season in a recital last night at the Town Hall. A highly responsive audience greeted the pianist.

NEW ORLEANS, March 17. -- Biff, a 5-year-old gelding which seldom finishes out of the money, came through with another victory today when he won the one-mile Alexander Milne Handicap at the Fair Grounds.

CARMEL, N.Y., March 17. -- Heavy voting marked the election in the three villages in Putnam County today. In Brewster the Republican candidates for trustees, Alfred Dahm and John E. Pugsley, were elected. Four hundred and sixty of the 750 voters cast ballots. The results were: Republican, Dahm, 300; Pugsley, 268; Democrat, Ross, 198; Maher, 158.

NYACK, N.Y., March 17. -- William P. Haring Jr., former Mayor of the village of Piermont, who recently took up residence in the village of Upper Nyack, was chosen trustee of the latter village in today's election, when by a surprise vote he defeated the incumbent candidate, Charles W. Roberts, a Republican.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- President Roosevelt conferred at the White House with Congressional leaders preparatory to sending to Congress tomorrow his relief appropriation message in which he is expected to ask for more than $1,000,000,000.

Mrs. William Adams Kissam gave a luncheon yesterday in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria for Mr. and Mrs. Clifford N. Carver, Mrs. Russell Gilbert, Mrs. Owen F. Roberts, Mrs. E. Parker Glenn, Mrs. Nelson O'Shaughnessy, Mrs. Arthur W. Little, Mrs. Edward Purcell Mellon, Mrs. Arthur van Siclen, Miss Alice Van Rensselaer, Miss Louise Scott and William Matheus Sullivan.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- An administrative reorganization of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration which would leave the old set-up virtually intact was announced by that agency today as the Senate approved a conference committee report making $470,000,000 available for carrying out the new soil conservation program.

Jose Iturbi conducted the Philadelphia Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall. He conducted a poetical performance of Weber's "Oberon" overture, beginning the program. He then gave a careful but much too polite and smalls-scaled performance of the savage and stirring Second symphony of Sibelius.

GOSHEN, N.Y., March 17. -- Voters in all except two villages in Orange County expressed their confidence in the present village administration, and offered no opposition to the election of Mayors and Trustees held in the thirteen villages in the county today.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 17. -- Many parties featured the special buffet luncheon today at the Everglades Club, where replacing the weekly fashion show was a spirited tombola and program of dance numbers. Mrs. Graham Youngs entertained there in honor of Mrs. Ruth Hanna of Cleveland.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 17. -- President Will Harridge of the American League was wrestling with his breakfast grapefruit and saying he was about to hie himself northward. He had cast an appraising eye over the American League clubs training in Florida and looked for a great race this year. He never saw the teams looking better.

The attitude which the Federal Government will take toward the crew of the Panama Pacific liner California upon its arrival in port from the Pacific Coast this morning remained a mystery last night to government officials in New York and officials of the line.

New York University's fencing team, intercollegiate three-weapon champion, defeated Columbia, 16 to 11, last night on the strips of the East Building at Washington Square. It was the third triumph for the Violet swordsmen in seven engagements.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- New York State urged the Supreme Court today to review the four-to-three decision by which the New York Court of Appeals only two weeks ago held the State Minimum Wage Law unconstitutional in so far as it applied to women.

With the removal from receivership of the McCrory Stores Corporation and subsidiaries expected within a few weeks, the Irving Trust Company, trustee, filed yesterday with the United States District Court here a report of the group's operations for 1935, which showed a net profit of $1,769,258, after all charges, including special reserves but not including the trustee's fees.

A man, whose photographs, with the grim notation -- "Wanted for Murder" -- had been plastered on police station walls all over the country for the last nineteen years, spent ten days in the hands of Florida police charged with burglary and then was released for lack of evidence last Saturday night, it was learned yesterday.

BAY SHORE, L.I., March 17. -- Early returns from the village elections held today in Suffolk County disclosed a complete upset in Sag Harbor, where the Conservative party drove the Advancement party from power, gaining control of the Village Board in the heaviest voting Sag Harbor had experienced in sixteen years.

From whatever collection of sociological observations or tabulated trends taken, the following piece of information given by an editorial writer in The Times of London is welcome as an illustration of the value of time and the demands of publicity in these United States:

The constant popping-up of bills to protect trade-marks in various State Legislatures throughout the country is becoming a source of worry to advertisers and publishers. After such proposals had been killed in Nevada, Maryland, New Jersey and this State, another bill has been introduced in the Rhode Island Senate, requiring mandatory registration of trade-marks.

ROYAL OAK, Mich., March 17 (AP). -- Fire early today destroyed the modest frame church where Father Charles E. Coughlin began his radio broadcasts ten years ago. Efforts toward completion of the new $750,000 Shrine of the Little Flower were spurred by the loss, estimated at $30,000, and covered largely by insurance.

LONDON, March 17. -- A fresh French "ultimatum" to Germany was delivered tonight by Pierre-Etienne Flandin, France's Foreign Minister. He issued a statement containing two demands that he said must be met before France will negotiate on Germany's peace plans.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Wednesday, March 18. -- Swirling flood waters from two streams swept through the principal streets of this city and its suburbs to a depth of fourteen feet or more last night, marooning an estimated 75,000 persons and recalling some of the scenes of the disastrous Johnstown flood of 1889.

THE TIMES of March 8 contained an article on the proposed trip of Dr. H.J. Spinden, curator of the Brooklyn Museum, into the Mayan jungle to study the Chorotegan tribe, the Mesquito and Suma Indians. I quote:

A consolidated net income of $6, 147,878 for 1935, after all charges, taxes and depreciation, was reported yesterday by the Phelps Dodge Corporation and subsidiaries. This was equal to $1.21 each on 5,071,240 capital shares. It compared with earnings of $3,224,915, or 60 cents each on 5,342,922 shares, in 1934.

Although the intense rivalry that accompanied last year's election of officials of the New York Stock Exchange is absent this year, some members expect a surprisingly large turnover in the governing committee. The renomination and re-election of Charles R. Gay as president is regarded as a certainty, but many new names are expected to appear on the official slate of ten governors and two "governing members" that the committee will submit on April 13.

In an editorial you state that Vermont voted to refuse a gift of an $18,000,000 parkway. To begin with, Vermont had to buy the right of way and deed to the government a strip of land not less than 1,000 feet wide, the whole length of the State, dividing the State into two parts by a strip of Federal-owned land over which the people of Vermont would have no control.
CUMBERLAND, Md., March 17 (AP). -- Flood waters swirled in twelve foot-deep torrents through the main streets here tonight, drove hundreds from their homes and piled up more than $500,000 damage.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 17. -- The village elections held today in Nassau County were featured by the success of the Republican-Citizens Committee group in Hempstead, which retained control of the Village Board in a close race. Victory was scored by one Democratic-Economy League candidate.

Amalgamated Properties, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of the Prudence Company, Inc., filed yesterday in the Federal court in Brooklyn a petition seeking reorganization under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Law. The petition asked that the proceedings be severed from those of its parent company, which are in the same court.

The fifth in the series of exhibitions at the Temporary Galleries of the Municipal Art Committee, 62 West Fifty-third Street, opens today to continue for three weeks. For the first time since the opening show, sculpture is included, the whole first floor being given over to varied works in this medium.

Business failures increased in the wholesale, retail and construction divisions but declined in the manufacturing branch in the week ended March 12 as compared with the previous week, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Tony Scarpati, 22-year-old Brooklyn boxer, was near death in Bushwick Hospital early this morning as the result of a skull fracture, suffered when he fell to the ring floor of the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night after being struck on the jaw by Lou Ambers of Herkimer, N.Y., a leading light-weight championship contender.

A banking group headed by the Chase National Bank and including Brown Harriman Co., Inc., Salomon Brothers Hutzler and R.W. Pressprich Co., obtained yesterday a new issue of $6,000,000 of New York City special corporate stock notes, dated March 12 and maturing on Nov. 12.
An employe of the city's Department of Sanitation appeared yesterday before Magistrate Charles Solomon in Flatbush Court on a charge of violating the city anti-noise ordinance.
ALBANY, March 17. -- The Court of Appeals today upheld the constitutionality of the State Housing Law which permits cities to set up authorities to foster housing and slum-clearance projects.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- A preliminary tabulation by the Treasury Department of income tax collections from Jan. 1 to March 16, showing an increase of 45.6 per cent over returns for the same period last year and apparently in excess of the administration's estimates, came today as a heartening revelation to framers of new tax legislation, particularly to those who are seeking a pretext for throwing overboard the proposed re-enactment of agricultural processing levies.

" Anarchy or World Order," which will be published by Oxford on April 2, contains the lectures delivered at the Geneva Institute of International Relations last August. Among the authors represented are John B. Whitton and Clarence K. Streit.

PITTSBURGH, March 17. -- Floods spread over Western Pennsylvania and West Virginia anew today, with the forecast that the water would rise to 33 or 34 feet at the junction of the Monongahela. Allegheny and Ohio Rivers tomorrow. A thirty-four-foot stage would be within one foot of the disastrous flood of 1907.

An end-of-March holiday has become a fixture on the Roosevelt calendar. When the President leaves Washington tomorrow, bound for a fishing trip off Florida, he will be duplicating a departure timed almost to the same day in 1934 and 1935.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- Pierce Butler, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, observed his seventieth birthday today and automatically became the sixth member of the highest court eligible to retire.

Going ahead after the first five minutes and staying there, the St. John's Prep quintet overpowered Brooklyn Cathedral Prep, 24 -- 13, in a play-off for the Brooklyn C.H.S.A.A. championship at the De Gray gymnasium yesterday. A packed gallery of 1,000 saw the Redmen, holding little regard for the zone defense of the Blue and White, unleash a powerful offensive.

Two theatrical producers arrived yesterday on the Berengaria, Gilbert Miller and J.J. Shubert. Mr. Miller said he had come over to see his favorite play, "Victoria Regina," and would return to London in three weeks.

JOHNSTOWN, March 17. -- As flood waters engulfed Johnstown tonight, the surging torrent lapped against the second stories of many downtown buildings and all the city's bridges were under water. The big Napoleon Street span was covered from one end to the other.
PRAGUE, March 17 (AP). -- Gilbert Marshall of Seattle advanced to the last eight in the world's table tennis championship by scoring two victories today.

TRENTON, N.J., March 17. -- After meeting for less than an hour tonight, the Assembly adjourned until next Monday without making any further effort to find $19,000,000 needed for emergency relief from April 15 to the end of the year.

Federal tax collections for 1936 to date in the Third New York District, which embraces Manhattan north of Twenty-third Street, have increased 18 per cent over last year, Joseph T. Higgins, internal revenue collector, reported yesterday.

The United States Treasury heard some good news yesterday. Its district offices throughout the country reported that income tax collections during the first sixteen days of March amounted to $281,000,000 -- an increase of no less than 46 per cent compared with receipts from the same source during the same sixteen days last year.

The brownstone and brick front of an imposing house at 322 West Ninetieth Street was revealed yesterday as the screen behind which bank robberies and possibly even murders were planned by a gang of young thugs who used it as their hideaway.

CHICAGO, March 17. -- The demand for hogs here today was much less active. Weights under 200 pounds sold to the best advantage, but they brought no better than steady prices, while some of the heavier kinds were off as much as 15 cents a hundredweight.
A new golden-yellow rose, the winner recently of the international contest held in Rome, won new honors yesterday at the twenty-third annual Flower Show at the Grand Central Palace.
ALBANY, March 17. -- State Controller Tremaine responded promptly today to the Assembly resolution calling on him to report in detail temporary loans made by him in anticipation of revenues.

Establishment of a separate Federal bureau for gathering and collating information on setting up of effective machinery for "industrial self-government" was urged yesterday by Alexander Printz of the Printz-Biederman Company, Cleveland, and chairman of the National Coat and Suit Recovery Board, in a letter to Major Charles R. Berry, Federal Coordinator of Industry.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- The government's machinery for social insurance moved forward today with the sending of checks to two States and the District of Columbia to administer their unemployment insurance legislation, and issuance by the Internal Revenue Bureau of regulations under the Carriers' Taxing Act, which is the fiscal section of the railway labor retirement set-up.

The net loss of the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad in February, after adjustment and interest, was about $319,000, against a loss of $512,000 in February, 1935, Matthew S. Sloan, chairman and president, reports. Gross earnings were about $2,225,000, against $1,779,812.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- Senator Black offered a joint resolution today which, if approved, would put President Roosevelt and the House of Representatives behind the Senate lobby investigation. The resolution provides for an appropriation of $10,000 to pay counsel to aid the committee in its fight on attacks made upon it in the courts.

Three members of the Rangers' "Old Guard," survivors of the original blue-jerseyed sextet of 1926, helped to keep the New York agregation in the running for an American group berth in the National Hockey League play-offs last night.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 17. -- "The States of the Little Entente and Soviet Russia have given the French Government firm assurance that they are ready to fulfill their obligations resulting from membership in the League of Nations and their alliances with France," declares Dr. Kamil Krofta, the new Foreign Minister.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- A request of Burco, Inc., that the Supreme Court decide the constitutionality of the Holding Company Act was joined today by the trustees of the insolvent American States Public Service Company; the corporation itself; Dr. Ferd Lautenbach, holder of some American States Public Service Company bonds, and its reorganization managers.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- Resolutions condemning war as a means of settling international disputes and calling upon the United States Government to "reiterate its renouncement of war" made in the Kellogg-Briand pact were adopted at the closing session today of the biennial convention of the United Synagogue of America.
BUFFALO, March 17. -- One of the season's heaviest snowfalls nearly halted traffic in this region today, crushed a hockey stadium and closed schools in at least two towns.

FRANKURT-AM-MAIN, Germany, March 17. -- General Hermann Goering, the Air Minister, completed what he described as a triumphant drive from Wiesbaden through the whole of the Rhineland with a speech to an audience of 15,000 in Westfalen Hall at Dortmund tonight.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 17. -- For two weeks and five days the 1936 Dodgers and the Allentown rookies have been getting into shape to play ball, and practically all of them have participated in the four exhibition games played, from which the Dodgers emerged with an even break.

The refusal of Abraham Kesselman, a lawyer, to sign a waiver of immunity before the Broklyn extraordinary grand jury in its bribery investigation in connection with the murder of Samuel Drukman drew yesterday the criticism of Supreme Court Justice Erskine C. Rogers.
U.S. Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Three armed robbers, described by the police as "nice-looking young Americans," obtained $1,380 worth of jewelry yesterday on the ninth floor at 62 West Forty-seventh Street by holding up a jewelry polishing concern and robbing customers who entered.

LONDON, March 17. -- Today, on the fifth day of the London debate and the eleventh day after German troops entered the Rhineland, the Germans have boldly decided to come to London and take their chances. They have quickly made up their minds with no other written condition than to be treated like the other Locarno powers. If in their talks with the British they have received other promises France is not bound by these.

MIAMI, Fla., March 17. -- Dusty Dawn, benefiting by his recent effort over the local strip, led from flag fall to finish in the St. Patrick's Day Handicap, six-furlong feature of a seven-race program that attracted a large throng to the Gables Racing Association's picturesque Tropical Park plant today.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., March 17. -- The residents of this community, across the Bronx boundary line, prefer street cars to streamlined bus transportation, especially since riding the old trolly line here would be half as costly as buses. They said so today by a vote of 549 to 156.

ALBANY, March 17. -- A new trial for Manny Strewl, now serving a term of fifty years in Clinton prison for the kidnapping of John J. O'Connell here in 1933, was ordered in a decision handed down by the Appellate Division today.

The entire disaster relief staff of the National Red Cross was thrown into the field last night for the first time since the Mississippi floods of 1927 and 1929, Edward H. Powers, one of the workers, reported last night through The Associated Press.

The weekly total of new measles cases resumed the upward climb that has been maintained with few exceptions since the first of the year, according to the Health Department's report on vital statistics for last week, made public yesterday.

LONDON, March 17. -- The great new $1,500,000 studios of Alexander Korda's London Film Productions, Ltd., now being constructed at Denham, Buckinghamshire, was seriously threatened by fire today when a blaze broke out in the first completed sound stage.

American Brake Shoe and Foundry The American Brake Shoe and Foundry Company declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 30 cents on the common stock. The previous quarterly rate was 25 cents. A quarterly dividend of $1.75 also was declared on the preferred stock.
The New York Public Library, which annually serves millions of the city's readers, has been making a detailed effort to check up on the extent to which it meets or fails to meet the public's needs.

HARROGATE, England, March 17 (AP). -- Five American women players won two matches apiece today in the opening day's play of the North England squash racquets championship, with the loss of only one game among them.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- Hope was expressed by President Roosevelt today that the Inter-American Peace Conference, which will convene in Buenos Aires in a few months, will have the practical effect of cementing peaceful relations among the American republics.

ALBANY, March 17. -- The principles of Governor Lehman's social security program won virtually unanimous approval from divergent interests at a public hearing today before the Senate Finance Committee and the Assembly Committee on Public Relief and Welfare.

The foreign complications into which HITLER has rushed should not blind us to the fact that he is entering upon a great political campaign within Germany. He is to submit his policies to a referendum of the German people on March 29. This impending vote is visibly affecting the speeches which he is making day after day.

E.S. Dulin, president of the Byron Jackson Company, received in 1935 $23,999 salary and owned 19,278 shares of the company's common stock, the listing and permanent registration of the issue on the New York Stock Exchange disclosed yesterday.

Miss Sonja Henie, the 23-year-old Norwegian girl who recently won her third Olympic title, announced yesterday that she would embark upon a career in this country next week as a professional figure skater.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 17. -- The Republicans today won two villages from the Democratic columns in the annual elections of 21 Westchester villages. They were Croton-on-Hudson and Irvington-on-Hudson.

The Metropolitan Opera House's Spring season will begin on Monday evening, May 11, and will continue into June, it was announced last night after a meeting of members of the special board appointed for this supplementary undertaking.
Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that $7,500,000 would be spent soon to modernize the automotive equipment of the Sanitation Department, particularly apparatus used in snow removal.

While the upturn in some lines of business should make the second quarter of 1936 the best of the present year, in most cases it is not likely to result in increases as great as those which were experienced in so many branches of business in the third and fourth quarters of 1935, Chapin Hoskins, managing editor of Forbes Magazine, declared last night.
TOKYO, March 17. -- The new government of Koki Hirota issued a declaration of policy tonight after prolonged consultation with the army, which bears the mark of dual parentage.

When the Queens Boulevard section of the Eighth Avenue subway begins operation to Jamaica within the next year, the Long Island Railroad estimates that it will lose an additional $1,000,000 a year in revenue, Hobart Rawson, railroad statistician, told Leon G. Godley, State Transit Commissioner, and Meal Brewster, Public Service Commissioner, yesterday morning at another hearing on the railroad's application for an increase in commutation fares.

LONDON, March 17. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange continued to make headway today. British Government stock registered substantial gains. International securities generally were firm, with dealings especially active in International Nickel because of the unexpectedly favorable report of the company's earnings.

DENVER, March 17 (AP). -- The Penn Athletic Club of Philadelphia, coming from behind in the second half, defeated Oregon Normal of Monmouth, 38 to 27, in the second round of the National A.A.U. championship basketball tournament today.

LONDON, March 17. -- A German delegation headed by Joachim von Ribbentrop, Adolf Hitler's Ambassador at Large, will arrive in London tomorrow morning to participate in the League of Nations Council's consideration of the German Government's violation of the Locarno treaty by the military reoccupation of the Rhineland.

The Eastman Kodak Company and wholly owned subsidiaries reported yesterday for the fifty-two weeks ended on Dec. 28 last a consolidated net profit of $15,913,251 after taxes and reserves. After dividend requirements on the preferred stock the earnings were equal to $6.90 a share on the outstanding common stock.

Needy children suffering from cardiac ailments will be the beneficiaries of a card party and tea to be held this afternoon at 5 East Sixty-sixth Street under the auspices of the cardiac committee of the New York Post-Graduate Hospital.

Senator's BORAH'S incursion into Republican politics in Oklahoma had an effect which was curious and not a little comic. Admitting that he had no first-hand knowledge of the facts, he said that Republicans from that State had told him that Standard Oil officials were busying themselves with the election of delegates to the Cleveland convention.

World markets are being opened to American goods on a scale not approached since the depression started, exporters gathered at the Hotel Pennsylvania for the annual "get-together" meeting of the Export Managers Club of New York, Inc., agreed yesterday.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 17. -- Startled by a report of a plan to kidnap him, Tommy Manville, heir to asbestos millions, tonight doubled the guard on his barricaded Premium Point estate. He enumerated details of the alleged plot, which, he said he was informed, was to have been attempted last night.

Buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday were below the figures for the preceding week. However, the total was well above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES. Buyer registrations during the past week were 856 as against 951 in the previous week and 773 in the same period last year.

A proposal to rebuild the city according to a long-range plan to be devised and carried out by a City Plan Board as part of the municipal government was offered last night by Harold Riegelman, former counsel in the Treasury Department on housing and mortgage finance, at a meeting of the New York Society of Architects at 115 East Fortieth Street.

The Metropolitan Opera Association closed its Brooklyn season last night with "Aida" at the Academy of Music, with Mme. Giannini and Messrs. Jagel and Thomas singing the leading roles. Ettore Panizza conducted.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- The problem of displacement of employes by railroad unification will be placed before President Roosevelt tomorrow or Thursday as a result of the failure of the railway management and railway union committees to reach an agreement, it was learned tonight.

Mrs. Herbert Hoover, national president of the Girl Scouts, was able to announce yesterday the culmination of a dream she had cherished for many years -- the establishment of a "holiday farm" for Girl Scouts in the metropolitan district.
MADRID, March 17 (AP). -- Fresh disorders in Spain's bitter political strife had cost ten lives tonight, but the government expressed confidence that violence was on the wane.

World industrial production registered the first slight decline in January since last July, according to the monthly report issued yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board. World prices of foodstuffs and raw materials, the board states, advanced sharply in January.
In relation to your editorial "City Provincialism" may I call to your attention that educational formalisms and requirements are more preferred by the ERB than the merit system?

BERLIN, March 17. -- The delegation that will represent Germany in London at the examination by the Council of the League of Nations of the Reich's abrogation of the demilitarized zone in the Rhineland will comprise Joachim von Ribbentrop, Chancellor Adolf Hitler's special Ambassador at Large; Dr. Hans Heinrich Dieckhoff, director of the Anglo-American section of the Foreign Office, and Dr. Ernst Woermann of the Foreign Office's legal department.

In issuing the annual report of the Niles-Bement-Pond Company, Charles K. Seymour, president, announced yesterday plans for a merger of that company and the General Machinery Corporation. A new corporation, the Niles-Bement-Pond Company, will be organized, which will offer its securities for stocks of the merging units.

ALBANY, March 17.--The Assembly today passed the Brownell bill providing for automatic recanvass of returns in New York City within thirty days after an election. The vote was 79 to 65, with the Democrats solidly in opposition.
BERLIN, March 17. -- Germany's foreign trade, exports and imports, have dropped again for the second successive month, according to official figures just issued for February.

VIENNA, March 17. -- The trial of thirty Socialists accused of high treason because they reorganized in secret the Social Democratic party, which Austrian Fascists shattered in 1933, was marked today by the continued defiance of the defendants and attacks on the present Fascists regime.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- Plans of the Associated Railways Company to acquire the $47,000,000 Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad for $7,200,000 and divide the property among seven Western roads were laid formally today before the Interstate Commerce Commission in an application for authority to borrow the purchase money from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

MONTREAL, March 17 (Canadien Press). -- The Maroons, Stanley Cup champions, turned back Toronto, 2 -1, tonight before a capacity crowd of 12,000 and established themselves strong favorites to finish at the top of the National Hockey League's International section.
Housing and building properties were among the Manhattan items in realty transactions reported yesterday.
Housing and building properties were among the Manhattan items in realty transactions reported yesterday.

The Senate is to be congratulated for upholding its Appropriations Committee in striking out the provision inserted on the floor of the House in the War Department Appropriation Bill which would limit the manufacturer's profit on each Government order of more than $10,000 for aircraft, aircraft engines or ordnance to 10 per cent.

LOUIS KRONENBERGER'S introduction to his "An Eighteenth Century Miscellany" (Putnam, $3) is quickening both as exquisite prose and as an insight into a romantic but self-consciously guilty passion. As prose the contribution holds its own even in its company -- and that company includes Swift's "The Drapier Letters," Sterne's "A Sentimental Journey," Gibbon's memoirs and Chesterfield's letters to his son.
WASHINGTON, March 17. -- Peter Grimm of New York resigned today as special assistant to Secretary Morgenthau to return to his realty business in New York.

LONDON, Wednesday, March 18. -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden presented yesterday to Pierre-Etienne Flandin, French Foreign Minister, a draft of the British proposals for settlement of the conflict with Germany over the demilitarized Rhineland zone, which provoked a violent explosion of indignation among the French delegates.
BERLIN, March 17. -- Germany's foreign trade, exports and imports, have dropped again for the second successive month, according to official figures just issued for February.

OCALA, Fla., March 18. -- George J. Timmerman, an unemployed bricklayer, was found nailed to a cross in a heavily wooded section near here today. His lips were sewn shut and a heavy hunting coat was tied over his head to muffle his groans.
WILLIAMSPORT, Md., March 18 -- The worst flood in forty-seven years surged relentlessly down the Potomac River Valley tonight, inundating at least seven towns and making hundreds homeless.

LONDON, March 18. -- Trade union and labor leaders from fifteen European countries claiming to represent 36,000,000 working men and women will meet here tomorrow to formulate labor's policy in the present international crisis.

In a recent issue Arthur L. Boulton discussed in a letter to the editor the water needs of New York City and arrived at the strange conclusion that New York will require so much additional water in the future that it would be folly to save a mere 180,000,000 gallons a day through metering.

An easterly wind, sweeping moisture-laden air from the Atlantic toward the city, blanketed the outer harbor with heavy fog yesterday on the next-to-last day of Winter, delaying liners and blotting out the customary bustle of tugs and ferries.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- An airplane trip up the Potomac River and further on to the Conemaugh at Johnstown revealed this afternoon that at Johnstown and Cumberland, Md., two of the cities hardest hit by flooding waters last night, the waters were receding, but other points along the river were feeling the effects of one of the worst floods in years.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Peter Grimm of New York City has retired from the government service as coordinator of the housing program without having achieved complete coordination, although he stayed on four or five months longer than he had planned in the hope of that.

Exotic blooms of the Mediterranean including many of the varieties that flowered in the gardens of Napoleon, Julius Caesar and the Sultans of Turkey, were viewed by more than 30,000 lovers of horticultural beauty at the Flower Show yesterday.

The baptismal name of VENIZELOS (ELEUTHERIOS) is one that is associated with the name of Zeus (Eleutherios) the Deliverer. And it belongs to VENIZELOS no less than to the Zeus who, according to the myth, escaped an untimely death as a child by being hidden for a time in Crete.

A letter has been addressed to stockholders of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation by Sosthenes Behn, president, advising them that steps are to be taken to refund bank loans and part of the funded debt and that at a special meeting on May 13 they will be asked to approve a reduction in the value of the common stock, the cancellation of employes' stock purchase plans and the creation of general reserves exceeding $100,000,000.

CHARLESTON, S.C., March 18. -- Henry Picard of Hershey, Pa., and Ky Laffoon of Chicago came through with 67s, four under par, today to lead the field in the first round of the $3,000 Tournament of Gardens.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- A committee of the Council for Industrial Progress has recommended that Congress be asked to create a commission to determine minimum wages and maximum hours and to regulate child labor. The recommendations were submitted to President Roosevelt by George L. Berry, Industrial Coordinator.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 18. -- There was little comfort for the Yankees today on their first trip of the Spring training season. The Ruppert forces went down to defeat for the second time in as many days at the hands of the Cardinals. The score was 6 to 5, a typical late rally bringing the Cards three runs and victory.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., March 18. -- Homeless and without food, thousands of Johnstown's terror-stricken residents huddled in misery tonight upon the rain-soaked Conemaugh Hills above the city, battered by flood waters from the Conemaugh River and Stony Creek.

No longer will the skillfulness of Dr. William Holland Wilmer restore the blessings of sight to thousands. To the medical world his passing means the loss of one of its outstanding members. Justly he earned a distinction in his chosen profession that is worldwide.

Steel production has risen this week to 61 per cent of capacity, a four-point gain, as a result of the placing of heavy orders or steel prior to the expected stabilization of prices in the second quarter of the year, according to The Iron Age. Output is at as high a level as it has been since June, 1930, although mills operated at the same rate in the second week of June, 1934.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 18. -- Names of the Vassar College sophomores who will carry the daisy chain in the class day exercises in June were announced today at chapel service. The selections were made by the class day committee, of which Eleanor Bodine of Philadelphia is chairman.

Stockholders of the General Foods Corporation will be asked to vote at the annual meeting next month on a profit-incentive plan for 1936 which has been recommended by the directors, it was revealed yesterday in the pamphlet report of the company for 1935.

Although no association of truck owners or union of teamsters would take the responsibility for saying that they were backing the movement, threats were being made yesterday of a protest strike by owners and drivers against the proposed store-pickup and delivery service to be started on April 1 by eight railroads entering New York.
KOENIGSBERG, East Prussia, March 18. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler delivered here tonight a campaign address notable only for the matters he did not mention.

Thomas N. McCarter, president of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey, has notified stockholders of a proposal to provide a special reserve by transferring $38,000,000 from the stated value of the no-par common stock. The change will require a vote of two-thirds of the stock of each class at the annual meeting on April 20.

LONDON, March 18. -- The Academic Assistance Council, formed in 1933 under the presidency of Lord Rutherford to assist scholars and scientists who because of religion, race or opinion were unable to continue work in their own countries, has decided to establish as its permanent successor the Society for the Protection of Science and Learning.

TRENTON, March 18. -- Attorney General David T. Wilentz and Prosecutor Anthony M. Hauck expect to interview Dr. John F. Condon tomorrow or Friday, it was learned here today, while Governor Harold G. Hoffman still sought in vain for arrangements that would permit him to question the "Jafsie" of the Lindbergh ransom negotiations.

Retail credit collections during February increased 2.14 per cent, according to the index of twenty local key stores, issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York. The gain compares with a rise of 1.55 per cent in January and with 0.53 per cent in February a year ago.

TRENTON, N.J., March 18. -- Over the objection of former Senator Everett Colby of Llewellyn Park, a leader of the Essex County "Clean Government" group, the Republican State Committee today recommended the election of Governor Hoffman with three others as delegates at large to the national convention.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Congress received President Roosevelt's bid for $1,500,000,000 additional relief money today with applause on one hand and on the other a disposition to demand a "bill of particulars" as to how it would be spent.

Mrs. Philip Rhinelander 2d gave a luncheon yesterday in the Terrace Room of the Plaza for Mrs. Lee Delafield. Other guests were Mrs. William V.B. Kip, Mrs. George Gordon Battle, Mrs. W. Henry Harrison, Mrs. J.G. Phelps Stokes, Mrs. J. Herbert Johnston, Mrs. John Godfrey Saxe, Mrs. John W. Livermore, Mrs. Peter N. Malevsky-Malevitch, Mrs. Philip Kip Rhinelander, Mrs. Charles Duncan Miller and Mrs. D. McRa Livingston.
PARIS, March 18. -- Eleutherios Venizelos, for many years a towering figure in Greek politics, died in exile here today at the age of 71 years after a short illness. Pneumonia was the cause of death.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Spurred by an order from President Roosevelt, government and Red Cross officials made strenuous efforts today to lend all possible assistance to flood sufferers throughout the nation as the city of Washington worked feverishly to combat a flood problem at its doorstep.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- In anticipation of forthcoming political campaigns throughout the country, Works Progress Administrator Hopkins sent out today to all State administrators a regulation forbidding solicitation of political contributions from any worker and notifying all workers that they were not required to make any such contributions.
ALBANY, March 18. -- Eligibility for old-age relief is reduced from 70 to 65 years under the bill of Assemblyman Wadsworth, Republican of Livingston, passed today in the Assembly by unanimous vote.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses was sued in the Supreme Court yesterday for a temporary injunction to restrain him from proceeding with his plan to tear down the Central Park Casino building and use the site for a playground.

With passage of the Copeland bill to revise the pure food and drug laws very unlikely at this session of Congress, reports yesterday indicated that a new bill would be framed for the next session and that it would be considerably more drastic than the current one.

Movements of prices of bonds were mixed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, the market lacking the buoyancy that had characterized it on Tuesday. Transactions totaled $11,942,400, against $10,735,800 on Tuesday. Excepting a few of the more speculative issues, price movements were confined to fractions in the domestic corporate section.

Delegates representing 254 separate groups in the Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations were asked yesterday to aid the current emergency campaigns in behalf of Jewish refugees in European countries at a general meeting of the federation at Congregation Emanu-El Community House, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street.
WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's message to Congress on the new relief program:

Something new in the way of yawl rig on the Long Island Sound racing yachts yesterday seemed likely to appear next Summer. Commodore R.J. Schaefer of the Larchmont Yacht Club gave an order to Sparkman Stephens for the conversion of his sloop Edlu from sloop to yawl rig, and upon learning of the planned change George Ratsey said he would make a yawl out of his sloop Zaida, which originally was a schooner.
ROME, March 18. -- The Austrian and Hungarian delegations to the Italo-Austro-Hungarian conference at Rome will arrive here Friday evening and will be met at the station by Premier Mussolini.

Yesterday was the anniversary of the bull market that began on March 18, 1935. Trading in stocks was unsentimental in this respect. Indeed, transactions were unusually light, and the trend was toward lower levels. The twelvemonth has been replete with far-reaching court decisions and with reports of steady recovery in trade and industry.
LONDON, March 18. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange turned dull as profit-taking became active this afternoon. British Government securities opened strong, but reacted later.

BOSTON, March 18. -- Flood-beleaguered residents of Western Massachusetts sent out frantic calls for help tonight as raging waters, whipped up by a steady southwest storm, ravaged New England for the second time in a week. The rain would continue until late tomorrow, Weather Bureau officials said.

ALBANY, March 18. -- John J. Dunnigan, Democratic Senate leader, and George R. Fearon, Republican floor chieftain, clashed sharply today in the upper house over a Democratic resolution to establish a committee of inquiry to examine assertions that business was being driven out of the State.

LONDON, Thursday, March 19. -- Joachim von Ribbentrop and his fellow-German delegates arrived in London late yesterday afternoon for today's continued discussion by the League Council of Germany's violation of the Locarno treaty. They remained in their hotel only long enough to drop their baggage and then went immediately to the House of Commons, where they had an appointment for consultation with Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Registration statements covering $66,609,082 of new security issues were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission. They included commercial and industrial bonds and shares, investment trusts, securities in reorganization and certificates of deposit.

Shackled to detectives and surrounded by extra guards, the seven men and three women arrested on Tuesday in the underworld arsenal at 322 West Ninetieth Street were held without bail yesterday to give the police a chance to check on their activities.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- President Roosevelt sent a message to Congress asking an appropriation of $1,500,000,000 to continue relief work during the year beginning next July 1, and issued an order directing all government agencies concerned to assist in areas where floods exist or are threatened.

Under an active covering demand March contracts on the Cotton Exchange advanced above 11.40 cents a pound yesterday to the highest figure for the last month and increased the premium over October to around 130 points. Settlement of obligations in the spot month contributed the major portion of business although selling pressure in the afternoon in new crop deliveries left the list with gains of 3 points to a loss of 8 points.

HARROGATE, England, March 18 (AP). -- Miss Anne Page of Philadelphia, the American champion, entered the semi-final round of the North England squash racquets championship today, defeating her compatriot, Miss Edith Drury of Boston, in four games, 0 -- 9, 9 -- 6, 9 -- 1, 9 -- 6.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- The public debt on March 16 reached $31,447,106,057 as a result of new securities issues amounting to $1,896,763,250, the Treasury announced today. A year ago the total debt was $28,594,738,092.

HAVANA, March 18. -- Provincial Governors and Councilors and Mayors and municipal officials elected in the general elections on Jan. 10 will take office March 25, according to a decree approved by the Cabinet.
BINGHAMTON, March 18. -- Flood waters of the Susquehanna and Chenango Rivers crippled Binghamton's water supply today and inundated several hundred homes.
A consolidation move in Manhattan by a business machine and office equipment firm was announced in conjunction with business leases reported yesterday.

" Larger Than Life," due next Monday evening at the Forty-sixth Street, instead will have its premiere there a week from tonight. Having played Springfield and Hartford, the Joseph Schrank-Norman Matson comedy opens a three-day stand tonight in New Haven.
Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., won the award of a new issue of $1,238,000 of primary road refunding bonds of Webster County, Iowa, at 100.799 for 2s. The bonds will mature from 1937 to 1945.

VIENNA, March 18. -- The third day of the mass Socialist trial here brought few sensations but gave an instructive picture of what Austria's former democratic republic has become under a Fascist dictatorship.

The condition of Tony Scarpati, 22-year-old Brooklyn boxer who sustained a fractured skull in a bout with Lou Ambers of Herkimer, N.Y., at the Broadway Arena on Tuesday night, was still reported as "critical" last night at the Bushwick Hospital.

T. Jefferson Coolidge, who resigned recently as Under-Secretary of the Treasury, and Arthur A. Pollan were elected directors of the United Fruit Company yesterday at the annual meeting in Jersey City. The directors will meet in Boston on Monday to elect officers for the year.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., March 18. -- Thousands of residents of Ohio River cities fled today before the menace of the greatest flood in history.

ATHENS, March 18. -- The news of Eleutherios Venizelos's death was received calmly throughout Greece today. Only in his native Crete and in Macedonia did the news create outward signs of sorrow, although a feeling of loss touched even the Peloponnesus peasant and the Cyclades fisherman, his lifelong opponents.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Possibility of an early continuation of railway management-union conferences looking toward the protection of employes who may be displaced by consolidations or unifications was seen here today as a result of developments in the last twenty-four hours.

BERLIN, March 18. -- Two giant Junker planes carrying the German delegation to the proceedings of the Council of the League of Nations in London took off from the Tempelhof airdrome shortly after noon today.
As the executive secretary of the City Projects Council may I comment on a letter entitled "Communists in the WPA" and signed "WPA Worker"?

If there is to be a real drive against sewage pollution of the beaches and other waters surrounding New York City, the public must be willing to spend about $20,000,000 a year for five years on the necessary engineering works, according to a report presented last night by Walter D. Binger, Deputy Commissioner of the Department of Sanitation.

PARIS, March 18. -- General Louis Felix Maurin, the War Minister, replying to a request for information by the Army Commission of the Chamber of Deputies, told that body today that in all probability the French Government would have to ask for supplementary defense expenditures.

ALBANY, March 18. -- The "hasty marriage" bill of Assemblywoman Jane Todd, Republican, of Westchester, was passed by the Assembly today and the compromise pistol bill of Assemblyman William Schwartz by the Senate.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 18. -- A capacity audience greeted the Theatre Intime's production, "Talk of the Town," a satire on the campus club system, presented in the Murray Theatre tonight.

To provide funds of more than $15,000,000 for continued expansion of plants and to increase production and develop new markets, directors of the Continental Can Company approved yesterday the offering of rights to common shareholders and the sale of additional common stock to employes.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., March 18. -- Mount Holyoke College announced today its list of graduate fellowships for the next academic year. The awards will go to graduates of the college and to girls who are candidates for the degree of Bachelor of Arts next June at Mount Holyoke or some other institution.

As a result of the assent of holders of 88 per cent of all allowed claims to the plan of reorganization of General Theatres Equipment, Inc., the Chase National Bank has waived its conditions for participation in the plan. The reorganization committee, meeting yesterday in the office of its chairman, Arthur W. Loasby, declared the plan operative.

Play in the world's open squash tennis championship will get under way at the Shelton Hotel courts tonight, with ten of the leading professionals and as many amateur stars entered. The first match is scheduled to start at 7:30 o'clock.

Six Eastern railroad presidents are to begin today conferences on a reduction in the basic passenger fare in this region from the level of 3.6 cents a mile, at which it has stood since 1920. The new rate is expected to be a compromise between the present one and the tariff of 2 cents a mile for coaches and 3 cents a mile for Pullman travel that was ordered recently by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

The Shippers Conference of Greater New York urged the New York and New Jersey members of Congress yesterday to oppose Representative Samuel Pettengill's bill designed to eliminate the long-and-short-haul provisions of the Interstate Commerce Act.

TORONTO, March 18 (Canadian Press). -- Snow which fell over most of South Central Ontario for twenty-four hours stopped early today, leaving a large part of the Province under a foot-deep covering, isolating several towns from highway traffic, cut communications, slowed traffic and added to the flood hazard.

ALBANY, March 18. -- Objectors to Republican cuts in Governor Lehman's executive budget crowded the Senate chamber today at a public hearing on the amended budget measures before the Finance Committee. The session began soon after 2 o'clock and lasted until far into the evening.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 18. -- Lack of planning has forced many municipalities to be content with WPA and PWA projects of "questionable merit," Russell Van Next Black, consultant-director of the New Jersey State Planning Board, told the State-wide planning conference, held here today under auspices of the State Planning Board.

The death of a narcotic peddler, possibly resulting from injuries inflicted in reprisal by members of a Mott Street vice gang arrested by raiders from the office of Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey, was disclosed yesterday as the man's partner, Benjamin de Francisco, 32 years old, of 532 East 184th Street, was sentenced by Federal Judge John C. Knox to five years for possession of opium.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- The services supplied by the American Telegraph and Telephone Company to racing news and gambling establishments, the amount of the revenues annually derived there-from and the efforts of the company to protect its teletype machines from seizure or destruction in the event of police raids on their clients, were subjects of lively discussion at both sessions today of the Federal Communications Commission's investigation of the A.T. T. affairs.

NEW ORLEANS, March 18. -- S.J. Molay's Declaration, beaten in every one of his sixteen starts last year, came through with the fourth victory of his 4-year-old campaign today in whipping seven other platers in the mile feature at the Fair Grounds.

PRAGUE, March 18 (AP). -- Miss Ruth Hughes Aarons of New York won the world's women's table tennis championship tonight, defeating Miss Kretzbach of Germany in the final round, 21 -- 16, 21 -- 14, 21 -11. Earlier in the day the New York girl had eliminated the defending titleholder, Miss Kettner of Czechoslovakia, 19 -- 21, 21 -- 13, 21 -- 17, 21 -- 18.
