WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Thursday, March 19. -- After a day in which flood conditions had driven 50,000 persons from their homes in the region between here and Scranton, the plight of residents in Kingston Borough, opposite Wilkes-Barre, was regarded as increasingly desperate early this morning.

Graphic descriptions of peril in the flood areas of Western Pennsylvania were told yesterday on the radio by eyewitnesses, several of whom the next minute were required to flee from rapidly rising waters.

Twenty-four women cited for success in business and the professions bowed acknowledgment of plaudits last night at the second annual "achievement dinner" and smiled approval of its keynote of cooperation with men, not opposition to them. Their hostesses were members of the New York League of Business and Professional Women.

A new diagnostic test by which it is hoped to facilitate the detection of cancer in its early stages, when the chances for cure are much greater, is reported in the current issue of The American Journal of Cancer by Dr. William Carpenter MacCarty of the Mayo Clinic, Rochester, Minn.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 18. -- A large attendance marked tonight's program, including "In a Persian Garden" and other numbers, at the Cloisters of Bethesda-by-the-Sea, sponsored by the Women's Guild of the Church for Charity.

Commodity futures continued to decline yesterday in more active trading on the local markets. Cottonseed oil advanced and wooltops and cocoa were firm. On the cash markets, cotton, lard, hides, standard tin, cocoa and silk advanced, while declines appeared in wheat, corn, rye, oats, coffees, rubber, butter and printcloths.

With Misses Dorothy Locke and Marion Lloyd leading the way, the Salle d'Armes Vince captured the women's national fencing championship for the seventh successive year by sweeping to a 5-0 decision over the home team in the annual competition held last night at the Fencers Club.

The Fordham University Glee Club made its thirteenth annual appearance in a recital last night at the Town Hall. The chorus, comprised of eighty voices, was under the direction of Frederic Joslyn. Both the choristers and Mr. Joslyn were enthusiastically greeted by a large audience.
WINTER HAVEN, March 18. -- Opening their exhibition home stand today, Jimmy Wilson's Phillies walloped the Dodgers, 7 to 3, for their first grapefruit league victory.

PITTSBURGH, March 18. -- The worst flood in local history brought the terror of darkness to this city tonight as power plants were thrown out of use, and fifteen hundred National Guardsmen patrolled the streets while Mayor William McNair directed the mobilization of every agency against the danger of food and water shortages, pillaging and the spread of disease.

Five men were arrested on charges of forgery yesterday after a police raid at a printing plant at 257 West Seventeenth Street, where huge quantities of fake two-cent State of Pennsylvania cigarette stamps were being printed. Detectives confiscated about 100,000 of the stamps in large sheets and destroyed four plates from which they had been printed.

The failure of two economic conferences called to consider stabilization of currencies was due to lack of preparation, according to Sigfrid Edstrom of Sweden, vice president of the International Chamber of Commerce, who spoke yesterday at a luncheon given for him at the Bankers Club.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 18. -- A continuous rain prevented the playing of the quarter-finals in the Bermuda tennis championships scheduled for today. They will be held tomorrow, weather permitting. The forecast is for showers in the morning, with improving conditions later.

DAYTON, Ohio, March 18. -- The start of the tenth annual show of the Dayton Kennel Club was delayed today because of the floods in Pennsylvania which prevented the appearance of the experts scheduled to do the major part of the Judging.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Another defeat for the administration's proposal to exempt from State taxation preferred stocks of national banks and capital notes and debentures of State banks held by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation seemed possible tonight as an alleged "deal" between Democratic leaders of the House Banking and Currency Committee brought threats from both Republican and Democratic members of the committee to reject the legislation.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP). -- The Red Cross appealed to the nation tonight to contribute $3,000,000 to a flood relief fund.

BALTIMORE, March 18. -- Western Maryland seen from an airplane today was a swirling rush of waters which isolated towns, marooned hundreds of motorists, tore up sections of railroad tracks, overwhelmed bridges, uprooted trees, smashed down poles and sent houses floating down the raging Potomac.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 18 (AP). -- Dams collapsed at New Hartford and Willington today under the additional strain of a heavy downpour of rain, destroyed dozens of buildings and made more than 200 families homeless. Snow and ice previously had played havoc with the waters in these areas.

CHICAGO, March 18 (AP). -- Unless schedules are changed at the last minute, the major grain markets in the United States will not be in session during the same hours tomorrow, for the first time in years.

NEWARK, N.J., March 18. -- Putting into effect the plan announced in January, the City Commission adopted today the ordinance restoring all salaries of city employes, effective July 1. The ordinance repealed as of June 30 an ordinance adopted three years ago reducing all salaries 2 to 25 per cent.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 18. -- The proxy battle of Charles G. Guth, former president of Loft, Inc., which operates candy stores and restaurants, to regain control of the company from James W. Carkner, now president, apparently ended tonight when his representatives failed even to nominate a slate of directors and the nominations were closed with the management's slate unopposed.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 18. -- More than 600 women guests from New York, Philadelphia, Baltimore, Detroit and other sections of the country are expected to arrive in Princeton tomorrow and Friday to attend the annual Princeton University junior promenade, highlight of the university's Winter social season.

HARRISBURG. March 18. -- Faced by devastating floods doing millions of dollars of damage, the State, the WPA and the various branches of the emergency relief board threw all their resources into relief efforts today.

The New York Americans will play their last regularly scheduled home hockey game of the season in Madison Square Garden tonight, meeting the Canadiens of Montreal. Although assured of a berth in the play-offs, the Americans hope to avenge some of the early defeats administered by the Montreal skaters.

Friends of Grover Cleveland and admirers of his political principles joined yesterday in tributes to his memory on the ninety-ninth anniversary of his birth. President Roosevelt, in a message from Washington, hailed his Democratic predecessor in the New York Governorship and the Presidency as a "massive figure in our nation's history."

It may well prove that "arsenal" is the exact word to describe the underworld rooming-house off Riverside Drive so impressively run down and occupied by the police. They seized seven men with records and three women companions, but even for a gang of that size the store of munitions seems more than normal.

A crowd of 4,000 saw Ernest Hefner, German giant, toss Dave Levin of Jamaica in the feature wrestling match, slated to a finish, at the Ridgewood Grove S.C., Brooklyn, last night. After being punished for a greater part of the contest by a series of flying tackles and body slams employed by his rival, Hefner took the offensive and upset Levin with three successive crotch holds before finally pinning him with a body slam.

DEERFIELD, Mass., March 18. -- The largest part of this historic old village is under water tonight, with several hundred of the population marooned in second-story rooms while the river bounding the village proper is rising at the rate of fourteen inches every hour.

MIAMI, Fla., March 18. -- Mrs. T. Stevenson's Tempestuous, fleet 4-year-old son of Sickle, came within two-fifths of a second of the mile and sixteenth track record of 1:43 in winning the Lake City Handicap by three lengths at Tropical Park today.

CHICAGO, March 18. -- Five major airlines joined forces today to obtain a type of transport airplane which will combine the safety, range, speed, economy of operation and capacity deemed necessary to meet the expanding demands of air traffic.

The Panama Pacific liner California, on which members of the crew went on strike earlier in the month under conditions which the company and Department of Commerce officials considered mutinous, docked yesterday morning at West Twenty-first Street, and after waiting for several hours for the Department of Justice to take action against the seamen, officials of the line ordered the men signed off in the usual manner.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Efforts of William Randolph Hearst, through injunction suits pending in the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia, to prevent the Senate lobby investigating committee from using as evidence or making public a telegram sent by Mr. Hearst to one of his editorial employes, were frustrated in the House today.
Relief expenditures aggregating $27,691,000 for April, May and June were authorized yesterday by the Board of Estimate at a special meeting at City Hall.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French frano on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- A repudiation of widespread charges that a member of the Communications Commission could be "bought" or "controlled" in connection with a New York State radio broadcasting squabble was made public today by the commission on the basis of investigations by the Department of Justice and the commission.
WHEELING, W. Va., Thursday, March 19. -- The death toll from the floods sweeping through this city rose to six early today following an explosion in the southern part of Wheeling.

With the streets of Johnstown, Pa., flooded to ten and fourteen feet, with the Allegheny and Monongahela Rivers overflowing and water pouring over a large section of Pittsburgh, with nearly every Northeastern State reporting floods of alarming height and volume, Spring is ushered in with a destructive wetness that proves how helpless we still are when natural forces insist on having their way.

Upon the intervention of Mayor La Guardia and his Board of Survey, which settled the strike of building service employes, the Realty Advisory Board submitted yesterday the settlement agreement for ratification to its 2,365 members.

Six of the elusive birds of paradise which were brought years ago from New Guinea to Little Tobago, British West Indies, were seen by Dr. William Beebe during his twenty-second expedition for the New York Zoological Society, Dr. Beebe revealed yesterday on his return.
LONDON, March 18. -- Following is the text of the speech made here today before the League of Nations Council by Dino Grandi, Italian Ambassador to London and delegate to the Council:

PRINCETON, N.J., March 18. -- Nineteen colleges have applied for permission to start Veterans of Future Wars posts, it was announced here today by Lewis J. Gorin of Louisville, Ky., National Commander.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Frederic A. Delano, an uncle of President Roosevelt, was designated today by the Federal Reserve Board as chairman of the bank and Federal Reserve agent at the Richmond Federal Reserve Bank. Mr. Delano, who is 73 years old, will serve without salary under a new rule of the board that the Reserve agents will not draw compensation and will act chiefly in an advisory capacity.

At the request of the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency, B.W. Pizzini, specialist in guaranteed railroad stocks, submitted by letter to the committee yesterday a proposed "yardstick" by which the Securities and Exchange Commission might determine whether securities should be traded on organized markets or over the counter.
Apartment buildings and a taxpayer were among Bronx properties sold yesterday.

MADRID, March 18. -- Arrests of Fascists continued throughout Spain today. The Falange Espanola, the only authentic Spanish Fascist organization, was suspended by court order and all its clubs in Madrid and in the provinces are being closed.

LONDON, March 18. -- The largest field in recent years was predicted today when thirty-seven jumpers, seven of them American-owned, were named in the final acceptances for the Grand National Steeplechase at Aintree, March 27. Twenty-seven faced the barrier last year and thirty the year before.

Messages from amateur radio operators, members of the United States Naval Reserve, describing the conditions prevailing in the flooded areas of Pennsylvania were received here last night at the naval communications office, 641 Washington Street.

Passage of the Robinson-Patman bill to control trade practices, now pending in Congress, would result in higher retail prices, increased production costs, accentuation of seasonal peaks and valleys in factory output and an ultimate decline in purchasing power, W.T. Grant, founder and chairman of the W.T. Grant Company, declared here yesterday.

ALBANY, March 18. -- Constantly rising floods drove 2,000 or more persons from their homes in New York State today. National Guardsmen received orders from Adjt. Gen. Walter G. Robinson to hold themselves in readiness for mobilization if the emergency got worse.

The Central Maine Power Company reports for 1935 net income of $1,305,749, after all deductions, or $25,604 less than full underlying and preferred dividend requirements, comparing with $1,349,462 for 1934. Gross revenue was $6,048,319, against $5,915,518.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 18. -- Scoring victories in first and second round matches, Mark J. Stuart, former metropolitan amateur titleholder, advanced to the semi-finals in the Winter championship of Florida for the Ponce de Leon Cup on the St. Augustine links today.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- A new rule requiring regular quarterly reports from banks holding public utility securities but claiming exemption from the provisions of the Public Utility Act was adopted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Abraham Kesselman, an attorney, appeared again yesterday before the extraordinary grand jury in Brooklyn which is investigating charges of bribery in connection with the Samuel Drukman murder. But again, as on Tuesday, he refused to sign a waiver of immunity. Special Prosecutor Hiram C. Todd thereupon dismissed him.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today for a new lump-sum appropriation of $1,500,000,000 with which to continue work relief for another year, beginning July 1, and at the same time urged private business to accept the responsibility for obviating such outlays in the future by another nation-wide drive for reemployment.
JOHNSTOWN, March 18. -- Red Cross agencies estimated that 10,000 were without homes in darkened Johnstown tonight, with 1,000 in great need.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 18. -- The most elaborate academic celebration in American history, marked by more than forty special events during the next six months, will take place in connection with the 300th anniversary of the founding of Harvard, according to announcement today by Jerome D. Greene, director of the tercentenary.
HARRISBURG, March 18. -- The Highway Department reported all major roads closed throughout the State, with the exception of Southeastern and Northeastern Pennsylvania.

Edward Rogers of Glen Cove, L.I., present titleholder, and Lewis Brooks of Philadelphia each scored 126 points in the second block of their national amateur pocket billiard challenge match at the Strand Billiard Academy last night. Brooks is leading the champion, 255 to 221, with the final block scheduled for tonight.

Blind young women will have leading roles in three one-act plays which will be presented tonight and tomorrow night by members of the Lighthouse Players at their Little Theatre, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street. The plays to be given include a fantasy, written by two members of the group; a comedy and a drama based on the life of Joan of Arc.
BERLIN, March 18. -- The Boerse was somewhat more active and stronger today, although the turnover continued strictly limited and quotations were regarded as of little real significance.

Charged with embezzlement, conduct unbecoming an officer, and false swearing and subornation of witnesses, Captain Ralph E. Fleischer, Quartermaster Corps, United States Army, went on trial yesterday before a general court-martial at Governors Island.

LONDON, Thursday, March 19. -- The conference of the Locarno treaty powers -- Britain, France, Belgium and Italy -- came to a dramatic end at 2:15 this morning after a laborious session. If the British Cabinet ratifies the agreement the French delegation has apparently carried its principal points:

The proposed production schedule for the Spring season at popular prices to be presented at the Metropolitan Opera House beginning on May 11 looks to the presentation of three operas each week, it was disclosed yesterday.

Vice Chancellor Charles M. Egan in Jersey City issued yesterday an injunction restraining the Cuban-American Sugar Company from putting into effect a reorganization plan which would clear up the accumulations of its 7 per cent preferred stock.

Maintenance of the wilderness character of the State Forest Preserve is of greater importance than its recreational development, Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne declared in an address at Lake Placid on Tuesday night.

After a lively hearing before Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler yesterday, Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, consented to study and report to the court whether he would alter his opinion as to the advisability of selling three title companies to the Aetna Casualty and Surety Company for $1,376,282.

Airplane pilots for TWA, shuttling yesterday between Newark Airport and flood-stricken Pittsburgh on regular and extra schedules looked down on flooded business streets and steel mills, and over Johnstown saw frantic activity as residents in higher parts of the city tried to save their belongings.

Details of an extraordinarily complete and extensive system of defense against air attack in Germany are revealed in a pocket handbook called The Soldier's Friend for 1936, a copy of which has reached this country.

The restless activity and excessive drive of the American business man, not overwork of the brain, are responsible for "5 o'clock fatigue" and death in the late fifties from heart disease, Professor Josephine L. Rathbone of the Department of Physical Education in Teachers College, Columbia University, declared yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, March 18. -- Voting trustees of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company at the annual meeting today ousted Dr. Arthur A. Mitten as a director of the company despite threats and shouts of derision from about 1,000 stockholders, most of whom were employes.

LONDON, March 18. -- Streamlined, like a silver bullet, a new British bomber that is among the world's fastest took to the air today in its first demonstration before air experts at the Fairey Aircraft Company's airdrome at Hayes, Middlesex.

PITTSBURGH, March 18. -- Beleaguered Pittsburgh closed its business section tonight to commerce. Thomas A. Dunn, Safety Director, told building owners in the "Golden Triangle" -- where most of the nation's steel is bought and sold -- not to open for business tomorrow.

ADDIS ABABA, March 18. -- The Ethiopian Government, which yesterday denied conducting direct negotiations with Italy, issued a denial today of indirect negotiations with any "so-called semi-official representatives."

Directors of the Atlas Tack Corporation yesterday declared a dividend of 25 cents a share on the common capital stock. The last dividend paid by the company was in 1920. At the annual meeting of stockholders Charles F. Simmons was elected a director to fill a vacancy.

BERLIN, March 18. -- Orders were issued by the Minister of Education, Dr. Bernhard Rust, today to all candidates for teaching posts in the Prussian middle and higher schools to attend the new National Socialist propagandistic normal schools for at least two semesters before entering the universities.

The Delaware and Passaic Rivers as well as many smaller streams in New Jersey were at flood stage last night and still rising, with no indication that the peak of the flood had been reached. Because of the terrain there was comparatively little danger of loss of life, but officials at Trenton made plans yesterday to care for families which may be driven from their homes.
Delayed by floods and heavy snows, the Pennsylvania Railroad's Red Arrow Special arrived in the Grand Central Terminal at 12:30 o'clock this morning, about fifteen hours overdue.

A coordinated movement on the part of present and former members of this country's military forces with patriotic and other lay organizations to carry out the intent of existing legislation for national defense was revealed yesterday by Major Gen. Frank Parker, commander of the "Fightin' First."

HAMILTON, Ont., March 18 (Canadian Press). -- Sammy Richardson, 17-year-old runner from Toronto, and Joe Mangan of Cornell shared honors tonight at the Seventy-first Highlandery Athletic Association indoor track and field meet. Each turned in a record-breaking performance.

BELLEAIR, Fla., March 18. -- Babe Ruth helped bring about his own defeat today in the Belleview amateur golf championship by laying himself three stymies in his match with Guy Berner of Buffalo. Berner won by 4 and 3 and moved into the semi-final round, where he will meet F.H. Gouverneur of Rochester, who topped John R. Murray of Chicago by 1 up in twenty-one holes.

WHAT appears to be a warming-up for some sort of epic concerned with third-string pioneers who do their traveling in dusty day coaches and strike their claims from dingy rooms in railroad hotels, is contributed today by Paul Horgan, who has thrown over the chattering sophisticates of his "No Quarter Given" and "The Fault of Angels" to write of a store supply salesman, a woman evangelist and their son.

With at least fifty-seven persons dead, thousands of others homeless and the property damage increasing by millions hourly, devastating floods raged through twelve States last night, while tornadic winds, sleet and snow in other States increased the death list and losses.

AKRON, March 18. -- High winds lashed record snows into the worst road blockade in modern times in Summit County and all of Northeastern Ohio today. Mounting temperatures and a drizzling rain late in the day failed to relieve the tie-up of motor traffic and brought the threat of increased flood perils for the State.

Solomon Shepneck, who is on parole from State Prison on a charge of possessing machine guns, John Warren, a convicted forger, and three other men were arraigned yesterday before Garrett W. Cotter, United States Commissioner, on a charge of using the mails to promote the sale of lottery tickets.
PENSACOLA, Fla., March 18. -- Events in the affairs of the Giants clicked more smoothly today than they have in quite a while.

A pair of upsets marked the start of the Olympic basketball eliminations for District 1 last night as both Manhattan, top-ranking metropolitan quintet, and Springfield, New England champion, were beaten, to the complete surprise of a crowd of 7,000. Niagara conquered the Jaspers in the final, 28 to 22, while St. Francis, giving the best demonstration of the evening, turned back the Maroon, 44 to 36.

The operatic best-seller, "Tristan und Isolde," had its seventh and final performance of the regular season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. In some respects it took on the air of a festival occasion, so intent was the capacity audience on the enfoldment of Wagner's puissant music-drama and so responsive was it to the brilliant individual and ensemble performances of the evening.

Net profit of Montgomery Ward Co., Inc., for the year ended on Jan. 31 was $13,527,310 after expenses, depreciation, amortization, provision for Federal and State income taxes and all other charges, according to the sixty-fourth annual statement, which will be made public today.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Ending practically all hope of adjournment by May 1, Chairman Doughton of the House Ways and Means Committee informed President Roosevelt at the White House today that the proposed Tax Bill would not be brought up in the House for a vote before the middle of April.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 18. -- The sunburned saxophonist, G. Stanley Cochrane, was lobbing a ball backward and forward with Bill Rogell, the Detroit shortstop. He answered questions and popped a few of his own without interrupting his warm-up exercises.

Leaders in the waste material industry from all sections of the country were told last night by Merle Thorpe, editor of The Nation's Business, that they are overlooking their biggest market for the salvaging of waste and the junking of obsolete machinery.

A banking group headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., and Bonbright Co., Inc., will offer today a new issue of $55,830,000 of Consumers Power Company first-mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds due on Nov. 1, 1970. The bonds are priced at 103 1/2, to yield 3.31 per cent to 1965, when they become callable at par, or 3.33 per cent if held to maturity.

Declaring that it would be "an abuse of discretion to grant approval," Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler denied yesterday for a second time a petition by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, to approve compromise of two suits brought against the former directors of the General Surety Company and the State Title and Mortgage Company.

ROME, March 18. -- Of considerable importance is the news received today from Italian Somaliland that the Italians are hard at work building a permanent road capable of permitting heavy traffic throughout the rainy season from Mogadiscio to Gorahai.

At the instigation of the Queens County Bar Association, the Appellate Division in Brooklyn designated yesterday Supreme Court Justice Leander B. Faber to conduct a sweeping inquiry into alleged corrupt practices of certain Queens lawyers in ambulance chasing and condemnation cases.
WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Senator Borah left tonight for Youngstown, Ohio, where tomorrow he will make his first speech in his drive for Ohio delegates to the Republican National Convention.

After an all-week session of indoor drills, the Brooklyn College varsity baseball team will stage its first outdoor practice when the squad of fifty candidates moves to the Wingate Memorial Field tomorrow afternoon. Coach Tommy Harrington, substituting for Dutch Conner, who is returning from Denver with the basketball team, will continue to instruct the Kingsmen in fundamentals.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Under the program of enlistments authorized by Congress to expand the navy to meet the requirements of operating additional ships, the strength of personnel will reach 93,500 men on June 30, Rear Admiral Adolphus Andrews, Acting Secretary, said today. It is now 89,000 men.
Telephone communication in the inundated areas of Western Pennsylvania was seriously disrupted yesterday as the rising waters tore down telephone poles and flooded central office power plants.

President ROOSEVELT'S long-awaited message on relief went to Congress yesterday and proved to be something more than an estimate of needs and an appeal for funds. As to these immediate questions: the President estimates that he will have in June an unexpended balance of about $1,000,000,000, carried over from earlier relief appropriations, and that the new budget already carries $600,000,000 for CCC and public works.

LONDON, March 18. -- The Court of Criminal Appeal today upheld the recent convictions of Barabed Bishirgian, so-called pepper king of London's commodity markets, and John Howeson, former dictator of the world's tin industry, for the issuance of a fraudulent prospectus during the great pepper and shellac gamble of last year.

Walter Baer, supervising engineer, of Portland, Ore., has been going straight ever since 1921, when he served a sentence for forgery in State prison, but Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson ruled yesterday that he was powerless to prevent his deportation to Germany as an alien.

DENVER, March 18 (AP). -- The Santa Fe Trails of Kansas City, defending champions, used their crushing offensive today to drive into the quarter-finals of the National A.A.U. basketball tournament with a 43-to-28 victory over a stubborn fighting United Service team of St. Louis.
Transportation facilities from New York to the flooded areas in Western Pennsylvania were tied up considerably yesterday.
BINGHAMTON, March 18. -- "I lost everything I had in today's flood except what clothes the three children and I could carry from the house when they rescued us.

ALBANY, March 18. -- The Burchill bill creating a Long Island Rapid Transit Authority with power to take over and operate the Long Island Railroad, was praised and condemned today at a public hearing on the measure.

Rudy Vallee, who has been crooning in the "Scandals," and George White, producer of that show, are no longer friends. Mr. Vallee did not appear in Mr. White's revue yesterday afternoon, and his name has come down from the marquee of the New Amsterdam Theatre.

The committee on securities of the New York Stock Exchange ruled yesterday that Granby Consolidated Mining, Smelting and Power Company, Ltd., capital stock shall be traded on Friday ex the $8 per share liquidating dividend recently declared and that all certificates delivered in settlement of transactions after Friday shall be stamped to indicate the payment.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- The sweep of flood waters to the highest points on record at Binghamton and other places in Central land Southern New York gave urgent emphasis today to the appeals made by New York and Pennsylvania representatives at a hearing before the Board on Rivers and Harbors of the Corps of Army Engineers for a prompt undertaking by the Federal Government of a comprehensive flood-protection program in that area.

Joe Louis will begin preparations late next month for his June bout with Max Schmeling, it was disclosed yesterday when announcement was made of the heavyweight's plans for a temporary camp at Lafayetteville, N.Y., sixteen miles from Hyde Park.
GLEN COVE, L.I., Thursday, March 19. -- Fire of unknown origin early this morning destroyed the country home of Thomas Dickson, a Wealthy coal dealer, on the North Shore of Long Island.

MOSCOW, March 18. -- Soviet alimony-jumpers are getting an opportunity behind the bars to think over desertion of wives and children, according to I.A. Smirnoff, president of the Moscow City Court, who today revealed that during the past six months more than 100 Moscow engineers, bookkeepers and actors had gone to jail for an average period of six months for failing to pay allowances to their divorced wives and abandoned children.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 18 (AP). -- Arrival of the Honolulu team tomorrow held the attention of officials of the American Bowling Congress tonight as they planned a fitting reception for the Hawaiians, who are traveling more than 9,000 miles for approximately four hours of bowling.
AIKEN, S.C., March 18. -- The favorites came through victorious in the first round of match play in the forty-first annual Southern Cross tournament at the Palmetto Golf Club today.

Balked in an attempt to obtain an immediate trial of their test case before the United States Customs Court, attorneys for domestic interests abandoned hope yesterday of getting a United States Supreme Court ruling on the constitutionality of the Reciprocal Trade Agreement Act before the end of this year.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP). -- Opponents of compulsory military training were defeated, 59 to 18, in the Senate today, but a final vote on the $611,000,000 War Department supply bill was delayed again by a new debate over airplane contracts and the Florida ship canal.

CHICAGO, March 18. -- Liquidation by recent buyers of wheat on the Board of Trade here carried the May delivery today 1 3/8 cents a bushel below yesterday's closing price and new crop deliveries somewhat less, and while there was buying by holders of bids and also short covering, the close was at net losses of 3/8 to 1 cent, with the May leading.

Representative Edward A. Kenney of New Jersey has been refused permission to give a talk over WNEW advocating a reduction in tunnel and bridge vehicular tolls between New York and New Jersey because of an objection voiced by the Port of New York Authority, according to a statement yesterday by Jay Lewis, WNEW feature program manager.

NEW HAVEN, March 18. -- Richard C. Berens, 19, of 35 West Seventieth Street, New York City, a Yale freshman, was found shot this afternoon in his room in Byers Memorial Hall. Fellow-students who heard the shot sent him to the New Haven Hospital, where it was said tonight that his recovery is expected.

President Roosevelt's proposed tax on undistributed corporation profits would benefit small stockholders and small business men, prevent the use of corporations for tax evasion by large stockholders and tend to stop increasing concentration of wealth, Robert H. Jackson, Assistant Attorney General, declared last night.
LONDON, March 18. -- The text of the address of Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, to the Council of the League of Nations today follows:

BOGOTA, Colombia, March 18. -- An enormous political sensation was created here by the publication in newspapers this morning of a manifesto from Colombia's whole Catholic episcopate against the new national Constitution, which Congress is debating, and of a letter from the Conservative party leaders to the President asking him to try to prevent its adoption.

LONDON, March 18. -- The statesmen who have worked themselves to a frazzle over the international crisis for the last ten days had to don full dress and uniforms and spend several hours of precious time today attending the first levee of King Edward's reign.
Houghton Mifflin have received three-quarters of the manuscript of Dorothy Speare's new novel, which they will publish this Fall. As yet unnamed, the story is about Hollywood.

FRIEDRICHSHAFEN, Germany, March 18. -- The new Zeppelin LZ-129 finished a thirty-hour test flight this afternoon. The ship made a quick experimental landing and reascent at 8 o'clock this morning, which was the only break in the monotony of its slow, steady progress in broad circles over South Germany and Lake Constance since it started early yesterday.
In the more recent history of Greece no man played a more outstanding part nor did any man suffer such extraordinary changes of fortune as did Eleutherios Venizelos.

CHICAGO, March 18. -- The demand for hogs here today was not aggressive and while weights above 170 pounds were steady to 10 cents a hundredweight lower than yesterday, light lights were off as much as 15 cents. Fresh pork loins were unchanged at 17 to 21 1/2 cents a pound wholesale.
LONDON, March 19 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

WHEELING, W.Va., March 19. -- This flood-beleaguered city tonight watched the raging Ohio River slowly recede from its destructive crest after taking a toll of seventeen lives and causing great property damage.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 19. -- Three giant star-dust "wedding rings" in the Milky Way, in the form of planetary nebulae, probably hundreds of times larger than the solar system, have been discovered in the southern sky by Mrs. Muriel M. Seyfert, research assistant of the Harvard College Observatory staff, through the examination of photographic plates made at the Harvard astronomical station at Bloemfontein, South Africa.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., March 19. -- Republican Presidential campaigning opened in Illinois today with Colonel Frank Knox, Chicago publisher, the first aspirant for the nomination to appear in the State and speak for delegate support.

Stressing the importance of cooperation to stabilize conditions in the dress industry here, Harry Uviller, newly-appointed impartial chairman of the group, which embraces more than 105,000 workers and 3,500 employes, last night predicted a "prolonged armistice in industrial conflict while capital and labor jointly strive for economic rehabilitation."

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Breathing spell or no breathing spell, the President has not changed his mind about the attitude of private industry. His relief message demonstrated once more that he is impatient for what he calls "further efforts toward increased output and employment," and seems to be aware of no reason why these cannot be boldly and effectively made.
WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Internal revenue collections for the eight months ended on Feb. 29 were $1,966,039,076, or $52,573,701 above those in the same period last year, the Treasury announced today.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 19 (AP). -- Harry Schornstein, Indianapolis, lost an opportunity to land a high place in the individual standings of the American Bowling Congress today, but his 643 was good for eleventh place in the solo event.

Activities of the New York Adult Education Council were almost doubled in the last year, the third of its existence, Miss Winifred Fisher, executive director of the council, reported yesterday at its annual meeting at the Central Y. W. C. A., 610 Lexington Avenue.

BALTIMORE, Md., March 19. -- Passengers of Eastbound and Westbound railroad trains are receiving a lot for the money paid for their fares. Those who boarded the Pennsylvania Railroad's Liberty Limited at Chicago about 2 o'clock Tuesday afternoon reached here at 2 o'clock this morning, officials of the line said.
None of the items in yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks reached a new high or low point for the year, but the ratio of reserve for the New York Bank was at the lowest for 1936.

LONDON, March 19. -- Ambassador Ivan M. Maisky of Russia told the Fabian Society tonight that Germany had been invited to participate in the Franco-Soviet pact on an equal footing and that the invitation was still open.

Ways in which the American woman may bring greater economic security to her home and strengthen herself as a moral, practical and esthetic influence within the family were discussed by speakers yesterday at a conference in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
ALBANY, N.Y., March 19 (AP). -- Several amendments to the State's unemployment insurance act became law today by a scratch of Governor Lehman's pen.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- President Roosevelt today granted to Major Gen. Johnson Hagood a request for a personal interview. The general was removed recently from command of the Corps Area Headquarters at San Antonio, Texas, as a result of critical statements made by him before a House committee regarding the administration relief program.

In a resume of social security plans in various States, a committee of the Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut points to "many inconsistencies and ambiguities" in security legislation, and urges laws which will conform more nearly with the theory behind the Federal Social Security Act.

CHARLESTON, S.C., March 19. -- Shattering par by two strokes, Henry Picard of Hershey, Pa., today added a 69 to his 67 of yesterday to take a formidable lead in the fourth annual $3,000 Tournament of Gardens with a total of 136.

Debutantes headed by Miss Barbara Crim have been active in the sale of boxes and seats for the special performance of "Parsifal," with Kirsten Flagstad and Lauritz Melchior in the leading roles, this afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the New York Kindergarten Association.

A statement defending its failure to take a stand on a proposed compromise of suits against former directors of the General Surety Company and the State Title and Mortgage Company was issued yesterday by the State Mortgage Commission.

PITTSBURGH, March 19. -- The flood waters of the Monongahela and Allegheny Rivers, which spilled over Pittsburgh's "Golden Triangle" to cause property damage estimated at $25,000,000, began to recede today, leaving this unprepared industrial city in the condition of a town of the horse-and-buggy era.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- President Roosevelt today assumed personal direction of flood relief in the nation as the raging Potomac flooded the capital's riverfront district and dikes were thrown up only two blocks from the White House. He issued a proclamation calling upon the public to subscribe at least $3,000,000 to the Red Cross to care for about 200,000 made homeless in twelve States.

Joseph Murphy, alias Joseph Heel, and Michael Kane, alias Michael Healy, two of the ten prisoners taken at 322 West Ninetieth Street on Tuesday in rooms filled with guns and ammunition, were indicted yesterday, one for the possession of a machine gun and the other for possession of a silencer.

A "very grave hazard" from sudden high floods exists in certain sections of the Mohawk Valley, according to a report presented yesterday at a meeting of the New York State Planning Council by E.S. Cullings, water resources consultant to the council.

Mrs. Robert Taylor Swaine, chairman of the patroness committee, gave a tea yesterday afternoon at her home, 1,120 Fifth Avenue, for members of the committees working for the success of the Wellesley-Princeton concert and dance March 27 at the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP). -Senator Bilbo, Democrat of Mississippi, lost his first major battle in the Senate today when the nomination of Edwin R. Holmes of Mississippi to the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals was overwhelmingly confirmed.

Random House has for distribution in this country 200 copies of "The Nonesuch Century," the hundredth book published by the Nonesuch Press of London. Priced at $16.50, the volume is subtitled "An Appraisal, a Personal Note and a Bibliography" of the work of the press from 1923 to 1934.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 19. -- "Her Week-End," directed, written and produced by Anne Nichols, was presented to a small but appreciative audience in the McCarter Theatre tonight. The comedy marked the return to the theatre of the author of "Abie's Irish Rose."
LONDON, March 19. -- Following is the text of today's address to the League of Nation Council by Joachim von Ribbentrop, chief of the delegation sent here by Germany:

CHICAGO, March 19 (AP). -- Champion High School of Prairie Du Chien, Wis., which has made numerous trips to Loyola's national Catholic interscholastic basketball tournament without winning the coveted honor, staged a stirring comeback today to score in the first round of the 1936 championship.

For the program of the concert given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall last night, Hans Lange arranged a succession of pieces calculated alternately to soothe and lacerate the conservative breast. The concert began with a suite of dances taken from operas and ballets of Rameau, freely arranged for orchestra by Hermann Zilcher, who now lives at Wurzburg, "composer, pedagogue and pianist."
DEFUNIAK SPRINGS, Fla., March 19. -- This gay little resort of some 2,000 souls trained out en masse today to view its first exhibition of major league baseball.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 19. -- The breeze was coming in off Sarasota Bay and Joe Cronin came striding along with no hat on and his brown hair waving in the wind. The youthful player-manager of the rich Red Sox was as cheerful as usual. Why wouldn't he be? He was custodian of the richest collection of ivory in the big leagues.

In forty-eight simultaneous meetings in as many cities the American Institute of Electrical Engineers celebrates today the beginning of the alternating current system in this country. For it was on March 20, 1886, that WILLIAM STANLEY first publicly demonstrated his transformer in Great Barrington, Mass., his home town.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today amended Rule NB2 dealing with exemptions of certain transactions by underwriters from the provisions of Section 16 (b) of the Securities Exchange Act in an effort to clarify and broaden somewhat the original rule.

CAMDEN, S.C., March 19. -- Royal Reveler, capable chestnut gelding belonging to Miss Wilhelmine S. Kirby of Bedford Hills, N.Y., was the outstanding performer as competition in the twenty-sixth annual Camden horse show started in the ring of the Cherokee Club today.

The improvement in the marketing of town houses which has been the high light of realty activity in this city in recent weeks was shown again yesterday when two more residences on the East Side were sold. In both instances the deals involved buildings that had been modernized.

TRENTON, March 19. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman continued "negotiating" today for an interview with Dr. John F. Condon, while Attorney General David T. Wilentz made a sudden call upon the Lindbergh case witness which he tried unsuccessfully to keep a secret.

Excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System were reduced $620,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a total of about $2,390,000,000 as a result of tax payments on Monday and cash subscriptions to new Treasury securities.
HARTFORD, Conn., March 19. -- This city tonight became the outpost between New York and the upper manufacturing districts of the Connecticut Valley.
Wild, irregular pealing of the bells of St. Joseph's Church in Eighty-seventh Street between First and York Avenues startled the good housewives of the district late yesterday afternoon.

The Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation in its report for 1935, issued yesterday, shows consolidated net income of $3,563,087, after all charges including $400,000 for Federal income tax, compared with $1,273,069 for 1934. The earnings were equivalent, after provision for preferred shares, to $1.24 a share on the common stock.

Judge Dowling, in the Supreme Court at Utica, held the New York State Unemployment Insurance Law constitutional with the exception of one provision, which if finally held unconstitutional will eliminate certain unemployed persons from the right to benefits.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended March 18, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,478,000,000, an increase of $4,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $17,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1935.

BERLIN, March 19. -- The early German reaction to the memorandum of the Locarno powers setting conditions for the solution of the Rhineland crisis and proposing a new peace conference suggests that its terms are anything but acceptable.

BOSTON, March 19. -- Flood-drenched New England today was suffering the worst industrial and transportation tie-up in her history as still raging rivers moved seaward with the flood peak expected to be reached on the lower reaches of two major waterways -- the Connecticut and Merrimack Rivers -- some time tonight.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., March 19. -- The muddy Susquehanna and Chenango Rivers dropped a foot tonight and Binghamton plunged into the task of fighting off a dangerous water shortage and caring for 2,000 homeless flood refugees.

A retrospective exhibition of paintings by Paul Gauguin (1848-1903) opened with a preview yesterday afternoon at the Wildenstein Galleries, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street, and may be visited by the public, beginning today. An admission fee of 50 cents is charged, since this show is being held for the benefit of Les Amis de Paul Gauguin and the Penn Normal Industrial and Agricultural School of St. Helena Island, S.C.

With an army of emergency field crews working day and night in a battle with the rising waters in the inundated areas of the Eastern sections of the country, telephone and telegraph companies succeeded yesterday in restoring most of the communication lines which had been destroyed by the floods.

Two strangely contrasting gardens, one a picturesque reproduction of a backyard in distant Persia and the other a floral collection containing many hints for the cliff-dwelling New Yorker, won prizes at the Flower Show in Grand Central Palace yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- The extent to which the Federal Reserve member banks are financing governmental operations was disclosed today in the monthly bulletin of the Federal Reserve Board. The tabulation showed that the member banks at the end of 1935 held a total of $10,500,000,000 of direct obligations of the United States, a gain of $600,000,000 in the year.

Bank clearings gained more than a billion dollars in the week ended on Wednesday and thus reached a point not equaled since the week ended on Oct. 8, 1931. The total, as reported to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., for twenty-two leading cities in the United States was $7,207,983,000, compared with $5,985,252,000 for the same period of last year.

With additional hundreds of building service workers taken back, the situation resulting from the recent walkout showed considerable improvement yesterday as both sides were preparing to go into arbitration on the wage question, in accordance with the strike settlement agreement.

Changes in the racing rules of the New York Yacht Club affecting the Class J, or America's Cup yachts, are to be taken up at the club meeting next Thursday night. They include points disputed by T.O.M. Sopwith in his international match with his yacht Endeavour off Newport in 1934, and are expected further to clear the way for a challenge from him with his new Endeavour II for next year.

Six men, said to be associated with the widely publicized American Hospitals Sweepstakes, were arrested yesterday after raiding parties from the Kings County District Attorney's office and police headquarters had visited offices in Brooklyn and Manhattan.

The United States Government offers the week's only premiere tonight -- "Murder in the Cathedral," T.S. Eliot's poetic drama of the martyrdom of Thomas a Becket. The Manhattan Theatre, home of the popular price unit of the Federal Theatre Project, receives it at 8:40 P.M. for a limited engagement (until March 31).

WILLIAMSPORT, Md., March 19 (AP). -- At least four persons were dead as the swollen Potomac River continued its $5,000,000 sweep through the narrow, mountain-lined valley of Maryland-Virginia-West Virginia, and gathered fury to loose on the nation's capital.

BRADENTOWN, Fla., March 19. -- The Cardinals' management greeted Jerome H. Dean, ace pitcher, like a long-lost son today, and Ole Diz was visibly touched -- to the extent of signing a pledge of loyalty and obedience.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 19. -- Maybe it was the presence of Colonel Jacob Ruppert, who was looking at his baseball investment for the first time this year. Perhaps it was the joy of celebrating the first really favorable day the athletes have had since coming here.
BOSTON, March 19. -- New England's greatest flood swept relentlessly seaward tonight leaving in its wake a constantly mounting toll of life and property damage.

James J. Walker, former Mayor of New York, and his wife adopted a 5-week-old baby girl from The Cradle, a child-placing society in Evanston, Ill., on Tuesday, it was disclosed yesterday when papers were filed.

ALBANY, March 19. -- All State forces have been ordered by Governor Lehman to aid sufferers from the floods, he stated today as he kept in constant touch with New York areas where the high waters have menaced lives and property. Further, he has asked President Roosevelt for "full Federal assistance."

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 19. -- A congratulatory message from President Roosevelt was received by the Right Rev. Mgr. Nelson H. Baker who today celebrated his sixtieth anniversary as a priest of the Roman Catholic Church. Father Baker, who is head of the four institutions of Our Lady of Victory, recently celebrated his ninety-fifth birthday.

Miss Carolyn Trippe gave a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Miss Margaret Caperton. The other guests were Mrs. Le Brun Rhinelander, Mrs. Moses Taylor Campbell, Mrs. John Aspegren, Mrs. Dudley P. Gilbert, Mrs. Joel Ellis Fisher Jr., Mrs. Charles S. Whitman and Miss Elizabeth Emmons.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- A supplementary report on transactions in securities in January and earlier months by officers, directors and the principal stockholders of corporations was made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Friday, March 20. -- Flood-stricken Williamsport sent out its definite news dispatch today describing scenes of horror and desolation.
Dr. Franz Boas, for thirty-seven years Professor of Anthropology at Columbia University, will retire from active service June 30, it was announced yesterday. He will be 78 years old in July.

LONDON, March 19 (Canadian Press). -- Leading bookmakers still rated Miss Dorothy Paget's Golden Miller as the favorite for the Grand National Steeplechase to be run at Aintree on March 27 in odds released today. Golden Miller was quoted at 6 to 1, with Reynoldstown, victor last year, the second choice at 13 to 2.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Some inhabitants of the national capital took to boats today as an 18.1-foot crest at 6 P.M. brought the Potomac River to a record high and put parts of the business and residential districts of Georgetown and other riverfront sections of Washington under many feet of water.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 19. -- Details of two of the largest Eastern intercollegiate rowing regattas, the Yale-Harvard and the Columbia-Pennsylvania-Yale events, were announced today.
JOHNSTOWN, Pa., March 19 (AP). -- Fresh additions to the death list, mitigated by fresh food and aid to suffering survivors, came to this stricken city tonight in the wake of a devastating flood.

St. Francis College of Brooklyn and Niagara University, surprise survivors of Wednesday night's preliminary-round contests, will meet tonight at Madison Square Garden for the right to represent District No. 1 in the college Olympic basketball tryouts.

No immediate danger threatens the milk supply of the metropolitan district as a result of flood conditions, it was reported yesterday by the principal milk distributing agencies. Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, following conferences with officials of milk companies, said that New York milk receipts were being closely watched.

A temporary halt in current shipments will be followed by heavy purchasing of pre-Easter merchandise by buyers of stores in the flood areas to replace millions of dollars worth of goods damaged by water and mud, reports here yesterday indicated.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has the right to subpoena witnesses in the course of its investigations without according to them the privilege of inspecting minutes or bringing their own stenographers along, Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson ruled yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- An increase of more than $5,000,000 in the value of United States exports to Canada over the total for the preceding month was a feature of the Federal foreign trade statistics for January, according to revised figures made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Flood conditions which have caused much damage and loss of life throughout the East have filled the city water system reservoirs to capacity, or rather to overflowing, Maurice P. Davidson, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, said yesterday.

New York City residents and corporations paid about $100,000,000 in income taxes in the period ending March 16, according to figures given out yesterday at the three local district offices of the Bureau of Internal Revenue. A 26 per cent increase over last year's collections was reported.

The following film programs, which will be shown over the week-end, have been endorsed by the schools motion picture committee, a voluntary organization of faculty members and parents of children in public and private schools:
Spring is icumen in at 1:58 o'clock sharp this afternoon. At that minute the sun will cross the Equator on its journey northward.

Again yesterday the only means of travel to and from some of the flooded sections of the East was through the air. TWA, which serves Pittsburgh on its transcontinental line, put every available bit of equipment into service and added two freight planes to its fourteen-passenger Douglas transports.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 19. -- To meet Jane Peterson (Mrs. M. Bernard Philipp) and other artists now here whose works will be on display from tomorrow until March 26 at the Society of the Four Arts, Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Dillman entertained members of that organization and other friends with a preview and tea today at the salon.

The New York County grand jury, after listening to many witnesses in District Attorney Dodge's investigation of ambulance chasing and bogus accident claims, ordered "informations" filed in Special Sessions yesterday against two lawyers.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- The Central Maine Power Company of Augusta, Me., filed today a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Securities Act of 1933 for the issuance of $9,000,000 of first and general mortgage bonds, Series H, 4 per cent, due on Feb. 1, 1966.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 19. -- The burlesque bonus movement among college students, which originated at Princeton University this week, spread today to eleven more campuses in this part of the country, bringing the total to thirty, it was announced at the national offices of the Veterans of Future Wars on Nassau Street here.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., March 19. -- Policemen, United States Navy sailors and National Guardsmen united in an effort to halt looting, which started in Springfield's many miles of inundated streets hero tonight.

Brokers' loans, as reported by member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City, declined $79,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the condition statement of the banks, published yesterday. The reduction, which carried loans to brokers and dealers down to $1,010,000,000, wiped out about half of the rise of $159,000,000 which had occurred in the two preceding weeks.

CHICAGO, March 19. -- A much better undertone prevailed in the wheat market on the Board of Trade today with some enlargement in general speculative interest because of persistent dust storms and dry weather reports from the Southwest.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- After a four-day conference of Federal Reserve Bank presidents with the Federal Reserve Board, announcement was made today of the organization of the new open-market committee of the Federal Reserve System to determine the open-market policies of the system.

Anxiety over the floods in New Jersey continued yesterday as efforts for the relief of stricken families were united. The waters of the Delaware River receded slowly after-rising to more than sixteen feet above normal at Trenton.

In his message to Congress recommending a relief appropriation for next year, President ROOSEVELT declined to estimate how many people now lack work. No figure "can be even approximately accurate," he said, "because "of the impossibility of an exact defini"tion of what constitutes unemploy"ment."

A prolonged armistice in industrial conflict while capital and labor jointly strive for economic rehabilitation was predicted last night by Harry Uviller, newly appointed impartial chairman of the dress industry, at a dinner tendered him in the Hotel Astor last night by employers' associations and unions in the apparel trades.
WASHINGTON, March 19. -- President Roosevelt today broke the deadlock in the railroad management-union conferences and arranged for a continuation of the joint meeting at 10 A.M. tomorrow.

With thousands of motorists, anxious to start on trips, telephoning to automobile clubs, oil companies and other road information services, word went out to postpone any long tours in New York and nearby States until highways were safe for use.

It is surprising how little the average citizen knows about the officers and men comprising the New York City Police Department. Like thousands of others, it was my impression that, particularly among the higher officers, there were "soft" jobs.

ATHENS, March 19. -- Many missing fragments of pottery from vessels exhibited in the National Museum of Greece have been discovered by Lincoln MacVeagh, United States Minister to Greece, in excavations beneath the eastern face of Acropolis Hill.

The future control of tuberculosis in this city and in other thickly populated areas will depend upon the concentration of study and treatment of this disease among small units of population, according to authorities in this field who addressed the section on health education of the Welfare Council at a luncheon yesterday in the Hotel Lexington.

OTTAWA, March 19 (Canadian Press). -- Deposits by the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada in the week ended yesterday decreased $3,106,523, as deposits by chartered banks increased $5,182,294, said the weekly statement of the bank, issued today. The statement follows:
Formation of a Columbia College post of the Veterans of Future Wars and of a Teachers College chapter of the Future Gold Star Mothers was announced yesterday at Columbia University.

It may seem strange that a Cuban should attempt to give you advice concerning your administration of national affairs, but I have a soft spot in my heart for your country, especially the Central West, where I grew from a mere boy into a man.

The warning that "selfish interests" are misleading the American people into the belief that the antimonopoly laws, aimed to preserve fair competition, are "an economic fallacy and a mistake," was sounded last night by Charles H. March, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, in an address at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Counsel for former directors of the closed State Title and Mortgage Company and the General Surety Company objected yesterday to having Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler sit as trial justice when they defend two actions brought by the State Superintendent of Insurance for $10,000,000 damages for negligence and waste of assets of the corporations.

Many persons in the financial community were busy yesterday trying to arrive at some conclusion as to the probable effect of the floods on the security markets. Some were of the opinion that the floods would not be an important factor, while a few persons were inclined to the belief that some companies, particularly those engaged largely in the building industry, would be benefited.

Today's new films are "Petticoat Fever," adapted by Metro from Mark Reed's play and featuring Robert Montgomery, Myrna Loy and Reginald Owen, at the Capitol, and "The Preview Murder Mystery," with Reginald Denny, Frances Drake and Gail Patrick, at the Rialto.

Against a rosy word picture predicting future prosperity for the Associated Gas Company system delineated yesterday before Federal Judge Julian W. Mack, Jack Lewis Kraus 2d, attorney for a small group of creditors, argued that the vast $700,000,000 holding company system was hopelessly insolvent and would fall into a thousand pieces if the court failed to save its assets.

LOS ANGELES, March 19. -- A 23-year-old wanderer from Henderson, Ky., and a 60-year-old semi-invalid were held by police tonight, accused of being the principals in a plot which resulted in the slaying of Mrs. Ethel Whittaker, 44 years old, in her apartment here Tuesday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 19. -- The Yale swimming team tonight achieved its 151st consecutive victory in turning back a fast and well-balanced Harvard aggregation, 45 to 26. The meet was not decided until the penultimate event.

A statement of condition as of March 4 by J.P. Morgan Co. and Drexel Co., their Philadelphia branch, published yesterday, disclosed a decline of $79,276,745 in deposits and one of $79,826,778 in total resources compared with Dec. 31, 1935.

Tenders will be considered on April 10 by Cuyahoga County, Ohio, for a new issue of $1,050,000 of poor relief bonds. The bonds, which will be dated April 1, 1936, and mature on March 1, 1937 to 1944, will carry a 6 per cent interest rate.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 19. -- The names of nearly 500 couples who will attend the annual promenade of the junior class of Princeton University in the university gymnasium tomorrow night were announced here tonight by E. Newton Cutler, '37, of Morristown, chairman of the promenade committee.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Lammot du Pont, president of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., received a salary of $100,219 in 1934 and W. S. Carpenter Jr., vice president, remuneration of $106,270, the latter including a bonus of $45,500, according to data filed by the company with the Securities and Exchange Commission, made public today.

A patrol wagon from the West Twentieth Street police station yesterday morning was carried in a freight elevator to the tenth floor of the Port Authority Building, 111 Eighth Avenue, where ten of a band of WPA demonstrators were arrested.
WILKES-BARRE, Pa., March 19. -- After starting downward, the raging waters of the Susquehanna River climbed to a new record tonight, passing the thirty-three-foot mark at Wilkes-Barre.

HATFIELD, Mass. (Via Telephone to Albany, N.Y.), March 19 (AP). -- Hip-booted State police in motor boats, aided by giant flood lights, completed tonight a dramatic rescue of 150 men, women and children marooned for twenty-four hours in a town hall surrounded by the raging Connecticut River.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the receipt of applications to list the securities of ten corporations. The companies and their issues were as follows:

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 19. -- Play in the Bermuda tennis championships was resumed today before a large gallery which included Governor General Sir Thomas Astley Cubitt. The schedule was speeded to recover the time lost through yesterday's postponement, some players competing in three matches.

Higher prices for meats, potatoes, butter, lemons, sugar and cotton sent The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices up 0.9 point to 125.4 on Tuesday from 124.5 the Tuesday previous. Wheat and oats were lower. The European crisis continued without apparent effect on prices.

The extremely heavy precipitation of rain and snow by a storm which formed over Alabama on March 16 and gradually proceeded northeast until its center was over New York City yesterday is the principal reason for the almost simultaneous outbreak of severe floods in more than a dozen States, Dr. James H. Kimball, chief of the Weather Bureau here, said yesterday.

ALBANY, March 19. -- The deadlock between the Republican-dominated Assembly and the Democrat-controlled Senate over the former's reductions in Governor Lehman's budget, aggregating $15,562,000, held firm today with no prospect of either party of the Governor shifting ground.
The New York Americans brought their regular National Hockey League season to a close last night by defeating the Canadiens of Montreal at Madison Square Garden, 4 to 1.

SHERBROOKE, Que., March 19 (Canadian Press). -- The St. Francis River was still a raging torrent tonight as rain added to flood difficulties in this section of the eastern townships. Water was rising again after receding slightly during the day, and damages were mounting to many thousands of dollars.
May I as President of the Municipal Civil Service Commission ask your readers for help in using the present opportunity to make permanent civil service gains for our public?

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, March 19. -- In a militant speech, marking the opening of his campaign for the Republican nomination for President and his drive for the delegates from Ohio, Senator Borah tonight defined his position on vital national issues.

Softer airs, upthrusting green swords of the early bulbs, a flush of color in bark of bough and twig, even an occasional liquid bird song -- all these are welcome harbingers of Spring. The prudent dweller in suburb or more open country will recall, however, that with new leaves soon to clothe again the nakedness of tree and shrub will come destructive forces threatening their beauty and their use.

Declaring that the "government has not got the money" to care for all those in need, former Governor Alfred E. Smith participated yesterday in launching the annual appeal for funds by the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York. The meeting, held to organize the special gifts committee for the drive, was in the rooms of the Empire State Club at the Empire State Building.

The Hamburg-American liner Hansa will arrive today from Germany many and way ports. Her passengers include Baroness Herma von Goerne, Dr. and Mrs. Rudolf Mattfeldt, Mrs. Amalie Pfeiffer, Capt. E.J. Ketels-Harken, Miss Marion Young, Harry G. Roth and Mr. and Mrs. Richard Strauss.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 19 (AP). -- A general recession of flood waters in some sections of the State has permitted the reopening of several roads during the last twelve hours, the State Highway Division reported tonight.

DETROIT, March 19. -- James J. O'Shea, vice president of the National Bank of Detroit, was arrested this afternoon on a Federal warrant charging violation of the Federal Reserve Act by misapplication of nearly $349,000 in the city trust fund on deposit in the bank of which he was an official.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 19 (AP). -- The mad, yellow Susquehanna resembled an endless lake from the air today as its swollen waters, fed by a driving rain, spilled over hilltop and lowland for more than 1,100 miles.

Mayor La Guardia, his transit advisers, the Transit Commission and the privately operated rapid transit companies are opposed to the bill introduced by Assemblyman Edward S. Moran Jr., Brooklyn Democrat, calling for approval by popular referendum of a rapid transit unification plan.

The demand for stocks continued selective in character yesterday, although a little wider than on the day before, so that more than half of the active issues advanced from fractions to about 4 points while the remainder either held unchanged or closed slightly lower on the average.
The New York Athletic Club's saber team captured the national title on its home strips last night with one of the best performances seen here in a long time.

NEWARK, N.J., March 19. -- The painting of a nude Venus lying on the seashore, which hangs above the bar in a Paterson saloon and outraged the wife of a local minister, need not be removed, D. Frederick Burnett, New Jersey Alcohol Beverage Control Commissioner, ruled here today.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- A tentative agreement on the treatment of banks, insurance companies and other fiduciary groups in the new tax legislation was reached today by the taxation subcommittee of the Ways and Means Committee.

Spirited bidding marked the sale at foreclosure of the four-story house at 20 East Sixty-eighth Street yesterday when Edwin J. McDonald, auctioneer, received sixty-seven bids for the property from five bidders. The parcel was finally struck down on a bid of $22,325 to Morton Freedman, who acted for a client.
Store, office and showroom space was in good demand again yesterday when brokers and renting agents of buildings throughout the city announced many additional contracts for quarters.

MADRID, March 19. -- Parliamentary debate on the cause of the recent disorders in Spain and the responsibility for them was postponed today because Interior Minister Amos Salvador, who is in charge of law enforcement, was indisposed.

Eleven members of the American Olympic hockey team returned yesterday on the United States liner Manhattan following more than two months of play in Europe. Manager Walter Brown, heading the party, had high praise for the spirit displayed by the squad throughout its extended tour.

LONDON, Friday other world peace time this year is one of the proposals in an agreement of four Locarno powers, reached yesterday and submitted last night to the Cabinets of Great Britain, France and Belgium for their immediate consideration.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

There was six feet of water in the Beaverkill at Roscoe yesterday afternoon. The river still was over the banks in some spots, but had resumed its natural course for most of its length and was dropping gradually.

Harry F. Wolf, the national amateur squash tennis champion from the New York A.C., defeated A.H. Marckwald of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club last night as the national open championship got under way at the Hotel Shelton. The score was 15 -- 6, 15 -- 4, 18 -- 13.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Charges by members of the Senate Lobby Investigating Committee that James A. Arnold, general manager of the American Taxpayers' League, used Poor's Manual of Directors as "a sucker list" in soliciting financial contributions to the league so angered Mr. Arnold as a witness today that he jumped to his feet and denounced the group as a "polecat committee."

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- The Federal Communications Commission was told today that racing news wire services were developing into major rackets, rivaling the profits of the palmiest days of bootlegging and threatening the well-being and even the lives of the citizens and as such should not have the facilities of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

The prices of commodity futures generally were higher yesterday, with the trading volume improved a little. In the cash market wheat, flour, cocoa, lard and rubber were higher, while corn, oats, butter, eggs, tin and cotton were lower.

Bond trading was routine yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange with prices generally holding to narrow limits on a moderate turnover. The averages for domestic corporation issues eased off slightly on the day. Transactions amounted to $10,444,400, compared with $11,942,400 on Wednesday.

Yehudi Menuhin, the young American violinist, returned from Europe yesterday on the Paris, prepared to make his final appearance, before a two-year vacation, at Carnegie Hall next Sunday. After that he will retire to his ranch home in the Santa Cruz Mountains near San Francisco so as to "get back to earth for a while."

LONDON, March 19. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange today were quiet, but prices were firm with the heavy settlement. Renewed investment support caused early improvement in British funds, although they reacted later.
ALBANY, March 19. -- Two cases involving the validity of the Unemployment Insurance Law were put before the Court of Appeals this afternoon.
GREEN ISLAND, N.Y., March 19 (AP). -- The Hudson River inundated half of this island town of 7,000 population today but apparently began to recede slightly this afternoon.

Retail parcel deliveries for the week ended March 14 showed an increase of 10 per cent over the same period last year, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The figure is slightly lower than the gain of 11 per cent noted for the preceding week, but was taken here yesterday to reflect the maintenance of an active retail trade pace despite the inclement weather last week.

Grover Cleveland and Newtown High Schools finished in a tie for the Queens P.S.A.L. basketball title by triumphing in the final contests of the regular tournament yesterday. Paced by Captain Jim Sarullo, Cleveland crushed Bryant, 44 -- 18, in an afternoon battle at Cleveland, while Newtown routed John Adams, 37 -- 13, last night at Newtown.

Clearly forecast was yesterday's unanimous vote of the Council of the League of Nations against Germany. Previous expressions of opinion by the separate members had made it certain that they would hold her to be a deliberate violator of treaties. This action, it will be noted, stands by itself.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Wholesale prices declined to a new low level for the year in the week ended on March 14, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The index, based on the 1926 average as 100, was 79.2, compared with 79.7 the preceding week and 79.4 a year ago.

DAYTON, Ohio, March 19. -- The special for best in show at the close of the tenth annual exhibition of the Dayton Kennel Club tonight was won by the cocker spaniel Ch. My Black Model, owned by William Gass and Mrs. N.J. Levine and handled by N.J. Levine.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- The House today reversed its stand of last month and passed a bill to exempt from all taxation shares of preferred bank stock held by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. The vote was 218 to 144.

TRENTON, March 19. -- A list of delegates pledged to cast their combined quota of thirty-two votes for President Roosevelt at the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia next June was filed with the Secretary of State here today by Charles Quinn, secretary of the Democratic State Committee.

The council of the Dramatists Guild declined yesterday to accept the invitation of the League of New York Theatres to meet with it to "negotiate," or in other words change, the new minimum basic agreement of the dramatists.

SAN JUAN CAPISTRANO, Calif., March 19. -- The swallows fluttered in from the Western sky to their San Juan Capistrano Mission home today, for this is March 19, but their sixty-nine-year-old record for punctuality was broken by the early arrival of several hundred.

BERLIN, March 19. -- Actual unemployment in the Reich in the past Winter increased by nearly 50 per cent more than the officially registered unemployment figures indicated, according to a report published today by the Institute for Business Research.

With business activity since the first of the year proceeding at a good rate, worries about the adverse effect of a Presidential year on general conditions are abating somewhat and large advertisers are beginning to shape up budgets for the last six months.

Leading public utility groups yesterday were throwing all available facilities in the various flood areas together in order to bring service to the areas affected and keep light and heat communications and water service going as far as possible and to restore services to the areas hardest hit.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, March 19. -- German satisfaction over Rhineland rearmament reaches a climax in the industrial section of the demilitarized zone, which stretches in an almost unbroken forest of smokestacks along the east bank of the Rhine from Cologne to Essen and includes the canals of the vast inland harbor of Ruhrort, a post-war development.

From the Ohio and Potomac Valleys to Maine, the greatest floods of this century in the northeastern section of the country rolled on unchecked last night in eleven States. The death toll had mounted to 134 or more. Thousands were fleeing from newly threatened communities and the ravaged sections were fighting to combat widespread disease, hunger and looting.
Transportation to the flooded areas of Pennsylvania, Western New York and New England was still paralyzed yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 19. -- Hogs were in good demand here today with prices strong to 10 cents a hundred-weight higher than yesterday the greater part of the day.
