Near the close hogs weighing above 230 pounds lost their early upturn and were quoted around steady. The top price was 5 cents higher with the day's average up a like amount to $10.30.
ALBANY, March 19 (AP). -- Floods receded slowly in New York State tonight, leaving a problem for relief agencies who are trying to aid 4,000 homeless.

The presidents of six Eastern railroads agreed yesterday to a reduction of the basic passenger fare in this region for the first time in this century. It was indicated that tariffs embodying the reductions would be filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission by May 2 at the latest.

TORONTO, March 19. -- The Boston Bruins won themselves a sure third position in the National Hockey League's American Group tonight by tying the Toronto Maple Leafs, 2 -- 2, in a game that had all the thrills of a play-off.

A State law requiring certificates of origin for coal trucked here from other States was suggested yesterday by Walter Gordon Merritt, counsel to the Anthracite Institute, as a means of checking the "stolen coal" competition with which the anthracite industry is contending.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- On the heels of President Roosevelt's request for a new appropriation of $1,500,000,000 to continue work relief another year, the Senate Committee on Expenditures in Executive Departments today approved an investigation of the entire Works Progress Administration.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 19. -Paced by the solid batting of a hitherto hitless Brooklyn athlete, Casey Stengel's Dodgers today returned to last Spring's habit of beating the champion Tigers and disappointed 1,000 Detroit rooters by halting Mickey Cochrane's men, 10 to 6.

EASTON, Pa., March 19. -- The waters of the Delaware and Lehigh Rivers, which flooded most of the business section and forced scores to leave their homes on the banks of the rivers, were slowly receding tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -President Roosevelt postponed his departure for Florida on a fishing trip, took a fifty-mile ride to view the flooded areas in Washington and vicinity and issued an appeal for $3,000,000 in public subscriptions to the Red Cross for flood relief.
MARIETTA, Ohio, March 19 (AP). -- Flood waters pushed unabated out of the industrially-rich upper Ohio River valley into a less populated agricultural region, today.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP). -- Boys and girls in their teens appealed today to the Senate Education and Labor Subcommittee for passage of the Amlie-Benson bill providing jobs for youths and aid for students.

LONDON, March 19. -- Labor leaders of fifteen European countries proved at their conference here today that, although they are Socialists and internationalists on the surface, most of them are also patriots and nationalists under the skin.

MIAMI, Fla., March 19. -- W.J. Hirsch's filly, Columbiana, second to the Kentucky Derby favorite, Brevity, at Hialeah in her last appearance, ran as her short odds indicated to win the Pomona Purse of one mile, chief magnet on the eight-race card presented today at Tropical Park.

With only three full and two short trading sessions left before March goes off the board at noon on next Wednesday, progress was made yesterday in releasing March contracts on the Cotton Exchange. It was estimated that houses handling government business distributed fully 15,000 bales which reduced pool holdings in the spot month to about 50,000.

RICHMOND, Va., March 19 (AP). -- The State Capital moved hurriedly tonight to protect itself from the swirling waters of the James River, rising toward the highest mark in decades. Other sections of Virginia were suffering from the ravages of flood waters that have swept through the State the past two days, bringing death to four persons.
PARIS, March 19 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

A local relief organization to carry out New York's assigned part in the national appeal by the American Red Cross for a fund of $3,000,000 to relieve flood sufferers in eleven States will be set up immediately, General Robert C. Davis, director of the New York chapter of the Red Cross, said last night.

PARIS, March 19. -- Foreign Minister Pierre-Etienne Flandin returned to Paris this evening and laid his account of the London negotiations and the draft of the agreement between the Locarno treaty experts before the Cabinet.

A plan under which the City Abstract Corporation would operate title companies organized by Superintendent of Insurance Pink to carry on the title business of mortgage companies now in his hands for rehabilitation was submitted yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Frankenthaler at the hearing on the Aetna Casualty and Surety Company's offer of $1,376,282 for three such title companies.

Business activity underwent another substantial setback last month according to The Annalist index of business activity, which declined to 88.1 (preliminary) from 91.3 for January. The index now has lost 6.7 points since December, or slightly more than 40 per cent of the May-December, 1935, rise.

The strengthening of the transcontinental railroads as competitors with the intercoastal ship lines for long-haul freight was urged yesterday by George C. Lucas, vice president of the National Publishers Association, in an address at a meeting of the Traffic Club of New York at the Hotel Biltmore.

Joe Louis and Max Schmeling will fight in this city in June. Announcement to that effect was made yesterday by Mike Jacobs, secretary of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club, under whose auspices the bout will take place. The Free Milk Fund for Babies, Inc., will share in the proceeds.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Charges that the Bethlehem Steel Company and fourteen other large manufacturers of tin plate had entered an agreement which tended to create a monopoly in the manufacture of tin containers on the part of the American Can Company and Continental Can Company, which together consume about 65 per cent of the production of tin plate, were made in a complaint issued today by the Federal Trade Commission.

ALBANY, March 19. -- A public hearing on ratification of the child labor amendment to the Federal Constitution will be conducted by the Senate Judiciary Committee on March 31, Senator William T. Byrne, Albany Democratic chairman, decided tonight.

Writing in The Annalist, GEORGE B. ROBINSON suggests an alternative to the proposed punitive tax on undistributed corporation profits. It is simply that corporation taxes be abolished entirely, and that in place of them stockholders be taxed on their pro rata shares of the annual income of the corporations just as if it were part of their personal incomes.

Mrs. Melita Lynch, 31 years old, wife of Willard A. Lynch, a member of the brokerage firm of W.C. Langley Co., 115 Broadway, fell or jumped to her death at 1:10 o'clock this morning, according to a preliminary police report, from a bedroom window in the Lynch apartment on the twelfth floor of 1,070 Park Avenue, at the southwest corner of Eighty-eighth Street.

"Just a plain piece of cheese," cucumbers, chickens, fruit cakes and other edibles, a "mysterious meat-block" and an unknown element named Ella all crept into the proceedings of the army court-martial of Captain Ralph E. Fleischer at Governors Island yesterday.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week amounts to only $14,500,809, representing one State and sixty-four municipalities. The revised total for this week is $24,319,651. The weekly average for the year to date is $23,442,325.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 20. -- The name of the Association of Gold Star Mothers, an affiliate of the Veterans of Future Wars, was changed here today to the Ladies Auxiliary of Future Veterans. The Future Veterans is an organization of college students demanding a bonus of $1,000 each for their activity in "future" wars.

The golden jubilee of the establishment of the first alternating current system in America, regarded by electrical engineers as having ushered in the modern-day electrical era, was celebrated last night under the auspices of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers in forty-eight principal cities throughout the country.

ALBANY, March 20. -- After conferences between Governor Lehman, leaders of the Legislature and relief experts, which have been in progress at different times for more than a month, an agreement was reached in the early morning hours today on a plan for putting the administration of unemployment relief on a basis of permanency as a division of the State Department of Social Welfare.

Emmanuel Greenberg, who was appointed to the New York State Court of Claims by Governor Lehman two weeks ago, was sworn in yesterday morning in the Appellate Term court room of the Brooklyn Supreme Court Building. The oath was administered by James J. Barrett, presiding justice of the Court of Claims.

LEXINGTON, Va., March 20. -Westerners, paced by representatives of Oklahoma colleges, monopolized the spotlight today during the opening rounds of the ninth annual National Collegiate Athletic Association wrestling championships in Doremus Memorial Gymnasium at Washington and Lee University.

With Ruggiero Ricci, the boy violin virtuoso, as soloist, Paul Stassevitch and his fifty-five-piece orchestra were heard last night in Town Hall in a program consisting of Geminiani's concerto in C minor, in the Adolfo Betti edition; the Casella "Serenata" and the Beethoven and Mendelssohn violin concertos.

As a result of the political manoeuvring and "dilly-dallying" of the Legislature, which has held up revision of the New York old age assistance laws, New York City is faced with a direct loss in revenue of $268,000, William Hodson, Commissioner of Public Welfare, charged yesterday at a luncheon meeting at the City Club.

LONDON, March 20. -- The British and French Governments made public today their proposals, framed in collaboration with Belgium and Italy, for rectifying the menacing European situation caused by Germany's violation of the Locarno treaty two weeks ago when she sent her troops into the demilitarized zone.

PARIS, March 20. -- France's attention, absorbed for the past two weeks by the international political crisis, was drawn sharply back to the treasury situation by a bill increasing treasury issues which was passed by Parliament tonight.

A few weeks ago we referred to the report of the British Board of Trade on Great Britain's balance of international payments, visible and invisible, during 1935. The general figures showed clearly the recovery that had occurred in shipping income and income from foreign investments, through which an excess of 1,000,000 in payments over receipts during 1934 was turned in 1935 into an excess of receipts amounting to 37,000,000, the largest since 1929.

Collection of a $100,000 campaign fund for Senator William E. Borah of Idaho, candidate for the Republican nomination for President, is sought by the recently organized Farmers' and Business Men's National Committee for Borah, it was disclosed yesterday by receipt of letters soliciting subscriptions by local Republicans.
U.S. Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

LONDON, March 20. -- Discord within the Council of the League of Nations was disclosed tonight over provisions of the Rhineland program as mapped by representatives of the four Locarno powers. A row broke out when the document was submitted at a private session of the Council.

WESTFIELD, N.J., March 20. -Playing host to twenty-two strange children, stranded by the Johnstown flood, is the novel experience of Andrew B. Crichton, president of the Johnstown Coal and Coke Company. The Crichton home, in Westmont, a suburb of Johnstown, is approximately 1,000 feet above the level of the city's business section and has escaped flood damage.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:
LONDON, March 20. -- Highlights of the four-power plan published today in a British White Paper are:

In your editorial "Isolated Germany" you call the action of the present German Government "need]ess and stupid." I am sure many Americans do not subscribe to that sentiment. If anything must be called needless and studio% St would be the Treaty of Versailles, document of blind hatred and irresponsibility.

The National City Bank was negligent in its administration of the estate of Adolph Hollander, insurance man, and must pay back to the estate $103,489 and interest, William J. O'Shea Jr., as special referee, held in a report just filed in Surrogate's Court.
ROME, Saturday, March 21 (AP). -Italian dispatches reported today that Italian airplanes flew over the important city of Harar in Eastern Ethiopia and bombarded large Ethiopian formations.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- The number of farms in the United States on Jan. 1, 1935, was 6,812,350, an increase of 8.3 per cent over the 6,288,648 on April 1, 1930, according to a digest from the 1935 Federal farm census released by William L. Austin, director of the Bureau of the Census, Department of Commerce.
LOS ANGELES, March 20. -- One of the world's foremost authorities on the human body said today that the march of science had left the human being by the wayside.

In the book of the martyrs one of the finest chapters is T.S. Eliot's "Murder in the Cathedral," which the Federal Theatre Project put on at the Manhattan last evening. Specifically, it is a dramatization of the murder of Thomas a Becket at Canterbury on the fateful Dec. 29, 1170, and it was first produced at Canterbury Festival last June.

LONDON, March 20. -- Labor and Socialist leaders from fifteen European countries ended their three-day conference on the international crisis tonight by denouncing Germany's reoccupation of the Rhineland as a "wantom act" and a "grave menace to peace."
SEDALIA, Mo., March 20 (AP). -Herman P. Faris, 77, once a Prohibition nominee for President of the United States in 1924, was killed today when his motor car crashed into a bridge near Deepwater, Mo.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 20. -- Three weeks of training under surprisingly tricky Florida weather finds the Yankees today at a point which is satisfactory with Manager Joe McCarthy. The unfavorable climatic conditions encountered here for the first time since he assumed the helm in 1931 has left its mark on the athletes of Marse Joe, but not to an extent that is causing him alarm.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP). -The tax troubles of a movie actress, a public utilities leader, a former Representative and a security holder in an Insull company featured today's activities of the Board of Tax Appeals.

A preliminary proceeding seeking to have the Associated Gas and Electric Company declared insolvent as the first step to reorganize it under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act was ended yesterday when Federal Judge Julian W. Mack ordered trial of the issue before himself, beginning April 13, instead of turning the case over to an advisory master.

BOSTON, March 20. -- As competition in the women's singles division of the New England open badminton championships started today on the courts of the University Club, Mrs. R. Bergman, unseeded and unheralded entry, engineered the first major upset by defeating Miss Elizabeth Smith of Boston, ranked No. 2, by 11 -- 5, 11 -- 9, in a second-round match.

Attorney General BENNETT has acted with commendable promptness in appealing the New York State minimum wage case to the Supreme Court. The four-to-three decision of the Court of Appeals holding the Minimum Wage Law unconstitutional was based almost entirely on a five-to-three decision of the Supreme Court more than a dozen years ago, which declared invalid a Minimum Wage Law of the District of Columbia.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 20. -Harvard tonight opened the formal observance of the 300th anniversary of its founding with exercises in Sanders Theatre in commemoration of the birthday of Dr. Charles W. Eliot, former president of Harvard University.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Two major agreements on the plan to tax the undivided profits of corporations were reached today by the Ways and Means Subcommittee, but there still remained so many details to be ironed out that it was not considered likely that a complete plan would be laid before the full committee before the end of next week.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Democratic leaders in the Senate moved today to bring under control what they thought might otherwise turn out to be a political investigation of the Works Progress Administration.
LONDON, March 20. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange were firm today following the agreement on the German situation, but business was quiet.

I would like to cite three examples of successful mass production in athletics by three coaches of three different sports at three disassociated institutions. They are Bob Kiphuth, Yale swimming coach; Nat Holman, City College basketball coach, and Pete Waters, Manhattan track coach.

Stock prices moved irregularly, yesterday, and for the most part narrowly, as cautious sentiment continued to prevail. The closing was slightly lower, on the average. Trading was slower, amounting to 1,888,000 shares on the Stock Exchange, against 2,016,000 the day before.

ALBANY, March 20. -- Dr. Thomas Parran Jr., State Commissioner of Health, submitted a detailed report to Governor Lehman today on steps taken by his department to protect the health of residents in the flood-ravaged communities.

Colonel Jennings C. Wise gave a dinner last night in the Russian Eagle of the Sherry-Netherland for the Duke and Duchess Armand de Richelieu, Count and Countess Philippe de Forceville, Colonel and Mrs. George H. Burr, Mr. and Mrs. Richmond Parry Kennard, Mr. and Mrs. John L. Johnston, Mr. and Mrs. Albert Boardman Kerr, Mrs. Thompson Drexel and Dr. George de Bothezart.

PARIS, March 20. -- Foreign Minister Pierre-Etienne Flandin presented today, in a long statement to the Chamber of Deputies, his account of the London negotiations of the League of Nations Council and the Locarno treaty powers and their results.

There is no room for unqualified condemnation of Hitler for his breach of the Treaty of Versailles, even though he should have lived up to it, to do his country ethical justice; but the fact is well known that Germany was repressed in a most inhumane manner, and against her will forced to sign a blank check and an arbitrary agreement.

TORONTO, March 20 (Canadian Press). -- Half the places on the National Hockey League's all-star team went to members of the Boston Bruins, according to the balloting conducted by The Canadian Press and announced tonight.

Four jurors were chosen yesterday from a special panel of 100 talesmen at the start of the General Sessions trial of Miss Vera Stretz, 23 years old, former New York University student, on the first-degree murder indictment in the shooting of Dr. Fritz Gebhardt, German industrial agent in this country.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP). -Secretary Ickes charged before the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee today that "industry has not been helping out" with the recovery program.

CAMDEN, S.C., March 20. -- The entries of Miss Wilhelmine S. Kirby of Bedford Hills, N.Y., again featured the twenty-sixth annual Camden horse show today as competition came to a close in the ring of the Cherokee Club. More than 100 horses competed in the two-day event, which attracted many leading exhibitors from the North.

After three arbitrators in the George White-Rudy Valee controversy ruled last night that the "clash of temperament" was not sufficient ground for the discharge of the crooner, Hyman Bushel, attorney for Vallee announced that his client would not continue with the Scandals at the New Amsterdam Theatre.
The swimmers of St. Francis Prep retained the city Catholic High Schools championship last night in the title meet staged at the New York Athletic Club pool.

Franklin Simon Co. and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31 a net loss of $147,753 after depreciation, amortization of buildings, Federal taxes and other charges. The loss in the preceding year was $241,103 after similar deductions, and for the year ended on Jan. 31, 1934, the loss amounted to $548,831.

The Gallery Boys of the Lambs Club are preparing to give a testimonial dinner at the clubhouse, 128 West Forty-fourth Street, for Tom Lamb, 4-year-old feline bar-fly and mascot of the club. No date has been set for the feast, but it will be held as soon after the Lambs annual Gambol on March 29 as arrangements can be made.

Charging that the Robinson-Patman and related price discrimination bills pending in Congress will destroy rather than foster competition, Dr. Malcolm P. McNair of Harvard University yesterday warned members of the Association of Buying Offices, Inc., that they must work aggressively to prevent enactment of the bills by Congress.

Contributions to the Red Cross flood relief fund being raised by the New York Chapter reached $47,243.21 last night, according to an announcement by General Robert C. Davis, executive director. The chapter seeks to raise $375,000 as its quota in the national drive of the Red Cross to obtain $3,000,000.

Tom Iannicelli of the Essex Club, Newark, the defending titleholder, defeated Phil T. Moore, Columbia University Club amateur, in a second-round match last night in the National open squash tennis championship at the Hotel Shelton. The score was 15 -- 6, 15 -- 5, 15 -- 6.

ROME, March 20. -- It is emphatically asserted in Rome that sanctions have not been the object of any "deal" between Italy and France. France, it is said, has revised her attitude toward sanctions because she could not help herself.

A new principle or method of diplomacy appears to be in the making. Instead a proceeding from the complex to the simple, it reverses that order. When a single issue has become highly troublesome and intractable, the new plan seems to be to put it together with a lot of other difficult public questions and then throw them all into a common melting-pot.

Directors of the Virginia-Carolina Chemical Corporation approved yesterday the redemption and retirement of all of the company's 7 per cent cumulative prior preference stock. About 38,000 shares are held by the public.

LONDON, March 20. -- The announcement that the League of Nations Conciliation Committee of Thirteen would meet again Monday after many postponements suddenly revived hopes today that hostilities in Ethiopia would be ended soon and that sanctions against Italy would be dropped without long delay.

Lehman Brothers and associates have agreed to purchase from the Royal Dutch-Shell interests 330,614 shares of the Class B common stock of the Flintkote Company, manufacturer of asphalt products, at $45 a share, or a total consideration of approximately $15,000,000, it was disclosed in a registration statement filed yesterday by the company with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

BERLIN, March 20. -- Dr. Wilhelm Zoellner, 80-year-old government-appointed head of the Protestant Reich Church directorate created by Hanns Kerrl, Minister for Church Affairs, issued today a political proclamation to all the world's Christian churches urging them to stand with Germany against Bolshevist Russia in the present international crisis.
Transportation to the flooded areas of Pennsylvania, Western New York and New England was partly restored yesterday by railroad and bus companies.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- The Eastern Gas and Fuel Associates has filed an amendment to its registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 for the issuance of $75,000,000 of first mortgage and collateral trust bonds, Series A, 4 per cent, due on March 1, 1956, giving the underwriters and the allocation to each as follows:

Residents of New Jersey and Pennsylvania communities along both banks of the Delaware River from Easton, Pa., to Philadelphia began yesterday repairing damage done by this week's high water in the valley, as the floods, which reached a peak of sixteen and onehalf feet Thursday afternoon, receded to half that.
BERLIN, March 20. -- The Boerse once again was completely paralyzed today by the double pressure of nervousness regarding the foreign situation and the official domination of the market.

Because of flood conditions affecting sanitation in wide areas, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, has ordered his milk inspectors to see that all pasteurization plants bring their milk "well above the minimum pasteurization point of 143 degrees Fahrenheit."

ALBANY, N.Y., March 20 (AP). -New rains forecast tonight threatened to delay New York State's recovery from the serious flood conditions. Health and relief agencies pressed their efforts to prevent disease and halt suffering.

Continuing the improvement noted late in February, department store trade in the metropolitan area for the thirteen shopping days from March 2 to 16 showed an increase of 11.1 per cent, according to figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

TRENTON, N.J., March 20. -The execution of Bruno Richard Hauptmann was fixed today for March 31 at 8 P.M. as C. Lloyd Fisher, Hauptmann's counsel, revealed a statement by the prisoner that he had seen Dr. John F. Condon before and after the ransom payment in April, 1932.
Increased activity by retail merchants was indicated in the Manhattan realty deals reported yesterday, as the apartment trading continued in volume.

This morning finds the cast of "Idiot's Delight" somewhere between Pittsburgh and New York. It may still be on a bus from Pennsylvania to Columbus, or on a train from Ohio here; no one can say definitely. At all events, the company, which had withstood the flood, finally left the Nixon early last evening, canceling three performances.

While the process of evening up remaining March obligations reduced pool holdings about 15,000 bales yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange displayed decided steadiness and closed with a loss of 1 point to a gain of 4 points. An advance in Liverpool brought buying here and May rose above 11 cents for the first time since January.

MOSCOW, March 20. -- The Soviet regime is developing its defensive capacities along a third line with intensity and success. This has a special interest in view of the present strained European situation.

The realty division of the Title and Mortgage Rehabilitation and Liquidation Bureau of the State Insurance Department issued a report yesterday showing sales of 189 parcels of real estate and mortgages for an aggregate sum of $3,748,201.
PORTLAND, Me., March 20 (AP). -- Maine's ebbing flood waters took additional death toll tonight while military and civil authorities marshaled forces to battle disease and want.

BERLIN, March 20. -- An official German reaction to yesterday's memorandum of the Locarno powers more explicit than Chancellor Adolf Hitler's speech in Hamburg tonight was not forthcoming today, and it was laconically stated that examination of the memorandum's terms had not extended beyond the stage of first impressions.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- The time by which foreign governments and political subdivisions and foreign private corporate issuers must make application for permanent registration of their securities on American Exchanges, if trading in them is to be continued, was extended until May 15 today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
FREEHOLD, N.J., March 20. -One person was killed and four others injured near here today in the head-on collision of two automobiles.

The quarantine against dogs instituted by the Westchester County Board of Health covering the southern section of the county has now been extended by the State Department of Health to cover the whole county in an effort to stamp out the epidemic of rabies, of which twenty-eight cases have been reported in Westchester thus far this year.

NANUET, N.Y., Saturday, March 21. -- Federal agents, New Jersey and New York police joined forces early this morning in a hunt for four armed bandits who held up the Nanuet National Bank yesterday afternoon and escaped by kidnapping two sisters in stolen cars.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 20. -- Taking long bus trips just for the ride seems to be becoming a habit with Casey Stengel and his Dodgers. Today they dropped in here on the first half of a 170-mile round-trip prepared to play a game with the four times defeated Red Sox.
JOHNSTOWN, Pa., March 20. -Mayor Daniel L. Shields addressed an urgent appeal to President Roosevelt today for a special fund of $10,000,000 for the rehabilitation of Johnstown.

Last night President CONANT began the tercentenary season with an address which he whimsically called "Why Present Harvard Should Have a Future." There is a necessary confusion in the word "Harvard." Is the college meant or the whole university, the professional schools and all the departments?
LONDON, March 20. -- The following is the text of the British White Paper disclosing the terms of the four-power Locarno accord:

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Senator Wagner has presented to the Senate, as a contradiction of the charges of New Deal critics that business recovery has come of its own impetus and not because of the legislative activities of the Roosevelt administration, a speech made a year ago today by Joseph P. Kennedy, then chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, in which was predicted the progress which has been attained.

Two of the gang of ten captured Tuesday in a gun-filled rooming house at 322 West Ninetieth Street were identified yesterday as participants in the $75,000 robbery of Hodgson Kennard, Boston jewelers, last Aug. 30.

ROME, March 20. -- Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg of Austria and Premier Julius Goemboes of Hungary, with their Foreign Ministers and large entourages, arrived this evening for talks with Premier Benito Mussolini that are expected to strengthen the provisions and widen the scope of the agreements concluded in Rome March 17, 1934.

I was much interested in reading under dates of March 3 and 4 comments and implied defense by your Washington correspondent of the President's new tax proposals, also his concept of their inspiration and objectives.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- A soil conservation program designed to shift at least 30,000,000 acres of commercial crop land to grasses and legumes at an estimated cost of $470,000,000 this year was announced today by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration amid official misgivings as to its popularity in other than single crop sections.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 20. -With confusion and excitement reigning in Hartford's streets while more than a fifth of its area was covered by the waters of the raging Connecticut River, this capital city of the State today bore the brunt of the great flood in the Connecticut Valley.

While business was almost at a standstill in flooded areas of the country this week, consumer spending in other districts was at the best rate in five years, gains running 10 to 15 per cent over the previous week, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

LOS ANGELES, March 20. -- Concentration of scientific thought on the problems of the intellectual world and toward the achievement of the more abundant life for mankind, rather than scientific grasping to control the material wealth and production of the universe, was urged as a goal for advanced modern thinkers today by Dr. Carrel.

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 20. -- It may have been the spanking breeze which swept off the Gulf with plenty of wintry sting to it. Then again it may have been overconfidence as a result of their easy victory in Defunlak Springs yesterday.

Retail trade here maintained an active pace during the week, despite some inclement weather. Leading department stores here showed increases ranging around 12 per cent over the same period a year ago, a ratio of gain slightly better than that noted in the Federal Reserve report for the first half of March.

A thirty-day workhouse term was imposed and promptly stayed in Special Sessions yesterday on Mrs. Sarah Radin, 49 years old, on her plea of guilty to a misdemeanor in operating in her home at 20 Magaw Place, Washington Heights, a "stuffed flat" for furniture sales.
LONDON, March 20. -- The text of the speech made in the House of Commons yesterday by Anthony Eden, Foreign Secretary, follows:

Power companies in Western Pennsylvania yesterday arranged to supply Pittsburgh with all the current the various transmission lines could carry throughout the week-end, and possibly for a longer period, after it was ascertained that the Duquesne Light plants at Pittsburgh and the Springdale plant of the West Penn Power Company cannot be operated without careful reconditioning.

The United Air Lines Transport Corporation in its annual statement for 1935, to be released to stockholders today by W.A. Patterson, president, shows a net loss of $1,392. In the previous year the loss of the company and its predecessors amounted to $2,283,525, of which $1,117,567 was incurred in the air mail annulment period, when the company was deprived of mail revenue.

The proposal made recently in Miami by C. Blackburn Miller, president of the Salt Water Anglers of America, that legislation be fostered to establish the broadbill swordfish, marlin and sailfish as game fish exclusively, and to prohibit their capture for commercial purposes or in any manner except by rod and reel, has aroused widespread discussion among followers of the sport.

Declaring that inter-industry competition is increasing, regardless of business expansion or depression, a committee of the New York Trade Association Executives reported yesterday that "the trade association is the most logical medium, not only to harness the promotional forces of the individual members of the industry but to develop a broad 'reason why' for the industry."

The 400 naval reservists, radio operators and technicians who were mobilized through the Third Naval District Wednesday to meet the flood emergency have been working, in many cases, twenty-four hours a day since then, Lieutenant James V. Candido, U.S.N.R., in charge of public relations, said yesterday.

BERLIN, March 20. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler has assured himself of a 100 per cent majority of all the valid votes cast in the Reichstag election on March 29 by creating a ballot that leaves the voter only the choice of voting for him or invalidating the ballot.

Two candidates are being put forward by their respective friends for the office of Moderator of the 148th annual general assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America to succeed the Rev. Dr. Joseph A. Vance of Detroit. The assembly will open in Syracuse, N.Y., on May 28 and continue about a week.

NEWARK, N.J., March 20. -- The City Commission's hospital and high school construction plans, to cost $5,121,817, were definitely ended today when letters were received by the City Commission and the Board of Education from Colonel C.C. Vermeule Jr., acting State director of the Public Works Administration, notifying them that the PWA had rescinded the allotments to the two bodies.

Dr. John Robert Gregg, founder of the Gregg system of shorthand, received the medal of the Ulster Irish Society of New York for "notable service to the nation" by an individual of Ulster-Irish descent at the tenth annual dinner of the society at the Hotel Commodore last night.

Niagara had too much rugged power and too great a physical advantage for St. Francis in the District 1 College Olympic basketball eleminations at Madison Square Garden last night, and so the Eagles, least favored of the four teams that started in the tournament two nights ago, emerged as the New York and New England representative in the nation-wide competition.

On the ground that its property has been illegally assessed and overvalued, the New York Telephone Company filed suit yesterday against the New York City Board of Taxes and Assessments demanding that the assessment be reduced from $162,776,000 to $50,139,202.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Balking at a Treasury Department plan to levy a "tax on taxes," some members of the Ways and Means subcommittee set out today to make broad changes in the proposed tax on undistributed profits of corporations.

Unable to muster a crew for the Panama Pacific liner California, the International Mercantile Marine Company yesterday canceled her sailing, which was scheduled for noon today, and announced that she would be withdrawn from service until labor conditions in the port had calmed down.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Employment decreased by about 32,700 workers but payroll totals increased about $1,500,000 from January to February of this year, due largely to weather conditions, which curtailed activity in several industries but created demands for additional production requiring overtime work in others, Secretary of Labor Perkins reported today.

WHEELING, W. Va., March 20 (AP). -- Terrified and incredulous, thousands of refugees in this flood-plagued city surveyed the wreckage of their homes and business places today and wondered if their experiences could have been true.

While the head of the Connecticut River flood was moving yesterday between Northampton, Mass., and Hartford, Conn., a cross-State airplane inspection of the devastated valley from Long Island tidewater to a point near the Vermont border revealed a joint agricultural and industrial empire laid waste by water.

College youth all over the country is organizing itself into local posts of the Veterans of Future Wars. The object is to collect a bonus for the next war in which the beneficiary may participate. As against the existing bonus system, the distinct advantage is claimed that it enables the recipient to have a lot of fun with his bonus money before he does any fighting.
New bond financing this week amounted to $78,459,000, compared with $119,227,000 last week and only $8,230,000 a year ago.

Once again yesterday the only open road in the flood-washed East was the road of the air. The airlines pressed into service every available plane. With waters ebbing in much of the Pennsylvania area, new danger spots and new inundations were reported by pilots flying over West Virginia and New England. Tons of emergency supplies were flown to Pittsburgh.
BOSTON, March 20. -- New England's flood-made homeless ranged into the tens of thousands tonight as tempestuous waters swept savage courses to the sea.

CHICAGO, March 20 (AP). -- Two eagle-eyed young Braves, Leonard Quick Bear and Steven Red Elk, led the St. Francis (S.D.) Mission School to a place in the quarterfinals of Loyola's thirteenth annual national Catholic interscholastic basketball championship tournament tonight, starring in a 36-28 victory over St. Patrick's High of Elizabeth, N.J.

The annual report of the Western Union Telegraph Company for 1935, issued yesterday, puts gross operating revenues at $89,868,573, an increase of $2,638,000, or 3 per cent, over revenues of $87,230,228 in 1934. The gain was due to better general business and to continued development and promotion of the company's services, according to Newcomb Carlton, chairman, and R.B. White, president, who sign the report.

CHICAGO, March 20. -- Senator Borah arrived here tonight and expressed confidence that he would win the Republican preferential vote in the Illinois primary April 14. Such a victory, he said, would mean his nomination at the Cleveland convention. He will speak here tomorrow night.

The balance sheet of the Associated Gas and Electric Company for Dec. 31, last, audited by Haskins Sells, puts total assets at $469,916,413, compared with $527,910,904 at the end of 1934. Investment in common stock of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation was reduced from $507,624,540 to $381,264,445.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 20 (AP). -The Chene-Trombley Recreation team of Detroit moved into third place in the American Bowling Congress tournament tonight by hitting the pins for 2,859. Joseph Green anchored the team with 625. The team games were 919, 917 and 970.

A meeting of the Building Service Employes Union, Local 32B, that started tumultuously at 8:30 o'clock last night at the Star Casino, 105 East 107th Street, ended peacefully less than two hours later, but not before a definite threat of a new city-wide walkout of service employes had been made.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20. -- Judge Allen M. Stearne ruled in the Orphans' court today that the removal of Herbert E. Blackman, secretary of The Philadelphia Inquirer Company, as administrator of the estate of Colonel James Elverson Jr. would be premature.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Representations have been made to the State Department by Canada against some Treasury policies which affect adversely the export of Canadian liquor to the United States, but the Treasury has not indicated that it will modify its policies.

PARIS, March 20. -- Foreign Minister Pierre-Etienne Flandin told the Chamber of Deputies today that he was seeking "rapidly to bring about simultaneous suspension of hostilities in Ethiopia and of sanctions against Italy."

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Emphasizing that competition was the outstanding factor in proper income distribution, a committee on internal and external competition reported today to George L. Berry, Industrial Coordinator, on six specific remedies for defects in the machinery of competition.

United States Government bonds rose in the broadest buying movement in many weeks yesterday, the demand carrying eleven issues to new high marks for the year and nine to new high records since their date of issue. Trading volume in the Federal obligations on the New York Stock Exchange amounted to $4,620,900, the heaviest turnover since Sept. 20, 1935, when sales were $4,912,900.

Just as the contemporary theatre feeds upon itself -- some of our "best plays" being built around the allegedly glamorous figures of playwrights and stage people -- so the screen is occasionally reduced to autophagy, with results in nine pictures out of ten not half so bearable as "The Preview Murder Mystery" at the Rialto.

Another patrol wagon arrest de luxe took place at 5:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon on the tenth floor of the Port Authority Building, 111 Eighth Avenue, where the main offices of the WPA are located, when eleven noisy demonstrators, protesting job dismissals as others were leaving their work to go home, were held for the police by WPA officers.

School days started again yesterday for forty-four captains and six lieutenants of the New York City Fire Department as they assembled for a post-graduate course in fire fighting in the Fire College in the Packard Building at 30-02 Queens Boulevard, Long Island City.

Spring arrived on schedule at 1:58 yesterday afternoon, according to a unanimous report made by a contingent of Boy Scouts of Troop 472, Kips Bay Boys Club, who cited forty-three tangible reasons for their unofficial decision.

As flood waters receded from inundated areas of the Eastern sections of the country, leaving behind a tangled mess of mire and debris, emergency telephone and telegraph field crews pushed into the region yesterday and re-established practically all of the communication lines destroyed by the floods.

Among the treasured sayings of Bishop BERKELEY (which include his contention that nothing has subsistence without a mind, and that the course or star of empire westward takes its way) was one that is more pertinent to the advance of the mind's masteries:

PITTSBURGH, March 20. -- With the rivers which flooded Pittsburgh once more within their banks, two facts stood out clearly today. The first was that the damage was much greater than even the most extravagant of the earlier estimates.
NEW ORLEANS, March 20 (AP). -- Pulling away in the stretch, E.K. Bryson's U Demon easily captured the mile-and-a-sixteenth test for older platers at the Fair Grounds today.

CHICAGO, March 20. -- Keen competition today between small packers and shippers for the limited supplies of hogs advanced prices 5 to 15 cents a hundredweight. More than 50 per cent of the 6,500 hogs received went direct to packers.

At the Republican State Convention in Oklahoma, which instructed the delegates to the national convention for Governor LANDON, an advocate of his nomination for the Presidency declared that "he has both feet on the ground." There is something solid and satisfying about this figure of speech.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Mass power of more than 2,250,000 young men and women was thrown behind the "American Youth Act" as the Senate Committee on Education and Labor today held hearings on this bill which proposes to pay wages and living expenses to 5,000,000 unemployed young persons and needy students at a cost of $3,500,000,000 to the United States Government.

TAMPA, Fla., March 20. -- What happened on the night of Nov. 30 last year, just outside of this city, when three men were so brutally flogged, tarred and feathered that one died after nine days of agony, is finally to be told in court. After repeated motions for delay, the trial of ten men in the Joseph A. Shoemaker case is scheduled to start next Tuesday.

So far as Wall Street is concerned the floods in the East were less of a market factor yesterday than they had been. In the Pittsburgh district steel plants were reported to be gradually reopening and it is expected that soon nearly all will be operating on the pre-flood basis.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 20. -An appeal to President Roosevelt for $10,000,000 of Federal funds to help rehabilitate flood-swept Pennsylvania was made tonight in a telegram sent by Governor George H. Earle.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., March 20. -- Although the Susquehanna River, which climbed today to 33.06 feet, the highest since 1875, was receding steadily tonight, State, county and city authorities were still gravely concerned about the hundreds of families marooned in the lowlands of the Wyoming Valley.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20. -Tulips, jonquils and narcissi against a background of smilax and cibotium fern formed a setting for the Spring dinner dance given tonight at the Bellevue-Stratford by the Women's Auxiliary for the benefit of the Broad Street Hospital.

Inability to get bonds yielding good interest rates, the "meager" return on governments bonds and the "relative lack" of new corporate issues will drive investment institutions into the mortgage field and new building will follow, Robert L. Hoguet, president of the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, yesterday told a group of architects contributing to McCutcheon's current exhibition of residential architecture, at a luncheon given to them by the store in the RCA Building, Rockefeller Center.

The eloquent and very impressive performance of Wagner's "Parsifal" yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House held numerous audience for long hours under its spell. Here is a music drama which is outside the present day and which violates most of the precepts of effective theatre.

Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, dismissed as baseless yesterday charges made recently before the Board of Estimate by John J. Walsh, Queens civic worker, that the Green Bus Lines, which is seeking a city franchise, had paid out a considerable sum of money to politicians.

Joseph E. Widener's Brevity, winner of the Florida Derby, has been made a 3-to-1 favorite to capture the Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs May 2, in the future book prices issued yesterday by Tom Shaw, one of the leading operators on the New York tracks.

Main-floor buyers of the Joseph Horne Company, Pittsburgh, were scheduled to arrive here last night and will immediately begin the purchase of several hundred thousand dollars' worth of merchandise to replace stocks damaged by the flood, it was announced here last night by A.H. Burchfield, vice president of the company, following telephonic communication with other executives of the store.

TAMPA, Fla., March 20. -- Chunky little Chuck Dressen, manager of the Cincinnati Reds, was leaning on the batting cage and watching his hirelings hit. Between blows he talked in a jerky way about his team, such as it is. He has some hopes, but few illusions. Chuck is a practical little gent who sees things as they are and hustles to make the best of them.

With a jaunty red carnation in his buttonhole, former President Herbert Hoover, accompanied by Mrs. Hoover, visited the Flower Show at the Grand Central Palace yesterday morning. Both described their visit as "one of the most delightful" experiences of their stay in this city.

J.B. Doblin, Inc., a men's tailoring firm established in 1878, is returning from Brooklyn to Manhattan, where it has leased a store and two floors in the Canadian Pacific Building at 338 Madison Avenue. Opening in the Bowery, near Grand Street, the firm later moved to Fourteenth Street and Broadway, where it served various prominent New Yorkers.

Postmaster General James A. Farley is attacked as a political "spoilsman" and a juggler of figures in claiming a surplus for the Post-office Department when there is really a deficit by Lawrence Sullivan in an article in the April issue of the Atlantic Monthly.
BOSTON, March 20. -- Food shortages in several flood devasted areas of New England became an actuality today because of disrupted transportation facilities.
WASHINGTON, March 20. -- President Roosevelt today sent to the Senate the nomination of George H. Combs Jr. to be State Director for the National Emergency Council for New York.

SHANGHAI, March 20. -- Formulation of plans for issuance of an independent currency for Hopei and Charhar Provinces and for barring circulation of Chinese Government money in those provinces, was revealed today by Major Gen. Rensuke Isogai, the Japanese Military Attache, after a hurried trip to Peiping and Tientsin.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 20. -- A packed gallery saw the quarter-final and semi-final matches in the Bermuda Tennis Stadium today. In a men's singles quarter-final match Bryan (Bitsy) Grant of Atlanta, playing a spectacular game featured by smooth, crisp shots, easily defeated L. Watt of Canada, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3.

A "preponderant majority" of the wool goods industry would support the Ellenbogen bill if it "were confined to the simple elements of a general minimum wage and maximum hours of labor" and providing that it was legal and could be enforced, Arthur Besse, president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers, declared yesterday in protesting against the redraft of the original bill, just introduced.
While several main automobile routes in flooded areas were opened to traffic yesterday, more than a score of highways in Connecticut, Massachusetts, Pennsylvania and other States remained closed.

A hulking but mild-mannered, rather bewildered Chinese, in whose apartment at 37 Mort Street narcotic agents found a suit of steel armor, stood accused yesterday in Federal court of being Public Enemy No. 1 of Chinatown.
HARTFORD, Conn., March 20. -Terror gripped this insurance capital of the nation tonight as the Connecticut River flooded the electric power plant and threw the city into darkness.

Schedules for the operation of Germany's new airships, the new Hindenburg, or LZ-29, and the Graf Zeppelin, this season were made public here yesterday by F. W. von Meister, special representative of the Luftschiffbau Zeppelin.

Tony Scarpati, South Brooklyn welterweight boxer, died at noon yesterday in Bushwick Hospital, Brooklyn, as a result of a fractured skull suffered in a bout with Lou Ambers of Herkimer, N.Y., at the Broadway Arena on Tuesday night.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- The study that the Securities and Exchange Commission is making of the activities of investment trusts of various types was broadened today when a questionnaire was sent to the sponsors of investment plans with periodic, installment or partial payment, endowment, thrift or insurance provisions.

MIAMI, Fla., March 20. -- Eleven 3-year-olds, eight of which are eligible for the $5,000 added Derby Consolation Stakes, the Gables Racing Association's richest special to be run on closing day April 4, were nominated today as starters in the $2,000 added Royal Palm Handicap, feature of tomorrow's program at Tropical Park.

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., March 20. -- With the flood waters of the Susquehanna River receding rapidly after having isolated this city of 56,000 population for more than 24 hours, Williamsport officials reported tonight that there were at least four dead and property damage of more than $3,500,000.

WARSAW, March 20. -- Ritual cattle slaughter for Jews will be maintained in Poland as the result of a government amendment to a slaughter reform bill that was passed tonight by the lower house of Parliament. Religious communities with special methods of animal killing will have their own slaughter houses or slaughter animals according to their practice.

VERSIFIED calls to be up and doing are becoming shriller every day; no longer the sweet Longfellow cadence. For men starve, crops rot, troops train; tonight there may be revolution in Berlin, riots in Liverpool -- perhaps even blood on the pavement at Michigan Boulevard and State Street, in Union Square, on the knob of Knob Hill.

Staging a spirited rally in the second half, the St. John's Prep quintet of Brooklyn annexed the city C. H. S. A. A. championship by subduing La Salle Academy's plucky five, finalist last year, at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon. A crowd of 3,000 saw the Brooklynites triumph, 18 to 14.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20. -- Albert Vande Weghe, Hun School, back-stroke star, broke the world's prep school record for 100 yards in the thirty-second annual Penn National scholastic swimming championships at the Penn A.C. pool tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP). -Howard C. Hopson of the Associated Gas and Electric Company asked the Board of Tax Appeals today to redetermine a $1,515,221 Treasury deficiency assessment for income taxes, interest and a penalty.

In his first speech made in Ohio as a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination Senator BORAH declared that he is not and never has been in favor of inflation; what he wants is "a stable dollar."

The House Ways and Means Committee has approved a tentative schedule of rates for taxation on current reserve -- 15 per cent on amounts up to 10 per cent of net income; 30 per cent on amounts between 10 and 15 per cent, 45 per cent on amounts between 20 and 30 per cent and 55 per cent on amounts above 30 per cent.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

TORONTO, March 20 (AP). -- Joe Mangan, Cornell University law student, shattered the Canadian indoor record in winning the mile race at the annual indoor track meet in Maple Leaf Gardens tonight. He covered the distance in 4:16.2 to defeat Bill Daly of Detroit University and Frank Nordell of the New York A.C.
PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, March 20. -- Ohio River Valley flood waters pushed on relentlessly tonight, with ever-increasing refugee lists and devastation.

John Macionis, brilliant sophomore swimming star from Yale, transferred his record-shattering activities to the Columbia University pool yesterday as the annual Intercollegiate Swimming Association championship meet got under way.

Many pastors will preach tomorrow about the floods of the week which have affected so many parts of the East. The clergymen will offer prayers for the flood sufferers and will urge their parishioners to contribute liberally toward the National Red Cross Emergency Fund being raised by direction of President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- The Senate by a unanimous vote today put itself behind the Black Lobby Investigating Committee in its fight to maintain its right to obtain under "blanket subpoenas" the telegraphic and other correspondence files of corporations or individuals.

Corporal Adam J. Grochmal, assigned to the butcher shop of the general mess at Fort Slocum, near New Rochelle, told yesterday at Governors Island how he had faithfully carried out an old edict of the army -- "Always obey the last order."

MANILA, March 20. -- Open rebellion threatens in Moro Province as the result of an attempt to start registration April 1 for military service. The Moros in Lanao Province, which is the chief center of many previous uprisings, are taking to the mountains, rebuilding abandoned cottas, or native fortresses, and refusing flatly to submit to military service.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- The House split along sectional lines today as debate started on the Pettengill bill to modify the stringent regulations of the Fourth Section of the Interstate Commerce Act amid demands for a "fair deal" for the railroads and warnings of what the change would mean to shipping interests.
ROME, March 20. -- A sweeping plan for renovation of the Italian Army was outlined in the Chamber of Deputies this afternoon by General Federico Baistrocchi, Under-Secretary of State for War.

Leading European currencies fell yesterday to the lowest levels in two months as developments abroad indicated that the governments of England, France, Italy and Belgium were prepared to take a strong stand against Germany's violation of the Locarno agreement.
WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Acting under blanket authorization from President Roosevelt, the Red Cross and government departments today threw men, money and supplies into the task of flood relief.
VIENNA, March 20. -- The mass Socialist trial began this morning with speeches by the State Attorney Scheibert and eight of the seventeen counsel for the thirty defendants.
Appleton-Century will publish on March 27 George A. Malcolm's "The Commonwealth of the Philippines." Mr. Malcolm was formerly senior justice of the Supreme Court of the islands.

Delegates of the clubs in the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound met last night in the Harvard Club, 27 West Forty-fourth Street, and adopted the championship racing schedule for next Summer.

HAMBURG, March 20. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler delivered a stormy oration here tonight on the old thesis of German equality which outdid in fury any of his preceding campaign speeches and aroused an audience of 40,000 in the huge hall erected for the Max Schmeling-Steve Hamas fight to new heights of patriotic hysteria.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 20. -Mrs. George Barnett of Washington, Mr. and Mrs. Alec T. Roberts of London, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Thomas Carmody of Waterbury, Conn., guests of Mrs. Irving Hall Chase, were honored by Mrs. Henry Ellsworth Bemis, at a party today at Bemisyde.

The medical profession was urged yesterday by Dr. Elmer V. McCollum, Professor of Biochemistry at Johns Hopkins University and discoverer of Vitamin D, to forestall the "extravagant claims" of retailers for the qualities of their medicinal preparations by thoroughly investigating all important new scientific discoveries.

LONDON, Saturday, March 21. -- The British press is virtually unanimous in declaring that the proposals of the four Locarno powers register the first and not the last stage of the agreement, that there is latitude for Germany to modify them and that it is now Chancellor Hitler's turn to seize his supreme chance of statesmanship.

Although the Hudson River, now at flood stage and wreaking destruction nearer its source, is at the doors of New York, the city has nothing to fear from fresh-water floods, the Weather Bureau and army engineers explained yesterday. The Hudson, on the Manhattan shore, was not more than a foot and a half above the predicted tide level yesterday, although it had reached twenty feet above the mean up-State.

Miss Margaret Kelsey heads a group of younger members of society who are aiding in the sale of boxes and seats for the performance of the Monte Carlo Ballet Russe the night of April 13 at the Metropolitan Opera House, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Society for the Relief of Half Orphan and Destitute Children.

BOSTON, March 21 (AP). -- Clearing weather over large areas gave some promise of surcease from New England's worst flood tonight, but through the lower reaches of two of her largest and most populous river valleys water still raged high.

THE fate of peace on the Asiatic Continent and of capitalism and the Constitution in Japan rests at this moment more than at any other time in decades in the hands of one man. This man is Koki Hirota, Japan's new Premier, since he represents a desperate and perhaps a last effort by Emperor Hirohito to restrain the forces of extremism and keep Japan somewhere near a middle course, abroad and at home.

MUCH the worst thing about this book is its title. The book itself is one of the most striking novels that have come out of England for some time past and should do much toward strengthening Mr. Winter's position in America.

District Attorney Dodge expressed sharp resentment yesterday over what he described as an attempt by Commissioner of Accounts Blanshard "to grab a lot of, publicity" in trapping a man Mr. Dodge had planned to arrest.

BRUSSELS, March 20. -- Out of the events of the past two weeks in the Rhineland and in London there has evolved in Belgium a much clearer conception of what the Belgians want in the way of peace organization than they have, had since the Treaty of Versailles was signed.

Preparations for the Spring festival and ball to be held in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria on April 17 signify that the event will be a reproduction of a gay outdoor fete. It will be given under the auspices of the German-American Charities, Inc., in the interest of various German American relief organizations in the metropolitan area.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Unemployment relief is still recognized by the national administration as its most difficult problem. For substantiation of this statement one has but to refer to the message which President Roosevelt sent to Congress on Wednesday.

A snoopy old lady living in a Chicago hotel sees another guest, obviously intoxicated, enter his room after some fumbling with the key; she hears a tinkle as of breaking glass, followed by a heavy fall, and she rushes to his door in alarm.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- The faces of the President's opponents are lengthening with the re-election odds. Reports from every quarter are that the strong drift against Mr. Roosevelt in the early Winter has been markedly reversed. This testimony comes to all the forecasters in the political community.
Your editorial "A Century of Patents" is most timely. You accurately state that the basic patent legislation of 1836 "has done its work" and "needs reforming."

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Industrial production increased seasonally in the first half of March, after a downward trend in January and February, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly business survey.
To advance the work of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association, a Monopoly tournament and tea will be held on Thursday at the Barclay.

PROSPECTIVE travelers in foreign lands will do well to begin thinking early of their passports -- those formidable documents of identification without which travel is impossible in practically all foreign lands -- and to begin amassing information about visa customs in the countries they intend to visit.

DRAMA, unscheduled and unrehearsed, flashed into broadcasting during the past week when rivers ran riot and floods swept over a dozen States. While wireless amateurs worked feverishly to maintain communication with the outside world, relaying calls for help and news dispatches, the regular broadcasters rushed microphones and radio paraphernalia into the stricken areas to assist in communication enabling the radio audience to eavesdrop on graphic eyewitness descriptions of the destructive deluge.

BARBARA LUCAS'S second novel is a very engaging story that gets under your skin. It concerns Chris Garnett, a young English girl of gentle family. In the course of three episodes in her early twenties, Chris tries to decide whether her life shall be splendidly devoted to bettering social conditions or, equally splendidly, dedicated to deep personal feelings.

LEXINGTON, Va., March 21. -- Topped by a pair of their State rivals, Oklahoma University and Oklahoma Central Teachers College, respectively, Ed Gallagher's band of grapplers from Oklahoma A. and M. College went down to defeat for the first time in the meet's history as the ninth annual National Collegiate Athletic Association wrestling championships closed tonight in Doremus Memorial Gymnasium at Washington and Lee University.

Not only on my own account but also on behalf of all Siegfrieds I protest against the expression of your correspondent naming Goering "the Siegfried of the Third Reich." Perhaps your correspondent is not familiar with the German saga which says that Siegfried forged his own sword, that he always fought first in line, that he never lied and, what is more, that famous Siegfried never had a bodyguard.

WITH Spring Scouting's thought turns campward to the forest trails now awakening for a fresh life. It is true that Winter camping in recent years has made large strides, but the camping season for most Scouts does not get into full swing until late June after the public schools close.

ITALIAN EXPORTS: Costa Rica, which refused to participate in League of Nations sanctions against Italy, recently ordered from Italy an assortment of arms, including 350 submachine guns. As a sign of gratitude the Italian Government last week notified Costa Rica it was donating 175 of the guns.

YESTERDAY'S headlines are history. Very well, Mr. Greene seems to have said to himself, I can't deny that; in fact, I don't want to tamper with the truism, but what about the reverse? Today's history must be yesterday's headlines -- and that may make yesterday's headlines news, from a historical point of view.

Whether there will be another world war in the next few years depends largely on Great Britain, declares Karl Radek, eminent Soviet editor and expert on international affairs, in an article on "Britain's Way in World Politics," in April Current History.

CHAMBERSBURG, Pa., March 21. -- An interesting training routine in swimming has been brought forward by the record of the naiads of the Penn Hall Junior College and Preparatory School. Victors in twenty-eight of their last twenty-nine meets, the Penn Hall girls have shown the results of a thorough program designed to develop their aquatic technique.

As a logical sequence in its activities on behalf of reform of county government, the State board of management of the League of Women Voters yesterday announced its support of the Buckley bill, sponsored by State Senator John L. Buckley and now pending in the Legislature.

ERIC DEVINE sings the sagas of those daring souls who have sailed the world around in small ships. He admires very much both all who have done this heart-testing feat and those who, although just as courageous, have not ventured upon so long a voyage, but have done much sailing and braved many difficult voyages in small vessels.

INSTEAD of packing their bags and returning home to risk cold snaps, tourists are lingering in Florida longer than usual this year. The peak of the season heretofore has always come about February 22, but many visitors have ignored that date in order to remain for the buoyant first days of Spring, which Florida residents always have regarded as the most delightful season of the year.

The full report of the British Board of Trade for the balance of foreign payments of Great Britain during 1935, received by mail, makes possible the subjoined table of items in the report, compared with a series of preceding years. Credits and debits are classified in the report as follows (figures in millions of pounds sterling):
PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Easter weeks, always active ones in Palm Beach, will be quickened in pace this year, for never have so many large house parties been assembled from colleges and schools.
The Ludlum Steel Company has called for redemption on May 4 its convertible 6 1/2 per cent preferred stock at $110 a share plus a dividend of 61 cents for the period from April 1 to May 4.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., March 21 (AP). -- Food and clothing for flood sufferers poured into Binghamton tonight as relief organizations began moving hundreds of families back into silt covered homes left free by receding flood waters.

BOSTON, March 20. -- The New England delegation to the Democratic National Convention probably will be a solid bloc for the renomination of President Roosevelt. The vote in New Hampshire in the first Presidential primary of the year, the disintegration of the anti-Roosevelt movement in Massachusetts and reported sentiment from the four other States make this prediction almost a certainty.

YESTERDAY the Rhineland was the one unarmed area of Europe. In the demilitarized zone 14,000,000 people -- a population about as large as that of Czechoslovakia -- lived in a state of disarmament that had the semblance of peace. Now the sole gap in the armed front has been filled.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, March 21 (Canadian Press). -- Loss of $200,000 attributed to "forgery or theft" was disclosed today by Trinidad Commissioners of Currency after a check-up on a recalled issue showing there were 200,000 more $1 notes turned in than had been issued.
WASHINGTON, March 21. -- With the flood waters receding in all but two regions, the Works Progress Administration mobilized 250,000 men today in a great coordinated rehabilitation movement.

ONE of New York's odd industries is candlemaking by hand. At present the candle-makers are preparing to fill orders for the Easter season. From beehives on Long Island comes the amber wax; a near-by factory melts the honeycomb into smooth molds, and across the river in a Manhattan shop craftsmen carve and fashion the product for the altars of churches and cathedrals.

A large audience is assured at the song recital by Armand Tokatyan on April 4 at the Town Hall for the benefit of the New York City Cancer Committee. Mrs. Robert G. Mead heads the concert committee. A special group associated in the sale of boxes and seats includes Mrs. Howard Chandler Christy and Mrs. Edmondo Gerli.

WITH the departure of Mae West and Marlene Dietrich from Paramount, the lot is more tranquil than in months. Difficulties with George Raft have been settled, Margaret Sullavan has assumed the role vacated by Miss Dietrich in "I Loved a Soldier," and shooting of the epic has been resumed.
PARIS, March 21 (AP). -- Prince Louis of Monaco invoked the right of a ruler today in defense of charges by his son-in-law that he had "kidnapped" Princess Antoinette, daughter of Prince Pierre.

IN a week with more than fifty new attractions in the local galleries, a number of openings came too late in the week to permit a review in these columns. Notifications of others were received too late to permit of their being visited.

SAMUEL GOLDWYN'S purchase of the screen rights to Lillian Hellman's "The Children's Hour" was one of the funniest Goldwyn stories of last year. He paid $50,000 for a play which the Hays office had frowned upon, buying it with the understanding that he could not use its title or its plot or even mention the fact that he had acquired it.

SHOES for Spring suggest the creak of good harness leather, the clean smack of mallet against polo ball and the acrid, pleasant smell of saddle soap and liniment in the tack room. Those who know and love good leather are demanding more of the natural tone in their shoes.

PHILADELPHIA, March 21 -- John Lynch, representing St. Francis High of Brooklyn, lifted the 100-yard back-stroke title in the thirty- second annual Penn interscholastic championships held at the Penn A.C. pool today before a large crowd of spectators.

THE Metropolitan Opera season, so far as New York is concerned, came to an end last night. A few more performances will be given on tour, beginning tomorrow with a week of performances in Boston. Some supplementary single performances will be given when the association returns to New York.

Bainbridge Colby characterized yesterday as "untrue" a statement that "in the case of the American Taxpayers League every telegram which passed between Mr. Colby and James A. Arnold, general manager of the league, had been destroyed," which Senator Black, chairman of the Senate Lobby Investigating Committee, made in Washington Friday.

Mr. Sinclair evidently believes that his saying, "every proposition is true and its opposite is equally true," is justified in metaphysics, for "all statements about ultimates and absolutes are just words." I submit that this destroys the very basis of Mr. Sinclair's book.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., March 21. -- A course in the training of physical education teachers, open to graduates of colleges of approved standing, will be offered at Smith College in the Fall of 1937.

CONGRESS last year passed a bill to provide for aviation cadets in the Naval Reserve and Marine Corps Reserve the significance of which has recently been clarified by a statement of the procedure and activities contemplated for the coming training season.

IT would be unfair to Rachel Field to call the poems in this collection light verse, for although lightness, deftness of touch and felicity of phrase are the dominant characteristics of these pieces, there is an underlying fund of thought and thoughtfulness which lifts them to a higher category.

PARIS, March 21. -- At 3 o'clock this morning after one last long and incoherent session the French Chamber of Deputies shut its doors until June 1, when the new legislature will take its place. There were few who, looking back on the past four years of this Parliament, could regard its achievements with satisfaction.

In discussing the new tax program there are three questions: What is it? Why is it? What of it? In other words, what are the chief provisions of the plan? What are the reasons advanced for its adoption? What will be the probable results?

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Several conservative Democratic Senators today planned to take advantage of considerable opposition in Congress to voting the President another unrestricted lump sum for relief by proposing a plan that would virtually eliminate white-collar "boondoggling."

ROME, March 20. -- Events have been following each other with such swift succession in East Africa and are still developing so rapidly that one hardly knows where to begin to review the military situation.

DESPITE rumors early in the Winter that war in Africa would stop Mediterranean cruises, practically all steamship lines making ports east of Gibraltar are having capacity sailings. Tramp freighters wandering from port to port share patronage with de luxe liners.

NEW LONDON, Conn., March 21. -- Plans have been completed for the new dormitory which is to be built at Connecticut College this Spring. The building, which will house seventy-two students will be of simple design and constructed of granite and limestone like the others on the campus.

TEN years of broadcasting under the royal charter granted the British Broadcasting Corporation seems to have been satisfactory to the Englishman, so the committee of inquiry is urging that the government renew the charter for another decade.

PORTLAND Me., March 21 (AP). -- Renewed rainfall drenched the Maine flood scene tonight as the Saco River, swollen to its highest point in history, raced from its headquarters in New Hampshire to the ocean.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- The Consolidated Gas Company of New York has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering a $70,000,000 refunding issue in an operation calculated to reduce fixed charges on outstanding obligations by about $1,387,500 a year.

The thirty-fourth annual Greek Games at Barnard College will be staged in the gymnasium of the college on April 4. This year the theme will center around the story of Prometheus, who carried fire from heaven to earth. Eighteen years ago this same theme was presented, and Aline MacMahon, now a film actress, was cast in the role of the sophomore priestess.

Tracy H. Lewis was the principal victor at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. He took the High-Over-All Cup with 98 out of 100 targets, annexed both the doubles scratch and handicap prizes on a card of 28 out of 30 and was the only gunner to win a Long Run Cup. He broke 81 straight.

CHICAGO, March 21. -- Both wholesale and retail trade improved sharply in the last week. Gains with the wholesale dry goods houses ran as high as 14 per cent over last year; with the large department stores, from 12 to 20 per cent. A week earlier the wholesale margin was about 5 per cent and that of the larger retail stores, 13 per cent.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 21. -- Pennsylvania's worst-known flood, receding steadily tonight on all fronts, did an aggregate damage estimated at several hundred millions of dollars. That is the estimated loss to industry and individuals, but there has been a loss to farm lands, placed at $100,000,000 by the State Department of Agriculture, which cannot be made up for years since the rich soil of some of the commonwealth's most fertile fields has been washed away.

The annual reception for members of the Central Council of Associations of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York will take place Wednesday afternoon at the institute's headquarters, 25 South Street. The address of welcome will be given by the Rev. Harold H. Kelley, the superintendent, who also will introduce the council's new chairman, Mrs. Archibald R. Mansfield, successor to Mrs. H. Schuyler Cammann.
LONDON, March 21. -- A move to withdraw British support from the Olympic Games to be held next Summer in Germany was sidetracked today at a meeting of the Amateur Athletic Association.

THERE have been published tributes by sons to their fathers. This is something more rare: a tribute by a distinguished father to a distinguished son. In a sense, the book is an avowal by the son of his own worth, for the larger and, indeed, the best part of it is made up of Antony's letters, which are distinguished by something more than literary quality.

BAYONNE, N.J., March 21. -- After brooding for two years over his savings, tied up under the New Jersey Altman Act, William Feehan, 55-year-old plumber, attempted to wreck the interior of the Mechanics Trust Company, 19 West Eighth Street, with an axe this forenoon.

THE recent International Musical Festival in Stockholm was opened with a concert by the Philharmonic Society's orchestra at which Hans Pfitzner conducted his C minor symphony. The rest of the program was in the hands of the society's own conductor, Adolf Wiklund.

The new Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary will leave the basin of the John Brown shipyard at Clydebank, Scotland, at flood tide on Tuesday, on the first leg of the trip that eventially will bring her to her American terminal in the North River on June 1.

Hastily called conferences between business men, bankers and construction engineers at the close of last week signalized the beginning of a huge scale plant and store rehabilitation program, necessitated by the destruction wrought by the floods.
