PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 21. -- After experimenting for more than a year, the John Hay Library at Brown University is pushing ahead with a nine-point plan for making additional film copies of rare books, manuscripts and other items in a project to increase the library's resources.

LONDON. -- Apart from the spectacular issues of the day, the British Government is quietly engaged upon work of a permanently important nature. The public hears little about these activities, yet they are bound up with the existence of the British Empire itself.

Rags, the self-made hero who began as a gutter puppy in Paris, lived through some startling experiences in the World War and later found it infinitely harder to get into a dog show than into the affections of the First Division, is dead.

PARIS fashions, for the Spring and Summer of 1936, are no longer just cabled reports, radioed silhouettes and illustrations for the American woman. The imports are actually in the stores; they are realities in beautiful fabrics; the models are being copied so that all may see and, better yet, possess.

Pickets representing the striking seamen of the Panama Pacific liner California continued to parade before the International Mercantile Marine piers on the Chelsea waterfront yesterday, but the threat to extend the strike to other lines did not materialize.
Reports to the High School Teachers Association show that civic groups throughout the city are enlisting support for the Feld-Crews bill for a $300,000,000 bond issue to finance new school building.

It was recently stated in THE NEW YORK TIMES that Professor Samuel E. Morison of Harvard University has discovered that beer was regularly served to Harvard undergraduates in the early days of the college.

GENEVA, March 20. -- Threats to move the League of Nations Council back from London to Geneva serve as a reminder that the Geneva atmosphere, despite all its failures, remains a factor in world affairs.

WEST POINT, N.Y., March 21. -- Royal Military College of Kingston, Ont., defeated the Army at hockey tonight by the score of 5 to 2. The game, the fourteenth meeting between the military schools of Canada and the United States, was witnessed by a crowd of 2,000 spectators who jammed the West Point skating arena to its capacity.

PHILADELPHIA, March 21. -- Attention is now being given to rebuilding and refurnishing the flood-swept sections of Pennsylvania. The Legislature is in session, and public and private aid will be sought to put communities on their feet, which will thus create a demand for labor, construction materials and household goods,

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- A most harmonious national convention at Philadelphia next June, with President Roosevelt and Vice President Garner renominated by virtually unanimous vote and a platform drafted in line with the administration's record, is now expected by the Democratic high command.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 21. -- St. Peter's of New Brunswick won the New Jersey Group 2 prep school championship today by defeating Good Counsel of Newark, 22 to 21. A last minute goal by Jim McKendrick, substitute forward, decided the issue.

MONTREAL, March 21 (AP). -- The Chicago Black Hawks were shoved back into third place in the American group of the National Hockey League tonight when the Montreal Maroons clinched top place in the international group by downing them, 3 -- 1, in a fast game.

Clio of New York will sponsor the initial program of the recently formed Committee on International Relations of the City Federation of Women's Clubs, at the Hotel Astor tomorrow, with Miss Jeanette Rankin, first woman elected to Congress, as its spokesman.
TOKYO, Sunday, March 22. -- The dramatic details of Premier Keisuke Okada's escape from assassins in last month's military uprising here were revealed today for the first time in press accounts.

BECAUSE the New Jersey Legislature had recently diverted an additional $3,000,000 from highway funds for unemployment relief, E. Donald Sterner, State Highway Commissioner, announced last week the cancellation of three projected improvements.

Arithmetic, often a burden to school children, is being popularized at the Board of Education through a revision of teaching methods to give social significance and appeal to the subject and to permit an understanding even of the mathematical maze of current government expenditures.
The Salvation Army, Boy Scouts and many other public and private agencies reported on the progress of their flood relief work last night.
The Boy Scout-O-Rama, a two-day demonstration of every phase of the Boy Scout program, will be staged next Friday and Saturday evenings at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and Fiftieth Street.

BOSTON, March 21. -- Mayor La Guardia of New York and Mayor R.B. Marvin of Syracuse engaged in an angry exchange over the merits of the WPA at today's session of the northeastern meeting of the United States Conference of Mayors.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- The Fair Trades Practices Committee of the Council for Industrial Progress has recommended that the authority and jurisdiction of the Federal Trade Commission be increased "to enable it to deal effectively with competitive and group buying practices shown to be destructive in any particular industry or trade."

WASHINGTON -- To follow the march of the versatile soybean, America's fastest growing crop, the Department of Agriculture, with the cooperation of twelve North Central States, has established a soybean research laboratory at the University of Illinois at Urbana.

SEA ISLAND, Ga. -- With members of the large group of vacationists from Eastern colleges and prep schools as central figures a scavenger hunt will be held here next Thursday afternoon, starting from the Cloister Hotel lawns. Written clues will take the searchers to all parts of the island to find the objects indicated.

MADISON, Wis., March 21. -- While Wisconsin National Guardsmen waited tensely in their barracks here, seventy city, county and special policemen marched into the Assembly Chamber of the State Capitol and ended a ten-day occupation by striking WPA workers from the industrial Fox River Valley.

An imposing edifice of stone in Georgian design soon will be built in Grosvenor Square, London, to house nearly all of the United States Government representatives and offices there, it was learned yesterday.

Despite the effect of the flood upon Pennsylvania and New England orders, the heavy mail volume received and the large number of visiting buyers in the markets here made last week the most active period since the Spring buying season began, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by the McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

IRONY, the bitter, remorseless irony we so often find in real life is the keynote of Joanna Cannan's very able and very tense novel. But it is irony tempered and in a way emphasized by a poignant sympathy with the man who is fate's plaything.

THE illustrations, both in color and in black and white, are reproductions of the exhibits of advertising art displayed by the Art Directors Club of New York in its annual show held last Spring at Macy's. They were selected (for that showing and for the book) as representative of the best work in the various classes.

THE demand for native talent, particularly for young singers and instrumentalists, is increasing with great rapidity throughout the country, according to the authorities of the Columbia Concerts Corporation. Of the 109 artists and special attractions under its management at present, 65 per cent are American born.

FORT WORTH, March 21 (AP). -- Nine men were under bond today on Federal indictments charging conspiracy to defraud or using inferior pipe and lumber in construction of Dalworthington Gardens, a Federal subsistence homestead colony near Arlington, Texas.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP). -- Whether the Mississippi Valley will see this Spring a flood comparable to that of 1927 depends on the amount of rain in the next six weeks.

Bird-dog enthusiasts in this section will open the field-trial season this week with the happy prospect of a full month of competition in the covers hereabout. There is such a variety of Spring meetings that every one with a puppy, junior, all-age or just a good shooting-dog candidate will have opportunities aplenty to compete for cash and trophies.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 21 -- The $15,000 contract demand of Charles (Red) Ruffing, ace right-hand pitcher of the Yankees, tonight was rejected by Colonel Jacob Ruppert, owner of the club. His offer of a compromise contract for two years at $13,500 likewise was spurned.

IN these days of super-liners and smaller luxury ships it is impossible for the traveler to realize the discomforts of forty years ago at sea, for probably no other form of transportation has undergone greater changes for the convenience and comfort of the passenger.

Experience proved too strong for grim determination to overcome as the New York Rugby Club out-smarted the Long Island University Rugby squad, 14 -- 0, in a well-attended contest at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

While describing the everyday doings of a little Indian boy, Mr. Birney has succeeded in giving an accurate picture of life among the Navajos. His book answers the questions that boys and girls are eager to ask and supplies the full and exact detail that children enjoy.

THE Salzburg Mozarteum Academy of the International Mozart Foundation, in Salzburg, Austria, will open its eighth season in July and continue its activities until the end of August. The academy, which is an international Summer school of conducting, music, theatre and the dance, as usual, will have a strong faculty, made up of celebrated authorities from many of the world's leading music centers.

WITH some definite facts available, it is possible to say that the Spring season at the Metropolitan is on. Here are the facts. Duration, beginning May 11, running into June, exact length undetermined, Price range, $3 to 25 cents. Performances a week, five.

AN all-Wagner program, conducted by Toscanini, will be given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Wednesday night for the benefit of the Orchestra Pension Fund. Albert Spalding will be soloist this afternoon with the Philharmonic, and on Thursday, Friday and next Sunday the Russian violinist, Nathan Milstein, will be heard in the Mendelssohn Concerto.

HONOLULU. -- Inauguration of regularly scheduled commercial airplane service across the Pacific may endanger agriculture unless effective means of halting an influx of insect "stowaways" are applied immediately.

WEST POINT, N.Y., March 21. -- Army swordsmen lost two matches today, the Cadet varsity team bowing to the Fencers Club of New York, 15 1/2 to 11 1/2, while the plebes were beaten by Barringer High School, 11 1/2 to 5 1/2.

Angling, literal and figurative. is the burden of this humorous short story. George Baldwin Potter and his pretty wife, Isabelle, who have appeared before in fishing tales by John Taintor Foots, do the angling. George is a passionate fisherman, his enthusiasm over a chance at a twenty-two-inch rainbow trout being the one thing that tops his desire to please the adorable Isabelle.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Dr. William F. Draper, Acting Surgeon General, declaring that the threat of disease in the flood areas is "exceedingly grave," has rushed a corps of sanitary engineers into Pennsylvania and West Virginia to set up emergency chlorination systems where flood waters have reached the public water supply.

In his introduction to this omnibus volume S.S. Van Dine, who, as everybody now knows, is Willard Huntington Wright, tells how he came to write the Philo Vance stories, why he adopted the pen name of S.S. Van Dine and many other interesting things about himself.

ADDIS ABABA, March 21. -- Asphyxiating and corrosive gases of many types are being used by the Italians along the entire length of the northern front, according to information from Ethiopian Army headquarters at Quoram.

THE most salient features of organized crime in New York since repeal are depicted here in their expiring last stand against the law. An acknowledged master at this kind of novel, Mr. Train has produced a tale fit to rank on all counts with those outstanding few which the post-dry era has brought forth.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP). -- One of the most unusual petitions in the annals of Virginia politics has been prepared by Democrats to keep their veteran Senator, Carter Glass, in office.
SALISBURY, Md., March 21 (AP). -- An alleged $20,000 "joke" found its way into Circuit Court records here today.

LONDON. -- Not long ago King Edward, then Prince of Wales, seldom wore a hat and his example was followed by countless others throughout the country. Then it was brought to his attention that the hat industry was suffering severely from this trend, so now he is setting an example in the opposite direction.

MADISON, Wis. -- Known history in this State now goes back 15,000 years and a new record of ancient residents here is announced by Professor Ralph Linton, University of Wisconsin anthropologist, in the discovery of what are said to be the first portrait death masks ever found in America.

Net profit of the Ohio Oil Company and subsidiaries for 1935 was reported yesterday as $5,488,267 after taxes, depreciation, depletion, interest and other charges. This was equal to 33 cents each on 6,563,377 no-par common shares outstanding.

ONE of the most interesting steps taken by air transport operators in America was confirmed last week when the joint order by five major lines, American Airlines, Eastern Air Lines, Pan American Airways, TWA and United Air Lines, was placed with the Douglas Company for a $500,000 prototype four-engined, forty-passenger plane.

With communication lines once more restored to almost normal condition in the flooded areas, officials of the American Telephone ute yesterday to the army of emergency field crews and telephone op- and Telegraph Company paid triberators who waged a four-day battle with the floods.

A CLASSROOM experiment in which murals serve as textbook and incentive to further study is in progress at the Julia Richman High School, where a series of wall paintings, entitled "A Decorative Map of the World," has been installed.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 21 (AP). -- Richard Reid, Georgia lawyer, editor and educator, today received the Laetare Medal, awarded annually by the University of Notre Dame to an outstanding member of the Catholic laity.

HOLLYWOOD. THE studio gate has been regarded for years as an impenetrable barrier to those who desire to tread the same ground on which walk the dream children of the silver sheet. But it isn't. It is wide open.

PORTLAND, Ore., March 20. -- In the Far West, principal stronghold of Townsend political strength, membership in the pension clubs maintains its surprising pace, but dissension and disagreement also continue to stir the movement. Most astonishing of the internal conflicts is that which apparently exists between Dr. F.E. Townsend himself and Robert E. Clements, "co-founder" of the Townsend plan, over the transaction tax feature of the McGroarty bill, now before Congress.

A brilliant, fast-riding Yale trio vanquished an aggressive Princeton team, 10 1/2 to 3, in a quarter final round match of the national intercollegiate indoor polo tournament last night at the Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn.

The Music Library at Wellesley College and the Music Fund of Princeton University will be joint beneficiaries of the Wellesley-Princeton concert and dance to be held on Friday night at the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Osgood Perkins heads the group which has charge of the sale of boxes and seats for the benefit.
HOUSTON, Texas, March 21 (AP). -- Mrs. A.M. Creeh's Sound Advice, 4-year-old colt, took the $1,500 Houston Handicap, feature race at Epsom Downs today, before a crowd of 10,000 spectators.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., March 21 (AP). -- The roaring Connecticut River rose steadily in Middletown today, battering the shaky 1,200-foot highway bridge connecting Portland and Middletown while a steady rain hampered attempts to restore the city's electric power.

NOT one of the Five Mavericks had ever killed a man except in open warfare. They were outlaws, of course, but after (a long way after, if you like) the pattern of Robin Hood. When they robbed, or in a range trouble used their guns to help the underdog, they saw to it that they did not harm ordinary decent citizens.

LOUISIANA State University's projected student farm colony of 1,000 youths is approaching actuality as Spring drainage and clearance get under way on 675 acres of new farm land adjoining the university's 2,500-acre site, and as preparations are completed for the inauguration of the "work-study" program at the end of the 1936 Summer session.

WITH guns blazing in Africa, England bleeding its treasury for greater armaments, Russia sharpening its swords for a meddling Japan, France fearing the worst and Hitler throwing silken gloved threats and guns at a perplexed Europe, there seems not much cause for writing or reading a book on the graceful art of diplomacy as a means devised and developed for the high human ideal of making and keeping peace among nations.
Led by Captain Vic Despard, the Yale Rugby team began its fourth invasion of Bermuda yesterday as twenty-two members of the squad sailed aboard the Furness Bermuda liner Monarch of Bermuda.

BEING scrupulously conscientious in her use of words, Eveline M. Burns calls her exposition of the Social Security Act "Toward Social Security" because she thinks that it does not achieve the desired result, is, in fact, merely the first step in that direction.

The provisions and implications of the Social Security Law have not yet been brought home to the average man. He will be compelled to take an active interest in them in less than a year, when more than half of the workers in the United States will be obliged to pay a tax upon their wages or salaries to support a Federal pension plan.

TO Postmaster General Farley's many other duties has been added the ticklish task of choosing from the pages of American wartime history some fifteen heroes to be honored in a new series of soldier and sailor stamps.

UNDER the joint auspices of the College Art Association and the Italy America Society, a large group show of contemporary Italian paintings is being held in galleries on the sixth floor of International Building, Rockefeller Center.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 21. -- The Tatsuta Maru has as telephone operator one of the foremost girl athletes of Japan. She is Misi Futiko Fujita of Kobe, who competed in the last Olympics at Los Angeles and is on the team which will go to Germany this Summer.

LAST S. Summer, when James A. Farley was attending the commencement exercises at West Point, some one remarked to him: "Just think, Jim, all those hundreds of lifetime Federal Jobs being hunded out and you didn't have a word to say about it!"

THE Get-Lou-Holtz-Out-of-Florida- Race-Tracks Club, a patient organization, can learn this morning that Mr. Holtz and David Freedman have been at work for two weeks on the book of a new musical. It has no producer yet, nor a composer.
INDIANAPOLIS, March 21 (AP). -- Louis Levine of Chicago rolled himself to the top of three divisions in the American Bowling Congress tournament tonight.

Motorization of all longitudinal street car lines of the New York Railways system will be achieved on Wednesday when buses will be substituted for surface cars on the Lexington Avenue-Lenox Avenue line, the company announced yesterday.
BERLIN, March 21. -- Prince Louis Ferdinand of Prussia, the former Crown Prince's son, who worked in the Ford plant in Detroit some years ago, will return to the United States for a vacation.
Brace Connlng's recent letter regarding the Federal Theatre Project in Syracuse stated that he knew "that $62,000 had been given for the Syracuse Theatre Project."

In the course of the murder investigation with which this story deals, Miss Hildegarde Withers, the schoolteacher-detective, wins a substantial sum at the race track by following a system of her own, promotes a romance by somewhat similar methods, and catches a murderer by breaking what seems to be a perfect alibi if there ever was one.

In your recent editorial "Stabilization" you comment on the telegram by the Committee for the Nation to Secretary Hull regarding his Baltimore address in which the subject of currency stabilization was discussed.

When Mme. Madeleine Gerard lectured to the women of Springdale. Ohio, on "What Paris Thinks of Your Clothes," she caused a pleasantly piquant sensation by criticizing their clothes and praising their personalities. When she and her 20-year-old son Andre became house guests at the Coopers, after her next lecture date fell through, she threatened to cause a greater upheaval in that quiet small town home.

DALLAS, March 21. -- Business conditions throughout the Eleventh Federal Reserve District have reflected the same general broadening tendency shown during the early weeks of 1936, as Spring-like weather has prevailed for the last two weeks.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., March 21. -- Cadet Lieutenant Cyrus S. Radford of Haverford, Pa., has been appointed battalion commander at the Admiral Farragut Academy, naval preparatory school here, it was announced today. Other cadet officers appointed follow:

MAIMI BEACH, Fla., March 21. -- S. Mortimer Auerbach, the Atlantic City sportsman who, Summer and Winter, makes records and frequently breaks them on regatta courses in many cities, set another world's speed mark today on the first of four days of motor boat racing that will bring the Florida circuit to an end.
The question of just how to translate one of Hitler's German words into English seems to have played a somewhat important part in the international negotiations now going on in London.

A great deal of advance praise has been lavished on the poems in this book, and clearly some of it is richly deserved. While not all of the poems in the collection are notable either for their originality of thought or their metrical boldness, several arrest attention sharply.

CAIRO, March 20. -- While the Western world's interest is centered on Germany's occupation of the Rhineland, the Near Eastern countries, little concerned over Europe's upheavals, are concentrating entirely on their own affairs.

A motorist who picked up a 12-year-old boy who had been struck by his automobile carried the lad to a Queens gasoline station last night and asked that an ambulance be called for him, but became panic-stricken and fled when he heard the station attendant ask for the police.

THE Canadian pioneers, we are told, "almost tread on the threshold of today." It was not until about the middle of the nineteenth century that individual painters began definitely to leave their imprint. The reproduced work in this volume tells a story that calls for little amplification in text, save, perhaps, as a matter of completing the record.

SINCLAIR LEWIS, Thornton Wilder and Louis Bromfield will serve as judges in the eighth biennial Harper Prize Novel competition, which closes on Feb. 1, 1937. Any author who is a citizen of the United States and who has not published a novel in book form prior to Jan. 1, 1921, is eligible to compete.
THE atmospherics have been ideal for foreign short-wave reception during the past week. Long distance "catches" have been numerous.

THE proposal that Merit Markers be awarded cars not involved in any accident or serious traffic violation during a specified period of time -- advocated on this page recently by Professor R.B. Stoeckel of Yale University, formerly Motor Vehicle Commissinor of Connecticut -- continues to evoke comment pro and con.

A novel event now being planned to aid the Art Workers Club for Women is a garden party to be held on April 16 at the Hampton Shops, 18 East Fiftieth Street, marking the opening of a modern garden apartment designed and executed by Alexander H. Girard.

TAMPA, Fla., March 21. -- Sheriff J.R. McLeod, J. Rex Farrior, State's Attorney; C. Jay Hardee, County Solicitor, and their assistants expect to prove that the flogging which brought death to Joseph A. Shoemaker here last Fall was not an impromptu affair, but was planned in advance.

AMERICAN horticulture at this season -- or "in-between season," to be more accurate -- is preoccupied by the Spring flower shows now being held in the larger cities throughout the land. These shows have become a national institution, playing a vital part in the development of gardening in America.

LEWISBURG, Pa., March 21. -- Because of the growing importance propaganda has assumed in American life since the World War, the Bucknell University Summer session this year will present a seminar course in propaganda, featuring such lecturers as M.H. Aylesworth, former president of the National Broadcasting Company, and Charles Michelson, director of publicity of the Democratic National Committee.

CLEVELAND, March 21. -- While industrial operations were reported on an up-grade in this district at the beginning of the week, the heavy storm in Northern Ohio and the unprecedented floods in Western Pennsylvania and the Ohio River Valley did untold damage and caused all business to cease temporarily in some localities.

Milton Bleiman of the Ninety-second Street Y.M.H.A. won the heavyweight title in the National U.M.H.A. championship wrestling tournament at the Ninety-second Street clubhouse last night, gaining a decision over Harry Packer of Philadelphia in the final round.

In the slowest trading since Dec. 14, share prices fluctuated narrowly yesterday to close steady at irregularly lower levels. From the stand-point of breadth, the number of issues dealt in, the market on the Hew York Stock Exchange was the narrowest since Oct. 19, last, a total of but 706, against 685 on the October date.

For a very special reason the President of the United States did not forget his green tie and green carnation on St. Patrick's Day. And the first lady of the land remembered to wear the Gibson girl pin-on watch designed by her husband in 1905 for a particular occasion.

MIAMI, Fla. -- History set to music will provide one of the striking features of the Dade County Centennial celebration, which, amplified and intensified, opens next Friday and extends through April 14.
Concern was felt yesterday in Southern New Jersey, particularly in Camden, Timber Park and National Park, as rain added to the hazard of floods from already swollen streams.
PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, March 21. -- Exposure from cold imperiled thousands of homeless refugees in the Upper Ohio River Valley tonight.

ART museums were once morgage for treasures that were held too precious for handling and viewable only through glass cases by visitors. The modern conception of an art museum is to have it also serve persons in all-age groups unable to go to the museum.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- Preparations are being completed for the annual St. Petersburg-to-Havana yacht race, in which more than twenty boats will start next Saturday at noon. Festivity will precede the start of the race. Already the waterfront is dotted with yachts here for the meet, and visiting boatmen from ports as far west as New Orleans are being entertained by the resident colony.

DUBLIN, March 21. -- Dublin went all-American today for the ceremonies preceding the Grand National sweepstake draw Tuesday. Both continents of the New World had been chosen by the sweep promoters as the subject for one of the most effective pageants yet staged.

CLEARWATER. Fla., March 21 -Eight of the nineteen Dodgers who met the Tigers today turned in nineteen assists, but Mickey Cochrane's world champions had a majority in runs -- 10 to 1, in fact -- and gained almost complete revenge for last Spring's four straight defeats by Casey Stengel's citrus circuit pennant winners.

There are dictatorial moods in nature as well as in man; in neither is the product likely to be pretty. Last week, as Europe struggled with the problems posed by a human dictator, we in America became the victims of the ancient and terrible force of flood. The Eastern States -- in which our democracy was born -- suffered from more water than at any time in their history.
HARTFORD, Conn., March 21. -- Hours after the peak of this city's most devastating flood, life remained at a standstill tonight.

EXHIBITIONS of decorative pottery, such as those at the Argent Gallery and the Little Gallery recently, are reminders of the wide variety of expression of which ceramic art is capable. For the connoisseur of glazes there are still turned out meticulously worked pieces in which the technique of glaze and subtlety of shape are emphasized.

MILWAUKEE, March 21 (AP). -- Arrested at his own insistence during a strike demonstration, Heywood Broun, New York columnist and president of the American Newspaper Guild, spent two hours in a jail cell today before he and six others were released on bail.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 21. -- Replying to demands that Congress investigate the Veterans of Future Wars, youth organization demanding payment of a $1,000 bonus for future war service, a letter sent to Senator Hugh Black offering full access to all records of the association was made public here today at the national headquarters of the organization.

BERLIN, March 21 (AP). -- Cardinal Bertram indicated tonight in a message that the attitude of Roman Catholics as regards the German parliamentary elections of March 29 was one of caution and reserve.

The swimming team of Posse College from Kendall Green, Mass., led by the brilliant Miss Alice Bridges, broke the winning streak of New York University's co-eds yesterday when it defeated the Violet, 31 to 22, in the twenty-five-yard pool of the Women's Swimming Association. It was the first setback for the local squad in six engagements this year and defeat in the 200-yard relay event ended the string of victories.

TAMPA, Fla., March 21. -- With the brim of his gray felt hat pulled down over his bushy eyebrows, the silver-thatched Clark Griffith, president of the Washington Senators, announced that his team was in great shape.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP). -- Dry rot has set in at the old Hoover camp on the Rapidan in the Blue Ridge Mountains.
When the requirements of income-tax law run contra to, or are inconsistent with, a corporation's existing obligations to its creditors, they violate sound fiscal principles.
ST. LOUIS, March 21. -- While floods have not reached the Eighth Federal Reserve District as yet, considerable apprehension exists and farmers are planning to meet the situation.

TRENTON, N.J., March 21. -- The attorneys for Bruno Richard Hauptmann were investigating today reports that the convicted kidnap-murderer of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr. and Dr. John F. Condon had been seen in a Bronx restaurant several times prior to the kidnapping.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- The fact that the Federal Government has a budget which on its revenue side is improving beyond expectation, but which continues to be overbalanced on its expenditure side by the burden of relief, was demonstrated by two developments here during the past week.

HUNTINGTON, W. Va., March 21. -- This city of 85,000 in the Ohio River Valley watched the waters of the river encroach upon its business section today and waited calmly for the crest of the flood which has left death, desolation and distress in its wake between here and Pittsburgh.

Jack O'Brien is a blase black bear cub to whom publicity means nothing. The furry four and a quarter pound youngster made his debut at the Central Park Zoo early yesterday afternoon in a state of complete somnolence, curled in the corner of a tiny, glass-enclosed incubator placed in a fern and palm banked bower in the elephant house.

The twenty-third annual International Flower Show, which opened in Grand Central Palace last Monday, closed last night after an exhibition which in point of beauty, attendance and sales was described by the committee in charge as the most successful in the history of the event.

NASSAU, Bahamas. -- Nassau's harbor is gay with the craft of yachtsmen assembled here to watch or participate in the international Star Class series of races, which begin on Wednesday and continue until March 30.

THE basic pattern of Mr. Gardner's Perry Mason stories is always the same, but the variations that he is able to introduce into that pattern are so ingenious that each story is at least as interesting as any of the previous ones.
THE Eastman School Festival of American Music will consist this year of five evening concerts to be given on consecutive nights from April 27 to May 1.

In his excellent book "The United States of Europe," which apparently has been greatly neglected in America and almost completely ignored in Europe, Edouard Herriot proves that the very reasons that should preserve peace in Europe are used to provoke wars.

BACK in the Mesozoic, or custard-pie, era of Hollywood the scene-painter was a man of consequence. He was more important than the director and got twice as much money as the star. Given some yards of canvas, a few pots of color, brushes and a plug of tobacco, he would turn his imagination loose and fix up a Venetian palace, an Aztec temple or a Western dance hall, all complete, inside of two hours.

In his budget message to Congress last Jan. 3 President Roosevelt made no provision for relief. Explaining that he considered it too early to arrive at an accurate estimate of the amount needed, he promised to deal with the question at a later date. The later date came last Wednesday, when Congress received a supplemental message requesting a lump-sum appropriation of $1,500,000,000.

DARJEELING, India, March 6 (By Mail). -- When the 1933 Mount Everest Expedition returned home, having once more failed to reach the summit, it seemed unlikely that we should be able to renew the attack for many years to come.

In the Court of Session at Edinburgh early in this month a petition was presented by Baron CLINTON, the eldest direct descendant of Sir WILLIAM FORBES, one of BOSWELL'S executors, for the appointment of a "judicial factor," an agent to settle the estate of the sometime laird of Auchinleck.

Edith Patch's "Holiday Hill," "Holiday Meadow," "Holiday Pond" and "Holiday Shore," which she wrote with Dr. Fenton, are well known and rank high among nature stories for children. The tales in this most recent volume deal with animals who live in the hills and forests of the Rocky Mountain country.

TWICKENHAM, England, March 21. -- A stern battle between two evenly matched teams today resulted in a 9-8 victory for England over Scotland in the closing international Rugby match of the season. While Wales, by its defeat of Ireland a week ago, had clinched first place in the tournament, the decision gave England the Calcutta Cup, held by the Scots by virtue of a victory last year.

NOT many men who have spent their lives at a schoolmaster's desk have won such a tribute as this book makes to the man who was known all his professional life to his pupils as "Bott" -- Mather A. Abbott, who for fifteen years before his death, in 1934, had been headmaster of the famous Lawrenceville School.

In most of the flood-stricken areas of thirteen States the waters were receding yesterday. The total deaths were estimated at 170, those homeless at 221,500 and the total damage approached $300,000,000. In Western Pennsylvania and Northern West Virginia a blizzard intensified the misery of the homeless. New rains threatened to renew the Connecticut Valley inundation.

ACCESSORIES, in the last analysis, make the well-groomed man, and he has now a particularly wide range of haberdashery from which to choose. The quantity of color being used, even in the most conservative town clothes, makes for a great variety in bright and harmonious designs.

The habit that nations have of warring on each other when they have a dispute should be condemned more boldly and more courageously than it is at present, Mrs. Carrie Chapman Cart, president of the National Committee on Cause and Cure of War, said last night.

Monday morning, Feb. 12, 1934, civil war broke out in Austria. Government and Fascist troops bombarded the huge apartment blocks which the Social Democrats had built in Vienna, Linz and other cities after the World War. On both sides many were killed and wounded.

THE small, engaging species tulips open their dainty blossoms the first sunny days of March or early April -- according to climate and season -- with bloom from various varieties carrying on through April uncertainties, until they play a part even in the floral pageantry of May.

ALBANY, March 21. -- "Fraternizing" between policemen and holders of retail liquor licenses is responsible for the failure of community enforcement of New York State's Alcoholic Beverage Control Law, Mrs. John S. Sheppard, a member of the State Liquor Authority, asserted tonight.

CHICAGO, March 21. -- Liquidation of grains was resumed today at the opening of the Board of Trade. The extreme loss in wheat was less than 1 cent a bushel, but the July delivery was carried to the lowest price since Oct. 29, and the September to within 1/8 cent of the season's bottom mark.

The accurate-passing Newtown High School quintet of Elmhurst annexed the Queens P.S.A.L. basketball championship by vanquishing Grover Cleveland High of Ridgewood, 23 to 20, in a play-off at the Jamaica Arena yesterday, thereby gaining the right to compete in the round-robin tourney for the city title.

THE well-known authors of this tall tale have drawn upon ancient Buddhist lore for their plot, bringing the story's few characters under the omnipotent but benign influence of supernatural powers which alternately punish, reward or destroy these mortals, as the case of each deserves.

Sartorial changes formed one of the unusual features of the recital given by Robert Crawford, baritone, at Town Hall yesterday afternoon. The soloist and his accompanist, Arthur Peterson, appeared for the first half of the program in conventional afternoon garb, but after the intermission, both saw fit to come forward in different toggery -- Mr. Crawford in a sky-blue costume he wears when sky-piloting, and Mr. Peterson in light sport tweeds.

RUTH FENDER has apparently discovered the alchemic formula for popularity: she knows what people dream about. Beneath a superficial layer of Continental sophistication and a substratum of shrewd wit, she is a hyper-romantic.

BERLIN, March 21. -- Joachim von Ribbentrop, head of the German delegation to the League of Nations and Locarno conferences in London, arrived in Berlin tonight to report to Chancellor Adolf Hitler and participate in government conferences over the weekend.

DETAILED description of the new four-engined flying boats nearing completion for Imperial Airways at the works of Short Brothers, Rochester and Bedford, England, for use on the long Empire routes to South Africa and India, operated by the airline for mail and passengers, reached New York last week.

He has lately been speaking with a pungency and vigor that have given his arguments an added impact. There is no doubt at all that he has been regaining some of the public regard he lost because a world-wide depression failed to heed his commands to come no further.

BRUSSELS, March 21. -- There is no rejoicing in Belgium over the London agreement, but the comments upon Premier Paul van Zeeland's declaration to Parliament reflect satisfaction that he succeeded in obtaining a promise of collaboration of the French and British general staffs for the defense of this country.

TORONTO, March 21. -- Ontario's mineral production in 1935, valued at $159,044,887, exceeded that of any previous year, according to official year-end reports. Mineral production in Canada as a whole amounted to $310,162,455 in 1935 and was exceeded only in 1929, when production was $310,850,246.

BOSTON, March 21. -- The student yachting organization recently established at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology is to have a pavilion on the Charles River Basin for its headquarters, and sailing is to be taught in a serious way, it was announced at the institute today.

OUTSIDE those regions ravaged by floods in the week, retail trade continued to mark up substantial gains over a year ago. The increases seemed to average around 15 per cent, with the best results in the Middle West and Southwest.

OKLAHOMA CITY, March 20. -- Senator Borah's charge of Standard Oil interference in Oklahoma politics, broadcast on the eve of the Republican State convention, was taken far more seriously in the East than it was at home.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., March 21. -- As the Susquehanna River continued to recede steadily tonight State, county and city authorities centered their attention on efforts to protect the health of the thousands of people in the flood-swept Wyoming Valley.

BERLIN, March 21. -- The semi-official newspaper, Diplomatische Korrespondenz, has discovered usefulness for its purposes of the Rhineland documents of the postwar period published in Washington last week. It says today:

VIENNA, March 20. -- It is difficult for a correspondent resident in any of Europe's dictatorially ruled countries to present to a democratic country a convincing picture of the situation through daily reports of the arrests, crushing sentences and police beatings of which political opponents of the regime are victims.

An unidentified man dived from the recreation pier at the foot of Catharine Street yesterday afternoon, swam out into the cold East River and rescued a dog that had become exhausted from an hour's battle with the swift tide.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 21. -- Action of the Syracuse University student senate this week in ordering gradual but drastic reduction of membership in the three junior societies is evidence of growing dissatisfaction with the existing campus political and honorary machinery, controlled for the past decade by these societies.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., March 21. -- An 8-to-1 shot, Holl Image, carried the red, white and blue silks of Jack Carter to victory today in the $5,000 added Arkansas Derby, revived at Oaklawn Park as a centennial year feature after a two-decade lapse.

GENEVA, N. Y., March 21. -- Student activity in the Hobart College Biology Department ranges all the way from experiments to determine the true value of various antiseptics and disinfectants now on the market to the filing and cataloging of thousands of plants and shrubs in the central part of New York State.

When the New York Yacht Club permits women to pass safely by the stone lions guarding its portals at 37 West Forty-fourth Street this afternoon, for the first time in its long history, it will only be following the lead of many other men's clubs in this city.

A new zoning plan designed to curtail sharply the structural bulk of office skyscrapers and to insure "a more orderly development of business districts in New York" has been worked out by the Regional Plan Association.

THERE was a week in Winnipeg some years ago when Alfred Lunt appeared on the same vaudeville bill with Fink's mules. Mr. Lunt remembers the occasion very well, for Lily Langtry -- that would be the Jersey Lily -- whose leading man he was, thought the combination irreconcilable and told the hooking office so in words that could hardly be called uncertain.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- The fishing fraternity at Hot Springs has been gratified to note that the Game Commission is stocking streams in Bath County with large quantities of trout. On Tuesday more than seventeen truckloads, or 20,000 trout of legal size, went into the Cascades Stream, Cowpasture, Bullpasture and Jackson Rivers.

PITTSBURGH, March 21. -- The Eastern States pressed swiftly for reconstruction of flood-wrecked property on a vast scale today, aided measurably by President Roosevelt's $43,000,000 allocation to the WPA for flood repairs and replacements.

ROME, March 21. -- Admiral Domenico Cavagnari, Under-Secretary of the Navy, speaking in the Chamber of Deputies today, said Italy was not entirely satisfied with the naval agreement drawn up by the London conference and he confirmed Italy's intention not to sign as long as sanctions remained in force.
The first of three charity figure skating carnivals that are to be staged at Madison Square Garden within a week will be presented to a gathering of 16,000 tonight.

Lloyd-James, adviser on spoken English to the British Broadcasting Corporation, seeking cooperation on this side of the Atlantic, points out the sea of pronunciation troubles that radio has brought upon writers.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 21. -- According to its annual custom, the Yale Debating Association is sponsoring the trip of two students through the South on a schedule calling for debates with fourteen universities in eleven days.

MADRID, March 20. -- The disorders in Spain since the general election last month have seriously weakened the position of Premier Azana, who led the Left or Popular Front on the victorious ticket. The Premier himself realizes this perhaps more than any one else and there is increasing confidence in this country that he will find the way to save the republic from its enemies of both the extreme Right and extreme Left.

In the work of adjusting courses to children with varying needs, reducing retardation and increasing promotions, the city's junior high school system was pronounced a success yesterday by speakers at the sixth annual city-wide conference on junior high schools in the Hotel Astor.

A retaining wall supporting the rear yards of ten one-family houses on Eagle Avenue, the Bronx, ten feet above that of a six-story apartment house at 710-20 St. Ann's Avenue, crumbled shortly after 5 o'clock last night, sending boulders through the rear wall of the apartment house and filling rear apartments and the yard with tons of dirt, rocks and brick.

Although floods paralyzed business in general last week in wide areas of the East and New England and caused huge losses to merchandise stocks and industrial equipment, trade expanded sharply in all other sections of the country under the influence of Springlike weather conditions.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- The floods now devastating the country lend a costly and tragic emphasis to the need for Federal flood control. While our first thought naturally is to relieve the suffering and distress of the emergency, there must be no delay in effecting a coordinated system of flood control for the nation.

Volume of passenger travel by air, to the flood stricken regions of Pennsylvania slackened a bit yesterday. TWA, the "Lindbergh Line," flew five extra sections, or twelve in all, as compared with fifteen on Friday out of Newark for Pittsburgh.

SUNBURY, Pa., March 21. -- A conflict of authority between Red Cross officials and the Pennsylvania National Guard led to the circulation of a report today that a general order had been issued for evacuation of Sunbury because of the danger of epidemics.

The designation "totalitarian State" has attained new prominence since it has been applied to Paraguay under her new regime. Virtually unheard of until after the World War, the word totalitarian came into general use with the establishment of the Fascist government by Benito Mussolini.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP). -- Salaries of industrial leaders and motion picture stars were made public today through a report to the House Ways and Means Committee of salaries of $15,000 or more a year paid by corporations.
WASHINGTON, March 21. -- An order that all engineers on PWA projects report to State administrators instead of to PWA offices in Washington was issued today by Secretary Ickes.

THE term "poor prune" used to have two meanings, both derogatory. In its more literal application it meant a thin, hard, dried food, representative of the dehydrated fruits of an era that knew little of sanitation. Grocers displayed prunes, along with many of their other wares, in open boxes and bins.

Mayor La Guardia will use a pneumatic drill to break ground at noon tomorrow for the first section of the city's $57,000,000 subway under Sixth Avenue. The ceremony will take place at a point in the sidewalk in Bryant Park opposite Forty-first Street.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., March 21. -- Elaborate plans to observe the centenary of the induction of Mark Hopkins as fourth president of Williams College are moving forward as a result of the appointment of O. Dickinson Street, '01, of New York and Lee, Mass., as director of the celebration, which is expected to attract an unprecedented number of alumni to the campus Oct. 10-12.
AN AMERICAN GROUP, with membership greatly augmented, is holding its single exhibition of the season at the Ehrich-Newhouse Galleries (on until April 4).
ISTANBUL, March 21. -- Germany's denunciation of the Locarno pact and her military reoccupation of the Rhineland have placed the Turkish Government in an embarrassing position.
Loyalty oaths, teachers organizations and education in the South will be under discussion starting next week by the Open Forum of Hunter College for its term study of education in the United States.

THE Matriarch was her great-aunt; and the child Gladys was not really fond of that despotic old lady. Even as a little girl she was "able to remain fairly aloof from what most of the family, and all her vast circle of friends, declared to be her charm and magneticism."

ITHACA, N.Y., March 21. -- Cornell's track forces amassed 69 points to overwhelm Syracuse and Colgate in their annual indoor triangular meet in the drill hall tonight, but Eddie O'Brien turned in the top performance.

For the first time in the history of the city's public school system, according to the memory of officials of the Board of Education, the annual report of the Superintendent of Schools has gone into a second printing.

FOR this first week of Spring the collector's fancy turns willy-nilly to three auctions and untold quantities of dealers' catalogues which seek to captivate him with rival attractions. The current season has witnessed an unprecedented number of tender shoots signalizing the arrival of newcomers in the trade.

The habit of more than a decade again prevailed last night as swimmers from Yale, led by the versatile sophomore, John Macionis, carried off the major share of honors in the thirtieth annual championship meet of the Intercollegiate Swimming Association in the Columbia University pool.

IN its constant search for new and better materials, the automobile industry recently has turned with growing interest to molded plastics for many car parts. Since this material can be molded into a variety of colors and combinations of colors which permanently retain their luster, it is being used effectively for decorative parts, such as knobs, ratchets and small panels and moldings.

New York City's campaign to have Floyd Bennett Field made the Eastern air-mail terminus instead of the Newark (N.J.) Airport received a second setback yesterday when Postmaster General James A. Farley in Washington rejected the city's plea that the change be made.

For the first time since 1929 sales programs scaled to pre-depression levels have been worked out by manufacturers dealing in export markets, executives who came here last week to attend the annual gathering of export managers reported. The trend to expanded operations, it was pointed out, is general in practically all manufacturing lines but the markets in which promotional and sales effort will be spent vary considerably from those of six to ten years ago.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP). -- Senate lobby investigators today reported the receipt of evidence that several anti-New Deal organizations have drawn their principal financial support from a virtually identical list of large contributors.

COPENHAGEN, March 21. -- Danish waiters have declared war on the stiff shirt and starched collar and on costumes that were at one time associated only with grand opera and fancy-dress balls, demanding more comfort and dignity and less color in their working apparel.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 21. -- Harvard's varsity and freshman fencing teams defeated Yale rivals by identical scores of 14 -- 13 as the Crimson's Winter sports program closed today in the indoor athletic building.

AS you grow older -- suppose we discard that polite evasion and say, instead, as you grow old -- you remember things of the past though your memory for a dinner to be held next week may blur or vanish. Although I must confess that seldom happens to me, who, in the vernacular of the under-middle-age, am "one of the older women" with a very kind emphasis on the polite adjective.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and Mrs. James Roosevelt have accepted invitations to act as honorary patronesses for the Butterfly Ball dinner dance which will take place on April 14 at the Ritz-Carlton. The ball, an annual event of the Spring season, will benefit the House of Rest at Sprain Ridge, near Yonkers, a hospital devoted to the treatment of men, women and children afflicted with pulmonary tuberculosis.

In this book of verse, her first in several years, Jean Starr Untermeyer has brought together a sheaf fastidiously chosen, and in many respects distinguished. Indeed, no less a sister artist than Amy Lowell once called attention to the "high distinction" of Mrs. Untermeyer's work.

YORK HOUSE, in St. James's Palace, which the King occupied as Prince of Wales, is shortly to be occupied by his brother, the Duke of York, who is the heir presumptive to the throne. With him will be the Duchess of York and their two small daughters, Princess Elizabeth, who is just short of 10, and Princess Margaret Rose, who is 5.

Governor Lehman and Mayor La Guardia have consented to serve with more than one hundred civic, business and political leaders who are actively taking part in the Citizens Family Welfare Committee campaign for a minimum of $1,500,000.

ALMOST every country in Europe seeks a place this Summer on the itinerary of the American traveler. The tourist with a full purse and unlimited time at his disposal can make one of any number of socalled "grand tours," witlb side tri, following his whim from e.;atry to country and being sure, II the while, of absorbing enterainment and knowledge wherever he goes.

Forces of the radio broadcasting companies, which played a conspicuous part in the flood tragedy, are returning from the field full of tales about the misery and difficulties encountered in broadcasting.

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 21. -- The Cubs, National League champions, invaded Pensacola today to launch a six-game series with the Giants and forthwith put their very best foot forward. Whereupon the Giants stepped all over it, just to show that ball players can carry a fine rivalry right through a hard Winter.

Rallying strongly in the second half, the Manhattanville basketball team defeated the St. Joseph's College girls of Brooklyn, 27 to 14, at the Benziger Gymnasium on the victors' campus yesterday. It was the forty-seventh consecutive triumph over a four-year period for the Scarlet and the eighth victory this season.

PUBLISHED in England under the title "Genetrix," this novel details the story of a woman's absorption in her son whom she had created because, at the time, "them was none in the world that had come up to her dreams."

IN radio circles the most publicized and talked-about new program of the week was that introduced by WPA and CCC workers, who took to the "air" in the first of a series prepared by the Educational Radio Project of the United States Office of Education.

Riverdale Country School's youthful foilsmen dominated the annual Athletic Association of Private Schools fencing championships on the strips of the Fencers Club yesterday. Their team upset the Trinity School combination, 5 -- 2, to annex the team crown and 17-year-old Jack Zaugg went through eleven bouts, three in team competition, without a setback to capture the individual title.

WESTERNS without cowboys have become a sort of specialty with Jackson Gregory of late. Yet this prolific delineator of the Far Western scene makes his novels of the life out there quite as adventurous and exciting as any cowboy yarns ever spun -- and perhaps even more ro mantic.

EUROPE expects by for the heaviest American season this Summer since the crash set in. All the old countries have augmented their Summer programs. Filled with old castles, old cathedrals, old towns and old ways of living, yet pulsating with modern life, they have arranged a truly embarrassing wealth of attractions for their visitors to pick and choose from.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Exports during February gained more than 8 per cent over February, 1935, and imports increased more than 26 per cent, the Department of Commerce announced today. Part of the increases are accounted for by the extra day in February of this year.

PARIS, March 21. -- This somewhat disturbed week on the Bourse closed calmly today, with little business and a slight fall in prices. Rentes dropped 5 to 25 centimes. Bank of France shares were off 180, Suez Canal 115 and Royal Dutch 15.

PARIS, March 20. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler's invitation to both France and Germany to "bury the hatchet" and start living like good neighbors has not had the kind of reception on this side of the Rhine that would give any immediate promise that such a happy state of affairs could exist outside a dream.

BERLIN, March 20. -- The concentration by the League of Nations Council and the Locarno powers on the judicial and technical aspects of the Franco-German dispute have completely obscured thus far the greater reality that lies behind them and gives them their importance.

MANILA. -- Steps are being taken to put into practice as soon as possible universal military service in the Philippines. The call for general registration was issued early this year and has been followed by a call for instructors.

An increase in the demand for July contracts was a feature in trading yesterday on the Cotton Exchange. Prices, as a result, advanced 1 to 10 points in the short session. While houses doing government business supplied about 5,000 bales of March within a 2-point range, foreign and domestic buying of July spurred a 10-point improvement.

Owing to my absence from the city I am only now able to reply to Mr. Seldes's letter in your issue of Feb. 2 regarding his book "Sawdust Caesar." This may not seem to you necessary, since there is nothing in the facts he alleges which, if accurate, would support the statement that the book was "suppressed" by H.M. Government.

The Foreign Commerce Club will stage its third annual observance of Port of New York Day, on Wednesday, with the assistance of ship lines and operators in waterborne commerce. Ship lines have agreed to dress their ships and to have a three-whistle blast sounded at noon, and owners of buildings in the downtown shipping district have ordered that flags be flown.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 21. -- National Guardsmen, their numbers augmented by fresh troops, took virtual control of Hartford tonight with orders to be especially vigilant against vandals in the darkened, flooded area.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 21. -- The recent Nieman bequest of from $3,000,000 to $5,000,000 to Harvard University "to promote journalism" has drawn attention to the fact that Harvard is one of the few large universities in the United States where training in journalism is kept out of the classroom and confined to undergraduate publications.
AKRON, Ohio, March 21 (AP). -- A seven-point agreement settled the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company strike late today and the company announced that work would be resumed "as quickly as possible."

COMING BACK: There has never been another play on Broadway like "Abie's Irish Rose." It ran from May of 1922 to October of 1927 -- 2,327 performances, a world's record. Most of the critics sneered when it opened; the actors took a 50 per cent pay cut in the first weeks.

The formidable undertaking of presenting fifteen of the greatest violin concertos in the repertoire, in a series of five programs, was brought to its conclusion by Mischa Elman and the National Orchestral Association yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall before a capacity audience.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 21 (AP). -- Ohio State's one man track team, Jesse Owens, tonight returned to intercollegiate competition by winning the 60-yard low hurdles in the fourth annual Butler indoor relay carnival. His time was 6:09.

NEW designs in rubber footwear are expected to widen its use in sports. For golfers who cannot wait until the ground dries, there are rubbers with cleats on the soles. These, in black or brown, have high tongues in front and are made secure with an extra strap over the instep.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP). -- More than 200 youths of high school and college age, including a large percentage of girls, appeared at a Senate hearing today in support of the Benson-Amlie bill to give them pay while they go to school or study vocations.

WARRENTON, Va. -- Entries for the point-to-point races of Saturday next, which mark the end of the hunting season here, will close on Wednesday. The committee consists of Amory S. Carhart, M.F.H., Captain R.J. Kirkpatrick and W. Henry Pool.

BAY CITY, Mich., March 21. -- While rummaging through the vault of the Pitts Company lumber mill, long since defunct, Samuel P. Cranage, only heir to the lumber company business, today came upon United States Government debentures of a face value of $55,147,000.

CLEVELAND, March 20. -- Senator Borah made a militant campaign invasion of Ohio this week, but all the forecasts are that his primary fight against what he terms the Ohio Old Guard is destined for very hard going.

Heavy with moisture from the Gulf of Mexico, storm clouds swept along the Appalachian highlands, hovered over the Virginias and added their torrents to those that had inundated New England the week before. A fortuitous combination of snow and rain resulted in a relentless rising of water.

A COPY of what may be the first authentic account of Ethiopia, published about 1521, has been acquired by the British Museum. It is in Portuguese and is entitled "Letter of the News Which Came to the King Our Lord of the Discovery of Prester John."

ROME, March 21. -- The Italo-Austro-Hungarian conference opened today with two meetings in the Palazzo Venezia. Italy was represented by Premier Benito Mussolini and Under-Secretary of State Fulvio Suvich, Austria by Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg and Foreign Minister Egon Berger-Waldenegg and Hungary by Premier Julius Goemboes and Foreign Minister Koloman de Kanya.

Art property from the Newport, R.I., residence of Perry Belmont, property of George H. Drew of Southampton, L.I., and other owners will be offered at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Thursday, Friday and Saturday afternoons.

MEN'S fashions for Spring are in agreement with the modern architectural theory of "functionalism." Architects hold that a building should conform to the purpose for which is is erected, and that it is not good design to house a factory in what seems from the outside to be a Greek temple.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 21. -- Crime, its causes, treatment and prevention, will be the subject of a two-day conference at Vassar College on April 3 and 4.

Higher levels of industrial and financial volume are foreseen for the Spring and Summer, despite reports of varying conditions in the country, the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents reported yesterday in its monthly survey of business conditions.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 21. -- The reorganization of the Nassau County Historical and Genealogical Society was completed today with the announcement of plans for a county-wide membership campaign, to start tomorrow. The society had been inactive for several years until recently, when a group of Nassau civic leaders and amateur historians launched plans to revive it.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., March 21. -- A dinner dance sponsored by the Westchester Assemblies for members of the younger set from Pelham, Bronxville, Scarsdale and Rye will be held on Saturday at the Siwanoy Country Club here. Mrs. J. Robertson Maccoll of Bronxville heads the committee in charge.

AFTER paying his respects in no uncertain terms to loose thinking and loose phrasing on the subject of art, Forbes Watson, from his position as adviser to the Treasury Department Art Projects, makes some illuminating -- and perhaps contentious -- observations in "The Return to the Facts," published in the March number of the American Magazine of Art.

THESE two slim volumes, Mr. Dorman's stating the case for the Townsend Plan, and Mr. Roosevelt's that against it, form an instructive antithesis. Mr. Dorman's volume is almost "official," as it carries an approving foreword by Dr. Townsend himself.

Supported by a decision of the State's second highest court -- the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court -- License Commissioner Paul Moss last week forced all playlands to cease awarding, or advertising, prizes to pin-game players. The ruling was greeted enthusiastically by the city administration, which had been fighting the pin game for two years.

ABOUT 7,000,000 years ago a star blew up in the constellation Virgo. Dr. Hubble and Glenn Moore at Mount Wilson became aware of the catastrophe only last week. If they were 7,000,000 years behind the astronomic times, theirs was not the fault.
LOWELL, Mass., March 21. -- Residents of Lowell gave credit today to a man long dead for saving the city from a twenty-six-foot wall of flood water.

PITTSBURGH, March 21. -- Heavy snows buried the prostrate cities and towns of Western Pennsylvania today while an army of relief workers fought to restore order along the trail of the flood waters that claimed at least eighty-three lives in this area and caused damage estimated in the hundreds of millions.

CHICAGO, March 21 (AP). -- Military records of Xerxes, the Persian Emperor whose army was defeated by the Greeks at Marathon almost five centuries before the birth of Christ, were among 54,000 pounds of Persian antiquities received today at the University of Chicago.

Institutional buying of new securities has received a severe blow, in the opinion of investment bankers, from the restrictions placed on member banks of the Federal Reserve System regarding the type of securities eligible for investment by them.

TRENTON, N.J., March 21. -- New Jersey's organization candidates for delegates at large to the Republican National Convention will be for the nomination of Governor Alfred M. Landon of Kansas for President. Announcement to this effect was made today at Governor Harold G. Hoffman's office after a luncheon conference at New York City.

An economist said the other day that women own two-fifths of the country's wealth. "They are moving inexorably toward a majority ownership." This is bound to make people ask what will the economic life of this nation be like when the women control it.

MOSCOW, March 21. -- Although the recent diplomatic tension between the Soviet Union and Japan is greatly relaxed, there was a renewal today of reports that Soviet citizens had been abused by Japanese in Manchukuo.

Representative Vito Marcantonio, who withdrew from a conference of "native American radicals" in Chicago last July in the belief that the group's effort to form a third party was "not only premature but also wrong," called yesterday for the formation of an "all inclusive, united front farmer-labor party."

AN American reading his newapapers and listening to his radio becomes conscious of an ironical twist in the ways of the modern world, and of a queer contrast between his own country and some others. In wide areas of Europe democracy has been deliberately rooted out.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Announcement was made by Chairman Doughton today that the full Ways and Means Committee would begin public hearings March 30 on the proposed new tax program. This was coincident with a statement from the Treasury showing that income-tax collections for the first twenty days of this month amounted to $389,694,381.48, or 28 per cent more than a year ago.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Unseasonal warm weather descended on the Atlantic Coast area last week-end. From South Carolina to Northern Maine it was mild enough for May. In the South the last depths of frozen ground began thawing on the high slopes of the Blue Ridge and the Great Smokies. In the hills and valleys of New England, and on the wooded sides of the Pennsylvania mountains, the snow melted with great rapidity.

No one, not even the editors who bought her drawings satirizing New York life. knew Zalie Clare. She had become an almost legendary figure in sophisticated New York circles by the time she held at 19, her first one-man show and joined the staff of Manhattan Days.

AMERICA'S resurgent urge to visit the Old World that gave it birth seems stronger this year than at any time since 1931. The transatlantic travel season opened with various economic and psychological factors working toward fuller passenger lists and longer trips.

The Grand National Steeplechase, which is probably the most severe test for horses held anywhere, will hold the interest of the turf world this week when it is renewed over the Aintree course just outside of Liverpool, England, Friday.

LONDON, March 21 (Canadian Press). -- Two famous teams qualified today for the most colorful event in the realm of soccer -- the final for the English Cup. Vanquishing Grimsby Town, 1 -- 0, at Huddersfield, Arsenal will oppose Sheffield United at Wembley Stadium April 25 in the closing struggle of the long competition.

Subscription to the two benefit performances of the International Skating Carnival at Madison Square Garden -- tonight and Wednesday night -- has attained sellout proportions, according to an announcement from the committee that all the boxes had been taken and virtually all the seats sold.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Although, at the request of President Roosevelt, the Railway Management Committee of Nine and the Railway Labor Executives Association resumed negotiating this week on the problem of caring for employes displaced by consolidations and unifications, indications of an agreement appeared to be very slight.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP). -- Government construction of a fleet of commercial lighter-than-air craft and replacement of the Akron and the Macon with new airships for joint army and navy use was recommended to a Senate Air Safety Committee today by aviation experts.

WORCESTER, Mass., March 21. -- Continuance of a steady rise in the scholastic standing of the student body at Worcester Tech was reported today with the publication of the registrar of the weighted averages for the first half of the current college year.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 21. -- An allotment by the WPA to Westchester County of several tons of chloride of lime, ear- marked for use in disinfecting flood areas, today puzzled engineers and health officials. Rivers overflowed their banks ten days ago but conditions have been virtually normal ever since.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- President Roosevelt, on the eve of his departure for a fishing vacation in Florida waters, was understood tonight to have rescinded orders to reduce the Civilian Conservation Corps camps to a minimum of 300,000 by July 1, and instead, is reported to have authorized a continuance of the personnel on a basis of slightly more than 350,000.

A total of $36,495.79 in checks was received yesterday at the headquarters of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross, 315 Lexington Avenue, General Robert C. Davis, executive director, stated last night. This brings the total to $83,739.90 on the second day of the campaign.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- The New York State Mortgage Moratorium Law of 1933 was challenged in an appeal entered in the United States Supreme Court today by Joseph and Angelina Loporto, holders of a second mortgage on a tenement house at 39 Henry Street, New York City.

CHICAGO, March 21. -- Opening his Illinois campaign tonight, Senator Borah warned the party leaders in an impassioned speech that he might "walk out" if the corporation interests dictated the nominee and shaped the platform at the Cleveland convention.

LONDON, March 4, 1936. THE British Broadcasting Corporation has given us two memorable concerts in the past weeks. Stravinsky's "Oedipus Rex" was the mainstay of one; the program of the other consisted of Berlioz's "Messe des Morts" and "Grand Symphonie Funebre et Triomphale."

PAUL GAUGUIN, shortly before he died, remarked that a man's work must explain the man if it is to accomplish anything at all. Everything he had learned from others, he said -- with a gesture that was perhaps a little pavonine -- had been torment.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 21. -- The special judicial commission of the Presbyterian Synod of New Jersey has upheld the decision of the Presbytery of New Brunswick in ousting the Rev. Dr. J. Gresham Machen of Philadelphia, according to a pronouncement today by the Rev. Dr. George G. Felmeth of this city, secretary of the commission.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP). -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States and the National Association of Manufacturers joined hands today in opposing legislation to establish labor standards for plants filling government contracts.

RICHMOND, March 20. -- Retail business this week has been satisfactory, although conditions were bad, due to floods throughout the district. Department stores and specialty shops were seasonally busy and report no decline in Spring buying. Automotive and fertilizer sales were off, however.

Army's polo team, starting the defense of its intercollegiate indoor title, rode through to the final round at Squadron A Armory last night, defeating Harvard, 9 1/2 to 9. The Crimson trio played an aggressive game throughout, coming very close to producing an upset.

BORN before the close of the seventeenth century, James Edward Oglethorpe, parliamentarian, social reformer, colonizer, soldier and English gentleman, lived to greet John Adams as first American Minister to England in 1785.

THIS volume, with Miss Parton's two preceding Newburyport stories, "Tabitha Mary, a Little Girl of 1810." and "Melissa Ann, a Little Girl of the 1820's." recreate the life of a New England seaport town in the first half of the nineteenth century.

IT would not seem at first glance that a book which is avowedly the history of the Christianization of the South Sea islanders could offer much excitement to the lay reader. But in "Puritans in the South Seas," the playing out of a long drama is so vividly set forth that far more excitement is provided than one would anticipate.

MANY readers of The Times Literary Supplement must have rubbed their eyes when they caught sight of the headline "American Writers Look Left" stretching in big letters across its front page. That a journal of so great authority and influence in the literary world should devote its leading article to such a subject is, at any rate, highly significant.

WHEN a fine figure of a lass with a saucily waving green plume on the hat of her ducked under the arm of a policeman at Fifty-sixth Street on St. Patrick's Day and scampered through a band of high-stepping Kerry men toward the west side of Fifth Avenue, the holiday crowd gave her the rousing salute it always accords the venturesome.

PHILADELPHIA, March 21. -- The University of Pittsburgh, after spotting St. John's of Annapolis an early 7-3 lead, rallied to win its District 2 college Olympic elimination semi-final at the Palestra tonight, 29 to 21, before 2,000 spectators.

The photograph shows gold being handled in a United States mint. The stock of the United States -- valued at over $10,000,000,000 -- would make a cube less than 20 feet to the side. All the gold produced in the world since 1493 --about 1,200 million fine ounces -- would make a cube less than 41 feet to the side.

BERLIN, March 21. -- The situation in the Protestant Church in Germany has changed completely in the past forty-eight hours. Both Church Minister Hanns Kerrl and the fighting Rev. Martin Niemoeller's followers controlling the Confessional Synods are faced with what amounts to a Protestant coup d'etat.

CHARLESTON, S.C., March 21. -- Turning in a pair of 17s today for a seventy-two-hole total of 278, six under par, Henry Picard of Hershey, Pa., won the $3,000 Tournament of the Gardens by exactly the same score with which he captured this open golf competition last year.

One of Randolph Sayre's birthday presents explodes in his hand and kills him instantly. Fleming Stone, who just happens to be visiting in the neighborhood, is called in to help the local authorities investigate the crime, and for many pages the great detective is completely stumped.

John A. Keogh, a wallpaper salesman of Perth Amboy, N.J., returning to New York after thirty-six hours in the flooded area of Connecticut, told of having traveled on two boats, a tractor and an ancient Ford after being forced to abandon his own car near Windsor, between Hartford and Springfield, on Thursday.

TOTAJADA and her sixteen Moorish dancing girls serpentined their way across the stage to ring up the curtain, and, incidentally, launch a brand-new theatre on its way to "institutional" prestige. It was March 20, 1911, and the Messrs. Lee and J. J. Shubert, proprietors of the Winter Garden, were presenting their opening bill, "Bow Sing," described in dignified fashion as a Chinese opera, and "La Belle Paree," modestly subtitled "A Jumble of Jollity."

The Thomas Jefferson and Samuel J. Tilden High School quintets, Brooklyn titleholders in Divisions 1 and 2 respectively, gained close victories as play in the P.S.A.L. round-robin series to decide the city championship began on the neutral De Witt Clinton High School court yesterday.

PARIS, March 19. -- Louise Bourbon has gone to the garden to get things to trim her latest Summer hats. Tiny birds, fruits, flowers, leaves and ribbons are used on a small-brimmed shape. She handles these charmingly, reviving old-time fashions.

TORONTO, March 21. -- The Toronto Maple Leafs scored a 4-1 victory over the New York Americans in the final game of the National Hockey League season tonight, but knew before the game was over that their chance of winning the International group title was gone.

AMERICA'S last frontier, a land where the hardy and the adventurous may wrest gold from the earth or settle on a fertile homestead, has come into the spotlight with the establishment of the government's relief colony in the Matanuska Valley of Alaska.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Debits to individual accounts as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ending March 18 aggregated $10,046,000,000, or 19 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week, and 25 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year.
ALBANY, March 21. -- Governor Lehman so far has made no public announcement that he will be the candidate of his party for a third term at the election this Autumn.
SWARTHMORE, Pa., March 21. -- A talk early in April by Sir Arthur Salter, British economist, will bring a climax to the sixth year of an economics discussion group at Swarthmore College.

Transportation to the flooded areas of Pennsylvania and Western New York was considerably improved yesterday but was still paralyzed in the Connecticut Valley region from Hartford, Conn., to Springfield, Mass.
