Conditions in the oil industry are considered materially better now than they were a year ago, although gasoline stocks are almost 9,000,000 barrels larger than they were then. Earnings of the industry are reported generally to be satisfactory and to be running at a much higher rate than in 1935.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 21. -- Closed informal house parties were held tonight by three Rutgers University fraternity chapters. About sixty guests attended the parties given by Theta Chi, Tau Kappa Epsilon and Tau Delta Phi.

Let's Look at the Stars" is particularly welcome because it is suitable for the younger children. It will appeal especially to 9, 10 and 11 year olds, although it may also serve as a first book on astronomy for older boys and girls whose interest in the subject is just awakening.

WASHINGTON. -- Motion pictures will be used as part of the administration's program for educating the farmers of America to the need of soil conservation, keystone of the substitute for the invalidated AAA. An appropriation bill carries 79,000 for the preparation and distribution of motion pictures dealing with the Department of Agriculture's scientific work.

WHEN a Woodside street-main burst a few weeks ago and deprived the neighborhood of water one of the housewives took the affliction philosophically. "My husband is on the night shift," she explained, "and doesn't have to wash his face in the morning."

OMAHA, Neb., March 20. -- Corn Belt farmers will plant more corn this year than they did last, but less than the average for the five years preceding the AAA and much less than in 1932, the year of abnormally expanded production.

GREAT BRITAIN'S foreign policy, her practice of what is called realistic diplomacy, her varying views toward treaty violations, puzzle friends and adversaries alike; and nothing is more puzzling than her repeated assertions that she is not actuated by self-interest.

LONDON, March 21. -- Official British quarters announced today that they had invited Chancellor Adolf Hitler to make counter-proposals to the tentative plan of the four remaining Locarno powers. They said that the Germans were free to express their point of view and to make alternative suggestions for any provisions in the Locarno powers' accord which they regarded as objectionable.

VERY fragile and brief, and written with a kind of breathless lyricism, "The Hill" is a first novel of considerable originality. For some tastes it may be too sensitive and fine-spun, but it does manage to distill naked emotion in fresh, subtle prose.

Several social events will be held in conjunction with the Boy Scout-O-Rama at Madison Square Garden next Friday and Saturday nights. Before the first performance on Friday, Mrs. George B. St. George will entertain at the Hotel Biltmore the associate chairmen of the women's committee, of which she is chairman.

The American Commercial Alcohol Corporation reported yesterday for 1935 the greatest volume of sales in its history and a net profit of $1,016,943 after excise taxes and other charges. Before consideration of a special reserve of $315,018 for inventory valuation, the earnings for the 264,890 shares of common stock outstanding were equivalent to $4.36 a share, and after deducting this reserve they amounted to $3.16 a share.

IT is of distinct advantage to this reviewer that the author of "Peace in the Balkans" quotes more frequently news and comment from THE NEW YORK TIMES than he does from any other newspaper. Citations from official publications, whether issued by the governments involved, by the League of Nations or by organizations whose object is identical with that of the author, are more frequent.

Signatures of ninety-one Sheriffs in fifteen Southern States where lynching has been most frequent were obtained during 1935 by the Association of Southern Women for the Prevention of Lynching, as reported in the summary of the year's work, issued by officials of the organization.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 21. -- Under any name, Boston's National League club looks the same to the Yankees. Manager Joe McCarthy's athletes finally caught up with the Hub clan at Waterfront Park today, after two of their scheduled games had been washed out by rain, and treated this year's Bees as if they were last year's Braves.

Women of society will act as manikins in the fashion show and luncheon under the auspices of the Alumnae Association of Rosemary Hall, on Tuesday at Sherry's, for the benefit of the school's scholarship fund.

ONCE more the National Academy is with us. The 111th annual opened with a varnishing reception last Tuesday and to the public Wednesday. It will be on until April 10, admittance free, hours 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. and on Sundays from 1:30 to 6 P.M.

Mushrooms, crabmeat, canned oysters and other toothsome edibles were added yesterday to the well-stuffed verbal larder in the record of the general court-martial at Governors Island of Captain Ralph E. Fleischer, United States Army.

LONDON, March 21. -- If the British Empire gives itself a total of more than seventy cruisers during the next six years the United States will feel free to resume building 10,000-ton cruisers, even though new construction of this class of ship is forbidden during the lifetime of the new naval treaty.
Early returns indicate that earnings of the railroads last month were the largest for a February since 1930.

Young matrons and debutantes of recent seasons will act as manikins in an unusual fashion show, entitled "Styles of a Century," which will be a feature of the luncheon in behalf of the Generosity Thrift Shop on April 7 in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
BERLIN, March 20. -- Once again Europe has looked over the precipice into the purgatory of war and has shuddered back at the last moment.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- The Louisville Nashville Railroad has asked the Interstate Commerce Commission not to require it to provide for a sinking fund in connection with the issuance of $30,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage bonds on the ground that it would constitute an "unnecessary and unreasonable burden."

VITALITY characterizes the paintings by Emil Ganso in the current display at Weyhe's (until April 4). There are endearing and lusty qualities in this work. Landscapes present sharp contrasts -- pleasant greens of foliage with slaty skies, an effect he carries over from his oils to his water-colors as well.

A summary of highway conditions in the flooded areas of New England, New York, Pennsylvania, West Virginia and Maryland, as of noon yesterday, was made public last night by the Automobile Club of New York as follows:

DURING a fateful evening in 1827, Hector Berlioz made two discoveries. One was Henrietta Smithson, the other William Shakespeare -- in whose tragedy of "Hamlet" the lady was cast as Ophelia. On the whole, the effects of his experience were disastrous.

LONDON, March 21. -- Joachim won Ribbentrop, Chancellor Adolf Hitler's Ambassador at Large, flew back to Berlin this afternoon to discuss with the Fuehrer the plan of four Locarno powers for a solution of the threatening European situation brought about by Germany's military reoccupation of the Rhineland.

The New York State Bar Association, in a report made public by its Committee on State Legislation, approves the formation of a Department of Justice and appointment instead of election of the Attorney General. The committee recommended disapproval of bills providing that newspaper men, and also public accountants, be privileged to refuse to disclose sources of information.

Much interest is being evidenced in the exhibition of amateur photography in behalf of the American Colony Charities Association which will open on April 1 in the Art Galleries of the Squibb Building, 745 Fifth Avenue, and will continue there through April 4.
Almost complete restoration of all communication lines in the flooded areas of the Eastern section of the country was reported yesterday by telephone and telegraph companies.

AN autobiographical narrative of the life of a young Englishman since the end of the World War, this book does not follow the usual formal, chronological lines of such reminiscences. Instead, Mr. Douie takes up in separate chapters the several activities and interests of his life, telling the story of each with only slight regard to the time element or to his other activities.

OF the making of books about Billy the Kid there seems, literally, to be no end. His brief but bloody life, the battle, murder and sudden death which for ten years spouted from his hands, the utter lawlessness of his nature seem to act so like a magnet upon many pens that the result becomes one of the minor curiosities of current literature.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, March 21. -- Frank Purnell, president of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company, said today that he expected the current high rate of operations in the steel industry would continue at least until July 1.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 21. -- Closing its home season today, the Naval Academy fencing team won from Cornell, 18 to 9. The victors gained a one-point advantage with the foils and won by decisive margins with the saber and epee.

Security and commodity prices moved narrowly last week. Stocks gained irregularly in the slowest trading in three months; Treasury bonds rose to high records and corporate liens held reasonably steady; grains declined as other commodities were steady.

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., March 21. -- Conditions here were much improved today. The same was true of towns along the Susquehanna River in the sixty-mile stretch from Sunbury to Lockhaven, one of the hardest hit sections of the flood area.

The committee on passenger fares for the Eastern railroads, headed by F.E. Williamson, president of the New York Central, this week will resume deliberations which are providing a turning point in the history of passenger fares in this country.

Miss America Olvera, trapeze acrobat, who was severely injured in a fall of about twenty-five feet in the Madison Square Garden last year, will again perform her aerial feat in New York City, when Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus returns next month, she announced in a letter from Offenbach, Germany, received here yesterday.

TIMES have changed since the blind man settled down to make the best of what to people with vision appeared to be a small world; steadily his horizon has broadened as educational methods adapted to his capabilities have been developed.

In the issue of Foreign Affairs for April, published last week, there is a group of articles singularly apposite to the chief interest of the present moment. When international searchlights are again turned full upon Germany, it is helpful to have such studies of various aspects of her life given to the public. Professor CHARLES A. BEARD writes of German education under Nazi rule.

John Rosch of White Plains likes to recall that prior to 1890 the Bronx River was one of the best trout streams in the State. As a boy, he passed many happy hours fishing for big brook trout in bright, clear waters between Scarsdale and his home town.

LONDON, Feb. 27. MONSIEUR HENRY BERNSTEIN'S "Espoir" has appeared in London under the title "Promise," with every assistance that our theatre can give to the work of a distinguished foreign dramatist.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 21. -- Following torrential rains which made morning play impossible, the Bermuda tennis championships were resumed this ofternoon in bright sunshine. In the feature engagement Mrs. Sylvia Henrotin of France easily retained the women's singles crown by defeating Miss Norma Taubele of New York, 6 -- 2, 8 -- 6.

THE importance which sociologists attach to the pursuit of hobbies as a means toward rational living is nowhere more clearly emphasized than in the boys' clubs of New York, whose function it is to guide the recreational activities of the city's underprivileged youth.

PRESENTING what is described as the most comprehensive highway program ever advanced to meet the requirements of this motor age, the Highway Survey Committee's recent report to the New York Legislature would provide for the extension and improvement of a State road system designed to meet fully the present and increasing number and use of motor vehicles.

BOSTON, March 21. -- The Simmons Faculty Players, a dramatic group drawn from the instruction staff of Simmons College, will present its third annual play in Boston on April 4 by reviving "Tom Cobb, or Fortune's Toy," a whimsical comedy written by W.S. Gilbert in 1875.

The Federal Government, now by way of being the country's biggest play producer, is getting a taste of the theatrical temperament. Beset from all sides, attacked in every direction, it has found a measure that was essentially an aid to relief construed in as many ways as there are opinions.
Mass picketing revealed itself in a fairly novel form in the Times Square district yesterday. Fifteen participants were arrested.

PUNCH'S cartoon of Benjamin Disraeli as the Sphinx would seem to be, still, his definitive portrait. Monypenny and Buckle's scholarly biography showed us the man as he cared to reveal himself in letters, in the so-called "Mutilated Diary" and in his actions, but these biographers refrained from undocumented conjecture.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 20. -- Now that the Senate has refused to appropriate $12,000,000 for the Florida ship canal, most observers throughout the State, pointing out that the project has gone down twice, believe it is destined to drown in a sea of opposition despite Senator Fletcher's efforts to rescue it.

The committee on passenger fares for the Eastern railroads, headed by F.E. Williamson, president of the New York Central, this week will resume deliberations which are providing a turning point in the history of passenger fares in this country.

Miss America Olvera, trapeze acrobat, who was severely injured in a fall of about twenty-five feet in the Madison Square Garden last year, will again perform her aerial feat in New York City, when Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus returns next month, she announced in a letter from Offenbach, Germany, received here yesterday.

When international searchlights are again turned full upon Germany, it is helpful to have such studies of various aspects of her life given to the public. Professor CHARLES A. BEARD writes of German education under Nazi rule.

John Rosch of White Plains likes to recall that prior to 1890 the Bronx River was one of the best trout streams in the State. As a boy, he passed many happy hours fishing for big brook trout in bright, clear waters between Scarsdale and his home town.

LONDON, Feb. 27. MONSIEUR HENRY BERNSTEIN'S "Espoir" has appeared in London under the title "Promise," with every assistance that our theatre can give to the work of a distinguished foreign dramatist.

CARTOONISTS and humorists, in their constant search for something funny, often fall back on the number of mistakes a bridge expert may be depended upon to make. Their witty remarks are not exaggerations. Rarely does even the best bridge player go through as many as sixteen hands without slipping at least once.
AIKEN, S.C. -- The eighth annual Aiken Field Trials will open tomorrow at Home Run, the plantation of Miss Claudia Phelps twelve miles south of here.

THE newest hats will have wider brims, lower and more rounded crowns and will be worn with a center crease, or the crown dented in diamond or triangular form: From the campuses of Eastern universities, where so many good hat styles have originated, comes the latest version of the "university hat."

WHATEVER else American youth may have been doing since 1929 it hasn't flamed. Flaming was a luxury reserved for a happier period, and the most successful flaming was done by youth which was living on its papa's money. Surprisingly little economic worry crept into the cynicism of the postwar generation -- its malaise was both spirituous and spiritual, but it was rarely, so far as the written record goes, financial.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- The Court of Appeals of New York will penetrate a new field of legal controversy in its consideration and decision of the constitutionality of the New York Unemployment Compensation Act, a vital issue now awaiting that court's determination.

Quietly and undramatically, the Supreme Court of the United States wrote finis early this month to a task launched twenty-eight years ago by the General Federation of Women's Clubs. Quietly but not undramatically, Miss Julia Jaffray, for twenty-six of those years a strategic figure in the fight, told yesterday how it was waged and won.

HACKENSACK, N.J., March 21. -- The metropolitan area will undergo an early Spring assault from mosquitos as a result of flood conditions prevailing in the 12,000 acres of the Hackensack meadow marshlands, it was predicted here today by John P. Peterson, superintendent of the Bergen County Mosquito Extermination Commission.

FOR many an old magazine the wastebasket is not, by any means, the end of the trail. Janitors and waste-paper dealers conspire to salvage an amazing proportion of all printed matter not given directly to welfare organizations.

Like the cigar store Indian, the day and age of push-poles for Long Island yachtsmen on Great South Bay seems nearly over. This item of equipment gear, almost unknown elsewhere, but lashed to many a cruiser cabin top by Amityville and Freeport skippers for service when grounded in a shallow channel, has served its purpose well.

ST. JOHN, N.B., March 21 (Canadian Press). -- Shortage of food and drinking water confronted flood-harassed residents today in the devastated lowlands of the St. John River where they have been isolated since early Thursday about twenty miles below Fredericton.

BERLIN, March 21. -- Lieut. Gen. Kurt Daluege, commander-in-chief of the German police, has issued formal orders to them to bring every citizen to the polls on March 29 whether said citizen wants to come or not. The police also have been instructed to get out into the streets and propagandize for the National Socialist party.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP). -- Just what shall be the relationship between government and business is the question for which the Chamber of Commerce of the United States will seek an answer at its annual meeting here April 27-30.

Harvard undergraduates arranging the production of "The Lid's Off," the annual presentation of the Hasty Pudding Club, are being assisted by a New York committee of debutantes who are now working toward the success of the performance of the play here on April 3 at Mecca Temple.

The Elmira College Glee Club will give its first concert in New York on the night of April 1 in the Music Room of the Biltmore, under the auspices of the Elmira College Club of New York, of which Miss Virginia Brown of Yonkers is president.

The foreign exchange market concluded yesterday a week of steady reaction, with further declines to the lowest quotations in about two months. The pound sterling fell to $4.95 7/8 and closed at $4.96 1/8, off 1/8 cent on the day and 1 3/4 cents on the week.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- With a full calendar of sports events on the program for the remainder of March and early April, Southern Pines has as its principal event this week the first annual Midsouth Open Championship to be held at the Southern Pines Country Club tomorrow.

AMONG many revivals of prewar fashions by the Paris couture probably none evokes a more complete picture of that social period than the beaded dress. It calls up memories of the first performances of "The Merry Widow," of great cotillions, of excitingly clandestine -- but, oh, how innocent! -- evenings at the Bal Tabarin or Maxim's (now so respectable!).

IT would be easy to dismiss this book as just another novel of the soil, another of those depressing accounts of a long and unequal struggle against hostile natural and economic forces, one more recital of the familiar woes of the farmer.

A silvery-haired centenarian who wasn't a clubwoman until she was 54 will celebrate her forty-six years of club activity on Tuesday as the guest of eleven organizations to which she now belongs. Other Brooklyn groups also have joined the ranks to pay tribute to Mrs. Amorette E. Fraser at the Hotel St. George. Five hundred civic, church and club representatives will attend.

The pamphlet report for 1935 of the Engineers Public Service Com pany indicates that should it develop, as a result of the administration of Title II of the Public Utility Act of 1935, that certain subsidiaries would be subjected to requirements that, in the opinion of counsel, were both injurious and beyond the constitutional power of the Federal Government, it might become necessary to institute court proceedings.

Your reviewer, Mr. Alfred Kazin, expresses some approval and some disapproval of my book, "What God Means to Me." I have to ask your permission to correct a serious misrepresentation of my point of view.

The Metropolitan Opera season, the first under the direction of Edward Johnson, came to a close yesterday. Although a tour and several scattered post-season performances here are listed in the next three weeks, the regular fourteen-week season ended with the matinee presentation of "La Rondine" and an evening production of "Goetterdaemmerung."

A striking evenness in participation revealed itself yesterday in the Constitution contest which THE NEW YORK TIMES is conducting for the best teaching plans and articles prepared by high school teachers of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. The total number of high schools entered in the competition reached 367 last night, and these were found to be divided as follows: city, 127; suburbs, 109; country, 132.

A RADIO program meter designed by two professors at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to "picture" listeners' preference also reveals that Sunday, in the Boston area, offers the largest audience; Wednesday and Thursday, second; Monday and Friday, third, and Tuesday and Saturday, fourth, with the latter having a slight edge.

NEW ORLEANS, March 21 (AP). -- Heart Break, the consistent daughter of Morvich, from R.A. Coward's stable, came through with her second straight victory today in winning the six-furlong feature at the Fair Grounds.

IN picturesque Visby, medieval wall city on the island of Gothland, midway in the Baltic, Agnes von Krusenstierna lays the opening scenes of "Fattig Adel" ("Poor Nobility") with its vivid scenes of childhood in a titled army officer's family.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 21. -- A heavy fall of soggy snow and rain throughout the Rochester area and the southern tier today complicated the task of linemen struggling to restore communication and gave possibility of a repetition of Tuesday's disastrous sleet storm.

THE orange tree was a fashionable window plant some years ago. But styles change, even in indoor gardening, and this really excellent subject fell into disuse. Today it is returning to popularity, for it is a colorful and dependable plant.

President ROOSEVELT summoned American business to a new crusade last week, when he urged it to take up the slack of unemployment and by that means enable the Government to scale down its enormous relief expenditures. To Congress he said that he sees no reason to believe that business can absorb large numbers of new employes "by individual and uncoordinated action."

MR. SMITH'S novel be might called a tragedy of manners. He has recognized, without underscoring, the fact that romantic love in our time is like a footnote to politics, and while intent on the telling of a simple story, he has provided that story with a motivation that seems reasonable only because of an accurate and vital background.

The author of this story does not play fair with his readers. In one of the early chapters he describes an encounter between two persons and near the end of the story he declares that this encounter never took place -- that it is a fiction devised by one of the persons concerned.

A RODEO in the little Western town of Dove Creek is a mighty different affair from one in Madison Square Garden. But what Dove Creek lacks in pace, quantity and showmanship it makes up in personal feeling and free-for-all fights.

Yesterday's short session of the commodity futures markets produced few price changes and trading was small. In the cash markets, lard, cotton and rye moved higher, corn and tin declined and other staples were unchanged.

The march of child labor into the mills and factories of the nation -- halted for a time by the provisions of NRA codes -- has been resumed. Reference is made to it, it was learned last week, in a report to President Roosevelt that compared NRA and post-NRA conditions in various Industries.
LONDON, March 20. -- Whatever else they may achieve, the diplomatic manoeuvres in London during the past week have provided an illuminating revelation of how the British look at Continental problems.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- A campaign to induce veterans to spend their bonus money on home construction and repair will soon be started by the Federal Housing Administration with White House approval, it was disclosed today when the administration made its first move to stimulate private employment by pushing plans for an amplified housing program.

ATHOS, in Greece, of course, as all the world knows, is the only sizable part of its face on which no female creature, whether woman, cow or cat, is allowed to set foot. Ralph H. Brewster, who is interested in photography and has wandered widely over Europe, heard so much about Athos that he decided to go there and see it at first hand.

Federal legislation intended to check price discrimination took the center of the stage here yesterday on reports that the Robinson-Patman bill might reach a Senate vote this week while related measures are being given public hearings by the Senate Judiciary Committee.
Following is that part of Senator Borah's speech in Chicago last night transcribed in New York by the National Broadcasting Company:

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation has agreed to lend $4,000,000 to the Metropolitan Casualty Insurance Company of New York, $4,389,745 to the Unified Debenture Corporation and $699,688 to the Interstate Debenture Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Howe S. Landers, president of Metropolitan Casualty.

DUBLIN, March 20. -- The estimates of the Irish Free State's supply services for the current fiscal year, recently issued, portend a sound budgetary situation next month when Finance Minister Sean Macentee introduces Fianna Fail's last budget before facing a general election early in 1937.

Commenting on former Governor Pinchot's letter, THE TIMES takes for granted that the Republican convention will write a platform "full of fair-sounding phrases about relief, social security, the welfare of farmers, the rights of labor, "

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, March 21. -- J.M. Albir, private secretary to President Carias of Honduras, has telegraphed to the San Jose radio station Voice of the Tropics: "This government is amazed at your radio station for its broadcasts of false information in regard to revolutionary activities in Honduras, v/here all is peaceful. ,a. revolution exists only in the imagination of a few discontented voluntary exiles."

PRESIDENTS of American colleges have been invited to send some sixty students to Washington on March 29 for a seven-day inspection of Federal activities under plans announced recently by the National Institute of Public Affairs.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 21. -- Harvard University has informed the City Council of Cambridge that it could not "properly comply" with the council's request for a gift to the city of $300,000 on the occasion of the 300th anniversary of Harvard College.

Much has been said for and against the new flood control, river correction, irrigation and hydroelectric undertakings of the present administration. But there is one important point in connection with these undertakings, involving vast expenditures, which does not seem to be generally understood.

An Easter supper-dance for juniors in society will be held under the direction of Miss Adeline King Robinson on Saturday night in the main ballroom of the Plaza. On the receiving committee will be Mrs. Ernest R. Adee, Mrs. Robert Winthrop Kean, Mrs. James B. Taylor Jr., Mrs. Livingston Parsons, Mrs. Samuel Sloan Walker, Mrs. Alexander T. Baldwin, Mrs. Henry B.H. Ripley and Mrs. O'Donnell Iselin.

Encouraged by developments since the first of the year, retailers have increased their sales gain expectancy in home furnishings lines and now look for volume increases ranging up to 35 per cent over last year, according to J.R. Ozanne, merchandising counsel of the Merchandise Mart, Chicago, who was here last week visiting local resident buyers.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 21. -- Mr. and Mrs. Sidney J. Legendre of Medway, S.C., were honored by Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Sanford, Miss Sarah Jane Sanford and John Sanford at a dinner dance tonight at Villa Marina.

"Flight" is a complete, well-organized photographic record of aviation. Its one hundred and seventy-five photographs are admirably selected both for beauty and significance. Since so much reading matter and so many pictures on the subject of aviation are now available, it is highly satisfactory to find a volume that is not only complete but concise.

CINCINNATI, March 21. -- The seventeenth annual show of the Cincinnati Kennel Club opened at the Xavier University field house with 668 dogs, representing fifty-four breeds, benched. The entry was 100 more than last year. The leading breeds were cocker spaniels, beagles, collies, Scottish terriers, Boston terriers and chows.

MR.ROSENFELD has been hearing and criticizing music and musicians for a considerable time, as his several books testify. He has hitherto attended mostly to modern composers and their works. But, apparently in the last five years, in the course of his "reporting" for various periodicals he has extended his researches backward, and discovered much; learned, as he says, something about music as a creative force.

ATLANTA, March 21. -- Trade soared to new high levels in the Sixth Federal Reserve District this week. Pre-Easter buying was reported to be the heaviest since 1930 as a group of leading department stores revealed sales gains over the corresponding period a year ago ranging from 10 to 20 per cent.

CUMBERLAND, Md., March 21 (AP). -- Snow, rain and cold threatened Maryland's second largest city with new misery and suffering tonight, but relief forces apparently had the situation well in hand. The call was general in Western Maryland.

WASHINGTON, March 2l. -- Announcement of some details of the new farm program brought a quick response today in telegraphed protests against rates and conditions for paying soil conservation subsidies to producers of rice, sugar cane and sugar beets.

PRESIDENTS of American colleges have been invited to send some sixty students to Washington on March 29 for a seven-day inspection of Federal activities under plans announced recently by the National Institute of Public Affairs.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 21. -- Harvard University has informed the City Council of Cambridge that it could not "properly comply" with the council's request for a gift to the city of $300,000 on the occasion of the 300th anniversary of Harvard College.

WASHINGTON, March 2l. -- Announcement of some details of the new farm program brought a quick response today in telegraphed protests against rates and conditions for paying soil conservation subsidies to producers of rice, sugar cane and sugar beets.

Three Spring flower shows, two of which have been fixtures on the North Shore of Long Island for more than twenty-five years, are scheduled to be held in New York this year in the rooms of the Horticultural Society of New York at 598 Madison Avenue, it was revealed yesterday through the issuance of preliminary schedules by the Nassau Horticultural Society.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 21. -- In its first game of the season the Princeton Rugby Club downed the French Rugby Club of New York, 9 -- 0, today on Bedford Field. Hugh Davis, veteran forward, was high scorer for the Tigers, with two tries.

The Committee on Legislation of the Citizens Union announced yesterday its approval of the Dunnigan-Steingut bill, recommended by Governor Lehman, to bring the State social security program in line with Federal statutes.

COLLEGE teaching still merits its reputation for meager financial rewards. Five thousand a year is today a high salary even for a full-time State university professor, according to an investigation just completed by the United States Office of Education in our leading land-grant colleges.

To provide a keener grasp of the situation in international relations for various groups of women, the Foreign Policy Association will stage an International Relations Institute on Saturday at the Hotel Astor, for which invitations have been issued to those women of the metropolitan area who are particularly interested in the topic.

IN a few weeks the world's greatest tourist migration will begin, the annual trek of travelers from America to Europe. In the throng will be the inveterate pleasure seekers -- transatlantic commuters one might call them -- teachers, students, scientists, artists, political observers and business people: a line of pilgrims covering a wide range of the social scale.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 21. -Breaking forty-seven targets, C. H. iSayre triumphed in a skeet shoot fat the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. J. C. Couzens took the handicap cup in a shoot-off, the second prize going to Mrs. W. R, Coe Jr.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 21. -- Warfare has broken out within the ranks of the Townsend old-age pension movement in Calfornia over Representative McGroarty's candidacy as leader of a Townsend delegation to the Democratic National Convention in the May 5 California Presidential primary.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 21. -- The floods in Central Pennsylvania added new thrills to student life at the Pennsylvania State College this week, along with some anxiety about the folks back home.
PORTLAND, Me., March 22 (AP). -- The Saco River roared through its southwestern Maine valley today while the State and communities mobilized to quell disease and distress.
Five of the twenty competitors in the women's championship tournament at the Marshall Chess Club qualified for the finale yesterday when games in the ninth round were contested.

BERLIN, March 21. -- Political and financial circles regained confidence this week and declared the risk of an acute conflict over the Locarno treaty violation insignificant, the Boerse recovering substantially.

The pamphlet report for 1935 of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company, released for publication today, shows as of Dec. 31 last current assets of $76,588,329 and current liabilities of $10,016,210, compared with $67,856,820 and $67,645,362 respectively on Dec. 31, 1934. The reduction in current liabilities was effected largely by the funding last year of $59,549,120 bank loans which were outstanding at the end of 1934.

ALBANY, March 22. -- The death rate in the State in January, 12.7 per 1,000 population, was a fraction below the 1935 rate and has been lower but twice in the past fifty years, the Department of Health reported today.

PITTSBURGH, March 22. -- Nation-wide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 50 per cent of capacity, against 57 per cent in the preceding week. Last week opened with the promise of a rate of about 62 per cent, which would have been the highest since June, 1930, but floods suddenly caused a curtailment.

MIAMI, Fla., March 22. -- An experiment of national proportions, which will take two years to conclude but which may settle once and for all the starting problem that has vexed American racing for a generation, has been initiated by Joseph E. Widener and other leaders, it was disclosed today.

A section of pavement on Riverside Drive, about thirty feet long and extending across the northbound traffic lane of the Drive at 148th Street, collapsed at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, just as the Sunday procession of motorists bound for the George Washington Bridge, Westchester County and other points was approaching peak proportions.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- Employers who attempt to negotiate workers' grievances on an individual basis do not comply with collective bargaining requirements of existing law "no matter how happily grievances may be adjusted," the National Labor Relations Board ruled today.

LONDON, March 22. -- In a speech tonight to a crowd that filled Albert Hall, the largest auditorium in Britain, Sir Oswald Mosley took advantage of the disturbed international situation to make a new appeal for support by representing his Fascist movement as a champion of peace and reconciliation with Germany.

BERLIN, March 21. -- An export surplus of 40,000,000 marks in February was regarded as favorable, since the month generally is doubtful from a seasonal standpoint, and in 1935 there was a deficit of 57,000,000 marks for the period.

John Hamilton, Republican National Committeeman from Kansas and manager of Governor Alf. M. Landon's campaign for the nomination for President, announced yesterday that he would open a personal office in New York City and, in effect, superseded the New York State Landon-for-President committee, organized and headed by Albert Ottinger, former Attorney General.

PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, March 22. -- Three miles of concrete wall and a mile of railroad embankment, built to withstand all but unprecedented floods, stood between this thriving industrial city and disaster today as the Ohio River flood crest rolled westward to the Mississippi, leaving scores of inundated cities and towns behind it.

CHICAGO, March 22. -- Lard prices here were 60 to 67 1/2 cents a hundredweight higher last week than the previous week, the latter on May and July which closed at $11.05, the best of the week. There was said to be export buying and short covering.

Last week, interest was divided between the gestures and manoeuvres in Europe's divided political camps, and the extraordinary river overflows in many important sections of this country. The one tended at least to occasion hesitancy in financial markets; the other was apparently bound to reduce activity in the flooded area, alike in production and transportation.

Two dance recitals set up in opposition to each other last night when Lillian Shapero and her group gave their first formal performance at the Civic Repertory Theatre and the Dance Guild presented five solo dancers in what was also its first formal performance at the Vanderbilt.

ALBANY, March 22 (AP). -- Forty-seven relief projects, calling for $678,991.11, were approved today by Lester M. Herzog, up-State WPA administrator, who estimated that they would give 203 months' employment to 1,847 men and 57 women.
JOHNSTOWN, Pa., March 22 (AP). -- Two new deaths increased the list of flood fatalities in this community to twenty-two today.
I wonder if those who are so vehement in their diatribes against slow driving are not actuated more by their personal discomfort than by thought of the Public welfare.

The annual Gift Horse party in behalf of the New York Exchange for Woman's Work will be held the afternoon of April 15 at the Exchange Restaurant, 541 Madison Avenue. A feature of the party, as in previous seasons, will be a "Gift Horse" laden with gifts that have been donated by members of society for distribution among the guests.

Pierre-Etienne Flandin, French Foreign Minister, reviewed the work of the London conferences of the Locarno treaty powers and the League of Nations Council in a broadcast from Paris that was rebroadcast over the Columbia System yesterday from 12:45 to 1 P.M.

BRESLAU, Germany, March 22. -- Silesians greeting Adolf Hitler here today vied in their vociferous enthusiasm with the East Prussians who had welcomed him to Koenigsberg and the nearly hysterical audience that had cheered him in Hamburg.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1936, as well as last price, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:
The first in a series of meetings in behalf of the work of the Vocational Service for Juniors will be held this morning at the home of Mrs. R. Keith Kane, 121 East Seventy-eighth Street.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 22. -- Jerome (Dizzy) Dean signed a one-year contract tonight to pitch for the Cardinals. The salary was not announced, but Dizzy declared he was "satisfied." Branch Rickey said he was "happy."

A banking group headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. will offer today four new issues of bonds of the city of Minneapolis, Minn., aggregating $2,540,000. The offering consists of $840,000 of 2 per cent bonds, $170,000 of 2.40 per cent, and two issues amounting to $1,530,000 of 2.60 per cent bonds, issued for sewage disposal system, public market and other civic undertakings.

DETROIT, March 22. -- Detroit's Red Wings ended the National League season tonight with a 7-to-2 victory over the New York Americans, which gave the Wings a warm-up for the opening of first-place play-offs at Montreal Tuesday. It was the Wings' twenty-fourth victory of the season and the twenty-fifth defeat for the Americans.

Your editorial "The Relief Program" states: "The best plan would be to abandon the program of centralized control grid constant experiment with new methods, and to substitute for it a plain offer by the Federal Government to contribute to the cost of relief in direct proportion to the funds raised by State and local governments, leaving to the latter full responsibility to decide how these funds can be used locally to best advantage."

HARTFORD, March 22. -- This flood-stricken city was in almost a state of siege tonight, with all highways under strict patrol by National Guardsmen and no one allowed to enter or leave without permission from the authorities.

Henry Hayden Sands, a former Manhattan real estate owner and son of the late Dr. Henry B. Sands, who was a prominent New York surgeon, was found dead last night in a furnished room he had occupied for the last three weeks at 508 Monroe Avenue, Asbury Park, N.J. The police listed the death as a suicide.

PARIS, March 21. -- The report of the Bank of France dated March 13 shows the repercussion of Chancellor Hitler's Rhineland coup on the money market here. The sudden increase of more than 1,000,000,000 francs in circulation at a time when it normally tends to diminish was due solely to withdrawals of deposits from the savings banks and the private banks by the public.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22. -- The only member of the Elmira team of the New York-Pennsylvania League who is being treated to the luxury of a Southern training trip is the manager thereof, the same being none other than W. Jacques Maranville, the perennial Rabbit who bounded about the big leagues for a full two dozen years.

Dr. ALEXIS CARREL said in Los Angeles that a middle-aged man today has a smaller chance to live to be 80 than his grandfather did. He thinks that our resistance to fatigue, to sorrow, to worry, has been decreasing.

Weaknesses in our present patent system are pointed out in THE TIMES editorial "A Century of Patent" and some pertinent questions are asked. The editorial states: "We need new industries to absorb the unemployed."

If the cafeteria-conscious world tried dining instead of eating, international problems would be solved easily, Hendrik Willem Van Loon, author, lecturer and diner extraordinary, declared yesterday in an address on the eating habits of nations.

Survivors of the New York Golden Gloves amateur boxing competition will pit their strength against an invading team from Chicago in the ninth annual intercity Golden Gloves final at Madison Square Garden tonight, and as usual approximately 20,000 persons are expected to witness the events.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 22 (AP). -- John Godfrey Saxe, president of the New York State Bar Association, today appointed a new grievance committee, supplanting a former elective committee, to hear complaints against lawyers.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- In light of fading hopes for quick passage of President Roosevelt's new tax plan, Congressional leaders are expected this week to place the proposed $1,500,000,000 lump sum work relief appropriation as No. 1 on the legislative slate, and to hold it there until it has ridden out the gathering political storm.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 22 (AP). -- The Exler brothers of St. Louis did things to the standing board of the American Bowlers Congress minor events today. When they had ceased firing one, Leo, was on top in the all-events and second in the doubles, and another, Hubert, held seventh place in the singles.

CHICAGO, March 22. -- Livestock trading in the Middle West was affected last week to a moderate extent by the floods in the East, which cut off buying and shipments, but on the whole the effect was less than would ordinarily be expected.

PREAKNESS, N.S., March 22. -- County, municipal and township officials were among 800 persons who attended the formal dedication here today of Passaic County's new $1,000,000 welfare home. The four-story brick structure, construction of which was begun by the County Board of Freeholders in 1931, will be ready for occupancy April 1.
Peter J. McGuinness, Sheriff of Kings County, helped out the people of Brownsville yesterday afternoon by resorting to his original occupation. In short, he drove a team of horses.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- Savings deposits in all types of banks in the United States increased $1,242,484,000 in the twelve months from June 30, 1934, to June 29, 1935, J.F.T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, revealed in his annual report for the year ended on Oct. 31, 1935.

MOSCOW, March 22. -- Disappointed at what it regards as the equivocal position of Great Britain on Germany's march into the Rhineland and her denunciation of Locarno, the Soviet Union intends to strengthen its own already powerful armaments in the conviction that only in this way can it safeguard its own security.

Of the "cubist" and "abstractionist" exhibition now going on at the Modern Museum of Art, LEWIS MUMFORD in The New Yorker presents an ingenious defense. To begin with, he argues, all painting and sculpture is abstract. Even at its most realistic it is a displacement of something that exists in life with a symbol that has only a limited number of points of resemblance.

While there was a wide expansion in buying in the wholesale markets here last week, the difficulty in making deliveries of fashion merchandise for Easter selling became more serious, due to transportation delays caused by floods in various sections of the country.

With many of the leading amateur players in the East listed to compete, the nineteenth annual Poggenburg Memorial Cup 18.2 balkline billiard tournament will get under way today. Play will be held at the Lawler Brothers Manhattan and Brooklyn rooms.

ON BOARD PRESIDENTIAL TRAIN, March 22. -- Putting aside political and legislative controversies for a fortnight's vacation fishing in the South Atlantic, President Roosevelt left Washington today on a holiday postponed three times in as many days because of the flood disaster.

A letter from President Roosevelt was read yesterday afternoon at the Ninth Street Temple, near Sixth Avenue, Brooklyn, during a celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of Congregation B'nai Sholaum, which worships there.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 22 (AP). -- Under the season's first perfect weather, the Eastern-Central Pennsylvania area took its first definite steps today toward fighting its way out of the desolation left by last week's flood.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 22. -- Now and then in a motor boat regatta the fastest craft does not win the trophy and today upward of 30,000 spectators witnessing the concluding heats of the twenty-third annual Biscayne Bay events saw this phenomenon with their own eyes.
CAPE TOWN, March 22. -- General Jan Christiaan Smuts begged Europe's statesmen today to "take Hitler at his word" and rebuild peace on surer foundations.

While it is generally held that there is no transmission of "acquired character," one has been prompted to offer in opposition to this theory the famous family of mathematicians -- the BERNOULLIS, at least four of whom attained encyclopedia distinction in that field of science.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., March 22. -- La Salle Academy of New York, Manhattan Catholic High Schools Athletic Association champion, today accepted an invitation to participate in the Eastern States basketball tournament here April 2, 3 and 4, according to an announcement made by Ralph Knight, tournament chairman, following a long-distance telephone conversation with Brother Leo, athletic director of the La Salle team.
ALBANY, March 22 (AP). -- Rehabilitation of flood sufferers went forward rapidly today while construction crews battled a strange contrast of elements on the State's highways.

A full gale cleared New York skies yesterday, but tore huge signs from their moorings, ripped crosses from church steeples, caved in shop windows, sent hundreds of small boat adrift, gave ferryboat skippers a hard day and even made walking a hazard.
BRESLAU, Germany, March 22. -- The part of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's address here dealing with foreign relations follows:

The final opera concert of the season took place at the Metropolitan Opera House last night before a large and immensely enthusiastic audience. The novelty of the program was a classic ballet presented by the American Ballet principals and ensemble to Chopin's Piano Concerto in F sharp minor.

Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., will offer today $9,292,000 of Louisville Nashville Railroad Company first and refunding mortgage 4 per cent bonds, Series D, due on April 1, 2003, at par and accrued interest.
A rebirth of the church to combat growing materialism and paganism was urged by clergy of different denominations in their sermons in the city yesterday morning.
CHICAGO, March 22 (AP). -- The weatherman called for rain today, and Mississippi Valley rivermen watched anxiously for signs of flood.

Commissioner of Accounts Paul Blanshard, denying charges by District Attorney Dodge that he had entered a job-buying investigation "to grab a lot of publicity," issued a statement yesterday asserting that there was nothing unusual in the fact that his office had cooperated with the police in the case.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22. -- Babe Ruth got his first look at the 1936 model Yankee baseball machine at Waterfront Park this afternoon, and saw a pretty snappy team.
AKRON, Ohio, March 22 (AP). -- Maintenance employes went to work today at the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company to prepare for resumption of production following settlement of a five weeks' strike.

In the long controversy over the relief question two major arguments have been made for "work relief" as against the "dole." One is that the morale of people who lack employment is better sustained if they are given something to do, and a wage of some kind to work for, than if they merely receive a small gratuity while they remain in idleness.

LOS ANGELES, March 22. -- Having raised the American flag over the last unclaimed land on earth and named it for my father. I am overjoyed at being in my own country again, but have nothing as yet to report on my future plans.

Mankind, unknowingly, is the victim of many evils in disguised forms, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of the Union Theological Seminary, declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

BOSTON, March 22. -- The brilliant contingent of Canadian players dominated the final-round matches of the New England open badminton championships which were played on the courts of the University Club today.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP). -- Representative Isabella Greenway of Arizona announced tonight that she would retire from office at the end of her present term.
Cotton futures continued to move in a narrow price range last week. At Saturday's close prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were 1 point down to 11 points up from the previous week.

IN his introduction to this book Robert Frost calls Sarah N. Cleghorn an Abolitionist as of 1861. One might go even further back and call her a Brook Farmer or an Owenite, or speak of Fruitlands and the Oneida Community. Yet any such identification would be merely figurative; Sarah N. Cleghorn is very much alive today, as her newly published autobiography, "Threescore" (Smith Haas, $3), makes clear.

LONDON, Monday, March 23 (AP). -- The drafting committee of the international naval conference was called today to give final consideration to various drafts of proposed texts for a new six-year treaty, to be signed Wednesday by the United States, Great Britain and France.

ADDIS ABABA, March 22. -- Twenty-seven Italian military planes circled for an hour over Jijiga, fifty miles northeast of Harar, today, dropping a rain of incendiary bombs in the heaviest and most protracted aerial action of the war.

NICE, France, March 22. -- Prince Louis of Monaco has canceled the guardianship conferred upon Prince Pierre upon his divorce from Princess Charlotte, the daughter of Prince Louis. This is a result of the reported dispute between Princess Antoinette and her father, Prince Pierre.

FORT LEE, N.J., March 22. -With his church still padlocked against him, the Roy. Vincent G. Burns, ousted pastor of the Union Church of Palisade, Interdenominational, held his second Sunday morning service today in the log cabin studio on his own property here.

An exhibition of the work of John LaFarge (1835-1910), arranged to commemorate the hundredth anniversary of his birth, will open at the Metropolitan Museum with a private view today and to the public tomorrow. The material, borrowed from various museums and private collections, has been placed in Gallery D6.

Beekman Pool of the Harvard Club, metropolitan Class A singles champion, heads the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association rankings for the third time, according to an announcement made yesterday by the committee. Robert Grant 3d, another Harvard Club star, is rated second. Grant was first last Winter.

BERLIN, March 21. -- The Reichsbank's report for mid-March reflects the tension of the early part of this month by showing a decline of only 50,000,000 marks in total credits. The annual report of the Reichsbank for 1935 showed a net profit of 40,000,000 marks, unchanged, and the dividend also was unchanged at 12 per cent, of which one-third was withheld and invested in public securities under the loan stock law.

" We need more friendship in the world" and poverty must be combated, the Rev. George Arthur Buttrick said yesterday in his sermon at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Seventy-third Street. Nearly 1,000 persons crowded the large auditorium and galleries at morning services.

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 22. -- The Giants tried to take the second game of their current exhibition series with the Cubs right in their stride today, but something tripped them and they sprawled rather inelegantly to the general discomfiture of a gallery of some 2,000 well-wishers.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 22. -- One or more army fliers were killed here tonight when an airplane, struggling against the high winds, crashed into a building at Fort Slocum.

LONDON, March 22. -- Germany's reply to the Locarno powers' proposals was being awaited with mounting eagerness in London tonight in the belief that it would be reasonable enough to permit the starting of the most ambitious peace negotiations in Europe since 1919.

MEXICO, D.F., March 22 (AP). -- Unification of Mexican labor sought by President Lazaro Cardenas was far from realized today when four organizations professing different aims held meetings in various parts of the city.

Because the spirit unites men regardless of how much the material affairs of life, politics, economics and nationality pull them apart, the Catholic Church, "the only catholic thing left in the world today," is the one institution capable of "holding the world together," Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen declared yesterday morning at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, where he delivered the fourth in a series of Lenten sermons.

In the absence of further word yesterday from Washington, where Rags died, members of the First Division stationed at Fort Hamilton were laying plans to bury the heroic one-eyed dog and to erect a monument in his memory.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 22. -- Plans of the Westchester County Commission on Government for reorganization of the county's governmental system were approved in substance today in a letter from the Westchester League of Women Voters.
With Bishop William T. Manning officiating, the Rev. Gordon Wadhams was inducted yesterday morning as rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Resurrection, 115 East Seventy-fourth Street.

Music Education Week will begin in New York next Saturday with the arrival of delegates for the Music Educators' National Conference. It will be the twenty-fourth meeting and fifth biennial of the conference, which will continue through April 3.

Traffic on the Interborough Rapid Transit Company system, including both subway and elevated lines, was 5.28 per cent greater last month than in February of 1935, according to a report made public yesterday by Thomas E. Murray Jr., Federal receiver for the company.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- The "campaign class" for wives of Democratic Senators and Representatives will open tomorrow with "The New Farm Act and the Background the Pigs" as of Little the topic for lesson one.
The prospect of an Oxford University rugby invasion this season was brightened by the action of the Eastern Rugby Union of America at a meeting held yesterday at the George Washington Hotel.

Some of the best horses in the country in the various age divisions are named for the seven stake events at Empire City during the Summer meeting in July, according to an announcement made yesterday by James Butler, president of the Empire City Racing Association.

ALBANY, March 22 (AP). -- The State Mayors' conference said tonight that the proposed constitutional limitation amendment would "create financial chaos in practically every unit of government in the State."

As the subcommittee on taxation of the House Ways and Means Committee delves further into the proposed undistributed profits tax, it finds itself in deeper and deeper water. It is compelled to recognize more and more "exceptional cases" which it feels obliged to exempt, and this leads to talk of higher and higher rates on the other corporations in order to make up the lost revenue.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,318,333,100. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing disccunt bills.

A prospective event that has received the cooperation of many members of society for several weeks is the New York debut of the Hollywood Ballet, performances of which will be given tomorrow night and Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Boys Club of New York.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 22. -- Ray Murphy, National Commander of the American Legion, began a telegraphic mobilization today of the full strength of his organization to assist the Red Cross in raising $3,000,000 for flood-relief work.

The Merchants Association announced yesterday its opposition to the Crawford-Rapp bill, pending in Albany, which would amend the State Constitution by lowering the real estate taxation limit in New York City from 2 per cent to 1 3/4 per cent, exclusive of sums for debt service, and 1 1/2 per cent elsewhere in the State, with the debt-incurring power limited to 10 per cent, both in the city and elsewhere.

Five thousand children from eighty Jewish religious schools in the city took part in a pageant depicting the evolution of Jewish charity at the Roxy Theatre yesterday morning. Sponsored by the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies and the Jewish Education Association, it was called "a mass lesson in philanthropy.''
MONTREAL, March 22. -- The stage was set tonight for the playoffs for the National Hockey League championship and the Stanley Cup, emblem of world professional honors.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 22. -- Mrs. Sylvia Henrotin of France and Mrs. Dorothy Andrus of Stamford, Conn., successfully defended their Bermuda women's tennis doubles championship today, defeating the Misses Norma Taubele and Florence Le Boutillier of New York, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 0, in the final.
May I comment on your editorial "Labor Facts and Theories"?

Some memorable playing was heard from Albert Spalding yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall when that accomplished American violinist appeared as soloist with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Hans Lange's direction, in the Bruch G minor concerto.

About 100 members of families descended from the Twelve patentees who founded the village of New Paltz in what is now Ulster County, in 1678, met yesterday afternoon at the French Church du Saint-Esprit, 229 East Sixty-first Street, and organized the Descendants of New Paltz Patentees.

Injury and defeat continued to stalk the trail of the New York Rovers as they lost a 4-2 decision to the Pittsburgh Yellow Jackets in the main contest on the amateur hockey program at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon. A gathering of 9,800 persons witnessed the game, one in the series for the Hershey Cup.

LONG BEACH, Calif., March 22 (AP). -- Dr. Francis E. Townsend tonight affirmed his support of Senator Borah of Idaho for the Presidency and announced that he had changed his registration from "independent" to Republican.
BOSTON, March 22. -- The New York Rangers ended their most unsuccessful National Hockey League season in ten years tonight by defeating the Boston Bruins, 3 -- 1, at the Boston Garden.

TOKYO, Monday, March 23. -- Hitherto the Japanese Navy, trained on the British model, has avoided politics, but a step toward its more active participation in national policy is announced by the newspaper Asahi. Admiral Osami Nagano, the Navy Minister, has decided to establish within the Navy Office a State policy investigation board to focus the navy's views for the information of the government.

A phonetic transcription of "Jabberwocky" is included in Harry Morgan Ayres's "Carroll's Alice," which Columbia University Press will publish within a month. Jane Dorsey Zimmerman made the transcription.

The pamphlet report of the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation for 1935 showed net income of $21,701,275 after all deductions, equal after preferred dividends to $8.71 a share on the common stock, compared with $17,548,355, or $6.83 a share, in 1934.
MOSCOW, March 22. -- The Stakhanoff movement has hit the Moscow telephone system, and subscribers are going batty.

The switch in consumer interest from durability to style and other factors, which has been accentuated in the last few years, is the dominant factor in the merchandizing of all new products, according to authorities here yesterday. As a result of this trend definite limits on prices which manufacturers can charge for products are set and pricing becomes of greater importance than heretofore.

Sanford Peters has been appointed transportation manager of the Northern Warren Corporation and subsidiary companies, 191 Hudson Street, and he has removed his office from 226 East Seventieth Street to 551 Fifth Avenue.

High winds that swept in from Long Island Sound were responsible for poor scores at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. A. L. Burns, a Class A gunner, led the field with 94 out of 100 targets.

The scope and the extent of Catholic political action in the United States were defined yesterday by speakers at a symposium on the "Limitations of Catholic Political Action," held under the auspices of the National Catholic Alumni Federation, at the Center Club, 120 Central Park South.

PARIS, March 22. -- How a section of French opinion has reacted to the German reoccupation of the Rhineland was shown today by approval of the speech delivered by General Maxime Weygand last evening in which he declared: "We have just suffered a humiliation."
The Cardinals and Indians rule the "grapefruit league," the first check-up on results of exhibition games played by major league ball teams in the South and West by The Associated Press revealed.
BOSTON, March 22. -- "On Your Toes," a new musical show, had its world premiere last night at the Shubert Theatre here.

New York again showed its interest in figure skating by filling Madison Square Garden to capacity at the ice carnival staged last night for the benefit of the Bellevue Hospital social service and the Carroll Club.

LONDON, March 20. -- After the first shock of the political crisis the foreign exchanges are gradually settling down to more normal conditions. Strong official support for the franc was required at first, but is no longer needed, although there is still some evidence that the apprehension on the Continent is still turning francs into dollars.

THE TIMES prints today a letter from President Finegan of the New York Municipal Civil Service Commission, which refers to the non-competitive classification of Board of Election clerks by the New York City Civil Service Commission and the disapproval of the resolution for such non-competitive classification by the State Civil Service Commission.

The Polish Government was charged with "deliberate violations of its pledges made in the treaty of June, 1919, in Which the Jews, together with other minority groups, were assured full equality of rights and status," by an emergency conference at the Hotel Edison yesterday, attended by delegates of nearly 500 Jewish organizations.

ALBANY, March 22. -- Further expansion of the State forest preserve was among ten major recommendations made by Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne in his annual report, which will be submitted to the Legislature tomorrow night.

Leonard Sillman's "New Faces of 1936" is nearing the rehearsal point -- March 30, perhaps -- and should be ready for a premiere at the Vanderbilt about April 20 or 27. Or so Mr. Sillman thought yesterday, adding that there will be thirty-six in the cast, end no chorus.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- American manufacturers are unwarranted in their fears of Japanese competition, and also this country profits greatly in the balance of trade with that country, a report issued by the Foreign Policy Association asserted today.

CHICAGO, March 22. -- Liquidation was the rule last week in the grain markets of the United States and Canada, as well as in certain European centers, with prices around the lowest of the season. Nor was there any rally of consequence. Efforts were made by a few local traders to stem the decline, but the pressure was too urgent.

ALBANY, March 22. -- Legislative leaders admitted tonight that there was little prospect of a break this week in the deadlock between the Democratic Senate and the Republican Assembly over the action of the lower house in reducing Governor Lehman's budget by more than $15,000,000 in order to eliminate the emergency one-cent gasoline tax.
DETROIT, March 22 (AP). -- Father Charles E. Coughlin, in his first radio broadcast from the new shrine of his Royal Oak, Mich., parish, linked the floods and the depression today.

A new period in church history is evolving from the current religious unrest in Germany which will challenge the entire Christian church to defend itself against paganism, the Rev. Dr. F.H. Otto Melle, president of the Federal Council of Free Churches in Germany, declared in a sermon yesterday morning in Queens.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- Charging that the New Deal has "squandered" $21,000,000,000 only to deepen the depression, Henry P. Fletcher, chairman of the Republican National Committee, declared today that, contrary to President Roosevelt's relief message to Congress last week calling upon business to employ more labor if relief expenditures were to be reduced, the depression will continue until the United States becomes "frankly socialistic," unless there is a return to "sanity and common sense."

CHICAGO, March 22 (AP). -- A polished five from De La Salle High of Chicago overpowered the St. Mary's team, from Anderson, Ind., tonight, 45 to 29, to win its third National Catholic Interscholastic Basketball championship.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- The Works Progress Administration has concluded after an exhaustive survey that bigger families, less employment and smaller incomes were chiefly responsible for economic disaster overtaking rural families who went on relief early in the depression.

CHICAGO, March 22.--Senator Borah's chances for support in the industrial East and among conservative Republicans, if the reaction among politicians here is to be accepted, were distinctly lessened by the slashing attack which he made last night on corporate interests and the Republican organization leaders in his fighting speech opening his Western campaign.

Orders received by the General Electric Company in 1935 amounted to $217,361,587, against $183,660,303 in 1934, a gain of 18 per cent, according to its report for 1935. The company's income account for last year has been published before. An increase of $8,776,934 in earned surplus is shown in the following tabulation:

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- Admiral Cary T. Grayson, chairman of the American Red Cross, said today that week-end rains had hampered relief work in flood areas and that the organization might have to extend its operations to the lower Ohio valley along the Mississippi River within the next few days.

TAMPA, Fla., March 22. -- There were few hits in the Brooklyn bats as the Dodgers furnished an excellent brand of entertainment for 1,000 fans today by losing to Chuck Dressen's Reds, 4 -- 2. The Dodgers failed to score until the ninth and then didn't alarm the spectators unduly, as the second run came in with the second out and no other men on base.

CINCINNATI, March 22. -- The special award for the best in show was won by the Sealyham terrier, Champion St. Margaret Magnificent of Clairedale, at the close of the seventeenth annual two-day dog show of the Cincinnati Kennel Club tonight in Xavier Field House.

ASMARA, Eritrea, March 22. -- After a six-day trip to the front it is possible to say now that a situation of utmost importance is developing swiftly on the northern front. This development has a twofold aspect, but it is permitted at present to speak only of one of them, that which concerns Emperor Haile Selassie.

HARTFORD, March 22. -- Tonight's 9 o'clock curfew was applied by the flood relief committee to a three-quarter-mile belt from the railroad station east to the river, and embraced a district containing principal insurance and other buildings in this famous insurance center.

PITTSBURGH, March 22 (AP). -- Millions of gallons of filtered drinking water were pumped into the reservoirs of the flood-stricken steel metropolis today to allay fears of contamination and disease that impeded the restoration of economic life.

Members of the Alumnae of the Sacred Heart will meet Wednesday morning at the Convent of the Sacred Heart, 1 East Ninety-first Street, to complete plans for their annual luncheon on April 21. Arrangements will be discussed also for the final lecture in a series for the benefit of the Duchesne Placement Bureau which will be given Friday morning at the convent.

Commodity futures generally were higher last week, although price changes were narrow. A moderate increase in activity, however, was taken as an indication that public interest in commodities was gaining. In the cash markets, cotton, lard, rubber, hides, wool tops, silks and cocoa were up, while wheat, corn, rye, oats, coffee, print cloths, tin and pork were lower.

Floods sweeping the eastern part of the United States prompted many clergymen in New York City, in their sermons yesterday morning, to challenge the old belief that such disasters were visitations upon erring man by Divine Providence. Some of the clergy foresaw good to come of the floods.

DARJEELING, India, March 7 (By Mail) -- For our purpose there was no need to go straight to Mount Everest, and on our journey westward we were able to see a good deal of the beautiful, unexplored ranges lying around the peaks of Nyonno Ri and Ama Drimi.
BOSTON, March 22 (AP). -- Flood waters in New England, except in the Saco River area, receded slowly today, leaving behind unestimated damage and scenes of desolation.

LONDON, March 20. -- While negotiations here on Germany's Rhineland action proceed along their tortuous and difficult course, confidence is steadily growing in the City that the deliberations will produce results well worth the time which necessarily is being devoted to them.

School superintendents, principals, teachers and members of Boards of Education, not to mention parent-teacher groups throughout the State, are beginning to see red as they contemplate the spectacle in the Assembly Chamber at Albany.

Foreign exchange values last week were depressed to the lowest level in the last two months, an aftermath of the political crisis abroad. The proposed four-power plan to take a strong stand against Germany's occupation of the Rhineland was the underlying reason.

A "Christian program of society" which would substitute a planned program of economy for the present economic order is advocated in a survey report prepared by the Methodist Federation for Social Service, 150 Fifth Avenue, and sent to Methodist ministers and laymen throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP). -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States was disclosed today to have started a pamphlet campaign to bring to the country's attention its contention that "political obstacles" stand in the way of recovery.

Officials of the International Seamen's Union threw their full force yesterday into an effort to halt the strike called "ran kand file" by elements in this port, but the strikers refused to recede from their position threatening instead to seek a tie-up of all shipping on the Atlantic Coast.

TRENTON, March 22. -- Bruno Richard Hauptmann's attorneys will apply Tuesday for a new hearing before the New Jersey Court of Pardons and ask that Dr. John F. Condon be summoned for questioning, it was learned today.

BERLIN, March 22. -- The examination by Chancellor Adolf Hitler and his closer collaborators of the proposal of the Locarno powers as laid down in a British White Paper was interrupted long enough today to permit the Chancellor to fly to Breslau, where he addressed another monster campaign meeting this afternoon.

" Is this an ultimatum?" asked the rejected lover. "It is an ultimatissimum," replied the frigid and learned lady. Things in Europe have not yet come to that last despairing pass. Captain EDEN used significant words when he handed to the German diplomatic representative in London the findings of fact and the conclusions reached by the Locarno Powers.

The Division of Fish and Game, operated and maintained on the money paid for licenses and violations of the law, received $1,064,593 during the last fiscal year, Commissioner Lithgow Osborne of the New Fork Conservation Department states in his annual report.

The concert given by the New York Festival Orchestra, under the direction of Eugene Plotnikoff, at the Manhattan Theatre last night marked the inception of paid admission concerts on the part of the New York concert division of the Federal Music Project.

Numerous small lots of foreign bonds and parts of several municipal issues, called to satisfy sinking fund requirements, lifted the number of announcements of bonds called for payment before maturity last week above the total of the preceding period.

ATHENS, March 22. -- About 1,000 anti-Venizelists staged a demonstration today in the streets of this capital. They were headed by a peasant constabulary major, George Dikaios, who was one of the participants in the attempt to assassinate the late Eleutherios Venizelos in June, 1933.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- An administration survey to ascertain which of the multitudinous New Deal agencies shall be scrapped, reduced or molded into the permanent government framework was ordered by President Roosevelt today shortly before he left Washington for his Florida vacation.

ROME, March 22. -- The Italo-Austro-Hungarian conference ended this evening at the Palazzo Venezia with the conclusion of two agreements, one political and one economic, which are to be signed tomorrow.

Transportation and communication facilities to the flood areas were almost completely restored yesterday except for railroad and bus tie-ups in the Connecticut Valley from Hartford to Springfield, Mass.
KANSAS CITY, March 22 (AP). -- March winds flung dust over wide patches of the West today.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, March 22. -- Officials of the Youngstown Welding and Engineering Company have announced that after three years of experiment they have been successful in covering steel rolls with nickel and monel metal. The rolls are expected to be widely used in the manufacture of glass, paper, fiber and steel and in other industries where non-corrosive rolls are necessary.

Darlo Niccodemi is not unknown here. Broadway has seen the translations "Stolen Fruit" and "The Whirlwind"; Fourteenth Street his "La Nemica" as interpreted by Mimi Aguglia. The American premiere of his "Prete Pero" was given by Commendatore Sterni's Teatro d'Arte at the Venice Theatre yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., March 23. -- Shot Up, 3-year-old son of Chance Shot, received a rousing ride from Wayne Wright to win the featured Redlands Purse while Owner J.E. Widener, president of the Miami Jockey Club, looked on as guest of William Dwyer, managing director of Tropical Park, today.

FRIEDRICHSHAFEN, Germany, March 23. -- The new Zeppelin LZ-129 will start on her first South American flight March 30 or 31, immediately after completing the forty-eight-hour propaganda trip ordered by the government. She will fly directly to Rio de Janeiro, where the necessary landing facilities are now available.

Governor Lehman's administration has opposed all efforts to reduce expenditure of public funds, George R. Fearon, Republican leader of the Senate, charged yesterday morning in an address before 200 members and guests at the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street.

Armed guards and other guards swinging night-sticks patroled the corridors of WPA headquarters in the Port Authority Building, 111 Eighth Avenue, yesterday, following the third disturbance within a week caused by demonstrators and pickets who went there to protest the forthcoming cut of 40,000 in WPA rolls.
GUYMON, Okla., March 23. -- The worst dust storm of the year blew across Central Oklahoma from the Panhandle late today while beneficial snows and rains fell in other sections of the "dust bowl."

QUEBEC, Que., March 23. -- A new plan by which a Canadian syndicate, backed by shareholders of Price Brothers Co. and sponsored by Canadian banks, would take over the assets of the company is scheduled to be set before the official trustee, Gordon Scott, and bondholders of the company tomorrow or the next day, it is learned here.
