HARRISBURG, Pa., March 23 (AP). -- An army of 300,000 WPA and CCC workers began the vast task of rehabilitating flood-swept areas of Eastern-Central Pennsylvania today, while two new deaths brought the total for the area to 34.

BERLIN, March 23. -- The Boerse, which continues to be a dark glass through which to view German financial and commercial developments had today, as usual, a small turnover, but showed some signs of strength.

Criticism of one of the anti-crime acts passed recently by the Legislature was voiced by Judge Otto A. Rosalsky in General Sessions yesterday. The law in question requires prosecutors to state their reasons in writing in cases where defendants are allowed to plead guilty to charges of lesser seriousness than those named in the indictment.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- If the President, as his eulogists insist, is the cleverest politician of modern times, then his selection of the CCC camps as the starting-point for dismantling the great Federal relief machine was made with full knowledge the effort would be unsuccessful, as a determined Congressional bloc demonstrated today.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- The Senate Judiciary Committee today voted to recommend confirmation by the Senate of Lamar Hardy as District Attorney for the Southern District of New York. Since he already had the endorsement of the New York Senators, it is thought probable that confirmation will follow.

LONDON, March 23. -- Unperturbed by the discovery that some one had damaged its motor launch by removing two carburetors, the Oxford crew, in training for the boat race with Cambridge April 4, rowed today from Chiswick Steps to Hammersmith Bridge in record time.

LOS ANGELES, March 23. -- The threat of a Townsend pension plan third party was revived tonight by Dr. Francis E. Townsend, author of the plan which would give $200 a month to persons over 60 years of age.

Three pairs moved into the second round of the fourth annual metropolitan squash racquets mixed doubles championship yesterday at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn and one of the players was a half of the team that won the title a year ago.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 23. -- Bryan M. Grant Jr. of Atlanta retained his Bermuda tennis title today after a thrilling five-set battle with Robert P. Murray of Montreal, McGill University law student and one of Canada's outstanding net stars.

ALBANY, March 23. -- Dr. Thomas Parran Jr. will be the fourth person to follow the President from Empire State service into high office in the national government if his nomination is confirmed. The others are:

The letter of William A. Murphy on the city water supply states facts and figures vital to the people of the city and to the owners of property forming the watersheds from which much of our present water supply is taken and from which more may be obtained.

PARIS, March 23. -- Instead of going to London to be present when Joachim von Ribbentrop, Chancellor Adolf Hitler's Ambassador at Large, arrives with the German Government's reply to the Locarno powers' proposals, Foreign Minister Pierre-Etienne Flandin of France will leave tomorrow for the Yonne Department to begin his lection campaign, it was announced tonight.

CHICAGO, March 23. -- Hogs were in demand here today, with offerings somewhat below trade and shipper needs and prices advanced 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight, the top moving up 15 cents from Friday's level to $11, a new high since Feb. 18, while the day's average was up 10 cents at $10.50.
MOSCOW, March 23. -- Soviet grain exports are again on the upgrade after a decline in recent years, according to official figures made public today by the Commissariat of Foreign Trade.
Beauty styles, which seem to be about as changeable as automobile designs, have taken a radical turn to the exotic this year.

LONDON, March 23. -- The diplomatic tug-of-war between Britain and France was renewed tonight even before Chancellor Adolf Hitler delivered Germany's reply to the proposals of the Locarno treaty powers.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Major Gen. Frank Parker, commander of the First Division of the army at Fort Hamilton, N.Y., was ordered today to San Antonio to assume command of the Third Field Army and the Eighth Corps Area, succeeding General Hagood.

The opening guns in the battle for the Stanley Cup, symbolic of the world's hockey championship, will be fired on three fronts tonight. The six teams that won play-off berths in the regular National Hockey League race will engage in the first of their post-season games, while two of the sextets -- the Detroit Red Wings and the Montreal Maroons -- will start a series that will determine the championship of the loop.

The best performance this writer has heard from the National Orchestral Association was given last night under Leon Barzin's direction in Carnegie Hall. This performance was of the orchestral version of Schoenberg's early string sextet, "Verklaerte Nacht.

GENEVA, March 23. -- World trade last January was about 6 per cent higher than in 1935, according to the March number of the League of Nations monthly bulletin of statistics. It is reported that the volume of trade for the last quarter of 1935 reached 84 per cent of its 1929 level, the highest figure recorded since the end of 1931.

Dr. John F. Condon, who as "Jafsie" acted as intermediary in the Lindbergh kidnapping case, made known last night his acceptance of an invitation to confer with Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Support for President Roosevelt's new $1,500,000,000 relief program was believed by Congressional leaders to have been materially strengthened today by the "compromise" on the controverted reduction of the Civilian Conservation Corps.

DALLAS, Texas, March 23 (AP). --Purchase for $2,499,960 of control of the Southwestern Life Insurance Company by business men of Dallas from a group in New York was announced today. The purchasers agreed to pay to the equity corporation $60 a share for 41,666 of 50,000 shares of the General American Life Insurance Company of St. Louis.

Workmen demolishing the old south cell blocks on Welfare Island uncovered a bit of New York history recently when they found traces of the apartment used by Boss Tweed during his incarceration there in 1874, Correction Commissioner Austin H. MacCormick revealed yesterday.
Multi-family and industrial structures for Manhattan and dwellings for the Bronx, Brooklyn and Manhattan were included in the plans filed yesterday, as follows:

INDIANAPOLIS, Tuesday, March 24 (AP). -- The government today hanged George W. Barrett for the murder last August of Nelson B. Klein, a Federal agent. The trap was sprung at 12:02. The man was pronounced dead ten minutes later.

ROME, March 23.--Sweeping constitutional, economic and social reforms in preparation for an inevitable war were announced by Premier Benito Mussolini this morning in a speech delivered to a general meeting of the twenty-two corporations of the Fascist State.

Brief periods of convulsive but inaudible sobbing shook the otherwise inscrutable Miss Vera Stretz in General Session Court yesterday during the weary business of choosing a jury to try her for the murder of Dr. Fritz Gebhardt, German economist.

TRENTON, N.J., March 23. -- Although available funds will be exhausted April 15 and about $20,000,000 more will be required to carry through until the end of the year, the Assembly made no progress tonight toward solving the problem of financing emergency relief.
LONDON, March 23 (AP). -- Naval conference delegates sat today in a final technical session revising the new treaty to be signed by three powers Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Chairman I-Iill of the Ways and Means faxation subcommittee explained today the decision to cut the rate of capital stock tax in half by sayingi that the new undivided profits taxI would be in effect for the entire] calendar year 1936, while the capi-] tal stock levy is based on the fiscal] year -- July 1 to June 30.

The International Seamen's Union announced last night that it had arranged to provide a complete crew for the United States liner Manhattan, which is scheduled to sail tomorrow at noon for the Channel ports and Hamburg.

BERLIN, March 23.--Germany's reply to the Locarno powers' proposals will be delivered to Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden in London tomorrow by Joachim von Ribbentrop, head of the German delegation, who has been in steady consultation here with Chancellor Adolf Hitler over the weekend.
CINCINNATI, March 23. -- The Ohio River, its fury somewhat abated, climbed slowly to a crest here tonight as the Upper Ohio Valley started the task of rehabilitation.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 23. -- More than 120 swimmers from thirty colleges were included in the entry list which tonight closed at Yale University for the thirteenth annual National Collegiate Athletic Association championships in the Payne Whitney pool next Friday and Saturday.

More testimony of friction and discord at Fort Slocum with officers spying upon officers and the army post on David's Island near New Rochelle divided against itself, was given yesterday at the general court-martial at Governors Island of Captain Ralph E. Fleischer, formerly in charge of the enlisted men's messes and assistant commandant of the bakers and cooks school at the fort.
A subway "rate war," with the city and its independent system on one side and the Interborough and the B.M.T. on the other, was threatened yesterday by Mayor La Guardia.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 23. -- Frank B. Whitlock, secretary-treasurer of the New Brunswick Trust Company and in past years active in affairs of the New Jersey Bankers Association, committed suicide in the cellar of his home at 94 Lincoln Avenue, Highland Park, early this morning.
LONDON, March 23 (Canadian Press). -- No dominion, it is authoritatively learned, has been asked to make commitments under the new Locarno plan. No dominion made any commitments.

MOSCOW, March 23. -- If France is attacked by Germany the Soviet Union will give all necessary aid in conformity with the recently ratified Franco-Soviet mutual assistance pact, Premier Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff told Jacques Chastenet, chief editor of Le Temps of Paris, in an interview granted on Thursday and published in Paris today.

The League of Composers presented a program of music by contemporary composers at the French Institute last night. The artists who took part in the program were William Kroll, violinist; Zolthan Kurthy, violinist; Ethel Luening, soprano; Otto Luening, flutist; Frank Sheridan and Josef Wissow, pianists, and Victor Gottlieb, 'cellist, taking the place of Horace Britt, who was unable to appear.

A large-scale job, that of selling itself to the public, confronts big business today, T.K. Quinn, former vice president of the General Electric Corporation, in charge of refrigerator sales, advised the Sales Executives Club of New York, Inc., yesterday at its weekly luncheon meeting in the Hotel Roosevelt.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 23. -- President Roosevelt sailed away from Florida tonight toward the fishing banks off the Bahama Islands after a day in Florida marked by the presentation of special honors to both him and Mrs. Roosevelt by Rollins College at Winter Park.

How marvelous would have seemed to COPERNICUS, working out his revolutionary theories of astronomy at Frauenburg, near Cracow; how touched with the black art of his day, special performance at the Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History last week.

The contents of the Louis C. Tiffany Studios, 46 West Twenty-third Street, including many examples of Favrile glass, perfected by the late Louis Comfort Tiffany, have been bought by Percy A. Joseph, auctioneer, and will be disposed of at private sale on the premises, it was announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, March 23 (AP). -- The 1936 football coaching set-up at the University of Pennsylvania will be headed by Harvey J. Harman for the sixth season, and will coordinate the "entire program of freshman athletics" under one man -- George Munger, an all-round Quaker sports son.

Jack Singer and Harry Kovner were elected co-captains of next year's City College basketball team, according to an announcement made yesterday by Professor Walter Williamson, faculty athletic manager.

AMHERST, Mass., March 23. -- Amherst College continued today to care for flood victims from the surrounding towns of Hadley, Sunderland and Hatfield. For five days the campus has had the aspect of an emergency camp, with college authorities, Red Cross units, the National Guard and students aiding the 500 who fled to the college at the height of the flood.

Communication and transport companies announced last night that services to and throughout the flood areas were fast approaching normal save in a few spots. Northern New England, except along the Maine Coast, is almost devoid of railroad traffic.

ALBANY, March 23. -- With the Senate and Assembly still deadlocked over the budget bills, Governor Lehman signed today the bill continuing for another year the emergency tax of 4 per cent on un-incorporated business of more than $5,000 a year.

NEWARK, N.J., March 23. -- The Rev. Vincent J. Burns, ousted as pastor of the Union Church of Palisades in Fort Lee, applied today to Supreme Court Justice Joseph I. Bodine here for a writ of certiorari to review the proceedings by which he was removed.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C., March 23 (AP). -- A brilliant best ball of 64, seven under par, gave Roy Bronsdon of Osterville, Mass., and Ellis Maples of Southern Pines the title in the first Mid-South open golf tournament today.

Hailed as marking the beginning of a boom in home construction, the National Home Show and Building Exposition, sponsored by the Federal Housing Administration and the Rehabilitation and Modernistic Association, opened last night at the Port Authority Building at 111 Eighth Avenue, with an attendance of nearly 1,000.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP). -- A petition contending that sections of the New York State Insurance Law are unconstitutional was filed in the Supreme Court today by G.T. Mortimer, president of the New York Title and Mortgage Company.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 23. -- With scores of 81, Miss Kathryn Hemphill of Columbia, S.C., and Miss Peggy Wattles of Buffalo, N.Y., the 1935 medalist, were deadlocked tonight for medalist honors in the sixth annual women's Augusta invitation golf tournament.

New York, for several days vaguely conscious of the Texas Centennial because of the Postoffice Department's latest commemorative 3-cent stamp, showed signs yesterday of being more acutely aware of the celebration.

PITTSBURGH, March 23. -- Danger of disease and famine all but disappeared and industry moved to put its house in order today while the task was begun of rehabilitating the desolate 200-mile area where flood demoralized the pursuits of some 4,000,000 inhabitants.

Debutantes of this and recent seasons are aiding in the plans for a supper dance to be held under the auspices of the Junior Guild of the Church of the Heavenly Rest April 15 in the Garden Room of the Park Lane for the benefit of the relief work among the unemployed in the parish of the church.

SELMA, Ala., March 23. -- Colonel Bill Terry's penchant for exploring virgin baseball soil brought a handsome profit to the Giant-Cub expeditionary forces today when this little hamlet in the Cotton Belt turned out a crowd of close to 3,000 to catch its first glimpse of major league competition.

Two strike-breakers who worked during the recent building service strike testified yesterday at a hearing before Abraham S. Wechsler, deputy chief of the State Division of Licenses, that they had received checks from real estate management companies that had subsequently "bounced back."

The feud between District Attorney William C. Dodge and Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, growing out of the arrest last Friday of Louis Feldstein, 27 years old, on the charge that he tried to "sell" for $3,000 a post on Mr. Dodge's staff, was taken into the Supreme Court yesterday.

The board of directors of the World's Fair Corporation, which proposes to raise about $20,000,000 of private capital and to organize the 1939 Fair on the Flushing Meadows, agreed unanimously yesterday at a full meeting in the Empire State Club that there was no use in further meetings until and unless the State and city act.

The Continental Oil Company in its report for 1935, issued for publication today, shows consolidated net earnings of $8,813,560 after depreciation, depletion, intangible development costs and taxes, equal to $1.88 a share on the 4,682,664 shares outstanding, exclusive of 55,929 shares held in the treasury.

David J. Schweitzer, vice chairman of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, attached to the Paris office, outlined yesterday the problems facing the committee, which is engaged in a $3,500,000 drive in this country, $1,500,000 of which is sought in New York.

OTTAWA, March 23 (Canadian Press). -- An operating profit of $200,000 for 1935 was reported today by the Canadian National Steamships, Ltd. For the first time since the line was started in 1921, there was a surplus available for interest requirements.

BOSTON, March 23. -- Paul Edwards, Acting WPA Administrator, suspended today an order for the discharge of 8,500 WPA workers on April 1. All would be employed on flood relief projects, he said. He has asked Washington to be allowed to double the present WPA quota of 125,000.

Nine trucks, three from the Salvation Army's headquarters and six from the Volunteers of America, left New York City yesterday afternoon laden with bedding, clothing and food for refugees in the flood areas. All the material was collected late Sunday and yesterday morning, following appeals over the radio.

ALBANY, March 23. -- The State police, after a survey of the flood regions, reported to the Assembly tonight that the damage to public and private property aggregated $4,458,150. Of this, $3,487,650 was in southern tier counties, including $1,932,700 in Binghamton and vicinity.

Expenditures of the Milbank Memorial Fund for 1935 in the fields of public health, medicine, social welfare and research amounted to $320,778, according to the annual report of the fund, issued today. This brings the total appropriations for philanthropic purposes by the fund since its establishment in 1905 by Mrs. Elizabeth Milbank Anderson to $10,171,899.

Five additional applications, including one from Philadelphia, yesterday increased the total list of entries to forty-four for the preliminaries of the United States chess championship tournament, beginning in this city next Monday evening.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- The Senate passed the $611,362,604 War Department Appropriation Bill by a vote of 53 to 12, debated the Agriculture Department Appropriation Bill, received bills for flood relief, received the nomination of Dr. Thomas Parran as Surgeon General of the United States and recessed at 4:16 P.M. until noon tomorrow.

After advancing to the highest record since Jan. 25, March contracts on the Cotton Exchange here ended with a gain of 1 point yesterday while later months lost as much as 6 points. Houses doing government business released several thousand bales prior to the expiration of trading in the spot month at noon tomorrow.

TRENTON, March 23. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman tonight postponed introduction of a resolution calling for an investigation of the Lindbergh kidnapping-murder case rather than let such a bill, which had been prepared, be interpreted as a ground for a further reprieve for Bruno Richard Hauptmann.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP). -- The Senate took up the $197,447,000 Agricultural Appropriation Bill today after hearing a demand for information on large AAA subsidy payments.

Lack of agreement of the Japanese Navy with the more extreme elements in the army and a trend toward a naval alliance with the moderate civil authorities appeared clearly in connection with the army mutiny of Feb. 26. Not only did no navy men participate in the rebellion, but two big fleets steamed into Tokyo harbor and marines were landed to help suppress the rebels if necessary .

HUNTINGTON, L.I., March 23. -- Charged with being the hit-and-run truck driver who struck and killed two school girls on the Jericho Turnpike at Commack on March 14, Helen Kiefer, 29-year-old wife of Charles Kiefer of Vernon Valley Road, Northport, a laundress at the United States Veterans Hospital, East Northport, was arraigned in Huntington Court today on charges of manslaughter and leaving the scene of an accident without reporting.

For the first time since the various "Who's Who" editions have been published an attempt has been made this year to list the names of prominent individuals on that strip of land which extends from the Arctic lorth to the Mediterranean, consisting of a population of aboutI 140,000,000 in sixteen States.

CHICAGO, March 23. -- Senator Borah by his speech here Saturday attacking the leadership of the Republican party as controlled by the "big interests" of finance and industry injected issues into the State's Presidential primary contest which political observers here look upon as holding the possibilities of great weight in the national convention and the election.

In his speech at Chicago on Saturday Senator BORAH presented a statistical puzzle or paradox. He declared that four years ago 10,000,000 Republicans were driven out of their party. Yet the net loss in the Republican popular vote of 1932, as compared with 1928, was only about 6,000,000.

The estate of Mrs. Amy Akin Sands, widow of B. Aymar Sands, lawyer and real estate operator, was appraised yesterday as $597,496 gross and $541,612 net, when she died last Dec. 1. The bulk of the estate was in securities worth $389,104 and real estate valued at $91,500.

ALBANY, March 23. -- The Assembly tonight passed four liquor bills, including the Brownell bill to permit the sale of liquor in legitimate theatres in New York City. The vote on this bill was 123 to 25, all the negative votes except two being by up-State Republicans.

At the recent hearing at Albany before the joint Senate and Assembly Committees on the Affairs of the City of New York, of which Senator Samuel Mandelbaum was chairman, I gave the testimony of Henry Street nurses as to conditions they find. The day before I had visited a tenement on Ludlow Street, from a visit to which by Lillian D. Wald in 1893 sprang the Henry Street Settlement and Visiting Nurse Service.

Two more games tonight will mark the resumption of the polo championships at the Squadron A Armory, Ninety-fourth Street and Madison Avenue. In one contest the intercollegiate semi-finals will be completed and in the other the Eastern senior championship will reach its third and deciding match between the New York Athletic Club and Aknusti.

SEBRING, Fla., March 23. -- The Yankees' record of successive victories in this Spring training campaign was menaced for a time today when the McCarthymen faced the Newark Bears, International League link of Colonel Jacob Ruppert's baseball chain.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., March 23. -- The combined Federal and New York State inheritance and transfer taxes on the individual estate of Colonel Henry H. Rogers of Manhattan and Southampton will total about $13,138,000, according to a brief filed today in the Suffolk County Surrogate's Court here by Simpson, Thatcher Bartlett, attorneys for Mrs. Millicent Rogers Balcom, Colonel Rogers's daughter.
U.S. Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 23. -- A three-month leave for Major Gen. Johnson Hagood, during which his "future assignment to duty" will be decided, was announced today after President Roosevelt had conferred with the former commander of the Eighth Corps Area.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., March 23. -- The First Methodist Episcopal Church of this city, which two weeks ago "asked" its pastor to resign because of his liberal preaching and emphasis on social problems, has issued a call to the Rev. Otto C. Nelson, pastor of the Methodist Episcopal church at Port Jervis, N.Y., to assume the pastorate of the church here, it was announced today.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 23. -- All official Hartford turned out today for the gigantic task of mopping up after the flood. The waters continued to subside at the rate of an inch an hour as refugees from the inundated parts of the city stood in a long queue at Red Cross headquarters to register for relief.

Mrs. Ernest Iselin gave a luncheon yesterday at her home, 144 East Sixty-fifth Street, for the members of the committees active in arranging the "Styles of the Century" luncheon and fashion show which will be held in the Waldorf-Astoria on April 7 for the benefit of the Generosity Thrift Shop.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 23. -- Pushing the world's speed record two notches higher in the 225 cubic inch class, .destined to become motor boat racing's most popular and sensational division this season, S. Mortimer Auerbach of Atlantic City today made it all the more difficult for rivals to overtake him.
The right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, papers and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures, shall not be violated.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- A caucus of House members whose districts have been devastated by floods voted today to prepare legislation providing for the appointment of a joint Congressional committee to study the cause and cure of flood conditions.

GLASGOW, March 23. -- On the eve of the liner Queen Mary's first trip of fifteen miles from the builder's yard down the River Clyde, which experts declare will be "the most momentous, most venturesome and certainly the most ticklish trip of her whole career," her gross tonnage was officially declared tonight to be 80,773.

The thin character of the share market was apparent again yesterday when a moderate demand concentrated on a small group of issues on the Stock Exchange sent prices for that group 1 to 6 1/2 points higher on the day. The main body of stocks gained fractionally.

Pedro Montanez, top-flight Puerto Rican lightweight, hurdled his twelfth and most important obstacle in this country last night when he decisively outpointed Bobby Pacho, California Mexican, in a ten-round bout at the St. Nicholas Palace.

TOKYO, Tuesday, March 24. -- The navy's new investigation board, which was constituted yesterday, will deal primarily with naval administrative reforms and will touch general policies only when they affect naval affairs.

With $34,311.96 received yesterday, flood relief contributions to the New York Chapter of the Red Cross reached $151,115.33, it was announced by General Robert C. Davis, executive director. The chapter's minimum quota was set at $375,000 when the drive opened four days ago, but efforts will be made to exceed this goal by a wide margin.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 23 (AP). -- Brilliant scoring in the singles featured the American Bowling Congress tournament today as leaders were shifted frequently and the top figure of 704 was threatened several times.
New York came from behind to gain a tie with Chicago in the ninth annual intercity Golden Gloves amateur boxing tournament at Madison Square Garden last night.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 23. -- By way of atonement for their two straight defeats by major league clubs, the Dodgers today scored a 5-3 victory over the visiting Rochester Red Wings, and did it more easily than the score indicates.
MEXICO, D.F., March 23. -- About thirty persons were killed and many wounded in week-end disorders in various parts of Mexico, press dispatches reported today.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 23 (AP). -- The rebellious Dean brothers, Jerome (Dizzy) and Paul, relieved of holdout arguments, turned their attention today to the more serious business of helping the Cardinals win the National League pennant.

What happened yesterday in Italy was forecast by MUSSOLINI more than two years ago. In a celebrated speech made late in 1933 he declared that the Chamber of Deputies -- "anachronistic in its very title" -- did not please him and never had. It was an institution alien to the logic and the spirit of fascism.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- The National Labor Relations Board directed today that an election be held to determine which of three competing labor organizations whose engineers are employed on vessels of the International Mercantile Marine Company, operating out of New York, shall represent the engineers for collective bargaining.

Buffalo, N.Y., will enter the market with a new issue of $1,000,000 of work or home relief bonds, award of which will be made on April 1. The bonds will be dated April 15, 1936, and will mature serially from April 15, 1937 to 1946.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 23. -- Mrs. Arthur A. Small of Chicago was honored by Mrs. Charles Harrington Chadwick at dinner and contract tonight at Villa Today. Other guests were Mr. and Mrs. George Angue Doybne, Mr. and Mrs. Chester Milton Williams, Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Jergens, Mrs. Alexander A. McKay, Mrs. Frank Vernon Skiff, Mrs. James Irving Corbett, Dr. Edmund Le Roy Dow, Oscar Smith, Major Charles Moore, Prince Vladimir Eristoff and Charles Frazier.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Raiding of National Guard armories and other government arsenals by gangsters and criminals seeking firearms decreased last year, J. Edgar Hoover of the Division of Investigation of the Justice Department declared today.

Rival labor organizations in Mexico, D.F., held demonstrations on Sunday and apparently a situation arose exactly parallel to the case of General SHERMAN'S trooper, who declared that no sheep could bite him and escape punishment.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Mutual friendship and understanding between Norway and the United States were the keynotes of a ceremony in the Capitol today when Norwegian friends of America presented to Congress an oil painting of Leiv Eiriksson discovering the New World five centuries before the voyage of Columbus.

Elimination of the surcharge for travel in Pullman cars and reduction of railroad passenger rates in the West and South were followed last year by an increase in Pullman travel, David A. Crawford, president of Pullman, Inc., said in his report for 1935, issued yesterday.
RENO, March 23. -- Mrs. Dorothy Heckscher received a divorce here today from G. Maurice Heckscher of New York. She charged cruelty. There was a property agreement.

Schimmer Kerner, brokers, sold for the Kendall Estate a first motgage of $26,000 on 1,080 Bryant Av., the Bronx, a five-story apartment house. The building is assessed for $46,000. Joseph Jacowitz represented the buyer.

The rise of the flood waters throughout the East has been all most matched by the upturn in the stocks of building-equipment, home-equipment and flood-control issues on the security exchanges. The stocks of most companies which might participate in home-repair work have risen from 1 to 5 points since the middle of last week.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses sent two officials of the Triborough Bridge Authority to Washington yesterday with instructions to sound out the RFC as to its attitude on the PWA decentralization order issued Saturday by Secretary Ickes.

Net income of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation for the year ended on Jan. 31 was $1,234,770 after depreciation, taxes, interest, provision for Federal income taxes and other charges, according to the report issued yesterday. After allowing for dividend requirements on the first and second preferred stocks, the income was equivalent to 5 cents each on 599,400 shares of $1-par common stock.

Mayor La Guardia will argue against representatives of eight business organizations in Albany today for the passage of a bill giving New York City the right to sell bonds for the construction of a municipal power plant. The Mayor announced last night that he would go to Albany this morning.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Dr. Thomas Parran Jr., Health Commissioner of New York State, was nominated today by President Roosevelt as Surgeon General of the Public Health Service, to succeed Dr. Hugh S. Cumming, who retired Feb. 1, about six weeks before the expiration of his four-year term.
MONTREAL, March 23. -- In his second year of big league competition Dave (Sweeney) Schriner was hailed today as scoring leader of the National Hockey League.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 23. -- President Getulio Vargas tonight ordered martial law for ninety days throughout Brazil. Several prominent persons, including a Senator and two members of the Chamber of Deputies, were arrested.
MEXICO, D.F., March 23. -- While the War Department declared the country quiet, newspaper dispatches reported fresh disturbances today.
WINTER PARK, Fla., March 23. -- The text of the address delivered today by President Roosevelt in accepting an honorary degree from Rollins College follows:

The largest single bond flotation so far undertaken under the Securities Act of 1933 will take place today in the offering of a new issue of $90,000,000 of Pacific Gas and Electric Company first and refunding-mortgage 3 3/4 per cent Series H bonds, due in 1961, by a nation-wide banking syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc.

The Hart House String Quartet, which was founded and has its home in Canada, presented a program of music by Mozart, H. Waldo Warner and Beethoven at the Town Hall last night. The ensemble was organized in 1924 by Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Massey, and three of its players -- H. Arn Adaskin, Milton Blackstone and Boris Hambourg -- have been with it since the beginning.

Robert Tucker, Ocean A.C. entrant, stopped John Lasinski, metropolitan and Kings County champion, in the first round of a 175-pound special bout, feature of the boxing show at the New York Athletic Club's city clubhouse last night.

PORTLAND, Me., March 23 (AP). -- -- Health and police authorities maintained a dual vigil in Maine flood zones tonight; the one against incipient disease, the other against looting. Swollen rivers abated.

To prevent "overemphasis" by the public in appraising probable market values based on information from quarterly reports, the New York Stock Exchange has suggested to all corporations whose securities it lists that henceforth statements of earnings issued every three months cover the preceding twelve months rather than the single quarter.

LONDON, March 23. -- The American-bred Bagatelle II, owned by Alvin Untermyer, was scratched today from the list of entries for the Grand National Steeplechase on Friday at Aintree. The veteran jumper ran unplaced in four races since he arrived from America.

PHILADELPHIA, March 23. -- The State Supreme Court today upheld the disbarment of State Senator Samuel W. Salus; his brother, former Civil Service Commissioner Herbert W. Salus; Albert P. Goldberg, a salaried attorney in the employ of the Salus firm, and Bernard L. Lemisch, well known here in the practice of criminal law.

It is safe to say that the gala audience which assembled at the Metropolitan Opera House last night for the first of two performances by the Hollywood Ballet for the benefit of the Boys Club was there for the purpose of aiding an admirable social welfare organization rather than for reasons of art.

PHILADELPHIA, March 23 (AP). -- The complicated legal fight over the $17,000,000 fortune which Walter Garrett founded on snuff in the nineteenth century was simplified somewhat today in a State Supreme Court ruling barring his kin from laying any claim to the estate.

BOSTON, March 23. -- Paul J. McCullough, aged 52, Brookline, a member of the famous vaudeville and musical comedy team of Clark and McCullough, slashed his throat today with a razor he had wrested from a barber who was about to shave him in Medford.

Governor Alfred M. Landon of Kansas, a leading candidate for the Republican nomination for President, was "presented" last night to the radio listeners of the United States by John Hamilton, his campaign manager and National Committeeman from his home State.

Debate in the House of Commons the other day on a private member's bill to amend the Licensing Act brought out the usual recitation of the anomalous and repressive restrictions on free-born Englishmen when they

BERLIN, March 23. -- Those Germans who may be indifferent to Chancellor Adolf Hitler's appeal to all the nation to support him in the coming Reichstag election are beginning to feel the heavy hand of the Nazi party and its subordinate organizations.

Oils, water-colors and drawings by Andre Dunoyer de Segonzac -- work carefully selected from a period of perhaps fifteen years beginning about the time of the World War -- were put on view yesterday at the Jacques Seligmann Galleries. There is an added retrospective interest in comparing these pictures with the last previous large exhibition of the artist's work -- that of recent paintings at Brummer's a year or more ago.

Prices of commodity futures were moderately lower on the local markets yesterday, although rubber, copper and sugar were fairly steady. On the cash markets cotton, lard, oats, butter, eggs and silk advanced, while wheat, corn, rye, flour, antimony, wooltops and standard tin declined.

TRENTON, March 23. -- Assemblyman Thomas M. Muir of Union County, an adherent of Governor Hoffman, who is expected to refuse reappointment to Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf, superintendent of the State police, charged tonight in the House that Colonel Schwarzkopf accepted $25 a week from the State for board during the month that he was a guest at the Lindbergh home near Hopewell following the kidnapping of the Lindbergh baby.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

PHILADELPHIA, March 23. -- A Washington letter and a sixteenth century story of Frobisher's voyages in search of a Northwest passage sold for $2,000 each today at the opening session of an auction of the library of the late Charles T. Jeffery of Merion, conducted by Samuel T. Freeman Co.
NEW ORLEANS, March 23. -- Ski and Arctic Star, horses with winter-like names running in a Southern clime, finished one, two in the mile-and-a-sixteenth feature at the Fair Grounds today.

" It is remarkable how many of our Presidential elections seem to be the most critical," said F.R. Coudert to me. It was in 1912, and he was speaking of the imperative need of electing Woodrow Wilson, which need I had just set forth in an impassioned campaign speech.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, with deposits of $3,254,054,000 on Dec. 31 last, heads the annual list of the 150 largest banks in the English-speaking world, compiled by the California Bank, Los Angeles. Second on the list, and the largest commercial bank in the world, is the Midland Bank Limited of London.

Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, called on the city's school teachers yesterday to emphasize the importance of peace, but warned against advancing any doctrine of "pacifism or non-resistance."

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP). -- Captain Homer B. Millard, head of a preparatory school here, his wife and eight schoolboys were safe aboard the steamer Rosario today after abandoning their foundering schooner yacht off the Carolina Capes.
ALBANY, March 23. -- Governor Lehman hailed tonight the appointment of Dr. Thomas Parran Jr. as Surgeon General of the United States. Governor Lehman said:
Business leasing activity extending throughout the city and suburbs was reported by brokers yesterday.

The use to which imported newsprint is put, rather than the weight or measurements of the paper, is the gauge set up by the Customs Court in determining whether or not newsprint is entitled to free entry into the United States, according to a decision handed down here yesterday by the Second Division of the court.

Great film "names" do not mean that their owners could "hold" a scene in the legitimate theatre, Sidney Howard, president of the Dramatists Guild and top-flight scenario writer, told the graduating class of the American Academy of Dramatic Arts yesterday afternoon at the Empire Theatre.

DARJEELING, India, March 8 (By Mail). -- We started to descend from the North Col on the morning of July 16. At dawn, for a short half-hour, we were granted a heavenly prospect over the unknown ranges of Eastern Nepal.

Carlos Chavez, Mexican composer and conductor, who will make his first appearance with a major orchestra in this country next Friday and Saturday when he directs the Philadelphia Orchestra, has been engaged to conduct the Boston Symphony Orchestra on Friday afternoon, April 10, and Saturday evening, April 11, it was announced yesterday.

Major William H. Ball, finance officer of the Federal Theatre Project and founder of the Theatre Project Veterans League, who has been at variance with the executive heads of the theatre project since he charged that Communists dominated the organization, has been transferred to the WPA Finance Department, it was revealed yesterday.

BOSTON, March 23. -- Ali Merrimack River Valley cities and towns in Massachusetts were placed in the hands of the State Department of Public Health tonight to prevent spread of disease by polluted flood waters.

LONDON, March 23. -- Behind the smoke screen of the Franco-German tussle over the Rhineland zone, which is complicated by the Anglo-French quarrel about the exact nature of the repressive measures to be taken against the German treaty-breaker, an internal political crisis is slowly maturing in London.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- The Senate passed the War Department Appropriation Bill today by a vote of 53 to 12, adding $66,136,286 to the $545,226,318 voted by the House, bringing the total to $611,362,604. The bill now represents the largest expenditure for the country's military establishment proposed in time of peace.

Supreme Court Justice Carew reserved decision yesterday on an application to dismiss counterclaims filed by James J. Bambrick, president, and other officers of Local 32B of the Building Service Employes International Union, in answer to a $1,000,000 suit for an accounting brought by twenty- eight members of the union.

Larry Laughlin, sturdy youngster from Columbia University, captured the intercollegiate freshman foils championship last night on the strips of the Fencers Club with a splendid exhibition. In addition to the title he was rewarded with the coveted Clemens Medal.

James J. Lyons, borough president of the Bronx, who also is manager of a large tanning business, will be a featured speaker at the style conference of the National Shoe Retailers Association to be held at the Waldorf in conjunction with the Fall opening exhibit of American leathers by the Tanners Council of America next Monday and Tuesday.
ALBANY, March 23. -- The Senate and Assembly worked under pressure tonight in an attempt to clear their calendars for important measures during the balance of the week.

With some exceptions, all the principal highways in New York, Pennsylvania, Connecticut and Maryland flood areas were open for travel yesterday, according to reports received by the Automobile Club of New York from affiliated clubs in those States.

CHICAGO, March 23. -- New low levels on the current downturn in the grain markets were established today on the Board of Trade as the result of continued liquidation by longs. A forecast of rain or snow over parts of the dry areas in Kansas and Nebraska and a sharp break in the wheat market in Minneapolis were partly responsible for the selling.
Spring and the flounder fishing season arrived simultaneously at Echo Bay.

BERLIN, March 23. -- The great financial losses suffered by German shipping in recent years were revealed anew today with the announcement of the long-awaited financial reorganization plan for the Hamburg-American and North German Lloyd lines.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., March 23. -- An extensive alcoholic beverage distillery, extending from the cellar to the attic of a three-story house in one of the best residential sections of East Orange, was raided today by police.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- A series of tentative agreements to be incorporated in the first draft of the new tax legislation, with a view to rushing it to public hearings next Monday, were reached today by the Ways and Means subcommittee.
Any one dealing directly with people on relief, and needing relief, must be considerably surprised at the current discussion whether transiency is ebbing or increasing.

Immediate steps to establish a city university, embracing all the municipality's existing facilities for higher education and adding some new ones, are urged by Professor Charles P. Barry of New York University and Professor Edward L. Smith of Hunter College in an analysis of public higher education, published yesterday.

OKLAHOMA CITY, March 23 (AP). -- A hint of possible military rule hung over Oklahoma City tonight as the long dispute over further extension of oil drilling zones within the city neared a climax in tomorrow's special election.

Several industrial loans stood out as the only active features in quiet trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The trading pace was slightly below the average for last week, sales amounting to $10,240,300, compared with $15,121,900 last Friday.

ATHENS, March 23. -- Elaborate plans to pay final honors to Eleutherios Venizelos, seven times Premier of Greece, were abandoned here tonight at the request of his widow. Two destroyers which had been sent to Brindisi, Italy, to bring back his body were ordered to take it to Canea, Crete, where the funeral will be held.

The Knickerbocker Greys, junior cadet corps, will hold their annual Fathers and Sons Review this afternoon at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street. The exercises will include an evening parade in honor of the headmasters of schools attended by members of the corps, and a dinner in the Appleton Mess Hall.

PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, March 23. -- The Ohio River, which has smothered factory fires and flooded homes and business houses in the valley between here and Pittsburgh, flowed swiftly past the city of Portsmouth today high above the heads of most of the 44,000 citizens, sheltered securely behind protecting walls of steel and concrete.

Robert Brackman is having two one-man shows, both of them opening today. Oils are hung in the large west room of the Grand Central (Fifth Avenue) Galleries, corner of Fifty-first Street, while at the Macbeth Gallery, 11 East Fifty-seventh Street, visitors will find a group of pen-and-ink drawings and pastels.

The Crucible Steel Company of America declined yesterday to recognize the right of the National Labor Relations Board to hear charges against it under the National Relations Act or any other Federal statute.

NEWARK, N.J., March 23. -- The plump Venus of Paterson, whose picture over a bar outraged the wife of a local Methodist minister but was adjudged bad art and in no way obscene by E. Frederick Burnett, State Commissioner of Alcoholic Beverage Control, served today as a peg on which a group of New Jersey artists hung their own art controversy.

Random House will publish this Fall a limited edition of a work on Jo Davidson, containing more than 100 reproductions of the sculptor's most famous statues and portraits and an introduction by Mr. Davidson.

CHICAGO, March 23. -- Mr. and Mrs. James J. Walker of New York appeared unexpectedly before County Judge Edmund K. Jarecki today and obtained an order for the adoption of a baby girl, 6 weeks old, from The Cradle, adoption home, in Evanston, Ill.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on March 18 shows increases for the week of $269,000,000 in holdings of United States Government direct obligations and $272,000,000 in government deposits and decreases of $535,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $268,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and $321,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credits of domestic banks.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 23. -- "Three Men on a Horse," the J.C. Williamson experiment with the latest style of American farce on Australian audiences, in association with Alex Yokel, promises to be a big financial success. Critics after the first performance in Melbourne Saturday acclaim it variously as fresh, snappy, amusing, brilliant or shameless.

Mail orders and reorders were again numerous in the market here yesterday, with retailers in most sections stressing shipment of women's apparel and accessories on order. Easing of the tension in the flood areas was noted in advices from merchants, and confidence was expressed that within the next few days forwarding of shipments which have been held up will be requested by retailers in Pennsylvania and New England.

SYRACUSE, March 23 (AP). -- Central New York rivers and lakes rose from a half inch to six inches today, according to a survey made by engineers of the Department of Public Works. They said the peak probably would be reached tomorrow, unless heavy rains brought higher water.

PHILADELPHIA, March 23 (AP). -- The major issue of the 1936 political campaign was defined by Colonel Frank Knox today as liberty, self-government and a "struggle against a dictator growing up in our midst and assuming the guise of a Democratic President."

It seems there was a hoofer named Alfred Lunt who strayed into the legit and dragged the Theatre Guild in after him. This evening the pair of them come into their own, when Robert E. Sherwood's "Idiot's Delight" opens at the Shubert, with Mr. Lunt surrounded by six chorus girls and Lynn Fontanne in a blond wig.

The appointment of the Rev. Dr. Irving Husted Berg as dean of the New York University College of Arts and Pure Science was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of the university. Dr Berg, who has been chaplain of the university since 1919, succeeds Dr. Archibald L. Bouton, who is retiring from the deanship after twenty-two years in that capacity.
Housing and business properties were included in the Manhattan realty turnover reported yesterday.

SYRACUSE, March 23 (AP). -- Central New York rivers and lakes rose from a half inch to six inches today, according to a survey made by engineers of the Department of Public Works. They said the peak probably would be reached tomorrow, unless heavy rains brought higher water.

PHILADELPHIA, March 23 (AP). -- The major issue of the 1936 political campaign was defined by Colonel Frank Knox today as liberty, self-government and a "struggle against a dictator growing up in our midst and assuming the guise of a Democratic President."

It seems there was a hoofer named Alfred Lunt who strayed into the legit and dragged the Theatre Guild in after him. This evening the pair of them come into their own, when Robert E. Sherwood's "Idiot's Delight" opens at the Shubert, with Mr. Lunt surrounded by six chorus girls and Lynn Fontanne in a blond wig.

The appointment of the Rev. Dr. Irving Husted Berg as dean of the New York University College of Arts and Pure Science was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of the university. Dr Berg, who has been chaplain of the university since 1919, succeeds Dr. Archibald L. Bouton, who is retiring from the deanship after twenty-two years in that capacity.
Housing and business properties were included in the Manhattan realty turnover reported yesterday.

Leo Collins, professional at the Harmonic Club, reached the quarter-final round of the national open squash tennis championship at the Hotel Shelton last night, defeating Frank Iannicelli, New York A.C. amateur, in the second round. The score was 15 -- 4, 15 -- 4, 15 -- 8.
One of Brooklyn's largest apartment houses changed ownership yesterday. A small multi-family building and two dwellings also figured in the trading in that borough.
MINNEAPOLIS, March 24 (AP). -- Tommy Touhy, convicted mail robber and last of the Touhy gang, was sentenced to twenty-three years in Leavenworth Penitentiary today by Federal Judge Gunnar H. Nordbye.
WASHINGTON, March 24. -- The Copeland Ship Subsidy Bill reported favorably today by the Senate Commerce Committee was met at once by the threat of a filibuster by a member of the committee.

Mr. Sherwood's love of a good time and his anxiety about world affairs result in one of his most likable entertainments, "Idiot's Delight," which the Theatre Guild put on at the Shubert last evening. Already it is widely known as the show in which Alfred Lunt plays the part of a third-rate hoofer and Lynn Fontanne wears an exotic blonde wig.
What has become of the anti-smoke campaign? The city is filthier than ever before.

DUBLIN, March 24. -- Vice Admiral Henry Boyle Somerville, who during the World War convoyed troops between the United States and Great Britain, was shot dead when four armed men raided his home at Castle Townshend, County Cork, tonight. He was 72 years old.

Laundry racket charged which occupied the attention of an extraordinary grand jury in Brooklyn nearly three years ago were ressurrected in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday when eleven independent laundries sought to collect $1,650,000 from nearly 200 defendants, including Jacob Mellon, former laundry "czar," and a number of his associates.

BOSTON, March 24. -- Federal Judge Elisha H. Brewster late today refused to grant a preliminary injunction to William Filene's Sons Company of Boston, one of the city's largest department stores, against the Fashion Originators Guild of America, New York, on the ground that the guild has not caused any damage or loss to the Boston firm.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP). -- The Norris bill to create a Mississippi Valley Authority similar to the TVA was endorsed today by Morris L. Cooke, rural electrification administrator, as another step to combat the "greatest crisis" in the nation's history -- the danger from floods, dust storms and waste of soil.

ALBANY, March 24. -- Mayor La Guardia came to the Capitol today to urge prompt and favorable action by the Legislature on his "yardstick" bill to enable New York City to establish and finance a municipal power and lighting plant without pledging the city's credit.

Net profit of $9,756,440 was reported yesterday by the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Feb. 29, after all deductions. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 2 cents a share on 33,673,325 no-par common shares.

In the appeal of the Administration to private industry to give many more jobs to the unemployed, it seems to be taken for granted that there is as much work available as there was in 1929. This is plainly not the case at present. Since that date our foreign trade, for example, has been heavily cut down, partly as a result of the mistakes of our own Government.

TOPEKA, Kan., March 24 (AP). -- Governor Alfred M. Landon, responding today to inquiries arising from the movement to nominate him for President, pictured Republican harmony as transcending personal preferment.
VIENNA, March 24. -- Light sentences were imposed today on twelve of the thirty Socialists who had been tried for high treason. The rest were acquitted.

Retail credit bureaus in various cities throughout the country can play a vital role in further credit sales by developing research to help stores use credit in inducing more people to buy, Paul E. Murphy, advertising manager of Frederick Loeser Co., Inc., said last night in an address before the Associated Retail Credit Men of New York City, Inc., at the Hotel Governor Clinton.

Mr. JOHN HAMILTON, in "presenting" Governor LANDON over the radio on Monday evening, spoke of the way in which he shunned the ordinary means of political advertisement. He has no publicity bureau. He has no press agent. Thus far he has made only two set speeches and may not deliver any more.

Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew reserved decision yesterday on the application of Louis H. Saltzman, a restaurateur, and the 330 West Seventy-third Street Corporation, suing as taxpayers for a temporary injunction restraining Park Commissioner Robert Moses from demolishing the Central Park Casino building and using the site for a children's playground.

One local debut which seems to have escaped general attention is that of the little marginal playgrounds for children inside Central Park. At least one of them, at Fifth Avenue and Ninety-sixth Street, blossomed out with the warm weather of the last few days.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- The Rhine Westphalia Electric Power Corporation of Essen, Germany, one of the largest in Europe, and the German Central Bank for Agriculture of Berlin filed applications today with the Securities and Exchange Commission for permanent registration of their securities on the New York Stock Exchange.

MONTREAL, Wednesday, March 25. -- Modere Bruneteau, a rookie from the minors, stepped into hockey's hall of fame early this morning when he broke up the longest game on record in the National League after 1 hour 56 minutes and 30 seconds of overtime to give the Detroit Red Wings a 1-0 triumph over the Maroons.

Even in the best of times the appointment of a new Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service is a grave social responsibility. Today much of the country north of the Potomac is flooded. Water supplies are cut off. The drainage systems of a hundred communities are impaired.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 24 (AP). -- Frank Caruana of Buffalo, who several years ago rolled two perfect scores in one league series, boomed into the lead of the singles event in the American Bowling Congress tournament late today with a 705 series.

Senator VANDENBERG acknowledges that the average payments to farmers under the AAA have been small, but he wants to know whether this mathematical average has been greatly influenced by "enormous" payments to certain individuals. To his personal knowledge, he asserts, one cotton grower was paid $168,000 for not planting 7,000 acres, and a corn-hog contract in another State gave one beneficiary $219,825 in two years for not raising 14,587 hogs.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- The deadlock over ship subsidy legislation existing since the middle of the last session of Congress was broken today, for the time being at least, when the Senate Commerce Committee voted to report a revised version of the bill which Chairman Copeland introduced at the beginning of the present session.

The drill hall of the Seventh Regiment Armory was filled yesterday afternoon with sounds of drum and bugle music, light marching footsteps and the rattle of small muskets as the Knickerbocker Greys, the smart junior cadet corps, performed at their annual fathers and sons review.

Plowing through the green waters of the New York A.C. pool with tireless, methodical stroke, Jack Kasley of the University of Michigan, one of America's greatest threats to Japanese breast-stroke supremacy, broke the world record for the 200-yard breast stroke last night.

Communications and transportation in the flood areas are virtually back to normal except in a few relatively small sections, according to reports reaching the offices of the companies affected here yesterday. The Connecticut River Valley between Hartford, Conn., and Springfield, Mass., was still quite badly tied up, however.

Several staples continued weak on local commodity future markets yesterday. Sugar and silk futures were strong and cottonseed oil and coffee fairly steady. On the cash markets wheat, corn, oats, cotton, lard, butter, silk and raw sugar advanced, while rye, cocoa, wool tops, rubber and tins declined.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- Secretary of the Interior Ickes, involved in another fight with Robert Moses, New York Park Commissioner, declared today that he would not permit the New Yorker to "dictate" to PWA or override his administrative order making it necessary for Wharton Green, Triborough Bridge manager, to report to Arthur S. Tuttle, New York PWA administrator, instead of to Washington.

Captain Hugh Brown, master of the freighter Southern Sword, was held in $5,000 bail yesterday by United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter on a charge of conspiring to smuggle alcohol into the country. Named with Captain Brown in the charges was Austin Callahan, said to be president of the Alco Steamship Company, of 50 Broad Street, operators of the Southern Sword.

A plan for reorganizing the Universal Pipe and Radiator Company and its chief subsidiary, the Central Foundry Company, was filed in Federal court yesterday. It would allow participation by all classes of security holders.

MADISON, March 24. -- Wisconsin, in common with others of the Northwestern tier of States, is expected by most observers to send to the Republican convention at Cleveland twenty-four delegates for Borah.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- The Pettengill Bill, relaxing the long and short haul clause of the Fourth Section of the Interstate Commerce Act passed the House today by a standing vote of 215 to 41, the leaders defeating all attempts to force a record vote.

A code of ethics for newspaper advertising by liquor retailers is being prepared by the Retail Wine and Liquor Guild, Colonel Ralph C. Tobin, head of the guild, announced here yesterday. Advertising men and agencies employed by the liquor retailers will submit suggestions for the code before the close of the month.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- Without a record vote, the Senate today passed the annual Agricultural Department Appropriation Bill after adding nearly $40,000,000 to the amount voted by the House. This brought up to $153,733,980.05 the amount by which the Senate has increased regular supply measures for the Agriculture, Interior, War and Treasury-Postoffice Departments, as passed by the House.

New cases of measles reported to the Health Department last week totaled 1,736, a new high for the year, according to the weekly summary of vital statistics made public yesterday. This figure compared with 1,581 cases the week before and 1,145 for the corresponding week of 1935.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- Seeking source information about cold waves which move into the United States from the Far North, the Weather Bureau is planning a daily airplane observation at Fort Smith, south of Great Slave Lake in Alberta.

Eleven more truckloads of bedding and clothing left here yesterday for the West Pennsylvania flood area, sent by the Volunteers of America. The trucks, containing 1,100 blankets and 95,000 garments, are bound for Pittsburgh by way of Binghamton, according to Major W.O. Ulrey, State Commander of the Volunteers, with offices at 34 West Twenty-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- Major Gen. Stanley Ford, commander of the First Brigade in New York City, was assigned today by the War Department to the command of the First Division, with headquarters, at Fort Hamilton. He succeeds Major Gen. Frank Parker, who yesterday was ordered to command the Third Army and Eighth Corps Area at Fort Sam Houston, Texas.
Nineteen individuals and two corporations accused of having failed to pay a tax on 300,000 gallons of alcohol distilled during four months were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury.

A group of 100 etchings by John Sloan constitutes the special feature of an exhibition that opened yesterday at the Whitney Museum of American Art, to continue until April 5. Everything shown comes out of the permanent collection and many of the oils and sculptural works have not previously been exhibited for several years.
Drastic reorganization of the Sanitation Department to improve its morale and efficiency is being planned by Mayor La Guardia, it was reported yesterday.

Fruit and vegetable dealers representing a thousand retail stores in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn, at a joint meeting of the Kings County Fruit Merchants Association and the Fruit Merchants Association of Manhattan and the Bronx, held at the Concourse Plaza Hotel in the Bronx last night, voted to close their stores indefinitely in a lockout move directed against the demands of the Fruit, Vegetable and Dairy Clerks Union 335.

While the official worlds of Albany and Newark spent yesterday sneering at the morals of "Tobacco Road," the local company thereof chalked up its 1,000th performance. Only two other shows in the history of the New York theatre have done that, so the goose hung pretty high up at the Forrest.

HOUSTON, Texas, March 24 (AP). -- Billy Jones, 7-year-old pride of T.C. Worden's stables, captured the richest prize of the 21-day Spring meet at Epsom Downs today, winning the $2,500 Texas Centennial Handicap, at a mile and an eighth.

CINCINNATI, March 24. -- With the crest of the Ohio River flood near this city tonight, high water began creeping into parts of Louisville as it drained out of stores, homes and factories in the towns and cities as far east as Ironton. A 325-mile reach of the Ohio was in flood.

At 11:30 A.M. yesterday, the sixth day of the general court-martial of Captain Ralph E. Fleischer on charges of violating three articles of war, Captain Ernest M. Brannon, trial judge advocate, stepped before the court of nine officers and announced crisply:
KANSAS CITY, March 24. -- A tardy cold wave gripped the West and Southwest tonight as silt clouds from yesterday's dust storm rolled eastward to the Great Lakes.

Formation of a wholesale board of trade to enforce fair-trade practices for the local wholesale wine and liquor industry was announced here yesterday by the New York Institute of Wine and Spirit Distributors, Inc. Joseph H. Choate Jr., former administrator of the Federal Alcohol Control Authority, has been engaged as arbiter for the board, with power to assess fines ranging from $100 to $500 upon members offending against the trade practice rules.

The Philadelphia Orchestra's schedule for the 1936-37 season calls for about 105 concerts in twenty-eight weeks, it was announced yesterday by Alfred Reginald Allen, manager of the orchestra, Eugene Ormandy, former conductor of the Minneapolis Symphony Orchestra, will direct more than two-thirds of the season and Leopold Stokowski for six weeks altogether.

WASHINGTON, March 24.--The Eastern Gas and Fuel Associates, in an amendment to its registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 for the issuance of $75,000,000 of first mortgage and collateral trust bonds, Series A 4 per cent, due on March 1, 1956, gave the offering date as Thursday.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 24. -- The tricky Augusta Country Club course took its toll of favorites today, including Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky., the defending title-holder, in the opening round of the sixth annual Augusta women's invitation golf tournament.

As trading in the March position on the Cotton Exchanges will end at noon today, evening up in the spot month contributed most of yesterday's business and the list closed a point higher to 7 points lower than on Monday.

The number of visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday increased slightly over the figures for the preceding week and for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- Reversing a stand which it has maintained for twenty years, the Authors League declared its unqualified opposition today to adherence of the United States to the Berne Copyright Convention.

The railway managements made a new offer of compensation to be paid to employees displaced by consolidations as negotiations with the Railway Labor Executives Association resumed yesterday. The essentials of the offer would be the payment of six months' wages in a lump sum to a displaced employee or, as an alternative, putting the employee on half-pay for two years.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP). -- The building up of a fleet of 4,000 military airplanes was unanimously recommended to Congress today in a report by the House Military Committee, describing equipment of the Army Air Corps as "impotent'' and "inadequate."

ROME, March 24. -- Every point in the Mediterranean is now under control of the Italian Air Force, it was asserted today by General Giuseppe Valle, Under-Secretary of State for Aviation, in an address in the Chamber of Deputies.

PARIS, March 24. -- Before the contents of the German message to London had been received Foreign Minister Pierre-Etienne Flandin left Paris today for his district in Yonne Department to begin his election campaign. Prior to his departure he conferred with Premier Albert Sarraut on the international situation, but the fact that he did not remain in Paris was itself significant of the French feeling that for the moment negotiations are at a standstill.

LONDON, March 24. -- The House of Commons displayed deep hostility today toward the form of the legislative council it is proposed to establish in Palestine and also toward a proposal to forbid existing cultivators to sell all their land. There was no vote because the debate was technically on the consolidated fund bill, but if there had been a vote the government would have had an awkward moment.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- Tolerant smiles on Capitol Hill greeted the President's departing letter to the Vice President and the Speaker about his intention to cooperate with Congress in a study of ways to reorganize the government after the end of the emergency.

BERLIN, March 24. -- Dr. Joseph Goebbels as Propaganda Minister and Reich Election Director issued instructions today for the grand finale of the election campaign which promises to outdo all previous efforts at National Socialist propaganda.

Business rentals continued in volume yesterday, with activity centering in the midtown and downtown areas of Manhattan. The midtown lessees included garment, fur, millinery and furniture makers in addition to various retailers and two publicity agencies.

Retail failures in the United States in the week ended March 19 showed a gain of six above the average of those for the last twelve months, while the number in the manufacturing and wholesale divisions registered a decline, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Landscape architects facing the problem of how to suit the garden to the modern American house are drawing mainly upon the gardens of the Old World for ideas, Richardson Wright told the Junior League yesterday.

The New York Americans served notice last night that they are to be held none too lightly as Stanley Cup finalists by overpowering the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden. The spangled skaters, meeting the Windy City sextet in the first game of a two-game series that will be decided on total goals, turned back their rivals by a score of 3 to 0.

The Securities and Exchange Commission, it was learned yesterday, has denied the request of newspapers here that they receive the stock-trading questionnaires now being sent out by the SEC to more than 300 member firms of the Stock Exchange and Curb Exchange clearing organizations.

CHICAGO, March 24. -- The National Labor Relations Act was declared unconstitutional in its entirety by Judge John P. Barnes in the Federal District Court today. He filed a twenty-one-page memoandum in a suit brought Feb. 1 by the Bendix Products Corporation of South Bend, a subsidiary of the Bendix Aviation Corporation, and said he would issue a preliminary injunction restraining the Federal Labor Relations Board from interfering with the business of the petitioner.

The fact that New York's World's Fair will not be held until 1939 does not mean that there is time to waste in planning for it. An enormous amount of preliminary work must be undertaken before construction can be begun. For this reason it is regrettable to find that matters have now reached a stand- still.

LONDON, March 24 (AP). -- Miss Eleonora Sears of Boston and Miss Margot Lumb, the British titleholder, won, their first-round match in the British doubles squash racquets championship today, defeating another Anglo-American combination, Miss Edith Drury of Boston and Lady Katherine Cairns, 15 -- 11, 15 -- 10. 15 -- 16, 15 -- 12.

Defining "100 per cent Americanism" as a "100 per cent belief in democracy, justice and liberty," the New York County American Legion has issued a booklet as a guide to Legion speakers. Liberty means "above all else freedom of speech," it declares, because without that freedom "there can be no search for the truth."

PITTSBURGH, March 24. -- The only department store here which did not suffer a heavy loss from the flood is Frank Seder, at Fifth Avenue and Smithfield Street. Water backstopped through the sewers into the sub-basement but all merchandise was removed before the water entered.

MIAMI, Fla., March 24. -- With his white duck hat pulled low over his eyes to protect them from the bright sunlight which glared up from the sea, President Roosevelt, beginning his third Winter vacation since he became President, fished today in the shoal waters off Cat Island, about fifty reties east of here.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- The House Judiciary Committee today reported favorably a rewritten Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination Bill, generally known as "Anti-Chain Store" Bill, while witnesses before the Senate Judiciary Committee declared their preference for the bill with similar aims introduced by Senators Borah and Van Nuys.

Maurice Hotchner, counsel for the Association of Long Island Commuters, tried unsuccessfully yesterday to have Martin W. Clement, president of the Pennsylvania and Long Island Railroads, summoned as a witness in the proceedings for an increase in commutation rates.

TRENTON, March 24. -- Confronted by conditions which, his advisers insist, will vitiate efforts to obtain further information on the Hauptmann case from Dr. John F. Condon, Governor Harold G. Hoffman continued today to make plans for an interview with the man who negotiated the futile ransom payment for Charles A. Lindbergh Jr.

After pointing higher in narrow trading during most of the day, stock prices weakened in the final hour yesterday, so that the closing was irregularly lower on the day. Some of the leaders were down one or more points. The trading pace increased moderately, but market sentiment continued cautious and buying, selective in character.

The nineteenth annual series of Summer concerts at Lewisohn Stadium is planned to begin on Wednesday evening, June 24, provided a fund of $75,000 can be raised to support the undertaking, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer, chairman of Stadium Concerts, Inc.

More than two thousand truck owners and drivers met at the Manhattan Opera House last night to protest the prospective store-door delivery of freight by railroads which the Interstate Commerce Commission is expected to rule upon before April 1.

Flood relief fund contributions to the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross jumped yesterday to a day's total of almost $90,000, bringing the total of the chapter's fund to $240,547,26, it was announced by General Robert C. Davis, executive secretary.
LIVERPOOL, March 24. -- The annual fever produced by the Grand National Steeplechase at Aintree had the British Isles running a high temperature tonight.

DOTHAN, Ala., March 24. -- Bill Terry today returned to the town where, twenty-one years ago, they gave him his unconditional release and tried to advise him, in a brotherly sort of way, that while he appeared to be a young man of many promising accomplishments, baseball certainly was not one of them.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- The Buffalo Stock Exchange was permitted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to withdraw its registration as a national securities exchange, with the privilege of applying, before April 1, 1937, for reinstatement upon compliance with certain conditions.

LONDON, March 24. -- The only far-reaching treaty of armament limitation since 1930 will be signed in Queen Anne's drawing room at St. James's Palace tomorrow afternoon by the naval delegates of the United States, France and Britain and by all the British dominions, except the Irish Free State and South Africa.

The anthracite wage agreement, expiring on March 31, will be extended until May 1 and possibly further so that production may not be interrupted if a new agreement is not reached before the expiration of the old contract, it was announced last night by the joint negotiating committee representing the United Mine Workers of America and the anthracite operators.

WASHINGTON, March 24.--The Senate passed the Agricultural Department Appropriation Bill, extended until April 1, 1937, the power of the Federal Housing Administration with certain modifications to insure modernization loans, and recessed at 2:55 P.M. until Thursday noon.

NEWARK, N.J., March 24. -- Seven passengers, a stewardess and the pilot and co-pilot of a large Douglas airliner were badly shaken up tonight at Newark Airport when the plane nosed over after "overshooting" the landing runway.

TAMPA, Fla., March 24. -- Trial of three Tampa policemen in the flogging case of Nov. 30, in which one man died and which has since attracted nation-wide attention, was temporarily halted almost at its start in Criminal Court today by another motion of defense lawyers for a change of venue from Hillsborough County.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 24. -- Tamed by the aging soup-bone of George Earnshaw and the baffling slants of Tom Baker, young hurler from Louisiana via Allentown, the Yankees went into a terrific nose-dive this afternoon. Their four-game winning streak was snapped as they suffered their first shut-out of the citrus belt season, losing to the rollicking Brooklyn Dodgers, 3 to 0.
SAVANNAH, Ga., March 24. -- Henry Ford in an interview today denounced crop curtailment as "worse than thievery" and a violation of the laws of nature.
Commenting last night upon Judge Brewster's decision, Maurice Renter, chairman of the Fashion Originators Guild of America, said:

The Feld-Ostertag bill, making special provision for veteran relief, which was vetoed by the Governor last year, has been introduced in similar form this year under the same sponsorship. The same objections hold that were offered last year, and with even greater weight. If enacted the measure would make mandatory the creation of a separate relief agency in up-State cities having separate welfare districts and in each up-State county.

Harry Wolf of the New York A.C., national amateur champion, and W.J. Hall of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club advanced to the quarter-final round of the national open squash tennis championship last night at the Hotel Shelton.

The WPA dismissed its staff of more than 3,000 men and women thirty minutes ahead of time last night to avert a possible clash between the relief workers and several hundred pickets holding a demonstration in the street outside WPA headquarters in the Port Authority Building, 111 Eighth Avenue.

The program for the Lucrezia Bori farewell concert next Sunday night at the Metropolitan Opera House was announced yesterday. Miss Bori herself will take part, singing as Violetta in Act II of "La Traviata" and as Manon Lescaut in Act III of "Manon."

Miss Vera Stretz stopped her ears with quivering fingers in General Sessions Court yesterday afternoon and sobbed as the State's first witness, a medical examiner, described the wounds of Dr. Fritz Gebhardt, who was shot dead at 3 Mitchell Place early on the morning of last Nov. 12.
Resale of apartment houses in Manhattan and the Bronx featured the urban realty trading reported yesterday.
