Indications of considerable opposition were seen yesterday in Wall Street to the plan of the New York Stock Exchange to obtain quarterly earnings reports for the preceding twelve months from all corporations whose securities are listed. The Exchange's proposal was in the form of a "request" in a letter to corporate executives, made public yesterday.

The Curtis Chamber Music Ensemble played last night in the Town Hall, played individually with varying degrees of excellence, and collectively with a lusty enthusiasm and vitality which bespoke youth and talent. The concert was conducted by Louis Bailly of the Curtis School of Music.

MIAMI, Fla., March 24. -- Mrs. George P. Brett of New York gave a tea this afternoon for members of the committee on arrangements, of which she is chairman, for the benefit garden party to be given April 1 at the estate of Mrs. John B. Semple to aid the American Marine Library Association.

Alumnae of Rosemary Hall living in New York, Pennsylvania, Maryland, Connecticut, Long Island, New Jersey and Westchester attended the luncheon and fashion show for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the school yesterday at Sherry's.

MOSCOW, March 24. -- Preparations were completed today for take-offs in the next few days by two Soviet planes for the first flight from the continent of Europe to Franz Josef Land, on the edge of the polar circle, more than 2,500 miles from Moscow.

With a quid on the failing that causes city dwellers to litter the streets just as profusely as they did a century ago, Mrs. Amorette E. Fraser, sometimes called the dean of clubwomen, celebrated her 100th birthday last night at a testimonial dinner at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.
NEWARK, N.J., March 24. -- The Essex County Grand Jury, which is investigating corruption in the Newark Finance Department, was faced tonight with a questioning of the eating habits of its members.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP). -- Secretary Hull filed objections today to proposed legislation to confine to American ships the pleasure cruises to near-by foreign ports and "voyages to nowhere."
PINEHURST, N.C., March 24. -- In the first round of the North and South open golf championship today none of the outstanding stars of the professional world was able to break 70.

Receding flood waters in Pennsylvania, Ohio and New England are leaving silt-grimed machinery, ruined stocks of raw materials and damaged buildings which industry must replace and repair before production can again be started, purchasing executives, machine-tool builders and manufacturers said here yesterday.
MOUNTAIN LAKES, N.J., March 24. -- Never will it be said that the Stevenses do not hold to their agreements at least, not if Mrs. E.E. Stevens of 141 Look-out Road can help it.

Fifteen members of the City College basketball squad received sweaters from Maurice Deiches, chairman of the extracurricular committee of the board of higher education at the annual dinner tendered to the team at the City College Club last night.

A shortage of licensed officers for merchant marine service has developed in American ports with the increase of water-borne commerce and the return to service of ships withdrawn during the depression, the United Licensed Officers Association revealed yesterday.

MADRID, March 24. -- Dr. Alfredo Martinez, former Minister of Labor and Justice in one of the Center-Right coalition Cabinets that governed Spain before the recent election, died early this morning in Oviedo of wounds received when he was shot down by an unidentified assassin in front of his house Sunday night.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 24. - Mr. and Mrs. J. Jay O'Brien entertained forty at a dinner tonight.

CHICAGO, March 24. -- Release of a large number of hogs and a liberal supply of fresh pork which had been held up by floods in the East resulted in an extremely small shipping demand for hogs today. Furthermore the warm weather curtailed the local demand for fresh pork and hog prices dropped 10 to as much as 40 cents a hundredweight from yesterday's levels with weights under 200 pounds showing the most loss.

Entry blanks for the steeplechase stake events at the Belmont Park Spring meeting, May 11 to June 6, and the Summer meeting at Aqueduct, June 8 to July 2, were sent out yesterday with the announcements to horsemen that the entries for Belmont Park will close April 7 and those for Aqueduct May 7.

The League of New York Theatres, apparently weary of importuning the Dramatists Guild to "negotiate" or arbitrate its new minimum basic agreement, expects to fire its heaviest guns today. It plans to present to its members for ratification a brand-new contract form for use in dealings with playwrights.

When Louis Feldstein, 27 years old, entered a not guilty plea yesterday in General Sessions to an attempt to "shake down" a lawyer under pretense he would have him appointed a prosecutor on the staff of District Attorney Dodge, his attorney told Judge Donnellan that Feldstein's arrest was a frame-up by Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts.

Prince Henry of Reuss and Mr. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor are among the passengers due to arrive today from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania. Others on the ship include Alfred Anson, Professor J.H. Jones, Captain L.A.K. Holcomb, George Norsworthy, British author, with Mrs. Norsworthy; Bruce Brodie, Mrs. William Clark, Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Ramsden, Morrow Kendrik, Lew Leslie, theatrical producer; Miss Gina Malo, actress, and Walter D. Gilbey.

LONDON, March 24. -- The present phase of the Rhineland crisis ended tonight when Joachim yon Ribbentrop, Germany's Ambassador at Large, delivered what was regarded here as a conciliatory reply to the Locarno powers' proposals.

The New York State Landon-for- President Committee, of which former Attorney General Albert Ottinger is chairman, has not closed its headquarters in the Hotel Astor despite the statement of John Hamilton, Landon campaign manager, that the committee was not authorized to represent Governor Landon nor to solicit contributions for his campaign.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- While a statement issued by Mr. Clements described his differences with Dr. Townsend as being over "fundamental policies of both organization and method of gaining enactment of the Townsend plan into law," he told reporters that he was dissatisfied with Dr. Townsend's political activity.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- The Smith bill requiring registration by paid lobbyists and filing of the sources and amounts of their income from lobbying activities was passed on favorably by the Rules Committee today and probably will be considered by the House tomorrow.

Work relief will become the permanent American system of solving the unemployment problem, Mayor La Guardia told members of the Association of Foreign Press Correspondents at a dinner last night at the Hotel Lombardy, 111 East Fifty-sixth Street.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 24. -- Last-minute efforts were made to save an elderly German gold seeker, Ludwig Schmidt, from hanging for slaying three New Guinea natives when the Labor party moved for adjournment of the House of Representatives today.
LONDON, March 24. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange were quiet and dull again today pending international developments. British funds maintained yesterday's levels.
In the address delivered by Colonel Frank Knox before the Economic Club last night he said:

ALBANY, March 24. -- Erie County Republicans moved today to wrest from New York City, Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk County Republicans their present virtual control over the State Committee and put it in the hands of up-State leaders.

BOSTON, March 24. -- The Boston Bruins, limited to a dozen shots during sixty minutes of play, opened their National Hockey League runners-up play-off series by defeating the Toronto Leafs, 3 -- 0, tonight.

Last week's floods cut steel production from an opening level of 62 per cent of ingot capacity to an estimate of 53 per cent, as made by THE NEW YORK TIMES, and the adjusted index declined to 71.3 from 77.5 in the previous week. For the week ended March 23, 1935, the index was 62.9.

TOKYO, March 24. -- Instructions were sent today by Premier Koki Hirota, who is also Foreign Minister, to Ambassador Tamekichi Ota embodying concessions to the Russian Viewpoint that are expected to lead to negotiations on and a favorable issue from the frontier disputes between the Soviet and Manchukuo, which have so often threatened the peace of the Far East.

The City of New York will borrow $35,000,000 on Friday under the terms of the Bankers Agreement, Controller Frank J. Taylor. yesterday informed J.P. Morgan Co., agents for the bankers. The loan, for which revenue bills secured by real estate taxes for the first half of the current year will be issued, will be payable on or before June 30 and will carry a 2 per cent interest rate.

Alexander Garbai, Social Democrat, who was President of Hungary for six months in 1919 and who has been in political exile ever since, is in this country conducting "a spiritual and ethical mobilization" against the present Hungarian Government.
The second showing of the charity figure-skating carnival that filled Madison Square Garden to capacity on Sunday evening will be presented tonight before another gathering of 16,000.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- Robert E. Clements, co-founder of Old-Age Revolving Pensions, Ltd., commonly known as the Townsend plan, and secretary and director of the movement, resigned today, effective April 1, because of differences with Dr. Francis E. Townsend over fundamental principles of the plan and its enactment into law.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- Investigation of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company was resumed today by the Federal Communications Commission, which issued warnings to all telephone companies tonight to retain all their records pending conclusion of the inquiry.

With a balanced exhibition that kept it in control of a well-played game, the New York Athletic Club defeated Aknusti last night at the Squadron A Armory by 9 to 6, gaining the Eastern senior championship and the right to represent this district at Chicago in the East-West indoor polo championships.

CHICAGO, March 24. -- An oversold condition was disclosed in the grain markets today and when shorts tried to cover on the failure of the forecasted rain to develop in the sections of the Winter wheat belt where moisture is most needed they found offerings relatively light.
ROME, March 24. -- The text of three Italo-Austro-Hungarian pro-tocols signed yesterday were made public today. In substance the agreements may be summed up as follows:...

Apparently intent on testing the legality of filing a complaint against the City of New York for violation of its own anti-noise campaign while at the same time branding the drive as "ridiculous" and an impediment "to the wheels of progress," Magistrate Sylvester Sabbatino in Flatbush Court, Brooklyh, refused yesterday to permit withdrawal of the charge on the assertion that the city had remedied the cause of the complaint.

The situation in Germany today is analogous to that which existed in the Southern States at the close of the Civil War. Following the surrender of the Confederacy, President Lincoln had a plan for reconstruction based on fairness and the desire to heal the wounds of war.

Jack Dempsey, former heavyweight champion, and Brig. Gen. Phelan, New York State Boxing Commissioner, were among the more than 1,000 persons who attended the funeral yesterday of Tony Scarpati, Brooklyn fighter, who died last Friday from injuries received during a bout with Lou Ambers at the Broadway Arena on March 17.

Good fortune brought happiness yesterday to more than 150 New Yorkers and residents of the metropolitan district. They were among 325 Americans who held tickets drawn in the Irish Hospitals Sweepstakes at the City Hall in Dublin, Ireland, on horses entered in the Grand National Sweepstakes to be run on Friday at Aintree, outside of Liverpool, England.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,835,950 barrels, compared with 2,808,350 in the preceding week, an increase of 27,600, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Gains of 11,150 barrels in Oklahoma, 9,850 in Kansas, 8,800 in Louisiana and 7,850 in Texas were the important changes.
GLASGOW, Scotland, March 24. -- The liner Queen Mary got safely to the open water of the Firth of Clyde today after twice having grounded in the narrow River Clyde.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 24.- The police issued a communique today declaring documents found in the possession of Luis Carlos Prestes, alleged leader of the radical revolt last November, and Harry Berger, foreign Communist, and in the archives of the secretariat of the Communist party here, had furnished sufficient proof that a Federal Senator and four Representatives had connived with the elements responsible for the uprising.
WASHINGTON. March 24. -- Income tax collections for March are expected to be close to $412,000,000, Treasury experts said today.

Revision of the New York State fire insurance law to include a provision to the effect that a breach of a policy condition or warranty should not void the insurance unless it contributes to the loss was advocated here last night by Julian Lucas, president of Davis, Dorland Co. and of the National Brokers Association.
RALEIGH, N.C., March 24 (AP). -- North Carolina's delegation will go to the Republican National Convention backing a "favorite don" for the Presidential nomination.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 24. -- Military rule was partly lifted tonight and the curfew was limited to sections adjacent to the flood areas, most of which are east of Main Street. More than four-fifths of the city resumed its normal life.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- An urgent appeal to Red Cross chapters to surpass the goal of flood relief contributions, set at $3,000,000 by President Roosevelt, was voiced today by Admiral Cary T. Grayson, chairman of the American Red Cross, as the number of stricken families being cared for increased from 82,000 yesterday to 89,581.

The average Columbia College senior, almost 21 years old and weighing 153 pounds, is slightly antipathetic to the New Deal, would rather win a Phi Beta Kappa key than an athletic award and would not fight in a war conducted outside the United States.
SAN JOSE, Calif., March 24 (AP). -I The State failed again today to convict David A. bamson, former Standard University press official, of murdering his wife.

BERLIN, March 24. -- Through five miles of streets thickly hung with swastika flags, Chancellor Hitler rode with his escort to reaffirm tonight the German refusal to accept the Locarno powers' proposals. His entrance into Deutschland Hall was cheered for six minutes by a crowd of 20,000.
BERLIN, March 24. -- A summary and partial text of the German answer rejecting the proposals drawn up by the four remaining Locarno treaty powers follows:

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn gave Special Prosecutor Hiram C. Todd virtually unlimited scope yesterday in his examination of bank accounts of persons whose funds he has been scrutinizing in an investigation into charges that bribes were paid to suppress evidence after the murder of Samuel Drukman.

Frederick H. Ecker, president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company since 1929, has been elected to the new office of chairman of the board and has been succeeded as president by Leroy A. Lincoln, formerly vice president and general counsel.

Delayed by illness in his family so that he was unable to be present at the opening of his first show in America, Pierre Sicard, who arrives today on the Champlain, will find his exhibition of paintings in full swing at the Marie Sterner Galleries.

Regular trolley-car service will end on Lexington Avenue at 9:30 o'clock this morning and buses, operated by the New York Omnibus Company, a subsidiary of New York Railways, will begin their runs immediately afterward.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- Opponents of agricultural processing levies took new heart today when the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Taxation, completing its first study of President Roosevelt's three-point tax program, agreed to "suggest," but not to "recommend" this method.
LONDON, March 24. -- Turkey gave notice to her League of Nations colleagues tonight that she would remilitarize the Dardanelles if Germany was allowed to reoccupy the Rhineland without penalty.
Although trading in bonds increased somewhat yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, price movements continued narrow, with public attention centered in the sharp sell-off in Italian bonds.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- The four-year troubles of Gus Flood, an Iowa farmer, in trying to collect a 10 per cent reward on $100,500 stolen by bandits from the City National Bank of Clinton, Iowa, were told in a brief filed today with the Supreme Court by the bank, which is fighting Mr. Flood's efforts.

R.A. Macleod, formerly assistant controller, has been appointed assistant vice president of the Bank of New York and Trust Company. James Carey, assistant secretary, has been made assistant controller. Charles W. Metcalf has been made Southern representative of the Textile Banking Corporation of New York with offices in Charlotte, N.C. Edmund H. Leland will assume charge of the New England States.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 24. -- Over the protest of Devereaux Milburn, polo player and president of the Meadowbrook Land Company, the Hempstead Town Board granted today the application of the Roosevelt Field Corporation to rezone 242 acres of the Roosevelt Field tract to permit the construction and operation of an automobile racing track.
Value of Dollar in Exchange The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are tn cents:

The James Monroe High School basketball team, representing the Bronx, conquered the quintet from Samuel J. Tilden High School of Brooklyn, 28 to 21, yesterday at the Textile High School court before a capacity crowd in their first meeting in the series of round-robin matches which will decide the P.S.A.L. championship.

ROME, March 24. -- Heavy selling sent stocks tumbling today in the reaction of Italian business to one of Premier Benito Mussolini's stiffest blows, his announcement that large private industries must pass into government hands.
Gleanings from an outdoor editor's mailbag:

Minority Leader Thomas J. Curran of the Board of Aldermen, who usually defends relief agencies from attacks of the Democratic Aldermen, joined them yesterday in criticizing the WPA for having dismissed Joseph J. McGraw of 31 Bank Street, Manhattan.

After nineteen years the police have caught up with Benjamin Chayton, wanted for murder. He was arrested yesterday in Cleveland and is being held there for New York City detectives. Twice Chayton has been arrested for minor offenses and released before the police learned that he was sought on an indictment charging him with the murder of George F. Sweeney in Brooklyn in 1917.

BERLIN, March 24. -- The Boerse was stagnant and completely under official control today. The turn- over was insignificant. A little private trading is believed to be going on, however. Investing and speculative interests have both withdrawn from the official market to wait the outcome of the international crisis.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 24. -- John F. Gaffey, State Administrator, announced today that Federal Housing Administration loans would be available for the repair of residential and commercial build ings damaged by the floods. The Red Cross appeals for relief-funds have brought more than $30,000.

Colonel KNOX presented himself last night as an "eager" candidate for the Republican nomination and, on the whole, a tolerant critic of the Democratic Administration. He would be prepared "to keep what is good" and to eliminate "the impractical theories" and "the unworkable remedies."

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- A convention of the two groups of building trade unions which have been at odds for eighteen months will be held here tomorrow and, according to indications tonight, formal unification into one building trades department of the American Federation of Labor will be effected.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 24. -- The military court of appeals confirmed today the death sentences imposed by a lower military court on Colonel Damian Veltcheff and Colonel Cyril Stantcheff on charges of conspiracy and high treason. According to law, death sentences must be carried out within twenty-four hours unless the condemned appeal for the King's mercy, and since the two colonels did so this afternoon the executions must await his decision.

Colonel Frank Knox of Chicago, speaking "as a candidate for the Presidency of the United States" to 750 members and guests of the Economic Club at a dinner in the Hotel Astor and to a nation-wide radio audience over a National Broadcasting network, delivered an address here last night "to give you as clear a picture as I can of what I stand for."

Two up-State entrants, Christian Brothers Academy of Syracuse and St. Mary's Academy of Dunkirk, turned in convincing triumphs in two of the four battles staged in the opening round of the first Eastern Catholic High Schools' basketball tournament at the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, clubhouse in Brooklyn last night.

Ten realty auction sales were held in Manhattan yesterday, the properties foreclosed including a group of three buildings in West Sixty-fifth Street and a ten-story loft structure in East Seventeenth Street, The largest scheduled offering, involving the eighteen-story building at 505 Fifth Avenue, which was in a $1,140,253 action by the Chase National Bank against the Park Avenue Operating Company, was adjourned indefinitely.

The board of directors of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., declared yesterday a dividend of $2 a share on the prefered stock, payable on April 15, to stock of record of April 10. The last previous payment was $1.75 a share on Feb. 1, 1932.

PITTSBURGH, March 24 (AP). -- Flood waters climbed over river banks again tonight on far-flung tributaries of the Ohio, while the spirit of rebuilding swept flood-scarred Pittsburgh. Business and industry here united in a great reconstruction program.

Among the commercial leases reported yesterday were several in the Broadway district. The Procurement Division of the Treasury Department took the fifth floor in 326 Broadway through the Charles F. Noyes Company.

IN his unending effort to kick a little life into the Goddess of History, to make the dramatic events of the past as moving and exciting as though they were happening now and just outside the window, Fletcher Pratt rather out-does himself in the opening pages of his "Hail, Caesar!" (Smith Haas, $3.50). To say that he has written his first chapters as fables in slang would be going too far.

MONTREAL, March 25. -- A new plan for reorganization of Price Brothers Co., Ltd., newsprint makers, has been placed in the hands of Gordon W. Scott, trustee in bankruptcy, for submission to creditors and holders of securities of the company.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP). -- The Senate Commerce Committee today shaped a $305,000,000 bill which would include construction of reservoirs and levees in recently flooded Eastern States. It was described as a move to take flood-control projects out of the "pork-barrel" class.

Prince Guido Pignatelli, Count and Countess Bernadotte of Wisborg, Mr. and Mrs. Tuck French and Count and Countess Kotzebue are among the passengers arriving today from Mediterranean ports on the Italian liner Conte di Savola. Also on board the ship are Mr. and Mrs. Hiram Manville, Mr. and Mrs. Hubert Roemer, Marchesa Lanza D. Aoetta and John Fry.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP). -- Foes of the Bland bill to tighten coastwise shipping laws told the House Merchant Marine Committee today that the measure would "destroy the cruise business and provide no substitute."

The New York County grand jury handed up indictments to Judge Donnellan in General Sessions yesterday against seven men under the forgery and old "green goods" laws in the counterfeiting of about 2,500,000 two-cent stamps of the Pennsylvania cigarette tax enacted last year.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 25 (AP). -- It was "Cincinnati Night" in the American Bowling Congress tournament tonight, but contestants from twenty-five other cities and seven States were on hand to enliven competition.

Health Commissioner John L. Rice yesterday warned the public of the necessity of thoroughly cooking all pork products. The warning resulted from a recent outbreak of trichinosis in the Bronx with the death of three members of one family and the serious illness of four others.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 25 (AP). -- Governor Wilbur L. Cross intervened today in a dispute between Mayor Thomas J. Spellacy and the WPA over the rehabilitation program for this city. As a result, assurance was given that the WPA would act promptly on all flood projects here.

Judge Robert A. Inch in the United States District Court in Brooklyn granted yesterday the application of the Bush Terminal Company for dismissal of a suit in equity pending against it and for dismissal of a voluntary petition seeking reorganization under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

Government ownership of the merchant marine was described as impractical and potentially dangerous to the development of foreign markets for American goods in a letter forwarded yesterday by Commander Robert C. Lee, vice president of Moore McCormack, shipping operators, to United States Senator Bennett C. Clark.

The prompt and generous response by the people of this city to the Red Cross flood appeal is most gratifying. The total amount reported yesterday was considerably beyond the half-way mark toward the New York minimum quota of the national fund, which is a larger percentage than that reported for the country at large.

From the day when the Wagner Labor Disputes Act became law it was obvious that it would itself create confusion and dispute. It defined the phrase "affecting commerce," for example, much more broadly than did the unanimous Supreme Court decision in the Schechter case.
WASHINGTON, March 25. -- Discovery of a new type of vitamin D in fish oils, and synthesis of the new vitamin in the laboratory, were announced today before the American Institute of Nutrition.

Arbitration of wages of building service employes was begun yesterday by Ferdinand A. Silcox, Chief Forester of the United States, in accordance with the settlement agreement which ended the recent strike of the Building Service Employes Union.

The New York Stock Exchange approved yesterday the listing of securities of five companies, including 200,649 shares of no-par common stock of the Continental Steel Corporation, previously traded on the Chicago Stock Exchange.

ALBANY, March 25. -- Governor Lehman sent a special message to the Legislature today, accompanied by four bills amending the personal income tax law and designed to make it easier to reach the higher-ups in organized crime and racketeering.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 25. -- Seventy finally has been broken in competition on the revamped No. 2 course here, Ray Mangrum, an unattached pro, shooting a brilliant 68 today to take the lead in the North and South open golf tournament. The Texan's score gave him a total of 141 for the first two eighteen-hole rounds.

Recommendations for tightening the laws affecting persons operating automobiles while under the influence of intoxicating liquor was submitted to Mayor La Guardia yesterday by the committee he named recently to study the problem of drunken drivers.

TRENTON, March 25. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman declared late today that there would be no further reprieve for Bruno Richard Hauptmann and no conference with Dr. John F. Condon under the conditions laid down by the man who negotiated the payment of $50,000 futile ransom for Charles A. Lindbergh Jr.

While the recent revelations of special discounts, advertising allowances, , granted by manufacturers to large buyers have aroused many complaints from less favored customers and caused some producers to cut down on them, most manufacturers who engage in a cooperative advertising campaign with retailers, without discrimination, are going right ahead with their plans, according to reports yesterday.

James H. Van Alen, former champion and the most dangerous challenger for the crown held by Ogden Phipps, launched his quest for the national amateur court tennis title yesterday by defeating Charles Shipman Payson in the opening round of the tournament at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

A.G. Thacher Jr. of Heights Casino, who won the 1935 metropolitan squash racquets mixed doubles crown with Mrs. Rogers Dunn of the Junior League club as his partner, is making steady progress with his new teammate, Mrs. A.W. Paine, in the championship now in progress at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn.
Statements of earnings for February issued by the railroads yesterday continued to show an upward trend. The reports follow:

The modern motor bus replaced the outmoded street car on Lexington Avenue yesterday. The passing of the trolley cars, in operation since 1901, was marked by ceremonies in which former Governor Alfred E. Smith and others participated.

MONTREAL, March 25. -- The longest game in hockey history behind them, the Maroons and the Detroit Red Wings rival group leaders, today rallied their jaded forces for the second game of the National League championship series here tomorrow night.

Fritz Reiner, who is one of the conductors mentioned to direct the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra for some weeks next season, has been engaged to conduct at Covent Garden in London during the season from April 15 to June 13, according to a cable received yesterday from Sir Thomas Beecham, general music director of the Covent Garden Opera Company.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- Greenbacks were flashed in the House today in violation of its rules when members, listening to a plea of Representative Dunn of Mississippi for "real relief" for a former tenant farmer, contributed $44 for the needy family.

A revelation that the defendant, accused of strangling her day-old baby, was not 21 years old, as she asserted, but only 15, halted the trial of "Joan Patterson" in General Sessions yesterday. Subsequently, under her true name of Marie Woron, she was held in Children's Court as a juvenile delinquent for hearing tomorrow.

ALBANY, March 25. -- Governor Lehman was accused today on the floor of the Assembly of delaying the passage of legislation which would enable New York City to set machinery into motion for the 1939 World's Fair.

Mrs. Nicholas F. Brady gave a dinner last night at her home, 910 Fifth Avenue, taking her guests later to the second performance of the annual international skating carnival at the Madison Square Garden for the benefit of the Carroll Club and Vacation Camp and for the convalescent relief division of Bellevue Hospital Social Service Bureau.
Although demonstrations of alleged unemployed continued yesterday before the offices of the WPA at 111 Eighth Avenue, the day passed without incident or additional arrests.

MOSCOW, March 25. -- The recent series of criticisms for failures in the Stakhanoff movement and the ofifcial demand for higher efficiency in many lines of work were punctuated today by the announcement that the railroads had completed a ten-day test period with startling success.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP). -- The proposed central postoffice for Queens County, in Greater New York, involving a two-cent postage rate for all its communities, was supported by some Queens spokesmen and opposed by the Jamaica Chamber of Commerce at a hearing today before a House subcommittee.
MEDFORD, Mass., March 25. -- Paul McCullough, the comedian who slashed his throat with a razor in a barber shop here Monday, died at the Lawrence Memorial Hospital today from his wounds.

Deputy Commissioner John E. Eastmond of the New York Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity announces that fishing will be permitted in the Long Island watershed this season, starting next Wednesday and continuing through Aug. 31.

The State of Louisiana will be in the market with a new issue of $2,500,000 of highway 4 1/4 per cent, Series P. bonds, award of which will be made on April 28. The bonds will be dated April 15, 1936, and mature on April 15, 1940 to 1961.

CHICAGO, March 25. -- Red Dutton led his New York Americans into Chicago tonight on the crest of the wave. The spangled sextet, in the National Hockey League play- offs for the first time since 1929, looked forward eagerly to their meeting with the Black Hawks tomorrow night, when they engage the Windy City sextet in the second contest of the two-game series that will be decided on total goals.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 25 (AP). -- Playing over a rain-drenched course, four veterans of the links survived the second round of the sixth annual Augusta women's invitation golf tournament today to enter the semi-finals.
ALBANY, March 25 (AP). -- "The present prospects are that tax burdens will increase during the next few years," the State Tax Commission told the Legislature today in its report for 1935.

Records of the American Birth Control League show that 41 per cent of the mothers who came to the league's clinics last year were receiving public relief, Dr. Eric M. Matsner, medical director of the league, said yesterday at a meeting of the organization's campaign committee in the home of Mrs. Goodhue Livingston, 38 East Sixty-fifth Street.

The effects of "bootlegging" anthracite are cited by L.F. Loree, president of the Hudson Coal Company, in explaining an increase in its net loss in 1935. The company operates the coal properties of the Delaware and Hudson Company.

It is probable that in his whole eleven seasons in New York as conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra Arturo Toscanini never received such demonstrations of profound respect and wild enthusiasm as those which acknowledged his sovereign art when he conducted the Pension Fund concert last night in Carnegie Hall.

Replying to "misleading statements" by Senator George R. Fearon and others that industry is leaving New York State, Elmer F. Andrews. State Industrial Commissioner, declared yesterday that a careful analysis of the facts showed that the State's relative industrial position has not declined either during the depression or since 1904.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- The following is the text of the naval agreement signed in London today, which was reached on Monday after many revisions and which was made public here by the State Department:

COVINGTON, Ky., March 25. -- This city of 60,000 persons, across the Ohio River from Cincinnati, forbade all public gatherings today as a precaution against a possible outbreak of spinal meningitis such as took fifty lives in eight Kentucky hill counties during the Winter.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was honor guest at dinner tonight of the Seventy-third Club, made up of wives of members of the Seventy-third Congress. Each member had the privilege of bringing her husband to the dinner, which brought the attendance to a total of 348.

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 25. -- After two days of junketing in neighboring Alabama, the Giants returned today for one more afternoon at their training base and forthwith demonstrated that all their strenuous activities of the past month have not been in vain.

EDMONTON, March 25. -- Unforeseen circumstances have set aside, for the time being, government plans for the registration of Alberta citizens eligible for Social Credit basic dividends. Meanwhile Premier Aberhart declared today that his administration was going ahead with legislation now before the House.
Dock Commissioner John McKenzie announced last night that studies are under way which may result in further reductions in the pier rentals in this port as an attraction to commerce.

Recent events and announced plans in Italy show the destiny and inevitable course of dictatorship. It may begin tentatively and modestly, but it ends by sweeping everything within its scope and power. The Government starts out by taking over certain forms of business, but is driven step by step to take over all business.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- Congressional investigation of the circumstances under which more than 250 veterans in Federal Emergency Relief Administration camps on the Florida Keys lost their lives in last year's hurricane was assured today when Representative Rankin of Mississippi obtained passage of a resolution in the House enabling him to put under oath witnesses who will appear before the Committee on Veterans' Affairs, of which he is chairman.

Sir Alfred Zimmern, Professor of International Relations at Oxford University and one of England's outstanding authorities on that subject, arrived yesterday on the French liner Champlain to visit friends and to join his wife, who has spent the Winter in this country.

MIAMI, Fla., March 25. -- After stepping today for the first time on the deck of the new Presidential yacht, the Potomac, President Roosevelt took a hand at "bottom fishing" near Great Inagua Island, situated about 350 miles east of Miami off the northeast tip of Cuba.

The share market yesterday more than made up for the setback of the day before although the trading pace was not increased. For once, at least, an old Wall Street aphorism pointed true; namely, that when stocks close weak in a dull market, the early trading the next day develops comparative strength.

The Triborough Bridge Authority wrote yesterday to Secretary of the Interior Ickes formally asking him to reconsider his PWA decentralization order which places Wharton Green, local PWA project engineer, under Arthur S. Tuttle, State engineer, instead of under Washington directly.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP). -- Representative Mitchell, Democrat of Illinois, today named six Negro youths as candidates for West Point and Annapolis, recalling that only three members of that race ever had been graduated from either of these academies.

Commodore Daniel F.B. Hickey of the New York Athletic Club's yachting department last night at a meeting of the members in the city clubhouse announced that the annual cruiser race to Block Island will be conducted on July 11. F.W. Horenburger, chairman of the regatta committee, declared a record entry is expected.

Sears, Roebuck Co., excluding insurance companies not consolidated, reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 29 a consolidated net profit of $21,519,218 after Federal taxes, depreciation, special charges and reserves and contributions to employes' savings and profit-sharing pension funds.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today extended the deadline for filing the certified financial statements of certain issuers which registered securities under the Securities Exchange Act.

Plans for the Book Sharing Week campaign sponsored by a large committee of prominent men and women representative of social, literary and educational circles will be discussed by Mrs. Sherman Post Haight and Warden Lewis E. Lawes, co-chairmen of the committee, at a tea being given this afternoon by Mrs. Frank C. Fisher at her home, 128 East Seventy-first Street.

TOKYO, March 25. -- "That still holds good; I said there would be no war while I was Foreign Minister, and there will be no war while I am Prime Minister," said Koki Hirota to this correspondent at a reception to foreign correspondents this afternoon.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler approved yesterday a petition by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, for permission to compromise for $1,475,000 two suits against former directors of the New York Title Company, the Bank of the Manhattan Company and the National Mortgage Corporation.

Over-the-counter dealers in this city, who have furnished some opposition to the unlisted trading bill sponsored by the Securities and Exchange Commission, are understood to be undecided whether or not to fight for the inclusion of a definite "yardstick" for measuring the right of a security to trading on an organized exchange.

The State Mortgage Bank of Yugoslavia has announced that it hopes within two months to be able to enter into an agreement with the holders of its secured 7 per cent bonds due in 1957, in circulation outside of Yugoslavia, for the payment of interest coupons dated Oct. 1, 1935, to April 1, 1937, inclusive.
WASHINGTON, March 25. -- Senator Borah probably will not enter the California primary fight after all.
ALBANY, March 25. -- Opposition to the bill to provide for State regulation of fee-charging employment agencies increased today at a hearing before the Assembly Labor and Industry Committee.

LONDON, March 25. -- Trading on the London Stock Exchange was quiet again today, with prices steady, particularly among industrian and Brazilian securities were scarcely altered in quotations. Austrian and Brizilian securities were firmer in the foreign department, with Japanese dull and Germans droopy in the absence of support.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 25. -- Plans for a debate with James E. Van Zandt, commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, on a nationwide radio hook-up next week were announced here today by Lewis J. Gorin, national commander of the Veterans of Future Wars.
MOSCOW, March 25. -- An eclipse of the sun whose path of totality will sweep across the whole breadth of the Soviet Union on June 19 will be put to good political use by the Communist government.

Purchases of close to $300,000 in American merchandise have been made by the Houndsditch Warehouse Company, Ltd., and Burstins Limited, large wholesale firms in London, it was announced yesterday by Philip Halperin, managing director and chairman of the board of the companies.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- The nineteen building trade unions in the American Federation of Labor, divided into rival camps for eighteen months, united today, formed one building trades department, elected officers and announced the creation of machinery to handle jurisdictional disputes without interruption of building operations.

PARIS, March 25. -- French officials said tonight that Italy had flatly refused to accept the proposal arrived at in London by the delegates of the four remaining Locarno powers, including herself, to negotiate a new European peace.

MEXICO, D.F., March 25. -- Reports of extensive reopenings of Catholic churches in Mexico are unconfirmed. The capital, with a population of more than 1,000,000, remains restricted to twenty-five churches with twenty-five priests.

More than 300 animals, birds and fish were entered in the twelfth annual pet show of the Kips Bay Boys Club last night in the auditorium of the club building at 301 East Fifty- second Street. The show opened at 7 o'clock and closed at 9, with an estimated attendance of about 2,000 persons.

Tom Iannicelli, Essex Club professional, and Harry F. Wolf of the New York A.C. led the field into the semi-final round in the world's open squash tennis championship tournament last night at the Hotel Shelton. They registered impressive victories in quarterfinal encounters.

The powerful Christian Brothers Academy quintet of Syracuse met with unexpected opposition from another formidable upper New York State combination before turning back the St. Mary's Academy of Dunkirk, 25 to 22, in a tense battle for the Eastern Catholic high schools championship last night at the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus clubhouse.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 25. -- Officials of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad reported tonight that train service between Springfield and Hartford would be resumed tomorrow.
LONDON, March 25. -- The House of Commons by a vote of 150 to 56 tonight approved a private member's motion calling for the revision of Ministers' salaries.

Gains ranging up to 12 per cent in Easter trade were foreseen yesterday by David Ovens, vice-president and general manager of the J.B. Ivey Company, Charlotte, N.C. and former president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association. Mr. Ovens reported that the floods were not a factor in the South and that improved weather spurring Spring demand has featured recent weeks.

Early advances in most commodity futures were lost in the late trading on the commodity markets yesterday. Coffee futures were particularly active. In the cash markets antimony and butter advanced and lard sold at a new high price for the year. Other staples were lower.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- An increase in the number of preferred and common stock issues by corporations was shown by a summary covering $212,088,937 of securities of all kinds, registration for which under the Securities Act of 1933 became effective in February, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

LONDON, March 25. -- With the League Council and Locarno conferences vanished from London, members of Parliament are going to have an opportunity to debate the foreign situation tomorrow. Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden will make a statement of the British government's position as between France and Germany which has developed during the last three weeks.

Three robbers forced their way into the home of Arnold J. Evans, a retired jeweler, in a residential section of Staten Island last night and escaped with loot valued at $7,500 after tying up the four occupants in the house.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 25. -- Smudge pots, old automobile tires and brush fires burned in California's orchards tonight as a killing frost settled on the blossoming fruit crops for the second consecutive night.

WELLESLEY, Mass., March 25. -- President Angell of Yale University, speaking at the Honors Day celebration of scholarship at Wellesley College this morning, urging students to keep alive by daily use whatever they find most precious in their college experience.

Sporting goods and cameras, with a rise of 64.3 per cent over 1935, led the sections showing the greatest sales increases in local department stores in February, according to the analysis issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

A pictorial jeremiad against New Deal personalities and policies enlivened the walls of a temporary gallery at 5 East Fifty-seventh Street yesterday afternoon when the Defenders of Democracy showed privately ten murals painted by an anti-Roosevelt artist who masks his identity under the pseudonym Jere-Miah II.

LONDON, March 25. -- The United States and Great Britain announced to the whole world tonight that they would keep the principle of parity between their navies, even though each will become free at the end of this year to build as many warships as it wishes.

NASSAU, Bahamas, March 25. -- E.S. White's Shucks and Stanley Ogilvy's Jay of the United States, led the Star Class fleet of twelve across the finish line today in the first of a series of three races for the Johnnie Walker Trophy.

The New York A.C. water polo team, not quite the awesome operator with a hard ball as it is with a soft one, was formidable enough for the Jewish People's Institute seven of Chicago last night as the Winged Footers retained their national A.A.U. hard-ball championship in the N.Y.A.C. pool.
ALBANY, March 25. -- Compulsory insurance for motor vehicles was assailed and defended today at a public hearing on the Berg-Weisman and Berg-Stewart bills.

In spite of progress by the city Sanitation Department, improvement has been "painfully slow" in street cleaning and "the streets of New York continue to have an appearance of a frontier town up to 11 A.M. and even later," the Committee of Twenty on Street and Outdoor Cleanliness declared in a statement last night.

A nation-wide banking syndicate of fifty-five investment houses, headed by the First Boston Corporation and the Mellon Securities Company, Inc., will offer today an issue of $75,000,000 of Eastern Gas and Fuel Associates first-mortgage and collateral trust, Series A, 4 per cent bonds due on March 1, 1956, at 96 1/2 and accrued interest.
ALBANY, March 25 (AP). -- Lester W. Herzog, up-State WPA Administrator, allocated $1,485,051.54 today for work-relief projects, of which $1,003,211.30 is for five Westchester County jobs.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP). -- The Red Cross flood-relief fund, which had reached $1,474,000 yesterday passed the $2,000,000 mark today on its way toward the $3,000,000 goal. The total was $2,039,214.

About 600 more Americans, half of them in this vicinity, won prizes yesterday in the second and final day's drawing in Dublin, Ireland, of the Irish Hospital Sweepstakes. Four, including a butcher, a cook and a bell-hop who live in this area, will get residual cash prizes of about $27,000 each.

The Rehn Galleries, 683 Fifth Avenue, opened yesterday a large group exhibition called "1936." It is made up of work by Rehn "regulars." Fifteen artists are represented by paintings, a few of them also by drawings, while a new lithograph by Robert Riggs, "Club Fighter," is added.

CHICAGO, March 25. -- Wheat prices receded slowly today on the Board of Trade on persistent selling by scattered longs and pressure from local operators, many of whom were bearish because of the forecasts for rains in parts of the dry areas in the West and Southwest.

WASHINGTON, March 25.-- Rarely since the Teapot Dome inquiry has Washington been so keenly interested in a Congressional investigation as it is in the Townsend old age pension plan inquiry, which is scheduled to begin before a House committee tomorrow morning.
ALBANY, March 25. -- -The text of Governor Lehman's message to the Legislature was as follows:

The itinerary for the expedition of the American women golfers who are going abroad to play in the international matches for the Curtis Cup was announced yesterday by the United States Golf Association.

Attempts of striking seamen to delay the sailing of two ships in protest against a new wage contract signed by sailors' union representatives and the ship lines failed yesterday. The United States liner Manhattan and the New York and Cuba Mail Line ship Oriente sailed on time for the Channel ports and Hamburg and Havana.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- Past ventures and present activities of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in the motion-picture field were presented in detail at the hearing today before the Federal Communications Commission.

DUBLIN, March 25. -- The shooting of Vice Admiral Henry Boyle Somerville in his home at Castle Townshend near Skibbereen last night may be the first move in a terrorist campaign being initiated by extremists to prevent recruiting for the British Army and Navy in the Irish Free State.

WASHINGTON, March 25.--Upon further consideration today the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Taxation struck all mention of agricultural processing taxes from its report on President Roosevelt's new tax program.

President Rice of the State Civil Service Commission in his letter to THE TIMES defends the continued exemption of Board of Election clerks and the rejection of the local resolution subjecting them to civil service examination, on the ground that the State commission was complying with the law as interpreted by the Attorney General, as legal adviser of the State commission.

Two printed silk chiffon gowns that have just been added to the wardrobe of Mrs. Franklin Roosevelt reflect the designing talent of two high school girls, winners in a competition sponsored by the International Silk Guild. One is an afternoon gown in a flower and leaf pattern, the other a dinner dress in two shades of blue -- Eleanor and Roosevelt blue, contrasted with white.

The New York Power and Light Corporation, one of the largest units of the Niagara Hudson System, reported yesterday for 1935 a net income of $3,041,182, after depreciation, taxes, interest, amortization and other charges. This was equal to $12.63 a share on the outstanding $7 and $6 preferred stocks.

New York City is "too big, too great and too much hated by the rest of the country" to fail in its "duty" to provide funds for the support of its private welfare agencies, former Governor Alfred E. Smith told members of the commerce and industry division of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee at a luncheon yesterday at India House.

Serious difficulties due to the floods affect about 30 per cent of women's wear woolen production, although production and deliveries of silks by representative mills were comparatively unaffected, according to the results of surveys announced yesterday.

At the annual meeting of stockholders of Mack Trucks, Inc., here yesterday A.J. Brosseau, president, said he looked for expansion of the company's business from replacement of old models. The bus department was becoming increasingly important and the need for new trucks was growing, he said.

MIAMI, Fla., March 25. -- Curtis King's Phildia gave favorite players a stunning setback when the gelding finished last in the feature fifth race today at Tropical Park. Five horses of $2,000 caliber started in the six-furlong claiming dash and the winner turned up in the Liberty Lane Stable's Fake, which returned $13.90 for a $2 mutuel ticket.
Before another enthusiastic gathering of 16,000, the charity figure skating carnival was staged at Madison Square Garden again last night.

LONDON, March 25. -- Following are the texts of a Setter sent by Norman H. Davis, head of the American delegation to the London naval conference, to Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, and of Mr. Eden's reply, which were made public today:

MOSCOW, March 25. -- One of the most serious of many incidents along the Soviet-Manchurian border and the first since the new Japanese Government came into power occurred today near Hunchun, in the vicinity of the juncture of the Soviet, Manchurian and Korean borders.

Their eagerness checked by the unemotional, cut-and-dried questions of Miles O'Brien, prosecutor in the trial of Miss Vera Stretz for the murder of Dr. Fritz Gebhardt, ten State witnesses outlined in General Sessions Court yesterday the story of the crime.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- The practice of the navy and of the marine corps of providing free a $10,000 life insurance policy for cadet fliers, retaining the graduated cadets for three years, and giving each flier a $1,500 bonus when he leaves the service, was declared by army air corps officials today to be the reason the army cannot obtain qualified young men for flight training at its training camp at San Antonio.

ADDIS ABABA, March 25. -- The greatest losses suffered by Ethiopians from Italian air raids were inflicted today on Jijiga and surrounding villages, including El Bhai and others nearer the frontier of British Somaliland when they were heavily bombarded by more than twenty Italian airplanes.

The services of nineteen employes of the Bureau of Attendance of the public school system were terminated, at least technically, by the Board of Education last night in line with a decision of the Court of Appeals holding eligible lists from which they were appointed illegal.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- Air mail carried in January totaled 1,177,753 pounds, an all-time record, Postmaster General Farley reported today. He added that new air mail poundage records were established in every month of 1935, but that the air mail showed a deficit of $2,999,371.

PITTSBURGH, March 25. -- As the flood which crippled Pittsburgh industry a week ago rolled slowly down the Ohio past Cincinnati a new one poured out of the Monongahela today, threatening this city with a second inundation.

CAMDEN, S.C., March 25. -- The seventh annual running of the Carolina Cup race will be staged over the famous Springdale course Saturday with an exceptionally large entry scheduled to compete in the seven events on the program. Preparations are being made to accommodate the largest crowd in the history of the meeting.
Following is the text of the speech of Viscount Monsell. First Lord of The British Admiralty, at the naval conference in London yesterday, as transcribed here by the National Broadcasting Company:

LINCOLN, England, March 25. -- Overcoat, which finished fourth in the Lincolnshire Handicap last year, won the eighty-first running of the same race today, but Bow and Arrow, second in the 1935 running, stumbled and caused a pile-up which resulted in injuries to three jockeys and the death of one horse in the first of the season's flat racing fixtures.
BOSTON, March 25 (AP). -- Rehabilitation and resumption of industry in New England flood areas went forward today as financial preliminaries were hurried in all the affected States.
Flood-relief contributions sent yesterday to the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross amounted to nearly $47,330, bringing the total of the chapter's fund to $287,876.77.

CHICAGO, March 25. -- A much improved shipping demand for hogs had considerable influence on the market today with sales steady to 10 cents a hundred weight higher than yesterday's level. This buying and the continued relatively light receipts more than offset a decline of 1/2 cent a pound in fresh pork loins.
PARIS, March 25. -- Both rentes and francs weakened today on the Bourse, which market has become a prey to all kinds of rumors and suggestions.

BERLIN, March 25 (AP). -- Trade negotiations between Germany and Soviet Russia have come to a halt, both German and Russian official sources said today, since Adolf Hitler's March 7 Reichstag speech announcing occupation of the Rhineland and denunciation of the Locarno pact.

While Governor CROSS of Connecticut is waiting till the flood decayeth and drieth up, and is actively attending to all the extraordinary as well as ordinary duties of his office, we notice in The Hartford Courant that the "party leaders expect he will be renominated" next Fall.

NEWARK, N.J., March 25. -- Criticism of the cost of meals for its members held the Essex County grand jury's attention today. The procession of witnesses before the grand jury in its investigation of charges of corruption in the City Hall was interrupted while two men who had figured in publicity given to the grand jurors' dinner bills were summoned.

First Deputy Police Commissioner Harold Fowler, in charge of traffic, received yesterday from the ninety-four troops of the Girl Scouts in the Bronx traffic safety pledges bearing 20,000 signatures. The presentation was made at Police Headquarters by Miss Edith J. Broderick, Bronx director of the Girl Scouts; Jean Nast of Troop 5 and Marie Martin of Troop 25.

People in Hollywood are known to attend the movies, and natives of France have occasionally been observed enjoying crepes Suzette, so it is not inconceivable that now and then a native of the Irish Free State wins a prize in the Irish Sweepstakes.

Congress has no right to empower the President of the United States to outlaw the shipment of arms to belligerent nations, even if in his opinion such an embargo would tend to re-establish peace, Federal Judge Mortimer W. Byers ruled yesterday.

Announcing that a drastic shake-up would be made in the detective division in the near future, Police Commissioner Valentine revealed yesterday that he had ordered an exchange of posts between Deputy Chief Inspector John J. Ryan, who has been in command of Brooklyn detectives, and Acting Deputy Chief Inspector John J. Gallagher, in command of Queens detectives.
What is termed the first complete and documented biography of Adolf Hitler will soon be published by Knopf. The author is Konrad Heiden.

BERLIN, March 25. -- Prices on the Boerse were slightly stronger today without any significant tendency developing. Activity is still very much limited and the markets continue to be completely under official control.
LONDON, March 25 (By Wireless). -- Now that the naval conference is over it is possible to forecast with some assurance the effect of its labors on the international position at sea.

George J. Rhodius of 82-73 167th Street, Jamaica, Queens, was arraigned before Magistrate Frank Giorgio in the Ridgewood magistrate's court yesterday on a charge of practicing law without having been admitted to the bar. He pleaded not guilty and was paroled for an examination in the same court on April 3.

ALBANY, March 25. -- The deadlock in the Legislature over Governor Lehman's executive budget tightened today when the Senate Finance Committee reported the budget bills after restoring more than $14,000,000 of the items eliminated by the Republicans in the Assembly.

TAMPA, Fla., March 25. -- After half a day of heated arguments for a change of venue to another county for the Tampa flogging trials and an entire day devoted to reading more than 100 exhibits, Judge Robert T. Dewell decided today that the trials should proceed, at least for the present, in Hillsborough County.

Miss Marion Lloyd, former national champion, came back from the edge of defeat to vanquish her closest rival, Miss Dorothy Locke, 5 to 4, last night at the Fencers Club in a fence-off for first place in the fourth of the series of Olympic tryouts which will help determine the membership of the United States women's team in Berlin next Summer.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- Registration statements for twelve proposed securities issues with a total value of $40,340,986 were made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Of the proposed issues, $355,000 (aggregate face value) were for reorganization purposes.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- The naval treaty signed in London today is regarded by the administration as the best that could be expected in the light of world conditions. It is not viewed, however, as constituting in any sense an alliance between the United States and Great Britain.

More than half the decline in steel operations caused by the floods last week will be regained this week, and next week's output may be larger than that in the week prior to the flood, according to Iron Age's weekly summary, issued yesterday.

The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, which is wholly owned by the General Motors Corporation and which finances the distribution and sale of General Motors products, made last year a net operating profit of $12,099,695, compared with $10,700,862 in 1934, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

Routine trading characterized yesterday's bond market on the New York Stock Exchange, with narrow and mixed price movements prevailing among the major groups. Transactions, which were the smallest in more than a week, totaled $9,667,800, compared with $12,324,400 on Tuesday.

A number of changes in the officer personnel at Fort Slocum were announced in War Department orders yesterday as the defense in the general court-martial at Governors Island of Captain Ralph E. Fleischer of Fort Slocum started the presentation of its case.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- A $60,344,000 refunding by the Virginian Railway Company through which it expects to save $542,700 a year for five years and about $626,700 a year from 1946 to 1966 was authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
Critics of Mayor La Guardia's plans for a city-owned power plant were invited by the Mayor yesterday to submit bids for the operation of the city-owned Thirty-ninth Street ferry for a five-year term.

Improvements in artificial illumination, which were described by two engineers as bringing man for the first time "within arm's reach" of artificial sunshine, were shown last night before an audience at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

It was with intense interest that we read Arthur Krock's summary of the housing situation as it now stands in Washington. His remarks served to clarify a situation which has become increasingly cloudy of late.
CINCINNATI, March 25. -- Thousands of the residents of the upper Ohio Valley fled from their homes again tonight before onrushing headwaters that sent the Ohio River surging from its banks.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 25. -- Invitations to take part in the greatest alumni reunion in American academic history during the exercises climaxing the Harvard tercentenary celebration, Sept. 17 and 18, were mailed tonight to 65,000 graduates and former students.

TAMPA, Fla., March 25. -- The tall, thin mahout of the white elephants, Mr. Cornelius McGillicuddy, took his anemic pachyderms through this territory and then headed for West Palm Beach. He was not traveling fast. If he had moved off a slow walk he would have left all his ball club behind him.
OKLAHOMA CITY, March 25 (AP). -- Oil drilling crews rushed into the heart of a residential district here tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- The Federal Government was forced today to abandon the lighthouse on Cape Hatteras -- the tallest, most famous and, some say, the most beautiful such structure in the United States.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered yesterday and closed with gains of 3 to 8 points. Termination of the March interest created more than the usual last-day activity as many foreign shorts postponed covering until the last moment. After selling at 11.49 cents a pound, the best quotation since Jan. 23 and within 9 points of the season's high record, March went off the board at noon at 11.45 cents.

In its drive to correct violations in old-law tenements, the Tenement House Department has arranged with the Federal Housing Administration to help landlords who need financial assistance to repair their buildings, Harry Prince, First Deputy Tenement House Commissioner, said last night.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- The text of the speech of Norman H. Davis, chief of the United States delegation, upon the signing of the naval treaty in London today was given out by the State Department as follows:

A resolution condemning the alleged murder of Victor Allen Barron, American youth, by Brazilian authorities and demanding release of 17,000 Brazilian political prisoners, was adopted by a crowd of nearly 1,000 persons at a mass-meeting at Irving Plaza last night.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- The Distinguished Service Cross was awarded by the War Department today to Major John H. Hilldring, now at the Command and General Staff School at Fort Leavenworth. The award is for extraordinary heroism in action in the Fere Forest, near Jaulgonne, France, on July 22. 1918, when he was a first lieutenant in Company K, Thirty-eighth Infantry, Third Division.

Representative Vito Marcantonio, whose activities in behalf of labor have won him a reputation as a radical leader, has endorsed the candidacy of Hamilton Fish Jr. as a delegate to the Republican National Convention, it was disclosed yesterday.

A seven-point program for studying and attacking the problems of unemployment was coupled here yesterday with a sharp defense of manufacturing industry in helping recovery, in a statement made by directors of the National Association of Manufacturers, following a meeting at the Hotel Biltmore.
BERLIN, March 25 (AP). -- The Reichsbank statement as of March 23 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:
WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP). -- Motion picture "executives" were blamed today by John Howard Lawson of the Dramatists Guild of America for "repetitious jokes and indecent allusions" in films.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 25. -- Joseph E. Widener entertained with a luncheon today at II Palmetto, followed by exhibition tennis matches for the benefit of the Good Samaritan Hospital fund. Players competing in two singles and two doubles were Charles Harris, Martin Buxby, Carroll Turner, Joe Whalen, John Hendrix, George Andrade, Gardner Mulloy and Arthur Hendrix.

LIEGE, Belgium, March 25. -- Here is the frontier most profoundly shaken by the appearance of German troops in the Rhineland demilitarized zone. It is necessary to come to Belgium to realize how real to a people once invaded was the threat represented by Chancellor Adolf Hitler's "symbolic" army. It is still real.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 25. -- The Brooklyn baseball club is definitely for sale if a bona fide purchaser has $2,000,000 to pay for it, Vice President Joseph Gilleaudeau admitted today.

WASHINGTON, D.C., March 25. -- An explanation of the Slaughter Reform Bill and a defense of the attitude of the Polish Government as one based on an age-long tradition of "equality and tolerance" were included in a letter to Dr. Cyrus Adler, president of the American Jewish Committee, made public today by the Polish Embassy.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- An assertion that large unsalable surpluses of wheat and corn and resulting low prices were inevitable in 1937, with ordinary weather conditions this year, unless grain belt farmers cooperated in the new conservation program and shifted millions of acres of commercial crop land to grass was made by Secretary Wallace today.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., March 25 (AP). -- Ernest Wagner, Justice of the Peace, exonerated Mrs. Dorothea Longcope Livermore today on charges of shooting and wounding her son, Jesse Livermore Jr., last Thanksgiving.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 25. -- Returning the pleasant call paid them in St. Petersburg yesterday, Colonel Jacob Ruppert and his Yankees came to the swanky Brooklyn field for a game today and went away apparently convinced of one thing -- that John (Buddy) Hassett is worth the $55,000 the colonel charged the Dodgers for him.
Charles S. Sargent of G.M.-P. Murphy Co. has been elected a director of the American Machine and Metals Company.
PHILADELPHIA, March 25. -- There will be a luncheon at the Cosmopolitan Club on Tuesday, March 31, at which two committees working for the Devon Horse Show and Country Fair will discuss plans.
West Side apartment house sales featured the Manhattan realty trading reported yesterday.

The protective committee for holders of bonds of the Republic of El Salvador, of which F.J. Lisman is chairman, announced yesterday the completion of negotiations with that Central American government whereby the three bond issues are to be scaled as to interest and sinking fund, proportionate to their rank as first, second and third liens, on the custom house receipts.

ALBANY, March 25. -- The Senate passed today, 28 to 16, the bill of Senator Joseph for the creation of mortgage banks which would be permitted to make loans on first mortgages on income-producing real property.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- Banks of the United States were placed today on the same basis as brokers and dealers so far as the purchasing or carrying of stocks registered on national securities Exchanges is concerned.

" Jumbo," that lustrous circus which relighted the Hippodrome on Nov. 16, will say good-bye to Sixth Avenue on Saturday night, April 18. That is about a month before it had been scheduled to leave, and it is not clear just what, if anything, it will be doing before it opens in Texas next July as a feature of the "Frontier Centennial" in Fort Worth.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

ASMARA, March 25. -- Slowly and steadily the gap separating the Italian forces from the Ethiopian armies that have been gathering in the Lake Ashangi region is narrowing. Emperor Haile Selassie still gives no sign of falling back and seems to be intensifying his preparations.

Asserting that he was sure Jacob Smith, 21 years old, of 5,110 Nineteenth Avenue, Brooklyn, a clothing cutter, had no criminal intent when he married 15-year-old Dorothea J. Wildman March 9 in Goshen, N.Y., Magistrate Sabbatino in Flatbush court yesterday released the youth on $1 bail on a charge of abduction.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- Banks of the United States were placed today on the same basis as brokers and dealers so far as the purchasing or carrying of stocks registered on national securities Exchanges is concerned.
Robert W. Bingham, United States Ambassador to England, will sail tonight for England on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania. He will be accompanied by Mrs. Bingham.

The Soviet Government is all set to deliver a telling blow against superstition on June 19. A total eclipse of the sun will sweep all of Siberia and Central Asia on that day, and every precaution is being taken to prevent a repetition of the panic fear which shook the natives on the last similar occasion in 1887.

AINTREE, England, March 26. -- Steeplechase followers were placing bets thick and fast tonight on American colors for tomorrow's Grand National. In the field named for the classic, there were six American-owned horses among the thirty-five of the best jumpers bred on this side of the Atlantic in many years, and one, Castle Irwell, will be ridden by his owner, G.H. (Pete) Bostwick, star amateur rider.

The WPA organization in this city now has on hand sufficient funds for its operation until July 1 with the 191,000 employes who will remain after 40,000 men have been laid off on orders from Washington. Of this number 12,000 are to be dismissed by Wednesday.

Detective Dominick Pape and Patrolman William Murphy of the East Twenty-second Street station were arrested yesterday afternoon outside the quarters of the New York County grand jury and charged with the theft of $750 from Max W. Federbush, a loose-leaf book dealer at 91 Seventh Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Wholesale prices gained slightly in the week ended on March 21, reversing the trend of the three preceding weeks, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, bases on the 1926 average at 100, rose to 79.3 from 79.2 on March 14.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 26 (AP). -- The Pabst Blue Ribbon five-man team of New York soared into first place in the American Bowling Congress tournament tonight with a 3,065 total. It was the third new leader in as many events.
For the seventh year in a row, Harry Francis Wolf of the New York Athletic Club tops the rankings of the National Squash Tennis Association.

Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, notified District Attorney William C. Dodge yesterday that he had withdrawn his subpoena to question the prosecutor's confidential secretary, Miss Florence Krellberg, in the investigation of the alleged job fixer, Louis Feldstein.
Dwelling deals featured the Manhattan realty turnover reported yesterday.

Earlier in the season a group of Gallic players got together uptown to bring the French word to the local stage. Reorganized as the French Theatre Guild, under distinguished patronage and with a considerably strengthened cast, it presented at the Barbizon-Plaza Theatre last night Felix Gandera's "Atout . . . Coeur" ("Hearts Are Trumps").

A reception and tea marked the opening of the first public exhibition of art by former students of the Friends Seminary, 15 Rutherford Place, yesterday afternoon. The exhibition is one of a series of events in commemoration of the 150th anniversary of the school, founded in 1786.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Friday, March 27 (AP). -- The three-day battle of proxies at the annual meeting of the American Woolen Company was still being waged early today. Following an earlier session, marred by a scuffle, the group resumed at 10 o'clock last night an effort to carry out the program for the election of three directors, a clerk and a treasurer of the corporation.
BERLIN, March 26. -- Dr. Hugo Eckener's two zeppelins, the old Graf Zeppelin and the new LZ-129, started at dawn today on a four- day election propaganda flight over Germany.

Apparently convinced that the World's Fair of 1939 will never materialize, Park Commissioner Moses has decided to proceed with his original plans for completing Grand Central Parkway Extension through the Flushing Meadows in Queens, proposed site of the fair.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- An executive order by President Roosevelt creating a Committee of Industrial Analysis to study the effects of codes upon industrial and labor conditions was made public at the White House.

Up from the South comes Jed Harris with the hint that he may add Philip Barry's new and untitled play to this waning season. If he does, it will be a May production; otherwise, it will go over to next season. There will be a definite decision next Wednesday.

Representatives of railway unions completed yesterday their reply to a proposal by the managements of the railways that employes displaced through consolidations receive six months' pay, or, as an alternative, be placed for two years on half pay, subject to recall.

A period of great growth in public health work, partly stimulated by grants to States under the Federal Social Security Act, was seen yesterday by health authorities, attending the fourteenth annual conference of the Milbank Memorial Fund at the New York Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street.

The concert and dance to be given by the Wellesley College Choir and the Princeton University Glee Club tonight in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria will be preceded by several dinners to be given by the subscribers. The event will benefit the Music Library at Wellesley and the Music Fund of Princeton.

TORONTO, March 26. -- The Toronto Maple Leafs, smashing hockey's greatest defense to bits with an astonishing display of power, overcame the Boston Bruins, 8 -- 3, tonight before a hysterical crowd of 14,000 and qualified for the Stanley Cup semi-finals.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The House approved by a voice vote today a measure extending until April 1, 1937, provisions of Title I and II of the Federal Housing Law and sent it to the Senate, where a compromise is expected within a few days.

Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey spent five hours yesterday in the former Bronx home of Bruno Richard Hauptmann studying the famous "rail 16" of the kidnap ladder. Last night after his return to Trenton he issued a long statement implying doubt that any part of the ladder had come from the Hauptmann home.

ALBANY, March 26. -- Despite a warning by several New York City members that State milk control had increased prices to the consumer, the Senate by a vote of 30 to 13 today passed the bill continuing control and price-fixing law for another year, beginning April 1.

An extra appropriation of $203,474 to provide personnel and material to complete its program of surveying the value and reassessing all property owned by public utilities in New York City is being sought by the Board of Taxes and Assessments.

The new Federal Reserve margin regulations, scrapping the complicated, sliding-scale, "anti-pyramid" schedule of margins in favor of a flat rule, permitting loans up to 45 per cent of the market value of stocks and placing banks and brokers on an equal footing with respect to loans made for the purpose of purchasing or carrying registered stocks, were received favorably in Wall Street yesterday.

Allegations that the assets of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., have been wasted as a result of the purchase of seven music publishing houses were made in the Supreme Court yesterday in a suit by two stockholders, Morris and Emilia Sharof of Roxbury, Mass.

In the presence of what is still truthfully called the European crisis, a vast amount of diplomatic activity is going on. From Rome comes word that Italy and Rumania and Austria have united in a solemn agreement to consult each other before doing anything important in the international field. They would do that anyhow.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- President Roosevelt's tax program took its first real legislative step today when the Ways and Means Committee adopted, without change, the recommendations of its subcommittee on taxation on methods of carrying the new revenue ideas into effect.
