NASSAU, Bahamas, March 26. -- Stanley Ogilvy's Jay of the United States triumphed in the first race of the Spring championship for the Santa Maria Trophy today. Ogilvy's yacht led the Star Class fleet over the ten-mile course in 2:51:31.

LEIPZIG, Germany, March 26. -- Adolf Hitler continued today to hammer into the German mind the simple elements of his appeal in this plebiscite Reichstag election. Appearing in Saxony for the first time this year he again attacked foreign statesmen who wanted to stain Germany's honor; Bolsheviki; Versailles, the former German parties and foreigners who did not believe in his peace pledges.

MOSCOW, March 26. -- A dispatch tonight from Ulan Bator, the Outer Mongolian capital, said guns and airplanes had figured in frontier collisions between Outer Mongolians and a joint Japanese-Manchukuoan detachment during the last three days.

TOKYO, March 26. -- Three Japanese officers and nine men were wounded in the severe engagement between Soviet and Japanese-Manchukuoan forces on the eastern border of Manchukuo near Hunchun yesterday.

MEXICO, D.F., March 26. -- In the worst accident in the history of Mexican aviation fourteen persons, including ten European passengers, were killed this morning when the plane in which they were traveling from this capital to the capital of Guatemala crashed forty miles from here.

The report of the Stewart-Warner Corporation for 1935, issued yesterday, showed earnings three times as large as those of 1934. Consolidated net income after all charges, including depreciation and Federal taxes, was $1,724,313. This was equivalent to $1.39 a share on the 1,241,847 shares of common stock outstanding in the hands of the public at the close of the year.

George Grosz, German painter and caricaturist, whose satirical drawings have been published in book form Under the title of "Ecce Homo," has completed sixty drawings' for a new book "Interregnum," which will be published on May 1 by Caresse Crosby of the Black Sun Press.

BADAJOZ, Spain, March 26 (AP). -- The Left Spanish Government took swift action tonight to eject 60,000 squatters who took over large farmlands in this area, impatient at the government's delay in the program of breaking up big estates.

In keeping with other activity in the realty field, building projects continued in volume yesterday. Reflecting greater travel and business expansion, several gasoline station plans were submitted, and the basic industrial improvement was marked by a $110,000 factory project for Queens.

The brisk demand for the guaranteed bonds of the United States Government, including the Home Owners Loan Corporation and Federal Farm Mortgage obligations, were a feature in the otherwise quiet and routine trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.
ENID, Okla., March 26. -- A darkening dust storm billowed eastward from Oklahoma tonight while midwinter weather nipped at the West's budding Spring crops.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -"Bottle babies," predicted by Aldous Huxley for the distant future in a "brave new world" where children will be born in test tubes, have been brought at least part way toward actuality by Dr. Gregory Pincus at the Harvard Biological Institute.

CAMDEN, S.C., March 26. -- With the largest number of entries in history and expectations of a record attendance, the seventh annual Carolina Cup meet, to be run over the Springvale course Saturday, will be attended by circumstances of unparalleled interest.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 26. -- Overcoming serious challenges in their semi-final matches, Miss Jane Cothran of Greenville, S.C., and Miss Peggy Wattles of Buffalo, N.Y., today entered the championship round of the sixth annual women's Augusta invitation tournament.

On the witness stand in General Sessions Court this morning Miss Vera Stretz will try to justify the killing of Dr. Fritz Gebhardt, German industrialist who was found with four bullets in his body early on the morning of Nov. 12 in his apartment in Beekman Tower, 3 Mitchell Place.

Bank clearings rose 7.3 per cent in the week ended on Wednesday, making $5,372,442,000 for the twenty-two leading cities in the United States reporting to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This compared with $5,006,828,000 a year ago and with an increase of 20.4 per cent in the preceding week.

ROME, March 26. -- Crown Princess Marie Jose received an overwheling sendoff from the populace of Naples when she embarked this evening for East Africa aboard the hospital ship Cesarea, on which she is to serve as a nurse.
HSINKING, Manchukuo, March 26. -- Another frontier clash between Japanese and Outer Mongolians was reported today in a communigue issued by the Kwantung army.
Flood-relief contributions sent yesterday to the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross aggregated nearly $43,930, bringing the chapter's total to $331,800.05.

With the twelve members of the Intercollegiate Fencing Association entering approximately 150 swordsmen, the forty-third annual championships, team and individual, will get under way at 10 o'clock this morning in the Hotel Biltmore's main ballroom, which will be a converted salle d'armes until tomorrow evening.

Brokers estimated yesterday that the Federal Reserve Board's abandonment of its complicated "three-prong" formula in favor of a flat percentage basis of calculation of margins would reduce the amount of clerical work in the average firm by about 20 per cent.
I have been pondering over President Roosevelt's contention, in a recent speech, that "social and political methods must change continually, else they grow stagnant."

ROCHESTER, March 26 (AP). -- The Genesee River today exceeded last July's flood mark by eighteen inches as eight feet of water swept over the dam at Mount Morris. The mark was the highest in ten years.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP). -- Compensation of executives of various companies in New York State in 1934 was reported today to Congress by Secretary Morgenthau as follows:

A further decline of $80,000,000 in the excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve was reported for the week ended on Wednesday in the Federal Reserve statements published yesterday. Following a reduction of $620,000,000 the previous week, this week's decline carried the total of excess reserves down to $2,310,000,000, or precisely $1,000,000,000 below the high record established on Dec. 11 last.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Justice Stone, in the minority AAA decision, warned his colleagues that an "interpretation of our great charter which proceeds on any assumption" that a particular government branch was anointed to save the other two, and the Constitution along with them, was more likely to obliterate than to preserve the balance in our national system.
U. S. Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

LONDON, March 26. -- Ambassador-at-Large Norman H. Davis and the rest of the United States delegation boarded the liner Washington at Southampton tonight on their way home almost four months after coming to London to negotiate a new naval treaty.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 26 (AP). -- Hank Greenberg, last of the important holdouts, signed a contract to play first base for the world champion Tigers after a long conference with club officials tonight.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 26. -- Uncorking five runs in the ninth inning, the final two riding home on the crest of a rousing two-base smash against the right field fence by Sambo Leslie, the Giants today sent the Cubs on their way in a frame of mind not likely to inspire overconfidence in the National League champions on their 1936 pennant prospects.

What Mr. Toscanini had accomplised with Wagner at the Pension Fund concert on Wednesday evening he accomplished with Schumann when he interpreted the "Manfred" overture at the concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra given last night in Carnegie Hall.

In an opinion characterizing Park Commissioner Robert Moses as "the passing creature of a day," Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew granted a temporary injunction yesterday restraining him from tearing down the Central Park Casino to make a children's playground.
ALBANY, March 26. -- Governor Lehman issued a proclamation today setting aside the week of April 1 as Conservation Week and urging special ceremonies to stress conservation work. He said:

LONDON, March 26. -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, in a debate on foreign affairs in the House of Commons today, took Parliament and the public into his confidence in telling what the British Government had done so far and was still trying to do to avert a European war.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- On receiving word this afternoon of court actions against it in Philadelphia by three corporations to restrain it from making public salaries and other data filed with the request that the information be considered confidential, the Securities and Exchange Commission prepared to contest the suits.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- A drive to remove inefficient job supervisors from WPA projects, including some political hirelings who have crept into administrative positions, has been ordered by Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator.
ALBANY, March 26. -- Democratic leaders in the Legislature prepared today to make a new overture to the Republicans in the budget deadlock which has gripped the two houses for several weeks.

MONTREAL, March 26. -- Detroit took a firm hold on the National Hockey League championship tonight by defeating the Maroons, 3 -- 0, in a bruising battle that was waged evenly for 49 minutes until Syd Howe tallied while Dave Trottier was in the penalty box.

CHICAGO, March 26. -- Scattered liquidation and pressure from houses with Southwestern connections dropped the price of May wheat on the Board of Trade today to the lowest mark since early in December and that of the September to the lowest point of the season to date, but an oversold condition developed after commission houses had absorbed the offerings of resting orders and the close was unchanged to 1/4 cent a bushel higher than yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company of San Francisco, a subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $30,000,000 of refunding mortgage bonds, Series B, due on April 1, 1966, at the low interest rate of 3 1/4 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- President Roosevelt has created a Committee of Industrial Analysis which will begin on April 1 to summarize the accomplishments of the National Recovery Administration. This was announced at the White House today when a copy of the President's executive order was made public.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 26. -- This town is all agog over a hunt for a mustache cup to be presented, when, as and if found, to Stanley George Bordagaray of the bewildering Brooklyn Dodgers.

BARTOW, Fla., March 26. -- The long shadow of a former Dodger was cast over Manager Stengel's athletes this afternoon as the Rochester Red Wings, performing before a small but loyal band of rooters, defeated the Flatbush boys, 6 to 2.

The following film programs, which will be shown over the weekend, have been endorsed by the schools motion picture committee, a voluntary organization of faculty members and parents of children in public and private schools:

CHICAGO, March 26. -- The New York Americans were outscored by the Chicago Black Hawks tonight, 5 goals to 4, but that little matter failed to worry Red Dutton and his skaters, for they emerged the winners anyway.

Polo's only interscholastic championship event will take place tomorrow night at the Squadron A Armory when New York's indoor season comes to a close with both the schoolboy and college title games. Army, victor in 1935, will oppose Yale in a battle for the college laurels.
With the foregoing changes yesterday's statement, which covers the actual position of the bank at the end of last week, compares as follows with reports for previous weeks, in millions of francs:

VIENNA, March 26. -- A special tax on every insurance company operating in Austria, to be passed on, after pay-cut economies, to insured persons in the form of an increase in premiums and a reduction of the sums paid in settlement of claims, will be imposed to make up the deficiency in premium reserves of the Austrian Phoenix Life Insurance Society.

Another supper dance in the series of "Get-Together Dances" directed by Miss Edith Massena Benjamin for future debutantes and their young men friends was held last night in the main ballroom of the Pierre. Mrs. James Lenox Banks Jr. was chairman and Mrs. Henry B.H. Ripley, vice chairman, of the reception committee.

The Bank of China of Shanghai, China's leading commercial bank and the institution through which the Nanking Government manages its new paper-standard currency, has applied to the State Banking Department for permission to establish an agency in this city, it was announced yesterday by Thomas E. Huser, counsel to the bank here.

ALBANY, March 26 (AP). -- Dr. Frank P. Graves, State Commissioner of Education, declared today that the size of classes in the elementary public schools of New York City was a matter wholly within the jurisdiction of the city Board of Education.

In addition to numerous Garment Center rentals, midtown business leases reported yesterday included an expansion move by an advertising agency. A three-block move in the downtown area by a travel agency also was reported.

PITTSBURGH, March 26. -- This great industrial city, paralyzed a little more than a week ago by the worst flood in its history, was getting out of the mud and the darkness which the receding rivers left behind them today, and its business leaders predicted a boom which would soon take it "out of the red."

The Notre Dame Study Club, meeting last night at the Church of Notre Dame, 114th Street and Morningside Drive, called upon every Catholic parish group in the United States to support the Catholic Church's efforts to get social justice for the Negro.
Mayor La Guardia called the public's attention yesterday to the events for Music Festival Week, which will begin on Monday.
MARIETTA, Ohio, March 26 (AP). -- A fresh flood crest of the Ohio River moved slowly toward Marietta tonight, while in its upper reaches the river receded slightly.

BERLIN, March 26. -- Chancellor Hitler's constant insistence in his election speeches that German honor takes the precedence over treaty paragraphs receives note-worthy application in the reaction of the German press to measures taken by neighboring states against alleged National Socialist activities within their borders.
" Winterset," Maxwell Anderson's poetic play -- the theme of which had been suggested by the Sacco-Vanzetti case -- won yesterday the first annual prize awarded by the New York Drama Critics Circle.

It has been an open secret for some time that morale in the Air Corps has been under unnecessary strain, due to inequalities of the temporary promotion plan, a lack of flying officer personnel and restriction of flight pay for certain classes of senior officers who have been officially "grounded" as pilots due to various physical disabilities, although they have continued to fly as observers.

Major Gen. Frank Parker, who just returned from the Philippines to assume command of the First Division recently, inspected the Sixteenth Infantry at Governors Island yesterday. A tea and reception followed at the Officers Club as a "hail and farewell" to the general and his family.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 26. -- On the yacht Day Dream, on which he is passing several weeks in Lake Worth with his parents, Mr. and Mrs. William S. Gubelmann, Walter Stanley Gubelmann was host to many of the younger set today for dancing.

Today's new films are "Moonlight Murder," with Chester Morris and Madge Evans, at the Rialto, and "Dancing Feet," with Ben Lyon, Joan Marsh and Eddie Nugent, at the Roxy. "Boulder Dam," featuring Ross Alexander and Patricia Ellis, opens tonight at the Astor.
BRUSSELS, March 26. -- It is the fate of Belgium not only to stand between France and Germany but in the present crisis to hold the balance between France and Great Britain.

With the early trout opening in New York State, anglers who fare-forth for the first day's fishing generally find the streams moderately high and the water temperatures low. The surface water may register around 48 degrees, as was the case last year in the Croton watershed.

To whatever extent the investigation of the Townsend Plan by a committee of the House is judicial, semi-judicial or purely political without being partisan, philological and sociological interest justifies a reference to the question put yesterday by the committee's counsel to Mr. CLEMENTS, formerly the secretary of Dr. TOWNSEND'S Old Age Revolving Pension Organization.

LOS ANGELES, March 26. -- Another eight-ship construction program of express silk freighters for transpacific services of Kawasaki Kisen Kaisha has been revealed here by Captain Shojo Hagao, who brought the twenty-three-knot K line tanker silk carrier Tatekawa Maru in from Japan.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 26. -- Practically every outstanding college swimmer in the country had! checked in at New Haven tonight for the thirteenth annual Nationl al Collegiate Athletic Association j championships, which will be held~ tomorrow and Saturday in the Payne ~Vhitney Pool.

Pleas for continued financial aid for the maintenance of Jewish children in Palestine were made yesterday at the close of the Winter campaign conducted by Hadassah, Women's Zionist Organization of America.
LONDON, March 26 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

ADDIS ABABA, March 26. -- Harar was reconnoitered by Italian planes this afternoon. Neither there nor in Addis Ababa, however, has confirmation been received of a reported Italian advance in the Fafan Valley in the south. All remains quiet on land on the northern front.

MIAMI, March 26. -- President Roosevelt set a new distance mark for his Winter fishing cruises today when he sailed the new Presidential yacht Potomac to West Caicos Island, which lies in the extreme southeastern portion of the Bahamas, north of the Dominican Republic.
LONDON, March 26. -- Following are important excerpts from Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's speech to the House of Commons today on the German reoccupation of the Rhineland:
WARSAW, March 26 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency). -- The Senate enacted today a law prohibiting Jews from selling vegetables and dairy products. It had been passed by the Sejm (lower house) last week.
The Long Island Lighting Company's report for 1935, issued yesterday, contained the following comparable figures for last year and 1934:

Shorter working hours and an increase in pay for musicians engaged in broadcasting for the three major networks is embodied in a new two-year agreement between the radio chains and the Musicians Union, Local 802, it was announced yesterday by Jacob Rosenberg, secretary of the union.

A rise in the number of women admitted to Bellevue Hospital for alcoholism to 17.9 per cent of each 1,000 population in 1934 and 1935 is reported in the current issue of Science by Norman Jolliffe. He adds, however, that this "is too brief an experience from which a significant change in the trend may be predicted."

PARIS, March 26. -- Anthony Eden's speech in the House of Commons today, it is believed, will do something to allay the irritation and alarm which have been felt here since it was realized that British opinion did not see eye to eye with France regarding what should be done about the German reoccupation of the Rhineland.

MEMPHIS, March 26. -- Willingness of bankers to extend every reasonable credit to agriculture and to replace the work of many governmental agencies which have functioned during the depression was pledged tonight by speakers at the Southern Conference on Banking Service.

A plea for realism and the abandonment of the "big brother" idea in favor of neighborliness in dealing with the problem of peace in the Western Hemisphere was made yesterday by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt as the speaker of the "Pan-American Day" celebration of the Pan-American Students League at Washington Irving High School, Irving Place and Seventeenth Street.

The Ways and Means Committee has accepted the report of its subcommittee on taxation. This report strikes out all mention of the agricultural processing taxes recommended by the President. A valid defense could be made of such an action if a substitute tax had been provided.

The 93-foot triple-screw Diesel yacht Semloh, costing more than $200,000, was launched yesterday at the yacht yard of Henry B. Nevins at City Island, where the rakish craft was under construction the last eight months.
WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The report of the House Ways and Means subcommittee on the proposed Tax Bill reads as follows:

Miss Mary W. Dewson, chairman of the advisory committee of the women's division, Democratic National Committee, who has just returned from a nine-week tour through fifteen Western and Midwestern States, said yesterday that the women voters in those sections were enthusiastically for President Roosevelt's re-election.

PHILADELPHIA, March 26. -- Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, warned tonight that American schools and colleges "serve society in a sorry manner if we help to produce leaders who are unprincipled, able and efficient men who are selfish and anti-social in their attitude."

Some irregularity developed in the trading on the local commodity futures markets yesterday, but price changes were small and the volume of trading in general was moderate. On the cash markets, wheat, corn, oats, cotton, lard and cocoa advanced, and rye, butter, eggs, wool-tops, standard tin and rubber declined.

The severity of the past Winter brings to mind the real need for effective general means for indoor exercise and recreational facilities. The annual expenditure for parks, playgrounds and amusement facilities increases from year to year. But in Summer the whole family will, and health statistics indicate they do, find ways to get out and get exercise.

Irregularities again marked the commodity price movement last week and The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices was unchanged on Tuesday at 125.3 (revised). Grain prices were lower except for oats; butter declined, cheese lost ground; cocoa, coffee and bananas were lower, and tin dropped.

For the third evening this week Madison Square Garden was filled to capacity for another performance of the International Figure Skating Carnival. The total attendance of 48,000 for the three nights is something new, even for sports-loving New York.

OTTAWA, March 26 (Canadian Press). -- Deposits by the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada increased $3,910,727 and deposits by chartered banks decreased $3,910,547 in the week ended yesterday, the bank reported today. The statement follows:

AMECAMECA, Mexico, March 26. -- The ten European tourists who were killed in an airplane crash near here today were on their way home via Central America after a Mexican visit. Hurtling down on the snow-clad bridge between Popocatepetl and Ixtaccihuatl volcanoes, the plane scattered its wreckage over the mountainous plateau.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass, March 26. -- Seventy-five prominent scientists and scholars, among them fourteen Nobel Prize winners, will meet here for the Harvard Tercentenary Conference of Arts and Sciences from Aug. 31 to Sept. 12, Jerome D. Greene, director of the tercentenary celebration, announced this evening.
None of the items in yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks reached a new high or low point for the year, but the ratio of reserve for the New York bank was at the lowest for 1936.

The Delaware Hudson Company reported for 1935 a net loss of $3,062,876, compared with a net loss of $1,738,726 in 1934. This increased deficit resulted from larger losses by the Delaware Hudson Railroad and Hudson Coal Company.

With the March position off the board, traders on the Cotton Exchange centered attention yesterday on the May delivery, which advanced to its best price since Jan. 1 25. In contrast with the improvement in near months, however, the new crop was under pressure and the list ended with a gain of 6 points to a loss of 7 points.

TAMPA, Fla., March 26. -- Probable lines of defense and prosecution in the series of kidnapping and murder cases growing out of the fatal flogging of Joseph Shoemaker last November were indicated by opposing attorneys' questions to prospective jurors today as the first of the trials, that of three former Tampa policemen charged with the kidnapping of Eugene F. Poulnot, got under way.

Two different elements have been troubling the waters in Spain since the recent general election. One may be called almost purely political. The party in power, which was a Right and Center party, with a strong infusion of Catholics, had treated with great rigor their Left opponents.

The Kennecott Copper Corporation reported yesterday for 1935 consolidated net income of 913,164,571 after charges, taxes and depreciation, but before depletion. This was equal to $1.22 a share on the 10,773,485 common shares outstanding.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP). -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee today exonerated Hugh S. Gibson, United States Ambassador to Brazil, of any responsibility for the arrest and death of Victor A. Barron, American Communist, who allegedly killed himself in Rio de Janeiro on March 5 while in the custody of the Brazilian police.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended March 25, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,504,000,000, an increase of $26,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $46,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1935.

AINTREE, England, March 26 (Canadian Press). -- Golden Miller was still "the tops" tonight on the eve of the ninety-eight running of the Grand National -- sternest test the world has to offer in the way of horse racing.

A plan for the reorganization of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad is to be filed by May 1, L.W. Baldwin, chairman of the board, said yesterday. He made the announcement after a conference between officers of the company and representatives of insurance companies and other large bondholders in the company's office here.

Although industrial activity again declined in February, according to the monthly survey of the National Industrial Conference Board, there was some improvement during the first two weeks of March. Output in February, the board reported yesterday, remained higher than for any month in the first half of 1935.

MIAMI, Fla., March 26. -- Backers of short-priced horses met with a severe setback in the Mermaid Handicap, one-mile feature for fillies and mares, today at the Tropical Park when C.V. Whitney's two-time winner, Hollyhock, 4-to-5-shot, met with defeat.

ALBANY, March 26. -- Taking Assemblyman Herbert Brownell to task for criticizing Governor Lehman on his attitude toward the World's Fair, the eight Democratic legislators from Queens issued a joint statement today praising the Governor's stand.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 26. -- One of the most prolonged holdout situations that Manager Joe McCarthy has faced since he assumed the leadership of the Yankees ended tonight. Charley (Red) Ruffing, right-hander from Nokomis, Ill., signed a contract to pitch through the approaching championship season after losing twenty-five days of the club's training siege here.

MOSCOW, March 26. -- The prospect of a reduction in Soviet prices, which on most goods are exorbitantly high, was seen today in statistics showing a remarkable gain in the production of foodstuffs and light industry products and in preparation for further increasing production rapidly this year.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Robert E. Clements, 43-year-old cofounder of the Townsend $200-a-month old-age pension plan, entered no denial today when he was told, while testifying before a special House committee, that one State manager was drawing down fees of from $1,800 to $2,000 a month.

GENEVA, March 26. -- Germany and Japan are the only great powers that remain silent and non-cooperative toward the convention for the use of broadcasting in the cause of peace, on which the League of Nations has been working for three years.

The Norman Thomas faction of the Socialist party won a victory over the "old guard" Socialist group headed by Louis Waldman yesterday when the Appellate Division reversed the decision of Supreme Court Justice Hofstadter and restored the names of 173 Thomas designees for county committeemen in the Bronx to the ballots for the county primaries April 2.

Urging American women to make a more careful appraisal of the value of adult education, the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs held an all-day symposium yesterday in the Hotel Commodore at which a number of educators, administrators of WPA projects and lay authorities discussed the subject.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP). -- New York City in a sharply worded brief asked the Supreme Court today to grant a review and find constitutional the New York State Minimum Wage Law for women and children.

Larry Cowell, former Penn State star, representing the West Side Y.M.C.A., scored two impressive victories in the 145-pound division as the Olympic semi-final wrestling tryouts for the metropolitan district started at the New York Athletic Club last night.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman attacked Speaker Irving M. Ives of the Assembly and other legislators who have blocked his anti-crime bills last night in an address before the Association of Grand Jurors of New York County at the Hotel Waldorf Astoria.

The International Mercantile Marine Company announced last night the sale of the Panama Pacific liner Columbia to Douglas Ramsey of Glasgow. The ship was retired from active service in the late Summer of 1935 and has been tied up at Pier 62, North River.
ALBANY, March 26. -- A new deadlock between the Democratic Senate and the Republican Assembly is looming up, this time over the Governor's eight-point social security program.

BERLIN, March 26. -- The Boerse was relatively inactive at the opening today, although fairly firm, while scattered signs of weakness appeared near the close. The market continues under complete official control.

Companies and services in the flood areas used newspaper space to broadcast a variety of information, a cheek-up yesterday revealed. Space was taken to advise of change of address, efforts to continue deliveries of foodstuffs and "no interruption of services."
Henry P. Fry's letter hits the bull's eye in its estimate of the Versailles treaty and its war-breeding effect, but he cannot show that Germany signed the Locarno pact "under duress."

The Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania has declared a quarterly dividend of $2 a share on the common stock, placing the stock on an $8 annual basis, against $6 previously paid. All the common stock is owned by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Debate on the possibilities of a national flood control program to prevent disasters such as swept many sections of the Eastern part of the country last week, occupied most of the time of the Senate today. Senator Davis introduced a new bill to authorize the Federal Government to lend up to $50,000,000 for the restoration of buildings and equipment damaged by the inundations.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The intrusion of government into competition with private enterprise, "except in situations where the public welfare can only thus be served, is wholly destructive," according to the Committee on Government Competition with Private Enterprise, it was announced today by George L. Berry, Coordinator of Industrial Cooperation.

Characterizing the case as "a scandal that lays itself at the door of the Motor Vehicle Bureau," Magistrate Charles Solomon, in Brooklyn Traffic Court, yesterday canceled the license of a driver whose mental age he placed at 7 years.

Eleven parcels were bought in by plaintiffs at Manhattan foreclosure auctions yesterday. The majority of the properties taken over by the mortgagees comprised apartment houses and dwellings on the upper West Side. The results were as follows:

Excavation was completed yesterday in preparation for an immediate start on the steel work of the large Rockefeller apartment buildings which will rise at 17-23 West Fifty-fourth Street and 24-36 West Fifty-fifth Street, north of Rockefeller Center.

New and important evidence has been uncovered in the investigation of the bribery phase of the Drukman murder case, Hiram C. Todd. special prosecutor, disclosed yesterday in obtaining a postponement of the trial of Henry G. Singer, former chief Assistant District Attorney in Brooklyn.

The comebacks of Frederick S. Moseley Jr., former Harvard football back, and W.A.W. Stewart Jr. featured play in the national amateur court tennis championship at the Racquet and Tennis Club yesterday as they gained the semi-final round with Ogden Phipps, defending titleholder, and James H. Van Alern.
Mr. Fry claims to have no interest in Germany or in any other country in Europe, but in perusing his letter one is immediately struck with his championing of Germany and lashing out at France.

LONDON, March 26. -- Queen Mary paid a surprise visit to doomed Adelphi Terrace and the arches this afternoon to see David Garrick's house and other famous buildings for a last time before they are demolished.

Engineering construction operations during the past week showed an aggregate cost volume of $34,111,000, as compared with $33,606,000 for the preceding week, The Engineering News-Record reports. For the corresponding week one year ago the volume was $18,584,000.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas showed a rise of 15 per cent for the week ended March 21, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The increase is the largest for any week thus far this year and compares with a gain of 10 per Cent for the preceding week.

For years we have been told by the Fascist dictator that Italy was doomed to "expand or to explode" due to her need of raw materials. The aggression against Ethiopia has somehow been justified by this questionable reason.
CHICAGO, March 26 (AP). -- Discovery of a toy jewel setting in the heart of new-born child was reported today by the London correspondent of The Journal of the American Medical Association.

PHILADELPHIA, March 26. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission was ordered by the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals here today not to make public the salaries of officers, directors and employes of the National Biscuit Company, the P. Lorillard Company and Congoleum-Nairn, Inc.

Captain Ralph E. Fleischer took the witness stand in his own defense yesterday afternoon and for almost three hours made an emphatic and detailed denial of all the charges for which he is being tried by general court-martial at Governors Island.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 26. -- California Republicans will have two tickets of national convention delegates on their Presidential primary ballot May 5 and the Democrats have three slates of candidates.

Trading in stocks yesterday continued to be mainly professional in character. Following a higher opening, the market picked up strength in the forenoon, then turned dull and sold off during the final hour. The closing was irregular. Sales on the Stock Exchange amounted to 1,872,000 shares, compared with 1,907,000 the day before.

Despite a city ordinance which prohibits the killing of hawks, the pastor and congregation of the Riverside Church at Riverside Drive and 122d Street are seeking an expert hawk hunter. For some time a pigeon hawk has been swooping down on the tower of the huge church and killing off the pigeons which use the cupolas as a sanctuary.

The Harris Trust and Savings Bank and the Mercantile-Commerce Bank and Trust Company obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $840,000 of advancement fund bonds of Marion County, Indiana, on their bid of 100.537 for 2s. The bonds will be dated April 10, 1936, and mature on June 1 and Dec. 1, 1937 to 1946.
In his address before the Association of Grand Jurors of New York County last night, Governor Lekman said:
The Federal Government served notice on Park Commissioner Moses yesterday that it proposed to collect an income tax on the $10,000 salary he received as commissioner in 1934.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- To reduce further the fixed charges on its obligations in the favorable money market, the Kingdom of Norway filed today a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1983 for the issuance of $31,500,000 of twenty-nine-year 4 1/4 per cent sinking fund external loan bonds due on April 1, 1985.
WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The Black Senate lobby investigating committee today challenged the jurisdiction of the District Supreme Court to interfere with its activities.
It seems to me that had Henry P. Fry reflected, he would have realized that his analogy of the present state of Europe to post-Civil War conditions in the South goes far to disprove his own case.

The Gotham Silk Hosiery Company, Inc., will redeem on April 27 its ten-year 6 per cent debentures, due on Dec. 1, 1936, at par and accrued interest. Payment will be made at the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company.

Now that Summer is so definitely around the corner, the theatre is beginning again to think of vacation. Not every show has to worry about July, to be certain, but a few are already brooding over plans for cooling systems, lay-offs and the like.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- The National Dairy Products Corporation filed today an amendment to its registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 for the issuance of $62,545,500 of 3 3/4 per cent debentures due in 1951, with common stock warrants.

The Long Island Railroad announces several changes in the operation of fishermen's excursion specials for the coming season that will be of interest to metropolitan anglers who travel to Montauk and Peconic Bay. Last year more than 36,000 persons were transported on these trains.
St. Joseph's Convert, a landmark in Flushing, Queens, has been placed on the market for $1,000,000, the Halleran Agency reported yesterday.

Joseph H. Appel has resigned as executive manager of John Wanamaker New York and has been elected a member of the board of directors, it was announced yesterday by William L. Nevin, president. Mr. Appel has been connected with the Wanamaker organization in New York and Philadelphia for more than thirty-six years.

CHICAGO, March 27. -- New York was listed today as the "safest" of the nation's most populous communities by the National Safety Council, which released figures showing that motor vehicle deaths in the United States during February were about 1,950, a decrease of 13 per cent from February, 1935.

Public health authorities, meeting at the annual conference of the Milbank Memorial Fund at the New York Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street, were told yesterday that 25,000 to 30,000 lives might be saved annually in the country if inexpensive or free pneumonia serum were generally and quickly available.

PRAGUE, March 27. -- Far-reaching powers would be conferred upon the Czechoslovak Government by a bill introduced in Parliament in the event of war or mobilization or when within the country or on its frontiers events occurred seriously threatening the nation's unity, its republican constitution or public order.
CHICAGO, March 27. -- Five Middle Western farm publications were ordered today to pay damages of $37,000 for violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Law in restraint of trade and normal competition.

March winds slapped rain against the dusty windows in darkened General Sessions Court all day yesterday as Miss Vera Stretz, on trial for the murder of Dr. Fritz Gebhardt, told judge, jury and an audience of 300 the story of her life and of her relationship with Dr. Gebhardt.
Expansion leases in several boroughs of the city and in the suburbs were included in the business rentals reported yesterday, as follows:

Police of half a dozen precincts were busy yesterday trailing a hold-up man who made six calls on chain stores within four hours. At one of these stops, Ninth Avenue and Fifteenth Street, a clerk was stabbed.

TORONTO, March 27. -- The New York Americans, elated at having survived the third place play-off round in the race for the Stanley Cup and the world's hockey championship, arrived here tonight, ready for their series with the surprising Toronto Maple Leafs.

Dry goods wholesalers in areas not affected by the floods were reported yesterday to have enjoyed a substantial volume of business in the last few days from their retail accounts. The long pent-up Spring demand has finally been released, it was said, and stores, encouraged by the advent of milder weather, are covering their needs.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 27. -- The seventy-two holes of the North and South open golf championship were not enough to bring forth a new champion, for at the end of today's third and fourth rounds there was a tie at 288 between Henry Picard of Hershey, Pa., and Ray Mangrum, unattached pro, who originally hailed from Dallas, Texas.

CHICAGO, March 27. -- The market for hogs developed a decidedly easier undertone here today, with the shipping demand relatively slow. Early sales were steady to 10 cents a hundredweight lower, but prices continued on the down-grade, and at the last business was being transacted at 10 to 15 cents decline.

Two professionals, James T. Reid Jr. of the Crescent athletic-Hamilton Club and L.T. Collins of the Harmonie Club, vanquished two amateurs from the New York A.C. to gain semi-final brackets in the world's open squash tennis championship at the Hotel Shelton last night.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- An estimate of 12,550,000 unemployed in the United States in February, a reduction of 214,000 from February, 1935, was made by an American Federation of Labor report given out today by President William Green.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- A battle between Tammany Hall and the Roosevelt administration over a bill to create two additional Federal judgeships urged for the Southern District of New York came into the open in the Senate today and was checked only by an agreement to vote Thursday on the measure.
LONDON, March 27. -- Lovers of Charles Dickens's writings began a whole week of thanksgiving today for an event that occurred 100 years ago and brought immeasurable joy to the human race.
Value of Dollar in Exchange The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, eomDares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

A proposed amendment to the new minimum basic agreement of the Dramatists Guild which would eliminate the disputed sliding scale for the distribution of "film money" between playwright and manager, and substitute instead a straight 60-40 split with the playwright getting the larger share, was unanimously favored at a general meeting of the Guild yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Biltmore.

Salvatore Citarelli Jr., liquor-store dealer, of 548 West 148th Street, was convicted before Magistrate Mogelesky on Sunday, July 29, last, and fined $5 for violating the Sunday Law by having his store painted. The Appellate Division reversed the conviction yesterday and ordered a new trial on the ground that the magistrate had no right to hear the case on Sunday.

CINCINNATI, March 27 (AP). -- For the first time in history the Ohio River stood above flood stage today along its entire 981 miles from Pittsburgh to Cairo, Ill. However, a forecast of fair weather allayed fears tonight of greater floods as residents along tributary rivers deserted their homes before advancing tides.

Several dinners were given last night in the Sert and Empire Rooms of the Waldorf-Astoria before the concert and dance of the Wellesley College choir and Princeton University Glee Club in the grand ballroom. The proceeds of the joint event will be used to aid the college music library and the glee club music fund.
CLEVELAND, March 27 (AP). -- In a will filed today the late Charles Lehman Richman, vice chairman of the board of Richman Bros. Company, disposed of an estate of more than $1,500,000.

Joseph (Joie) Rao, Harlem gangster, was held in bail of $1,000 yesterday when arraigned with two companions before Magistrate Adolph Stern in Harlem Court on charges of vagrancy. The other two men, Charles Lanza, 28 years old, of 777 Adee Avenue, the Bronx, and Charles Alberto, 33, of 2,455 Amsterdam Avenue, were held in bail of $500.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- Testimony that the income of the Townsend Plan from dues and other sources from its formation to the present time had amounted to about $952,000 was given today by Robert E. Clements, co-founder and recently resigned secretary of the organization, before a House investigating committee.

" One egg, one embryo, one adult -- normality," explains the Director of Hatcheries and Conditioning in ALDOUS HUXLEY'S "Brave New World." A hypothetical Bokanovsky changed all that. "A bokanovskified egg will bud, "will proliferate, will divide. * * * "Making ninety-six human beings "grow where only one grew before.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- A decision by Eastern railroad heads to ask the Interstate Commerce Commission for a postponement of its order reducing passenger fares and for authority to establish experimental fares, presumably on a higher basis than those ordered, was announced today by F.E. Williamson, president of the New York Central Railroad, following a meeting of the executives here.

BERLIN, March 27. -- The Boerse failed again today to develop any significant tendency and interest was centered on specialties. The market continues to be dominated by officially dictated political considerations.

LONDON, March 27. -- Joachim von Ribbentrop, Chancellor Adolf Hitler's Ambassador at Large, flew back to Berlin today, taking the news that Anglo-French general staff talks would be begun with the least possible delay.

Under the stimulus of broadening pre-Easter buying, retail sales this week mounted to a new high for the year, gains of 20 to 30 per cent over the previous week's volume being reported in some cities, according to the weekly survey of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The proposed dissolution of White Stanley and the formation of Stanley, Janeway Howe by Julian C. Stanley, Edward G. Janeway, Nathaniel S. Howe and Thomas S. Adams Jr. was announced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. Several other firm changes also were made public by the Exchange.

AINTREE, England, March 27. -- A chorus from 250,000 throats welled over Aintree's sun-drenched countryside today as Major Noel Furlong's Reynoldstown, gallant 9-year-old Irish jumper, won the ninety-eighth running of the Grand National Steeplechase.

Indoor polo comes to a close in New York City tonight with two championship finals at Squadron A Armory, Ninety-fourth Street and Madison Avenue. In the opener, starting at 8:30 o'clock, the school championship of the year will be at stake in the contest between Lawrenceville School of New Jersey and Culver Military Academy of Indiana.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 27. -- The Yankees were trailing by two runs in the ninth inning today, when Frankie Crosetti hit a home run with two on, sending the Boston Bees to defeat. The score was 4 to 3, for the New Yorkers' third straight victory over the Bees.

Grace Moore the singer; Colonel Jacques Balsan and Mrs. Balsan, who is the former Consuelo Vanderbilt; Countess Charlotte Dandini de Sylva and Countess Elena Dandini de Sylva are among the passengers sailing today for Mediterranean ports on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia.

In contrast with selling pressure on new crop cotton contracts, active covering advanced the near months sharply on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and the list ended with a gain of 14 points to a loss of 2 points. With the producers' pool holding 200,000 bales of May and 317,000 of July and only 31,000 bales of certificated cotton at the eight delivery markets, trade interests again retired obligations with stimulating effect on prices.

Twenty-three Catholic general and special hospitals in the New York Archdiocese during 1935 sustained an operating deficit of $292,438, it is disclosed in the annual report made public today by the Very Rev. Mgr. John F. Brady, director of the division of health of the Catholic Charities of New York.

The pamphlet report of the United Gas Improvement Company for 1935, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income of $29,214,258, a decrease of $2,249,492 from 1934, and a balance, after preferred dividends, equal to $1.09 each on 23,251,755 shares of common stock, compared with $1.19 a share the year before.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 27. -- Van Lingle Mungo, the big fireball hurler once more or less facetiously referred to as "the Dodger pitching staff," apparently aspires to be at least one-third of Manager Stengel's starting pitchers.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Patrol wagons were busy all day yesterday making trips between a five-story loft building at 718 East Eleventh Street, near Avenue D. and the Sheriff Street Police Station. Their mission was the removal from a top floor loft of huge quantities of obscene books, pamphlets, comic strips, pictures and playing cards.

TRENTON, N.J., March 27. -- The Bruno Richard Hauptmann case brought forth a series of stinging attacks and replies today as the long smoldering fight between Governor Harold G. Hoffman and the prosecution officials broke into the open.

A statement made by State Industrial Commissioner ELMER F. ANDREWS maintains that New York State's relative industrial position has not declined since the depression or even since 1904. This confutes with supporting statistics the assertions which have been widely made that there has been an exodus of industry to other States in recent years.

MOSCOW, Saturday, March 28. -- The third serious clash within three days on the Manchurian border occurred yesterday. In it three of a party of five horsemen, who were alleged to have invaded a Soviet island on the River Argun, were killed.

The French franc, which has been falling steadily for a week, yesterday broke 2 1/8 points to below the gold-import point at 6.58 7/8 cents, the cheapest price since Dec. 28, 1935. Lacking an unexpected improvement in the French financial situation in the next few days, bankers expect the flow of gold from France to the United States to be resumed next week after an interruption of two months.
PARIS, March 27. -- Minister of War General Louis Felix Maurin, appearing before the Senate Army Commission today, gave reassuring information as to the state of France's preparedness for defense.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- The Federal Communications Commission twice within the past year refused to make available to executive agencies of the government telegrams and telephone records, it was revealed today, although it subsequently helped the Black lobby investigating committee to obtain telegrams from the files of telegraph offices here.

PHILADELPHIA, March 27. -- A prediction that the "not distant future" would bring "conclusive evidence" of a wane in unemployment was made today by Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, before the Bond Club of Philadelphia.

ALBANY, March 27 (AP). -- Dr. Frank P. Graves, State Commissioner of Education, refused today to reopen the case of William R. Hayward, principal of the Theodore Roosevelt High School, New York, whose reinstatement he ordered March 5 after the teacher had been dismissed by the City Board of Education.

Senator NORRIS has entered upon many seemingly hopeless enterprises in his time. Sometimes they have succeeded in spite of seemingly irresistible obstacles. His notice that he will oppose the confirmation of Mr. LAMAR HARDY as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York is a characteristic instance of his defiance of impossibilities.
AINTREE, England, March 27. -- There was enough material in the 9 minutes and 37 seconds of today's Grand National for a full-length sporting thriller.

An indictment charging grand larceny in the first degree was handed up in General Sessions yesterday against Detective Dominick Pape and Patrolman William F. Murphy of the East Twenty-second Street station. The grand jury voted the bill the day before on the complaint of Max W. Federbush, a stationer at 91 Seventh Avenue, that they took $750 from him.

The Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, for the last twelve years pastor of the New York Avenue Presbyterian Church, Washington, D.C., will be formally installed on Sunday, May 10, at 4 P.M. as pastor of the historic Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, which is coming to be known as "The Church of Rockefeller Center."

BERLIN, March 27. -- The appeal that Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden of Britain addressed to Chancellor Adolf Hitler yesterday to make a "sufficient contribution" toward peace was answered by Hitler today in a speech delivered to the nation from the Krupp works at Essen.

Despite the fact that some opposition was manifest yesterday, it is expected that the proposed amendment to the constitution of the New York Stock Exchange empowering the committee on bonds to require members to execute on the floor of the Exchange commission orders for listed bonds will be approved by the membership.

Operators of merchant ship lines in the intercoastal trade have decided to seek a strong leader and confer upon him broad powers as director of their field, in an attempt to effect peace among lines and a stable rate system, it was learned yesterday.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- The Railway Labor Executives Association has told the Joint Conference Committee of Railroad Managers that it would assent to consolidation plans if employes laid off would receive stipulated allowances as set forth in the unions' latest formula, it was learned today.

Ashbel Green, secretary, of the New York Stock Exchange, sent yesterday to members of the Exchange a letter interpreting the effect of the Federal Reserve Board's new margin requirements upon customers' accounts existing at the close of business on March 31.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- A discovery that the germ of tuberculosis "manufactures" in the human body three particularly poisonous chemicals by means of which the disease is produced, and the isolation of a fourth substance necessary for the germ's breathing processes, were reported here today before the annual meeting of the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology.

CAMDEN, S.C., March 27. -- The Carolina Cup Steeplechase, grueling three-mile race over timber for amateur riders, will have its seventh running over the Springdale course tomorrow. Seven veteran jumpers were named overnight for the chase, which is expected to attract a record crowd of more than 20,000.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, who is expected home tomorrow from a six-week vacation on the West Coast, will be asked to withdraw the acceptance by Columbia of an invitation to send a delegate to Heidelberg University's 550th anniversary celebration in June, it was announced yesterday by a student committee in charge of the protest.

TOKYO, Saturday, March 28. -- Tense conditions in the region where the Russian, Manchukuoan and Korean frontiers converge were reported by radiophone this morning from Keijo (Seoul), Korea. That is the area in which two Japanese privates were killed and three officers and nine privates were wounded by Russian border guards in a clash last Wednesday.

Richard C. Patterson Jr. has resigned as executive vice president and director of the National Broadcasting Company, it was announced last night. He resigned as Commissioner of Correction of New York City in September, 1932, after a service of five years in that office, to assume the executive post with the radio network.

Officials of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation are engaged in studies of corporate and capital changes in the program of ultimately eliminating the various subsidiary operating companies in this State.

Your editorial "The New Tax Schedule'' has been corroborated by the fact that some large corporations have lost more money, as a result of the recent floods, than they made in 1935 and for two or three years prior thereto. These companies must, nevertheless, pay the income tax on profits realized in 1935.

CHICAGO, March 27. -- Liquidation was under way in May wheat, both on the Board of Trade and at Minneapolis. Prices in the Northwest were 2 cents a bushel lower as the result of stop loss selling, while the old crop month in the local market was off 7/8 cent and at a new low since early in December.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- Germany's repudiation of the Treaty of Versailles was described by Senator William E. Borah of Idaho as no worse than the refusal of European nations to pay war debts to the United States, and Senator Joseph T. Robinson of Arkansas, majority leader, termed the results of the London Naval Conference "disappointing," as the European situation was discussed on the Senate floor today for the first time since Germany reoccupied the Rhineland.

ESSEN, Germany, March 27. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler stood on a platform resting on the chassis of a huge engine in the biggest locomotive shop in Europe today and delivered his twelfth speech in one of the most remarkable campaigns ever seen, a campaign made in Germany but addressed to the world.

ALBANY, March 27. -- Speaker Ives of the Assembly hit back tonight at Governor Lehman for his latest attack on legislators for blocking his anti-crime program. He asserted that the Governor was attempting to "throw a smoke screen around the fact that he is on the wrong side of the budget question."

Motor buses will replace the street cars on the Twenty-third Street crosstown line of the New York Railways system on April 8. The Twenty-third Street Association announced yesterday that it would celebrate the change with ceremonies and a luncheon.

The opening concert-symposium of the choral festival sponsored by Congregation Emanu-El and devoted to "American music and its ancestry" was held in the assembly hall of Temple Emanu-El yesterday afternoon under the musical direction of Lazare Saminsky.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- Twenty-one more applications from New York City for registration as brokers and dealers in the over-the-counter market have been received by the Securities and Exchange Commission, as follows (Symbols: S, sole proprietor; P, partnership; C, corporation):

Frequent Communist demonstrations at WPA headquarters to protest the proposed reduction of 40,000 in WPA rolls are so prejudicing business men against relief workers who are seeking jobs in private industry that Victor F. Ridder, WPA Administrator, has organized a speakers' bureau to reassure prospective employers.
Operators' deals in housing featured the Manhattan realty trading reported yesterday.

MEXICO, D.F., March 27. -- The cause of the air disaster yesterday between Mexico's famous volcanoes, Popocatapetl and Ixtaccihuatl, resulting in the death of fourteen persons -- ten European passengers and four members of the plane's crew -- will probably never be positively known.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- Senator Borah took another step today in his move to obtain popular endorsement for his campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination by filing as a candidate in the primary elections to be held in Oregon May 15.
LONDON, March 27. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange continued quiet today, but the price undertone was firm in most sections. British Government stocks were steady.

A 23-year-old waitress, suspected of having committed about 100 burglaries in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx, was held without bail on charges of burglary and possessing burglar's tools yesterday by Magistrate Peter Abeles in Bronx magistrate's court.

LINCOLN PARK, N.J., March 27. -- A running gun battle between Federal men and New York State Troopers and bandits held responsible for holding up the Nanuet (N.Y.) National Bank last Friday, was staged here tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- The upward trend in the dollar values and the turnover of stocks on all registered securities exchanges continued in February, reaching the highest figure in both instances since the Securities and Exchange Commission began compiling figures in October, 1934.

The New York Chapter of the American Red Cross announced yesterday that it had exceeded the original $375,000 quota in the nation-wide $3,000,000 flood-relief drive. During the day contributions amounting to nearly $49,700 brought the chapter's fund to $381,496.51.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 27. -- Succeeding where veteran reporters have failed, Robert P. Smith, a Princeton University freshman of Burlington, Vt., obtained an interview with Professor Albert Einstein today.

ST. PAUL, March 27 (AP). -- Governor Olson today invited the formation of a national third party and proposed to the State Farmer-Labor convention ownership of business by the Federal Government, with a check rein on "despotic powers" of the Supreme Court.

The nervousness that has prevailed in the share market during the last few weeks was heightened yesterday by the admittedly pessimistic character of the foreign news. Stock prices were reactionary during most of the day and the closing was lower, many of the leaders losing 1 to 3 points.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- Opposition to a Supreme Court test of the Holding Company Act through the lawsuit brought by Burco, Inc., was expressed by the government today on the ground that the Burco case is "inappropriate," whereas a decision based on the suit of the Securities and Exchange Commission against the Electric Bond and Share Company would go to the heart of the constitutionality of the law.
A new collection of short stories by Edith Wharton, entitled "The World Over," will be published by Appleton-Century on April 24.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today amended the instruction books to forms 12-K and 12A-K on which annual reports are made under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 by railroads and communication companies having securities registered on national securities Exchanges.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 27. -- Governor Earle will issue a call in a few days for a special session of the Legislature, beginning May 4, to raise $70,500,000 for direct relief purposes in Pennsylvania until the end of this year.

The largest and second largest corporation loans ever undertaken under the Securities Act of 1933 were marketed this week, lifting the total of new bond financing for the period to $194,557,000. This is the greatest volume for a week since Dec. 13, when the offering of $100,000,000 of Federal Land Bank 3s swelled the total for that week to $205,536,000.
Three paintings have been acquired recently by art museums in this country and abroad from New York art firms.

Total sales of the reporting wholesale firms in this district during February, which included one more business day than a year ago, averaged 18 per cent higher than last year, the largest percentage increase since April, 1934, according to the monthly review issued today by the Federal Reserve agent here.
The fencing teams of N.Y.U. and Yale finished the first day's competition all even for the three-weapon trophy in the intercollegiate championship at the Hotel Biltmore last night.

Price movements were mixed on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. Sugar and cocoa were strong and coffee and cottonseed oil weak. On the cash markets, cotton, corn, cocoa and silk advanced, and other grains, rubber, tins, butter, eggs and wool tops declined.

E.M.S. in a letter to THE TIMES suggests a so-called "new union." I am not a member of any union, but I was one at some time. It is true that many union leaders in this country have net always proved worthy of their positions. They are primarily job holders, receiving fat salaries and fearful of a change in the status quo.
Continuance of activity prevalent in 167th Street since opening of the Concourse division of the Eighth Avenue subway was reported in the Bronx realty field yesterday.
Ogden Phipps of Roslyn, L.I., and James H. Van Alert of Newport once again confront each other in the final of the national amateur court tennis championship.
CHICAGO, March 27. -- With dramatic suddenness detectives tonight solved the mystery murder of Dr. Silber C. Peacock, children's specialist, who was shot to death Jan. 2.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- The plight of the sharecroppers in the Cotton Belt and of tenant farmers and other agricultural workers in different parts of the country was reported today to Secretary Wallace and heads of departments charged with farm relief and rehabilitation by men who came from Alabama and Arkansas, New Jersey and the Imperial Valley of California to tell their stories and ask for help.

It has frequently been pointed out that no city in the State of New York enjoys complete self-government in the matter of finances. This is because of State legislation requiring certain mandatory expenditures. The City of New York, for example, cannot decide for itself how much it will pay its school teachers or its police or firemen.

Carlo Conti, 55 years old, a cement and mason contractor, was arrested last night at his home, 1,336 Herkimer Street, Brooklyn, for the murder of a man in Harrisburg, Pa., twenty-one years ago. He was locked up at Brooklyn police headquarters to await arraignment as a fugitive from justice. Conti denied he had ever been in Harrisburg, saying he had lived in Brooklyn the last thirty years and knew nothing of the murder.
ARLINGTON, Texas, March 27 (AP). -- The Milky Way Farms' Whiskolo won the fifth and feature race at the Arlington Downs Spring meet today before a crowd of 8,000 fans.
MIAMI, Fla., March 27. -- President Roosevelt found fishing luck today for the first time on his vacation cruise since he sailed from Port Everglades last Monday afternoon.

Mayor La Guardia introduced in the Board of Estimate branch of the Municipal Assembly yesterday an amendment to the city charter establishing a city Department of Commerce and Labor to deal generally with commercial and labor problems.

A long-standing claim against the city for six medals presented to visiting notables was finally put through for payment by the Board of Estimate yesterday after the manufacturers had waited more than two years.

Following receipt of a formal request from Mayor La Guardia, Governor Lehman announced late yesterday afternoon at Albany that he would send to the Legislature a "home rule" message for passage of the Nunan-Brownell bill to effable New York City to cooperate in the World's Fair of 1939.

I was greatly interested in the recent letter signed "Old Timer" in which he told how the New York National League baseball players originally got the name of Giants. They were known as the Giants, just as "Old Timer" said, as far back as the early part of 1888.

NEWARK, N.J., March 27. -- The flowing Easter bowls of eggnog on the bar may be a fine old custom to the State of New Jersey, but not to the Federal Government. So the eggnog may be in trouble in the next few weeks, despite the ruling of D. Frederick Burnett, State Commissioner of Alcoholic Beverage Control, that it has behaved well and may adorn the bars at Easter, Christmas and New Year's.

PHILADELPHIA, March 27. -- Repudiating the "whole concept of dictatorship," Dr. G. Bromley Oxnam, president of De Pauw University, contended here tonight that democracy would be preserved "in so far as the percentage of cultured people in the community increases."

Perhaps the strangest of all reasons put forward in favor of the proposed tax on undistributed corporation profits is that it will increase "the velocity of money." The origin of the belief that it is desirable to increase the rapidity with which money and bank deposits circulate is not difficult to trace.

Tropical Park will continue its pioneering for a longer racing season in Miami. Five years ago experienced racing men would have laughed away a proposal to operate thoroughbred racing here before Jan. 1 or after March 1, but this Winter our Gables Association opened a successful first meeting on Dec. 16 and it will close another successful meet on April 4.

ALBANY, March 27 (AP). -- Lester W. Herzog, State PWA Administrator, announced the allocation today of $151,855 to repair and recondition buildings of the Army Post at Mitchel Field, Long Island. Mr. Herzog also approved the allocation of $991,572.71 for other work relief projects.
Captain Ralph E. Fleischer, Quartermaster Corps, United States Army, stood at attention yesterday as a general court-martial on Governors Island sentenced him "to be dismissed from the service."
Brooklyn, for the first time in fifty-two years, will not be visited by the Ringling Brothers-Barnum Bailey Circus this Spring, License Commissioner Paul Moss decreed yesterday afternoon.

CHICAGO, March 27. -- Senator Borah's platform tour of down-State Illinois will start on April 8, less than a week before the primaries, on April 14, according to tentative plans received at his Illinois headquarters today from Washington.
I have read and have been duly annoyed by the article in THE TIMES of March 24, concerning the teaching of pacifism in New York public schools.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP). -- Atlanta captured the grand award for the best fire prevention record during 1935.

Supreme Court Justice Valente yesterday authorized Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, to accept a bid of $101.50 a share for 70 per cent of the capital stock of the National Surety Corporation by the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation. He directed Mr. Pink to hold the remaining 30 per cent pending arrangements for a plan for creditors to buy the remaining stock at the same price.

PHILADELPHIA, March 27. -- A group of the junior committee members for the Devon Horse Show gave a supper dance at the Philadelphia Country Club this evening for the benefit of the motor car concession to be made at the show, which takes place from May 25 to May 30.
Sailing on the Furness Bermuda liner Monarch of Bermuda last night were most of the Long Island Sound crews which will engage in the international yacht races there starting on Wednesday.
ALBANY, March 27. -- The following announcements were made today by the State Banking Department:

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 27 (AP). -- Eggs destined to hatch rooster chicks may be made to hatch hens, it was revealed today by Dr. Benjamin H. Willier, Professor of Zoology at the University of Rochester.

GULFPORT, Miss., March 27. -- Surmounting a number of difficulties, not the least of these being a lashing Gulf gale that carried with it plenty of sting and a drizzling rain, the Giants blanked the Atlanta Crackers today, 5 to 0.

A mural in one of the smoking rooms of the Queen Mary shows the Mauretania on her way to the shipbreakers. When they removed the trolley cars from Lexington Avenue on Wednesday and substituted buses, they staged a procession in honor of the past, linking it with the present and the future.

MIAMI, Fla., March 27. -- J.E. Widener's handsome 3-year-old Shot Up, making his first effort over a distance of ground, proved much the best of the small field that contested the mile and a sixteenth of the featured Pompano Purse today at Tropical Park.

Your editorial entitled "Germany Strait-Jacketed" has no doubt put many people to deep thinking about the tremendous price that unfortunate Germany will be called upon to pay to her own descendants in the not too distant future for Goebbels's "great renaissance of pure German art" which has already resulted in the crushing out of those great spirits which might have developed into the Duerers, the Handels and the Haydns of the coming years.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 27. -- Jack Medica and Johnny Macionis came churning down the Yale University pool tonight in a flurry of foam and spume, locked in a bitter struggle for the National Collegiate Athletic Association 220-yard championship, outstanding event in the opening session of the thirteenth annual title meet.

Determined to stiffen discipline and increase effectiveness, Police Commissioner Valentine revealed yesterday that he had decided on important changes in the department, possibly involving a shift of high personnel in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens.

ROME, March 27. -- Well-informed Italian quarters have seized the occasion offered by the denial of the reports that when Premier Mussolini received the French Ambassador yesterday the Italian leader pleaded for France's cooperation to end the League of Nations sanctions.

Another period of comparative inactivity in the market for new State and municipal bonds is indicated for next week with only $6,352,215, scheduled to be offered by two States and thirty-seven municipalities. This is the smallest total for the week so far this year.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- Both House and Senate struck at lobbyists today. The House passed without a record vote a measure calling for the registration of all persons engaged in efforts to influence legislation and for detailed statements of contributions, expenditures and salaries.

ESSEN, March 27. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler reforged old phrases of defiance today and warned foreign statesmen he would not "relinquish so much as one room in a German house nor permit any outsider to say what shall happen here."

PHILADELPHIA, March 27. -- Carlos Chavez, noted Mexican composer and conductor, making his debut as guest conductor of the Philadelphia orchestra, had a cordial reception at the Academy of Music this afternoon in a concert of wide range.

Speaking on "What Agency Men Think of Premiums," T.C. Dunnington of Young Rubicam, Inc., advertising agency, assured premium manufacturers gathered at a luncheon meeting of the Premium Advertising Association of America in the New Weston Hotel yesterday that the demand for premiums is reaching record proportions among advertisers.

MANILA, March 27. -- Police guarded Alvan T. Simonds, manufacturer of Fitchburg, Mass., and his wife in a Manila hotel tonight after they expressed fears of being attacked because Mr. Simonds criticized the Nazi government in an interview.

The recent news stories of "Black Maria's" Pegasus-like ascent to the sky-scraper nerve-center of the local WPA have been extremely amusing. The expression of astonishment on the faces of the first group of agitators, as John Law's chariot was disgorged from the cavernous jaws of the elevator, must have repaid Victor Ridder and his aides for many of their too prevalent headaches.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., March 27. -- All six of the Eastern Intercollegiate Boxing Association champions seeking additional laurels in the National Collegiate Athletic Association title tourney advanced into the semi-finals as the latter event got under way today in Memorial Gymnasium at the University of Virginia.

Always on the alert for any opportunity to "do something different," the night club impresarios hereabout -- at least the more playful of them -- probably will hit upon Wednesday evening to indulge some lively pranks. Nothing malicious, of course, but just little things like rubber eggs, phony calls to the front door and maybe even a puckishly tampered drink are always in order.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- Administration leaders in Congress were looking for every possible means today to hold both houses closer to the line of fiscal policy outlined by President Roosevelt in his budget and tax messages, following further word that any great departure therefrom would be met with new Executive demands for legislation.

CANEA, Crete, March 27. -- A year almost to the day after former Premier Eleutherios Venizelos fled from his revolutionary headquarters with his wife under a rain of bombs from Greek army airplanes, the late Cretan dictator's body was brought here today aboard a Greek destroyer.
WINTER HAVEN, Fla., March 27. -- The handsomest club president in the National League, Mr. Gerald P. Nugent of the Phillies, sat in the grand stand with a badly sunburned nose and said:

The law firm of Cravath, de Gersdorff, Swaine Wood announced yesterday that Supreme Court Justice Church had signed an order on behalf of its client, Richard Gimbel, director of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., directing Bernard Gimbel, president of the company, and Samuel Nass, treasurer, to show cause on Tuesday why information regarding the corporation's financial condition and the salaries of its officers should not be made available to the directors.
WINTER HAVEN, Fla., March 27. -- The handsomest club president in the National League, Mr. Gerald P. Nugent of the Phillies, sat in the grand stand with a badly sunburned nose and said:

The law firm of Cravath, de Gersdorff, Swaine Wood announced yesterday that Supreme Court Justice Church had signed an order on behalf of its client, Richard Gimbel, director of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., directing Bernard Gimbel, president of the company, and Samuel Nass, treasurer, to show cause on Tuesday why information regarding the corporation's financial condition and the salaries of its officers should not be made available to the directors.

I deeply regret that in recent public utterances, responsible statesmen have continued to proclaim the doctrine of American isolation. No one, of course, desires America to be embroiled in European squabbles, yet on the other hand, no one desires America to be an outcast from the family of nations, or a lonely hermit living an anti-social life of selfish nationalism.
Apartment and dwelling parcels were included in the Brooklyn and Queens turnover reported yesterday.

PARIS, March 27. -- Pierre-Etienne Flandin, French Foreign Minister, and Maxim M. Litvinoff, Russian Foreign Commissar, today at the Quai d'Orsay put their signatures to the much-discussed Franco-Soviet pact of mutual assistance which now is in force.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, reasserted today his intention of withdrawing the federation convention from Tampa unless the trial in the flogging case is "fairly, openly, diligently and honestly conducted."

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP). -- Senator Wheeler of Montana, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Committee of the Senate, announced today that W.A. Irvin, president of the United States Steel Corporation, and Eugene G. Grace, president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, had been requested "explicitly" to appear before the committee on April 2 and 3 to testify on basing-point legislation.
