ALBANY, March 27. -- Six amendments to the Unemployment Insurance Law, designed to correct defects pointed out by Justice Pierce H. Russell of the Supreme Court in declaring the statute unconstitutional, will be offered tomorrow in the Legislature by Senator Desmond, Republican, of Orange.
WASHINGTON, March 27. -- Final preparations for the payment of the soldiers' bonus were made by the Treasury Department today.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, March 27. -- With all the grace of a sailing ship, the liner Queen Mary glided up the waters of her new home port today and floated with the greatest ease into the giant King George V graving dock, which had been built especially to receive her.

New York Athletic Club stars captured four of the seven qualifying berths as the Olympic wrestling semi-finals for the metropolitan district came to a close at the Winged Foot club last night. The victors are entitled to compete in the finals which will be held at Lehigh University next month.

Olive Bond, a comely soprano, who was born in Johannesburg, South Africa, and studied in Paris, Milan and in this country, made her debut in a recital last night at the Town Hall. The newcomer has appeared in opera houses abroad, and this stage experience was reflected in an easy grace and a charming manner, which made a pleasing impression from the start.

The United States Government continues to make public the salary of every officer and employe of an American corporation who was paid more than $15,000 in salary, commissions and bonuses in 1934. Yesterday's instrument included compensation paid by corporations listed alphabetically from A to C.

Fifteen thousand Boy Scouts brought into the arena of Madison Square Garden last night a colorful panorama of scouting as they know it, and live it, under the title of the Boy Scout-O-Rama. Produced under the supervision of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York, the show was said to be the largest Scout spectacle ever staged indoors.

An exhibition of paintings representative of the work done in some seventy-five public, private and parochial schools in various parts of the United States has been arranged and will open in the Mezzanine Galleries of the RCA Building on April 13, continuing for two weeks.

Passion Sunday, which is tomorrow, will be observed in churches of virtually every faith. There will be special sermons on "The Passion," and oratorios, cantatas, pageants and dramas. A week from tomorrow will be Palm Sunday and two weeks from tomorrow will be Easter.

Operations of the Texas Corporation and subsidiaries in 1935 resulted in a net profit of $17,065,037 after deducting interest, depreciation, amortization of drilling costs, Federal taxes and other charges. This is equivalent to $1.83 each on 9,340,069 shares of $25-par capital stock, excluding 511,174 shares held in the treasury.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- Having denied applications that the material be held confidential, the Securities and Exchange Commission made public today remunerations to officers and other data filed with it by additional companies.

The board of governors of the New York Curb Exchange announced yesterday proposed amendments to the constitution and rules of the Exchange which would subdivide the work of the committee on listing, broaden the privileges of officials of the Exchange to employ substitutes on the trading floor and liberalize the rules respecting entertainment by customers' men.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 27. -- A picture of more than $6,500,000,000 in consumer credits escaping from the bank into the hands of competitive financial agencies was drawn here today at the Southern Conference of the American Bankers Association.

There is much less litter in the streets now than a few years ago, Sanitation Commissioner Hammond asserted last night. The commissioner's statement was a reply to questions submitted to him on Wednesday by the Committee of Twenty on Street and Outdoor Cleanliness of the Academy of Medicine.
Five of the major prizes, totaling $375,000, went to residents of New York and vicinity yesterday in the Irish Hospital Sweepstakes on the Grand National Steeplechase at Aintree, England.

The collection of Chippendale and other English period furniture assembled by the late Marsden J. Perry of Providence, R.I., will be sold at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Friday and Saturday afternoons.

The gala jubilee to be held by the Junior League on April 17 at its clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street, is enlisting the support of many young women of society as members of several committees which have been formed to arrange the entertainment program and other features of the evening.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., March 28. -- Although two of the five competing Eastern Intercollegiate Boxing Association champions met their masters tonight in the finals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tourney, representatives of Eastern institutions carried off the lion's share of the honors, taking five of the eight individual crowns before 4,000 fans in Memorial Gymnasium at the University of Virginia.

Music students as well as teachers of music in the public schools will participate in the biennial convention of the Music Educators National Conference here this week. There will be 4,300 pupils in choruses, bands and orchestras. Madison Square Garden will be given over entirely to the city's schools for a festival tomorrow night, and the junior high school pupils will have a program of their own in the Metropolitan Opera House on Thursday afternoon.
AUSTIN, Texas, March 28. -- Despite a stiff wind, records were smashed today in the Texas relays, the nation's first major outdoor meet of the Olympic year.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., March 28. -- Speaking on what he termed "one of the two most unpopular causes" in the world, Leon Fraser today gave a sympathetic presentation of Italy's reasons for insisting on territory in Ethiopia, despite the opposition of the League of Nations, in his first address before the students and faculty of Union College, of which he is a trustee.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- The Hasty Pudding Club of Harvard University will present its annual show, "The Lid's Off," at the auditorium of the Greenbrier on Wednesday. Following the performance a supper dance will be given in the Colonnades Room for members of the cast and their guests.

WHEN a music lover listening on the western edge of the continent is moved by sound alone from an opera house 3,000 miles away to send a check for $15, the price of two seats, the broadcasters consider it evidence of success in the alchemy of music and electricity.

THE progress made in the organized campaign against tuberculosis is probably the most remarkable achievement of sanitary and medical science during the last thirty-five years. At the beginning of the century this plague of mankind led all other diseases in its toll of death, causing in the United States alone more than 200 deaths for each 100,000 of population a year.

WHILE substantial gains in trade were reported for several sections of the country, sales volume in general seemed to slip somewhat for the week. In the areas affected by floods the reduced gains over last year could be explained readily enough, but in other sections the reasons were not quite so plain.
CHICAGO, March 28. -- Mr. Hoover outlined briefly today "four jobs" he believes Republicans must tackle in the campaign. These are as follows:

BERLIN, March 28. -- Dr. Hugo Eckener's new Hindenburg and the old Graf Zeppelin, Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels's most valuable aids in the closing days of the plebiscite campaign, appeared this afternoon and tonight over Berlin.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., March 28. -- The Children's Village at Dobbs Ferry will be the beneficiary of a concert to be presented by the Harvard Glee Club under the auspices of the Crestwood Junior Women's Club on Tuesday evening in the Bronxville School's auditorium. G. Wallace Woodworth will conduct the chorus of sixty voices.
CHICAGO, March 28. -- Thomas Courtney, State's Attorney, sped preparations today for a quick trial of the four youths charged with the murder of Dr. Silber Peacock.

WHEN she was a child of 7 Mrs. McClung was taken by her family from Grey County, Ontario, where they were farmers, to the Red River country in Manitoba, where they pioneered and she saw the Canadian West develop from open prairie lands, almost uninhabited, to the civilized and prosperous wheat country it had become by the turn of the century, when her narrative closes.

A CHINESE painting acquired by Professor George Rowley of Princeton University for the Worcester Museum has just been placed on view in Gallery IV. It represents the Emperor Ming Hwang with his favorite, Yang Kuei-fe, reviewing the imperial orchestra.

THE people of Vermont, says Robert Frost, are "taken care of by three great ladies. And one of these is wise and a novelist, one is mystic and an essayist and the third is saintly and a poet." Both Dorothy Canfield and Zephine Humphrey have a place in this book, as they have in the life of the author, their friend.

Typical of the dull markets that have prevailed lately, stocks yesterday were the slowest of any Saturday since Sept. 28. Prices moved narrowly, and the closing was steady, with net changes on the day of small consequence. The turnover on the Stock Exchange amounted to but 656,000 shares, compared with 840,000 the Saturday before.

BERLIN, March 28. -- An inkling of the German ideas about fortification of the Rhineland zone is provided in a guarded article by Lieut. Gen. von Metzsch, an authority on military affairs, to appear in tomorrow's Berliner Tageblatt.

With the liquor industry rapidly forging to the forefront of large advertisers among the country's industries, simultaneous moves by wholesalers and retailers last week to improve ethics in advertising indicated the desire of executives in the field to place their campaigns and appeals on a basis that would eliminate criticism, according to opinions expressed here yesterday.

A group of youths ranging in ages from 13 to 17 years arrived on the Empire State Limited at Grand Central Terminal last night for a greeting in the New York manner by a large delegation of citizens. The boys, most of whom never saw the city before, comprised the much heralded Township High School Band of Joliet, six times winners of the National School Band championship.

Revised by-laws, designed to make committee work more efficient without depriving judicial districts of representation, were approved yesterday by the executive committee of the New York State Bar Association at a meeting in the Manhattan Club, Madison Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street.

Mrs. Adele Rivero of Manhattan, one of the six finalists in the women's championship tournament at the Marshall Chess Club, took the lead yesterday in the second round, defeating Miss Helen White of Manhattan. It was Mrs. Rivero's second victory in the finals and the eleventh, including the preliminaries, in which she was undefeated.

SU TUNG P'O was born in Such'uan Province, China, exactly 900 years ago. He came from a literary family -- his father, mother, brother and sister have left literary reputations. At 10, Su Tung P'o was "conversant with all the leading events in his country's annals."

THE Grand National Tournament begins tomorrow afternoon at the Park Central Hotel with a team-of-four tournament and continues through the week with sessions of an open pair tournament in play every night through Thursday and a team-of-four tournament every afternoon.

MOUNTAIN LAKES, N.J., March 28 -- Mr. and Mrs. Laurence E. Carpenter gave a dinner and dance for their daughter, Miss Natalie Carpenter, tonight, at the Mountain Lakes Club. Miss Carpenter, who will enter the Ogontz Junior College next Autumn, and her cousin, Miss Julia Gilbert of Bayshore, L.I., received.

Retail trade picked up last week, with the major demand reaching the best levels of the year so far. Sales of apparel and dress accessories led, as usual, with the approach of Easter. Home furnishings volume was good considering the season of the year and consumer buying held up satisfactorily on furniture, electrical appliances and small homewares.

Long Island University's baseball nine stepped out on the right foot in its quest for metropolitan diamond honors yesterday, shutting out C.C.N.Y., 5 to 0, at Lewisohn Stadium. It was the opening contest of the season for both teams.

GOSHEN, N.Y., March 28. -- Forty contests will be held at the primaries on Thursday in Orange County which include a contest in the Socialist party for a delegate to the national convention and an alternate delegate, a contest in each Assembly district for State committeemen in the Democratic party and thirty-six contests for Democratic County Committee members.

THERE is a simple grandeur about Peter Freuchen: he is like a great mountain of granite. Not only is the man huge in size, but he has the vast tolerance and patience and sym pathy which is a part of true simplicity, an understanding which is vivid in every page of his book.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP). -- Notice was given today by Chairman Black of the Senate Lobby Committee that he would drive to expand the Smith Lobby Registration Bill, passed yesterday by the House.

This, like the author's "The Glass Book" and "The Steel Book," which appeared last Summer, is chiefly important for its pictures, for it is undoubtedly true that good photographs provide one of the best means of answering the questions that children ask.

LONDON, March 5. NO one who is not deeply familiar with the tastes and fads of England can easily understand how perilous was the production of "Pride and Prejudice" in London or how creditable is its success. Its detail has, I believe, been carefully sifted for anachronism since it opened in New York, and it is now, in dialogue, scenery and costume, faultlessly in period.

OTTAWA, March 27. -- The Dionne quintuplets became an imperial problem this week after earlier endeavors to make a race and religious issue of them had failed to take root in the soil of Canadian public opinion.

The opening of the Garden Room of the Park Lane on April 14 will be the occasion for a gala benefit in behalf of the Goddard Neighborhood Center, 599 First Avenue. The beneficiary, now in its forty-fourth year of social service, will share in the receipts of the afternoon and evening festivities on the opening day.

IT would be difficult to find a theme more complex or more difficult than the one Helen Beauclerk has treated, and that with brilliant success, in her new book, "The Mountain and the Tree." History and sociology and religion are mingled in these pictures of the development, not so much of woman as of the idea of woman, from the Stone Age to the third century, A.D.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- The severe floods in the East seriously hampered business in the week ended on March 21, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey. As a consequence, a temporary recession may be expected in some of the weekly indicators.

Women who long have taken an active interest in the work that is being accomplished for Southern mountaineers by the Industrial Educational Association have arranged a card party in behalf of that organization for the afternoon of April 16 in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

THE recent floods that wrought destruction and suffering in many of the Northeastern States occasioned a summons to Boy Scouts to bear a hand in the vast work of relief. In the districts affected by the raging waters there are seventy-seven councils with 4,768 troops, enrolling 104,678 boys and 32,726 adult leaders.

The board of directors of New York World's Fair, 1939, Inc., shrugged their shoulders last week; there seemed to be no use in their laboring further without the help of the governments of New York City and State. The directors decided not to meet again until enabling legislation pending at Albany had been enacted.

A telephone message received by the wrong man starts off this swiftly moving story of international intrigue. A wild Nazi, wilder even than Herr Hitler, is the villain of the piece, and the hero, who is also the narrator, is Alec Mackenzie, a Member of Parliament who becomes, for the duration of the story, virtually a member of the British Military Intelligence.

CHICAGO, March 27. -- The threatened upset of the powerful Kelly-Nash Chicago Democratic organization in the April 14 primaries may create new problems of alliances and patronage for Chairman James A. Farley in Illinois.

The decision of the Delaware Hudson Company to cease dividends in 1933 after paying them continuously since 1880 was seen as justified, in the light of its report on 1935 operations issued last week. The summary showed that the holding company's net loss, which was $4,895,528 in 1933, increased to $3,062,876 in 1935 after a decline to $1,738,626 in 1934.

MIAMI, March 28. -- With six days of complete rest behind him while he cruised and fished in the Atlantic to the eastward, President Roosevelt prepared tonight to begin tomorrow the interspersing of work with his vacation sport.

SPRING is in the air and the salad is on the table, for with the arrival of crocuses and daffodils in the garden there stirs in the beholder an appetite for lighter food. Green crisp and cold and appetizingly dressed with condiments and oils are a cure for that fagged feeling known as Spring fever.
AIKEN, S.C. -- Aiken's resort season will reach a climax this week with the twentieth annual Horse Show, to be held on Wednesday and Thursday.

BETTE DAVIS was gay about that academy award, just as gay as if she had held a winning sweepstakes ticket on a long shot, and for a like reason. Lots of people think she should have had the honor a year sooner, for her work as Mildred in "Of Human Bondage," but the slim blonde visitor would rather have things as they are.

PHILADELPHIA, March 28. -- In one of the most sensational games seen here in many years, Temple University defeated Niagara University, 37 to 36, at the Palestra tonight in the final of Districts 1 and 2 collegiate Olympic elimination series.

Before the depression Dr. Francis E. Townsend was a worthy but undistinguished individual in the horde of Middle Westerners who had earned competences and had retired to enjoy California's sun. The depression cleaned him of everything except $500 and, in recompense, started him thinking about the plight of aging persons facing want.

One of the most important phases of American national defense has seemingly been overlooked. It is the matter of sinking beneath the surface of the ground, or water, the huge storage tanks in which reserves of fuel oil for the navy and gasoline reserves for the air forces are stored.

Strongly urging immediate action by the departments and municipalities of the Republic of Colombia toward a settlement on their defaulted dollar bonds, the Colombian Bondholders Committees, in a letter to that republic's political subdivisions, have stated their readiness to take foreclosure steps in accordance with provisions in the trust indentures unless some effort is made on behalf of those departments to negotiate for some service on their external dollar obligations.

SPRING flowers, rabbits and pert little yellow chicks are making stationers' shops bright and gay in their annual appearance on Easter cards. Should one wish to send something different from the traditional card, there are etchings in color of scenes from an old Hungarian legend relating to a village magistrate who met strange adventures when he visited Buda, the capital.

HIGH WALL" is a very good book, not, however, to be recommended lightly to any one inclined to be jittery. It is the clinically and humanly interesting story of several months which David Stephens spent in the Tri-State Sanitarium.

For twenty minutes last Tuesday morning a million spectators, who had come to cheer on the banks of the River Clyde, held their breath. They had come to watch the new liner Queen Mary slip from her shipyard birthplace and journey to the sea; instead they saw her stranded.

NEW ORLEANS, March 28. -- Colonel Bill Terry's intrepid band of frontiersmen, who the past few days have been exploring the hinterlands of Alabama and Mississippi, finally caught up with the Indians today.

In a game played at a blistering pace from beginning to end the Army trio retained its intercollegiate indoor polo championship by defeating Yale, 10 1/2 to 6 1/2, at the Squadron A armory last night.

CHICAGO, March 28. -- Four youths, who last night confessed the murder of Dr. Silber G. Peacock, child specialist, started talking today. And when they finished there was unfolded a tale of two other murders, a shooting and scores of robberies, the details of which were so spotted with brutality that even hardened police were shocked.

HELSINGFORS, March 28. -- At the request of the owners of thirteen Finnish ships which the American authorities in 1917 and 1918 subjected to alleged "unwarranted and unnecessary detention" in United States ports, the Finnish Government has decided to take up the matter with Washington.

Ten-year-old Johnny Neill, whose skull was fractured by a hit-and-run automobile driver on Dec. 11, walked out of Bellevue Hospital yesterday with his mother, Mrs. Angela Neill of 1,065 Madison Avenue, more interested in taking up football again than in the fact that he was. a living testament to a feat of surgery.

Princeton broke up the Long Island University rugby team's rugged goal-line stands to batter home a 20-0 victory at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. It was the opening intercollegiate rugby clash of the season.

In the eighteen months since the promulgation of Regulation T the Federal Reserve Board has unobtrusively raised stock margin requirements from 25 or 30 per cent to 55 per cent of market value, according to Charles H. Meyer, lawyer and author of several books on the law of stockbrokerage.

TO write a biography of Kenneth Grahame is, in reality, to write two biographies. Kenneth Grahame, author of "The Golden Age," "Dream Days" and "The Wind in the Willows," is a man whose truest biography is his own books.

PHILADELPHIA, March 28. -- Members of the Mask and Wig Club of the University of Pennsylvania soon will be ready to lampoon American politicians and Latin-American "communistic" activities before audiences in five States.

A MOST provocative book, Mr. Link's volume deserves a great deal of attention not only because it is likely to stir even the laziest mind to assent or objection but equally because it is the product of profound psychology and practical acquaintance with human nature and because it presents the reaction of a strong, well-balanced character to the steady pressure upon it of this combination of scientific and practical knowledge.

MADRID, March 28. -- Jose Antonio Primo de Rivera, son of the late dictator, who was arrested recently with hundreds of Fascist followers on charges of having tried to foment a revolution, was convicted today on the much less serious charge of having insulted a policeman.

THE Spring lists promise several interesting books, and one or two that should be outstanding. I give here a list of these announced to date (asterisks indicate books likely to be of general interest).

The automobile industry insists that speed has little or nothing to do with automobile accidents. Advertising the "safety" which, the industry says, is built into its products, it continues to make cars capable of running comfortably at speeds of from 60 to 125 miles an hour and sells them to be operated on highways, many of which were built for the horse and buggy.

THE greatest wave of newcomers that the town has seen in years is sweeping in from all parts of the land. The studios have signed every potential Garbo and Gable that industrious talent scouts have unearthed.

SHANGHAI. -- Some time in July a railway line first projected seventy years ago by Sir MacDonald Stephenson will be completed and through rail traffic will be possible between Peiping in the north and Canton in the south.

In spite of the depression, every woman's clubhouse in New York and the suburbs has kept out of bankruptcy. Within the year, the New Haven Woman's Club added a new auditorium and the Hartford Woman's Club made up a savings account of thousands of dollars wiped out by a bank failure.

The legislation and taxation committee of the Real Estate Board of New York announces its disapproval of the bill introduced by Assemblyman oran in the Legislature amending the present statute covering municipally operated railways to make a 5-cent fare nndatory in perpetuity.

THE lords of the film industry are experiencing considerable uneasiness. Like the feudal barons of another day, they are apprehensive over the revolt of the peasants. James Cagney's suit against the Warner Brothers, calculated to clear up several moot points in actor-producer relations, seems only to have complicated matters.
The Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria will open on May 7 for the Summer season with a gala dinner and supper dance for the benefit of the Humane Society.

Albert Bein is a realist with a sense that modern society should be changed. In 1938 he contributed "Little Ol' Boy" to the New York stage, a study -- and in many ways a powerful one -- of the reformatory schools. This year he has dramatized a Grace Lumpkin novel into "Let Freedom Ring."

In the six months that have passed since Federal funds ceased to be available for that phase of the Emergency Relief Bureau's work concerned with the housing of transients, readjustments of the service thus far have absorbed those needing help so that virtually no women or girls are stranded in the city without shelter, inquiry among social service agencies reveals.
A further improvement in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday carried the May above 11 1/4 cents a pound, the highest figure since Jan. 6, leaving the list with net gains of 5 to 9 points.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- A Congressional session brings wear and tear on furniture and office equipment as well as on nerves. This year the House of Representatives has drawn a check on its contingent fund for more than $40,000 for furniture replacement and repair.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., March 28. -- A cross-section of the problems faced by "The Modern American" as an individual will provide material for lectures and discussion at the third session of the Mount Holyoke Alumnae College, to be held on the campus from June 8 to 12.

Subscribers to the joint concert to be given tonight at the Town Hall by the Harvard Glee Club and the Radcliffe Choral Society include many graduates of the two institutions. The President and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt head the honorary committee of sponsors.

EUROPE'S new post-Locarno crisis must have raised in many minds the question that was bluntly put by some one the other day: "We have a situation in which the dictators strut about and slap the free governments of Western Europe in the face and the latter do nothing about it.

WITH Spring rains and warmer temperatures, roses, perennials and rock plants are starting into growth. Where effective Winter mulching has been applied, early growth is held in check: this, in fact, is one of the main purposes of such mulching, which lessens the danger of frost injury to prematurely ambitious buds and shoots.

Newtown High's quintet remained unbeaten in two starts while Thomas Jefferson recorded its second decision in three games by winning as the round-robin series for the city Public Schools Athletic League championship continued yesterday.

Elena Gerhardt, the renowned German Lieder singer, gave a recital of songs by Schubert and Brahms recently at the Queen's Hall, London. As well as some perennial favorites, Miss Gerhardt included several of the less frequently heard of Schubert's output, such as the first "Suleika" song and "Die Liebende schreibt," from the Goethe settings.

Government being possible only through the consent of the governed, Dr. John Haynes Holmes and Reginald Lawrence have idly wondered whether peace isn't most possible through the firm expression of opinion on the part of the potential warriors.
HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- The curtain is about to rise on the gayeties of the pre-Easter season and the Homestead is filled with students drawn from Eastern colleges and schools.

BROADWAY is still called the Great White Way and probably always will be, but a more honest name nowadays would be Rainbow Ravine, or -- if Moscow doesn't have it copyrighted -- even Red Square. Seventy-five per cent of the twenty miles of neon lights between Times Square and Columbus Circle are red.

A party of twelve boys comprising the Scholarship Club of the Burroughs Newsboys Foundation, Boston, arrived in New York yesterday for their annual visit. Under the direction of Harry B. Taplin, executive secretary of the foundation, the boys were received at City Hall by a representative of Mayor La Guardia and visited THE NEW YORK TIMES, and other places of interest.

Craig Kennedy, veteran hero of Arthur B. Reeve's detective stories, has gone in for astrology. When the charred body of rich old Maria Daskam is found in the ruins of her fire-swept tower at Hampton Hall, a quick reading of her horoscope convinces him at once that this is no accident.

THE row over the abandonment of the film version of "It Can't Happen Here" has dramatized a situation which is now dominant in the motion-picture industry. As Hollywood is increasingly dependent on the world market for its profits, it has become subject to what is really a world censorship of the screen.

WHILE the powers that be are working out the details for the Spring experiment, it will not be amiss to look ahead to the next regular season, which will start some time in December, possibly November. Edward Johnson has indicated that one of his major objectives will be novelties.

With the surge in Spring retail buying developing into broader proportions, business registered some of the sharpest gains of the year last week, although sections of New England, Pennsylvania and other parts of the East were still seriously affected as a result of the floods.

Perhaps no creature is dearer to the hearts of little children than the rabbit. For the Easter season Lois Lenski and the Oxford University Press have provided a jovial bunny who takes charge with a will of the Easter party planned by the farm yard animals for Ann Eliza, the little girl who has faithfully fed and taken care of them all Winter.

Several innovations will mark the fourth annual metropolitan badminton championship, which starts at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory Friday and continues through Tuesday, with the exception of Sunday. For the first time the mixed doubles competition will be recognized as an official championship, an advancement that the women's section of the Metropolitan Badminton Association has been working on for the past few seasons.

The scheduled changes in the Police Department, set for yesterday, were postponed until Wednesday by Commissioner Valentine after he had received word of the death of Deputy Chief Inspector Edward J. Hanley, commander of the uniformed force in Queens.

Breaking 98 out of 100 targets, T.H. Lewis took the High-Over-All Cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. In Class A, the trophy went to S.B. Masten, who had a card of 96, 5-100. F.A. Cauchois Jr. was the winner in Class B with 86, 14-100.

ELLEN GLASGOW says in her introduction to "Barren Ground" (The Modern Library, 95 cents) that years ago she resolved to "write of the South, not sentimentally as a conquered province, but dispassionately, as a part of the larger world * * * not of Southern characteristics but of human nature"; and she has kept this promise in good measure.

FROM a land where art is measured by standards set by Rembrandt, de Hooch, Van Gogh and the other great painters of the Dutch and Flemish schools comes Joris Ivens -- a young Dutch film director whose name has already become a part of the art legend of the Netherlands -- for a first American showing of his films.

When the United States Senate, on April 6, tries Judge Halstead L. Ritter of the Southern District of Florida in impeachment proceedings voted by the House, it will be acting in a rare instance of the sort. Only thirteen times has the House voted to impeach a Federal official.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 28. -- Henry Picard of Hershey, Pa., completed five rounds of consistent scoring by firing a 72 today to defeat Ray Mangrum of Pittsburgh by five strokes in the play-off for the North and South open golf championship.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Failure of the Federal Government's relief program to assist those most in need of help in rural areas was again charged today by Southern sharecropper and tenant farmer delegates at concluding sessions of the conference with government officials sponsored by the National Committee on Rural Social Planning.

A BROADWAY hit was born last Tuesday night -- the name is "Idiot's Delight" -- and as soon afterward as Wednesday it was well on the way to maturity. Among those who stood at the Shubert Theatre on the second evening and watched it grow (out front and back stage) was Robert E. Sherwood, who wrote it.

PIPESTEM or bouffant skirt -- which do you prefer? You can make your choice and pay your money, when it comes to your evening gown. Zip yourself into a Schiaparelli sheath, or buckle yourself into a Vionnet hoopskirt.

USE of a specific boric acid-borax mixture and subsequent doping with cellulose acetate on aircraft fabric has been found to minimize the fire risk by raising the ignition temperature of the fabric from 125 degrees centigrade to 300 degrees centigrade.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Former President Hoover and his immediate supporters are now advancing the cause of Senator Vandenberg for the Republican nomination for President, according to information in political circles here.

NASSAU, Bahamas. -- On Monday evening the Williams College Musical Association will present a concert by the Williams College Glee Club, the program ranging from songs of Williams and Negro spirituals to Russian folk songs and Gilbert and Sullivan selections.

A NEW professional approach to a business career is being offered by Western Reserve University to undergraduates in its liberal arts college. The development illustrates the evolution of an arts college in response to the changing interests of its students.

A DOCUMENT bearing the signatures of Stanley Baldwin, David Lloyd George, John Masefield, H.W. Nevinson. G.K. Chesterton and Walter de la Mare obviously claims attention. These names are appended to an appeal for a memorial to Edward Thomas.

THE Music Educators National Conference, which holds its first general session tomorrow morning at the Metropolitan Opera House, promises to be one of the largest conventions of its kind ever held in this city.

PHILADELPHIA. -- The Pennsylvania Supreme Court's affirmation of the disbarment of four criminal lawyers of this city as an outgrowth of an investigation by the Philadelphia Bar Association came as a climax to one of the most unusual proceedings in the city's legal history.

AUGUSTA, Ga. -- With the third annual Masters' Golf Tournament at the Augusta National Golf Club scheduled to begin on Thursday, all interest among Winter colonists here has turned to golf. Many are following the stars on their practice rounds.

An entertainment to be known as a "Spring Bundle Party" will be held on the night of April 16 at the Astor for the benefit of the joint Thrift Houses, permanent rummage shops maintained in behalf of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York under the direction of Mrs. Julius Ochs Adler.

THERE seems to be something about having to address a graduating class that brings out the worst in man. Sidney Howard, president of the Dramatists Guild and itinerant writer of screen plays, is the latest victim of the baccalaureate bacillus.

CHICAGO, March 28 (AP). -- The crack Squadron C trio of the New York National Guard halted a furious rally tonight to defeat the Cleveland Riding Club, 10 to 8 1/2, in the opening match of the 6 to 12 goal class of the national indoor polo championships at the 124th Field Artillery Armory.

College sport returns to the first event it ever knew this coming Saturday when Oxford and Cambridge meet once more in what England and the world knows as "the University Boat Race." It is the only intercollegiate rowing event in England and the oldest intercollegiate sporting event of any kind in the world.

THE report of the Legislature's Highway Survey Committee, of which Senator George R. Fearon is the chairman, covers seventy pages and the State of New York. It deals too extensively with too many related subjects to be summarized adequately in any review that must be confined to a newspaper column, but the object toward which every one of its pages joins the others in pushing can be stated in a sentence.

MOSCOW, March 28. -- The vigorous renewal of armed clashes on Russia's Far Eastern border and Japanese insistence that the proposed border investigating commission be limited to a study of only part of the Soviet-Manchurian boundary were ascribed today by the newspaper Izvestia to efforts of "adventurous elements" in the Japanese Army to maintain the strained relations between Russia and Japan.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- With three Federal District Courts holding the National Labor Relations Act constitutional and two courts regarding the law as invalid on constitutional grounds, the much-debated Wagner act will soon move on toward the Supreme Court for a final judgment as to its legality.

IN "South Riding," by Winifred Holtby, author of "Mandoa! Mandoa!" we have a very fine, substantial, panoramic novel of Yorkshire, somewhat in the vein of Anthony Trollope, although it would be a mistake to carry the analogy too far.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 28. -- A freshman electrical genius who combined a broken-down church organ, an old vacuum cleaner, a bottle of salt water and three electric light bulbs to produce a completely automatic organ that plays with the ease of a piano, has presented his "brainchild" to the stare of Princeton undergraduates.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 28. -- Reversing the score of last year's encounter with the Tiger nine, Fordham's baseball team today, downed Princeton, 2 -- 1, in a well-played game on University Field. It was the opening contest of the season for both teams.

WISCONSIN farm organizations in sixteen counties have organized active groups for the public discussion of rural problems. The University of Wisconsin College of Agriculture is aiding their plans to consider this season such questions as: "Why don't farm boys and girls go to high school?"

The Bermuda Blue Ball to be held at the Hamilton Hotel in Hamilton on Wednesday night is enlisting the active cooperation and support of prominent members of both the British and American colonies. Final plans are now being made for the event, which will be given for the benefit of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York and the Seamen's Institute of Bermuda.

A SECOND visit to the Vigeland Studios here in Oslo only accentuates the impression of four years ago (as then described in these columns) that this Norwegian project of a whole park of sculpture, now within a few years of completion, represents the one outstanding unified contribution within this field to the whole history of modern art.

TORONTO, March 28. -- A third-period scoring outburst in which Buzz Boll acounted for two goals and Harvey Jackson for one enabled the Toronto Maple Leafs to come from behind to defeat the New York Americans tonight, 3 to 1, in the opening match of the National Hockey League's semifinal play-offs.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., March 28. -- The Union College family had a foretaste tonight of the domestic felicity provided by the Hale House lounges and the new Colonial dining hall, sufficiently completed to permit an inaugural dinner for faculty, trustees, honorary fellows and students.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Contributions to the Red Cross flood relief fund today totaled $3,520,203. The organization announced that it had under its care more than 450,000 persons, with more families along the Ohio River and its tributaries being driven from their homes hourly by rising waters.
Four statements on the subject of peace or war made last week by four high officials of Old World nations deserve juxtaposition:

ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- The resort colonies of Asheville are being augmented daily by the arrival of Spring vacationists from the Northern States and by migrants en route to their Northern homes from Florida. Golf courses are dotted with players and the tennis enthusiasts are also out.

EUGENE SPEICHER, Charles Burchfield, Henry Mattson, Henry Varnum Poor, Allen Tucker, Edward Hopper, Kenneth Hayes Miller, George Biddle, John Carroll, Franklin Watkins, Morris Kantor, Reginald Marsh, Arnold Blanch, Henry Lee McFee and Peppino Mangravite are the "regulars" who participate in the "1936" group show of paintings and drawings at the Rehn Gallery (current until April 25).

Within two years Clifford Odets has become one of the theatre's major figures. In the season of 1934-35, the Group, with which he is associated, brought forth "Awake and Sing!" "Waiting for Lefty" and "'Till the Day I Die." This season it was "Paradise Lost."

Commodore William T. Crawford and others in the Middle Atlantic Outboard Association have added another superlative -- and with some justification -- to those they are using in describing the ninth annual Albany-to-New York marathon.

IN the olden days when the gringos were overrunning California, cutting up the original vast estates into ranches and mining claims, settling there and if they could not buy land squatting upon it, and the Alta-Californios were filled with bitter resentment at these things, young Romero Alvarado y Vallejo, heading a raiding party stampeding (but not stealing) cattle, was shot out of his saddle by the Vigilantes as darkness came down.

As its first move in an active campaign to bring the problem of venereal disease into the open, the Women's City Club, 22 Park Avenue, will open an exhibit of original posters, charts, pamphlets and books on prevention, treatment and cure, at its clubhouse on Wednesday.

The hearings at Albany on bills calling for compulsory insurance for motor vehicles seem to have brought out no new contentions on either side. The need for proper compensation for the victims of accidents is too clear to require argument. It has been calculated that automobile victims are dying in this State at the rate of one every three hours, and are being injured at nearly thirty-nine times that rate.

THERE are echoes of "Point Counter Point" and "The Counterfeiters" in this strange, rather brilliant book which seeks a new and fluid method of reducing chaos to some kind of order. Taking the reader behind the scenes, Mr. Bertram, a young Englishman, shows him how a novel can be constructed and what problems beset the writer in quest of an adequate formula for the confusion of modern life.

As a name HENRI MIGNET means little to Americans. In Europe he is a person of some consequence. His Pou de Ciel -- politely translated "Flying Flea" by the sensitive British -- lives up to its name. Seated in this homemade Pou Mr. MIGNET has crossed the Channel from St. Inglevert to Lympne in fifty-two minutes.
THIS department is in receipt of an advance copy of "The Foundations of Chinese Musical Art," by John Hazedel Levis. The publisher is Henry Vetch of Peiping.

By way of observing the centenary of the publication of "Pickwick," for which the first serial installment issued from the London press on March 31, 1836, The Nineteenth Century and After contains an article, written by a devoted Dickensian, on "How Press and Public Received the Pickwick Papers."

TO turn the leaves of this sturdy volume is to be moved with admiration of the patience, discrimination and literary deftness with which the editor has made his enormous collection of aphorisms and epigrams, to feel awed by the vast amount of labor, pains and time he must have put into it, and warmed by gratitude that he has made so easily accessible such a treasury of wit and wisdom.

BICYCLES will begin to roll again on a path of their own in Central Park on April 11. This event, which will be marked by a costume pageant, is one more evidence of the swing back to the once almost universal pastime of cycling in the United States.

Mrs. Charles S. Whitman gave a dinner last night at the Colony Club for her daughters, the Misses Anne S. Grosvenor and Louise T. Grosvenor, the guests later going to the Metropolitan Dance at the Ritz-Carlton and Miss Robinson's dance at the Plaza.

WHEN the depression struck the Colts with hurricane force, it wiped out Larry's Wall Street job and obliterated the financial value of their good old family name and their social standing. Susan, not altogether sorry, decided that from then on everything would be different.

ST. LOUIS, March 27. -- Missouri is in the unusual position of having three candidates for the Republican presidential nomination as its immediate neighbors -- Governor Landon of Kansas to the west, Colonel Knox of Illinois to the east and Senator Dickinson of Iowa to the north.

OMAHA, Neb., March 27. -- There has been some expression of opinion within the last few days that things have been looking a little up for Roosevelt in the Corn Belt. The belief is probably based on a considerable abatement of attacks on the New Deal and its policies.

THE distinctive features of Fletcher Pratt's work are partly those of manner, style and diction, but more those of conception, of approach. Not so much approach to consideration of a given subject; approach also to the whole method of treatment.

Friends and admirers of "Muster" Glencannon will heartily welcome the fourth volume of his roistering adventures. If you haven't met that distinguished old reprobate, Chief Engineer of the S.S. Inchcliffe Castle, and if you enjoy seagoing exploits in which Scotch canniness rules the waves, get "Three Sheets in the Wind" and make Mr. Glencannon's acquaintance.

Up to the last chapter this is an absorbing story of the deductions of Jabez Twombley, the country-bred detective who appeared in "The Murder of Miss Betty Sloan." But in that last chapter we find ourselves with two suspects, with about equally good evidence against each of them, and with no hint of collusion.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- A bill to compel deportation of criminal aliens, but at the same time to legalize the status of certain aliens who have entered the country illegally, was reported favorably today by the Senate Immigration Committee.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 28. -- The Spring vacation period, beginning today, will be utilized by a number of Princeton University juniors and seniors to obtain vocational information and advice from "alumni advisers" under a new program being arranged with the assistance of an alumni advisory committee.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 28. -- Mrs. Alfred D. Bell entertained today with a musicale at her home. Victor Hammer sang a number of Russian airs to his own guitar accompaniment. Several of the guests remained for a buffet supper and cards later.

The National A.A.U. indoor swimming championships for men and women will be decided at a four-day carnival in Chicago this week, starting Wednesday, and they are awaited with particularly keen interest, not only because they should afford a good idea of American Olympic prospects, but because the laurels of several title-holders appear to be seriously threatened.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 28. -- Recent endorsements of the charter plans of the Westchester Government Commission by influential organizations may force action on reform this year.

Critical reviews of different phases of its program by outstanding speakers will be a salient feature of the fourteenth convention of the New York State Conference of the National Council of Jewish Women, which will be formally opened tonight at Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, L.I.

BOMBAY. -- Under the existing living and farming conditions India can sustain a population of 441,000,000 persons and in another twenty-five years the population will have overrun that mark, according to Professor Mukerjee of Lucknow University, who spoke at the first Indian population conference held recently here.

PHILADELPHIA, March 28. -- The University of Pennsylvania nine was defeated by the Penn A.C. in an eight-inning contest on Franklin Field today, 11 to 9. The club team originally was scheduled to help Swarthmore College open the season, but the Garnets' field was not in shape and Coach Cariss invited them over for a practice game.

THERE is no question about the truth to life of Captain Jocelyn Lee Hardy's scenes of violence. He has been through similar scenes himself, or through worse. The story of his five attempts to escape from German prisons showed him a born fighter.

Gimbel Brothers, Inc., reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended Jan. 31 last net operating profit after depreciation of $1,539,652, as compared with an operating loss of $51,051 in the preceding twelve months. Net profit, after all deductions, was $1,017,332, contrasted with a net in 1934 of $347,586, which resulted from non-operating credits of $598,638.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP). -- A partial summary of salaries and compensation of corporation executives in New York State for 1934 was submitted today to Congress by Secretary Morgenthau as follows:

Contests for delegates to the Republican National Convention in ten Congressional districts and a State-wide fight for control of the State organization of the Socialist party will mark the primary election next Thursday.

Mrs. John H.F. Haskell has formed a junior committee to aid in the sale of seats for the performance of "Saint Joan," with Katharine Cornell in the leading role, the night of April 13 at the Martin Beck Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for St. Faith's House in Tarrytown.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 28 -- The Newark Bears beat the Dodgers in the tenth inning today, 6 to 5, and went happily back to their Sebring base in the rain, while Casey Stengel returned unhappily to his hotel talking to himself.

THE taint of insanity was in the Garland blood. For three generations all the Garlands who reached the age of 30 had gone mad. And so Dusty Dan Garland of the fourth generation and last of the line knew when he reached 29 that he had only one year to go.

BELLEAIR, Fla., March 28. -- The rumor through Pinellas County was that Landis, J., of the Supreme Court of Baseball, had been sitting tight on a couple of interesting cases and might be ready to render a few decisions. He was sitting on the veranda taking a judicial view of the emerald waters of the Gulf of Mexico when this tourist caught up with him.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., March 28. -- Three stakes were completed today in the annual field trial meeting of the North Shore Game Protective Association. The competition was opened this morning on the estate of Gerald M. Livingston in Lloyds Neck.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 28. -- Welcoming a year's contributions from the alumni fund of $269,869 from 7,355 graduates, in which twenty-six academic and twenty-nine scientific department classes increased their contributions, President Angell of Yale University in a statement today appealed for the sympathetic support of alumni.

FANTASTIC crime stories are Mr. Keeler's specialties. Any book of his can be depended upon to present so many bizarre complications that the reader is hopelessly bewildered, particularly as Mr. Keeler's characters talk and write in veritable torrents.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 28. -- Curriculum conferences and sports exhibitions will feature the fourth annual preparatory school week-end at Rutgers University, April 24 and 25, which will be attended by 300 selected high and preparatory school students from all parts of the East.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 28 (AP). -- Dipping and climbing in strong breezes, twenty-one sailing vessels swept across the starting line today in the seventh annual St. Petersburg-Havana yacht race and headed into the open waters of the Gulf of Mexico.

An economist said recently that women own two-fifths of the nation's wealth and that in time they will own more and more. The political observer may point to the tremendous influence women wield in politics, and the social student may draw attention to the entrenched, pivotal position women occupy in our economic life.

BETWEEN 150,000 and 250,000 persons are now planning a Spring journey to Washington. The nation's capital not only can count on this but knows it almost statistically. The passage of close to a quarter of a million Spring sightseers through Washington, between the last week in March and early May, has become one of the fixed American seasonal migrations.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- With a number of interesting sport events on the calendar for the remainder of March and early April, the event attracting attention here this week is the eighth annual women's Midsouth golf championship, to be held Southern Pines Country Club on Wednesday and Thursday.

The membership of the A.W.A. will fling wide its doors tomorrow and Tuesday in an old-fashioned routine of hospitality. Representatives of 350 organizations of women in the metropolitan area, including communities in Connecticut and New Jersey as well as New York State, will attend this revival of the tradition of open house and inspect the various club departments in action.

CAMDEN, S.C., March 28. -- The country's champion timber-topper, Indigo, was a gray flash against the green of the countryside today as he captured the seventh running of the Carolina Cup over the historic Springdale course while a crowd of 5,000 persons cheered him on.

FRAGMENTARY marble blocks found by American archaeologists in the Athenian agora have been identified by Sterling Dow, a Harvard Fellow of the American School of Classical Studies, as the hitherto unknown electoral machines of a city republic governed so democratically that it challenges imitation by its successors of today.
WASHINGTON, March 27. -- Floods in the East, dust in the West -- and Americans are warned once again that their conquest of a continent has loosed the elements of destruction.

An ordinance providing uniform penalties for makers of unnecessary noise, and thus putting teeth in the city's noise abatement campaign will be introduced in the Board of Aldermen this week by Alderman Murray Stand. It has the approval of Mayor La Guardia.

NOTHING would be better for orchestral conducting in this land, with the approaching and very regrettable departure of Arturo Toscanini from his post at the head of the Philharmonic-Symphony, than for various of his colleagues to cease imitating him by leading performances, without score, from memory.

THE first step toward weaving the television "talk-see" line between New York and Philadelphia has begun with construction of the so-called coaxial cable or "pipe" at the Western Electric plant in Baltimore. Terminal equipment is being designed at the Bell Telephone Laboratories in New York.

Announcements last week of bonds called for redemption before maturity were less than half the number called in the preceding week. Except for about six industrial calls, the notices were all for municipal bonds. There were no additional redemptions posted for this month, and the total of $160,094,000 for March, unchanged from last week, compared with $129,082,000 in February and $64,150,000 in March, 1935, for corresponding dates.

PARIS. MADELEINE VIONNET occupies a place apart in the Paris couture. Her art has a nobility that some compare to the effects of sculpture. Echoes of fashions first launched by Vionnet -- a sleeve, a neckline, the draping of a Sash -- continue strong in the visible mode for years after their first inception.
ONCE more the Metropolitan Museum has demonstrated its capacity to arrange shows that illumine the theme, whatever it may be, and that attract by virtue of a deft presentation of material.
HEWLETT, L.I., March 28. -- A tropical supper dance at the Seawane Club on Hewlett Harbor tonight was attended by 150 members of the South Shore colonies.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- The specter of new crop surpluses and falling farm prices has again risen to plague a national administration. Its agrarian leaders and political strategists are uncertain and dark shadows lie across the path of the fledgling soil conservation program.

One-third of the export and one-half of the import freight of the nation moves through the Port of New York, according to a report submitted by the Department of Commerce to the Foreign Commerce Club, which has undertaken a study of commercial traffic trends in the port.

To the office of the Blazon, a London newspaper, there comes on a Monday a letter that looks like a publicity stunt for the Murder League, a club composed of writers of detective stories. The letter calls attention to the great number of murders that have been committed on Mondays during the years since the war and suggests that all, or nearly all, of these murders may have been committed by the same person.

ROME, March 27. -- The speech that Premier Mussolini delivered last Monday to the National Assembly of Corporations marks a fundamental date in the development of fascism. Perhaps future generations will decide that the real Fascist revolution began only this week and that everything that went before was merely preparation for the profound social and economic changes, it is believed Italy is about to witness.

After the most thrilling final in the history of the 4-year-old event A.G. Thacher Jr. and Mrs. A.W. Paine captured the mixed doubles championship of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association for 1936 by defeating David B. McElroy of the University Club and Miss Margaret Bostwick of Sleepy Hollow yesterday at the Heights Casino.

CLEVELAND'S waterfront on Lake Erie resounds with the labors of thousands of workmen who are rushing to completion a "magic city" in which will be celebrated for 100 days, beginning June 27, the hundredth birthday of Cleveland and the century of progress which has converted the Great Lakes territory opened up by General Moses Cleave-land from an Indian-inhabited wilderness into a great iron and steel center.
The newly adopted daughter of former Mayor and Mrs. James J. Walker arrived here from Chicago late Friday night, her parents revealed yesterday at their home at 132 East Seventy-second Street.

Some years hence, when time has lent perspective, history may conclude that the worst fault of the Roosevelt Administration was its habit of changing its mind between the overture and the first curtain. Of this tendency the tax bill now before the Ways and Means Committee offers a perfect example.

FLOOD NOTES: For the week's most brilliant (and luckiest) newsreel shot, that of a terrified mob of Johnstown citizens hitting for high ground in cars, afoot, and on horseback after a false report that the big dam had gone, which would have thrown twenty additional feet of water into the town in twenty minutes, we salute Universal Newsreel with a couple of Very rockets and a parachute flare. (David Oliver, camera; Paul Hughes, assistant.)

In behalf of the Sisters of the Good Shepherd, two lectures have been arranged by members of the Good Shepherd Auxiliary, which will take place the afternoons of April 14 and 22 at the Waldorf-Astoria.

GLASGOW, March 28 (Canadian Press). -- Two noted Glasgow clubs will battle for the Scottish Football Cup at Hampden Park on April 18. In the penultimate round today, the Rangers gained the final with a 3-to-0 victory over Clyde while Third Lanark came from behind to defeat Falkirk, 3 -- 1.

Idlehour, built by the late William K. Vanderbilt a third of a century ago in Suffolk County as one of the outstanding country houses in the United States, has been purchased by a syndicate which expects to turn the place into a club or Summer resort.

CLINTON, N.Y., March 28. -- The Hamilton College Choir, called by some one of the leading college choral organizations, is enjoying another successful season, marked by concerts afield and a nationwide radio broadcast.

As an enrolled Republican pied by uninhibited free-trade complexes and similar unorthodox idiosyncrasies, I desire to raise one lone, protesting voice against the unrelenting build-up by my party of Kansas' Governor Alf Landon.

THE lives of the five men portrayed in this series of sketches all fall between the birth year of Humphry Davy, 1778, and the death of William Thomson, better known as Lord Kelvin, in 1907. Mr. Crowther finds it "significant that five scientists of their magnitude should have lived in one country during one century, and in that country where the industrial revolution had started and achieved its first triumphs."

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Where does the Townsend old-age pension movement go from here? That question is engaging many minds in Washington following the opening of a Congressional investigation and an open rupture in the movement's high command all within three days this week.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 28. -- Using the original of his famous putter "Calamity Jane" with a scoring touch such as he has rarely experienced, even at the height of his career, Bobby Jones cracked the Augusta national course record today with a 64, eight under par.

STUDENTS of Rutgers College who wish to arrange for a partner at a social function may now call upon a "data service." Founded at the beginning of the Fall term by a group of seniors, the bureau has arranged 200 "blind" dates.

A demonstration to protest the lay-off of 40,000 WPA workers, already under way, was staged by more than 2,000 men and women mobilized by the City Projects Council and other organizations of relief workers yesterday at WPA headquarters in the Port Authority Building, 111 Eighth Avenue.

MIAMI. -- Many Northern fishermen are remaining here to demonstrate their skill in the first annual metropolitan Miami fishing tournament, which will open next Sunday and continue through April 19. With national interest in deep-sea fishing in Miami waters stimulated by the annual outing of President Roosevelt, the new sports event is expected to get off to a good start.

HAVING always concerned itself with the welfare of women and girls, the Y.W.C.A., since its start in London in 1855, has paralleled the woman movement. Beginning as The Ladies' Christian Association to provide housing for nurses returning from the Crimean War, says Mary S. Sims, in a newly published history, it has participated in the changes occurring in the economic and social life of women ever since.

Many of the great field trial dogs of the United States will be seen in action this week in the annual field trial meeting of the English Setter Club of America, which will start tomorrow morning on the club's famous one-course preserve at Medford, N.J.

The contest between the Old Guard organization of the Socialist party and the left wing, headed by Norman Thomas, for control of the party in this State, which is to be decided at the primary election next Thursday, brought into the city yesterday delegates from near-by States and other party groups, which threw their support to the Old Guard.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Mexico filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an application for permanent registration of five of its bond issues now listed on the New York Stock Exchange, including $58,914,600 of two dollar bond issues, the others being in terms of other currencies.

In an atmosphere which stressed the gravity of the present threat to peace in Europe, some 600 members of the Foreign Policy Association heard Hitler's rearming of the Rhineland sharply attacked and vigorously defended at a luncheon meeting yesterday at the Hotel Astor, under the chairmanship of Raymond Leslie Buell, president of the organization.

Many women of society have subscribed as patronesses to the annual Spring dance of the Spence School Alumnae Society which will be held on April 16 in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Known as the Silver Spoon dinner and supper dance, the event each year benefits the Spence Alumnae Nursery at 232 East Sixty-second Street, which has as its outstanding feature of work the placement of infants for adoption.

Movements of security and commodity prices continued indecisive last week, with speculative activity at a low ebb. The term "selective" still applies to the buying of stocks, and the turnover in the stock market was the smallest of any week this year. Making for cheerfulness is the prospect of brisk Spring trade and the indications that the flood damage will not prove as great a setback to industrial recovery as had been first supposed.

Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute gained its second leg on the St. John's University rifle trophy, symbolic of the metropolitan intercollegiate championship, when its marksmen won the seventh annual St. John's tournament, held at the Manhattan School of Firearms yesterday.

IT is just nine years since I did this before. Those years have been enormously interesting and significant in the theatre, and in many ways a little bit depressing. When I stood up -- I think it was in the Lyceum Theatre I last faced the graduating class of the school -- when I stood up there nine years ago things were booming.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 28. -- The flooded Tennessee River, still rising steadily, poured far into the low-lying sections of Chattanooga tonight, washing about the foundations of 130 deserted homes and spilling destructively into the basements of numerous industrial plants.

PETER NEAGOE is the Rumanian painter whose delightful peasant tales appear from time to time in the smaller magazines, and whose rich and lively folk-novel, "Easter Sun," was published some two years ago. An immigrant to America in boyhood, he is in debt to us only for our language, which he has mastered perfectly; his subjects remain almost exclusively Rumanian.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., March 28. -- With the election of a Queen of the May by the undergraduates, Bryn Mawr College has begun its preparations for a quadrennial celebration of May Day as observed in the Elizabethan era.

OKLAHOMA CITY, March 27. -- This city having voted to open two tracts near the State Capitol to oil drillers, but not including an adjoining tract owned by the State, Governor E.W. Harland awaits the opinion of the Attorney General on whether he can use National Guardsman to protect drillers on the excluded State land.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- This resort will have both its Horse Show and its most important amateur golf tournament of the season this week. Later there will be two major golf tournaments, the tennis tournament, the Dog Show and the trapshooting championship, but these events are not bunched as this week's are.

The title of this novel is the clue to its romantic theme. Even more specific is its subtitle, "In the Garden of Edenbridge," Evelyn's charming little house in Abbey Road, London. But there was no serpent. The disturbing element was the fact that Evelyn loved Adam, but to Adam Evelyn was only the possessor of a divine voice, which he conscientiously coached, accompanied and admired.
With the trout season opening in this State next Saturday, the question uppermost in the minds of many metropolitan district anglers is, "Where can I go to wet a line?"

It is heartening to observe the lively and well-planned crusade of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union to checkmate, or rationalize, a widespread and ill-advised propaganda of liquor interests that is apparently calculated to make the United States the most disgustingly wet nation on earth.

There will be no official Northeast first and reserve field hockey teams chosen this coming season, according to a decision reached at the executive committee meeting of the Northeast Association at the Carroll Club yesterday. Instead there will be three days of more or less informal play, combined in all likelihood with the annual umpiring conference.

LONDON, March 28. -- The Pickwick centenary celebrations continued today with the annual conference of the Dickens Fellowship, held in the old hall of Lincoln's Inn, with its memories of "Bleak House" and Jarndyce vs. Jarndyce.

Assessment increases of $203,000,000 on properties of public utilities was cited as its greatest achievement of 1935 by the Board of Taxes and Assessments yesterday in its annual report to Mayor La Guardia.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 28. -- When a college president makes the rounds of the fraternity houses and wakes up sleeping students in their dormitories at 4 o'clock in the morning to do relief work for the Red Cross, that is news.

HAVANA, March 28 (AP). -- The prosecutor of the Audience Court here presented provisional accusations of murder and homicide today against former Major Pedros A. Castells and nineteen men who were under his command as warden of the model prison.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Men and women in fifteen groups of work in the field of art occupations in industry will lead round-table discussions at a conference to be held in New York at the clubhouse of the American Woman's Association April 25, Mrs. Jouett Shouse, chairman of the Institute of Women's Professional Relations, stated today.

An open meeting of the Home Makers Forum at the Hotel Pennsylvania on Thursday will be made the occasion for beginning a new enterprise of the department of municipal welfare of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs. It is a program of social hygiene, with Miss Laura A. Cauble as chairman, and plans for similar meetings in the various boroughs as an integral part of the project.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 28. -- The coming steamer tourist season will be one of the most active on the West Coast in many years, advance bookings overseas and on the East Coast indicate. The signs are especially promising for the big, fast liners operating between New York and San Francisco, which have been crowded almost to capacity even during the Winter months.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 28. -- Pat Malone came on the scene at Waterfront Park today in time to point the way not only to a Yankee victory but to the first shutout the McCarthymen have scored in this Spring exhibition play, and to forge a link in the chain he hopes will lead to a berth as a starting pitcher.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Regulations governing the selection of 1,000 reserve officers for training in the regular army for one year as second lieutenants, beginning next July 1, were issued by the War Department today.
DELAWARE, Ohio, March 28. -- A young astronomer from Holland, Professor Gerard Kuiper, announced tonight the discovery of a double star whose speed of revolution is the fastest yet known.

NEWARK airport, having again won its fight with New York over the designation as Eastern air-mail terminal, is deriving great contentment these days from the compilation of traffic figures for 1935 which has just been completed. This shows unquestionably the great activity of the airport where large sums of WPA money are now beginning to solve drainage and runway problems on a field the surface of which has long been far from ideal.

The collection of Owen Davis plays extends by this time almost around the room. There are melodramas, sentimental tales, folk plays, love stories and all the rest, for Mr. Davis is none of your specialized dramatists. Among the best three or four in all that vast gathering -- for he dashes off a couple a year -- is "Ethan Frome," derived from Mrs. Wharton's novel by Mr. Davis and his son, Donald.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- In the liquidation of more than 1,400 national banks under his jurisdiction, J.F.T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, through receivers, has carried Uncle Sam into a varied assortment of business enterprises.

CHICAGO, March 28. -- The wheat market on the Board of Trade showed a much improved undertone today, with a let-up in the recent scattered liquidation. May started fractionally off at a new low mark for the current downturn, but no pressure developed later.

Members of the Elmira College Glee Club will give their first concert here on Wednesday night in the Music Room of the Biltmore. Well-known alumnae of the college living in the metropolitan district are among the patronesses of the event.

Thirteen-year-old Jack Weipert, a student at Samuel J. Tilden High School, Brooklyn, was selected as the outstanding performer and received the championship award at the junior riding competition and horse show held by the Brooklyn Riding and Driving Club in its spacious arena at Prospect Park Plaza yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, March 28. -- A warning against permitting American schools to be turned into agencies of propaganda for the training of "yes men" for either the Right or Left was sounded today by Dr. Glenn Frank, president of the University of Wisconsin, at the schoolmen's week program at the University of Pennsylvania.

BERLIN, March 28. -- Chancellor Hitler clearly is determined to obtain in tomorrow's elections a 98 or 99 per cent vote for his regime -- or as near 100 per cent as is humanly and technically possible. To this end the high-geared Nazi party machine has undertaken to compel every eligible voter, whether a party member or not, to go to the polls.

CHALK signs on building, walls and sidewalks are entering British politics again. On the Embankment, in Piccadilly Circus, around Victoria Station -- everywhere in London as well as in many provincial towns of Great Britain -- slogans in chalk can be seen, usually accompanied by Communist or Fascist symbols.

THIS is a story of boyhood adventure and adolescent conflict of soul, romantic gypsy inheritance at odds with a more staid temperament drawn from Anglo-Saxon forbears. As such, it should please a double set of readers.

GLASS is more extensively used in our homes today than it was even in Venice during the heyday of Venetian glass-making. As quickly as the technician develops a carved or sand-blasted method of ornamentation we find the decorative designer making use of the embellished glass for screens, wall coverings, or the fronts of dressing tables.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 28. -- Republican favorite sons are being groomed at the University of Rochester preparatory to a model Republican National Convention to be held on the river campus April 23 and 24.

More than $300,000 is being spent on the renovation of Lewisohn Stadium at City College, scene of the Philharmonic Summer concerts and numerous athletic events, according to a review issued yesterday by President Frederick B. Robinson. The renovating program, begun as a Federal relief project in 1932, will be completed by next Spring.

Alterations begun less than three weeks ago to transform three and a half floors of offices and showrooms in the building at 2 Park Avenue into classrooms and laboratories for Hunter College students, whose programs were curtailed when fire destroyed the Park Avenue building of the college on Feb. 14, have been completed.

It has been said that separate and apart from taxes paid, the cost to taxpayers in the United States of preparing, filing and proving income-tax returns exceeds $1,000,000,000 a year. Assuming this statement to be true, if the suggested form of tax upon corporate undistributed earnings should be enacted into law, the share of such expenses now borne by corporations might well be expected to greatly increase.

In 1923 a Federal law which would have had the effect of raising the market value of women's services in the District of Columbia was held invalid in Adkins v. Children's Hospital, 261 U.S. 525. And on March 3 of this year a New York law which merely prohibits the payment of less than the existing value of the services was also held unconstitutional by the Court of Appeals.

I DOUBT if even China can equal our record of soil destruction. Within two or three hundred years, but mostly within the last hundred, we have ruined 50,000,000 acres of crop land in the United States, have seriously damaged probably 50,000,000 acres more, and are now making inroads upon another 100,000,000 acres.
Alice put down the morning paper and looked dolefully out of the window. "They're voting again in Europe," she said.

Color is all important in the new cottons and linens which will be featured in cotton shop sections opening around April 15, according to a fashion report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Tobe, fashion authority and consultant to more than 100 stores throughout the country.

LOS ANGELES, March 28. -- Belief that a human skeleton unearthed by WPA workers here may link the American Indian with the Mongolian race is expressed by Dr. A.O. Bowden, chief of the University of Southern California Anthropology Department, and some colleagues.

THE novels, generally characterized as "light," which Mrs. Banning has been producing steadily at the rate of one a year since 1920 -- skipping, it would seem, only thrice -- have won her a large following of readers whom she has delighted by her easy style and by her expert story-building.

When Premier Mussolini, at a meeting of Fascist corporations last Monday, announced his intention to effect sweeping constitutional and economic reforms in preparation for a war he regards as inevitable, he took one more step toward "coordination" of Italy's economic activities within the framework of the totalitarian State.

Miss Elsa Maxwell, inventor of social diversions for jaded society folk, sailed at noon yesterday on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia, more than a little uplifted and inspired by the thought that society was leaning toward the simple life.

Lower salaries, wages and profits and considerably reduced operating expenses account for much of the wide margin which separates selling prices of Japanese goods from those of American and other producers, H. Bentley MacKenzie, manager of the Western Electric Company (Orient), Ltd., with headquarters in Tokyo, told THE TIMES yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- America's reputed $500,000,000 racehorse business is under the close scrutiny of the Federal Government in connection with the nation-wide drive against the use of narcotics to stimulate or depress the running ability of the animals.

With the sailing from this port of the liner Carinthia next Saturday, the Cunard White Star Line will inaugurate a direct service to Scotland. The Franconia and the Samaria also will operate in the service, sailing fortnightly, stopping only at Boston en route from New York to Greenock, the Clyde River port for Glasgow.

AS a further aid to safety and quick contact with hospitals and police, an Evanston (Ill.) city ambulance and ten patrol cars will be equipped for two-way radio communication through installations to be made by the General Electric Company.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Economy, a word little used in Washington for three years, appeared again this week in the vocabulary of Congressmen and officials. Sanctioned by President Roosevelt, it became orthodox. Those who ponder upon the desirability of curtailing government expenditure no longer feel constrained to speak of the subject in whispers.
