USING a single family as his point of focus, Alexei Tolstoi has endeavored to translate their drama into the very drama of the Russian Revolution itself, and to impart to their destiny something significant of the Russian middle class as a whole.

PHILADELPHIA, March 28. -- Tom Gucker of Princeton broke his own world's record in the eleventh annual Eastern Intercollegiate Gymnastic League meet at Temple University today by scaling the twenty-foot rope in 3.8 seconds. Only a few weeks ago he set up a new record of 0:03.9 here.
PARIS, March 26. -- Smart Parisiennes don't take kindly to colored daytime stockings, except for active sports; but they are adopting them in pale pastel shades, fine as cobwebs, for evening.

TO "air mark" the United States so that airmen need never be lost for more than a few minutes during clear weather would require only 5,619 air markers, or an average of 117 per State, according to R.G. Parker, chief of the air marking division of the Illinois Aeronautics Commission, in an article describing his nation-wide plan in the current issue of The National Aeronautic Magazine.

Attention of a number of leading organizations of women will focus on Albany on Tuesday, when a hearing on the Child Labor Amendment is scheduled by the Senate Judiciary Committee. The legislation has been a topic of discussion and debate in the ranks of the feminine groups for years, and carries the endorsement of a majority.

"Lady Precious Stream" has been standing them up by the Great Wall for several centuries, one of China's favorite plays and among the oldest. Dr. S.I. Hsiung, who is a sort of middleman of languages -- translating Barrie, for example, into Chinese -- has made an adaptation for the English speaking stage.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 28 (AP). -- Baseball bounced into the nation's 1936 sports picture today at a Pacific Coast League opening which attracted more than 30,000 fans in four California cities.

MOST of us can recall closing a favorite volume with an ardent longing for a sequel which the author never wrote. Occasionally some book lover is able to translate this desire into accomplishment and himself writes a continuation of the story in the style of the original.
BERLIN, March 28. -- The Boerse remains under complete political domination, and activity is relatively limited. Today's market showed scattered signs of strength.

Novel fashion shows in behalf of charitable organizations have been arranged for the coming week. Stony Wold Sanatorium at Lake Kushaque, N.Y., will be aided by a fashion revue entitled, "Pairs on Parade," which will be presented during the luncheon hour Tuesday in the Tudor Room of the Lombardy.

Mayor La Guardia's proposal to set up a permanent city Department of Commerce and Labor to settle labor disputes and avert strikes received yesterday the disapproval of William D. Rawlins, executive secretary of the Realty Advisory Board.
LONDON, March 27. -- The openings for next week are these: ...

WHAT is this exotic, bright-plumed bird of passage cleaving a glamorous way across murky Victorian skies and leaving clouds of scandal in its wake? Surely, not one to be classified and ticketed in acordance with custom.
Mark Eisner, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, has expressed his approval of the general principle of unification for the city colleges.

Five pupils of the city's public schools, each representing a borough, will appear with Mayor La Guardia, Postmaster General Farley and Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, as speakers at the ninth annual celebration of Parents' Day on the Mall in Central Park, Sunday, May 10.
HAMILTON, Bermuda. -- With an exceptionally large number of visitors already in the island, it is expected that Bermuda Rugby Week, starting Monday, will attract unusual interest.

ANY novel which has New Orleans for a setting is usually oversupplied with atmospheric color. This is not true of "Day of Victory." Though Miss Linfield sketches in her background well, she does so lightly and, as it were, incidentally.

ATLANTIC CITY. -- Two events of interest -- the seventeenth annual Dog Show of the Atlantic City Kennel Club and the selection of the "fifty best-dressed women on the Boardwalk" -- are on the calendar for the Palm Sunday week-end.

Notwithstanding New York's reputation as anything but a city of private homes, single-family house areas dominate the city, the Mayor's Committee on City Planning reported yesterday. This fact was shown by the first of a series of maps of the city completed by the committee, of which Aldermanic President Timothy J. Sullivan is chairman.

While a small colony of campers is awaiting the Judgment Day in the California mountains three persons are murdered. Rocky Allan and his wife are on hand, not because they believe in the prophecies of Sapphira Barlow, but because their friend Theophilus Pope has sent for them.

The Citizens Union, through its committee on legislation, endorsed yesterday the State Health Insurance Bill, introduced by Senator Mandelbaum, as "a carefully constructed and practicable answer to one of the most serious problems with which the average person is confronted -- the high cost of proper medical care."

ADVANCE program schedules for April reveal no signs of a widespread Spring exodus from the radio studios. The few sponsors and performers who have served notice that they will relinquish their time on the air during the Spring and Summer, generally find other shows anxious to shift to the new time made available.

THE Philadelphia Orchestra, under Leopold Stokowski, will give its eighth and final New York concert of the season Tuesday night, April 7, in Carnegie Hall. The program will consist of three excerpts from Wagner's 'Parsifal," entr'acte from "Lady Macbeth of Mzensk" and Prelude in E flat minor, by Shostakovich, and Rimsky-Korsakoff's Russian Easter" overture.

THIS spiritual home of early American Revolutionary sentiment has launched a new revolution. Starting with its young folk, it has inaugurated a drive to root the spirit of competition out of the city's -- and eventually the nation's -- life, and to supplant it with the oft-praised but seldom practiced virtue of cooperation.

THAT margin of leadership in aviation, especially commercial aviation, of which the United States has been proud, is rapidly being cut down, according to the testimony of the latest competent observer to return from first-hand contact with developments in Europe.

SEA ISLAND, Ga. -- Assembling about a great bonfire on the beach in front of the Sea Island Casino, a group of Cloister guests and Sea Island residents will hold a beach party on Thursday evening. Songs, games and novel entertainment will be on the program.

THE anonymous authors of this book must have labored long to collect such an abundance of material on the world-wide ramifications of National Socialism and its system of political espionage. They have accomplished a remarkable feat by steering clear of generalization and overstatement, two cliffs on which more than one embittered political refugee has come to grief.

THIS swift new broadside by the most influential poet writing in America today swings with complete mastery from public issues that are shaking the world to the intensely personal confrontations of one man and one woman.

ROBERT BRACKMAN is having two shows. The larger one is at the Fifth Avenue establishment of the Grand Central Galleries (through this week). It contains his recent oils -- nearly a score of canvases, concerned, on the subject side, with figure work, portraiture, still-life and landscape.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Notice given by Senator Borah in a speech at Chicago that he, who has never openly bolted the Republican party, does not guarantee it his active support under certain circumstances in 1936 has undoubtedly affected the party prospect in a fundamental way.

IT'S not the Hayden Planetarium that's ruining his business, says one of the young men who set up telescopes in the streets; it's those whirligigs, those oranges that rise like suns, those meteors and comets and nebulae that are being run by electricity -- all those fake stars that shine along Broadway.

BEETHOVEN symphonies have been forming the programs of the Tuesday concerts of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra, in accordance with the annual custom of presenting the immortal nine in a weekly cycle in the German capital at this time of the year.

The last material obstacle to complete motorization of the street car lines of the New York Railways system in Manhattan was removed yesterday by a decision of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals. The court affirmed a District Court ruling that found the company insolvent and approved its reorganization plan.

The 1936 baseball campaign at University Heights was ushered in yesterday as William V. McCarthy's fifteenth New York University nine defeated an alumni squad, 9 to 2, before a crowd of 1,000 at Ohio Field.

Retail activity last week set a new high mark for the year, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buying office. Demand for coats and suits neared a peak for the season, with some stores reporting increases of from 25 to 50 per cent.

A MUSICAL festival featuring the group activities and accomplishments of the Federal Music Project is planned to be held early in May. In addition to public concerts, there will be demonstrations in the various centers.

BOSTON, March 27. -- Not in many years has Beacon Hill witnessed such uproarious scenes in its public hearings on proposed legislation as have marked the meetings just concluded on the bill for the repeal of the Teachers' Oath Law.

The story of an average American family living in Cleveland, "The Mainspring" deals affection ately and entertainingly with ordinary domestic happenings. It stresses the abiding strength of family loyalties. The high points in the Ramsdells' lives are concerned with the problems of the three children who are all in their early twenties.

THIS, obviously, is just the book for connoisseurs of the bizarre. Felipe Alfau, who calls himself an author at the mercy of his characters, is a young Spaniard living in America and writing, very wittily, in English.

SPRING blossoms forth today in a very realistic manner in Rockefeller Center, where, for the advent of the Easter season, the Sunken Plaza, the "channel" between the British Empire Building and La Maison Francaise, and other areas will be made gay with full-grown flowering Japanese cherries, azaleas in a wide range of colors, rhododendrons, dogwood, forsythias, magnolias, crabapples and flowering bulbs.

The campaign for and against the abolition of teachers' salary cuts, now a perennial program, again is reaching a climax with arguments hinging on the question as to whether the emergency which brought the reductions still exists.

BALTIMORE, March 28. -- Representatives in Congress from several States and members of their families, twenty-seven in all, were guests of the Pan American Airways today in a flight aboard the new Hawaiian Clipper.

A collision between a Webster Avenue trolley car and a new automobile at Webster Avenue and 209th Street late last night caused injuries to twenty persons, twelve of whom were taken to Fordham Hospital. None was in a serious condition.

From Maine to California the country has laughed this month -- or else growled -- over the sudden clamor of thousands of college students and other audacious young Americans for the immediate payment of a government bonus to them as veterans of future wars of the United States.

TRENTON, N.J., Sunday, March 29. -- Even though Governor Harold G. Hoffman wishes otherwise, developments today indicate that Bruno Richard Hauptmann will die in the electric chair on Tuesday unless the Court of Pardons, meeting on Monday, commutes his sentence or grants a stay.

Two firemen, trapped by clouds of choking fumes, clung to a window ledge more than seventy-five feet above the street level at 188 Huntington Street, Brooklyn, early last night until comrades were able to reach them by a ladder placed across a courtyard.

MR. McSPADDEN spreads a wide net in collecting the subjects for his book on light opera and musical comedy -- wide both in the periods covered and in the character of his material. He found the task of blazing the trail for such a book, of which, he says, there are no predecessors, an arduous and perilous performance, as he explains at length in his introduction.

NOW there is "Pride and Prejudice" for the Austenites -- or the Janeites, which is the British branch of the family. Helen Jerome has condensed the novel without losing the spirit of the main characters, making it alike playable for the stage and entertaining for the library.
ST. LOUIS, March 28. -- The best part of the second day of the twenty-fourth annual dog show of the Mississippi Valley Kennel Club was devoted to the judging of sporting dogs and terriers.

EVERYTHING LOVELY: About this time of year in the Nineteen Twenties the suspense would end only when the news came from the South that Babe Ruth, for a fairly ample contractual consideration, had signed up again with the Yankees and had gone into Spring training.

By the margin off a single point, Evander Childs High School captured its first P.S.A.L. indoor track and field championship last night as Coach Walter Degnan's athletes amassed a total of 28 points, one more than De Witt Clinton, in the thirty-third annual title meet at the Seventh Regiment Armory.
BUFFALO, March 28 (AP). -- A section of the Genesee Valley south of Rochester remained the only bad flood area in Western New York tonight.

THE proposal of Charles A. Harnett, New York's Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, for a fixed speed limit in this State of fifty miles an hour is a reversal of the trend toward regulations providing for "reasonable and proper" speeds which began several years ago and extended to many States.

ALBANY, March 28. -- Governor Lehman, it was announced here today, has called a conference for Tuesday at the Capitol in an effort to find ways and means in which the State can cooperate in the World's Fair of 1939.

To assist with preparations for the annual Butterfly Ball dinner-dance on April 14 at the Ritz-Carlton, a large dance committee has been organized under the direction of Mrs. Henry Holt and Mrs. Edward Thord-Gray. The party is given under the auspices of the junior auxiliary of the House of Rest at Sprain Ridge to assist that hospital in the treatment of persons afflicted with pulmonary tuberculosis.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, March 28. -- Experts today made a close inspection of the hull and keel of the liner Queen Mary as she lay high and dry in the King George V graving dock and found that she had been in no way damaged when she grounded on her trip down the River Clyde.

THERE is evidence on the air that Germany is expanding its short-wave broadcast plan, which is said to include new waves and higher power for existing transmitters. For instance, DJM, with a 6,080-kilocycle experimental listing, was heard at 4:50 P.M. recently on 9,679 kilocycles.

GERMANY heard its first performance of the original version of Mussorgsky's "Boris Gedunoff" recently in Hamburg, where it was staged at the State Opera. Naturally enough, this important musical event stirred up once again the feud of long standing between the admirers and detractors of the Rimsky-Korsakoff revision of the famous score.

THE commission appointed by Mayor La Guardia to study the growing menace of the drunken driver has found what it believes is a safe detour around the vexing problem of defining and proving drunkenness to the satisfaction of the courts.

Never was there so much political seed to the square acre sown so early as this year in a Presidential campaign, and never has so little of it sprouted. The activity of politician tillers of the soil has been intense. President ROOSEVELT urged members of his party to constitute themselves as "committees of one" to propagate the pure gospel of their party.

EXOTIC: Representatives of 42,000 beauty-shop owners of the United States, assembled last week in New York, selected Miss Ruth Coleman of Greenwich, Conn., as Miss 1937. (Blue eyes, reddish-blond hair, 5 feet 4, 106 pounds, 34-inch bust, 35-inch hips, 25-inch waist, married three years.)

Once again New York has had the honor of hearing Beethoven's Ninth Symphony performed by our distinguished New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society and the Schola Cantorum under the direction of Arturo Toscanini. The performance Thursday night and Friday afternoon again brought me face to ace with the ever present criticism concerning the choral finale; that it is written "too high,"

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Building construction activity in February was slightly below that in January, with a decline of 1.4 per cent in the value of building permits, but the total value of building was 86.8 per cent above February, 1935, Secretary Perkins reported today.

BOOKBINDING by hand, rich in traditions which date back to medieval times, is gaining rapidly in popularity among present-day hobbyists. Craft school and adult education directors report a growing demand for instruction in bookbinding and the related arts of tooling and cover design.

MOSCOW, March 27. -- In no department of its vast economic planning under a dictatorship does the Soviet Stare show itself more completely the master than in agriculture, the last field which it socialized. In agriculture, better perhaps than in anything else, this country is now demonstrating what socialism in the Soviet sense really means.

WASHINGTON. IN line with its increasing emphasis on the development of skills among its workers, WPA is broadening its program for assisting the blind. In twenty-two States projects for the blind are now in operation; others will soon be added.

Another three to five years must elapse before scientific marketing emerges from its present state of "canned" research into an era of intelligent and economical effort, carried on by individual companies, Frank R. Coutant, director of reseach for Pedlar Ryan and president of the American Marketing Society, told THE TIMES yesterday.

PATHOLOGISTS, physiologists, and nutrition experts met in Washington last week to tell one another and the world about the recent progress made in treating human ills. It is hard to single out any of their papers and hold it up as an outstanding contribution.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 27. -- The Progressive party in Wisconsin, controlled by the La Follette brothers, must choose between President Roosevelt and Senator William E. Borah of Idaho, in the election April 7 of national convention delegates.

PARIS, March 28. -- What might be termed the juridical era of the post-war period has ended. This means that the Versailles treaty stipulations, with the exception of its territorial provisions, are now dead.

BERLIN, March 27. -- The German people are going to the election on Sunday in much the same mood as a nation goes to war. They have buried for the occasion all personal differences, likes and dislikes; they have sidetracked genuine discontent with many conditions that pinch them; they are surrendering themselves to a great, inescapable inevitability that drags the individual along the path of national destiny whether he will or no.

A PUPPET show, touring the roads in a bright-painted truck, wandering the country over through Winter and Summer, with good luck and bad; three young puppeteers who did all their work for themselves, and who were some times hungry but always gay -- no, this isn't a European saga; this happened here.

ONE assumes that Barrett Willoughby knows her locale. She is herself a native Alaskan -- indeed, the first native Alaskan to find in that glamorous territory the stuff of fiction. Nevertheless, she has created here both a setting and a group of characters in whom it is next to impossible to believe.

Just now American shipping is constantly in the news. Efforts to secure greater safety at sea, frequent references to our shipping in radio programs, to say nothing of marine exhibitions, are helping us to become more sea minded. That is what America needs.

THE 100th anniversary of the first issue of the "Pickwick Papers" falls on March 31 of this year. In commemoration of that event, Charles Scribner's Sons, in conjunction with Chapman Hall, the original Pickwick publishers, will publish, early in April, "A Pickwick Portrait Gallery" containing prose portraits of various Pickwick characters by "divers admirers" and sixteen illustrations from the original plates by Seymour and "Phiz."

A bridge dansant will comprise the entertainment at the annual benefit of the Southern Women's Democratic Organization on Saturday in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Oliver Harriman will direct the card games and Miss Kitty Carlisle will be chairman of the committee in charge of the dancing.

Heralded by several fanfares of trumpets, an Angelfish, slightly more than 250 times its normal size; a Veiltail Fighting Fish, a Pompadour, a Bloodfin, three Rasbora and a following of four humble but monstrous tropical minnows floated into Times Square last night to stay.
LONDON, March 27. -- "If you want to know whether this new naval treaty is worth while," said a leading British delegate, "just try to imagine where we would be if there were no naval treaty at all."

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Consciousness, a force as mysterious as life itself and recognizable only indirectly through its manifestations, can now be "seen" by means of a "consciousness lens" described here today at the closing sessions of the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 28. -- The old-fashioned Summer school, with its conglomeration of unrelated courses and divided administrative responsibility, has given way at Cornell University to a carefully planned, unified Summer session designed to furnish a maximum of instruction and recreation to both young and old.

A ball and entertainment will be given in the main ballroom of the Plaza on Saturday night for the benefit of the Finch School Day Nursery, Inc., 338 East Sixty-ninth Street. It will mark the thirtieth anniversary of the beneficiary under the direction of its founder, Mrs. William H. Kelly.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 28. -- There are no Democratic or Republican primary contests in Westchester County but a number of Socialist contests. A list of candidates for delegates and alternates to the national conventions and members of the State committees follows:

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- A drive by supporters in Congress of Secretary Ickes for the appropriation of $700,000,000 for PWA heavy construction, in addition to the $1,500,000,000 requested by President Roosevelt for the work relief, threatened today the Chief Executive's plan to limit expenditures and new taxes.

PARIS, March 28. -- Symptoms of a new crisis in the franc were apparent in unofficial bank-to-bank transactions in foreign exchange today, when the pound reached 75.09 francs and the dollar 15.19, close to the gold-export point. The French are raising an outcry against speculators and in the nationalist press, especially, there is a charge that the British Exchange Equalization Fund's action is aggravating the tension.

In Japan the sailor, figuratively wearing on his arm the badge "M.P." (military police), laid a restraining hand last week upon the shoulder of the aggressive soldier. The army, driving ahead for four years in Asia, undeterred by curbs from outside Japan, ran head-on into the threat of a sharp check from within, from a quarter where it was least expected -- the navy.

Hollywood "gadgets," electric labor-saving devices and fancy dining rooms are not only not considered, but not wanted by the families living in New York's poorest "coldwater" flats, it was disclosed in a survey report made public yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 28. -- One of the most potent of war explosives promises to be a noteworthy agent in checking the spread of such epidemic maladies as encephalitis and infantile paralysis.

WITH the increased popularity of British and Continental architecture in America, gardens of the Old World type are also gaining in vogue. Espalier fruit trees, long a prominent feature of European horticulture, are consequently beginning to find a place in American gardens.

ASMARA, Eritrea, March 28. -- Forcing their way through two of the roughest sections of Ethiopia, Italian forces today took Socota and Debarech on widely separated fronts without the firing of a shot.

MADISONVILLE, Ky., March 28. -- Former Governor Ruby Laffoon came to the defense today of thousands of Kentucky colonels throughout the world whom Attorney General Beverly M. Vincent sought to "liquidate" with a ruling that their titles are "absolutely void."

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 28 (AP). -- The "Communist party, Section 2, District 25," today renewed its attacks on the Ku Klux Klan in Florida by inviting Jacksonville citizens to join those of Tampa in stamping out the organization with circulars signed by the Communists blamed for the tarring, feathering and flogging of three men in Tampa.

THIS republication of a most comprehensive study of the phenomena of sex is significant as a tribute to the steadfast, scholarly and enlightened pioneering of Havelock Ellis, a commanding figure in contemporary science and letters.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP). -- The Senate has voted to commemorate several periods in American history by authorizing coining of suitably engraved half-dollars.
CLEVELAND, March 28. -- The League of Nations was credited tonight by Newton D. Baker with having prevented the outbreak of a second World War in the past year.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Although the arrival of April terminates the standardized schedule of Winter, when golf, tennis, bridge and backgammon tournaments, gala dinners and luncheons at various clubs mark special days, there remain many informal events to hold the attention of those lingering late.

Army Day, calling attention to the necessity for an adequate national defense for the United States, will be celebrated nationally next Saturday by military, naval, veteran, patriotic and other organizations throughout the country.

CLEVELAND, March 28 (AP).-- Judge Joy Seth Hurd of Common Pleas Court will attempt to determine the legal timbre of noctural noises issuing from the throat of Megs, a two-year-old female Scottie, during an injunction suit hearing next Wednesday.

THE French Riviera is preparing for its Summer visitors. Although the old guard continues to patronize Cannes, Juan les Pins, Antibes and Nice, many tourists search for modest inns and small villas in the less prominent resorts.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- A week of festivities opens here tomorrow, when St. Petersburg pays tribute to its Winter guests with its annual Festival of States celebration. The program includes parades, dances, pageants and sports activities.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday the setting up of an interdepartmental agency, composed of representatives of eight branches of the city government, to deal with children running afoul of the law for the first time without instilling in them any fear of the courts.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- The disastrous floods centering in the Connecticut, Ohio, Susquehanna, Monongahela and other river basins east of the Mississippi, with their staggering tolls in lives and property, have awakened new interest here in long-delayed plans for a national flood-control policy.

Richard Wagner's grandson, Wieland Wagner, eldest son of the late Siegfried Wagner and Winifred Wagner, has just made his public debut as a designer for the stage. Six scenes of his designing have just been employed at the Municipal Theatre of Luebeck, Germany, in a production of Siegfried Wagner's "Der Baerenhaeuter."

LAST month there was shown at the Olin Memorial Library of Wesleyan University an unusually complete gathering of first editions of the late Edwin Arlington Robinson, together with original letters and manuscripts illustrating his career.

The Helvetia Maennerchor, now in its seventy-eighth season, gave a concert in the Town Hall last night for the benefit of the Swiss Benevolent Society of New York. The sixty-five members of the Swiss male chorus, under the direction of Edward E. Bechtel, delighted a large audience in a program made up principally of German and Swiss choral numbers, but also included selections in French and English.

CINCINNATI, March 28 (AP). -- The Ohio River, receding from above flood stage levels in the upper valley, pushed to higher stages below Cincinnati tonight and inundated additional thousands of acres of lowland sections in Kentucky and Indiana.

In behalf of the Cecilia Music School of the Madonna House Settlement there will be a recital by Jascha Heifetz, violinist, the night of April 21 at Carnegie Hall. Mrs. James Roosevelt is honorary chairman, and Mrs. V. Beaumonte Auguste is active chairman of the benefit committee.
PARIS, March 28 (AP). -- A French court today appointed a commission to investigate the complaint of Prince Pierre that his daughter had been "kidnapped" by her grandfather, Prince Louis of Monaco.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- In its broadest aspects the new naval limitation treaty signed in London last Wednesday means, in naval opinion here, that Great Britain and the United States, unless forced into heavy building programs by the activities of other powers, will adhere substantially during the next six years to the lines laid down in the Washington treaty of 1922 and the London treaty of 1930.

In one of the most dramatic and punishing matches court tennis has provided in a long time, Ogden Phipps of Roslyn, L.I., escaped defeat by a point and went on to win the national amateur championship for the third successive year yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 28. -- R. Marano finished with a card of 48 to annex the High Scratch Cup in a skeet event at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. S.C. Fowler had the same total but shot for targets only. C.H. Sayre, P.K. Leberman and L.M. Otis tied in the handicap competition, Sayre taking the extra string.
Flood-relief contributions to the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross yesterday were nearly $39,350, bringing the chapter's total fund to $420,829.18.

ST. PAUL, March 28. -- Sponsoring a plan pointing toward a possible national third party ticket in the 1936 political campaign, Minnesota Farmer-Laborites in State convention approved tonight a platform urging a changed economic system in which "monopolized industries ultimately will be collectively owned."

AFTER experimenting for months with small, fast-moving buses, Detroit's municipally operated Department of Street Railways has committed itself to this type of vehicle as against larger but slower buses. Lacking subways or any other form of public rapid transportation, Detroiters demand that bus schedules be speeded as much as possible in conformity with safety and efficient, comfortable service.

At 70, Bartholomew Blount, lord of the manor of Wintle Harford, was hale and hearty and irascible and rich. As such he was surrounded by a group of nieces and nephews, who all, with one exception, meekly endured his irascibility, longed to inherit his riches, and deplored the robust state of the old man's health.
NEWARK, N.J., March 28. -- The Ridgewood polo team, Jersey junior champions, came from behind to beat the Nassau Riding Club of Long Island, 7 1/2 to 3 1/2, tonight at the Essex Troop Armory.

Nobody can blame the Norwegians for their good intentions in presenting to Congress a painting of Leif Ericson discovering America five centuries before Columbus. But as the cult has long shown signs of getting out of hand perhaps it is time some advocatus diaboli like myself should intervene to note that we are dealing with legend, not with fact.

REPORTS received from various automobile companies, following tabulation of recent sales figures and surveys made to determine future probabilities, indicate that the anticipated Spring selling season is now definitely under way. Here are some of the reports from different sources offered as evidence of this.

THE famous "Knight, Death and Devil," by Duerer, has recently been acquired by the New York Public Library. "By the acquisition," writes Frank Weitenkampf in the Library Bulletin, "the Print Room now has that artist's famous three engravings, the others being 'Melancholia' and 'St. Jerome in His Study.'

PITTSBURGH, March 28 (AP). -- The Allegheny River flowed out of its banks today in Northwest Pennsylvania, flooding lowland streets of Franklin and Oil City and covering the Erie Railroad tracks at several points.

THE real theme of this book is to be found in the last of its eight essays -- "Some 'New' History and Historians." Professor Abbott's attack directed against the current school of "brilliant" history and soul-dissecting biography is not new; it first appeared in the volume of the Reports of the Massachusetts Historical Society and then in separate copies which a continuing demand has exhausted.

PARIS, March 21. -- Mrs. Burke Roche, Mrs. James Hyde, Mrs. Henri Van Heukelom, Francis Burke Roche and other Americans were at the reception given March 18, by Mrs. Blanche Vesnitch at her residence in the Avenue Pierre Ier de Serbie for Mrs. Albert Lebrun, wife of the President of the French Republic.

VIENNA, March 27. -- At first sight it is not easy to see what Chancellor Schuschnigg of Austria and Premier Goemboes of Hungary brought to their respective countries in their suitcases as souvenirs from Rome beyond additional protocols that seem rather a record gift to Premier Mussolini without substantial return.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP). -- After months of blueprint-drafting, officials of the Federal Housing Ad- ministration said today they had devised plans for a "small-town" house costing about $1,200.

VISITORS in the Deep South this week will find festivals prepared for them in Mobile, Natchez and Vicksburg -- festivals that will portray the romantic life of the old South in a setting provided by early Spring.

AS phlox spreads rapidly, it is desirable to lift and separate the clumps every second or third year. Often a gardener may arrange to trade some with a neighbor for different varieties. The finer, new varieties are available at moderate cost from nurseries, where one can compare colors while the plants are in bloom.

A bill to amend the State Banking Law in relation to the operation of personal loan departments by banks and trust companies which has been introduced in Albany as part of the State Banking Department's legislative program has aroused the strenuous opposition of a number of bankers.

The Keeshin Transcontinental Freight Lines, Inc., which, since its organization late in 1935, has developed into what is said to be the largest independent nation-wide truck transport organization, yesterday received a contract from the Baltimore Ohio Railroad Company for the store-door pick-up and delivery service in the principal areas served by the railroad.

THE battle which mankind has waged against plant pests since history began is continuing unabated with new weapons and new methods of attack. This year has seen increased use of the airplane and the autogiro in pest control, along with an improvement in the chemicals and methods of preventing disease outbreaks.

The choral festival of "American music and its ancestry" came to a close yesterday morning at Temple Emanu-El with a complete performance of Ernest Bloch's "Sacred Service" under the direction of Lazare Saminsky. The work itself is a Sabbath morning service, and yesterday marked its second performance.

WASHINGTON. THROUGH a WPA allotment of $500,000, young women on relief roils in New York City, the District of Columbia and twenty-one States, to the number of 7,600, will be trained, at public expense, as household workers. The instruction courses will include general housework, child care and the cooking and serving of food.
AN adroit, emphatic, eager journalist has here determined to win his public. He has seized the chance of telling a timely story as a stunt and a stunt it is.

FIRST, last and always, Professor Morison's Tercentennial History of Harvard is, precisely and monumentally -- just that; but, being so, it is much more. For the college was in its origin, and long continued to be, the glowing focus of the spiritual and cultural life of New England.

The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee estimated yesterday the number of refugees from Germany to various European countries since the beginning of the Hitler regime totaled 58,837. Of this total, 25,000 vent to France and 5,837 to Holland.

The International Seamen's Union asked for a court order yesterday to prohibit striking seamen of the Panama Pacific liner California from using the union's name in their activities along the North River waterfront. Following retaliatory measures by the line after they went on strike in California several weeks ago, the seamen refused to sign on a week ago Saturday and the company canceled the sailing, sending the California to drydock.

The Art Workers Club for Women, an organization of women artists and models, will benefit from a garden party to be held on April 16 at the opening of a modern garden apartment at the Hampton Shops, 18 East Fiftieth Street. The party, for which several features of entertainment are now being prepared, will have a springtime motif.

MR. HALL has moved his fictional scene from Africa to a rural township in Maine. The exotic adventures of dark "Salah and his American" seem even more removed when contrasted with the uneventful and undistinguished lives of New England's small farmers, yet the com monplace problems of the Harts of this story have more of interest to those in quest of the permanent in American literature.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 28 (AP). -- Standings in the American bowling congress tournament got another shakeup today as heavy firing was resumed following the lull occasioned by yesterday's business meeting.

The Citizens Family Welfare Committee's forthcoming campaign for a minimum of $1,500,000 for the support of private family welfare agencies was endorsed yesterday by Warden Lewis E. Lawes of Sing Sing, who characterized broken homes as a vulnerable spot in community life.
TRENTON, March 28. -- What lies behind Governor Harold G. Hoffman's personal activity in the case of Bruno Richard Hauptmann, and what effect will it have with regard to his own future?

The life of Charles Stewart Parnell, the leader of the Home Rule party in Ireland, was one of the most dramatic in fairly recent years. A prosaic chronological table would have made a play. But the late Elsie T. Shauffler did more than simply list the events, and so "Parnell" becomes a splendid drama for either the shelf marked history or that on romance.

PRAGUE, March 28. -- The proposal to settle the affairs of the Czechoslovak branch of the Austrian Phoenix Insurance Company by creating a premium guarantee fund similar to that established in Austria has met an insurmountable obstacle raised by other Czech insurance companies and certain political circles.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 28. -- Local Communists picketed the German Consulate and Hotel Statler here today as the national convention of the Friends of New Germany went into closed sessions. There was no disorder.

The decision of License Commissioner Paul Moss denying the Ringling Brothers-Barnum Bailey Circus permission to open in Brooklyn this Spring has been received with unconcealed dismay and incredulity in the borough.

Whether the gently mad Messrs. Hecht and MacArthur are the prototypes for much in "Boy Meets Girl" is probably beside the point. The Spewacks, Bells and Samuel, being forthright people and kind, have-denied it. The Messrs. Hecht and MacArthur have simply laughed.

NASSAU, Bahamas, March 28. -- Adrian Iselin 2d's Ace of the Western Long Island Sound fleet and Sampson Smith's Pioneer of Otsego Lake, N.Y., finished in a tie for first place today in the Star Class series for the Johnnie Walker Trophy. Each had 31 points.

TOKYO, March 28. -- Major Gen. Seisaburo Sato, presiding judge at the murder trial of Lieut. Col. Saburo Aizawa here, has been placed on the army waiting list. General Sato's successor is Major Gen. Soichi Naito. He will resume the trial soon.

MIAMI, Fla., March 28. -- The canary and blue silks of Chicago's Mrs. Emil Denemark, so conspicuous at the Hialeah Park meeting, were borne to a thrilling triumph by the Crusader gelding Chasar in the Coral Gables Spring Handicap, feature at Tropical Park today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 28. -- Cleaving the shimmering green waters of the Yale pool in tireless fashion, Jack Kasley of the University of Michigan swept aside all breast-stroke records today as he shattered beyond recognition two world marks at 200 yards and 200 meters.

IT is good to encounter again some of the works belonging to the Whitney Museum's permanent collection. The group of oils and sculpture that went on view last Tuesday (to be shown until April 5) contains examples that, if vividly remembered through the elapsed interim, have been in storage for a long while.

"Farm on the Hill" is a simple childlike story that 7 to 9 year olds instantly feel is describing for them, on their own level of interest, all kinds of pleasantly exciting happenings on a small farm, where milking and churning is done by hand.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Operators of scheduled interstate airlines today received orders from the Bureau of Air Commerce to instruct their pilots to remain constantly at the controls while in flight and to bar passengers from the pilots' cabin.

The second of this season's series of Dolphin Dances for girls who will be introduced to society next Winter will be held on Friday at the Pierre. The party is expected to draw a large attendance of younger members of society who are at home from school for the Spring recess.

FOR the first time in thirty years of existence, the Music Educators National Conference is holding its biennial convention in New York City this week. These thirty years have witnessed vast changes in the methods of school music teaching, and in the manner of its more serious acceptance by school and civic authorities.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Senator Borah is expected to enter the New Jersey primaries to be held May 19, as the result of the importunities of Russell C. Gates, Judge Henry Trimble and John H. Helpin of Newark. They conferred with him today and represented that New Jersey sentiment is most favorable to his cause.

Dr. John F. Condon, through a spokesman, last night replied sharply to a statement made earlier in the day by Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey who indicated that he would not attempt to question the Bronx educator in the Lindbergh kidnapping case.

Leaders in progressive education and in the protection of teachers' rights paid tribute to Dr. Henry R. Linville, president of the New York Teachers Guild and a veteran exponent of academic freedom, at a luncheon marking his seventieth birthday yesterday in the Hotel Astor. More than 700 teachers attended.

Women headed by Mrs. Albert Francke Jr., who are sponsoring the performance of "The Secret Garden," to be presented on Saturday morning at the Barbizon Plaza Theatre for the benefit of the Children's Welfare Federation, will give a party tomorrow afternoon on the terrace of the penthouse apartment of Mrs. Hardinge Scholle, 320 East Fifty-seventh Street, for a group of settlement children.

PARIS, March 27. -- Whatever may be the outcome of the German Government's offer to make peace on the new basis of Germany's equality with the nations that were joint victors eighteen years ago, it is certain that Germany has won the first round in her fight for a new deal.

THE two besetting sins of so many psychologists are the extremes of either making flimsy inductions on insufficient data or compiling volumes of facts lacking in organization and leading to conclusions of trivial value.

THE current exhibition of oils, water-colors and drawings by Segonzac, at the Jacques Seligmann Galleries (until April 11), stresses the early painting and the developing style of the artist through a period of about fifteen years prior to 1930.

WOODMERE, L.I., March 28. -- Mr. and Mrs. Addison Van Tine and Mr. and Mrs. Roger A. Derby of Lawrence gave a dance tonight at the Van Tine home for their sub-debutante daughters, Miss Elizabeth Derby and Miss Joy Van Tine, students in the Lawrence School.
HANOVER, N.H., March 28. -- One of the unique features of Dartmouth extracurricular activities is the annual interfraternity play contest which closed this week.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Funds for 410 WPA airport and airway projects to employ about 50,000 men had been released by State administrators of the Works Progress Administration to Feb. 15 and 325 of these projects were actually under construction, Harry L. Hopkins, WPA administrator, announced today.

There is not much mystery in this tale of the further adventures of Cardby Son, private detectives, but there is plenty of violent action and excitement. The elder Cardby is a former Scotland Yard man, and he is more or less bound by the traditions of that organization.

The truth of what was said of charity two thousand years ago has had fresh confirmation in the last few days. Whether there be prophecies of material disaster or of human woes they are "done away" by the spirit of human kindness which is inherent in true charity.

THE Spring publishing season is still too young to make prophecy a very safe pastime. Nevertheless, it is doubtful if the next few months hold in store for us anything more exciting in the way of a first novel than this extraordinary book by Karlton Kelm.

MR. PELLY'S little story is a touching and exasperating account of the life of an abject under dog. Besides Alonzo Pelly, Caspar Milquetoast seems a blustering swaggerer. The book opens with young Pelly as a schoolboy, fearful of boys who threaten to beat him up, dogs who bark and bite, and a family who throw empty beer bottles at him.

FORTUNATE is the poet who has a resourceful director to stage his play. Before the curtain went up on Maxwell Anderson's "Winterset" Guthrie McClintic molded the verse into intelligible theatre form. Halsted Welles has performed a service that is somewhat more creative on the withering text of T.S. Eliot's "Murder in the Cathedral," which is now visible and audible at the Manhattan Theatre under WPA auspices.

WHEN a new "see-speech" television line was opened recently between Berlin and Leipzig, 125 miles apart, the European press heralded the nine-day demonstration as "a technical miracle." At the same time considerable discussion was aroused as to the utility of such a service, which, it was said, would be very expensive compared with the telephone.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- An increase in loans and discounts, including overdrafts to a total of $14,697,208,000, or $202,701,000 since June 29, 1935, and of deposits to $44,123,285,000, or $5,029,121,000 during the year, was shown in a summary of the condition of 14,121 insured commercial banks, including national banks, as of Dec. 31, and made public today by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

THIS book of poems is a part of Neihardt's epic cycle of the West. Only one more volume, the fifth, will be added. All of these books have dealt with the history, Indian and white, of our frontier. Neihardt's peculiar gift, however, has been to make the Indian life a part of our poetic history.

WHEN the De Basil Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo opens its Spring engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House on Easter Sunday it will have two novelties, one semi-novelty and two revivals on its schedule.

Setting a phenomenal record in the foils competition, New York University swept off with the coveted three-weapon title and the foils team crown, as well at the forty-third annual intercollegiate fencing championships, which came to an end last night at the Hotel Biltmore.

LONDON, March 27. -- The negotiations with Germany that will begin when Adolf Hitler's reply to the western powers arrives on Tuesday will be greatly influenced by the prevalence in Great Britain of a sentiment that seems remarkably favorable to Germany.

The truth of what was said of charity two thousand years ago has had fresh confirmation in the last few days. Whether there be prophecies of material disaster or of human woes they are "done away" by the spirit of human kindness which is inherent in true charity.

THE Spring publishing season is still too young to make prophecy a very safe pastime. Nevertheless, it is doubtful if the next few months hold in store for us anything more exciting in the way of a first novel than this extraordinary book by Karlton Kelm.

The book opens with young Pelly as a schoolboy, fearful of boys who threaten to beat him up, dogs who bark and bite, and a family who throw empty beer bottles at him.

Halsted Welles has performed a service that is somewhat more creative on the withering text of T.S. Eliot's "Murder in the Cathedral," which is now visible and audible at the Manhattan Theatre under WPA auspices.

WHEN a new "see-speech" television line was opened recently between Berlin and Leipzig, 125 miles apart, the European press heralded the nine-day demonstration as "a technical miracle." At the same time considerable discussion was aroused as to the utility of such a service, which, it was said, would be very expensive compared with the telephone.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- An increase in loans and discounts, including overdrafts to a total of $14,697,208,000, or $202,701,000 since June 29, 1935, and of deposits to $44,123,285,000, or $5,029,121,000 during the year, was shown in a summary of the condition of 14,121 insured commercial banks, including national banks, as of Dec. 31, and made public today by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

THIS book of poems is a part of Neihardt's epic cycle of the West. Only one more volume, the fifth, will be added. All of these books have dealt with the history, Indian and white, of our frontier. Neihardt's peculiar gift, however, has been to make the Indian life a part of our poetic history.

WHEN the De Basil Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo opens its Spring engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House on Easter Sunday it will have two novelties, one semi-novelty and two revivals on its schedule.

Setting a phenomenal record in the foils competition, New York University swept off with the coveted three-weapon title and the foils team crown, as well at the forty-third annual intercollegiate fencing championships, which came to an end last night at the Hotel Biltmore.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 29. -- A jury of twelve men early today returned a verdict of guilty in the case of Harry Kaiser, Newark lawyer on trial before Judge Edward A. McGrath in the Union County Quarter Sessions Court here. Kaiser was tried on an indictment charging conspiracy to defraud the Fidelity and Casualty Company of New York of $200.

Dealing in the Bronx continues to be an active feature of the realty market and brokers report a steadily increasing demand in investment buying. The five-and-one-half-story apartment house in the upper section of that borough, at 15-17 Mosholu Parkway, northeast corner of Knox Place, covering a plot 121 by 110 feet, has been purchased by Etta Cherkos from the Simon Realty Corporation.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP). -- Dr. F.E. Townsend, leader of the old age pension organization, arrived in Washington today from Los Angeles. It was expected that he would appear at the Congressional inquiry into the Townsend movement, Wednesday, when Robert E. Clements, co-founder of the pension plan who recently resigned as national secretary, will resume his testimony before the House investigating committee.

The tense political and financial conditions abroad accounted for a sweeping downward revision in foreign currencies last week. On a volume of business which was small and all out of proportion to the size of the decline a number of the major units established new lows for the year while others scraped the previous minimums.
ALBANY, March 29. -- Following is a tabulation showing how members of the Legislature from the metropolitan area voted on important roll-calls last week:

ROCKAWAY, N.J., March 29. -- Mrs. Lillie Dickerson looked out from a window of her home today to the back wall of the old Town Hall here at Church and Wall Streets, which adjoins her property, and expressed both fear and a few ardent remarks about public officials -- nearly all public officials.

On Sept. 29 there was a chance discovery of human remains in a lonely ravine. No element of hideous sensation was missing from what proved to be the gruesome murder of two women. The procedure of the criminal authorities in England may be worth a word of recapitulation.

Congratulations on THE TIMES recent editorial "After the Deluge." This statement is a clear, forceful and comprehensive presentation of the situation relating to the periodic floods that occur in the river valleys of this country, and the lesson that they should teach us.

The First Boston Corporation led all investment houses in 1935 in volume of business, both as syndicate head and participant, according to figures in American Underwriting Houses and Their Issues, the sixth volume of which is ready for distribution.

Quietly the twelfth edition of George White's "Scandals" ended its somewhat stormy career on Saturday night at the New Amsterdam after 110 performances. Although the revue was known to be playing only to moderate business, its abrupt closing was unlooked for.

ALBANY, March 29. -- Governor Lehman made public tonight an opinion by Attorney General Bennett upholding him in his battle over the budget and declaring that the Republicans were proposing a clearly unconstitutional deferment of appropriations for debt service.

A new issue of $2,500,000 principal amount of city of Seattle, Wash., municipal light and power revenue 3 1/2 per cent bonds will be offered today by a syndicate at a price to yield from 2 to 3.7 per cent according to maturity. The bonds will be dated April 15 and will mature serially from 1938 to 1954.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Monday, March 30 (AP). -- Failing winds left the entire fleet of twenty-one yachts in the seventh annual St. Petersburg-Havana yacht race becalmed near Sanibel Island early today.

The Great Northern Railway repaid in 1935 $3,000,000 borrowed from the First National Bank in 1933, W.P. Kenney, president, disclosed in his report for last year. The company also repaid $319,340 on account of a loan of $3,000,000 extended by the Railroad Credit Corporation.

Urging Catholics to "seize the world for Christ," Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen, Professor of Fundamental Theology at the Catholic University of America, Washington, D.C., appealed to 3,000 worshipers at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday to exchange a critical, aloof attitude for "the attitude of our Lord, who converted thousands by finding a common denominator with them."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 29. -- Emphasizing the important role of classical studies during the 300 years at Harvard University, undergraduate members of the college Classical Club will present in Latin Plautus's "Mostellaria," as one of the student activities in the Tercentenary Celebration.

The pamphlet report of Best Co., Inc., for 1935 shows total current assets on Jan. 31 of $4,734,294 and current liabilities of $985,525, compared with $4,504,083 and $717, 050, respectively, on Jan. 31, 1935. The net income for the last fiscal year, $1,133,953, or $3.73 each on the 300,000 shares of common stock, was the same as in the preliminary estimate.

TORONTO, Ont., March 27. -- Output from Ontario gold mines for February was lower than in January but exceeded the February total in 1935, the Department of Mines reported this week. In the month thirty-nine mines made bullion shipments, compared with twenty-nine in February, 1935.

The New York Rovers made their final home stand of the season at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon by dropping a 2-1 decision to the Hershey sextet, Eastern Amateur Hockey League champion, in a Hershey Cup struggle.

Mrs. Catherine J. Fahys, 41 years old, wife of a former American Legion post commander, was killed about 3 P.M. yesterday when an automobile in which she was driving alone was struck by a railroad train at the Meadow Street grade crossing in Garden City, L.I.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- The story how 275,000 relief workers saved thousands of lives and millions of dollars in property during the floods that inundated wide areas throughout the United States during the past two weeks was told today by Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, who has been directing their activities.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 29. -- Frankie Frisch's "gas house gang," accompanied but unaided by the Dean boys, dropped in today for a repetition of the fun they had against the Dodgers at Bradenton two weeks ago, but all the enjoyment went to Casey Stengel's troupe and the 1,500 fans who saw a home team triumph by 6 to 3.

PITTSBURGH, March 29. -- Nation-wide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 56 per cent of capacity, up 3 points from the preceding week. The original estimate for the week before last was 50 per cent, but this has been revised to 53 per cent.

The Phoenix Securities Corporation reported last week net assets on Feb. 29 of $9,122,299, equivalent, after allowing for the preferred stock at $50 a share, to $6.26 a share on the common stock. This compared with net assets of $7,041,500, or $3.71 a share, on Aug. 31, 1935, and with $5,559,013, or $1.25 a share, on Feb. 28, 1935.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- Efforts of litigants to prevent the construction, extension or operation of publicly owned electrical generating or distributing systems have cost nearly $13,000,000 and operating delays of 289 years 8 months 22 days, according to a report to the Senate by the Federal Power Commission, made public today.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 29. -- John Schenk, 49, of Oklahoma Beach, shot and killed his daughter, Winifred, 18, and gravely wounded her two escorts early today following a quarrel with the girl over $17. He later was arrested.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 29. -- The post of Puerto Rican police chief has been offered to Colonel Alex J. McNab, D.S.A., retired, by Governor Blanton H. Winship, to succeed Colonel E. Francis Riggs, who was assassinated more than a month ago.
NEW ORLEANS, March 29 (AP). -- Rushaway, the heavy favorite, sped to a new track record today to win the $5,000 added Louisiana Derby, feature race closing the ninety-day season at the Fair Grounds.

TAMPA, March 29 (AP). -- A congress of lawyers, with delegates elected from every State comprising the body, was advocated today by William L. Ransom of New York, president of the American Bar Association.

The New York Queens Transit Corporation will submit to the Board of Estimate today an application for the right to substitute motor buses for trolley cars on thirty-four miles of track in Northern Queens. The company now operates under perpetual franchises on important highways such as Northern Boulevard through Jackson Heights and Woodside, Main Street in Flushing and Borden Avenue in Long Island City.

MOUNTAIN LAKES, N.J., March 29. -- The matter of a small piece of land, two swans and a duck, which caused complications as the result of a decision that while swans and ducks are both tender and legal they are not legal tender, will be settled Wednesday morning by public auction.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- Another government wood expert was reported today to have joined Arch W. Loney, PWA materials engineer, in his contention that the famous "Rail 16" of the Lindbergh kidnap ladder did not come from Bruno Richard Hauptmann's attic.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 29 (AP). -- Bobby Jones continued to play sub-par golf today in preparation for his third annual return to the wars in the Augusta National Invitation tournament opening Tuesday, but yielded the scoring honors to the home pro, Ed Dudley, in the chief attraction among the day's workouts.

Miss Anna Kaskas of Hartford, Conn., and Arthur Carron of Wiltshire, England, were announced yesterday as the winners of an elimination contest, conducted during a series of radio broadcasts, to select singers who will receive an opportunity to appear at the Metropolitan Opera House.
It was lovely out yesterday.

If a few extra flags are flown from the Treasury Building in Washington tomorrow no explanation will be required. March 31 will mark the end of the most successful month the Treasury has enjoyed in recent years. Not only have revenues exceeded the high figure of $700,000,000 for the first time since the depression began in earnest.

The proposed cancellation by Presidential act of ocean mail conlines is attacked as a breach of faith in resolutions adopted by the executive committee of the American Manufacturers Export Association.

Sixty American scholars, composers of music, poets, fiction writers, playwrights, artists and scientists will be enabled to carry on research and creative work in this country and abroad as a result of the twelfth annual series of fellowship awards totaling $115,000 made by the trustees of the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation.

VEZELAY, France, March 29. -- Foreign Minister Pierre-Etienne Flandin, condemning Germany's "philosophy of force," demanded today that Adolf Hitler renounce "aggression," as a condition for France to consider his peace offers.

The pamphlet report of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company for 1935, released for publication today, shows total operating revenues last year of $367,812,186, an increase of $24,143,487, or 7 per cent, over 1934. The increase, the company says, was due in part to higher freight rates.

Olga d'Allaz, whose patronymic derives from Dallas, Texas, her native city, gave a recital of Eastern European folk songs and dances in costume at the Guild Theatre last night before a large and responsive audience. The soprano, whose art is often that of the diseuse, has appeared here before and made herself favorably known.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 29. -- Speaking at the launching of an Australian-built naval sloop at Cockatoo Dock in Sydney Harbor yesterday, Defense Minister Robert A. Parkhill declared Australia was destined to play an important part in any developments in the Pacific and also east of Suez, including Egypt.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP). -- Nepotism in the offices of House members was shown today to have dwindled to a point where only thirty employes have the same name as their employer.

The letter of Helen Hall, director of Henry Street Settlement, is obviously intended as an indictment of "old-law" tenements, but certainly no jury acquainted with the facts would vote an indictment on Miss Hall's evidence.

For a number of years the Judicial Conference of Senior Circuit Judges called by the Chief Justice dwelt on the necessity of two additional Federal judges for the Southern District of California and the Southern District of New York. In his annual report the Attorney General recommended that such judgeships be established.
CHICAGO, March 29 (AP). -- Former President Herbert Hoover today denied reports that he was backing Senator Vandenberg of Michigan for the Republican Presidential nomination.

As was to be expected, the transportation industry and the steel-producing mills were hard hit by the widespread river inundations. Not only were many sections of the railways unable to operate because of overflow and damaged bridges but in some of the Pittsburgh steel plants water reached the height of eighteen feet.
If the Republican party hopes to elect a President this year it must find a candidate of higher intellectual and statesmanlike character than any of those now mentioned.

An incident in which wounded honor can be assuaged only by pistols at dawn one of these days, or by hurling bristly pineapples and hard-shell cocoanuts some mid-afternoon when the burning sun has dipped behind a skyscraper, occurred on the eighty-sixth floor of the Empire State Building yesterday.

Riddled with injuries, and tired almost to the point of exhaustion, the New York Americans arrived in town last night still entertaining the slim chance that the will be able to crash through to the Stanley Cup round.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- In making public today rules regarding service, sales and construction contracts under the Public Utility Act of 1935, the Securities and Exchange Commission exercised its exempting power by permitting registered holding companies and subsidiaries to carry on such activities at cost until Aug. 1.

Offering will be made today of a new issue of $6,500,000 of city of Oslo (Norway) 4 1/2 per cent sinking fund bonds at 99 1/2 and accrued interest. The underwriters who are to offer the securities are Kuhn, Loeb Co.; Brown Harriman Co., Inc.; Edward B. Smith Co.; Blyth Co., Inc., and White, Weld Co.

Communist cells exist at the majority of local public high schools, Dr. George G. Sullivan, editor and educator, charged yesterday at a symposium on "The Catholic Church and Communism," at the Centre Club, 120 Central Park South.

NEW HAVEN, March 28. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 82.6, which compares with 82.5 the week before, 82.4 two weeks before, 82.8 three weeks before and 83.3 four weeks before.

The story of the "mystery fish" related to this department recently by Captain John Peterson, Long Island Sound fishing boat captain, who told of encountering large schools of unidentified specimens last Fall, aroused the interest of a number of salt water anglers.

Pairings for the four groups of twelve players each, starting the preliminaries of the tournament for the United States chess championship tonight in the rooms of the Manhattan, Marshall, Empire City and Queens Chess Club, were announced yesterday.

VIENNA, March 29. -- Austrian anti-Semitism, which had been moving so cautiously that Jews labeled it "rubber-soled anti-Semitism," has shown signs during the last fortnight of having discarded the rubber soles for footwear suggestive of the Prussian jackboot.

L.F. Sanman broke 100 straight targets at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. He made the run after breaking 75 in a row in practice, giving him an unofficial total of 175. He was the winner of the High-Over-All Cup and the Long Run prize, taking the latter award on his regular score of 100.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., March 29. -- Mrs. Kenneth O'Brien of New York and Southampton, L.I., gave a tea in the Virginia Room at the Greenbrier this afternoon. Guests included Mr. and Mrs. F. Worthington Hine, Mr. and Mrs. Joshua L. Brooks, Mrs. Edmund C. Lynch, Mrs. James E. Davidson, Mrs. Paul F. Donnelly and the Misses Jean Hinsdale and Martha Sherwood.

PASADENA, March 29 (AP). -- Of the nation's insane and feebleminded 23,092 had been sterilized up to Jan. 1, the Human Betterment Foundation reported today. This was an increase of 3,029 since Jan. 1, 1935.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 29 (AP). -- Leaders in the doubles, singles and all-events withstood all attacks today in the American Bowling Congress tournament. It was the first time in several days there have been no changes in the first five places.

The various concert units of the WPA Federal Music Project joined last night in a demonstration concert at Carnegie Hall with the specific view to illustrate before the general public "what has been accomplished since the projects became part of the WPA" last August.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 29. -- Peter Harvard, 18-year-old son of the late Lionel de Jersey Harvard and a collateral descendant of John Harvard, will come from Sunderland, England, next September to enter Harvard College if the efforts made for seven years by prominent alumni, headed by Dr. A. Lawrence Lowell, former president, are successful.

The American Federation of Musicians, Local 802, threatened a "complete tie-up of the music publishing industry in New York" last night when its secretary, Jacob Rosenberg, issued a preliminary strike call to 150 arrangers, copyists and proofreaders of music and pianists employed by thirty-six members of the Music Publishers Protective Association.

While sugar soared to the highest level in almost eight years, other commodity futures were depressed last week, with silk and cottonseed oil irregular. Trading in general, nevertheless, was in good volume. In the cash markets cotton, oats, lard, raw sugar and silk advanced, while wheat, corn, rye, flour, coffee, cocoa, tin, wool-tops and rubber were easier.

The unchecked development of the smoke nuisance, with its incalculable waste and its toll upon the health of the people of the city, is reaching an alarmingly dangerous state, is declared in a report made public yesterday by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

The Rome Prize competition in classical studies conducted by the American Academy in Rome has been won by two New Jersey students, the academy announced yesterday at 101 Park Avenue. One is Walter F. Snyder of Merchantville, now doing graduate work at Yale, and the other is Susan M. Savage of Audubon, who is doing postgraduate work at the University of Pennsylvania.

Union Theological Seminary, known as a "theological university," will celebrate its 100th anniversary May 16-19, it was announced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, who in April will complete ten years as its president.

NEW ORLEANS, March 29. -- By dint of great perseverance and a number of other things as well the Giants finally brought down the Indians today just to correct an impression before a gallery of 5,000 that the matter could not be done at all.

The Rev. George A. Crapullo, pastor of the Irving Square Presbyterian Church in Wierfield Street, Brooklyn, criticized in his sermon yesterday morning the attitude of Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, in barring the doctrine of "Peace at any price" while urging peace instruction in the public schools.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 29. -- When the Yankees play any National League club but the harmless Boston Bees they seem to be over their heads. Today they faced the Cubs before a gathering of 2,500 and, though the McCarthymen forced their guests into a twelve-inning struggle, they went down to defeat.

The social Service of the Cancer Unit of the Post-Graduate Hospital will be aided by a card party to be held tomorrow afternoon in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Mrs. Samuel Adams Clark, president of the organization, heads the benefit committee.

ADDIS ABABA, March 29 (Reuters). -- Four hours after the bombing of Harar today the town was still a mass of flames. It was the biggest bombing attack of the war. No definite casualty figures or exact data on the extent of the material damage are available.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 29. -- Yachtsmen who delight in racing dinghies found ideal conditions at the Larchmont Yacht Club today.

The Missing Persons Bureau of the Police Department revealed yesterday that it had been requested to search for Mrs. M. Richardson of Port Elizabeth, South Africa, who was reported to have arrived here Thursday with diamonds and furs worth $100,000.

The widening of spreads between prices for the near-by and the distant deliveries of cotton constituted the principal development in the futures market last week. At the close on Saturday prices of active deliveries on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net changes for the week of 25 points up to 4 points down.

LONDON, March 30. -- The currencies of the gold bloc are now passing through another of their periodic crises, with the French franc as the center of the present attack. The financial editor of The Times of London, in his estimate of the situation tonight, says there is no doubt that the French authorities intend to defend the franc vigorously against any speculation by "short" interests.

PEMBERTON, N.J., March 29. -- Gouldy E. Foulks, 74-year-old woodsman who surprised neighbors last year by erecting a $10,000 mausoleum for himself, was found dead today in front of his home near here at Browns Mills.

A favorable impression was made by Eleanor Berger, contralto, at her song recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. Miss Berger, a native of Milwaukee, who at present resides in Easton, Pa., was heard here first last Spring at Aeolian Hall.

In order to impress upon the public the importance of foreign trade to the nation and particularly the Port of New York, the Merchants Association of New York, it was announced yesterday, has agreed to take the leadership in the development and promotion of a suitable program for this city for Foreign Trade Week which will be celebrated throughout the United States from May 17 to 23.

A strike of between 4,000 and 5,000 clerks and delivery boys in fruit and vegetable stores in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn to combat a threatened lock-out by independent store owners was voted yesterday afternoon by the Retail Dairy, Grocery, Fruit and Vegetable Clerks Union at a meeting of 3,000 of its members at the Manhattan Opera House.
BERLIN, March 28. -- The week's developments in the Locarno dispute failed to shake business confidence. The advance in stocks here continued and bonds, although irregular, were predominantly firm.

MEXICO, D.F., March 29. -- Thousands of Catholic churches throughout Mexico were reopened today after having been closed for more than a year, but there have been no changes in Federal or State religious laws and none appeared to be in immediate prospect.

Dr. Thomas R. Thorburn of New York City, president of the American Osteopathic Association, questioned yesterday the conclusions reached recently by Dr. Alfred Adler, Viennese physician and psychologist, that mothers who monopolize their children are responsible for juvenile neurotics and delinquents.

BERLIN, Monday, March 30. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler emerged from yesterday's national plebiscite on his policies with 98.79 per cent of the votes, according to official returns early today. These figures gave him 44,409,523 votes out of a total of 44,952,476.

Her leavetaking from the singing personnel of the Metropolitan Opera Association was the end of only one phase of her association with the institution, Lucrezia Bori insisted in an interview on the eve of her last performance on the Metropolitan stage.

A large subscription has been reported for the performance of the Monte Carlo Ballet Russe the night of April 13 at the Metropolitan Opera House, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Society for the Relief of Half Orphan and Destitute Children.

PARIS, March 29. -- While Germany voted today her approval of the reoccupation of the Rhineland and all of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's past and future acts, France's Foreign Minister, Pierre-Etienne Flandin, speaking to his electors at Vezelay, came near to denouncing Hitler's peace offers as a trick.

To read the world news today is like reading an account of a world's nightmare. It is difficult to imagine a situation more complex or more threatening. The time is here when it is imperative that clear thinking be done.
A surprisingly strong French Rugby Club fifteen upset the favored team of the New York Rugby Club at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday by 18 -- 10 before a crowd of more than 3,000.

The general attitude of indifference among Christians today was deplored by the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks in his sermon yesterday morning at St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street. "Not a single word is uttered in behalf of Christ or his teachings," he declared.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 29. -- Private wealth, under continued attrition of government taxing agencies, Federal and State, is being so crippled that it will take a diminishing part in the major philanthropies and social-welfare projects of the future, it was declared here today by Robert J. Koshland, first vice president of the Federation of Jewish Charities in San Francisco.

The church is awakening to the realization that if the principles of "Christian education" are to be taught in institutions of higher learning it must be done in the small denominational colleges, Dr. Thomas L. Cline, head of the department of English in Gettysburg College, declared in an address at the Lutheran Church of Our Saviour's Atonement, 189th Street and Bennett Avenue, yesterday morning.

Passengers due to arrive today from England on the American Banker of the American Merchant Lines include: Herbert Brenon, London film director; the Rev. Gordon Bodenwein, R.O. Campbell, Harold B. Hallett, Claude La-Brocque, Mrs. A.T. King and Miss T.M. Sutherby.

SAN ANTONIO, March 29. -- Mrs. Alice Morgan Coulter, wife of Harold K. (Duke) Coulter, former army captain and widely known as a polo player and trainer of ponies, was found shot to death in their apartment early today.

CONRAD is dead, O'Brien is dead, Maugham has turned cosmopolitan. If white shadows still darken the South Seas, there are few left to tell us so. Instead we look toward the north, toward white shadows over the Greenland ice cap. Even before the publication of Peter Freuchen's "Arctic Adventure" (Farrar Rinehart, $3.50) the sun had crossed the literary equator.
LONDON, March 29. -- The Italian invasion of Ethiopia has reached a point at which some attempt may again be made to assess its progress from a strictly military point of view.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- In two cases, involving complaints filed on behalf of nineteen employes of the Friedman-Harry Marks Clothing Company of Richmond, Va., the National Labor Relations Board announced today that the employer had deliberately disregarded the provisions of the National Labor Relations Act in discharging the employes for membership in the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America.

LONDON, March 27. -- The steady drift of European capital into securities, sterling and gold here, still is in evidence but the transfers are principally into sterling and gold. Not a day passes without some evidence of support for the franc through the British Exchange Fund.

Under the official billing of "Sonja Henie's Night," Miss Henie fittingly enough gave as her first number at Madison Square Garden last night the free skating program which has won for her ten world championships and three Olympic titles.

Charles A. Harnett, State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, in an address on "The World's Largest Motor Problem" yesterday at the sixth annual communion breakfast of the Sons of Xavier, alumni society of St. Francis Xavier High School, at the Hotel Commodore, advocated changes in the motor laws that would decrease deaths and injuries resulting from careless driving.

Nation-wide adoption of the five-day working week without reduction of wages was advocated yesterday morning by Governor James M. Curley of Massachusetts as an essential factor in the establishment of permanent social and economic security throughout the country.
