ST. LOUIS, March 29. -- Jockel V. Burglund, Doberman Pinscher owned by Owen A. West of Chicago and handled by Jimmy Sullivan, won the special for best in show at the close of the twenty-fourth annual Mississippi Valley Kennel Club exhibition tonight.
MOSCOW, March 29. -- The Soviet airplane expedition to Franz Josef Land began auspiciously today with a perfect flight to Archangel, completing the first leg of the trip without incident.

An outboard motorized plant estimated to have cost between $15,000 and $20,000 for turning automobile radiator and paint alcohols into "beverage" alcohol passed out of existence early yesterday morning when fire swept a three-story, frame house in a thinly settled district of Queens Village. The house is at 225-34 109th Avenue.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 29. -- The keeper of the Bees is mild Will McKechnie, the same gent who was boss of the Braves of recent seasons. It's the same team under a new name and new ownership.

The Town Hall Club, which has sponsored an annual spelling bee for several years, outdid itself last night with a "definitions bee." That turned out to be definable as a process by which birds get mixed up with fish, perspicuity tangles with perspicacity and a burro becomes a Rocky Mountain canary.

The importance of academic freedom as a factor in the changing social order was emphasized by Dr. Jesse H. Newlon, director of the Lincoln School, Teachers College, Columbia University, in his annual report to Dean William F. Russell, made public yesterday.

The mail carrier is not the only man whom storm or flood will not keep from the swift completion of his appointed rounds. A sturdier if less melodramatic figure is the milkman. How were the mail deliveries in flooded Pittsburgh when the water was highest? At least one dairy company reports that it maintained 100 per cent delivery in Pittsburgh during the entire week of the flood.

BOSTON, March 29. -- One of the nation's outstanding women aviators, Mrs. Theodore "Teddy" Kenyon, revealed today that she and several other women were preparing for war-time service, should they ever be needed.
The New York Chapter of the American Red Cross received $16,825 in flood-relief contributions yesterday, bringing the chapter's total fund to $437,655,14.

There were 31,050 accidents, including twenty-six that were fatal, among the 250,000 relief workers employed under the local WPA in the six months ended on Jan. 31, 1936, it was disclosed in a report submitted yesterday to Victor F. Ridder, local WPA Administrator, by John Hamblin, Assistant Compensation Officer of WPA.

At the meeting of the Peace Conference in Cleveland on Saturday night Mr. NEWTON D. BAKER made a short address on the League of Nations. He recounted some of its successes and admitted its "disheartening failures." Yet one continuous achievement can be set down to its lasting credit. It has made an end of secret diplomacy.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- A flood of business protest against President Roosevelt's three-point tax program, held in check since submission of the proposals to Congress nearly four weeks ago, is expected to break through the dikes this week during public hearings before the Ways and Means Committee.

Walter Leslie Runciman, joint managing director of the Anchor Line at Glasgow, grandson of Lord Runciman, chief owner of the steamship company and son of Sir Walter Runciman, president of the Board of Trade, arrived yesterday on the Transylvania to spend two weeks studying shipping conditions here. He was accompanied by Mrs. Runciman.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- Scores of aroused Senators and lqepresentatives began a drive today to restore nearly $500,000,000 worth of projects %o the "omnibus" Flood Control Bill hastily revamped because of the East's recent floods.

Lucrezia Bori sang her farewell to opera at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. In the building she loves, the soprano ended a career of twenty-eight years and an association of twenty-six with the Metropolitan Opera itself.

CHICAGO, March 29. -- Liquidation and pressure from short sellers last week carried prices of most grains on the Board of Trade to the lowest levels of the season, but there were moderate rallies and an improved technical situation at the close.

Two new "confessions" in the Hauptmann case were disclosed yesterday. One was ascribed to Paul H. Wendel, disbarred Trenton lawyer, who had once spent four days under observation in a hospital for the insane.

It is a far cry from the free-and-easy type of singing vouchsafed by the college youth of other years to that serious sort of ensemble work set forth by the Harvard Glee Club and the Radcliffe Choral Society in their joint concert last night at the Town Hall, under the baton of G. Wallace Woodworth.

PARIS, March 28. -- In the eyes of French financiers, particularly of Bourse professionals, who take a practical standpoint without considering either questions of national prestige or long-term outlook, the present position of negotiations in the Rhineland dispute appears more reassuring than otherwise, in the sense that they are expected to be protracted and nobody believes it is possible for them to end in war.

Replacement buying by merchants in flood areas, as well as a steady flow of orders from other sections of the country for all types of Spring apparel, made last week one of the most active periods experienced by wholesalers here so far this season.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., March 29. -- Rosedale Bob, hero of many a hard race in Eastern field trial competition, added more honors today to the fine record that he has made in recent years. This big white and lemon pointer dog, owned and handled by Samuel Faile of White Plains, earned first place in the open all-age stake, which concluded the annual Spring meeting of the North Shore Game Protective Association.

MIAMI, Fla., March 29. -- While the Presidential yacht Potomac rocked lazily on the swells off the reefs of Crooked Island today President Roosevelt divided his time between relaxation on deck and the handling of urgent mail delivered to him by airplane from the temporary White House offices here.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- Federal funds are now being given to twenty-four States and Hawaii to enable them to cooperate under the maternal and child health services of the Social Security Act, it was announced by Secretary of Labor Perkins today.

CHICAGO, March 28. -- Receipts of hogs last week, while slightly larger than in the week before, were a little less than a year ago, but ample for all requirements of shippers and packers. The top price was $10.80 a hundredweight with most trading at $10.20 to $10.70.

AMHERST, Mass., March 29. -- Representatives of nearly every agricultural organization in the State and many governmental and relief agencies met at Massachusetts State College today to attack the problem of rehabilitating flood-stricken Massachusetts agriculture.

An estimated gross deficit of $2,264,390 for 1936 confronts private family welfare agencies in New York City, Laurence M. Marks, chairman of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee, pointed out in a statement mailed yesterday to 25,000 former contributors to the committee.

MOSCOW, Monday, March 30. -- Two more incidents on the Far Eastern border -- this time two alleged invasions of the territory of Outer Mongolia -- were reported to Moscow today from Ulan Bator, Outer Mongolian capital.

DETROIT, March 29 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin appealed today to members of his National Union for Social Justice to endorse candidates for Congress "who prefer the welfare of the American people to the crass partisanship" of the major political organizations.

From the pulpit of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Fiftieth Street and Park Avenue, Bishop William T. Manning expressed disapproval yesterday afternoon of the proposed legalization of lotteries by the State, even for purposes of relieving distress. He characterized the gambling spirit as a "habit-forming drug."

GLEN COVE, L.I., March 29. -- For the third year in a row the Piping Rock Club of Locust Valley triumphed in the interclub shoot against the representatives of the Rockaway Hunting Club of Cedarhurst and the Nassau Country Club of this town.
WASHINGTON, March 29. -- The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress last week are given in the following tabulation:

An estimated gross deficit of $2,264,390 for 1936 confronts private family welfare agencies in New York City, Laurence M. Marks, chairman of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee, pointed out in a statement mailed yesterday to 25,000 former contributors to the committee.

MOSCOW, Monday, March 30. -- Two more incidents on the Far Eastern border -- this time two alleged invasions of the territory of Outer Mongolia -- were reported to Moscow today from Ulan Bator, Outer Mongolian capital.

DETROIT, March 29 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin appealed today to members of his National Union for Social Justice to endorse candidates for Congress "who prefer the welfare of the American people to the crass partisanship" of the major political organizations.

From the pulpit of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Fiftieth Street and Park Avenue, Bishop William T. Manning expressed disapproval yesterday afternoon of the proposed legalization of lotteries by the State, even for purposes of relieving distress. He characterized the gambling spirit as a "habit-forming drug."

GLEN COVE, L.I., March 29. -- For the third year in a row the Piping Rock Club of Locust Valley triumphed in the interclub shoot against the representatives of the Rockaway Hunting Club of Cedarhurst and the Nassau Country Club of this town.
WASHINGTON, March 29. -- The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress last week are given in the following tabulation:

DETROIT, March 29. -- The Red Wings of Detroit, seizing a 2 to 1 decision over the Montreal Maroons on a third-period goal by Scotty Bowman, won the National Hockey League championship for the second time in three years tonight. The victory sent them into the Stanley Cup finals, where they were beaten in 1934.

Revenues of the Market Department were increased 34 per cent last year, to a total of $370,143.90 against $275,919,82 in 1934, Commissioner William Fellowes Morgan Jr. reported yesterday in his annual report to Mayor La Guardia.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- Americans, in a battle against common enemies and in search of common goals, can reach beyond racial and religious lines for the common good, Secretary Roper assured the officers and trustees of the National Jewish Hospital of Denver at a banquet featuring the thirty-sixth annual meeting of the institution here tonight.

The proposed tax on undistributed corporation profits would work hardship upon employes by tending to discourage the accumulation of surplus out of which corporations finance industrial expansion and maintain employment in periods of depression, the Guaranty Trust Company declares in a discussion of the workers' stake in the cost of government in the current issue of The Guaranty Survey.
FORT DAVIS, Texas, March 29. -- Petticoats rule this rugged cow county, where a swivel-chair woman Sheriff likes her job so well she seeks re-election.

Norman Thomas, leader of the left wing faction of the Socialist party, charged the Old Guard Socialists with becoming merely the left wing of the New Deal, while Louis Waldman, State chairman and Old Guard leader, accused the Thomas faction of Communist tactics and aims, in two rallies held here yesterday.
Those were stirring words, spoken by the Flatbush magistrate on progress and civilization and the peril to these twin concepts of noise abatement campaigns.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, challenged the American Federation of Labor tonight to hold a referendum among its worker-members under the auspices of the Department of Labor, on the question of craft or industrial unionization, and predicted that if this were done there would be an overwhelming demand for organization along industrial lines.

Reading a statement in THE TIMES to the effect that the Federal Housing Administration had arranged to help landlords repair their buildings, I wonder whether it is generally known that these loans, which run from very small amounts up to $50,000, carry an interest charge which varies between 10 and 12 per cent.

The road to progress lies in the restoration of the principle of free enterprise and the encouragement of individual initiative in this country, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of General Motors Corporation, says in the corporation's annual pamphlet report to stockholders, issued today.

ADDIS ABABA, March 29. -- After two forces of Italian airplanes, one estimated to total twenty-five machines and the other thirty-five, had converged on Harar and reconnoitered over the city early this morning, fifteen of the planes later returned and at 7:15 o'clock began a heavy bombardment with incendiary bombs.

The McPherson Oilers and the Hollywood Universals, the two A.A.U. teams which are the favored finalists, have gained places in opposite halves of the draw for the final Olympic basketball tryouts, which will be played at Madison Square Garden on Friday, Saturday and either Sunday or Monday, it was announced yesterday by Avery Brundage, president of the American Olympic Committee.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., March 29 (AP). -- After three dogs were called in the second series, Jab's Blondie Himkins, lemon and white pointer owned by Perry Moore, Moorestown, was declared winner today in the all-age stake at the trials of the South Jersey Field Trial Club on the English setter farm near here.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., March 29. -- George Schwalb, E. Kohler and R. Kohler each broke 47 out of 50 targets in the regular sixteen-yard event over the traps of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club today. In the shoot-off Schwalb won the trophy.

The Fire Department has completed its first inspection of the 1,832 cabarets and dance halls in the city and has ordered fire hazards eliminated in 1,005 of them, Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott announced yesterday.

Frank Raichle, the 72-year-old cashier in Van's Meat Market at 92-51 New York Avenue, Jamaica, with whom an absent-minded customer left $90 change last Wednesday, was discharged yesterday. He gave the police a signed statement accusing Abraham Alexander, owner of the store, of dismissing him because he turned the money over to the police and not to the employer.
Tha dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

DENVER, Col., March 30. -- Frigid winds, sweeping from subzero areas in Montana and Wyoming, hurled storm clouds of dust over portions of four States today and carried an unseasonal cold wave over the West.

THE desire for a President who -- like a wellbred child of yesterday -- will do his work in a quiet way, and only speak when spoken to, is strong in those houses where for three years the front-paged news from Washington has almost daily ruined breakfast-time tempers. In his "This Man Landon" (Dodd, Mead, $1.50) Frederick Palmer inferentially expresses this desire and enthusiastically hails its near fulfillment.

ALBANY, March 30. -- In a special message to the Legislature tonight, Governor Lehman called upon the Assembly for immediate passage of his Social Security Bill, embodying his whole eight-point program, which was unanimously approved last week by the Senate.

The city administration served notice on Supreme Court Justice Faber in Brooklyn yesterday that it would seek to have him disqualified from signing the final decree in the $5,996,000 Grand Central Parkway condemnation proceeding in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Provisions of the Washington State law of 1933 imposing an occupation tax on radio broadcasting were held unconstitutional today by the Supreme Court. A unanimous opinion delivered by Justice Stone held that broadcasting was a phase of interstate commerce, and reversed the ruling of the Washington Supreme Court approving the levy.

The liquidating committee of the Broadway National Bank and Trust Company, reporting yesterday to certificate holders in session at the Colonial Trust Company, 261 Fifth Avenue, said that from Sept. 27, 1930, to Dec. 31, 1935, it had handled receipts of $1,889,042 and disbursements of $1,878,776, at a total cost to certificate holders of $32,850.

ROME, March 30. -- It is said in well-informed Italian circles that Italy will probably attend any new meeting of the four Locarno powers but that it is still uncertain whether she will participate in the general staff consultations. That will depend on the attitude Italy finally assumes toward the proposals of the four Locarno powers, which in turn will depend on the reply Adolf Hitler makes to them.
LONDON, March 30. -- London, which has been generally notoriously backward in her railway stations, will have in five years a great new terminus that can proudly hold its own with any.

TRENTON, N.J., March 30. -- With the Bergen County Republicans and the members of the Democratic minority voting against it, the Luxury Tax Bill introduced by Assemblyman Henry Young Jr. of Essex County was defeated again tonight by the House, 27 to 32. Thirty-one votes were needed for passage.

Discussions looking to the formation of a national association of general management investment trusts have been held here recently by sponsors of some of the largest investment companies. If the plan is carried out, an organization would be formed similar to the Investment Bankers Association.

Little interest was apparent in the market for bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. In the slowest trading in about two weeks prices eased slightly in most of the major groups, excepting United States Government issues.

PARIS, March 30. -- On the heels of the German denunciation of the Locarno treaty, it has been learned here, the pension granted by Germany to the widow of Dr. Gustav Stresemann, signer of the treaty for the Reich, was canceled.

An exhibition well outside the usual "run" opened yesterday at the Bignou Galleries, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street. It is devoted entirely to modern tapestries. The artists furnishing the designs are all well-known members of what we loosely call the School of Paris: Braque, Raoul Dufy, Leger, Lurcat, Matisse, Picasso and Rouault.

CHICAGO, March 30. -- Asserting that there is no real hedge against inflation, Orrin G. Wood of Boston, president of the Investment Bankers Association of America, today urged investment men and the Federal Government to take steps in their respective fields to block the coming of any violent form of inflation.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- New Deal laws are to have the fairest possible test of their constitutionality, the Supreme Court said in effect today when it refused to pass on the validity of the Public Utility Act on the narrow and unilateral basis of the Burco, Inc., suit from Baltimore.

Facing a stoppage of publication of new music, the Music Publishers Protective Association yesterday urged the Musicians Union, Local 802, of the American Federation of Musicians, to delay its strike of 150 arrangers, copyists and proofreaders of music pending further negotiations of wages and working conditions.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Senator Vandenberg asked in the Senate today whether "a great New York bank collected $705,488.66 as its residuary share of AAA payments to one Puerto Rican sugar operation in one year." He was renewing his criticism of Secretary Wallace for unwillingness to compile a list of beneficiaries of more than $10,000 a year under the AAA.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The Ways and Means Committee's revised tax program was described today by Guy T. Helvering, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, as inadequate to meet President Roosevelt's demand for enough new revenue to restore the budget to the position it held before the Agricultural Adjustment Act was invalidated and the bonus payment bill enacted.

A slight firming of leather prices in the last week, following the recovery in hide quotations, was the outstanding development yesterday at the official opening of Fall leathers by sixty-five members of the Tanners' Council of America at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin C. Fincke gave a dinner last night at their home, 55 East Eighty-sixth Street, for their granddaughter, Miss Gwendolyn F. Humphreys, later taking their guests to a theatre. After the performance a supper party was given in the Persian Room of the Plaza by Mrs. Fincke Humphreys for her daughter and the other members of the party.
PHILADELPHIA, Pa., March 30. -- The following contracts were awarded today by the Army Quartermaster's Depot here on textile garment supplies, as follows:

ADDIS ABABA, March 30. -- It now seems certain that heavy fighting occurred the middle of last week in Ogaden Province, in the east, at the same time as rumors were current in Harar that Sasa Baneh and Anale (a well site) had fallen.

C.M. Chester, president of the National Association of Manufacturers and chairman of the board of the General Foods Corporation, gave the point of view of industry in a talk last night over Station WJZ and a network of the National Broadcasting Company.

BALBOA, C.Z., March 30. -- The Wyatt Earp, the Ellsworth Antarctic expedition's ship, with Sir Hubert Wilkins in command, arrived at Balboa today from Valparaiso and went through the Canal this afternoon. It will sail from Cristobal for Norfolk, Va., on Wednesday. There Sir Hubert will resume work on plans for a submarine expedition through the Arctic.

Recent comments regarding the decision of the Court of Appeals holding the Minimum Fair Wage Law of 1933 unconstitutional have, in some instances, been misleading with respect to the laundry industry.

The State of Rhode Island will be in the market on April 7 with a new issue of $500,000 of relief bonds, dated Sept. 16, 1935, and maturing on April 15, 1940. Bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 3 1/2 per cent.

SPOKANE, Wash., March 30 (AP). -- Former Senator Clarence C. Dill's "love-at-first-sight" romance with the former "General" Rosalie Gardner Jones, one-time New York suffragist leader, reached the divorce court today.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt lost today her fight to gain control of her 12-year-old daughter Gloria, the Supreme Court refusing, without explanation, to review a decision of New York courts that the child must remain a ward of her aunt, Mrs. Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney, and spend most of the time with her.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 30. -- Twenty-two Dodgers and seventeen Red Sox battled this afternoon until the brief tropical twilight descended upon them and then they called it a day with the score knotted at 6 -- all at the end of the thirteenth inning.

An advertising program, aimed to push a product along the entire line of distribution, from manufacturer to the ultimate consumer, is the most urgent present need of sales management, H.B. LeQuatte, president of Churchill-Hall, Inc., and also president of the Advertising Club, told members of the Sales Executives Club of New York at their weekly luncheon meeting yesterday at the Hotel Roosevelt.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 30. -- Prince Mikhail A. Goundoroff entertained nearly one hundred today with a cocktail party at which Russian entertainers performed.
WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Walter L. Rice, special assistant to the Attorney General, who participated in argument of the Sugar Institute case for the government, said:
Harry F. Wolf of the New York A.C., national amateur champion, was eliminated from the world's open squash tennis championship last night at the Hotel Shelton.
PHILADELPHIA, March 30. -- Wildness of two pitchers helped Temple University open its Baseball season with a 14-2 victory over Dartmouth today.

Leonard Del Genio registered a surprise triumph over Wesley Ramey, clever Grand Rapids lightweight, in the feature bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. The Harlem battler, on the short end of 5-to-1 odds, built up an early lead to gain the majority verdict over his foe.

A stiff left jab followed by a hard right cross saved Samuel Sutker, a 110-pound jeweler of 2,316 Broadway, from being robbed by four armed men yesterday morning. Although his courage cost Mr. Sutker several scalp wounds, the robbers fared decidedly worse.

A common-sense attitude in determining the distinction between motion pictures with a message and those dealing with "self-serving propaganda" was urged upon the film industry yesterday by Will H. Hays in his annual report to the directors of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America Inc.

William Ziegler Jr., chairman of the New Fork State Borah for President Committee, sent a telegram to Governor Lehman yesterday, asking immediate investigation of an alleged raid on the printing office of Herman L. Bogart, a Farmingdale (L.I.) publisher.

Shadows lengthened in General Sessions Court late yesterday afternoon as an audience of more than 300 edged forward, ears strained, to hear Vera Stretz sob through a tiny lace handkerchief her explanation of why she shot and killed Dr. Fritz Gebhardt at 2 A.M. last Nov. 12 in Beekman Tower.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Recommendations that six new dam projects to cost $144,500,000 be undertaken are contained in a report filed with Congress today by the Tennesse Valley Authority. The report covers the TVA's progress and plans for the integrated development of navigation, flood and control, land conservation and power program for the seven Tennessee Valley States.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member hanks in 101 leading cities on March 25 shows decreases for the week of $26,000,000 in total loans and investments, $81,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $24,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and $124,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks.

BOSTON, March 30. -- Denouncing the Townsend plan as an "absurd panacea," the Boston Chamber of Commerce, through Philip Nichols, chairman of its committee on Federal taxation and expenditures, today presented figures to show that the plan would cost Massachusetts taxpayers a billion dollars a year.

The Democratic platform of 1932 favored "maintenance of the national "credit by a Federal budget annually "balanced." The last two words are significant. In the early years of the depression there were some theorists who contended that, while it was of course necessary to balance the budget over a long period, there was no reason why this need be done during a depression.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 30. -- Eight women and twelve men will compose a joint expedition of Harvard and Massachusetts Institute of Technology scientists who will go to Soviet Russia to observe the total eclipse of the sun on June 19, Dr. Donald H. Menzel of the Harvard Observatory, in charge of the expedition, declared today.

MADRID, March 30. -- Six weeks after the Parliamentary elections, the Cortes still is not officially constituted because definite approval has been obtained for the seating of barely more than half of the 473 Deputies.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 30. -- Reaching the offerings of three Tiger hurlers for fifteen hits that included two triples and a double, the strong Long Island University baseball team downed Princeton, 8 -- 3, on University Field today.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The government won a victory today when the Supreme Court rejected the plea of Burco, Inc., to decide the constitutionality of the Utility Holding Company Act through a review of its suit against the American States Public Service Company.

The flood-relief fund raised by the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross reached $459,100.41 yesterday, as additional contributions of $21,445.27 were received and listed. Further gifts received late in the day were not tabulated, the chapter reported.

PHILADELPHIA, March 30. -- Trustees at the Philadelphia yearly meeting of the Society of Friends are considering seriously the advisability of reinvesting their unrestricted funds in equities which they believe will best survive possible currency inflation.

Lieut. Col. John K. Brown of this city, well-known polo player, was elected president of the Metropolitan Equestrian Club which held its organization dinner and meeting last night at the Hotel Shelton. Seventy-five persons were present for the occasion.

Clayton Seagears of Middletown, N.Y., a young man with a genius for compressing a maximum mount of information in a minimum of space, last year published a fishing map of the lower Catskills region that proved a boon to many New York anglers who are confronted annually with the perplexing problem of finding suitable open waters.
ROME, March 30. -- Premier Benito Mussolini received today a delegation of the International Red Cross headed by its president, Max Huber.
The logical, temperate and convincing letter of the Rev. W. Taylor Dale is a welcome contribution to the theme of American foreign policy.

BERLIN, March 30. -- It was still undecided at a late hour tonight whether Joachim von Ribbentrop, German Ambassador at Large, would fly to London tomorrow carrying a new version of Adolf Hitler's seven-point peace program.

NEW DELHI, India, March 30. -The Indian Legislative Assembly, by a vote of 70 to 65, decided today to give notice of termination of the trade agreement signed in Ottawa in 1932 between Britain and India.

Legal action was started yesterday by Andrew Furuseth, president of the International Seamen's Union, against Joseph Curran, chairman of the strikers' committee of the Panama Pacific liner California, charging misrepresentation on the part of the strikers in their efforts to effect sympathy strikes on other Atlantic ships.

Fifty years ago yesterday Richard Steere, an eager young man who was just old enough to vote, put on a black mohair jacket and started his first job as a clerk in Park Tilford's grocery and cigar store on upper Fifth Avenue.
The grand national championships of the United States Bridge Association opened yesterday at the Park Central Hotel. Competition for teams-of-four and open pairs will continue through Saturday.

CHICAGO, March 30. -- Hogs met with a fairly good demand here today, and while the general market was quoted as steady some sales of desirable light kinds appeared 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight higher than on last Friday. The top price was unchanged at $10.80, while the day's average was steady at $10.45. Most sales were at $10.20 to $10.75.

ALBANY, March 30. -- After two messages from Governor Lehman, the Assembly tonight unanimously passed the bill of Assemblyman Brownell, New York Republican, authorizing New York City to lease the Flushing Meadows site for the 1939 world's fair.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 30 (AP). -- Bucking a light head wind, three yachts were approaching Rebecca Shoals as they beat toward the treacherous Florida Strait late tonight in the annual St. Petersburg-Havana race.

NORTH BERGEN, N.J., March 30. -- This township presented a petition of bankruptcy today to Federal Judge Guy L. Fake in Newark, in which it presents a readjustment plan which calls for refunding finances over a period of forty years and for reduction in the interest rate on the town's obligations from 6 per cent to an average of 4 1/2 per cent.
Elimination states them in the face, but the New York Americans, nevertheless, are prepared to fight to the last ditch against the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Despite official statements that devaluation is not contemplated and indications of strong support from the British and United States stabilization funds, the franc remained below the gold-import point yesterday and thus permitted the advent of a new gold movement from France.

Yvon Robert, spectacular Canadian heavyweight grappler, conquered Joe Savoldi of Three Oaks, Mich., in the feature finish wrestling engagement at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory last night before 3,000 fans.

Public high schools should not seek to dissuade students from joining undergraduate Communist societies any more than they seek to discourage membership in Democratic, Republican or Socialist clubs, Dr. John L. Tildsley, Assistant Superintendent of Schools assigned to high schools, said yesterday.

Directors of the Holly Sugar Corporation yesterday declared an initial dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock, payable on May 1, to stock of record of April 15. Directors also ordered that $300,000 be set aside to satisfy the sinking-fund requirements on the preferred stock for the fiscal years ended on March 31, 1934, 1935 and 1936.

MIAMI, Fla., March 30. -- Miss Purray, consistent mare from the Liberty Lane Stable ridden by Jockey Joe Rosen, led all the way to win the Pertinax Purse, the mile and a sixteenth feature witnessed by 7,500 at Tropical Park today. El Puma was a threatening second, a length back, and three lengths in advance of Donnahona, third in the field of seven.

It was a saying of BISMARCK, to show how hard it was for his fellow-countrymen to agree about public affairs, that wherever three Germans meet to discuss politics there are always four opinions. ADOLF HITLER may move to amend by asserting that whenever three Germans go to the polls they cast five ballots all for him.

A further improvement in the May delivery on the Cotton Exchange yesterday carried that month to its highest quotation since Jan. 6, but the general market encountered a slightly increased supply of contracts and lost 1 to 5 points.

LONDON, March 30. -- Great indignation was shown in both houses of Parliament today over reports of Italy's use of poison gas and indiscriminate bombing by Italian aircraft in the warfare in Ethiopia.

The Supreme Court handed down a decision yesterday which deals with the important question of how far groups of business men may go, in attempting to substitute for NRA some form of private control of competitive trade practices. The matter under review was the activity of the Sugar Institute, formed in 1927 by the fifteen principal refiners of cane sugar, for the declared purpose of stabilizing conditions in that industry.

Mail orders for women's apparel and accessories reaching this market yesterday were heavy, reflecting the excellent consumer demand for Spring merchandise at the week-end. Retailers stressed deliveries of merchandise now on order to fill out stocks and manufacturers are working at top speed to get goods in the stores for the peak trade expected this week.

PARIS, March 30. -- Following the advance in the discount rate of the Bank of France on Saturday from 3 1/2 to 5 per cent, another effort was begun today to present the situation to a somewhat skeptical public as perfectly satisfactory. Rentes rose by small amounts, but both the pound sterling and the dollar exchanges moved slightly against the franc to 75.14 francs and 15.18 1/4 francs, respectively.

BOSTON, March 30 (AP). -- Rear Admiral Cary T. Grayson, national chairman of the American Red Cross, said that he found the Connecticut River Valley the hardest hit flood area of any he has inspected thus far. Arriving here late last night, he said:

ALBANY, March 30. -- After protracted and heated debate, the Senate after midnight passed Governor Lehman's principal budget bill, with Democratic amendments restoring most of the items, aggregating $15,562,000, which had been cut out by the Republican-controlled Assembly.

"Ah, the land of the rustling of wings" is the ancient prophet's pronouncement of the doom of Ethiopia. And the report of the bombing of a defenseless city by bombs carried by wings would seem to be a literal fulfillment of this prophecy in spite of all that a civilized world can do to prevent such a catastrophe.

MIAMI, Fla., March 30. -- President Roosevelt took his first official action since he started on his fishing cruise when he issued an executive order today continuing George L. Berry as Coordinator for Industrial Cooperation.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- A great rush to add flood-control projects to the bill being considered by the Senate Commerce Committee, resulting in a nation-wide program calling for an expenditure of $1,000,000,000 over ten years, was reported today by Chairman Copeland.

Although there was sufficient news bearing on the stock market yesterday to have enlivened proceedings in a period when speculative activity and "public" participation were sizable, trading was very slow and price movements were narrow.

The International Mining Corporation reported that on Dec. 31 the net asset value of its 400,055 shares of common stock was $21.93 each, compared with $21.65 on Dec. 31, 1934. The figure for the end of last year was after deductions of approximately $1.74 a share for a reserve for mining venture Josses and unrealized profits on securities held.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Congress, which enacted the Transportation Act of 1920, introducing the principle of consolidation of railway corporations, cannot now desert some 150,000 railway employes whose jobs would be endangered if contemplated economies are affected, George M. Harrison, president of the Railway Labor Executives Association, said today when he spoke in favor of the Wheeler-Crosser bill before a subcommittee of the House Interstate Commerce Commission.

An order temporarily restraining Walter P. McCaffray Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange with offices at 25 Broad Street, from dealing in securities was signed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice William Harmon Black on application of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr.

TOKYO, Tuesday, March 31. -- The situation on the eastern frontier of Manchukuo has improved since Soviet Army officers received Japanese staff officers and arranged another meeting for today, when the bodies of the two Japanese killed in last week's clash will be handed over.

GENEVA, March 30. -- The League of Nations sent to its members today two Ethiopian telegrams protesting yesterday's bombing of Harar as "a flagrant violation" of Article 25 of the 1907 Hague Convention No. 4.

LONDON, March 30. -- The stock markets here generally were quiet and dull today pending international developments. British funds were fairly well maintained, although the tone eased in the afternoon on lack of support.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The cruiser provisions of the new London naval treaty were declared at the Navy Department today to be perfectly satisfactory to the United States, notwithstanding attacks that have been made on the clauses relating to this class of ships.
WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Reppresentative Allen T. Treadway criticized in the House today the tariff views recenty expressed by Colonel Frank Knox.

Work on "The Battle of Jutland," to be published by the United States Naval Institute on April 15, was begun by the author, the late Commander Holloway H. Frost, soon after the battle and continued until his death about a year ago. The manuscript was completed by his friend and literary executor, Edwin A. Falk, author of the recently published "Togo and the Rise of Japanese Sea Power" (Longmans, Green.)

NORTH BERGEN, N.J., March 30. -- Two men were killed instantly and a third injured critically here today when the car in which they were riding crashed into a telegraph pole after colliding with another automobile. The driver of the second car, a woman, was uninjured.

Miss Rose Schneidermann was re-elected president of the Women's Trade Union League at the annual meeting of that organization last night at the league's clubhouse, 247 Lexington Avenue. Miss Maud Swartz and Miss Mary Dreier were named vice presidents and Mrs. Richard S. Childs was re-elected treasurer.

The rabbit clan, a fortnight in advance, descended en masse upon New York yesterday when the first bunny show ever presented in this city was opened in the Sunken Plaza in Rockefeller Center as part of a two-week Easter festival.

Seven games were decided yesterday in the opening round of the annual tournament for the individual championship of the H.Y.P.D. Chess League, in which Harvard, Yale and Princeton entered two players each and Dartmouth one at the Marshall Chess Club.
TRENTON, March 30. -- The New Jersey Court of Pardons, Bruno Richard Hauptmann's last resort, for the second time turned down his plea for clemency today.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Announcement was made by the State Department today that the Treasury had received from the Greek Government last Thursday $152,544, representing 35 per cent of the semi-annual interest amounting to $217,920 due May 10, 1935, and $217,920 due Nov. 10, 1935, on the 4 per cent loan of 1929 by the United States to Greece.

The consolidated net profit of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana for 1935 amounted to approximately $30,179,000 after depreciation, depletion, amortization, Federal income taxes and other charges, according to Edward G. Seubert, president.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The Tennessee Valley Authority was charged by the Southern Railway in a brief filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission with entire disregard of its duty and obligations under the Constitution in attempting "by force of arms" to take over the railroad's twelve-mile line from Vaspar to LaFollette in Tennessee without just compensation.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 30. -- Batting practice today for the third annual Augusta invitation golf tournament was marred by another par-cracking round for Bob Jones, a hole-in-one for Horton Smith of Chicago, 1934 winner of the event, and Gene Sarazen's insistence upon his arrival that he "hasn't a chance" to repeat his startling victory of last year.

In the ranks of the Socialist party it is now war to a finish between the Old Guard and the Left Wing. That, at least, is the way most of the newspaper reports describe it, letting the anachronisms fall where they may.

The four officials who will handle the games of the final Olympic basketball tryout tournament at Madison Square Garden on Friday, Saturlay and either Sunday or Monday were named yesterday. Heading the list of the country's outstanding arbiters is Pat Kennedy of Hoboken, the dynamic young man who has worked at nearly every one of the Garden shows this year.

LONDON, March 30. -- After a hundred years Mr. Pickwick today drove again behind a four-in-hand in the selfsame Commodore coach thirty-one miles from London to Rochester, commemorating the centenary of the publication of the first part of the immortal "Pickwick Papers."

Recognition for pre-eminent success in reducing the highway accidents of the nation in 1935 was awarded yesterday by the National Safety Council to the representatives of three States and six municipalities at a luncheon at the Hotel Pennsylvania at which Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of General Motors, declared that the shock troops in the war for highway safety are public officials.

To their "Dear Fellow Republicans" enrolled in the First Congressional District the candidates of the Borah-for-President Committee for delegates and alternates to the Cleveland convention have sent a letter of admonition, instruction and appeal. On April 2, primary day, those voters will have their first and only opportunity to shape the "course of events in the most import" ant national election in our day, if "not in the history of our country."

The National Public Housing Conference, representing more than fifty affiliated organizations, sent a letter yesterday to President Roosevelt asking him to "throw the full weight of administration support" behind the Wagner Slum Clearance and Low Rent Housing Bill.

Miss Adele S. Raettig of Hoboken, N.J., the only woman competitor of the forty-eight who started play last night in the United States championship preliminaries, carried off the honors in Group A at the Manhattan Chess Club, where she was the first to finish a game.
Nine more persons, including three physicians, were arrested in Brooklyn yesterday as suspects in an insurance swindle that, to date, has resulted in indictments against forty-nine.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., March 30 (AP). -- Twenty-two boxers in the National Collegiate Athletic Association championships held Friday and Saturday were announced today as candidates for the final Olympic trials at Chicago in May.

A large group of younger members of society is aiding Harvard undergraduates in the arrangements for the performance of "The Lid's Off," the annual production of the Hasty Pudding Club, which will be presented here Friday night at Mecca Temple.

United States Senator Robert F. Wagner, discussing the Slum Clearance Bill he intends to re-introduce in Congress on Wednesday, called attention last night to the paradoxical situation in this country of wealth and poverty side by side.

PINHURST, N.C., March 30. -- George T. Dunlap Jr., four times holder of the title, and Sam Friedman Jr., youthful golfer from Tuscaloosa, Ala., led a field of thirty-two into the championship flight of the annual North and South amateur tourney by shooting 73s today to tie for medal honors.

A general advance in raw and refined sugar prices, while refiners and dealers swept the raw market of available offerings yesterday, lifted sugar futures to the highest levels in nearly eight years. The volume was the largest in several months. Prices in the outside market were the best in six and one-half years and refined prices were advanced, effective today, to 5 cents a pound.

Il Duce will not care much for the new play at the Civic Repertory. While he is disciplining the contrary Ethiopians the insurgents of the Theatre Union are undermining Italian Fascism with "Bitter Stream," which was put on in Fourteenth Street last evening.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP).-Completion of the Senate Lobby Committee's field investigation was disclosed today, simultaneously with a new outburst on the Senate floor against William Randolph Hearst for his criticism of the committee.

MOSCOW, March 30. -- How far the Soviet Government has advanced from its actively hostile attitude of only a few years ago toward persons who, although valuable or potentially valuable members of the community, have been stigmatized as "class enemies" was shown today in a resolution by the directorate of the Communist party rebuking a local party leader in Northern Caucasus for discriminating against the daughter of an exiled kulak.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The constitutionality of New York State's Minimum Wage Law as applied to women and children will be decided by the Supreme Court. The court agreed today to a review and will hear arguments April 28.

Accommodations for an entry list expected to surpass the 1930 record of 1,177 were announced yesterday by the United States Golf Association for the sectional qualifying rounds preceding the 1936 national open championship. The 1935 entry was 1,125.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- A proposal to give the title of honorary poet laureate of the United States to Representative John Steven McGroarty of California was made today in a joint resolution introduced in the House by Representative Monaghan of Montana.

ALBANY, March 30. -- Governor Lehman was assailed in the Senate tonight for "reckless disregard of the truth," and called upon to make "public retraction over the radio" for his latest attack on what the Executive termed the opposition to his program of anti-crime legislation.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The House completed consideration of a bill today to raise the capitalization of the Commodity Credit Corporation from the present $3,000,000 to $100,000,000. Under the bill this would be accomplished through the Reconstruction Finance Corporation at no additional outlay of government funds.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Thirty-six registration statements under the Securities Act of 1933, including one covering the issuance of $40,000,000 of securities by the Saguenay Power Company, Ltd., of Montreal, Canada, were filed over the week-end with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

CHICAGO, March 30. -- While the wheat market on the Board of Trade today showed considerable resistance to pressure, the aggregate trade was light. Aside from the selling of a fair-sized line of July wheat which pit brokers attributed to a local professional there was little interest in the market.

MEDFORD, N.J., March 30. -- Booneville Dr. Bill, white and liver pointer dog by Shore's Jack Doone and out of Shore's Lemon Lady, owned by Jay F. Carlisle of East Islip, L.I., ran an outstanding race today to win the members' Derby Stake, first event of the thirty-sixth annual Spring field trial meeting of the English Setter Club of America.
WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Continuation of the Industrial Council was regarded here tonight as a part of President Roosevelt's new drive to get the unemployed back into private industry.

Sir Philip Astley, Baron and Baroness Raymond de Luze, Maurice Dekobra, French author, and Count and Countess Robert de Vogue are among the prominent persons due to arrive today from Havre via Plymouth on the French liner Ile de France.

The Authors League of America completed its reorganization yesterday afternoon at the Shelton Hotel, when its members approved a new constitution giving the league's council entire governing power over the Authors Guild, the Dramatists Guild and the Screen Writers Guild.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 30. -- Harvard University's rugby football team, which arrived on the Queen of Bermuda today, showed greatly improved form over last year in defeating the Bermuda Athletic Association fifteen on the latter's field, 15 to 5.

OKLAHOMA CITY, March 30 (AP). -- Senator Elmer Thomas predicted before the Oklahoma Democratic State Convention today that President Rooseevlt "will sweep the country" on the New Deal issue in his re-election campaign.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 30 (AP). -- High scores were the rule rather than the exception in the American Bowling Congress today as three Chicago pinmen and two Toledo keglers pounded their way to recognition. Herman Beth, Chicago, took the lead in the all events with 1,970 and hung up 287 for the high single game in the tourney.

The El Paso Natural Gas Company, as a result of plans being formulated for a refunding of debts of itself and subsidiaries, has given effect to an option obtained by the Engineers Public Service Company several years ago in connection with the purchase of $3,500,000 bonds of the Western Gas Company, a subsidiary.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 30. -- Serious rioting by Croat nationalists occurred today at the funeral in Zagreb of Stepan Javor, former Croat student. He was serving a sentence of twenty years in prison in connection with the murder in 1929 of Toni Schlegel, Croat editor who went over to the side of King Alexander's dictatorship. Javor died in prison a few days ago.

Sixteen commercial groups of the New York Port District urged the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday to adopt the metropolitan district as laid down by a special committee of the Merchants Association in 1927 as the official district of exemption in the administration of the new Motor Carriers Act.

Sharply increased imports of iron and steel last year resulted in a loss equivalent to $16 in wages for each employe of the steel industry in this country, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday. Additional losses were sustained by employes of mining and transportation companies engaged in supplying the steel industry with raw materials, the institute said.

Mayor La Guardia, reversing a decision made last Friday by License Commissioner Paul Moss, decided yesterday that the Ringling Brothers and Barnum and Bailey Circus will be permitted this year, as in the past, to pitch its tents in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The Iranian (Persian) Government has informed the State Department that as a protest against the treatment given Iranian subjects in the American press it is closing its diplomatic and consular offices in this country and will maintain diplomatic relations with the United States through the American Legation in Teheran.

May I avail myself of your columns to announce that if, as I have reason to believe will be the case, I can secure endorsement from a sufficient number of residents of our State, I shall be prepared to give up my present occupation and run for the United States Senate on a platform calling for the doing away with all privacy in individual as well as in corporate life?
Holders of Crucible Steel Company ten-year 5 per cent debentures due on May 1, 1940, have been notified that $2,000,000 of these bonds will be redeemed on May 1 at 101 and accrued interest.
ALEXANDRIA, La., March 30. -- With the exception of Hal Schumacher's famed sinker ball, the Giants and Indians arrived here today on time and with all their paraphernalia intact.

TOPEKA, March 30 (AP). -- Governor C. Douglass Buck of Delaware, here today to confer with Governor Alf M. Landon, predicted that the Kansas Governor would be the Republican Presidential nominee, but laughed at mention of himself as a possible Vice Presidential candidate.
Two men were arrested and three others were sentenced yesterday in Special Sessions Court on charges growing out of District Attorney Dodge's investigation of fraudulent accident claims.
Two men were arrested and three others were sentenced yesterday in Special Sessions Court on charges growing out of District Attorney Dodge's investigation of fraudulent accident claims.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP). -- B. Coles Neidecker and his two brothers, wanted by the French Government on charges resulting from failure of their Paris bank, asked the Supreme Court today to dismiss without a hearing an appeal by Police Commissioner Valentine of New York City and French officials from a Circuit Court ruling.

While an increase in steel operations was expected for the current week because of the subsidence of the floods in the Pittsburgh district, the gain of 8.3 points, or 15 1/2 per cent, to 62 per cent of capacity, the highest level since the American Iron and Steel Institute started issuing indicated weekly rates in October, 1933, was larger than the financial community had been looking for.
Opposition to three "so-called patriotic bills" pending in the State Legislature was expressed yesterday in a committee report to the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP). -- Investigation of alleged political discrimination in Works Progress employment in Atlantic, Cumberland and Cape May Counties, N.J., was asked today by Representative Bacharach of New York.

ROME, March 30. -- According to unofficial advices from the northern front, the Italian troops operating in Amhara Province of Ethiopia have advanced far beyond Debarech, whose occupation was officially announced only today, and are already in Dabat, about twenty miles southwest.

PHILADELPHIA, March 30. -- Dr. Merle Middletown Odgers, Dean of the College of Liberal Arts for Women at the University of Pennsylvania, was elected president of Girard College today to succeed Dr. Cheesman A. Herrick, who has resigned.
Family breadwinners, dropped by mistake in the lay-off of 40,000 WPA relief workers which is under way, will be reinstated, it was announced yesterday by Victor F. Ridder, local WPA administrator.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 30. -- The overtime Influence clings to the Yankees. So does their hitting helplessness. They had to travel ten rounds today to conquer the stingless Boston Bees in their farewell for the year. The score was 5 -- 4, giving Marse Joe McCarthy's lads a clean sweep of the five-game series.

ALBANY, March 30. -- A legislative committee recommended to the Legislature tonight that New York State buy and develop mineral water springs in Erie, Schoharie and Otsego Counties "if their transfer to State authority will be profitable and justifiable from a financial standpoint."
HOUSTON, March 30 (AP). -- Most seeded stars in the sixth annual River Oaks tennis tournament breezed through opening matches today.

A petition signed by more than 1,000 students and instructors of Columbia University was presented yesterday to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, with a request that the university withdraw acceptance of an invitation to send a delegate to Germany in July for a celebration of the 550th anniversary of Heidelberg University.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- A sharp decline in revenue from dues to the Old Age Revolving Pensions, Ltd., the corporate name of the Townsend old-age pension plan, has been revealed by evidence obtained by the special House committee investigating the movement.

LONDON, March 30. -- Little hope is held by the British Government that Chancellor Adolf Hitler of Germany will make any material contribution to a solution of the problem precipitated by his military reoccupation of the Rhineland in violation of the Locarno treaty.

In announcing the re-election of five directors of the Gulf States Steel Company, William H. Coverdale, president, charged last night that the Republic Steel Corporation had made an unsuccessful attempt to seize control of the company at the annual meeting of Gulf States's stockholders, held yesterday afternoon in Wilmington, Del.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP). -- An upward trend in salaries of corporation executives from 1934 to 1935 was indicated today in reports of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Filing of data for 1935 under the Securities Exchange Act has just begun.

Before an audience of 18,000 persons, including Mayor La Guardia, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and others prominent in civic and national life, more than 3,500 children from the elementary and high schools of the city gave a program of choral and symphonic music last night in Madison Square Garden.

To last Saturday night's casualties add "Case of Clyde Griffiths," which the Group Theatre and Milton Shubert presented at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre on March 13. The Group wanted to take over the show and continue it, but was unable to come to terms with Mr. Shubert.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP). -- The Republican National Committee accused the New Deal today of being the sponsor of farm communities which are "communistic in conception."

An assertion that Bishop Samuel Seabury, first Protestant Episcopal Bishop in this country, used the proceeds of a lottery to build a church at Cheshire, Conn., was Mrs. Oliver Harriman's reply yesterday to a sermon by Bishop William T. Manning denouncing the movement for legalizing lotteries in this State.

Robert C. Stanley, president of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., said to stockholders at the annual meeting in Toronto yesterday that the company was not planning to retire or to convert its preferred stock at present.

Cooperation between manufacturer and retailer will be stressed in the new outdoor advertising campaign, which Gimbel Brothers is inaugurating. Nationally advertised products carried by Gimbel's New York store will be featured, together with the slogan, "Gimbel's Tells the Truth."
LONDON, March 31. -- Lord Eustace Percy, Minister Without Portfolio, resigned from the Cabinet tonight because Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin was giving him too little to do.
LONDON, March 31. -- For the fourth year in succession Great Britain has closed her national accounts with a surplus.

The East's high-goal indoor polo champions started for Chicago and the national East-West matches yesterday. Three members of the New York Athletic Club team, senior Eastern titleholders, left by train to compete in their first match tonight at the 124th Field Artillery Armory there.
Another steamship company will utilize midtown space for ticket offices and allied purposes, according to a lease reported yesterday by the R.B. Wattley Company and Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., brokers.

KALIMPONG, India, March 15 (By Air Mail via London). -- As the advance party of the 1936 Mount Everest Expedition left Kalimpong today on a 300-mile march to the foot of the mountain, we were gratified to note the efficiency of the 165 native porters and the 250 transport animals.

It has often been said that the new generation is mentally superior to the one that preceded it. Now we know, and with pride or humility we must confess, that this is true. The creation of the Veterans of Future Wars at Princeton proves it.

The ideal of music as "a privilege for all" rather than "a luxury for the rich" was stressed by Dr. Walter Damrosch yesterday at a session of the Music Educators National Conference in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The first words heard from the Palestine broadcasting station, which was opened on Monday by the High Commissioner, were, "This is Jerusalem calling," spoken in three languages, English, Hebrew and Arabic. It was a significant event. As great a seeming miracle as that which once appeared in the skies of that city has been wrought again.

The estate of Mrs. Florence Adelaide Pratt of Newport, Singer Sewing Machine heiress, whose will was unsuccessfully contested by her sister, Mrs. Margaret A. Alexander, was appraised yesterday at $4,697,060 gross and $4,478,559 net. The bulk of the estate was in securities, including 13,248 shares of Singer Manufacturing Company worth $1,344,672.

BERLIN, March 31 (AP). -- A capital reconstruction of the Allgemeine Elektrizitaets Gesellschaft (General Electric Company of Germany), one of the biggest industrial concerns in the country, was spoken of as inevitable today by Dr. Hermann Buecher, a member of the board of directors.

The local Works Progress Administration announced yesterday that within a few days it would start Spring plowing in more than 5,000 subsistence gardens in Brooklyn, Queens, Richmond and the Bronx, where relief families are expected to raise enough fresh vegetables to carry them through the season and a canned surplus for the coming Winter.

TRENTON, N.J., March 31. -- Crowds estimated by the police at close to 8,000 persons were slow to leave the vicinity of the prison tonight when it was learned that Bruno Richard Hauptmann's execution had been postponed. The police shouted again and again "Hauptmann has been reprieved for forty-eight hours" and men, women and children merely stood their ground at first and laughed.

Joe Jerwa kept the New York Americans in the running as a Stanley Cup possibility last night. The big defenseman, working with splendid and precise assistance from Art Chapman and Dave Schriner, scored the goal that enabled the spangled sextet to defeat the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden, 1 to 0.

MOSCOW, March 31. -- The decision to hunt for older and higher forms of life in the frozen soil of the Ice Age that still grips Northern Siberia was explained today by Professor Peter Keptereff, who recently returned from the northern border of Manchuria with minute, shrimp-like creatures hatched from eggs that had been frozen 1,000 to 3,000 years.

How far the world has moved technologically in the hundred years since "Pickwick" we can best realize by comparing two outstanding popular elections. One is the plebiscite of last Sunday in which Herr HITLER proved that you can poll all of the German people all of the time.

NEVER mind the title, "Stubborn Roots" (Macmillan, $2.50). Get into the novel and before many pages you will feel as though you had had some part in a discovery. For this book by Elms Godchaux is one of those blue-moon novels of the soil which succeed in proving that novels of the soil can really be colorful. In the ordinary run, of course, they are not.

HOUSTON, Texas, March 31 (AP). -- John Van Ryn of Philadelphia and Henry Culley of Santa Barbara, Calif., overcame surprisingly stiff opposition by University of Texas rivals to advance to the third round of the singles play in the annual River Oaks tennis tournament today.

Fewer diphtheria deaths occurred during the first quarter of 1936 than in any previous three months in the city's history, Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, announced yesterday. Only five deaths from this disease have been reported for the year to date, compared to a previous low of ten deaths for the third quarter of 1935.
WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Mayor William N. McNair of Pittsburgh appeared at the Capitol today for the second time in two years to protest new Federal taxes.

Operating revenue of the Union Pacific Railroad is running from 8 to 10 per cent above last year's levels, Carl R. Gray, president, said yesterday. While gross revenues in March were well over the $9,757,674 total for March, 1935, only a slight increase in net operating income from the total of $1,241,688 a year ago resulted, because of increased rail and tie replacements.

The total profits of 700 leading industrial and mercantile concerns in 1935 were 48 per cent larger than in 1934 and were the largest since 1930, although still only half as large as in 1929, according to a compilation presented by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its monthly review, published yesterday.

Joseph Miller Jr., secretary of the Board of Education, has been asked by the Fusion group on the board to resign his position and has replied he will make a determined fight to retain the $12,000 post, it was learned yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., March 31. -- Bootless, which will be Colonel E.R. Bradley's main hope for the Derby Consolation Stakes here on Saturday, qualified handsomely for that engagement when he thrilled 8,000 spectators by scoring by a head in the Surf Purse, the mile feature at Tropical Park today.

The Markets Department late this month will move from its quarters in the Municipal Building into two floors of the building at 139 Center Street that was formerly occupied by the Health Department, William C. Morrisey Jr., head of the Real Estate Division of the Finance Department, announced yesterday.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., March 31. -- A brilliant audience attended the Harvard Hasty Pudding Club's annual production, "The Lid's Off," in the Homestead Theatre. Mrs. Rudolph R. Loening gave a dinner in the Empire Room. Miss Mary D. Brooks entertained for Mr. and Mrs. William Sergeant Kendall at dinner in the Colonial Room before attending the performance.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 31. -- Bobby Cruickshank, the little Scot whose bid for national open championship honors was balked thirteen years ago by Bobby Jones, signalized his visit to his Georgia rival's home grounds today by taking apart the first nine holes of the Augusta National golf course.

When the Children's Court at 137 East Twenty-second Street opens this morning an intake bureau, called the Bureau of Adjustments, will decide whether a child shall go before the judge or whether its case can be handled by agencies other than the judicial.

ALBANY, March 31. -- The bill sponsored by Senator Jacob J. Schwartzwald of Kings affecting compensation for sufferers from silicosis was backed by organized labor and spokesmen for industry at a public bearing today before the Senate Committee on Labor and Industry.

WITH THE NORTHERN ITALIAN ARMY, Gondar, Ethiopia, March 31. -- Italy's "mechanized cavalry" captured this strategic Ethioplan city today and established itself close to a vital zone of British influence.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month was slower than in February, but the largest for a March since 1931. Sales, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, totaled 51,025,148 shares, compared with 60,871,262 in February and 15,849,017 in March last year.

TRENTON, N.J., March 31. -- Mrs. Bruno Richard Hauptmann, lying down in her room tonight, was awaiting news that her husband was dead. The telephone beside her bed rang and was answered by Robert W. Hicks, one of Governor Hoffman's investigators.

Bids were submitted to the Port of New York Authority yesterday by four contractors for the construction of the ventilation building of the new Hudson Midtown Tunnel on the New Jersey side of the river.

Bicycles and the costumes worn by women who rode them prior to the turn of the century held the spotlight yesterday afternoon at a bicycle fashion show in the Savoy Plaza Hotel, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

BOWIE, Md., March 31. -- A dash of excitement was added today to the flutter preceding the opening of the Eastern racing season here tomorrow when Singing Wood, overnight favorite for the $2,500-added Inaugural Handicap, tossed his rider and ran away during a workout, throwing some doubt on his fitness.

The Timken-Detroit Axle Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for 1935 a net profit of $1,173,202 after depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges. After dividend requirements on the 7 per cent preferred stock this was equal to $1.02 each on 980,000 shares of $10-par common stock.

California has a large majority of enrolled Republicans, yet they have shown surprising skill and ingenuity in splitting it up or frittering it away. What they did in 1916 Mr. HUGHES has surely not forgotten. What they did in 1932 Mr. HOOVER cannot have forgotten. Just now California, or at least her Republican party, is all aflutter over the election of delegates to the Cleveland convention.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 31. -- The feature of the opening day of the nineteenth annual Pinehurst Horse Show was the performance of Tony, a black gelding and unquestionably the oldest entry in the show. This veteran jumper, owned, trained and shown by Sergeant J.R. Gwin of Battery D, Eighty-third Artillery, Fort Bragg, has appeared in ten shows here and has not yet ticked once.

The Police Department will undergo a far-reaching shake-up today with demotions of at least two officers of the higher ranks, many promotions and extensive shifting of commands. Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine announced the proposed changes yesterday with only the terse explanation, "for the good of the service."

NEWARK, N.J., March 31. -- Closing its investigation of charges of irregularities of the Newark City Hall, the Essex County grand jury handed to Common Pleas Judge Richard Hartshorne today indictments naming four men, including three former or present city employees.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP). -- Secretary Wallace announced today the extension of the Dutch elm disease quarantine to include twenty-six more townships in New Jersey and thirteen more towns in New York.

TRENTON, N.J., March 31. -- A few hours before Charles Zeid, 37-year-old member of the Mais-Legenza "Tri-State Gang" of killers and robbers, was scheduled to die in the electric chair tonight for the murder of a Camden (N.J.) policeman, he received a thirty-day reprieve from Governor Harold G. Hoffman.

MADRID, March 31. -- Parliamentary government in republican Spain hung in the balance tonight, six weeks after the general election. All except forty of the more than 200 Center and Right Deputies-elect have withdrawn from the Cortes in protest against the Left's order invalidating the election of Rightists in Granada and other constituencies.
ASMARA, Eritrea, March 30 (delayed). -- Italian troops have completed the occupation of the rich Sultanate of Aussa, bordering on French Somaliland, it was announced here today.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Considerable opposition developed in Congress today to the plan advanced by army engineers of allocating a portion of the cost of flood-control projects to benefited communities. This provision is now contained in the tentative draft of the $385,000,000 omnibus Flood Control Bill pending before the Senate Commerce Committee.

Mrs. Maxwell Ehrlich of Staten Island was elected president of the New York State Conference of the National Council of Jewish Women yesterday at the closing session of the fourteenth convention of the conference in the Jamaica Jewish Centre, Jamaica, Queens. Mrs. Judah Dresner presided.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- By a seven-to-three decision the Interstate Commerce Commission today suspended from tomorrow until Nov. 1 the schedules under which railroads of the Eastern territory proposed to inaugurate free pick-up and delivery service on less than carload shipments.

All six of the favored contract bridge teams led their opponents last evening in the Park Central Hotel at the close of the first session of team play in the Grand National championships of the United States Bridge Association. Most of them had commanding leads after the first thirty-six hands had been completed.

TRENTON, March 31. -- Colonel Mark O. Kimberling, principal keeper in charge of the New Jersey State prison, announced tonight that he had postponed the execution of Bruno Richard Hauptmann for the murder of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr. for at least forty-eight hours.

LONDON, March 31. -- In a mood of deepest pessimism the British Government waited tonight for the documents that Joachim yon Ribbentrop, German Ambassador at Large, will hand to Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, tomorrow morning in answer to the Locarno powers' plan of a fortnight ago.
Preparing for the Summer season that has become so large a factor in the theatrical industry away from Broadway, the Actors Equity Association yesterday took decisive steps to protect its members.

Major Charles R. Morrison of the 245th Coast Defense Command of the New York National Guard, which has its armory at Sumner, Putnam and Jefferson Avenues, in Brooklyn, pleaded not guilty in Federal court in Brooklyn yesterday to an indictment charging him with presenting false vouchers to the War Department and with forgery.

Organization of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee campaign for a minimum of $1,500,000 is progressing satisfactorily, it was announced yesterday by Laurence M. Marks, chairman, and Myron C. Taylor, head of the commerce and industry division. The drive will begin April 21.

Retail failures in the United States declined in the week ended March 26, as compared with the previous week, but the manufacturing and wholesale divisions showed increases, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
James H. Dewson Jr., Francis Peterson and John T. Stephenson Jr. are in the New York office of Schoellkopf, Hutton Pomeroy, Inc.

A keeper and two young prisoners being held in the Bronx County jail, Third Avenue and 161st Street, were wounded last night when the two inmates, armed with a pistol and a pocket knife, made an unsuccessful attempt to escape from the jail.

MEDFORD, N.J., March 31. -- Fourteen brace were run today in the members' all-age stake of the annual Spring field trial meeting of the English Setter Club of America. Four more brace will be run tomorrow morning, following which a start will be made in the junior open all-age event.

James E. Van Zandt, National Commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, doffs his overseas cap to that "monkey" organization of college boys who venture to style themselves Veterans of Future Wars. They will never be veterans, prophesies the commander; they are "too yellow to go to war."

Stony Wold Sanatorium at Lake Kushaqua, N.Y., was the beneficiary of a fashion show entitled "Pairs on Parade," held yesterday during the luncheon hour in the Tudor Room of the Lombardy under the auspices of the Social Service Auxiliary of Stony Wold.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., refunding agent for the Chicago Park District, announced yesterday that holders of about 70 per cent of the bonds of the park districts, superseded by the Chicago Park District, have assented to the latter's refunding offer or are in the process of doing so.

HAVANA, March 31. -- The Cuban Cabinet granted the military authorities still more ample powers this afternoon when members of the armed forces received police powers in all cities and rural districts.

Property and merchandise losses to the extent of a half billion dollars in the flood areas were estimated by field agents of the New York Credit Men's Association, who have been canvassing the stricken districts for the last week, William W. Orr, executive secretary of the organization, reported here yesterday.
The grip of the Pennsylvania Railroad on the Boston Maine Railroad was maintained in 1935, the list of the twenty largest stockholders of the latter road disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The House Military Affairs Committee reported favorably today a bill providing for commercial use by airplanes of Governors Island, and also a measure to authorize the sale of the Newark Army Supply Base to the city of Newark on a long-term contract.

LONDON, March 31. -- Frank Vosper, in his own thriller, "Love From a Stranger," based on a story by Agatha Christie, was presented for a run at the New Theatre tonight. It was recently seen in a Sunday performance.

PARIS, March 31. -- On the seventh anniversary of the death of former American Ambassador Myron T. Herrick, his memory was honored today in Paris in a manner that seemed marked by the warmth of his own great personality.

Covering of a line of short cotton which was sold several weeks ago caused an improvement of 3 to 14 points on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. Though the Weather Bureau predicted showers in western sections where moisture is deficient, the absence of any pressure in new crop positions had an unsettling influence on recent sellers, and execution of several buying orders lifted July to around the 11-cent level in closing dealings.

KAMENZ, Germany, Wednesday, April 1. -- Mrs. Pauline Hauptmann was awakened by her friends at 4 o'clock this morning, German time, to hear the news that her son had not been executed. She had gone to bed in a friend's house convinced that all hope was past -- that Bruno Richard Hauptmann would be dead before morning.

Moderation in their demands for passage of the "American Youth Act," appropriating $3,500,000,000 for the youth of the country, was urged upon 500 young persons of the lower East Side yesterday by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the President, in an address at the Playhouse of the Henry Street Settlement, 466 Grand Street.

Declaring that shoes are a prime necessity and not an accessory. L.F. Tuffly, president of the National Shoe Retailers Association told the closing style conference of the organization yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria that footwear has become as vitally important as the entire costume to women.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 31. In the third game of the fourth annual Bermuda rugby week today Harvard defeated Yale, 8 to 5, In a match for the Bermuda Trade Development Board trophy.

The Jones Laughlin Steel Company of Pittsburgh filed yesterday an amendment to its registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission calling for offering tomorrow of $30,000,000 of 4 1/4 per cent bonds, due on March 1, 1961, at 97. The Mellon Securities Company, Inc., heads the banking syndicate.

While nearly every mail brings pleas to contribute to this or that boys' club or boys' camp to provide Summer rest and recreation for underprivileged city boys, who is thinking of the city girls -- the potential homemakers and mothers of the next generation? The hot, dirty, crowded streets seem to be good enough character builders for them.

Although temperatures dipped downward somewhat yesterday, the drop was not sufficient to take from last month the distinction of being the warmest March, with one exception, since 2871, the United States Weather Bureau said last night.
