PRINCETON, N.J., March 31. -- A hard-hitting Williams College baseball team pounded four pitchers for seventeen hits this afternoon to defeat Princeton, 17 -- 10, on University Field. It was the third straight setback for the Tigers.

The once famous novel, "Ten Thousand a Year," meant, of course, pounds not dollars. But Senator VANDENBERG is showing an unworthy curiosity about farmers who have received $10,000 annually from the Government for not working -- that is, for not raising crops, or for plowing them under, or killing young pigs.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 31 (AP). -- The Bowes Sealfast team of Indianapolis overcame a bad start tonight to batter down a total of 2,997 and take over third position in the five-man event of the American Bowling Congress.

In a decision handed down yesterday Judge Mortimer W. Byers in the Federal court in Brooklyn awarded fees to persons connected with the reorganization of the Lehrenkrauss Corporation, which is now known as the Fulton Service Corporation.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 31. -- Herman L. Bogart, owner of The Park Press at Farmingdale, L.I., was held in $500 bail for a further hearing on Monday by Police Judge George B. Serenbetz this morning on a charge of violating Section 209 of the State Labor Law by unlawfully using a union label on campaign literature printed for the Nassau County Borah-for-President Committee.

BERLIN, March 31. -- The Boerse was very quiet today. Heavy industrial issues showed some signs of strengthening, Mannesmann gaining point and Hoesch 1/4. The potash list was inactive and the chemical group was quiet, although I.G. Farben gained a point.

Bond issues offered publicly here in March reached the largest total for any month for five years and the total sum of stock offerings was the largest since May, 1931. Bond issues, most of which were for refunding in the public utility and industrial fields, included the largest single issue of bonds floated since the Securities Act of 1933 was legalized.

NASSAU, The Bahamas, March 31. -- After a week of cruising among the southern group of the Bahama Islands; which gave him a fine coat of tan and a new stock of fish stories, President Roosevelt stopped here for a few hours today and then sailed out for another week of vacation.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The Long Island Lighting Company was exempted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission from all provisions of the Public Utility Act which would require it to register as a holding company, the commission adding that therefore its subsidiary companies would not be subject to the obligations which otherwise would have been imposed upon them as subsidiaries.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Praise of the Federal agents under J. Edgar Hoover and a recommendation for an increased appropriation to allow for the employment of 252 more men next year in the field service of the Bureau of Investigation, were features of a report of the House Appropriations Subcommittee in submitting the supply measure for the Departments of State, Justice, Labor and Commerce.

DAVENPORT, Iowa, March 31. -- The sixth annual dog show of the Tricity Kennel Club opened today in the Masonic Temple with thirty-seven breeds represented in the entry and the entire judging program in the hands of Alfred Delmont of Wynewood, Pa.
IT was discovered while rambling around the Grapefruit Circuit in Florida that the proud palefaces of the American League have deep suspicions and no little fear of the Cleveland Indians.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- The NRA finally passed out of existence today, but left behind it four active offspring.

County Judge John J. Fitzgerald in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that John R. Coletti, former patrolman attached to the Sheepshead Bay station in Brooklyn, must stand trial for the murder of Robert Twigg in Brooklyn on March 14, 1935.
Fire in a fourth-floor dance studio at 209 West Forty-eighth Street early last night draped a curtain of smoke over the upper part of Times Square and attracted a throng of 15,000 persons.

While the combined strike and lockout of some 450 to 500 clerks and delivery boys in 140 independent grocery and vegetable stores of Brooklyn, Manhattan and the Bronx failed to spread yesterday, representatives of the merchants organization failed to keep a conference with William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets, to discuss a settlement.

LONDON, March 31 (AP). -- Clarence C. Pell of New York won his second round match in the British racquets singles championship today, defeating Robert C. Risley, 15 -- 9, 15 -- 8, 10 -- 15, 4 -- 15, 15 -- 7.

Mrs. C. Perry Beadleston gave a luncheon yesterday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin for her daughter, Miss Margaret McG. Beadleston, in connection with the "All American Fashion Revue of Summer Styles." The other guests were the Misses Caroline Pratt, Hope Saunders, Lydia Hickox, Alison Pyne, Lesley Ripley, Vieva Banks, Jean Rhoades, Sylvia Mitchell, Nancy Post, Margaret Holt, Sylvia Mason, Sheila Crimmins and Jean Reid.

LONDON, March 31. -- The firm of Chapman Hall, who a century ago today published the first number of "The Posthumous Papers of the Pickwick Club," organized an all-star matinee at the Palladium Theatre this afternoon in commemoration of the centenary.

Henri Bendel, founder and president of a women's specialty shop, who died on March 22, named A. Beekman Bastedo of 399 Park Avenue, an employe, one of his principal heirs in his will, which was filed for probate yesterday. The value of his estate was not disclosed.

More than 1,200 Columbia University students and their friends are expected to attend the opening performance at the Hotel Lismore tonight of "Off Your Marx," forty-third annual varsity show, it was announced yesterday at the university.

CHICAGO, March 31. -- The demand for hogs was not aggressive here today, and while the general market was quoted as steady to 10 cents a hundredweight lower some light lights were off 10 to 15 cents and a few sales of medium quality hogs sold as much as 25 cents lower.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Condemning the price-fixing practices of some chain-store groups, the House Judiciary Committee favorably reported today the Patman bill to "restore equality of opportunity in business" and to add "teeth" to the anti-trust laws as they apply to trade practices of chain-store groups.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31. -- The 1936 Army-Navy football game will be played in the Municipal Stadium here on Nov. 28, Mayor S. Davis Wilson announced today following a conference with repre sentatives of the West Point and Annapolis institutions.

ALBANY, March 31. -- A conference committee, composed of three Senators and five members of the Assembly has been appointed to break the deadlock between the two bodies over Governor Lehman's budget and more particularly over the elimination by the Republican majority in the Assembly of items aggregating $15,562,000.

One constant characteristic of Dr. TOWNSEND'S movement for old-age pensions has been its strong emotional and semi-religious communicative enthusiasm. Meetings usually began with the singing of hymns. The number of old retired clergymen and school teachers was noticeable.
"Gale," an oil by Arthur Dove has been purchased from An American Place by the University of Minnesota for inclusion in its small gallery of selected contemporary work.
Prominent men and women are subscribing generously to the song recital by Armand Tokatyan, which will take place on Saturday night at the Town Hall to aid the New York City Cancer Committee.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 31. -- The Dodgers' luck against the Cubs is no better in Florida than in Wrigley Field. Today, while 600 fans viewed the proceedings with mild disfavor and Casey Stengel watched with boiling temper, Charley Grimm's champions outscored the Flatbush troupe, 9 to 5, with five of the Cub runs unearned.

Despite the Supreme Court's reminder in the Sugar Institute case that the anti-trust laws are still with us, trade association executives and their counsel will find in the decision a harbinger of new hope for American business, it was stated here yesterday by Gilbert H. Montague, chairman, Committee on Federal Trade Commission and Anti-Trust Laws, Merchants Association of New York.

The Phoenix Securities Corporation, which holds the majority stock interest in Hunter Baltimore Rye Distillery, Inc., has entered into a contract for the sale to McKesson Robbins, Inc., of the principal assets of the distillery company. The assets consist chiefly of the Modern Distillery at Gwynnbrook, Md., the blending plant in Baltimore, and the inventories, trade name and good-will.

BALTIMORE, March 31. -- Colonel Henry Breckinridge of New York filed today at Annapolis his candidacy in the State Democratic primaries as an opponent of President Roosevelt for the nomination for President. He flew here from New York and was met by a committee of the Association for Defense of the Constitution, which conducted him to the Capitol.

Wall Street observers felt yesterday that neither the New York Stock Exchange nor the Curb Exchange had added to their prestige by their handling of the case of Walter P. McCaffray Co., which was brought to public notice by the action of the Attorney General's office in obtaining an injunction against the firm.

The methods that the Ways and Means Committee has so far pursued on the new tax program are not calculated to create confidence in its desire to allow criticism a full and fair hearing. The committee began by departing from the sound practice of drawing a tentative bill before the hearings, so that witnesses might have at least the advantage of knowing precisely what was proposed.

MEXICO, D.F., March 31. -- The church and State crisis in Mexico as regards government policy was clearly outlined last night by President Lazaro Cardenas at Ciudad Gonzales, in the State of Guanajuato, where he went to investigate Sunday's fatal clash between a cultural mission from the Ministry of Education and agrarians on the one side and a Catholic group he classed as fanatics on the other.

ROME, March 31. -- With the occupation of Sardo, in the heart of Aussa Sultanate, the Italians are believed to have completed a semicircle of troops around whatever forces still exist for the defense of Ethiopia. It is thought here that Emperor Haile Selassie cannot hold out much longer.

CHICAGO, March 31. -- Heavy pressure developed today in the wheat market on the Board of Trade as the result of a forecast of general rain or snow over the Winter wheat belt, including the "dust bowl" in the Southwest. The July and September dropped into new ground for the season and closed at the bottom with net losses of 2 5/8 to 2 3/4 cents a bushel.

S.M. Chartock yesterday formally entered the Gilbert and Sullivan Spring Sweepstakes, announcing that "The Mikado" would open a week from tomorrow night at the Majestic Theatre. (Up to last night there was no contract signed for the house, however.)

Jerome T. Meighan, floor member of Walter P. McCaffray Co., the New York Stock Exchange firm that was enjoined on Monday by Supreme Court Justice William Harmon Black from dealing in securities, was suspended yesterday for three years by the board of governors of the Exchange.

Mrs. Thomas Wistar Whitall and Mrs. Harold Fortington gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for their daughters, the Misses Frances S. Whitall, A. Lovice Whitall and Nadia Fortington, later taking their party to Miss Edith Massena Benjamin's Senior Get-Together dance in the main ballroom of the Pierre.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP). -- Three new articles of impeachment, of which two charge evasion of taxes on 1929-30 income, have been voted by the House against Federal Judge Halsted L. Ritter of Florida.
The city editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES will receive the following communication this morning:

"Starvation among wildlife in sections of some Northern States has been so serious that nature lovers should prepare now to prevent its recurrence," says the More Game Birds Foundation, in announcing plans for its second national waterfowl refuge contest.

James Monroe High of the Bronx remained in the running for the city P.S.A.L. basketball title by conquering Textile of Manhattan, 26 to 18, in a round-robin series game at the DeWitt Clinton gymnasium yesterday.

HAVANA, Wednesday, April 1. -- Vamarie, 72-foot staysail ketch owned and sailed by Vadim S. Makaroff of Oyster Bay, N.Y., crossed the finish line off Morro Castle in Havana Harbor at 10:54:04 last night, first to finish in the seventh annual race of 284 nautical miles from St. Petersburg, Fla.

Passage of the proposed Corporate Tax Law in anything resembling its present form would subject commodity processing industries to the danger of having working capital virtually confiscated through the operation of an arbitrary scheme, it was declared yesterday by the Tanners' Council of America.

EDMONTON, March 31. -- Alberta tonight faced default on a $3,200,000 bond maturity. Unless aided by a last-hour move at Ottawa the Province will become the first in Canada to fail to meet such an obligation.

Charley Gomer of Baltimore, substituting for Charley Badami, scored a technical knockout over Davey Fine, British lightweight, in the feature bout before 2,500 persons at the Broadway Arena. Brooklyn, last night. Each weighed 134 1/2 pounds.

PARIS, March 31. -- Although only a bare outline of the new German proposals in the Locarno dispute is known here, the French Government, through the usual channels, indicated tonight that it would adopt an attitude as uncompromisingly hostile as that it took on the first day of the German occupation of the Rhineland.

The export movement of gold from this country, which had its inception in February, ended in the first week of March. Thereafter imports increased and the total for last month more than doubled that for February.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Because of determined opposition led by Senator Norris, the Senate was unable today to agree on the confirmation of Lamar Hardy as United States District Attorney for the Southern District of New York and, by agreement, deferred final action until tomorrow.

ELDORADO, Ark., March 31. -- This trim little hamlet, which lies nestled in the hills of Southern Arkansas, and which hails Schoolboy Rowe as its foremost citizen, forgot all about its favorite schoolboy this afternoon as the Giants uncorked another one of those Garrison finishes to turn back the Indians, 5 to 2, in the seventh game of this touring series.

Despite unfavorable natural influences in March, wholesale collection and sales conditions in 94 cities of the country reveal resistance to declines, according to the March survey released this morning by the National Association of Credit Men in its official publication.

TRENTON, April 1, Wednesday. -- The Mercer County grand jury, which took the investigation of Paul H. Wendel's "confession" out of the hands of the Prosecutor yesterday and then caused the postponement of Bruno Richard Hauptmann's execution, adjourned early this morning without having reached any conclusion.

Five additional results were recorded during the second day's play in the annual individual championship tournament of the H.Y.P.D. College Chess League at the rooms of the Marshall Chess Club yesterday. Robert M. Ryder of Yale, who is still ahead of his schedule, gained an additional point and continued in the lead with four straight triumphs.

Irwin L. Moore, president of the International Hydro-Electric System, has informed holders of its 6 per cent debentures due in 1944 that on an initial basis the new contract between the Gatineau Power Company, a subsidiary, and the Ontario Hydro-Electric Power Commission will mean a reduction of about $2,000,000 in annual revenue.
Four adjourned games were played off in the preliminary groups of the tournament for the United States chess championship last night at the rooms of the Marshall, Empire City and Queens Chess Clubs.
Hotel, apartment and business properties were included in the Manhattan realty turnover reported yesterday.

Dividends declared last month were larger than those of March 1935, but smaller than those of February. A total of $235,542,166 in dividends was voted in March for stockholders in 1,174 corporations against $277,964,942 for 783 companies in the preceding month and $232,938,129 for 1,114 companies in March, 1935.

TOKYO, March 31. -- An authoritative source said tonight that Premier Koki Hirota had informed his Cabinet that the latest series of clashes on the frontiers of Manchukuo were already "being liquidated through diplomatic channels."
BERLIN, March 31. -- Adolf Hitler's amplified proposals for a resettlement in Europe were dispatched to London tonight in the keeping of his Ambassador at Large, Joachim von Ribbentrop.

Members of the Fashion Originators Guild, at a meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night, reaffirmed their policy of maintaining "the closest possible cooperation with retailers in safeguarding styles and eliminating trade abuses" in the dress industry. Maurice Rentner, chairman of the guild, declared that steps probably would be taken to establish a permanent and official forum for retailer-manufacturer collaboration of a national character, embracing the broadest possible range of subjects.

WILMINGTON, March 31. -- Before a group of scientists and newspaper men the chemists of the du Pont Experimental Station exhibited today a machine that whirls solutions at such speed that the centrifugal force generated exceeds gravity by 250,000 times.

TOKYO, Wednesday, April 1. -- It is not possible that Japanese troops would invade Outer Mongolia, without special orders, Eiji Amau, the Foreign Office spokesman, said today in denying Russian news agency reports that a strong Japanese force entered Outer Mongolia yesterday to attack a town twenty-eight miles from the border.

Visiting buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday numbered less than in the preceding week and in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES. For the week 803 arrivals were registered, as against 865 in the previous week and 818 in the same period last year.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, March 31. -- Thirty-four high school boys and girls, whose ages vary from 11 to 18 years, were arrested today in a drive against communism.

A plea for cooperation between building officials and architects, in order that they may "improve shelter as to safety and sanitation and make it better serve the requirements of society," was made yesterday by Stephen F. Voorhees, president of the American Institute of Architects, at the convention of the Building Officials Conference of America in the Hotel New Yorker.

ALBANY, March 31. -- In pursuance of an agreement reached at a conference in the afternoon between Governor Lehman, Mayor La Guardia, George McAneny, head of the World's Fair Corporation, and Democratic and Republican leaders of the Legislature the Senate tonight adopted a concurrent resolution creating a legislative committee to investigate the advisability of and extent to which, "if any," the State should participate in the proposed 1939 exposition in New York City.

On the ground that his personal and professional reputation had been damaged in advertisements by a cafeteria chain that he had furnished it with a recipe for artichokes, Giovanni Martinelli, Metropolitan Opera tenor, has filed suit in the Supreme Court against the Wil-Low Cafeterias, Inc., for $20,000.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,876,200 barrels, compared with 2,835,950 in the preceding week, a gain of 40,250, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Gains of 20,150 and of 8,600 barrels, respectively, in the daily average outputs of Oklahoma and Kansas were the important changes.

Trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange failed to emerge from Monday's lethargy. Dealings generally were routine, with fluctuations within narrow limits. While several of the more speculative corporate loans responded to a fairly good demand with moderate advances, the combined price averages were a shade lower on the day.

Four Manhattan crews will participate in nineteen races this Spring, according to the schedules released yesterday by Brother Anselm, director of athletics. The season will get under way on April 11 when the Jasper varsity, freshman and lightweight varsity and lightweight freshman eights are slated to meet Columbia rivals on the Harlem.

Actors, managers, musicians, chorines, prompters -- all the elements of the Yiddish theatre world foregathered to honor Jacob R. Schiff, lawyer and theatre patron, at a dinner held last night at the Central Plaza, 111 Second Avenue, under the auspices of the Hebrew Actors Union and affiliated organizations.

An amateur photography exhibition in aid of the American Colony Charities Association will open today in the art galleries of the Squibb Building, 745 Fifth Avenue, and will continue there throughout Saturday. Mrs. Thomas Curtis heads a group of members of the Contemporary Art Chapter of the association in charge of the arrangements.

For three hours and forty minutes yesterday in General Sessions Court Assistant District Attorney Miles M. O'Brien assailed Miss Vera Stretz's story of how and why she killed Dr. Fritz Gebhardt on the morning of Nov. 12. When he finished the defense rested.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, April 1. -- After receipt of Soviet dispatches describing an alleged invasion of Outer Mongolia by Japanese-Manchukuoan forces, B. S. Stomoniakoff, Vice Commissar of Foreign Affairs, told Ambassador Tamekichi Ota of Japan tonight the situation "does not permit pacifically waiting for development of events."
TRENTON, March 31. -- Bruno Richard Hauptmann spent part of the night before his scheduled execution writing a long letter to Governor Harold G. Hoffman in which he affirmed his innocence.

Musicians Union, Local 802, of the American Federation of Labor, extended to fifty-six independent music publishing houses yesterday the strike of arrangers, copyists and proofreaders called on Monday evening against thirty-six members of the Music Publishers Protective Association.

CHICAGO, March 31. -- America's biggest indoor swimming round-up, the National A.A.U. senior championships for women and men, opens tomorrow night, with champions facing the strongest challenging fields ever assembled.

Unranked a year ago, Stanley Galowin of the City Athletic Club heads the new ratings of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association for the season of 1935-1936, as announced yesterday by Acting Secretary George Abbott of the Bayside Tennis Club.

The twenty-nine missionary Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church scattered throughout the world received cablegrams and telegrams yesterday containing the news that the threatened drastic curtailment of the church's missionary work had been averted.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The Wheeler-Crosser bill providing for compensation for railway employes who lose their jobs because of consolidation or contraction of railway facilities, will tie the hands of the carriers and will not react to the interest of the railroads, their employes or the public, a subcommittee of the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce was told today.

LONDON, March 31. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange continued quiet and restricted today, although there were some good features, notably the rise of international issues to above parity levels. Nickel stocks were in good demand in anticipation of the annual meeting.

Share prices edged higher yesterday in slightly more active trading, but as the day's news, domestic and foreign, leaned to the side of the routine, trading was indecisive and the recent dullness went unrelieved. The market moved generally within narrow confines, closing firm.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP). -- A bitter attack on William Randolph Hearst, in which he was called an advocate of fascism and a publisher of stolen documents, was made in the Senate today.

Senator Desmond's proposed amendments to the Unemployment Insurance Law will receive the careful study which you call for in your editorial this morning. At my request he has promised to furnish copies of his bill immediately, and they will be placed in the hands of each member of the Advisory Council for close examination.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Drastic changes in the management of Old Age Revolving Pensions, Ltd., were announced today by Dr. Francis E. Townsend on the eve of a special House committee's resumption of an inquiry into the movement.

Bonds called for payment in March before maturity made the largest total for a month since January and were more than double the amount retired a year ago. It was the largest total for March since 1928.

Art work by students in the elementary and junior high schools of New York has been installed in the Hall of Education of the American Museum of Natural History. The exhibition, which is large and diversified, will open with a reception this afternoon, when groups of children will demonstrate free painting, modeling soap sculpture, block printing and metal craft.

Sugar, coffee and cottonseed oil futures were sharply lower yesterday in active trading on the commodity markets, whereas other staples were slightly irregular and quiet. On the cash markets refined sugar was 15 points higher, at cents a pound, and cotton, eggs and tins advanced.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, April 1. -- A force of several hundred Japanese and Manchukuoan troops, accompanied by artillery, tanks, armored trucks and airplanes, advanced twenty-eight miles into Outer Mongolian territory yesterday and engaged Mongolians in a pitched battle, which is still going on, according to Soviet reports from Ulan Bator, capital of Outer Mongolia.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 31 (AP). -- Undaunted by the impressive record of his veteran opponent, Bobby Dunkelberger, a 16-year-old schoolboy, ousted Francis Ouimet, twice national amateur and once open champion, from the North and South amateur golf tournament with a 1 up victory in the first round of match play today.

James G. McDonald, former League of Nations High Commissioner for Refugees from Germany and for many years chairman of the board of the Foreign Policy Association, becomes a member of the editorial staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES today.

Federal legislation affecting business men in all divisions of production and distribution were the major topics of consideration yesterday at the monthly luncheon meeting of the Trade Association Executives in New York City at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
The Commonwealth of Massachusetts will consider bids on next Monday for a new issue of $4,000,000 of notes to be dated April 15, 1936, and become payable on April 2, 1937.

Holders of Irish Free State (Saorstat Eireann) external 5 per cent bonds, due on Nov. 1, 1960, have been notified by the National City Bank that there have been drawn by lot for redemption on May 1, 1936, $12,000 of these bonds at par for the sinking fund.
LONDON, March 31 (Canadian Press). -- Oxford rowed from the Mile Post to Putney Bridge in 4 minutes 37 seconds today as training for Saturday's intervarsity classic continued.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The minority leader of the Senate is now Arthur H. Vandenberg, although the official lists still give the name of Charles McNary. It is the Michigan Senator who, after long urging by friends interested in his career and in Republican prospects, has lately made the real opposition to the President.

TAMPA, Fla., March 31. -- The trial of the first of the Tampa flogging cases was transferred today from Tampa to the little city of Bartow, in neighboring Polk County, and the restart of the trial set for April 13.

The quota for the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross in the flood relief fund was exceeded by more than $100,000 yesterday when $16,979.13 in new contributions brought the local fund to $476,079.54.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- A bill to extend the life of Title I of the Federal Housing Act for one year with some modifications of the Federal Housing Administration's powers was sent to President Roosevelt for signature today when the House, by a standing vote of 112 to 50, adopted a conference report.

The recommendation of the stock list committee of the New York Stock Exchange that quarterly earnings reports of listed companies be prepared on the basis of twelve-month periods yesterday won the praise of Frederick H. Hurdman, chairman of the special committee on cooperation with stock exchanges of the American Institute of Accountants.

The pamphlet report of the Federal Water Service Corporation and subsidiaries for 1935, issued yesterday, showed operating revenues of $15,880,833, a gain of $195,547 over 1934, and net earnings of $7,394,373 before charges and Federal taxes, compared with $7,500,704 in 1934.

A heavy turnover in the auction market paralleled the extensive trading in the Manhattan realty field yesterday. Twenty-one buildings in seventeen parcels were taken over by plaintiffs in foreclosure actions to protect their mortgage liens.

Little, Brown offer some statistics today. Copies printed of Richard Sherman's "To Mary With Love" number 7,000; of Johan Fabricius's "The Son of Marietta," 22,500; of Evalyn Walsh McLean's "Father Struck It Rich," 12,500; of Nordhoff and Hall's "The Hurricane," 45,000.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The Minneapolis Gas Light Company filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 today for the issuance of $11,000,000 of first-mortgage 4 per cent bonds, series of 1950, and transferable receipts for the company's 4 1/2 per cent first-mortgage gold bonds, series due in 1950, of which $10,778,000 are outstanding.

Interest rates for both call and time loans in March were unchanged for the fifth consecutive month. Call loan rates of three-quarters of 1 per cent on the New York Stock Exchange and 1 1/4 per cent on the New York Curb Exchanged, compared with 1 per cent and 1 1/2 per cent rates, respectively, a year ago.

Senator William E. Borah, to win the Republican nomination for President, must show popular strength with the voters in the primary elections in Wisconsin, Illinois and other States, his principal supporter, Hamilton Fish Jr., declared in a radio address last night.

BERLIN, March 31. -- The name of Dr. Hugo Eckener, whose presence aboard the von Hindenburg on her first transatlantic flight was featured in the headlines by the German press up to noon today, disappeared from the afternoon newspapers suddenly and completely.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 31. -- The most successful Winter the Everglades Club has seen for a decade was closed tonight with the dinner dance in the orange gardens. More than 300 members and guests attended. On the special program were miniature horse races, tap dancing and Negro entertainers.

A concerted drive to reduce fatalities in home accidents will be started tonight by the five American Red Cross chapters in New York City in cooperation with the Board of Education, parochial and private schools, and other organizations.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31. -- Mrs. Cornelia Bryce Pinchot, wife of former Governor Gifford Pinchot, decided today to become an active candidate for the Republican nomination for Congress in the Fifth Pennsylvania District, Northeast Philadelphia.

Some of my veteran friends are wondering what is the attitude of Princeton University World War veterans regarding the activities of the members of the Veterans of the Future Wars, composed of undergraduates at the old New Jersey university.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31. -- The first American performance of level's ballet, "Daphnis and Chloe," known in this country previously only as an orchestral suite, was given at the Academy of Music here tonight by the Philadelphia Ballet Company, of which Catherine Littlefield is director.
ALBANY, March 31. -- The Brown- ell bill making permanent the Public Enemy Law was passed by the Assembly today, 110 to 20.

ABOARD THE ZEPPELIN VON HINDENBURG, over the North Atlantic, March 31 (Reuters). -- The white cliffs of Dover were our last glimpse of England as this giant airship passed them this afternoon a mile from shore on her first voyage to South America.

More than 100 professional and volunteer social welfare workers, representing organizations whose interest centers in placing underprivileged children in Summer camps, attended a conference on "Summer Vacation Problems" yesterday at the Town Hall Club.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Solicitor Karl A. Crowley of the Postoffice Department made known today that Mrs. Oliver Harriman's National Conference on Legalizing Lotteries had been cited "to show cause" why it should not be barred from the mails for conducting a lottery.

Protests to Mayor La Guardia and Police Commissioner Valentine disclosed yesterday that an assistant to Borough President Harvey of Queens, acting with the approval of his chief, had denied the application of the Jamaica branch of the American League Against War and Fascism the use of Jamaica Town Hall on April 15.

Former Mayor John P. O'Brien, speaking last night at a dinner at the Hotel Astor of the Tammany Hall finance committee attended by many leaders of the party, called for the loyalty of all Democrats in the city in the coming campaign.

ALBANY, March 31. -- By a vote of 93 to 35 the Assembly defeated today the bill sponsored by Assemblywoman Jane Todd, Westchester Republican, making three years desertion grounds for absolute divorce.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- New authorization by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in February totaled $19,111,219, exclusive of $38,989,300 set aside for the purchase of marketable securities from the Public Works Administration, which the RFC expects to sell later at premiums to the highest bidders in the private investment market.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 31 (AP). -- Governor Alf M. Landon of Kansas won the endorsement today, of the Kentucky Republican Convention which unanimously instructed its delegates from the State-at-large to vote for him so long as his name remains before the national convention at Cleveland.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 31. -- The important question of Charley (Red) Ruffing's effectiveness at the present time, was answered today when the Newark Bears, Colonel Jacob Ruppert's farm team, downed the Yankees, 7 -- 2.

ALBANY, March 31. -- Ratification of the Child Labor Amendment to the Federal Constitution by the State Legislature was the subject of sharp controversy at a crowded public hearing today before the Senate Judiciary Committee.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP). -- At a hearing enlivened by repartee, the Communications Commission today heard from Walter S. Gifford, president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, what he thought lobbyists should and should not do.

The House of Representatives has adopted a bill intended to protect Congress against "lobbying," and the Senate will doubtless add its own approval shortly. This measure would compel registration on the part of all visitors to Capitol Hill whose mission is the enactment or defeat of pending legislation.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The Fletcher bill to permit continued trading in unlisted securities on national Exchanges was favorably reported to the Senate today by its Banking and Currency Committee, after it had been considerably revised in the weeks it has been under consideration.

LEWISTON, Me., March 31 (AP). -- The Maine State Democratic Convention today pledged the party's ten votes in the national convention at Philadelphia next June to President Roosevelt for renomination.
The Friends of the New Germany, supporters in this country of the Nazi philosophy, have changed the name of the organization to the German-American League.

YPSILANTI, Mich., March 31 (AP). -- The executive committee of the National Boxing Association let it be known today through its quarterly rankings of fighters that it still considers Wesley Ramey No. 1 challenger for Tony Canzoneri's lightweight crown.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., March 31. -- Collecting a dozen hits off two twirlers, Budzyna and Sunderland, Virginia's nine opened its season by defeating Vermont today, 14 to 4.

After a four-month inquiry, the Kings County December grand jury reported to County Judge Taylor in a presentment yesterday that the weekly strike demonstrations in front of May's department store at 510 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, were caused chiefly by "outside" radical agitation.

ALBANY, April 1. -- The joint legislative committee appointed at the request of Speaker Ires to compose differences over Governor Lehman's budget, which have kept the Senate and Assembly deadlocked for more than a month, will hold its first meeting Tuesday and it became apparent today that at least a fortnight must elapse before final action is taken on the principal budget bill providing appropriations for the administrative State departments.

Although denying that he is legally disqualified and declaring his ability to give the defendants a fair trial, Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler decided yesterday to refer to another justice the trial of the two $5,000,000 suits brought by the State Superintendent of Insurance against the former directors of the State Title and Mortgage Company and the General Surety Company.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP). -- Renewing his attack on William Randolph Hearst, Senator Schwellenbach accused the publisher today of shaping his editorial policies to fit the views of big advertisers.

In faultlessly clear and comprehensive English the Constitution of the State of New York says that all appointments to the civil service shall be made according to merit, determined, as far as practicable, by examinations. This, then, is fundamental to all law and practice in regard to civil service appointments in this State.

CHICAGO, April 1. -- The influenza epidemic in Milwaukee led Senator Borah today to change his plans to deliver a speech in that city next Monday night, according to word tonight from Washington. Instead his managers are arranging for Borah to broadcast his Wisconsin speech from Chicago over WGN at 6:15 P.M.

A militant campaign to impress upon the public that more than 1,000,000 persons are suffering from venereal diseases in this city and to urge the necessary educational measures to reduce the present ravages of syphilis and gonorrhea was opened yesterday at the Women's City Club, 22 Park Avenue.

Edward A. Glennon, 45 years old, suspended head keeper in the Harlem prison, pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions to the theft of $3,095 of the court's funds which he had been ordered to place in a bank. Judge Freschi released him in $1,500 bail, pending sentence on April 10.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 1. -- On her plea that she has no other assets, except some jewelry regarding which there is a question of ownership, Mrs. Margaret Leonard Stoneham, widow of Charles A. Stoneham, former owner of the New York Giants Baseball Club, was permitted today by Supreme Court Justice Witschief to mortgage property of her two minor children.

The Brooklyn Woman's Club held its sixty-seventh annual luncheon yesterday in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. A reception preceded the luncheon, which was attended by 500 members and their guests. Miss Jane L. Moore, president, presided.

A jury before Supreme Court Justice Shientag, after two hours' deliberation, returned a verdict for $250,000 yesterday in a $2,000,000 breach of promise suit by Lillian Mendal against Frederic Adam Gimbel. Mr. Gimbel, who is abroad, did not attend the trial.

The Denver Safeways, crack A.A.U. basketball team that won the national championship of the Y.M.C.A., arrived in New York yesterday for the final Olympic tryouts at Madison Square Garden, the three-day show starting tomorrow.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 1. -- A record vote in the Nassau County Republican primary election tomorrow was forecast here today at Republican County Headquarters in the Courtview Hotel. The regular organization candidates for delegates from the First Congressional District to the Republican National Convention at Cleveland in June will win in Nassau County by at least 8 to 1, according to J. Russel Sprague, Republican county leader and candidate for delegate.

Hopeful signs against the possibility of early war are clearly to be seen on the stormy European horizon in the opinion of Roy W. Howard, chairman of the hoard of directors of Scripps-Howard newspapers, who returned on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen yesterday after a world tour.

Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. of New York and United States Senator Elmer Thomas of Oklahoma debated on the merits of the New Deal last night before an audience of 500 persons in the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Ben Howe, chairman of the City Fusion party, presided.

Edward J. Flynn, Bronx Democratic political boss, a close friend of Governor Lehman and President Roosevelt and a power in national as well as State politics, gave a lecture to Columbia students last night.

Total advertising of New York and Brooklyn stores last month comprised 3,415,048 lines, against 3,232,402 lines in the same month a year ago, according to figures compiled by Media Records. This represents a gain of 5.65 per cent over the same month a year ago.

Leaders of both the Old Guard and the Left Wing in the Socialist party made final appeals last night to enrolled Socialists for support in today's primary contest for control of the New York State organization of the party. Socialists throughout the country are interested in the results, which are expected to have an important bearing on control of the party in the nation.

TOKYO, Thursday, April 2. -- Twelve Mongolian military planes crossed the Manchukuoan border on Tuesday and bombed a Japanese-Manchukuoan patrol at a point twelve miles north of Tawlan, southwest of Lake Bor, a Kwantung army communique reports.

Analysis of the proposed tax on undistributed income of corporations as contained in the report of the subcommittee of the House Committee on Ways and Means indicates that the recommendations as to the basis for the proposed tax are unworkable.

The excitement and alarm caused by HITLER'S acts and words on March 7 had largely subsided by March 31. No sensible person now believes that war is imminent. Every reasonable man hopes that the resources of civilization and of statesmanship will be able, during the next few months, not only to avert an appeal to arms but to establish a more trustworthy system of collective security than Europe has ever known.

FOR grisly humor try "The Rape of Africa" (Smith Haas, $3), by Lamar Middleton. It would appear that the author is a liberal and a bit of an idealist, who has suffered so much nervous shock through his studies of Europe's assaults on Africa that he has come to think it is all funny, though funny in a somewhat ghastly way.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 1. -- Bermuda's one-design yachts took the first race of the international series with Long Island Sound's Interclub Class knockabouts today in the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club's Spring regatta.

John T. Brook, former president of the Pelham National Bank, and Carroll T. Latimer, former cashier, both of whom were convicted more than a year ago of misappropriating funds, were found guilty last night of having filed false entries with the Controller of the Currency and of conspiracy.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP). -- Thomas Riggs Jr., Princeton student and national treasurer of The Veterans of Future Wars, has become a lobbyist for a $2,500,000,000 bonus.

Six women gained the right to represent New York in the women's national fencing championship on April 24 by emerging from the qualifying trials last night at the Fencers Club. Leading the qualifiers were Miss Dorothy Locke and her Salle d'Armes Vince team-mate, Miss Marion Lloyd, both former titleholders.

Judge and Mrs. David H. Kincheloe gave a dinner last night at their home, 115 East Eighty-sixth Street, for their daughter, Mrs. James H. Davis of Honolulu, and several of the girls who were her classmates at the Finch School. The guests were Mrs. Joseph Donahue, the Misses Elvera Farrar, Aileen Wallau, Barbara Davis, Kathryn Young, Alice Burch, Aileen Donnelly, Jean Hulbert, Genevieve Kincheloe and Lucile Hammack.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 1. -An All-Bermuda fifteen conquered a team composed of members of the visiting Harvard and Yale squads, 6 to 0, today in the fourth game of the annual Rugby Week program here. The contest was keenly fought all the way.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 1. -- Little Jeff, one of the oldest jumpers in the ring, scored a popular victory in the final session of the nineteenth annual Pinehurst Horse Show today. The veteran performer, an entry of the Thorndale Stables of Southern Pines, owned by Mrs. Lawrence B. Smith and Mrs. Landon K. Thorne, New York, carried off the honors in the Carolina Class.

MIAMI, April 1. -- In his quest after new fishing thrills President Roosevelt on the yacht Potomac entered today the mysterious area known as Tongue of the Ocean, the northern edge of which lies about sixty miles south of Nassau.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- Seven exemptions from certain provisions of the Public Utility Act were granted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. They were to the Lynn Gas and Electric Company and trustees under a voting trust agreement concerning stock; the Rockland Light and Power Company, the East Missouri Power Company, Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.; the Hydro-Electric Securities Company, the Singer Manufacturing Company and the J.G. Curtis Leather Company.

PARIS, April 1. -- Germany's proposals were not received today with any signs of approval from France. The first reaction of both the government and the press was extremely unfavorable, but the proposals are going to be studied carefully during the next few days, and well-informed diplomatic circles now believe that this study will lead to negotiations.

Net income of the Aluminum Company of America and wholly owned subsidiaries for 1935 was $9,571,206, after taxes, depreciation, depletion and other charges and including $152,086 gain from purchase and retirement of preferred stock, the company announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The recent incident in which a witness at the tax hearing before the House Ways and Means Committee was asked about the salary of the president of his company was cited today by Representative Treadway of Massachusetts in urging speedy passage of his bill to repeal the law requiring publicity on all corporate salaries above $15,000 a year.
CLEVELAND, April 1. -- Otis Co. issued tonight the following relative to the action of the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington:

The Associated Glee Clubs of America, a male chorus of 2,000 voices representing forty-four clubs in the East, appeared in concert at Madison Square Garden last night. The event was arranged in connection with the Music Educators National Conference, which is in session in New York this week.

Every once in a while one finds in the obituary Columns of the London papers modern specimens of delightful old lads of the universities such as JOHN AUBREY collected in the seventeenth century and Mr. E.F. BENSON in our own. Such in a mild way was Dr. ALEXANDER NAIRNE, Canon of Windsor, formerly Regius Professor of Divinity at Cambridge, who died the other day.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The Cleveland investment banking firm of Otis Co. was charged today by the Securities and Exchange Commission with violating Federal laws regulating the issuance and sale of securities and simultaneously was made a party to a permanent injunction suit compelling discontinuance of the alleged irregular practices.

Mrs. Oliver Harriman, president of the National Conference on Legalizing Lotteries, yesterday said that she approved the investigation by the Postoffice Department of sweepstake contests here. She expressed certainty that her own organization, the only one with which she is connected, would come out of the current investigation with a clear record.

HOUSTON, Texas, April 1. -- The nation's No. 1 tennis star, Wilmer Allison, named only today as captain of the United States Davis Cup team against Mexico, had to battle into darkness to break even in the first two sets of his match with Arthur Hendrix, Lakeland (Fla.) ace, in the annual River Oaks tournament.

S.S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, wrote yesterday to Mgr. John F. Brady, director of the division of health of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, praising the campaign for funds for the support of hospitals which the archdiocese has sponsored.

Democratic primaries this year are mainly a formality. The Democrats have power, pull, machine. To our Republican friends, deprived of their old privileges and appurtenances, perturbed and pieless, suspicious, split into factions, the sympathies of humanitarians should flow today.

LONDON, April 1. -- Germany replied today to the Locarno powers' proposals with glowing offers of future peace and reconciliation, but with virtually no "positive" contributions toward easing the present emergency along the Franco-German frontier.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The Senate confirmed the nomination of Lamar Hardy as District Attorney for New York City by a vote of 57 to 9, debated the Capper bill to amend the Stockyards Act, amended the resolution setting up a committee to investigate campaign expenditures, to include the use of public funds, and recessed at 4:37 P.M. until noon tomorrow.

Harry Moses, that one-play-a-season producer, has lined up his program for the semester that begins next Fall. The item -- and Mr. Moses says he has an option on it -- is "Thanks for Three Years," a comedy-drama by one Michael Sheridan, who lives on the Coast and has written for the films.

Alonzo B. See, wealthy elevator manufacturer, who became an enemy of progressive women a few years ago because of his insistence that their place was in the home, confessed meekly last night that he had changed his mind.

A juvenile maternal impulse caused considerable excitement yesterday when two small girls adopted, temporarily, a year-old baby asleep in its carriage in front of 873 Columbus Avenue. The frantic cries of the mother, upon discovering her loss, aroused neighbors, whose telephone calls brought eighteen police radio cars to the scene.

MOUNTAIN LAKES, N.J., April 1. -- A strip of land which has been the center of a legal snarl for many months passed out of the ownership of the borough of Mountain Lakes tonight, and for $5 -- with a $1.25 deposit -- became the property of the adjoining community of Arrowhead Lake.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 1 (AP). -- Three teams from New Haven, Conn., held long-distance traveling honors as sixty-four teams lined up tonight for an assault on the leading 3,065 of Pabst Blue Ribbon of New York in the American Bowling Congress tournament.

A radio announcer wearing an electrified Easter "bonnet," in the form of a radio-equipped silk hat, will promenade with the Easter morning strollers on Park Avenue, describe the fashions and eavesdrop on conversations unbeknown to those on the sidewalks.

Easter Trade at High Level Easter trade both locally and out of town is building up very fast and peak trade in apparel and accessory sections ranging around 25 per cent over last year is indicated as a possibility for this week. Trade tomorrow and Saturday is expected to be particularly heavy and will probably outstrip volume on these days last week by a wide margin.

An injunction suit against David Katzman, described as one of the outstanding Jewish cantors in the city and considered a successor to the late Josef Rosenblatt, was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday by the First American Rumanian Congregation, an Orthodox synagogue on the lower East Side.

A first mortgage of $180,000 was placed on the new six-story elevator apartment at 567-77 Fort Washington Av. by Pease Elliman, as agents for the New York State Teachers Retirement System, in cooperation with George C. Ponter Co., as broker. The building is reported fully rented.

CHICAGO, April 1. -- The New York Athletic Club, paced by Clarence (Buddy) Combs's seven-goal exhibition, speedily overcame a handicap of three to crush the Cleveland Riding Club seniors, 13 to 5 1/2, tonight to take a one-game lead in the high goal division series of the national indoor polo championships.
Apartment house deals by operators featured the urban realty trading reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The possibility was forecast today by Senator Copeland of a further enlargement of the omnibus Flood Control Bill to include projects now excluded from the tentative draft before the Senate Commerce Committee because of their possible value as sources of hydroelectric power.

MIAMI, Fla., April 1. -- Brown Feathers, spurting brilliantly in theI [last seventy yards to save the day l i for Mrs. Emil Denemark' entryt [when Chasar wilted under fire, I snatched a nose camera finish de-I Icision over E. R. Bradley's Bird! Flower in the lXTewspaper Guild I t I -- Iandicap, the mile and a sixteenthi feature, before 8,500 spectators atI I Tropical Park today.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 1. -- Mr. Margett, the area manager here for the Townsend old-age pension plan, declared today that former indictments against him "grew out of political feuds." He said that he was cleared of all the indictments in Seattle twenty years ago.
BUFFALO, N.Y., April 1. -- Exploding in midair, an American Air Lines plane bound from New York crashed in flames about forty-five miles from Buffalo tonight, with the death of two persons.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP). -- Masters of orchestration told the House Patents Committee today that music in America "will become a robot" unless new copyright laws are enacted to protect the rights of living performers.

The drastic administrative changes in the Old Age Revolving Pensions, Ltd., made public Tuesday by Dr. Francis E. Townsend, founder of the plan, were characterized yesterday afternoon by Dr. Clinton Wunder, eastern regional director, as a necessary step by the leaders of the movement "to break up the one-man control" of Robert E. Clements, former national secretary who resigned March 24.

In the first four years of the depression the total of undistributed net income accumulated by all the corporations in the United States in the nine years preceding the depression was wiped out, together with $9,700,000,000 of previously accumulated surplus or capital, the National City Bank of New York calculates in a discussion of the proposed tax on undistributed profits in its April bulletin.

Child problems ranging from that of an 11-year-old girl, whose mother suffers from the delusion that her neighbors and the police are seeking her life, to that of a 17-year-old Negro boy, so lazy and so unruly his mother complained about him, were among the puzzles submitted to the new intake bureau in Children's Court when it opened yesterday.

While Victor F. Ridder, works progress administrator, yesterday denied reports that any additional immediate cuts in the number of WPA workers employed on park projects were contemplated beyond the 15,000 scheduled to go by July 1 as part of the general reduction of 40,000 in the WPA personnel, indications were that substantial reductions will be accomplished by Oct. 1.

With the announcement yesterday of the American Yacht Club to hold another of its cruises the coming season, the total of port-to-port stretches of racing was increased to four, two short and two long ones.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 1. -- The Yankees' first day here was a complete washout, viewed from any angle. The expected agreement between Ben Chapman and Manager Joe McCarthy failed to materialize and the Barons of the Southern Association slapped a 5-to-4 beating on their guests.
Statements or condition issued yesterday by local banks and trust companies as of March 31 showed substantial increases in deposits and resources compared with the end of last year.
Several moves in the midtown section were reported in connection with business leases yesterday.

OTTAWA, April 1. -- Premier W.C. Aberhart's proposal for a compulsory conversion of part of Alberta's debt, as much as his refusal to accept supervision of future borrowing by a Dominion-Provincial loan council, led the Dominion Government to decline to prevent default by the Province to day on a $3,200,000 bond maturity.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- Dr. Francis E. Townsend, originator of the plan for payment of pensions of $200 a month to persons over 60, foresaw a possibility of developing his organization to a point where "there might be millions in it," the House inquiry revealed today.

Twenty-six charitable, educational and religious institutions receive bequests under the will of Henry Wollman, senior member of the law firm of Wollman Wollman, which was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday. Mr. Wollman was 76 years old at the time of his death on March 13, last.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- In an attack on the Bureau of Air Commerce, which regulates commercial air traffic, Representative Bacon of New York told the House today that the bureau was "infested" with politicians, and that money appropriated by Congress for safety improvements had been diverted for construction purposes.

Tom Iannicelli, professional of the Essex Club, Newark, retained the world open squash tennis championship last night at the Hotel Shelton. In the final round of the tournament the defender defeated James T. Reid Jr., Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club pro by the overwhelming margin of 15 -- 4, 15 -- 8, 15 -- 3.
A balloon hoax at Rockefeller Center yesterday was something of an April Fool's Day novelty, but otherwise the 1st of April, 1936, was Just about the same at its predecessors. Some people got stung.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 1. -- The retirement of W. Lawson Little Jr. from the ranks of amateurism was confirmed here today by the stalwart Californian who has won the last two British and United States amateur golf crowns.

Disclosure yesterday of the content, if not the actual text, of the German memorandum to the Locarno Treaty powers, showing a conciliatory tone, found immediate response in the stock market. In the heaviest trading since last Thursday, 1,686,000 shares on the Stock Exchange, against 1,041,000 on Tuesday, prices were bid up briskly so that at the closing leading issues were up 1 to 5 points on the day; a few, even more.

ALBANY, April 1. -- Affixing his signature today to the William Schwartz bill making discovery of a pistol in a stolen vehicle presumptive evidence of its illegal ownership by all occupants, Governor Lehman renewed his demand for a broader bill designed to strike at the activities of gangsters and racketeers.
ROME, April 1. -- Official quarters refused today to comment on Chancellor Adolf Hitler's reply to the proposals of the powers on the plea that the text of the reply had not yet been received.

CANBERRA, Australia, April 1. -- The discussion of a tariff schedule, which has occupied the House of Representatives' attention since the Federal Parliament reassembled three weeks ago, was interrupted today when Sir George Fairbairn, government supporter, moved adjournment to discuss "the alarming growth of imports from the United States, which is proving a grave menace to trade with Britain and other good customer countries and also to Australian export industries."

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- Activity for or against legislation either Federal or State, even to the extent of participating in the drafting of such legislation, was charged against officials of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and freely admitted by them at today's hearing before the Federal Communications Commission.

BOWIE, Md., April 1. -- John Hay Whitney's Singing Wood set a new record of 1:07 1-5 in capturing the Inaugural Handicap at the opening of the Eastern racing season at Bowie today before Postmaster General Farley and a large contingent of those well known in politics.

ABOARD THE ZEPPELIN VON HINDENBURG, April 1 (Reuters). -- The Von Hindenburg traveled at sixty miles an hour at a height of 600 feet today along the Portuguese coast, passing over Las Palmas, Canary Islands, at 9 P.M. Greenwich mean time, on its way across the Atlantic Ocean.

New methods of construction expected to stimulate building were described at yesterday's sessions of the twenty-first annual convention of the Building Officials Conference of America at the Hotel New Yorker. Pre-cast concrete joist floors, air-conditioning and fusion welding for structural steel work were among the topics.

CHICAGO, April 1. -- The local market for hogs was unsettled today, with weights under 200 pounds quoted as weak to 10 cents a hundredweight lower than yesterday, owing to a subnormal shipping demand, while heavier kinds were in good demand from local interests and steady to 10 cents higher.

TRENTON, N.J., April 1. -- Senator William E. Borah of Idaho and Governor Alf M. Landon of Kansas will compete for the preferential vote of New Jersey Republicans for the Presidential nomination at the primary election to be held May 19.

For the third successive time Great Britain ends a fiscal year with a surplus. It is not brought about by the bookkeeping device of throwing all expenditures above revenues into an "extraordinary" budget. It is a real surplus: the Government took in more than it paid out.

Belgium yesterday celebrated the first anniversary of the devaluation of its currency by making permanent the cut of 28 per cent that was announced a year ago. At that time Belgium followed the lead of the United States by authorizing devaluation within changeable limits.
EDMONTON, Alberta, April 1. -- The Province of Alberta failed today to redeem two bond issues totaling $3,200,000, thus becoming the first Canadian Province to default on a bond maturity.

LONDON, April 1 (AP) -- The British Air Ministry authorized Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh today to fly his private plane over Great Britain -- provided he does not engage in commercial flights or accept pay for his services.

The following is the text of the letter handed by Antimony Eden, the British Foreign Secretary, to the Ambassadors of France and Belgium yesterday assuring the two countries of Britain's adherence to the terms of the Locarno treaty.

Norman H. Davis, United States Ambassador at Large, and five delegates who have been attending the naval conference in London are returning today on the Washington of the United States Lines. The others are Admiral William H. Standley, Commander Roscoe Schuirmann, Royal Ingersoll, Lieutenant James R. Fulton and Lieutenant Arthur Ayrault.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP). -- Radical changes in American anti-aircraft defenses to meet new dangers from highly increased speeds of bombing planes have been recommended by Major William Irvine, War College artillery tactician. He urged a doubling of heavy gun batteries.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 1. -- A claim for more than $13,000,000 arising from the rejection by the Connecticut Company of leases and other agreements relating to the property of the Connecticut Railway and Lighting Company has been filed by the latter in the proceedings for reorganization of the Connecticut Company.

HAVANA, April 1. -- Babe, the thirty-foot cutter skippered by Commodore H.M. Matheson of Miami, Fla., which arrived at 4:12:26 this morning, was unofficially conceded to be the winner in Class B of the seventh annual yacht race from St. Petersburg, Fla., to Havana, and took the fleet honors for the event. The race, over a course of 284 nautical miles, started at noon last Saturday.

WHITE SULPUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 1. -- Many smart dinner and supper parties were given tonight at the Greenbrier before and after the presentation in the Hotel auditorium of "The Lid's Off," the annual show of the Hasty Pudding Club of Harvard University.

SEETHING with indignation -- and he is one of the finest seethers in any sport -- Mr. Connie Smythe has gone back to Toronto with his Maple Leafs. What made him irate was that he was right all along even if his team was found to be slightly in the wrong in the last clash on Garden ice.

Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, former Police Commissioner, disclosed yesterday that he had reconsidered an earlier refusal and become special counsel to the pin game industry, with dictatorial power to set its house in order.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- Though Congress is in session, and (once more) "the most momentous Presidential campaign in history" will begin in three months, Washington has never been quieter. An explorer returning from two years at the Pole might easily assume from surface indications that the whole world is peaceful and prosperous, that Congress is in recess, America is without problems and no general election is anywhere near at hand.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 1. -- The most spectacular demonstration ever accorded a Bermuda Governor marked the departure for England today of General Sir Thomas Astley Cubitt, retiring after completing his five-year term of office.

Mayor La Guardia took the first step yesterday in the largest police shake-up since he has been Mayor by appointing former Deputy Chief Inspector David J. McAuliffe as Fourth Deputy Police Commissioner in charge of Brooklyn and Richmond.

Nothing Mr. Toscanini has recently accomplished looms larger in the writer's estimation than his performance last night at the Philharmonic-Symphony concert in Carnegie Hall of a little overture by Carl Maria von Weber. "Little" applies partly to the fact that in point of musical inspiration the overture to "Oberon" does not have the rank of the overture to "Freischuetz," and also to the modest dimensions of the piece, and the delicate and simple instrumentation.

PHILADELPHIA, April 1. -- Meteors flashed across the sky of the Fels Planetarium here last night, "new" stars came into view and the moon approached so near that it was finally exploded before the eyes of a group of spectators seeking an answer to the question: "How will the world end?"

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The Grand National Treasure Hunt Contest, Inc., is an "object lesson" in what could be done if there were legal lotteries, Major Thomas G. Lanphier testified today in a hearing on the Association for the Legalization of Lotteries and the Grand National Treasure Hunt, Inc., before the Postoffice Department.

ASMARA, Eritrea, April 1. -- At dawn yesterday an Ethiopian army of 45,000 men, including the Imperial Guard, launched a gallant surprise attack against the Italian First Army Corps between Alaji and Lake Ashangi.

MEDFORD, N.J., April 1. -- Hexer's Carolina Jack, white and liver pointer dog, owned and handled by Dr. E.K. Tingley of Marietta, Pa., today won the members' all-age stage in the annual Spring field trial meeting of the English Setter Club of America.
The Old Country Club in Flushing, L.I., one of the oldest properties of its kind in the country, has been purchased for cash in one of the largest realty deals on Long Island in several months.

LONDON, April 1. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin, flushed and embarrassed, agreed to adjourn the House of Commons at 8:45 o'clock tonight after the government had been defeated technically by eight votes in a thinly attended session on an opposing Laborite motion to pay women the same salaries as men in civil service posts won by competitive examination.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 1. -- Mr. and Mrs. James A. Moffett gave a dinner tonight in the patio of their residence. Dancing took place later on the ocean front terrace to which additional guests were invited. The event was in honor of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Davies of Washington, guests of Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Stotesbury.

There will always be breadlines and private charities in New York City, former Governor Alfred E. Smith told a group of 100 young business men yesterday in appealing for their aid in the campaign of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee for a minimum of $1,500,000.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 1. -- The Princeton and Williams baseball teams battled for three hours to a 12-12 tie on University Field today. The game was called at the end of the tenth inning by mutual agreement as darkness and the cold made further play impossible.

MOSCOW, Thursday, April 2. -- The fight between a Japanese-Manchukuoan force and Mongolian troops that began Tuesday morning ended yesterday with the final repulse of the former and their expulsion from Outer Mongolian territory, according to Soviet dispatches today from Ulan Bator, capital of Outer Mongolia.
WASHINGTON, April 1. -- Names of naval heroes were assigned by the Navy Department today to fifteen destroyers now under construction. Five of the names appear for the first time on the navy list.

Until the arrival of Johnny Barris on the scene, few in the crowd of 4,000 baseball enthusiasts who turned out for the opening game of the 1936 campaign on Old Rose Hill yesterday would have predicted a Fordham victory over Harvard.

The Wilson English Construction Company of New York City has submitted the low bid of $254,220 to the State Department of Public Works for the final contract for Laurelton Parkway, it was announced yesterday by the Long Island State Park Commission.

Lehigh Portland Cement Company 4 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock and $25-par common stock have been admitted to the list and the company's old 7 per cent preferred and $50-par common stock suspended from dealings.

Returning very recently from a motor trip of over 5,000 miles through all the very snowy and icy areas of the Middle Northwest I found that the State highway men everywhere did a magnificent and heroic job in keeping the main country highways open and that, with very few exceptions, the towns did a very poor, inept, exasperating job, if any at all.
BUFFALO, April 1 (AP). -- Buffalo sold today to a syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co. $1,000,000 of relief bonds at 2.69 per cent net interest cost.

HAZLETON, Pa., April 1 (AP). -- The taxpayers of Union Township tried vainly today to start things moving toward a settlement of the Sheppton High School strike, while students on the picket line kept the school closed through the third successive day.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The mounting plea of debt-ridden corporations for preferential treatment, under the proposed undistributed corporate profits tax, of income withheld from stockholders to pay obligations incurred during the depression, met a cool reception today from leaders of the Ways and Means Committee.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The State Department revealed plans today for the creation of a globe-circling radio news service of its own, intended to keep American diplomatic and consular officials completely abreast of developments here that concern them.

The quadrennial Spring primary election, held in Presidential years to elect delegates to the national conventions and members of the party State committees as well, will take place in New York State today. The polls in the city will be open from 3 to 10 P. M. and up-State from noon to 9 P. M.

Jerome T. Meighan, floor member of Walter P. McCaffray Co., who on Tuesday was suspended from the New York Stock Exchange for three years by the board of governors, yesterday sold his membership in the Exchange for $150,000 to a broker whose identity was not disclosed.

With their esprit de corps noticeably higher than it was on Tuesday, the New York Americans entrained last night for Toronto. There they will engage the Maple Leafs this evening in the third game of the two-out-of-three series to provide an opponent for the Detroit Red Wings for the Stanley Cup, emblematic of the world's hockey championship.

Three of the twelve teams of four competing in the Grand National contract bridge championships at the Park Central Hotel were eliminated yesterday afternoon in a stormy session of play. In this event, a team must be defeated twice to be eliminated.

The formal opening and dedication of the recently completed headquarters of the Juvenile Service League, to be known as Juvenile House, at 974 East 156th Street will take place Sunday afternoon. The speakers will be Magistrate Jonah J. Goldstein and Borough President James J. Lyons.

The new sister ship of the United States liners Manhattan and Washington, which will be built to fill the gap caused by the withdrawal of the liner Leviathan, may be constructed in a navy yard, it was indicated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- Adhering to the unwritten law of Senatorial courtesy, the Senate voted by 57 to 9 today to confirm the nomination of Lamar Hardy as District Attorney for the Southern District of New York. Mr. Hardy had the endorsement of Senators Wagner and Copeland, and the Senate almost invariably accepts the judgment of the two Senators concerned in an appointment in their State.

ALBANY, April 1. -- The Assembly unanimously concurred today in the action of the Senate last night on the resolution for a joint legislative committee to survey the proposal for State participation in the World's Fair projected for New York City in 1939.

ALBANY, April 1. -- Governor Lehman announced today the signing of bills continuing the present milk control law for another year and extending the life of the temporary Emergency Relief Administration until June 30, 1937.
LONDON, April 1. -- Following is the text of the German reply to the Locarno powers' memorandum on the Rhineland crisis, as made public here today:

"Off Your Marx," Columbia University's forty-third annual musical show, began a three-day engagement at the Hotel Lismora last night before an enthusiastic audience of more than 1,200 undergraduates and their friends, who filled the grand ballroom to overflowing.

More than 200 delegates to the monthly meeting of the United Parents Association, representing a total of 60,000 parents of children now attending school in this city, were sharply divided last night at the Commodore Hotel over the distinction between peace and pacifism, and the proper attitude to take toward the impending Peace Day demonstrations of April 22.

Protests to Mayor La Guardia and Police Commissioner Valentine disclosed yesterday that an assistant to Borough President Harvey of Queens, acting with the approval of his chief, had denied the application of the Jamaica branch of the American League Against War and Fascism for the use of Jamaica Town Hall on April 15.

The first of the monthly index numbers as of April 1, computes decrease of 3 1-3 percent in average prices during March. Thus far in the present year the net decrease Ifrom the end o 1935 was 21/2 percent. The average is now five-eighths of 1 per cent above that of the corresponding date a year ago, and is still the highest for the corresponding date since 1930.

DAVENPORT, Iowa, April 1. -- Jockel von Burglund, Doberman pinscher, owned by Owen West of Chicago, won the special for the best in the show at the Tri-City Kennel Club exhibition tonight. The judge was Alfred Delmont of Wynnewood, Pa.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- Formation of an organization to be known as Labor's Nonpartisan League, which has as its immediate purpose the obtaining of united labor support for President Roosevelt's re-election this year, was announced today by George L. Berry, Coordinator for Industrial Cooperation.

PHILADELPHIA, April 1. -- The National Labor Relations Act, attacked by counsel for the Pennsylvania Greyhound Lines, Inc., as an attempt to enact social legislation under the guise of regulating commerce among the States, was defended by counsel for the Labor Relations Board today as designed to protect the rights of labor which have been deeply imbedded in American tradition and judicial decisions.
The Manufacturers Trust Company is transfer agent for 500,000 shares of common stock of F.L. Jacobs Company, Inc.

The forty-eight players entered in the preliminaries of the United States chess championship tournament under the auspices of the National Chess Federation began the second-round games at the rooms of the Manhattan, Marshall, Empire City and Queens Chess Clubs last night.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 1. -- The Rev. George Noble Bell of South Nyack, N.Y., was fatally injured when a Providence-New York bus struck a disabled truck parked at the roadside near Hopkinton.

PINE BLUFF, Ark., April 1. -- Two days of Arkansas climate, invigorating though it may be, proved just a trifle too much for the Giants. After three successive victories, they suddenly lost their winning touch and went down before the Indians, 3 to 2, in the eighth game of this globe-trotting series.

BERLIN, April 1. -- The laconic if revealing statement with which the Cabinet announced the passage of the budget for the new fiscal year beginning today indicates that although the struggle between Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics and President of the Reichs bank, and the National Socialist radicals regarding financial and economic policies continues, for the moment Dr. Schacht has been able to score a partial victory.

The bond market firmed up moderately yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange without any material increase in the trading volume. High-grade bonds, as well as the more speculative issues, were in better demand, with the latter group scoring the most impressive advances.

Aaron Sapiro, who acted as attorney for Elaine Jacobs Barrie, protegee of John Barrymore, while the actor was avowedly attempting to evade her last year, represented the actor yesterday in Federal Court in a suit brought against his former attorneys.

A test devised by Professor Victor H. Noll of Rhode Island State College, for use in determining whether a person thinks "scientifically," was made public yesterday by the Teachers College, Columbia University Bureau of Publications.
TRENTON, April 1. -- The execution of Bruno Richard Hauptmann for the murder of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr., which was postponed last night, was fixed this afternoon for 8 o'clock Friday night.

LONDON, April 1. -- Conditions on the London Stock Exchange were brightened today by the budget surplus and the latest news regarding the international situation. British funds generally were higher, while the German group rallied sharply in the foreign department.

When the jury in the trial of Miss Vera Stretz for the slaying of Dr. Fritz Gebhardt begins its deliberations tomorrow it may be confined to consideration of second-degree murder and first-degree manslaughter verdicts.

VIENNA, April 1. -- Austria repudiated her military obligations under the treaty of St. Germain today, and through the mouth of her Chancellor, Dr. Kurt Schuschnigg, proclaimed universal national service "with or without arms."

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 1. -- A steady downpour of rain forced the competitors in the third annual masters' tournament which will be held at the Augusta National Golf Club into idleness today and caused the postponement of the start from tomorrow to Friday.

No sooner did Hitler become master of Germany than he circulated in Central Europe, when I lived on the Continent, a map of "Greater Germany," with the intimation that he would make it authoritative as soon as he got ready. It covered parts of Denmark, France, Switzerland, Yugoslavia, Poland, Russia, and all of Czechoslovakia and Austria.
