Outer Mongolia, the scene of heavy fighting during the last few days, lies at the crossroads of two main lines of empire: a wild tract of plateau country populated by cattle-breeders who have been stumbling hastily along a strange new path that leads from fourteenth-century feudalism to twentieth-century communism.

Trolley cars were replaced by motor buses yesterday on the Thirty-fourth Street and the 116th Street lines of the New York Railways system. The passing of the electric street car on the Thirty-fourth Street route was marked by a parade and special ceremonies in which former Governor Alfred E. Smith, Mayor La Guardia and Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan took part.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 1 (AP). -- The bitter State Democratic primary campaign resulted today in a stoppage of pay for 32,000 State employes, their pay checks being held up by Treasurer John Stelle, a leader in the faction of the party opposing Governor Horner's renomination.

The foreign exchanges, led by the franc, recovered further yesterday as the tension in European markets was relieved by the reply sent by Chancellor Adolf Hitler to the Locarno powers. The improvement began before the Chancellor's message was disclosed.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- Nearly $150,000,000 of securities of foreign governments and corporations, exclusive of two no-par issues of domestic concerns, were involved in registration statements filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The decision of the Friends of the New Germany, now renamed the German-American League, to seek a "firm foothold" in the political life of the United States was told last night by Rudolf Markmann, new Eastern leader of the organization, at a meeting of the Brooklyn branch at the Schwabenhalle, Myrtle and Knickerbocker Avenues, Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, April 1. -- Miss Katherine Rawls, slim Miami Beach star, made full use of her only opportunity to defend a championship in the senior A.A.U. meet tonight by establishing a pair of new records for the 300-yard individual medley at the Lake Shore Athletic Club.

Mr. and Mrs. Cleveland F. Bacon gave a dinner dance last night in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre for their son, Grover Cleveland Bacon, a student at Groton School. The room was decorated with colored balloons and Spring flowers for the occasion.

The executive board of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers of America and the officials of District Council No. 9 of the union settled their differences before Supreme Court Justice Miller yesterday. The settlement, made during the trial, discontinued an action by Hyman Marcal, elected president of the council on Feb. 29, and other council officers against the executive board for an injunction.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 1. -- The series of "Three Lenten Conferences," which opened on March 19 with Katherine Ruth Heyman discoursing on "Ancient Modes in Modern Music," will close tomorrow morning when the pianist will deliver an illustrated "Conference" on the great Russian composer and mystic whose music she has evangelized throughout the world since his death in 1915: "Scriabin: the Apprentice, the Lover, the Waster."

The fifteenth annual book drive of the American Merchant Marine Library Association will take place April 20-25, with headquarters for the drive at 732 Fifth Avenue. Plans for the campaign to obtain 50,000 or more books for seamen of the merchant marine were discussed at a meeting held yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Hammond, 1 Sutton Place South.

Louis Jr., 2-year-old African monkey, is the hero of the Ferarro household, which includes Winnie, a white spitz; Red, an angora cat, and Minnie, an alley cat. From now on life to him will be just one banana after another, for his master, Louis Ferarro, a produce merchant in the Gansevoort Market, is appreciative, and, besides, what's a banana to a produce merchant?

Spirited bidding between rival groups of concessionaires resulted yesterday in the city's obtaining the highest rents in recent years for lunch room and soda fountain privileges at the South Ferry and St. George terminals of the Staten Island Ferry.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The Senate amended today its resolution to investigate campaign expenditures so as to include any use of public funds which might have furthered the interests of any candidate in the coming primary and general elections. The change was sponsored by Senator Hastings and was pushed, in his absence, by Senator McNary, minority leader.

Columbia opened its baseball season yesterday by defeating City College, 8 to 6, in a frigid setting at Baker Field. The Lions straggled along with a 6-1 deficit until the fifth, when they blasted in four runs, and then the Blue added three more in the sixth to topple the Beaver nine.

TRENTON, April 1. -- The grand jury that staved off the execution of Bruno Richard Hauptmann abandoned temporarily today the case of Paul H. Wendel, on which the postponement was based, and planned to resume it at 9 A.M. tomorrow.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 1. -- The series of "Three Lenten Conferences," which opened on March 19 with Katherine Ruth Heyman discoursing on "Ancient Modes in Modern Music," will close tomorrow morning when the pianist will deliver an illustrated "Conference" on the great Russian composer and mystic whose music she has evangelized throughout the world since his death in 1915: "Scriabin: the Apprentice, the Lover, the Waster."

The fifteenth annual book drive of the American Merchant Marine Library Association will take place April 20-25, with headquarters for the drive at 732 Fifth Avenue. Plans for the campaign to obtain 50,000 or more books for seamen of the merchant marine were discussed at a meeting held yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Hammond, 1 Sutton Place South.

CHICAGO, April 1. -- The pressure on the new crop deliveries of wheat, which was in evidence yesterday, was lacking today on the Board of Trade, and while belated liquidation by longs carried the July and September about a half cent a bushel lower to a new bottom mark for the season, failure of the day areas in the Southwest to receive any moisture of consequence led to short covering and a quick rally.

Manhattan and Bronx contributions for the flood relief fund of the American Red Cross passed the half-million mark yesterday, and the Brooklyn Red Cross exceeded its original quota of $50,000. The total of the New York Chapter at the end of the day was $500,051.59 and the Brooklyn chapter reported $55,705.

NEWARK, N.J., April 1. -- Lawrence Tibbett sang the title role of Verdi's "Rigoletto" to a capacity house at the Mosque Theatre here tonight. For the last two days an S.R.O. sign has been standing in the lobby of the theatre, indicating once more the enthusiasm with which this community receives Metropolitan Opera productions.

A monthly increase of 25,000,000 yards in Calcutta burlap stocks over the next several months was predicted in the local market yesterday, following receipt of cable advices on the tentative operating plans of mills there. The forty-hour week agreement, which has been in effect for several years, expired on Tuesday and no substitute for it has been devised.

Building plans were submitted to the various Building Departments in volume yesterday, continuing activity apparent also last week. Store structures, apartment houses and dwellings were listed among the projects, as follows:

It may well turn out that this newspaper made journalistic history yesterday when it decided to forego the usual light April 1 story. This may prove to be the crack in the dike, the camel's head in the tent, the unhallowed hand on the sacred ark of the Constitution.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 1 (AP). -- April brought snow and wintry weather to most of the West toZ night.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 1. -- Close competition, five of the eight matches going to the home hole or beyond, today featured the second round of the North and South amateur golf championship, which saw the elimination of Bobby Dunkelberger, sensational 16-year-old player.

With three players still in the running -- two from Harvard and one from Yale -- the annual individual championship of the H.Y.P.D. College Chess League was halted at the Marshall Chess Club last night with the title still undecided.

CLEARWATER, Fla., April 1. -- Mr. Charles Dillon Stengel, manager of the Brooklyn baseball club, formally announced today without equivocation that he intends to retain Tom Baker on his pitching staff. He wasn't pressed for reasons because that young man, who won't reach his twenty-first birthday until June 11, has pretty well proved his worth in the citrus circuit competition.

BERLIN, April 1. -- The German proposals for a resettlement of Europe, submitted today to Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, are viewed in diplomatic and neutral quarters here as representing Chancellor Hitler's personal political philosophy as expressed in his Reichstag speeches and his more recent campaign utterances.
New legislation affecting trout fishermen, who open the season on Saturday, was announced yesterday by the New York Conservation Department.

A reception given by the American-Russian Institute and the American-Russian Chamber of Commerce at the Architectural League of New York, 115 East Fortieth Street, yesterday afternoon terminated the unofficial American visit of Mrs. Olga Karpovskaya-Molotov, wife of Vyacheslaff Molotov, President of the Council of Commissars and Premier of the Soviet Union.

PARIS, April 1. -- Andre Maurois, in an article describing "torture by hope," will declare in Le Figaro tomorrow that it would be inhuman to execute Bruno Richard Hauptmann after his successive reprieves.
TJ, S. Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Praising the courage with which Keeper Frank McGarry and others in the Bronx County jail annex at Third Avenue and 161st Street had acted in thwarting an attempted jail break Sunday night, District Attorney Samuel J. Foley yesterday continued his investigation of the possibility that a revolver and two pen-knives which two prisoners possessed might have been smuggled in by relief workers assigned to the place.
ROME, April 1. -- Yesterday's defeat of the Ethiopian Army, announced in today's official war bulletin, was acclaimed in Rome as the beginning of the end of the East African campaign.

Steel production this week rose to the highest rate at which the industry has operated since June, 1930, and stands at 62 1/2 per cent of capacity, according to The Iron Age. This is a gain of 4 1/2 points over the preceding week and of 1 1/2 points above the level of a fortnight ago, when floods caused curtailment.

Coffee and rubber futures were strong on local commodity futures markets yesterday. Other staples were weak to steady in quiet trading. On the cash markets all the grains, butter, tins and rubber were higher, while cotton, lard, wool tops, silk and Santos coffee declined.

Among the notable exhibitions arranged in London by the Royal Academy to illustrate the art of different countries, the one devoted to the art of China, closed last month, proved outstandingly successful. The Burlington House galleries were thronged with visitors from various parts of the world who came to study China's great art in what was, perhaps, the most important such exhibition ever assembled outside Asia.

Chief Judge Frederick E. Crane of the Court of Appeals attacked sharply the tendencies of most citizens to shirk jury duty in this State. Speaking at a meeting of Phi Beta Kappa alumni at the Savoy-Plaza last night, he said there were far too many exemptions at law from jury duty, and added:

The Old Guard of the Republican party triumphed in the primary election yesterday, spiked the Presidential boom of Senator William E. Borah, so far as New York State is concerned, and will have a unanimously unpledged and uncommitted delegation at the Republican National Convention next June.

Mayor La Guardia said last night that when he became Mayor he "got more than I bargained for." He was not complaining, he said, because, "after all, no one asked me to take this job; I looked for it."

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- A $9,000,000 saving for the Chicago Union Station Company and the four proprietary railroads controlling the terminal was made possible today by the Interstate Commerce Commission in a decision approving the $44,000,000 refunding operation contemplated by the company.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 2. -- Rain further dulled the dormant interest in primary voting today and, with the exception of enrolled Socialists of whom there are 606 in Westchester County, few voters went to the polls.
ADDIS ABABA, April 2. -- A victory for Emperor Haile Selassie's own army north of Lake Ashangi was reported in a communique issued from general headquarters this morning.

The trio of Warren A. Dow, Jose R. de Capriles and Miguel A. de Cipriles, composing the University Fencers Club A. team, won the national three-weapon team championship at the Fencers Club last night. Opposing the winners in the final round, Irving E. Cantor, Track Jaeckel and Norman C. Armitage of the Fencers Club B team were unable to take a single bout.

An unprecedented rush by property owners to pay their real estate taxes for the current year has brought so much money into the city treasury, Controller Taylor announced yesterday, that within a week he will redeem $20,000,000 of revenue bills not due until June 30.

LONDON, April 2. -- While fierce and prolonged discussion was raging in the House of Commons today about the consequences of the government's defeat last night as a result of its refusal to pay women civil servants the same salaries as men, it suffered two sharp reverses in the House of Lords, where resolutions relating to the administration of the farm workers' insurance were adopted in the face of protests by government spokesmen.
PARIS, April 2. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler's peace proposals have thus far served only to widen the dangerous gulf between France and Germany. Their reception here could not have been worse.

HAZLETON, Pa., April 2 (AP). -- Union Township taxpayers took up the fight of their children tonight, sending a committee before the School Board to demand that George Weiksner be retained as instructor of physical education at Sheppton High School.

Denouncing WPA agitators as "Communist rats and vermin," Victor F. Ridder, local Works Progress Administrator, declared yesterday in a speech at the Hotel Commodore that any relief worker caught demonstrating in future would be discharged.

Both local and out-of-town merchants have planned the most lavish window displays for Easter to be seen any time since 1929, reports here yesterday indicated. Window display executives said that the Easter period has now assumed an importance comparable to that of Christmas.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 2. -- Nationalist leaders were shocked late this afternoon by the swiftness with which Judge Robert A. Cooper in the United States District Court sentenced Juan Antonio Corretjer, general secretary of the Nationalist party and one of a group of Nationalist leaders under arrest, to one year in jail for contempt of court.
SHIFTING the scene from a balcony in Verona to the mezzanine in the Garden, the following revision is offered for the original Shakespearean script:

CHICAGO, April 2. -- What the United States needs most to restore prosperity "is that business men and bankers be given the opportunity to resume the leadership which played such an important part in the growth and development of the country," Robert V. Fleming, president of the American Bankers Association, said today as he opened the association's two-day Midwest Conference on Banking Service here.

GREENSBORO, N.C., April 2 (AP). -- A tornado which swept a path several blocks wide through Southwest Greensboro early tonight left eleven known dead, more than 100 injured, property damage estimated in excess of $1,000,000 to $1,500,000 and the possibility that many others had been killed or seriously hurt.

BALTIMORE, April 2. -- Dr. Hugh Young, nationally known physician from Johns Hopkins Hospital, and Tilghman Pitts, leader of the Bachelors' Cotillon, have Joined with Mayor Howard Jackson and the officers of the Maryland Jockey Club in the formation of a general committee to establish

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP). -- A plea for quick action, made by Representative Bankhead of Alabama, failed today to win the House Rules Committee's immediate approval for expenditure of $10,000 to defend the Senate Lobby Committee's telegram seizures.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- The Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation filed today a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering $109,000,000 of securities, chiefly for refunding purposes. The amount is the largest ever included in a single registration statement filed under the Securities Act of 1933.
The Union Club, at Park Avenue and Sixty-ninth Street, officially opened its doors to women yesterday afternoon for the fifth time in its 100 years at a reception which was held from 4 to 7 o'clock.

A campaign against the social diseases, emphasizing the serious dimensions of the problem and the best means of attack on it, has been launched by the Women's City Club. The chairman of the campaign committee hopes that women will not let the ancient tradition of prudery, silence and ignorance stand in the way of their hearty cooperation.

HAVANA, April 2. -- Venturer, 58-foot schooner sailed by E.D. Spence of Clearwater, Fla., tonight was declared winner in Class A of the seventh annual St. Petersburg to Havana yacht race with a corrected time of 81 hours 57 minutes 3 seconds.

BERLIN, April 2 (AP). -- The refusal of Dr. Hugo Eckener, commander of the Graf Zeppelin, to come out with a special appeal during the Reichstag election campaign has caused the Propaganda Ministry to issue secret orders to the press to drop his name hereafter out of any publicity concerning the Graf Zeppelin or the giant new dirigible von Hindenburg.

The fear that opera was losing its hold on the public, current in musical circles as recently as last Fall, has been dissipated by the "almost miraculous" season which the Metropolitan company has just closed, Mrs. August Belmont, chairman of the Metropolitan Opera Guild, told the conference dinner of the fifth biennial convention of the Music Educators National Conference at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night.
WASHINGTON, April 2. -- The Senate passed the Murphy bill to strengthen the Packers Act of 1931, debated the Floods Control Bill and recessed at 5:26 P.M. until noon tomorrow.

The Silicosis Bill now before the State Legislature has called forth the condemnation of Secretary FRANCES PERKINS as well as of the American Association for Labor Legislation. It drastically limits payments and medical benefits, makes no allowance for partial disability, fixes liability only on the last employer, and in its essentials violates every fundamental principle of the Compensation Act now in force.
WASHINGTON, April 2. -- The House today received a "warning" that unless it "unconditionally surrendered'' the country to a "new messiah" the United States and other nations would be destroyed.

The trial of Mae Scheible, who is accused of having violated the Mann Act when she moved her vice operations from Pittsburgh to New York two years ago, caused a minor riot yesterday in the third-floor corridor of the new Federal building at Foley Square.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- Tentative preparations for a Summer adjournment of the Supreme Court on June 1 were being made today by attaches of the court long skilled in estimating the day when the nine justices would leave the bench for several months each year.

Extension of a Staten Island housing development was reported yesterday in connection with sales by the Mathews Brothers to the New York City Housing Corporation, headed by Frank H. Crabtree, an attorney. The Mathews Realty and Construction Company has been active in Staten Island and Queens.

Patrolman Thomas O'Rourke arrested Graffo Mariano, 23 years old, of 1,118 East Ninety-first Street, Brooklyn, last night for alleged illegal voting. On the way to Ralph Avenue station with his prisoner the patrolman also arrested Charles Gullotta, 36, of 145 George Street, Brooklyn, for offering him $5 to let Mariano have his freedom.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP). -- The navy busied itself with blueprints and figures tonight, ready to build, if called upon, a passenger ship for a government-aided private line to replace the Leviathan.

TRENTON, April 2. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman revealed today that the automobile with which the caretaker of the former Lindbergh estate at Hopewell charged he was assaulted yesterday was registered by the State Board for the Cleaning and Dyeing Trade, of which Frank Holmes, a Trenton garage man and friend of the Governor, is chairman.

ALBANY, April 2. -- Governor Lehman sent invitations today to twelve Governors and representatives of five foreign nations to attend a dinner in Brooklyn on June 6, which will mark the close of the Long Island tercentenary celebration.

BALTIMORE, April 2. -- Before the most brilliant assemblage of its kind ever gathered here, Lucrezia Bori tonight bade farewell to the American operatic stage. Miss Bori sang the role of Mini in Puccini's "La Boheme" at the Lyric Theatre.

The senior class of Fordham College has broken a tradition of long standing in its annual "celebrities" poll by voting the entire football team, which had one of its most successful seasons last Fall, as having done most for Fordham this year instead of choosing an individual person, as is the custom.

For the first time in the history of the fraternal order in New Jersey, the 100,000 members of 278 lodges of the Masonic order will meet simultaneously in their respective lodges April 15. The order for the State-wide mobilization was issued yesterday by Martin J. Dietz of Weehawken, Grand Master of Masons in New Jersey.

TOKYO, April 2. -- Frontier incidents will not affect the general relations of Russia and Japan, Hachiro Arita, the new Foreign Minister, and Major Gen. Kenji Doihara, chief of the special service section of the Kwantung army, told Japanese newspaper men today.

Edward Reynolds Jr. was elected yesterday president of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation to succeed Philip G. Gossler, who was chosen chairman of the board, a post vacant since the death of George W. Crawford nearly a year ago.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 2. -- The jinx the weather has put on the masters' golf tournament ever since its inception two years ago seemed to have disappeared today when, following a night of torrential rains, the sun shone brilliantly and augured well for tomorrow's opening eighteeen-hole round.

Relief workers on WPA school projects are demoralized by fear they will lose their jobs, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, declared yesterday in a letter to Harry L. Hopkins, urging the Federal Administrator to restore to duty those already dismissed and to order no further layoffs.

Protective committees for the bonds of the Vertientes Sugar Company and the Camaguey Sugar Company will discuss today plans for a merger of these two properties. Tentative plans, it is said, provide for the formation of a new company to take over the assets of both companies, which own extensive sugar plantations in the Province of Camaguey, Cuba.

LONDON, April 2. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange were firm but operations were quieter today, business being restricted by the settlement. British funds remained strong under the influence of the budget surplus.
LONDON, April 2 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

With an increase of more than 13 per cent over the same period in 1935, bank clearings in twenty-two leading cities in the country for the week ended on Wednesday amounted to $6,455,717,000, according to reports to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This compares with $5,710,133,000 for the same week in the preceding year, and is a gain of 13.1 per cent against a gain of 7.3 per cent registered in the previous week.

CLEVELAND, April 2. -- Megs, a be-whiskered Scottish terrier, "conducted herself as a perfect lady" in the eyes of Common Pleas Judge Silbert today and escaped an injunction against a few "yips" in her own back yard.

More than 2,000 property owners, including many large merchants of the midtown shopping area, have signed the petition for a ramp to he West Side elevated highway at Thirty-fourth Street, it was reported yesterday by Thomas A. Mason, executive secretary of the Thirty-fourth Street Midtown Association, which is sponsor of the project.
" Clear to partly cloudy and moderately cool."

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- Start on about half of the administration's $200,000,000 program for eliminating dangerous grade crossings will not be made until midsummer, despite seven months of preparation, Thomas H. MacDonald, chief of the Bureau of Public Roads, revealed today.

Edward S. Jackson Jr., S. Silberman, Robert L. Bornholz and Ted Barron scored in last night's sessions of the preliminaries of the United States chess championship in which adjourned games from earlier rounds were played at the rooms of the Manhattan, Empire City and Queens clubs.

The State of Minnesota awarded yesterday a new issue of $2,650,000 of highway bonds to a syndicate headed by the National City Bank at a price of 100.619 for 2 1/2s. The bonds will be dated May 1, 1936, and mature on May 1, 1948 to 1952.

Dr. James A. Naismith, 74-year-old Professor of Physical Education at the University of Kansas, who invented the game of basketball in 1891, when it was played with peach baskets for goal targets, has played the game only twice in his life.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed the reserve note circulation to be at the highest point of the year to date.

The basketball rules are essentially satisfactory, as they stand, the National Association of Basketball Coaches generally agreed yesterday as it opened its three-day convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania on the eve of the final Olympic basketball tryouts at the Garden.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., April 2. -- White Plains High School, Westchester County champion, defeated the fast Trenton (N.J.) High team tonight in the first game of the seventeenth annual Eastern States basketball tournament by 26 to 25.

Fifty-two horses out of 184 originally nominated and including some of the best 3-year-olds in the country still remain eligible for the Belmont Stakes to be run at Belmont Park June 6, following-the final declarations which were announced yesterday by the Westchester Racing Association.

Norman H. Davis, who returned from London yesterday on the United States liner Washington, declared that the naval accord recently signed at London by Great Britain, France and the United States was the most complete naval treaty ever written -- "from technical standpoints."

For seven hours yesterday the dusty walls in General Sessions Court reverberated to oratory and pleading as defense and prosecution summed up in the trial of Miss Vera Stretz for the murder of Dr. Fritz Gebhardt at 3 Mitchell Place on Nov. 12.

In some years of concert-going in this city the writer has seldom seen such a demonstration as the one which followed Koussevitzky's performance of the Sibelius Second symphony with the Boston Symphony Orchestra, last night in Carnegie Hall. New York concert audiences, when they are enthusiastic, are not backward in expressing themselves.

The three-story store and apartment building at 6,822-24 Bay Parkway, corner of Sixty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Stride Realty Corporation to an investor through Henry Brinsley, broker. Cash was paid above a first mortgage of $38,250 held by the Chemical Bank and Trust Company.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

William Calamares, 17 years old, of 212 East Thirteenth Street, was arrested yesterday afternoon and charged with killing Frank Vasquez, 18, of 350 East Thirteenth Street, who died at 4 A.M. in Columbus Hospital of wounds, which were caused, according to the police, by a stab in the back.

TRENTON, N.J., April 2. -- Tabulation of the list of candidates today who have filed nominating petitions for election at next month's primaries as district delegates to the Republican National Convention shows that while some are pledged without reservation either to Senator Borah or Governor Landon, some are unpledged and others will consider themselves bound by the preferential vote cast for these Presidential contenders.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 2. -- More than twenty mothers and fathers of Harvard students living in the Lowell House moved in today to take the place of their sons as "Harvard students" and paying about the customary rates for their meals.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 2. -- The election of officers of the Contemporary Club of this city took place this morning. Officers chosen were Mrs. Julian Olney, president; Mrs. Ivan Johnson, first vice president; Mrs. Kenneth F. Clark, second vice president; Mrs. Thomas Hoffman, third vice president; Mrs. C.C. Meleney, recording secretary; Mrs. Edward Newton, corresponding secretary, and Mrs. T.D. Nichols, treasurer.
BERLIN, April 2 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of March 31 shows the following charges in reichsmark:
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows.

NORTH CONWAY, N.H., April 2. -- Separated while descending the precipitous icy slopes of Mount Washington, John Winthrop Fowler, 19, of New York, a Princeton junior, plunged 300 feet to his death upon rocks above the Tuckerman Ravine Head Wall and his companion, a class-mate, McKim Daingerfield of Baltimore, narrowly escaped fatal injury in a similar fall near by.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- The conciliation service of the Department of Labor has intervened in some 15,900 labor disputes; involving 16,000,000 workers, since 1917, according to Hugh Kerwin, director of the conciliation organization, who was a witness today before the National Labor Relations Board.
CORDELE, Ga., April 2. -- Spring storms, sweeping erratically through five Southern States, caused at least thirty-seven deaths and left millions of dollars of property damage in their wake tonight.

ALBANY, April 2. -- Senator Desmond renewed his plea for a Legislature of one house in a radio address tonight from Station WGY at Schenectady. At the same time he reiterated his demand for changes in the unemployment insurance law.

The five-story apartment house at 1,821 University Avenue, in the Bronx, containing thirty-one suites has been purchased by an investing client of Joseph Howard Katz, lawyer, from Adler Friedman, Inc.
INDIANAPOLIS, April 2 (AP). -- Fifth place in the singles and seventh in the doubles fell today during the minor events of the American Bowling Congress tournament.

LYNDHURST, N.J., April 2. -- Alfred Dupre, 25 years old, of 14 Ellis Avenue, Irvington, committed suicide in the home of a 19-year-old Lyndhurst high school senior this morning after the girl had refused to marry him. After questioning by the police, the girl, Mildred Thornton of 143 Forest Avenue, Lyndhurst, was absolved of blame.
ASMARA, Eritrea, April 2. -- Details have reached here of the remarkable march of the Italian forces that occupied Gondar, twenty miles north of Lake Tana, yesterday.

CANBERRA, Australia, April 2. -- Losing no time in putting into effect the decision to restrict imports from the United States, a Cabinet subcommittee has already begun considering action to rectify the unfavorable trade balance.

The following film programs, which will be shown over the week-end, have been endorsed by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of faculty members and parents of children in public and private schools:

The story of a reformed criminal who was befriended by a policeman who once had sought him for thirteen years turned to a paradoxical ending yesterday with the revelation that the policeman, now a detective sergeant, had taken up a collection to save the reformed criminal from burial in Potter's field.
PARIS, April 2 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

TORONTO, April 2. -- The New York Americans came to the end of their trail tonight, when they bowed to the Maple Leafs in the last of the three-game series in the semi-final round of the National Hockey League's play-offs.

ASMARA, Eritrea, April 2. -- The "little rainy season" has commenced. Asmara's sky, which had been clear, except at rare intervals, for nearly six months, became overcast a few days ago, and today rain began to fall.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, denied today that politics influenced the selection of persons for WPA jobs, but said that the Works Progress administrative staff throughout the country had been chosen from among those favorable to President Roosevelt's work relief ideas.

BERLIN, April 2. -- Two of the larger Berlin photoplay houses at which American films are ordinarily introduced to the German public -- the Marmorhaus and the Capitol in the Kurfurstendamm, the bright lights district, have been purchased by UFA, largest German film producing concern.

Activity continued at a brisk pace yesterday in the Manhattan realty field. Various apartment and dwelling properties changed hands, the Rockefeller Center area being particularly active. Operators again figured as important factors in the market.

The Transit Commission announced yesterday that it would begin public hearings on April 15 on an application filed by Clinton L. Bardo, trustee of the New York, Westchester Boston Railway Company, seeking to reduce train service within the city limits.

Supreme Court Justice McCook denied yesterday an application by three hotel companies, of which Henry Blum is president, to compel Thomas E. Dewey, Deputy Assistant District Attorney, to return to them books subpoenaed five weeks ago for use in a racketeering investigation.
Gains and losses were about evenly divided among commodity futures yesterday. On the cash markets, cotton, butter, eggs, cocoa and tins advanced, while all the grains, lard and silk eased.

Representatives of parent-teacher associations of New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania adopted yesterday a seven-point program for traffic safety education directed toward the 2,000,000 members of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers.

Oswald Jacoby and David Burnstine, members of the famous Four Aces combination, nosed out Sherman Stearns and M.D. Maier in the final session of the contract pair event to win the 1936 Grand National championship early this morning.

CINCINNATI, April 2 (AP). -- The Reds, who once sold Floyd (Babe) Herman for $75,000 and then repurchased him at the National League waiver price, served notice on the tall outfielder today to sign his 1936 contract or quit baseball.

MIAMI, Fla., April 2. -- After two days of fishing in waters at the edge of the Tongue of the Ocean, 200 miles east of here, and a total of ten days of ocean cruising, President Roosevelt tonight set aside tomorrow for the handling of various official matters that have accumulated at the temporary White House offices here.

BOWIE, Md., April 2. -- The power of the Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt string, largest in the country, made itself felt at Bowie today when bearers of the cerise and white blocks won the two features and finished second and third in other races.

Charles (Lucky) Luciana and eleven of his alleged lieutenants in the operation of the city's $10,000,000 vice ring were accused of compulsory prostitution in four indictments, each containing six counts, returned yesterday by the extraordinary grand jury investigating racketeering in New York County.

GREENVVOOD, Miss., April 2. -- George (Kiddo) Davis and Charlie English, who are making a determined effort this Spring to convince Colonel Bill Terry that he is overlooking a couple of sterling regulars, produced some powerful evidence in their behalf today by helping the Giants bring down the Indians in a most spectacular manner.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP). -- Immediate prospects of the steel industry were pictured as "favorable" and "encouraging" today by W.A. Irvin, president of the United States Steel Corporation, and Eugene G. Grace, president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.

In certain respects the machinery of dictatorship is simplicity itself. Consider the matter of finances. No other question causes so much trouble for old-fashioned democratic Governments. Estimates have to be submitted to a Parliament or a Congress. Hostile criticism must be faced.

I have been marveling for the last several weeks at the extraordinary resignation of the people of New York. Probably the depression has put them in a frame of mind to accept anything in the way of public service, no matter how inadequate.

Control of the Socialist party in the State remained in doubt early this morning, although returns available indicated the strong possibility of a victory for the Left Wing forces, headed by Norman Thomas.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 2. -- The Long Island Sound Interclub Class yachts won both of today's races in the international series with the Bermuda one-design boats. The races were sailed over a triangular course in Great Sound, with brisk southwest breezes blowing.

BERLIN, April 2. -- The Boerse continued today to show only small fluctuations in a limited market without developing any significant trend. With trading remaining under strict official control, the situation is intensified because of the still uncertain foreign political situation.

Once industry recognizes that the consumer is the beginning of all business, selling wilt become streamlined and products will move from the raw material stage to the ultimate customer in a single, unbroken chain, Kenneth B. Goode, president of the Sales Executive Club of New York, declared yesterday in an address before the Advertising Club.
DES MOINES, April 2. -- Secretary Wallace will officially become a Democrat immediately after the State Convention here tomorrow, Governor Clyde L. Herring announced today.

The American Machine and Foundry Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for 1935 a net profit of $1,120,985 after interest, depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges, but exclusive of proportionate earnings of International Cigar Machinery Company not declared as dividends.

TRENTON, N.J., April 2. -- Thirty-eight of the sixty members of the Assembly met in a closed session for several hours today to consider the problem of financing emergency relief from April 15 to the end of the year. They did not find the answer.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- The Senate Agriculture Committee probably will decline any responsibility for the resolution Senator Vandenberg introduced some time ago directing the Secretary of Agriculture to furnish to the Senate a list of the names of persons or corporations who have collected $10,000 or more in benefits under the Agricultural Adjustment Act, Chairman Smith indicated today.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- Business interests made their long-delayed attack on President Roosevelt's new tax plan today, declaring it a "promoter of monopolies," a "penalizer of thrift," a "share-the-wealth proposal in disguise," and "a direct attack upon capitalism."

Plans of a $300,000 house for eighty-nine families on a block front in Richmond Hill, Queens, featured the building projects filed yesterday. The six-story structure planned will occupy a site 96 by 231 feet on the west side of 149th Street, from Ninetieth Avenue to Ninetieth Road. Brighton Gardens, Inc., J. Strauss, president, of 26 Court Street, Brooklyn, is the owner. Martin Weinstein designed the structure.

OTTAWA, April 2 (Canadian Press). -- Deposits of the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada declined $3,778,777 in the week ended yesterday, according to the weekly statement of the bank issued today. Deposits of chartered banks decreased $733,012.

CLEVELAND, April 2. -- C.W. Hannon, president of the Murray Ohio Manufacturing Company, issued today the following statement relative to the action taken yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission against Otis Co. of this city for their operations in stock of Mr. Hannon's company:

MEDFORD, N.J., April 2. -- Completed under dispiriting conditions this morning, the open junior all-age stake of the annual field trial meeting of the English Setter Club of America was won by the white and liver pointer dog Allegheney's Baconrind, owned by Captain R.H. Clemmer of Waynesboro, Va., and handled by Ed Mack Farrior.

CHICAGO, April 2. -- Improvement in the shipping demand for hogs resulted today in an advance of 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight in light weights, which had led the decline yesterday. Heavier offerings were steady to strong. The top price was unchanged at $10.80 and the average of $10.45 was steady.

Voicing opposition to the use of tax revenues to finance social reforms or a utopian commonwealth, State Tax Commissioner John J. Merrill declared yesterday that the State of New York has passed the limit of sane assessment and reasonable cost of government.

The advantage gained in the stock market on Wednesday was followed up yesterday, although in less vigorous fashion than on the day before. Trading, however, was productive of several interesting features. For one thing, the volume on the Stock Exchange mounted to 2,194,000 shares, the heaviest since March 17, and the number of issues dealt in was the greatest since March 13.

The title and mortgage rehabilitation and liquidation bureau of the State Insurance Department yesterday announced the closing of several realty sales. The parcels involved were assets of title and mortgage guaranty companies under supervision of the State body.

Gifts from public school children helped yesterday to raise to $509,500.51 the flood relief fund of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross, it was announced by General Robert C. Davis, executive director.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP). -- Representative Vito Marcantonio of New York, charging on the floor of the House of Representatives that Victor A. Barron, an American citizen, was tortured and murdered by the police of Rio de Janeiro on March 5, today demanded an investigation of "State Department negligence."
The City Bank Farmers Trust Company has been appointed registrar for 1,500,000 shares of common stock voting trust certificates of the Universal Corporation.

Monetary gold stocks of the country rose to a new high level of $10,185,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, a gain of $8,000,000 over the previous week, according to the Federal Reserve reports, issued yesterday. The present total is an increase of $1,617,000,000 over a year ago and a rise of $3,356,000,000 since the devaluation of the dollar on Jan. 31, 1934.

MOSCOW, April 2. -- Communist party members who are university students were upbraided editorially in the newspaper Pravda today for their bad showing in their studies as compared with non-party students.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 2 (AP). -- George T. Dunlap Jr., defending his North and South amateur title, set a new amateur record of 69 over the par 71 No. 2 championship course today in qualifying for the semi-final round.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended April 1, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,483,000,000, a decrease of $21,000,000,-compared with the preceding week and an increase of $14,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1935.

Some members of the Ways and Means Committee have been asking rhetorically why, if the proposed tax on undistributed profits is so unsound, more witnesses have not appeared to denounce it. The question is not difficult to answer when one analyzes the sources from which interested protest might be expected to come.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 2. -- The body of William G. Roehrich, secretary of the Oxford University Press, in New York, was found last night floating in a lagoon in Harrington Sound. The feet were tied together with a fishing line.

The New York Curb Exchange announced yesterday the suspension for three years of Frank E. Snow, William J. Heaney and Eugene J. Mitchell, all partners in Walter P. McCaffray Co., which firm on Monday was enjoined by Supreme Court Justice William Harmon Black from dealing in securities.

CHICAGO, April 2. -- Swimming by himself all the way, Adolph Kiefer, sensational Chicago high school boy, smashed all records for the 150-yard back-stroke tonight in the men's senior national A.A.U. championships, finishing in the amazing time of 1:32.7.

No less a combatant than the Actors Equity Association yesterday stepped into the arena where the playwrights and managers have been at war over the division of sums derived from film sales. With every sign of being serious, Frank Gillmore, Equity president, declared that the actor deserves a share because he is the "expert salesman" who "contributes in no small measure to the success of a play."

GENEVA, April 2. -- The German note has received a generally cold reception here, with a minority hopeful that it may lead to something. The majority agree in expecting it to lead at least to more negotiations, although they foresee great difficulty for Britain in finding a basis for them.

Readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES will commend it for its endorsement of the logical insistence of Senator Vandenberg upon the same publicity for Federal largess to the American farmer that Federal Government representatives insolently insist upon with respect to the salaries paid to officials of corporations.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- Avoiding a ruling on the constitutionality of the National Labor Relations Act, Justice Jesse C. Adkins in District Supreme Court today dismissed for lack of jurisdiction four suits brought by manufacturing concerns to bar moves by the board.

The seizure of the Norwegian freighter Reidun by Federal authorities for her alleged transportation of liquor to rum-runners off the Newfoundland coast for smuggling into the United States was made the subject of legal action yesterday in the United States District Court in Brooklyn.
WARSAW, April 2. -- The dangers of German hegemony in Eastern and Central Europe were stressed in Polish press comments today on Germany's latest offer.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 2. -- Aroused by recent developments in the Hauptmann case, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, and a group of distinguished scholars and graduates petitioned the New Jersey Legislature today to determine whether or not any public officials connected with the case are open to impeachment proceedings or removal from office.

A sharp recovery occurred in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday when an analysis of the plans for marketing government holdings showed that cotton was not to be sold below the level of quotations now prevailing in the South.

Five years ago the Division of Anthropology of Harvard University began to contemplate the possibility of making a study of man in Ireland -- ancient man and modern man, their prehistoric and historic cultures, their past and present social institutions, the sequence of races and the physical status of the modern population.

Walter S. Wyman, president of the Central Maine Power Company, reported yesterday a net income of $1,306,876 for the company and subsidiaries for the year ended on Feb. 29, after all deductions. This compared with $1,286,113 in the preceding year.

The largest industrial bond issue registered under the Securities Act of 1933, consisting of $62,545,500 of National Dairy Products Corporation 3 3/4 per cent debentures due on May 1, 1951, with common stock purchase warrants attached, will be offered today to holders of common stock and outstanding debentures of the corporation.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, April 2. -- Fritz Busch, the famous composer who was expelled from Germany after the Nazi revolution, received a cablegram tonight from Arturo Toscanini offering him the leadership of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.
WASHINGTON, April 2. -- Income tax collections for March were $412,452,233, compared with $326,268,511 for the same month last year, according to final figures issued by the Treasury Department.

Three armed men were foiled in their attempt to rob the Louis Fried Jewelry Shop, 2,182 Broadway, near Seventy-seventh Street, yesterday morning when a fast-thinking clerk dropped to the floor behind the counter and kicked a concealed switch that set off a burglar siren outside the store.
KAMENZ, Germany, April 2 (AP). -- Bruno Richard Hauptmann asserted, in a letter received by his mother today, that his wife intended to demand the arrest of two State witnesses as his trial.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 2. -- A collision or collisions with extraterrestrial bodies may have been responsible in the dim past for the river valleys which cut through the earth and indent the surface of the earth below oceans and lakes, it was said today.

CHICAGO, April 2. -- A wave of liquidation by holders of wheat contracts swept over the markets in North America today. The July and September deliveries in Chicago and Kansas City representing the 1936 crop and all deliveries at Minneapolis and Winnipeg dropped sharply to new low prices for the season.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 2. -- A Harvard-Yale picked team defeated the Royal Navy fifteen, 15 to 0, today in the concluding match of the annual Rugby Week program. The keen team play and strategy of the invading college stars featured the encounter.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- Once more -- through a resolution offered by Representative Lehlbach of New Jersey today -- attention has been publicly drawn to James A. Farley's joint incumbency of the offices of Postmaster General and National Democratic Committee Chairman.
In the interest of accuracy and the future record I am venturing a correction of your article in the News Review today regarding Mr. Roosevelt's honorary degrees.

Turnover of ready-to-wear and most accessory items, together with the difficulties which have been experienced on deliveries on reorders, indicate that most retailers will be able to go through with plans to delay clearances, reports here yesterday indicated.
LONDON, April 2. -- King Edward's coronation will take place some time in May, 1937, Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin told the House of Commons this afternoon.

Murray M. Shoemaker in a letter to THE TIMES expressed alarm at this country's intention to build superliners to rival those now flying the flags of Great Britain and France, his prime reason for apprehension being that this country would be called upon to pay their costs.

TRENTON, Friday, April 3. -- The likelihood that Bruno Richard Hauptmann will finally go to the electric chair at 8 o'clock tonight, the hour now set for the execution, was greatly increased last midnight when the Mercer County grand jury adjourned after voting to discontinue its investigation and failing to return an indictment against Paul H. Wendel on a murder charge in the Lindbergh kidnapping case.
Robert M. Shields of Clark, Dodge Co. was disclosed yesterday to have been the purchaser of the membership in the New York Stock Exchange of Jerome T. Meighan for $150,000.

LONDON, April 2. -- The net results of conversations today between Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, and Joachim von Ribbentrop, German Ambassador at Large, and later between Mr. Eden and the French and the Belgian Ambassadors demonstrate that two outstanding points of friction still remain in the situation growling out of Adolf Hitler's Locarno violation.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 2. -- Joe McCarthy, Yankee pilot, shook up his batting order today, took to the coaching line at third base, instituting what he plans to be a daily custom, and shook out a victory over the Birmingham Barons as a farewell gesture of the New Yorkers' annual visit here.

HOUSTON, Texas, April 2. -- Wilmer Allison, whose racquet has cut down such tennis giants as Fred Perry, had to call forth all his court cunning today to vanquish an unawed Lakeland (Fla.) ace, Arthur Hendrix.

The 1935 American Hebrew Medal for the Promotion of Better Understanding Between Christian and Jew in America was presented last night to Roger Williams Straus, co-chairman of the National Conference of Jews and Christians, in the presence of an inter-faith gathering, including the official representatives of several foreign countries.

MIAMI, Fla., April 2. -- A dead heat between two horses for third place -- a rarity in racing -- was called in the five-and-a-half-furlong opener today at Tropical Park. Climaxing a stretch duel in which the Waite camera-finish device showed Old Ironsides getting a head victory over Zowie, the pictures further along on the strip showed Tramway and Balaath in a dead heat for the show money.

The annual Pulitzer Prize dinner, at which awards will be announced for the year's outstanding work in journalism, drama and letters, will be held at the Hotel Commodore May 4 under the sponsorship of the Alumni Association of the Columbia University School of Journalism, it was announced yesterday.

A loss of 0.9 point for the week carried The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices to 124.4 on Tuesday, the lowest since last Summer. Prices were lower for wheat, flour, butter, eggs, steers, beef, pork, potatoes, tin and rubber. Cotton, sugar, apples and bananas were higher.

ROME, April 2. -- Now that Italian flags are flying over Gondar, only twenty miles north of Lake Tana, all Italians turn their eyes to Great Britain and are wondering how she is going to take the invasion of a region that has always been recognized as forming part of a British sphere of influence.

If there is to be national economic recovery and a balanced budget, the Treasury and Federal Reserve System must maintain a policy of low interest rates, Russell C. Leffingwell, partner of J.P. Morgan Co., said last night in an address at the semi-annual dinner of the Academy of Political Science in the Hotel Astor.

A brisk demand for convertible obligations and the more speculative among corporate issues characterized otherwise routine trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The trading pace, however, was stepped up considerably, with sales amounting to $11,057,100, compared with $8,708,900 on Wednesday.
CHICAGO, April 2 (UP). - An April onset of cold, wind, rain and snow- storms cost many lives and heavy property damage throughout the country today.

Officials of the national parks system joined with members of the National Life Conservation Society yesterday in protesting against the proposed Rocky Mountain tunnel project as an invasion of public rights by a commercial venture and as a dangerous precedent affecting the future status of all national parks.

A credit boom is so definitely in prospect that banking leaders of the country and outstanding professors, addressing the semi-annual meeting of the Academy of Political Science at the Hotel Astor yesterday, devoted their principal attention to the necessity of controlling it.

SEBRING, Fla., April 2. -- The infield and outfield combinations with which the Dodgers will open the National League season were used today for the first time this Spring in an exhibition game against Oscar Vitt's Newark International League team. They functioned well and the Dodgers won, 10 to 5.

Exports and imports from and into the United States by classified groups during February, as announced by the Department of Commerce, compare as follows with those of a month ago and the corresponding period in 1935.

Ownership of more than 90 per cent of the common stock of the Universal Pictures Company, Inc., passed yesterday from Carl Laemmle and associates to the Universal Corporation, it was announced by J. Cheever Cowdin and Robert H. Cochrane. The consideration was $5,500,000.
GENEVA, April 2. -- Ethiopia appealed to the League of Nations for further aid in a long note from her Paris Minister, Wolde Mariam Ayeleu. The Ethiopian Government asked for aid along four lines.

A strong hint that an indictment will "transcend in importance" any so far returned in the investigation of the bribery phase of the Drukman murder case is in the offing was offered yesterday by Hiram C. Todd, special prosecutor in the case, during proceedings before Supreme Court Justice Erskine C. Rogers in Brooklyn.

It seems that past generations of Americans had one great advantage in fighting their depressions. They took it for granted that in hard times everybody must work harder than usual, and that the few groups that were fortunate enough to be spared by reverses had a moral duty to assist the others.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- The wholesale price was unchanged in the week ended on March 28, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 weekly average as 100, remained at 79.3, compared with 78.9 a year ago.

Five Manhattan foreclosure auctions yesterday included sale of the twenty-story Broadway Building at 915 Broadway to the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, plaintiff, on a $1,000,000 bid. The site, about 72 by 128 feet, is at the southwest corner of Twenty-first Street.

A basketball show of superlative attractiveness will be presented in Madison Square Garden this weekend when the final Olympic court tryouts are staged to select the American representative for the international competition this Summer.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP). -- A hope that the Communications Commission would do nothing "to unfairly injure the reputation of the A.T. T." was coupled by President Walter S. Gifford today with a promise to scan the utility's "lobbying" practices to determine whether they should be reformed.

A farewell dinner, followed by dancing, was given by Mrs. William Randolph Hearst last night at her home, 137 Riverside Drive, for the Duchess of Marlborough, the Duchess of Sutherland, the Countess of Abingdon and Mrs. James W. Corrigan.

TRENTON, April 2. -- Attorney General David T. Wilentz, speaking before the grand jury voted to drop the Wendel investigation, said that he did not believe the Mercer County grand jury had jurisdiction in the case of Paul H. Wendel.
Mrs. Cardera Collin May, socially prominent in this city, was killed when she was hit by an automobile late Wednesday night at Madison Avenue and Seventy-fourth Street. Mrs. May was 76 years old.

Unfilled orders for wool fabrics this week were estimated at 42,000,000 linear yards, or the equivalent of thirteen weeks' production at the present rate of operations, it was reported yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.

Rehabilitation of old buildings was favored over new construction in addresses at yesterday's sessions of the convention of the Building Officials Conference of America in the Hotel New Yorker. Joseph P. Day, realty man, urged that municipalities not increase assessments, over a specified period, where improvements were made as a means of encouraging such rehabilitation, and Walter Hess of Clark

EDMONTON, Alberta, April 2. -- Power to convert every dollar of Alberta's $160,000,000 provincial debt into perpetual provincial stock on which the principal need never be paid is contained in the Aberhardt government's compulsory refunding legislation, it was revealed today as the bill came before the Legislature.

Mrs. Gerard Swope, Mrs. Kendal Emerson, Miss Louise Watson and Mrs. Sherman Barnes were among the officials of the People's Mandate Committee to End War who acted as hostesses yesterday afternoon at the opening of the mandate committee's office in the Hotel Biltmore.

PHILADELPHIA, April 2. -- A daring prehistoric architect's conception of a combined citadel and temple of worship antedating by nearly three centuries the earliest biblical reference to temple-fortresses has been uncovered by archaeologists at Tepe Gawra, in Northern Mesopotamia, it was announced today at the University of Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- Assertions that the "Golden Stakes" contest was not a lottery and that purchasers of tickets were not "led to believe they are buying tickets in a drawing for prizes similar to a foreign lottery" were made by attorneys and officials of the Golden Stakes Advertising Corporation at a Postoffice Department hearing today.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- Ultimate expenditure of at least $1,500,000,000 would be required to finance the national flood control program urged by extreme advocates, Senator Copeland told the Senate today. The Commerce Committee, of which he is chairman, would report a measure next week authorizing not more than $500,000,000 in Federal expense, he predicted.

District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn and Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine were checking last night Paul Wendel's story of having been kidnapped, held a prisoner in Brooklyn for ten days and tortured into signing a "confession" that he kidnapped the Lindbergh baby.

The Cunard White Star liner Berengaria will depart tonight for Cherbourg and Southampton. The Duchess of Marlborough, the Duchess of Sutherland, Willem van Hoogstraten, conductor, and Walter Greenwood, playwright, are among those leaving on this vessel.
Your news of a Congressional resolution "to make John Steven McGroarty honorary poet laureate of the United States of America" invites several questions.

MOSCOW, April 2. -- As part of the present vigorous efforts to increase the production of consumers' goods, the government and Communist party abolished today the Central Institute of Labor of the Commissariat for Light Industry.

WARSAW, April 2. -- More than 500 alleged Communists have been arrested in the last few days in a country-wide round-up of Reds. A secret radio station with short-wave receiving and transmitting sets was discovered early today in Warsaw.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP). -- A dispute over services celebrating the Jewish holiday in the Bronx and application to them of a novel New York State law brought an appeal today to the Supreme Court.

BANGOR, Me., April 2 (AP). -- The Maine Republican convention tonight ratified a slate of thirteen national delegates, unpledged but "disposed" to support Colonel Frank Knox for the Presidential nomination "as long as he has a chance," according to party leaders.

JERUSALEM, April 2. -- Nebimusa, Palestine Moslems' festival, when Arabs from all parts of the country assemble in Jerusalem to make a pilgrimage to the supposed tomb of Moses, near Jericho, begins tomorrow.

A two-club race for the National League pennant, with the Cardinals dethroning the Cubs by a narrow margin, was forecast by the nation's baseball experts, casting ballots in The Associated Press tenth annual poll, the results of which were announced yesterday.

Yesterday's rise of stock prices was regarded as highly important by students of the technical action of the market. THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks rose to a new high level for this year at 125.05, thus piercing the resistance level formed by the top prices of March, when on two occasions the average could rise no higher than 124.

Groups of German Jewish exiles who have been forced to leave their native land under Nazi pressure continue to arrive in New York weekly, and steamship officials estimated yesterday that between 1,000 and 2,000 had landed here within the last two months.

Polo players and ponies swell the increasing flow toward England of that sport with the sailing of two vessels from New York today. At noon thirty-one of the well-known string of ponies owned by Charles B. Wrightsman, the Californian, will be loaded aboard the American Merchant liner American Banker, which sails at 4 o'clock in the afternoon.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- Dr. F.E. Townsend collected $1,700 at a mass meeting in Los Angeles on Feb. 20, but Old Age Revolving Pensions, Ltd., never got the money, according to a statement by Robert E. Clements, co-founder of OARP, today before the House committee investigating the Townsend plan.
LONDON, April 3. -- The following is the text of the speech of Anthony Eden, Foreign Secretary, before the House of Commons today, outlining Britain's efforts to conciliate the Rhineland controversy:

Sailing today for Europe on the French liner Ile de France are several prominent operatic and theatrical figures, leaving after the close of the season in New York. The list includes Mme, Elisabeth Rethberg, soprano; Ezio Pinza, basso; Ettore Panizza, conductor, with Mme. Panizza; Mme. Karin Branzell, mezzo-soprano; Yribe Escudero, dancer; Mme. Germaine Schnitzer, pianist; Mme. Ganna Walska; Eric Charell, English producer, and Gilbert Miller, American theatrical producer.

Loans to member firms of the New York Stock Exchange at the close of business on March 31 were $996,894,018, the Exchange announced yesterday. This is the highest since June, 1934, when the total was $1,082,240,000. The borrowings on collateral increased $72,573,474 in March.

Flood relief contributions of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross rose to $515,833.30 yesterday. as word was received from national headquarters in Washington that a new flood vas threatening in North Carolina. A tornado has also brought need for Red Cross aid ill that State.

As the first prison sentence was being imposed in Special Sessions yesterday in District Attorney Dodge's investigation of the furniture racket, the retiring March grand jury, of which John D. Rockefeller 3d was a member, handed up a presentment to General Sessions Judge Donnellan on its findings in that and other business rackets in the city.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- In declining today to make any contribution toward the American Federation of Labor's campaign to organize the steel industry, Arthur O. Wharton, president of the International Association of Machinists, blamed lack of harmony in the campaign on the Committee for Industrial Organization headed by John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America.

Judge Robert A. Inch, in the United States District Court, in Brooklyn, signed yesterday an order directing James C. Van Siclen and C. Walter Randall, trustees in reorganization proceedings of Bush Terminal Company, to start suit on behalf of the creditors of the corporation to recover $3,639,058.06 paid in dividends by the company in a period of three and one-half years.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP). -- Adrastic revision of the projected War Profits Bill to allow more profit and less restriction on industry, but to increase taxes sharply in the lower brackets, was ordered today by the Senate Finance Committee.
ALBANY, April 3. -- The following announcements were made today by the State Banking Department:

CHICAGO, April 3 (AP). -- From universities, colleges, Y.M.C.A.'s and industrial plants of the nation, nearly 300 youths opened the national A.A.U. wrestling championships at De Paul University gymnasium today, with thirty-three first-round matches.

In an editorial note in your "Letters" columns on March 29 you listed the players who have hit two home runs in one inning in major league games. But Buck Ewing was not included in the compilation. I personally saw Ewing hit two homers in one inning in a game played between the Giants and, I believe, Boston at the old Polo Grounds at Fifth Avenue and 110th Street.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 8. -- The right kind of law enforcement officials are more important in the solution of the country's crime problem than more crime legislation, Lewis E. Lawes said here today as the principal speaker at the opening session of a two-day conference on crime, its causes and treatment, being held under the auspices of Vassar College.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 3. -- Named in honor of the late John Schultz, Princeton rigger and sculling instructor, a new eight-oared shell to be used by the Princeton varsity crew this year was launched this morning. The shell is the gift of a former varsity crew man whose name was not made public.
A rollicking comedy-drama, "The Lid's Off," was presented last night by the Hasty Pudding Club of Harvard University before a packed house of 3,500 at Mecca Temple.

TRENTON, N.J., April 3. -- Mrs. Anna Hauptmann did all she could today to save the life of her husband and at the end, lying face downward across her hotel bed, heard that it had been unavailing. She wept uncontrollably.
Joseph A. Solovei, an attorney, asked the Brooklyn Bar Association yesterday to conduct an immediate inquiry into his activities in the case growing out of the murder of Samuel Drukman.

Charles Augustus Lindbergh Jr., 20 months old, was kidnapped from his crib in the nursery of the Lindbergh country home near Hopewell, N.J., in the isolated Sourland Mountain region of Western New Jersey, on the night of Tuesday, March 1, 1932.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- Business interests, large and small, continued their attacks upon President Roosevelt's tax plan today, with representatives of Class I railroads and of small meat packers making pleas to the Ways and Means Committee for relief from pending proposals.

Miss Vera Stretz was acquitted in General Sessions Court last night of the murder of Dr. Fritz Gebhardt at Beekman Tower, 3 Mitchell Place, the morning of last Nov. 12. The jury deliberated only three hours and five minutes.
Broadway apartment corner uptown and a business building downtown were among the eight Manhattan properties bid in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday, as follows:

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C., April 3 (AP). -- Miss Deborah Verry, Worcester (Mass.) star, regained the Mid-South golf title she won in 1933 by conquering Miss Estelle Lawson of Chapel Hill, N.C., in an eighteen-hole play-off today after the two had tied at 165 for the honors in the thirty-six-hole medal play tourney.

With Bruno Richard Hauptmann dead last night, attention shifted to Brooklyn, where District Attorney Geoghan sought to question Ellis H. Parker, the New Jersey county detective, concerning his knowledge of Paul Wendel's repudiated "confession" to the Lindbergh kidnapping.

PHILADELPHIA, April 3. -- This city was accused today, at a four-State conference, as the chief offender in contributing to the pollution of the Delaware River. New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware were represented at the meeting, called by the Pennsylvania commission on interstate cooperation.

ROME, April 3. -- The Italian press is still in great pains to calm the storm of protest raging in Britain in consequence of the Italian occupation of Gondar and to assure Britain that her rights in the Tana district of Ethiopia will be respected.

Cardinal Hayes returned home at 5:50 P.M. yesterday from Nassau, the Bahama Islands, where he went six weeks ago to recuperate from a severe attack of bronchitis. He appeared in good health and was said to be "practically" well again.

A group of Broadway managers met yesterday afternoon and decided that from now on they will buy plays under the terms of their own contract. This contract they would not reveal, but they said it had been drawn up after the producers failed to accept the one offered some time ago by the Dramatists Guild of America, representing the playwrights.

Sir Arthur Salter, British economist, who was the guest of honor and principal speaker at a luncheon of the League for Political Education at the Hotel Astor yesterday, told an audience of 800 that what the world most needed today was an increase in political wisdom in the large and important countries of the world.

" Night of January 16" closes its career tonight at the Ambassador, having set up a run of 232 performances. It is the only closing of the evening on Times Square, though up at the Lafayette Theatre, in Harlem, the WPA will draw down the curtain on "Conjure-Man Dies."

BALTIMORE, April 3. -- A suit by Laurence Baker and his wife, Mrs. Rebekah Baker, to restrain the Howard County Hunt Club from permitting its fox hounds to run over their estate will be argued before the Circuit Court of Howard County within two or three weeks, according to lawyers on both sides.

LONDON, April 3. -- The Cambridge eight is likely to defeat Oxford for the thirteenth successive year tomorrow morning when the annual university boat race is rowed over the historic 4 1/4 mile Thames course from Putney to Mortlake.

HOUSTON, Texas, April 3 (AP). -Wilmer Allison, Austin, and Bryan Grant, Atlanta, top seeded in the annual River Oaks tennis tournament, advanced into the semi-finals today with victories over Wilbur Hess of Houston and Charles R. Harris of West Palm Beach, Fla.

Thousands will find themselves today in agreement with IZAAK WALTON, who wrote, "Doubtless a Trout af-"fords the most pleasure to the angler "of any sort of fish whatever," as the season for the speckled beauties opens in the Empire State. Ardent fishermen will be wetting their lines from just above tidewater to the Canadian boundary.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- A government brief, filed today in the District Court of Appeals, charged that the strategy of dominant utility holding companies has not been designed as a protection of constitutional rights, but rather to manoeuvre into the Supreme Court, upon inadequate records, such cases as would most effectively conceal the real constitutional issues involved in holding company situations.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP). -Congressional sources today disclosed a new move by the administration to obtain legislation placing exchanges for all commodities, with the possible exception of cotton, under a Commodity Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP). -- Asserting that the issue was "between private ownership and government ownership" of the merchant marine, the Senate Commerce Committee today reported a Ship Subsidy Bill intended to replace existing ocean-mail contracts.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- A permanent low-cost housing and slum-clearance program with Federal assistance to local bodies through grants and loans is provided in a bill introduced today by Senator Wagner, as the outcome of six months' conferences between housing experts both inside and outside the government and the heads of the government financial agencies.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- The government will speed its reply in a suit testing the constitutionality of the Federal gift tax which was brought by Lammot du Pont before the Federal District Court in Wilmington, Del., on March 20, attorneys of the Department of Justice said today.

A smiling, pretty girl of 17 was revealed yesterday as the person who smuggled a pistol into the Bronx County Jail Annex so that her brother, awaiting sentence for robbery as a second offender, could try to force his way out Tuesday night. It was the brother and his companion in the attempted escape who informed on the girl yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 3. -- Jack Medica, giant star from the University of Washington and the Washington A.C. of Seattle, turned on a withering burst of speed in the last twenty yards tonight to beat Ralph Gilman of Ohio State University and retain his national senior A.A.U. indoor 220-yard free-style title.

TRENTON, N.J., April 3. -- Again it was an unbelieving crowd that gathered behind the police lines outside the New Jersey State prison tonight to wait for the death of Bruno Richard Hauptmann. It was a smaller crowd than that of last Tuesday, when the people, men, women and children, lingered there, refusing to believe the police when they shouted "Reprieved."

District Attorney William C. Dodge announced yesterday he had ordered subpoenas issued for a grand jury investigation on Monday of the death of Louis Feldstein, who plunged from the fourteenth floor of the Park Central Hotel last Saturday forenoon after being indicted as a job fixer.

Three players and thirty-one horses yesterday headed toward what promises to be the most important London polo season in years when two members of C.B. Wrightsman's Texas Rangers, entered in the British open championship, and Robert E. Strawbridge Jr., leader of the American international team, sailed from New York for England.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP). -- An investigation by Ambassador Hugh S. Gibson and his staff at Rio de Janeiro was demanded today by Representative Mareantonio in a resolution as the aftermath of the violent death of Victor A. Barron in the Brazilian capital March 5.

The formation of a Public Affairs Committee to make available to the public information regarding public affairs and to place at the disposal of educational agencies some of the resources of existing research institutions was announced yesterday.

Enactment into law at this session of Congress of the Robinson Patman Price Discrimination Bill was predicted yesterday by Representative Patman in an address before the conference of the International Association of Sales Executives at the Hotel Biltmore.

BERLIN, April 3. -- The German Economist, a periodical that is often regarded as the mouthpiece of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics, turns in a sharp leading article against the "chatter" at home and abroad regarding an impending change in Dr. Schacht's position and coming devaluation.

BOWIE, Md., April 3. -- Whether Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt has a Kentucky Derby threat in the Display colt Winter Sport will be demonstrated tomorrow when the Rowe Memorial Handicap is run with this fellow scheduled to make his seasonal debut.
PITTSBURGH, April 3. -- Two young students have been married here under a unique "romance agreement" which permits them to return to college without facing the necessity of maintaining a home.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 3. -Chancellor Wolcott today issued a rule requiring the Equity Corporation to appear on May 8 to defend an action to impress a trust brought against it by R. Emmet O'Malley, Superintendent of Insurance of Missouri, and the General American Life Insurance Company.

Net assets of the Lehman Corporation, investment trust managed by Lehman Brothers, were $82,902,665, equivalent to $121.25 a share, on March 31, according to the quarterly report issued yesterday. This was after deducting the dividend of 75 cents a share payable today and after deducting $4,930,000, or $7.21 a share, for a reserve for Federal and State taxes based on unrealized appreciation on investments and for management compensation.

Reports on the state of trade and industry continue encouraging; less attention, marketwise, is being paid to the European political situation, but sufficient unfinished business, legislative and judicial, remains in Washington to operate as a check on unbridled bullish enthusiasm.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- The Right Rev. Joseph M. Corrigan, rector of St. Charles Seminary at Overbrook, Pa., has been appointed by the Holy See rector of the Catholic University of America, succeeding the Most Rev. James Hugh Ryan, Bishop of Omaha.

Dr. Walter Damrosch, appearing in the dual role of conductor and composer, directed an orchestra of eighty pieces in the special music appreciation hour arranged by him and the National Broadcasting Company in honor of the Music Educators National Conference, yesterday morning at the Metropolitan Opera House.
