Thousands of us have just had the wonderful experience of listening to performances of Beethoven, Wagner, Tchaikovsky and others led by David Mannes in the great rotunda of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

A flat refusal to accept any interpretation of the block rule as sought by Eastern coaches was the most important step taken by the National Association of Basketball Coaches as it concluded its convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

Successfully opening the defense of his Class A singles crown, Kenneth J. Ridgway of the Garden City Casino recorded one of the feature triumphs as play started yesterday at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory in the annual metropolitan badminton championships with more than 200 entrants in six divisions.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- The salary of Charles M. Schwab, chairman of the board and director of Bethlehem Steel Corporation for 1935 at $203,332 represented a cut of $46,668 from the flat $250,000 that he received in the previous year, according to the annual report of the corporation filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The annual report of the Ohio Public Service Company and its subsidiary for 1935, issued yesterday, shows a net profit of $1,974,231 after all deductions, equivalent to $14.33 a share on 137,697 combined shares of preferred stock, against $1,821,578, or $13.23 a share in 1934.

ADDIS ABABA, April 3. -- The next few weeks hold fateful possibilities for the whole world. It is clear in that period Ethiopia will either lose the war or by a superhuman heroic effort postpone its end.

Declaring that there has been an "eclipse of the American idea" in recent years, Miss Helen Varick Boswell, veteran national Republican leader among women, urged a group of women yesterday to conduct a campaign along party lines and minimize "personalities."

BERLIN, April 3. -- The Boerse continued today to go around in circles without developing anything that could be regarded as a price tendency. The opening was fairly firm, but the closing, as so often lately, was slightly weaker.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 3. -- The Yankee baseball machine exposed itself to chilblains and frost-bite at Ponce de Leon Park today to keep an exhibition date with the Atlanta Crackers before a gathering of exactly 180.

CHICAGO, April 3. -- Revision of taxing and of chartering of banks was urged today as part of a comprehensive program for maintaining soundness of the nation's banking structure as fundamentals were stressed in the final day of the American Bankers Association midWest conference on banking service.

Extensive alterations to the street system at the Brooklyn end of the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges to facilitate the movement of traffic from Manhattan, relieve road congestion in the Brooklyn business center and aid plans for the proposed 1939 New York World's Fair were approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 3 (AP). -- A sensational strike-burst in the final game netting 1,169 carried the Birk Brothers of Chicago into third place in the American Bowling Congress tournament tonight with a 3,047 total.

Apartment and business properties were included in the urban realty turnover reported yesterday. Max losenfeld and Isadore B. Geller, operators, sold through their liverside Drive Corporation a fivestory house for thirty-nine families at 2,504 Olinville Avenue, the Bronx.

CLARKSDALE, Miss., April 3. -A determined bid on the part of our Giants, which began away back in Pensacola on March 13, was crowned with success today when the Terrymen tripped the Indians by a score of 6 to 5 and finally drew even in this marathon series.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- Senator Borah, on the heels of the New York primary, said today that he plans to center his attack upon the alleged control of the Republican party by "big business" when he invades the Middle West next week for a speaking tour.

A unique method of defrauding the government out of liquor taxes was charged yesterday in an indictment returned by a Federal grand jury against twelve men and four corporations who were accused of hoaxing retailers and the consuming public on an extensive scale.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange declined 2 to 7 points yesterday despite the absence of relief in dry areas west of the Mississippi River and favorable weekly statistics. An advance in foreign quotations brought some improvement at the opening, but a flood of selling later influenced the course of the market.

Professor Smith and Professor Barry, in their treatise "A Discussion of Public Higher Education," have stated succinctly the problems affecting public education of college students and affecting the financial administration of public higher education in the City of New York.

More than 20,000 soldiers, sailors and members of veterans' and patriotic organizations are scheduled to march in the city's eighth annual Army Day parade this afternoon. About 175,000 spectators are expected.

MAIMI, April 3. -- President Roosevelt today put aside the deep-sea fishing tackle he had used for ten days during a fishing cruise in the waters of the Bahamas and turned to a light rod and line, with which he went casting for the elusive bonefish.

The Class I railroads had an increase of 17.9 per cent in gross revenues and one of 27.8 per cent in net operating income in February, the Association of American Railroads announced yesterday. This brought the gain in net for the first two months of the year to 43.8 per cent.

Pia Damerini, a pianist from Milan, Italy, made her New York debut in a recital last night at the Town Hall in a program of which the chief items consisted of the Schubert "Wanderer" fantasie and a group of six Chopin etudes. Miss Damerini studied with Appiani at the Milan Conservatory, where she won the Countess Durini prize, and later became a pupil of Leopold Godowsky.
The nation's sports editors and baseball writers have made the Tigers prime favorites to win the American League pennant for the third successive year.

With advertising volume for the first quarter of this year registering substantial gains, the total for 1930 will be the largest since 1930, according to opinions expressed here yesterday. Practically all media have shared in the upturn and with both industrial production and retail trade running consistently ahead of 1935, advertising should make further gains this year.

The third Easter dance in the series of Dolphin Dances, inaugurated a few years ago as a revival of the old Patriarch Dances, took place last night in the main ballroom of the Pierre. The parties are given for debutantes of the coming season, enabling them to meet many of the girls who already have been introduced to society.

Even if an apple a day is supposed to cause unemployment in the medical profession, physicians seem to bear no grudge against fruit from a purely esthetic point of view, for it is one of the popular subjects at the ninth annual exhibition of the New York Physicians Art Club at the New York Academy of Medicine, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street.

PARIS, April 3. -- A beginning was made today in Paris at framing what was called a "constructive reply" to the German peace proposals in place of the blank negative that has thus far issued from the Quai d'Orsay. It is going to take some weeks to mature and may not be presented to the world until after the French elections, April 26 and May 3.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 3 (AP). -- Richard Cramer, New York Negro, tonight won the 135-pound class title in the national amateur junior boxing tournament before 6,500 spectators.

A complete collapse of Senator William E. Borah's Presidential boom in the East was seen yesterday by Republican leaders as almost certain to follow the result of Thursday's primary election in this State.

A blessing is pronounced upon peacemakers, but they often have to wait a long time before getting and enjoying it. The first effect of their intervening in a personal quarrel, or in an international dispute, is frequently to be denounced and even hated by both sides. The British Government is just now going through this experience.

As a substitute for the proposed Park Revenues Fund the Board of Estimate voted yesterday to advance $750,000 for recreation facilities in city parks and playgrounds, with the understanding that park revenues would amortize the amount.

Within ten minutes after Mayor La Guardia had vetoed yesterday the Lyons City Residence Bill affecting relief workers, Democratic members of the Board of Estimate took the lead in overriding his veto by a vote of eleven to five.

MIAMI, Fla., April 3. -- Fred Coppa's Boocap, an elderly member of the claiming brigade, raced to her second straight victory in a week when she easily subdued five opponents in the Indian Creek Purse, the mile and a sixteenth feature today at Tropical Park.

Reconnoitering along the fishing front: All roads, as the saying goes, lead to Troutland today. . . . And though Winter lingers in the lap of Spring, the fisherman cares not a whit. . . . Winds may bite and sting, skies may glower and hide the sun, but what of it?

DES MOINES, April 3 (AP). -- Iowa Democrats, in convention here today, reaffirmed faith in President Roosevelt, assailed the Liberty League, and pledged the President the State's twenty-two national convention votes.

The Left Wing faction of the Socialist party, led by Norman Thomas, scored a decisive victory over the Old Guard in the party primary in New York City yesterday and seemed to be certain of a majority in the State committee.

The Whitney Museum of American Art announces that it will open, with a preview next Tuesday afternoon, two exhibitions, one devoted to paintings by David G. Blythe, the other to drawings by Joseph Boggs Beale. Both of them are little-known Pennsylvania artists.

Arbitration of minimum wages for elevator operators and other building service employes before Ferdinand A. Silcox, Assistant Secretary of Agriculture, sitting at the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street, was interrupted yesterday morning by a clash between Walter Gordon Merritt, counsel for the Realty Advisory Board, and James J. Bambrick, president of Local 32-B, Building Service Employes International Union.

The 107th Infantry, former Seventh Regiment, one of the oldest National Guard units in the United States, paraded last night in honor of the centennial of its Park Avenue neighbor, the Union Club -- the nation's oldest social club -- at the regimental armory, Sixty-sixth Street and Park Avenue.

Judge Mortimer W. Byers, in the United States District Court, in Brooklyn, reserved decision yesterday on an application to approve the plans for reorganization of the James Butler Grocery Company, which operates 483 retail stores in the metropolitan district.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 3. -- Mayor Pedro Ernesto Baptista was arrested tonight and held a prisoner in the military police barracks. A communique stated that an investigation by police authorities revealed that Ernesto Baptista had helped organize the November revolt against the government.

Rising above the comparative totals back to 1930, retail sales throughout the country this week were estimated at 15 to 20 per cent over the volume for the corresponding period last year, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Condon gave a farewell dinner last night in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador before sailing today on the Ile de France for their home in Chartres, France.
TRENTON, N.J., April 3. -- An hour and ten minutes before the execution tonight of Bruno Richard Hauptmann, Governor Harold G. Hoffman denied a reprieve.

A large turnout of music makers and nocturnal notables is expected tomorrow night for the supper show at the Hollywood Restaurant to bid farewell to Abe Lyman, the orchestra leader and part owner of the spot, who will conclude his engagement there. (It is possible, too, that Mr. Lyman will conclude his connection with the Hollywood shortly.)

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, last night predicted government ownership and operation of railroads in this country. He spoke before more than 1,200 trade unionists and Socialists at the twelfth anniversary dinner of The New Leader, a Socialist publication, in Webster Hall, 119 East Eleventh Street.

The total of new State and municipal financing scheduled for next week is $24,613,225, representing three States and fifty-six municipalities. The revised total for this week is $31,794,215. The weekly average for the year to date is $23,614,494.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 3. -- Incomplete Socialist primary returns at the Westchester Bureau of Elections tonight showed the Norman Thomas faction of the party had overwhelmed the Old Guard opposition in this county.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today granted exemptions from the holding-company provisions of the Public Utility Act of 1935 to seven more companies and their public-utility subsidiaries.

TRENTON, April 3. -- Bruno Richard Hauptmann's last wish, as well as his last statement "for publication," were revealed tonight in a joint statement by the ministers who were with him at the end. The wish was that his body be cremated.

TRENTON, April 3. -- Silent to the end except for renewed declarations of his innocence, Bruno Richard Hauptmann was put to death by the State of New Jersey tonight for the murder of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr.

More than a year elapsed between the conviction of BRUNO RICHARD HAUPTMANN and his execution last night for the crime of which a New Jersey jury found him guilty. In that year the fairness of his conviction was weighed, and weighed again. In the calm, unhurried atmosphere of the Court of Errors and Appeals fourteen judges heard a restatement of the case in oral and written argument.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- A charge that Daniel W. MacCormack, Commissioner of Immigration, had suppressed vital information in reporting to Congress the records of aliens allowed to remain in the country contrary to the deportation laws vas made today by Senator Reynolds.

The so-called "digger" or "crane" machines, which displaced pin-ball machines in sportland centers and amusement halls after the courts ruled that the pin-ball machines are gambling devices, also fell afoul of the law yesterday when the Appellate Division reversed a decision by Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer in a suit by the International Mutoscope Reel Company, Inc., and other manufacturers of the machines against Police Commissioner Valentine.

KAMENZ, Saturday, April 3. -Bruno Richard Hauptmann's mother learned an hour after his execution that her son had paid the final penalty for the murder of the Lindbergh baby. She appeared at the door of her house almost at once when a reporter came with the news from Trenton.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 3 (AP). -- George T. Dunlap Jr. of New York, seeking his fifth North and South amateur championship and his fourth consecutive one, will meet A.C. Giles of New York tomorrow for the title. The final is set for thirty-six holes.

GREENSBORO, N.C., April 3 (AP). -Two storm-ravaged cities and a number of smaller communities made burial plans tonight for forty dead left amid millions of dollars' damage by windstorms which struck Florida and Alabama before descending in full force on Georgia and the Carolinas yesterday and last night.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 3. -- Robert Tyre Jones Jr., the man who had the golf world at his feet until he retired in 1930 after winning the four major championships for the first and only time such a feat has been performed, started his comeback today with disappointing results.
TRENTON, N.J., April 3. -- The demand for an investigation of Governor Harold G. Hoffman's activities in the Hauptmann case met with the Executive's approval today.

IT'S good news these days to hear that a young fellow has found a job. Even so, as W. Lawson Little stepped into his new position he made a disquieting statement in his inaugural speech. A great golfer himself, he said he was now going to devote his immediate future to enlarging and improving the golf game of citizens in general.

PASSAIC, N.J., April 3. -- Eleven-year-old Michael Koroteff was charged with the murder of his mother by the police here today. The police said the boy confessed he deliberately shot his mother in their home at 215 Monroe Street because he feared she was going to whip him.

Price movements continued mixed on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. Coffee, sugar, bacon, silk and hide futures were strong. On the cash markets butter and cocoa advanced, while declines appeared in wheat, corn and rye, cotton, lard, printcloths, wool-tops, rubber and tins.
New bond financing this week amounted to $62,942,000, compared with $194,557,000 last week, and with $61,229,000 a year ago this week.

Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the six months ended on Jan. 31 a profit of $2,822,625 after depreciation, interest, income and profits taxes and other deductions.
. S. Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Play in the preliminaries of the United States chess championship tournament was resumed last night when matches were begun at the rooms of the Manhattan, Marshall, Empire City and Queens Chess Clubs.

Prices of bonds were irregularly higher in dull trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The market, as a whole, was unable to shake off its recent lethargy and, with the exception of a few individual price fluctuations, movements, in most cases, were confined to fractions.

Taking advantage of every technical loophole discovered, Charles (Lucky) Luciana fought off yesterday attempts in court to transfer him from Hot Springs, Ark., to Little Rock for extradition proceedings.

Many of us love a rebel, on condition that he is not successful and thereby stripped of his romantic character. It was a gallant enterprise of the New York friends of Mr. BORAH to try and elect delegates pledged to his nomination; and it is not necessaly to inquire whether any personal dislikes born of lingering quarrels among the local magnificoes of the party colored that enterprise.

CHICAGO, April 3. -- The thirty-fifth annual show of the Chicago Kennel Club opened today with an entry of 800 dogs, representing fifty-nine breeds. The judging assignments for the early part of the day were in the hands of Walter H. Reeves of Canada, J.G. Murphy of St. Paul and Mrs. Robert Stein of Detroit.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

Details of the plan for developing a sports center and a four-mile automobile racing course on part of Roosevelt Field at Mineola, L.I., were revealed yesterday when the sponsors of the project and officials of the aviation field announced the signing of a lease for that section of the property known as Unit 1.

Palm Sunday, which is tomorrow, will be observed in churches of every faith. There will be sermons on the triumphant entry into Jerusalem of Jesus Christ. There will be oratorios of "The Crucifixion," there will be cantatas, and virtually everywhere "The Palms," by Faure, will be sung.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- Construction of two 35,000-ton battleships as replacements for over-age ships and of twelve 7,500-ton six-inch gun cruisers in the next four years was advocated by Admiral William H. Standley, Chief of Naval Operations and Acting Secretary of the Navy, on his return today from the London naval conference.

In spite of official support, believed to have come from the British Equalization Account, the French franc weakened further yesterday to fall once more below the Paris-to-New York gold-shipping point. Other European currencies declined with the franc and the discount on forward contracts in the gold-bloc currencies widened.

A proposal to hold in the city next Spring an International Singing Festival for choirs, glee clubs and concert groups was announced yesterday by the American Choral and Festival Alliance and the Intercollegiate Musical Council.

BERLIN, April 3. -- As time passes and the circumstances of the recent German election begin to become known, not only abroad but also at home, the value of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's 99 per cent majority is becoming more and more problematical.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- The New York Central Railroad expects to save $66,722,150 by 1946 under plans for retiring and refinancing obligations now outstanding and to wipe out $62,900,000 of demand bank loans in the same period, according to statements by officials of the road made public today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Many thousands of dollars' worth of paintings and art objects were damaged last night as the result of a fire that swept through the eighth and ninth floors of the nine-story Beaux Arts Studios, a landmark housing forty-one artists' studios at the southwest corner of Fortieth Street and Sixth Avenue.

The United States Government pressed its drive on crime not with the intention of usurping State and local authorities but to stop interstate traffic in crime, Homer S. Cummings, United States Attorney General, said last night. He spoke before 3,000 members of the three Brooklyn Masonic districts in Kismet Temple, 92 Herkimer Street, Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, April 3. -- A Supreme Court petition today told the justices that a hair's breadth is exactly "one two-hundred-and-fiftieth of an inch," or "four one-thousandths."

MADRID, April 3. -- A Socialist motion stating that, inasmuch as President Niceto Alcala Zamora had already exhausted his constitutional right to dissolve Parliament twice, the newly elected Cortes should judge whether he was justified in having done so, was adopted late tonight by 182 votes to 84.

Presiding Justice Francis Martin of the Appellate Division suggested yesterday from the bench that there should be some board to pass upon the destruction of public buildings, even though they are in parks, before Park Commissioner Robert Moses "becomes a Mussolini."

The attention of the public in the last fortnight has been centered upon the loss of life, the personal accidents and the damage to property caused by the widespread floods. The American Red Cross, which has performed such a vast work of relief on short notice, has for months been preparing for another great service but of a preventive nature -that of helping people to avert accidents in their own homes.
LONDON, April 3. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange today were quiet, but the price undertone remained firm. British funds maintained their levels.

Holders of bonds of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad proposed the sale of part of its control to competing lines, such as the Chicago, Burlington Quincy or the Union Pacific, at a meeting here yesterday. The company is now controlled by the Missouri Pacific and the Western Pacific.

LONDON, April 3. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler has had his innings, but now the diplomatic offensive passes into the hands of France, strongly backed by Great Britain. A consultation of the military and naval staffs will be the forerunner of a general tightening of the Anglo-French entente.
WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP). -The House Committee inquiry into the Townsend pension plan took a new turn tonight when a one-man investigating committee was ordered to the West Coast.

HAVANA, April 3. -- Albatross, the only Cuban yacht in the St. Petersburg (Fla.) to Havana race, reached port late tonight, leaving the Sea Call the only entry unaccounted for. The Cuban craft was delayed by failing winds, according to Dr. H.M. Sardo of Havana, her owner and skipper.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- Registration statements for the issuance of securities involving $95,000,000 by two corporations were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Securities Act of 1933. This lifts the total for two days, including the record filing of $109,000,000 yesterday by Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit and smaller issues, to more than $200,000,000.

Having acquired a definite taste for consecutive victories, the Long Island University Blackbirds continued from where they left off in basketball by adding their third straight baseball triumph yesterday in their opening home contest at Dexter Park.

HAZLETON, Pa., April 3 (AP). -Two men were shot and wounded today at the Spring Mountain stripping operation of the Lehigh Valley Coal Company at Yorktown, in what company sources described as a clash of company police with 200 coal raiders.

MEDFORD, N.J., April 3. -- In the presence of an enthusiastic but chilled gallery the $1,000 Free-for-All Stake, leading event of the annual field trial meeting of the English Setter Club of America, was finished late today. After a second series the honors were awarded to Bill's Dr. Ricks, liver and white pointer dog owned by Clarence Gaines of Sherburne, N.Y., and handled by James Crangle.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP). -- A categorical denial of all House impeachment charges was entered in the Senate today by counsel for Judge Halsted L. Ritter of Florida after Senators, sitting as a court, overruled a defense motion to strike out two articles dealing with alleged "excessive" receivership fees.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP). -- William A. Irvin, president of the United States Steel Corporation, told, the Senate Interstate Com merce Committee today that elimination of the basing-point formula of price determination would "dislocate" industry.

One of Albrecht Durer's masterpieces of engraving, "Adam and Eve," brought $10,000 last night at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., at the auction of fine etchings and engravings collected by Henry Graves Jr. of this city. The 115 lots in the sale yielded a total of $79,635.

In January the Alberta Minister of Finance approved the Loan Council Plan. That is, he agreed that loans or guarantees by the Federal Treasury should be approved by an advisory council consisting of the Dominion Finance Minister, the Provincial Treasurer and the Governor of the Bank of Canada. Prime Minister ABERHART, eager for Federal money to pay a maturing bond issue, stood haughtily on Provincial autonomy.

Edward W. Roemer, Building Commissioner of Boston, Mass., was unanimously re-elected yesterday to the presidency of the Building Officials Conference of America at the closing session of its twenty-first annual convention in the Hotel New Yorker.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers.

Exchanges of checks at the principal clearing houses of the country in March totaled $28,857,690,986, the largest amount for a month since December, 1931. The total represented a gain of 20.2 per cent from February and one of 9.4 per cent from March, 1935.

LONDON, April 3. -- Despite Chancellor Adolf Hitler's continued refusal to grant the British plea for further conciliatory concessions to allay French fears, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden has informed the governments of both Paris and Brussels that he does not yet consider that the negotiations with Berlin to end peacefully the Rhineland episode have failed.

The City of New York has no right to collect a 2 per cent sales tax on gasoline sales under a computation ordered by Controller Taylor which includes the State tax of 4 cents a gallon, the Appellate Division decided yesterday in a suit brought by the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company and nine other leading distributors.
I have been in seven countries and in hundreds of cities, but New York is outstanding in its sidewalk annoyances. Some which are glaringly in evidence are:

Stolidly for the most part, residents of Yorkville, the center of New York's German-American population on the upper East Side, took the news of Bruno Richard Hauptmann's execution without demonstration last night. Crowds had waited patiently about loudspeakers at radio stores.

Dr. Toyohiko Kagawa, Japanese Christian leader, will speak Wednesday at one of the thirteenth annual series of Holy Week noon services to be held at 12:15 P.M. each day next week in the Palace Theatre, Broadway and Forty-seventh Street, by courtesy of the theatre management, under the auspices of the Greater New York Federation of Churches.

Despite some poor selling weather, retail trade in the metropolitan area during the week was active. Estimates indicate that the average volume of department stores here is running about 15 per cent ahead of the same week last year. It was pointed out, however, that with the early Easter this year trade has been moved forward by one week.

BERLIN, April 3. -- In conformity with orders issued by the Propaganga Ministry, the Reich League of German Periodical Publishers, which is part of the Reich Press Chamber, has issued the following instructions to its members, who include the publishers of all newspapers and periodicals:
ASMARA, Eritrea, April 3. -- Emperor Haile Selassie and his Ethiopian forces are passing through an extremely critical period.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 3. -- A jury in Westchester County Court decided late this afternoon it was better to have a red car parked in front of your house bearing large white letters reading "we collect bad debts" than to be subjected to the debt-collecting tactics of lawyers.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 3. -Win, lose or draw, the Dodgers practically completed the first phase of their 1936 campaign when they shook the Florida sand from their spikes and headed north at noon today. Their first destination is Norfolk and their next game at Portsmouth tomorrow, within ferrying distance of the old Virginia seaport.

GREENVILLE, S.C., April 3 (AP). -- Alston H. Garside, economist of the New York Cotton Exchange, proposed today a new form of government control of the cotton-growing industry as a basis for "unprecedented prosperity" for the industry and the South generally.
POTTSVILLE, Pa., April 3. -- George Treskoloski, who spent 48 fear-filled hours with only his head and one arm above a collapsed mass of earth and rock, was saved from death today.

NORTH CONWAY, N.H., April 3 (AP). -- The body of John Winthrop Fowler, 19, a Princeton junior, killed in a plunge down Mount Washington's icy, rock-strewn slope, left here tonight for his New York home, accompanied by an aunt, Mrs. George S. West of Brookline, Mass.

Since the minimum-wage decision was handed down by the New York Court of Appeals the press has been flooded with the lamentations of those who see the downfall of their method of protecting women workers.

In regard to the prevalent idea that the weights carried in horse racing in this country are too low, it is my opinion that the only way in which higher weight can be put into use is for all the tracks in the United States to agree to it.
GENEVA, April 3. -- Japan leads the world in the number of factories licensed to make dangerous drugs for export and is followed by Germany, according to a League of Nations document just issued.

Drawn faces figured prominently yesterday afternoon in the Park Central Hotel, were four teams of contract bridge players survived the quarter-finals after a grueling session of play. When the final scores came in it was established that the four teams from the New York area had earned the right to play in the semi-final round tonight of the annual play for the Grand National championship of the United States Bridge Association.

HUDSON, N.Y., April 3 (AP). -- The Federal Government rushed food into Hudson tonight to feed hundreds of relief clients cut off from home relief by the City Charities Commission because of lack of funds.

A lien assessing a tax of $788,114.37 for unpaid income taxes was filed in Federal court here yesterday against John R. Geary of Philadelphia, Pa., who was former president of the General Electric Company of Japan. The document was sent by William H. Kelly, Internal Revenue Collector for Newark.

About 3,500 relief workers with three or more dependents, who were dropped from WPA rolls in the reduction which will embrace 40,000 by June 1, were reinstated yesterday because their dismissal had been attributed to a misunderstanding.
MOSCOW, April 3. -- A new method of studying the substratosphere by a glider train was successfully demonstrated here today, although there was an accident that might have resulted disastrously.

Inquiries about ticket arrangements for the third annual Princeton Invitation Track Meet to be held in Palmer Stadium on Saturday, June 13, indicate that misunderstanding exists. The following questions and answers have been evolved in an effort to clear up the most common misconceptions:

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., April 3. -- White Plains (N.Y.) High School earned its right to play in the final of the Eastern States basketball tournament tomorrow night when it defeated LaSalle Academy tonight, 32 -- 29.

In a brilliant show, jammed to the utmost with thrills, spectacular playing and the most amazing shot-making ever seen in New York, the final Olympic basketball tryouts sped away from the starting mark in Madison Square Garden last night while a crowd of 12,000 sat spellbound through six hours.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- Testimony that Alfred E. Smith Jr. has worked "conscientiously" as attorney and vice president of the Golden Stakes Corporation for $5,200 a year, and was not employed to give "respectability" to the organization, was given at a Post-office Department hearing today.

It was the late Judge Edward J. Welsh who ran the third leg for i Fordham in its match relay race with Syracuse at Troy on Feb. 22, 1912, and not 3//agistrate Jack Sullivan, as John Iieran says in a recent column.

OMAHA, Neb., April 3. -- The Corn Belt country schoolhouse is doing double duty these days. Where the farmers' boys and girls learn the three R's in the daytime the farmer himself is being instructed in the 1936 revision of the three A's in the evening.

PARIS. AS a result of the controversy which has arisen over the restoration of one of Rembrandt's paintings, the Louvre has announced the creation of a new board of control to direct the care of paintings and the creation of a school for instruction in the art of restoration.

MIAMI, Fla., April 4. -- Bright Plumage, stout-hearted son of Macaw and Beaming that is pointed to bear the colors of C.V. Whitney in the Kentucky Derby, raced to a handy victory in the second running of the Derby Consolation Stakes, the mile and a furlong feature of the final racing program of the ninety-six-day Florida season, witnessed by 18,000 at Tropical Park today.

Adverse action last week by the Assembly on her bill to make desertion grounds for divorce in New York State has halted only the legislative phase of her activities, Assemblywoman Jane Todd of Westchester declared yesterday. Her fight for easier divorce laws, she revealed, will be carried on through the formation of a citizens committee which will be a nucleus for the opponents of the present statutes.

A request by the Triborough Bridge Authority to permit a forty-hour-a-week schedule on the Randalls Island junction of the Triborough Bridge has been denied by the Public Works Administration, headed by Secretary Harold L. Ickes.

TOO many people think of Louis XIV only in the role of pompous dalliance. They forget the sober, dignified man of business, the distinguished patron of the theatre and fine arts, the patron of vast engineering exploits, of improvements in a big way, the clever diplomatist, and above all, the great lover of France, the indefatigable aspirant to the Left Bank of the Rhine.

WHETHER deliberately or not, Miss Hull has chosen an incongruous title for this volume of short stories. Her characters, almost without exception, are quintessentially common place. They are the kind of homely, typical people whom one meets in small towns and in suburban flats.

An exhibition of the art work in the elementary and junior high schools which opened last week at the Museum of Natural History will continue through April 20. On April 16 pupils will demonstrate easel painting, block printing, modeling, soap carving and metal craft.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., April 4. -- The navy's new airplane carrier Yorktown, the largest craft ever built by the United States for that particular purpose, rode at anchor in the James River tonight, where for the next twelve months it will rise and fall with the tides as a small army of workmen completes the installation of equipment and armament to make it one of the most formidable of American warships.

SERIOUS airline accidents within the last two years have caused much public discussion of safety in the air and unfounded rumors as to the cause of these misfortunes. The Bureau of Air Commerce has investigated each of these accidents thoroughly, and of the thirteen fatal crashes on which it has reported since authorized nearly two years ago to make accident findings public, only one was unsolvable or remained mysterious.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP). -- The story of a "beautiful and extraordinarily passionate" girl and her tragic affair with a "singing and guitar-playing lady killer" came before the Supreme Court today in a copyright suit.

THE bloody business of Shakespeare's "Macbeth" has found itself re-enacted upon a great many stages and under a variety of peculiar circumstances since that monstrous tragedy first fell into the public domain some three hundred years ago.

OTTAWA, April 3. -- Alberta having defaulted on her $32,000,000 bond maturity and the Dominion Government having let her default, two questions are now agitating the minds of Federal politicians and Eastern financiers. One is the possible effect on Dominion credit of this first default by a Canadian Province.

IT is again planting time in the South; the lethargy that has hovered over the land since the last cotton was ginned has gone. From the county agent's office in town word has gone out that the government is going to have another "program." In the plantation country this means that farmers will again be paid for planting less cotton.
In rising for twelve consecutive months, the stock market has broken a twenty-five-year record for a sustained upward movement.

IN America it has always seemed wisest and easiest to forget the troublesome race problem. That there are Japanese and Chinese on the West Coast, Indians and Mexicans in the Southwest, and Negroes both North and South every one knows.

The narrator and central character in this story is Henry Prince, sometimes known as Royal. He is the leader of a band of crooks whose operations he directs, but he is not content to play the role of a general behind the lines. When a job requires particular finesse he does it in person.

AMHERST, Mass., April 4. -- The notion held by some that Phi Beta Kappa men are merely bookworms and that varsity athletes may be the uneducated products of boiler factories and shipyards is disproved by the athletic attainments of a large proportion of the Amherst College students recently elected to Phi Beta Kappa.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 4. -- Elizabeth Myers, a junior at the New Jersey College for Women, was today elected editor-in-chief of Campus News, bi-weekly undergraduate publication, to succeed Marion Short. Miss Myers will go into office immediately following the Spring recess.

At hearings held by the Ways and Means Committee last week the critics of the new tax program -- of which the major point is a proposal to set up a new system of taxing corporations by levying against their undivided profits -- had their opportunity to state the reasons for their opposition.

Scoring six runs, five of them with two out, in the eighth inning, St. John's University overtook the Wagner College nine and triumphed, 10 -- 7, yesterday at Sisco Park, Port Richmond, S.I., in the season's inaugural for both teams.

In this season of early robins the Department of Sanitation -- visions of January's ice-clogged streets still with it -- is preparing a $7,500,000 campaign of attack on the snows of next Winter. The department will ask for an appropriation to buy some thousand new pieces of equipment in an attempt to make a clean sweep of its snow problem.

In the several States the laws provide varied machinery for testing and expressing the sentiment of political parties. Most of it lies readiest to the hands of members of the regular organizations. They hold the key positions. They know how to operate the apparatus. Party primaries, and even "Presidential preference" primaries, are to them little more than added cards with which to play the old political game.

EASTON, Pa., April 4. -- The annual conference of college and university trustees will be held at Lafayette College April 24. Members of governing boards of sixty institutions in the East will attend.

During the past week the House Ways and Means Committee has held hearings at Washington upon certain proposals made by the subcommittee on taxation for the revision of income taxes affecting undistributed incomes of corporations.

LONDON, April 4. -- Scotland added another cup to is soccer trophies today. Drawing 1 -- 1 with England in a thrilling encounter at Wembley Stadium, as 90,000 persons looked on, the Scots won the international championship outright for the seventeenth time and became the first possessors of the trophy awarded by the Football Association in commemoration of the late King George's silver jubilee.

Armand Tokatyan, former Metropolitan tenor, gave a recital last night at Town Hall, under the auspices of the New York City Cancer Committee of the American Society for the Control of Cancer. The benefit was attended by a large audience which applauded the artist strenuously after each and all of his offerings.

It is the fashion these days to divide the great powers into two classes: (1) the satisfied statics, or haves, and (2) the dissatisfied dynamics, or have-nots. In the second class are Germany, Italy and Japan, nations which have in common certain characteristics, such as strongly centralized government, strongly felt grievances and strongly evidenced faith in airplanes, artillery and machine guns.

Fred Bornemann, a sportsman interested in conserving salt water fishes, recently sent this column a letter in which he propounded a number of questions regarding the New York Conservation Department's jurisdiction over the marine district.

Cardinal Hayes issued a pastoral yesterday to the clergy of the Archdiocese of New York announcing that the annual collection for the maintenance of Cathedral College, Madison Avenue and Fifty-first Street, will be taken at all Easter services.

A VOLUME in which is discussed the art of Raphael, particularly his "Stanza" in the Vatican, has just been issued by Colonel Vincenzo Janni. It represents, he tells us in a foreword, "the realization of a long-cherished desire to undertake a strenuous campaign on behalf of the spread of Italian art in America.
The Philharmonic-Symphony Society disclosed yesterday that it is now negotiating with a conductor, whose name was not revealed, to direct the first part of its 1936-37 season.

Two organizations of women interested in civil affairs have issued what amounts to a challenge to James E. Finegan, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, to bring before the public the matter of his proposed ruling that women will not be permitted to take the forthcoming civil service examination for court attendants.

ISTANBUL, April 4. -- March 16 was the fifteenth anniversary of the signature of the first Turco-Soviet treaty of friendship. The occasion was celebrated in Ankara by a reception and dinner given by the Foreign Office when speeches were made by the acting Turkish Foreign Minister and Lev Michailovich Karakhan, the Soviet Ambassador.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- An ingenious plan for disposing by next September of at least 1,000,000 bales of government-owned cotton, on which the administration expects to have a minimum loss of $10,000,000, was announced today by the Commodity Credit Corporation.

Marionettes, from the simple fist puppets that can be handled by 9 and 10 year olds, to the elaborate contrivances worked by strings, are an engrossing hobby nowadays for many boys and girls. It is natural, therefore, that puppets and puppet makers should begin to figure in fiction.

NEW LONDON, Conn., April 4 (AP). -- The undefeated New York University rifle team won the New England regional intercollegiate rifle championship today with a score of 1,362. The match at the Coast Guard Academy was one of five meets conducted by the National Rifle Association to determine the United States intercollegiate titleholder.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- The Yearbook of Agriculture, the first of its kind ever published, will be issued within the next two weeks by the Department of Agriculture, Secretary Henry A. Wallace announced today. The book will summarize the results of a world-wide survey of "superior germplasms" in the plant and animal kingdoms.
City College's varsity lacrosse team opened its 1936 schedule at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday by vanquishing the Savage Institute ten, 17 to 9.

ST. LOUIS, April 4 (AP). -- Representative James W. Wadsworth of New York asserted in an address thought before the John Marshall Republican Club that compulsory forcement of the New Deal policy -- "the way of Hitler and Mussolini" -- was at the heart of the Roosevelt administration.

LONDON, March 23. THERE exists among many people an unfortunate and, in its effects, a dangerous impression that those who do not share their political views are dangerous lunatics. Particularly is this true when the subject discussed is one of those that invite men to submit their opinions to their temperament rather than to their intellect -- for example, the subject of peace and how best it may be safeguarded.

Retail business continued at a good pace last week, sustaining wholesale activity in the markets here, according to a report prepared especially for THE TIMES by the McGreevey, Werring Howell Co., resident buyers. Pre-Easter store volume was reported up to expectations.

NEW LONDON, Conn., April 4. -Studies of phases of city life in New London which will provide private and public welfare agencies with useful information are being made by a group of Connecticut College students. Under the direction of Dr. Charles G. Chakerian of the social science faculty a sociology class is collecting the data as part of a practical course on social trends.

PASSAIC, N.J., April 4. -- Eleven-year-old Michael Korotaeff, who shot and killed his mother because he feared she was going to whip him, was officially charged with murder today despite the objection of a probation officer in whose custody the child has been placed.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- The refusal of several world powers to release important State papers until they had aged into "history" was declared today to be the reason for delay of 15 years or more in publication of American diplomatic documents.

WHAT does a violin prodigy do during a two-year sabbatical? Yehudi Menuhin intends to rest and study. He is taking a trunkful of scores to the ranch in the Santa Cruz Mountains in California on which the family is to live during the withdrawal from public activity.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 4. -- Legal definition of a public enemy class to conform to the definition which now exists by virtue of public consciousness of the modern crime problem was recommended here today at the closing session of a two-day conference on crime.

MOSCOW, April 4. -- Every foot of land in the Soviet Union belongs to the State, and the sale, rental or mortgaging of land is absolutely forbidden by the statute by which land was nationalized. Here the land is in exactly the same category as the air -- it is for the public use and free.

Moscow, March 10, 1936. DMITRI SHOSTAKOVICH, Soviet Russia's outstanding young composer, whose opera "Lady Macbeth" has been acclaimed the first successful Soviet opera, was recently denounced in a special editorial of the Pravda, official newspaper of the Communist party.

The Ward Line has made an offer totaling $1,250,000 to more than 400 claimants against the company for damages and losses suffered in the Morro Castle and Mohawk disasters, and the offer has been informally accepted, it was learned yesterday.

NASSAU, Bahamas. -- Winter seasonal activities in Nassau will end on Friday when the Fort Montagu Beach Hotel closes with a mystery ball in the Jungle Club. The British Colonial Hotel and most of the clubs that cater to tourists closed during the past week.

The Merchants' Truckmen's Bureau defended yesterday its opposition to the proposed free trucking of freight by the Eastern railroads to and from their terminals, on the ground that the service would benefit a small group of shippers but create higher rates for others.

TIENTSIN. -- A by-product of the disturbed conditions in North China has been the growth of smuggling. It is carried on with open audacity and on a scale which not only defrauds the Chinese Government of much revenue but threatens to extinguish several lines of foreign trade.

WARSAW, April 3. -- Maxim Litvinoff, the Soviet Foreign Commissar, who has been trying to avoid Germany in his diplomatic journeys and has been traveling from London to Paris via Vienna, has just been compelled to spend eighteen hours instead of the usual two in the Polish capital waiting for a train to Moscow.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., April 4. -- Dartmouth's nine defeated Virginia today, 7 to 3, to register its fourth successive victory on its Southern trip.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 4. -Mrs. Vincent Astor of New York, whose estate in St. George's, Ferry Reach, is one of the show places of the island, will exhibit several elaborate displays from her gardens at the Bermuda Flower Show, a feature of the Easter festival, scheduled for a week beginning Tuesday.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., April 4. -Former President Hoover continued his attacks on the New Deal and President Roosevelt here tonight, when he spoke before the Fourth District Republican organization of this city. His address was broadcast over a network of the National Broadcasting Company.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- If this were not an election year, or if budget-balancing promised to be less of a political issue during the Presidential campaign, the new tax program would be given little chance of passage in anything like the form in which it now stands before Congress.

Miss Elisabeth B. McDonald, who was elected last week to her second term as president of the New York alumnae chapter of Kappa Alpha Theta at the annual meeting at the Beekman Tower, has also been named as the chapter's delegate to the national convention to be held at Glacier Park, Montana, in June.
Eleven new playgrounds -- nine in Manhattan, one in the Bronx and one in Brooklyn -- were opened yesterday by the Department of Parks. The playgrounds were constructed entirely with WPA funds.

The contention has frequently been made by the American Federation of Labor and others in recent months that production has been increasing much faster than either employment or "workers' purchasing power." Official indexes of employment and production do not appear to bear out this contention.

AFFRONTED: Arguing that the grandeur properly surrounding the career of a grand opera star had been damaged, Giovanni Martinelli of the Metropolitan Opera brought a $20,000 suit last week against a New York chain of cafeterias.

The lead changed hands nine times in the first half and then the famed McPherson Oilers unleashed the full fury of their devastating whirlwind attack on the University of Washington quintet in Madison Square Garden last night as the National A.A.U. champions advanced to the final of the Olympic basketball tryouts.

ANIMALS in art may be irritating, but as a matter of fact they seldom are. It is not often that an artist essays an animal subject unless he is specially interested in just that creature and, in consequence, does pretty well with it.

ABOUT a century ago Richard Henry Dana, in "Two Years Before the Mast," set a mark at which amateur sailors have now and then shot with varying degrees of success. Since then no bullseyes have been scored, but even an arrow sent in the general direction may be worth following in its course.

LESS than three months hence the Republican party will be called upon to choose a candidate for President, and if present signs hold true the American people, always loving romance, will be treated to another demonstration of the functioning of a free democracy.

ST. PAUL, April 3. -- Two years ago the Farmer-Labor party of Minnesota announced in its platform that it proposed to take immediate steps for the abolition of capitalism and substitution of a "cooperative Commonwealth," in which all natural resources and the entire machinery of production, transportation and finance should be owned by the government.

HAMILTON, Bermuda. -- Although the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club's annual series of races for boats of the six-meter and one-design classes, which started on Wednesday, will continue to occupy the attention of sportsmen for the next ten days, several other social and sporting events are listed for the present week.

Timely hitting following free passes and costly errors by the opposition enabled the Fordham University baseball squad to register a 14-to-1 victory over St. Francis College of Brooklyn at Fordham Field yesterday.

THE newer perennials, most of them improved strains of older varieties, deserve inclusion in every garden. They represent a great advance over their progenitors. One never knows until one tries them what joy can be had from the perennial border.

MYRTLE BEACH, S.C., April 4. -- No waterway improvement in recent years is more important to yachtsmen along the Atlantic Coast than the new canal which will be opened formally next Saturday between Georgetown, S.C., on Winyah Bay and Little River, S.C., near the State line where the two Carolinas meet.

Under the joint sponsorship of a number of civic, church and social organizations a benefit concert to aid the Red Cross relief fund will be staged tonight at 8:30 at the Bronxville Theatre. Mrs. George M. Stiegler, head of the music department of the Bronxville Woman's Club, is chairman of the event.

The Emergency Shelter, a philanthropic institution at 261 Greene Street, will be the beneficiary of a large luncheon and fashion show now being arranged for April 14 in the Caprice Room of the Weylin. Many women of prominence in society are members of a committee of patronesses headed by Mrs. Charles L. Lawrance.

PHILADELPHIA April 4. -- Before a chilled crowd of 800 spectators, Pennsylvania opened the Eastern Intercollegiate League baseball season by defeating Cornell in a free-hitting game on Franklin Field today, 17 to 9.

Although the great mechanical influences of the twentieth century have made New York a relatively horseless city, changes in the keeping of small animals for pets have vastly increased the work of veterinarians and the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP). -- A third of the witnesses for the impeachment trial of Federal Judge Halsted L. Ritter of Florida were excused today because of a change in the charges against the judge. Defense and prosecution released twenty-nine persons who were to have appeared in the trial, which is scheduled for Monday before the Senate.

THE oratory of the auctioneer has challenged many generations of New Yorkers. In the past it waxed on bombastic phrases and tongue-twisting words, and the auctioneer's voice had to be booming and dramatic. Today he speaks into a microphone instead of directly to the bidders, and his sandpaper tones are carried out to the sidewalks.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- An elaborate souvenir program containing a history of the country and a record of activities of the government will be issued by the Democratic National Convention for the Philadelphia convention. Profits will be used to pay expenses of the convention.

WASHINGTON. -- Twenty midshipmen annually will hereafter be appointed by the Secretary of the Navy to the Naval Academy at Annapolis. The candidates for appointment will come from the Naval Reserves Officers Training Corps and from among the honor graduates of the "honor schools" designated each year by the War Department.

THE first privately operated air mail-passenger flight was made ten years ago tomorrow when a pilot on a division of what is now United Air Lines flew from Pasco, Wash., to Elko, Nev., in a single-engined airplane. This marked the withdrawal of the Postoffice Department from the operation of air mail service.

SHERATON-STYLE antique furniture, always appreciated by connoisseurs for its grace and simplicity, fits in especially with this season's decorative vogues because it connotes the first days of the Republic, a period now in fashion, it was contemporary with the early hand-blocked wallpapers, Colonial chintzes and the pottery and decorative accessories now being revived.

DETROIT, April 4. -- Hockey fandom in the "city of champions" is eagerly awaiting tomorrow night and the game that will come with it. More than 14,000 persons, as many as the Olympia will hold, will turn out to see the Detroit Red Wings, champions of the National Hockey League, oppose the Toronto Maple Leafs in the first clash of a three-out-of-five-game series for the Stanley Cup, emblematic of the world's hockey supremacy.

PHILADELPHIA, April 4. -- Five hundred guests danced tonight in costume at the fourth Junior Bal Masque in the Rose Garden of the Bellevue-Stratford. The party was for the benefit of the Bryn Mawr War Memorial and Community House Association, which aids 3,000 children.
In his article in THE TIMES of March 22 Ernest Curran has indeed brought out some interesting food for thought.

ALBANY, April 4. -- Federal Judge Frank Cooper has ruled that a bank stockholder who contributed without obligation to bolster a bank's resources is entitled to be repaid his loan before anything can be distributed to stockholders. The decision was made yesterday in a $25,000 suit brought by Fillmore G. Utley, vice president of the Pulaski National Bank, against Louis J. Clarke, president, and Frederick J. Reasoner, Federal receiver.

MOSCOW, April 4. -- The dismissal of 250 mine managers and their replacement by Stakhanoffist workers will be the answer of the Communist party and the Commissariat for Heavy Industry to opposition to the Stakhanoffist movement in the Donetz Basin coal fields.

The one interest of Great Britain in Ethiopia is Lake Tana, a sheet about an eighth as large as Lake Erie, source of the Blue Nile, a stream which supplies not only 70 per cent of the water that flows into the Nile at Khartum, center of the irrigated cotton-growing region of the Sudan and Egypt, but also most of the silt, without which there would be no cotton.

MIAMI. -- "Cavalcade," the musical extravaganza marking the centennial of Dade County, will be staged in Bayfront Park here tomorrow and Wednesday. The production, which will employ music and dancing to depict Dade County's history since its founding in 1836, will be featured by an abundance of queens.
Behind the splendid hurling of Sam Altman, freshman, formerly of Stuyvesant High, the Brooklyn College nine shut out the alumni, 4 -- 0, in the season's opener at Manhattan Beach yesterday.

Members of society are evidencing much interest in the fashion show, "Styles of a Century," which will be given in conjunction with a luncheon, Tuesday, in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Generosity Thrift Shop. Fashions from 1836 to the present day will be displayed by young matrons and debutantes of recent seasons headed by Miss Josephine T. Terry.

More than 3,000 relief recipients and employes and WPA workers marched up Broadway from the Battery to City Hall early yesterday afternoon, held a mass meeting around the Benjamin Franklin statue in Printers Square and then dispersed. There was no disorder.

SMITHTOWN BRANCH, L.I., April 4. -- The trout season opened at the Wyandanch Club this morning with more than twenty members from the metropolitan area in area in attendance. Each caught attendance. Each caught his quota before 9 o'clock.

VIENNA, April 4. -- Austria's defiance of the St. Germain treaty ban on conscription is of greater internal than external significance. Nobody believes the increased military forces available to defend 6,000,000 Austrians will deter any action that Germany with her 66,000,000 population might intend.

TWO new buildings, the remodeling of another and the renovation of one campus would be practically all the physical alterations necessary to set up the proposed new "University of the City of New York," with five separate undergraduate colleges, three professional schools and a program of graduate education, in the opinion of Edward L. Smith and Charles P. Barry, the two professors who made the recent report on the subject.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 4. -Appointment of Professor B. Alden Thresher as director of admissions at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology was announced tonight. Dr. Thresher will succeed Dr. Tryon, who retires this year after serving sixteen years as a member of the administration.

DOUGLAS CHURCHILL, in some of his recent bulletins from Hollywood, has had occasion to refer to Arthur Caesar, who made the justly celebrated remark about changing the outcome of the Battle of Waterloo to suit the whim of a film producer.

One million books for re-distribution to hospitals, institutions, churches and charitable organizations are being sought in a campaign by the Book Sharing Week committee, which has as co-chairman Mrs. Sherman Post Haight and Warden Lewis E. Lawes. Mayor La Guardia is ex-officio chairman of the drive, which will culminate with Book Sharing Week April 16-23.
The Metropolitan Golf Association introduced additional testimony yesterday to golfing fans that the Spring tournament season is not far away.

BASLE, Switzerland, April 4. -Striking evidence of how extremely short of money Germany has become is seen here in the unprecedented fact that the governor-members of the World Bank board will hold their monthly meeting tomorrow across the frontier, in Badenweiler, Germany.

While the aggregate production of all types of foodstuffs is likely to be higher this year, the improvement in business in general will lead to an increase in consumption, with the result that prices will hold close to their present levels, according to an analysis completed yesterday by the American Institute of Food Distribution, Inc.

INDISPENSABLE is a fit adjective to apply to this book for readers who want to understand the governmental systems in the news and who want a background for the explanatory articles about them that march incessantly through the monthly magazines.
CHICAGO, April 4 (AP). -- Traffic policing was stepped up in the educational scale to the rank of a graduate course today by Northwestern University, a pioneer in the field of accident control.

GENEVA, April 4. -- In a surprise move backed by Great Britain, Salvador de Madariaga, chairman, tonight convoked the League Committee of Thirteen to meet here Wednesday to consider Italian aggression in Ethiopia. Wednesday is the day Pierre-Etienne Flandin, French Foreign Minister, has just proposed to Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, for the Locarno powers to meet in Brussels to consider the German violation of the Locarno treaty.

News comes from Washington that friction has arisen between this country and the Iranian Government, sufficient to result in the latter nation closing its diplomatic and consular offices here and announcing that diplomatic relations will henceforth be maintained only through our legation in Teheran.

There is nothing more misleading to Be thoughtless than a false analogy. President Roosevelt, in expressing dispproval of the decision of the United .States Supreme Court which declared the IVRA unconstitutional, and in re.ferring to the "horse-and-buggy age," knplied that as we have advanced in means of transportation and in natural processes and results, we should expect equal progress in governmental procedures.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., April 4. -- The championship of the seventeenth annual Eastern States scholastic tournament was won tonight by Brown Prep School of Philadelphia, when it defeated the fast White Plains High five of Westchester County by 29 to 28.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- Strengthening of Federal laws to insure the rights of labor was advocated today in a pamphlet prepared by research experts of the Public Affairs Committee, of which Raymond Buell is chairman and Francis P. Miller is executive secretary. The pamphlet summarized the inquiry of the Twentieth Century Fund into the relations of government and labor.

PARIS, April 3. -- For the third time within a year what is described as "an attack on the franc" has been checked this week by the action of the Bank of France in raising the bank rate to 5 per cent and by stimulation through the press of confidence that all was well not only with the franc but with business in this country.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP). -- Planning a searching inquiry into how business can reduce unemployment, the Chamber of Commerce of the United States has given this question major position in the program for its annual meeting here April 27-30.

A report that an effort has been made to bring to New York the great exhibition of Chinese art recently lent by the Chinese Government to the British Royal Academy and shown at Burlington House, London, is published in the current issue of The Art Digest.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 4. -- Stocky Gene Sarazen, winner of top honors in the masters' tournament here a year ago, put himself back in a position for a repeat performance today when he tied the competitive record for the Augusta National Golf Club course.

WHILE the Military Affairs Committee of the House was reporting favorably last week on the bill backed by Mayor La Guardia for the use of Governors Island as a commercial traffic airport for New York, Boston had in her pocket a lease of her own Governors Island for a period of fifty years to provide an extension to her airport.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 4. -Plans are under way for the sixth annual Lawridge Horse Show to be held on May 10 in the outdoor ring of the estate of the late Robert Law for the benefit of the Greenwich Milk Fund and the United Hospital, Port Chester.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., April 4. -- The Smith College Dramatic Association will present "The Distaff Side," by the English author, John Van Druten, as its Spring production on April 16 and 17. The association, which presents two plays during the college year, gave "The World We Live In," a Czechoslovak fantasy by the brothers Josef and Karel Capek, as its presentation last Fall.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- Despite a protest from the Chamber of Commerce of the United States against the alleged slip-shod procedure by which the new tax plan is being formulated, Congressional leaders gave notice today that they intend to rush to the House floor for action within ten days a measure embodying the essentials of President Roosevelt's program.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 4. -- Pacific Coast shipping was active in March, rates and demand held steady, chartering volume was well maintained and berth lines continued to run with full cargoes.

ALBANY, April 4. -- Governor Lehman, since he has occupied his present high office, on more than one occasion has won distinction as an arbiter of acute differences between employers and employes in recurrent labor disturbances.

Great Britain ended its 1935-36 fiscal year on March 31 with a treasury surplus of 2,941,701 ($14,561,425) after having applied 12,500,000 ($61,875,000) toward reducing the national debt. It was the fourth successive year of surplus, and the amount was larger than had been expected because income, estate and customs taxes were unexpectedly productive.

THE highly engaging idea of this book in honor of the centenary of the first issue of "The Posthumous Papers of the Pickwick Club," subsequently to be known under the simpler title "The Pickwick Papers," was conceived in the editorial rooms of the London publishing house of Chapman Hall, whose predecessors in 1836 sponsored the original undertaking.
This is apparently the first appearance of the wolverine, or carcajou, in fiction, although an account of his habits may be found in Ernest Seton-Thompson's "Game Animals and the Lives They Live."

ST. LOUIS, April 4 (AP). -- Harold Osborn, 36-year-old Olympic record holder, topped the world record in the standing high jump at the St. Louis relays tonight, leaping 5 feet 6 inches. His only rival was Bob Lange of the Missouri School of Mines, who dropped out before Osborn bettered the mark of 5 feet 5 3/4 inches set in 1913 by Leo Goehring and equaled by Osborn in 1925.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- The Department of Agriculture has practical suggestions to offer flood sufferers as they face the job of rehabilitation. These suggestions are found in twenty-two Farmers Bulletins covering a wide range of subjects -- from plumbing repairs on the farm to mosquito remedies.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., April 4. -Dr. Lester K. Ade, Superintendent of Public Instruction of Pennsylvania, will give the principal address at the 104th anniversary observance on Tuesday of the founding of Gettysburg College. Dr. Ade will speak on "An Adequate Philosophy of Education."

ATLANTIC CITY. -- With thousands of visitors already here for the Easter holiday period, Atlantic City has speeded up to a high tempo to provide for their entertainment. The Boardwalk, where the Palm Sunday preview of Easter fashion parade takes place, is the center of interest today.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 4 (AP). -- Welcomed back from prison at a banquet in his honor, Colonel Luke Lea told several hundred of his friends tonight that when misfortune first overtook him he considered whether to cause his "insurance to mature and thus provide security for my wife and the dearest children who ever lived."

PRODIGIOUS is the perspective summoned up for us by the modern French tapestries at the Bignou (shown there under the sponsorship of Les Amis du Musee de Blerancourt and to remain on view until the end of April).
Recently THE NEW YORK TIMES published an account of the ceremony of the presentation to Congress of a copy of Christian Krohg's famous painting of Leif Ericsson now in the National Gallery at Oslo.

RECENT tests in the Northeastern United States have conclusively shown that very early Spring is the best time to prune most trees and a large number of shrubs. Wounds made on trees between the first of February and the last of April heal quicker than at any other time of year.

BALTIMORE, April 4. -- Riding in his first race, 15-year-old Billy Pfefferkorn brought his chestnut mare Decanter home first by a nose in the fifth annual running of the junior cross-country steeplechase today in the Worthington Valley.

LIKE many another tale of the treasure hunt genre, this one ends with failure of the trove seekers to recover the missing hoard and with the probability that, if the treasure still exists, its hiding-place will never be found. Three centuries ago Sir Giles Cortenay, gentleman buccaneer, had returned to his native English domain with an immense fortune in precious stones, his loot from Spanish Main piracies.

Again the perennial friction between Japan and Russia has flashed into flame. Within seven days' time their opposing frontier forces, or those of th ir proteges, Manchukuo and Outer Mongolia, have lunged at one another on the eastern, the northern and the western borders of Manchukuo, scattered over 1,300 miles.

ONCE more the insistent monotone of the Pacific beats ominously, even amid the jangling discords of Europe. The problems of the greatest of oceans, which have become more and more complex ever since Magellan and Cook and Bligh braved "foam of perilous seas" unknown, are again becoming crucial -- problems pointed up sharply by Japan's failure to participate in the naval accord recently signed by Great Britain, France and the United States.
More than $20,000 in cash and silver trophies will be at stake in the tenth annual show of the Morris and Essex Kennel Club at the Giralda Farms, Madison, N.J., on Saturday, May 23.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- In the opinion of House leaders, Representative Bankhead of Alabama must invoke the full force of his popularity and his prestige as majority leader next week if an unwilling House is to adopt Senator Black's joint resolution to relax existing law in the payment of counsel fees in connection with the Senate lobby committee's court fight on its right to subpoena private telegrams.

WHEN two such poetic writers as Waldemar Bonsels and Walther Eidlitz take us into distant parts of the world it is not merely our store of information which is enriched. Their vision is infinite in its scope, their hearts catch the whisper of deeply hidden springs, feel the course of mysterious currents and intuitively sense ultimate solutions.
SPRING, "with that nameless pathos in the air," comes early to coastal South Carolina, and each year this historic region lures an ever-increasing throng of visitors.

PARIS, April 4. -- The Action Francaise, militant royalist group, was branded today as an organization aiming at the overthrow of the French Republic by force in a ruling of the French Council of State, the supreme authority on the administration and application of laws in France.
The Merchants Association announced yesterday its approval of several recommendations regarding legislation for public utilities made by the Mack Committee.

The "doughboys" and the "yellow legs" had their day yesterday and the caissons went rolling along Upper Fifth Avenue as a brisk breeze whipped battle streamers and tattered flags and sunlight gleamed from bayonets and burnished gun muzzles.

The committee on legislation of the Citizens Union announced yesterday its approval of the Buckley-Streit bill to carry out the proposal of Thomas E. Dewey, rackets prosecutor, to consolidate indictments for similar crimes. This change was recommended by Governor Lehman in a special message to the Legislature, in which he said it would help the police and prosecutors by making it easier to convict "higher-ups" in racketeering activities.

CHICAGO, April 4. -- Philip K. Wrigley, 41-year-old owner of the National League champion Cubs, today came up with a novel plan for selling reserved seats at Wrigley Field, effective with the opening of the baseball season.

The growing movement to legalize lotteries was under scrutiny last week; the activities of several of its most ardent supporters were subjected to hearings by the Postoffice Department in Washington. Country-wide interest in the proceedings was heightened by the memory, only a few days old, of the excitement occasioned by the drawings in one of the world's largest lotteries -- the Irish Hospital Sweepstakes.

The war danger in the Far East seems on the surface greater than ever. The latest clash between the forces of Manchukuo and Outer Mongolia has been of so serious a character as almost to convey the impression that war has already begun. According to the Japanese, there have been more than a hundred such clashes in the last year, and everything seems to indicate that they are increasing rather than diminishing in violence.

RICHMOND, Va., April 4. -- Ghost Dancer, ridden by the expert Noel Laing, sped over post and rail for three miles to carry the black and red silks of Carleton H. Palmer of New York to victory in the Deep Run Hunt Cup, feature event of the ninth annual Deep Run Spring race meeting over the historic Curles Neck course today.
PARIS. FOR more than 200 years Easter Island has been counted among the world's mysteries, and around its giant stone faces staring up into the sun strange and stimulating legends have been built.

The belief that a decisive turn in France's financial affairs is not far away has been gaining ground among bankers here in recent weeks. It is felt that the present French Government is making desperate efforts to stave off a crisis until after the elections, now about three weeks away, but that after the voting conclusive action to repair the national credit and settle the future of the franc cannot much longer be postponed.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica. -- The outlook for organized communism in Costa Rica is not particularly bright. In fact, there is good reason for believing that the movement is already dying.

A GENERATION or so ago appeared a series of agreeably concise and well-written musical biographies, called "The Master Musicians Series." The public demand for such biographies continues unabated. In these intervening years the researches of musical scholars have added to the information available about the composers in question, have corrected errors and especially have uprooted various legends that are peculiarly apt to grow luxuriantly around the lives of musicians.
SYRACUSE, April 4. -- Police gave a ticket to Miss Henrietta Schumann, pianist, for leaving her automobile parked from 2 A.M. to 5 A.M. contrary to city regulations.

THE drama's latest casus belli, the new minimum basic agreement, raised its argumentative head the other day in Los Angeles, which is a long way from the legitimate's headquarters. Homer Curran had verbally arranged for a tryout of George Kelly's new play, "Reflected Glory," and Tallulah Bankhead was to be the star.
CINCINNATI, April 4 (AP). -- Outfielder Floyd (Babe) Herman signed his contract with the Cincinnati Reds late today after a three-hour conference with General Manager Larry MacPhail.

SIX cities won first honors in the fourth annual traffic safety contest conducted last year by the National Safety Council. They were Evanston, Ill.; Milwaukee, Wis.; Providence, R.I.; Syracuse, N.Y.; Superior, Wis., and Swissvale, Pa.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., April 4. -A movement for a ban on the unauthorized sale and use of fireworks in three States, with the New Jersey headquarters in East Orange, has been started, it was learned here today.

ANNOUNCEMENT last week by the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation of its twelfth annual series of fellowship awards brings to the fore the influence exerted by the foundation on American culture and scientific progress since its inception.

COLONEL WILLARD T. CHEVALIER, vice president of McGraw-Hill Publishing Company, will be inaugurated as president of the American Road Builders Association at its annual meeting in Washington April 15-17, it is announced.

THIS volume is indeed a unique memorial to a man -- as individual as was the man himself. The compilers say that when they asked through the press and the radio for stories by or about Will Rogers and reminiscences of him that would enable them to prepare such a memorial volume they received in response an overwhelming amount of material.

AN Easter holiday exodus which is expected to attain record-breaking proportions will get under way within the next few days.
