Over a wide vacation front thousands of Americans will move by train, plane, steamer, bus and motor car in search of recreation ranging from active sports to appreciation of the first Spring flowers.

A petition for the closing of the entrance to the abandoned street car tunnel at Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, to widen the avenue's northbound roadway there, has been filed with Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan and with the local improvement board of the Murray Hill district.

PARIS, April 4. -- Having changed tactics yesterday and decided to reply to the German peace proposals with a peace plan of its own, the French Government is now anxious to hurry events along and have its plan ready for approval by the Cabinet Monday and for presentation to the world immediately afterward.

The United States holds all records in respect to speed by standard passenger trains, according to the magazine Railway Age. The record of 127.2 miles an hour was established here in 1905 and is followed by records of 119 an hour in Germany, 115.6 miles an hour in France and 112 miles an hour in England.

MAX GORDON last night left the road to its own devices. While Walter Huston was taking his last curtain calls as Samuel Dodsworth at the Taft Theatre in Cincinnati, Guy Robertson was conducting "The Beautiful Blue Danube" through its final stanzas at the Chicago Auditorium.

GIOVANNI MARIA CARDINAL MASTAI-FERRETTI was elected Pope June 16, 1846, taking the name of Pins IX Nearly two years later, March 4, 1848, King Carlo Alberto granted his Sardinian subjects the "Statuto fondamentale del Regno," thereby laying the cornerstone of the unification which was to be measurably realized, twenty-three years later, by his son, Vittorio Emanuele II, with the Pope a "prisoner" in the Vatican.

On the termination of the plan of rearrangement of debt capitalization of the Associated Gas and Electric Company on next Tuesday, officials of the utility expect that almost $200,000,000 of the company's debentures will have been exchanged under the three options, providing for such, leaving about $70,000,000 of debentures unconverted.

PARIS, April 2. -- Many interesting fashion notes were seen at the Auteuil Grand Prix du Printemps. Red composition accessories were worn with black costumes. Two especially smart Spring-like hats attracted attention: one was of navy felt, trimmed at one side with a red feather heart which was pierced with a gray feather arrow; the other was a small black straw cap partially covered with a visor of white pique leaves.

Alderman Murray W. Stand's proposed anti-noise ordinance, which provides fines of from $1 to $10 for persons responsible for any of fourteen specific noise nuisances has received the unanimous endorsement of the executive committee of Mayor La Guardia's Noise Abatement Committee, it was announced yesterday.

A NEW kind of South Sea island story, which steers clear of all beach combers, Alan Le May's new novel centers about the ownership of an island not far from Hawaii. Twenty years before the story opens the island had been sold to the Wayne family by old Garrett Watterson, who had immediately disappeared.

ADELPHI TERRACE, overlooking the Thames and the Embankment in London, has gathered many antiquarian, architectural, historical and literary associations in its 160 years; recently Queen Mary visited it unannounced to view its dwellings and caverns on the eve of its demolition.

The sophomore class won from the freshman class yesterday in the thirty-fourth presentation of Greek games at Barnard College. The events, many of which were in the nature of a pageant arranged by the students with the cooperation of members of the faculty, took place in the college gymnasium before about 1,000 spectators.

AFTER the American Bridge League has completed its annual team-of-four and individual tournaments for "masters" (those who have previously won tournaments) the week of April 13, there will not be a large contract bridge tournament in New York until November, when four-man teams compete for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup.

THE Pickwick centenary surely sets a new precedent. Commemorations of the birth and death of famous men and women are nowadays so frequent that they threaten to become a bore, and we are also occasionally reminded that a hundred years have passed since some important historical event.

DARIUS MILHAUD'S quartet, No. 9, and Werner Josten's quartet in B minor will be given their New York premieres at the final concert of the series of the League of Composers Monday night, April 13, at the French Institute.

THIS novel -- which might, for any of the author's several purposes, have been much more effectively titled -- is set against the background of a Louisiana sugar plantation. It is a background which Elma Godchaux evidently knows very well, indeed, and which she describes with a good deal of color and feeling.

ALTHOUGH the Spring selling season is just getting under way, retail demand for motor cars already has soared to a point which has surprised both factories and dealers. The next sixty days promise to be the busiest period in the automobile industry since 1929, if one can judge accurately from the public's purchases in the last two weeks.

WHILE the gardener stands breathless over the first crocus or daffodil he will do well to give some thought to the later flowering trees and shrubs, whose fragrance and blossoms will in turn soon be the season's delight.

The author of this book, so the publishers inform us, is a well-known Western cattleman who is 65 years old. This is his first attempt at writing. Joseph Bowen, by the way, is not his real name. He is an avid reader of detective stories, but he has never found one that satisfied him completely, so he decided to write his own.

THIS week-end the earlier varieties of daffodils, including the natural species which in recent years have been attracting so much attention among gardeners, are in their glory both in the New York Botanical Garden and the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.
BROADCASTERS won what they call an important victory on March 30 when the United States Supreme Court invalidated a State tax on gross receipts of broadcasting stations.
WILLIAM C. WHITE, who will be remembered by many as the author of "These Russians" and "Made in Russia," embarked on a new literary enterprise dealing with "The Makers of the Revolution."

Uncompromising pacifism was the keynote of the third day's session of the yearly meeting of the general conference of the Society of Friends in New York and New Jersey yesterday at the Friends Meeting House, 221 East Fifteenth Street.

THIS volume has a very distinctive reason for existence. It represents one desperate layman's reaction to explanation and exhortation by certain charming but incomprehensible experts in physics and astronomy. George W. Gray is a student by choice and a writer by profession.
GENEVA, April 4. -- The quarterly report on world unemployment issued today by the International Labor Office for the first time contains no figures on the number of Italian jobless.

With both sides working fast through a succession of spectacular manoeuvres, the State of New York, with the active help of Arkansas authorities, achieved an important step forward yesterday in the drive to compel the return to this city of Charles (Lucky) Luciana, big time racketeer, to face trial on charges of compulsory prostitution.

BOSTON, April 4. -- New England business conditions are gradually recovering from the adverse effects of the serious floods of a fortnight ago. Reports from the sections most affected indicate that, while progress is being made in rehabilitation, the situation is still far from normal and it probably will be some weeks before either industrial operations or retail trade get back to where they were at mid-March.

RYE, N.Y., April 4. -- A supper dance was held at the Westchester Country Club here tonight. Among those who had guests were Mr. and Mrs. Harry Dow, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Gates, Mr. and Mrs. Percy Adamson, Mr. and Mrs. A.S. Healey, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Haggerty, Mr. and Mrs. J. Henry Walters, Dr. and Mrs. O.E. Farley and Mr. and Mrs. David Corin.

Parents who spank children for indulging in temper tantrums, crying, whining or sucking their thumbs were advised yesterday in a statement by Professor Christine Heinig of the Child Development Institute of Columbia University that they themselves should be spanked rather than the children.
BOSTON, April 4 (AP). -- The Massachusetts Supreme Court ruled today the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Inc., must pay in full the taxes assessed by the City of Boston.

BERLIN, April 4 (AP). -- Hints in some of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's recent campaign speeches that the Reich Government was moving toward a more conciliatory policy in internal affairs were borne out partly today by news of conciliatory actions in the provinces.

BASED on a study of broadcasts during the late afternoon hours, only thirteen bear the unqualified stamp of approval of parents and children, according to the Women's National Radio Committee. Nine of the approved programs are listed as "sustaining,'' that is, they are staged by the stations without commercial sponsorship.

Trailing two sets down, Frank (Bunny) Gannon, professional of the Tuxedo Racquet Club, rallied to defeat Fred Robinson, the rising young professional of the Racquet and Tennis Club, yesterday in a special match of unusual interest. The score was 4 -- 6, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 3.

DALLAS, April 4. -- Department store sales in the Eleventh Federal Reserve District during March show a gain of approximately 16 per cent over the 1935 month, while the volume of building permits are more than five times as large as during the corresponding period of last year, it is disclosed in statistics gathered by the Federal Reserve Bank.

While approving, in principle, of managed currency, as discussed by Professor Irving Fisher in his letter to THE TIMES, I must take exception to the statements that price-level stability is necessarily desirable, or that it fixes an invariable buying power of the monetary unit, or that inflation and deflation may be avoided thereby.

CHICAGO, April 4. -- Bullish enthusiasm regarding the trend of the May wheat delivery on the Board of Trade here and in Kansas City has largely evaporated, and persistent scattered liquidation carried the price off about 1 cent from yesterday's finish to 93 5/8 cents, the lowest level since early in September.

Phil Sommese, 183, Westbury, out-pointed Louis Le Paige, 190 1/2, Paterson, N.J., in the main bout of a card of four-rounders involving heavyweight boxers last night at the Ridgewood Grove. Al Demedowitz, 182, Brooklyn, conquered Jack Moran, 183 1/2, Ashland, Pa., and James J. Johnston, 170, Mobile, Ala., bowed to Stanley Hasrato, 166 3/4, Yorkville.

THAT your automobile weathered the Winter does not mean it will operate efficiently and economically in the Spring unless you make it your responsibility to see that it is put in condition to do so. It has been a matter of pride on the part of the automobile maker that, during the hardest Winter in years, his product performed so well.

The late Marsden J. Perry's collection of Chippendale furniture and other art objects realized $110,030 when it was auctioned yesterday and Friday at the American Art Association Anderson Galleris. Yesterday's total alone was $74,525.

TO the snow train and the fish train, devised by American railroads for the benefit of outdoor sportsmen, Great Britain now has added the camping coach, an idea suggested by C.J. Cutliffe Hyne, British sportsman and author.

Ferry boats plowed back and forth across the dark waters of the Hudson River last night carrying a strange assortment of passengers. They were well-mannered, as ferry boat passengers go, but occasionally they gave forth weird, almost terrifying sounds that seemed hardly in keeping with a city that is trying to follow the edicts of the Mayor's anti-noise campaign.

I LOVE the clothes this Spring," said an attractive girl; "they make me look just as my mother did!" That exactly explains the new things; about them cling sentiment and romance whether they be for day or night time.

THE Limited Editions Club is planning to celebrate its tenth anniversary, several years from now, with the publication of a thirty-eight-volume edition of Shakespeare, illustrated by thirty-eight of the leading book artists of the world.

LAMBROS DEMETRIOS CALLIMAHOS, the Greek-American flautist, though but 24 years of age, was recently appointed professor at the Mozarteum Academy in Salzburg, Austria, for the coming season. As the faculty of the Mozarteum consists of leading authorities in music and the drama, his appointment as a member of the faculty evidences the high place the gifted young artist has made for himself abroad.

CARACAS, Venezuela. -- This capital city, remote from the world on its mountain-girdled plateau, is living an answer to the question that many Europeans have asked since the war: What happens to a nation when its dictator dies? The city lives on quietly but uneasily and its people say, "Wait until the election.

Younger members of society have formed several groups to assist with preparations for the May Day Ball which will be given at the Plaza on May 1 in aid of the New York Skin and Cancer Unit. This beneficiary, situated at 301 East Nineteenth Street, specializes in the treatment of cancer and skin diseases, the greater part of its work being among the very poor.

Breaking 97 out of 100 targets, A.L. Burns won the High-Over-All Cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. In Class A, C.S. Wills and A.S. Cornhill each finished with a full card, the first named gunner scoring in the shoot-off.

THE possibilities of stamp collecting are so limitless that the orderly collector often restricts his album to certain subjects, such as the stamps of some particular country or continent; the portraits of rulers or historical personages; ships, airplanes, mountains, trees, animals or birds.

Three boys who had disappeared from their East Side homes Friday turned up yesterday on the high seas, non-paying guests aboard the Holland-America liner Veendam. And if Captain T. Magaay, master of the Veendam, was startled at the sudden addition to his passenger list, his surprise vas no match to that manifested by the boys' mothers to the detectives of the Missing Persons Bureau.
MOSCOW, April 3. -- The most striking feature of Moscow's reaction to the new and unprecedentedly serious clashes on the Mongolian-Manchukuoan border is calmness.

For the first time since the beginning of the depression, consumption of cigars will show an increase this year, it was announced yesterday by John H. Duys, president of the Associated Cigar Manufacturers and Leaf Tobacco Dealers.

Outboard drivers are showing their interest in the coming opening regatta of the season with a crescendo of enthusiasm. The Albany-to-New York marathon on Sunday, May 10, is their principal topic of discussion these days, especially because the first of the weekly joint meetings of the drivers and the technical committees and officials was held the other night at the Hotel Lexington.

Hendrik de Leeuw, explorer and author, arrived with Mrs. de Leeuw last week on the Holland-American liner Veendam, having just completed some researches in the Holland district of Zeeland, the seat of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's forebears.

PHILADELPHIA, April 3. -- Mrs. Cornelia Bryce Pinchot, wife of Pennsylvania's former Governor, has decided to make her third campaign for a seat in Congress and believes she will win. Even opposing Democratic party workers concede her "a chance."

LONDON, April 3. -- Germany's note this week again sought to prevent the cooperation of Great Britain and France by objecting to their military consultations for the defense of France and Belgium. Ex-Prime Minister Lloyd George and other Britons likewise object on the ground that the consultations may compromise peace.

WHAT is by all counts one of the outstanding choreographic achievements of the season will be given its second performance tonight when Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman and their company present their "Theatre Piece" and "New Dance" at the Adelphi Theatre.
PHILADELPHIA, April 4. -- Study of 10,000 cases has convinced Dr. Alice E. Johnson, psychiatrist for the Municipal Court, that there are six leading reasons for failure of marriages.
More diversification was apparent last week than in the previous period in the announcements of bonds called for redemption before maturity.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- Palm Sunday will find a large crowd at the Greenbrier. Many more are expected for the Easter week-end. Activities today will center around the Greenbrier Golf and Tennis Club and the Tangerine Room at the Casino which will be the scene of scores of luncheon parties.
A plea for support of the Catholic Charities drive was made yesterday by former Governor Alfred E. Smith, honorary chairman of the special gifts committee, in a letter to the New York Archdiocese.

THIS is a rambling romantic tale of life along a more or less historic road of some time ago that looped over grassy undulations of the wearily empty land of "that part of Kansas west of Wichita," a road known at that time as Whisky Trail.
ROME, April 4 (AP). -- Italy was said by excellent sources tonight to be planning to obliterate the last vestiges of Ethiopian resistance by launching a terrific general air attack next week.
BOSTON, April 3. -- With courage and gumption, the mill towns of New England are carrying on in spite of the flood damage.

"Should the Robinson-Patman price discrimination" bill become new at this session of Congress, as predicted here by Representative Patman toward the end of the creek, a legal battle which will barry the measure to the United States Supreme Court is inevitable, according to views in well-informed detail circles here.
MILWAUKEE, April 4. -- Joseph John Shinners, 54, up from the sidewalks he used to patrol as a policeman, is rapping on the door of Mayor Hoan's office in City Hall.

CHICAGO, April 4. -- The New York Athletic Club won its third straight national high-goal indoor polo championship tonight when the trio of hard-riding Easterners defeated the Cleveland Riding Club seniors, 7 -- 5, in the final game of the East-West classic. A crowd of 10,000 attended.

GEORGE MARSHALL had a problem. He is a movie director, and his problem was one of dramatic technique. In solving the dramatic problem he created a mechanical problem. The mechanical solution involved a medical problem, and when that was solved he faced a psychological problem.

PRINCETON, April 4. -- Coming from behind in the eighth inning, Princeton's baseball team staged a five-run rally today to defeat the C.C.N.Y. nine, 10 -- 7, on University Field. It was the first victory for the Tigers this season in five starts.

MOST of the year the Australian aborigines are on the move, following the waterholes which alternately dry up and become abundant at regular periods. Such sources not only supply the tribesman with his own needs but also attract the kangaroo, emu and other game on which he lives.

MR. ADAMS'S approach to Jefferson combines the interest of the historian and biographer and the zeal of a political pamphleteer. Jefferson, he declares, "was, and still is, the greatest and most influential American exponent of both liberalism and Americanism."
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French frano on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- So gradually is the season tapering off at Palm Beach that the only notable difference between this and preceding weeks is that affairs are smaller and more impromptu. Daily programs are running the usual Spring gamut of swimming, golf, tennis and bridge, with informal tea or dinner dances at their close.

It obviously must be Spring, because the Gilbert and Sullivan companies are mustering. When the voice of "The Mikado" is heard in the land it will make no difference whether outside it looks like Spring or not. Last year was the semi-centennial of Ko-Ko, Pooh-Bah and Yum-Yum.

CHICAGO, April 4. -- Miss Mary Lou Petty, sturdy little free-style star from the Washington A.C. of Seattle, defeated the defending champion, Mrs. Lenore Kight Wingard of Cincinnati, to win the 500-yard race tonight and gain her second title in the women's national senior indoor A.A.U. meet at the Lake Shore Athletic Club.

Women interested in the Prosperity Shop have arranged a luncheon and revue of styles, to be known as the Spring Fever Fashion Show, for April 29 in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador to raise funds for philanthropic enterprises aided by the shop.
One of your correspondents protests against the attempts of what she calls the Republican machine to put Governor Landon over.

MR. O'CONNOR'S stories have the Irish in them and they still have the good old-fashioned way of telling a good story. Such forthrightness is out of favor at the moment, when one turns a page to discover that the story has ended with a sigh and a suggestion.

TORONTO, Ont., April 4. -- Teck Hughes Gold Mines, Ltd., in an interim report covering operations for the six months ended on Feb. 29 reveals a balance of $1,214,844, equal to 25 cents per share on the 4,807,144 shares outstanding.

CONTRARY to general belief, the okapi, that brilliantly colored deerlike animal peculiar to the Belgian Congo, is not rare or nearing extinction. So reports Attilio Gatti, head of the eighth Gatti African expedition now in the Ituri Forest in Equatorial Africa.
New York City's parks are now in process of getting the most thorough Spring cleaning, face lifting and general rejuvenation in their long and verdant history.

AS Patience explains, the Abbe children's father watches the world go by. And when James E. Abbe wanders over the earth's surface catching pictures of humanity's forward -- or backward -- movement, he often takes the family along.

A group of twenty men, playing pinochle and bridge in the Rio Bridge Parlor, at 3,825 Broadway, near 159th Street, late yesterday afternoon were stripped of their trousers and lined up against the wall while four armed bandits took $511 from them. A short time after the gunmen left, a policeman caught two suspects a few blocks away after a chase in which he fired several shots.

It looks at last as though the girl graduate, newly initialed by her alma mater with an imposing degree, can trot cheerfully off the campus this June, or out of the business college into a world disposed to welcome her youthful energy and enthusiasm.

The Philharmonic-Symphony concerts for children and young people, under the direction of Ernest Schelling, were concluded yesterday morning at Carnegie Hall. For his sixth and final concert, Mr. Schelling devoted his program to works requested by his youthful audience.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -Members of the Southern Pines colony are preparing for the third annual Spring blossom festival, which will be held April 16, 17 and 18. R.S. Durant, general chairman, last week announced the detailed program for the event, which is the principal one on the April calendar.

CAN'T HAPPEN HERE: Dr. George E. Vincent, former president of the Rockefeller Foundation, said last week in a speech in Chicago: "Humor is the symbol of liberty in a country where we can see the ridiculous side of politics. When there is a repression of laughter and witticism about political personages such as now exists in Europe, the loss of other liberties is on the way."

An American newspaper correspondent named John Keats is the central figure in this terrifying story of the next European war. Keats represents The Universe News, and his mission is to cover all events of international importance in Europe.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., April 4. -Following is the proclamation of Army Day, issued last night by President Rosevelt from the yacht Potomac:
ALBANY, April 4. -- Governor Lehman today signed the bill which eliminates from the Civil Practice Act what he characterized as "cumbersome and detailed provisions" relating to bills of particulars.

IT is appropriate that April should have come in on a Spring freshet of water-color. Elsewhere today will be found further reference to work in this delightful medium; the items seen by the present reviewer were those by Barse Miller, John Whorf, Jacob Epstein and Sonia Gagarin.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 4. -Fine Hall, Princeton University's "House for Mathematics," is completing its first five years of existence this week as the center of study for some of the world's most eminent mathematicians.

WEATHER observers who a few weeks ago were predicting an extremely late Spring are now pulling in their horns. All signs at present indicate that it will be unusually early, rather than unusually late -though the weather map, which is apparently registering eccentric tendencies this year, may still reverse prospects and wind up Winter with another belated cold snap.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 3. -More than 120,000 persons in Milwaukee and suburbs have been attacked in the last ten days by a baffling intestinal malady that physicians of the city are still at a loss to explain.
WASHINGTON, April 4. -- Industrial operations generally have been restored to normal after the March floods, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly business survey.

CHICAGO, April 4 (AP). -- Wrestlers representing Oklahoma A. and M. carried off six of the nine individual titles as the National A.A.U. championships were concluded in the DePaul University gymnasium tonight. They also won the team honors.

THE recent success of two New York high school girls in designing fabrics which Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt selected for Easter gowns has drawn attention to the city's steadily widening vocational education program. The girls' designs were adjudged best in a contest entered by a dozen schools in which textile courses are given.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP). -Railroad labor today urged Congress to enact legislation to protect workers in railway consolidations, contending that the carriers had failed to meet the problem in negotiations.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- Officials of the housing agencies who have consulted with President Roosevelt in recent months about legislation to spur slum clearance and the building of low-rental homes saw a challenge today in the Wagner bill introduced in the Senate yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 4. -- Democratic headquarters announced tonight the receipt of a letter from a World War veteran contributing his bonus money to help re-elect President Roosevelt.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 4 (AP). -- The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company received permission today from the Federal Court to seek postponement of the reduction in passenger fares ordered recently by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 3. -Kentucky Republicans, having agreed to cast their national convention ballots for Governor Landon of Kansas and strengthened their State committee, are united for the Presidential campaign.

HOUSTON, Texas, April 4 (AP). -- Miss Eunice Dean of San Antonio captured the women's honors in the sixth annual River Oaks tennis tournament today by defeating Mrs. Marjorie Gladman Van Ryn, of Philadelphia. The score was 4 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 7 -- 5.

Reporting on women's conditions in Russia, Walter Duranty told us recently that one-third of the unskilled workers on railroad construction, building projects, irrigation and so forth are women doing the hardest "donkey work," and he put the question: "Why not? At least they are independent."

BOWIE, Md., April 4. -- The Kentucky Derby stock of the Shandon Farm's Bright Light went skyrocketing today when he won the Rowe Memorial Handicap before 15,000 persons after being practically left at the post. Nine started and at the finish there was a Derby eligible on either end, the trailer being Winter Sport from the Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt string.

Amateur players recruited from society, members of the Blue Hill Troupe, are holding frequent rehearsals for the three performances of Gilbert and Sullivan's "The Mikado," which the troupe will present on April 15, 16 and 17 at the Heckscher Theatre for the benefit of Christodora House.

PHILADELPHIA, April 4. -- The first experimental evidence that cancers carry within them invisible chemical activators which are capable of reproducing the disease by injection in healthy animals is reported from several leading cancer-research laboratories in Europe and the United States in the third annual scientific report of the International Cancer Research Foundation, endowed by William H. Donner of this city.

IT was not so long that the country was marveling at the literary talents of the Roosevelt administration. From obscure experts in the New Deal agencies, as well as from the President and his immediate family, came books outlining the facts and philosophy of what had been done and remained to be done.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 4 (AP). -- George T. Dunlap Jr. of New York, former national amateur champion, won his fifth North and South amateur title in a walk today, defeating A.C. Giles of Briarcliff, N.Y., 8 and 7, in the thirtysix-hole final round.

Price advances in distant positions for sugar and coffee stood out yesterday as features of the short trading session in the local markets for commodity futures. In the cash markets silk and wool tops were higher, while wheat, rye and cotton were lower.

ST. LOUIS, April 4. -- Record cold weather for April in the last few days has caused serious injury to the fruit crop in the Eighth Federal Reserve District and has had a slowing-down effect upon retail sales of Spring goods, although a gain of 10 per cent is reported over last year's.

A FEW days ago Mayor La Guardia beat a tattoo with a pneumatic drill -- the official signal for the building of the long-discussed Sixth Avenue subway line. In a few months the Queens Boulevard route of the Independent system will be opened for service.

More effective teaching of the social sciences to help forestall "some of the most obvious social frauds that threaten us today" was urged yesterday by Professor William Withers of New College, Columbia University, at the closing session of the Spring conference of the Eastern State Association of Professional Schools for Teachers at the Hotel Commodore.

Public Schools 82 and 51 of Manhattan shared the team honors in the annual elementary school swimming championships held yesterday in the 25-yard pool of City College. The former won the title in the senior group, open to students in the seventh and eighth years, with 28 points, and P.S. 51 gained the junior crown, scoring 7 markers.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 4. -Students from leading schools in all sections of the United States have been thronging here for a week. Among the institutions well represented are Vassar, Harvard, Yale, Sweet Briar, Mount Holyoke, Babson, Park, Farmington, Westover and Ethel Walker, Seventy-five Smith College girls are staying at the Bermudiana.

PARIS. IF hats continue their downward course, they will soon be sitting on our eyebrows as they did in 1915. This trend is another of many signs that Paris modistes are no longer looking to the remote past for their inspiration but are searching in epochs closer to our own.

The Sala Norteamericana of the National Library of Chile, in Santiago, was inaugurated on March 17 with elaborate ceremonies attended by the Ambassador of the United States, the Chilean Minister of Foreign Affairs, the Minister of Education, men and women prominent in Chilean education and many members of the American colony.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 4. -- Scholarship ratings of the twenty-one national and local fraternities on the Rutgers University campus, announced today by Luther H. Martin, registrar, reveal that Tau Delta Phi, with an average of 78.483 per cent, stands highest for academic work during the first semester this year.

MIAMI, April 4. -- With two bonefish to the credit of his fishing party in a one-day excursion in quest of this hard-to-get species, President Roosevelt steamed today to within less than 200 miles of the mainland.

WELLESLEY, Mass., April 4. -Students and faculty of Wellesley College are making plans to arrest the trend of progress in higher education for one day so that "outsiders" may view its accomplishments to date. On May 2 the college will welcome visitors to its laboratories and classrooms where they may investigate the practical application of educational theories.

HOLLYWOOD. OF the 428 pictures in which he has appeared, "Greed" was the greatest, but it is "The Country Doctor" that will bring him fame, affluence and popularity with the masses. Jean Hersholt pondered this the other day as he sat at a luncheon surrounded by a group celebrating the completion of his thirtieth year in the cinema.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- An embargo effective from April 16 to July 1 was placed today on the export of tin-plate scrap, a commodity useful in war, by Secretary of State Cordell Hull as chairman of the National Munitions Control Board.

The annual Spring campaign of the Social Service Committee of Hunter College to raise funds for underprivileged children will begin tomorrow with a "tag day" for the benefit of the Lenox Hill Settlement, according to an announcement by Miss Sophie Weiner, chairman of the committee.

IN "The Golden Lady" Dorothy Gardiner tells the story of a generation in the life of a Colorado mining town, of the fever that grips the searchers after gold, and of a girl whose life was dominated by the influence of a mine and what it stood for.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 4. -- The villa of Major and Mrs. Barclay H. Warburton was the setting today for a tea and cocktail party at which Mr. and Mrs. C. Egerton Warburton and Miss Mary Brown Warburton were hosts.

The United States Treasury is entering the last quarter of the current fiscal year with an unusually large cash balance. It amounted on April 1 to about $2,400,000,000. This is near the highest point on record, except for a brief period in February and March, 1934, when the Treasury made a practice of including in its working balance the large "profit" resulting from devaluation of the dollar.

PHILADELPHIA, April 4. -- Harvard, after being idle for two days because of rain, resumed its Southern baseball tour today and lost to Temple University at the Owls' Stadium, 17 to 6. The game was called in the middle of the seventh by agreement.

A dinner dance with an unusual entertainment in celebration of the Russian Easter will be held on the night of April 15 in La Maisonette Russe of the St. Regis. Net proceeds will be donated to the American Society for the Relief of Russian Exiles, of which Mrs. Landon K. Thorne is president.

"THE Street" -- Broadway -- swears that it is finally so. Last season it was only a whisper in scarcely credulous ears. The "legitimate" coming back? Perhaps, but you couldn't be sure. There were too many "angles." Weary and suspicious since the bubble broke in '29.
More than 200 guests attended the annual senior promenade of the New York University School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance last night at the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.

FRANCE is still exporting artists to us. One of the interesting recent arrivals is a young painter named Menkes, whose oils and water-colors are now to be seen at Mrs. Sullivan's Gallery. It is spirited work, dashingly decorative, very French.

WHEN Father Fiorello H. Knickerbocker put his finger to his lips last Fall and said "Quiet, Please!" to this once turbulent town, he probably never figured that his anti-noise edict would echo in Hollywood.

SOME years ago writer, in the making out an order for tulips, added to it as a rather reckless garden "adventure," an order for fifty Easter lilies (Lilium longiflorum giganteum), the lily in pots that the shops are fragrant with at Easter time.

ENGLAND'S new superliner Queen Mary will be "ahead of her time" in radio, according to reports from London relative to the ultra-modern apparatus, which will enable passengers in any of the 500 staterooms to hold radio telephone conversations with any part of the world in which there are telephones.

A summation of the work of the National Committee on the Cause and Cure of War since the organization was formed eleven years ago, and an outline of future activities will be presented by Miss Josephine Schain, chairman, at the Spring meeting of the executive committee tomorrow at 99 Park Avenue.

The National Basketball Rules Committee of the United States and Canada met at the Hotel McAlpin yesterday for a study of the court code for 1936-37. What actions were taken will not be known until the final session today, but there was one significant development.
WARRENTON, Va. -- The Middleburg Hunt will hold its Spring races for the benefit of the Loudoun Hospital on the course at Glenwood next Saturday and on Wednesday, April 15.

RESIDENTS of New Jersey are being aroused to the necessity of protecting their main motor highways. Opinion is being expressed on several counts -- on safety, on driving comfort and on appearance. Hundreds of miles of fine new roads, completed in recent years, are already congested, their natural roadside beauty needlessly defaced.

As reported in Friday's TIMES, an extended anthropological study has been made of the remote past of Ireland (by a Harvard expedition that has been intensively at work for several years) and of its present -- as if the secret of the rare qualities of that race were ever to be revealed by any science.

LONDON, April 3. -- The Evening Standard columnist, giving what he purports to be a report of a private meeting of the Conservative central organization last Wednesday, says that Lord Stanhope, Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, referring to Britain's position regarding mandated territories, said the "time will doubtless come when we shall have to give back Tanganyika to Germany."

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- Senator Borah, before leaving tonight for Milwaukee, where he will open his Wisconsin campaign Monday night, said he had been informed that money collected for the Republican National Committee was being spent in the Wisconsin primaries against him.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- Indications of a possible factional break-up of the Townsend Old-Age Revolving Pension movement are clearly apparent here as a result of the second week's developments in the hearings on the organization's management policies and financial affairs being conducted by a House of Representatives investigation committee headed by Congressman C. Jasper Bell of Missouri.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 4. -- Police today refused to give further details concerning the arrest last night of Pedro Ernesto Baptista, Mayor of Rio de Janeiro, on charges of aiding in the organization of the November revolt.

EXTENDED paths through national parks, new and longer tunnels, giant dams, and the pick of nature's beauty spots, are on the itineraries of tourists heading west. Whether the traveler wishes to view the cathedral-like pinnacles of Arizona's Grand Canyon from the back of a horse, the spouting geysers of Glacier National Park from a bus, or to wander into wild trails afoot, he will find provision for his convenience.
FORT WAYNE, Ind., April 4. -The address of Herbert Hoover here tonight on "Has the New Deal Solved Our National Problems?" as follows:

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- Sharp exchanges between attorneys over the implications in the term "fraud order" marked the hearing of the National Conference on Legalizing Lotteries, Inc., before the Postoffice Department today. Officials and attorneys of the organization have been cited to show cause why a fraud order should not be issued against them.

Two socially prominent women, Mrs. J.C. Thaw and Mrs. George U. Harris, paired with Raymond Balfe and John Mattheys, upset a crack field of contract bridge experts yesterday at the Park Central Hotel and marched off with the Grand National championship for mixed teams of four in the current tournament of the United States Bridge Association.

Irregularly higher prices ruled yesterday at the end of dull trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange. High-grade investments were almost unchanged on a firm undertone while selective buying among the more speculative and convertible domestic corporate loans resulted in several good-sized gains.

EXPRESSING themselves as unwilling to continue fighting battles of mere principle while more urgent and personal problems pressed, Paramount officials conceded a tacit victory to the Screen Directors Guild in the first incident that has arisen to test the guild's strength and the justice of its contentions.

ADDIS ABABA, April 4. -- A telephone clerk at a station south of Dessye rang up Addis Ababa at 6:45 this morning and reported that Italian planes were flying fast from the east toward this capital. At 7:06 A.M. a warning gun fired three shots from the palace.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., April 4. -- Union College has organized a new course in biology especially for students from the social studies and language and literature divisions, with the object of discussing biological facts or theories which may throw light on social problems.

TRENTON, April 4. -- With the long-delayed execution of Bruno Richard Hauptmann a completed fact today, Federal investigators and the police of two States concentrated on the story of being kidnapped told by Paul H. Wendel, who "confessed" to the Lindbergh kidnapping, repudiated his confession and is still held here on a charge of murder.

Strange, colorful and assorted wares will be set forth on Thursday and Friday of this week in the Odd Fellows Building in Hempstead, L.I., as the annual rummage sale through which the Garden City Woman's Club finances its Visiting Nurse Service is repeated.

IN hundreds of communities throughout the nation the Boy Scouts are staging their annual Spring shows. Such productions serve as interpreters of Scouting to the public. In New York, for example, more than 27,000 persons recently witnessed the Scout-O-Rama at Madison Square Garden, in which 15,000 boys (half of Gotham's Scout population) gave a panoramic demonstration of pioneering, camping, Cubbing and Sea Scouting.

PARIS, April 4. -- Yesterday's active intervention by the British Exchange Equalization Fund had effect today in holding franc exchange, with the result that speculators proved shy this morning and prices were steady.

THIS novel about the red-neck miners of Laurel, Pa., asserts once again the insistent theme of proletarian writing -- the uncompromising opposition of capital to labor. On the side of capital are the villains -- the government, the mine owners, the prosecuting attorney, the paid hirelings.

CHICAGO, April 4. -- Despite the efforts of railroads and safety organizations to impress upon the public the necessity for greater precaution in passing over highway-railroad grade-crossings, more persons lost their lives in 1935 in accidents at grade-crossings than in any year since 1931, according to reports made public by the Safety Section of the Association of American Railroads.

The new intake bureau known as the Bureau of Adjustments in the Children's Court, announced last week by Mayor La Guardia, represents New York's first official move to coordinate the welfare facilities of the whole community in the interests of juvenile offenders.

By a special ruling of the basketball committee of the P.S.A.L., Thomas Jefferson of Brooklyn and James Monroe of the Bronx became co-holders of the city court championship yesterday as each team registered a victory in the final contests of the round-robin tournament on the James Madison court.

TO cover the entire field of biography within a volume of little more than 200 scantily printed pages and to treat even the outstanding figures with anything like comprehensiveness or profundity, would be about as easy as to stuff a mountain into one's vest pocket.

A resurgence of nationalistic feeling on a scale several times as great as that of 1932 is promised by industrialists, raw material producers and others aligning themselves behind movements preaching a gospel of buying goods produced by American workmen.

SHOPS are full of nonsensical or serious objects with which to decorate the table for the family dinner on Easter Day. Symbolical paschal lambs of porcelain about four inches high come in yellow or blue and have hollowed backs in which to place bunches of flowers.

AFTER a decline which set in five years ago, the consumption of bread turned upward recently. Window displays at some of New York's thousands of bakeries bear testimony to the variety of loaves now being baked, and inside the shops there is further evidence that the bread tray on the family table need never be monotonous.
New York University's baseball team started its intercollegiate schedule with a smashing 19-to-5 victory over Columbia yesterday at Ohio Field before a crowd of about 500 shivering spectators.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky, conductor, ended in a very impressive manner its New York season of 1935-1936 yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. The concluding performance was rightly that of a symphony of epical greatness, the First of Brahms, and the performance was in noble and epical vein.
ATLANTA, Ga., April 4. -- Manager Joe McCarthy of the Yankees today added the last of his outfield defense line, but lost another link in the chain, temporarily, at least.

ONE of the most valuable services that books perform for young people, or indeed for readers of any age, is to set them journeying to strange lands, and to parts of their own country with which they have no first-hand acquaintance.
Seeded players moved into the quarter-finals almost in a body yesterday in the annual metropolitan badminton championship at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory.

BERLIN, April 3. -- Whatever happens beyond the frontiers as a result of the combined peace move and war watch on the Rhine, inside Germany the national mood mellows as sovereignty is re-established in the Rhineland, as the army grows apace, as a leading role in European councils is resumed and, above all, as Adolf Hitler puts up a front of German unity almost as formidable as France's Maginot Line.

While snow and below-freezing temperatures resulted in a temporary recession in retail buying in some parts of the country last week, business in sections where the weather was more seasonable continued to expand as preparations were made for the Easter holiday.

MAXWELL ANDERSON has seen justice done, or at any rate, he will see it this evening. At a private dinner at the Algonquin Hotel, the New York Drama Critics Circle proposes to give him its first award in honor of "Winterset," which has been selected, by a vote of 14 to 3, as the best American play produced this season.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 3. -- Some decline was shown in the volume of sales at retail, due, in part, to inclement weather and to payment of Federal and State taxes. Most encouraging is the continued activity in building of all kinds.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- The $31,500,000 of 4 1/4 per cent sinking fund external loan bonds due on April 1, 1965, that the Kingdom of Norway registered recently under the Securities Act of 1933 for the purpose of refunding bonds now drawing higher interest will be offered to the public on Tuesday, according to an amendment filed today to the registration statement.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 4 (AP). -- Chicago and Cleveland bowlers turned loose in the American Bowling Congress tournament today and mowed down some top totals in the doubles and singles.

AMHERST, April 4. -- A method whereby fraternity politics, usually the curse of student elections, will benefit rather than hinder elections to high student offices at Massachusetts State College is contained in a new plan announced today by John L. McConchie of Monson, president of the student senate.

TRENTON, April 4. -- Loser in the fight to save Bruno Richard Hauptmann from execution for the murder of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr., Governor Harold G. Hoffman was up to his neck today in a battle for his own political survival.

GENEVA, April 3. -- The success with which two dictators during the past month have baffled the League of Nations' two leaders, Britain and France, seems in many places to have deepened the feeling that it is hopeless to expect any valuable form of collective security to be worked out.

THE dingier side of New York, deliberately painted in bright colors, is the background for Tawny's story. She was born in 1905, when there were still horse cars on Twenty-third Street, and the novel carries her on to the present time.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP). -- Two letters which Secretary Perkins said were meant to reply to a political "whispering campaign" were made public tonight by the Labor Department.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 4. -Colonel Bill Terry marched his Giants into his home town today, but a number of annoying circumstances conspired to make the occasion considerably less auspicious than the man from Memphis doubtless desired.
FORT WAYNE, Ind., April 4. -- Some of the highlights of former President Hoover's address here tonight were:

LONDON, April 4. -- Cambridge, for the thirteenth year in succession, won the annual university boat race on the famous Thames course today, defeating the Oxford crew by five lengths. The time of the victors was 21:06.

BEHIND a veil of secrecy in so far as construction details are concerned, work was being rushed last week on the largest land transport ever laid down for air service in the United States. Five major airlines have cooperated in placing the order for this new superplane.

JOHN EVANS is the son of Mabel Dodge Luhan, and the husband of Claire Spencer, who is remembered for her fine novel, "Gallows Orchard." He himself, in 1933, published his first novel, "Andrews' Harvest," a story of two people bound together by a blend of hatred and physical passion.

ATHENS. -- Many missing fragments of pottery from vessels now exhibited in the National Museum have been discovered by Lincoln MacVeagh, American Minister to Greece, in his excavations beneath the eastern face of the Acropolis hill.

Elections of undergraduate officers at Barnard College have just been completed for the term 1936-37. Students elected are as follows: Miss Martha Reed, president of the Undergraduate Association; Miss Betty MacIver, vice president; Miss Beatrice Tenney, secretary, and Miss Sofia Simmonds, treasurer. Other officers are:
IN August of 1914 Europe was plunged into the most disastrous of all wars. Today there has arisen another crisis in Europe and war is again a word on men's lips. One crisis recalls the other.

THE Pro-Arts String Quartet of Brussels, described by the broadcasters as "one of the most famous chamber music ensembles," has been engaged for five Music Guild concerts between April 14 and 23. The first broadcast from Radio City is scheduled for WEAF at 1:45 P.M., on the 14th.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., April 4. -- Confronted by a marked decline in the number of freshmen registering for Latin courses, Williams College authorities are undertaking to solve the problems arising from the abandonment of stringent entrance demands.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- In the filing today of a suit in the Federal court in New York by the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation to restrain the Securities and Exchange Commission from making public certain data filed with it including gross sales, the commission was faced with twelve suits brought in various courts and revolving around the same question.

Seventeen-year-old Sylvio Giolito, who won the Public Schools Athletic League foils championship a year ago, emerged victor from a field of twenty-four in the interscholastic tourney sponsored by the Amateur Fencers League of America at the Fencers Club yesterday.

IT all depends upon the pitching and it's too early to tell anything about that except a few tales of horror. Down on the Citrus Circuit that willowy left-hander, Don Vernon Gomez, was doling out bases on balls in great profusion, an old fault of which a certain heavy-set gent in the Yankee home office thought he had cured the hurling hidalgo.

OEDIPE," the new lyric tragedy by Georges Enesco, which was given its premiere March 13 at the Paris Opera, undoubtedly takes rank as a work of more than ordinary importance, judging from its press. Its libretto, highly praised for its dramatic treatment of the ancient Theban myth dealing with the life of Oedipus, is by Edmond Fleg, who has drawn upon the "Oedipus Tyrannus" and "Oedipus at Colonus" of Sophocles for his material.

The card party and dance for the benefit of St. Ambrose Mission at 236 East 111th Street, which will be held April 17 at the Plaza, has enlisted the aid of many prominent women, including Mrs. James Roosevelt and Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor.

LONDON, April 4. -- Rumors about the impending conclusion of a treaty of alliance between Germany and Japan have a basis of solid fact. Conversations between the two governments now may be said to have reached a stage where it is possible to make the transaction complete if the two nations want to do so.

Criticism of the conduct of the Hauptmann case was expressed last night by speakers at the annual meeting of the Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut at the annual meeting at the Hotel Commodore. More than 1,000 persons attended the meeting, called to commemorate the opening of the new Federal court house in this district.

Active retail trade and brisk reordering by merchants of apparel and accessories for pre-Easter selling featured business activity in the metropolitan area last week. Sales of leading department stores here are estimated to have shown an increase of about 15 per cent over the same period a year ago, with women's apparel departments making a particularly good showing.
WASHINGTON, April 4. -- Chairman Fletcher told a regional meeting of party leaders here today that the national Republican treasury was "$250,000 out of the red with everything paid."

Action in furtherance of plans for the World's Fair projected for New York City in 1939 came last week after months of delay. A joint legislative committee, appointed through a concurrent resolution of the Senate and Assembly, will examine the proposal that the State participate in the exposition and give financial aid.

Despite its thorough demolition of "really effective open price reporting," the Supreme Court, in its Sugar Institute decision last week, failed to affect harmfully trade association work and its approval of advance announcement of quotations and terms by agreement actually constituted a step forward, according to opinions expressed here yesterday by association attorneys.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- An agreement under which Japan will restrict her exports of cotton rugs to the United States to 8,120,000 square yards for the twelve months ending on May 31, 1936, compared with 7,550,000 square yards in the preceding year, was announced today by the State Department.
PARIS, April 4. -- Diplomats said today France would insist that sanctions be imposed or Germany or lifted from Italy.
Recent and prospective dismissals of WPA workers on education and recreation programs in the city have caused concern and some resentment among school and city officials and project supervisors.

THE business of Washington at all times is politics, and in election year this business becomes the very breath of life. It is not politics in the large; it is politics in the sense of party rivalry, of struggle for national power. The echoes strike a visitor's ear as soon as he sets foot in the capital city and reverberate until the visit has ended.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- In two swift surprise moves, the Senate Agriculture Committee voted today to attempt to override President Roosevelt's veto of the $50,000,000 Feed and Seed Loan Bill an to demand from Secretary Wallace a full report on big AAA benefit payments.
The annual convention of the College Art Association, which will take place here from Wednesday through Saturday, will mark the twenty-fifth anniversary of the organization.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- The Pinehurst season reaches its climax this week-end, with golf predominant in the picture. The annual North and South invitation amateur golf championship of the past six days, with its attendant April Tournament, will have its feminine counterpart this week in the thirty-fourth annual North and South women's championship.

LONDON, April 3. -- There will be two openings next Sunday, Jean Pinard's "Moonflowers," directed by the Norwegian, Stein Bugge, will have its premiere at the Westminster so that the censor can have a look at it; and "Policeman's Holiday," with Richard Bird, opens at the Aldwych.

CHICAGO, April 4. -- Judging of Doberman pinschers, the largest entry among the working dogs, drew considerable attention at the second day of the thirty-fifth annual show of the Chicago Kennel Club at the Coliseum today.

Among the passengers who sailed for Europe yesterday on the French liner Ile de France were Elizabeth Rethberg, soprano, and Ezio Pinza, basso, both of the Metropolitan Opera Company, who are to make a world tour of opera and concerts. After singing at Covent Garden, London, and in other capitals of Europe, they will proceed to Australia for a joint concert tour of that continent, with twenty-five appearances already scheduled.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 4. -- Officials of Syracuse University have announced the formation of an inexpensive local fraternity, Pi Alpha Chi, designed to broaden the social life of men students, especially those earning their way through college, who are financially unable to join any of the twenty-seven other Greek-letter fraternities on the campus.

High prices were paid yesterday for several rare specimens of privately minted California gold coins of the 1850 period at the auction sale of United States and foreign coins conducted by Thomas L. Elder at 8 West Thirty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP). -- The Federal Communications Commission was urged today to keep television on an experimental basis until it had determined what effect it would have on radio broadcasting, newspapers and the motion picture industry.

Thousands of Easter cruise passengers will leave port this week, using ten special cruise ships and two other ships whose sailing dates have been altered to meet the demand. The Easter bookings mark the continuance of a cruise season which has been marked throughout by unusually heavy travel.

I have read about enough of these letters like the one entitled "Man's Sad Plight" and feel that a little straight talk from one of these obstreperous females might be appreciated. I am one of them, and for seventeen years have associated with both men and women in business, and I have yet to find any example of the female plotting to overcome the male and thus blot him out of the cosmic plan.
